title: Thaw for Warsaw
description: In recent years, the Polish Government official who has dealt most intensively with the Reagan Administration has been Foreign Minister Marian Orzechowski, and on Friday, at the conclusion of five days of meetings here, he remarked that there had been ''certain progress'' toward normal relations.

title: The 'Simple' $4.5 Million Marcos House
description: Things are not the way they were when Imelda Marcos was here. As a fresh breeze gusted off the sea today outside Lindenmere, her erstwhile country place at the edge of this Suffolk County town, members of the Philippine Presidential Commission on Good Government sat around the kitchen table, eating cake.

title: Delay Is a Part of the Routine For the Shuttle's Next Flight
description: With a conservatism born of adversity and an apparent resistance to pressure to quicken the pace, space agency managers and engineers are moving gingerly in preparing for the first flight of a space shuttle since the Challenger disaster two and a half years ago.

title: Latin Trade Plan Shaped
description: A Latin American export financing consortium, Latinequip, plans to propose to central banks of Mexico, Brazil and Argentina that foreign debt paper from those countries be used to finance trade.

title: Scientists Trying to Give Crops An Edge Over Nature's Forces
description: Agricultural universities and private farm research centers are working with a new urgency on hundreds of projects to help American farmers sustain harvests in droughts.

title: Give Housing Tax Credits More Time
description: The House Ways and Means Committee acted wisely when it voted a year's extension of the housing tax-credit program. This useful measure is the only low-rent housing production program still on the books after eight Reagan years. It deserves final approval by the full House and Senate.

title: ACTION PERPLEXES ARABS AND ISRAELIS
description: After analyzing and debating King Hussein's moves to cut his links to the West Bank, neither Israelis nor Palestinians in the occupied territories were quite sure today what to make of it.

title: Scientist's View of Lasers Helped 'Star Wars'
description: Recently declassified documents show that Edward Teller had viewed the nuclear X-ray laser, a disputed ''Star Wars'' weapon, as potentially vastly more powerful and flexible than had been discussed publicly.

title: Executive Changes
description: * American Savings and Loan Assn. of Florida, Miami, named as directors Laurence D. Fink, chairman and chief executive of a financial services firm, Blackstone Financial Management, and general partner of the Blackstone Group, and Donald M. Kaplan, managing director and a founder partner of the financial consulting firm of Kaplan, Smith & Associates Inc.

title: Felice Locker and Robert Fenwick-Smith Marry
description: The marriage of Felice Sarah Locker and Robert Henry Fenwick-Smith, who both received M.B.A. degrees in June from Harvard University, took place yesterday at the Richmond County Country Club in Todt Hill, S.I. Cantor David Benedict and the Rev. Peter Brennan, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in some copies Saturday, with an article about Japan's new tax plan, misidentified the Japanese Prime Minister. He is Noboru Takeshita.

title: Cloud Lifted In Banking; Others Lurk
description: With a rescue plan finally in place at the First Republicbank Corporation, bank regulators have removed one of the darkest clouds over the United States banking system.

title: JACKSON ACCEPTS REQUEST TO MEET KOCH TO HEAL RIFT
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said yesterday that he has accepted a request from Governor Cuomo to try to make peace with Mayor Koch, whose sharp attacks on Mr. Jackson dominated the New York primary in April.

title: A Soft Approach Toward Hardware
description: At a time when the boom in personal computer magazines is thought to be over, the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company is gambling that there is room for one more.

title: Miami Wins At Wembley
description: Dave Archer sped into the end zone with 1 minute 28 seconds remaining to give the Miami Dolphins a 27-21 victory over the San Francisco 49ers in an National Football League preseason game at Wembley Stadium tonight.

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * China's ability to pay back its $20 billion to $30 billion external debt was rated ''satisfactory'' by Standard & Poor's. It was the first time the rating service had evaluated the country's debt. The rating corresponds to the lower third of S.&P.'s investment-grade category. The rating was influenced by China's economic changes over the past decade, in which market forces have replaced some central planning. That strategy has led to growth in both production and per-capita income, S.&P. said. Because the country has taken a conservative approach to foreign borrowing, its deficits and debts are modest.

title: Catholic Bishops Are Cautioned About Candidate Endorsements
description: Roman Catholic bishops and other church leaders who label a political candidate ''pro-abortion'' or who otherwise praise or condemn those running for public office jeopardize the tax-exempt status of the Catholic Church, according to a Catholic memorandum.

title: Sports World Specials; Super Scalping
description: The game is almost six months away, nobody knows which teams will be playing in it, and the tickets haven't even been printed. Even so, football fans with a little bit of foresight and a whole lot of wherewithal are reserving their seats for the 1989 Super Bowl at Joe Robbie Stadium in Miami next Jan. 22.

title: Allison Back in Alabama
description: Bobby Allison returned home to Alabama today, six weeks after he was seriously injured in a crash at Pocono International Raceway in Pennsylvania.

title: Few Are Jobless in Japan
description: High demand for workers because of rapid economic growth pushed Japan's unemployment rate down to 2.4 percent in June, its lowest level in 67 months, the Government announced Friday. The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate for June was a tenth of a percentage point lower than in May and sixth-tenths of a percentage point below the previous year's level, the Management and Coordination Agency said. The number of job holders in June totaled nearly 61.1 million, equaling the record set in May, the agency said. The number represented an increase of 1.1 million jobs from June 1987.

title: Review/Opera; Bavarians Do 'Capriccio,' by a Hometown Boy
description: The Bavarian State Opera has always been assiduous in its loyalty to Richard Strauss, who counts as a hometown boy despite his longtime residence in Garmisch in the nearby Alps and his lifelong activity in Vienna, Berlin and beyond.

title: British 'People Meter' Firm Suspends Its U.S. Operation
description: AGB Television Research, which took on the A. C. Nielsen Company in a costly war for the business of measuring the American television audience, has surrendered and will suspend its ratings operation in the United States.

title: Sports World Specials; Staying Busy
description: Seven years ago, Ashby Harper, who was 65 years old, told a friend that he planned to swim across the English Channel.

title: Michael Cohen Wed To Meryl Ilene Stone
description: Meryl Ilene Stone and Michael H. Cohen were married last evening at the Short Hills, a catering establishment in Short Hills, N.J., by Rabbi Irving Block.

title: Concern About Lyme Disease Surges
description: Across the New York metropolitan region this summer, health experts are reporting a surge of concern about Lyme disease, a vexing and potentially crippling illness that is spread by a tiny tick.

title: Why Dukakis Can Run on the Economy
description: LEAD: What exactly is Gov. Michael S. Dukakis going to say about the economy to convince voters that the Democrats can do a better job? How can he land a punch on the Republican record?

title: Loan Talks For Brazilian
description: A Brazilian Finance Ministry official began a tour of Persian Gulf banks today to outline details of a new $63.6 billion debt-rescheduling package and a plan to raise $5.8 billion.

title: Barbara Jordan Reported 'Vastly Improved'
description: Former Representative Barbara Jordan was ''vastly improved,'' her doctor said today, a day after she nearly drowned in her swimming pool.

title: An Animator Breaks Old Rules And New Ground in 'Roger Rabbit'
description: At the age of 5, Richard Williams visited a movie theater in Toronto with his mother and saw ''Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs.'' ''She said I was never the same again,'' recalled Mr. Williams with a laugh. ''It just knocked me out. I said 'That's what I want to do; that's what I have to do.' ''

title: Publishers Profit by Reviving Old Authors
description: Placing greater emphasis than ever on their more profitable older books, publishers are reissuing or introducing the works of dead authors with greater regularity.

title: Not True Christians
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan's About-Face on Mergers, Acquisitions
description: The preference of Japanese industry for home-grown expansion and its disdain for American-style mergers and acquisitions appear to be changing.

title: As Growth Slows, More Network Affiliates Are for Sale
description: For years television was known as a ''drop dead'' business. Profits rose so predictably that a station manager could drop dead and the station would run itself.

title: American a Spy, Lebanese Says
description: A senior member in the pro-Iranian Party of God said today that an American who was supervising a United Nations peacekeeping force was on a spying mission when he was abducted in southern Lebanon last February.

title: U.S. PEACE PLAN IN JEOPARDY; Internal Tensions
description: King Hussein of Jordan tonight abandoned to the Palestine Liberation Organization any claim to the Israeli-occupied West Bank his Hashemite family ruled between 1948 and 1967.

title: Forstmann And Pullman Reach Deal
description: Forstmann Little & Company and the Pullman Company have reached a definitive merger agreement under which Pullman would receive about $650 million.

title: Steep Rise Seen in Private Use Of Federal Racketeering Law
description: The Federal racketeering law, created to help fight organized crime, is now being used primarily by private individuals and corporations trying to extract large damage awards from legitimate businesses.

title: Review/Television; Series on PBS Studies Nuclear Arms
description: The opening lines of ''The Journey'' serve as a kind of warning, or, perhaps, a reassurance, depending on your political point of view. Peter Watkins, the British narrator - and co-producer with the Swedish Peace and Arbitration Society - of the 14-hour series on the nuclear arms race, expresses the hope that the viewer will not ''feel there is anything objective about the information I'll give you.'' It is accurate, he says. But, he goes on, ''I must emphasize that our presentation of the information is biased due to our very strong feeling about the subject of this film.''

title: Soviet Leader's Burden; Behind Opposition to Gorbachev's Policies Is an Economy That Refuses to Spruce Up
description: The euphoria of attempts by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, to revive Soviet society, the intoxicating swirl of political debate and cultural experimentation, seems each month more in danger from the mundane miseries of the unyielding Soviet economy.

title: Panel Faults Airlines On Hiring of Blacks
description: A committee in the House of Representatives charged today that the airline industry had failed to hire enough blacks as pilots, as managers or for other positions requiring advanced education and skills.

title: Dr. Joanna Fine Weds S. M. Harnik, Lawyer
description: Dr. Joanna Lisa Fine, a child psychiatrist, and Stephen Michael Harnik, a lawyer, who graduated together from the Dalton School in 1971 were married yesterday at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park. Jerome Raik, the president of Ansche Chesed Congregation in Manhattan, officiated.

title: National League; Hershiser Blunts Astros' Momentum
description: Orel Hershiser pitched a five-hitter today to become the National League's second 15-game winner and John Shelby had a two-run single as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated Houston, 6-1, to snap the Astros' four-game winning streak.

title: Thorny Issue: Peeking Into a Privileged Pouch
description: For centuries the diplomatic pouch has guarded the confidentiality of official messages exchanged between governments and their envoys stationed abroad.

title: Mid-Quarter Refunding Issues to Be Priced
description: Today's regular weekly Treasury auction of three- and six-month bills heads a light calendar of new offerings. On Wednesday, the Treasury is scheduled to announce the terms of its mid-quarter refunding auctions, which would be held next week.

title: As Eastern Prepares to Cut Service, Kansas City Puts Its Hope in Braniff
description: To Robert Morris, the outlook seemed bleak, despite the hustle and bustle surrounding him on a ramp at the Kansas City International Airport. On Aug. 31 much of that activity will be ended by sharp service cuts announced by Eastern Airlines.

title: Sports World Specials; The Games Go On
description: It's not easy to stay the course in the Big Apple, and when the founding and sustaining sponsor of the Mobil Big Apple Games decided to move its corporate headquarters from Manhattan to Fairfax, Va., it sounded like a death knell to the games.

title: Ms. Webb Weds Dr. A. M. Singer
description: Heidi-Rachel Webb, a daughter of Dr. Gertrude Mikels Webb and J. Chester Webb of Waltham, Mass., was married in the garden of her parents' home yesterday to Dr. Andrew Millard Singer, the son of Lucille Singer of Stamford, Conn., and the late Edwin Singer. Rabbi Herman Blumberg performed the ceremony.

title: James Galef Married To Kirsten A. Solsvig
description: Kirsten Ann Solsvig, the daughter of Beverly M. Solsvig of Milwaukee and the late Curtis M. Solsvig 2d, was married in New York yesterday to James M. Galef, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Bennett G. Galef of New York. The Rev. Charles A. Amstein, a Presbyterian minister, and Rabbi Martin Zion officiated at the Burden Mansion.

title: Letter: On the B-1; A Bomber to Serve Into the 21st Century
description: To the Editor:

title: Many No's to Parting 'South' From Its Bronx
description: Ask Albert Wimmer what he thinks about changing the name of the South Bronx, and he'll say, ''That's like trying to change the name of a fish.''

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Aug. 1, 1988: MONDAY

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Agassi Wins in Vermont: Andre Agassi won his fifth Nabisco Grand Prix singles title of the year yesterday, defeating Paul Annacone, 6-2, 6-4, at the Volvo International in Stratton Mountain, Vt. Agassi, 18, seeded second, used a powerful forehand passing shot and a backhand lob to earn $114,000. Annacone won $57,000. (AP) Graf Wins on Her Turf: Steffi Graf captured the Virginia Slims tournament in Hamburg, West Germany, with a 6-4, 6-2 victory over Katerina Maleeva of Bulgaria. Graf, who won her first Wimbledon title earlier this month, needed 86 minutes to dispatch Maleeva for her seventh tournament victory this year.(AP) Sanchez Scores Upset: Second-seeded Emilio Sanchez of Spain defeated top-seeded Guillermo Perez-Roldan of Argentina, 6-3, 6-1, 3-6, 6-3, to capture the Nabisco Grand Prix tournament in Hilversum, the Netherlands.(AP) Road Racing Sunday in the Park: Bob Meighan of the Central Park Track Club won the New York Road Runners Club's Coca-Cola Classic two-mile run in 9 minutes 22 seconds at Central Park yesterday. Bea Huste of the Atalanta Track Club was first among the women in 11:02. Mark Bragan of the Shore Athletic Club captured the two-mile race walk in 14:20, while Laurin Seidel of the New Jersey Striders led the women in 18:22. Golf 3 Straight for Rodriguez: Chi Chi Rodriguez survived a double bogey on the next-to-last hole yesterday to win the Digital senior tournament and set a senior tour record by winning the event for the third consecutive year. Rodriguez, who led by three or four strokes through most of the final round at Nashawtuc Country Club in Concord, Mass., finished with rounds of 68, 65 and 69 for a 202 total, one stroke ahead of Bob Charles. He won $45,000.(AP) Okamoto Wins by a Stroke: Ayako Okamoto shot a four-under-par 67 yesterday to register a one-stroke victory over Connie Chillemi and Beth Daniel in the $225,000 Greater Washington Open in Bethesda, Md. Okamoto finished with 206 in the 54-hole tournament at the Bethesda Country Club.(AP) Verplank Wins Buick: Scott Verplank shot a final-round 66 to win the Buick Open by two strokes over Doug Tewell. Verplank, 24 years old, finished at 20-under-par 268 to earn $126,000 for his first professional victory in a PGA Tour event. Fred Couples had a 65 to finish at 17-under 271 and Tim Norris had a 66 for 272. (AP) Auto Racing Schrader Finishes First: Ken Schrader charged from fourth to first on the final lap yesterday to earn his first Winston Cup victory in the Talladega 500. Schrader started the final trip around the 2.66-mile Alabama International Motor Speedway trailing Dale Earnhardt, Geoff Bodine and Sterling Marlin. As the leaders came out of the fourth turn, Marlin moved to the outside, got past Bodine and pulled alongside Earnhardt. The cars of Earnhardt and Marlin bumped, and Schrader's Chevrolet Monte Carlo found an open lane and zoomed past on the high side of the banked track. (AP) Horse Racing Claramount by a Neck: Claramount stalked Jazzing Around to the stretch, took over there and went on to carry 117 pounds under Chris Antley to a neck victory in the $86,700 Evan Shipman Stakes for New York-bred 3-years-old and up yesterday at Belmont Park. Tinchen's Prince was second. Claramount equaled the stakes record posted by Judge Costa in 1985 covering a mile and one-sixteenth on the fast track in 1:41 4/5. The victory was the 11th in 31 career starts for the 4-year-old son of Policeman, who earned $52,020 for Edwin Wachtel and paid $22.60 for $2 to win as the fifth choice in the field of seven. Track and Field American Men Win: The United States ended with victories in the men's 400- and 1,600-meter relays as the world junior championships ended in Sudbury, Ontario. Kevin Braunskill of Riverhead, L.I., who won the 200-meter title Saturday, and Andre Cason of Texas, who won the 100 meters Friday, were on the winning 400-meter team that set a meet record of 39.27 seconds. Jerome Williams of Yonkers had a 46.4-second third-leg split on the 1,600-meter foursome, which was first in 3 minutes 5.09 seconds. Soccer Stars Edge Eagles: The Washington Stars kept their hopes of securing a Northern Division playoff spot alive with a 2-1 victory over the New Jersey Eagles in an American Soccer League game yesterday in Paterson, N.J. After a 1-1 tie in regulation, each team made three of its five overtime shots from 12 yards out. Dave Masur of the eagles hit the goal post with his first shot. Seconds later, Washington's Orville Reynolds ended the game when he beat New Jersey's goalie, Terry Higgins.

title: Energy Dept. Shows Prudence on Nuclear Waste
description: To the Editor:

title: Prudent Takes Hampton
description: Katie Monahan Prudent of Middleburg, Va., rode Mrs. W. Averell Harriman's The Empress to win the $50,000 Chrysler-Gucci Hampton Classic Grand Prix. The 24-year-old rider edged out Greg Best and Santos, over a shortened second-round course. Jeff Welles was third on Webster, and Christian Currey, fourth, on Mirador.

title: Exchange Rate Keeps Canadian Industry on Pins and Needles
description: When Brian Friesen was driving to work last Monday in the Vancouver, British Columbia, suburb of New Westminster, a radio news report quickened his pulse. In trading in Toronto the Canadian dollar had reversed its steep climb of the previous months against the United States currency and tumbled nearly a full United States cent in value, its sharpest one-day move in months.

title: Residents Clash With the Police In Village Park
description: Residents clashed with the police early yesterday morning in an East Village park that has come to symbolize the neighborhood's resistance to gentrification.

title: Windsurfing Makes Big Splash on the Sound
description: ON Thursday afternoon, the fourth day of instruction, it did not appear that anyone would learn how.

title: Couple in Parked Car Found Shot to Death
description: A couple were shot to death as they sat in a parked car in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn yesterday in what the police believe were drug-related murders, the police.

title: Harness Racing; Looking Beyond Roosevelt Closing
description: Even though harness racing in the metropolitan area suffered a severe setback with the closing of Roosevelt Raceway on Long Island, there is plenty of optimism at Yonkers Raceway and the Meadowlands.

title: They'll Be Better Than Reagan
description: The political wrecking crews are tearing down Vice President Bush and Governor Dukakis. ''Our wimp can beat your shrimp,'' says one Republican campaign button. On the other side, the Democrats say Bush won't pick Senator Dole as his running mate because Bush would then have to spend four more years playing No. 2.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Jordan, McGrath Gets Nestle Grocery Venture
description: For more than 20 years Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor, under its various guises, has handled assignments from the Nestle Foods Corporation. Now it has been tapped to work for Nestle Enterprises' newly formed subsidiary, the Fresnes Corporation, based in Solon, Ohio, which will begin testing a line of grocery products next month.

title: DUKAKIS MAINTAINS AGGRESSIVE STANCE
description: Michael S. Dukakis, determined not to squander the momentum achieved in Atlanta, has become increasingly aggressive in recent days, turning up the heat on both President Reagan and Vice President Bush.

title: Sports of The Times; A Sinister Darling
description: RON DARLING, cover boy for men's apparel magazines and family newspapers and Ivy League periodicals, appeared instead yesterday as if he should be featured on the cover of Tales From the Crypt. He was dressed to kill, more or less. He went out to the mound with baseball cap yanked at a serious, not to say sinister, level to his eyes, his knickers at close to an all-time unfashionable low to his baseball shoes and with a facial stubble that had not felt the scrape of a razor in six days.

title: Review/Opera; A New 'Dutchman' for Santa Fe
description: All of Wagner's mature operas are ghost ships, fated to sail about the world in search of the ultimately convincing interpretation. Vain voyages. For any important work there is no final port to be reached, at least not while the culture that produced it survives. Certainly there is life enough left in ''Der Fliegende Hollander,'' Wagner's first great experiment in psychological music drama. The legend of the Flying Dutchman, a man without a homeland who is doomed to endless travel, might be read, for instance, as the symbolic story of this century's hordes of political refugees.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: The Iron Law Of Arms Control
description: In the treaty eliminating Soviet and American intermediate-range missiles, the iron law of negotiation was demonstrated once again: The side in a hurry makes the concessions. Mikhail S. Gorbachev was in a hurry; President Reagan was not. So Mr. Gorbachev made the concessions and agreed to a treaty that he and his three predecessors had denounced as a wicked ploy to achieve American military superiority.

title: Producers End Talks With Writers
description: Calling negotiations with Hollywood's 9,000 striking writers ''hopelessly deadlocked,'' the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers said today that the talks with the Writers Guild of America in the 22-week strike were permanently ended.

title: South Africa Violated Pact, Mozambique Says
description: The official Mozambican press agency said today that South Africa had secretly flown foreign journalists into rebel-held areas of Mozambique in violation of a security pact between the two countries.

title: Officials Split On Inquiring About AIDS
description: Koch administration officials are split over a draft proposal to require all candidates for police, fire, sanitation and certain other ''public safety'' jobs to disclose if they have received a diagnosis of AIDS or AIDS-related complex.

title: Any Advice?
description: LEAD: I voted for Lyndon Johnson in 1964 because he said he'd keep us from getting bogged down in Vietnam.

title: Kitty Dukakis: Pride, but Not Passion, About Dress
description: There is nothing coy about Kitty Dukakis.

title: Pay Congress for Service, Not Lunch
description: Because of the crabbed, resentful public attitude toward paying public servants, voting themselves a raise can be hazardous to the political health of senators and representatives.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Marc Goldstein has joined Lintas:USA as senior vice president, director of national broadcast media and programming, for both Lintas:New York and Lintas:Campbell-Ewald.

title: Andrea Bass Wed To J. J. Glickson
description: Andrea Bass, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin L. Bass of New York, was married yesterday to James J. Glickson, the son of David Glickson of St. Paul and the late Sarae Glickson. Rabbi Henry Glazer performed the ceremony at the Pierre in New York.

title: Jeffrey John Baum Is Wed To Anne Alexandra Tyno
description: Anne Alexandra Tyno, the daughter of Marion Tyno of Rye, N.Y., and the late Stephen Tyno, was married yesterday to Jeffrey John Baum, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Manfred Baum of Bergenfield, N.J. Rabbi Jerome Blass performed the ceremony at the Fair Lawn (N.J.) Jewish Center.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Assignments for Grey, Y.&R. and Biederman
description: Grey Advertising, Young & Rubicam and Biederman & Company announced new assignments last week.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Hill, Holliday Fills Key Job In New York
description: For Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos's New York office, last week was one of those in-and-out kind of times so typical of the give-and-take agency business.

title: Arthur Klein, an Educator, Is Dead at 90
description: Arthur Klein, an educator who worked in the New York City public-school system for 50 years, died of cancer Friday night in a Pittsburgh nursing home. He was 90 years old.

title: Nigerians Discover Gorillas Thought Extinct
description: For years, the outside world thought that gorillas were extinct here. But Jacob Osang and Napoleon Mkpe knew better, and whenever they spied an adult gorilla in the thick rain forest here they saw $200 worth of walking restaurant meat.

title: Books of The Times; U.S. and Nicaragua Since '80
description: Banana Diplomacy The Making of American Policy in Nicaragua 1981-1987. By Roy Gutman 404 pages. Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Lottery Winner Accused of Plotting Death of Son's Wife
description: A woman who won $5 million in a Canadian lottery in 1984 has had her house seized for back taxes and has been arrested and accused of plotting to kill her daughter-in-law.

title: Boxers Join in the Corporate Road Race
description: DONNY LALONDE carries a gym bag, not a brief case, when he goes to work. He eschews three-piece suits and ties in favor of sweatpants and 10-ounce gloves. While others might punch computer keys, LaLonde earns his living punching opponents.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: U.S. PEACE PLAN IN JEOPARDY; Shultz Concerned
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that Jordan should continue to take part in any Middle East peace negotiations, even though King Hussein of Jordan has given up his claims to the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

title: Man Killed, 2d Shot In Times Sq. Dispute
description: One man was shot dead and another wounded in a dispute in Times Square early yesterday, the police said. A third man was arrested and was being questioned about the shootings.

title: Cable TV Deal Collapses
description: The Times Mirror Company said a deal to trade its cable television operations in Arizona for cable properties owned by Tele-Communications Inc. and United Artists Communications has collapsed. The decision to call off the deal, which was announced in March and was valued by analysts at about $740 million, ''was a mutual agreement between all three parties,'' Times Mirror, owner of The Los Angeles Times, Newsday and The Baltimore Sun newspapers, said Thursday.

title: Brazilians Master the Fine Art of Cash Juggling
description: Defying the maxim that liquid assets are the worst defense against inflation, Brazilians with the money and skill to play the local financial markets are profiting handsomely from rocketing prices here.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-11 King Hussein yielded to the P.L.O. all claims to the West Bank. The action by the Jordanian ruler, whose family ruled the territory from 1948 to 1967, reinforced doubts on an American peace plan. Page A1

title: Shultz Says He Would Meet With Iranian
description: The United States has received a private response to American messages sent to Iran, Administration officials said today, and Secretary of State George P. Shultz indicated his willingness to meet with Iran's Foreign Minister if the Iranians asked for such a meeting.

title: Participant Sports: Top 20
description: Swimming heads the list of 40 participant sports in a survey taken in 1987 by the National Sporting Goods Association. More than 66 million Americans took the plunge last year, and swimming was followed in the poll by exercise walking (58.1 million), which drew the most new participants (7.2 million).

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Turk Group to Join ABP International
description: The Turk Group, which has been part of Kornhauser & Calene, is splitting with the parent company to become part of ABP International.

title: Teamsters Extend Pact With Studio Craftsmen
description: The Teamsters and Basic Crafts Unions have agreed to extend their contract with the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers on a day-to-day basis. The contract with studio drivers, plumbers, electricians, plasterers and laborers was to have expired at midnight Sunday. A joint statement released Sunday afternoon said negotiations would resume Wednesday, ''with the expectation of negotiating to conclusion.''

title: Strawberry's Blast Defeats Pirates, 2-1
description: Darryl Strawberry leaned back in his chair and said the Pirates had nothing to be ashamed of. Bob Walk sat silently in the trainer's room in the Pittsburgh clubhouse, understanding full well that there was nothing for the Pirates to feel particularly proud of, either.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New McDonald's Job For Laurence, Charles
description: The new Philadelphia office of Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson will be handling the central Pennsylvania McDonald's co-op, made up of 53 restaurants. The ad budget is $2 million, bringing the office to $12 million.

title: Outdoors: Big Catch, Revisited
description: AFTER more than 55 years of catching everything from giant bluefin tuna to tiny brook trout, I know that I will never become a consistently successful angler.

title: Excerpts From Hussein's Address on Abandoning Claims to the West Bank
description: Following are excerpts from King Hussein's address today, as translated from the Arabic by The Associated Press:

title: Shultz Denies Rebuff By Two Latin Nations
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz disputed a report today that two Central American nations opposed a proposed joint communique circulated by the United States that denounced Nicaragua for inviting Soviet-bloc intervention in regional affairs.

title: Jets Rookies Shaky In First Scrimmage
description: It was only a scrimmage against the Super Bowl champions, but the Jets' defensive problems couldn't have been more evident.

title: Drug Thugs and Rambo Guns
description: ''Mushrooms'' - that's the drug gunman's brutal slang for innocent bystanders who pop up unexpectedly in his line of fire. In the past year 10 New Yorkers have been killed and more than 20 wounded by drug criminals' stray bullets, and the lethal fire is hardly unique to New York.

title:
Market Place;
Success Stories In Bank Funds
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH as a group they showed strong gains in the last quarter, common stock funds administered by banks lost a little ground in relation to the stock market in general.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: If Jim Plunkett doesn't retire, Tim Brown makes the cut, Marcus Allen stays healthy and Bo Jackson joins all three when the baseball season ends, the Los Angeles Raiders will have four Heisman Trophy winners on their squad. Has a team ever had that many before?

title: Energy Dept. Shows Prudence on Nuclear Waste; Funds for Nevada
description: To the Editor:

title: Tax Watch
description: TAXES seldom take a holiday. Indeed, one of the intentions of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 was to halt such perceived abuses as tax breaks for schoolteachers, who, having spent some time in summer strolling down the Champs-Elysees, claimed an educational-travel deduction for their newly acquired aplomb and panache.

title: Outlook for Rate Rise Tempered
description: Technical market factors are expected to temper any upward pressure on interest rates that results from the release of a number of economic reports this week.

title: West Germany First in Exports
description: West Germany outdistanced the United States as the world's biggest exporter for the second year in a row, according to the International Monetary Fund.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Doskocil Founder Seeks To Diversify Meat Sales
description: LEAD: As a struggling entrepreneur in the early 1960's, Larry D. Doskocil, now chairman of Doskocil Companies Inc., slept on a cot in an abandoned chicken hatchery that housed his one-man sausage business in Hutchinson, Kan.

title: Full-Size Portable Bike
description: At a time when bicycle thieves are able to break through the toughest of locks, the idea of a folding bicycle - one that you can carry with you - begins to make sense.

title: ON YOUR OWN: Fitness; The Hand Weights Gospel
description: WHILE he and his wife were strolling in Manhattan one hot summer evening a few years ago, Leonard Schwartz, the Pittsburgh psychiatrist who invented Heavyhands, spied a runner with the hand weights. But instead of pumping the weights up and down as he ran, the young man was merely carrying them.

title: Bridge
description: Players from Washington, New York City, Philadelphia and Los Angeles won major titles at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here Saturday night.

title: Daniel Jacobson Wed To Amy Rosenbaum
description: Amy Diane Rosenbaum, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Robert Rosenbaum of Los Angeles, was married there yesterday to Daniel R. Jacobson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Jacobson of Larchmont, N.Y. Rabbi Leonard Beerman performed the ceremony at the Regency Club.

title: Nancy Weiss Wed to Burton G. Malkiel
description: Nancy Joan Weiss, the dean of the college and a professor of history at Princeton University, and Burton Gordon Malkiel, the William S. Beinecke Professor of Management Studies and a professor of economics at Yale University, were married yesterday at the Princeton University Chapel by Rabbi Ely E. Pilchick.

title: Democrats Weigh Contra Aid Plan
description: Senate Democrats are preparing legislation that would immediately provide the Nicaraguan rebels with funds for food, clothing and medical supplies and are considering future assistance for arms and ammunition, Congressional staff members said today.

title: C.F.T.C. Clears Foreign Sales
description: Option contracts traded on exchanges in Montreal, Singapore and Sydney, Australia, can now be sold to persons in the United States, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission said Friday.

title: Brooklyn Girl Killed When Gun Goes Off
description: A 13-year-old Brooklyn girl was fatally shot yesterday when a handgun some youths were playing with discharged and she was struck in the chest, the police said.

title: Deficit Plan By Argentina
description: Argentina will temporarily close its banks on Monday and Tuesday to coincide with the announcement of measures to stem inflation and reduce the public sector deficit, Government officials said tonight.

title: Dr. L. S. Hurley Thompson
description: Dr. Lucille S. Hurley Thompson, a nutrition scholar whose research linked some dietary deficiencies of expectant mothers with birth defects, died after open-heart surgery Thursday at a Sacramento hospital. She was 66 years old.

title: Overtime Cuts Urged For Correction Dept.
description: The New York City Correction Department could save $1.25 million a year by hiring 145 full-time correction officers and by establishing permanent hospital duty posts for them, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said in an audit released yesterday.

title: American League; Morris Ends a Monthlong Drought
description: Jack Morris won for the first time since June 27, and Dwayne Murphy had two hits and scored the winning run on his first day with the Tigers as Detroit beat the Texas Rangers today, 5-1. It was the sixth victory in seven games for Detroit.

title: A Close Call in House
description: Although 98 percent of House members have been returned to office in recent elections, some contests do make a difference. One primary race this year already appears critical to the fate of the legislation requiring large employers to give 60 days' notice of a plant closing or large-scale layoff.

title: SAMOAN DELEGATE ACCUSED OF FRAUD
description: American Samoa's delegate to the House of Representatives and his administrative assistant conspired to defraud the Government of more than $130,000 and will plead guilty of the offense, the United States Attorney's office has announced.

title: Congress Facing Key Issues Affecting Military Readiness
description: The Congressional Budget Office has warned Congress that it may soon face a choice between reducing the size of the armed forces or making them less ready for combat because operational and support funds are being held down in favor of buying more arms.

title: Volkswagen Prices Rise
description: Volkswagen A.G. said it would raise its car prices by an average of 1.9 percent in its new model year, which begins Monday. Volkswagen said Saturday that the increases were linked to improvements in accessories, but the company gave no details.

title: Administration Sugar Policy: How Sweet It Isn't
description: To the Editor:

title: Hall of Fame; Stargell a Hit First Time Up
description: In a ceremony that seemed as inevitable as one of his extra-base hits, Willie Stargell completed his journey from rookie to renown today, becoming the 200th man to be inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame.

title: Lending a Voice
description: The sense of crisis surrounding the savings and loan industry is bubbling up to the attention of some big thinkers who are looking forward to the next administration.

title: Boxing; McGirt Knocks Out Davis in Round 1
description: James (Buddy) McGirt retained his International Boxing Federation junior welterweight title when he knocked out Howard Davis yesterday at 2 minutes 45 seconds of the first round of a scheduled 15-round bout at the Felt Forum.

title: Waterfront Access for the Many, or the Few?
description: To the Editor:

title: Schools Remain Stuck in the Ballpoint Era
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Opera; Marilyn Mims as Verdi's Violetta
description: Watching the New York City Opera's current production of ''La Traviata'' on Saturday evening at the New York State Theater, I couldn't help wondering who the company imagines its audience to be. Directed by Frank Corsaro, the production is a superficially traditional look at the Verdi opera, with sets and costumes that are a mismatched, historic pastiche, and with blocking that is unlikely to awaken new insight into the characters for operagoers acquainted with the work. Newcomers, meanwhile, are liable to focus on the supertitles, which in this production provide only the sketchiest paraphrase of what is being sung.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Ad Scene; Big Sales of Network Time Prove a Disturbing Point
description: EARLIER this month, in the middle of the three-week ''up front'' period when advertising agencies buy most of their network time for the new television season on behalf of their largest clients, Young & Rubicam issued a forecast consistent with those of the rest of Madison Avenue. ''We do not see any innovative or 'breakthrough' hits among the crop of new shows,'' it said, ''either in program type, content or rating success.''

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Award Created in Honor Of Robert V. Goldstein
description: The Robert V. Goldstein Award for Distinguished Service as an Advertising Council Campaign Director has been established by the Association of National Advertisers, of which he was chairman, and the Advertising Council, of which he was a director. It honors the memory of a man who was among the advertising men killed in the tragic white-water rafting accident a year ago in British Columbia.

title: New Yorkers & Co.; Scavenging for a Song, Reselling for a Steal
description: Harvey Mandlin and one of his salespeople, Marc Marshall, were discussing a business deal: as much as 1.2 million pounds of frozen Australian goat meat was up for sale on the West Coast, cheap.

title: One of Every 30 Condemned Since '77 Has Been Executed
description: Of every 30 people sentenced to death since the death penalty was reinstated by the Supreme Court in 1976, 10 left death row and one was executed, the Justice Department said today.

title: Strawberry's Home Runs: Going, Going, Still Going
description: THE baseball exploded off Darryl Strawberry's bat, and when it hit the digital clock in Busch Stadium, time was perhaps the only thing that didn't stand still. Players stopped in their tracks; images were frozen in memories, and an imposing precedent was set.

title: All Aboard Amtrak On the West Side
description: To the Editor:

title: For Dropouts, Finding Jobs Is Tough Task
description: Broderick Montgomery, an 18-year-old with a gold tooth in his smile and a baseball cap on his head, walked into a youth employment agency in Brooklyn recently looking for a job. Mr. Montgomery, a 10th-grade dropout with no skills to speak of, said he wanted to earn $5.50 or $6 an hour, maybe ''lifting boxes.''

title: TV Notes
description: Dukakis and TV

title: Walker Suffers Second Seizure
description: Greg Walker, the Chicago White Sox first baseman, suffered a second seizure this morning, but was stabilized without further complications, club officials announced.

title: INSIDE
description: Bank Outlook Brightens A plan to rescue First Republicbank of Dallas removes the darkest cloud over the banking system. News analysis, page D1. The War Over Shoreham A battle of rare political intensity is raging on Long Island over the agreement to shut the Shoreham nuclear power plant. Page B1.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We respect the wish of the P.L.O., the sole legitimate representative of the Palestinian people to secede from us in an independent Palestinian state.'' - King Hussein of Jordan. [ A1:6. ]

title: Yanks Leave Toronto On a Winning Note
description: Considering the condition of their pitching staff, the Yankees felt a collective sense of relief today.

title: Koch's Shift on Ireland Lampooned in London
description: The conversion of Mayor Koch on Northern Ireland was lampooned today in Britain.

title: Cuomo vs. Legislators: Hand-to-Hand Combat Over Shoreham
description: During his monthly statewide radio program last week, Governor Cuomo defended his plan to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant, making a rare direct emotional plea to the public: ''All you people on Long Island, listen to me.''

title: Purchasers Say Economy Grew More Slowly in July
description: The growth rate of the nation's economy slowed slightly in July, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its monthly report, which is scheduled to be released today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Y.&R. and Poppe Tyson Acquire a Unit Apiece
description: Poppe Tyson, a subsidiary of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, has acquired Williams, London, Marchin, Weltman & Associates, an agency in West Orange, N.J., billing $15 million, and Young & Rubicam has acquired Arthur E. Wilk Inc., a health-care agency in Chicago billing $20 million.

title: ANTI-MAFIA DRIVE LOSES A KEY MAN
description: Italy's top anti-Mafia prosecutor has unexpectedly quit his post, joining a protest by Sicilian law enforcement officials who have accused the Government of hindering their efforts to fight organized crime.

title: Bush's Son Sought Post for Educator
description: Jeb Bush, who is expected to play a major role in helping to court the Hispanic vote for the Presidential campaign of his father, Vice President Bush, tried to have the White House nominate the Cuban-American president of a Florida university as the new Secretary of Education.

title: Montpelier Journal; A Rising Debate Over a Plan to Raise the Skyline
description: The striking gold dome of the State House has long been the architectural focus of this smallest of capital cities.

title: Fast Texas Profits Seen By NCNB
description: The NCNB Corporation is counting on its new stake in the First Republicbank Corporation of Texas to contribute an immediate and steadily rising share of NCNB profits - 38.5 percent by 1994.

title: Brussels Journal; The New NATO: A Pronounced German Accent
description: ''The alliance is run by the Germans,'' said Manfred Worner, breaking into English and a smile. It was just a little joke, and, he acknowledged, hardly true.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Quotation of the Day yesterday was misattributed. It was Sister Christine Tan, a nun who lives in a Manila slum, who said: ''I had thought freedom was more important to people than rice, but it isn't. Rice is more important. These people just want to survive, survive, survive.''

title: Revitalized Red Sox Are Back in the Race
description: Forget Michael S. Dukakis. If this town voted today, Joe Morgan would be president.

title: Critic's Notebook; Actors Confront AIDS on Stage
description: Loyal readers of Variety, the weekly newspaper of show business, have traditionally opened each issue first to ''the grosses'' - the listing of box-office receipts for movies and plays around the nation. That Pavlovian reflex may have changed of late, because the most dramatic news in the industry now, the struggle with AIDS, is spotlighted on the obituary pages. There the listings of the week's dead intermingle with black-bordered memorial advertisements recalling the fatalities of years past.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Aim of Rales Brothers Rises on Takeovers
description: LEAD: With their offer last week for Interco Inc., a big furniture and shoe manufacturer, the Rales brothers are also bidding for an entree into the top ranks of takeover specialists.

title: Baseball Fever Is Spreading
description: BASEBALL pilgrims rivaling the United Nations in geographic diversity are visiting the national baseball museum and library here to worship at the shrine of the national game and, at the same time, pick up expertise that may be used when baseball becomes a gold-medal sport in the 1992 Olympics.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Bonnie Lee Reid Becomes Bride of David Bokman
description: The marriage of Bonnie Lee Reid, the daughter of the late Patricia Lee Reid and the late Harry Emery Snook, both of Charlotte, N.C., to David Bokman, a son of Salomon Bokman and Hilda Aronson, both of New York, took place yesterday. Justice Sondra Miller of State Supreme Court in White Plains officiated at a private home in Pound Ridge, N.Y.

title: Subpoenas in Business Week Inquiry
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has issued subpoenas to the R.R. Donnelley & Sons Company of Chicago in the expanding inquiry into stock trading apparently based on leaks of information in Business Week magazine, people familiar with the investigation said yesterday.

title: Crusade for Spielberg: Saving a British Studio
description: Movie maker Steven Spielberg, now in England filming ''Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade,'' has embarked on a crusade of his own. With the help of British and American investors, he is trying to prevent Britain's legendary Elstree Studios from being razed for commercial development.

title: Chip Maker Without a Country
description: If any company represents the new wave in European industry, it is probably European Silicon Structures. For a host of reasons, many industrialists point to this computer chip maker as a model for what European companies should become as the European Community prepares to end all of its internal trade barriers in 1992.

title: Yanks Are Looking for Help
description: The presence of the general manager gave the weekend a sense of urgency, as if the Yankees were feeling the need to make a deal. But Bob Quinn said today he was merely here to meet with Lou Piniella and discuss the state of the pitching staff. There was a lot to talk about. With one pitcher disabled, two others hurting and another in the minors with a sore elbow, the Yankees are suddenly strapped for strong arms. Yet Quinn insisted they were not necessarily in the market for help.

title: Metro Matters; Making E-mc#2 An Equation For Summer Fun
description: Charles Horton, who is 8 years old and will be a third grader at Central Park East School in East Harlem next month, stood on a chair and released a paper cup connected with plastic straws to a small patch of green plastic. It plunged rapidly to the floor.

title: Bolsheviks Buried Czar's Weak Heirs
description: To the Editor:

title: Valenzuela Sidelined
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers put Fernando Valenzuela on the 21-day disabled list today, and the 27-year-old left-hander will miss his turn in the rotation for the first time in his eight-year career.

title: Christian Dior Stake to Be Sold
description: The businessman who controls the fashion house Christian Dior plans to sell part of his Dior stake to raise money to play an important role in Louis Vuitton Moet Hennessy. Financial executives said Bernard Arnault's Financiere Agache plans to raise $500 million by selling 40 percent of his Dior stake to increase his LVMH holdings to 18 percent.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 23 about the beginning of the post-convention Dukakis campaign identified a new member of the Democratic National Committee incompletely and misstated her views. Ruth Ann Skaff is a vocal supporter of the Palestinian cause but not explicitly of the Palestine Liberation Organization; she is also the Texas coordinator for the Arab American Institute. She says that while she favors Palestinian statehood, along with security for Israel, she believes that the Palestinians have the right to choose their own representatives, whether the P.L.O. or some other body.

title: First American Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a tax benefit of $3,535,000. The prior year results have been restated for the March 1 acquisition of First Roane County Bancorp Inc., accounted for as a pooling of interests, and to reflect a change in accounting for non-refundable loan fees and costs.

title: For Better Living Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Why Do People Crave the Experience?
description: WHY do people submit themselves to roller coasters and their mutations, the ''scream machines'' that seem so ubiquitous on the summer landscape?

title: Stricter Observance of Afghan Pact Pledged
description: The parties to the accords on Afghanistan have agreed to overlook some 400 accusations of Pakistani violations, to guarantee better access for United Nations forces monitoring compliance and to observe the agreement more strictly, the top official overseeing the settlement said.

title: Network Computing Lures Husband-and-Wife Team
description: When William Carrico and Judith Estrin resigned as president and senior vice president of the 3Com Corporation in June, their plan was to take three months off and see the world. But it has not worked out that way. The husband-and-wife founders of Bridge Communications Inc., which merged with 3Com in September 1987, soon found themselves deluged with job offers and business plans, and yesterday announced they have joined Network Computing Devices Inc., a startup company based in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: Hussein's Slap at P.L.O.; Apparent Disengagement Is Seen by Many As an Effort to Get Arafat Out of the Way
description: King Hussein's decision to break Jordanian ties to the Israeli-occupied West Bank is a direct challenge to the Palestine Liberation Organization to make good on its words, the King's aides and Western diplomats said today. They said the move was born of frustration in his peace efforts with Israelis, Arabs, Americans and, above all, the P.L.O. itself.

title: New York Receives Its Fair Federal Share
description: To the Editor:

title: Richardson Italy-Bound
description: Micheal Ray Richardson, who was reinstated by the N.B.A. last month following a two-year ban for cocaine use, has reportedly decided to fulfill a commitment to play in Italy.

title: Subtle Bird Expresses Her Approval Quietly
description: BIRDS, like people, can use body language to send romantic signals, a new study has shown.

title: Trinidad Silva Jr., 38, 'Hill Street' Star, Dies
description: Trinidad Silva Jr., who portrayed a gang leader in the movie ''Colors'' and in the NBC television series ''Hill Street Blues,'' was killed Sunday in an automobile accident that also injured his wife and son, the police said. He was 38 years old and lived here.

title: Progressive Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a capital gain on securities sales of $600,000 for the quarter and a capital gain of $900,000 for the 6 months. c-After capital gains of $3.5 million for the quarter and $10.2 million for the 6 months.

title: Alexander & Alexander Servces Inc reports earnings for b52,028,000
description: b-Includes gains from investment transactions of $1,136,000 for the quarter and $902,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes gains from investment transactions of $9,440,000 and $13,922,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Nichols Institute reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a credit of $210,000 from an accounting change.

title: Critic's Notebook; At Bayreuth, a Wagnerian Togetherness
description: A true festival, one devoted single-mindedly to a particular composer or theme and taking place far from the distractions of big-city life, does more than provide great performances. It binds the audience into a community.

title: Stern Nearing Deal
description: David Stern, the National Basketball Association commissioner, will return from the Soviet Union this week, and a report says that an agreement is near that would allow two Russian players to play professional basketball in the United States after the Olympic Games.

title: Laser Precision Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said the latest second quarter included a $236,000 charge for management restructuring.

title: Public Library Preserves Intellectual Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Will Hold to Its Terms for Dealing With P.L.O.
description: The United States said today that it would not change its conditions for dealing with the Palestine Liberation Organization, but Administration officials said they would put new pressure on the P.L.O. through intermediaries to accept those conditions.

title: Mesa Limited Partnership reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Biaggi Appeal Fails and Judge Sequesters the Wedtech Jury
description: The judge in the Wedtech trial sequestered the jury immediately yesterday after learning that a Federal appeals court panel had rejected Representative Mario Biaggi's request for an appeal of his conviction last year for receiving an illegal gratuity.

title: Senator Kassebaum Insists She Doesn't Want No. 2 Job
description: Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum of Kansas has sought to dismiss speculation that she might be selected by Vice President Bush as his runing mate on the Republican Presidential ticket.

title: Alexander & Alexander Servces Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Montevideo Journal; Tupamaros Are Back in Business (Radio, That Is)
description: The Tupamaros, the former leftist guerrillas who once did bloody battle with the Uruguayan armed forces, are now fighting ''hand to hand,'' in the words of one member, to win a very capitalistic contest.

title: Experts Advise Caution on Using Balloons to Clear Arteries
description: AFTER a surge in the popularity of balloon angioplasty, the American Heart Association and the American College of Cardiology have issued the first guidelines on the procedure, in which a tiny balloon is threaded through an artery and then expanded to clear blockage.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alco Health Services Corp., Valley Forge, Pa., a distributor of pharmaceuticals, elected Ray B. Mundt as acting chairman and chief executive.

title: Boston Journal; Highway Project: A 10-Year Plague?
description: Arthur Maass, a retired Harvard University professor, may move out of his ocean-view condominium in the North End when it begins. Eloise Young, a graduate student at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is glad she will have graduated and moved away before it starts. And Frederick C. Langone, a former City Council member here who does not want to move, plans to challenge it in court.

title:
FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
Seven-Year Notes
description: LEAD: The Philip Morris Companies yesterday tapped the corporate bond market with a $250 million issue of 9 1/2 percent notes due in 1995 at a price of 99.70 to yield 9.559 percent through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

title: Masstor Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Reagan Veto Is Seen as Less Likely
description: Under heavy political pressure from the Bush campaign and Republican Congressional leaders, President Reagan is now leaning against a veto of legislation that would require companies to give 60 days' notice of plant closings or major layoffs, White House and Congressional sources said today.

title: United Savers Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Vice President at G.M. Takes Post at Navistar
description: Roy S. Roberts, who presided over an effort to shake up the General Motors Corporation's entrenched bureaucracy, was named yesterday as vice president for truck operations at Navistar International Corporation.

title: Chip Pact Falls Short of Goals
description: The two-year-old semiconductor trade agreement between the United States and Japan has failed to achieve many of its objectives, and executives of computer companies in the United States want it modified or scrapped.

title: American Water Works Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lincoln National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After realized losses of $2,025,000 for the quarter and $6,489,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes realized gains of $754,000 and $47,528,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Weston, Roy F Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $529,400 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Deerfield Savings & Loan reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the year-ago 9-month share earnings was not available; the company went public in March 1987.

title: Noxell Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Willcox & Gibbs Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Corrections
description: A brief report in the Media Business pages last Wednesday about the Washington Post Company's earnings incorrectly characterized the performance of the company's businesses outside of newspapers, television and cable. Excluding the results of businesses that were sold before the second quarter, those operations reported higher revenue.

title: Gillette and Coniston Drop Suits
description: After months of persistent wrangling, the Gillette Company and its largest shareholder, Coniston Partners, said yesterday that they had agreed to drop all litigation stemming from Coniston's unsuccessful attempt in April to unseat four members of Gillette's board.

title: Our Towns; A Groundswell Of Rent-Revolt Shakes a Domain
description: About 300 families in this seaside hamlet own their houses but not the land underneath them. That belongs to the American Timber Company, a family-owned business that charges the tenants land rent every year. And for more than 60 years, the company and homeowners treated each other more like family than like landlord and tenants.

title: Homestead Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The 1988 year-to-date results reflect non-recurring charges of $14.4 million recorded in the first quarter and the adoption of FASB No. 91, accounting for loan fees. Non-recurring income in the second quarter of 1987 totaled $16.4 million, including gain on sale of assets of $7.7 million and litigation settlements of $8.7 million, while such income was only $568,000 in 1988.

title: PATTERNS
description: Old Store, New Looks

title: Dial M For Money
description: LEAD: Why do people give money to Presidential campaigns? If you believe conventional wisdom, it's because they want to influence policy, get a job in Washington or, sometimes, because they actually like a candidate's policies. But when I asked a number of people who helped finance Gov. Michael S. Dukakis' march to Atlanta, something else turned up entirely.

title: Talking Business with Morton of John Hancock; Maverick Backs Deregulation
description: The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company is somewhat of a maverick when it comes to deregulation of the financial services industry. While major insurance underwriters and independent agents have been lobbying to keep the banking industry out of their business, Hancock has joined Citicorp, American Express and Merrill Lynch in trying to get Congress to open insurance to banks and banking to insurance companies.

title: Paul C. Reardon, 78; Led Study Urging Curbs on Trial Publicity
description: Paul C. Reardon, a former Associate Justice of the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, who directed a study that advocated restrictions on the release and publication of information about people accused of crimes, died of heart failure Friday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 78 years old.

title: Review/Television; From the Heartland To L.A.
description: The slack-season audition series ''CBS Summer Playhouse,'' which passes the time with pilot dramas and comedies that may or may not find favor, trots out a rather amiable, amusing piece at 8 o'clock tonight.

title: 2 Regional Brokerages to Merge GREGORY A. ROBB
description: Faced with an unsettled business climate since the October stock market collapse, two regional securities firms said today that they had agreed to join forces.

title: Gradco Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $211,000 for the latest quarter and $130,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: 32 Prison Inmates Seize 5 Guards, Then Free 1
description: Thirty-two inmates housed in a special unit for prisoners with disciplinary problems overpowered five guards at the Coxsackie Correctional Facility here Monday morning. One of the guards was released Monday night, and the other four were held for more than 14 hours, before being released early today.

title: Pirates Avoid Sweep by Mets
description: When they arrived here Friday afternoon, the Pirates were met with a hospitable sign at the end of their dugout at Shea Stadium. ''The Bucs Start Here,'' it read. But what began for the Bucs was actually a scary little plummet. Their hitting went into a dramatic decline and their spirits deflated as they dropped three consecutive games to the Mets.

title: Newhall Resources reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $198,000 from the sale of property. The share earnings are in units.

title: Who Cares About Historic Ships? South Street Seaport Does
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Prison Guards Held Hostage Thirty-two inmates housed in a special unit took five guards hostage at the Coxsackie Correctional Facility in New York. All five were released after 14 hours. Page B1. Phasing Out Welfare Hotels Mayor Koch, facing pressure from the Reagan Administration, said the city would end its use of welfare hotels by June 1990, cutting two years off its timetable. Page B1. Reagan Veto Less Likely Facing pressure from Republicans, the President is leaning against a veto of legislation requiring companies to give 60 days' notice of plant closings or major layoffs. Page B4. Fun With Physics Using the principles of physics, designers are putting new thrills into roller coasters, such as the clothoid loop at right. Science Times, page C1. Move by Dissident Writers A Writers Guild group said it would try to force a vote on TV and movie producers' last offer. Page C20.

title: Hotel Shelters To End by '90, Koch Says
description: Mayor Koch, facing a possible loss of $70 million in Federal aid for homeless families, announced yesterday that New York City would end its use of welfare hotels in two years.

title: First Federal Savings Bank- Tennessee reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The bank went public on Dec. 30, 1987.

title: Gilbert Associates Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $2,070,000 charge associated with consolidations of certain operations. Year-ago share net figures are adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid on May 6.

title: U.N. Chief Says He Will Declare A Cease-Fire in the Iran-Iraq War
description: In an attempt to break the deadlock in the talks on the Persian Gulf war, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said tonight that he would declare a cease-fire in the war that Iran appears likely to accept, leaving Baghdad to decide if it wants to keep fighting.

title: Basketball Team Faces Tall Order
description: The news from the Soviet Union last week was a little unsettling for John Thompson. The Soviet team defeated the Atlanta Hawks of the National Basketball Association in the final game of a closely contested three-game exhibition series that was the best barometer thus far of the caliber of competition the Americans may face in the Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea, in September.

title: FOR PALESTINIANS, THE SENSE OF JOY AND ABANDONMENT
description: Across the West Bank, many Palestinians expressed joy today over King Hussein's decision to end the Jordanian presence in Israel's occupied territories. But at least a few Palestinians, still loyal to the King, were distraught.

title: Shortage Seen For Antifreeze
description: The price of antifreeze has doubled to about $7 a gallon because of low supplies and may move higher, suppliers and distributors said.

title: Data Switch Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Worldcorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $3.2 million from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $14,412,000 for the quarter and $18,083,000 for the 6 months. d-Net loss

title: Ply-Gem Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $1,851,000 from an accounting change. The latest periods included gains of about $2.3 million for the quarter and $2.6 million for the 6 months from investment transactions, and $1.3 million, or 11 cents a share, and $1.8 million, or 16 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, both from tax benefits.

title: Southland Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The 1988 and 1987 results are reported on different accounting basis and therefore are not comparable because of the leveraged buyout (LBO) in December 1987. The 1988 results excludes sales from 1,000 convenience stores and the business units being divested. The 1987 period excludes sales only from the business units being divested. The 1988 period included the amortization of the excess of cost over fair value of the net assets acquired in the merger, the second step of the LBO, as well as other LBO-related non-cash expenses.

title: Review/Music; Canadian Brass, in a Serious Concert
description: A decade ago, the Canadian Brass was a fairly good ensemble, as brass quintets go - which is to say that it played its constricted repertory of Baroque transcriptions, marches and ragtime works with polish and panache. Since then, the quintet has discovered that cutesiness and middle-brow comedy are more lucrative than straightforward musicianship, and as its sound grew tarnished, it devoted itself to such gimmicks as dressing in tutus to play ballet medleys and recording an execrable disco track called ''Boy Mozart.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES Gillette and Coniston signed a cease-fire agreement. The company and its largest shareholder agreed to drop all litigation stemming from Coniston's attempt in April to unseat four directors. Coniston agreed not to increase its stake for three years, while Gillette agreed to buy back 16 million shares of its 112 million shares outstanding for $45 each, $7.50 above market value. [ Page D1. ] Donald J. Trump has bought a small stake in Pillsbury and is seeking Government clearance to buy up to 25 percent of the giant food company. Of his investment Mr. Trump would say only, ''I think it's got potential.'' [ D1. ] First Republicbank filed for bankruptcy protection, following the takeover of 41 of its banks on Friday by NCNB, a North Carolina banking company, and the F.D.I.C. [ D14. ] Wheat, First Securities will merge with Butcher & Singer. The brokerages will be part of a single operating company, but Butcher will retain its identity. [ D4. ] A new chief executive for North American Philips was named by Philips N.V., which also split $1 billion worth of operations into an independent subsidiary. [ D4. ] The Bank of New York was dealt a legal setback and will be forced to seek a third extension on its bid for Irving. [ D7. ] NBC is seeking a stake in Visnews, a European news agency, in an attempt to pare the costs of covering the news. [ C18. ] INTERNATIONAL The U.S.-Japan semiconductor agreement has failed to achieve many of its objectives. Executives of American companies want the accord modified or scrapped. [ D1. ] Argentina declared a two-day bank holiday as the Government struggled to deal with runaway inflation and the increasingly tough demands of foreign creditor banks and the I.M.F. [ D1. ] THE MARKETS Strong export demand and a return of hot and dry weather sent prices of soybeans and grains soaring. All soybean, bean oil and meal deliveries closed with limit rises, except for the unrestricted spot August contracts, which posted much larger gains. The Commodity Research Bureau index of futures prices climbed 3.26, to 249.45 of its 1967 base of 100. [ D1. ] Accounts at two dozen major Wall Street firms are being studied in the investigation of trading based on advance knowledge of articles in Business Week magazine, people close to the inquiry said. R. R. Donnelley, which owns two plants at which the weekly is printed, dismissed one employee and suspended another. [ D2. ] The N.Y.S.E. will report program trading on a half-hourly basis by year-end, in another effort to increase investor confidence. [ D2. ] The stock market rose for the third consecutive session, but its gains were small and trading volume contracted sharply. The Dow Jones industrial average added 1.78 points, to close at 2,130.51. [ D8. ] Prices of Treasury bonds and notes moved higher in very light trading. Many investors are awaiting details of the Treasury's refunding, which will be announced tomorrow. [ D14. ] The dollar finished lower against most major currencies amid fears that central banks could drive the dollar down. Gold was down $1.70 an ounce, to $434.40, on the Comex. [ D16. ] THE ECONOMY The S.E.C. put the military contracting business on notice that companies that are a subject of the Pentagon procurement investigation must disclose that fact in filings. [ B5. ] Construction spending inched up 0.1 percent in June as a big increase in investment for new factories helped offset declines in housing and government projects. [ D4. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance is a maverick among insurers, hoping that Congress will open insurance to banks and banking to insurance companies. Talking Business. [ D2. ] May Department Stores is moving to become even bigger while fortifying its anti-takeover defenses. Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: Crater in Iowa Is Linked to Impact
description: AN analysis of samples extracted from wells has convinced geologists that a crater 20 miles wide was formed some 66 million years ago when an object two miles in diameter struck what is now Iowa. The crater, long since filled in, is the largest known impact structure in the United States.

title: Build Schools, Not Obstacles
description: There is wide agreement that New York City's Board of Education ought to get out of the business of building schools, and the State Legislature is about to create a public authority to take over the task of school construction. But negotiations are hung up on the Wicks Law, which prohibits use of a general contractor on public construction jobs. Subjecting the new agency to the law would be like dropping it in a tub of wet concrete.

title: Senators Rule Out New Arms Package for Contras
description: Senate Democrats trying to draft legislation to continue aid for the Nicaraguan rebels said today that they had ruled out any plan that would earmark any immediate money for arms and ammunition.

title: Window Glass Tracks Exposure to Radon
description: GLASS in windows or picture frames retains lasting traces of radon pollution inside homes, a Swedish researcher has found. Hence the glass in homes could be used to help determine the extent of past exposure to the radioactive gas.

title: Wolverine World Wide Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Perfect Circle Was a Bad Idea
description: Circular loops were tried and rejected decades ago because roller coaster cars moved too fast at the bottom and too slowly at the top. The rapid upward climb created excessive centrifugal force that pressed riders into seats uncomfortably. But the slowdown at the top could let upside-down riders fall out of their seats as centrifugal force weakened and gravity became the cominant force. Today's designers realize that they control the speed of a roller coaster by modifying the radii of the loop. Thus, in a teardrop-shaped loop, the large lower radius than they would in a perfect circle and more quickly at the top, where the radius is small.

description: Four years ago, Sir David Willcocks, the British choral director, made his Mostly Mozart debut with a program that included the Mozart Requiem in a new edition by Richard Maunder. At the time, this edition excited considerable interest, since Mr. Maunder had not only revamped Franz Sussmayr's awkward scoring (undertaken after Mozart's death, the composer having left this final work incomplete), but did away with several movements believed to be fully composed by Sussmayr, and added an Amen fugue based on a Mozart sketch.

title: Jordanians and Israelis: A History in Maps
description: 1918: British forces under Gen. Sir Edmund Allenby defeat the Turks in a battle south of the West Bank city of Nablus, ending Ottoman control over Palestine. 1923: The League of Nations gives Britain a mandate over Palestine, an area that includes the East Bank of the Jordan River. Palestinian leaders protest the decision and demand independence. Later that year, Britain effectively partitions Palestine, handing over the East Bank - the Transjordan - to Emir Abdullah and retaining rule, under the mandate, in the rest of Palestine, including the West Bank. 1946: The East Bank becomes the Hashemite Kingdom of Transjordan. 1947: The United Nations, under international pressure to fulfill aspirations for a Jewish homeland, votes to end the British mandate and partitions Palestine into Jewish and Arab zones. Immediately after the decision, armed hostilities break out between Jews and Arabs. Jewish soldiers establish themselves in most areas accorded them in the partition plan. 1948: After Israel declares independence in May, Arab armies cross the border and attack the Israeli forces. The Arab Legion wins control over most lands accorded to the Arabs in the United Nations partition plan. At the same time, the Israelis gained control over lands beyond the United Nations mandate. 1950: Jordan annexes the West Bank. 1967: The Israeli Army captures Arab East Jerusalem and the West Bank from Jordan in the June war. It also seizes the Sinai Peninsula from Egypt and the Golan Heights, where it has long been strategically vulnerable, from Syria. 1974: Arab leaders attending a summit meeting in Rabat, Morocco, decide that the Palestine Liberation Organization is the sole legitimate representative of the Palestinian people, formally divesting Jordan of this role. 1987: In December, Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip begin an uprising against the Israeli occupation. 1988: King Hussein of Jordan cancels a $1.3 billion development plan for the West Bank, dissolves the house of Parliament in which the occupied lands are represented, and announces that Jordan will cut legal and administrative ties with the West Bank in favor of the P.L.O. Source: The Associated Press

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Ideas, Not Insults
