title: Soros Buys 10.6% Of Paradyne Stock
description: The New York money manager George Soros told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he had bought a 10.6 percent stake in the Paradyne Corporation, a data equipment manufacturer based in Largo, Fla. Paradyne has been struggling since it pleaded guilty and was fined $1 million last year for defrauding the Social Security Administration to win a $115 million contract.

title: China's Growing Debt
description: China said today that it did not face a debt crisis but admitted that its debt had grown too fast and needed better management. The magazine Beijing Review said foreign debt had climbed more than 30 percent a year in the last few years and would reach $40 billion by the mid-1990's, with a repayment burden of $13 billion a year. The magazine said China's debt-service ratio, measuring repayments as a proportion of export earnings, would hit a peak of 19 percent in the mid-1990's.

title: Bank Credit Set For Control Data

In the previous week, the rig count had increased by 4, to 903. A year ago, the total was 973, the company said. Baker Hughes's rig count, a widely watched measure of drilling activity, reflects the number of rigs actively exploring for oil, not the number of rigs producing oil.

Revenues in the period rose 96.4 percent, to $365.1 million, from $185.9 million a year ago.

Reviews/Music; Murder, Suicide and the Black Plague
description: In another life, Krzysztof Penderecki might have found a career producing Hollywood horror films. The Polish composer, who made his mark internationally in 1960 with his ''Threnody for the Victims of Hiroshima'' and filled the stage with sex-crazed nuns in his 1969 opera ''The Devils of Loudon,'' has always been attracted to subjects intended to make the audience's skin crawl. That is the aim, too, in his latest opera, ''The Black Mask,'' which had its American premiere at the Santa Fe Opera on Saturday evening: as he explained in an interview before the performance, he wanted the whole work to ''have the feel of a dance of death.''

They also receive a 50 percent discount off a multinight stay at Hyatt with every 20,000 miles awarded by United. title: Out of South Africa, a Playwright's Raw Material

''My first memory of South Africa is getting off the airplane and seeing a sign in the airport that read, 'This door for whites only,' '' Mr. Baitz recalled the other day over coffee in his Chelsea apartment. ''A group of men who worked for my father were standing very nervously as we took in this sign in the shimmering heat. And then we went in the door and entered this other world.''

title: Review/Music; A Cool Night in the Park With the Philharmonic
description: This summer's heat has been hard on those attending outdoor concerts. But the New York Philharmonic and its fans were in luck on Monday evening, when comparatively cool, breezy weather helped turn the opening of the orchestra's 24th season of free parks concerts into the kind of idyllic evening these events are intended to be. Some 75,000 people assembled on the Great Lawn of Central Park to hear the orchestra, and what heat there was, was generated on the stage and in a fireworks display afterward.

The police said that Kimball ran his automobile into a crowd of more than 30 people on a dead-end road late Monday night, killing two teen-age boys and injuring six other people.

Sims, Concurrent's president and chief executive, will be chairman, president and chief executive of the new company.

title: A Revised Proposal On Texas Property

Jim Choate, a lawyer for the Royal Bank, said it had received a revised proposal from Southland on Monday and would extend the sale date to review it. The bank must make a decision by Aug. 16, he said.

title: Varieties of Begging
description: For years in New York City, beggars seemed to fall into two categories: the legless man propelling himself on a little wheeled platform and the sightless man asking for help to buy a Seeing Eye dog. And if the passer-by paused before reaching into a pocket - asking ''Aren't there agencies to help these people?'' or ''Is this guy really blind?'' -chances are that one handed over some change anyway. It's always better, one reasoned, to err on the side of generosity.

It's a blocklong tunnel away and you've got drop another buck to get there.

title: First, and Fast: Cease-Fire in the Gulf
description: As Iran and Iraq are learning, wars are harder to finish than to start. Iraq's continued attacks, and Iran's offers to help secure release of America's hostages, are moves in a complex end game that could easily become protracted. That's why so much depends on the efforts of the United Nations Secretary General to achieve the immediate goal, a cease-fire. Once the shooting is over, the slaughter on the front will cease, the risks to U.S. Navy ships in the gulf will ease and the process of creating a lasting settlement can begin.

title: Review/Film; An 'Alice' for Adults
description: Of all the ways to adapt ''Alice in Wonderland,'' the most perverse, it seems, would be to peel back its genteel Victorian veneer. Without the story's decorum and fairy-tale disguises, the Hatter would seem dangerously mad, the Caterpillar would be a seductive snake, all of Wonderland would be haunted rather than fantastic. That is precisely what Jan Svankmajer, a Czechoslovak animator, has done in ''Alice,'' and though he strips away all sweetness and light, he does not violate Lewis Carroll's story.

description: A music review on Monday about ''La Traviata'' at the New York State Theater on Saturday misidentified the conductor. He was Michael Morgan.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; The Prestige Seats
description: The front row in the White House press room is a place of prestige reserved for the senior correspondentsfrom the three major television networks and the news services. So chroniclers of Washington ways found it noteworthy yesterday when five of the six seats were occupied by women - the first time, in anybody's memory, that that had occurred.

title: 45% of New Yorkers Are Outside Labor Force
description: Even though many New York employers are struggling to fill jobs, nearly half the city's working-age residents are neither employed nor looking for work, a Federal report says.

title: Florence Eldridge, 86, Actress on Stage and Screen
description: Florence Eldridge, the actress who appeared with her husband, Fredric March, in several Broadway plays and movies, including ''Long Day's Journey Into Night,'' ''The Skin of Our Teeth'' and ''Another Part of the Forest,'' died in a hospital emergency room Monday night in Santa Barbara, Calif. She was 86 years old.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Highs and Lows
description: Just as in the instance of dudgeon - there is aiain ''dudgeon'' and there is ''high dudgeon'' - so there is a distinction between a ''canard'' and a ''base canard.'' Currently, in the case of the Theodore Roosevelt Association, it is a matter of high dudgeon about what it holds to be a base canard started last May both by CBS News and by People magazine alleging that the 26th President of the United States, like the current occupants of the White House, sought guidance from astrology.

title: Wyman-Gordon Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $8,530,000 from an accounting change.

title: Coffee Prices Hit Lowest Level in Year
description: Coffee prices continued to plunge yesterday, and analysts said the international coffee market was in almost total disarray. At the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, the spot September delivery fell an additional 7.84 cents a pound, to $1.0883, a 12-month low.

title: Advances in Drugs, Courtesy of Computers
description: Drug companies are not ready to abandon the ''spray and pray'' random sampling of compounds to find potential new drugs, but excitement is growing about using computers to design tomorrow's pharmaceuticals in a more rational way.

title: Prison Siege Is Described As Unplanned
description: Hours after the last of five guards held hostage by inmates at a maximum-security prison were released early today, state officials said that what one called ''15 hours of terror'' appeared to have begun with an argument between one guard and one prisoner.

title: Review/Music; The Elusive Haydn's 'Paris' Group
description: Listening to music is, in one sense, an attempt to appropriate a little of its power for ourselves. We are comforted when we can take its measure - assign it a style, a design, a message, a place in history. Music appreciation involves this process of reduction in which a work much wider than we are is shrunk to form a neat compartment within the listener's sensibilities. To ''understand'' is to tame. Our egos are grateful when that happens.

title: Accused Official Asks Subpoenas in Brawley Case
description: Steven A. Pagones, who has been accused of participating in a sexual attack on Tawana Brawley, made an appeal today that was unusual for a grand jury witness. He asked that his accusers and Miss Brawley be subpoenaed.

title: Education; Finding New Ways to Make Geography Exciting
description: Even before a survey that found young Americans to be geographic illiterates compared with their foreign counterparts, one teacher, Peggy Steele Clay, of Florence, Ala., was planning to make geography ''rich and exciting'' for her second-grade students this fall.

title: Hard-Core Smokers Face Their Addiction
description: The moment of truth about Bonnie Drum's addiction came in the middle of a sleepless night, when all her defenses broke down. Mrs. Drum recalled the incident vividly: she wanted a cigarette, she needed a cigarette, she demanded a cigarette.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; China on the Line
description: Call-in radio shows have become commonplace in this country, but officials of the Voice of America thought it might be stretching things a bit to expect residents of the Peoples Republic of China to telephone Washington with their questions, even on a universal subject like cancer. After all, such callers would have to go to the local post office from 10 P.M. to midnight, Beijing time, and fill out a form just to place a call, then wait for as long as an hour for it to come through.

title: Factory Center At Old Terminal To Be Expanded
description: Proclaiming success in its effort to turn part of the old Brooklyn Army Terminal into a manufacturing center, the Koch administration said yesterday that it would double the capacity of the center by spending $44.5 million to renovate an additional one million square feet of space by mid-1990.

Review/Art; A Tip for the Track: Saratoga Museum
description: Though anesthetized to the temptations of gambling and rated way below zero as a horseman, this critic spent a memorable day at the enlarged and totally redesigned National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame at Saratoga Springs, N.Y. Where horseracing is concerned, he arrived as a novice and left, some hours later, as what the French call a confirmed turfist. Were it not for fear of dismissal from his post, he would have stayed on through the three-week season of thoroughbred racing that opens today. And he would have counted every minute of those weeks well spent.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: BLACK sea bass is popular in restaurants and fish markets today, especially since striped-bass fishing has been banned in many areas because of water pollution. The black sea bass, while much smaller than the striped bass, has mild-flavored white meat that is well suited to simple dishes made with fresh herbs.

title: To Circumvent Dress Codes, Some Simply Eat Elsewhere
description: JUDGING by the mail received in response to a recent column on restaurant dress codes, many readers have fairly strong opinions about the need for such regulations. But then readers of this column have pretty strong opinions about everything. That's why it is impossible to answer all the mail, except through the occasional column.

title: Fears on Economy's Growth
description: The Government's main economic forecasting gauge advanced sharply in June, leading analysts to predict that further increases in interest rates may be soon be needed to head off inflation. Page D1.

title: What Tugboat Strike?
description: Forty-two years ago, a 12-day tugboat strike brought New York City to a standstill. Coal to make electricity and heat buildings was practically exhausted. Food supplies were menaced. Mayor William O'Dwyer ordered all places of public assembly closed to cut travel and electric use and to dramatize the dangers posed by the labor conflict, prodding both sides into an agreement.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-7 An Iranian airliner was shot down because of error by radar operators on the Navy warship caused by the stress of being in battle for the first time, Defense Department officials said an investigation found. Page A1 Baghdad will not accept a cease-fire declared by Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, the Iraqi delegation to the Persian Gulf talks said, demanding direct talks with Iran before the fighting can stop. A1

title: Flash Floods and Drought Ravage China
description: Flash flooding along China's eastern coast has killed thousands of people and left tens of thousands homeless so far this year, and a drought in the country's central and southern grain belts has damaged millions of acres of crops.

title: Lorimar Sells Affiliates
description: The Lorimar Telepictures Corporation said Monday that it had sold three network-affiliated television stations for a total of $23 million. The previously announced transaction involved the stations KCMP-TV, Chico-Redding, Calif.; KMID-TV, Midland-Odessa, Tex., and KSPR-TV, Springfield, Mo. The buyer was Goltrin Acquisition Partnership, whose principals are Joseph Goldfarb, a former Lorimar executive; Barbara E. Goldfarb, a Los Angeles lawyer, and Melvyn J. Estrin, chairman of Human Services Group Inc., a Washington financial investment and management services company.

title: Atek Metals Center reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: Katsina Journal; The Emir's Proud Horsemen, Jet-Age Vassals
description: Wave upon wave of turbaned horsemen, their swords flashing, galloped toward the palace walls. Outside the palace gate, Katsina's Emir waited, mounted on a white horse and shielded only by a pink parasol.

title: Sports of The Times; Sabonis And the Big Boys
description: ARVIDAS SABONIS has no fear of the giants of the National Basketball Association - not of their elbows, not of their aerodynamics, not of their poise. But back in the Soviet Union there are men of more modest size who worry Arvidas Sabonis.

title: Donald Erickson, A Magazine Editor At The Times, 56
description: Donald Erickson, a former editor in chief of Esquire magazine and more recently an editor with The New York Times Magazine, died of throat cancer yesterday at the Harkness Pavilion of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 56 years old and lived in Manhattan and Clinton Corners, N.Y.

title: Home Sales Jump 8.4%, Biggest Rise in 4 Months
description: Sales of new homes surged 8.4 percent in June, the biggest increase in four months, as rising mortgage rates encouraged potential buyers to close deals before rates increased further.

description: BASEBALL CINCINNATI (NL) - Signed Ken Griffey, outfielder, to a free-agent contract. Released Eddie Milner, outfielder. Sent Darryl Hamilton, outfielder, to Denver of the American Association. TORONTO (AL) - Placed Lloyd Moseby, outfielder, on the 15-day disabled list. Purchased the contract of Rob Ducey, outfielder, from Syracuse of the International League. BASKETBALL ATLANTA (NBA) - Named Cazzie Russell assistant coach. CLEVELAND (NBA) - Signed Tree Rollins, center, to a two-year contract. LOS ANGELES LAKERS (NBA) -Signed David Rivers, guard, to a multiyear contract. COLLEGES JERSEY CITY STATE - Named Kim Culligan women's volleyball coach and softball coach. OHIO STATE - Named Russ Rogers men's track and field and cross-country coach. FOOTBALL BUFFALO (AFC) - Cut Clint Sampson, wide receiver. MIAMI (AFC) - Cut Marvell Burgess, safety. PITTSBURGH (AFC) - Waived Tim Calcagno, offensive tackle. SAN DIEGO (AFC) - Cut Toa Saipale, running back; Paul McJulien, punter; Wendell Phillips, safety, and Brandy Wells, cornerback. WASHINGTON (NFC) - Cut Gilert Hawkins, wide receiver. HOCKEY BOSTON (NHL) - Signed Ken Linseman, center, to a two-year contract. RANGERS (NHL) - Signed Stephane Brochu, defenseman. MONDAY BASEBALL CHICAGO (AL) - Placed Greg Walker, first baseman, on the 15-day disabled list, retroactive to July 30. Purchased the contract of James Randall, first baseman-outfielder, from Vancouver of the Pacific Coast League. BASKETBALL BOSTON (NBA) - Signed Reggie Lewis, forward, to a multiyear contract. CHICAGO (NBA) - Agreed to terms with Sam Vincent, guard. HOUSTON (NBA) - Named John Killilea assistant coach of personnel. MILWAUKEE (NBA) - Signed Tito Horford, center, to a three-year contract. PHOENIX (NBA) - Signed Andrew Lang, center, to a multiyear contract. UTAH (NBA) - Signed Bart Kofoed, guard, to a two-year contract. FOOTBALL BUFFALO (AFC) - Cut Mike Akiu and Chas Fox, wide receivers; Willie Beecher, kicker; Tim Borcky, guard, and Kevin Starks, tight end. Signed Vincent Courville, wide receiver. DALLAS (NFC) - Cut Tommy Duhart and Al Huge, defensive tackles; Tony Griffin and Sean Washington, cornerbacks; James Hardman, guard; Victor Harmon and Mark Wallace, linebackers; Alan Hooker, wide receiver; Harper LeBel, tight end; Derek Schmidt and Len Strandley, kickers; Dewayne Terry, safety, and Chris Thomas, running back.

description: Samuel H. Maw once knew little more about coffee shops and fast-food outlets than the average casual diner. But in 1969, he quit his chosen field of engineering for fry cooks and walk-in freezers to join a former college teammate who had taken public a Hardee's hamburger franchise.

title: Martha Graham Fall Season
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company is to open its three-week season at the City Center on Oct. 4, with a gala benefit starring Mikhail Baryshnikov, Maya Plisetskaya and Kathleen Turner. Mr. Baryshnikov will dance the title role in ''El Penitente'' and Miss Turner will interpret ''She Who Speaks'' in ''Letter to the World,'' a major Graham revival. Miss Plisetskaya will perform Michel Fokine's ''Dying Swan.'' The program will be completed by ''Diversion of Angels.'' Tickets for the performance and a supper and dance afterward are $1,000 and $500. Information: 832-1786.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: AUGUST ANGST (On the occasion of a psychiatrist's vacation) Sorry, but our time is up for today and for next week and even the week after because I have to get out from behind the analytic couch and my suit and my silence and maybe you will be angry, happy, sad at our hiatus, but I will be back (it only feels as if I won't) and then we will talk about my endless absence and grow together into the fall. ROGER GRANET

title: MICROWAVE COOKING
description: LITTLE is more refreshing on a hot day than a cold bowl of intensely flavored soup for a simple lunch or to start a meal. And at a time when fat and cholesterol are on everyone's least-wanted list, summer soups can form the basis for satisfying, guilt-free meals. These soups must be made ahead, but with a microwave oven, they will take little time to cook and even less time to chill. For the best and quickest results, always chill soups in a stainless steel bowl.

A novel program is helping to provide rural artisans like Mrs. Kenny with supplemental sources of income.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL The most sweeping trade bill in a generation was passed by the Senate, 85 to 11, and sent to the President. The legislation is intended to make the U.S. more assertive and competitive by giving the President broader powers to retaliate against unfair trading practices. The bill also seeks from foreign governments access to their markets similar to what the U.S. provides for their exports. Mr. Reagan said he would sign the bill. [ Page A1. ] Japan issued a strong protest after the bill was passed. [ D19. ] Droughts in North America and Asia are cutting sharply into world production of wheat, corn and other cereal crops, Government and private studies indicate. As a result, grain stockpiles may fall to their lowest levels since 1973. [ D1. ] Five OPEC ministers expressed concern about oil prices and overproduction but did not call for an emergency meeting of the organization. Oil prices fell further after the news. [ D1. ] Argentina needs more flexibility from foreign creditors, officials and politicians told Secretary of State Shultz. [ D2. ] THE ECONOMY The savings industry continues to pile up heavy losses and $50 billion may ultimately be required to rescue it, the head of the F.D.I.C. said. This figure was the highest yet acknowledged by a Federal regulator. [ D1. ] The Federal Reserve Board gave final approval to the international accord that will require banks to maintain higher levels of capital, based on the riskiness of their loans and other assets. [ D2. ] Sales of cars and light trucks fell slightly in July. Domestic manufacturers reported unexpected gains and importers showed surprising losses. [ D4. ] Movie and television producers and writers tentatively agreed to end their 22-week-old strike. [ A1. ] COMPANIES A Federal judge temporarily blocked Eastern Air Lines' planned cutbacks, in response to a suit by two unions. The airline wants to end service to 14 cities and lay off 4,000 workers. [ D1. ] G.M. warranties will be broader and shorter. The company will offer a three-year, 50,000-mile warranty instead of six-year, 60,000-mile coverage of basic engine and transmission parts. [ D4. ] The assets of one of South Florida's largest developers will be bought by Shearson, Triangle and Michael Swerdlow. [ D4. ] Coastal and the Chinese Government announced a joint venture to operate Coastal's West Coast properties. [ D4. ] MARKETS R. R. Donnelley dismissed two employees at plants where Business Week is printed, and another employee resigned. The moves came as the investigation continued into trading on advance knowledge of Business Week articles. [ D3. ] A bill setting larger penalties for insider trading was introduced in the House. [ D3. ] The Dow Jones industrial average rose for the fifth straight day, closing at 2,134.07, up 2.85 points. Trading volume increased significantly, but the market was generally calm. [ D6. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped slightly in very sluggish trading, as market participants seemed to shrug off a larger-than-expected borrowing by the Treasury. [ D13. ] Coffee futures prices soared more than 9 cents a pound, reversing a recent trend. Crop and livestock futures were mixed. [ D14. ] The dollar drifted fractionally lower against most major currencies. Gold rose $1.80 an ounce, to $433.30. [ D14. ] Yields rose slowly on C.D.'s, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds. [ D15. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS NCNB was the only bidder to obtain an I.R.S. ruling assuring that it would be able to take advantage of $5 billion in tax losses when it acquired First Republicbank's assets. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] Are disk-drive manufacturers in trouble? Some analysts think the industry is in for hard times. Market Place. [ D6. ]

''With all those colors coming at me all at once, I thought, 'Oh no!,' '' said Anita Boston Dana, who has been hand-painting children's furniture for five years. ''But it worked out absolutely perfectly.''

title: Cup Skipper Named
description: David Barnes of Auckland yesterday was named skipper of New Zealand's 132-foot monohull sloop for next month's America's Cup races. The series will be held off Point Loma in San Diego against the San Diego Yacht Club's 60-foot catamaran.

title: Allied Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After realized investment losses of $51,196 for the quarter and realized investment gains of $383,547 for the 6 months. c-Includes realized investment gains of $33,401 and $41,508 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Corrected from Tuesday, Aug. 2, editions.

title: Currents; Historic Lighting Revisited
description: ''LIGHTING a historic building poses a multitude of historic problems,'' writes Dr. Roger W. Moss in ''Lighting For Historic Buildings,'' the last volume in the Historic Interiors Series published by the Preservation Press in Washington. Among the challenges are selecting appropriate light fixtures and duplicating historic light levels.

title: Arafat Describes His Early Life as a Tourist
description: Yasir Arafat says that before he became chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, he was a wealthy, free-spending tourist who traveled through Europe and lived the good life.

title: Pro-Syria Force Told to Keep Arafat's Men Out of Beirut
description: A Syrian-backed guerrilla force fanned out in two Palestinian districts in southern Beirut today, and authorities said the force had instructions to keep followers of Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, out of Beirut.

title: Acme Electric reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Computer Microfilm reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago figures are restated to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend in August 1987.

title: Rockaway Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $938,000 on the sale of discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months; the 6 months also included a gain of $31,000 from discontinued operations. c-After gains from discontinued operations of $52,000 for the quarter and $109,000 for the 6 months; the 6 months also included a gain of $633,000 from an accounting change.

title: For the Pentagon, Reform and Laissez-Faire; Liability Decision
description: To the Editor:

title: East Village: New Wave Of Creativity
description: ''NEVER mind that some of the galleries have disappeared,'' said Michel Hurst, who with his partner Robert Swope owns Full House, one of the East Village's most stylish home furnishings shops. ''We believe there will be a second wave of retail businesses, and we want to stay in a part of the city we like,'' Mr. Hurst said.

title: Private School, After Closing, Sells All It Has
description: Jim Giannone was not happy to be back in school yesterday. He is a 1958 graduate of the McBurney School, a private institution that closed last week after wrestling with financial problems and declining enrollments.

title: Shevardnadze Deplores Pakistan's Afghan Role
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, told his Pakistani counterpart today that Pakistan was responsible for terrorist activity in aiding guerrilla forces in Afghanistan despite international efforts to end the war there.

title: First Executive Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $2,673,000 for the quarter and $4,964,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes investment gains of $2,441,000 and $4,638,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: First Western Financial reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a $146,000 charge for a Federal Home Loan Board prepayment penalty for both the quarter and 6 months. Year-ago quarter and 6-month include the write-off of Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp. secondary reserve prepayment net of income taxes of $2,542,000.

title: Poverty, Fear and Strife Still Add Up to Fewer Jobs for Catholics in Ulster
description: Nearly 20 years after a group of young Roman Catholic civil rights demonstrators began a major protest against job discrimination, the Catholic minority in Northern Ireland still has more unemployment than the Protestant majority.

title: Currents; Art World's Bright Spot: Traveling Neon Museum
description: ''IT was a spiritual journey,'' Leonard Davidson of Philadelphia said of his recent pilgrimage to Jacksonville, Ill., where he rescued a vintage 1950's porcelain enamel and neon sign, depicting Simple Simon and the Pieman, from a former Howard Johnson's.

title: Decision Favors Espey
description: The Espey Manufacturing and Electronics Corporation, a military equipment maker in Great Neck, L.I., said Tuesday that the Defense Department had ended its debarment proceedings against Espey and two officers after hearings. As a result, Espey remains eligible to receive contracts from Federal agencies.

title: Israeli Army Raids 'Terrorist Gang' Homes
description: The Israeli Army destroyed or sealed 12 houses in the occupied West Bank today, and a military spokesman said the homeowners had been charged with belonging to ''terrorist gangs'' and attacking military and civilian cars with firebombs.

title: Beverly Investment Properies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Zenith National Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After investment gains of $523,000 for the quarter and $1,132,000 for the 6 months. c-After investment gains of $1,592,000 for the quarter and $3,960,000 for the 6 months.

title: Midwest Energy reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Review/Theater; A Harlem Musical Opens in Atlanta
description: It is amateur night at the newly reopened Apollo Theater in Harlem, and among the lip-moving ventriloquists, rhythmless rap singers and earthbound ballet dancers, an overconfident band called I. C. and the Chills wins a chance to open a show featuring Patti Austin and Peabo Bryson. On this slenderest and most simplistic of plot lines, George Faison has hung ''The Apollo . . . It Was Just Like Magic,'' a musical of nearly three hours that does nothing to honor the First National Black Arts Festival, which sponsored its premiere Tuesday night at the Fox Theater.

title: Saratoga Opens on Familiar Note: Lukas Victory
description: Saratoga is a place of traditions, and D. Wayne Lukas has started one: winning the Schuylerville Stakes for 2-year-old fillies on opening day. The trainer did it two years ago with Sacahuista, last year with Over All, and today with Wonders Delight, who scored a 1 1/2-length victory in the $90,300 Schuylerville as Saratoga opened its 121st season.

title: Medicare-Glaser Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Prince Philip's Mother Buried in Jerusalem
description: The dying wish of Queen Elizabeth's mother-in-law was fulfilled today when her body, protected by armed Israeli border police, was laid to rest here 19 years after her death.

title: Cardinal Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Fort Apache Journal; What's in a Name? For Indians, Cultural Survival
description: ''When you cross the Salt River you will be on my land,'' said Ronnie Lupe, guiding a visitor not to his house but to the 1.5 million-acre Indian reservation that he and 9,000 other White Mountain Apaches regard as a remnant of their ancestral home.

title: Maritrans Partners L P reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago figures are pro-forma results, assuming that the partnership began Jan. 1, 1987. The share earnings are in units.

title: 153-Mile Hudson Swim
description: Skip Storch, who inspects local waters for a living, finished the longest inspection of his career yesterday when he completed a 153-mile swim down the Hudson River from Port Albany, N.Y., to the Statue of Liberty.

title: Florida Rock Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a $1,507,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: Review/Opera; A 'Barber of Seville' In the Rossini Tradition
description: The New York City Opera filled one of its deepest repertory needs on Tuesday evening with a presentable new staging of ''Il Barbiere di Siviglia.'' Since 1984, when the company's previous production collapsed of directorial ineptitude and had to be rethought from performance to performance, Rossini's comic masterpiece has been in limbo. Little tinkering should be needed on the new staging by Lotfi Mansouri, partly because it follows Rossini tradition so faithfully and sensibly that the gears cannot help meshing.

title: Criticizing U.S., Hanoi Withdraws Offer to Help Account for Missing
description: Vietnam has suspended cooperation with the United States on efforts to determine what happened to the 1,758 American military men still unaccounted for in Vietnam, the two countries said today.

title: Market Place; Debate on Stocks Of Drive Makers
description: SEAGATE TECHNOLOGY INC.'s announcement Monday of production cuts and a possible loss in the current quarter followed a series of disappointing quarterly earnings reports from manufacturers of hard disk drives for personal computers.

title: Tecogen Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-After tax credits of $38,000 for the quarter and $57,000 for the 9 months.

title: Raymond Stross, Producer, 72
description: Raymond Stross, a movie producer and director, died of heart disease Sunday at his home in Beverly Hills. He was 72 years old.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Talking Deals; F.D.I.C.'s Savvy On Bank's Taxes
description: NO one likes to pay taxes. That includes the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which helps explain why the agency last Friday picked the NCNB Corporation to rebuild the crippled banking network of the First Republicbank Corporation.

title: No Cooling Hum in This Urban Oasis
description: William Gross is sweltering through the steamy, sticky days of summer wishing he could walk into the nearest appliance store and buy the biggest air-conditioner in stock.

title: Trade Canceled
description: The Cleveland Browns yesterday rescinded the trade that brought the wide receiver Daryl Turner from the Seattle Seahawks because Turner failed the Browns' physical examination. Turner has a congenital problem in his lower back that might keep him from playing or practicing in the future, the Browns' coach, Marty Schottenheimer, said. (AP)

title: CREDIT MARKETS;
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped slightly in very sluggish trading yesterday, as market participants tended to shrug off a new borrowings announcement from the Treasury that was a bit higher than anticipated.

title: New Test to Detect Herpes Virus Should Reduce Caesareans
description: A new test that takes just four hours to detect herpes simplex virus infections is expected to help women avoid unnecessary Caesarean sections and to help patients with herpes eye infections get prompt, often sight-saving, treatment.

title: Meese Assails Senate Testimony of Ex-Aides
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d today accused two of his former aides of presenting Congress with a ''false and distorted picture of the situation'' in the Justice Department.

title: Cannon Express reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
National FSI reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Badger Paper Mills reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Baseball Notebook; Hernandez Hopes to Revive Met Offense
description: Last winter and spring, some people said this would be the last season for Keith Hernandez with the Mets. This summer more people have said the Mets wouldn't last the season in the pennant race without Hernandez.

title: Kenya Restricts Independence of Judges
description: Parliament has amended the Kenyan Constitution to give the President unrestricted power to dismiss judges, and the police wider powers of detention. Lawyers and religious leaders have criticized the move as a threat to democratic freedoms.

title: Yonkers Residents React With Anger, Anxiety and Some Support for Judge
description: Across Yonkers today, the mood ranged from angry denial to somber resignation as the city and three councilmen began paying daily fines for defying a Federal judge's order to build 1,000 units of subsidized housing in predominantly white neighborhoods.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: First Contempt Fine Is Paid by Yonkers Over Housing Plan
description: The City of Yonkers prepared a ''doomsday scenario'' today as it paid its first daily fine for refusing to adopt a court-ordered housing desegregation plan. City officials said the scenario showed the city would run out of money to pay either fines or salaries in 18 days.

title: Moscow Frees Young German Pilot
description: Mathias Rust, the young West German who flew a single-engine plane to the edge of Red Square last year and was later sentenced to four years in prison, was freed and expelled from the Soviet Union today.

title: School Is Part of Drug Inquiry
description: Norm Sloan, the University of Florida basketball coach, made a voluntary appearance yesterday before a Federal grand jury investigating cocaine trafficking in Gainesville.

title: Police and Guardian Angels Continuing Confrontations
description: After almost two months of patrolling the same streets on Manhattan's West Side, the Guardian Angels and the New York City Police Department often appear more interested in grappling over turf and tactics than in uprooting the drug trade that is their common enemy.

title: Dying Rural Towns Play Let's Make a Deal
description: This town is offering a free lot and $1,200 to anyone willing to move here.

title: U.S. Proposes Two New Reactors Of Differing Types to Aid Arsenal
description: The Secretary of Energy yesterday proposed an urgent effort to build new nuclear reactors in South Carolina and Idaho to replace aging, breakdown-prone plants that are at the heart of the system for maintaining the nation's arsenal of nuclear weapons.

title: Joint Venture to Handle Nicorette Chewing Gum
description: Rubin Reid Noto & Erenthal, a consumer ad agency, and Grace & Lewis, specialists in prescription drug advertising, have formed a joint venture, Rubin Grace Associates, to handle the advertising for Nicorette, a nicotene chewing gum from Lakeside Pharmaceuticals that is used in some therapies intended to stop the smoking habit.

title: Galoob, Lewis, Toys reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Pepperell Names Official To Position at Stevens
description: LEAD: West Point-Pepperell Inc., one of the nation's leading textile companies, has appointed a senior executive as the president of J. P. Stevens & Company, which it acquired in May for $1.2 billion.

title: Currents; Teapots, as Meditations On Free-Form Freeways
description: IF you call Los Angeles directory assistance, you will find Peter Shire listed under ''Potter to the Cars.'' The highway has long held a fascination for Mr. Shire, the artist, ceramicist and furniture designer who was the only original American member of the Italian Memphis group. ''As Americans,'' he said, ''we were born with motor oil in our blood.''

title: Regulator Rejects Bid for Farmers
description: Washington's insurance commissioner has rejected an unfriendly takeover bid for Farmers Group Inc. by the British conglomerate B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. ''The policyholders could quite possibly lose from the acquisition, and they do not stand to gain anything from it,'' the commissioner, Dick Marquardt, said in an order Tuesday turning down the bid. Mr. Marquardt's spokesman, Ed Ives, said the company was expected to appeal the decision.

title: Japan Acts to Curb Insiders
description: A series of stock scandals has prompted the Government to accelerate its efforts to control insider trading in Japan, where privileged information has been a traditional feature of securities trading.

title: life in the 30's
description: SMALL children make useful companions, unless you are interested in eating at expensive restaurants. You can take them to see movies like ''Bambi,'' and no one will think you are weird enough to want to see those movies yourself. You can use them as an excuse to go to amusement parks and to consume leftover bits of hot dogs and cotton candy.

title: MAJOR TRADE BILL SENT TO PRESIDENT BY SENATE, 85-11
description: The Senate overwhelmingly passed and sent to the President today the most sweeping trade legislation in a quarter-century.

title: Argentines Ask Shultz For Flexibility on Debt
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, visiting Argentina in the midst of a new crisis over inflation and foreign-debt financing, has heard pleas from top officials and politicians for more flexibility from foreign creditors.

title: Compromise Made On Issue of Warrant In Larry Davis Trial
description: The defense and the prosecution reached a compromise yesterday in the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court on an issue involving a warrant that threatened to interrupt the trial of Larry Davis in the Bronx.

title: National Mine Service reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-After tax benefits of $206,000. c-Net loss

title: Grumman Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $35,000,000 from an accounting change.

title: Metro Matters; Mario Biaggi, Hearing a Sad, Haunted Voice
description: He was slouched on a bench, by himself, in the last row of courtroom 506 in Foley Square, lulled into light sleep by the haunting arias of ''The Phantom of the Opera'' that flowed from the headset of his son's cassette player.

title: Robert Half International reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $276,000 for the quarter and net of $372,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations. The latest periods' revenue reflects the acquisition of 33 offices acquired from franchisees in 1987.

title: Death Penalty in '82 Murder Voided in Jersey
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court, in a 4-to-3 opinion, upheld today the conviction of James J. Koedatich for the 1982 murder of Amie Hoffman, but threw out his death sentence.

title: Shelter Components reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: Ford May Raise Some '89 Prices
description: The Ford Motor Company, following the lead of the Chrysler Corporation, said it tentatively plans to raise 1989 prices on six cars by up to 5.3 percent. The models are the Ford Mustang and Crown Victoria, the Mercury Grand Marquis, and the Lincoln Continental, Mark VII and Town Car. Ford also said that it had begun to sell the 1989 models ahead of the fall introduction date.

title: Perini Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest quarter and 6 months' share earnings included the effect of dividends accrued on the company's depositary preferred stock of 16 cents and 34 cents, respectively. The share were issued in June 1987.

title: Dukakis Releases Medical Details To Stop Rumors on Mental Health
description: Michael S. Dukakis, seeking to quash rumors about his mental health, eased his reluctance to discuss his medical history today and ordered his doctor to release a more detailed report that gave him a clean bill of health.

title: Lending Loss At Silverado
description: Silverado Banking, one of Colorado's biggest savings and loan institutions, has been put up for sale after reporting a $245 million loss related to commercial real estate loans.

title: 48 Concerns to Pay $17 Million in Waste Cleanup
description: Forty-eight companies have agreed to reimburse the Government $17 million in costs to clean up toxic wastes that a hauling company illegally dumped at four sites in Massachusetts and New Hampshire without their knowledge, according to the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Long Renovations
description: To The Home Section:

title: United Industrial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Fine Crystal but Without the Fanfare
description: LEAD: IN years past, couples would select a crystal pattern before they were married, and with luck, they might be given most of what they needed as wedding gifts. Today, people are not waiting for such ceremonial occasions and are purchasing their own crystal, everything from serving dishes to candlesticks to stemware.

title: Lintas Print Campaign For G. H. Bass Shoes
description: G. H. Bass & Company, shoemaker by appointment to preppie royalty of yesteryear, is going to invest $4 million in print advertising to re-establish the preference for its Weejuns, Rangeleys, Camp Moccasins and Bucs.

title: F.B.I. Valued Presser as Informer
description: Jackie Presser, the teamster chief who died last month, was an informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation as early as 1974, according to Oliver B. Revell, the bureau's executive assistant director of investigations.

title: Review/Music; A House Party At the Ritz
description: Cherubic, honey-voiced, glittering with diamonds and casually peerless in his self-made New Orleans rock-and-roll, Fats Domino returned to New York on Monday to start a week of shows at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street. Backed by a 12-piece band featuring Lee Allen, the saxophonist who played on Mr. Domino's 1950's hits and innumerable other New Orleans standards, Mr. Domino's songs rolled and swaggered, chuckled and sighed - not like classics, which is what they are, but like the sounds of a long-running house party.

title: Dr. Henry Chase, Horse Show Secretary, 64
description: Dr. Henry Chase, the secretary of the National Horse Show, died Tuesday after apparently suffering a heart attack at his home in Manhattan. He was 64 years old.

title: Augat Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Legislative Panel Approves Funds for G.O.P. Convention
description: A Louisiana legislative budget panel today approved the use of $500,000 in state funds to help pay some costs of the Republican National Convention.

title: INSIDE
description: Stocks of Grains Declining

title: Nephew of Convict Held in Girl's Slaying
description: The nephew of a major Queens drug dealer was arrested yesterday in the shooting death late Tuesday night of a 15-year old girl in South Jamaica and may have inadvertently shot off his left thumb, the police said.

title: For the Pentagon, Reform and Laissez-Faire; Blips, and Blips
description: To the Editor:

title: Maxwell May Expand
description: The British publisher Robert Maxwell is considering expanding his operations in Europe by acquiring a stake in CLT, a Luxembourg-based broadcasting group, people in the industry said today.

title: Scherer, R P, Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bill That Lifts Insider Fines Is Introduced
description: Two key Democratic members of the House today introduced legislation that would expose brokerage firms and individuals to larger penalties if employees were found to be trading stock or other securities based on confidential inside information.

title: Repair Effort Increases Ambulances in Service
description: A week after the Koch administration began emergency efforts to repair and maintain New York City's troubled ambulance fleet, the average number of vehicles out of service has fallen by 7 percentage points, to 39 percent from 46 percent, officials said yesterday.

title: Commercial Federal Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $519,000 and $1,990,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. All share earnings data is fully diluted, giving effect to the preferred stock dividend requirements. The company said certain amounts in the fiscal 1987 periods have been reclassified to conform to classifications of the current fiscal year periods. The company also said that fiscal 1988 results primarily reflected the pre-tax loss of $20 million by Systems Marketing Inc., a non-savings and loan subsidiary, due to a decline in residual values of leased computer equipment and poor operating results.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; On Drugs and Politics
description: Debate on new legislation to control the sale and use of illicit drugs will begin on the House floor next week, but Speaker Jim Wright acceded yesterday to Republican pleas to postpone votes on major and controversial amendments until after the Republican National Convention.

title: Currents; Where the 50's Live On
description: ON a rare auto-oriented stretch of Manhattan known for its diners and car-wash outlets, the five-month-old Hot Rod Diner and Bar has made an auto-architectural statement.

title: Request on Interco
description: The Washington investors, Steven M. Rales and Mitchell P. Rales, demanded a list of all of the shareholders of Interco Inc. The Rales brothers have offered to acquire Interco, the nation's biggest manufacturer of furniture and men's shoes, for $64 a share, or $2.1 billion. In a letter to Interco dated Tuesday, contained in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the Rales brothers said that the purpose of their demand is to communicate directly with the company's shareholders. An Interco spokesman said the company would have no comment on the S.E.C. filing.

title: Red Sox Tie Mark And Tigers for First
description: Jody Reed singled home the winning run with two outs in the eighth inning as the Boston Red Sox edged the Texas Rangers, 5-4, tonight for their 22d consecutive home victory, tying the American League record set by the 1931 Philadelphia Athletics.

title: Georgia-Pacific Yield Is 10.541%
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation entered the debt market yesterday with a $250 million issue of 10 1/2 percent debentures due in 2018 at a price of 99.625 to yield 10.541 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Caleb Gattegno, 76, a Proponent Of Novel Learning Theories, Dies
description: Caleb Gattegno, an educator who developed novel and sometimes controversial theories of the learning process, died last Thursday after surgery for cancer at a clinic in Paris. He was 76 years old.

title: A Spinoff For Sports Illustrated
description: SPORTS ILLUSTRATED, the Time Inc. weekly that is celebrating its 35th anniversary next year, will begin 1989 by spinning off a new magazine with a number of missions.

title: For the Pentagon, Reform and Laissez-Faire; Remember the B-17
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Backs Party Chairman
description: Vice President Bush said today that he would keep Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr. on as chairman of the Republican National Committee, even though his campaign was moving toward greater control of the party structure for the general election. ''He offered to resign - the Vice President didn't want him to,'' said Lee Atwater, the campaign manager. Mr. Bush did say, however, that his convention manager, Fred V. Malek, would have an expanded role in the Republican National Committee and would be designated deputy chairman.

title: Barefoot, Pregnant - and Maybe Dead
description: ''Two women in 160 years is about par for the course,'' said Ann Richards, the State Treasurer of Texas, when she became the second female keynote speaker at a Democratic Convention. If her wry comment made millions of American women laugh, it's because they can afford to. They know as well as does the eloquent Mrs. Richards that women are making gains all over the place.

title: Lawyer Finds Judge to Take Plea
description: After almost half the judges in the Eastern District of New York excused themselves from his case, a prominent defense lawyer finally found a judge yesterday who was willing to accept his plea of guilty in a tax-evasion case.

title: Senior Open; Toughest Hazard May Be the Heat
description: With the temperature over 100 degrees on the fairways and no relief forecast for the next few days in the Chicago area, the ninth United States Senior Open may be much more of an endurance test than a golf tournament.

title: Hamilton Oil Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
American Power Conversion reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $22,000 for the quarter and $96,000 for the 6 months.

title: A Verdict on the Vincennes
description: Now that the Pentagon appears ready to blame human error aboard the cruiser Vincennes for the shootdown of the Iranian airliner last month, should Americans feel guiltier for the tragedy? Or just sorrier for an accident of war? And what can now be done to learn the lessons of the tragedy and avoid repetitions?

title: Japan Protests Trade Sanctions in the Bill
description: The Japanese Government and the Toshiba Corporation issued strong protests today after the United States Senate passed a broad trade bill that strengthens the President's power to retaliate against America's trading partners.

title: Q&A
description: Q. In 1982, we had a wood deck built with a bench around the edge to serve as a rail. Unfortunately, the builder didn't use pressure-treated lumber. The following year the wood was stained with a gray wood preservative, and two years ago, when the whole house was painted, the deck was stained again. The painter apparently used a paint or some mixture of paint and stain. The color is fine, but now the finish is peeling in many places.

title: 7 Rail Officers Suspended For Joke Tape
description: Seven longtime Metro-North police officers were suspended yesterday after a five-year-old videotape came to light, showing them clowning in Grand Central Terminal while on duty and, in the case of one officer, harassing a homeless man with racist remarks.

title: Kansas City Life Insurance Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes investment gains of $19,000 and $440,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes investment gains of of $477,000 for the quarter and $847,000 for the 6 months.

title: Mild-Mannered U.S. Judge Under Attack
description: Ordinarily soft-spoken in his courtroom and with a reputation for settling cases long before they get to trial, Judge Leonard B. Sand appears to be an unlikely target for diatribe.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Anyone Can Play
description: The phrase ''journalism is a a young man's game'' was made at least partly obsolete years ago by large numbers of extraordinarily talented women in all branches of the profession.

title: New York Marine & General Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After investment losses of $37,964 for the quarter and $364,739 for the 6 months. c-After investment gains of $212,016 for the quarter and $31,304 for the 6 months.

title: Behind New York's Offer on Dumping
description: By pledging with great fanfare to stop dumping sludge in the ocean within a decade, New York is trying to shift the terms of a Congressional debate of enormous importance to the city.

title: Dow's Fifth Straight Gain Is Small, at 2.85
description: LEAD: The stock market was again becalmed yesterday, although the Dow Jones industrial average managed its fifth consecutive gain, closing at 2,134.07, up 2.85 points.

title: Science Management reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $155,000 for the quarter and $214,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income

title: Home Improvement
description: SUSPENDED ceilings, which consist of lightweight panels supported by a grid of metal strips hung from the existing ceiling or ceiling framework, are easy for amateurs to install. Available in a wide variety of styles and colors, the panels and structural components can be purchased at home centers in kit form and are inexpensive enough to consider as an alternative to extensive patching and repainting.

title: Andre Navarra, Cellist, 77
description: Andre Navarra, a cellist and a longtime professor at the Conservatoire Nationale de Paris, died of a heart attack Sunday at his hotel in Siena, Italy. He was 77 years old. Mr. Navarra had been offering advanced music courses at nearby Chigiana, a summer activity he had pursued since 1954. The cellist was a respected practitioner of the French school of string playing and an active concert and recording artist. His current recordings for the Calliope label include the Bach suites, and music by such composers as Faure and Saint-Saens.

title: PSE Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The year-ago results are restated to reflect the adoption of FASB Standard No. 96.

title: OPEC Panel Does Little About Output
description: A committee of five oil ministers from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries expressed concern today that the serious deterioration of oil prices since June is mainly the result of ''overproduction from some OPEC members as well as high level of production from non-OPEC members.''

title: Massachusetts Inquiry Results in No Charges
description: No charges will be filed as a result of a preliminary inquiry into allegations that the administration of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis gave developers confidential information about potential sites of new prisons, a spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investiation said today.

title: J P Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest quarter includes a charge of $567,000 for additional costs relating to the integration and consolidation of two aftermarket distribution centers.

title: Court Upholds Release of Democrats' Funds
description: Rejecting arguments by Republicans, a Federal appeals court today upheld the payment of $46.1 million in public funds to Michael S. Dukakis's Presidential campaign.

title: ABC's '20/20' Is Alive And Well in Ratings
description: To the Editor:

title: From Tiny Liberty to Giants
description: Although most of the attention in the Giants' training camp has been focused on the offensive line, there has been a surprising development in the secondary. Wayne Haddix, a former free agent from Liberty University, is making a serious bid for Mark Collins's starting job at left cornerback.

title: Grumman's Profit Up 56.7%
description: The Grumman Corporation reported yesterday that a strong showing by its aerospace business helped to lift its earnings by 56.7 percent and sales by 8.7 percent in the second quarter.

title: Correction
description: A recipe for plum torte in the De Gustibus column of The Living Section yesterday misstated the amount of sifted, unbleached flour. The correct amount is 1 cup.

title: General RE Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a realized investment loss of $4.3 million for the quarter and a realized investment gain of $1.6 million for the 6 months, and losses from discontinued operations of $43.1 million and $36.5 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes realized investment gains of $5.8 million and $10.6 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, gains from discontinued operations of $10.9 million for the quarter and $19.4 million for the 6 months, and the 6-month also includes a tax loss carryforward of $11.7 million.

title: Marijuana Fine Suspended
description: A judge suspended a $1 fine today against a cancer patient convicted last week of possessing marijuana he used to counter severe nausea from his treatment. Johnson County District Judge John A. Gardner is also considering whether to void the conviction of Rick Morris, 31 years old, of Van Lear if Mr. Morris completes a drug treatment program.

title: Placer Dome Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago sales figures were restated. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: TV Notes
description: Help for NewsHour

title: Lakes Leads Gymnastics
description: Charles Lakes of Chatsworth, Calif., moved into a commanding lead tonight in trying to qualify for the United States men's Olympic gymnastics team.

title: U.S. Asks More of Nicaragua Than of Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Pop; Mostly Fusion By a French Gypsy Guitarist
description: The French gypsy guitarist Bireli Lagrene made a small tactical error at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night. Though he opened with ''Blues for Ike,'' a composition by Django Reinhardt, Mr. Lagrene spent most of the set playing anonymous fusion on his electric guitar. To make things worse, the band, featuring an electric bass, an instrument nearly impossible to make swing, was obviously unrehearsed and had the rhythmic surety of goats on ice.

title: Review/Pop; Rhythm, in a Suit and Tie
description: If not for his experimental streak, Robert Palmer could be the Pat Boone of the 1980's. Like the white singers who covered black rhythm-and-blues songs in the 1950's, Mr. Palmer has toned down reggae, soul, rock and funk for the pop audience, offering a well-tailored image - he performed Tuesday at Radio City Music Hall in his typical suit and tie, never even loosening his collar - and performances that exemplify control rather than passion or abandon.

title: Early Start Monday Night
description: Monday night football games will begin at 8 o'clock, Eastern time, an hour earlier than previously scheduled, for the first four weeks of the National Football League season Dennis Swanson, president of ABC Sports, said today that competition from the Olympics was a factor in the decision.

title: M D C Asset Investors reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
F.S.L.I.C.'s Need Put at $50 Billion
description: The head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, L. William Seidman, said today that the savings and loan industry continues to pile up heavy losses and that some $50 billion would ultimately be required to rescue it.

title: Ban on Options Trader
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange today suspended a former trader for profiting from phony options trades that he submitted to the exchange's clearinghouse. Eric Joseph, a market maker, was censured and suspended from membership on the exchange for five years. He was also banned from associating with any exchange member in that period. Mr. Joseph was accused of writing tickets for both sides of a transaction without actually having a party to the trades - thereby establishing profits in his own account.

title: Erika Mumford, Poet, 53
description: Erika Mumford, a prize-winning poet, died of breast cancer Saturday. She was 53 years old.

title: An Employer Has Seen the Future, and It's Subsidized Day Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Fibreboard Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $847,000 for the quarter and $17,870,000 for the 6 months. c-After gains of $1,329,000 and $2,523,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, both from discontinued operations.

title: Micro Mask reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $153,000 for the quarter and $711,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: Losses Bring Gains For Farmer in Futures
description: The drought has already stunted the soybeans and ravaged the corn. But Robert B. Johnson, the business manager of his family's 3,000-acre farm, thinks he can turn misfortune into profit by using the futures markets.

title: Kennedy Introduces Meajsure For Long-Term Nursing Care
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, introduced a $20 billion-a-year program today to provide long-term health care for the elderly, chronically ill and disabled in nursing homes or at home.

title: Healthco International reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Quaker Chemical reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Rospatch Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $93,700 for the quarter and $42,500 for the 6 months. c-Net loss and after income of $104,700 for the quarter and $57,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations, and a gain of $114,400 resulting from a revision to estimate on disposal for both periods.

title: For the Pentagon, Reform and Laissez-Faire; Where Was the Senate?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bayou Steel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Fed Approves Rules Requiring More Capital at All Banks
description: The Federal Reserve Board gave its final approval today to an international agreement that will require banks to maintain higher levels of capital.

title: Review/Theater; A Love Object Shows Who's Boss
description: Carlo Goldoni's mid-18th century comedy about the battle of the sexes, ''The Mistress of the Inn,'' is something of a Halley's Comet of a play, one that isn't seen very often. We should be elated that it has landed once again in New York, this time accompanied by a bright star, Tovah Feldshuh, in the lead role at the Roundabout Theater Company, where it opened last night.

title: Reagan Vetoes Pentagon Bill, Setting Up a Campaign Battle
description: President Reagan today vetoed legislation governing $299.6 billion in military programs for the coming fiscal year and accused Democrats of pursuing a policy of ''weakness and accommodation'' on national defense issues.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the Pentagon procurement fraud case included a company erroneously among those known to be under investigation. A spokesman for the company, Boeing, says it has not been served with a search warrant or a subpoena.

title: Alfa Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Terex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Crystal Brands Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest quarter results include operations for Trifari, Krussman & Fishel Inc., acquired May 1. The unit's operations incurred a net loss of $2,013,000, including a charge of $598,000 resulting from purchase accounting for the two-month period ending June 26.

title: Kustom Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $23,000 and $58,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and extraordinary gains of $16,000 for the quarter and $107,000 for the 9 months.

title: Forsaken Brooch Auctioned for $632,500
description: A Tiffany emerald and diamond brooch, abandoned seven years ago in a safe deposit box in a New York bank, was auctioned yesterday for $632,500 at William Doyle Galleries, 175 East 87th Street. New York State will be the main beneficiary.

title: Cipher Data Products reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest quarter and year include about $3.4 million in pretax income related to back royalties owed by Rexon Inc. of Simi Valley, Calf. under recently settled patent litigation.

title: Bridge
description: Some former world champions found themselves on the sidelines in both major events at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here today.

title: U.S. Makers Of Vehicles Gain Ground
description: The domestic manufacturers of cars and light trucks today reported unexpectedly strong sales for July while imports showed surprising losses. Over all, vehicle sales were down about three-tenths of 1 percent from the strong level of a year earlier.

title: Help the Homeless Drop In
description: ''Let me say this in the quietest voice possible. We will not let you do it.'' Thus did a resident of East 77th Street in Manhattan respond to the idea of establishing a drop-in and referral center for the homeless in the neighborhood. That's Nimby at its worst: not in my backyard, no matter how urgently the community needs this project of the Neighborhood Coalition for Shelter.

title: Glasgow Waived
description: The defensive back Nesby Glasgow, a nine-year veteran, has been waived by the Indianapolis Colts.

title: How to Take Care of Caned Furniture
description: LEAD: The original idea behind seats of woven cane in the mid-17th century was that they would support mattresses, pillows or padding. Someone suffering an attack of the vapors would not have been too comfortable reclining on the bare cane of a chaise longue, even though the weaving of such an extensive area would certainly have ''give'' in it.

title: Jacor Communications reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
World War II Planes Found in Greenland In Ice 260 Feet Deep
description: Six American fighter planes and two bombers that crash-landed in Greenland in World War II have been found 46 years later buried under 260 feet of ice, searchers said today.

title: Beneficial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes interest income of $24 million from a tax settlement for both the quarter and 6 months, income from discontinued operations of $900,000 for the quarter and $2 million for the 6 months, and the 6-month also includes an extraordinary credit from utilization of tax loss carryforwards of $35.7 million.

title: Question of Honor
description: In its commitment to truth, the Pentagon investigation into the Iranian airline disaster has gone a long way toward redeeming the honor of the United States. Not many countries would examine the performance of their own armed forces in such an incident with the candor of this investigation's reported findings.

title: Engine Room Fire Injures 20 Aboard U.S.S. Constellation
description: An engine room fire aboard the United States aircraft carrier Constellation injured 20 crew members but did not cripple the ship, a Navy spokesman said today. The fire occurred Tuesday afternoon after the vessel left San Diego for a training cruise.

title: American Financial Network reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: First Central Financial reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Drought Means Deluge in Grain Pit
description: In this city where much of the nation's supply of corn, soybeans and wheat is exchanged, the crowds packing the trading pits are just one sign of how the drought has brought about a resurgence of the grain markets.

title: Massengale Named
description: Martin A. Massengale, the chancellor of the University of Nebraska, has been elected chairman of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Presidents' Commission. He replaced John B. Slaughter, the former Maryland president who left the commission when he became president of Occidental College.

title: CNA Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes investment gains of $15.3 million and $87.4 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-After investment losses of $27 million for the quarter and $11.6 million for the 6 months.

title: Divers Search River For Explosives
description: Divers searched the Willimantic River yesterday for missing military explosives, including a rocket-like projectile that could kill people within 150 feet, the state police said.

title: IRAQ IS SAID TO USE POISON GAS AGAIN
description: In what appears to be a new setback for the talks to end the Persian Gulf fighting, Iran accused Iraq today of a new attack against its forces with chemical weapons.

title: More Contra Aid: Torching the Talks
description: LEAD: The Senate might well pass the Dole amendment providing more military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, based on a fundamental misunderstanding of the status of the cease-fire negotiations between the Sandinistas and contras.

title: Computer Network Techology reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Tiny, Adaptable Houses In a Hoboken Enclave
description: LEAD: JUDITH MACHMER laughs as she remembers the day four years ago when she walked into a real-estate sales office in Hoboken, N.J., and announced that she wanted to buy a house for $70,000. A resident of Manhattan at the time, Miss Machmer, an admiralty lawyer, was taken to see one of the 80 tiny row houses that make up Willow

title: Growth Forecast in '89
description: Gains in trade and capital spending should sustain United States economic growth in 1989, although inflation and interest rates pose a serious threat, Jerry Jasinowski, the chief economist of the National Association of Manufacturers said today. ''Led by improvements in manufacturing, the economy shows a remarkably well-balanced growth picture in its sixth year of expansion,'' Mr. Jasinowski said in a midyear report. Although a recession probably will be avoided in the first half of 1989, Mr. Jasinowski said that growth would slow from a projected 3.1 percent rate this year because the Federal Reserve will tighten monetary policy in an effort to counter inflationary pressures.

title: Harvard Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,606,000 from cumulative effect of accounting change. The company said the 1988 third quarter and 9-month results include the operations of Kingston-Warren Corp. and Hayes-Albion Corp., acquired at the end of December 1986. For comparison purposes, results for the 1987 periods include the operating results of the December 1986 acquisitions for only two quarters.

title: A Fresh Look to Help Ad Council's Vote Effort
description: Backer Spielvogel Bates has given a new, fresh look to an old, traditional advertising chore - the get-out-the-vote campaign for the Advertising Council.

title: U.S.-Japan Food Accord
description: The United States and Japan signed a farm trade agreement Tuesday. The Reagan Administration expects it to double American exports of processed food products to Japan, to $160 million annually, by 1990. Japan is to phase out quotas on imports in seven categories, including dairy and fruit items, while increasing quotas in two others and compensating the United States for keeping restrictions in two others. An earlier pact expanded American beef and citrus exports to Japan.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: MOTHERS and fathers used to pick up the tricks of the child-rearing trade mostly from their own parents or by trading tips with other moms and dads. Today, a growing number of parents are turning to formal classes and workshops. While programs that focus on childbirth and the first year of life deal primarily with the mechanics of child care, classes for parents of older children emphasize understanding how a child or adolescent thinks.

title: The Road to Olympic Gold Often Strewed With Green
description: The last time Florence Griffith Joyner ran on the European track circuit, she received about $1,500 in appearance money for each race. Now, after her spectacular success in last month's United States Olympic trials, she is getting $25,000 a race, and she is turning down many more races than she accepts.

title: Small Beauties the Eye Unaided Cannot See
description: CONSTANT new discoveries are part of gardeners' lives, I think, from the time they first begin to dig in the earth until the day they are at last laid there for good. And often these discoveries are wonderful accidents, instances of pure serendipity.

title: The Mind of a Manager
description: WHAT'S so amazing about the surge of the Red Sox is not how well they're suddenly doing, but how dumb John McNamara suddenly became.

title: Abrams Acts to Extend Jury in Brawley Case
description: New York State Attorney General Robert Abrams said today that he had recommended to the grand jury investigating the Tawana Brawley case that it continue meeting beyond its scheduled closing date of Aug. 11.

title: D.K. deNeuf, 81, Ex-Head of Press Wireless
description: Donald K. deNeuf, retired president of Press Wireless Inc., the international telecommunications carrier and subsidiary of ITT, died of a heart attack July 24 at St. Mary's Hospital in Waterbury, Conn. He was 81 years old and lived in Southbury, Conn.

title: Opus Computer reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $10,210 for the quarter and $66,310 for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: Eagles Are Giving McPherson a Shot
description: Even though he led Syracuse to an 11-0-1 record and was the runner-up in the Heisman Trophy voting, there was some reluctance on the part of National Football League teams to take a chance on Don McPherson.

title: Airlines Improve On-Time Rates
description: The nation's 13 largest airlines in June had their best record of on-time flights since the Government began issuing performance reports, the Department of Transportation said today.

title: Owners of Too-Tall Tower Offer to Renovate 102d St. Tenements
description: The developers of an Upper East Side apartment tower that is 12 stories too tall have asked the city for permission to keep the extra floors in exchange for renovating two East Harlem tenements as housing for the aged.

title: Jane Fonda Finds Peace In Her Time
description: Frank Fabbri, World War II veteran and American Legionnaire, couldn't figure it out. This used to be a tough town, a ''Better Dead Than Red'' kind of town. Why were all those people rushing up to Jane Fonda for an autograph? Didn't they remember Vietnam? Hanoi Jane? ''It's sad,'' said Mr. Fabbri, one of a half-dozen demonstrators standing outside the brick warehouse-turned-movie-set where the actress was being mobbed by 200 starry-eyed extras last Friday. ''If Jane Fonda had done what she'd done back when I was young, she would be afraid to drive through town. Jeeze, where are the men nowadays?''

title: Large Sale Of Florida Real Estate
description: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., Triangle Industries and the Michael Swerdlow Companies announced yesterday that they had entered a joint venture to buy the assets of one of South Florida's largest developers.

title: Producers and Striking Writers Reach a Pact
description: Movie and television producers and writers reached a tentative agreement today to end the writers' 22-week-old strike. The strike, one of the longest ever in Hollywood, has already delayed the start of the next television season.

title: Sutcliffe Keeps Mets' Bats Quiet
description: Just when people were talking about the great offensive revival, the Mets plunged back into their summer slumber last night in Shea Stadium.

title: Court Blocks Publication of John Cheever Stories
description: Publication of ''The Uncollected Short Stories of John Cheever,'' which includes 68 stories from The New Yorker and other magazines, was temporarily halted Tuesday in Federal District Court in White Plains. The book had been scheduled for publication next month by Academy Chicago, an independent house in Chicago. No time limit has been placed on the temporary injunction.

title: Taco Villa Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said net income for 1988 included a $6,520,000 gain on the sale of its Applebee's Restaurant business in the first quarter.

title: Joe Carcione, TV's 'Green Grocer,' 73
description: Joe Carcione, who offered millions of consumers advice about produce as television's ''Green Grocer,'' died of cardiac arrest Tuesday at Peninsula Hospital. He was 73 years old and had been suffering from intestinal cancer.

title: 2 Teamster Leaders Dismissed
description: William J. McCarthy, the new president of the teamsters' union, has dismissed two of the union's top regional officers.

title: Loyola Capital Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lighthouse Keepers Are Ending Their Watch
description: LEAD: THERE are certain things about being a lighthouse keeper that Henry Sieg, a Coast Guard petty officer, definitely will not miss: getting out of bed on cold, stormy nights to switch on the foghorn, rising at dawn and climbing the lighthouse tower to check the harbor buoys, bundling his children into neoprene survival suits in mid

title: Merger Deals Near Record
description: The dollar value of mergers, acquisitions and divestitures involving American companies reached the second-highest level on record in the second quarter, according to a report released today.

title: Lawmakers Receive $9.8 Million for Speeches
description: Special interest groups gave $9.8 million in speaking fees to members of Congress last year, trying to influence legislation, the public interest lobby Common Cause said Tuesday.
