title: U.S. AIDES CAUTIOUS ON AIRBUS INQUIRY
description: The Reagan Administration and Congressional leaders reacted cautiously today to a news report that a military investigation would show that mistakes by the crew aboard an American warship in the Persian Gulf were responsible for the downing of an Iranian airbus a month ago.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Leconte Wins a Day Later: Top-seeded Henri Leconte of France defeated Markus Rackl of West Germany, 7-6, 6-3, yesterday in a first-round match in the Austrian Open in Kitzbuehel. The match had been suspended by rain Tuesday after the first set.(AP) Gilbert Gains: Third-seeded Brad Gilbert outlasted Jimmy Brown, 7-6, 6-4, yesterday in the second round of the $415,000 United States Hardcourts tournament in Indianapolis. The tie-breaker score was 7-5.(AP) Track and Field Ashford Wins Dash: Evelyn Ashford won the women's 100-meter dash at an International Amateur Athletic Federation meet in Viareggio, Italy. Ashford's time was 11.23 seconds. Other American winners included Antonio McKay in the 400 meters, Mark Deady in the 1,500 meters, Dave Kenworthy in the pole vault and David Patrik in the 400-meter hurdles.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Arlen Corp., a maker of steel shopping carts, agreed to acquire Masters Inc., a privately owned apparel retailer. Terms were not disclosed.

title: G.M. to Shorten but Widen Coverage of Its Warranty
description: The General Motors Corporation announced today that it would change the warranty it offers on most of its cars and light trucks from six-year, 60,000-mile coverage of basic engine and transmission parts to a more comprehensive three-year, 50,000-mile package. The change will apply to 1989 models. The new warranty will cover virtually all the parts on a vehicle, G.M. said, including air-conditioning and electronic and power equipment. At present, G.M. offers this broad coverage for one year or 12,000 miles and then extended coverage for the engine and other power-train parts for six years or 60,000 miles, whichever comes first.

title: General Re to Sell Reinsurance Unit
description: The General Re Corporation reached an agreement to sell its life reinsurance subsidiary, the General Reassurance Corporation, to a new company formed by the partners of Insurance Investment Associates of New Canaan, Conn., and Lewiston, Me., for more than $300 million in cash. The acquiring company, called the Reassurance Acquisition Corporation, is a partnership made up of three individuals who have acted as agents in the merger and acquisition of insurance companies.

title: Re Capital Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $78,000 for the quarter and $59,000 for the 6 months.

title: Yield Rises Are Slowing
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were up for the week ended yesterday, but the rises were not as great as they have been during the last two weeks.

title: Sunflowers Grand and Majestic
description: VANGOGH painted them. Oscar Wilde wore them. Milliners at the turn of the century made them out of silk to decorate fashionable bonnets. Nowadays, sunflowers turn the heads of shoppers by rearing their own -large and luminous with vivid yellow petals and deep brown centers. Like royalty, they nod to the lowly herbs and the more colorful but less majestic zinnias and marigolds.

title: Senate Democrats Agree on Contra Aid Plan
description: Senate Democrats agreed today on a plan to provide the Nicaraguan rebels with $27 million for food, clothing, shelter and medical supplies. But they ruled out any money for arms and ammunition except under carefully circumscribed conditions and a subsequent vote by both houses of Congress.

title: ANGOLA AND CUBA REBUFF PRETORIA ON TROOP PULLOUT
description: Angola and Cuba today rejected a South African timetable for ending hostilities in southern Africa, accusing Pretoria of negotiating in bad faith and violating the ground rules of secret American-sponsored negotiations.

title: Pantasote Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $95,000 for the quarter and $335,000 for the 6 months. The year-ago periods reflected results for a 16-week period for the quarter and 28 weeks for the 6 months, both ended July 10. Reporting periods have been changed to reflect 3-month intervals.

title: Researchers Add Sounds of Silence To the Growing List of Health Risks
description: Being cut off from friendships and one's family doubles a person's chances of sickness or death, a new report indicates.

title: Carmike Cinemas Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
New York City Completes Big Competitive Note Sale
description: The City of New York completed the largest competitive note sale outside the Federal Government yesterday when it offered $1.2 billion worth of general-obligation revenue-anticipation and tax-anticipation notes.

title: 'Last Exit' Brings Pleasant Moments at Last
description: When ''Last Exit To Brooklyn'' was first published 24 years ago, Hubert Selby's violent, profane collection of stories immediately prompted a heated debate about its portrayal of life among the prostitutes, transvestites, vicious young thugs, striking union workers and ex-convicts inhabiting the Brooklyn waterfront.

title: National Health Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
New Magazine In Hong Kong
description: A bilingual magazine was introduced today by publishers who hope to profit from the number of people planning to leave this British colony before China takes over in 1997.

title: CNW Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $696,000 and $2,736,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, a gain of $22,224,000 from the sale of a unit and an extraordinary charge of $8,050,000 from early retirement of debt for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $1,465,000 for the quarter and $2,668,000 for the 6 months.

title: STARS' DATA HINT AT OTHER PLANETS
description: Astronomers from the United States and Canada have found evidence of 10 planet-like objects orbiting distant stars, a discovery that intensifies speculation about the existence of life beyond Earth.

title: Study in Africa Finds AIDS Risk to Be Higher In Uncircumcised Men
description: Uncircumcised men are at greater risk of infection with the AIDS virus regardless of whether they have a history of genital ulcers, a new study of men in Nairobi, Kenya, suggests.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A black public official must be held to same standard that any other public official is held to. A lower standard would be patronizing, and a higher standard would be racism.

title: Burma Imposes Martial Law In the Capital After a Protest
description: Burma's capital, Rangoon, was placed under martial law today after thousands of masked students marched through the downtown area and denounced what they called repression by the new President, witnesses said.

title: Review/Cabaret; A New Singer of Old Songs
description: It's a shame that today's musical theater offers such a paucity of opportunities for singers like Jeff Harnar, a diminutive young cabaret performer who is playing an extended series of Saturday performances at the new Greenwich Village club Eighty Eight's, at 228 West 10th Street.

title: Moto Photo reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The year-ago quarter's share earnings was less than 1 cent because of preferred dividend requirements.

title: Consolidated Natural Gas Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Panel Approves Insider Bill
description: The House Energy and Commerce Committee's Subcommittee on Telecommunications and Finance today unanimously approved legislation to increase the penalties for insider trading violations and sent the measure to the full committee for consideration.

title: Biocraft Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the first quarter of last year benefited from initial sales of Cephalexin, a product which experienced substantial price erosion in the second half of last year. The company also said net was hurt by $1,369,000 in legal fees and expenses resulting from the company's patent litigation with Merck & Co.

title: Talks on Southern Africa Extended by a Day
description: American-sponsored talks on southern Africa were extended for an extra day today despite a public dispute over South Africa's attempt to seize the initiative by publicly disclosing its negotiating position.

title: Oregon Law Clinic Battles the Timber Industry
description: A long-running dispute between the University of Oregon Law School and the timber industry has intensified, raising concern about academic freedom and questions about programs at public universities through which students participate in litigation.

title: A Lawyer for Goetz Says He Is Quitting
description: A lawyer defending Bernhard H. Goetz against $63.5 million in suits by four teen-agers he shot on the IRT said yesterday that he had quit because Mr. Goetz refused to pay him or follow his advice.

title: Women and House Pay Scale
description: A study of the salaries of House committee staff members by Representative Lynn Martin shows women clustered at the bottom of the pay scale, and the Illinois Republican urged Congress today to obey the laws it imposes on the nation.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
description: Wieden & Kennedy of Portland, Ore., has created a dozen commercials with athletes in front of the camera and directorial stars behind it for a $20 million one-month advertising effort in behalf of the Nike athletic shoe line. In the first week alone, $7 million will be used.

title: Metro-North Challenged On Officers' Suspension
description: A former Metro-North Railroad police captain said yesterday that the day after he received a videotape showing seven officers clowning around Grand Central Terminal, he turned the tape over to his superiors.

title: Reviews/Art; Provocative Exhibitions at Museums and Galleries That Are New New York city
description: On Long Island

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday HISTORY BY PHOTO

title: Attorney General Given Troops' Fond Farewell
description: Among the plaques and the trophies and the other goodbye gifts presented today to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d at the Justice Department, two seemed particularly appropriate: a gold-plated hand grenade and a tomahawk.

title: Cohu Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Britain Plans Sale Of Aircraft Maker
description: The British Government plans to sell Short Brothers P.L.C., a state-owned aircraft manufacturer, as a single unit rather than split up the concern, a company spokesman said. ''The Government has agreed to a Short proposal that the company must remain intact as an integrated design and manufacturing aerospace business,'' the spokesman said.

title: Tech-Ops Landauer Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
Insilco Takes $950 Million Buyout by Group
description: An investor group headed by the First Boston Corporation and senior executives of the Insilco Corporation said yesterday that they had reached agreement to buy the consumer conglomerate for $29 a share, or $950 million in cash, including debt.

title: Grant F. Walton, 63, Ex-Cook College Dean
description: Dr. Grant F. Walton, a former dean of Cook College at Rutgers University, died Wednesday at Doylestown (Pa.) Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived in Stockton, N.J.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Brand-name Experts to The Rescue
description: AT the same time that the longevity of brands is being threatened by a growing dependence on sales promotion ploys, a small band has rallied beneath a ''save that brand'' banner.

title: Rocking Horse Child Care Centers of America reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Sports People; Austin Plays Again
description: Sitting in the broadcast booth at Wimbledon helped Tracy Austin make a career decision. She had finally recovered from recurring back and neck injuries. ''Then it all came to me at Wimbledon when I was doing TV and sitting with you guys, asking questions,'' she told reporters. ''I had a strong desire to play.''

title: First Republic's Unit Seized
description: Federal regulators have taken control of the First Republicbank Corporation's remaining subsidiary, a credit card operation in Delaware, resolving a dispute with banking authorities there.

title: Economic Scene; Long-Term View: Gloomy Forecasts
description: A PRESIDENTIAL election year is always a time for peering into the future, and everybody's doing it. Despite the current surge of the economy, highlighted by this week's jump in the leading indicators, the longer-term prophecies are, on the whole, gloomy.

title: Wages That Raise Eyebrows
description: Because of a shortage of workers, wages are rising faster in Massachusetts than they are in any other state.

title: McCormick Capital reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Koch, Offering New Rules, Lifts Ban on Vendors in Midtown
description: Mayor Koch, in an unexpected move, yesterday lifted a six-week ban that had prohibited vendors from working in midtown Manhattan, and agreed to a compromise to limit food stands on the most congested corners. The agreement, which requires City Council action, permits the vendors to return today to their most lucrative spots.

title: At the Movies
description: Summer in the City

title: Presidents' Checks
description: Apparently there are checks and balances with regard to the executive branch that escaped the attention of the Constitution's Framers: the personal checks written by Presidents and their bank balances.

title: Bush Child-Care Plan Gives Families Power
description: To the Editor:

title: O'Brien Feels Well Protected
description: Jets quarterbacks were sacked 66 times last season and Ken O'Brien absorbed 50 of those.

title: F.C.C. to Reconsider Cable Proposal
description: The Federal Communications Commission today revived a proposal to allow national television networks to own cable television systems.

title: Treasury Working on $500 Million Loan to Aid Argentina
description: The Treasury announced today that it was working to arrange an emergency $500 million loan from major industrial countries to ease the latest economic crisis in Argentina, where inflation climbed 25 percent in July alone.

title: HERTZ ADMITS USE OF FRAUD IN BILLS FOR AUTO REPAIRS
description: The Hertz Corporation pleaded guilty yesterday to defrauding 110,000 customers and other motorists and insurance companies by charging them inflated and sometimes fictitious collision-repair costs.

title: Bill Vehr, 48, Actor Who Was Director Of 70's Cult Classics
description: Bill Vehr, an actor, playwright and film maker, died of AIDS on Tuesday at Beth Israel Hospital in New York. He was 48 years old. Mr. Vehr, born in Green Hills, Ohio, had no formal training in theater. He became known, in the late 1960's and 1970's, as the underground film maker who created and directed such cult classics as ''Avocada,'' ''Brothel,'' ''The Mystery of the Spanish Lady'' and ''M. M. for M. M.,'' all starring Mario Montez.

title: Pondering The Puzzle Of Hussein
description: ''What am I today? A Palestinian? A Jordanian?''

title: Universal Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
For Moscow Jews, Fear Of Prejudice Is Stirring
description: There is a sense of fear among Jews in Moscow these days, a disquieting feeling that the changes taking place in Soviet society, changes that seem to encourage more openness and tolerance, are somehow stimulating the anti-Semitism that has deep historical roots in this country.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; Filly to Use Whitney as Road to Title
description: Two years ago, Lady's Secret sailed through the mud to become only the fourth filly to win the Whitney Handicap at Saratoga Race Track. She lost two subsequent starts against males, but at season's end she was named the Horse of the Year.

title: Meister Playing Cage
description: Rudolf Meister, the pianist, is to play John Cage's complete ''Sonatas and Interludes'' in a free concert at the Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden of the Museum of Modert Art, 14 West 54th Street, tonight at 7:30. The performance will be repeated at the same time tomorrow. Information: 708-9850.

title: Scientific Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The share earnings reflect a 1-for-5 reverse stock split effective June 24, 1988.

title: Mirrors of Life
description: Perched high in a cab behind the engine, the driver of a large truck often cannot see pedestrians in crosswalks directly in front of him. Sensible legislation proposed by New York City's Department of Transportation would eliminate this dangerous blind spot by requiring inexpensive convex safety mirrors.

title: Two Banks Agree On Loans to Revco
description: Wells Fargo Bank and Marine Midland Bank have agreed to lend $25 million immediately to Revco D.S. Inc. and $25 million more when the Federal Bankruptcy Court approves arrangements to keep management in charge of the company during its reorganization. The deal would assure lenders that management of the drugstore chain has the authority to direct company operations and control its assets.

title: Toy Guns, Real Crimes
description: A bill passed quietly last month by the New York State Legislature and just signed by Governor Cuomo bans the manufacture and sale of realistic-looking toy guns. That should set a powerful example for Congress.

title: American Medical
description: A Miami physician, M. Lee Pearce, has applied for permission from Federal antitrust regulators to raise his stake in American Medical International Inc., a Beverly Hills, Calif., hospital concern, to 15 percent from his current 7.5 percent holding. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Dr. Pearce repeated that he may initiate a proxy fight to remove certain of the company's directors. Dr. Pearce has also asked the company's board to remove Walter L. Weisman as its chief executive.

title: British Financier Gets Bail
description: The British financier Peter Clowes, charged in connection with the collapse of management funds that owe investors an estimated $:190 million, or $325 million, was granted bail today until January.

title: A Web of Corruption
description: 1965 John Mariotta, a tool and die maker whose parents came from Puerto Rico, establishes a small machine shop in the South Bronx: Welbilt Electronic Die Corporation, later Wedtech. 1970 With a partner, Fred Neuberger, an immigrant from Rumania, Mr. Mariotta seeks Government contracts set aside for minority-owned businesses. Late 1970's Wedtech gives more than $20,000 in campaign contributions to Bronx Borough President Stanley Simon, whose office helped expedite requests for city help. 1979 The company hires the law firm of Biaggi & Ehrlich, after Representative Mario Biaggi offered its services. May 1982 Lyn Nofziger, a former top adviser to President Reagan, who left the White House in January 1982 to start a public relations concern, begins to work for Wedtech and writes to the deputy White House counsel about an Army contract. May 19, 1982 At a meeting in the White House, attended by representatives of Wedtech, the Army and the Small Business Administration, Wedtech's problems are solved. The Army agrees to pay $27.7 million for 1,300 small gasoline engines; the S.B.A. agrees to provide a $3 million grant and $2 million loan. February 1987 Four company executives plead guilty to forging invoices and other charges. They also assert Wedtech made payoffs to 20 officials, including Mr. Biaggi and Mr. Simon. February 1987 A special prosecutor, James C. McKay, is named to investigate Mr. Nofziger's links to Wedtech. The investigation is later expanded to include Mr. Meese, the former White House counsel and current Attorney General. June 1987 Mr. Biaggi, his son Richard, and five others are indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of transforming Wedtech into a criminal racketeering enterprise. July 1987 Mr. Nofziger is indicted on charges that he illegally ''profited from the political reputation and influence'' he gained as a top White House aide, in lobbying for Wedtech. July 1988 Attorney General Meese announces he has been vindicated by the independent prosecutor's report and plans to resign later in the summer. Although Mr. McKay does not recommend criminal charges, the report finds Mr. Meese and his staff were ''instrumental'' in helping Wedtech win a $32 million Army contract that was awarded without bidding. Aug. 4, 1988 Mr. Biaggi and four of his five co-defendants are convicted of various charges.

title: Atlantis Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $791,000 and $1,612,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $712,000 for the quarter and $619,000 for the 6 months.

title: Buyout Is Set For Plantronics
description: Plantronics Inc., a manufacturer of telephone headsets and other communications products based in Santa Cruz, Calif., said today that it had agreed to be acquired in a management buyout for $25 a share, or about $128.3 million.

title: Legislators Balk at Compensation for Jet Downing
description: President Reagan's plan to compensate the families of those who died when an American warship shot down an Iranian airliner over the Persian Gulf ran into heavy opposition in Congress today.

title: Zondervan Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $590,000 related to a tentative settlement of a shareholder lawsuit for both the quarter and 6 months. c-After an extraordinary gain of $332,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Craig Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain from settlement of prior year's tax issues of $270,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Fitness for Office; Trend Toward Disclosure Is Arising, But Fear of Public's Reaction Persists
description: The Presidential candidates' release of certain details of their medical histories this week is in keeping with the recent trend of office-seekers to divulge more about their health.

title: Hostetler in a Better Position This Year
description: With every training camp that passes, it becomes more difficult for Jeff Hostetler to go through the motions. He has endured the late-summer practice sessions just as the rest of his veteran teammates have, only to receive assignments on special teams most coaches wouldn't dream of giving their quarterbacks.

title: Sports People; Beer Containers Found
description: The Tampa Tribune reported yesterday that sheriff's deputies said they had found eight empty beer containers in the car driven by Bruce Kimball, the Olympic diver, that struck and killed two people and injured six Monday night. Kimball reportedly told investigators he began drinking nine hours before he lost control of his automobile and ran through a group of teen-agers.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; In-Flight Magazines Offering Bonus Pages
description: Jeffrey S. Butler, president of East/West Network, which publishes seven in-flight magazines, has created a wonderfully expensive carrot on a stick.

title: Acquittal After 'Monsoon'
description: For Ronald Betso, the injured Vietnam War veteran and former New York City police officer who was acquitted yesterday of all charges in the Wedtech trial, calling the end of his five-month ordeal bittersweet is probably a gross understatement.

title: Stake in Formica To Investor Group
description: A 9.6 percent stake in the Formica Corporation has been acquired by Malcolm I. Glazer, members of his family and companies that he controls. A filing by Mr. Glazer, a Rochester investor, said he ''may seek to acquire a controlling interest'' in the Wayne, N.J., manufacturer of decorative laminates. Formica has almost 11.1 million shares outstanding. At today's closing price of $13 a share, the company has a value of about $144 million.

title: Cambrex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,461,700 from sale of discontinued operations for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: American Biltrite Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $281,000 and $600,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Dow Slumps 7.47 Points, To 2,126.60
description: Stock trading continued to be moribund, as the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday suffered its first setback in six sessions.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: The Earl King Sound

title: Jostens Buys Stake In Software Maker
description: Broderbund Inc., a leading producer of software for home and school use, said that Jostens Inc. of Minneapolis had acquired more than 20 percent of the company's common stock for an undisclosed amount of cash. Privately held Broderbund, based in San Rafael, Calif., has annual sales of more than $40 million.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Profits Up at Ogilvy
description: The Ogilvy Group reported its second-quarter financial results yesterday. Revenues were $210.7 million, a 13.9 percent increase from the $184.9 million in the second quarter in 1987, while net income was up 10.9 percent to $9.1 million, or 63 cents a share, from $8.2 million, or 55 cents a share.

title: On Stage
description: New Star for 'Ziegfeld'

title: Loews Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes net gain of $29.5 million, or 39 cents a share, on sale by the company's Lorillard unit of its chewing toacco and little cigar business for both the quarter and 6 months, net realized investment gains of $8.4 million, or 11 cents a share, and $98,816,000, or $1.29 a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and the 6-month also includes net of $18,067,000, or 24 cents a share, from discontinued operations. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $3,102,000, or 4 cents a share, and $11,085,000, or 14 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and the quarter also includes net realized investment gains of $11.2 million, or 14 cents a share.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Ingersoll-Rand Picks Chairman's Successor
description: LEAD: The Ingersoll-Rand Company yesterday appointed Theodore H. Black chairman and chief executive, effective Oct. 1. He succeeds Thomas A. Holmes, who will reach the company's retirement age of 65 in September.

title: Bank Bailouts: The Cost of Delay
description: ''The worst is over,'' says William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, after bailing out yet another Texas bank. But that refers only to bank failures. He estimates that $50 billion is needed to rescue insolvent savings and loan institutions - and counting. Every month that goes by without a remedy raises the bill, he thinks, by another billion.

title: SIMON ALSO GUILTY
description: Representative Mario Biaggi, the senior member of New York City's Congressional delegation, was convicted yesterday of 15 felony counts in the Wedtech racketeering trial.

title: 'On Art' at Whitney
description: The seventh annual series of ''Film and Video on Art'' continues this weekend at the Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue at 75th Street. The program of 14 films and 13 videotapes includes profiles of Alice Aycock, Jennifer Bartlett, Romare Bearden, Alfred Stieglitz and others. A tape on the photographer Robert Mapplethorpe and a filmed interview with the architect Frank Gehry are complements of their work now on view. The screenings are included in the museum admission of $4.50 ($2.50 for those over 62). High school and college students are admitted free. Hours are 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Wednesday to Saturday, noon to 6 Sunday and 1 to 8 P.M. Tuesday. On Tuesdays, admission is free from 6 to 8 P.M. Information: 570-3633.

title: Taiwan Seeks Free Trade
description: Taiwan's Prime Minister Yu Kuo-hua said Taiwan wants a free-trade agreement with the United States, its largest trading partner, a Taipei newspaper said Wednesday.

title: Mortgage Bonds By Idaho Agency
description: The Idaho Housing Agency is offering $35 million in single-family mortgage bonds, some of which will be subjected to an alternative minimum tax for certain investors. Yields range from 6 percent for serial bonds due in 1990 to 7.75 percent for those due in 2000.

title: Wendy's International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''FINN McCOOL,'' an Irish story, told by Jody Moore, and ''The Real Princess,'' a story by Hans Christian Andersen, told by Tom White, 11 A.M. Saturday at the Andersen statue, near 72d Street and Fifth Avenue in Central Park. Free. ''WIDE-AWAKE JAKE,'' a play based on an English storybook of the same name by Helen Young, about a little boy who cannot fall asleep, performed by Tada and directed by Janine Nina Trevens, 11 A.M. Friday and Monday, and 1 and 3 P.M. Saturday and Sunday, at the group's new theater, 120 West 28th Street. Last performances. Tickets: children, $5, adults, $5.50. Information: 627-1732. ''IN THE NICK OF TIME,'' a musical by the Penny Bridge Players, 10:30 A.M. Friday, the Assumption Church, 59 Cranberry Street, in the Brooklyn Heights section. Tickets: $4. Information: (718) 522-0255 or (718) 855-6346. ''CINDERELLA WORE COMBAT BOOTS,'' a play with a new slant on the legendary character, 5 P.M. Friday, 1 P.M. Saturday and Sunday, at the Westside Arts Theater, 407 West 43d Street. Tickets: $7. Reservations: 541-8394. ''PINOCCHIO,'' a musical version of the classic story, presented by the Theater Workshop, 10:30 A.M. and 1 P.M. Saturday, at the Fantasy Playhouse, 317 Merrick Road, Lynbrook, L.I. Tickets: $5. Reservations required: (516) 599-1982. JAPANESE HILL AND POND GARDEN, with fish in the pond and a water-lilies display, at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. The garden is open Tuesday through Friday from 8 A.M. to 6 P.M., and weekends and holidays 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., 1000 Washington Avenue, at Crown Street, Crown Heights. Information: (718) 622-4433.

title: Showboat Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $813,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Net income d-After extraordinary losses of $2,564,000 for the quarter and $3,034,000 for the 6 months, relating to the repurchase of debt securities. The company said comparison of the respective three month 1988 and 1987 periods is distorted by the revenue which resulted from the April 1987 opening of the new casino in Atlantic City.

title: New Thai Prime Minister
description: Chatichai Choonhavan, a former soldier and diplomat, became Thailand's first elected Prime Minister in 12 years today. Mr. Chatichai's nomination by a coalition of parties that won a majority of seats in parliamentary elections July 24 was approved by King Bhumibol Adulyadej.

title: Books of The Times; Peepholes, Porn and the Darker Erotic Mysteries
description: Scandal By Shusaku Endo Translated from the Japanese by Van C. Gessel. 261 pages. Dodd, Mead. $18.95.

title: Traders Wary on Weather As Grain Contracts Climb
description: Deteriorating crop conditions pushed up prices of soybeans and corn yesterday, while the wheat market was bolstered by continued demand from overseas buyers.

title: Samoan Delegate Enters Plea
description: American Samoa's nonvoting delegate to Congress has pleaded guilty to a charge that he participated in a $130,920 payroll padding scheme, his lawyer says.

title: Mets Squander Their Chances
description: When you have to strike out Darryl Strawberry three times with six men on base to beat the Mets, you are living dangerously.

title: Utility Executive Leads Potential Merger Trend
description: Howard P. Allen, the chairman and chief executive of SCEcorp, one of the nation's largest utilities, lives 10 miles from where he was born in Upland, Calif., a onetime citrus-growing region 45 miles east of Los Angeles.

title: National Datacomputer reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $132,000 from favorable settlement of a lawsuit.

title: Bankruptcy for Ex-Editor
description: Lewis D'Vorkin, who resigned suddenly on June 29 as the Page One editor of The Wall Street Journal, filed for personal bankruptcy yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Review/Film; Youthful Heroics, In 'Rescue'
description: Kiddie-centrism reaches some new pinnacle with ''The Rescue,'' the story of five brave youngsters who storm their way into North Korea to free their fathers, who have just become prisoners of war for reasons that only the screenwriters (Jim Thomas and John Thomas, also authors of ''Predator'') would understand. In the process, these young heroes discover that going to war is a lot like visiting an amusement park, except the noises are louder. Parents may not regard this as an ideal lesson for young viewers.

title: Scandal's Origins
description: Wedtech, once a symbol of hope for the depressed inner city, is now an emblem of white-collar greed and political corruption. Page B4. . . . and Biaggi's Outlook

title: Lawsuit Filed On E-II Sale
description: An investment group headed by Michael Steinhardt filed suit Wednesday in a New York State court seeking to undo American Brands Inc.'s recent sale of E-II Holdings Inc. to a family concern controlled by Meshulam Riklis. The sale transferred nine

title: Dukakis Campaigns in South
description: Michael S. Dukakis took his campaign to Mississippi and had to confront the enigmatic political character of the Deep South. Page A12.

title: Tootsie Roll Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earnings net figures have been restated for 3 percent stock dividends paid April 23, 1987 and April 26, 1988, as well as for a 2-for-1 stock paid May 29, 1987.

title: Cerner Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Aloysius Mazewski, 72, Polish-American Chief
description: Aloysius Mazewski, president of the Polish American Congress since 1967, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at his summer home in Portage, Wis. He was 72 years old and lived in Northbrook, Ill., a Chicago suburb.

title: Dividend Halt To Continue At Big Bank
description: The BankAmerica Corporation will not restore a common stock dividend this year, A.W. Clausen, its chairman and chief executive, has said. He seemed to suggest, however, that a dividend might be restored next year.

title: Johnston Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $50,000 from discontinued operations for both the quarter and year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $558,000 for the quarter and $959,000 for the year.

title: Heavily Salted Sandwich Has the Police Unamused
description: A 16-year-old convenience store clerk has been charged with putting too much salt on a state trooper's sandwich.

title: Laser Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Koch's Chef Said to Misuse City Workers
description: An official investigation has found that Mayor Koch's chef at Gracie Mansion improperly used city workers and equipment in his private catering business, and Mr. Koch said yesterday that he had given the chef one week to decide whether to divest himself of the business or quit.

title: Banister Continental Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Righetti Still Feels at a Loss
description: The night was no escape. Dave Righetti returned to the solitude of his downtown hotel room late Wednesday, closed the door behind him and tried to sleep. He tossed and turned.

title: Eighty Eight Journal; A Date That Will Live in Kentucky
description: From her cubbyhole post office in the front corner of the 88 Market, Donnie Sue Bacon handles mail for 70 rural addresses. In a town this size, the postmistress knows everybody in town by name, face and magazine subscription. Most of the 200 people of Eighty Eight get their mail by general delivery. That means Mrs. Bacon puts it aside until they come in and get it. Why buy a post office box if you went to school with the postmistress?

title: Under the Stars and Jets, a Summer Celebration
description: Nine pianos, 12 reel-to-reel tape recorders and a chorus of dog's-head masks are required for the John Cage tribute. Alfred Desio will plug himself in for an electronic tap-dancing performance. Guirgai, a street theater company from Madrid, will incorporate huge set pieces and props for their journey to Eldorado. And Jenneth Webster is praying that it will not rain on the Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors Festival.

title: Senate Affirms U.S. Backing Of F.S.L.I.C. Debt Issue
description: The Senate today pledged the full faith and credit of the Federal Government behind notes issued by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. It also urged Federal regulators to stop more than 500 insolvent savings and loan institutions from making more loans.

title: XL-Datacomp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Shultz Denounces Nicaragua And Says It Endangers U.S.
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the Soviet Union is building airstrips in Nicaragua, which he termed a cancer that the United States must cut out.

title: Restaurants
description: The Lincoln Center area still suffers from a relatively lackluster cast of restaurants, considering the demand for quality dining before and after performances. Several promising places have opened in the neighborhood over the last year, but none so far rivals five-year-old Cafe Luxembourg for its consistently appealing fare and kinetic ambiance.

title: Nation's Messages of Support for the Defiant
description: From all over the country, dozens of people have telephoned and written to Yonkers City Hall, most in support of the four City Councilmen who voted against a Federal desegregation order.

title: Towers Financial Charged by S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday charged a big New York-based factoring firm, which last year made an unsuccessful bid for control of Pan American World Airways Inc., with failing to register $20 million in securities before selling them publicly.

title: Conferees in Urban League Dismayed Over the Election
description: In vigorous forums and backroom debates, delegates to the National Urban League's annual convention here have spent the last several days searching for answers at a time of political uncertainty for many black voters.

title: Review/Theater; Charles Fuller's 'Sally'
description: At what price comes freedom? With ''Sally,'' the first installment in a planned five-play cycle tracing the history of black Americans from the Civil War until the turn of the century, Charles Fuller confronts the issue as both a fiscal and metaphorical debate. For the newly freed slaves serving in a regiment of the Union Army at wages less than those paid to whites, money comes increasingly to symbolize the elusiveness of a promised liberation.

title: Waging Holy Peace
description: The leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization will meet soon in an important crisis conclave. But once again the meeting will be on the wrong topic. Still absent from the agenda will be the single most important subject confronting the Palestinians.

title: Thomas Sinclair, 73, Ex-Civil Court Judge
description: Thomas V. Sinclair Jr., a retired judge of the New York City Civil Court, died Tuesday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a stroke. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Are Museums Doing Their Job of Preservation?
description: To the Editor:

title: Tech-Ops Sevcon reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
Computer Halts Shuttle Test After Sensing Faulty Valve
description: Engineers today came within a split second of ignition for the space shuttle Discovery's much-delayed engine test, only to be frustrated by an apparently sluggish fuel valve.

title: Fears of a New Famine Ease in Ethiopia
description: Government and international aid workers here say they no longer fear a severe famine similar to the disaster that took the lives of hundreds of thousands of Ethiopians three years ago.

title: George Morris Jr., 71, Former G.M. Executive
description: George B. Morris Jr., a retired vice president for industrial relations at the General Motors Corporation, died of respiratory failure Tuesday at the Charlevoix (Mich.) Area Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Grosse Pointe Shores, Mich.

title: Chemical War: Threat in Third World?
description: American military officers say Iraq's routine use of chemical weapons against Iran in their eight-year-old war could encourage the common use of poison gas in future wars between third-world nations.

title: A. L. Rauschenplat, Airline Executive, 55
description: A. L. Rauschenplat, a former vice president-Latin America for Pan American World Airways, died Wednesday at his home in Torremolinos, Spain, after a long illness. He was 55 years old.

title: Wenzhou Journal; 3 Chinese Bankers Full of Nonrevolutionary Zeal
description: In early 1976, when the campaign to ''beat back the deviationist wind from the right'' was in full force, Yang Jiaxing figured it was a good time to go into private business.

title: DSC Communications reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $3,260,000 and $3,785,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Contractor in Pentagon Inquiry Closes
description: A small Florida company that has figured prominently in the investigation of fraud and bribery in military procurement said today that it had closed its operations because it had lost its major customer.

title: U.S. Presses Iraqis to Accept Cease-Fire
description: The United States is pressing Iraq to observe a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war, but American officials say their influence is limited.

title: TV Weekend; A Potpourri Of Eccentric Personalities
description: One of the oldest potpourris on television is ''Independent Focus,'' the vehicle for independent film and video makers that tops off weekends on Channel 13 at 11 P.M. on Sundays. This weekend's sextet of pieces on the 90-minute show gives some idea of the grab-bag ''Independent Focus'' is.

title: Sports People; Driving for Madden
description: Jerry Knick of Woodbridge, Va., who has worked as a Greyhound driver for 15 years, defeated nine other finalists to win a job as special chauffeur for John Madden, the television sports analyst, for the next six months. The National Football League schedule will have the former coach of the Raiders zipping from coast to coast, but he does not fly.

title: Pop/Jazz; Classical Jazz By Modern Masters At Lincoln Center
description: JUST by its nature, the programming of a concert series always indicates ideological intent - which apples are included, which oranges get left out in the cold. Classical Jazz, a five-night series opening tonight at Lincoln Center, doesn't mince words, announcing its intentions in its title. Mostly programmed by Wynton Marsalis, the jazz trumpeter, critic and artistic adviser to the series, and Alina Bloomgarden, the producer, Classical Jazz is heavy with tributes: the composers Tadd Dameron and Duke Ellington, and the drummer Max Roach are all given a night. There's a show devoted to jazz standards and a night given over to singers. If it's as good as last year's festival, it should be spectacular.

title: Democracy Still a Distant Rumor in Chile
description: To the Editor:

title: Advantage For Toyota
description: The Toyota Motor Company can now develop a new automobile in one year - years faster than its United States competitors, a former top engineer at the General Motors Corporation said today.

title: George Palmer, 81, Retired Parks Official
description: George A. Palmer, a former superintendent of the Statue of Liberty and the first superintendent of the Home of Franklin D. Roosevelt National Historic Site at Hyde Park, died of a heart attack Tuesday at the Cooper Hospital University Medical Center in Camden, N.J. He was 81 years old and lived in Collingswood, N.J.

title: Dyatron Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Moody's Suspends Rating For Yonkers, Citing Fines
description: Yonkers' fiscal problems mounted in its dispute with a Federal judge over a court-ordered desegregation plan as hopes faded for the resignation of a defiant City Councilman.

title: Bush, in Scalding Address, Says Rival Would Make World Riskier
description: Vice President Bush today leveled his most scalding attack yet against Michael S. Dukakis, charging that the Democratic Presidential nominee would make the world a more dangerous place because he has repudiated the foreign policy vision of John F. Kennedy.

title: Cabinet Push for Bush
description: While the White House denies it has become worried by the troubled appearance of Vice President Bush's campaign, President Reagan it upon himself at a recent Cabinet meeting to make a pitch for his candidate.

title: Where the Shows Are in 3-State Region
description: The following museums and galleries were visited. Addresses and hours are indicated; admission is free unless otherwise noted. Long Island LEE KRASNER (Through Sept. 10); Fine Arts Center Art Gallery, State University College at Stony Brook, (516) 689-6000. Tuesdays-Saturdays, noon to 4 P.M. ''JAMES BROOKS: A QUARTER-CENTURY OF WORK'' (Through Aug. 28); Heckscher Museum, Prime Avenue, Huntington, (516) 351-3250. Tuesdays-Fridays, 10 A.M.-5 P.M.; Saturdays-Sundays, 1-5 P.M. ''AMERICAN MODERNISM: PAINTINGS FROM THE PHILLIPS COLLECTION'' (Through Sept. 11); Parrish Art Museum, 25 Jobs Lane, Southampton, (516) 283-2118. Tuesdays, 10 A.M.-5 P.M.; Thursdays-Saturdays 10 A.M.-5 P.M.; Sundays 1-5 P.M. ''TATTOOED ANGEL: PAINTING AND SCULPTURE BY ROBERT KOBAYASHI'' (Through Aug. 14); Nassau County Museum of Fine Art, Northern Boulevard and Museum Drive, Roslyn Harbor, (516) 484-9337. Tuesdays-Fridays 10 A.M.-4:30 P.M.; Saturdays-Sundays 1-5 P.M. Westchester County ''STEPHEN DE STAEBLER: THE FIGURE'' (Through Sept. 11); Neuberger Museum, State University College at Purchase, (914) 253-5133. Tuesdays-Fridays 10 A.M.-4 P.M.; Saturdays-Sundays 1-5 P.M. ''COLUMNAR'' (Through Oct. 16); Hudson River Museum, 511 Warburton Avenue, Yonkers, (914) 963-4550. Wednesdays, Fridays, Saturdays, 10 A.M.-5 P.M.; Thursdays 10 A.M.-9 P.M.; Sundays noon-5 P.M. Adults, $2; children under 12 and the elderly, $1. title: Review/Film; Lauper and Goldblum in Tale of Intrigue and ESP
description: Cyndi Lauper, known for her zany style, is remarkably subdued in ''Vibes,'' in which she and Jeff Goldblum co-star as a pair of psychics who become embroiled in an intrigue plot. The craziest thing she does is to appear in this film at all.

title: Correction
description: Because of a mechanical error, an article in Business Day yesterday about world grain supplies omitted part of a paragraph. The paragraph should have read: ''According to the estimates that Mr. Brown will publish next week in his organization's magazine, World Watch, the droughts will cut global grain production this year to 1.521 billion metric tons, or 76 million metric tons less than last year.

title: Defendant in Arms Case Says Casey Backed Him
description: A defense lawyer contended yesterday that a defendant charged with plotting to sell weapons to Iran had held many telephone conversations with William J. Casey, who was the Director of Central Intelligence.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Markets

title: Elie Wiesel Asks Gorbachev To Clear 24 Victims of Stalin
description: Elie Wiesel, winner of the 1986 Nobel Peace Prize, sent a telegram yesterday to Mikhail S. Gorbachev asking the Soviet leader to clear the names of 24 Soviet Jewish writers and other cultural figures who were killed under orders from Stalin 36 years ago this month.

title: Control Resources Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
House Leaders Set Date to Weigh Action on Biaggi
description: The leadership of the House of Representatives today set Sept. 7 as the date it will consider a recommendation by its ethics committee to expel Representative Mario Biaggi from Congress.

title: 'Final Opportunity' To Testify Is Offered To Tawana Brawley
description: The grand jury looking into allegations that Tawana Brawley was abducted and raped by a gang of white men has written Miss Brawley, offering her a ''final opportunity'' to tell her story to the panel.

title: 10 Are Indicted In Major Fraud On Blood Tests
description: AIDS-infected drug addicts and hundreds of other sick and desperate poor people were paid pittances to donate blood samples that a New York City ''blood trafficking ring'' used to defraud the state Medicaid program of at least $15 million, state officials charged yesterday.

description: Jordan announced today that it would stop paying the salaries of virtually all its employees in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

description: b-Net loss The company said the latest quarter operating profit was reduced by $875,000, primarily as a result of increased reserves for doubtful accounts, for writedowns of inventory and for costs associated with an acquisition.

title: Atlantic Southeast Airlines reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Unsteady Foundation of the Criminal Justice System
description: The idea that guilt must be proved ''beyond a reasonable doubt'' undergirds the American criminal justice system. But that foundation, it seems, is a bit unsteady. The legal profession lacks a precise definition of just how much doubt is ''reasonable.'' And confusion abounds, studies show.

title: Louisiana General Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the year-ago quarter and 9 months included a gain of $485,000 from the sale of land.

title: Review/Pop; Blues, Opera and Humor
description: In the last several years, Phoebe Legere has cut an intriguing figure in the downtown performance world. An operatically trained singer who loves the blues, she exploits extreme stylistic contrast both in her music and in her provocatively exhibitionistic stage demeanor.

title: Gunman Is Subdued In a Station House
description: A man drew a .22-caliber revolver in the 28th Precinct station house in Harlem yesterday and pulled the trigger ''numerous times,'' but the gun misfired and a police officer subdued him, the police reported.

title: Aluminum Engine For '89 Corvette
description: The redesigned 1989 Corvette from the General Motors Corporation's Chevrolet division will have an engine made almost entirely of aluminum, G.M. said. A Chevrolet spokesman, Ed Lechtzin, said the car was scheduled to be introduced next spring.

title: International Telecharge reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Sports of The Times; Colorful Lindsey Nelson
description: THE newest memento in the Baseball Hall of Fame, right in there with the old brown gloves and the old tan bats, is a sport jacket of 10 or 12 gaudy colors, randomly slapped together in squares.

title: Gulf States Utilities Co reports earnings for 12mo June 30
description: The latest quarter reflects an accounting change that doesn't allow the company to accrue a non-cash return on the Texas retail portion of unit 1 of the River Bend nuclear power plant. In addition, the company is not recovering any costs associated with the $677 million of River Bend plant investment disallowed by the Louisiana Public Service Commission in November 1987.

title: Case Remains Open Despite Plea of Guilt To Missouri Slaying
description: An investigation will continue even though a man has pleaded guilty and been sentenced to life in the death of a former boarder whose head was found buried in the defendant's yard, the police said today.

description: Universal Pictures announced today that it would release Martin Scorsese's movie ''The Last Temptation of Christ'' on Aug. 12, a month ahead of schedule.

COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * General Electric Co., Fairfield, Conn., will form a Japanese-based joint venture in plastics with two Japanese partners: Mitsui Petrochemical Industries and Nagase & Company.

description: British Airways P.L.C. said today that its first-quarter profit fell 9 percent from a year earlier, hurt by its acquisition of the money-losing British Caledonian Airways.

description: Sugar Ray Leonard and Donny Lalonde signed today to fight for the World Boxing Council light-heavyweight (175-pound limit) title held by Lalonde and for a newly created W.B.C. supermiddleweight (168-pound limit) crown.

title: Cuomo Compromise for Yonkers: Smaller Projects, Spread Widely
description: Governor Cuomo, saying he understood the anger of middle-class Yonkers residents opposing the construction of subsidized housing units, called today for a compromise that would spread the housing more widely around the city and said he hoped to get Federal aid to achieve it.

title: Auctions
description: Annual Shaker Sale

title: Market Place; Computer Stocks' 'Network' Factor
description: A number of analysts think that the impressive quarterly and year-end financial results reported Monday by Sun Microsystems Inc., the Mountain View, Calif., maker of computer work stations, are strong evidence that the computer industry is headed into an era when the greatest growth will come in distributed, or ''network,'' computing. This would be the fourth era of computing growth, following periods in which mainframe, minicomputer and personal computer companies were the growth leaders.

title: Teleconcepts Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: View of Amber's Trapping Gases Is Disputed
description: An astonishing report last fall that tiny bubbles of ancient gas had been trapped in amber for 80 million years has now met with severe criticism.

title:
About Real Estate;
Walk-Ups Make Comeback in Queens Condominiums
description: LEAD: An old style of building, the walk-up apartment house, is being revived in a number of projects in Queens by developers who consider it a way to hold down construction costs and make the best use of small lots.

title: Celebration All Over the Lot, and Off
description: Larry Konner, the co-author of ''Jewel of the Nile,'' drove onto the lot of Paramount Pictures today as a producer. On Monday he hopes to walk through the studio gates as a writer.

title: Quaker Oats Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Reflect a one-time net charge of $29.9 million for the closing and consolidation of certain overseas and domestic manufacturing operations, as well as a one-time net benefit of $10.1 million related to a charge in accounting for inventory costs. The net impact of these one-time events is a charge of 18 cents a share to earnings from continuing operations. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $58.2 million, or 74 cents a share, and after a $20.9 million pretax one-time charge for pet foods manufacturing plant closing.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addendum
description: * Kobs & Draft Advertising, a direct marketing subsidiary of Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide, has opened its first Canadian office, in Toronto.

title: Quaker Oats Asks Trading Inquiry
description: The Quaker Oats Company has asked the New York Stock Exchange and the Securities and Exchange Commission to investigate trading in its stock, which has jumped recently on rumors of a possible takeover. Shares in the Chicago-based food company leaped $5.25, to $58, in early trading on the New York Stock Exchange today before falling back to close at $52.50, down 25 cents. The stock closed at $46.75 last Friday.

title: Fire Destroys 30 Classic Cars Collected by Reggie Jackson
description: About 30 classic cars owned by Reggie Jackson, the retired baseball star, were destroyed Wednesday night in a fire and explosions that wrecked a warehouse and caused about $4 million in damage.

title: American International Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized gains of $26,569,000 and $54,581,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes realized gains of $26,899,000 for the quarter and $53,458,000 for the 6 months.

title: Sun-Times Publisher Quits; No Successor Is Appointed
description: Robert E. Page, the publisher and president of The Chicago Sun-Times Inc., resigned yesterday.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Connors Falls: Robert Seguso, ranked 67th in the world, upset second-seeded Jimmy Connors, 7-6, 4-6, 7-6, yesterday to gain a quarterfinal berth in the United States Hardcourt tournament at Indianapolis.

title: Jack Goldberger, Labor Leader, 84
description: Jack Goldberger, a labor leader in the San Francisco Bay area for more than four decades, died Tuesday. He was 84 years old.

title: CTS Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a $625,000 loss from an accounting change. c-Includes tax benefits of $351,000 and $815,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Electricity Use Sets Records
description: Demand for electricity at Midwest utilities set sharply higher records in the last few days. The increases were the largest since the early 1970's.

title: Let the Possibilities for the West Side Waterfront Be Explored
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Overturns Restriction On Garment District Space
description: A zoning restriction meant to protect manufacturing space in New York's Garment Center has been overturned by a state judge because city planners did not fully assess its potential environmental impact.

title: Review/Opera; The Final 2 Parts Of Bayreuth's 'Ring'
description: Harry Kupfer has now completed his new Bayreuth Festival production of Wagner's ''Ring des Nibelungen,'' and the staging of ''Siegfried'' last Saturday and ''Gotterdammerung'' on Monday did not so much confirm as complicate the impression left by his earlier ''Das Rheingold'' and ''Die Walkure.'' Indeed, if one task of a director is to keep the audience guessing as to his intentions right up to the end, Mr. Kupfer succeeded admirably.

title: Many Minor Tax Changes In Bill Approved by House
description: By an overwhelming majority, the House today approved a $7.1 billion package of minor tax changes benefiting farmers, mutual fund investors, freelance writers and rural mail carriers.

title: Reagan Spurred Latin Democracy? Nonsense.
description: It will come as a big surprise in Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay, Peru and Ecuador to learn that the Reagan Administration claims leadership of the recent democratic advances in those countries. Democracy has indeed enjoyed a remarkable renaissance in the hemisphere during President Reagan's watch. But there is little to suggest that his Administration brought about these changes.

title: Baseball; Clemens Rocked as Tigers Regain First
description: Alan Trammell drove in five runs with two doubles tonight as the Tigers beat Boston, 11-6, ending the Boston's seven-game winning streak and regaining sole possession of first place in the American League East.

title: Review/Film; 'The Blob,' Modernized
description: Modern technology has yielded at least one definite advance in the last 30 years: a better Blob. Whereas the original 1958 model, a rolling heap of silicone, did little more than wobble and eat, the updated Blob is infinitely more advanced. It can climb to the ceiling and plop down on anyone below. It can choose its victims mischievously, rather than on its predecessor's catch-as-catch-can basis. It can play practical jokes. And it can overtake, subdue and digest its prey right before the audience's very eyes. This is progress, after a fashion. So by any reasonable standard, Chuck Russell's current ''Blob'' is new and improved. It's a more professional effort in every way. The special effects look sickeningly good, and the actors show signs of being able to act, which could not be said of any members of the original cast - not even Steve McQueen, who was Steven McQueen then and appearing in his first major film role. Yet for reasons having nothing to do with merit, the 1958 film earned a place in history. The remake, enterprising as it is, won't do the same.

title: Are Museums Doing Their Job of Preservation?; Saving Everything
description: To the Editor:

title: Chicago Milwaukee To Shed Properties
description: The Chicago Milwaukee Corporation said it would spin off its real estate properties into a limited partnership to be distributed to shareholders. The interests are expected to go out in December after shareholder approval is obtained, it said.

title: Underwriters to Be Sought For Farm Credit Agency
description: The Federal Agricultural Mortgage Corporation, created by the Agricultural Credit Act of 1987 to build a secondary market facility for agricultural real estate loans, will come a step closer to reality today.

title: Emery Air Freight Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the year-ago results are not comparable, since they include Purolator Courier Corp. operations only after April 29, 1987.

title: BOC to Buy Spectramed
description: In a move to broaden its health care operations, Britain's BOC Group P.L.C. said today that it had agreed to acquire Spectramed Inc. of Newport Beach, Calif., for $12 a share, or $101 million.

title: Review/Theater; Milner's 'Checkmates,' Story of 2 Households
description: While it's easy to name a recent Broadway play or two as awful as ''Checkmates,'' it may be necessary to get out the scrapbooks to recall one quite so amateurish and boring. ''Checkmates'' is a comedy in which the characters say such lines as ''A man's home is his castle'' and ''It's a whole new ball game'' - and aren't joking. It's a play in which an actor can finish a speech with the question ''What the hell am I talking about?'' and be absolutely certain that no one on stage or off would dare vouchsafe an answer.

title: Comissiona Quits as City Opera Conductor After Only a Year
description: Sergiu Comissiona, who began his first season as music director of the New York City Opera only a year ago, announced yesterday that he wouldquit the job at the end of this year.

description: b-Include an $8,500,000 one-time restructuring charge. c-Net income

title: Marisa Bellisario Dies in Turin; Industrialist Was in Her Early 50's
description: Marisa Bellisario, president of Italy's Italtel telecommunications company and former head of Olivetti Corporation of America, died of cancer today at her home in Turin. She was in her early 50's.

description: The company said the latest quarter and 6-month include a charge of $30 million from the discontinuance of AM General's medium and heavy military truck business, along with writedowns of equipment, facilities and inventories and personnel costs. The company also said its latest 6-month earnings include a $24.8 million gain from the sale of two iron ore carrying vessels.

description: As this city faces mounting fines imposed by a Federal judge for refusing to accept a housing desegregation plan, Deputy Mayor Henry Spallone has never been so exhilarated.

description: b-Includes a tax loss carryforwards of $2 million for both the quarter and 6 months. c-After tax loss carryforwards of $5.2 million and $9.2 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Year-ago results are pro forma and presented as if the Allied Supermarkets Inc. merger and asset sale had occurred at the beginning of the periods presented.

title: At a Fair in Mississippi, Dukakis Plays Politics in Black and White

title: How Wedtech Worked
description: The tale of how a tiny South Bronx machine shop grew almost overnight into a $100 million defense contractor - the Wedtech Corporation -stretches from the lowest sewer of New York City politics to the Reagan White House. Now a Federal jury in Manhattan has convicted Representative Mario Biaggi, former Bronx Borough President Stanley Simon and four others of turning Wedtech into a racketeering enterprise. It's a damning denouement.

METRO DATELINES;
description: The natural mother of Lisa Steinberg filed a notice of claim for $30 million yesterday against the couple charged in the beating death of the 6-year-old girl and against New York City and other defendants. Michele Launders, 27, of Hempstead, L.I., contends that various city departments were aware that Lisa, who died Nov. 5, was an abused child but did nothing to help her, according to legal papers provided by her lawyer, Joseph Famighetti.

GTE shares closed at $41.125, up 50 cents, in heavy trading of almost 2.9 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Earlier in the day, the stock had been up as much as $2. At its closing price, the stock buyback would be worth more than $1 billion. GTE has about 330 million shares outstanding.

Five of the men, all facing racketeering, conspiracy and fraud charges, are top officers in Princeton/Newport, a New Jersey investment partnership. description: Floyd Youmans, the Montreal Expos pitcher who was suspended indefinitely on June 25 for failing to comply with his drug-testing program, met with officials of the baseball commissioner's office yesterday to begin the process of having his suspension lifted. Youmans met with a lawyer for the owners and with a member of baseball's security staff. The purpose of the meeting was to allow Youmans an opportunity to give assurances that he was adhering to a rehabilitation program. (AP)

Art exhibitions outside New York City in the dog days of the year are a serious business, put on by serious people.

Sunday, Michael Shall of the American Museum of Natural History is to demonstrate the Japanese art at the Jacques Marchais Center of Tibetan Art, 338 Lighthouse Avenue in Richmondtown, S.I. title: Soviet Grain Harvest Up
description: A Soviet agricultural official said Wednesday that farmers were bringing in more grain this year than in 1987. Alexander Zholobov of the State Agro-Industrial Committee told the Tass news agency that harvesting rates were ahead of last year's, when 211 million metric tons were reaped. Last month, the United States Agriculture Department forecast this year's Soviet crop at 215 million metric tons, while the London-based International Wheat Council predicted it would be 218 million metric tons.

title: Dining Out Guide: Saturday Lunch
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Cafe Pierre * (July 10, 1987), Fifth Avenue at 61st Street (838-8000) - Cafe Pierre is an appealing choice for Saturday lunch in a formal, elegant setting. Murals of clouds decorate the room, along with ornate mirrors and luxurious draped fabric. A new menu includes appetizers of marinated langoustine with zucchini salad, and vegetable ''gateau'' with duck confit. A few of the lunch entrees are seafood panache on a pasta leaf; lobster and artichoke salad with orange vinaigrette; warm chicken breast with crushed pepper on seasonal greens, and braised sweetbreads with a celery-root-and-currant flan. The dessert menu offers homemade sorbets and chocolate dacquoise. Lunch prices are $7.50 to $15 for appetizers, $18.50 to $28 for main courses. Lunch hours: noon to 2:30 P.M. Friday and Saturday. David K's Cafe Diner's Journal (March 11, 1988), 1115 Third Avenue; entrance on 65th Street between Second and Third Avenues (935-1161) - A variety of intriguing Chinese dishes can be sampled at this casual cafe, one of the better East Side places for bargains. Oriental porcelain and bronze, glazed black tiles around the banquettes and bar and background music by the new-age composer Kitaro provide the atmosphere. Recommended dishes include a terrinelike combination of shredded lamb bound in gelatin, homemade noodles tossed with shredded beef and thin strips of cucumber, northern family noodles with a sauce of minced pork, dried bean curd, scallions, coriander and hoisin, superb pan-fried dumplings filled with beef and scallions, or with shrimp. Prices are $1.95 to $5.95 for appetizers, $3.95 to $9.95 for main courses. Opens for lunch at noon Saturday and serves until 1 A.M. Docks * (Feb. 6, 1987), 2427 Broadway, near 89th Street (724-5588) - This busy fishhouse sparkles with black and white ceramic tiles and a glass and brass oyster bar. Docks is an ambitious restaurant offering a changing assortment of fresh fish, and a broad sampling of oysters and clams. At lunch, start with shellfish in season, or share an order of the light, greaseless fried calamari. A variety of seafood salads are on the lunch menu, as well as steamed lobster, cold lobster cocktail, grilled swordfish and tuna, cold poached or smoked fish. Crunch fresh coleslaw and french-fried yams make excellent side dishes. Key lime and chocolate mud pies are good desserts. Prices at lunch range from $3 to $6 for appetizers, and $6.50 to $14 for entrees. Lunch served from 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. Friday and Saturday. La Gauloise ** (May 29, 1987), 502 Avenue of the Americas, near 12th Street (691-1363) - A real French bistro is a place that puts one at ease. La Gauloise, a genial Village restaurant decorated with mahagony-framed mirrors and lace curtains from the Alsatian home of the owner's grandmother, fits the bill. Appetizers at lunch include lobster-stuffed ravioli, warm shrimp and sole pate, and lamb tongue salad with cornichons. Among the entrees are cold grilled salmon on a bed of endive with creme fraiche, grilled chicken, skate wing with lemon and caper sauce, and a warm vegetable plate composed of seasonal vegetables prepared several ways. Desserts include rice pudding with fresh fruit in mint-tea sauce, tarte aux pommes, and individual cheese cakes made with chevre. Prices at lunch range from $4 to $10.50 for appetizers, and $7.50 to $16.50 for entrees. Open noon to 3 P.M. for Friday and Saturday lunch. What the stars mean, page C20.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Curren Advances: Third-seeded Kevin Curren yesterday advanced to the semifinals of the Head Classic tournament in Stowe, Vt., as his opponent, Robbie Weiss, was forced to withdraw with a slipped vertebra. In a semifinal, Curren will meet top-seeded Andres Gomez. Curren played an exhibition against Nicolas Pereira and won the pro set, 8-6. Curren said that Weiss's injury was ''something that happens in sports.'' In yesterday's other quarterfinal match, Dan Goldie defeated Leif Shiras, 6-1 6-3. (AP) Seguso Gains Semifinal: Robert Seguso, who upset Jimmy Connors Thursday, eliminated 10th-seeded Derrick Rostagno, 6-4, 6-1, yesterday to advance to the semifinals of the $415,000 United States Hardcourt tournament in Indianapolis. Seguso, seeded 15th, needed little more than an hour to beat Rostagno.(AP) Golf Richard Triumphs: Deb Richard went on a birdie spree on the back nine yesterday and finished with 22 points to win the second day of the $400,000 Pat Bradley International Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament at High Point, N.C. Richard posted eight birdies, three of them on the first four holes of the back nine. She also had three birdies on the front nine of the 6,260-yard Willow Creek Golf Club course.(AP) Track and Field Johnson Breezes in Return: Ben Johnson, competing for the first time in nearly three months, coasted to victory in his heat in the 100-meter dash yesterday at the Canadian Olympic trials in Ottawa. Racing for the first time since a leg injury May 13, Johnson won in 10.38 seconds after easing up with 30 meters to go.(AP)

title: GUIDEPOST: Finishing the Unfinished
description: Summer auctions and country-furniture sales are yielding furniture that may have been stripped of its finish or sold in its natural state. All such furniture needs some kind of protective coating. Stains and dyes should be sealed by a clear finish. If the wood is attractive, a clear finish may be all that is needed. Beware of surprises: stains can react with hidden pigment in the wood to produce strange colors, and applying a coat of clear finish tends to darken the overall color. One way to avoid ending up with a muddy brown chair when you wanted pickled pine is to use a one-step finish - clear finish mixed with an appropriate color - so that what you see is what you get. These finishes are best applied with a fine-tipped foam rubber brush, whcih easily mops up extra liquid that has a tendency to gather in corners. Here are some tips for refinishing stripped furniture or raw wood. PURPOSE METHOD Clean Sand is surface is rough, then wipe with a cloth dampened with paint thinner. Stain Use a one-step finish, such as Polyshades by Minwax, which comes in several colors and high gloss or satin luster. Use it as is or mix shades to get the color you want. Seal To strengthen the finish without deepening the color, apply clear polyurethane. This is essential for furniture that is used often.

title: Kennedy Center Plans Honor for Alvin Ailey
description: The choreographer Alvin Ailey is among five artists to be honored by the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts on Dec. 4.

title: KEY RATES
Contractor in Fraud Inquiry Will Remain Closed
description: Executives of Armtec Inc., a military subcontractor that has become a focus of the Federal investigation into corruption in military procurement practices, decided today to close the company permanently.

title: Matec Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Toronto Sun to Expand
description: The Toronto Sun Publishing Corporation, publisher of British-style tabloids in Toronto, and Calgary and Edmonton, Alberta, today announced an agreement in principle to buy the weekly Ottawa Sunday Herald for less than $1 million Canadian ($830,000 United States). Douglas Creighton, the president of Toronto Sun, said the company plans to transform the five-year-old newspaper into a daily as soon as possible. Initially it will be renamed the Ottawa Sunday Sun and remain a weekly.

title: Unemployment: The Biggest States
description: Civilian unemployment. Figures are seasonally adjusted.

title: Tapes of Agent Slain by Captors: 'Don't Hit Me'
description: An exhausted Federal drug agent pleaded ''don't hit me anymore'' to his captors in 1985 as he disclosed confidential Government information in a futile effort to save his life, according to tapes that have been played in court.

title: Hambletonian Is Today
description: The 63d edition of the Hambletonian will be staged at the Meadowlands Saturday afternoon with Armbro Goal the early favorite at 7-5.

title: Fire Damages Brazilian Park
description: Fire has destroyed at least 60 percent of Brazil's National Park of the Rheas, one of the richest wildlife preserves in South America, officials said today.

title: Colin Higgins, 47, Director and Writer Of Hollywood Films
description: Colin Higgins, a screenwriter and director whose works include ''Silver Streak,'' ''Foul Play'' and the quirky cult movie ''Harold and Maude'' died yesterday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 47 years old and had been suffering from AIDS, said a spokeswoman for his production company.

title: Stanley Interiors Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Briggs & Stratton Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ault Inc reports earnings for Year to May 29
description: b-Net income

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5, 26 South Africa, Angola and Cuba said that they had agreed on a plan for steps to end conflicts in southern Africa. A communique issued after four days of American-sponsored talks gave no details on the accord. Page 1 A United Nations peacekeeping force of 250 members would be sent to monitor any cease-fire agreement between Iran and Iraq, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar told the Security Council. 3 Military analysis: American forces have not been trained to act as peacekeepers in political wars. The downing of an Iranian jetliner is the latest illustration of their deployment where the line between war and peace is unclear. 3 Palestinians who lost salaries that Jordan paid in part or in full before King Hussein cut ties with the Israeli-occupied West Bank were angry over the action, but pleased at the degree of autonomy they gained. 3 American bases in the Philippines would be closed gradually, according to a plan proposed by some Filipino legislators as a compromise in a national debate over the continued presence of the bases. 4 Changing Japanese vacation habits is the aim of a Government campaign to encourage workers to use their vacation days and stagger vacation schedules. Many Japanese only take time off when their offices close. 4 A $27 million plan to aid the contras was offered by Senate Democratic leaders. The plan would provide the Nicaraguan rebels with money for food, clothing, shelter and medical supplies. 5 Spain is re-examining bullfighting, questioning whether it is a sport or cruelty to animals. Attendance at bullfights is down, and the European Parliament is considering a proposal that could lead to a ban. 5 The detention of a Rumanian citizen, Dumitru Mazilu, by Bucharest has prompted a protest from Washington for his release so that he may present a report on human rights violations to the United Nations. 26 National 6-8, 31-32 Oliver North's trial will be delayed until at least mid-November to give lawyers extra time to sort through thousands of classified documents, the judge in the Iran-contra case announced. 1 Treasury Secretary James Baker resigned to join Vice President Bush's Presidential campaign. Nicholas Brady, a former Senator from New Jersey, was named Mr. Baker's successor by President Reagan. 1 News analysis: James A. Baker 3d has earned high marks within the Republican Party as a political operative, and his success as Treasury Secretary would put him in line for a major post if Vice President Bush wins. 8 A surge in job growth for July suggests that the economy is gathering momentum that could speed up the rate of inflation, Government figures showed. Unemployment edged up from a 14-year low in June. 1 Region's unemployment at a low 32 A company will exclude employees from medical coverage if they become sick from AIDS, alcohol, drug abuse or self-inflicted wounds. The Circle K Corporation seeks to base coverage on ''life style'' decisions. 1 Many business and trade schools, which could profit from requirements that more welfare recipients get job training and work, have registered unqualified students and abused tuition aid programs, officials say. 1 Unfilled promise of training prompts suit 6 An engine test for the space shuttle Discovery will be delayed until at least late next week to give workers time to replace the valve system whose malfunction halted ignition Thursday, officials said. 6 The nominee for Attorney General, Dick Thornburgh, pledged at his Senate confirmation hearing that he would be ''hypersensitive'' in avoiding the appearance of impropriety on ethical questions. 8 Politics 7 Michael S.
