Dukakis struck back at Vice President Bush, charging that the prospective Republican Presidential nominee lacks the skill to conduct the nation's foreign policy, and challenged him to a debate. 1 Vice President Bush is healthy and suffers only mild osteoarthritis in his hips and knees, his White House doctor said, keeping the candidates' health an issue in the Presidential campaign. 7 White supremacist guilty of threatening Jackson 7 Narrowing Bush's No. 2 choices 7 Bush seems to be planning only a token campaign in New York 7 Regional 27-30 Changing a housing plan for Yonkers as part of a compromise would pose great difficulties and require new negotiations among the city, the housing department and the plaintiffs in the case, a Federal official said. 1 Bronxville has few black families and no poor neighborhoods. Opinion in the town, which is across the parkway from Yonkers, is split over Yonkers's defiance of a court-ordered desegregation plan. 28 Mario Biaggi said he would resign from the House of Representatives and announced that he would not seek an 11th term in Congress after his conviction on corruption charges twice in the last year. 27 Loyalty to Mario Biaggi is strong in the Bronx-Westchester Congressional district he represented for 10 terms. Colleagues and friends said that loyalty was the result of his efforts on behalf of constituents. 30 Wedtech scandal is far from over 30 A black inventor's home in Queens, now scheduled for demolition, would be moved and turned into a museum under a plan proposed by descendants of Lewis Latimer, a pioneer in developing electric lighting. 27 The chief of the Metro-North police, John Esposito, was dismissed because he had failed to turn over to his superiors a copy of a videotape in which seven officers were shown clowning around Grand Central Terminal. 27 Weed-eating fish in Connecticut, valued by pond owners because they help clear stagnant water, could damage the environment, according to state officials, who are telling pond owners to kill the fish. 27 An angry former Hertz employee who had been dismissed set in motion the inquiry that ended with the company's pleading guilty to defrauding customers and insurers on collision repairs. 29 East Orange to drop limit on moving 29

title: After Hiroshima, The Second Coming
description: LEAD: My feelings toward the Japanese oscillate from affection for the many friends I have made the last 30 years, to admiration for Japanese achievements, to loathing and apprehension over the manner with which the Japanese regard countries like mine. Maybe, they cannot help themselves.

title: The Shift Of Rather; Channel 2's Object Is Better Ratings
description: The flagship CBS television station in New York, WCBS/Channel 2, made official yesterday a long-expected programming move that has been a source of deep dispute inside the network for almost two years: the replacement of Dan Rather's ''Evening News'' broadcast in the 7 P.M. time slot with a game show.

title: Datascope Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
W. L. Knickerbocker, A Retired Admiral, 84
description: Rear Admiral William L. Knickerbocker, who retired from the United States Navy in 1963 after a 40-year career, died of cardiac arrest on Tuesday in York, Me., where he lived. He was 84 years old.

title: Leader of Pakistan's Shiites Is Killed, Spurring Protests
description: An unidentified gunman killed Pakistan's most prominent Shiite Moslem clergyman here today, leading to violent protests and to fears of a new outbreak of sectarian killings.

title: Southwest Gas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
IMPEACHED JUDGE TO LIMIT CASELOAD
description: Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings said today that he had asked to be relieved of most his duties while his impeachment trial is pending in the Senate. He also said he would not resign his $89,500-a-year post.

title: Changes in Welfare a Boon to Trade Schools
description: The pending changes in the nation's welfare system to require more recipients to work, enroll in job training or lose their benefits could steer tens of thousands of people to profit-making business and trade schools.

title: It's Official! Vacations Really Aren't Un-Japanese
description: It is hard work getting Japanese to relax. But the summer holidays are looming, and the Labor Ministry is gearing up for a tough campaign.

title: New Lipstick? A Safer Sample
description: A bill to safeguard consumers from the health hazards of sharing test cosmetics in stores was signed into law by Governor Cuomo this week. It is the first law of its kind in the country.

title: Essex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Baltek Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earnings figures are restated for a 10 percent dividend in December 1987.

title: Cigna Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $16.4 million for the quarter and $28.1 million for the 6 months. c-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $16.2 million and $32.2 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, tax credits of $11.9 million for the quarter and $26.2 million for the 6 months, and a loss from early extinguishment of debt of $3.8 million for both the quarter and 6 months. The company said the 1988 income from continuing operations includes an investment loss of $7.5 million for the quarter and the 6-month includes an investment gain of $500,000, or one cent a share. The company also said the year-ago quarter and 6-month net from continuing operations include investment gains of $34.8 million, or 43 cents a share, and $65.6 million, or 80 cents a share, respectively.

title: Atlantic Energy Inc reports earnings for 12mo June 30
Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the movie ''The Last Temptation of Christ'' misstated the church affiliation of the Rev. Donald Wildmon, an opponent of the film. He is a minister of the United Methodist Church, not a Baptist.

title: Treasury Prices Fall On Job Data
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes tumbled yesterday after the Labor Department reported a surge in job creation for July. The department also revised its June statistics to show more new jobs for the month than had previously been reported.

title: Annette Overby, 86, A Former Psychologist
description: Annette Overby, a retired psychologist and a former executive director of the National Psychological Association for Psychoanalysis, died of Alzheimer's disease yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 86 years old.

title: Nominee for Meese Post Gives Panel His Standards
description: President Reagan's nominee for Attorney General, former Gov. Dick Thornburgh of Pennsylvania, pledged at his Senate confirmation hearing today that he would be ''hypersensitive'' in avoiding the sort of ethical questions that plagued Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d.

title: Mel Lewis at Birdland
description: Mel Lewis, a drummer, is leading a quartet tonight at Birdland, 2745 Broadway, at 105th Street (749-2228). Music begins at 9 P.M.; there is a $5 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 10.

title: Workers Speaking Up In a Lot of Languages
description: Donald Creadore, an attorney with a Manhattan law firm, says speaking English is no longer enough.

title: Investment Group Seeks Diasonics
description: An investment group led by Integrated Resources Inc., the New York financial services concern, has offered to purchase all of the shares of Diasonics Inc. that it does not own for $3.12 a share, or a total of about $206 million.

title: A CAMPAIGN TO REMEMBER AN INVENTOR
description: For the last 20 years of his life, Lewis H. Latimer, a black inventor and major pioneer in the development of electric lighting, lived in a comfortable two-and-a-half-story frame house in Flushing, Queens.

title: Ferry Is Rammed in Mexico And at Least 17 Are Drowned
description: A ferryboat carrying workers home from a night shift split in two and sank after it was rammed by a barge, and at least 17 people drowned, officials reported today. A Red Cross worker put the toll at about 38.

title: Mullaney Resigns
description: Joe Mullaney, whose basketball teams at Providence College won at least 20 games nine times in the 1950's and 1960's, resigned yesterday as associate athletic director at the college. He had left Providence in 1969 to coach the Los Angeles Lakers and then coached pro teams at Utah, Kentucky, Memphis and Buffalo before returning to college coaching at Brown in 1978. He returned to coach basketball again at Providence in 1981 but again resigned in 1985 and became the associate athletic director at the school.

title: Company Halting Health Plan On Some 'Life Style' Illnesses
description: The Circle K Corporation, the nation's second-largest convenience store chain, says it will cut off the medical coverage of employees who become sick or injured as a result of AIDS, alcohol, drug abuse or self-inflicted wounds.

title: Hyde Athletic Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Meese Readies Detroit Ruling
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d plans to rule next week on whether the Government will allow a partial merger of Detroit's two newspapers. Mr. Meese said Thursday in

title: Harleysvill Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the year-ago 6-month includes a 7 cents a share benefit from tax adjustment. Similar adjustments weren't material for the latest 6-month.

title: Hernandez Blasts Back
description: After missing 52 games, half of which the Mets lost, Keith Hernandez made a storybook return tonight when he hit a double and a two-run home run that beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 3-2, and nudged the Mets five games in front of their nearest rivals in the National League East.

title: Chelsea Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-Net income The company said its lower earnings were due to a LIFO charge but did not provide the amount of the charge.

title: Horse Racing; Trapp Mountain Triumphs Again
description: Trapp Mountain proved that his flashy debut last month was as good as it looked by returning today to score a four-length victory in the $87,900 Saratoga Special at Saratoga Race Track. The victory established him as one of the nation's three leading 2-year-olds, along with Houston and King Glorious.

title: Zayre Discloses F.T.C. Notice
description: The Zayre Corporation said today that it had received a notice that the Haft family of Washington intended to seek Federal antitrust permission to purchase more than $15 million worth of its stock.

title: JOB SURGE SPURS INFLATION WORRY
description: A surge in the number of new jobs created in July suggests that the economy is gathering new momentum that could increase the rate of inflation, Government figures showed today.

title: Hampton Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Palestinians Lose in a U.S. Court
description: A United States Appeals Court panel today upheld the Reagan Administration's order to close an information office in Washington affiliated with the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: The Editorial Notebook; A Planner Faces Reality
description: What many Americans think of as the heart of New York is changing with volcanic force. Gaping holes along Broadway and Seventh Avenue expose the granite subsurface of midtown near Times Square. For a brief moment you can see long-concealed structures like the Hotel Edison, on 47th Street, from blocks away.

title: A New York State of Mind for Bush
description: New York has the second-largest block of electoral votes in the country, a pair of attention-grabbing politicians and a generous contingent of reporters and cameras to record the doings of political candidates.

title: Japan Data On Economy
description: The Japanese Government issued an optimistic report today on the nation's economy, but officials said the gap between rich and poor was growing, with many Japanese feeling they have been left out of the nation's economic boom.

title: DEMOCRATS REVISE CONTRA AID PLAN
description: Senate Democratic leaders today offered a $27 million plan to aid the Nicaraguan rebels as an amendment to a pending military spending bill. They said they were optimistic that Republicans would support it when a vote is taken next Monday.

title: First Federal S&L Assn of East Hardford reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per share figures for the year-ago periods are not available; the company converted to stock ownership in June 1987.

title: Moving Fee No One Liked
description: Charges against a woman accused of violating an ordinance that requires a police permit to move into and out of this city will be dropped, a lawyer for the city said today.

title: Sliwas Meet With Police Official
description: Curtis and Lisa Sliwa, the husband and wife who head the Guardian Angels, met yesterday with an aide to the Police Department's Chief of Patrol at Police Headquarters in Manhattan, following two months of confrontations between the police and the unarmed citizens' patrol group.

title: Texas Insurer To Sell 2 Units
description: The American General Corporation, a leading life and health insurance company, based in Houston, said today that it plans to sell its property-liability business and its group life and health insurance business, two of the company's smallest business segments.

title: Kenya a Renamo Foe
description: To the Editor A July 31 front-page story contained a baseless allegation of my country's sympathy for Renamo, the Mozambican rebel group. Kenya adheres strictly to the principles of the charter of the Organization of African Unity, which include noninterference in the internal affairs of other states. We do not support clandestine movements bent on destabilizing legally constituted Governments.

title: Irish Music
description: Brendan Mulvihill, a fiddler, is to play Irish traditional music, accompanied by Donna Long, a pianist, tonight at the Eagle Tavern, 355 West 14th Street (924-0275). Sets are at 9 and 10:30 P.M.; tickets are $5.

title: Gamma Biologicals Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Invacare Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ruling Aids Bid by B.A.T.
description: B.A.T. Industries' arduous $4.35 billion takeover pursuit of Farmers Group gained some ground today when a state court ordered California's insurance commissioner to reverse a previous ruling and approve the merger.

title: G.E. Receives Jet Engine Order
description: The General Electric Company said that it would supply jet engines for 15 Boeing planes ordered by Japan Air Lines in a deal that will bring G.E. $400 million. General Electric said Japan Air Lines had exercised options for 15 Boeing 747-400 aircraft to be powered by G.E.'s CF6-80C2 engines. The airline ordered five G.E.-powered aircraft last January. Until then, the Japanese carrier's fleet used only engines made by G.E.'s biggest competitor, the Pratt & Whitney division of the United Technologies Corporation.

title: Save Deconstruction From Its Explicators
description: To the Editor:

title: Financial Corp. Posts Loss
description: The Financial Corporation of America, the parent of the nation's largest insolvent savings institution, said today that it lost $160.5 million in the second quarter, providing further evidence of the depth of the company's problems as it awaits completion of a Federal rescue plan.

title: Why My Wife Quit
description: LEAD: My wife used to be a teacher, but the New York City school system will never see her again.

title: Contel Cellular Inc reports earnings for 1988
England Still Has Final Word On Archbishop of Canterbury
description: Bishops from Anglican churches around the world voted by a narrow margin today to allow England to continue appointing the Archbishop of Canterbury, the leader of the Anglican Communion.

title: Borland International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said the three months ended June 30, 1987, are restated for the pooling of interests and the retroactive adoption of FAS No. 96, accounting for income taxes. The company is traded publicly on the unlisted securities market of the London Stock Exchange.

title: Joule Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 24
description: b-Includes a gain of $700,000 from an accounting change.

title: BRIDGE
description: An astonishing final quarter here Thursday night, providing perhaps the greatest stretch drive in the history of major bridge events, ended one Spingold Knockout semifinal at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals.

title: Del Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest 6-month results are adjusted to reflect application of the treasury stock method.

title: Unfilled Promise of Training and $40,000 Job Spurs Suit
description: Elizabeth M. Imholz, a lawyer with South Brooklyn Legal Services, has filed two lawsuits on behalf of people who said they were hurt by their experiences in private trade and business schools.

title: Wedtech Scandal: Years Of Court Fights to Come
description: Representative Mario Biaggi's conviction in the Wedtech racketeering case brought an end to a five-month trial that resounded with allegations of corruption by officials in New York and Washington, but the scandal is far from over.

title: G.S.A. Voids Postal Pact With Perot
description: The General Services Administration's Board of Contract Appeals ruled yesterday that a no-bid contract that the Postal Service awarded to a company owned by the Texas billionare H. Ross Perot was ''illegal and void'' because it violated Federal contracting rules.

title: Wedco Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a credit of $862,327 representing the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Cullum Reports Several Offers
description: Tender offer documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by Cullum Companies Inc., a Dallas-based operator of grocery stores, disclosed that the Dart Group Inc. of Landover, Md., and Odyssey Partners of New York, a leveraged buyout group affiliated with Oppenheimer & Company, had expressed an interest in acquiring the company at one time. Others that had contracted the concern's chairman, Jack Evans Sr., about buying the company included Randall's Inc., a Houston-based grocery store chain; two cafeteria groups, and investment groups from California and Switzerland.

title: Your Money; The Trap of Debt Can Be Avoided
description: Too often in America, the signs of success -the lovely home, the prestige car - are actually signs of debt. While the debtor ought to control the debt, all too often it's the other way about, leading to secret feelings of shame and anxiety, and even to troubled marriages and distractions at work.

title: Flamemaster Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings results reflect a 20 percent stock dividend paid on July 25.

title: Sun-Times Hires Personnel Firm
description: The executive search firm of Heidrick & Struggles Inc. has been hired to find a new publisher and president for The Chicago Sun-Times Inc., a spokesman for Adler & Shaykin Inc. said. Robert E. Page resigned those positions Thursday amid reports of a conflict with the newspaper's chief financial officer, Donald F. Piazza.

title: Maria O'Neil Marries James Ruddock
description: In the chapel at the Convent of the Sacred Heart in New York, Maria O'Neil, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph M. O'Neil of Cleveland, was married yesterday to Samuel James Ruddock 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Neil T. Ruddock of Gates Mills, Ohio. The Rev. D. Bradley Murray, an uncle of the bride, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Universal Matchbox Group Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $463,000 for the quarter and $546,000 for the 6 months.

title: Concord Computing Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Corrections
description: The On Stage column in Weekend on July 29 gave an incorrect location and starting date for a summer stock production of ''A Walk in the Woods.''

title: IRAN-CONTRA TRIAL OF NORTH PUT OFF TILL PAST ELECTION
description: The judge in the Iran-contra case announced today that the trial of Oliver L. North, the former White House aide, would be delayed until at least mid-November to give lawyers extra time to sort through thousands of classified documents.

title: Governor Nobody-Asked-Me
description: What a pinched, technical definition of a governor's responsibility Mario Cuomo now offers regarding the ugly battle between a Federal judge and public officials in Yonkers. Why hasn't he played a more active role? Because ''Nobody asked me to.'' Why hasn't he spoken up in support of Judge Leonard Sand? Because ''Judge Sand didn't call me until things got a little bit hot.''

title: Italy Seeks Origins Of Getty Acquisition; Police Back Museum
description: The Los Angeles police, in response to a request by the Italian authorities, have questioned officials of the Getty Museum extensively about its acquisition of a statue believed to be the goddess Aphrodite and have found no evidence of improprieties.

title: Household International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Telecom Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
McMillan Waived
description: Randy McMillan, the Indianapolis Colts' running back who was the fifth-leading rusher in the history of the franchise, was waived yesterday. He missed all of last season because of injuries suffered in an automobile accident.

title: Biaggi Quits, Will Not Seek An 11th Term
description: Fifty years of public service ended at a 15-minute news conference yesterday as a tearful Mario Biaggi announced that he would resign from the House of Representatives and not seek an 11th term after his second conviction on corruption charges within the last year.

title: Biaggi: Treading a Path of Success, But Trailed by an Image in Shadow
description: With a tearful news conference, Representative Mario Biaggi yesterday ended his 50-year career of public service. But his emotional resignation, which came one day after his conviction on extortion and racketeering charges in the Wedtech scandal, marked only one dramatic moment in a political life filled with the glory of high achievement and dark suspicions of impropriety.

title: Donnelly Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Arthur Albert Alexander, Executive, 86
description: Arthur Albert Alexander, a former executive with American President Lines, Ltd., worldwide shipping operators, died Wednesday at Eastern Long Island Hospital in Greenport, after a brief illness. He was 86 years old and lived on Shelter Island.

title: Why Not Swathe Shoreham in Fine Silk?
description: To the Editor:

title: About New York; We're Off to See A Wizard, Only He's Not Talking
description: Strange things are afoot this summer. A guy in a wheelchair eagerly dangles from the Brooklyn Bridge; another swims from Albany to the Statue of Liberty, drinking the water of all things, and, now, money is washing up on the beaches. Is it all the work of some strange wizard?

title: United Inns Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest quarter includes an after-tax loss of $2.2 million on the company's disposition of the Austin Airport Hilton and Towers.

title: Marks & Spencer To Buy Grocer
description: Marks & Spencer P.L.C., the British retailer that acquired the Brooks Brothers specialty store chain in the United States earlier this year, agreed to buy New Jersey-based Kings Super Markets Inc. for $108 million. The Kings acquisition, together with a recently signed agreement with the Toronto-based retailer and developer, Campeau Corporation, will enable Marks & Spencer to build a significant food retailing operation in the United States, said Lord Rayner, the British retailer's chairman.

title: Koger Properties Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary gain of $5,004,000.

title: Allen Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,636,000 on disposal of discontinued European operations for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes a net of $1,786,000 and $1,798,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from discontinued European operations.

title: Casper Leads by 3 And Equals Mark
description: Billy Casper, a successful front-runner with two United States Open championships and one United States Senior Open title among his 60 tour victories, was running a record three shots ahead of the field after two rounds of the Senior Open today.

title: U.S. Official Casts Doubt on Prospects For Yonkers Accord
description: A Federal housing official said today that reaching a compromise in the desegregation dispute here, as called for by Governor Cuomo, posed great difficulties.

title: Pinetop Perkins
description: Pinetop Perkins, a blues pianist, is appearing tonight at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777-5077), with sets at 9:30 and midnight. There is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: The Last Time I Saw Paris
description: LEAD: Are you the kind of person who worries about gray market VCR's? Or worse, about whether the warranty on your gray market VCR is valid? You are? If the proliferation of gray market goods continues, then consider the possibility that you maysoon be reading a fable like this:

title: Wilfred American Educational Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Cadmus Communications Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Rate of AIDS Infection Found Low in Military
description: The largest AIDS testing program to date in a specific group of Americans has found that just over one in 1,000 active-duty military personnel carry the AIDS virus, lower than the rate among the general population, officials said Thursday.

title: Transcapital Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MOVING PLUTONIUM BY SEA IS ASSAILED
description: Several members of the House and the Senate wrote to President Reagan today to oppose amending a recently signed treaty that allows plutonium shipments from Europe to Japan. The treaty allows shipments by air, and the changes would permit transportation by sea.

title: Arabs Seeing Pay Cut as 'Autonomy'
description: Like many Palestinians, Dr. Yasir Obeid, Jordan's chief health administrator in the West Bank, was angry but optimistic today.

title: The Talk of Bronxville; IN EXCLUSIVE BRONXVILLE, RESIDENTS CHOOSE SIDES OVER A DEFIANT NEIGHBOR
description: Right across the Bronx River Parkway from the furor in Yonkers over a court-ordered housing desegregation plan, this mile-square village, is the prototype of the Westchester County suburb: Cozy and exclusive.

title: Mears Wins Pole For Marlboro 500
description: Rick Mears posted a lap of 218.427 miles per hour today despite gusty winds and a hot track and won the pole position for the Marlboro 500 Indy-car race on Sunday.

title: U.N. Plans 250 Peacekeepers for Gulf
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar told the Security Council today that he plans to a send a 250-member peacekeeping force to monitor any cease-fire agreement between Iran and Iraq and the disengagement of their forces, diplomats said.

title: U.S. Protests Rumanian Detention of U.N. Official
description: The United States has protested to Rumania for the second time this year about the detention of a Rumanian citizen working for the United Nations, Administration and United Nations officials say. The Rumanian has been blocked from traveling abroad to carry out his duties, the officials said.

title: Review/Dance; A Fearless Taylor Troupe Outdoors
description: The Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors Festival got off to a cheerful start on Wednesday with a burst of drumming, clowns, soaring balloons - and the Paul Taylor Dance Company, which formally opened the monthlong free festival with an evening performance at the Damrosch Park band shell.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the resignation of Sergiu Comissiona as music director of the New York City Opera misattributed an interpretive comment about the company's prospects. The statement - that the progress made by the opera's orchestra during the last year might be dissipated with Mr. Comissiona's departure - was The Times's interpretation, not that of Beverly Sills, general director of the company.

title: Faltering Yanks Are Swept by Twins
description: The idea, Lou Piniella said, was to use this weekend as an audition for his starting rotation. After two losses in a doubleheader last night at the Stadium, the casting promises to be difficult. So far, the aspirants do not appear prepared for the part.

title: Patents; Untested Compounds For Mental Disorders
description: The Nova Pharmaceutical Corporation, a young company based in Baltimore, won patent approval this week for a series of compounds it says could treat a wide variety of psychiatric disorders. The company has yet to apply for permission to test the drugs in humans.

title: Adams Resources & Energy Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Gymnastics; Can Karolyi and 'Kids' Break Ties That Bind?
description: Once the women's compulsory round of the United States gymnastics Olympic trials ended Thursday night, it seemed likely that three and possibly four women coached by Bela Karolyi would make the team.

title: Top South African Executive To Run Anti-Apartheid Party
description: A senior executive of South Africa's largest corporation today was elected leader of the anti-apartheid Progressive Federal Party.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: 4 Passers-By Save 8 in Fire In Brooklyn
description: LEAD: Four Brooklyn men rescued six sleeping children and two adults from two burning apartment buildings yesterday in a predawn fire that destroyed the homes of 30 people, witnesses and fire officials said.

title: Elcotel Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $54,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Stouffer Makes Debut
description: The waiting is over for Kelly Stouffer, who stayed out of football last year as he argued with the St. Louis Cardinals over how much a first-round draft pick should be paid.

title: Helmerich & Payne International Drilling Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest third quarter and 9-month include gains from the sale of securities totaling $81,000 and $1,812,000, respectively. Results for the year-ago quarter and 9-month include gains from the sale of securities totaling $2,260,000 and $15,927,000, respectively.

title: Ex-Louisiana Aide Sentenced
description: A onetime aide to Edwin W. Edwards when he was Governor was sentenced today to four years in prison for a scheme in which he took thousands of dollars to steer state contracts to consulting engineering firms. The former aide, Wayne Ray, received consecutive two-year sentences for two counts of filing false income taxes and a five-year probated sentence for an extortion count. Federal District Judge John Parker said the 44-year-old defendant, who pleaded guilty June 17, would be required to pay back $185,000 in taxes and penalties.

title: COPING: With Storage Problems
description: Anyone who has left valued personal property with a storage company has no doubt been chilled by the New-York Historical Society's recent discovery that off-site storage of some of its paintings had left the artworks badly damaged.

title: Metro-North Police Chief Dismissed Over Tape
description: The police chief of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad was dismissed last night for failing, two years ago, to turn over to his superiors a copy of a videotape in which seven railroad police officers are shown clowning around Grand Central Terminal.

title: The Financier 'Who Knows What Is Going On'
description: Nicholas F. Brady, the 58-year-old Wall Street financier tapped by President Reagan to succeed James A. Baker 3d as Treasury Secretary, is of the old school, with a family pedigree and Ivy League education that smoothed his way into corporate boardrooms.

title: Times Editor Given Public Affairs Post
description: Peter Millones, special assistant to the executive editor of The New York Times, has been named manager of public affairs and government relations for The New York Times Company. The announcement was made yesterday by Walter E. Mattson, president of the company.

title: New Mexico & Arizona Land Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: 'What the Bush Ticket Needs'
description: Vice President Bush is not saying anything. But even if he is not narrowing the field in his search for a running mate, others are trying to narrow it for him.

title: Odetics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes recognition of $400,000 in tax credits as a result of the company's adoption of FASB Statement 96.

title: GTI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Review/Music; Opposite Styles Attract
description: An attraction of opposites can make chamber music work almost as well as the meeting of like minds. It depends on one's tastes - do you prefer total harmony or a little healthy conflict? Thursday's edition of the Mostly Mozart series at Avery Fisher Hall had a little of both schools to it.

title: Save Deconstruction From Its Explicators; Joyce's Words Matter
description: To the Editor:

title: Move by Pfizer in India Spurs Furor
description: In an effort to increase the sales of its sagging subsidiary in India and streamline its operations, Pfizer Inc., the pharmaceutical company, has appointed an American as the unit's new managing director after 17 years of Indian management.

title: Baker Resigns to Work for Bush; Brady Is Named for Treasury Job
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d resigned today to join Vice President Bush's Presidential campaign, completing the dismantling of the White House team that gave President Reagan his greatest successes.

title: A Cool Choice for Treasury
description: For Nicholas Brady to replace the remarkably capable James Baker as Secretary of the Treasury should rattle no one. Despite the importance of the office and Mr. Baker's powerful command of economic policy through the second Reagan term, he leaves nothing undone that Mr. Brady can't handle.

title: Catalina Lighting reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Reviews/Music; Classical Prokofiev Joins Sensuous Mozart
description: Wednesday's concert at Avery Fisher Hall held out the routine pleasures that Mostly Mozart seems intended to provide. Gerard Schwarz conducted the Festival's orchestra, Jean-Pierre Rampal played the flute and Stephen Hough was the pianist.

title: Talks on Acid Rain Endorsed
description: President Reagan has approved continuing negotiations toward American participation in an international treaty to freeze emissions of a precursor to acid rain, the White House said today.

title: Shareholder Rights Plan for Wendy's
description: Wendy's International Inc., the fast-food restaurant company, said that it had adopted a plan intended to protect shareholder interests in an unfair takeover effort. Wendy's said the shareholder rights plan was not adopted in response to any known takeover effort. Under the plan, shareholders will receive for each share a right to buy, if certain conditions are met, a fraction of a share of a new series of preferred stock for $25. The price of the company's stock on the New York Stock Exchange fell 12.5 cents, to $5.875.

title: A One-Man Company Records Ethnic Musicians
description: On a recent evening in San Francisco, fans of the late accordionist and singer Clifton Chenier gathered to watch a new video of the Cajun musician and his Red Hot Louisiana Band. The tape was the latest release of Arhoolie Records, a local label that specializes in regional and ethnic music.

title: Manila View: Bases Go Home, Slowly
description: As the Philippines struggles to find a national consensus over the presence of American bases here, a growing number of legislators are advocating a compromise involving a gradual closing of the installations.

title: Racial Slur Denied By Greek Embassy
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Quarterly Jobless Rate Dips to 3.6%
description: Unemployment rates in New York and New Jersey fell to a 19-year quarterly low in the second quarter of the year, an indication of the regional economy's continuing strength, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Western Sagas Born From New York's Asphalt
description: In his Brooklyn basement, Robert J. Randisi writes novels about the Old West that are partly inspired by racehorses he has watched at Belmont and Aqueduct.

title: A Tie With the Bronx
description: When Friday afternoon comes, most of the students at the Horace Greeley High School summer session in Chappaqua bolt for area pools and tennis courts. But 15 students head for the 3:02 train that will carry them back to their homes in the South Bronx.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Rhode Island Takes a Holiday

title: About the Chess Moves
description: Starting this week, The New York Times is changing the notation system it uses to describe chess moves. The new system, known as algebraic notation, is widely preferred in the world chess community and has been officially recommended by the International Chess Federation.

title: Glen Cove Sculpture Needs Appropriate Site
description: On July 10, reference was made [ Long Island Journal ] to a proposed sculpture to be installed at ''the entrance to Glen Cove'' and that it might be 20 feet high.

title: Question of the Week; Are the Red Sox In for Another Fall?
description: The Red Sox have 32 remaining road games, 8 against the Yankees and Tigers (and 13 on the West Coast). Left-handed relief pitching could be crucial, and the Sox just haven't got it. I'm sure the Yankee left-handed hitters - Mattingly, Washingon, Phelps and Pagliarulo - and the Detroit lefties - Whitaker, Evans, Sheridan and Nokes - are looking forward to their coming games with the Red Sox. RICHARD MATTIG Brooklyn

title: Zap! An Electronic Application Form
description: FORGET recalcitrant pens and those forms that never seem to line up properly in the typewriter. Now you can apply to college by computer.

title: Lisa Gayle Brody Marries Bruce Clark
description: In the chapel of St. George's School in Newport, R.I., Lisa Gayle Brody, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger S. Brody of Westfield, N.J., and Peru, Vt., was married to Bruce James Clark, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Clark of Greenville, Del., and Essex, N.Y. The nondenominational ceremony was performed by the Rev. Philip Dietterich, a United Methodist minister.

title: Blackout Affects Thousands on the Upper West Side
description: An electrical blackout that began late Friday night left thousands of people in Harlem and on the Upper West Side of Manhattan without power yesterday. Power was restored to most customers by 8:06 P.M., but electric utility officials said they could not rule out the possibility of further disruptions.

title: Ms. Savin to Wed T. V. Ealy in Fall
description: Amy Michele Savin and Thomas Vincent Ealy, who both received M.B.A. degrees in June from Harvard University, plan to marry Oct. 15.

title: Stefanie Jacobs, A Physician, Wed To H. E. Feldman
description: At Congregation B'nai Jeshrun in Short Hills, N.J., Dr. Stefanie Sue Jacobs, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Fred M. Jacobs of Short Hills, and Boca Raton, Fla., was married last evening to Hadley Evan Feldman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger B. Feldman of Potomac, Md., and Grantham, N.H. Rabbi Barry Hewitt officiated.

title: FRANCIS COPPOLA'S CAREER
description: I appreciate the interest, but feel that Robert Lindsey's article, ''Francis Ford Coppola: Promises to Keep'' (July 24) repeats some tired old ideas about me: maverick; mad at Hollywood, etc.

title: A Writer On His Characters
description: To the Editor:

title: A Rift in the Anti-Mafia Connection
description: IN a shaded room inside a garish, well-guarded apartment block in Palermo, Sicily, a Mafia prosecutor stacked two art books and a silver box on his coffee table. ''There are three levels,'' said Giusto Sciacchitano, an investigating magistrate. The bottom book represented members of the Mafia, the soldiers, he explained. The next book, he said, was the leadership, the ruling commission. ''The third level is the political level,'' the prosecutor said, lifting the silver box. ''This is what we are looking at now. But we lack evidence.''

title: Northern Towns Serach for Options on Garbage
description: LEAD: THE potential consequences of a dispute over whether Mount Kisco has the right to condemn a parcel of property it is leasing to a carting company has added impetus to the efforts by other northern Westchester communities to find a joint solution to their garbage-removal problems.

title: A Drug Program for Inmantes
description: THE penitentiary at the Westchester County correctional complex here is attempting to help inmates break the cycle of drug dependency and crime through a new 28-day program of intensive alcohol and drug rehabilitation before their release.

title: A Walking Tour Of Boston's North End
description: LEAD: Not far from City Hall and Quincy Market is Boston's oldest neighborhood, where houses represent the 17th to 20th centuries, Italian is still spoken and cannoli are made fresh daily. ''Noisy, garrulous, good-natured and vital'' is how ''The W.P.A. Guide to Massachusetts'' described the historic North

title: Lanford Wilson Creates a Musical From a Play
description: TALK about the plays of Lanford Wilson and it is not likely that ''The Great Nebula in Orion'' will come up. Nor will ''Ikke Ikke Nye Nye Nye'' or ''The Family Continues,'' its companion pieces in a 1971 Off Off Broadway triple bill, that was called simply ''Three Plays by Lanford Wilson.''

title: DATA UPDATE
description: MEDIAN RESALE HOUSE PRICES

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;
Median House Price a Record $320,000
description: LEAD: The median sale price of a single-family house in Westchester, which had been declining since the latter part of 1987, turned sharply upward during the second quarter of this year, reaching a record $320,000.

title: FICTION
description: NIGHTS AS DAY, DAYS AS NIGHT. By Michel Leiris. Translated by Richard Sieburth. (Eridanos Press, P.O. Box 211, Hygiene, Colo., Cloth, $22; Paper, $13.) Born in 1901, Michel Leiris has shirked no adventure of the French intellectual left. Surrealist writer, then ethnographer, he has worked with the giants of modern art and social thought, but his most intrepid explorations have been autobiographical. This 1961 volume, attentively translated by Richard Sieburth under the title ''Nights as Day, Days as Night,'' is an auxiliary to Mr. Leiris's more sustained enterprise of self-observation. In it, he collects nocturnal dreams, waking dreams and dreamlike incidents of waking life, all meticulously recorded over four decades. ''Dream - a scintillating mirage surrounded by shadows - is essentially poetry,'' Mr. Leiris asserts; and each brief prose episode simultaneously displays his poetic lyricism and his scientific detachment. The incidents and images are largely uninterpreted, although some readers will find the pensive essay, here published as a foreword, in which Maurice Blanchot reflects on Mr. Leiris's text to be the gem of this volume. Many of the pieces themselves are pedestrian, and the author is uncomfortably faithful to the solemnity and self-dramatization that often color dream experience. But arresting images do emerge. True to his epigraph from Gerard de Nerval - ''Dream is a second life'' - Mr. Leiris cherishes all evidence of experience, waking or sleeping, and reserves his intolerance for a post-surgical occasion of anesthesia-induced oblivion. ''It was not so much the void that bothered me, but rather the gaping fault-line represented by this truly dead time that had been cut out of my life by the stroke of an axe.''

title: Reagan, in Switch, Agrees to a Plan on Acid Rain
description: President Reagan has agreed to freeze emission levels of nitrogen oxide, an important air pollutant, for at least the next seven years. The action will allow the United States to join in a major international treaty to reduce acid rain.

title: Drunken Driving: A Lesson Learned?
description: If experience is the best teacher, then Marc N. Turk didn't learn a great deal from his tragic automobile incident [ ''The Dream That Fell to Earth,'' July 31 ] .

title: ON THE ROAD TO THE QUAGMIRE
description: APPROACHING VIETNAM From World War II Through Dienbienphu 1941-1954. By Lloyd C. Gardner. 440 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Company.

title: A Businesslike University
description: AT HAMPTON University in Virginia, learning pays - literally. Entering students whose combined Scholastic Aptitude Test scores exceed 1200 (out of a possible 1600) get free tuition; those with scores over 1300 get free tuition, room and board. Students who qualify for the honors dormitory on the city's Hampton River waterfront pay lower rent and enjoy other amenities, such as a swimming pool. Nor are the incentives limited to the student body. A faculty member who publishes an article in a so-called refereed journal, whose content is reviewed by peers, receives $1,000; faculty members can compete for a few hundred dollars more by writing the most book reviews in the three local newspapers.

title: Dry Soil Blows Away, Carrying Hope With It
description: The dismay still clouded Mark Jahner's face as the young farmer looked out over a field he had hoped to see covered with wheat. Now there was nothing there except barren subsoil. The rich topsoil had dried up and blown away, leaving yet another scar from the drought of 1988.

title: THE WORLD: Carlucci Is Skeptical; Is the Soviet Military On the Gorbachev Diet?
description: IF a senior Soviet military officer had suggested two or three years ago that the American Secretary of Defense be invited to inspect the most advanced Russian warplanes, he probably would have been sent to a remote Siberian army base if not a mental ward.

title: Searching For the Right Frame for the Right Job
description: FOR two years I combed the antique print shops in Boston and New York searching for a wedding gift for a very special young couple. Then, to my surprise, I found two old prints I wanted at a local antique show held in a church near my home each year.

title: ANTI-MAFIA EFFORT STUMBLES IN ITALY
description: ''The Mafia Gives Thanks'' was the headline in more than one Italian newspaper this week as judicial and political leaders struggled to prevent a collapse of the nation's most important law enforcement effort, a campaign against the criminal organization.

title: For Britain's Health Service, Little Cash but Big Demands
description: Barrie Dowdeswell, general manager of the Royal Victoria Infirmary here, stands at the front line of Britain's troubled National Health Service, once viewed as a world model of a successful national medical service.

title: Cuban Exile Group Plans Private TV Broadcasts
description: Some Cuban exiles here say they are planning an invasion of Cuba. But these Cubans say that their invasion, unlike previous attempts by small bands with rifles and explosives, will be carried out with television signals.

title: Healthful Cruise on a Hospital Barge
description: As the barge glided along the Hudson River, 10-year-old Shawn Coleman lip-synched and danced to Michael Jackson's ''Bad'' on the upper deck. Later, he would go to the lower deck - to get a dental checkup.

title: After the Americans Leave, What Next?
description: MORE than 170 American companies have sold their holdings in South Africa in the last three years as a result of considerable political and economic pressure from within the United States and abroad. Disinvested companies include such familiar names as the Xerox Corporation, the International Business Machines Corporation, the Coca-Cola Company, the Ford Motor Company, the General Motors Corporation, Citicorp and the Eastman Kodak Company. Why have so many companies left? Social activists have been very successful at using a number of tactics which taken together have created economic as well as moral pressure for disinvestment.

title: Congress Considers Ocean Cleanup Plan
description: THE Reagan Administration and members of Congress from coastal states are at odds over a proposal to clean up 10 polluted bodies of water in the country, including the New York Bight, which has been plagued by sewage, hospital waste and other debris.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Towson, Md.;
Buildings Rise In Bustling City
description: LEAD: Three new office buildings, a high-rise apartment house with some office space and a 900-car garage are under construction in this growing county seat seven miles north of Baltimore's business district.

title: Lacy Leather
description: THE key to Paris couture is luxury, but this does not always mean gleaming bead embroideries and sumptuous furs; elegant workmanship and rich materials are taken for granted. Exquisite details mark the difference between ready-to-wear and made-to-order clothes.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE SUMMER CIRCUS ARTS CAMP;
Hopes and Dreams Soar As Novices Learn Ropes, Etc.
description: PURCHASE NO sawdust, no striped tent, no brass band. No peanuts, no cotton candy. No sequined costumes.

title: FOCUS: Cape Cod, Mass.; The Buyers Are Now in the Driver's Seat
description: NEVER before has Cape Cod had so many houses, condominiums and commercial spaces for sale as it has today. And at no time in recent years have there been so few prospective buyers.

title: Question of the Week; Are the Red Sox In for Another Fall?
description: The question would be appropriate if the Yankees had just won 17 of 18 games to cut the Red Sox lead from 9 games to 1. However, because just the opposite has happened, I must respond with a question of my own: ''Where was George?'' STEPHEN J. ZEOLI Westport, Conn.

title: 69 More Opponents Of Abortion Jailed In Atlanta Protests
description: Demonstrations by opponents of abortion led to the arrest of 69 more protesters today. Those arrested joined more than 120 other people in jail from anti-abortion demonstrations that began July 19 at the time of the Democratic National Convention.

title: AFTER THE KILLING FIELDS
description: Your article made it clear that more needs to be done for the refugees and displaced persons living in border encampments along the Thai-Kampuchean border.

title: THE WORLD: Disagreement Over Nicaragua; A Chorus of Criticism, A Lone Call to Action
description: AS Secretary of State George P. Shultz toured Latin America last week seeking support for the Nicaraguan rebels, he denounced Nicaragua's Sandinista Government at every opportunity, describing it as ''a cancer'' that must be removed. President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica, an outspoken critic of the contras, was no less vehement. He described the Sandinistas' recent crackdown on opposition groups as outrageous, and said the Managua Government ''should be punished'' by other countries.

title: TALKING: No Smoking; Developing New Rules In Condos
description: SHOULD smoking still be permitted in the community rooms, health clubs and public hallways of co-ops and condominiums? Or even alongside a condominium's open-air pool?

title: RED IS RIGHT NOW
description: THEY MAY BE SWEET strawberry blondes or deep coppery redheads, blondes streaked with bits of rose or brunettes spun with auburn, but red is the captivating hair color of the moment. A year ago, blond was the color of choice. This summer, those who were born red are flaunting it, and those who were not are giving nature a nudge. Red may even be pushing other shades to the back of the beauty salon.

title: Colin Higgins, Film Director, 47, Creator of 'Harold and Maude'
description: Colin Higgins, a screenwriter and director whose works include ''Silver Streak,'' ''Foul Play'' and ''Harold and Maude,'' died Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 47 years old and had been suffering from AIDS, said a spokeswoman for his production company.

title: COMPANIONSHIP WAS EVERYTHING
description: CHARLOTTE MEW AND HER FRIENDS With a Selection of Her Poems. By Penelope Fitzgerald. Foreword by Brad Leithauser. Illustrated. 276 pp. Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley. $17.95.

title: The Vecht River
description: To the Editor: The article on the Vecht River in the Netherlands (Travel, July 10) recommends access to that appealing region merely ''by auto, by bike or by foot.'' But a better way to view that area of ''windmills, castles and dozens of mansions,'' since they ''display their grandest facades to the Vecht,'' is from the water by either barge or boat.

title: For Quick Sale: College Nest Eggs
description: NOT LONG AGO, a devoted grandfather laid out a total of $13,113 to cover four years' worth of tuition, room and board at the University of Wyoming for his two granddaughters. Quite a gift. The earliest that the older child, a 6-year-old, might become a freshman is 1999, when the school's four-year costs are expected to be $19,225, more than two and a half times the prepayment of $7,488; for the other grandchild, who is 3, the $5,625 prepayment will become the equivalent of nearly $23,000 starting in 2002.

title: Corporate Logos Spruce Themselves Up; Preserve Americana
description: To the Editor:

title: Sewer Outflow Irks Huntington
description: LEAD: A RECENT waste spill from Huntington's sewage plant has raised questions about the effectiveness of the facility, which was built last year at a cost of $14 million.

title: Tina L. Speiser, A Lawyer, Weds
description: The marriage of Tina Lisa Speiser and Joseph Charles Heinzmann Jr., both 1987 graduates of the Syracuse University College of Law, took place last evening at Holy Trinity Chapel in Manhattan. The Rev. Raymond Rafferty, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Charles D. Lippman officiated.

title: Heeere's the Band. . . But How Much longer?
description: In a culture whose critical mass has nourished rock and roll for 30 years, the fall of the big bands toward extinction has been inevitable. The old swing-era infrastructure of bands, ballrooms, broadcasts and booking agencies is gone. Most of the legendary figures are dead. And now, Johnny Carson's contract will be up in September. If that last observation sounds like a nonsequitur, consider this: the Tonight Show Band with Doc Severinsen is the last, modern, full-time big band in America - and of course the last in American broadcasting. It has musical power and star power and stands today at the peak of its fame, yet its continued existence hangs by the thread of Mr. Carson's future.

title: LAW SETS JURY PAY AT $15 IN NEW YORK
description: Jurors throughout New York will get $15 a day starting next April under a bill signed into law this week by Governor Cuomo.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: GOOD SKATES While it may be too early for most folks to think ''ice'' (except in tall, cool glasses) it's never soon enough for skaters. Today's the day the new competitive figure skating season begins, as hopefuls from the east show their stuff at ''Skate Long Island.'' One hundred and seventeen competitors, including the current National Novice Men's Silver Medalist and Eastern Sectional Novice Men's Champion and several Japanese skaters studying in the area, take to the ice at the Cantiague Park Rink in Hicksville in the first of a demanding series of qualifying events on the way to the United States Figure Skating Championships in February. They'll be evaluated by a panel that includes one of the international judges who worked the women's Gold Medal event at last winter's Olympics. This United States Figure Skating Association-sanctioned event takes place from 8 A.M. to 10 P.M. at the park on West John Street and there's no charge to get out of the heat and watch. CLASSIC ROCK

title: Cuomo Signs a Bill on Liberty Scholarships
description: Governor Cuomo has signed a bill creating the Liberty Scholarship program, which he described as the nation's first state-run effort to cover all college costs for low-income students.

title: The Pits
description: ''WE DEVELOP NEW VARIETIES of stone fruit,'' Floyd Zaiger says of Zaiger's Genetics, the business he runs in Modesto, Calif., with his daughter and two sons. ''Primarily we work with peaches, nectarines, plums and apricots.'' Lately the focus has been on the last two; Zaiger is cross-pollinating them, and what he has dubbed ''pluots'' are on the way.

title: The Teen Drug Of Choice: Alcohol
description: STANDING in front of his seventh-grade class, his Hawaiian shirt a burst of color against the chalkboard, Willy straightened his aviator glasses, shifted his weight from foot to foot and held out a 12-ounce can marked ''beer.'' ''Want some?'' he asked the teacher, his voice part bravado, part nervousness. ''No, I don't think so,'' the teacher said. ''Sure?'' asked Willy.

title: All Aboard for the Queen of India's Railroads
description: Six mornings a week, at 9 A.M., the Rajdhani Express, queen of India's vast railroad network and its only fully air-conditioned train, eases into the New Delhi railroad station from Bombay. It is rarely late. But the plushness of this flagship -with tinted windows, uniformed room attendants, six-course meals, special linen for the wide and soft bunk beds and even showers in the bathrooms of the first-class coaches - is in vivid contrast to the overcrowded and dirty trains that are more common in India. ''It is the cream of the railways, our showpiece,'' said one senior department official.

title: Europe Wary of Greece's Anti-Terrorism Role
description: Greece's assumption of the rotating presidency of the European Community may set back promising efforts by Western Europe and the United States to coordinate anti-terrorist policies, in the view of well-placed British, French and West German officials.

title: New Rule on Help for Boaters Draws Ire
description: A NEW Government regulation on the handling of boaters seeking help has prompted an outcry from private tow-boat operators and the Coast Guard Auxiliary.

title: FICTION
description: OCEAN VU, JOG TO BEACH. By Clement Biddle Wood. (St. Martin's, $17.95) According to Clement Biddle Wood, yuppies never identify themselves as such - it is unyuppie-ish to even think the word. Mr. Wood's amusing novel about seven young urban professionals who share a summer home on Long Island's South Fork gently satirizes the mores of this tanned and limber race. The tenants of Historic Slocum House include a numbers-obsessed arbitrageur, a young writer working on her first novel, a rambunctious sports reporter, an art dealer and a sycophantic corporate lawyer who has rented the house to be near one of his firm's partners. Their vacations, made hectic by career-oriented ''workplay,'' are observed by a diminutive Russian emigre poet, Vladimir Yurevich Ouspenskiy, who tags along as housekeeper and omniscient narrator. Presented as a mock sociological treatise, complete with 81 footnotes, ''Ocean Vu, Jog to Beach'' records Vlady's fascination with the ''capitalist/consumerist summer commune.'' While this literary conceit - not to mention Vlady's frequent references to his subjects as ''Y-persons'' - soon becomes labored, Mr. Wood does create several appealing characters. Yuppies who refuse to call themselves yuppies are unlikely to want to read about yuppies, but Mr. Wood, who is also the author of ''Welcome to the Club,'' presents in his second novel the kind of light entertainment that is well suited for yuppie vacation reading.

title: Karolyi Pupils Are Standouts in Trials
description: Bela Karolyi's expertise in developing female gymnasts was never more apparent than today as three of his athletes qualified for the six-member United States Olympic team and two others won spots as alternates.

title: Battery Park City
description: To the Editor:

title:
ON LANGUAGE;
You Say Potato ...
description: LEAD: There is faith, hope and charity, Hard-won prosperity In a little tin box

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: San Francisco;
Forward To the Past
description: LEAD: LIKE many other movie palaces of the 1920's, the Alhambra Theater suffered indignities to its original architecture over the years. When sound came to films, acoustical plaster was applied over elaborate wall stenciling and other design details. In the mid-50's the ornate proscenium was covered by a

title: Equal Hazard Employment
description: Some of the journalists in WOMEN OF THE WORLD: The Great Foreign Correspondents by Julia Edwards (Houghton Mifflin, $17.95) have become legends, and their stories are as dramatic as the events they recorded. But even such stars as Mary Roberts Rinehart, Dorothy Thompson, Martha Gellhorn, Margaret Bourke-White and Marguerite Higgins did not have an easy time. The book chronicles the struggle of these foreign correspondents - and others less well known - for the right to cover world events as equals to their male colleagues. In an engaging and spirited style, Julia Edwards, a foreign correspondent for 25 years, describes how American women circumvented, challenged and ignored discriminatory rules and practices in print journalism. Progress, she recounts, could be measured from war to war. In World War I, when the United States Army refused to accredit women to cover the Western Front, three American women covered the Russian Front. In World War II, women were generally relegated to rear lines. In Korea, Gen. Walton H. Walker banned women because ''there are no facilities for ladies at the front,'' a decision overruled by Gen. Douglas MacArthur. Finally, in Vietnam, the Defense Department allowed women to cover combat as equals with men. The photographer Dickey Chapelle, was the first American woman combat correspondent killed in action. Spanning 140 years, the book rightly focuses on the war periods. Too little space, however, is devoted to the post-Vietnam generation. Ms. Edwards shows that inequalities persist, noting that in 1987, women accounted for increasing numbers of reporters and editors in the United States but only a fraction of foreign correspondents.

title: Lynne Beth Cohen Wed to Michael W. Wolitzer
description: Lynne Beth Cohen, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Michael H. Cohen of Tarrytown, N.Y., was married in Rye Brook, N.Y., last night to Michael William Wolitzer, a son of Faith Wolitzer of North Woodmere, L.I., and the late D. Lawrence Wolitzer. Rabbi Paul Siegel, assisted by Cantor Jerome Holland, performed the ceremony at the Rye Town Hilton.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE DEVELOPMENT OF BLACK THEATER IN AMERICA: From Shadows to Selves. By Leslie Catherine Sanders. (Louisiana State University, $25.) Leslie Catherine Sanders' new book has much to recommend it: thoughtful, trenchant analysis of black theater in America; informed discussions of certain black playwrights; and a deft exploration of the quest to achieve a ''black stage reality'' beyond the confines of European theatrical conventions. Unfortunately, there are omissions that speak as loudly as the works and writers she has included. Ms. Sanders, an associate professor of English at York University, Ontario, offers a broad overview of black playwrights - from Willis Richardson to Langston Hughes to Ed Bullins - and seems to understand the forces in society that have nurtured and sharpened black theater. She describes well the history of that theater, proving it was not solely a product of the 1960's and 70's. But she might have gone further. Such pivotal playwrights as Lorraine Hansberry and James Baldwin, and more contemporary voices like Ntozake Shange and Charles Fuller, are examined almost as afterthoughts. August Wilson, a recent Pulitzer Prize winner but no newcomer to the stage, isn't mentioned at all. Ms. Sanders has provided a solid background for black theatrical history, but one would have hoped for a more current and comprehensive study.

title: For Repair Units, Heat and Danger
description: LEAD: Peter McGrath, an emergency supervisor for Consolidated Edison, peered into a dank, murky manhole on Broadway near 118th Street yesterday as soot-streaked workers searched for faults in feeder cables. A large yellow fan hovered above the hole, but the breeze provided little comfort to those below.

title: For Lebanon, Slow Return To Business
description: The Lebanese economy is showing signs of recovery despite an increase in factional fighting over the presidential election scheduled this summer.

title: Officials Assert U.S. Is Trying To Weaken Costa Rica Chief
description: Publicly, the United States has praised President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica for leading the quest for peace in Central America. But privately, Reagan Administration officials have taken steps to embarrass and undermine him, and have derisively referred to him as ''the laureate,'' according to political leaders here and in Washington.

title: WILL THE WORLD FLOCK TO WICHITA FALLS?
description: THERE WAS A TIME NOT SO LONG AGO when my hometown of Wichita Falls was known as the worst town in Texas. The novelist Larry McMurtry, a Texan, once had a character call it ''the ugliest place on earth.''

title: All Dressed Up and No Place to Go?
description: AT a time when many individual investors have fled the stock market in fear, one pack of investors is feverishly raising cash to buy up stocks. Leveraged buyout investors, who buy companies with borrowed capital and then resell them for hefty profits, are furiously piling up billions of dollars.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Walker Starring Ed Harris, Richard Masur, Rene Auberjonois, Peter Boyle, Marlee Matlin, Blanca Guerra, Gerrit Graham, William O'Leary, Keith Szarabajka, Sy Richardson, Xander Berkeley. Directed by Alex Cox. 1987. MCA Home Video. 94 minutes. $79.95. Rated R.

title: Cher for the Defense
description: SUSPECT Starring Cher (in photo), Dennis Quaid, Liam Neeson, John Mahoney, Joe Mantegna (in photo), Philip Bosco. Directed by Peter Yates. 1987. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video. 121 minutes. $89.95. Rated R. As Kathleen Riley, a smart, hard-boiled, bespectacled public defender who sets out to clear a homeless deaf-mute of a murder charge, Cher gives a ''crisply compelling performance'' in this courtroom thriller, said The Times's reviewer, Janet Maslin.

title: Miss Williams to Wed Fred Vanderberg
description: The engagement of Marjorie Lynn Williams to Fred John Vandenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Heiman Vandenberg of New York and Rotterdam, the Netherlands, has been announced by her parents, Mrs. Robert W. Davis of New York and Garrison, N.Y., and Thomas O. Willliams of Portland, Me. A December wedding is planned. Miss Williams, an associate at Gillis Associates Architects in New York, graduated from the Brearley School and cum laude from Middlebury College. She was a member of the Junior Assembly in 1976. Her father is a senior vice president of Casco Northern Bank in Portland. The future bride is a granddaughter of the late Marjorie C. Bienstock of New York, who was the president of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service, now Spence-Chapin Services to Families and Children, and the late John James Murdock Jr. of Ojai, Calif. Her step-grandfather, the late Abraham L. Bienstock, was a lawyer and a director of R. H. Macy & Company. Miss Williams is also a granddaughter of Louise C. Williams of Boca Grande, Fla., and Prouts Neck, Me., and the late Ramon O. Williams, a partner in Tucker, Anthony & R. L. Day, stockbrokers in New York.

title: A Shift at the Top Of the Treasury
description: A well-known Wall Street figure may join the Cabinet as head of the Treasury Department. Nicholas F. Brady has been named to replace James A. Baker 3d, who resigned from the top Treasury post to run Vice President Bush's capaign for the presidency. Mr. Brady, 57 years old, is co-chairman of the Dillon, Read investment house and was the head of the Presidential commission that investigated last October's stock market collapse. Mr. Brady, if confirmed by the Senate, would be President Reagan's third Treasury Secretary. Donald T. Regan, former chairman of Merrill Lynch, was the first.

title: Time to End Illusions
description: The conflict between Israelis and Palestinians, defying solution for 40 years now, has its basis in a difficult reality: the attachment of both peoples to the same piece of territory. But compromise might have been possible if vision had not been obscured on all sides by illusions.

title: Hard Knocks Plaguing Vermont School System
description: In Bennington, where early American history dominates the landscape, residents are grappling with much more recent and less inspiring history: scandal and controversy in the Southwestern Vermont school system.

title: Derailed Train Hits Tank of Diesel Fuel, Forcing 300 to Flee
description: Twelve cars of a 113-car freight train derailed today and struck a tank of diesel fuel that exploded. The explosion and fire forced the evacuation of about 300 people, the authorities said, but no injuries were reported.

title:
ART;
In the Aftermath Of Hudson School
description: LEAD: THE Hudson River School, America's indigenous school of landscape painting, has been enjoying a great critical vogue and is equally popular with the public. It is only natural that some curator should extend the idea and present a show of the Hudson River School's influence and aftermath. Patricia Foley of the State Museum here has essayed such a show, ''After Eden: American Landscape 1875-1925.

title: O'Neill 'Horizon' Comes Into View
description: THE chance to see a seldomdone but once successful play by America's most honored playwright - in fact, his first produced full-length work, and a Pulitzer Prize-winning one at that - is surely an occasion to be bypassed only by churls and Philistines.

title: Ariantje DuBois Marries
description: At St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Washington, Ariantje DuBois, a daughter of Mrs. Eugene DuBois of Oyster Bay, L.I., and the late Mr. DuBois was married yesterday to Richard Neville Johnston, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Gregg Johnston of Connellsville, Pa. The Rev. James R. Adams performed the ceremony. Ms. DuBois, an artist who will retain her name, graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and the Corcoran School of Art in Washington. Mr. Johnston, also an artist, graduated from the School of Visual Arts in New York.

title: Correction
description: An article in this section last Sunday about the National Black Arts Festival in Atlanta incorrectly described Alain Locke. He was the first black American Rhodes scholar.

title: Who Should Pay for Nuclear Miscalculations?
description: SOMEDAY soon, utility shareholder and customers will find out which of them will pay for the last of the approximately 100 nuclear reactors that were ordered, but never completed, at a cost of about $30 billion.

title: So Close, but Yet So Far: Shoreham Solution Is Elusive
description: LEAD: DEBATE over Governor Cuomo's proposed settlement with the Long Island Lighting Company to close the Shoreham nuclear plant showed signs of going into extra innings last week, after seeming so close to ending.

title: Stephanie Gail Victor Weds James E. Corbo
description: The marriage of Stephanie Gail Victor, a second-year student at the Georgetown University Law Center, to James Edward Corbo, a mechanical engineer at ORI Inc. in Rockville, Md., took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. A. Paul Victor, parents of the bride, in Rye, N.Y. Rabbi Irwin Lowenheim and the Rev. Henry Fehrenbacher, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Another Deadly Parisian Train Crash
description: A passenger train slammed into a barrier at a railroad station here today, killing one person and injuring 57, the Paris fire department said.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: COMEDY AND DANCE Premiere performances of an off-beat comedy and an unusual dance-theater piece are being presented this week and next week by the River Arts Repertory Theater in Woodstock, N.Y. ''Tales of the Lost Formicans'' is a send-up of the American suburbs through the eyes of a couple of anthropologists from outer space; and ''La Goulue'' traces the flamboyant career of the Parisian can-can dancer who achieved immortality as the subject of paintings by Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Lenox, Mass.;
Arizona Spa For Berkshires
description: LEAD: THERE was a ground-breaking ceremony here last week for a $37 million Arizona-style health spa that will rise on a historic 120-acre estate in the lush countryside of Berkshire County.

title: PRIDE OF THE PAST
description: THIS WAS THE UGLIEST HOUSE IN THE neighborhood: a dark-brown elephant with asbestos siding. But to interior designer Kevin Walz and his wife, Barbra, a photographer, this was also a house with hidden charms. Not only was the property inviting, there were also porches on four sides, a series of untouched and well-proportioned main rooms on the ground floor, eight bedrooms upstairs and quirky Victorian details. Moreover, the location - Dering Harbor on Shelter Island -seemed like the ideal spot for children.

title: Homeless Plan Faces Vote in Mount Vernon
description: LEAD: THE Mount Vernon City Council, facing a vote on a project that would provide transitional housing for the homeless, could pave the way Wednesday night for construction of the first of a series of such projects to be built in Westchester.

title: James Devereux, War Hero, 85; Elected to Four Terms in Congress
description: James P. S. Devereux, a World War II hero and former Maryland Congressman, died Friday of pneumonia at Stella Maris Hospice in Baltimore. He was 85 years old and was a resident of Ruxton, Md.

title: Blueberries: Beyond Just Cream
description: YOU know it's summer when there are blueberries with the cereal in the morning. The berries are also delicious, as any child knows, in pies and tarts - and are particularly good for homemade ice cream.

title: THE SINS OF THE MOTHERS
description: LEAD: IN MY MOTHER'S HOUSE By Elizabeth Winthrop. 523 pp. New York: Doubleday. $19.95.

title: Review/Theater; Talk and Action by Cultural Provocateurs
description: If one had to choose a single word to characterize the respective styles of Frank Maya, Allen Ginsberg, Paul Krassner and Karen Finley, the four speakers who shared the stage at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening, one might call them manic, devotional, cheeky and hysterical.

title: Is 'Medigap' Insurance Still Needed?
description: THE sweeping changes in Medicare coverage recently signed into law have made some people wonder if they will continue to need ''Medigap'' policies - supplemental insurance provided by private companies that is intended to cover what Medicare does not. While there is some uncertainty about how these companies will redesign their policies in light of the new Medicare Catastrophic Protection Act, the general feeling among health-care experts is that supplemental coverage will continue to play an important role.

title: HOT TOMATOES
description: WHEN THE FIRST TOMATO ripens on the vine, I resist all temptation to bite then and there into the tight skin. Instead, I carry it into the kitchen and make a sandwich. The ritual is always the same: a lather of store-bought mayonnaise on two slices of plain white bread, a couple of thick slices of tomato, a dose of salt and pepper. When the bread becomes a little soggy and pink, I take my first bite and forget the anemic facsimiles with leathery skin and cottony pulp, the foolish sums I might pay for a Dutch or Israeli import, or the tomatoes I have tried to ripen in brown paper bags. Tomatoes have one season, and that is now.

title: Big Name on Campus
description: THEIR NAMES leap off the pages of course catalogues. Registering for their classes inspires the competitive, camping-out-on-the-ticket-line spirit usually reserved for a Bruce Springsteen concert.

title: Where America Goes for Entertainment
description: WHEN Americans go shopping these days, their destination is likely to be ashopping mall. They are everywhere. As of 1987, for the first time, the number of shopping centers exceeded the number of post offices or secondary schools - 30,600 nationwide, according to the International Council of Shopping Centers, an industry group.

title: The Politics of Lawn-Care Pesticides
description: AFTER John F. Cockerill, a Scarsdale landscaper, spends his usual 40 hours a week fighting Westchester's crabgrass and insects, he spends another 20 hours fighting the politics of pesticides.

title: For Anglicans, Things Stay Bright and Beautiful
description: Anglican bishops from all over the world are ending a three-week Anglican Conference this weekend convinced that their union of independent churches has been strengthened rather than shipwrecked on issues like the consecration of female bishops and maintaining common church doctrine and authority.

title: Correction
description: A listing of harness entries in Sports Pages yesterday misstated the race in which the horses were entered. It was not the Hambletonian but the Hambletonian Oaks, which was run Friday night. An account of the Hambletonian appears today in Section 8.

title:
TELEVISION;
Linda Ellerbee: Newscaster Without a Network
description: LEAD: A few months ago, Bruce Paisner, president of King Features Entertainment, the syndication arm of the Hearst stations, spent a plane trip reading ''And So It Goes,'' Linda Ellerbee's mostly lighthearted account of the pains and pleasures of the television news game. An idea was born; a meeeting with the author was arranged.

title: Practical Traveler; Getting Help Abroad For Credit Card Problems
description: When Judith and Paul Haskins of New York vacationed on the island of Hawaii last month, they used a Gold MasterCard to charge their Budget rental car and their accommodations at Volcano House. After a week, when they drove into the auto agency to extend the rental, the clerk told them that they had to turn the car in immediately because their line of credit on the MasterCard was exhausted.

title: Let There Be Light! The Better to See Our Memories
description: ''And on the seventh day the Lord rested, and came to beautiful Wrigley Field, to watch the Chicago Cubs, play His own game, on His own green grass, under His own lights.''

title: Relative of Jackson Indicted For Conspiracy in Death Plot
description: A state grand jury has indicted Noah Robinson, half-brother of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, on charges of conspiracy, obstruction of justice and intimidation of a witness in a plot to kill a murder witness.

title: Gay Groups Are Rallied To Aid 2 Women's Fight
description: Today, the eve of her 32d birthday, as Sharon Kowalski lies in a nursing home in Hibbing, Minn., demonstrators across the country will be demanding that her family let her see Karen Thompson, who says they intended to spend their lives as a couple.

title: Gurkhas Reportedly Ending Their Rebellion
description: The leader of the Gurkha separatist movement today formally announced the end of a violent, two-year-long insurgency, the United News of India reported.

title: Lesson Plan for the Savings Industry
