description: MANY of the nation's savings institutions are in big trouble, saddled with hemorrhaging portfolios of bad loans. In Texas and California alone, the Government may have to ante up tens of billions of dollars to keep depositors at savings and loan institutions from losing money. The Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, the agency that insures those deposits, is itself near bankruptcy.

title: A Nautical Setting in Darien
description: IN the unending quest for seafood, Darien offers a safe new harbor: Newport Grill. It is in a vast, rambling one-story building on the Post Road, vacated by Chi-Chi's, the unlamented pseudo-Mexican restaurant.

title: The Love Books
description: To the Editor:

title:
INVESTING;
The Allure of Reinvesting Dividends
description: LEAD: RISING corporate dividends are adding to the allure of dividend reinvestment plans. The Standard & Poor's Corporation reports that dividends from major companies may be up as much as 10 percent this year. That would be the largest yearly increase since 1979. In addition, 19 percent more companies raised their dividends in June of this year than in June 1987.

title: Note to Readers
description: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. Because of the growing volume of submissions, however, we regret that we can no longer return articles unless accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope.

title: Review/Art; A Show by Black Artists Rekindles an Old Debate
description: What, if anything, distinguishes black painting or sculpture from any other kind of art? In exhibitions that encompass the period stretching back to the Harlem Renaissance of the 1920's, the First National Black Arts Festival has assembled a diversity of objects implicitly intended to address this elusive issue.

title: SHOREHAM PLAN: HASTE MAKES WASTE
description: THE proposed settlement of the dispute over the Long Island Lighting Company and its Shoreham nuclear power plant has created an extraordinary conjunction of interests among groups that seem to have little in common.

title: The Welfare Web
description: To the Editor:

title: Holidays
description: To the Editor: The New York Times has long printed more news and articles about Canada than any other United States newspaper that I know of.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
OXBRIDGE REVISITED
description: LEAD: It often perplexes American visitors to Oxford University that New College is actually 600 years old, and that it is new compared with University College, which dates back to 1249 or so. Cambridge University, anyone in Oxford will tell you, is a young upstart - its yellow, Cotswold-quarried stone buildings did not rise along the banks of the river Cam until decades later.

title: MY FATHER, PHILIP GUSTON
description: MY FATHER HATED OPENINGS.

title: State Seeks Bigger Role In Making Of Movies
description: NINETY-FIVE years after Thomas A. Edison built the world's first film studio in New Jersey - near his laboratories in West Orange - the state is grappling for a bigger share of the industry it gave birth to.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE OBJECT OF MY AFFECTION, by Stephen McCauley. (Washington Square/Pocket, $6.95.) Nina, an aspiring psychologist, becomes pregnant and asks George, her homosexual roommate, to help her raise the child. Stephen McCauley ''brings his characters, his world astonishingly, captivatingly alive,'' Susan Fromberg Schaeffer said in The Book Review last year. This ''is surely one of the best books about what it is like to be young in these crazy times.'' GLORY-HUNTER: A Life of General Custer, by Frederic F. Van de Water. (Bison/University of Nebraska, $10.95.) With the publication of this biography in 1934, the legend of George Armstrong Custer began to change from that of a brave, if importunate hero to that of a tragic, driven egomaniac. ''The Custer so portrayed is a thousand times more fascinating, has far more claim to sympathy, than the plaster saint of poor Mrs. Custer's loving narratives,'' R. L. Duffus said here. ''The story has an epic movement, and at the last is heart-stirring and somberly beautiful.'' The same publisher has also reissued THE STORY OF THE LITTLE BIG HORN:

title: Expressway Plan Receives Mixed Notices
description: LEAD: RESIDENTS of Inwood in southwest Nassau are concerned that a new four-lane section of the Nassau Expressway will bring added commercial traffic problems to their area and wonder when New York State will build the ''missing link'' portions of the highway to connect it to Kennedy Airport and major Queens roads.

title: Merry I. White Weds Edward Baumeister Jr.
description: Merry I. White, an associate professor of sociology at Boston University, and Edward J. Baumeister Jr., the managing editor of The Trenton Times, were married yesterday in Princeton, N.J. Mayor Barbara Boggs Sigmund of Princeton Borough officiated at the bridegroom's home.

title: LEARNING TO WRITE CAN BE FUN
description: Hollins College, a small, 150-year-old women's college nestled in a quiet valley in Virginia's Blue Ridge Mountains, seems at first glance an unlikely literary center. Though respected in higher education circles, Hollins is not widely known outside the South; many of those who have heard of it tend to dismiss it as a tony finishing school for the daughters of Sun Belt aristocrats.

title: A Home-Building Upturn for Newark
description: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

title: Wedtech: Portrait of An American Scheme
description: IN a twisted way, the story of the Wedtech Corporation seemed a quintessential American tale, albeit one of bribery, theft, extortion and securities fraud that climaxed last week with the convictions of a Congressman and a former borough president.

title: How Yonkers Came to a Sad Impasse
description: MICHAEL EDELMAN, a Yonkers lawyer who was the city's Corporation Counsel in 1982, recalled last week: ''We could have settled the discrimination suit then for 100 units of low-income housing and a school integration plan that would not have included busing.''

title: States Cooperate to Collect Sales Tax
description: LEAD: A NEW YORK retailer recently advertised on a Connecticut radio station that there were seven and a half reasons to shop at his store. It was a not-so-thinly-disguised reference to Connecticut's 7 1/2 percent sales tax, according to Connecticut's State Revenue Services Commissioner, Timothy F. Bannon.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Scarsdale Aquatic Center
description: LEAD: A swirling vortex, a white-water ''creek,'' a whirlpool, a 10-foot water slide, a kiddy pool and an eight-lane swimming pool will be available to Scarsdale residents if a recently unveiled proposal for an indoor municipal aquatic center becomes reality.

title: Review/Theater; A Visit to the Lower Depths Among Life's Small Victims
description: The story is not new, and some of the dramatic devices used in telling it are awkward, but Jesus Gonzalez Davila's play, ''De la Calle'' (''From the Street''), is possessed by a kind of grim fury that leaves you feeling shocked, even horrified.

title:
GARDENING;
Time to Order Tree Peonies
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH it will be next spring before tree peonies are in blossom, now is a good time to consider adding them to the garden. Tree peony tops will begin to grow as soon as the soil warms up in spring, so fall planting is preferred to get roots established. Nursery orders can be mailed now for shipment when the summer heat subsides.

title: Brabham-Nissan Team Earns a Timeout to Bask
description: This is an open weekend on the International Motor Sports Association's Camel GT sports car racing circuit, and with one exception all of the teams that contest the races are breathing a collective sigh of relief and using the spare time trying to figure out how to coax more speed out of their cars.

title: Miss Isbrandtsen Wed To John Michael Dietz
description: Leise Isbrandtsen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jakob Isbrandtsen of Greenwich, Conn., and John Michael Dietz, a son of Mrs. Donald E. Dietz Jr. of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and the late Mr. Dietz, were married yesterday aboard the Wavertree, berthed at the South Street Seaport. The Rev. Richard H. Stearns, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: IN COMMAND: Admiral William J. Crowe
description: IT WAS 3:18 A.M. WHEN THE SECURE telephone rang beside Adm. William J. Crowe Jr.'s king-size bed in his quarters at Fort Myer, Va. The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff reached out a large, bare arm, propped the phone to his ear, and listened: in the Persian Gulf - where it was already late morning on this Sunday, July 3 - United States naval forces had just attacked some Iranian speedboats. The admiral grunted a sleepy reply in his soft Oklahoma drawl and he and his wife, Shirley, went back to sleep.

title: POSTINGS: Spring Lake Conversion; Condo Hotel
description: One of the few grand old hotels still left in Spring Lake, N.J. - the Hewitt Wellington - is now being divided into the seaside community's first condominium hotel. The town became known for its Victorian architecture when it was called the Irish Riviera - for the many wealthy Irish families who summered there. The 1892 hotel being reconstructed was modeled on their estates.

title: POSTINGS: Yorkville Options; Bonus Gym?
description: There is some urgency to Norman Segal's plans for the corner of 87th Street and Third Avenue. He hopes to top off the building he envisions there before the city dots the i's on new zoning rules.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: August 7, 1988
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 4 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles terrorists in England, Ireland and America. 2 5 WEEP NO MORE, MY LADY, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Dell, $4.95.) Love and murder at a swank California health spa. 3 16 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Warner, $4.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians and lawyers. 4 1 FALLEN HEARTS, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $4.95.) The scandals and horrors of her past return to haunt a bride in a backwoods town. 5 3 SARUM, by Edward Rutherfurd. (Ivy, $5.95.) Ten thousand years of British history, seen through the experiences of five families. 6 7 HEIRESS, by Janet Dailey. (Fawcett, $4.95.) How to solve your own problems while caring for other people's afflictions. 5 1 THE DANCE OF ANGER, by Harriet Goldhor Lerner. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $7.95.) Ways in which women can improve their personal relationships. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: A Dangerous Sports Edge
description: FOR EIGHT YEARS, Greg Hall was ''on the juice.'' Like thousands of athletes and body-builders, he was using anabolic steroids to gain a competitive edge. Now 30 years old, Mr. Hall, a fitness director for a major health and racquet club in Detroit, says that ''the drug nearly killed me.''

title: Flood the Market With Choice
description: ONCE again, the big steel companies - and their lobbyists - are beating the drums to renew the so-called ''voluntary'' restraint agreements. These agreements restrict the import of foreign steel into this country and are scheduled to expire in September 1989.

title: Towns Unite to Turn Vacant Plant Into a Place of Work Again
description: Wanted: Tenants with jobs for old factory in economically troubled Midwest area. 20,000 to 2 million sq. ft. available. Ideal distribution center. Will improve and subdivide. Very reasonable terms (also state and local incentives). Access to roads, RR, air transportation and markets for millions of Americans. River view. Call (309) 788-8880. Five years ago almost everyone in Rock Island and the other small cities clustered on the Mississippi here thought the developing tough times in agriculture and related industry were just another temporary trough in an economic cycle. Today they know better.

title: GORBACHEV DEPUTY CRITICIZES POLICY
description: In a clear challenge to the current direction of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's foreign policy, the second-ranking Kremlin leader, Yegor K. Ligachev, has publicly disagreed with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze on a key point of Communist ideology.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Newark-Buffalo Flights Increase

title: Mixed Signals in the Housing Market
description: WHAT is wrong with this advertisement: Charming Colonial, 4 bdrm. 2 1/2 baths, modern eat-in kitchen, fireplace, enclosed porch, in-ground pool, Greenburgh vicinity, asking $550,000?

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
A Monkey's Role
description: LEAD: THIS is the story of Amelia, who lives in Peekskill. Enticed by the glitter of the silver screen, Amelia toiled for years, never landing more than a few television commercials.

title: Hussein Cuts Off West Bank, Spites Arafat; Stay Tuned
description: IN April 1983, Yasir Arafat came to Jordan for a series of tense, and ultimately futile, talks with King Hussein on forming a Jordanian-Palestinian negotiating strategy for dealing with Israel. On the day of their first meeting, the P.L.O. leader's armor-plated silver Mercedes drove up to King Hussein's palace. The car door swung open, Mr. Arafat stepped out and, for one moment, no one was there to greet him. A second later King Hussein came rushing around the corner as though he had been reading the morning paper and his wife asked him to go and see who was unexpectedly knocking at the door.

title: Player and Charles Share Senior Lead
description: Billy Casper, who led the United States Senior Open after two rounds, took a bogey and a double-bogey to start today, so he opened the door for Walt Zembriski. Then Zembriski, the former ironworker from New Jersey, put two balls into water at the 17th hole to open the door for Gary Player, the defending champion, and Bob Charles, the southpaw from New Zealand.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: THERE are days - not too many, mind you - when Faith Stewart-Gordon wears a two-piece black dress printed with purple and red elephants. Before she pulls it out of the closet, she looks at it carefully and talks herself into thinking that it will look just fine. On it goes, and out she goes, and eventually she passes a mirror somewhere and almost has a heart attack.

title: FICTION
description: THE PASSION. By Jeanette Winterson. (Atlantic Monthly, $16.95.) ''It was Napoleon who had such a passion for chicken that he kept his chefs working around the clock.'' So Jeanette Winterson begins her tale of Henri, who slaughters and serves those chickens, and Villanelle, the sophisticated Venetian whose fate ultimately overtakes the simple soldier's. ''The Passion'' is Ms. Winterson's second novel (after ''Oranges Are Not the Only Fruit,'' which won England's Whitbread Prize). Its concentrated, beautifully detailed prose recalls the diction of fairy tales; its plot incorporates their magic, their shrewd wit and brutality. Two first-person narratives alternate: Henri, reflective and observant, brings the reader from the quiet French farm of his youth into Napoleon's camps in France, eastern Europe and finally Russia. Villanelle, bisexual and far from honest, deftly leads us through the mazy moral and emotional ambiguities of Venice's decadent gambling casinos. Ms. Winterson's characters are as vivid and haunting as figures in a dream. They pass easily from reality to miracle, as though the normally tough (if translucent) membrane between the natural and supernatural worlds were but a thin, discontinuous and shifting veil. Her theme is passion - religious, heroic and erotic -but her writing, for all its inventiveness, is thrifty, controlled and precise. Despite an incantatory repetition of phrases that threatens to break rather than cast a spell, ''The Passion'' is on the whole a deeply imagined and beautiful book, often arrestingly so.

title: Call to Support Soccer League
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Propaganda: Allied Issues
description: IN using stamps as propaganda in World War II, the United States preferred direct personal attacks on Hitler to the generalized anti-Semitism that the Third Reich displayed in forging British stamps. While Berlin boasted of false victories, Washington stuck to name-calling.

title: It Takes Two For a Rivalry
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''There will be some disappointment tonight in Germany and Japan.'' - Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas after passage of the trade bill.

title: In a Coffeeshop, Inflated Prices, Distorted Values
description: A NUMBER of years ago when I was newly married, my grandmother came to visit me. I had already learned to turn her off when she started to lecture me about my poor habits, especially when it came to money. After all, she had lived through the Great Depression, and everyone knew her ideas were a little warped.

title: Personal Ensign Wins Her 10th in Row
description: The last filly to win her first 10 starts was Ruffian, and the last to win the Whitney Handicap was Lady's Secret. Now there is a filly who has done both of those things, and today she earned a place in history alongside those two.

title: The Social Factor
description: I WANTED TO give low-income black children the same chance in life - through education - that I had had. I wanted to find out why the schools were not working for them and to help make them work. I was delighted to be assigned as head of an intervention team at two elementary schools, Simeon Baldwin and Martin Luther King Jr. in New Haven's inner city. All this was fine in theory, but I was totally unprepared for what happened the first day the students arrived. All hell broke loose.

title: To Live and Breathe in L.A.
description: LIKE Disneyland or Hollywood, smog has long been a symbol of Southern California. Now environmentalists, Government officials and the business community here are debating whether the cost of solving the intractable problem is the reining in of a local economy that has been as vibrant and unfettered as the air is dirty.

title: Why Does the United States Refuse to Pay Its U.N. Bill?
description: THE Senate made a significant but paradoxical gesture last month when it unanimously passed a nonbinding resolution acknowledging that the United Nations has been making some important contributions to world peace.

title: Phoenix Pressents A Mix of Satire and Vaudeville
description: ''Cream pies and existentialist philosophy'' is how ''Voidville'' has been described by its director, Michael Patrick King. He also calls it ''vaudeville for the 80's.'' But the revue is at its best when it settles for simply being a satirical revue and drops the pretentious act of mixing ''Sugar Babies'' with Kierkegaard.

title: So Who Really Spooked the Dollar, and Why?; More Japan-Bashing
description: To the Editor:

title: A Walk to Parade Dukakis's Fitness
description: The Democratic nominee for President of the United States went for a brisk walk today, alone in the rarefied Rocky Mountain dawn - except for 13 cars, a dozen reporters, eight aides, assorted politicians and supporters, five motorcycle outriders, four golf carts, two tour buses and a stretch limousine.

title: Bosworth's Tale
description: In a fortcoming autobiography, Brian Bosworth, the former all-America linebacker at Oklahoma, describes a Sooner football program in which players freebased cocaine, steroids were commonplace and National Collegiate Athletic Association violations occurred.

title: Jenny Holzer: The Message Is the Message
description: The selection of Jenny Holzer to represent the United States in the 1990 Venice Biennale illuminates a lot more than one admirable artist and the art she has helped to invent. It sheds light on curatorial thinking in the United States and on standards by which American artists are being evaluated. It demonstrates the enormous power of the summer exhibition circuit in Europe, on which the Biennale is one stop. If Holzer had not had a chance to shine on this circuit in 1987, she would not have been given the green light to represent the United States in the most prestigious international exhibition of 1990.

title: 38 Killed in India Ship Accident
description: A passenger ship carrying at least 300 Hindu pilgrims capsized today in the Ganges River in eastern India. At least 38 people were reported killed and hundreds were missing, the authorities said.

title: Bodies of 41 Torture Victims Found at Sikh Temple
description: Security officials in Punjab said today that they had found the bodies of 41 men, women and children who were tortured to death by Sikh militants in the months that the militants held control of the Golden Temple in Amritsar. The Indian police and military stormed the temple complex in May and ousted the Sikh rebels.

title: BREAKING THE DAT BARRIER
description: Things are looking brighter for digital audio tape, the first digital medium for home recording. A major legal obstacle to its launch has evaporated.

title: ProcrastinationIs the Mother Of More Work
description: SOME words, by definition, have a bad reputation. Take procrastination for instance: no one wants to have a whiff of that word smelling up letters of recommendation or hovering around evaluation forms. Procrastination is kid stuff. Grownups know those nasty things called responsibilities will always get you in the end, so why struggle against the inevitable.

title: So Who Really Spooked the Dollar, and Why?
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuomo Would Help Judge on Yonkers
description: Governor Cuomo told the Federal judge in the deadlocked Yonkers desegregation dispute again yesterday that he stood ready to help the judge enforce or modify his order for 800 new middle-income housing units.

title: AUSTRIA WITHOUT AUSTRIANS
description: REPETITION By Peter Handke. Translated by Ralph Manheim. 246 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

title: Israel Said to Seize Document On Establishing P.L.O. State
description: The Israeli television reported today that the authorities had seized a draft of a ''declaration of independence'' drawn up by Palestinian leaders who planned to set up a state led by the Palestine Liberation Organization in the occupied territories and parts of Israel.

title: Baby on Jet to Join Relatives
description: A baby girl found abandoned in a jetliner restroom only hours after her birth will soon be sent to live with her paternal grandparents in New York City, the lawyer appointed by a court to represent her said Friday.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: 'ROCKY AND DIEGO'

title: A MOLE WITHOUT PORTFOLIO
description: SPY vs. SPY Stalking Soviet Spies in America. By Ronald Kessler. Illustrated. 308 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $19.95.

title: State Will Review Site Near Walden Pond
description: Under pressure from conservationists, the developers of a proposed office complex near Walden Pond agreed Thursday to submit their plans for environmental review by the state.

title: New Penalties for Insiders
description: The latest scandal to involve stock trading based on insider information centers on Business Week magazine and information obtained from employees of its printer, the R.R. Donnelley & Sons Company. Last week new legislation was introduced in the House of Representatives that would attach stiffer penalties to insider trading violations. The bill increases the maximum penalty for criminal insider trading to $2.5 million for a company and $500,000 for an individual. It also provides a bounty for informants. The bill, already passed in committee, will most likely come up for a vote in the House in September. Will this legislation curb insider trading? John F. Hartigan Partner, Morgan, Lewis & Bockius and former assistant director of enforcement of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: THE REGION: To Burn or Not to Burn; The Medical Trash That's on the Beach Is Only the Start
description: NO one has been made ill, so far as is known, by the used hypodermic needles, vials of blood and other medical trash washing up on Northeast beaches. But the tides of medical waste still have ruined the summer for thousands of swimmers from Rhode Island to New Jersey, along with the shoreline businesses that depend on them.

title: ENGLISHWOMEN MAKE AN IMPACT AS DIRECTORS
description: Women directors are in the ascendancy at Stratford this season. Last year, Deborah Warner made her Royal Shakespeare Company debut with her stunning production of ''Titus Andronicus'' (starring Brian Cox). That production has since moved to the small Pit theater in the company's London home, the Barbican. Ms. Warner, founder of the Kick Theater Company, has followed up that initial success with her Stratford production of ''King John,'' once again demonstrating her ability to vivify one of Shakespeare's lesser works. At the same time this season, Garry Hynes (an Irish director and a co-founder of the Druid Theater in Galway) has made her own Stratford debut with ''The Man of Mode,'' an acerbic Restoration comedy by George Etherege. Di Trevis, by comparison an R.S.C. veteran, offers as her seasonal contribution a mainstage production of ''Much Ado About Nothing.'' Ms. Trevis's exuberant revival of ''The Revenger's Tragedy'' recently completed its engagement in the Pit, where it ran along with Ms. Warner's ''Titus Andronicus.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-19

title: Police Tape Gets National Attention
description: A 26-minute videotape recorded by a Metro-North Railroad police officer in Grand Central Terminal five years ago has caused a major shakeup at the railroad and become the focus of news reports around the nation.

title: Ms. Shelby Weds T. F. Anderson
description: Karen Adele Shelby, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Shelby of Montclair, N.J., was married last night to Timothy Farr Anderson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Anderson Jr. of Destin, Fla. Rabbi Harvey Goldman performed the ceremony at the Shelby home.

title: Sugar Ray Can't Stay Away From Ring
description: Many fans surely could have been knocked over by a feather when they heard the news Thursday that Sugar Ray Leonard had unretired yet again.

title: Watch Out for Mischief From a Powerful New Breed of Magnets
description: To the Editor:

title: IRAQI CHIEF MOVES TOWARD ACCEPTING TRUCE IN GULF WAR
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq said today that he was ready to accept a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war if Iran agreed to begin direct peace talks immediately after the truce, the Iraqi press service reported.

title: So Who Really Spooked the Dollar, and Why?; Harms, Not Helps
description: To the Editor:

title: Jocelyne Giroux, Investment Banker, To Wed David DeNunzio in October
description: The engagement of Jocelyne Antoinette Giroux to David Ames DeNunzio, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Dwight DeNunzio of Riverside, Conn., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Claude Andre Giroux of New York, parents of the bride-to-be.

title: Jersey Demands, and Awaits, Action From E.P.A.
description: WITH its ocean dumping, sewer overflows and monster landfill, New York has given New Jersey legislators plenty of ammunition for the ''sludge wars'' over how the Federal Government should deal with marine pollution. But in regard to medical wastes, the legislators have an additional target: the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Free Trade Is Ideology, Not Policy
description: At the 24th Constitutional Convention of the United Steel Workers Union, which just concluded in Las Vegas, Nev., a resolution was passed which called for ''managed trade'' between countries as a way to protect America's vital industries. Lynn R. Williams, the president of that union, talked with the Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman about managed trade, steel imports and competitiveness.

title: Movie Costumes on Display at Citicorp
description: ''The Glamour, the Glory and the Glitz of Hollywood,'' an exhibition of 20 costumes worn by some of the movie world's legendary performers, is at the Market at Citicorp Center, Lexington Avenue at 53d Street. The costumes are displayed on look-alike mannequins, and photographs show the artists in scenes from the films. Included are Vivien Leigh's ball gown from ''Gone With the Wind,'' Grace Kelly's evening dress from ''To Catch a Thief,'' and Claudette Colbert's wedding dress from ''It Happened One Night.'' Admission is free. Information: 559-2330.

title: THE SORCERESS OF BENNINGTON
description: PRIVATE DEMONS The Life of Shirley Jackson. By Judy Oppenheimer. Illustrated. 304 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $19.95.

title: Improve Aborigine Life, U.N. Urges Australia
description: A United Nations report urges Australia to improve conditions for its aborigines, saying that most of the country's original residents remain poor, unemployed and in ill health.

title: Headliners; In the Picture
description: When it came time to dissect a frog in her high school biology class, Jenifer Graham wanted no part of it. Her grade in the class was reduced from an A to a B as a result, and the California teen-ager, a vegetarian who opposes the killing of animals for scientific purposes, took the matter to court. In a lawsuit, she contended that school officials violated her rights by ordering her to dissect a frog over her conscientious objection. Last week, officials of the Victor Valley High School District offered a compromise: they would allow Miss Graham to learn about frog innards by viewing photographs of a dissected frog that had died of natural causes. That seemed reasonable to the judge, and he dismissed Miss Graham's suit. Lawyers for Miss Graham said they would discuss with their client whether to appeal the dismissal.

title: Calls Swamp Social Security
description: The Social Security Administration said it was inundated with telephone calls Friday after announcing it was offering free, individualized estimates of future benefits to workers of all ages. The agency's chief said she was adding 100 phone lines to handle the demand.

title: In the Summer, Dreams of Sleepaway Camp
description: ONCE upon a time, when my children were very small, and I, a working, commuting-to-New York mom, was very overwhelmed, I'd dream of having a few hours all to myself. Just a precious few - to read a magazine article all the way through, to stroll a shopping mall unencumbered, to speak on the phone without interruption. Simply to be alone with my thoughts seemed like heaven.

title: Is the Best of What We Have This Season Really Good Enough?
description: The other day my old friend Professor Harsch showed up at my front door. He had been away for two or three years, buried in the depths of the country; and now here he was back in town.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Clothes Make the Art ''THE things people wear says a lot about them,'' said Hedy Klineman, an artist from East Hampton. ''The spirit of a person is in his clothes.''

title: Risen Star: Media Creation?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Review/Music; Meditations and Ini Kamoze, Two Generations of Reggae
description: Two generations of reggae style, both full of life, shared a double bill Wednesday at S.O.B.'s, opening a two-night stand. The Meditations, a harmony group formed in 1974, and Ini Kamoze, a singer who made his first record in 1981, led crisply understated bands, putting secure grooves behind the singers' idiosyncratic mixtures of righteousness and playfulness.

title: Q And A
description: Leaky Windows in a Co-op Question: My building was converted into a co-op in June of 1985. In the year before the closing, the landlord, who was also the sponsor of the conversion plan, installed new windows. The job was botched and the windows leak, causing damage in many apartments. The board has been unsuccessful in getting the sponsor or the contractor to correct the problem. Do I have the right to make the co-op board responsible for repairing the problem and the damage? . . . A. C., Queens Answer: Yes. Stuart Saft, an attorney who is a vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives, said the corporation is responsible for correcting any deficiencies in the building's structure, including windows. Mr. Saft said that the board can take legal action against the contractor. Any warranties on the work given by the contractor would be assigned to the co-op corporation as a matter of course in the conversion plan.

title: Joseph A. Caruso, Executive, 67
description: Joseph A. Caruso, founder and chairman of the board of Bar Harbor Airways, died Friday. He was 67 years old.

title:
GARDENING;
Being Attentive to the Needs of Roses
description: LEAD: ALONG with many other flowering plants, roses often go into a summer slump. It's not uncommon for both growth and flowering to become sporadic or even stop. Much of this can be attributed to summer heat, but, when combined with drought, the results can be especially discouraging. Yet all is not lost.

title: Yvette C. Bender and James G. Rizzo Are Married
description: The marriage of Yvette Cecilia Bender, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Schuyler Bender of Bronxville, N.Y., and James Gerard Rizzo, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Dignan Rizzo of Bronxville, took place yesterday at St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church in Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. Eugene O'Brien, assisted by the Rev. James C. Finlay, performed the ceremony.

title: County Lists Historic Sites
description: COUNTY EXECUTIVE Andrew P. O'Rourke issued proclamations Tuesday to 10 county residents and organizations, placing their properties on the first listing of the Westchester County Inventory of Historic Places.

title: Review/Cabaret; Satire by Four Living Dolls
description: Although there is nothing amazing about the Amazing Pink Things, the mild-mannered musical comedy quartet currently appearing at Dannys' Skylight Room (346 West 46th Street), in one respect the group does live up to its name. Its garish costumes are encrusted with little pink nubs and beads that enhance its image as a quartet of living dolls.

title: THE WORLD: Q & A: John N. Turner; Canada's Liberals Battle the Trade Pact
description: CANADA'S opposition Liberal Party announced last month that its majority in the upper house of Parliament would block the legislation necessary to implement a free-trade agreement that Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, a Progressive Conservative, had negotiated with the United States.

title: A Change of Henrys
description: To the Editor:

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Canada Salutes Bowhead Whale
description: LEAD: THE bowhead whale, one of the world's largest sea mammals, will be featured on Canada's $100 gold coin this year. The coin will be the 13th in a series of $100 gold pieces issued annually since 1976 by the Royal Canadian Mint.

title: Men's Knockout Team Title Won by Three Match Points
description: One of the closest major finals in the 60-year history of contract bridge in North America ended here early this morning.

title: Another Chance For Doomed Dog
description: TWICE condemned to death, Bandit, described by his owner as a pit bull terrier, had his day in court in Stamford, Conn.

title: Question of the Week; Are the Red Sox In for Another Fall?
description: Time is on our side. Eventually, even the 70-year-old bridesmaid must walk down the aisle. THOMAS RADLO Westfield, Mass.

title: A Giant to Dominate Low-Rise Queens
description: FACE due east from the corner of 53d Street and Lexington Avenue in midtown Manhattan, and the huge new skyscraper taking up almost the entire plane of view appears to be just a few blocks away. But walk a few blocks in that direction and it becomes clear that the building is farther away than it seems - that it is, in fact, a Manhattan-sized tower sprouting up across the East River in Queens.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THANK GOD FOR THE ATOM BOMB: And Other Essays. By Paul Fussell. (Summit, $17.95.) Paul Fussell's essay ''A Well-Regulated Militia'' is a greater threat to the National Rifle Association than a battalion of St. Francises. His healthily perverse interpretation of the right-to-bear-arms amendment as a call to dig latrines leaves the N.R.A.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS;
description: THOUSANDS of people who are stung by bees every summer suffer only slight discomfort. Joseph Fevesh was one of the exceptions.

title: New Ordinance Would Stem Condominium Tide in Boston
description: A new Boston law on converting rental apartments to condominiums could become a model for other cities, according to advocates for affordable housing and real estate industry spokesmen.

title: Sarah Nicklin Is Married
description: Sarah Nicklin, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George Nicklin of Garden City, L.I., and Shelter Island, L.I., was married yesterday to James H. Moreno, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Moreno of South Plainfield, N.J. The Quaker ceremony took place at the Westbury (L.I.) Friends Meeting House. The bride, a fourth-year student at the Dartmouth Medical School, graduated cum laude from Bryn Mawr College. Mr. Moreno, a lawyer with the Legal Aid Society in Hartford, graduated from Lycoming College and the Vermont Law School.

title: Black Fraternity Getting Help Over Burned House
description: A University of Mississippi alumnus has guaranteed a $100,000 loan to rebuild what would have been the first black fraternity house on fraternity row, the school said Friday.

title:
DANCE;
Wit and Inventiveness Mark a Kinetic Panorama
description: LEAD: MURRAY LOUIS fluently speaks the language of kinetics. His A B C's include minutely vibrating movements, isolated body parts, quick directional shifts, pendulum-like arm and leg swings and a rich vocabulary of dynamic movements.

title: Baseball: Socialist as Apple Pie
description: While I am not myself identified with this current of thought, I continue to marvel at the indifference with which Americans of conservative view, those now commonly denoted as of the New Right, regard our commitment to socialist education, conditioning and indoctrination in our time. The latter is particularly significant as it affects the most vulnerable group in our society, the very young.

title: The SErvants of 2 Famous HOuseholds Recalled in Exhibit
description: LEAD: WHEN Mark Twain decided to define the word gentleman, it was not to any of his famed or wealthy friends that he turned for inspiration. His model was a servant, Patrick McAleer, who was the coachman for the family of Samuel Clemens for 25 years, dating to the time Twain married.

title: FICTION
description: AND BABY WILL FALL. By Michael Z. Lewin. (Morrow, $16.95.) Quietly, women authors have been introducing to the amateur mystery female sleuths who do more between adventures than get their nails wrapped. Now comes another sleuth, created by a male author, who can stand tall in this gathering crowd. Adele Buffington, an Indianapolis social worker, conducts herself like a mensch. She shows courage when a hulking intruder steals privileged information from the agency where she works. She uses her brains and initiative in linking the break-in to a larger pattern of events that includes, in addition to the murder of a fellow social worker, the criminal victimization of people who are too young, too old, too unsophisticated or too stupid to protect themselves. The caring heart that she wears on her sleeve also puts her in the same compassionate company as Lieut. Leroy Powder and a private eye named Albert Samson, the heroes of Mr. Lewin's two other Indianapolis crime series. For a while, it looks dicey when he sets his new heroine off on a romance with Homer Proffitt, the police detective who is assigned to the case. But, to Mr. Lewin's credit, he uses the partnership primarily for the contrast it offers between the feisty social worker's urban liberalism and the down-home cop's ''country wisdom.''

title: Wooing The Young Reader
description: CHILDREN in Moscow may be reading translations of books about Ellis Island and American Indian myths when an exchange of books takes place next year between the United States and the Soviet Union in celebration of the Year of the Young Reader.

title: Complaints on Agents Cited
description: THE State Attorney General's office has been handling a growing number of consumer complaints concerning talent, modeling and casting agencies that have set up operations in the state as a result of the booming television and motion picture business.

title: Political Notes; Mine Fields Await Democratic Party Chairman in the Bronx
description: Assemblyman George Friedman, the Bronx Democratic chairman, has had to deal with more political scandals and walk through more mine fields in the 18 months he has been Bronx leader than most politicians encounter in a lifetime. And, there is more to come.

title: Roosevelt Raceway at the Finish Line
description: JOHN COMBS and Paul Green have been grooming horses at Roosevelt Raceway for 29 years and 23 years, respectively. Seven days a week, they exercise, feed and rub down the horses and clean out their stalls. It is the only life they know. But now, with last month's announcement that the raceway will close, Mr. Combs, Mr. Green and the 73 other grooms who live rent-free in a dormitory at the track face the threat of losing not only their home but also, perhaps, their livelihood.

title: Tara M. Tierney Wed To Richard L. Ramsey
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J., Tara Maria Tierney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Donald Tierney of Morristown, N.J., and Vero Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Richard Lynn Ramsey, a son of Richard Lee Ramsey of Mobile, Ala., and the late Margaret R. Ramsey. Msgr. Owen J. McEnaney performed the ceremony.

title: Special Today; Education Life/Section 4A
description: * How specific academic, financial and social strategies are paying off for minorities.

title: Revere Beach
description: To the Editor: The piece on Revere Beach brought back happy memories of Sunday forays to that crowded beach with its 5-cent frankfurters and tonic, as we Bostonians called soda pop. Mr. Kotker talks of piles of Coke bottles but in my day Coke was unknown in Boston. Moxie, a strange bitter sweet mixture, was the reigning drink.

title: LIFE BECAME THE GREATEST FEAT
description: THE MAGIC WE DO HERE By Lawrence Rudner. 212 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $16.95.

title: Salem's Spell Goes Beyond Witchcraft
description: Jim McAllister, who calls himself the unofficial historian of Salem, Mass., conducts guided tours of his adopted hometown. ''There are four reasons why people come to Salem,'' he said. ''Maritime history. Architectural history. Nathaniel Hawthorne. And witches.''

title: Cynthia Hall Wed To R. M. Domine
description: At the First Presbyterian Church in New York, Cynthia Chesebrough Hall, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Goran L. Hall of Demarest, N.J., and Robert Michael Domine, a son of Annie N. Domine of Durand, Mich., were married yesterday by the Rev. John B. Macnab. Nancy Reynolds Hall was her sister's maid of honor, and Gregory T. Touma was best man.

title: No Joke, Director's Debut: 'Funny'
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH he founded and still heads a multifaceted, award-winning design and engineering firm that has made its mark in theatrical and movie special effects, Bran Ferren says, ''I have never taken life seriously.''

title: GIVING IS NOT ITS OWN REWARD
description: THE BEST CONGRESS MONEY CAN BUY By Philip M. Stern 321 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $18.95.

title: FICTION
description: OUTRAGE. By Dale Dye. (Little, Brown, $17.95.) So you'd like to write a thriller. Why not skim through some old newspapers until you get an idea for a plot? Maybe something like the bombing of the United States Marine headquarters in Lebanon in 1983. Now how about some characters? Say a brave colonel, a hard-bitten gunnery sergeant and an innocent corporal. And why not add a wacky Shiite and a Palestinian psycho? And, of course, an Arab Sophia Loren for the young corporal to fall for. You'll also need a wimpy American ambassador who worries more about red tape than reds. And a few other pencil-pushers to make life tough for the marines. Since everyone knows how it all turns out, you'll need something to keep your readers from dozing off. How about a little sex and a lot of dirty dialogue? That's Dale Dye's recipe for ''Outrage.'' Mr. Dye, a former Marine captain who served as technical adviser for the film ''Platoon,'' has managed to make his marines sound like marines. Unfortunately, it would take another marine to understand them - and an army of ellipses to make them quotable. Mr. Dye trips over the facts from time to time, blurring distinctions between Arabs and Iranians, Palestinians and Lebanese Shiites. But who cares about facts? More imporant, how's the fiction? Well, the prose, to quote one of Mr. Dye's more memorable lines, makes your ''head ring like a ten-penny nail beat with a greasy ballpeen hammer.'' Mr. Dye's third novel reads like the novelization of a television movie. Which isn't all that surprising since the publisher says it's going to be made into a motion picture. My advice is to skip the book and wait for the movie.

title: Blacks in Business Get a Tantalizing Glimpse of the Top
description: EARLY last year, A. Barry Rand was named as the Xerox Corporation's vice president in charge of the company's $4 billion marketing operation. A few months later, a group of investors led by Reginald F. Lewis, a Wall Street lawyer and financier, bought the Beatrice International Company, a food products company operating mainly in Europe, for nearly $1 billion. And just last month, Richard D. Parsons, an attorney, became president of the Dime Savings Bank of New York, the nation's 16th largest, with $10.9 billion in assets.

title: CENTRAL AMERICAN WRITERS MEET AMID THE DEATH SQUADS
description: LEAD: While Secretary of State George Shultz was meeting with Central American leaders in late June to discuss peace prospects in the isthmus, 35 Central American writers gathered in Guatemala City for the first time in 38 years. Though the Congress of Central American writers was sponsored by PEN International and received the backing of Guatemala's Ministry of Culture, writers and intellectuals have traditionally been the target of

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on July 10 about the Preston B. Bird and Mary Heinlein Tropical Fruit and Spice Park in Florida misidentified one fruit. The fruit, fuzzy and oval-shaped, is mountain soursop. Another picture caption with the same article characterized passion fruit incorrectly. It grows on a vine.

title: Headliners; Down the River
description: It might be said that Skip Storch put his mouth where his money was. Mr. Storch, who earns his living testing water in the New York City area, said he drank freely from the Hudson River last week on his way to becoming the first person to complete the 153-mile swim from Albany to Liberty Island at the southern tip of Manhattan.

title: 7 Homeless ProgramsTo Share $1 Million
description: LEAD: IT wasn't quite a lottery, but seven winning agencies will share $1 million in county funds to help Westchester's homeless.

title: It May Be Fun, But Is It Good Theater?
description: I don't recall the exact moment during ''Tony 'n' Tina's Wedding'' when the lines between make-believe and reality began to crumble. Midway through the four-hour wedding and reception staged by the environmental comedy troupe Artificial Intelligence, I stopped feeling like a member of the audience and became part of the raucous celebration. I toasted the newlyweds, shoveled down baked ziti, danced with the bride and chatted with members of the wedding party.

title: Hambletonian To Armbro Goal
description: Armbro Goal captured the 63d edition of the Hambletonian, the middle leg of trotting's triple crown, in straight heats this afternoon in a festive atmosphere at the Meadowlands race track.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Street Dumb
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
Photos by Twins: A Double Illusion
description: LEAD: MIKE AND DOUG STARN used to be billed as the Starn Twins, and one of the elusive mysteries in their work is which twin contributed what. The body of work looks as if one person, one sensibility might have made it. But above this issue, the Starns are important because they use photography as a raw medium, throwing it around much as a ceramist does clay.

title: A 1939 Weepie
description: THE OLD MAID Starring (left to right in photo) Miriam Hopkins, George Brent and Bette Davis. 1939. MGM/UA Home Video. 96 minutes. $24.95.

title: Cosmic Discoveries
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
High Quality in Englewood Cliffs
description: LEAD: IT sometimes seems that the more elegant the restaurant, the more mediocre the food, which makes it doubly pleasant to review a restaurant like Jamie's in Englewood Cliffs, where the quality of the food almost lives up to the attractiveness of the setting.

title: Question of the Week; Are the Red Sox In for Another Fall?
description: For Red Sox fans, this year is different. A lot of things are coming into place on the field, and the future, if anything, looks brighter than the present. Remember, it was Lou Gorman, the Boston general manager, who initiated all those long-ago plans for a continuously strong Mets team. PENELOPE PRUTSALIS Cambridge, Mass.

title: Strange Victory Scored By Mets
description: For an encore, Keith Hernandez sat in the dugout tonight, rested his tender hamstring muscle and watched the Mets defeat the Pittsburgh Pirates for the fifth time in six games in two weekends.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: WILSON;
Waiting and Worrying as anInterstate Link Approaches
description: LEAD: THE Wilson branch of the Windsor Public Library does more than just lend books. ''It's a little hub for the community,'' the branch manager, Gaye Rizzo, said. ''We sell stamps, we sell soda, we provide space for community activities and meetings.''

title: RECAPTURING BOBBY
description: LEAD: ROBERT KENNEDY In His Own Words. The Unpublished Recollections of the Kennedy Years. Edited by Edwin O. Guthman and Jeffrey Shulman. Illustrated. 493 pp. New York: Twenty-first Century Books/Bantam Books. $22.50.

title: The Right Track on Nicaragua
description: Senate Democrats have stumbled onto a good policy on the vexatious matter of contra aid. Their approach is to provide further food, medicine and clothing to the Nicaraguan rebels but to keep military aid in the far background. This tack prevents collapse of the contras and maintains the basis for negotiations. The Reagan Administration keeps proving anew that it cannot be trusted with more.

title: Lori Schimmerling Wed
description: Lori Ellen Schimmerling, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Schimmerling of Roslyn Heights, L.I., was married in New York last evening to Richard Scott Thal, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Thal of New York. Rabbi Norman Kahan and Cantor David Benedict officiated at the Plaza. Mrs. Thal, a nursery school teacher at the Stephen Wise School in Manhattan, graduated from the American University. Mr. Thal, a cum laude graduate of Tulane University, is a principal of Thal/Trent Associates, a manufacturers' distributor in Valley Stream, L.I.

title: U.S. and Soviet Youths Proselytize With Music
description: It is a project that exudes international brotherhood and good will, but its primary purpose is music. On Friday evening, the American-Soviet Youth Orchestra, 110 musicians from the United States and the Soviet Union, began a three-week tour of nine cities in both countries with a debut concert at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. Zubin Mehta, the director of the New York Philharmonic, conducted the performance. Sunday afternoon, the orchestra will play at Avery Fisher Hall in New York at 3 P.M., conducted by Dmitri Kitayenko, director of the Moscow Philharmonic.

title: Notebook; Wihout Boddicker, Yanks Might Lack an Ace in the Hole
description: The Yankees have had to summon Dave Eiland and Lee Guetterman from the minor leagues to start games (they had no interest in Mike Boddicker), John Candelaria has a sore elbow, Ron Guidry and Charles Hudson are on the disabled list (they had no interest in Mike Boddicker) and they don't know if they can trust Tommy John and Richard Dotson as starters any longer (they had no interest in Mike Boddicker).

title: Kelly Improving
description: Jim Kelly moved a step closer to returning to full workouts for the Buffalo Bills yesterday, throwing more than he had since camp opened three weeks ago.

title: Putting a Bloomingdale's In Towns Big and Small
description: AN article of faith in shopping center design is that a large nationally known department store lures customers, who then also spend money at the small, local, less well-known stores. Even as department stores have lost ground to smaller specialty shops, shopping centers with national retailers as anchors continue to outperform those that have only local tenants.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis McEnroe Advances: Fifth-seeded John McEnroe was on top of his game and temper in beating No. 15 Robert Seguso, 7-5, 6-3, to reach the finals of the $415,000 United States Hardcourts tournament in Indianapolis. Earlier, top-seeded Boris Becker ended the surprising run of a local hero by beating Todd Witsken, 6-3, 4-6, 6-4, in the other semifinal. Becker and McEnroe will compete today for the winner's check worth $50,575. Becker used his powerful serve to dominate the 28-minute first set, allowing Witsken just 7 points in the first five games. Then Witsken, from nearby Carmel, Ind., shook off his early jitters and served a love game to open the second set. He then led, 40-15, on Becker's serve, but the two-time Wimbledon champion reached deuce with consecutive aces. The game went to deuce three more times before Witsken netted a forehand return and Becker tied the set, 1-1. Witsken, 24 years old, began hitting the lines with accurate passing shots against a charging Becker for a crucial service break that gave him a 4-3 lead. He lost his serve again at 15 as Witsken took the second set to even the match. In the third set, Witsken was broken in the seventh game when Becker punched a forehand volley deep in Witsken's backcourt. Becker then held serve at love to take a 5-3 lead. Witsken took advantage of Becker's unforced errors to win the ninth game. But Becker reached back for an ace to go up 30-15 and gained match point when Witsken's forehand sailed long. He advanced when Witsken netted a service return.(AP) Track and Field Coe Upset in 1,500 Trials: Sebastian Coe's chances of defending his Olympic 1,500-meter title hung on the decision of the British selectors after he labored to fourth place in the heats and failed yesterday to qualify for the final of the British Olympic trials. In a big upset, the two-time Olympic champion rallied from sixth place in his heat, but his finishing speed was not there as he wound up behind three of his countrymen and failed to gain a spot in today's final at the Alexander Stadium. ''At 1,100 meters there was nothing there,'' Coe said. The first two finishers in each event automatically qualify for the Olympic squad. The selectors then pick a third entry at their discretion. Coe's only chance of defending his title is if the selectors overlook the claims of the also-rans in the final. While Coe struggled, there were triumphs for Steve Ovett and Steve Cram, the other two members of Britain's famed middle-distance trio. Ovett, the 1980 Olympic 800-meter gold medalist, won his 1,500-meter heat, while Cram posted an impressive triumph in the 800 meters.(AP) Johnson Wins: Ben Johnson, the world-record holder, won the 100-meter dash finals yesterday at the Canadian Olympic Trials in Ottawa, setting up a showdown in Seoul with Carl Lewis. Johnson, who set the world record of 9.83 seconds last year at the world championships in Rome, was timed in a wind-aided 9.90 seconds. The breeze of 3.7 meters a second was well over the limit of 2.0. Johnson was sidelined for nearly three months with a leg muscle injury before winning his heat Friday night in a slow 10.38. He was timed in 10.20 in yesterday's semifinal and won the final an hour later. Lewis ran a wind-aided time of 9.78 seconds last month in Indianapolis.(AP) Golf Bradley and Rosenthal Rally: Pat Bradley and Jody Rosenthal caught the early leader, Dot Germain, with birdies on the back nine yesterday to finish with 15 points and lead the field into an 18-hole final-round shootout at the $400,000 Pat Bradley International L.P.G.A. tournament at High Point, N.C. All three won $5,000, and will be among 18 players who will compete today for a $62,500 first prize. The 36-player field in yesterday's third round was cut in half, with Janet Anderson beating Sherri Steinhauer in a playoff for the last position. Germain, a North Carolina native whose Greensboro home is 20 minutes from the Willow Creek Golf Club course, steadied her game after an erratic start. After a 39-minute rain delay, Bradley caught Germain with a birdie at the par-5 16th hole when her putt hit the back of the cup, popped into the air and landed in the hole. Rosenthal hit a sand wedge to within eight feet of the pin and made her birdie to join the tie. Three golfers were tied for second with 14 points. Heather Farr had five birdies and a bogey, while Massey opened with a bogey and came back with her five birdies. Sally Quinlan birdied two of her last three holes to join that tie. Juli Inkster was alone at 13 points. Chris Johnson and Jerilyn Britz finished at 12 points. Martha Nause, Judy Dickinson and Ayako Okamoto were all at 11. Under the modified Stableford system, golfers receive 3 points for a birdie, 5 for an eagle and 8 for a double eagle. Players lose a point for a bogey and 3 points for a double bogey. Pars are worth nothing.(AP) Mudd Takes Lead: Jodie Mudd strung together three birdies on the back nine yesterday to overtake Tim Simpson and grab a stroke lead, at 67-203, after three rounds of the $953,842 St. Jude Classic at Memphis. Mudd, a six-time runner-up seeking his first Tour victory, chopped two strokes off par on the front nine, pulled even with Simpson with birdies at the par-4 14th and par-3 15th, then grabbed the lead with a birdie on the par-5, 545-yard 16th. David Rummells, who shot a 66, was alone in third place at 205.(AP) Thomas Advances to Final: Jeff Thomas of Plainfield West defeated P. J. Cowan of Pine Hills, 2 and 1, to earn his third final in the Metropolitan Golf Association Amateur Championship at the Plainfield (N.J.) Country Club. Thomas, the reigning New Jersey State Amateur who has earned that title five times, will oppose James McGovern of Hackensack in today's 36-hole final. The 23-year-old McGovern, the M.G.A. Open champion last year, had five birdies in a 5-and-4 victory over Malcolm Smith of Huntington Crescent. McGovern has 18 birdies in his three rounds of competition.

title: THE NATION: Political Concessions; Reagan Decides It's Time To Come to Aid of His Party
description: ALL Presidents are part legislator, part statesman and part politician. Last week, it was Ronald Reagan the politician who moved to the center of the White House stage, making two decisions that reflected the urging and the interest of Vice President Bush and his Presidential campaign.

title: Karpov's Comeback
description: JUST when it seemed that the marvelous rivalry between Gary Kasparov, the world champion, and his perpetual challenger, Anatoly Karpov, was about to degenerate into a lopsided thrashing by Kasparov, Karpov has sprung back with a vengeance.

title: U.S. Push on Exports Sets Up A New Battle of the Barriers
description: IN the 16th, 17th and 18th centuries, the major powers placed a high premium on exports as a source of national wealth and power. From exports came the bullion needed to maintain armies and pay the growing costs of civil government.

title: Infighting Over 'Outsiders'
description: Antiques shows in New York, London and Paris are adding - or soon may invite - foreign dealers, reflecting the increased internationalization of the antiques market. The stepped-up foreign presence in several major fairs comes at a time when the antiques market is booming and collectors are traveling abroad to acquire the rarest objects.

title: Cosmic Discoveries
description: To the Editor:

title: Cosmic Discoveries
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music; Russian Choral Society Celebrates 2 Anniversaries
description: The Russian Choral Society was founded in 1973 to encourage the study, publication and performance of the literature it is named for. As anyone who has sung in a choir that has delved into Russian music knows, this is a rich body of music, with characteristics that set it apart from the choral traditions of the Western European mainstream. Most notable among its attributes are a tendency toward modal rather than diatonic melodies (characteristic of the country's folk music, too), and thick textures founded upon especially low-lying bass lines. Hearing this music, one envisions monasteries of gigantic Rasputins chanting the lines effortlessly - although for American basses, it can be tough work.

title: Bears, Bulls and Students
description: OHIO STATE University's recent decision to entrust $5 million of its endowment to a class of business students surprised many. Schools, already in financial straits, were hit hard by last October's stock collapse, and Wall Street's uncertain mood since has dampened interest in money-management careers.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Marine Park
description: Twenty thousand people live in the Marine Park section of Brooklyn, and on Sundays, after a quiet morning in church or a quick jog through the park, many head for the municipal Marine Park Golf Course. Others navigate their small boats through Mill Basin and out to Jamaica Bay.

title: James Duncan Jr. Wed To Maeve F. Donovan
description: At St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Narragansett, R.I., Maeve Fitzgerald Donovan and James Thomas Duncan Jr., both graduates of Brown University, were married yesterday by the Rev. Richard J. Bushee.

title: A New Start For LeMond?
description: LEAD: Until he took the full force of a buckshot blast in his back, Greg LeMond didn't know what it was like to be inactive. He was the reigning Tour de France champion and looked ready to dominate the sport of pro cycling for many years.

title: There's Always a Catch
description: COMMIT A CRIME, they say, and the world is made of glass. I have long believed it. As a teen-ager in the Navy, I walked off my ship one shore liberty with half-a-dozen blank notebooks, property of Uncle Sam, hidden beneath the civilian clothes in my bag. At the end of the gangway, a crusty master-of-arms singled me out of the stream of shorebound sailors (most of them, I thought, with a lot more evil in their eyes than I), glared at the bag and asked me to open it. Caught red-handed, I mumbled something about my mother having sent the notebooks, an excuse dismissed immediately by the M.A., who merely pointed at Uncle's initials on the covers. I was sent back aboard to spend the glorious San Francisco weekend chipping paint off the old carrier's sides.

title: All Politics, No Defense
description: President Reagan's veto of the $299 billion Pentagon budget bill last week puts politics above national security. Though Defense Secretary Frank Carlucci and national security adviser Colin Powell had problems with aspects of the bill, they recommended White House approval. So did leading Congressional Republicans who helped negotiate the legislative compromises.

title:
GARDENING;
Being Attentive to the Needs of Roses
description: LEAD: ALONG with many other flowering plants, roses often go into a summer slump. It's not uncommon for both growth and flowering to become sporadic or even stop. Much of this can be attributed to summer heat, but, when combined with drought, the results can be especially discouraging. Yet all is not lost.

title: Jordan Shuts Office in Charge of West Bank
description: Jordan abolished its Occupied Territories Ministry today in another move to cut ties with the Israeli-occupied West Bank, the Jordan radio said.

title: Maine Dams Removing Obstructions to Salmon
description: The winding Saco River meets the sea at this southern Maine city and it is here that John Cadwallader fishes for brown trout, striped bass and bluefish. But he yearns for an Atlantic salmon.

title: Corporate Logos Spruce Themselves Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel's Gallery On a Mountaintop
description: Safad is a natural spot for an artists' colony. Atop Mount Canaan in Israel's northern region, it has a magnificent view of Upper Galilee's mountains and valleys. The 20th century has left few marks on the secluded town and its narrow stone-paved alleys, winding streets and ivy-draped houses built around courtyard gardens. Although Safad (also known as Zefat and Safed) is not mentioned in the Bible, it is reputed to be one of the four cities in Israel where a small Jewish population has always been present. (The other cities are Jerusalem, Tiberias and Hebron.) Artists and writers were drawn to Safad in the 1930's, but it wasn't until 1950 that a group of painters and sculptors formally established a colony in the historic Christian quarter under the auspices of the National Association of Painters and Sculptors, a professional organization. In the beginning only bona fide artists approved by the association were allowed to renovate the run-down stone houses. Eventually, though, others were permitted to buy, and now the quarter is about 50-50 artist and nonartist.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: CRAVING FOR JAZZ The New Haven Jazz Collective, a new cooperative, will open its rehearsals to the public from 5 to 7 P.M. today and the next two Sundays. The collective was formed in part to satisfy ''a craving among jazz lovers in New Haven for the real thing, unadulterated, not watered down,'' according to Allen Lowe, the tenor saxophonist and the spokesman for the group.

title: Ottawa Delights in a Dazzling New Museum
description: Seeing the sprawling new national Gallery here makes it hard not to wonder if there are not two Moshe Safdies. For there is a world of difference between this building, which is the architect's latest completed work, and the tower he recently designed for Columbus Circle in New York. The massive, angular New York tower, which was not built (it has now been replaced by a different design by another architect), looked as if it would have been a harsh and overpowering presence. The Ottawa museum is a sumptuous, even joyous, piece of civic architecture, almost noble in its public monumentality.

title: Anti-Bias Bill Needs Wider Scope
description: In its excellent coverage of Assemblymen Menendez's, Kenny's and Charles's bill on anti-bias violence (in the July 10 article ''Tougher Law Asked in Attacks on Indians,'' July 10), the New Jersey Weekly mentioned that the bill was modeled on similar legislation currently pending in the New York State Legislature. Anti-bias violence bills have passed and are now law in California and Wisconsin.

title: Q And A
description: Down Under Question: My wife and I are planning to ship our motorcycle to Australia and tour there and in New Zealand. Can you advise on making contact with local organizations that arrange home stays and with motorcycle clubs, and on how to arrange a stay at a sheep or cattle station? -M. H. M., La Palma, Calif. Answer: For Australia, one organization to contact is the Motorcycle Racing Club of New South Wales, 67 Dora Street, Hurstville, New South Wales 2220, Australia. The local telephone number is 605-9174. Hurstville is near Sydney. The club can advise on road conditions and the availability of gasoline in rural areas. Among several groups that make reservations for stays in private homes is Bed and Breakfast Australia, Post Office Box Q184, Queen Victoria Building, Sydney, New South Wales 2000 (telephone, 264-3155). This group can arrange accommodations with families in cities and small towns across the country, and it also books stays on sheep stations and cattle ranches. A similar group, Australian Home Accommodations, is represented by Islands in the Sun (760 West 16th Street, Costa Mesa, Calif. 92627; 714-645-8300), a tour company that sells packages to the South Pacific, including Australia and New Zealand. Another bed-and-breakfast service is Quality Homestay of Australia, 8 St. James Lane, Turramurra, New South Wales 2074 (44-4057).

title:
ART;
Hudson River Museum Spotlights the Column
description: LEAD: I some ways ''Columnar'' at the Hudson River Museum here is a snap to view. Every one of the works, painting or sculpture, contains either obvious or subtle columns, and we are made to remember that the column is one of the world's most ubiquitous shapes. The column doubtless derives from the tree and you don't need an almanac to tell you that there are more trees in the world than humans.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Bronxville, N.Y. $450,000 91 White Plains Road 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 24-year-old colonial; dining room, family room with fireplace, deck, attached garage; taxes $9,568. Hawthorne, N.Y. $210,000 32 Weed Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old colonial; living room with fireplace, family room, full basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,828. New Rochelle, N.Y. $300,000 40 Faneuil Place 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 66-year-old colonial; living room with fireplace, dining room, den, open porch, 2-car garage; taxes $3,657. Bridgeport, Conn. $225,000 531 Anton Street 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old colonial; large eat-in kitchen, possible professional use, 75- by 100-foot lot; taxes $2,730. Farmington, Conn. $241,000 2 Chassee Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 10-year-old Cape Cod; formal dining room, 2-car attached garage, two-thirds of an acre; taxes $1,673. Glastonbury, Conn. $134,000 45 Wrights Lane 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; walking distance to shops, buses and schools, 83- by 178-foot lot; taxes $1,321. OTHER AREAS West Babylon, L.I. $130,000 102 17th Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; den, 65- by 120-foot property, 1-car garage; taxes $2,300. Westbury, L.I. $259,000 15 Marlboro Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 35-year-old split level; den with wet bar, fireplace, finished basement; taxes $5,000. Millburn, N.J. $265,000 88 Elm Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 42-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, deck, garage; taxes $3,556.

title: Life Patents: Doubts Are Registering
description: THE House Judiciary Committee struck a compromise between farmers and the biotechnology industry last week when it decided that, in most instances, new forms of animals can be treated like mechanical inventions and patented. In deciding that farmers should be exempted from paying royalties on the offspring of the patented livestock they buy, and in specifically stating that humans should not be patented, the committee sent a strong signal that cultural, moral and ethical considerations are important factors in drawing up legislation to regulate new biological technologies. The legislation now moves to the House and Senate, and a vote could come in September.

title: Talks in Brazil Please Shultz
description: Arriving here today after a weeklong tour of Latin America, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said he was pleased with talks held in Brasilia with Brazilian leaders. The talks, held Friday, concerned Central American security and a trade dispute between the United States and Brazil.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Back-Office Tenants; Financial-Service Concerns Stay Put in Manhattan
description: Nearly 10 months after the stock market took its plunge, the financial-services industry still remains wary of committing major amounts of capital to moving back-office facilities from downtown Manhattan to cheaper office districts.

title: Panel Finds Less Support for U.S. Troops Abroad
description: Citing declining American political support for the deployment of forces abroad, a House Armed Services subcommittee warned today that Western Europe and Japan must rely less on the United States and more on their own forces and funds to defend themselves.

title: Rome
description: To the Editor: On a recent visit to Rome, we made two interesting discoveries. One was the Pension Suisse (56 Via Gregoriana) where we stayed three weeks. It was immaculate, efficient, well located, and it cost us $51 a day for two with Continental breakfast.

title: AFTER THE KILLING FIELDS
description: I was deeply moved by Barbara Crossette's article, ''After the Killing Fields'' (June 26). The story of displaced Cambodian families reminded me of my own Cherokee ancestors. Our people also were forcibly removed from our ancestral homeland. Many tribal groups were placed in the American version of a refugee camp - the reservation.

title: NONFICTION
description: YOUNG KATE. By Christopher Andersen. (Hutter/ Holt, $18.95.) For years Katharine Hepburn -a reclusive, independent figure - kept even the Hollywood gossips at bay. Here, in this entertaining, if slight, book based on conversations with Christopher Andersen, a writer and editor, she lets us in on her patrician past. ''Young Kate'' has the gushy sincerity of one of Miss Hepburn's lesser scripts. Her mother, Katharine (Kit) Houghton, orphaned granddaughter of the founder of Corning Glass and, like her own famous daughter, a tough-minded Bryn Mawr graduate, falls madly in love and marries Tom Hepburn, a dashing young surgeon from Virginia. He shrewdly parlays his wife's modest inheritance into a substantial fortune, and they settle down comfortably in a gabled Victorian cottage in Hartford, with ample servants to care for their five children, of whom Kate, born in 1907, is the second. Mother quickly grows restless, however, and goes off to embrace such controversial causes of the day as women's suffrage, birth control and socialism. Father, meanwhile, fights against prostitution and venereal disease. Ostracized because of their parents' unconventional pursuits, the children learn to think of themselves as tougher and better than those who spurn them. But a startling tragedy occurs: at the age of 13, young Kate discovers her beloved older brother hanging by a rope from his neck - a death she insists on believing accidental. After this she immerses herself in the make-believe world of acting. There is ample material here to suggest some deeply psychological connections, but they are never revealed or, perhaps, understood. Miss Hepburn's family remains her mainstay. Everyone lives happily ever after.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. The kitchen floor in our 1832 farmhouse is covered with layers of linoleum that we are taking off. The wood floor under this appears to be of four-inch-wide pine boards that we want to stain and seal. What is the best way to refinish this floor?

title: 200,000 Youths Said to Be in World's Armies
description: The world's armies include about 200,000 youths, some as young as 12 years of age, according to a report issued to a United Nations human rights meeting. Governments forcibly conscript many of the youths, the report said, and parents urge others to join to help the family gain food or money.

title: Bentsen Terms Veto of Military Bill Political
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, accused Republicans today of ''poisoning defense policy with partisan politics.''

title: Police Rules on Deadly Force Examined
description: TWO shooting incidents last month involving three Mountainside police officers have focused new attention on the rules governing the use of deadly force.

title: A Room With a Golden View
description: MICHELLE Diamono, a junior at California University in Pennsylvania, doesn't have to worry about her roommate blasting rock music and keeping her awake throughout the night. It's more likely her roommate will spend leisure hours telling stories about life during the World Wars and the Great Depression.

title: Elizabeth J. Levy Planning to Wed
description: Mrs. Theodore S. Sloane of Palm Beach, Fla., and Dr. Albert Levy of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Jane Levy, to Joseph Christopher Lewis, a son of Patti Lewis of Bel Air, Calif., and Jerry Lewis of Las Vegas, Nev. The couple plan to marry in December.

title: VIOLENT HORSES AND VIOLENT DREAMS
description: WHISTLEJACKET By John Hawkes. 194 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $17.95.

title:
GARDENING;
Being Attentive to the Needs of Roses
description: LEAD: ALONG with many other flowering plants, roses often go into a summer slump. It's not uncommon for both growth and flowering to become sporadic or even stop. Much of this can be attributed to summer heat, but, when combined with drought, the results can be especially discouraging. Yet all is not lost.

title: Martin Landau Rolls Up in a New Vehicle
description: Midway through a prerelease screening of Francis Ford Coppola's new film, ''Tucker: The Man and His Dream,'' one member of the audience turned to a companion and whispered: ''I thought Martin Landau was supposed to be in this picture.''

title:
ART;
Lee Krasner Emerges
description: LEAD: AMONG the artists who pioneered the New American Painting in the years immediately following World War II, Lee Krasner has long occupied a curious position.

title: COMPARING THE CANDIDATES
Mortadella: Bologna's Bologna
description: Bologna's most famous pork product is mortadella, the original bologna. Dubbed la Bologna in Milan and outside the region of Emilia-Romagna where it is produced, it is an impressively large, pale pink sausage with a finely ground pork forcemeat. Sound familiar? This is the exalted relative of our humble bologna. And the two are as different as their pronunciations. In this country, it is an everyday lunchmeat, an inexpensive product made of odd scraps of pork and other meats. In Bologna, it is a subtly flavored cooked sausage made from lean pork studded with small cubes of flavorful fat, and the best quality can cost as much as prosciutto or ham.

title: For the Children's Sake, Regulate Child Care
description: To the Editor:

title: New Year, Old Story: Jets Sacked
description: The offense, the part of the team that was supposed to work, generated such scant yardage tonight that it was outscored until the final minutes by its kick-blocking unit.

title: Robert Burke Is Engaged To Wed Andrea Kummel
description: Nina Kummel and Dr. Bertram M. Kummel, both of Convent Station, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter Andrea Jane Kummel to Robert Wayne Burke, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Jordan D. Burke of Short Hills, N.J.

title: Atlanta Panel Finds Racism Dividing City Police
