description: The Atlanta Police Department was divided by racism and failed to follow standard operating procedures in 1987 when it investigated charges that former State Senator Julian Bond was a drug abuser, a civilian review panel has said.

title: Musing on Mozart
description: To the Editor:

title: Betting That New Designs Will Bring Bigger Sales
description: IN the past, shopping center developers benefited from the nation's move to the suburbs and had their pick from among vast expanses of inexpensive land in new markets.

title: Alsace Journey: The Harmony Of Colmar
description: On a European trip early last fall I unexpectedly found myself with some extra days in Paris before my return to the United States. I was pleased. For once I would be able to enjoy my native city in a leisurely way, discover the Musee Picasso, explore in depth the Louvre, perhaps pay a call on ''La Dame a la Licorne'' in the Musee de Cluny. But Paris in that season proved disagreeable. It was still hot. A temperature inversion made the air harder to breathe than that of Mexico City. The museums were crowded.

title: The Blob as Social Barometer
description: Film lends extra poignancy To the passing of time, allowing an instant overview of the arc of a career. The Film Society of Lincoln Center's forthcoming ''New Directors/Newer Films'' series will make it possible to see these trajectories clearly, to trace the path of a Hector Babenco as he progressed from the raw ''Pixote'' to the brilliantly realized ''Kiss of the Spider Woman'' to the sodden ''Ironweed.'' It will show how George Miller went from the fiercely independent ''Road Warrior'' to the patently commercial ''Witches of Eastwick'' in only a few years' time, or how Spike Lee moved on from the short ''Joe's Bed-Stuy Barbershop: We Cut Heads'' to his mightily self-assured ''She's Gotta Have It.''

title: GOD'S POWER BROKER IN BOSTON
description: THE LAST AMERICAN PURITAN The Life of Increase Mather 1639-1723. By Michael G. Hall. Illustrated. 438 pp. Middletown, Conn.: Wesleyan University Press. $35.

title: Fresh Air Fund Attracts Young Professionals
description: What attracts young professionals to work for the Fresh Air Fund?

title: Hollywood's Version of Trade Wars
description: IN the patois they so artfully advanced, Daily Variety and the Hollywood Reporter are prepping to boost competish.

title: Social Evolution and the Scene at the Beach
description: This summer, I noticed how a day at the beaach has changed.

title: A Generaton's Fixation With Its Own Chidlhood
description: OVER the last several months, Hollywood has barraged us with a number of movies in which children suddenly become adults and, to borrow one film's title, vice versa. Film critics and columnists have said this suddenly popular genre, along with any number of nostalgia films and television programs, exposes a definitive characteristic of the baby boomer: an inexhaustible attachment to his own childhood. We are witness to the Peter Panning of an entire generation.

title: Brokhaven Seeks a Land Swap
description: LEAD: THE Town of Brookhaven is seeking to exchange 48 acres of pine barrens for a county-owned 55-acre parcel that the town could use for a recycling plant.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Quality a Concern in Breaking Up Estates
description: LEAD: Traveling along the winding roads of Nassau's North Shore is a trip back in time. Iron gates mark the entrances to secluded estates; horses graze in sight of white fences and red barns, and fields of sweet corn still line the roads.

title: The Healing Sun, the Rainbow's Return
description: ALL winter I wait impatiently for the warmth of summer. By the time I've threatened for the zillionth time that I'm throwing away all my ice scrapers, packing and heading straight for Arizona, I know I'm desperate.

title: Guiding Wedtech Trial, a Sure Hand
description: One of the rare points of agreement between the prosecution and the defense in the Wedtech racketeering trial was that, without the firm hand of Judge Constance Baker Motley guiding it, the complicated five-month trial probably would have gone on for another six months, risking mutiny by wearied jurors and running up huge costs for both sides.

title: An English 'Cosi' Set for Clinton
description: DON'T tell the Opera Theater of Connecticut that August is not a fine time to produce opera. The company has booked the Andrews Memorial Theater in Clinton for four performances of ''Cosi fan tutte.'' Accompanied by a 30-piece orchestra, a chorus of 25 and, in proper Mozartian style, conducted from the harpsichord by Robert Ashens, the opera will be mounted in 18th-century period costumes and sung in English.

title: Question of the Week; Are the Red Sox In for Another Fall?
description: Although the collective shadows of past tragedies loom large (Mike Torrez, Bill Buckner and Calvin Schiraldi), the present squad consists of the exciting blend of veterans, trade acquisitions and youngsters developed from the farm system. Roger Clemens, the consummate power pitcher, may extricate the franchise from the curse of Babe Ruth once and for all. This team seems capable of putting the distractions (the Wade Boggs and the Jim Rice incidents) behind them and concentrating on the matter at hand. The A.L. East has purchased the script of the other divisions, a competitive race in August. MICHAEL R. STINER Macungie, Pa.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Providence, R.I.; Amenities on The Waterfront
description: Ground will be broken this week for a $40 million condominium project that will rise here on the site of a former junkyard and nightclub in the Old Harbor District.

title: Tigers Top Red Sox And Widen Lead to 4
description: Doyle Alexander showed again today there's nobody better when the money's on the table.

title: Port of Call for Birds Off Cape Cod's Elbow
description: As an open launch approached the northern beach of Monomoy's north island, the passengers crowded into the cockpit raised a dozen pairs of binoculars to a dozen pairs of eyes. It was low tide. To the south and west on the tidal flats of Nantucket Sound, an immense congregation of shore and sea birds probed the shallows with bills of every contour and size.

title: Dori Goldsmith Engaged To Wed Eric David Cook
description: The engagement of Dori Beth Goldsmith to Eric David Cook, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome L. Cook of Plainview, L.I., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Marvin F. Goldsmith of Melville, L.I.

title: Living 40 Minutes Without Oxygen
description: BY ALL initial indications, 9-year-old Kendall Smith drowned in Dillon, S.C., on Jan. 12. Yet today he appears to be as active physically as any boy his age and mentally alert.

title: POSTINGS: Hartford Neighbor; 114 Units Serving Seniors
description: The snowbirds are returning home to roost, said Paul T. Liistro, the developer of an $11 million retirement community opening in October near Hartford. But as some abandon Florida for northern climes, many cannot find living space that caters to their needs. Retirement communities, which are thought to have originated in the Midwest and proliferated across the Sun Belt, are late in coming to New England. Hartford County, with 875,000 people, has only four such complexes, with 1,000 apartments, Mr. Liistro said. The Arbors at Hop Brook, with 114 units, will be the fifth. Thirty-seven units are rented.

title: Airport Alert System To Spot Wind Bursts Is Successful in Test
description: A new system that could go far toward conquering a persistent threat to aviation safety was put spectacularly to the test one day last month when three loud beeps summoned the Denver airport tower to action.

title: LESS CAN BE MORE
description: Robin Marantz Henig's aricle, ''Less Can Be More'' (Body and Mind, June 26) demonstrates some of the strengths and weaknesses of short-term psychotherapy. As a practitioner of brief treatment, I do not doubt its value. However, I hesitate to use the word ''cure,'' because it smacks of expectations of instant gratification that are, to my mind, a bane of modern American life. In a society characterized by fragmentation and alienation, let us not overly promote the notion of ''McTherapy.'' ROSALIND FORTI Chicopee, Mass.

title: GUNS SPEAK, POLICIES MUMBLE
description: THE MILITARY AND THE STATE IN LATIN AMERICA By Alain Rouquie. Translated by Paul E. Sigmund. 468 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $37.50

title: The Mets' Extended Family
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Poll Reveals Gains by Democrats Among Vital Middle-Class Voters
description: The Democratic Party is recapturing much of the crucial middle ground of American politics as the fall campaign approaches, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Catherine M. Zilliox Marries Arthur W. Malley 2d
description: At St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., Catherine M. Zilliox, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred M. Zilliox of Harrison, N.Y., was married yesterday to Arthur Wellington Malley 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Hamilton Malley of Greenwich. The Rev. David Riley performed the ceremony.

title: As Beaches Empty, Crowds at Pools Grow
description: FROM Greenwich to New London, the hottest topic of conversation this summer is the beaches. And the more people talk about the beaches, and the pollution and medical waste that has fouled them, the more popular pools get.

title: France
description: To the Editor: Although superhighways radiate out in all directions from Paris, traveling between them is apt to be on two-lane macadam roads, and if you find yourself behind a bicycle road race, as I did, it's best to forget American standards of highway speed and enjoy the scenery. Finally at Etampes the bike racers took a break and allowed traffic to pass.

title:
MUSIC;
Jazz, Beethoven and a New Ensemble
description: LEAD: LIONEL HAMPTON and his Big Band will perform old and new numbers at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn Thursday night at 8. Some of the selections were recently composed by the jazz artist, who has been dubbed ''king'' of both the vibes and the drums.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: A MIRROR FOR PRINCES. By Tom de Haan. (Knopf, $18.95.) This first novel by the pseudonymous Tom de Haan is a melding of genres: heroic fantasy, family power struggle, a cri de coeur from the burned-out youth of yet another - in this case feudal - society. King Reyhnard, a monarchical dropout living in secret poverty with a half-witted peasant girl, tells of his cruel and powerful father (who died), his two beloved brothers (who died), another brother he didn't love quite so much (who died), a sister he was in love with (likewise), and a calculating courtesan, his wife, who has in some sym

title: A Landed Degree
description: REAL ESTATE study. Until recently the very words brought to most minds the sort of schools that advertise on matchbook covers, offering no-frills courses for would-be brokers and investors.

title: Pamela Ellsworth Davis to Be Married To William B. Van Ingen in November
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael Hamilton Davis of New York and Stonington, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Ellsworth Davis, to William Booth Van Ingen, the son of Herbert Pratt Van Ingen of New York and Locust Valley, L.I., and Mrs. Evan D. Jennings 2d of Pittsburgh and Ligonier, Pa.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THE Department of Environmental Protection has released eight osprey chicks near the Wanaque Reservoir this summer in an effort to reintroduce the bird to northern New Jersey.

title: For $60, a License to Kill
description: The National Rifle Association promotes itself as an organization of wholesome sportsmen and gun collectors. A recent article in Newsday shows that its adherents also include another type: the inner-city gun runner.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Years in Court; Bhopal Suit Marches On, In Circles
description: SOON after toxic gas escaped from the Union Carbide pesticide plant in Bhopal in 1984, experts predicted that it could take years to untangle the lawsuits surrounding the worst industrial accident in history. Their fears have proven correct.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The dust clouds were so dark you could see them 10 miles away. But there wasn't a thing I could do to save the land.

title: INSIDE
description: Challenge to Gorbachev

title: Valve for Shuttle Is Delivered
description: The small valve that halted the firing of the space shuttle Discovery's main rocket engines was being removed today to prepare the craft for another attempt at the test, which could come as early as the middle of next week.

title: COMIC RELIEF FROM EXISTENTIAL DREAD
description: LEAD: WHAT IS IT THEN BETWEEN US? By Ehud Havazelet. 177 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $15.95.

title: IN PRAISE OF RUGGED MICROSOCIETIES
description: LEAD: MIDDLE AMERICAN INDIVIDUALISM The Future of Liberal Democracy. By Herbert J. Gans. 217 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95.

title: Political Marketing; TV's New Age of Thrust and Parry
description: The Republican Party struck first with a roundhouse pounding: a two-and-a-half-week, 50-state campaign on network, cable and local television costing $4 million.

title: New Journal Looks at Old Ways
description: It was only a matter of time. How long, after all, could the current fascination of American audiences with old music, old instruments and supposedly authentic performances go on without spawning a native special-interest publication? Not another minute. I have at at hand the first issue of Historical Performance, the journal of Early Music America, an organization whose stated aims are to improve professional standards, expand audiences in the United States and Canada, encourage historically informed performances, develop new educational programs and in general serve as a spokesman and rallying ground for the early-music movement.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bay Shore $155,000 73 Maple Avenue 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 28-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, enclosed porch, 1-car garage; taxes $3,300. Copiague $170,000 480 West Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 41-year-old Cape Cod; new eat-in kitchen, den, 1-car attached garage; taxes $3,800. East Northport $179,500 204 4th Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, fenced yard, aluminum siding, 1-car garage; taxes $2,200. Mineola $213,000 43 Juniper Avenue 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; dining room, new kitchen, beamed ceilings, attic; taxes $1,800. West Babylon $130,000 102 17th Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; den, 65- by 120-foot property, 1-car garage; taxes $2,300. Westbury $259,000 15 Marlboro Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 35-year-old split level; den with wet bar, fireplace, finished basement; taxes $5,000. OTHER AREAS Bronxville, N.Y. $450,000 91 White Plains Road 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 24-year-old colonial; dining room, fireplace, deck, attached garage; taxes $9,568. Bridgeport, Conn. $225,000 531 Anton Street 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old colonial, large eat-in kitchen, possible professional use, 75- by 100-foot lot; taxes, $2,730. Millburn, N.J. $265,000 88 Elm Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 42-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, deck.

title: PLAYING TO WIN
description: As a competitive swimmer when I was a girl, I lived for those moments when, body poised, toes tingling, I would hear the official intone: ''Judges and timers ready? On your mark, get set. . . .'' (Hers: ''Playing to Win,'' by Margaret A. Whitney, July 3). I would crack-splash into the pool and go for it, to the piercing cries of my mother, at the pool's edge: ''C'mon, Mal!'' Between events, my father would boast, in my presence, ''You should see that kid swim!''

title: A GIFT FOR THE CHEERFUL LIFE
description: LEAD: THE NATIVE By David Plante. 122 pp. New York: Atheneum. $13.95.

title: THE REST OF HIM
description: RECOLLECTIONS OF A LIFE By Alger Hiss. Illustrated. 240 pp. New York: Seaver Books/Henry Holt & Company. $19.95.

title: Capturing the Fading Signs of America as Art
description: LEAD: ROBERT COTTINGHAM is working on two paintings - one featuring a barber, the other a theater marquee in Brooklyn - in his rambling studio, which was once a dairy barn, next to his 1758 house in Newtown.

title: Don't Sell the Piano Player
description: ''ALL I need,'' I said last year as I began a legal separation toward an eventual amicable, uncontested divorce, ''is a room with a closet, space for a desk, a chair, and, er - what would you call them, odds and ends?''

title: A Zippier ZIP
description: To the Editor:

title: At Long Last, an Improved DOS
description: CAN you teach an old DOS new tricks? Definitely. That is made clear by version 4.0 of the Disk Operating System from the International Business Machines Corporation and the Microsoft Corporation. Upgrading to DOS 4.0 ($95 for those who want to upgrade from an earlier version, or $150 for new customers) is well worth the cost and effort for anyone who has been frustrated by cryptic symbols and commands like A< or COPY B:SUBDIR*.* C:JEEPERSIMLOST.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: TEDDY KOLLEK: Mayor of Jerusalem. By Naomi Shepherd. (Bessie/Harper & Row, $16.95.) Teddy Kollek, Mayor of Jerusalem since 1965, has struggled to maintain peaceful coexistence between Arabs and Jews who live in the biblical city. A secular Jew from Vienna, the 76-year-old Mayor Kollek believes everyone should get the social, economic and legal benefits of the city and has raised funds from around the world to build skyscrapers, parks, museums, schools.

title: No Savings In Lives or Money With Death Penalty
description: THE recent Federal drug bill reintroducing capital punishment for certain drug-related murders in an election year is further evidence that politics never changes. You can fool some of the people, but, one hopes, not all of the time.

title: Jeanne Voltz, Food Writer, Marries Frank MacKnight
description: The marriage of Jeanne Appleton Voltz, a food writer and freelance editor, to Frank Barnett MacKnight, a co-owner of MVP, a video production company in Lincoln, Neb., took place yesterday in New York. The Rev. Edward C. Horne performed the ceremony in the chapel at the United Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew.

title: Elderly and Young Mothers To Join in Renovated Hotel
description: Renovation work has begun to turn an Upper West Side hotel into an experimental residence in which homeless teen-age mothers and their children will be housed together with elderly people.

title: UP FROM CHILDHOOD
description: OUT ON THE MARSH By David Updike. 168 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $16.95.

title: When Japan Captured the French Imagination
description: When Admiral Perry sailed into Kurihama harbor in 1853, reopening Japan to active trade with the West, he unleashed an esthetic fusillade that was heard round the Western art world, loudest of all in its capital, the city of Paris. As Japanese prints, albums and objects began to arrive in plenty from the East, a kind of mania set in among artists, critics, designers and collectors alike. And when Japan proudly sent a large cache of art and objects to the 1867 International Exposition in Paris, that enthusiasm began to reach a broader public. The rest, as writers so often like to say, is history, but it is a history in which art, fashion and commerce, deep understanding and superficial exploitation, invention and mimickry mingle in about equal parts. It is also a history that forms one of the most exciting chapters in the story of 19th-century art and to which several generations of scholars and curators have devoted much time and thought in both written and exhibition form.

title: The Computer Revolution Revised
description: REMARKABLE new technology is introduced into the school system and experts predict education will be revolutionized. The technology will, as never before, allow the widespread dissemination of new concepts and ideas that will stimulate young minds and free the teacher for more creative pursuits. Yet the magic fails to materialize, and within a few years articles appear in the popular press asserting that the failure, obviously, arises from teachers not being skilled enough in the new technology.

title: Paterno Casts Vote SPORTS PEOPLE;
description: Based on the braying by Pennsylvania Democrats, you'd have thought the Republicans were out to transform the Nittany Lions into the Nittany Elephants. Actually, to the state's Democrats, what the Republicans are up to is worse. They have recruited Joe Paterno to give a seconding speech for George Bush at the Republican national convention.

title: Soda from SoNo angers SoHo
description: SAYING he believed that a hometown soft drink would help promote South Norwalk, where his parents own a deli, Ray Contone created SoNo Seaport Soda, which uses a common shortening for the area. But the move has angered the maker of a better-known drink, Soho Natural Soda.

title: Parents Turned In to Police
description: Two brothers turned in their parents to the police Thursday after finding marijuana plants growing behind their house, the police said. The brothers, 11-year-old Timothy Gustafs and 9-year-old Christopher Gustafs, said they acted because they did not want their 15-month-old sister to be exposed to illegal drugs.

title: 'Mass Appeal': 2 Roads to Rome
description: ''MASS APPEAL,'' by Bill C. Davis, seems at first like a routine examination of classic conflicts within the Roman Catholic Church. However, as beautifully detailed in the current production at Theater Three in Port Jefferson, ''Mass Appeal'' uses arguments between traditionalists and reformers as a container to hold complexities that transcend church dogma.

title:
GARDENING;
Being Attentive to the Needs of Roses
description: LEAD: ALONG with many other flowering plants, roses often go into a summer slump. It's not uncommon for both growth and flowering to become sporadic or even stop. Much of this can be attributed to summer heat, but, when combined with drought, the results can be especially discouraging. Yet all is not lost.

title: Cool, Classic Shorts For a Sultry Summer
description: CINEMATICALLY speaking, shorts precede the main feature.

title: 14 ARE IN HOSPITAL AFTER DERAILMENT
description: Thirteen passengers and an employee of Amtrak remained hospitalized today after a 12-car train derailment that was blamed on tracks warped by near-100-degree heat.

title: Correction
description: A caption accompanying a photo of the pianist Rudolf Firkusny in the Arts and Leisure section today gives the incorrect time for his performance at Caramoor this afternoon. It will begin at 5:30 P.M.

title: Congressman Lived for Month at Lobbyist's Home
description: Representative Bill Chappell Jr. lived temporarily at the home of a lobbyist for the General Electric Corporation in 1986, the same year the lawmaker wrote a letter to an Army official regarding a gun contract that the company was seeking, Defense Week magazine reported today.

title: Rachel Love Has Wedding
description: Rachel Cornelia Love, a daughter of James Spencer Love and Mrs. George I. Reynolds, both of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Per Arne Lorentzen Jr., a son of Mrs. Robert Pollard of Palm Beach, Fla., and Sugar Hill, N.H., and the late Mr. Lorentzen. The Rev. Robert Pollard, an Episcopal priest and the stepfather of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the home of Mrs. Thomas Baird Appleget, the bride's grandmother.

title: Revere Beach
description: To the Editor: Norman Kotker's article on Revere Beach (Travel, May 15) brought back many boyhood memories.

title: The Jobs They're In When School Is Out
description: LEAD: IN the past, New Jersey teachers often took summer jobs as vendors, clerks, painters, waiters and attendants. Three teachers in this Ocean County community have sidestepped those traditional sidelines and are having summer experiences in unusual fields.

title: Question of the Week; Are the Red Sox In for Another Fall?
description: With the Bosox hitting (tops in the majors), all they needed was one more solid pitcher to get to the playoffs. They acquired that and more with Boddicker. And when they reach the playoffs, a time where the three-man staff comes into play, Clemens, Hurst and Boddicker will lead the Sox to the championship. WILLIAM ORTNER New York

title: House Unit Approves Seizing Of Land Near Manassas Park
description: A bill authorizing the Federal Government to seize more than 500 acres of a developer's land adjacent to a historic Civil War battlefield has been cleared for House action, possibly next week.

title: Soviets Plan Atomic Rocket For Manned Mission to Mars
description: The Soviet Union hopes to develop an atomic-powered rocket engine to provide the propulsion for a manned mission to Mars early in the 21th century, a Soviet scientist has said.

title: Lead Tests Are Urged for All Preschoolers
description: LEAD: THE coordinator of Connecticut's lead poisoning prevention program is urging that all pre-school children in the state be tested annually for lead poisoning.

description: Edison $144,000 137 Winthrop Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, family room, patio; taxes $1,414. Iselin $159,000 1051 Woodruff Street 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 37-year-old expanded Cape Cod; den, formal dining room, patio; taxes $1,639. Millburn $265,000 88 Elm Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 42-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace in living room, deck, 1-car garage; taxes $3,556. Nutley $250,000 249 Nutley Place 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 20-year-old ranch; 2-zone heating, family room, patio, 2-car garage; taxes $4,712. Ramsey $322,000 33 Ronald Court 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1 1/2-year-old colonial; central air conditioning, deck, eat-in kitchen; taxes $3,661. Whippany $245,000 5 Deerfield Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; fireplace, central air conditioning, full basement, 2-car garage; taxes $1,931. OTHER AREAS Bronxville, N.Y. $450,000 91 White Plains Road 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 24-year-old colonial; dining room, deck, garage; taxes $9,568. title: Correction
description: An article July 17 about plans to build a replica of the inventor Guglielmo Marconi's yacht Elettra misstated the time it took for the first trans-Atlantic radio message to travel from England to Newfoundland. The transmission of the signal was virtually instantaneous; however, it took three days for Marconi's receiving equipment to register the message in Newfoundland.

title: Where the Fabric Of History Is Silk
description: LEAD: A man and a woman pore over swatches of the rarest silk. They have flown 6,000 miles to find inspiration for the latest designs of Yamato, a Japanese kimono maker, at the Museum of Fabric in Lyons, a French city with its own vocabulary.

title: The Political Kiss of Death
description: As the flap over Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's mental health indicates, we have created an impossible situation for our political leaders, a situation that undermines both them and the quality of our political life. Few ambitious politicians now dare seek out professional help for psychological, marital, alcohol or drug problems for fear they will be labeled ''mentally unbalanced.''

title: Care of Animals Teaches Teamwork
description: CHILDREN and animals - they have always been a natural combination. Animals can teach children about responsibility, love and even how to handle death.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Should Sugar Ray Leonard Box Again?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: The Producer as Musician
description: XYZ, a singer, steps out on stage in a music video. He starts a slow, graceful dance, surrounded by women. Dressed in a black hat, leather pants and silver studs, it's obvious that he's trying to build an image, however banal. The music, with a bass line that courses like a river, fits the image. He starts singing, and that too fits. The artist has a personality, and he's translating his personality into music. Right?

title: American Words
description: I WAS A small child when I heard the words from my neighbor's apartment: ''You shake my nerves and you rattle my brain . . .'' It was in Poland, in 1958, just five years after Stalin's death, and these were the first English words I had ever encountered. My redheaded neighbor, who was a singer, took advantage of the first rustle of freedom and bravely changed her repertoire from the Russian ''Dark Eyes'' to ''Great Balls of Fire.''

title: James E. Fleming And Lisa L. Lang, A Lawyer, Marry
description: At the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in Manhattan, Lisa Laverne Lang, a daughter of Cranford L. Lang of Sarasota, Fla., and Fern A. Lang of Little Rock, Ark., was married yesterday to James Edward Fleming, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Fleming of Nevada, Mo. The Rev. Carl B. Nelson performed the ceremony.

title: Too Late to Save a Wetland
description: HOW do you kill a wetland? First you get a zoning variance, then you bring in the bulldozers.

title: Heidi Alice Eklund Weds Bruno Gardien, a Banker
description: Heidi Alice Eklund, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Eklund of Hauppauge, L.I., was married yesterday to Bruno Gardien, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Gardien of Grenoble, France, and Rome. The Rev. Peter Colapietro prformed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

title: Local Economies
description: To the Editor:

title: STREETSCAPES: CBS Studio on 52d; At One Time, the 'Last Word in Broadcasting Design'
description: For nearly 50 years it was one of the most unusual buildings in midtown, with a seven-story-high modernistic facade, blank except for a strip of windows at the top. But earlier this year the ground-floor studio space in the CBS Studio Building at 49 East 52d Street was taken over by a Duane Reade drugstore, and a storefront has now replaced the ground floor's 50-foot expanse of gray and blue terra-cotta blocks.

title: DATABANK: August 7, 1988

IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: CROWNS OF THORNS AND GLORY. Mary Todd Lincoln and Varina Howell Davis: The Two First Ladies of the Civil War. By Gerry Van der Heuvel. (Dutton, $19.95.) Today news coverage of the White House automatically includes stories about Presidents' wives. However, before Mary Todd Lincoln and Varina Howell Davis became the First Ladies of their day (the one of the United States, the other of the Confederacy), a woman's name usually appeared in the newspapers no more than three times - when she was born, when she married and when she died.

title: Correction
description: A front-page article July 24 about the effect of air pollution on Appalachian forests misidentified a research group based in Washington that investigates stresses on trees and field crops. It is the World Resources Institute. MET

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. The kitchen floor in our 1832 farmhouse is covered with layers of linoleum that we are taking off. The wood floor under this appears to be of four-inch-wide pine boards that we want to stain and seal. What is the best way to refinish this floor?

title: At Home With Jane Austen
description: On the corner of a once-busy road to the ancient cathedral town of Winchester and a byway to the village of Gosport, there is an unassuming late 17th-century brick cottage that was built as the home of a farm bailiff. It stands alongside a few smaller cottages across the street from what is now Cassandra's Cup Tea Shop and a small antique store with blue and white china in the window.

title: San Francisco
description: To the Editor: In answer to L. R. of Toms River, N.J. (Q & A, May 15), Stanley Carr suggested that by sending $1 for postage to Convention and Visitors Bureau, Post Office Box 6977, San Francisco, Calif. 94101, one would receive a lodging guide containing information on small hotels. On May 17 I sent a $1 check, which was deposited promptly. But three followup requests, the last one containing a photo copy of the canceled check, failed to produce the material. BERNARD KAPLAN Brooklyn

title: Question of the Week; Are the Red Sox In for Another Fall?
description: Being a true Red Sox fan is a strange and immutable condition. For better or for worse, it is what you are. And there is no going back. MICHAEL EDWARD O'CONNOR New York

title: Treatment for Boyd
description: Doctors have treated the problem in Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd's right shoulder, but Boyd still doesn't know how long it will be before he can start pitching again for the Red Sox.

title: A Cast of Hundreds In Nonstop Action
description: AN event scheduled for the first half of April, 1989 will have many unusual features, and may rate a mention in the ''Guinness Book of World Records.'' It is the Marathon Bridge Battle of the Sexes to be played in New York and Paris with celebrity, charity and sponsor involvement.

LEAD: A sailboat mobile with moveable sails hangs in the bedroom of Kay Yow's home in Cary, N.C., a plaque dangling beneath it. ''You can't change the direction of the wind, but you can adjust your sails,'' the plaque reads.

title: Southern Writers
description: To the Editor:

title: BEST SELLERS: August 7, 1988
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 THE CARDINAL OF THE KREMLIN, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan races to the rescue of America's highest-ranking secret agent in the Soviet Union. $2 1 6 ALASKA, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $22.50.) The history of the 49th state told in fictional form. 3 2 5 TO BE THE BEST, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The Harte department store dynasty, founded by ''a woman of substance,'' undergoes emotional and financial strains. 4 3 40 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 5 4 13 ZOYA, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) One woman's story, from St. Petersburg during the Russian Revolution to contemporary New York. 6 * 9 4 TIMOTHY'S GAME, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam, $18.95.) A stock market operator investigates scams on Wall Street. 7 5 16 LOVE IN THE TIME OF CHOLERA, by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. (Knopf, $18.95.) A Colombian poet's perdurable love for a woman is tested by life's changing conditions. 8 12 2 DOCTORS, by Erich Segal. (Bantam, $19.95.) The life stories of five members of Harvard Medical School's class of 1962. 9 6 22 THE ICARUS AGENDA, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $19.95.) A congressman's secret dealings with terrorists may bring him the Presidency - or death. 10 7 5 A THIEF OF TIME, by Tony Hillerman. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) Tracking down a missing archeologist, missing artifacts and a murderer in the Indian ruins of New Mexico. 11 10 25 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. 12 * 8 13 PEOPLE LIKE US, by Dominick Dunne. (Crown, $19.95.) The rivalry of two clans in New York society and one man's role in it. 13 11 10 CRIMSON JOY, by Robert B. Parker. (Delacorte, $16.95.) The private eye Spenser in pursuit of a serial lady-killer in Boston. 14 13 16 ROCK STAR, by Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The glory and anguish of three rock-and- roll performers in tinselly southern California. 15 * 1 THE INDIA FAN, by Victoria Holt. (Doubleday, $18.95.) A shocking murder witnessed by a British woman during the Sepoy Rebellion changes the course of her life. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 16 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A British scientist's review of efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 2 2 8 TALKING STRAIGHT, by Lee Iacocca with Sonny Kleinfield. (Bantam, $21.95.) More experiences and opinions of the Chrysler chairman. 3 4 4 GENERATION OF SWINE, by Hunter S. Thompson. (Summit, $18.95.) Commentary on the current decade. 4 3 34 TRUMP, by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Random House, $19.95.) The career and business style of the New York entrepreneur. 5 11 3 THE DUCHESS OF WINDSOR, by Charles Higham. (McGraw-Hill, $17.95.) The life of the woman from Baltimore who married King Edward VIII. 6 7 8 A TRAIL OF MEMORIES, edited by Angelique L'Amour. (Bantam, $12.95.) Quotations from the works of Louis L'Amour, compiled by his daughter. 7 * 10 7 PICASSO, by Arianna Stassinopoulos Huffington. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) A portrait of the artist as ''creator and destroyer.'' 8 * 5 8 RIDING THE IRON ROOSTER, by Paul Theroux. (Putnam, $21.95.) A yearlong journey by train through China. 9 1 ALMOST GOLDEN, by Gwenda Blair. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The career of the television anchorwoman Jessica Savitch and the ways of newscasting during the past two decades. 10 9 38 THRIVING ON CHAOS, by Tom Peters. (Knopf, $19.95.) The author discusses ways for companies to survive in today's and tomorrow's turbulent world. 11 6 7 CAPOTE, by Gerald Clarke. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) The life of Truman Capote. 12 8 11 FOR THE RECORD, by Donald T. Regan. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $21.95.) The recollections of President Reagan's former Treasury Secretary and chief of staff. 13 13 27 THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GREAT POWERS, by Paul Kennedy. (Random House, $24.95.) How economic and military forces affected the fortunes of great nations in the past 500 years. 14 15 16 WASHINGTON GOES TO WAR, by David Brinkley. (Knopf, $18.95.) A social and political portrait of the nation's capital during World War II. 15 12 25 CHAOS, by James Gleick. (Viking, $19.95.) An account of a fast-developing new science that involves disorder, arrhythmia and the bizarre and the random in nature. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 57 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 2 2 18 SWIM WITH THE SHARKS WITHOUT BEING EATEN ALIVE, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $15.95.) Strategies for succeeding in business. 3 3 149 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $16.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 4 4 13 CONTROLLING CHOLESTEROL, by Kenneth H. Cooper. (Bantam, $17.95.) A physician's program to prevent heart disease through exercise and diet. 5 38 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) The Second College Edition of a standard work, updated in 1982. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) A FAR CRY FROM KENSINGTON, by Muriel Spark. (Houghton Mifflin, $17.95.) Mrs. Spark's 18th novel is a fine British comedy with such traditional elements as a rooming house full of lower-middle-class strugglers, but with more than traditional mordancy and a denouement that shows us how chance is turned to fate. SUMMER'S LEASE, by John Mortimer. (Viking, $19.95.) A fully packed novel about the antics of English summer people and expatriates in a Tuscan village, adorned with both farce and melodrama, including a dead body in the empty swimming pool. FORTAS: The Rise and Ruin of a Supreme Court Justice, by Bruce Allen Murphy. (Morrow, $25.) A long (717 pages), well-balanced study of Abe Fortas, a brilliant lawyer who was unable to limit his ambitions to the power and salary of a Supreme Court justice. POOR SUPPORT: Poverty in the American Family, by David T. Ellwood. (Basic, $19.95.) An ambitious and thorough analysis of welfare by a Harvard professor of public policy who proposes reforms designed to encourage individual autonomy, the work ethic and the primacy of the family. TWO BY ASTLEY: A Kindness Cup & The Acolyte, by Thea Astley. (Putnam, $18.95.) Two smart, compassionate novels, bound as one, both exploring the decay of conscience under mob pressure; both prize winners in the author's country, Australia. THE TURBAN FOR THE CROWN: The Islamic Revolution in Iran, by Said Amir Arjomand. (Oxford University, $21.95.) A sociologist's detailed argument that Iran's revolution may prove a watershed cataclysm like the French and Russian revolutions. BELIEVE THEM, by Mary Robison. (Knopf, $15.95.) Eleven stories in a variety of voices and textures, illuminating the lives of the disaffected and upwardly mobile through diamond-sharp detail.

title: Catherine Natoli Becomes a Bride
description: Resurrection Roman Catholic Church in Rye, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Catherine Jane Natoli, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Natoli of Plainsboro, N.J., to Francis Kirk Mahoney, a son of Judge and Mrs. J. Daniel Mahoney of Milford, Conn.

title: SECONDHAND ROSE
description: IN HIS DELIGHTFUL BOOK, ''Italian Wines,'' Victor Hazan has this to say about rose:

title: Military Government in Haiti Orders Canadian Priest Out
description: The military government expelled a Canadian priest accused of disturbing Haiti's social and political order after he refused to reveal the names of his parishioners, radio stations reported today.

title: Big Money's Election-Year Comeback
description: ONE of the richest men in America, M. Larry Lawrence, has sought to enrich the campaign of the Democratic nominee in the last 10 Presidential contests. He remembers well the days when candidates were bankrolled by a moneyed elite. He also recalls the change in direction after Watergate, when Congress wrote laws to drive big money out of Presidential politics through public financing of campaigns. And he sees the change back. With a vengeance, fat cats have returned and they are turning the system of public financing on its end.

title: Lost Lives, Shattered Dreams: The Aftermath of a Tragedy
description: LEAD: There is an invisible space between beauty and catastrophe in any diver's life. Nearly always the space is defined through unremitting training and by a rigorous sense of control. But even perfect athletic control is perfect only because it is so limited.

title: 20,000 Paraguayans March To Back Church in a Dispute
description: An estimated 20,000 people marched silently through the streets today in a show of solidarity with the Roman Catholic Church.

title:
CAMERA;
Shielding Equipment from the Heat
description: LEAD: AT some point in the course of taking high-school physics I learned that heat and light are related forms of energy. But those of us sweltering out the dog days of the summer of 1988 don't need physics to comprehend the link. When the sun's out, it gets hotter than blue blazes.

title: Seriously Now, Can Writerless Comics Cope?
description: It might have been one of the unfunny consequences of the Writers Guild of America strike: Johnny Carson and David Letterman would be denied their protective cordon of jokesmiths, leaving them writerless and vulnerable before the terrifying eye of the camera. Walking the video tightrope without a safety net, abandoned by their comedy support teams, there was every chance that America's premier late-night talk-showhosts would bomb before millions.

title: Lisa Green, a Student, Weds Dr. Gary Markoff
description: At the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York, Lisa Susan Green, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Green of Fair Lawn, N.J., was married last night to Dr. Gary Richard Markoff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell Markoff of Merrick, L.I., and Tamarac, Fla. Rabbi Stanley Bramnick officiated. Mrs. Markoff, a second-year student at the New York University School of Law, is a summer intern reporter for The National Law Journal in New York. She graduated cum laude from the University of Pennsylvania. Her father owns City Hall Service, a Mobil station in Paterson, N.J.

title: Planning a New Gutter System
description: A WELL-FUNCTIONING gutter system is essential. Without one, rainwater and melting snow dripping from a roof can easily saturate ground around the foundation, causing basement leakage and settling. If a gutter system is so badly deteriorated that repair is neither practical nor economical, a new system should be promptly installed to replace it.

title:
BODY AND MIND;
The Frozen Room
description: LEAD: THIS IS THE ROOM IN which the body confesses. My friend Charles, a pathologist, is resident soothsayer here. He calls it ''the frozen room.'' Charles and I are here early, at 7:30 A.M., in this small room across from the surgical suites. The operating rooms, connected by a maze of cool tile, are patrolled by nurses, physicians and technicians in blue-clad camaraderie, seriously joyful and absorbed just now in putting the world to sleep.

title: Jersey Senate to Vote on Changes in Car Insurance
description: With a state-operated automobile insurance system running a deficit of $20 million a month, the New Jersey Senate will vote Monday on a bill intended to solve the system's financial problems, but the measure faces a difficult passage through the Legislature.

title: Expos Win, 5-4, to Continue Their Mastery Over Cardinals
description: Tom Foley hit a two-run triple, and Otis Nixon added a two-run double as the Montreal Expos continued their hex over the St. Louis Cardinals with a 5-4 triumph today.

title: Chavez's Condition Worsens In Fast Over Grape Boycott
description: Cesar Chavez, head of the United Farm Workers, is suffering from bouts of nausea, dehydration, dizziness, and malnutrition, his doctor said today as Mr. Chavez entered the 21st day of a fast to call attention to his boycott of California table grapes.

title: When Avant-Garde Pieces Antagonize Audiences
description: ''Forewarned is forearmed'' is not a motto acceptable to those letter writers who have complained that they did not get what they expected at a performance of the Paris Opera Ballet. In other words, they found themselves at Robert Wilson's version of D'Annunzio's theater piece ''Le Martyre de Saint Sebastien'' instead of a conventional ballet.

title: The Love Books
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Hillary Allison Richardson Weds
description: Dr. Hillary Allison Richardson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Lust of Merrick, L.I., was married last evening to Dr. W. Michael Canning, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Canning of Boynton Beach, Fla. Rabbi Robert Block performed the ceremony at the St. Moritz Hotel.

title: U.S. STUDIES WAYS TO SPEED UP DRUGS FOR SERIOUSLY ILL
description: Responding to the rising demand for new AIDS treatments, the Reagan Administration is preparing a major regulatory proposal to permit faster evaluation of drugs for life-threatening illnesses.

title: Review/Music; Hager, Toradze And Mintz
description: Friday's Mostly Mozart program at Avery Fisher Hall provided the first hint that anybody in the concert business here is aware of - or cares about - the 200th anniversary of Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach's death in December. He was an immense force in 18th-century music, though largely ignored today, and the concert by the festival's orchestra under Leopold Hager began with the E-flat Symphony, one of four powerful works in this format written in the mid-1770's. C. P. E. Bach was the most talented of Sebastian's many talented sons, and his music balances daring and passion with one of the era's most thorough and well-organized minds. His great essay on keyboard methods and style was studied religiously by Mozart, Haydn, Beethoven and every serious musician of the century.

title: Musing on Mozart
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan McClellan To Marry in Fall
description: The engagement of Susan J. McClellan to G. Lindsay Valk, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Garry Valk of Cutchogue, L.I., and Sea Island, Ga., has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. George W. McClellan of Greenwich, Conn. An Oct. 1 wedding is planned.

title: South Korean Students Attack a U.S. Office
description: South Korean students demanding reunification talks with North Korean students attacked a United States diplomatic office and police stations today in the southern city of Kwangju, news reports said.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Books From The Times
description: YOU COULD LOOK IT UP. By William Safire. Illustrated by Keith Bendis. (Times Books, $22.50.) Brimming over with Lex Appeal, this collection is the fifth drawn from William Safire's ''On Language'' columns for The New York Times Magazine. The author and his band of Lexicographic Irregulars (readers and letter writers whose correspondence is also included) are unabashed Nosy Parkers when it comes to language. Ranging wide - from Womenclature and the Wicked Which to the Ash Heap (or is it the Dust Heap) of History -Mr. Safire issues a Ukase: ''If you use skullduggery [ ''skulduggery'' with one ''l'' is preferred ] when you mean huggermugger, you're all higgledy-piggledy.''

title: PERFECTING THE IRRATIONAL LIFE
description: LOVING ATTITUDES By Rachel Billington. 250 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $15.95.

title: Kristina E. Weisenstein to Marry in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Wojak of St. Louis have announced the engagement of Mrs. Wojak's daughter, Kristina Ellen Weisenstein, to Waddell Watters Stillman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Gordon B. Stillman of New York and Wrightsville Beach, N.C. Ms. Weisenstein and her fiance, both 1983 cum laude graduates of Yale University, plan to marry Oct. 1.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Fort Myers, Fla.;
A Chinatown With Pagoda
description: LEAD: THE first five homes have been built here in what developers are promoting nationally as an eventual new Chinatown, in an unincorporated area known as Lehigh Acres in southwestern Florida. Fifteen more houses are planned by the end of the year.

title: Fall Chrysanthemums Add Late-Season Color
description: TRANSPLANT broccoli, cabbage, kale and Brussels sprout seedlings to the vegetable garden; water in well and mulch to keep the soil moist. Resow a half row of beans. Keep up with squash and cucumber harvest. Allow tomatoes to ripen on the plant for best flavor. Chrysanthemums

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: FIDDLERS ON STAGE

title: Sacrifice Snaps Tie As Yanks Keep Up
description: Dave Righetti went to the mound with two out in the ninth inning and struck out Kent Hrbek for his 17th save as the Yankees defeated the Minnesota Twins, 5-3, before 40,814 last night at the Stadium.

title: Question of the Week; Are the Red Sox In for Another Fall?
description: What a cruel, heartless question! Anyway, regardless of where the Red Sox finish this fall, Joe Morgan has made watching (and, it seems, playing) baseball at Fenway fun again. And even if the Sox don't win it all this year, we Fenway Faithful have this compensation: neither will the Yankees. RICHARD L. MALONE Brooklyn

title: Mitteleuropa Revisited
description: To the Editor:

title: China's Ear Is Its Voice In a Colony
description: The bronze plaque on the front of the big marble and tile office building solemnly declares that it is the headquarters of the New China News Agency, Hong Kong Branch. But everyone here - from the British Governor of the colony to the Chinese taxi driver - knows better.

title: Aaron D. Cohen And Miss Ehrlich Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Simon B. Ehrlich of Norwalk, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Abigail Mary Ehrlich to Aaron Daniel Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Cohen of Roslyn Heights, L.I.

title: The Rules of the Game for Baseball Parents
description: SOME time ago, on a beautiful baseball day late in the season, I was watching my son's team play in a Little League contest. The parents attending were, of course, familiar to me. We had spent the pre-game warm-up speaking of pleasant things and preparing to root our charges onward.

title:
INVESTING;
Using Options in a Slow Market
description: LEAD: THE slowdown in stock trading has cut into the options market as well. Some investors would say this is only just: options, like futures, have been blamed for exacerbating the October stock market crash.

title: Blame and Recompense
description: Pentagon officials said last week that a Navy investigation had blamed crew error, arising from the stress of battle, for the downing of Iran Air Flight 655 by an American warship on July 3.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. The kitchen floor in our 1832 farmhouse is covered with layers of linoleum that we are taking off. The wood floor under this appears to be of four-inch-wide pine boards that we want to stain and seal. What is the best way to refinish this floor?

title: Success Strategies for Minorities
description: FEAR WAS PERHAPS Karla Munden's overriding emotion when she was admitted to the College of William and Mary, in Williamsburg, Va. As a black woman, she was aware that the school's population of blacks was small. Would she make friends and feel comfortable on such a campus miles away from home? Had her high school prepared her for William and Mary's demands?

title:
THEATER;
Ethyl Eichelberger Cartwheels Through History
description: LEAD: On July 21, while many New Yorkers were watching the Democratic Convention on television, 2,000 others were sitting in Alice Tully Hall witnessing a different sort of history lesson. Ethyl Eichelberger was performing excerpts from his one-person play, ''The Lincolns,'' as part of the Serious Fun! festival.

title:
DINING OUT;
Japanese Cuisine in North Tarrytown
description: LEAD: As one pulls up to this neat little restaurant, black and red Japanese characters painted on the white wall announce that one is about to enter Sushi Raku (''Sushi For Your Pleasure''), and the name could't be more accurate. This friendly dining spot is a welcome sight on the northwestern flank of the county until now deprived of this popular cuisine.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. The kitchen floor in our 1832 farmhouse is covered with layers of linoleum that we are taking off. The wood floor under this appears to be of four-inch-wide pine boards that we want to stain and seal. What is the best way to refinish this floor?

title: GREEK POLICE ON TERRORISM ALERT
description: The Greek police have been put on alert around the Athens airport and at American military bases and airlines offices here amid fears of terrorist attacks, a senior police official said today.

title: A Post-Mortem on the Defecit
description: LEAD: A SHORTFALL in business tax receipts is being blamed for a large part of the estimated $94 million state budget deficit for the 1987-88 fiscal year just completed, and state officials want to find out why it happened.

title: Ryokans
description: To the Editor: Having spent one night (all we could afford) in a ryokan (Japanese inn) during our three-week visit to Japan last summer, we sympathized with Kathy Jones and Clyde Haberman (Travel, June 12). However, they failed to alert potential visitors to a further hazard. Our guidebook informed us that it was customary to wear the yukata (cotton kimono) in the passages and public rooms of the ryokan. I verified this text in the morning, and accordingly, we appeared in the dining room for breakfast wearing our kimonos. The Japanese present were all wearing jeans, three-piece business suits, Bermuda shorts - anything but a yukata. With typical Japanese politeness, everyone ignored our faux pas; indeed, I am sure they would have displayed no more concern had we appeared stark naked. RALPH WESTON Brookhaven, L.I.

title: For Artists, Campus Is the Canvas
description: LEAD: ALAN SONFIST is a sculptor who believes that ''art has always brought a new awareness to one's society.'' Michelangelo, for example, didn't create his masterworks in an artistic vacuum, he said. ''He was working in an age, in a community, where religion was all important, and he tried to awaken the people's spirituality.

title: 2 Sides to the Story In Attacks on Indians
description: The article on attacks on New Jersey's Indian community does violence to the civil rights of the four juveniles indicted in the death of Mr. Mody (''Tougher Law Asked in Attacks on Indians'').

title: Question of the Week; Are the Red Sox In for Another Fall?
description: The 1988 Sox are unique. Unlike the squads of 1986 (curses on you, Bill Buckner), 1978 (blast you, Mike Torrez) and 1975 (shame on you, Larry Barnett), this year's version hasn't been in a position to choke. The way they're playing, they might be, but that's O.K. Their present position is an unexpected and highly pleasurable bonus. MICHAEL J. HEALEY New York

title: ASPEN
description: In summer Aspen's intellectual aspirations are as lofty as the surrounding Rockies. At this time of year the town's reputation as a glitzy ski resort is temporarily eclipsed by its image as a cultural center.

title: Question of the Week; Are the Red Sox In for Another Fall?
description: The Red Sox have given us real thrills. Take, for instance, Dave Henderson's incredible two-out ninth-inning home run in Game 6 of the 1986 playoffs to force a seventh game against the Angels. Moments like that are what being a fan is all about. It's not defeatism, impending doom or the ''Here we go again. . . .'' mentality that your question implies.

title: Canadians Make Bid on PTL Ministry and Park
description: Two Canadian businessmen made the first of what is expected to be a handful of competing proposals to acquire the bankrupt PTL ministry and its Heritage USA theme park, a trustee for the ministry said Friday.

title: Scrutable Surprises at a Chinese Oasis
description: JANI Chinese restaurant, squeezed between Herman's and Toys 'R' Us in Huntington Station's Filene's Shopping Center, is a cooling oasis in what seems like a culinary desert of chain stores. Although the restaurant is dwarfed by its larger neighbors, Jani is surprisingly spacious. It is deep, high and handsome. Twenty-foot ceilings even allow for a balcony. All is serene dove-gray highlighted with royal purple, subdued Oriental art and dramatic bouquets of flowers on the smoky-mirrored bar.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Infusing Life Into Downtown Plainfield
description: LEAD: Over the last two decades, Plainfield has watched its once-thriving downtown commercial district wither as residents and businesses fled to the suburbs, leaving behind empty storefronts and a city on the decline.

title: Notes From a Train Whistle: The Lonesome Blues in the Night
description: LATE at night, television off, family asleep, streets empty, I hear the lonely wail of a train whistle in the distance. That sound, poets and writers tell me, is supposed to awaken in me a longing for romance, adventure and far away places. But as the grade crossings are eliminated, no matter what the images, even the whistle of the L.I.R.R. will fade into the nostalgic past.

title: Dr. Jayne Cluett Weds
description: Dr. Jayne Candice Cluett, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Maxwell L. Cluett of Greenville, Del., was married there yesterday to Philip George Bodey, a son of Anne B. Travaglin of Colebrook, Conn., and the late Warren G. Bodey. The Rev. William B. Lane Jr. performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church Christiana Hundred. The bride is an obstetrician and gynecologist in Hartford, where her husband owns the Philip George Construction Company.

title: Musing on Mozart
description: To the Editor:

title: WANTED: THE MEANING OF LIFE
description: THREE SCIENTISTS AND THEIR GODS Looking for Meaning in an Age of Information By Robert Wright. 324 pp. New York: Times Books. $18.95.

title: Parking Violators Get the 'Boot'
description: COMMUTING to New York and planning to park on the narrow streets here to beat public garage fees? Better think twice, say officials of the Hoboken Parking Authority. Getting caught will cost

title:
Outdoors;
True Wilderness Is a Rare Adventure
description: LEAD: The quiet beauty of a true wilderness is becoming more difficult to find in the Eastern United States. But there are places set aside for use by back-country travelers that will always remain wild, clean and free of all permanent human intrusion.

title: Giants Look Impressive All-Round as They Defeat Packers
description: The Giants opened their preseason schedule in impressive fashion this evening. In fact things couldn't have gone much smoother if the coaching staff had scripted the team's 34-3 shellacking of the Green Bay Packers.

title: Of Thrills, Spills, Beaches and Department Stores
description: OUTSIDE, the temperature is below zero and the weather is grim. Inside, crowds are gathered in swimsuits on a sandy beach with palm trees. The scene is from the 5.2-million-square-foot West Edmonton Mall, the world's largest, which was developed by the Triple Five Corporation of Alberta, Canada.

title: 'The Mandrake': Roguish Life
description: ''THE one who survives is the one who connives.'' So goes a lyric from ''The Mandrake,'' which is being called a very loose or free adaptation from a story by Niccolo Machiavelli, ''La Mandragola.''

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Lenox, Mass.;
An Arizona Spa For Berkshires
description: LEAD: There was a ground-breaking ceremony here last week for a $37 million Arizona-style health spa that will rise on a historic 120-acre estate in the lush countryside of Berkshire County.

title: Limits are Lowered for State Mortgages
description: REAL-ESTATE agents welcomed the release of $100 million in low-interest mortgage money last week but said new rules would add to the difficulty in using it.

title: Ms. Chamberlin To Marry in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Stephen Chamberlin of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Patricia Ann Chamberlin to Edward Frank Keyes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert James Keyes of Barrington, R.I., and West Palm Beach, Fla. The couple plan to marry on Oct. 22.

title: Early Jazz as Never Heard Before on Disk
description: Robert Parker is a record collector, a jazz fan with a special fondness for the jazz of the 1920's and, as he says, ''coincidentally a sound engineer.'' Out of this combination of interests and skills has come something that collectors of early jazz recordings might never have thought possible: Reproductions of jazz records of the 1920's and earlier that are not only free of surface noise but reveal details, subtleties and a sense of presence that were not previously evident on the records, even in LP re-issues.

title: Some Sounds in the Country
description: IF the warm weather has brought out the wanderlust in you, consider the possibility of a pleasant country drive that can yield the further bonus of an attractive concert at your destination.

title: Elizabeth Cryan Wed To Benton H. Ingersoll
description: At St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church in Pocasset, Mass., Elizabeth Ann Cryan, the daughter of Joan B. Cryan of Pocasset and Michael J. Cryan of Boston, was married yesterday to Benton Howard Ingersoll, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Ingersoll of Waterford, Conn., and New York. The Rev. James W. Clark performed the ceremony.

title: Passenger Is Charged In Disruption of Flight
description: A man who said he would ''have to kill everyone who was not a born-again Christian'' tried to storm the cockpit of a jetliner as it was preparing to land, the authorities said.

title: Motherly Lecture and Late Snacks
description: THE Senate will return in a special session tomorrow to consider a compromise automobile insurance proposal by Governor Kean that could be the Legislature's last chance to do something about rising insurance costs this year.

title: At Camp, on a Rany Dy, You Can See Four Walls
description: THE first of a string of rainy days received mixed greetings from the campers and counselors of the Elmwood Day Camp, on Dobbs Ferry Road in White Plains. Boys and girls enthusiastically played ''ga-ga,'' a kickball game suitable for indoors, energetically danced to ''Ballin' the Jack,'' made tile trivots as well as beaded bracelets and played bingo. Counselors stretched their ingenuity to keep the children happy and occupied - even if for some youngsters nothing was as much fun as getting soaked under a leaky rain gutter.

title: Residential Resale
