Goldy) BROOKLYN Bedford-Stuyvesant $155,000 1470 Atlantic Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, single-family, 2-story, attached brick house; dining room, large kitchen, full basement, original moldings and details, 20- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $570 (Broker: John P. Barry Real Estate) Park Slope $525,000 222-A 6th Avenue 2-family, brownstone house; dining area in upper duplex; deck in lower, 2 bedrooms, 1 1/2 baths in each; finished basement, 17- by 85-ft. lot; taxes $1,144 (Broker: F.J. Kazeroid Realty) Windsor Terrace $230,000 173 Seeley Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, brick, attached house; dining room, large kitchen, full basement, 16- by 80-ft. lot; taxes $875 (Broker: Shelter Real Estate) QUEENS Briarwood $69,000 141-60 84th Road (The Claridge) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 700-sq.-ft. co-op, in a recently renovated postwar building; dining foyer, large kitchen, hardwood floors; maintenance $283, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Kraham Realty) Woodside $235,000 28-49 Hobart Street 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, single-family, brick, attached house; dining room, basement, 1-car garage, 17- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $928 (Broker: Century 21/Metalios Real Estate) STATEN ISLAND New Dorp $215,000 860 Tysens Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, single-family, semi-attached, frame house; dining area, large kitchen, 24- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $300 (Broker: Century 21/Papp Realty) Westerleigh $210,000 343 Demorest Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, detached colonial; dining room, large kitchen, above-ground pool, 80- by 75-ft. lot; taxes $925 (Broker: Weichert Realtors)

title: Gardeners Getting Telephone Advice
description: LEAD: ONE of the first questions Henry Ferris received as a volunteer master gardener for the University of Connecticut Cooperative Extension Service, was from a man who had found a snake in a wood pile and wondered how to get rid of it.

title: 'It's a Very Difficult Tax to Collect'
description: TIMOTHY F. BANNON, the Commissioner of Revenue Services, administers a staff of 860 employees collecting $3.9 billion in taxes a year. A 41-year-old Ohio native whose father was from Connecticut, Mr. Bannon is a 1977 graduate of the Yale University Law School who worked at private law firms and corporations before becoming an aide to Governor O'Neill in 1985. On July 23, 1987, he was named to lead the tax-collection agency, and in his first year has started several programs. He talked about his job in an interview at his office on Farmington Avenue in Hartford. Here are some excerpts from the conversation:

title: Regina Bahr Has a Bridal
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Joseph-on-the-Brandywine in Greenville, Del., Regina Thompson Bahr, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Bahr of Greenville, was married yesterday to Patrick Matthew Finn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond E. Finn of Towson, Md. The Rev. Roch Ciandella, the chaplain of the Canterbury School in New Milford, Conn., performed the ceremony. He was assisted by Msgr. Paul J. Schierse.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: MADONNA AND OTHER SPECTACLES. By Harold Jaffe. (PAJ Publications, $14.95.) Harold Jaffe's purpose in his fifth work of fiction seems to be to skewer contemporary society for all its soullessness and corruption. The unlikely juxtaposition is his chief tool, and so we have the Three Stooges cavorting in drag in a girl's lavatory, set in counterpoint with random musings about such matters as the black man's experience with the electric chair or the nature of genocide.

title: South African Paper Curbed
description: Police officers across South Africa today seized newsstand copies of The Weekly Mail, a prominent anti-apartheid newspaper.

title:
RECORDINGS;
Giving 20th-Century Masters Their Due
description: LEAD: The more cynical members of our relentlessly conservative, increasingly older concert audience complain shrilly about the quality and content of 20th-century music. What composers have the 20th century produced who are worthy of standing beside the masters of the past?, they ask. How much safer it is, given the museum-like state of our concert life, to venture into the 20th century only to savor Sibelius, Rachmaninoff, and Mahler, composers who conserved the

title: Corporate Logos Spruce Themselves Up; Things of Beauty
description: To the Editor:

title: Venice
description: To the Editor: Hooray for Roberto Suro! At last he lists, in ''What's Doing in Venice'' (Travel, June 12), some less expensive hotels instead of hotels charging $200 or more a night. I am sure other readers wish to know of second-class hotels not easily discoverable. LEE FIELDEN Collinsville, Conn.

title: 'Oliver North Day' Canceled In Philmont, His Hometown
description: Residents here in the hometown of a leading figure in the Iran-contra affair have decided to cancel the second annual ''Oliver North Day.''

title: Question of the Week; Are the Red Sox In for Another Fall?
description: Yes! And what a glorious fall it will be as the Sox sweep 50 of the remaining 59 games to win the A.L. East going away. Boston then routs Oakland in three and blows out the Mets in five with Mike Boddicker notching the clincher in Fenway Park. The world championship returns to Boston for the first time since 1918. KENT ATKINS Riverside, Conn.

title: POSTINGS: Forest Hills High-Rise; Risk Taker
description: Early this spring, Jack and Abram Shnay were in the midst of developing a project with a great deal going for it. Its Forest Hills address had cachet. Its site at Queens Boulevard and 75th Avenue was ready to be cleared. And city approvals were all in place. In fact, because it was approved just before new zoning that encourages shorter, fatter buildings was put in place, the Shnays's new, 27-story tower would be the last to rise so high over Queens.

title: Headliners; On the House
description: If American Samoa's non-voting Congressional delegate, Fofo I. F. Sunia, came to Washington promising to create jobs, he has kept his word. In fact, say Federal prosecutors, Mr. Sunia, with the help of his assistant, created 14 jobs on his Washington staff. The trouble was, he never bothered to fill some of the positions and failed to notify the House finance office when some of his staff members quit. Instead, the authorities said, Mr. Sunia and his aide, Matthew K. Iuli, deposited $131,000 in Federal paychecks into their own accounts over a three-year period and used the money to make mortgage and car loan payments, entertain constitutents and pay campaign expenses. Prosecutors said last week that Mr. Sunia had agreed to plead guilty to fraud charges.

title: Bring Back Floating Pools
description: Summer wears on, pollution discourages relief at the seashore and there's every reason to think next summer will be just as uncomfortable. The nonprofit Parks Council, which works on behalf of New York City's parks and waterfront, thus makes a constructive proposal: revive floating pools.

title:
NEW DIRECTIONS;
Making Music By the Byte
description: LEAD: DURING THE 1960's, Bob Dylan wrote of a man who was ''famous long ago / For playing the electric violin / On Desolation Row.'' That was thought to be Dylan being poetic, obscure, fanciful. But today there is an electronic violin at the Center for Computer Research in Music and Acoustics, at the Department of Music at Stanford University in California.

title: The 'Super' Jets Question the Jets of Today
description: Twenty years ago they were together at the Jets' training camp, blending the skills that would win Super Bowl III in one of pro football's historic games. More than 30 of those Jets will be together again tomorrow when the 20th anniversary of that Super Bowl team will be celebrated by the New York chapter of the National Football League Alumni at its annual golf outing at Quaker Ridge in Scarsdale. And by the nature of what those Jets created, they ask the same questions that Jet fans ask:

title: Cyndra Harvey To Marry Oct. 1
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Wayne Harvey of New Martinsville, W. Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter Cyndra Lynn Harvey to Alan Sterling Van Clief, a son of Mrs. Daniel Good Van Clief of Nydrie Farms, Esmont, Va., and the late Mr. Van Clief. The couple plan to marry Oct. 1.

title: After 20 Years, Fair Housing Teeth
description: Twenty years ago, America recognized the pain of those who suffer the humiliation of housing discrimination. But the Fair Housing Act of 1968, lacking strong enforcement provisions, has been a paper tiger. Now Congress, with the support of President Reagan, is about to give it teeth.

title: Support Rises for a P.L.O. Exile State
description: Support is growing within the Palestine Liberation Organization for the setting up of a government in exile now that King Hussein of Jordan has cut all administrative and legal ties with the Israeli-occupied West Bank, Palestinian representatives here said today.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON DECOLONIZATION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Man Freed From Chimney
description: Firefighters used crowbars and sledgehammers to free a man who became stuck while trying to crawl down a chimney after he was locked out of a relative's house in the middle of the night. Rodolpho Mohoro, stuck in the chimney about two hours, was treated for abrasions at a hospital and released. The chimney was nearly demolished.

title: Bush-Noreiga in '88?
description: LEAD: The political question of the moment is not ''Where was George?'' but ''Who is George going to pick for a running mate?''

title: Olympia Broadcasting Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $4,604,541 from the sale of a station for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Shuttle's Faulty Valve Replaced
description: Mechanics reconnected pipes and electrical lines on the spacecraft Discovery today after replacing a part that caused a computer to abort a crucial ignition test of the shuttle's main engines.

title: NO ROOM FOR FAILURE
description: ONCE every four years, sports fans wrap themselves in the red, white and blue, lending vocal, moral and even financial support to America's teams playing in the Olympics. For instance, tickets for yesterday's game between the United States Olympians and a pickup team of National Basketball Association players, at the Civic Center here, ranged from $41.50 to $50, a steep price for a chance to see the Olympians play players who were interrupting their off season for a day.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''What was significant about the meeting today was just to get some sense of human touch, some sense of feeling, some sense of sharing, some commitment for ongoing dialogue, some commitment to remove barriers, some ability to agree to agree or agree to disagree.'' - the Rev. Jesse Jackson after meeting with Moshe Arad, the Israeli Ambassador to the U.S. [ B5:2. ]

title: Market Place; Mixed Picture For Cable TV
description: POSITIVE trends in the $12 billion cable television industry such as higher pricing, new products and a growing interest by advertisers are being viewed by analysts as opening an ever-widening avenue for the long-term investor.

title: Jets Pick Up Pieces
description: There is going to be a lot of helmet-slapping by the Jets' offense this preseason.

title: 8/8/88: Let Octopi Clap And Let the Octets Sing
description: Acht! It's the eighth day of the eighth month of the eighty-eighth year of this enervating century, but you're far too slow. The number 8888 sold out faster than any other in the history of the New York State Lottery's Win Four game, all 1,000 tickets gone by 11:37 A.M. on Aug. 1, the first day they were offered.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Chiat/Day Creates Campaign for Bushmills
description: The San Francisco office of Chiat/ Day, the agency whose New York office is responsible for those delightful Nynex Yellow Pages commercials, has come up with some clever advertising for Bushmills Premium Irish Whiskey.

title: A $400,000 Fine for Reuters
description: The private British news agency Reuters Ltd. said today that it had taken steps to avoid future ''procedural errors'' like those that resulted in a $400,000 fine for re-exporting United States-origin microcomputer equipment.

title: Odetics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes recognition of $400,000 in tax credits as a result of the company's adoption of FASB Statement 96.

title: Irvine Sensors Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
Corrections
description: An article on Friday about gases in ancient amber misidentified a researcher who challenged a report that bubbles of air had been trapped in amber for 80 million years, and misstated his affiliation. He is Dr. Harold B. Hopfenberg of North Carolina State University in Raleigh.

title: Monique Miron Is Wed at Vassar
description: At the Vassar College Chapel in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., Monique Miron, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Lane Miron of Poughkeepsie, was married yesterday to Lieut. Jonathan E. Cayle of the Navy Medical Corps, the son of Dr. Theodore Cayle of Annapolis, Md., and Phyllis Cayle of Valley Stream, L.I. Rabbi Erwin Zimmet performed the ceremony.

title: Amy J. Silberstein Wed To a Lawyer in Boston
description: At the Sheraton Boston Hotel and Towers, Amy J. Silberstein was married yesterday to Howard Cohen. Rabbi Laurence Silberstein, the bride's uncle, and Rabbi Samuel Chiel officiated.

title: Pressures On the Fed Seen Rising
description: Pressures on the Federal Reserve Board to once again push up short-term interest rates are intensifying, a number of private credit market analysts contend, and the central bank may be forced to act soon, perhaps this week.

title: Astrex Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $313,000 on repurchase of debt. The company said the year-ago quarter is reclassified to reflect a loss on discontinued operations in 1987 of $4,000.

title: W.G. Helis, 70, Oil Producer in Louisiana
description: William G. Helis Jr., a Louisiana oil producer and sportsman, died at Ochsner Foundation Hospital here Saturday after a long illness. He was 70 years old.

title: 'One Felt Safer Than in Many Parts of London'
description: To the Editor:

title: Ingles Markets Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
ASTROS CHIP AWAY AT DODGERS' LEAD
description: Bob Knepper allowed five hits in seven and one-third innings today and Houston scored two runs on balks as the Astros beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4-2.

title: Medicine Shoppe Internaional reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
For Quebec: Independence, Non! Deregulation, Yes!
description: LEAD: Eighteen years ago, paratroopers patrolled the streets of Montreal in the wake of kidnappings and bombings by Quebec separatists. The English-speaking financial community of Montreal prepared to move to Toronto, and economic chaos threatened. Today, however, a politically peaceful Quebec leads its nation in another revolution: the global transformation of financial services.

title: Johnson Returns And Runs Well
description: In his first successful outdoor competition since last fall, Ben Johnson ran three 100-meter sprints in less than 24 hours at the Canadian track and field championships: a heat Friday night, then the semifinals and final Saturday afternoon. He won each race, as expected, and posted a winded-aided time of 9.90 seconds in the final.

title: Turkish Stocks Plunge by 7.9%
description: Turkish stock prices tumbled 7.9 percent on the Istanbul stock exchange last week as banks liquidated portfolios to raise cash after a money supply squeeze at the central bank, brokers said.

title: IRAN ACCEPTS PLAN BY IRAQ FOR TRUCE AND DIRECT TALKS
description: Iran today accepted Iraq's compromise proposal for a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war to be followed immediately by direct talks.

title: National Western Life Insurnce Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After capital losses of $436,779 and $352,450 for the quarter and the 6 months, respectively. c-Includes capital gains of $820,619 for the quarter and $1,604,838 for the 6 months.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Has a team ever won a pennant by 20 or more games?

title: KCS Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Pitt's Smith Leads U.S. Past Pro Squad
description: Broadway producers look forward to the 11 o'clock news and morning newspapers to sample the reviews. John Thompson, the Olympic basketball coach, was eagerly anticipating a viewing of the game films before giving an assessment of his team's exhibition game against National Basketball Association players today at the Civic Center. If first impressions mean anything, however, Thompson will say that the performance was fair.

title: Bull & Bear Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $39,000 for the quarter and $84,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Sports World Specials; Hoover's Legacy
description: Ordinarily, the annual commemoration of Herbert Hoover's birth is a distinctly subdued affair, drawing only a smattering of family members and others to the Hoover Presidential Library and Museum in West Branch, Iowa. The nation's 31st President was born in West Branch on Aug. 10, 1874.

title: Writers Ratify Contract, Ending Longest Strike
description: The five-month strike by 9,000 movie and television writers is officially over.

title: Laurel Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Disneyland for Hungary?
description: Hungary wants to build Eastern Europe's first Disneyland.

title: Internal Pentagon Report Faults Navy on Use of Consultants in Purchasing
description: The Navy's purchasing system for ships and the sophisticated equipment they carry has grown so dependent on private consultants that ''in some cases it has become difficult to determine where Government workers' functions stop and contractors' begin,'' according to an internal Pentagon report.

title: Lenders Force Builders To Put More Up Front
description: Banks, insurance companies and other lenders to the commercial real estate market have watched warily in recent years as building prices have risen far more rapidly than commercial rents, straining the capacity of building owners to keep up with mortgages.

title: Business Digest: Monday, August 8, 1988
description: The Media Business

title: McDonnell Douglas Begins Its Own Inquiry
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, under scrutiny in the Pentagon bribery inquiry, has begun an internal investigation of its use of former top-level Defense Department officials as procurement consultants.

title: Univex's Chief Expands Its Minority-Group Role
description: Wendell L. Crosswhite, who was recently named president of Universal Trading Exchange Inc., known as Univex, believes that his business has virtually no competition.

title: Separate Drownings In Same Closed Pool
description: Two men drowned in separate incidents in the same closed public pool over the weekend, the police said. In each case, the man sneaked in by climbing the fence of the Highbridge Pool in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan.

title: Aides Fret, but Bush Has to 'Be Me'
description: There is only one way to describe the look on Vice President Bush's face as he pushes up the throttle on his cigarette boat, sending the craft crashing over the waves and the passengers careening around the deck like pinballs. George Bush looks demonic. ''I want to go faster but I don't want to hurt anybody,'' he says, flying into the harbor on the red, white and blue Fidelity in a dramatic 40-mile-per-hour spray. He reminisced, with a certain perverse pride, about the time he took Tom Pettit of NBC News on a fast boat ride; Mr. Pettit threw out his back but stopped doing what Mr. Bush called ''wimp stories'' about him. (Mr. Pettit, asked what he thought of the Vice President's contention, said he had no comment, other than ''My back still hurts.'') ''You ever get hung up on all this stuff, you come out here and go and you don't stop,'' the Vice President said. Idling the boat to see if any bluefish were jumping, he gracefully cast his line into the water and warned: ''Those bluefish are dead meat.'' The Tasks Ahead

title: Condom Makers Change Approach
description: Nineteen months ago, Ansell-Americas, a maker of health-care products, ushered in a new era in condom marketing with an advertising campaign that was as scary as it was straightforward. ''I'll do a lot for love, but I'm not ready to die for it,'' a sober woman said in the ads for the company's Lifestyles condoms.

title: Milgray Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-Includes a gain of $351,200 from cumulative effect on prior years (to December 31, 1986) of changing to a different inventory method, net of taxes of $302,800.

title: Revive Artificial Heart With Money and Vision; Worthy Rescue
description: To the Editor:

title: Sun-Times Fills Vacancy
description: Chicago Sun-Times Inc. said Saturday that it had named Charles T. Price acting publisher following the resignation of Robert E. Page, the newspaper's publisher and chief executive.

title: Yachting; Catamarans in Racing Series
description: Tom Blackaller, the San Francisco yachtsman who is a veteran of 6-Meter and 12-Meter sailing, has turned to catamarans. He has abandoned the quasi-amateur status he assumed as an America's Cup skipper to embrace a new wave of professionalism in the sport.

title: Kenan Transport reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $1,500,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: Eric Friedland Is Wed To Deirdre C. Hanofee
description: St. John's Episcopal Church in Monticello, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Deirdre Constance Hanofee, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. Eugene M. Hanofee of Liberty, N.Y., and Eric Todd Friedland, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Friedland, also of Liberty. The Rev. Edward M. Story, assisted by the Rev. J. David Stanway, performed the ceremony.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt Duracell Holdings Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $750 million of debt securities. Duracell was taken private by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Co. on June 24.

title: For MCI at 20, Fewer Growing Pains
description: Two decades after a feisty young company set out to make a place for itself in the long-distance telephone market, the MCI Communications Corporation has survived the rites of passage into corporate adulthood.

title: Joseph A. Caruso; Executive, 67
description: Joseph A. Caruso, founder and chairman of the board of Bar Harbor Airways, died Friday. He was 67 years old.

title: Carrollton Journal; Murder Charges Are Met by Cries of Compassion
description: Groups that battle drunken driving say that Larry W. Mahoney, who has been charged in the church bus crash that killed 27 passengers here, is a murderer no different from those who use a gun.

title: 400 Now Feared Dead on Ganges Ferry
description: Indian Navy divers joined local rescue workers today in the rain-swollen Ganges River in a search for survivors of an overcrowded ferry boat that capsized, killing as many as 400 people.

title: English Greenhouse Products reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said the year-ago period does not include results from the company's Syn System Prefabricated Solar Greenhouses Inc. unit, which was acquired on Jan. 14.

title: Repairs Completed After Blackout That Hit Harlem and Morningside
description: Repairs were completed yesterday on the last of five 13,000-volt cables that failed Friday night, knocking out electric power to thousands of customers in Harlem and the Morningside Heights section of Manhattan.

title: Sports World Specials; Living Dolls
description: When the Mets lose do you ever feel, say, like wringing Gary Carter's neck? Or, when the Yankees falter, maybe sticking pins in Dave Righetti? When Darryl Strawberry hits one out, do you feel like giving him a big kiss? Maybe you wish Don Mattingly were small enough so you could carry him around in your pocket.

title: Moore Products Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
For a Better Kick, Get Mad
description: EVERY runner at one time or another experiences the helpless feeling of being unable to harness a kick at the end of a race. No matter how fit you are or how intelligently you run, droves of competitors pass you in the last half mile and afterwards you wonder: ''What am I doing wrong?''

title: Suit to Assert Election Bias By L.I. Town
description: A legal rights group plans to file a class action suit today challenging the election system of the Town of Hempstead in Nassau County, which the group contends excludes minorities from public office.

title: Business and the Law; Impartial Judges: A Growing Issue
description: GIVEN an unfavorable ruling, lawyers can always appeal until they reach the Supreme Court. In a number of recent cases, however, attorneys have tried another tactic: asking the judge to disqualify himself or herself on the basis of conflict of interest.

title: Dalkon Shield Trust Fund Organizes
description: The panel that will direct the $2.47 billion Dalkon Shield trust fund has taken preliminary steps to organize itself and prepare to disburse the money.

title: Genentech Wins Ruling
description: Genentech Inc. said Friday that the Federal District Court in San Francisco had ruled in its favor in a patent infringement suit brought by the Hormone Research Foundation and its licensee, Hoffman-La Roche Inc. The court ruled that Genentech does not infringe the foundation's patent by its manufacture and sale of genetically engineered human growth hormone. Genentech had 1987 sales exceeding $86 million of protropin human growth hormone, which is used to treat dwarfism in children.

title: Policies Reworked as Open Spaces Go Unused
description: A forbidding open-air mall across the street from Lincoln Center is being demolished, in the most dramatic example to date of New York City's repudiation of policies and practices that led to public spaces that the public will not or cannot use.

title: New Brunswick Scientific Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Bush Says He Will Debate
description: Vice President Bush said today that he would agree to ''more than one'' debate with Gov. Michael S. Dukakis but was not ready to be more specific on how many, when or where.

title: Treasury Financing This Week
description: Treasury financings will be substantial this week, beginning with today's regular auction of new three-month and six-month bills, totaling $13.6 billion. Tomorrow, the Treasury will start the first leg of its quarterly refunding with an $11 billion auction of new three-year notes, followed on Wednesday by a similar-size auction of 10-year notes.

title: G.M. Will Cut Suppliers
description: The General Motors Corporation plans to cut the number of its suppliers in half and will decide in the next six months which suppliers it will eliminate for contracts in the early 1990's, the company's supply chief said Friday.

title: Nassau County Learns to Live With Less Water
description: In this, the first full summer since Nassau County adopted rules to conserve its dwindling supply of drinking water, residents are taking shorter showers, washing clothes in less water and waking up earlier to water their lawns.

title: INSIDE
description: Judge Skelly Wright Dies J. Skelly Wright, who played a key role in promoting racial desegregation in a long career as a Federal judge, is dead. Page D10. Jackson and Israeli Confer The Rev. Jesse Jackson discussed black-Jewish relations and tensions in the Middle East at an embassy meeting in Washington. Page B5. Navy Purchasing Assailed The service has become so dependent on hired advisers that the role of its own workers is hard to determine, a Pentagon study concluded. Page A14. Public Spaces at Issue New York City is refining its policy of giving valuable building bonuses to developers in exchange for public spaces such as plazas. Page B1. No Love of Big-City Lights Provincial Mexicans view Mexico City residents as Americans west of the Hudson view New York City. The feeling is not of admiration. Page A4. Lights Going On at Wrigley Night baseball will finally come to Wrigley Field when the Chicago Cubs play the Philadelphia Phillies this evening. SportsMonday, page C1.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Insurance Deal Caps Careers of Consultants
description: LEAD: After almost a decade of criss-crossing the country scouting merger and acquisition deals for expansion-minded insurance companies and other investors, the three partners of Insurance Investments Associates have struck a deal for themselves.

title: Eastern Bloc Seeks Trade Ties to West
description: Countries of the Soviet bloc are scrambling to negotiate preferential trade agreements with the European Community - agreements that they hope will help lower barriers to imports of badly needed Western technology and foster the creation of joint ventures between Western companies and East bloc enterprises.

title: 'That Hellish Poison': Still Intolerable
description: The world should be outraged. Yet Iraq has suffered only ritual criticism for the first sustained use of poison gas since World War I. A recent United Nations report confirms that Iraq made mustard gas, cyanide and probably nerve gas into standard battlefield weapons.

title: METS BLITZ PIRATES AGAIN; PINCH-HITTERS LEAD ASSAULT
description: The Mets dismantled the Pittsburgh Pirates today with all the old fury, scoring four runs in the ninth inning, beating them for the third straight time and the sixth time in seven games in two weekends, and knocking them into third place. And then even Davey Johnson conceded that the summer's ''slump'' had probably ended.

title: Mellon Stock Faltering Since Plan's Debut
description: A backlash has developed in the investment community to the Mellon Bank Corporation's decision to spin off $1 billion of its bad loans into a separate entity and recapitalize the ''good'' bank that remains.

title: North Sea Pipeline Plan
description: The Dutch Petroleum Company B.V. said last week that it was leading a $1 billion project to build a 177-mile pipeline into the North Sea to speed up exploration of gas reserves. The project is scheduled to come on line in several phases starting in 1991, according to Dutch Petroleum, a joint venture of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group and the Exxon Corporation. The area of the Dutch continental shelf to be explored is thought to hold at least 7.8 trillion gallons of natural gas, about half the annual output of the Netherlands.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on July 21 about the proposed merger of Texas American Bancshares Inc. and the National Bancshares Corporation misstated the roles that top executives will have after the transaction is completed. Their roles have not yet been determined. In addition, the total of nonperforming loans in the combined banks at the end of March was misstated. It was $792 million.

title: McGrath Rentcorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Press Problems
description: White House correspondents customarily congregate for briefings in a room off the West Wing, where questions sometimes arise about just who can and who cannot enter.

title: Saints Win, 23-20
description: Morten Andersen's 36-yard field goal as time expired tonight gave New Orleans a 23-20 National Football League preseason victory over the Minnesota Vikings, who knocked the Saints out of the playoffs last season.

title: Biondi Endorses Line of Swimwear
description: Matt Biondia, America's leading male swimmer, has signed a multiyear endorsement contract with Arena International, the swimwear manufacturer announced today.

title: Japan 'Money Politics' Rears Its Head
description: Takako Doi is taking her message to the people, but so far, it seems, the people are not listening. Recently, Miss Doi, who heads the opposition Socialist Party, has been standing on street corners and shouting into a microphone to publicize her call for a full parliamentary investigation into a recent stock trading scandal involving some of the most important politicians in Japan.

title: Mauritius Envoy Makes a Study of American Life
description: Chitmansing Jesseramsing, the Ambassador of Mauritius, arrived here 20 years ago. As one of the longest-serving diplomats in the capital, he has become a student of American life.

title: JUDGE J. SKELLY WRIGHT, SEGREGATION FOE, DIES AT 77
description: J. Skelly Wright, who played an important role in promoting racial desegregation in a long career as a Federal judge, died of prostate cancer Saturday at his home in Westmoreland Hills, Md. He was 77 years old.

title: A Bad Deal For a Good Soldier
description: I am part of a team of Government lawyers. I have never received a perfect evaluation rating and I presume very few of my colleagues have. If one of us was fired for a reason that had nothing to do with his value to the Government - because he was addicted to old B movies, say - it might trigger a Congressional investigation into bureaucratic misconduct.

title: Facing Jail, Biaggi Leads Bronx Feast
description: More than 100 men, huffing and grunting, hoisted 5,000 pounds of shrine onto their shoulders yesterday and marched through a sweltering Bronx street to commemorate a feast that dates to fifth-century Italy. At the base of the 63-foot shrine, beneath figurines representing Saints Anthony and Joseph, the Blessed Mother, Christ and six cherubs, stood a tearful real-life figure: the grand marshal, Mario Biaggi.

title: Aerobics Searches for a Star
description: ANTHONY DeMaio wanted an athletic challenge. Gil Janklowicz needed an activity after an injury ended his Olympic dream. DeMaio, a former modern dancer, and Janklowicz, a former Israeli decathlon champion, discovered an extension of their performing careers. They are aerobics instructors, ''Men don't look at aerobics as just for women anymore,'' DeMaio said. ''Most people thought it would be a trend that would fade out. But its growth in the last five years has been unbelievable.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-12 Iran accepted Iraq's compromise for a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war to be followed by direct talks. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said he would announce a date for the truce today. Page A1

title: Lee Pharmaceuticals reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Met-Coil Systems reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
MEM Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest quarter and 6-month results include negative adjustments for new federal income taxes of $91,000 and $151,000, respectively.

title: Fascination With Faith Fuels Work By Scorsese
description: ''Fundamentalism is not the state religion in this country,'' said Martin Scorsese, with just a trace of anger beneath nervous laughter. The director of ''The Last Temptation of Christ'' had been discreet and controlled in earlier comments about the opposition of some religious groups to his new film. But as the controversy turned uglier a few weeks ago, the work he has repeatedly called ''an act of faith'' seemed engulfed in issues of freeedom of religion, freedom of speech, and anti-Semitism.

title: Golf; After 10 Years, Triumph for Nause
description: Martha Nause ended 10 years of tour frustration today, winning her first Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament by scoring 14 points under a new format. She held on for a 1-point triumph over Judy Dickinson and Debbie Massey in the $400,000 Pat Bradley International.

title: Metro Matters; In Fair Housing, Winning a Battle Leads to Another
description: Dwight H. Merriam's father was a house painter. His mother was a high school dropout. He attended public schools, graduated from Yale and is now a partner in a prestigious Hartford law firm. But he was reminded not long ago that the 768-square-foot house in which he grew up in Massachusetts would be illegal today in nearly one-fourth of Connecticut's 169 cities and towns.

title: TIMING OF WRITER'S STRIKE MAY BE GIFT FOR NETWORKS
description: FOR weeks, executives of the entertainment divisions at ABC, CBS and NBC insisted that the fall television season announced in May would be a casualty of the strike against producers by the Writers Guild of America. They scrambled to put together an ''interim season'' that would include reruns, coverage of news and sports events, series that had been completed but shelved, and other programs that could be made outside union jurisdiction. The strike would increase the defection of viewers to cable, they said, with a consequent reduction of advertising revenue and a further weakening of the networks.

title: PERES AND SHAMIR MEET SHULTZ AIDE
description: Richard W. Murphy, the Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, held talks this afternoon with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and Foreign Minister Shimon Peres.

title: Political Memo; Dukakis Works at Warmth, Yet Tries to Keep His Cool
description: Over the last three weeks, amid the burst of publicity that goes with a national nominating convention, much of America met Michael S. Dukakis for the first time.

title: Shakedown Cruise Pleases Parcells
description: Coach Bill Parcells spent the afternoon watching tapes of the Giants' 34-3 romp over the Packers Saturday night, and his comments, while subdued, were favorable.

title: Spotlight in Trials Shifts to Swimmers
description: With the Olympic Games starting less than six weeks from now in Seoul, South Korea, more than a quarter of the United States team is still to be chosen. Trials in the various sports will continue until Aug. 28.

title: Review/Music; 'Madama Butterfly' In City Opera Staging
description: The New York City Opera's production of ''Madama Butterfly'' has been in the company's repertory for 21 years, and has long been in need of complete directorial revamping. At the Saturday afternoon performance at the New York State Theater, the first in this season's run, it was clear that the needed face lift was not on the company's agenda: the aimless and inconsistent staging remains so distracting that the work's emotional drama nearly sails by unnoticed.

title: Find-Svp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said share earnings for the latest quarter was less than one cent a share.

title: METS BLITZ PIRATES AGAIN; YANKEES BEAT TWINS BY 5-1
description: The idea of an audition did not go over well. Richard Dotson considered the years he had spent as a starter - the games he had won and the innings he had pitched -and said openly that he believed it was unfair.

title: American League; Red Sox Finally Beat the Tigers, 3-0
description: Mike Greenwell's double in the 10th inning triggered a three-run rally today, and Bruce Hurst pitched a six-hitter as the Boston Red Sox beat the Detroit Tigers, 3-0. Boston avoided a sweep in the five-game series.

title: Five Reportedly Slain During Burma Unrest
description: Official Burmese newspapers were quoted as reporting today that five people were killed and an undetermined number were wounded during anti-Government protests over the weekend. Students in Rangoon, the capital, reportedly called for a nationwide general strike Monday.

title: Flying the Flag
description: The United States Navy is making no immediate plans to withdraw from the Persian Gulf even though Iran and Iraq are giving indications that they may end their eight-year war, thus reducing the threat to oil tankers the warships were sent to protect.

title: A Rural Landscape, but an Urban Boom
description: To many who live here in Wayne County, a land of magnificent pine and hardwood forests, of lakes, trout streams, deer and black bear in the far northwestern reaches of the Pocono Mountains, it all seems to have happened with frightening speed.

title: INTERNATIONAL REPORT: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: Iraq is to sell 47 state-run factories in a drive to spur private industry, The Baghdad Observer said. Hussein Kamel, the new Minister of Industry and Military Industrialization, told a recent meeting of business officials that the sale was ''designed to give a wider role for this sector in pushing forward Iraq's economic development.'' He said that if private business was not interested in buying the factories, the Government would form them into cooperatives with shares initially sold to employees. Business sources said the factories mostly made textile, plastic and aluminum products.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Gravymaster Moves To Posey Quest Genova
description: Gravymaster Inc., of Branford, Conn., has gone to Posey Quest Genova Inc. for advertising and marketing help for its Gravy Master Seasoning and Browning Sauce. It was formerly handled by the Highland Group in Southport, Conn.

title: An Officer Kills Youth in a Fight While Off Duty
description: An off-duty New York City police officer shot and killed a teen-ager and wounded three others Saturday night after he intervened in a fight that had broken out next door to his Long Island home and was attacked by the youths, the police said yesterday.

title: Mark Rothko's Harvard Murals Are Irreparably Faded by Sun
description: Although a quarter-century has passed since they were first displayed, the five murals Mark Rothko painted for Harvard remain a source of controversy and embarrassment at the university. Fingers have been pointed toward various factions in the Harvard administration and at the artist himself, but no matter where blame rests, the reasons for distress can clearly be seen: What Rothko donated to the university to cover the walls of a penthouse dining room intended for ceremonial functions has been irreparably damaged by overexposure to the sun. Lush crimson-toned paintings have faded to a variety of unrelated blue colors; they cannot be restored, The murals, which have also been ripped, spattered with food and marred by graffiti, were retired to storage nine years ago from the room in the Holyoke Center where they had been hung, their battered canvases a lingering humiliation to the university that had requested them. Plans to clean the panels and to install three of them in the school's Arthur M. Sackler Museum got far enough that the building's architect, James Stirling, included a niche for them in his plan.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Agency's New Name: Hawley Martin Partners
description: There's a new name on the agency scene in Richmond this morning. The new name is also an old name -Hawley Martin Partners.

title: International Totalizator Systems reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and includes tax credits of $97,000 for the quarter and $212,000 for the 6 months.

title: Anglican Leader Praises the American Church
description: Preaching this morning at the closing ceremony of a world meeting of Anglican bishops, the head of the Episcopal Church in the United States reinforced sensitive themes that have been identified with the American presence here - the role of women and the transformation of the church.

title: Judith Weinstein Weds Dr. Mathew MacCumber
description: The marriage of Judith Ann Weinstein, a daughter of Marcia Weinstein of West Orange, N.J., and the late Dr. David Weinstein, to Dr. Mathew Wilmen MacCumber, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Billy MacCumber of East Hanover, N.J., took place yesterday in South Orange, N.J. Rabbi Harvey Goldman performed the ceremony at Temple Sharey Tefilo-Israel.

title: 'Speed-the-Plow' Cast to Be Changed
description: David Rasche, Bob Balaban and Felicity Huffman will replace Joe Mantegna, Ron Silver and Madonna, respectively, in David Mamet's ''Speed-the-Plow,'' beginning Aug. 30 at the Royale Theater, 242 West 45th Street.

title: Women in the Law Say Path Is Limited by 'Mommy Track'
description: Despite inroads made by women at the nation's top law firms, a new two-level system is emerging in the legal profession, with women on the bottom.

title: In Haiti, Once Again, Murder in the Night
description: To the Editor:

title: Asia Lab to Help Grace Keep Up With Japanese
description: Kiichiro Sasaguri, a Japanese polymer scientist who last week opened W. R. Grace & Company's first research laboratory in Asia, sees himself as an international ''bridge'' between the business and scientific worlds.

title: JUICES FLOW IN CHICAGO AS WRIGLEY LIGHTS UP
description: AT the southwest corner of Clark and Addison, opposite the large red marquee that celebrates ''Wrigley Field Home of Chicago Cubs,'' Officer Frank Paluch knew what time it was without consulting a timepiece. ''Hey, game's over,'' he shouted to his colleagues. ''Let's go.''

title: Commodore Environmental Services reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss c-Net income

title: Gunmen Shoot 5 On a Bronx Street
description: Two people were critically injured and three others were wounded when four men walked up to a group of people in the Bronx and started firing early yesterday, the police said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Medcom Acquisition
description: Medcom Partners, largely owned by Park Avenue Publishing, has acquired Illustrated Medicine, from Wynwood Publishing. The publication is Medcom's fourth acquisition since spring. No details of the deal were disclosed. Illustrated Medicine is a single-subject, single-sponsor magazine with a 10-a-year publishing frequency.

title: WAR HERO AND A CONGRESSMAN
description: James P.S. Devereux, a World War II hero and former Maryland Congressman, died of pneumonia Friday at Stella Maris Hospice in Baltimore. He was 85 years old and was a resident of Ruxton, Md.

title: Cagle's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $155,000. c-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $278,000.

title:
ON YOUR OWN: FITNESS;
Mountain Biking: Exercise With a View
description: LEAD: THIRTY years ago, two brothers growing up on a cattle ranch here rode their cow ponies over the plains and through the mountains, helping with the ranch work. The horse was still a central figure in ranch life then, and it was routine to ride 10 miles at a bone-jarring trot in order to work with a group of cattle and then return home at the same unpleasant pace.

title: TV Notes
description: A Look at RKO Lore

title: HUSSEIN IS FROSTY ON NEW P.L.O. ROLE
description: King Hussein of Jordan repeatedly asserted today that he considers the Palestine Liberation Organization. ''the sole and legitimate representative of the Palestinian people.'' But there was little enthusiasm in his words, and his attitude toward the P.L.O. was cool throughout a news conference here..

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed belfor major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday Retail Sales July Friday Producer Prices July Inventory-Sales Ratio June

title: Ex-Justice Suggests Legislators Reconsider Capital Punishment
description: Former Supreme Court Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr., critical of the long delays that have prevented most death sentences from being carried out, suggested today that legislators reconsider whether capital punishment should be retained.

title: 'The Goldbergs' - Stereotypes Loved By Americans
description: LEAD: The death of the character actor Eli Mintz in June triggered memories of another era. In the late 40's and early 50's, he played the role of Uncle David in the hit television show ''The Goldbergs,'' a family sitcom that had begun as a radio serial in 1929.

title: 2 Suits Against Seagate
description: Seagate Technology Inc., a Scotts Valley, Calif., manufacturer of hard disk drives, said Friday that two suits had been filed accusing it of securities law violations in connection with public statements the company made from Oct. 13, 1987, to July 20, 1988. The class-action complaints, brought on behalf of everyone who bought Seagate stock in that period, were filed July 29 in United States District Court in San Jose, Calif. Seagate surprised Wall Street analysts on July 18 when it reported fourth-quarter earnings of $16.5 million, or 33 cents a share, less than half what they had estimated.

title: Hermosillo Journal; Scornful and Scorned, the New Yorkers of Mexico
description: A popular bumper sticker seen here and in other cities across the interior of Mexico demands, ''Chilangos go home.'' In the same spirit, walls here and elsewhere are covered with graffiti urging Mexicans, ''Do something for your country: Kill a chilango,'' or asking that ''God protect us from the chilangos.''

title: Cliffs Drilling Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago quarter and 6-month include a $23,698,000 charge to reduce the carrying value of the company's land drilling rigs to estimated recognizable size.

title: TAX-LOSS CASE DEFENDANTS APPEALING FREEZE ON ASSETS
description: A Federal appeals court is expected to rule today on a restraining order that froze some assets of six men indicted on charges that they had engaged in a racketeering conspiracy to create illegal tax losses through fraudulent stock deals.

title: Shultz, on Tour of Latin America, Is Spreading the Capitalist Word
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, touring emerging democratic nations of South America, is carrying the message that political democracy and free market economics are naturally linked.

title: Outdoors: Foiling the Dragonfly's Tactics of Evasion
description: LEAD: WITH heat wave after heat wave baking the tri-state area, largemouth bass should be off their feed and seeking refuge in spring holes. But this has not been the case in ponds that I have fished. The bass have been gorging themselves on adult dragonflies, which appear to be particularly abundant this summer.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; A Magazine Is Planned For Neiman
description: A COUPLE of the people who were involved in Tiffany, A Magazine of Celebration, a one-shot publication in 1987, are now creating another upscale print vehicle for yet another store synonymous with elegance: Neiman-Marcus.

title: Horse Racing; Brian's Time Wins Jim Dandy in Rally
description: Brian's Time was a late foal, born May 28 three years ago. As he competed in the Triple Crown races this spring, his trainer, John Veitch, kept saying that the colt would get even better as the season went on and the colt caught up to his contemporaries.

title: French Rail Chief Quits After 2d Paris Crash
description: The president of France's state-run railroad resigned today after the second fatal train crash in Paris in six weeks. The Government attributed the crash in part to a failure by officials to move ahead with measures ordered after the earlier wreck.

title: CBS Undergoes a Cultural Change
description: When it was announced last month that Howard Stringer, the president of CBS News, had been promoted to president of all CBS broadcast operations, a television producer named Steve Friedman was slightly disturbed by the development. It was nothing personal, but Mr. Friedman had a business interest at stake.

title: Associated Hosts Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
From North Sea to Greek Isles, Europe's Beaches Suffer, Too
description: Though the Germans are loath to admit it, the long arm of sea pollution has even reached Sylt, an island long famous for its pristine beaches and the summer resort of choice for West Germany's industrialists.

title: Computer Factory Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Review/Television; 'A Summer Ghost,' on Channel 13
description: A chubby, lonely young English girl, an Italian principessa of fading beauty and the legend of a man who haunts the house where his brother murdered him: ''A Summer Ghost'' has all the elements of an eerie psychological drama. When we first see the adolescent heroine, Maureen (Susan Bradley), she has tracing paper and crayons, and sits at a table intently re-creating a picture of Jesus while ''Love Letters in the Sand'' plays in the background. It is 1962, and this eldest of four children in a British family living in Italy is a pathetic and unlikely heroine. The skin around her constantly licked lips is always chapped. She is rude to the prim young Scottish woman who tutors the children, and she spends her time lying on her bed dreaming of being a svelte, alluring Hollywood starlet.

title: Late Subways Bode Ill For Metropolitan Area
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times; Tales of Love, Affection And a Distance of Years
description: Jack of Diamonds and Other Stories By Elizabeth Spencer 184 pages. Viking. $15.95.

title: U.S. Seniors Golf; Charles in Playoff After Losing Lead
description: Bob Charles, the left-hander from New Zealand, apparently had the United States Senior Open championship in hand with a three-shot lead and four holes to play in the final round at Medinah Country Club today. But he lost it all and finished in a tie with South Africa's Gary Player, the defending champion in this leading golf event for men 50 and older.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Aetna Life and Casualty Co., Hartford, an insurer, promoted Stephen B. Middlebrook to senior vice president and general counsel.

title: Murdoch Agrees to Buy TV Guide In a $3 Billion Sale by Annenberg
description: Walter H. Annenberg has agreed to sell Triangle Publications Inc., publisher of TV Guide, Daily Racing Form and Seventeen magazine, to Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation for $3 billion, a price that dwarfs the next largest takeover in publishing.

title: Natalia Makarova Dances Again With the Kirov
description: Natalia Makarova, the Russian ballerina who defected to the West 18 years ago, danced with the Kirov Ballet here last night, becoming the first Russian dancer allowed to perform with a Soviet company after emigrating to the West.

title: Radioactive Matter Believed Swallowed
description: A Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation employee apparently swallowed a radioactive substance while he was taking pictures under the Nine Mile 1 nuclear power plant reactor vessel in Oswego last month, a spokesman at the utility's headquarters here has confirmed.

title: Stream of Victims Tests Pretoria's War Hospital
description: The human cost of the 15-year conflict along the border between South-West Africa and Angola is starkly evident as South Africa's main military hospital receives a small but steady stream of soldiers, both black and white, who were wounded in clashes in Angola and on the border.

title: China Futures Roles Widened
description: Foreigners will be allowed to trade on China's planned commodities futures markets, the first in a communist country, a senior official said in a newspaper article.

title: Caracas Energy Minister Is Said to Resign
description: Venezuela's Energy Minister, Arturo Hernandez Grisanti, has resigned, the official press agency Venpres reported today.

title: Colonial Commercial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sports World Specials; Ferry's Trials
description: The early days of summer proved rather cruel for the family and the basketball fortunes of Danny Ferry, the Duke forward. Then again, they could have been far worse.

title: Many Good Reasons For Hiring a Tutor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexican Shift on Economy Seen
description: The contentiousness and turmoil of their Presidential election largely behind them, Mexicans are once again focusing on the country's longest-running drama: the perils of the economy.

title: Jackson Meets With Israel's Envoy
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson met for two and a half hours today with Moshe Arad, the Israeli Ambassador to the United States, and described the session as a ''tremendous beginning'' in repairing relations between American blacks and Jews.

title: Matthews & Wright Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
AN ODD TRIO FOR MURDOCH: TV, TEENS AND RACING
description: LEAD: Rupert Murdoch could hardly have pocketed three more eclectic publications - a weekly television guide that is the most widely read magazine in the country, a monthly magazine that tells teen-age girls how to stay fit and beautiful and a daily racing newspaper packed with track minutiae.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: AUTO RACING Senna Wins in Hungary: Ayrton Senna of Brazil and his teammate, Alain Prost of France, swept the top two places yesterday in the Hungarian Grand Prix at Budapest, stretching McLaren Honda's winning streak to 10 for the season.

title: Pedal Boats Go High Tech
description: The first versions of the pedal boat often appeared at amusement parks and hotel beachfronts. These pontoon-based craft, driven by paddle wheels, tended to skid sideways as easily as they moved forward. New technology has improved the idea, harnessing the power of the propeller and adapting it to foot pedals. The result is a recent wave of pedal boats that manufacturers claim will slice through the water at 5-10 miles per hour and track a straight course in a crosswind.

title: Karen Froimson Wed in Cleveland
description: Karen Beth Froimson, an associate at Weil, Gotshal & Manges, and Gregory Wade Conway, an associate at Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett, both New York law firms, were married yesterday at the Oakwood Club in Cleveland by Rabbi Armond E. Cohen.

title: Mandatory Prayer?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: Two experts from the New York metropolitan region held a commanding lead here tonight going into the final session of the Life Master Pair Championship, the concluding event of the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals.

title: Margaret Mead Film Series at Museum
description: The Chernobyl nuclear accident in the Soviet Union and Balinese and Hindu dancing are two of the subjects that will be included in the 12th Margaret Mead Film Festival, from Sept. 26 to 29 at the American Museum of Natural History. More than 50 films of sociological interest will be screened; some of them are New York premieres and several of them will be introduced by their directors.

title: Republicans Seeking Broad Platform
description: The Republican platform committee began gathering here today to write a document that party leaders hope will reaffirm the basic principles of the Reagan era while allowing Vice President Bush to address the more topical issues of 1988, such as child care.

title: Melissa Reiner Weds Geoffrey Greener
description: The marriage of Melissa Jill Reiner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur E. Reiner of New York and Middletown, N.J., to Geoffrey Stephen Greener, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Jack Greener of Hollywood, Fla., took place yesterday at the Pierre in New York. Rabbi Harlan J. Wechsler performed the ceremony.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Aug. 8, 1988: MONDAY Carlisle Co Meredith Corp TUESDAY Champion Spark Plug Questar Corp Chicago Pacific Russ Berrie & Co McDermott Intl SunTrust Banks Pennzoil Co Toro Co WEDNESDAY Alco Standard Corp Fort Howard Corp Baltimore Bancorp Leggett & Platt Current Income Shs USG Corp THURSDAY Allegheny Ludlum Lincoln National Corp Carpenter Tech Louisiana General Dover Corp Maytag Corp KeyCorp Wal-Mart Stores FRIDAY Centel Corp State Mutual Svcs Eastman Kodak Texas Utilities Hospital Corp America US Life Inc

title: Mark Edelstein Married To Stephanie Jacqueney
description: Stephanie A. Jacqueney, an assistant counsel at Manhattan Cable Television, and Mark Scott Edelstein, an associate at the Manhattan law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, were married yesterday at the International Center in New York by Rabbi Robert A. Jacobs.

title: The Trade Law's Potential
description: There is more bad than good in the foreign trade bill now on its way to the White House. But its ultimate impact depends on future Presidents. Only time will tell whether it sets off an endless cycle of crippling tit-for-tat restrictions or encourages healthy expansion.

title: Behind the Park Melee, a New Generation Gap
description: If the bloody clash early yesterday between hundreds of young people and 450 police officers in Tompkins Square bears the ragged earmarks of political protest, it is rooted in a less gripping social schism: a feud between the area's sleepless over-30 residents and younger, noisier revelers on the streets outside.

title: Tennis; Becker Smashes McEnroe
description: Top-seeded Boris Becker used his big serve to defeat John McEnroe, 6-4, 6-2, today and capture the $415,000 United States Hardcourts tennis tournament.

title: Park Curfew Protest Erupts Into a Battle And 38 Are Injured
description: Hundreds of demonstrators protesting the overnight closing of a park in Manhattan's East Village clashed with 450 riot-equipped police officers early yesterday in bloody street skirmishes that turned the neighborhood into something like a war zone.

title: Stock Market Warning
description: The Tokyo Stock Exchange issued a letter to all its employees last week, warning them never to trade on nonpublic information that they acquire in the course of duty or to participate in any activity that might give the appearance of insider trading.

title: Racing Boat Hits Spectators in Pittsburgh; 24 Hurt
description: A speeding Formula One racing boat veered out of control in a race on the Allegheny River today, hitting spectators on the bank of the river and injuring 24 people, eight critically. Eleven of the injured were children, the police said.

title: Revive Artificial Heart With Money and Vision
description: To the Editor:

title: The Shame of New York's Election Law
description: It's an embarrassing and pointless August ritual: the orgy of court fights over nominating petitions for New York's ballot. Endless legal challenges make New York home to fully half the election-law litigation in America. How many more elections will be marred before the State Legislature rescues voters from this affront to democracy?

title: Island-Bound
description: The Reagan White House has not yet given up rewarding political supporters. Robert O. Johns, a California podiatrist with longstanding ties to Mr. Reagan, has been selected to be Ambassador to Barbados.

title: For Governors, Focus Is Federalism
description: It is not, as Gov. John H. Sununu of New Hampshire concedes, the sexiest of political issues. Nor is it, as Gov. Gerald L. Baliles of Virginia notes, the ordinary stuff of ''table talk.''

title: Chess

They each scored 6 1/2-2 1/2 against an otherwise all-male field that included two grandmasters.

description: White-maned and approaching his 52d birthday, John S. McCain is the Senate's young man in a hurry.

title: Jim Baker and the Virtues of Pragmatism
description: James Baker has given President Reagan outstanding service in two quite different roles. As low-profile White House chief of staff in the first term and high-profile Secretary of the Treasury in the second, he leavened the Reagan revolution with healthy pragmatism, intelligence and political skill. He leaves the Treasury now to head Vice President Bush's Presidential campaign, perhaps to return in a Bush administration.

title: Levin's Family, Citing Drinking, Sues Dorrian's
description: The owners of Dorrian's Red Hand restaurant in Manhattan were accused yesterday of having used Robert E. Chambers as ''a decoy and an enticement'' to attract underage people, especially young women, as patrons.

description: IT'S back-to-school time, and for many parents and college-bound students it is also decision time. Does buying a personal computer make sense? If so, which computer to buy?

title: By Design; Holding Up
description: One of the first signs of fall could be the change in the shape of your handbag. The newest ones are - as they say in the business - structured. Translate that to mean the bag is no longer pliable or soft, changing its shape by what you put in it. Instead, the fabric or leather covering is applied around and over a frame. The bag will retain its shape no matter what is stuffed inside.

But there remains a duty for the committee to examine serious charges of wrongdoing made during the trial against another Representative from the Bronx, Robert Garcia.

title: For Rational, National Health Care
description: National health insurance: for 40 years the words have meant politically impossible, utopian. Now, perhaps, this idea's time has come. The plight of the uninsured was a recurrent theme at the Democratic Convention, and Michael Dukakis has committed himself to ''basic health insurance for every American.'' George Bush and the Republicans have not yet been heard from, but even Congressional conservatives acknowledge that something must be done for the uninsured.

title: Salming Returns
description: Borje Salming, the veteran of 15 National Hockey League seasons, said yesterday in a call from Sweden to Toronto that he had agreed to return to the Maple Leafs for a 16th year. Salming, 37, who became a free agent last month, said he accepted a one-year deal with Toronto that will pay him the same salary he received last season, approximately $350,000. ''I feel good about it,'' he said from Sweden. ''I was looking for either a one or two-year deal. One is fine.'' He said offers from Edmonton and Philadelphia might have given him ''a bit more money,'' but not enough to induce him to leave Toronto where his children attend school and his wife is established in the clothing business. (AP)

title: Market Place; The Sharp Rise In DeKalb's Stock
description: IN the 10 months that the DeKalb Corporation has been telling Wall Street about its unusual restructuring plan, the company's stock price has nearly doubled. The idea is for the Illinois-based conglomerate to split into three, possibly four, publicly traded companies by the end of this month. That would allow its disparate lines of business, which include oil and gas exploration, oil well servicing, irrigation equipment manufacturing and agricultural genetics, to stand alone.

title: Jets' Secondary Starting Over
description: The Jets made another dramatic cut with their recent past today, dropping Jerry Holmes, a former starting cornerback, and releasing Harry Hamilton, the unsigned free safety.

title: FOR JAZZ MUSICIANS, MAX ROACH A SYMBOL OF ART OVER AGE

''I thought it had something to do with the Chicago Jazz Festival, which is something I've always wanted to play at.''

title: SmithKline's Day of Reckoning

title: Science Watch; Serengeti 'Hot Spots'
description: Year after year, animals graze in ''hot spots'' in the grasslands of the Serengeti in Tazania. Some scientists have suggested that the animals congregate so they can cluster together to protect themselves from predators. Others have said it is so animals can cooperate in grazing, with some eating high grasses and other eating the lower grasses left behind. But neither of these explanations could account for why the animals always grazed in the same places.

A LESS DEFIANT CONTEMPORARY SPIRIT
description: This year's weeklong Contemporary Music Festival at Tanglewood advertises Hans Werner Henze and Elliott Carter as its principal components. Mr. Henze is in residence for the summer. His powerful and disturbing Seventh Symphony was played in the Shed on Saturday night by the Boston Symphony under Seiji Ozawa. On Sunday night his opera, ''Elegy for Young Lovers,'' was offered at the smaller Theater-Concert Hall. More Henze comes on Wednesday with the new (to this country) ''Sieben Liebeslieder'' for cello and orchestra.

title: Boxer Fails Drug Test
description: Miguel Lora of Colombia, the World Boxing Council bantamweight champion, won a unanimous 12-round decision over Albert Davila of Pomona, Calif., Aug. 1 at the Forum in Inglewood, Calif., but the California Athletic Commission announced yesterday that traces of two banned drugs had been found in the urine of Lora in postfight tests. Dr. Robert Karnes of Beverly Hills, the commission's physician, reported that traces of amphetamines and metaphine were found. The commission has scheduled a hearing for testimony from Lora, Davila and their representatives on Aug. 19. Any decision on the status of the championship, which Lora has held since 1985, would have to come from the W.B.C. president, Jose Sulaiman, in Mexico City.(AP)

title: Cuomo and Koch Start Push For a Transport Bond Issue
description: Saying there is ''nothing more significant than our effort to rehabilitate the infrastructure,'' Governor Cuomo, joined by Mayor Koch, met yesterday in front of the Williamsburg Bridge to press for passage of a $3 billion state transportation bond issue.

Becker Injured
description: Boris Becker, the two-time champion of Wimbledon, withdrew yesterday from the $815,000 Player's International tournament in Toronto with injuries to both feet that could jeopardize his participation in the United States Open at Flushing Meadows, Queens, later this month. Becker, who defeated John McEnroe in straight sets in the final of the United States Hardcourts championship in Indianapolis on Sunday, was found to have an inflammation of a fibrous tissue that runs from the heel to the toe, according to Dr. J. P. Schaman. He said Becker has a ''50-50 chance'' of healing in time for the Aug. 29 opening of the Open. Although he said he knew of no cases in which the injury required surgery, Schaman said the injury has the potential to become chronic if not treated immediately. Becker said he suffered the injury six weeks ago, but that it got better when he took time off. It resurfaced, he said, at Indianapolis from running on the hard courts. ''It sounds crazy that I beat McEnroe, 6-4, 6-2, yesterday and today I can't play,'' he said. ''But the farther I got in the tournament, the more it hurt. I woke up this morning and I said, 'I'm 20 years old and I can't walk to the bathroom. What is this?' ''We have the U.S. Open and the Olympics coming up and I want to be 100 percent for that.''(AP)

title: Elisa Malinovitz Wed
description: Elisa Malinovitz, a weather broadcaster for KDFW-TV in Dallas, and Jeffrey Eliasoph, a news anchor at KTBS-TV in Shreveport, La., were married yesterday at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens. Rabbi Thomas Weiner officiated. The bride, who uses the name Elisa Robin, is the daughter of Harold Malinovitz of North Hollywood, Calif., and the late Norma Malinovitz. Mr. Eliasoph is the son of Ann Eliasoph of New York and Dr. Ira Eliasoph of White Plains.

description: If film is centered in Los Angeles and theater in New York, then what of Poughkeepsie?

Strange Glow Is Found at Bottom of Pacific
description: INFERENCES drawn by a sharp-eyed biology student from her study of a peculiar eyeless shrimp have led to the discovery of a mysterious glow emitted by a scalding jet of water more than one mile beneath the surface of the Pacific Ocean.

title: PC Magazine Sees Buyers As 'Heroes'
description: ONE day recently vendors of new I.B.M. PC-compatible hardware and software -some of which was secret because of competitive pressure - quietly brought their equipment to 20 suites at the Plaza Hotel. It was Ziff-Davis's PC Magazine holding Editor's Day in New York.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING Fourstardave Wins Close One: Fourstardave and Whodam lumbered to the wire as a team and it took the fourth tight photo finish of the day to decide that Fourstardave had won the $100,000 Albany Stakes yesterday at Saratoga Race Track. Fourstardave, who conceded 12 pounds to the runner-up while carrying top weight of 126, scored by a nose in the race, restricted to New York-bred 3-year-olds. Ballindaggin finished third as the 3-2 favorite, 4 1/2 lengths behind the top pair and 2 1/2 lengths in front of Achenar. Fourstardave paid $8 for $2 to win and ran the mile and an eighth in 1:50 2/5 under Angel Cordero Jr. TRACK AND FIELD Slaney Falls Short of Mark: Mary Slaney missed her world mile record by six seconds, clocking 4 minutes 22.86 seconds at a meet yesterday in Malmo, Sweden. Her time was the best of the season for the 29-year-old American, who set the world record of 4:16.71 in the Weltklasse meet at Zurich in 1985. Ruth Wysocki was second in 4:28.25 and Vicki Huber made it an American triple in 4:28.77. TENNIS American Gains: Marty Davis of the United States beat Martin Wostenholme of Canada, 6-2, 3-6, 6-3, in an opening-round match yesterday in the $815,000 Player's International tournament in Toronto. Martin Laurendeau, a member of Canada's Olympic team, fell victim to unforced errors as Yaya Doumbia of Senegal won, 7-5, 6-3, in a night match. In other early matches, Derrick Rostagno beat a fellow American, Richey Reneberg, 7-5, 6-2, and Doug Flach of the United States beat Francisco Maciel of Mexico, 4-6, 6-1, 6-2.(AP)

Dukakis leading Vice President Bush, although the lead in the region - 44 percent to 35 percent - did not exceed the margin of sampling error for the 338 interviews there.

But the continued withholding of the American contribution to the United Nations budget casts doubt on the organization's ability to carry out the accords it has fostered.

title: Conoco to Buy Phillips Reserves
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company will sell its oil and gas holdings in the Williston Basin of Montana and North Dakota to Conoco Inc. for an undisclosed sum. The sale is part of Phillips's strategy to divest nonstrategic assets, a company spokesman said. Since 1985, Phillips has sold gas plants in Williston and Tioga, N.D., he said.
