description: The Kuala Lumpur Commodity Exchange began trading in cocoa futures today to coincide with the date 8/8/88, which many Chinese and others in Malaysia believe brings great prosperity. The exchange is the first futures market for cocoa in Asia. Malaysia is the world's third-largest producer of cocoa after the Ivory Coast and Brazil.

title: Tilghman Island Journal; Skipjack Fleet May Sail Into History
description: Darryl Larrimore never thought he would see the day when the Nellie L. Byrd would be for sale.

title: Alan Napier, Actor, Dies at 85
description: Alan Napier, a character actor in England and the United States for more than 50 years, and best known for his role in the ''Batman'' television series of the 1960's, died of pneumonia yesterday in the Berkeley East Convalescent Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 85 years old.

title: Bemis Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FMC Gold Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Angola Truce Now
description: South Africa, Angola and Cuba announced today that they had agreed that their forces would observe an immediate cease-fire in Angola and the neighboring territory of Namibia. They issued a joint statement declaring that ''a de facto cessation of hostilities is now in effect.''

title: On Horse Racing; Greatness Proven, Personal Ensign Aims at a Perfect Finish
description: No one took much time to savor Personal Ensign's smashing victory against the boys in the Whitney Handicap at Saratoga Race Track on Saturday. Instead, everyone wants her to do it again, and is asking two questions: Will the undefeated filly, having beaten males for the first time, ever try the boys again? Will she have to in order to win the Horse of the Year award?

title: On My Mind; The Tibetan File
description: The file has been on the desk for weeks - the clippings about arrests, beatings and killings and a copy of the historic speech to which the world paid almost no attention at all.

title: Shuttle Firing Rescheduled
description: The test firing of the shuttle's main engine, postponed by a series of leaks and other problems, has been rescheduled for Wednesday, NASA officials said today. They said a new valve, installed to replace one whose malfunction caused the latest delay, had tested satisfactorily in the shuttle Discovery's engine compartment.

title: Article 460888 -- No Title
description: The Senate today overwhelmingly approved a $3.9 billion bill to assist farmers, agricultural businesses and others hurt by the drought.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Pentagon auditors discovered repeated overcharges totaling hundreds of millions of dollars on military contracts with 95 suppliers. The four-year investigation is believed to be the most comprehensive ever of the pricing of military contracts. The confidential report provides detailed evidence that excessive charges by military contractors are common. [ Page A1. ] Attorney General Meese approved an antitrust exemption for The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press, overruling his staff. The waiver will allow the papers to merge business operations while publishing separately. Mr. Meese said The Free Press's losses would have forced it out of business. Opponents said that the papers' owners had not done all they could to stem losses. [ D1. ] A House committee called on the Postal Service to cancel the contract it awarded without bidding to Perot Systems. The committee said the Postal Service should comply with a ruling last week by the G.S.A. Board of Contract Appeals. [ D5. ] A Federal District judge froze more than 200 accounts or other assets associated with the six men charged with a racketeering conspiracy to create illegal tax losses. [ D2. ] People should not serve as anonymous sources for journalists, a New York public relations firm told its clients. [ D18. ] MARKETS The dollar held firm against major currencies despite efforts by the Federal Reserve, the Bank of England and the Bundesbank to slow its advance. Among central banks, only the Bank of Japan did not appear concerned that the strengthening U.S. economy and the prospect of higher interest rates would stimulate demand for dollars. Gold fell $1.90 an ounce, to $430.40, on the Comex. [ D1. ] The stock market weakened in the final minutes of trading after marking time for most of the session. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 11.73 points, to close at 2,107.40. [ D6. ] Oil futures prices surged after the announcement of a cease-fire in the eight-year war between Iran and Iraq. Corn, oat and soybean futures plunged after unexpectedly heavy showers in the northern Midwest. [ D13. ] Prices of Treasury bonds and notes were mixed in slow trading, as dealers prepared for today's start of the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions. [ D15. ] COMPANIES Rupert Murdoch's ability to finance his $3 billion deal for Triangle Publications, the publisher of TV Guide and other properties, is not questioned by most publishing executives. [ D1. ] Hershey Foods will sell its Friendly chain for about $375 million to Tennessee Restaurant. Friendly owns 850 full-service restaurants that specialize in ice cream. [ D1. ] Interco rejected a sweetened offer of $70 a share, or about $2.53 billion, from an investor group. Interco, the nation's largest maker of shoes and furniture, rejected the bid from City Capital Associates, which is controlled by the Rales brothers. [ D1. ] CBS will buy WCIX-TV, an independent station in Miami, for $59 million, from TVX Broadcast Group of Norfolk, Va. [ D18. ] Texas Air's losses widened sharply and TWA's profits soared in second-quarter earnings. [ D5. ] Grand Metropolitan may sell Inter-Continental Hotels. It said it had received inquiries from several parties. [ D4. ] Farmers Group will seek to overturn last week's court decision that ordered California's insurance commissioner to reverse herself and approve B.A.T. Industries' takeover of Farmers. [ D4. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Many experts on insurance benefits say Circle K overreacted when it said it would deny coverage to employees who have had illnesses and accidents related to alcohol, drugs and AIDS. Business and Health. [ D2. ] DeKalb's stock price has nearly doubled since it announced an unusual restructuring plan, in which it will split into three or four publicly traded companies. Market Place. [ D6. ]

title: Henri Frenay, Resistance Fighter, 82
description: Henri Frenay, a leader of the French Resistance in World War II, has died, family members said today. He was 82 years old.

title: Halsey Drug Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: U.S. Senior Open; Player Wins 2d Straight Title
description: Given a second chance when Bob Charles lost a three-shot lead Sunday, Gary Player came back today to beat the left-handed New Zealander by two shots in an 18-hole playoff for his second consecutive United States Senior Open championship.

title: Review/Theater; In Williamstown, Mass., 'Liaisons' Without the Dangereuses
description: A year after its Broadway closing, ''Les Liaisons Dangereuses'' has achieved a cult reputation well out of proportion to its modest four-month New York run. Not everyone who saw Christopher Hampton's stage adaptation of the 1782 Choderlos de Laclos novel admired it, but those who did were swept away. The play, like its literary source, has a distressing thematic afterlife. As two cynical but attractive French aristocrats of the ancien regime play their vicious games of sex and power, the distance between then and now steadily evaporates. Narcissism, aggression, revenge - these are human fashions, ugly yet eternally alluring, that neither political nor cultural revolutions can ever dethrone.

title: Experts Are Critical Of Police Handling Of Protest in Park
description: Inadequate deployment and supervision of officers were partly to blame for New York City police officers losing the upper hand and descending into a pitched battle with a band of bottle-throwing protesters and hapless bystanders in Tompkins Square, police officials and criminal-justice experts said yesterday.

title: Botswana's President Hurt in Jet Explosion
description: President Quett K. Masire of Botswana suffered minor back injuries Sunday night when one of the engines of his plane exploded at 35,000 feet while he was on the way to a meeting of southern African leaders in Angola.

title: Nuclear Metals Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Texas Air Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest periods' operating losses included an adjustment of $131 million made by Continental relating to an accounting adjustment associated with the re-estimation of its air traffic liability.

title: 1.5 Million Sudanese Homeless After Floods
description: About 1.5 million of Khartoum's 4 million people are without food or shelter after floods devastated the Sudanese capital last week, Government officials said today.

title: Determining Why Smog Can Be Deadly
description: MOST episodes of smog are simply annoying, but some can cause severe illness and death especially among the elderly and people with respiratory problems. Despite thousands of smog-related deaths here and abroad in recent decades, scientists are still uncertain why smog can sometimes be deadly.

title: Shultz Caravan Is Bomb Target On Bolivia Visit
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and his delegation escaped unhurt today when a bomb exploded along their motorcade route. Four vehicles were damaged, including the car carrying Mr. Shultz's wife, as the group traveled toward La Paz from the airport. She was unhurt.

title: Gibson Greetings Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest periods included a $1,949,000 gain from the sale of a foreign subsidiary. Revenue represents gross billings.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Looking to Autumn
description: Forget about caucuses, conventions, campaign speeches. The significant telltale of the November election, in the view of participants on both sides, is the baseball game to be played tonight in Alexandria, Va., between Republican and Democratic members of the Congress.

title: Moscow Begins Destruction Of SS-20 Missile Launchers
description: The Soviet Union has begun to destroy launchers and vehicles for SS-20 medium-range nuclear missiles under the recent superpower treaty, the Tass press agency reported today.

title: Coleman Sets Sale Of 2 Subsidiaries
description: The Coleman Company said it had agreed to sell its Coast Catamaran Corporation and Golden Eagle Archery Inc. units. Terms were not disclosed, but the company said the net result of the transactions would not have a negative effect on earnings.

title: This Time, Hussein Isn't Being Coy
description: LEAD: King Hussein's pronouncements are being interpreted, and reinterpreted, as if they were a Talmudic text. The plain truth has been lost: Far from being a ploy to prove that only he can govern the West Bank, his statements represent a fundamental decision for a Jordan without Palestine.

title: Project Will Scrutinize Psychotherapy Sessions
description: BECAUSE pyschotherapy takes place behind closed doors and so much of the undertaking is necessarily subjective, researchers have often expressed an intense scientific curiosity: What is really going on between the therapist and the patient? What makes one therapist more effective than another? Why do so many patients forget what they seem to learn during a session as soon as they leave it?

title: Chicago's Black-Jewish Divisions Made Worse; Only Certain Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: Taxes, By Any Other Name...
description: LEAD: The Democrats face a serious dilemma in their attempt to win the White House this November. They know they cannot prevail by advocating a tax increase. Walter F. Mondale taught them that much. Yet, to distinguish themselves from Republicans and for ideological reasons the party feels it must be true to its traditions of increasing social services and being the party of Big

title: Marriott Venture
description: The Marriott Corporation said that its Marriott In-Flite Services unit had formed a venture with the All Nippon Airways Company and the Sumitomo Corporation to seek business at the Kansai International Airport in Japan. The venture will compete for catering and concession operations at the airport, which is scheduled to open in Osaka in 1993, and pursue opportunities at other airports in Japan.

title: Pickens Interested In Tenneco Units
description: Mesa Limited Partnership would like to buy two of the eight packages of oil and gas properties that Tenneco Inc. has offered for sale, Mesa's general partner, T. Boone Pickens, said. Mr. Pickens said Mesa, an oil and gas company based in Amarillo, Tex., was interested in Tenneco's midcontinental North America holdings, which included its Rocky Mountain division.

title: To Find a Place for Spain in the Cultural Sun
description: For Spain's new Minister of Culture, Jorge Semprun, the task is simple yet staggering: to help the country prepare for 1992, a year when it will be the focus of international attention.

title: Progress on Crops Takes a Toll on Land
description: IN the four decades since independence, India has used advanced farming techniques to triple its grain output and banish the old specter of famine. But this remarkable achievement has also brought serious environmental problems.

title: Elegant Swimsuits Borrow Touches of Evening Wear
description: Necklines plunge to the waist. Fabrics are draped seductively through the torso in the Ungaro manner and sometimes are pleated like a Fortuny design. Sheer or lacy fabrics lightly veil the shoulders or midriff. The plush richness of velvet alternates with the glimmer of golden lame.

title: Springboard Software reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Dukakis Turns the Other Cheek, But Not Without Baring His Teeth
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis said today that he was not going to respond to every attack launched by Vice President Bush. Then, under questioning by reporters, he proceeded to rebut the prospective Republican nominee's latest criticism of his foreign policy credentials and threw a few one-line jabs of his own at Mr. Bush.

title: Houghton Mifflin Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Iran and Iraq will start a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war on Aug. 20 and open talks on a permanent peace accord in Geneva five days later, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar announced. Page A1

title: Soybean Yield Fall Seen
description: A survey of farmers attending the American Soybean Association's annual convention here projects that soybean yield in the United States this year could be almost 40 percent lower than normal because of the drought. The survey showed an expected average soybean yield of 24.4 bushels an acre, compared with a normal yield of slightly more than 40 bushels an acre. The survey is not considered an official estimate of production.

title: War Games in East Germany
description: About 14,500 Soviet and East German soldiers began joint manuevers today in central East Germany, the state-run East German press agency reported. The press agency did not say how long the war games would last. In Casteau, Belgium, meanwhile, NATO said about 250,000 soldiers, including 17,000 from the United States, will take part in the Western alliance's annual fall maneuvers in Europe.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why do birds take dust baths? A. The gestures that birds make when the put dust on their feathers and then shake and preen it off look like the movements they make when bathing in water, but the purpose is not exactly the same.

title: Group's Holding In C3 Is Disclosed
description: A group of British and American investors has purchased 9.6 percent of C3 Inc. and said it might offer to acquire the high-technology company, based in Herndon, Va. C3, which engineers computer systems for the Federal Government, has 9.91 million shares outstanding. At today's closing price of $13 a share on the New York Stock Exchange, the company is valued at about $128.8 million.

title: Detrex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain from an accounting change of $457,704. The year-ago figures are restated.

title: Detroit Newspaper Tie Allowed by Meese
description: Overruling his advisers, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d yesterday granted The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press an exemption from antitrust laws so that they can merge their business operations while still publishing separate newspapers.

title: Singapore Growth Seen
description: Singapore expects to register real economic growth of 9 percent in 1988, up from 8.8 percent in 1987, Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew said today. He said that gross domestic product grew by 11.1 percent in the first half of 1988, the highest first-half growth since 1975.

title: Tofruzen Inc reports earnings for Year to March 31
Drug Promotion Trend: Table Talk for Doctors
description: The growing trend in pharmaceutical promotion is what is being called interactive scientific meetings, which means getting 12 to 15 physicians together with pharmaceutical company experts for dinner and an in-depth discussion of a particular drug therapy.

title: Chrysler to Raise Prices of '89 Cars
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it would raise the prices of its 1989 models by an average of 2.3 percent, apparently signaling the end of an effort to increase market share by underselling its competitors. The increase is larger than those of the two previous years combined. Chrysler's vehicles then carried prices that were lower than for comparable products of the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company.

title: Court Freezes Assets Of 6 in Tax Fraud Case
description: A Federal District judge in Manhattan has frozen more than 200 accounts or other assets associated with the six men charged with engaging in a racketeering conspiracy to create illegal tax losses through fraudulent tax deals. The accounts are at dozens of financial institutions around the country.

title: 50 Residents Plan Suit On Yonkers Councilmen
description: A group of Yonkers residents said yesterday that they were filing a class-action lawsuit against four City Councilmen who rejected a court-ordered housing desegregation plan, charging them with doing ''irreparable damage'' to Yonkers's financial status and to its ''good name and image throughout the United States.''

title: Intellicorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Mattel Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Payco American Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $772,000 from an accounting change.

title: Technical Communications Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Blockbuster Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflects a 2-for-1 stock split paid March 29.

title: Stalemate in Bond and Note Sales
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes were mixed in slow trading yesterday, as dealers prepared for today's start of the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions.

title: In New York State Elections, a Sparsity of Contests
description: The number of uncontested primaries and elections in New York for the House of Representatives and the State Legislature has increased dramatically this year. At least one of every five members of the House and the Legislature does not have a major party opponent and is thus virtually assured of re-election in November.

title: Hughes Move On I.B.M. Bid
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company, the losing bidder for a $3.6 billion contract to modernize the nation's air traffic control system, has asked the Government to overturn a huge contract award made to the International Business Machines Corporation. Hughes cited irregularities. In a protest filed last week with the General Services Administration's Contract Appeals Board, Hughes contended that the Federal Aviation Administration violated procurement law in awarding the contract to I.B.M., which submitted a lower bid. Hughes, a unit of the General Motors Corporation, requested an immediate suspension hearing, which is expected to be held this week, an F.A.A. spokesman said.

title: Prosecutor Defends Handling of Inquiry on Meese
description: The independent prosecutor who investigated Edwin Meese 3d defended his handling of the inquiry today, asserting that he was required by law to report his conclusion that the Attorney General was ''probably'' guilty of a crime.

title: Chicago's Black-Jewish Divisions Made Worse; Today, Not Yesterday
description: To the Editor:

title: Three Friends Are Arraigned In Bronx Spree
description: Three classmates from a prep school in the Bronx appeared in court yesterday after being indicted on charges of armed robbery stemming from a crime spree in June that left another classmate dead.

title: PATTERNS
description: Fashion Warfare

title: For Pirate Rookie, What a Way to Start
description: The decline and fall of the Pittsburgh Pirates was dramatically delayed tonight by Rick Reed, a rookie from West Virginia who outpitched Bob Ojeda and muzzled the Mets on three hits in a smashing debut in the big leagues.

title: Farmers Seeks Ruling on Bid
description: In its continuing battle to fend off a $4.35 billion takeover bid from B.A.T. Industries P.L.C., Farmers Group Inc. today sought to overturn last week's California court decision that ordered the state's Insurance Commissioner to reverse herself and approve the merger. Farmers, in its appeal to the

title: American Filtrona Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Declaring Truce, Pretoria Asks U.N. Chief to Visit
description: South Africa, announcing today that it had put a ''de facto cessation of hostilities'' into effect in Angola, invited the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, to visit Pretoria as soon as possible to discuss independence for Namibia.

title: Arctic Alaska Fisheries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Turner Broadcasting System Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Field Is Set for Arlington
description: The United States and Britain are each represented by six horses in the starting invitational field for the eighth running of the Arlington Million on Aug. 20.

title: Hein-Werner Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Late Slide Leaves Dow at 2,107.40, Off 11.73
description: The stock market weakened in the final minutes of trading yesterday after marking time for most of the session.

title: Rig Count Up in Week
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States jumped last week by 51, to 945, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. A year ago the count stood at 983. The rig count measures the number of rigs being used to explore for oil.

title: Bidder Pursuing Miami Developer
description: Metropolitan Consolidated Industries said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it had offered to acquire the General Development Corporation, a Miami-based developer. The offer involves a share of Metropolitan common stock and a $10, 10 percent debenture that matures in 10 years for each of the 8.5 million General Development shares that are outstanding. Metropolitan's stock closed at $10.25, down 25 cents a share in over-the-counter trading, valuing the bid at about $87.1 million.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Trade Pact on Agenda
description: The House is expected to give approval today to the Canadian free trade agreement, eliminating trade barriers between the two countries in 10 years. Senate action will follow and that vote, too, will probably be strongly affirmative.

title: American Bankers Insurance Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After realized investment losses of $804,000 for the quarter and $642,000 for the 6 months. c-After securities losses of $17,000 for the quarter and securities gains of $491,000 for the 6 months.

title: Black Peruvians in Pictures
description: Recent photographs of the black population of Peru are on display at the Caribbean Cultural Center, 408 West 58th Street. The photographs are the work of Ricardo Salcedo, a young Peruvian who lived for two years with the people of El Carmen, the country's largest black community. Gallery hours are 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Tuesdays to Fridays, and 1 to 5 P.M. Saturdays. Suggested admission is $2 ($1 for students and the elderly). Information: 307-7420.

title: Krug International reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain from discontinued operations of $8,001,000. c-Net loss and after a gain of $176,000 from discontinued operations.

title: As All Power Is Restored, Con Edison Seeks Cause
description: About 30 sites in Upper Manhattan remained without power through most of yesterday, and the Consolidated Edison Company continued to search for the cause of a blackout that left tens of thousands of Manhattan customers without power for 22 hours over the weekend.

title: Report on Kimball
description: Bruce David Kimball, the platform diver who won a silver medal in the 1984 Olympic Games, reportedly had a blood alcohol level of 0.20 percent -twice the legal limit - when his car smashed into a group of more than 30 people, most of them teen-agers, on a dead-end road in Brandon, Fla., last Monday night. Two teen-age boys were killed and six other people were injured. The Tampa Tribune reported Sunday that a state crime laboratory told Hillsborough (Fla.) County authorities by phone Friday that Kimball's blood-alcohol level was 0.20. Prosecutors are awaiting written documentation of the test results before deciding whether to file any additional charges against Kimball. He has been charged with two counts of vehicular homicide.(AP)

title: Best Buy Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Notes Offered By Sallie Mae
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $400 million of short-term floating-rate notes due Feb. 9 through various securities dealers. Investors are being offered the securities at par, giving them a yield of about 55 hundredths of a percentage point more than the equivalent yield of the 91-day Treasury bill.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I now call upon the Islamic Republic of Iran and the Republic of Iraq to observe a cease-fire and to discontinue all military action on land, at sea and in the air as of 0300 G.M.T. on Aug. 20, 1988.'' - Javier Perez de Cuellar, Secretary General of the United Nations. [ A10:1. ]

title: Lights On! Now About That Dome
description: The realists who have spent years of painful afternoons on the North Side have lately been telling themselves again and again: Night baseball is no big deal. Progress, perhaps, or a necessary evil. But no big deal.

title: Merrimac Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Geico Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes investment gains of $16,1010,467 for the quarter and $37,760,326 for the 6 months. c-Includes investment gains of $19,540,580 and $36,825,230 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: It Was No Breeze for Olympic Skippers
description: There is an image of yachting left over from a century ago: wealthy owners, extravagant craft and upper-crust clubs. It's true that the sport has vestiges of the old way, but they are not portrayed by the eight Americans who will skipper in the Olympics next month.

title: Chartwell Group LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Tele-Art Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss from minority interests of $14,000 for the latest period, compared with a loss of $25,000 for year-ago period.

title: Grand Met May Sell Hotel Unit
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. said today that it was considering the sale of its Inter-Continental Hotels Corporation subsidiary after being approached by several parties.

title: E-II Holders Amend Suit
description: A group of bondholders of E-II Holdings Inc. filed an amended complaint against American Brands Inc. last week, asking for at least $350 million in damages.

title: Maxicare Health Hires A Movie Accountant
description: Peter J. Ratican, a 44-year-old film and television industry accountant, was named yesterday as chairman, president and chief executive of ailing Maxicare Health Plans Inc., the nation's largest health maintenance organization.

title: Volcker Warns on Dollar
description: The United States dollar is still vulnerable despite having risen above important resistance levels against the Japanese yen and the West German mark, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Paul A. Volcker, said today. ''The dollar, despite its recent strength, remains vulnerable and dependent on the confidence of a lot of people abroad,'' he told a news conference.

title: ANTI-SEMITISIM ISSUE SLOWS BRITISH FUND FOR ELIOT
description: A celebration honoring T. S. Eliot, one of the most influential poets of the 20th century, has turned into a dispute over accusations that the writer was anti-Semitic.

title: 27 Brutality Charges Now Filed in Clash
description: Charges of police brutality in weekend clashes with demonstrators protesting the nighttime closing of Tompkins Square Park rose sharply yesterday as inquiries into the ugly episode began and the troubled East Village community reflected on a night of violence.

title: Microage Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $431,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $653,000 for the 9 months.

title: Reagan, Pushing Bush, Cites 'Boom' in Midwest
description: President Reagan brought his campaign for Vice President Bush to the industrial Middle West today, boasting of the region's economic recovery under his Administration and telling voters they can continue that success by voting Republican in November.

title: Excel Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Nigeria Insists It'll Keep AIDS the Rare Exception
description: One Nigerian AIDS patient, a hemophiliac, received blood transfusions in the United States. Two other Nigerians, carriers of the AIDS virus, lived for some time in Zaire and Zambia, two Central African countries with high rates of the disease.

title: Richard Kavanaugh; Stage Actor Was 47
description: Richard Kavanaugh, an actor who made his Broadway debut portraying the fly-eating lunatic in ''Dracula'' and who was nominated for a Tony Award for his performance in ''Hothouse,'' by Harold Pinter, was found dead in his home in Providence, R.I., on Saturday. He was 47 years old. Family members said Mr. Kavanaugh had been suffering from a bronchial virus for the last two weeks.

title: Lynch Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Science Watch; The Coldest Gas
description: Scientists at the National Bureau of Standards have chilled sodium atoms to the lowest temperature ever recorded in a gas, 43 millionths of 1 degree Centigrade above the absolute zero. Absolute zero, defined as the temperature at which all molecular motion ceases, is about 273.16 degrees below zero Centigrade, or 459.69 degrees below zero Fahrenheit.

title: Linear Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: b-After a tax credit of $2,006,000. c-After tax credits of $907,000 for the quarter and $2,802,000 for the year.

title: Baseball; Scott Shutout Cuts Dodger Lead to 1 1/2
description: Mike Scott shut out Los Angeles on eight hits and Houston scored four first-inning runs tonight in a 10-0 rout that cut the Dodgers' lead in the National League West to one and a half games over the Astros.

title: Republicans Object to New Contra Deal
description: The White House and Senate Republicans today raised strong objections to a Democratic proposal on contra aid, but Senate leaders said talks would continue through Tuesday in hopes of fashioning a plan that all sides could agree to.

title: Our Towns; But, Otherwise, This Candidate Is Still Running
description: Don't be fooled by the show of unity at next week's Republican National Convention. At least one of the party's vanquished Presidential candidates vows he'll never endorse Vice President Bush. Or Michael Dukakis. Or anyone.

title: Jepson Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest periods' were reduced by after-tax Lifo charges of $1,369,000 for the quarter and $2,238,000 for the 6 months, compared with year-ago periods of $288,000 for the quarter and $458,000 for the 6 months.

title: Japan Honors Yankee Quality-Control Pioneer
description: To the Editor:

title: National Healthcorp LP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Yield of 8.55% For Dow Chemical
description: The Dow Chemical Company is offering $115.6 million of one-year extendible notes with a final maturity in 2015 through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. The notes were given a coupon of 8.43 percent and priced at 99.887 to yield 8.55 percent, or about one-half a percentage point more than the one-year Treasury bill. Underwriters said the issue was rated A-1 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's.

title: Deal in New Zealand
description: A company partly owned by Rupert Murdoch has acquired four New Zealand newspapers. Independent Newspapers Ltd., 40 percent held by Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation, said today that it had paid $6 million in New Zealand currency (about $4 million United States) to Brierley Investments Ltd. for The Daily Taranaki Herald and The Daily News as well as two weeklies, The Sunday Express and The Northern Star.

title: Republicans See Child Care as Aiding Pro-Family Image
description: After months of watching the Democrats campaign as the ''party of families,'' members of the Republican platform committee today pondered how to refute that claim and seize the initiative on the issue of child care.

title: TADD DAMERON'S GENTLE MELODIES
description: The first half of ''The Music of Tadd Dameron,'' the opening concert of Lincoln Center's ''Classical Jazz'' series on Friday night, was infused with gentleness. This was partly due to Mr. Dameron's compositions, which have an unhurried, calm melodic sense. But it was also due to the musicians - the pianist Tommy Flanagan, the bassist George Mraz, the drummer Kenny Washington and the tenor saxophonist Charlie Rouse.

title: Bridge
description: The American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals ended here last night with a victory for one of the country's greatest partnerships in the Life Master Pairs. Marty Bergen of White Plains and Larry Cohen of Little Falls, N.J., who won a string of major titles in the years 1983 to 1985, led into the final session and held on to win by almost two boards.

title: US West NewVector Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: THE SOUND OF 1,000 ACCORDIONS BLOOMS
description: Push came to squeeze this week at the New York Hilton, where at least a thousand accordionists gathered for the 50th-anniversary jubilee of the American Accordionists' Association. Their fingers skittering over keys and buttons, their bellows pumping enough air to fill a fleet of dirigibles, they came to compete and to celebrate the accordion's latest surge of popularity. ''You get a lot of music from a little box,'' said Faithe Deffner, the association's vice president.

title: Israel Is Urged to Court 'Moderate Palestinians'
description: Richard W. Murphy, the Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, asked Israeli leaders today to increase their contacts with ''moderate Palestinians.''

title: Mattie Rice Coney, 79, Midwest Civic Leader
description: Mattie Rice Coney, a schoolteacher and civic leader in Indianapolis known as an advocate for the inner-city poor, died Friday at Cambridge Health Care Center, Indianapolis, after a long illness. She was 79 years old.

title: Anonymous Sources Given Advice
description: Georgeson & Company, a New York proxy solicitation and public relations firm, has advised its clients not to be anonymous sources for journalists. The recommendation was mailed last Thursday to 2,700 customers and others.

title: Peripherals; Shorthand for Writers
description: FOR anyone who spends more than a few hours a week at a computer writing memos, business letters or Gothic novels, Productivity Plus is a wonderful program. It allows you to define your own shorthand versions of often-used words and phrases.

title: U.S. DELAYS MOVE ON SOVIET RADAR
description: Facing conflicting advice from his top advisers, President Reagan has put off a decision on whether the Soviet Union has committed a ''material breach'' of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, the White House said today.

title: Borden Completes 4 Acquisitions
description: Borden Inc. said it had completed the acquisition of four companies that would be added to its operations in pasta, snack foods and other grocery products. Terms were not disclosed, but the New York-based company said the operations had estimated annual sales totaling $44 million.

description: CBS Inc. announced yesterday that it had agreed to purchase WCIX-TV, an independent television station in Miami, for $59 million from the TVX Broadcast Group Inc. of Norfolk, Va.

Editors' Note
description: An article on July 21 about the ABC News program ''20/20'' described morale problems on its staff, citing complaints about leadership, budget cuts and pressure to allow more time for commercials. The article noted that 3 of the program's 25 producers had resigned - unhappily, it suggested - and predicted that others ''may soon follow.''

title: Hershey to Sell Its Restaurant Chain
description: The Hershey Foods Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its restaurant subsidiary, the Friendly Ice Cream Corporation, to the Tennessee Restaurant Company for about $375 million.

title: Insider Link Cited by U.S.
description: Stephen S. Wang Jr., the financial analyst charged in June with engaging in an insider trading scheme with an investor from Taiwan, was paid $7,000 from a checking account in the name of an individual whose stock trading was illegal, according to court papers.

description: A 16-foot river raft flipped over in ''fairly serious white water,'' killing three people taping a television show with former Gov. Jay Hammond, officials said today.

description: WRIGLEY FIELD was lit up like an old drunk.

description: With one day to spare, proponents of making English the state's official language got enough signatures to put a proposed constitutional amendment before the voters in November.

title: G.E. Offers $25,000 To Help Save House Of Queens Inventor
description: The General Electric Foundation, which seeks to support programs in science education, said yesterday that it would contribute $25,000 to a drive to save the Queens house of Lewis H. Latimer, a black inventor and a pioneer in the development of electric lighting who died in 1928.

title: China Plans Bond Market
description: China will open a nationwide bond market at the end of this year to curb black market trading in Government bonds, the Finance Ministry said.

title: Korea Royalty Payments
description: South Korean companies paid $321 million in royalties for high-technology imports from the United States and other countries in the first half of the year, up from $226 million a year earlier, a Finance Ministry report showed today. Officials attributed the sharp increase to South Korea's growing demand for high technology in the electric, electronic and chemical industries.

title: AIR SAFETY STEPS URGED FOR CHICAGO
description: Voicing new concerns about errors by air traffic controllers in Chicago, the National Transportation Safety Board yesterday issued 11 new recommendations for safer handling of flights there.

title: Dynascan Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $91,000 and $124,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: About the Chess Moves
description: Starting this week, The New York Times is changing the notation system it uses to describe chess moves. The new system, known as algebraic notation, is widely preferred in the world chess community and has been officially recommended by the International Chess Federation.

title: Aide to Cuomo Resigns Executive Services Post
description: Tonio Burgos, a close political aide to Governor Cuomo for more than a decade, announced today that he would resign as the Governor's Director of Executive Services.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS

title: Federated Stores Proposes 2 Issues Worth $1.15 Billion
description: Federated Department Stores Inc., a subsidiary of the Campeau Corporation, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed offering of $350 million in senior subordinated notes due in 1994 and $800 million in senior subordinated debentures due in 2000.

description: b-Includes losses on securities of $36,000, compared with a gain on securities of $16,000 a year ago. c-Net Income Latest and year-ago 6-month results include gains on securities of $100,000.

title: Bernard E. Pollak, 89, Wall St. Firm Partner
description: Bernard E. Pollak, former managing partner of Josephthal & Company, a Wall Street brokerage firm, died of heart failure Thursday at Syosset Community Hospital on Long Island. He was 89 years old and was a longtime resident of Freeport, L.I., who in recent years had lived at the United Presbyterian nursing home in Syosset.

title: Century Telephone Enterrises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings for all periods reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Aug. 1, to shareholders of record July 12.

description: Following is the text of Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar's statement to the Security Council today, delivered in English, announcing dates for a cease-fire in the Iran-Iraq war and the beginning of peace talks:

title: Anna Mae Keener Bury, Hotelier, 72
description: Anna Mae Keener Bury, who with her husband, Douglas, owned and operated the Antrim Lodge in Roscoe, N.Y., for 35 years, died Sunday at Community General Hospital in Harris, N.Y., after a long illness. She was 72 years old and lived in Roscoe.

title: KEY RATES
Republic Automotive Parts Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
At Last, a Joy for All Ages: Central Park Zoo Is Back
description: The Central Park Zoo, closed for five years, reopened its gates yesterday, and the various species on view did predictable things. Penguins played and people pushed. Seals swam and babies bawled. But despite the heat and the crowds, delight descended on the zoo, a series of elegant buildings and enchanting gardens that look as if they had been there all along.

title: Systems Engineering & Manufacturing Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Palau Loses Debt Fight
description: The Republic of Palau must pay an international consortium of banks $44.3 million on defaulted loans, a Federal District judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday.

title: Deep-Rooted Grass Fights Soil Erosion
description: DROUGHT has hit hard in recent years here in the Deccan Plateau in southern India, where the sandy red soil has been stripped of forests and become prone to flooding and erosion.

title: Precise New Method Helps Scientists Learn How Wounds Heal
description: A NEW research technique so sensitive that it can find individual substances made by single living cells is helping scientists learn how wounds heal.

title: Suddenly, Winfield Is Struggling at Bat
description: Someone said something about a slump. Dave Winfield merely shook his head and offered a half-smile. He knew there would be questions.

title: Pork Rinds And Snow Blowers
description: What is it about political campaigning in America that causes it to degenerate so swiftly, these days, into talk of eating pork rinds, fake accusations of mental instability, denials of wimp charges, boasts about ancient snow-blowers, and unprovable personal denunciations of an opponent?

title: Atlanta Gas Light Co reports earnings for 12mo June 30
Two Senators Reverse Stand On Sludge Bill
description: New York's senators have reversed themselves on the dumping of sludge at sea, saying today that they would co-sponsor a bill outlawing the practice by January 1992.

title: Topics of the Times; Blood and the Park
description: Fair-minded people can only endorse New York City's aim of enforcing a 1 A.M. curfew in Tompkins Square Park, on Manhattan's Lower East Side. In a crowded city, where recreational and residential space are closely joined, the exercise of personal liberty does not include the right to deprive others of their rest and quiet late at night.

title: Interco Shuns Higher Offer From Suitor
description: Interco Inc., the nation's largest manufacturer of furniture and shoes, yesterday rejected a takeover offer of $70 a share, or about $2.53 billion, from an investor group.

title: Garan Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Approval Nearing For Upjohn Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration has informed the Upjohn Company that its Rogaine baldness treatment is near final marketing approval, F.D.A. and Upjohn officials said. An ''approvable letter'' issued to Upjohn by the Federal agency signals that the company's research data on the drug have been accepted by the drug safety agency and that final marketing approval can come after last-minute details are taken care of, an F.D.A. spokesman said.

title: 5 Are Shot, 2 Fatally, From a Passing Auto
description: Two men were killed and three others, including a 15-year-old boy in a wheelchair, were wounded yesterday when they were shot from a car in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Medalist Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CELEBRATING NAPOLEON AS CORSICANS DO
description: MONDAY is the 219th anniversary of the birth of Napoleon Bonaparte and to celebrate, La Colombe d'Or, 134 East 26th Street, is holding a Corsican dinner at 8 P.M. Game bird pate, vegetables in pastry, grilled sardines, macaroni with meat, leg of lamb with wild herbs, anise sorbet, lemon tart and fresh figs - all typical Corsican dishes -along with Corsican wines are on the menu for $50 per person plus tax and gratuities. Call 212-689-0666.

title: Shultz Calls for New Nicaragua Talks
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz called today for a resumption of peace talks between Nicaraguan rebels and the Sandinista Government.

title: Correction
description: A recipe for plum torte in the De Gustibus column last Wednesday misstated the required quantity of sifted, unbleached flour. The correct amount is one cup.

title: Company Guilty of Violating Pesticide Law in Death of 2
description: An exterminating company has been convicted of violating Federal pesticide law for failing to monitor the fumigation of a house in which two people later died. The concern, the Atlanta-based Orkin Exterminating Company, could be fined up to $500,000.

title: Topics of The Times; Candidate for Protection
description: A St. Louis man pleaded guilty last week to threatening Jesse Jackson's life during the primary campaign. That plea and other recent threats to Mr. Jackson demonstrate why it would be wise to extend his Secret Service protection through the November election.

title: Celebrating the Arts With Endowments
description: The Fine Arts Work Center in Provincetown, Mass., will mark its 20th anniversary tomorrow by opening a $2.5 million capital and endowment campaign. Robert Motherwell, the painter, and Stanley Kunitz, the poet, both trustees of the center, are among those scheduled to speak at a 4 P.M. program at the center.

title: Misplaced Glee
description: To The Living Section:

title: Metro Datelines; Judge Agrees to Hear '80 Fire Convictions
description: state judge agreed yesterday to hear a motion to set aside the guilty verdict of a man convicted of setting the 1978 Waldbaum's supermarket fire that killed six firefighters.

description: b-Net income

Classroom Booth Asked For Girl, 6, With AIDS
description: A Federal district judge has ordered school officials to build an isolation booth with a glass front inside a classroom so a 6-year-old girl who has AIDS can be taught with other children.

title: Metro Datelines; 15-Year-Old Is Held In Subway Shooting
description: A 12-year-old boy, described by the police as ''an innocent bystander,'' was wounded in a Bronx subway station late Monday by a youth who fired a gun while chasing two other youths. A 15-year-old boy was arrested in the incident.

title: 12 RECIEVE NATIONAL MEDAL OF ARTS
description: President Reagan presented the National Medal of Arts today to 12 Americans who have enriched the nation's cultural life.

title: Leader of Beecham Deal Goes Back to His Roots
description: Barry E. Shipp announced yesterday that he and several partners had completed a $91.5 million buyout of Beecham Cosmetics from Britain's Beecham Group P.L.C.

title: Edmonton Trades Its Hockey Treasure
description: Wayne Gretzky was traded to the Los Angeles Kings yesterday.

title: Sports People; Boxers Injured
description: Three members of the 1988 United States Olympic boxing team are injured and will not compete against the Canadian team in the 1988 Carolinas Invitational at Fort Bragg, N.C., Saturday. The injured boxers are Kennedy McKinney of Killeen, Tex.; Roy Jones of Pensacola, Fla., and Riddick Bowe of New York. Jones and Bowe have hand injuries. McKinney is suffering from an inflamed elbow.(AP)

title: Youngsters in Plays
description: The Children's Acting Company, an organization that offers year-round theater classes to children between the ages of 5 and 19, will present excerpts from several plays, ranging from ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' to ''Vanities,'' on Monday at 6 P.M. at 311 West 43d Street. The show involves 18 students from the company's Summer Acting and Creative Drama Program. Suggested contributions are $5 ($3 for children); the money will support the company's scholarship fund. Reservations: 860-7101.

title: House Backs Trade Accord With Canada
description: The House today approved, 366 to 40, a landmark free-trade agreement with Canada that sweeps away most trade and investment barriers and creates a framework for managing the world's largest and most complex two-way trading relationship.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Arranged Marriages Live On
description: LEAD: ''IN my time, we preferred to marry into families we knew, who were from the same city,'' said Esther Moreh, an Iranian Jew who lives in Great Neck, L.I. ''I am from Teheran and my husband lived in Kashan. But my family knew him.''

title: Correcitons
description: A headline on the Washington Talk page yesterday about Senator John McCain misstated his tenure in the capital. His election to the Senate in 1986 did not begin his service in Washington. He had spent four years with the Navy's Senate Liaison Office and four more in the House of Representatives.

title: Taiwan Stocks Surge
description: An index of the Taiwan stock market soared past 7,000 for the first time today, less than two weeks after it first topped 6,000 points. Today's gain of 121.4 points brought the index to 7,120.09. Brokers say the surge, which has nearly tripled the index since the start of the year, was caused by the huge number of small private investors who see the stock market as a quick way to make huge profits.

title: Home Savings Bid
description: The Home Savings Bank announced yesterday that its board of directors had unanimously rejected an unsolicited merger proposal from the Emigrant Savings Bank, based in New York. It also said it was more than doubling its dividend to 37.5 cents a share, from 15 cents previously. The dividend will be payable on Oct. 20 to shareholders of record as of Oct. 3. On July 26 Emigrant offered to pay $20 a share for the 90 percent of Brooklyn-based Home Savings' shares that it did not already own. Emigrant's largest shareholders are Seymour and Paul Milstein, two New York real estate developers.

title: Maxim Integrated Products reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $201,000 for the quarter and $579,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $176,000 for the quarter and $330,000 for the year.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; A Bimonthly Magazine Aimed at the Polo Set

description: LINTAS:WORLDWIDE, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has acquired MacLaren Advertising of Toronto, one of Canada's top three agencies. The deal was announced yesterday in Canada.

After all, it was James Beard, that unrepentant Oregon boy, who first encouraged Ms. Figueroa, a native New Yorker, to pursue a professional cooking career.

Arafat Says Jordan Didn't Consult Him On West Bank Move
description: In his first comments on Jordan's decision to sever ties with the Israeli-occupied territories, Yasir Arafat expressed anger today that King Hussein had not consulted him and that other Arab countries had not informed him of the King's plans.

title: Bridge
description: British legislators are far more likely than their American counterparts to enjoy playing bridge. The 14th annual match between the House of Commons and the House of Lords was played on April 22, and the Commons players missed their chance to even the series. The Lords were victorious and now lead 8-6.

title: Sports of The Times; Say It Ain't So, Wayne
description: IN Edmonton, it is still summertime. People still flock to the world's largest indoor mall. The Oilers are still printing up their schedules for the next hockey season. But life has changed forever in Edmonton. Wayne Gretzky is gone.

description: Three more employees were dismissed by the company that prints Business Week magazine in the continuing investigation of trading based on advance knowledge of information contained in the publication, a company spokesman said yesterday.

description: Paul F. Douglass, a former president of the American University in Washington, died Sunday at the Rutland Regional Medical Center, Rutland, Vt., after a brief illness. He was 83 years old and lived in South Granville, N.Y.

title: Taiwan External Debt
description: Taiwan's external debt will hit a 14-year low this year after years of huge repayments, the Finance Ministry said today. The debt dropped to $1.65 billion (United States) at the end of June from about $2.2 billion a year earlier, a ministry official said. He said he expected the debt to fall to about $1.4 billion by the end of this year.

title: About New York; The Department Of Correction's Little Acre
description: Summertime on Rikers Island. No air-conditioning, few fans and most windows opening just a crack. Outside the island's six jails are towering fences within even higher fences -all entangled with miles and miles of razor ribbon glistening meanly in the relentless sun. Every minute or so another jet roars off from neighboring La Guardia Airport, as if to underline the fact that nobody here is going anywhere. Manhattan's skyline, sparkling on the horizon, might as well be on Mars.

description: Arthur Young & Company, one of accounting's prestigious Big Eight firms, said yesterday that it was promoting two of its partners to the position of co-managing partner.

Review/Theater; Fugard in Beckett Mode
description: ''The Island,'' the two-character play that Athol Fugard created with the black South African actors John Kani and Winston Ntshona, is one of the more Beckettian works by an author for whom the South African tragedy symbolizes metaphysical struggles that extend far beyond the horrors of apartheid.

title: Puzzle Makers Exchange Cross Words
description: Robert M. Guilbert Sr., a 76-year-old Milwaukee entrepreneur, has won the first battle in his quest to open the world's first Crossword Puzzle Hall of Fame.

title: CARLUCCI SEES CUT IN U.S. GULF FLEET
description: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci said today that a cease-fire between Iran and Iraq could bring about a substantial reduction in the American fleet in the Persian Gulf area once dangers to shipping subsided.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE STEPS UP INTEREST TO SLOW INFLATION
description: In a move to underscore its resolve in fighting inflation, the Federal Reserve Board voted unanimously today to raise its discount rate by a half point, to 6 1/2 percent.

title: ARAB NOW ADMITS ROLE IN HIJACKING
description: Mohammed Ali Hamadei unexpectedly admitted today that he took part in the 1985 air hijacking for which he is on trial in a Frankfurt court, but he denied that he killed an American hostage.

title: Lawyers Take Stance Against Discrimination
description: The American Bar Association's governing body passed resolutions today urging members to spurn private clubs that discriminate against women and racial minorities and opposing racism in the imposition of the death penalty.

title: RE-EXAMINING ON OF THE MOST SELF-EXAMINED LIVES
description: Tolstoy By A. N. Wilson 572 pages. W. W. Norton & Company. $25. Tolstoy The Ultimate Reconciliation By Martine de Courcel 458 pages. Charles Scribner's Sons. $27.50.

title: Harper Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
2d Night of Firsts at Wrigley
description: ''I had to write down two lineup cards tonight,'' Manager Dave Johnson said. ''Can you believe that?''

title: Army Doctor Picked As Hospital Director At Center on L.I.
description: Nassau County today named the Army's senior hospital administrator to take charge of the county's troubled medical center, the largest hospital on Long Island.

title: Robert Ricci, Couturier, 83, Dies; House Created Leading Perfume
description: Robert Ricci, the head of Nina Ricci, one of the oldest haute couture houses in Paris for over 50 years, died Monday night at the Hopital Cite Universitaire, after a heart attack the day before. He was 83 years old.

title: No Headline
description: Amnesty International urged the Indian Government today to investigate what it called increasingly credible reports that the Indian police have killed scores of Sikh militants in staged encounters.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Sports People; Miller Off Team
description: She led Southern Cal to National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championships in 1983 and 1984, and she helped the United States win a gold medal in women's basketball at the 1984 Olympic Games, but there'll be no glory this year for Cheryl Miller. In Colorado Springs yesterday, she was released from the 1988 Olympic squad because of an injury to her right knee. Miller was attempting to come back from reconstructive surgery, but she reinjured the knee during a scrimmage Saturday. ''I am very disappointed about being released from the team, but sometimes the mind says one thing and the body says another,'' she said. . . . The Oklahoma forward Stacy King was released yesterday from the United States men's Olympic basketball team at the training camp at Georgetown University. ''Stacy came into camp with a pulled muscle in his leg,'' said the coach, John Thompson, ''and this delayed his full involvement with the team.'' The 6-foot-11-inch King has averaged 14.2 points per game during his three years at Oklahoma. There are 16 finalists who are still competing for the 12-man Olympic roster. Thompson must make the final cuts by Sept. 2. (AP)

title: Yonkers and 4 Councilmen Fight Fines in Court
description: Lawyers for the city of Yonkers and four Councilmen, seeking relief from daily fines imposed by a Federal judge for their refusal to approve a housing desegregation plan, each argued before a Federal appeals court today that their clients were not personally responsible and should not be penalized.

title: New Jersey Resources reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: There were no share earnings in the year-ago quarter because preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: Great One for Big Deals
description: The trade that brought Wayne Gretzky to the Los Angeles Kings may have shocked most hockey fans, but to those who have followed the career of the Kings' new owner, it could hardly have come as a surprise.

title: ENSR Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Conner Peripherals reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Real Estate; A Mixed-Use Tower Rising Off Times Sq.
description: AFTER years of delay, construction is well under way at a midblock site on West 44th Street in Manhattan for a 52-story commercial tower that will include both a hotel and a conference center.

title: In Iraq, No Doubts, Merely 'Victory!'
description: Iraq proclaimed a ''great victory'' today in the war with Iran, and the sky over the Tigris River blazed with fireworks.

title: Reaction Favorable Around the N.H.L.
description: Many National Hockey League executives have long believed that Wayne Gretzky should be playing for a team in the United States, to give the league more exposure in this country.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Canadians Break Hold: Glenn Michibata, a veteran, and Andrew Sznajder, newcomer, ended a six-year Canadian losing run at the National Tennis Center yesterday when both won their first-round matches at the $815,000 Player's International in Toronto. Michibata, one of the last Canadians to win in Toronto, in 1982, defeated Jorge Lozano of Mexico 7-5, 6-3. Sznajder, the Canadian national champion who turned professional only two months ago, downed Andrew Castle of Britain, 6-4, 7-5. (AP) McNeil Stages Comeback: Lori McNeil battled back from a first-set loss to defeat Heather Ludloff, 4-6, 6-1, 6-3, yesterday in their second-round match in the $300,000 Virginia Slims of Los Angeles tournament at Manhattan Beach, Calif. (AP) Golf Kudysch Wins: Jon Kudysch of the Hamlet shot a 71 for a 12-under-par 201 to win the $55,000 Michelob Invitational at the par-71, 6,900-yard Mill River Country Club, Stratford, Conn., yesterday. Kudysch, in earning $10,000, held off Gary Ostrega of Colonia, who moved from fourth to second place with a 67 for 203. Racing Slew City Slew Wins: Slew City Slew scored a three-length victory over the 1-5 favorite Bet Twice to capture the $64,800 Grade III Salvator Mile yesterday at Monmouth Park in Oceanport, N.J. The 4-year-old colt returned $18.20, $3.80 and $2.10 for $2 across the board in beating Bet Twice, the 1987 Belmont Stakes and Haskell winner. Slew City Slew covered the mile in 1:35 for his fourth victory in 12 starts this year for earnings of $143,060.(AP)

title: Evans & Sutherland Computer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 24
Sports People; Atkinson Looks Ahead
description: Jess Atkinson, who never missed a kick with the Redskins, will not get a chance to extend his streak with Washington. Atkinson was released by the Redskins Monday night, leaving Ali Haji-Sheikh and the rookie Chip Lohmiller to duel for the team's place-kicking job. The move ended Atkinson's bid to reclaim the job he lost almost 11 months ago when he dislocated his left ankle in the Redskins' season opener against the Philadelphia Eagles. Atkinson, who has also kicked for the Giants, the Cardinals and the Patriots, claims to have recovered from his injury and plans to play with another club. Yesterday his plans took a positive turn when the Dallas Cowboys claimed him. With the Redskins, Atkinson made all seven of his field-goal attempts and all eight conversions. He was working as a mortgage banker when the Redskins signed him in December 1986. (AP)

title: Nuclear Support Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an accounting change gain of $600,000. c-Net income

title: Tougher Bill for Fair Housing Is Sent to Reagan for Signing
description: The House has passed and sent to President Reagan legislation that gives Federal officials new power to enforce fair housing laws and extends anti-discrimination protection to the disabled and families with children.

title: Topics of The Times; Weighty Eights
description: The portentous parade of eights continued all through Monday, 8/8/88:

title: WINE TALK
description: TOO many promises unkept, too many idols shattered, too many myths unmasked.

title: James R. Wolfe, 58, A Railroad Executive
description: James R. Wolfe, chairman and chief executive officer of the CNW Corporation, and its railroad subsidiary, Chicago and North Western Transportation Company, died of cancer Monday at Rush Presbyterian-St. Luke's Medical Center in Chicago. He was 58 years old and lived in Oak Brook, Ill.

title: Micom Accepts Bid by Odyssey
description: Micom Systems Inc., a communications equipment maker put up for sale in April to resolve a dispute with dissident shareholders, said that the New York investment firm Odyssey Partners had agreed to acquire the company for $16 a share, or $301.3 million.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''For the benefit of Wayne Gretzky, my new wife and our expected child in the new year.'' - Wayne Gretzky, the hockey player, explaining why he sought a trade. [ A1:2. ]

title: Fires in Yellowstone: Renewal and Criticism
description: The most widespread forest fires to roar through this park in 400 years have created both headaches and opportunities for the National Park Service and private landowners near the park.

title: Control Board Rulings Aren't New to Yonkers
description: Yonkers is no stranger to rulings by the Emergency Financial Control Board, which met yesterday to plan for the city's financial future. For many of the last 13 years, the financially strapped city has had to answer to such a state-appointed board.

title: Goldome,FSB reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Correction
description: An article on Monday about a challenge to the election system in the Town of Hempstead in Nassau County erroneously described the suit in New York City that led to the abolition of council members at large. The New York suit contended that the at-large positions violated the constitutional requirement of one person, one vote.

title: Skywalks and Tunnels Bring New Life to the Great Indoors
description: The temperature had just broken 100 here for the third consecutive day, but Linda Gibbons was not even warm. She did her banking, left her pumps at the shoemaker for new heels, picked up the photographs she dropped off for developing the day before, had a manicure and bought her lunch. And she never stepped outside.

title: Education; Doubts Abound on Boston U. Plan to Run Schools
description: The decision by school officials in the Boston suburb of Chelsea, Mass., to allow Boston University to manage their troubled schools has left some education experts concerned that the move could erode public supervision of schools. At the same time, educators were intrigued by the idea of a university managing a school system but skeptical that it could be done.

title: Jones Medical Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FROM DRUGS, ALCOHOL, EMBEZELLING AND DEATH, A ROAD TO HAPPINESS
description: At the start of ''Clean and Sober,'' Daryl Poynter (Michael Keaton) finds himself at rock bottom: he wakes up with a bad hangover, heavy debts and a comatose stranger in his bed. Daryl's alcohol and cocaine habits are the source of all this trouble, and they might have remained out of control indefinitely. But when Daryl's date fails to wake up at all and his irregular bookkeeping practices are in danger of being discovered, he thinks it wise to stage a temporary retreat. A chemical dependency center with a 21-day detoxification program sounds like just the place.

title: Alan Ameche, 55, Football Star Who Helped Colts Win '58 Title
description: Alan Ameche, the Baltimore Colt running back who scored in overtime to defeat the New York Giants in the National Football League's 1958 championship game, died of a heart attack on Monday in Houston after undergoing heart bypass surgery last week. He was 55 years old.

title: McGill Manufacturing Co Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net loss and after a charge of $3.3 million from an acccounting change.

description: In a move that could embarrass Vice President Bush next week, some key supporters of Pat Robertson are quietly pushing the candidacy of Ron Paul, a former Republican Congressman from Texas, as a Presidential candidate.

description: International airlines carried 6 percent more passengers in the first half of this year than in the same period last year, the International Air Transport Association said today.

title: Corrections

The book sale at the Alice and Hamilton Fish Library will be held Aug. 20, not this Saturday. The arts and crafts fair at the Garrison Art Center will be Aug. 20 and 21, not this weekend.

title: Dollar Up Sharply on Rate Rise
description: The dollar soared against major foreign currencies yesterday, propelled by an unexpected half-point rise in the Federal Reserve Board's discount rate to 6 1/2 percent.

title: Eating Well
description: ON an average Friday in August 1,200 customers stream through the door at Henry's Fish Market in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn. But last Friday was not an average day in August. ''I could read 'War and Peace' today and not be interrupted,'' said Michael Stein, who has owned the shop for 37 years. ''For the past two weeks people have been very hesitant to buy fish. They are constantly asking where it is from. They won't buy fish from local waters.''

description: The two Koreas moved closer today toward their first talks in nearly three years when North Korea proposed a preliminary meeting next week at the truce village of Panmunjom.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: FRESH mussels abound in seafood shops at this time of year, and they can be used for all sorts of tasty and inexpensive summer meals. The simplest way to prepare mussels is to steam then quickly in some white wine and shallots. But you could just as easily use ginger and fresh coriander or another combination of herbs and spices. The variations are endless and include all manner of mussel-and-pasta combinations.

title: Italian Allure, Armani to Zabaglione
description: ROBERTO PESENTI, an Italian journalist who lives in New York, can find everything he wants here. He can eat food so authentic it reminds him of what he might be served in Florence or Rome. Italian newspapers are available on the day they're published. And for the last year, he has been able to watch newscasts from Italy on Channel 31 every weeknight.

title: Sea Griever (With the connivance of John Masefield)

Prodigious numbers of red hots are eaten at Wrigley Field, Comiskey Park, O'Hare Airport and other spots around town. Which hot dog is paramount?

Everything must run smoothly and with split-second timing.

Surprisingly, some analysts are taking a long look at a sector that one would assume would be particularly ravaged: the agricultural banks.

title: The Missing Pieces in Southern Africa
description: It could all unravel quickly, but the announced cease-fire in Angola and Namibia brings 13 years of bloody warfare in southern Africa closer to a conclusion the world would welcome. Even so, the sincerity of South Africa's commitment on Namibia is far from established, and much depends on America's determination to press for a breakthrough on the other element of the southern African tangle: Angola's internal conflict.

Share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend declared in April 1988.

title: Sports People; Campbell in Hospital
description: The pain shooting through Earl Campbell's body did something no football opponent ever was able to do in the years when the running back bulled his way to a Heisman Trophy while at the University of Texas and all-Pro honors with the Houston Oilers. Campbell, a special assistant to the president at the University of Texas, was awakened by the pain Saturday, gasping. ''I was sitting on the couch and came back to the bedroom and I started crying,'' Campbell said yesterday from his room at St. Luke's Hospital in Houston. ''I told my wife, 'Call a bunch of ambulances.' Two of them showed up and I jumped in. Everytime I see one of those now I'm going to pull off my hat.'' The 33-year-old Campbell said that he had been subjected to a number of stress tests and that doctors had found no serious heart problems. He said it was uncertain when he would be released. Doctors said Campbell, who has been commuting regularly from Houston to the university in Austin, may be suffering from exhaustion or anxiety attacks.(AP)

title: Lawyer Gets 4 Months in Jail For Role in Trading Scheme
description: Michael N. David, the central figure in a 1986 insider trading conspiracy involving five young professionals, was sentenced to four months in prison and four years' probation yesterday.

title: Prices Plunge in Active Trading
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes dropped sharply in active trading yesterday after the Federal Reserve Board said it had raised its discount rate by half a percentage point, to 6 1/2 percent.

title: Olympic Gymnastics; Peters Explains Why He Quit
description: Don Peters said yesterday that he resigned as coach of the United States women's Olympic gymnastics team when it became apparent that he could not do an effective job in what he felt had become a turbulent atmosphere.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Paradise Lost
description: In the Federal Bureau of Investigation under J. Edgar Hoover, no place was closer to purgatory than Butte, Mont. The Butte field office was used as a dumping grounds for F.B.I. agents who had fallen into disfavor with Mr. Hoover.

title: KEY RATES
GERMAN DEALERS EXPECT FURTHER DOLLAR ADVANCE
description: West German currency dealers and analysts said today that they expected a further rise in the dollar, which surged past the crucial 1.90-mark level in late European trading after a key interest rate was raised in the United States.

description: To the Editor:

description: Vice President Bush tried today to deflate Democratic charges that he is running a negative campaign and to quiet some Republican fears that his own negative ratings could damage his chances this fall.

Sports People; Hometown Show
description: Mark Jackson of the Knicks, the National Basketball Association rookie of the year last season, will be among the players who will perform Aug. 21 at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum in the NY NBA/Pro Am Harlem Week All-Star Classic. Most of the players who will compete -also including Kenny Smith, Shelton Jones, Rodney McCray, Ed Pinckney and Walter Berry - learned the game while growing up in the New York City area.

title: Jo Henderson, 54, Nominee for a Tony For 'Play Memory'
description: Jo Henderson, a stage and film actress who was nominated for a Tony Award in 1984, died in an automobile accident Saturday in Chinle, Ariz. She was 54 years old and lived in Pomona, N.Y.

title: COURT HALTS FINES
description: A state board declared Yonkers to be in financial crisis today and froze all hiring and discretionary spending by its government. Hours later, an appeals court panel suspended the daily fines imposed on the city for its defiance of a Federal desegregation order, giving it temporary relief from the threat of bankruptcy.

title: Shortchange of Benefits Seen
description: Up to one-third of the people who have retired recently may be getting substantially shortchanged on their Social Security checks because of discrepancies in government records, a union representing Federal workers said today.

title: A Mecca for Psychedelic Pilgrims?
description: ON a balmy night a few weeks ago, 2,000 people filled an outdoor amphitheater in the Hollywood Hills at a benefit for the world's first LSD library and museum. Named after the drug's Swiss discoverer, Albert Hofmann, the acid archive has neither home nor opening date. Still, spirits ran high.

title: Governors Split Heatedly on Amendment Proposal
description: The usually harmonious National Governors' Association erupted in noisy contention today over a proposed constitutional amendment designed to help restore state powers that many governors believe have been usurped by the Federal Government.

description: The iceman cometh. He cometh from New York.
