description: In a possible challenge to one of the most ambitious United States aerospace projects, Japanese officials said today that they were planning a Government-coordinated effort to develop a superfast commercial aircraft.

title: The Tax Weasel
description: Does anybody here doubt that, regardless of Bush or Dukakis, taxes are going up as soon as the election is over? If so, wake up and smell the coffee, and don't answer any doorbells until you finish the third cup because Brooklyn Bridge salesmen all over town have your name at the top of their lists.

title: Sierra Pacific Resources reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes $2,240,000, or 11 cents a share, from cumulative effect of a change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Cubic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest 9-month includes a gain of $608,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: BLACK ARTS FESTIVAL: AMBITION IN PURSUIT OF VISION
description: As a cultural encore to the political convention that recently brought this city widespread attention, the First National Black Arts Festival, which ended Sunday, constituted another step in Atlanta's impressive effort at urban image-building.

title: Navy Takes Responsibility for Beach Trash
description: The Navy said today it was apparently responsible for medical debris that washed onto North Carolina beaches remote from any metropolitan area, but said it did not know how it happened.

title: Jean Dubos, 70, Dies; Biological Researcher
description: Jean Porter Dubos, who collaborated in biological and environmental research for several decades with her husband, Rene Dubos, died of ovarian cancer Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 70 years old.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Grey's 2d-Quarter Net Shows Increase of 55%
description: Grey Advertising has released its second-quarter earnings and they looked particularly good since they included an extra $1.9 million from the sale of a British subsidiary.

title: Moore Corp LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: All figures are in U.S. funds.

title: Education; Education Group Says Student Debts Rise
description: The American Council on Education says 43 percent of the members of the college class of 1984 were in debt for school expenses when they graduated.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on July 20 about restaurants' handling of sudden fame misstated the response at Arcadia in New York City after several favorable reviews. Anne Rosenzweig, co-owner and chef, says no tables were added.

title: BRIEFS
description: Balfour Maclaine Corp. agreed to sell the corn and sorghum operations of its Seedtec International Inc. subsidiary to Nickerson American Plant Breeders Inc. of Mission, Kan. The price will be in the range of $10 million to $14 million ,

title: A.L. Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Dillard Department Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest second quarter and 6-month include net unrealized gains on sales of marketable securities of $773,773.

title: Israel Bombs Lebanese Radio Site Linked to the Palestinian Uprising
description: Israeli fighter bombers raided Palestinian positions in southern Lebanon today and knocked out a radio station that reportedly broadcast messages from the Palestine Liberation Organization encouraging the Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories.

title: Henderson Miscues Costly to Yankees
description: In the quiet of their clubhouse last night, the Yankees seemed like a team at a crossroads. Another loss left them wobbly and a bit unsure, even though they did not lose ground on first place.

title: Senate Passes a Ban On Dumping at Sea
description: The Senate today approved a bill to outlaw the dumping of sewage sludge into the ocean by January 1992.

title: Infotron Systems reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Portec Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: U.S. SEEKING MONEY FOR U.N. GULF UNIT
description: The Reagan Administration is asking the Arab countries of the Persian Gulf and others benefiting directly from the end of the fighting in the gulf to pay proportionately more toward a United Nations observer force, a senior Reagan Administration official said today.

title: Jefferson Journal; Fire, and Fear, Sear a Town's Bonds
description: Like most of his neighbors, Bruce Hartford was sleeping that morning a little more than a month ago when the fire alarm sounded. Dense smoke was already curling from the top of his bedroom door as he scrambled to wake his wife and flee with her and their two children through a bathroom window.

title: Soviets Increase U.S. Spying, C.I.A. Chief Tells Bar Meeting
description: William H. Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, said today that the Soviet Union was increasing its spying in the United States.

title: Pope Resources reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Iran on a Peace Footing; Catchword Is Wariness
description: The acting commander of the Iranian military said today that his country would not initiate military actions against Iraq. But he said soldiers should keep their vigil against possible attacks.

title: The Call of the Lake is Music to Southern Ears
description: All around the hydroelectrically blessed South, reservoirs created by power-company dams have turned utility-making into a sacred socio-recreational institution. From the Memorial Day season opener until the Labor Day finale, the Friday-afternoon cry of ''Let's go to the lake!'' defies the work week pressures of efficiency and progress wrought by promoters of the Sun Belt. And for another weekend the South shall rise, to the lure of bass-fishing, ''booze cruising'' and general aquatic foolishness.

title: Ward Sets Up Review of Police Procedures
description: As the Civilian Complaint Review Board continued yesterday to receive allegations of police brutality arising from weekend clashes over a curfew in Tompkins Square Park, Mayor Koch said Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward had commissioned an internal management review of police procedures in the East Village melee.

title: Metro Datelines; Trenton Takes Over Jersey City Schools
description: New Jersey seized limited control of the Jersey City school system yesterday in a move that gives the state broad powers over the district's spending and personnel actions.

title: Triton Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $6,594,000 from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Pennzoil Company reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $1.7 billion extraordinary gain (after expenses and estimated current and deferred taxes) or $41.46 a share, associated with the $3 billion cash settlement of the litigation between Pennzoil and Texaco Inc. for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $1.7 for the 6 months. c-Includes provisions for losses of $489,300,000 on dispositions and writedowns of assets; the after-tax amount of these items totaled $303 million, or $7.58 a share for the quarter, and $7.51 a share for the 6 months. The year-ago periods have been restated.

title: Frontier Insurance Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After securities losses of $20,000 for the quarter and $128,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes securities gains of $155,000 and $67,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Jacques Chwat, Director, 53
description: Jacques Chwat, an experimental theater director, died of AIDS on Monday at his home in New York. He was 53 years old.

title: Datum Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Elco Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Food Notes
description: Bordeaux Tastings

title: Jets Rookie Enjoys A 'Stunning' Time
description: The past few days have been a bit overwhelming for James Hasty, the Jets' rookie cornerback. Take Saturday night for instance, when the third-round draft choice out of Washington State took the field in Veterans Memorial Stadium for a preseason game against the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: Metro Datelines; Nuclear Protesters Are Arrested on S.I.
description: Nearly five dozen protesters were arrested yesterday morning on Staten Island and on the West Side of Manhattan in anti-nuclear demonstrations on the 43d anniversary of the atomic bombing of Nagasaki.

title: Purchase Policy On Ambulances Draws Criticism
description: New York City's municipal ambulances are prone to chronic failure because of a misguided and poorly managed purchasing process, ambulance service experts said yesterday at a hearing.

title: Rogers-Houston TV Deal
description: Rogers Communications Inc. has agreed to sell its United States cable television business to a subsidiary of Texas-based Houston Industries for $1.3 billion, the companies announced today.

title: Reagan's Cabinet: Who Has Served
description: Starting date designates when officers were confirmed or sworn in as members of the Reagan cabinet. Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. (January 1981-July 1982) George P. Shultz (July 1982-) Secretary of the Treasury Donald T. Regan (January 1981-January 1985) James A. Baker 3d (January 1985-August 1988) Nicholas F. Brady (Nominated August 1988) Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger (January 1981-November 1987) Frank C. Carlucci (November 1987-) Attorney General William French Smith (January 1981-February 1985) Edwin Meese 3d (February 1985-August 1988) Dick Thornburgh (Nominated July 1988) Secretary of the Interior James G. Watt (January 1981-November 1983) William P. Clark (November 1983-January 1985) Donald P. Hodel (February 1985-) Secretary of Agriculture John R. Block (January 1981-January 1986) Richard E. Lyng (March 1986-) Secretary of Commerce Malcolm Baldrige (January 1981-Died July 1987) C. William Verity (November 1987-) Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan (February 1981-March 1985) William E. Brock (April 1985-November 1987) Ann McLaughlin (December 1987-) Secretary of Health and Human Services Richard S. Schweiker (January 1981-January 1983) Margaret M. title: Insider Trading, the Japanese Way
description: Insider trading is becoming as hot a scandal in the Tokyo stock market as it is on Wall Street. But this is insider trading Japanese-style, where buying and selling shares based on advance information is a time-honored tradition to cement relationships between brokers and their biggest clients.

title: SOUL PUNCTUATED BY BLUES
description: Denise LaSalle, the veteran rhythm-and-blues singer, made her first appearance in New York in over 15 years Saturday afternoon at the Central Park Band Shell. Ms. LaSalle, wearing a dark blue sequined dress, is a natural crowd pleaser; radiating good cheer despite the scorching heat, she launched into a program heavy on her soul hits and interspersed with blues. Like many longtime rhythm-and-blues performers, Ms. LaSalle can sing just about anything she wants.

title: Colonial Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Business Digest: Wednesday August 10, 1988
description: The Economy

title: Long-Term Issue By New York City
description: New York City yesterday tentatively priced its first long-term debt issue for the current fiscal year, which began July 1. The $500 million negotiated sale of general obligation bonds is being done through an underwriting group headed by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Soviets May Free Religious Prisoners
description: The official Soviet Human Rights Commission recommended today that the Government pardon all prisoners jailed under laws limiting religious activities, the official press agency Tass reported.

title: Jean C. Harris, 60, Ex-Museum Director And Professor of Art
description: Jean C. Harris, a professor of art at Mount Holyoke College and the former director of its art museum, died of cancer last Friday at Holyoke (Mass.) Hospital. She was 60 years old, and had been on the Mount Holyoke faculty since 1957.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: IT is lunch time in the city, and Jim Doyle of Brooklyn is strolling in Central Park near the band shell. A young woman approaches him.

title: McIntyre Mines LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and the 6 months included $6,081,000 share of gain reported by Falconbridge Ltd. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Computer Consoles Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,332,000 from the early extinguishment of debt. Year-ago results are restated for the adoption of an accounting standard.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Titles for Lawrence At Wells, Rich, Greene
description: James B. Lawrence, 41, who has been running the Detroit office of Wells, Rich, Greene and the Ford corporate account, has been given the new titles of executive vice president and managing director.

title: Washington Talk: Intelligence; Measuring the Years in Terms of C.I.A. Directors
description: David Wise's first book dealing with the United States intelligence community, ''The U-2 Affair,'' was about the high-flying American spy plane shot down in 1960 by the Soviets.

title: Manhattan's Peaceable Kingdom
description: What can you say about a project that took eight years and $35 million to complete? If you're talking about the new Central Park Zoo you can say, quite simply, that it is wonderful.

title: Drexel to Buy Staley's Commodities Business
description: Bolstering its position as one of the nation's largest commodities brokers, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. agreed today to buy Staley Commodities International Inc. for an undisclosed amount.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ad Agencies Take Back Marketing Operations
description: As more and more advertisers abandon the in-house marketing support operations that they took over from agencies in the last 30 to 40 years, agencies are once again incorporating those operations into their menu of services.

title: Dynatech Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The 1987 results have been restated to reflect acquisitions accounted for on a pooling-of-inerests basis.

title: Wal-Mart's Net Up 33.9% In Quarter
description: Two of the nation's leading retail store chains reported yesterday widely differing results for their latest fiscal quarters.

title: Good Guys Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Scavengers Steal Show At a Landmark Theater
description: Broadway may be on the verge of losing one of its landmark playhouses - not to the wrecking ball but to neglect, vandalism and arson.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Thomson Net Up 22.7%
description: International Thomson Organization Ltd., a diversified international information, publishing, travel and natural resources company, reported yesterday that earnings in the first six months of the year rose 22.7 percent. International Thomson, which is based in Toronto, said that net income in the first half rose to $54 million, or 19 cents a share, from $44 million, or 15 cents a share, in the comparable 1987 period. Sales advanced 15.8 percent, to $1.69 billion, from $1.46 billion.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-10

title: Despite U.N. Truces, Prospect Is Dim for U.S. Paying Its Back Dues
description: Although recent United Nations successes in arranging cease-fire agreements have improved the organization's tarnished image in Congress, prospects that the United States will make good on $467 million in back dues to the organization remain dim, lawmakers said today.

title: For Many Children, Home Is School
description: LEAD: Three of David and Micki Colfax's four sons have made it into Harvard so far. Grant, 23 years old, has graduated. Drew, 20, is a junior and Reed, 18, will be a freshman this fall.

title: Micom Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The 1987 results are restated to include the results of operations and accounts of Spectrum Digital Corp., which was acquired in December 1987 in a transaction accounted for as a pooling of interest.

title: Trading Bill Is Backed
description: The House Energy and Commerce Committee today approved a bill on insider trading by a voice vote after key House Democrats agreed to remove a provision that opponents called peripheral. The provision would have given parties injured by insider trading connected with a tender offer the right to seek damages. Aides to Representative Edward J. Markey, the Massachusetts Democrat who is chairman of the House Telecommunications and Finance Subcommittee, agreed to delete the language because he agreed it was peripheral to the main thrust of the bill.

title: Anchovy Allergies
description: To The Living Section:

title: Educations; Lessons
description: By now anyone not recently arrived from Krypton is aware of the 1981 graduation address that turned Eugene Lang into a modern American folk hero - the one in which he promised to finance the college educations of a whole class of sixth graders in East Harlem.

title: Tests at Trials Showed Drugs
description: Some athletes tested positive for drugs at the United States Olympic track and field trials in Indianapolis last month, according to Dr. Robert O. Voy, the chief medical officer for the United States Olympic Committee.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Aug. 6 profiled a Metropolitan Museum of Art conservator, John M. Brealey, who has been on loan to the Prado Museum in Madrid to oversee restoration of Spanish art treasures. It said he had turned down an invitation to stay past October, when his agreement ends. The article said Mr. Brealey cited dissatisfaction with working conditions, though some of his complaints had been resolved.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Account
description: Dunlop Slazenger's racquet sports division to Cole Henderson Drake, Atlanta.

title: Limited Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
G.O.P. Adjusts Some Old Ideas To New Decade
description: The Republican platform committee today began drafting a document intended to carry the party into the 1990's and adjust to a political landscape that has in some ways altered sharply since the glory days of 1984.

title: Landau Journal; Over the Screeching Jets, Germans Cry 'Enough!'
description: A screaming comes out of the sky, shattering the picture-book tranquillity of this town of half-timbered houses that slumbers, seemingly lost in time, in the verdant southern Palatinate. Two American F-16's are practicing for war low over the sun-drenched vineyards.

title: When the U.S. Kills Innocent People
description: ''They are human beings which became widows and orphans, not terrorists who kill and maim. They are like you and me and our neighbors. They are not our enemies.''

title: Olympic Swimming
description: On Monday night, Matt Biondi became overly excited and lost a race he might have won. This morning, he forgot to adjust his racing glasses and missed breaking a world record. Tonight, he did everything right and qualified for the Olympic swimming team in a second event.

title: Rates Increase At Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates rose sharply at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper yesterday.

title: Centralized Information On Self-Help Groups
description: To the Editor:

title: Raytech Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $65,714,000 and $72,314,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, primarily related to the divestiture of the company's Raymarx Corp. unit. c-Net income and includes a gain of $592,000.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Bar Group Widening Net and Impact
description: The American Bar Association, once the exclusive preserve of white male practicing attorneys, has made some effort in recent years to include other elements of the legal profession. As a result, more women, more blacks and members of other racial minorities, more law professors and even more representatives of foreign legal associations were present at the weeklong annual bar association meeting that concluded here today.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday on the timetable for a peace plan in southwestern Africa described the status of one point incorrectly. South Africa has called for a withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola to be completed by next June 1, but Angola and Cuba have not agreed on that date.

title: Pullman Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,422,000. c-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $197,000 and $513,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: George Dandrow, 89, Retired Sales Executive
description: C. George Dandrow, a retired sales executive of the Johns-Manville Corporation and a past president of the New York Building Congress, died of a heart ailment Tuesday in Jacksonville Beach, Fla., where he lived in retirement. He was 89 years old and had been a longtime resident of Bronxville, N.Y.

title: BUSH SEEKS THE GLOW OF LEADERSHIP
description: George Bush wanted to take a meeting with his makeup man.

title: New Methods Help Researchers Explore the Dark World of Dreams
description: While researchers still disagree about the function of dreams, whether they are central or peripheral to our well-being, proponents of modern dream research say that they have discovered new ways to explore mind and body relationships, to assist people in psychotherapy and to promote creative problem-solving.

title: Illinois Housing Authority Starts Dual Bond Offering
description: The Illinois Housing Development Authority is tentatively offering $54.2 million of residential mortgage revenue bonds. More than half are subject to the alternative minimum tax.

title: A WORKING RETREAT THAT'S USER-FRIENDLY
description: HERE in a quiet spot in Colorado unheralded by ski brochures or John Denver sits a little cabin on a hill surrounded by pinon and Ponderosa pine. Unpretentious, like its occupants, the simple, copper-roofed structure draws its architectural inspiration from a variety of sources: rickety windswept ghost towns, tacky log-cabin motel courts, early 20th-century Sears, Roebuck & Company ''kit'' houses and the hypnotic peaks of nearby mountains.

title: Timberjack Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the second quarter includes the results of Koehring Canada acquired in April 1988. Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Cooler Reality Contradicts Greenhouse Theory; 'The Midnight Sun'
description: To the Editor:

title: Sigma-Aldrich Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Review/Television; A Brutal, and True, Story
description: It's a familiar story, how the heel of dictatorship grinds the human spirit, but it's one always worth telling and telling again. And ''Enemies of the State,'' a drama that tells of repression in Czechoslovakia, to be broadcast at 10 P.M. today as part of the ''Channel Crossings'' series on Channel 13, has a special flavor.

title: Idaho Power Co reports earnings for 12mo June 30
description: The year-ago figures have been restated because of a one-time accounting change applicable to unbilled revenue which is required to be reported as if the change occurred in the first quarter of 1987. This accounting change resulted in a non-cash addition to net income of $11,302,000, or 33 cents a share, in 1987.

title:
Currents;
Ex-Warhol Compatriot Takes a Crack at Fame
description: LEAD: FAME usually comes to architects when they are well past 40. Marc Balet, just 40, didn't wait. In 1973, after receiving his architecture degree from the Rhode Island School of Design, he created miniature landscapes called ''Dream Houses'' for an exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

title: Q&A
description: Q. In one of your columns you advised against using paint on exterior wood shingles. However, my wood shingled house has already been painted several times, and is peeling and flaking as you predicted. What advice can you give? A. The ideal solution is to take all the paint off with a remover or by pressure-washing with chemicals. However, this is quite expensive. The only other alternative I would recommend is to scrape or wire brush off as much of the old paint as you can (or wait till it weathers off by itself), then apply one of the latex base ''heavy bodied shingle stains'' that advertise that they can be applied over weathered paint.

title: Edison Brothers Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss c-After a gain of $8.7 million from an accounting change.

title: Postal Service Truncates Perot's Role
description: The United States Postal Service plans to allow competitive bidding for part of the contract it awarded without bidding to the Perot Systems Corporation, Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank said today.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Arkla Inc., Shreveport, La., an integrated natural gas utility, announced the retirement of Gale L. Galloway as vice chairman, as well as from his posts as president, chairman and chief executive of the company's Entex unit in Houston. Mr. Galloway will continue to serve in an advisory capacity.

title: Affiliated Posts Loss
description: Affiliated Publications Inc., owner of The Boston Globe, yesterday reported a loss of $10.5 million in the second quarter of 1988, in contrast to a profit of $72.8 million a year earlier.

title: Two States Adopt Regulations On Tracking of Medical Waste
description: Governors Cuomo and Kean announced yesterday that both New York and New Jersey have adopted regulations to track infectious medical wastes from generation to disposal.

title: Cooler Reality Contradicts Greenhouse Theory; Yes, Cut CFC's
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Opera; A Dominion of Words
description: ''After Beethoven came the rot,'' said Benjamin Britten. The villain of Hans Werner Henze's ''Elegy for Young Lovers'' is a poet, not a composer, but Mr. Henze's 1961 opera - put on at the Tanglewood Music Center Sunday night - implies the same thing.

title: Washington Talk: The Pentagon; Veto Sours Feelings of Officers for Their Chief
description: The nation's military officers, who roundly applauded President Reagan for nearly eight years for rebuilding the armed forces and making military service respectable again, have become dismayed with their Commander in Chief.

title: A Fight Over an Ex-Nun's Mind and Soul
description: Dressed in the black, floor-length habit of her traditionalist Catholic order, Sister Mary Cecilia was taking a walk down a quiet country road some 300 yards from the entrance to her convent here when a rented silver car pulled up and made a sudden stop.

title: KOCH OFFERS TO REWORK STADIUM PACT
description: An agreement to keep the Yankees in New York City until 2032 has unraveled, leaving city officials offering to renegotiate and some state officials suggesting the state would do a better job of it.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Pannill Knitting Hires Outsider as Chairman
description: LEAD: The Pannill Knitting Company has named Lee M. Klinetobe as chairman and chief executive, succeeding William G. Pannill, 61 years old, the son of the company's founder.

title:
CURRENTS;
Re-creating a TV Lounge Of Three Decades Past
description: LEAD: PERHAPS you missed the days of High Television in the late 1950's and early 1960's, when the television set just sat there alone, an isolated icon in the middle of the living room or den. It was not part of a video and sound system that was tucked unobtrusively into a sleek wall of cabinets. Then, color was virtually a glimmer on the horizon, and there were no V

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have a policy around here that's more than four years and eight months old and that's how long I've been here. And that is responsibility and accountability. You take the money, you wear the brass, you carry the badge along with it, and everybody is responsible for their own action.'' - Benjamin Ward, New York City Police Commissioner. [ B22:2. ]

title: DEMOCRATS' PLAN TO ASSIST CONTRAS VOTED BY SENATE
description: The Senate narrowly approved a Democratic plan today to provide the Nicaraguan rebels with $27 million for food, clothing and medical supplies through March 1989, but no immediate money for arms and ammunition.

title: Health; Personal Health
description: Sexual impotence is becoming increasingly common as more men live to reach ages and develop ailments that, one way or another, interfere with their ability to achieve or maintain an erection. Since this ability depends on a complex interplay of both mental and physical factors, there are many ways in which it can be disrupted.

title: METS SLIDE AT 3 AS CUBS WIN, 6-5
description: The Mets didn't make any history today. In fact, they didn't make any progress, either, as they lost again to the Chicago Cubs, 6-5, for their third defeat in a row.

title: Family Reagan Tried to Visit Is Allowed to Leave for West
description: A Soviet Jewish family that was a focus of attention during the Moscow summit meeting last spring emigrated to the West today, ending an 11-year struggle to leave the Soviet Union.

title: 'Generation of Swine'
description: Hunter S. Thompson, who gained a fan club with such hand-stitched books as ''Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas'' and ''Fear and Loathing: On the Campaign Trail '72,'' is back with a collection of his pieces that appeared in The San Francisco Examiner in the last few years. They combine name-calling, bomb-throwing and sardonic humor. He's a little more strident this time out, but if you happen to share his public enemies, Mr. Thompson's your man.

title: Cray Sells a Supercomputer That Does Not Yet Exist
description: Cray Research Inc. has found its first buyer for what it predicts will be the world's most advanced computer. What is odd, however, is that the $25 million machine is being ordered two years ahead of scheduled delivery and does not yet exist - even as a prototype.

title: Judge Won't Halt Book On Scientology Leader
description: A Federal judge has refused to halt the publication of ''Bare-Faced Messiah,'' by Russell Miller, a biography critical of L. Ron Hubbard, the founder of the Church of Scientology.

title: Protestant Militants Report They Shot 2 Dead in Belfast
description: A Protestant paramilitary group today said that it had shot to death two men in a Belfast street in retaliation for an attack by the Irish Republican Army .

title: JETS WILL MISS HARRY HAMILTON
description: HAMILTONS do not back away.

title: WARD IS CRITICAL OF POLICE IN CLASH
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward yesterday sharply criticized his department's handling of a disturbance last weekend in Tompkins Square Park, saying that poor supervision and questionable tactical decisions at the scene caused crowd control to fail.

title: CRISIS IN YONKERS: APPLYING PRESSURE
description: In taking control Tuesday of Yonkers's spending, the Emergency Financial Control Board declared a financial crisis even though daily fines imposed on the city for rejecting a court-ordered housing desegregation plan were still relatively small, totaling $12,700, and even though a Federal appeals court panel was considering suspending the fines until they could be appealed.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; BellSouth Consolidating Accounts of Two Units
description: Tucker Wayne & Company of Atlanta and Luckie & Forney of Birmingham, Ala., merged earlier this year, forming Tucker Wayne/Luckie & Company, and now two of their clients are being consolidated.

title: Molex Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Insilco Gets More Takeover Inquiries
description: The Insilco Corporation, which has agreed to a buyout at $29 a share, or $950 million, by an investment group led by the First Boston Corporation and senior members of its management, has received ''several unsolicited contacts from parties who have expressed interest in acquiring'' the company, according to the First Boston group. The stock of the consumer products conglomerate, based in Meriden, Conn., rose 25 cents yesterday, to close at $29.375, on the New York Stock Exchange as some investors continued to speculate that a higher bid might emerge.

title: Fujitsu to Sell Sun Products
description: Sun Microsystems Inc., based in Mountain View, Calif., and Fujitsu Ltd. of Tokyo said today that they had signed a five-year agreement valued at a minimum of $280 million under which Fujitsu would market Sun's ''S Family'' products.

title: TLC Group Sells Some Asian Units
description: TLC Group, the New York investment company led by the financier Reginald F. Lewis, said it had sold the operations in Singapore and Malaysia of the Beatrice International Company to Fraser & Neave, a consumer products concern based in Singapore. TLC said the purchase price was about $30 million. TLC, which acquired Beatrice International last year for $985 million, has been shedding various units to bring down the debt it took on in the transaction.

title: MEXICO VICTOR IS CHALLENGED BY ALLIES, TOO
description: President-elect Carlos Salinas de Gortari is confronting simultaneous challenges to his authority from the newly strengthened political opposition and from restive elements in his own party.

title: House Passes Bill to Enlarge Park at Battlefield in Virginia
description: The first legislative skirmish in what has become known as the ''third battle of Manassas'' was fought on the floor of the House of Representatives today, with victory going to preservationists who want to expand the national park that now encompasses the historic Civil War site in nearby northern Virginia.

title: P.G.A. Championship; Ballesteros, Citing Schedule, Won't Rejoin U.S. Tour in 1989
description: Seve Ballesteros, who won the British Open for the third time last month, said today he did not intend to rejoin the PGA Tour as a card-carrying member in 1989.

title: Moog Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $197,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months; the 6 months also included a credit of $2,740,000 from an accounting change. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $351,000 for the quarter and $467,000 for the 6 months.

title: Resorts International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit credit of $4,300,000.

title: KEEPING LONDON 'ZIEGFELD' AFLOAT WITH COSMETICS AND FAST WORDS
description: Most of the London critics have so far not enjoyed their second viewing of the musical ''Ziegfeld'' much more than they did their first. One leading reviewer summed up its reworking, its restaging and the replacement in the title role of Len Cariou by the Israeli actor Topol as ''rearranging the furniture on the Titanic.''

title: A Passion for Wicker
description: ''IF it's wicker and antique, I can repair it,'' said David Alford, a man with a passion for wicker furniture.

title: Woolworth, F W Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Winthrop Palmer, 88, Educator and Author
description: Winthrop Bushnell Palmer, an educator and author, died at her home in Centre Island, L.I., Monday. Mrs. Palmer, who was the widow of Carleton Humphreys Palmer, a former president and chairman of E. R. Squibb & Sons, was 88 years old.

title: Security Pacific's $200 Million Issue
description: The Security Pacific Corporation, a Los Angeles-based bank holding company, is offering $200 million of 9 1/4 percent notes due in 1991 at par through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton.

title: Sports People; 60 Days for Youmans
description: The drug-related suspension of Floyd Youmans, the Montreal Expo pitcher, has been set at 60 days, the baseball commissioner's office announced yesterday. Youmans, suspended June 25 ''for failing to comply with his drug-testing program,'' will be placed on the disabled list Aug. 24, provided he continues in a drug treatment and testing program, the commissioner's office said in a statement. Once on the disabled list, Youmans will be sent to an Expo minor league affiliate under a rehabilitation program.(AP)

title: Procter Earns $140 Million
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said today that it earned $140 million in the fourth quarter, compared with a $324 million loss a year earlier.

title: Fay Acquires Trial Catamaran
description: The New Zealand Challenge chairman, Michael Fay, has acquired a catamaran for use as a trial horse against his America's Cup challenger yacht, which must face one of the dual-hulled boats in next month's cup regatta.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis

title: Parker Hannifin Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Novo Industri A/S reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The figures have been translated by the company into U.S. dollars from Danish kroner at the June 30, 1988 exchange rate of $1.00 equals 6.9085 Danish kroner. The share earnings represent American Depositary Shares (ADS) and each ADS is equal to one Novo class B share.

title: Genesco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: I.B.M. in Joint Deal On Trading System
description: I.B.M. said it is developing a portfolio trading system in a joint arrangement with Sumitomo Bank Capital Markets and Decision Software. The system, intended to automate the flow of paper generated by securities trading, will use the PC/RT work station made by the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: The Gretzky Trade: Two Sides; In Los Angeles, New Day Dawns
description: On a day when southern Californians who do not know Lady Byng from Bing Crosby suddenly began spouting scoring statistics and debating the finer points of the power play, the Los Angeles Kings began reaping the rewards of the trade that brought them Wayne Gretzky.

title: Books of The Times; The Art of the Insult, or Gonzo Writer Strikes Again
description: Generation of Swine Tales of Shame and Degradation in the 80's By Hunter S. Thompson 304 pages. Summit Books. $18.95

title: Aspin Threatens to Cut Money for the B-1 Bomber
description: The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, Representative Les Aspin, has warned the Pentagon that unless it demonstrates how problems with the new fleet of B-1 bombers can be fixed, he will move to cut off money for operations and maintenance.

title: E.P.A. Proposes Rules to Reduce Lead in Water
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today proposed regulations to minimize lead in the nation's drinking water.

title: Cooler Reality Contradicts Greenhouse Theory; Solar-Power Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater; Going Home Again, to Argentina
description: Nelly Fernandez Tiscornia's ''Made in Lanus'' looks like a simple domestic comedy, but it has a sharp emotional punch that leaves people dabbing their eyes while they laugh. On one level, the Argentine playwright's argument is that not only can you go home again, even from exile, but also that home is a place you can never leave. On another, she is celebrating the spirit of the Argentine people and arguing that it is they, not political leaders, and certainly not the military junta that ruled for a disastrous decade, who create the history of the nation. But she does all that with no more than one oblique reference to the generals, and her restraint is the real eloquence of the play.

title: Bar Condemns Sexual Barriers
description: The American Bar Association adopted a resolution today that commits the group and its 346,000 members to ''refuse to participate in, acquiesce in or condone barriers to the full integration and equal participation of women in the legal profession.''

title: U.S. NEWS & WORLD REPORT SETS CHANGE IN EDITOR'S POST
description: U.S. News & World Report has named its senior writer, Roger Rosenblatt, to replace David Gergen as editor.

title: After 20 Years, Justice Still Awaits Survivors of the U.S.S. Liberty
description: To the Editor:

title: Seoul Agrees to Meet with North
description: South Korean political leaders decided today to accept a North Korean proposal for a preliminary meeting at the truce village of Panmunjom next week, the first meeting between the two hostile neighbors in almost three years.

title: Carolco Pictures Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the year-ago quarter and 6 months are restated for acquisition of Orbis Communications, which was accounted for as a pooling of interest, and the deconsolidation of Ive. The company also said the latest second quarter includes revenue from the release of Rambo III and Red Heat.

title: Cooler Reality Contradicts Greenhouse Theory; Always Allergic
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Die in British Air Collision
description: Two Tornado jet fighters collided while on separate low-level night training flights, killing three British airmen and a West German trainee navigator, the Defense Ministry said today. Rescue workers recovered the bodies from wreckage scattered over a wide area in the Cumbrian hills of northwest England. The fighters collided Tuesday night over the sparsely populated hills near the village of Milburn, 240 miles from London.

title: As Blacks in Yonkers See It, Time to Say 'You're Wrong'
description: From the housing projects that pack the west side of Yonkers to the homes of stockbrokers, lawyers and administrators scattered in suburban neighborhoods, blacks are bitter over the response from public leaders to their city's defiance of a Federal desegregation order.

title: FGIC Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: CHAMBERS SAYS HE WON'T FIGHT SUIT BY THE LEVINS
description: Robert E. Chambers Jr., the confessed killer of Jennifer Levin, said yesterday in a handwritten note that he would not contest a $25 million civil damage suit filed against him by the victim's parents.

title: It's Not Rap, Give a Clap, Call It 'Cheers'
description: LEAD: ''EVERYBODY asks us, 'Can you teach us how to do the cheers?' '' said 11-year-old Elbe Vasquez of Brooklyn. ''But when we taught a girl from the Bronx, she told the whole world.''

title: Dime Savings Bank To Buy Starpointe
description: The Dime Savings Bank of New York said it had reached an agreement to buy Starpointe Savings Bank, based in Plainfield, N.J., for $21 a share, or about $63 million. The acquisition gives Dime greater access to the New Jersey market for retail deposits, which the company views as the logical extension of its New York operations, Harry W. Albright Jr., chairman and chief executive of Dime, said in a release.

title: KN Energy Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss c-After a gain of $3,158,000 from an accounting change. The year-ago periods restated to reflect changes in accounting for income taxes. The year-ago 6 months included a $4.5 million credit for previously recorded litigation expenses recovered in a settlement.

title: Slaying of U.S. Drug Agent Is Called Mistake
description: A Federal agent was killed after hours of torture because Rafael Caro Quintero, a leading Mexican narcotics trafficker, got ''carried away,'' a defendant in the murder case says on a videotape that has been viewed at his trial.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A G.O.P. Comeback
description: Representative Dan Coats, an Indiana Republican, viewed his Congressional baseball team's victory Tuesday night over the Democrats this way: ''The point is the Republicans were down and almost out, but we came back and stole the victory from the Democrats.''

title: Sports People; Walker Leaves Hospital
description: Greg Walker, the Chicago White Sox first baseman, was released yesterday from Christ Hospital in Chicago where he underwent tests after suffering two seizures. He was expected to begin workouts in 10 days to two weeks. Walker suffered one seizure during batting practice on July 30 and another at the hospital the next day. Doctors determined that Walker's seizures were caused by an inflammation of blood vessels in the brain, possibly resulting from a viral infection or an immunological problem.(AP)

title: Day of Apology and 'Sigh of Relief'
description: President Reagan's signing of legislation that provides for payments and apologies to Japanese-Americans who were forcibly relocated in World War II brings to an end the ''civil rights disaster'' of internment, leaders of organizations who worked for the measure said here today.

title: Doomed Hijackers Appeal
description: Five Palestinians sentenced to hang for the 1986 hijacking of a Pan Am jumbo jet that left 21 people dead appealed their death sentences today in a petition to Superior Court.

title: Fahnestock Viner Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Learning About Chekhov's Magic From a Soviet Theater Wizard
description: ''What does it mean, to love? Stanislavsky defined it very specifically. It means to want to touch.''

title: AIDS Virus Estimates Revised for New York
description: In a refinement of their controversial new AIDS estimates, New York City health officials now say 149,000 to 226,000 residents are infected with the AIDS virus.

title: 44% of Doctors Report Tests For AIDS on Donated Semen
description: Forty-four percent of the nation's 11,000 physicians who perform artificial insemination do tests on the donated semen for the AIDS virus, according to a study conducted for Congress.

title: President Signs Law to Redress Wartime Wrong
description: President Reagan, moving to ''right a grave wrong,'' signed legislation today that apologizes for the Government's forced relocation of 120,000 Japanese-Americans in World War II and establishes a $1.25 billion trust fund to pay reparations to those who were placed in camps and to their families.

title: Israeli Fur Flies on West Bank's Future
description: Israel's Parliament met in special session today, in part to berate the Government for its inaction since King Hussein of Jordan renounced his ties to the West Bank.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Aug. 2 about people who crave the thrill of riding a roller coaster misidentified brain chemicals that are believed to respond to excitement. They include adrenaline and noradrenaline, but not monoamine oxidase.

title: Arctic Alaska Fisheries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Corrected from Tuesday, Aug. 9, editions.

title: Fiscal Worries, But Politics, Too
description: The state agency that declared a financial crisis in Yonkers on Tuesday acted even though the daily fines imposed on the city for its defiance of a desegregation order were being appealed and bankruptcy was far from imminent.

title: A Crutch for Failing Newspapers
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese's decisions have not always been above reproach but his approval of a joint operating agreement for Detroit's two daily newspapers is defensible. He argued that otherwise, The Detroit Free Press would fail. And The Free Press seems to be the kind of newspaper Congress hoped to save with the 1970 Newspaper Preservation Act.

title: Jean Despres, 84; Ex-Coty Executive Ran U.S. Operation
description: Jean Despres, a former executive of the Coty fragrance house and the husband of the milliner Lilly Dache, died Aug. 9 at his home in Meudon, France, of natural causes. He was 84.

title: Man in The News; Dedicated Teacher and Bureaucrat: Lauro Fred Cavazos
description: Friends of Lauro F. Cavazos, the nominee for Secretary of Education, find irony in the charges that he was chosen as a political maneuver, a way to help Vice President Bush woo the Hispanic vote.

title: Anatoly Levchenko, 47, Is Dead; Test Pilot for Soviet Space Shuttle
description: Anatoly Levchenko, one of two test pilots preparing to fly the Soviet space shuttle, has died of a brain tumor at the age of 47, the official Soviet news agency Tass reported Tuesday.

title: TV GUIDE'S POWER OVER THE AIR
description: When Rupert Murdoch agreed earlier this week to buy TV Guide from Walter H. Annenberg, the publishing and television industries gasped - not so much because one of the most lucrative magazines in publishing history would be sold, but for the price it fetched and the speculation it set off about Mr. Murdoch's plans.

title: Sports People; Bosworth Disputed
description: Barry Switzer, the football coach at the University of Oklahoma, has taken issue with some statements made by Brian Bosworth in his book scheduled to be published next month, ''The Boz: Confessions of a Modern Anti-Hero.'' The former Sooner linebacker, now with the Seattle Seahawks, asserted that he had seen Oklahoma football players freebasing cocaine on game days and that steroids were as common as aspirin on the Sooner squad. ''I don't believe it,'' said Switzer in an interview with The Oklahoman newspaper. ''I've got to believe in our testing program and in our medical staff. We're no different from any program in the country in that we deal with the problems that exist.'' (AP)

title: Cooler Reality Contradicts Greenhouse Theory
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M.A.C. Notes To Be Redeemed
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, plans to redeem its 10 percent notes due in 1990. The principal amount, all of it outstanding, totals $500 million.

title: Clorox Company reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
IN EDMONTON, FUTURE IS ON HOLD
description: ''Edmonton Oilers. Can you hold, please?

title: JACKSON ADMONISHES DUKAKIS ON CIVIL RIGHTS
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that Gov. Michael S. Dukakis missed an opportunity last week by not speaking more about civil rights in a campaign appearance at Philadelphia, Miss., where three rights workers were killed in 1964.

title: Baseball Notebook; Expos Confident Of Catching Mets
description: Now it's Montreal's turn.

title: Yields Jump to a High for the Year
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell sharply for the second consecutive session yesterday, as the credit markets continued to react to the Federal Reserve's decision on Tuesday to raise its discount rate.

title: Health; Study Questions Coronary Bypass Benefits
description: Having a coronary bypass operation improves the chances of survival for heart disease patients who are considered at high risk, according to a study of more than 750 men. However, after five years, the differences in survival between those who have the surgery and those who are treated with drugs begin to diminish, the study found.

title: Talking Deals; Transactions That Limit Taxes
description: WHEN the Campeau Corporation sold its Brooks Brothers stores last spring, its chairman, Robert Campeau, could have insisted on cash up front from the buyer, Marks & Spencer P.L.C. Instead he listened to his tax advisers and suggested a 10-year note for a large chunk of the deal.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Street Fighting Grows in Rangoon; At Least 30 More Reported Killed
description: Violent clashes between security forces and anti-Government demonstrators intensified yesterday in the Burmese capital, according to the Government radio and other accounts. The radio said 30 people had been killed in street battles, but other reports put the figure as high as 100.

title: JB's Restaurants Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: The latest quarter included a non- cash after-tax charge of $1.6 million relating to the company's withdrawal from the Big Boy franchise system and the abandonment of its territorial license rights.

title: Review/Dance; Giddy Festival Within a Festival Makes a Splash
description: The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival's new Splash festival is just about as giddily adventurous as its name. The event sprawls out into Pillow studios, an open-air forest amphitheater and the venerable little Ted Shawn Theater. Twenty-six top dance, music and performance-art soloists and companies will be presented in the festival by its close on Aug. 21. On Tuesday alone, there was a world premiere by Ushio Amagatsu, the founder of Sankai Juku, a Japanese Butoh company, and an American premiere by Stephen Petronio, an up-and-coming young dance postmodernist, as well as the psychodances of Susan Marshall and mime from Bob Berky.

title: NBI Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $5,432,000 for the quarter and $33,470,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,044,000 for the quarter and $7,709,000 for the year; the year also included a gain on the repurchase of debentures of $509,000.

title: Gencor Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Public Funds Proposed For Campaign Measure
description: The New York City Charter Revision Commission yesterday agreed to a highly unusual proposal to require the city temporarily to pay for its own recently passed public campaign finance law. The measure, which sets no dollar amounts, is among the commission's first significant charter amendments planned for the ballot this fall.

title: Calendar of Events: Urban Harvest Fair
description: Country in the City, Floyd Bennett Field, near Exit 11S on the Belt Parkway, Brooklyn; 212-233-2926.

title: IRAN SAYS INQUIRY MUST ASSAIL IRAQ
description: The acting commander of the Iranian military said today that a United Nations inquiry must condemn Iraq as the aggressor in the Persian Gulf war or the region will face grave consequences.

title: Maine Public Service Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $830,000 from an accounting change.

title: Group Buys 8.3% Of Best Products
description: The Prospect Group Inc. has purchased an 8.3 percent stake in the Best Products Company and said it may hold talks with management about possible transactions, including an acquisition of the chain of catalogue showrooms. At today's closing price of $15.625 a share, down 62.5 cents, Best Products, with 26.8 million shares outstanding, is worth $418 million.

title: Drug Smuggler Given Attorney for Appeal
description: The co-defendant in the cocaine-smuggling trial of Carlos Lehder Rivas was declared indigent Tuesday and his trial lawyer was reappointed to serve as his appeal counsel.

title: Deal for Friendly Offers Official Chance to Shine
description: Donald N. Smith's latest venture, the purchase of the Friendly Ice Cream Corporation for about $375 million by his company, may restore his reputation as one of the restaurant industry's brightest stars.

title: Sears President to Retire
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that its president, Richard M. Jones, would retire at the end of the year. Mr. Jones, who has been with the nation's largest retailer for 38 years, will be 62 years old at the time of his retirement. The company said that Edward A. Brennan, Sears's chairman and chief executive, would add the title of president upon Mr. Jones's retirement.

title: WALDHEIM LINKED TO BRITISH DEATH
description: Allegations linking Kurt Waldheim to the execution of a British Army officer in Greece in World War II were made today by a Member of Parliament who once worked for Mr. Waldheim and by a British historian who commanded Allied operations in support of the Greek resistance.

title: Florida Growth For American
description: American Airlines Inc. announced plans to base as many as 700 pilots and flight attendants in South Florida, the home of embattled Eastern Airlines.

title: Foote, Cone & Belding Comunications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes equity in earnings of $436,000 and $683,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes equity in earnings of $208,000 for the quarter and $428,000 for the 6 months. The company said the year-ago quarter and 6 months include a one- time gain of $880,000, or 11 cents a share, on the sale of two subsidiaries.

title: Havana Journal; In or Out of Jail, Castro's Old Ally Is a Defiant Foe
description: For 13 years, Gustavo Arcos had been a loyal supporter of Fidel Castro. He fell wounded beside the Cuban leader in the first shoot-out of the revolution, languished in jail with Mr. Castro and later traveled through Latin America raising money and political support. When Mr. Castro finally took control of Cuba, Mr. Arcos became his ambassador to several European countries.

title: Overseas Shipholding Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest quarter and 6-month results include net gains of $651,000, or 3 cents a share, from disposal of vessels. The year-ago periods included similar gains of $530,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter, and $1,198,000, or 5 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: BRT Realty Trust reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain on sale of investments of $303,000.

title: Consumer Rates; Yields Rise On C.D.'s
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were up for the week ended yesterday, much the same pattern of the past few weeks.

title: Durham Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains on investments of $3,898,000 and $4,989,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes gains on investments of $2,742,000 for the quarter and $4,704,000 for the 6 months.

title: Racing Form: Trifecta for Murdoch?
description: Every day, as the bugler calls the horses to the post and the bettors to the betting windows at dozens of thoroughbred race tracks across North America, horse players have two ways of trying to pick winners: stabbing at their programs with a hatpin or consulting the sea of statistical data in the Daily Racing Form.

title: Panel Agrees on Raise for Federal Workers
description: A House-Senate conference committee agreed tonight on a 4.1 percent wage increase for the Federal Government's 4.4 million civilian and military employees.

title: Two Steps Back
description: To The Home Section:

title:
CURRENTS;
An Expansive Showcase For Italian Sportswear
description: LEAD: THE garment district's concentration of showrooms in the West 30's remains unchallenged. Yet in the last five years or so there has been a drift toward midtown, especially of showrooms for higher-priced ready-to-wear clothes. The blocks between 55th and 57th Streets, from Madison Avenue to Seventh Avenue, ''offer a more conducive ambiance for those buying high-quality merchandise,'' said Robert

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Marshall on Racism
description: Thurgood Marshall, the 80-year-old Supreme Court Justice, waxed philosophical in an address yesterday to more than 700 people at a luncheon of the National Bar Association, the nation's largest organization of black lawyers and judges.

title: Seattle Journal; Bountiful Salmon Run Has Anglers Beaming
description: Nature's annual gift to this city of urban outdoorsmen arrived on the Fourth of July weekend this year, when the first migrating sockeye salmon showed up at Seattle's doorstep, and the generosity of this year's gift has stirred a civic passion.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ford's Taiwan Work Awarded to Thompson
description: Since the Ford Motor Company is the largest client of the J. Walter Thompson Company, every aspect of the relationship of the two is important, especially because there have been a number of changes since the agency's hostile takeover by the WPP Group of Britain.

title: U.S. to Alter Chip Pricing
description: The Commerce Department is planning to revise its formula for computing minimum prices for Japanese chips under the 1986 semiconductor trade agreement between the United States and Japan. The changes, instituted in response to requests from chip producers and users, would help reduce prices for new generations of chips.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Tribute to a General
description: At noon today, with the temperature expected to be in the 90's, about 20 men 60 years old or over will form up on Lincoln Memorial Drive at the 101st Airborne Memorial. Then they will march to the grave in Arlington National Cemetery of the man who commanded the division at the Battle of the Bulge in December 1944: Gen. Anthony Clement McAuliffe.

title: Penn State Upsets Syracuse
description: Penn State and Syracuse, longtime powerful rivals in Eastern college football who have met annually since 1922, will end their rivalry in 1990 for an indefinite period.

title: Business Digest: Thursday August 11, 1988
description: The Economy

title: Soviets Check 2 U.S. Bases
description: Soviet inspectors today finished checking two United States cruise missile sites in Belgium under terms of the treaty to eliminate medium- and shorter-range nuclear weapons. The 20 Soviet experts visited the air base at Florennes, about 40 miles south of Brussels, and the European repair site at nearby Gosselies. The Russians arrived in Belgium on Monday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Dell Computer Account Goes to Chiat/Day
description: Chiat/Day, San Francisco, which was Apple Computer's agency from 1979 until it lost the account in 1986, has found a new outlet for its computer expertise, the Dell Computer Corporation of Austin, Tex., a maker and direct marketer of high-performance personal computers.

title: KOCH URGING GIFTS TO CHARITIES, NOT BEGGARS
description: In a step that harks back to the Great Depression of the 1930's, Mayor Koch said yesterday that the city was planning a publicity campaign to urge the public to contribute to established charities rather than to street beggars.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Social Analysis From Good Housekeeping
description: NOT long ago, while on a business trip, Alan Waxenberg, publisher of Good Housekeeping since May, and Sandra Spaeth, director of marketing and promotion, used the quiet of a plane ride to relate the magazine's readership to general social trends.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the American Bar Association's annual meeting in Toronto misattributed a quotation in a debate on capital sentencing. It was E. Michael McCann, the Milwaukee County District Attorney, who said: ''You and I know that racial discrimination in capital sentencing is wrong. We know it in our guts viscerally, and we know it in our minds. We cannot and ought not remain silent.''

title: Gould's Hong Kong Plan
description: Gould Inc. said today that a joint venture it owns equally with the Nippon Mining Company would build a plant in Hong Kong to produce copper foil used in printed circuit boards. Gould, an electronics company based here, said it is building the plant in response to increased demand from markets in Southeast Asia and China. The project includes an initial investment of $15 million to $20 million, a Gould spokesman said.

title: Review/Music; Soviet-American Concert
description: The American Soviet Youth Orchestra is an educational exchange program that was officially established as a byproduct of the last round of summit talks in May. It has 58 Americans and 52 Russians, all conservatory students who auditioned for the chance to spend 17 days rehearsing Russian and American music together at Oberlin Conservatory in Ohio and touring both in the United States and in the Soviet Union.

title: Vote in Senate on Aid to Contras
description: Following is the 49-47 roll-call vote by which the Senate approved a Democratic-sponsored plan to give the Nicaraguan guerrillas $27 million for food, clothing and medical supplies and set the stage for possible military aid later: FOR THE CONTRA AID PLAN - 49 Democrats - 49 Baucus, Mont.
