title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the appointment of an executive director for Nassau County's medical center omitted the full identity of the center.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Yonkers desegregation case misstated the circumstances under which the Emergency Financial Control Board took over Yonkers' finances in 1984. It acted after the Yonkers school board, facing a deficit, threatened to close the city's schools. In addition, the article incorrectly described the judicial panel that will hear the appeal of a contempt ruling against the city and four councilmen. It will be a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: Food Provider to Poor Offers Self-Esteem, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports People; Lakers Sign Woolridge
description: Orlando Woolridge, the 6-foot-9-inch forward who played a season and a half with the Nets before entering a drug rehabilitation program last February, signed a multiyear contract yesterday with the Los Angeles Lakers. Terms were not announced, but it was believed that the Lakers, the defending National Basketball Association champions, will pay Woolridge $500,000 a year. He was signed as a free agent with no compensation due to the Nets. Woolridge, 28 years old, averaged 16.4 points for the Nets last season before voluntarily entering a drug treatment center in Van Nuys, Calif.(AP)

title: Prudential to Sell Pieces of Its Private Placements
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America announced yesterday that it had formed a unit to market pieces of its $25 billion private placement portfolio and to syndicate portions of new investments to institutional investors.

title: HUMAN STUDIES START ON A DRUG DESIGNED TO BLOCK AIDS VIRUS
description: Human studies to evaluate the first drug that was specifically designed to block the AIDS virus are beginning this week. On the basis of laboratory studies, scientists hope the drug will preventing the AIDS virus from entering and infecting cells of the immune system.

title: G.O.P. STANDS FIRM AGAINST ABORTION
description: After an emotional and sometimes anguished debate, conservatives held the line in the Republican platform committee tonight and kept the party's official doctrine implacably opposed to abortion and silent on the proposed Federal Equal Rights Amendment for women.

title: Health; Doctors' Group Urges Limiting Accutane Use
description: Doctors should prescribe other drugs for acne patients if possible before resorting to Accutane, a medication that is effective in severe cases but has been reported to cause birth defects, the American Academy of Dermatology has recommended.

title: Review/Music; Pop Classics for Horn
description: Jazz musicians rarely get credit for keeping Tin Pan Alley standards current through the rock era. Yet they continue to honor that repertory, both by reclaiming pop melodies with eloquent phrasing and by evading them to reveal ingenious harmonic structures. ''Standards on Horn,'' part of the ''Classical Jazz'' series with Wynton Marsalis as artistic adviser, drew almost equally on pop standards (''Body and Soul,'' ''Embraceable You'') and be-bop tunes (''Confirmation,'' ''Blue Bossa''). With well-chosen soloists and a sophisticated rhythm section (Buster Williams on bass, Ben Riley on drums and Tommy Flanagan or Hank Jones on piano), the pieces sang out in thoroughly individual voices.

title: BRIEFS
description: AMR Corp., Fort Worth, parent of American Airlines, said it had completed the previously announced acquisition of Wings West Airlines for $10.50 a share, or about $41.7 million.

title: Bridge
description: A double confusion surrounds the Merrimac Coup. Some try to add a terminal 'k' to the name, thinking of the Civil War vessel that battled the Monitor. The maneuver is named for a coal-carrying vessel that was deliberately sunk in the Cuban harbor of Santiago during the Spanish-American War in order to bottle up the Spanish fleet.

title: Metro Matters; Legal Maneuver Transforms Gang Into Racketeers
description: The Miller gang lacks the public notoriety of, say, the James brothers or John Gotti. Nor is Sean Miller a stereotypical racketeer.

title: Yankees Talk to Themselves After Loss
description: Team officials for the Yankees, along with security guards and bat boys, stood unsmiling outside the closed door to the clubhouse after last night's 5-0 loss to the Blue Jays.

title: PAC DONATIONS TO DEMOCRATS RISE WHILE THOSE TO REPUBLICANS FALL
description: Contributions by political action committee to Democrats running for Congress this year have risen dramatically as against 1986 while their contributions to Republicans have dropped.

title: Result of Trade Is Sinking In
description: The trading of Wayne Gretzky, hockey's incomparable scorer and unparalleled craftsman, outraged a community, stunned a nation and electrified an entire league. A day later, it still remains hard to believe and difficult to describe.

title: Nigerian Leader's Political Agility Keeps Trouble at Bay and Him in Power
description: Newspaper cartoonists here often sketch the President of Nigeria as a soccer star, a general in playing shorts weaving unscathed through his nation's problems.

title: Sports People; Tyson-Bruno Date Set
description: Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, will defend his title against Frank Bruno, a mandatory challenger, on Oct. 8 in London. ''The fight is definitely on,'' Bill Cayton, Tyson's manager, said yesterday. Earlier this week, Jose Ribalta's manager, Luis de Cubas, said he and Ribalta had signed with Don King to fight Tyson in October. While de Cubas said the contract his fighter signed did not have Tyson's signature on it, he quoted Tyson as saying: ''It's going to be Ribalta and me in October'' when Tyson saw him in Los Angeles on Aug. 1. Cayton said that his attorney, Thomas Puccio, and Tyson's attorney, Michael Winston, worked out the final details of Tyson's end of the Bruno deal yesterday.

title: Pox on Landscape
description: To The Home Section:

title: Harris Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $35,085,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for income taxes--the adoption of FASB No. 96. The gain was credited to the company's first quarter results, which were therefore restated. The fiscal 1988 results also included after-tax charges totaling $33.1 million related to asset revaluations and restructuring costs. Most of that amount was charged in the fourth quarter.

title: Dollar Stages Late Retreat On Rumors of Intervention
description: The dollar fell yesterday after rumors circulated in the foreign exchange markets that central banks around the world had agreed on a plan to prevent further appreciation of the American currency.

title: Southern Strategy
description: Last Thursday, 24 years to the day after the bodies of three young civil rights workers were discovered near Philadelphia, Miss., Michael Dukakis made a campaign appearance there. He talked about economic development. He talked about being near the Meridian, Miss., birthplace of Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd, the Boston Red Sox pitcher. But the Democratic Presidential nominee did not mention the names Andrew Goodman, James Chaney and Michael Schwerner or their murder by the Ku Klux Klan, a pivotal event in the civil rights revolution. It was a breathtaking omission.

title: RIFT OVER CAMPAIGN FILMS
description: Tribute or propaganda? Documentary or advertisement? Entertainment or news? To air or not to air?

title: FATAL SYNDROME IN INFANTS RAISES PAINFUL QUESTIONS FOR DOCTORS
description: Every six months or so, Arthur Caplan, director of the Center for Bioethics at the University of Minnesota, gets a call from a troubled doctor. A newborn baby has developed short-gut syndrome and lacks any functioning intestines. It will never be able to absorb food normally.

title: Navy Checking Report Ship Left Boat People to Die
description: The United States Navy is investigating allegations that the crew of a Navy ship refused to rescue some Vietnamese boat people who later resorted to murder and cannibalism to survive at sea, officials said today.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Sockless Strategist
description: Roger Stone, the political strategist behind many Republican campaigns who otherwise has a reputation of sartorial elegance, frequently eschews wearing socks. In Ronald Reagan's 1980 Presidential campaign, Nancy Reagan fastidiously brought this to her husband's attention.

title: Alcan Power Plant
description: Alcan Smelters and Chemicals Ltd., a unit of Canada's Alcan Aluminium Ltd., said it would begin construction of a $600 million hydroelectric expansion project at Kemano in northwestern British Columbia. Bill Rich, Alcan's vice president for British Columbia, said the power would be used for extra aluminum smelting in the region and that surplus power would be sold to the Government-owned British Columbia Hydro and Power Authority. He said the project, to be completed in late 1994, would add about 520 megawatts of generating capacity to the current Kemano capacity of just under 896 megawatts.

title: Morgan Guaranty Sells 8.95% Notes
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company is offering $100 million of 8.95 percent notes due in 1990 at par through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Capital Funding.

title: Palestinian Factions Divided On Forming a State in Exile
description: Syrian-backed opponents of Yasir Arafat are opposing the establishment of a Palestinian government in exile, thus deepening a Palestinian split at a time of increased uncertainty over the future of the Israeli-occupied territories.

title: El Paso Electric Co reports earnings for 12mo June 30
description: The company said the prior 12 months includes a gain of $4,240,000 from an accounting change.

title: Mural Draws Shultz's Fire On Quito Trip
description: A giant mural on a wall of the Ecuadorean Congress that seems to equate the Central Intelligence Agency with Nazism was sharply criticized by Secretary of State George P. Shultz today as he arrived here for Ecuador's presidential inauguration.

title: For Blind Children, A Place to Have Fun
description: WHEN Cornell Williams first came to Camp Wapanacki 14 years ago he was terrified of boating, a fear camp counselors say is shared by many 5-year-olds. But for Mr. Williams, who is legally blind and ''rather fond of solid ground,'' learning to row made him feel, he says now, that he could ''conquer the world.''

title: Conseco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the sharply higher second quarter and first half revenue reflects the acquisition of Western National Life Insurance Co. in the third quarter of 1987.

title: Sports People; Islanders Add Muscle
description: The Islanders added a little more muscle to their corps of left wings by signing Mike Stevens, a free agent, who had 265 minutes in penalties last season in 63 games with the Maine Mariners of the American Hockey League. He had 30 goals and 25 assists in 63 games with the Mariners last season. Stevens is the brother of Scott Stevens, the defenseman of the Washington Capitals. Al Arbour, the vice president of player development for the Islanders, said that Stevens ''can add an element of toughness to our club.''

title: STUDY HINTS VDT MAY AFFECT FOCUS
description: Evaluations of more than 150 patients at a specialized eye clinic in California suggest that regular work at a video display terminal might damage the eye's ability to focus.

title: Political Memo; Some Fear Reagan Embrace Of Bush Could Be Suffocating
description: President Reagan has now made it clear that he will do everything possible to help elect George Bush this fall, even if it means altering some strongly held views and policy goals.

title: Paul Thek Dead at 54; An Artist of the Surreal
description: Paul Thek, an artist best known for installations of objects depicting surrealistic scenes of death and renewal, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 54 years old.

title: Drug Tests by N.C.A.A. Are Barred at Stanford
description: Stanford University cannot be required to test athletes under the National Collegiate Athletic Association's drug-testing program, a judge ruled today.

title: Paying the Price of Peace
description: ''The U.S. is in favor of peace,'' the U.S. delegate to the United Nations, Vernon Walters, said lamely this week. ''Peace has its price,'' retorted U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, and he's right. The U.S. is the U.N.'s biggest deadbeat, owing $467 million in back dues. Its continued failure to pay endangers the flourishing peace efforts of a revived U.N. That's foolish and shameful.

title: Koch Backs Allowing Extra Floors of Tower
description: Mayor Koch, who once favored dismantling the top 12 floors of an Upper East Side apartment tower that was built higher than zoning rules allow, now supports an arrangement in which the developers could keep the extra floors.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on June 7, July 2 and Aug. 3 about a Federal trial involving sanctuary for illegal aliens incorrectly described a defendant, the Rev. Glen Remer-Thamert. Mr. Remer-Thamert was removed from the clergy roster of the Lutheran Church in America several years ago and is not affiliated with its successor, the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America.

title: Teen-Age Gardeners Come to the Rescue
description: RANSEN DAILY knows what it means to sweat for money. While many of his friends are spending 90-degree days in the shade, Ransen is raking, weeding, pruning, sweeping and, especially this summer, sweating in Prospect Park in Brooklyn.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Farmers Stock Jumps On Higher B.A.T. Bid
description: The stock of Farmers Group Inc. rose sharply today in response to a sweetened but conditional $5 billion takeover offer from B.A.T. Industries. Shares of the Los Angeles-based insurer jumped $5.75, to $63.50, in trading of nearly three million shares, making it the most active over-the-counter issue.

title: Rise in Interest Cost Hurts Adjustable-Rate Debtors
description: Because of a fundamental change in the way consumers have been borrowing money in recent years, the current rise in interest rates is going to have a more pronounced effect on pocketbooks than increases in the past.

title: ARNULFO ARIAS, 87, PANAMANIAN WHO WAS PRESIDENT 3 TIMES
description: Dr. Arnulfo Arias Madrid, who long dominated civilian politics in Panama even though he was deposed from the presidency three times by the military, died in Miami today, the Panamanian consul here said. He was 87 years old.

title: Altos Computer Systems reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
description: b-Includes gains of $11 million and $14.1 million for the quarter and year, respectively, from the sale of the company's investment in Informix Corp. c-Includes a gain of $1.1 million for both the quarter and year from the sale of a portion of the Informix investment.

title: Biaggi Rethinks Tactic To Get Off of the Ballot
description: Faced with possible objections by Federal prosecutors, Mario Biaggi is reconsidering whether he can remove his name from the Sept. 15 primary ballot by changing his legal residence from the Bronx to Washington.

title: M. Scott Peck Traveling To a Different Publisher
description: A scant 10 weeks from now, ''The Road Less Traveled,'' by Dr. M. Scott Peck will almost certainly complete its fifth year on The New York Times's paperback nonfiction best-seller list. Other books have sold more copies over a longer lifetime, but no book that has neither been revised nor updated has come close to the best-selling longevity of Dr. Peck's book, an exploration of love and spirituality.

title: Gleason Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and includes a gain of $2,961,000 from an accounting change.

title: Jets Provide Tempting Targets
description: It was interesting to hear how chipper the Jets' rookie defensive backs sounded this week after the club decided to cut two veterans and go with youth.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: HAZEL Tishcoff jokes self-consciously about whether her college-bound son, Joel, will be able to get up in the morning to go to class.

title: Kerr Glass Manufacturing Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $1,271,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13 The Nicaraguan rebels were provided with $27 million in a Democratic plan that the Senate approved 49 to 47. Coming after a week of negotiations with the White House, the vote was a bittersweet victory for Democrats. Page A1

title:
Market Place;
Analysts Favor Pier 1 Imports
description: LEAD: WITH its Indian wallhangings, incense and inexpensive imported home decorative items, Pier 1 Imports Inc. was the store of choice for trend-conscious young people in the 1960's and 1970's.

title: Inflation Would Be Worse
description: The Federal Reserve Board took a necessary risk by raising the discount rate that it charges on loans to banks. It moves clearly against inflation, even at the risk of worsening the trade deficit. The Administration declares itself ''disappointed'' by the increase; it should be. The Fed's action and the stock market's jittery response say louder than any harangue by the Democrats that the economy isn't as sound as it looks.

title: Official of Kodak Unit Quits
description: John M. Pietruski said yesterday that he would resign on Aug. 31 as executive vice president of the Eastman Kodak Company and chairman and chief executive of its Sterling Drug unit. Kodak said it would name a successor today.

title: Life in the 30's
description: MY favorite city mouse/country mouse story is the one about the flat tire in the parking lot of the small-town supermarket. Naturally, it happened when the car was carrying two children, nine bags of groceries and no spare, and when I was carrying $11 in cash. The service station across the street called the body shop around the corner, which sent a man to pump the tire up and lead me back to his lot. All I could think of was the time in the city when the mechanic told me there was a $50 road charge up front before he even got out of his tow truck.

title: Dorm Design I: A Affordable and Fun
description: FEW college students believe in minimalist interior design.

title: ADELA R. ST. JOHNS, 94, JOURNALIST, NOVELIST, TEACHER AND SCRIPWRITER
description: Adela Rogers St. Johns, the journalist, author and screenwriter, died yesterday morning in the South County Convalescent Hospital in Arroyo Grande, Calif., her grandson, George St. Johns, said. She was 94 years old and had lived in Arroyo Grande for several years.

title: Scorsese's Spiritual Jesus
description: LEAD: Bigotry is particularly ugly when practiced by Christians, who ought to be humble and compassionate like the founder of their religion. The campaign by fundamentalist Protestants against Martin Scorsese's film of Nikos Kazantzakis's novel, ''The Last Temptation of Christ,'' conforms precisely to the dictionary definition of bigotry: intolerant narrow-mindedness in defiance of reason or argument.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Hall, Frank B & Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After charges from the reversal of tax loss carryforwards of $820,000 for the latest quarter and $1.6 million for the year-ago period. c-Net income The share earnings for the year-ago 6 months was less than 1 cent after preferrred dividend requirements.

title: Sports People; Dodgers Release Sutton
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers yesterday released Don Sutton, the active pitcher with the most victories in the major leagues. Sutton, 43 years old, failed to complete any of his 16 starts this season. He was 3-6 with a 3.92 earned run average. He was on the disabled list with a sprained elbow from June 29 until Tuesday, when he was activated and started against the Cincinnati Reds. He took the loss in a 6-0 shutout, giving up seven hits and six runs in seven innings.(AP)

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ritz Thrift Shop SpotIs Going to Be Changed
description: Here's bad news for fans of the Ritz Thrift Shop's TV commercial. After 14 years, that long-running advertising hit is going to be changed. And the second-hand fur retailer has called back DiIorio Wergeles, which did the original, for that momentous task.

title: Lessons of 60's Forgotten in Park Riot
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward's preliminary indictment of his force's handling of last weekend's protest in Tompkins Square reflects the unusual degree to which the police's own lapses in planning and tactics allowed a threatening and unruly situation to degenerate into a riot.

title: TV Notes
description: 'Louie Bluie,' With Cuts

title: Affiliated Publications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and includes a equity in gain on sale of discontinued operations of McCaw of $39,978,000 and equity in an extraordinary credit of $17,879,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. The company said the latest quarter and 6 months include equity in losses of continuing operations of McCaw Communications of $26,531,000 and $51,803,000, respectively, and the year-ago quarter and 6-month include equity in losses of $2,277,000 for the quarter and $4,508,000 for the 6 months.

title: Lieberman Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss c-After a loss of $443,000 for the quarter and income of $10,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations, and an extraordinary gain of $557,000 for the both periods. The latest periods' results included International Video Entertainment Inc. acquired Feb. 2.

title: NAC Re Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After realized losses of $201,000 for the quarter and $212,000 for the 6 months, and a tax benefit of $380,000 for the both periods. c-After a realized loss of $105,000 for the quarter and a realized gain of $645,000 for the 6 months; the 6 months also included a tax benefit of $188,000.

title: To NASA's Relief, Engineers Fire Up Shuttle Engines
description: After weeks of delay and a false start, engineers ignited the main engines of the space shuttle Discovery today and, to their relief, the engines apparently fired without serious flaw.

title: First Connecticut Small Busiess Investment Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $34,121 for the latest quarter and $105,278 for the year-earlier period.

title: INSIDE
description: New Rules Offered on Lead

title: But Will It Work?
description: It is a tantalizing diplomatic agreement. The terms announced this week by Angola, Cuba and South Africa promise so much to a ravaged corner of Africa. But there have been promises before.

title: Ward Cites Police Errors
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward, at a news conference yesterday, criticized his department's handling of a riot in Tompkins Square Park last weekend. Based on a preliminary investigation that the Commissioner ordered, he cited these 10 instances of flawed judgment or erroneous assumptions by the police:

title: Home Improvement
description: CERAMIC tiles are prized for their durability and resistance to moisture. But regular cleaning is necessary to prevent the filler between tiles, called grout, from becoming stained by dirt or mildew.

title: Inter-City Gas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a special gain of $15.9 million for the quarter and 6 months. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the latest second quarter. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: KEY RATES
44.99 Drop Puts Dow At 2,034.14
description: LEAD: The stock market's slide accelerated in a broad retreat yesterday.

title: Tokyo Stocks Plunge, Reacting to Fed Move
description: Reacting sharply to the Federal Reserve's decision to raise its discount rate, the Tokyo Stock Exchange lost more than 2 percent of its value on Wednesday. The Nikkei average plunged 615.49 points, its sharpest drop this year, to 27,554.87.

title: U.S. Contract With I.B.M. Suspended
description: The General Services Administration's Board of Contract Appeals today suspended a $3.6 billion contract that the Federal Aviation Administration awarded to the International Business Machines Corporation last month.

title: Baseball; Dodgers End Scoreless String
description: Mike Marshall's home run ended the Dodgers' scoreless streak at 22 innings and sparked a four-run rally tonight that led Los Angeles past the Cincinnati Reds, 8-5.

title: Research Shift For SmithKline
description: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation said yesterday that Stanley T. Crooke had resigned as head of drug research. He will be replaced by George H. Poste, a former cancer researcher and vice president of the company's Smith Kline & French Laboratories. Dr. Crooke, 43 years old, led an unsuccessful effort to find products to replace Tagamet, SmithKline's ulcer drug. Sales of Tagamet declined recently, contributing to an unexpected 25 percent drop in second-quarter earnings and a sharp decline in the company's stock. It closed yesterday at $46.25 a share, down $1. Dr. Poste, who was born in Polegate, England, in 1944, will direct $330 million of annual spending on drug research and development.

title: PRETORIA STARTING ANGOLAN PULLOUT
description: South African soldiers began moving south in Angola today in preparation for their withdrawal from the country, the Pretoria Government said.

title: Locked, Once More, in Ancient Combat
description: LEAD: AS soon as I was old enough to know it was possible, I began to plot my escape from California. This was not because California was such a terrible state in which to live. But between earthquakes, of which I was barely aware, it lacked drama. No thunderstorms, blizzards or violent displays of autumn leaves.

title: McCaw Cellular Communicaions reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and after gains of $158.1 million for the quarter and $138.4 million for the 6 months on a cable television sale, and a tax credit of $40.3 million for the both periods. The results of all previous periods restated for the May 13 merger with McCaw Communications Cos. and the acquisition of the cellular and paging joint venture interests of Affiliated Publications.

title: Unisys Says It Will Buy Convergent
description: The Unisys Corporation said today that it would buy Convergent Inc., one of its major suppliers of small computers.

title: Repayment To VW Set
description: A West German court has ordered Volkswagen A.G.'s former foreign exchange chief to pay $5.2 million in compensation for his role in a currency fraud.

title: NATO CHIEF SEES FEWER ATOM ARMS
description: The commander of American and allied forces in Europe said today that the United States could achieve ''a fairly significant reduction'' in its nuclear warheads on the continent over the next decade.

title: ONE MAINSTREAM DUKAKIS ...
description: In attacking Gov. Michael S. Dukakis for being ''far outside'' the ''mainstream'' of postwar American foreign policy, Vice President Bush has raised a campaign issue that may boomerang. For it is the Vice President who in recent speeches has not merely taken himself out of the mainstream but climbed way over on to the right bank.

title: Review/Film; Countryside vs. Class
description: Two young gentlemen from London are wandering through the Devon countryside in their walking tweeds on a summer day in 1902 when one of them twists his ankle. In search of help, he looks up to find a beautiful country lass in a simple frock, homespun apron and straw hat. She is carrying a sheaf of wheat.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Foote, Cone Profit Off
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications yesterday reported a 17.5 percent drop in net income, to $4.7 million, or 55 cents a share, from $5.7 million, or 68 cents a share, in the comparable 1987 quarter, when the results were lifted by a one-time gain. Revenues rose 13.8 percent, to $97.2 million, from $85.4 million.

title: Olympic Swimming; Biondi Sets Mark; Carey, Gaines Fail
description: Matt Biondi said he had a good time today. He swam fast in the morning, watched a television rerun of ''Leave It to Beaver'' in the afternoon and broke his world record at night by swimming the 100-meter freestyle in 48.42 seconds.

title: CARL HOLMAN, 69, A MAJOR FIGURE IN CIVIL RIGHTS MOVEMENT, IS DEAD
description: M. Carl Holman, president of the National Urban Coalition, a major figure in the fields of civil rights and urban affairs over four decades, died of cancer Tuesday night at Howard University Hospital in Washington. He was 69 years old and lived in Washington.

title:
CURRENTS;
Putting It All In Order
description: LEAD: WHETHER you practically live at your office or always work at home, you know the problem: your environment tends to look like the inside of a wastebasket. But those computer disks and papers can be stored away unobtrusively.

title: Senate Judiciary Panel Drafts Its Version of Anti-Fraud Bill
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee today drafted its version of new anti-fraud legislation that would tighten enforcement and stiffen penalties against contractors that defraud the Government.

title: SENATE PANEL BACKS THORNBURGH FOR MEESE'S POST
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee today unanimously recommended confirmation of Dick Thornburgh, a former Republican Governor of Pennsylvania, as Attorney General. Full Senate approval is expected Thursday.

title: New Housing Posts a Rise
description: Completions of new homes rose 2.1 percent in June, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.49 million units, after falling by 12.6 percent in May, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Review/Music; Cleveland Quartet And Friends
description: Last summer, the Cleveland Quartet and two notable collaborators appeared at the Mostly Mozart Festival for a chamber-music program that eventually lifted itself to a distinguished level of music making. But one of the collaborators didn't seem entirely compatible stylistically, and there was an oddly unsettled quality to some of the playing early on.

title:
Currents;
Vindications: British Hand-Painted Pottery and the Prince's Architectural Views
description: LEAD: THE healthy sales of factory-made pottery in Britain in the 1920's and 1930's didn't occur just because there were so many tea drinkers. Judy Spours writes in ''Art Deco Tableware, British Domestic Ceramics 1925-1939'' (Rizzoli, $35), that in the pared-down esthetic of modern design, ''the absence of clutter and consequent lack of color in rooms was unacceptable to average British taste.

title: Procter & Gamble Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a charge of $459 million.

title: Kulicke & Soffa Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: India Disputes Report On Rights Violations
description: The Indian Government has denounced as ''one-sided and distorted'' a report by Amnesty International that said scores of people had been killed illegally by security forces in Punjab state and elsewhere.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Catalyst and Coltrane

title: New Orleans and G.O.P. Make an Odd Coupling
description: Under any circumstances, this steamy port town, with its rich ethnic mix, persistent poverty and sensuous blend of funky charm and decadence appears to be an odd place for the conservative proselytizing of the Republican National Convention.

title: Review/Theater; Angelina Reaux Sings Weill at the Public
description: Kurt Weill was such a musical chameleon that the challenge of constructing a dramatically cohesive one-person show around his songs is daunting. After moving from Germany to the United States in 1935, Weill largely abandoned the mordant music-hall idiom of his collaborations with Bertolt Brecht for an airier, more melodious Broadway-oriented style. Working with American collaborators like Maxwell Anderson (''Knickerbocker Holiday'') and Ogden Nash (''Lady In the Dark'') who favored spiky satire over sophisticated sentiment, his music mellowed and acquired a stately sweetness.

title: Presidential Airways reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss Latest quarter share net exceeded by preferred dividend requirements.

title: Americans Tried to Ship Materials From Soviet Nuclear Testing Site
description: The United States is investigating charges by the Soviet Union that three Americans were caught last month trying to ship materials from that country's principal nuclear test site to the United States.

title: Reuter Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Brash Clubs or Haute Cuisine For Sultry Summer Nights
description: IN this summer of discontent for so many restaurants and clubs, not all is gloom and thunder. Sure, Il Palazzo has gone belly up. Maxwell's Plum has succumbed. Nobody talks about Nell's or Bice anymore, and there are empty banquettes at the Four Seasons and the Quilted Giraffe. But the Darwinian struggle rages on, and, while the pace has slowed, the fickle populace still has an insatiable taste for adventure. Here are some places where they are finding it this summer.

title: Kearney-National Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Congressman's Complex Relation to a Military Contractor
description: Two years ago, when Representative Bill Chappell Jr. urged a fledgling military contractor named Armtec Inc. to open its plant in his Florida district, he said he was doing what politicians are supposed to do: bring jobs and revenue to his constituents.

title: Century Papers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Review Board's Stiffest Test Posed by Tompkins Sq. Riot
description: In examining the conduct of the police in clashes with protesters at Tompkins Square Park last weekend, the Civilian Complaint Review Board will apparently face the toughest challenge of its 35-year history, police officials and other experts said yesterday.

title: Southdown Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $19,600,000 and $2,151,000 from an accounting change for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively. The company acquired Moore McCormack Inc. during the latest second quarter, and results reflect the acquisition. Results are restated for a 2-for-1 stock split in May 1988.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; The Wall Street Journal Shifts Work to GSD&M
description: The Wall Street Journal is pulling its business out of both Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis and the troubled British-owned Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein in New York and consolidating it at GSD&M, in Austin, Tex.

title: Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The share earnings for the Royal Dutch Petroleum Co.'s latest periods were $2.77 for the quarter and $6.29 for the 6 months, compared with $2.56 and $5.10 for the year-ago periods, respectively. The Shell Transport and Trading Co.'s share earnings for the latest periods were $1.53 for the quarter and $3.47 for the 6 months, compared with $1.42 and $2.82 for the year-ago periods, respectively. Sales represent sales proceeds. Royal Dutch and Shell Transport are listed separately on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Optelecom Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
G.O.P. Adopts Anti-Drug Plank Calling For Death to Traffickers
description: The Republican platform committee approved a set of anti-drug proposals today that call for the death penalty for major drug traffickers and urge states to suspend eligibility for a driver's license to anyone convicted of a drug-related offense.

title: Sports People; Majors's Pact Extended
description: The Tennessee athletic director, Doug Dickey, announced that Johnny Majors, the football coach, had been given a three-year contract extension through the 1994 season. The contract includes a raise in base salary from $85,000 to $96,000 a year and an equal amount from radio and television shows, or a total of $192,000 a year.

title: Business Digest: Friday August 12, 1988
description: The Economy

title: Nature's Bounty Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: Yankees Rally but Fall in 11th
description: Don Mattingly sat at his locker. A healthy distance was kept by both reporters and teammates. Frustration creased his angry stare.

title: Time Frame on Indictment Is Established for Mulheren
description: Lawyers for John A. Mulheren Jr. and Federal prosecutors reached an agreement yesterday establishing a time frame during which the Government will either indict the Wall Street arbitrager or drop the case against him. Mr. Mulheren was arrested in February for threatening to kill Ivan F. Boesky.

title: The Death Penalty Can't Be Saved From Itself
description: Lewis F. Powell Jr., the former Supreme Court Justice, put a pertinent question to the recent meeting of the American Bar Association: If the death penalty in the United States isn't swift and certain, should it be retained?

title: Visual Graphics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company attributed much of the sales gain to its recent acquisition of Litho Supply Depot.

title: Parole for Ex-Teamster Chief
description: Roy L. Williams, a former president of the teamsters' union, has won a parole from his 10-year prison term as a reward for testifying for the Government in criminal trials and because of his failing health. The 73-year-old Mr. Williams, who has served three years of the term imposed in 1982 for attempted bribery, will be paroled Jan. 13, David Dorworth, chief analyst with the United States Parole Commission in Washington, said Wednesday.

title: Gemco National Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $6,000 and $87,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss d-Includes a tax charge of $10,000 for the quarter and a tax benefit of $81,000 for the 6 months.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Chris Bosio, who has pitched nine complete games for the Milwaukee Brewers this season but has a club record-tying 10 straight losses, yesterday was optioned to the American League club's Triple-A Denver farm team. He has been troubled by a sore shoulder. Since beating Detroit May 16, the right-hander has been 0-10 with a 5.38 e.r.a. in 15 outings. . . . The Australian basketball star, Andrew Gaze, a 6-foot-6-inch forward-guard, will accept a one-year scholarship to attend Seton Hall, he said yesterday. Gaze, 23 years old, will join the Pirates immediately after representing Australia at the Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea next month. He averaged 36.9 points a game this year in the Australian National Basketball League. (AP)

title: Nuclear Challenge to Stay
description: The Massachusetts Supreme Court by a 3 to 2 ruled today that a measure that might close the state's two commercial nuclear power plants could go on the ballot in November.

title: Contributions By Sperry in '84
description: Several employees of the Sperry Corporation were told in 1984 to make political contributions, which were later reimbursed by the company through falsified expense vouchers, according to an internal investigation conducted last November by the Unisys Corporation, Sperry's successor company. Such reimbursements appear to violate Federal laws forbidding corporate contributions.

title: Desert Sprouts Dry School of Economists
description: To the Editor:

title: LSB Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: There were no share earnings for both 6-month periods because preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: Hope D. Brock, Hospital Official, 70
description: Hope D. Brock, a member of the board of directors of the Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan for 22 years, died Tuesday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston after a short illness. She was 70 years old and lived in Oyster Bay Cove, L.I.

title: May Department Stores Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: The second quarter earnings included a pre-tax gain of $47 million related to the sale of May Florida, the company's department store division based in Jacksonville, Fla. The company said second quarter results also included a pre-tax charge of $26 million for the costs associated with closing non-productive store locations and a $22 million pre-tax charge for integrating Foley's and Filene's.

description: b-Net income

title: Review/Art; Presenting Photos As Historical Relics And Curiosities
description: WHEN photographs are framed and hung in museums and galleries, we can assume they are meant to be considered works of art. Yet because they are often records of specific times and places, photographs also function as historical relics, showing us what our forebears considered worth preserving with a camera.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Creative Pair Shifts Style At D.D.B.
description: ROBERT MACKALL and John Mariucci, executive vice presidents and executive creative directors of DDB Needham, are following in the footsteps of Bob Gage, Bob Levenson, Margin Honig, Roy Grace and John Noble, all of whom were past creative leaders at Doyle Dane Bernbach. But they are the first to do the job as a duet. And their inspiration primarily comes from Keith Reinhard, creative man and chairman of DDB Needham, more than from the late William Bernbach, creative man, founder and chairman of D.D.B.

title: Magnitogorsk Journal; Russians Take a Stroll Down Easy Street, U.S.A.
description: Liliya and Andrei Markelev, 26-year-old newlyweds, thought they knew something about America. Even out here, 900 miles from Moscow, they watch television and read the newspapers, for heaven's sake.

description: b-Net income

title: COMPANY SUSPENDS INSURANCE CUTOFF
description: The Circle K Corporation today temporarily suspended a plan to cut off medical coverage of workers who become sick or injured as a result of AIDS, alcohol, drug abuse or self-inflicted wounds.

title: RESIGNATION OF HEALTH OFFICIAL IS SOUGHT
description: A court ruling that the Federal Government has illegally denied Medicare benefits for home health care to hundreds or even thousands of elderly patients prompted three members of Congress today to call for the resignation of Dr. William L. Roper, head of the Federal Health Care Financing Administration.

title: Big Rises Expected Today in Crop Prices
description: Prices of soybeans and grains eased yesterday as traders awaited the Agriculture Department's most important crop report of the season. When the report was released after the close of the Midwestern commodity markets, it confirmed the worst estimates of the damage caused by this year's severe drought.

title: ARIAS ASKS CASTRO FOR HELP IN TALKS
description: President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica said today that he had asked Fidel Castro, the Cuban leader, to help him revive the Central American peace process.

description: General Assembly

title: Deal for Comforto
description: Haworth Inc. has purchased the Comforto Group, a seating company based in Ahlen, West Germany, for $29.5 million in cash, Haworth announced. The deal was made with Vickers P.L.C., the British holding company that owned Comforto, a producer of office chairs and conference tables as well as seating for conference rooms and auditoriums. Comforto, which has 500 employees worldwide, had sales of about $50 million last year. Haworth is one of the world's largest manufacturers of office-systems furniture.

title: Economic Scene; Administration's View of Rate Rise
description: REACTING to the Federal Reserve Board's half-point increase in the discount rate, to 6.5 percent, the White House issued a statement that avoided direct criticism of the Fed's action. Rather, the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, praised the Fed with a faint damn, saying, ''Naturally, we are disappointed that the discount rate has increased.''

title: Design Gap - Not a Trade Gap
description: LEAD: Democrats and Republicans alike are intent on closing the trade gap. Unfortunately, both parties ignore the fundamental problem of creativity in American product design. They blame our trade policies for our failures rather than our ungainly coffeepots and (until recently) ugly cars. But the cruel truth is that

title: Currency Markets; Germany Delivers Warning On Continued Rise of Dollar
description: West Germany's Finance Minister, Gerhard Stoltenberg, said today that a further rise in the dollar's value was not desirable.

title: House Votes for More Pretoria Sanctions
description: The House of Representatives approved a measure today that would impose stringent economic sanctions against South Africa because of apartheid, including a requirement that American companies, institutions and individuals withdraw all investments in that country.

description: b-Net income

description: b-Net loss

description: For all the activity, there is a certain torpor to the annual meetings of the American Bar Association.

title: McReynolds Slam Saves the Day
description: Gary Carter, who hit the 299th home run of his 15-year career in San Diego on May 16, finally hit No. 300 this afternoon in Wrigley Field, 86 days and 225 times at bat later.

title: 30 Held in Sweep Against Drug Ring Tied to Officer's Killing
description: In an attack on the drug organization believed to be responsible for the execution-style murder of a police officer last winter, hundreds of police officers and Federal agents arrested 30 people yesterday and charged them with distributing heroin and cocaine, the authorities said.

title: New York Pulls Out of Rikers AIDS Unit
description: The New York City Department of Health, long accused by medical experts of providing poor care for city prisoners, gave up one of its last roles at Rikers Island yesterday.

title: Review/Film; 'Last Temptation,' Scorsese's View Of Jesus' Sacrifice
description: NIKOS KAZANTZAKIS'S radical, revisionist novel ''The Last Temptation of Christ'' redefines divinity through choice. It suggests that if Jesus accepted his destiny triumphantly, in full awareness of another alternative, his spiritual example was thus greatly enhanced by a human dimension. ''That part of Christ's nature which was profoundly human,'' Mr. Kazantzakis wrote in his introduction to this startling volume, ''helps us to understand him and love him and to pursue his Passion as though it were our own.''

title: At the Movies
description: Subliminal History

title: Horse Racing Notebook; Pick-Six Pool Climbs Toward $2 Million
description: Two million dollars.

title: Hong Kong Bribery Case
description: The Hong Kong Stock Exchange's former chairman, Ronald Li, and seven of his colleagues, all of whom are accused of accepting bribes, could face further charges, a prosecutor said in court today.

title: Liqui-Box Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
About Real Estate; Low-Cost Rental Units for East Village
description: An unusual deal struck with New York City officials in the early 1980's is producing some privately developed low-cost rentals in formerly vacant buildings near Tompkins Square in Manhattan's East Village - an area where neighborhood residents protesting gentrification clashed with the police last weekend. No public funds or tax concessions are involved in the project.

title: Where Else on Earth Is the Air So Sticky? Try the Rain Forest
description: Trapped under a steamy mountain of stagnant air, the New York region has taken on a climate resembling that of a tropical rain forest, leaving residents sweltering for 40 straight days of unusual heat and humidity.

title: Ernest St. John Metz, Opera Coach, 66
description: Ernest St. John (Jack) Metz, an opera coach and vocal adviser at the Los Angeles Opera Center, died of liver cancer on Tuesday at St. Joseph Medical Center here. He was 66 years old.

title: E.D.S. Protest On Postal Pact
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation said today that the United States Postal Service should allow companies to compete for all parts of the contract it had awarded without bidding to the Perot Systems Corporation. Postmaster General Anthony

title: Henley Group Posts Loss
description: The Henley Group Inc. said today that it had a loss of $57 million in the second quarter, compared with a loss of $37 million in the corresponding period a year ago.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS

Hewlett-Packard Sets 10% Purchase of Octel
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said today that it would buy a 10 percent stake in the Octel Communications Corporation, a fast-growing Silicon Valley company that supplies voice-processing systems. Octel products will also be distributed in Europe under the Hewlett-Packard name.

title: Delay in Judicial Elections Is Ordered
description: A Federal district judge here has found that Louisiana's judicial elections discriminate against blacks and has ordered a halt to most judicial elections while the Governor and the Legislature devise a new system.

title: Article 283888 -- No Title
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $200 million of 9.80 percent fixed-rate notes due in 2000 at a price of par through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

New Indictment Expected in Federal Racketeering Case
description: A Federal prosecutor said yesterday that the Government would bring a broader indictment within two months in a case against six men charged in a racketeering conspiracy to create illegal tax losses through fraudulent stock deals.

title: Steve's Homemade reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Telling the Truth About a Riot
description: New York's Police Commissioner, Benjamin Ward, now properly acknowledges and assails the way his department handled disorders last weekend in Tompkins Square Park. The case tests his leadership and the new Civilian Complaint Review Board's credibility.

title: Our Towns; From the Ashes: Will It Be Condos Or Tilt-a-Whirl?
description: Gifted Sara, psychic and priestess of the paranormal, had forgotten her crystal ball. A mental lapse, she said. Unfortunately, palm reading wouldn't work in this situation. Neither would tarot cards. ''Doesn't matter,'' she said, holding open the curtain on her seaside soothsaying stand. ''I use ESP.''

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A New Party Line
description: In the Senate, where talk is cheap, even the telephones are doing it. Without anyone even touching the instruments, phone conversations from one office are now, in effect, being broadcast in other Senate offices.

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Computers column in Science Times on July 25 gave an incorrect telephone number for Ocean Communications of San Jose, Calif., producer of a videotape on desktop publishing. Its number is (408) 437-8990.

title: THE SHOOTING OF A BASEBALL IDOL
description: ALONG Lake Michigan on the north side of Chicago there once stood a pink castle-like structure named the Edgewater Beach Hotel.

title: U.S. Notes and Bonds End Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were mixed in fairly active trading yesterday, as investors, attracted by yields that have risen sharply over the past few days, began to show interest in owning securities.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Feast of the Assumption, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City on Monday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on Tuesday about the DeKalb Corporation described an aspect of the company's restructuring plan incorrectly. For each share of DeKalb stock, shareholders will receive one share in the oil well service company, to be renamed Pride Petroleum Services Inc.; DeKalb will keep the oil and gas exploration business.

title: John Carter, Tenor, 77
description: John Carter, a former Metropolitan Opera tenor, died of a respiratory illness July 22 at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 77 years old.

title: NEW YORK TO BEGIN FREE-NEEDLE PLAN FOR DRUG ADDICTS
description: New York City health officials said yesterday that they would begin a long-debated experiment to distribute free, clean needles to 200 drug addicts in an attempt to slow the spread of AIDS.

title: SENATE, BY 90 TO 4, VOTES $282 BILLION FOR THE MILITARY
description: The Senate, by a vote of 90 to 4, today approved a $282.6 billion military spending bill that the White House warned might, if changed, plunge Congress and President Reagan into a confrontation in the midst of the fall election campaign.

title: American Integrity Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $1,628,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income and includes realized investments gains of $26,000 and $49,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Lauren L. Bass Is Married To Arthur M. Blick on L.I.
description: Lauren Lee Bass and Arthur Mark Blick, 1982 graduates of George Washington University, were married at the George Washington Manor restaurant in Roslyn, L.I., yesterday by Rabbi Jack Riemer.

title: More Bank Bailouts Under Study
description: The head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that the agency was closely monitoring one or two major banking institutions that may need substantial Government assistance.

title: Litigator as New Head of the A.B.A.: Robert Dunbar Raven
description: When Robert D. Raven sought office as the American Bar Association's president-elect two years ago, there were some in the organization who thought him too liberal for the job. So, in a departure from the association's tradition of consensus, the A.B.A. had a contested race.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $567,000, or 9 cents a share, and $1,423,000, or 22 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; a tax benefit of $548,000, or 8 cents a share, and $1,087,000, or 17 cents a share, from amortization of the fresh-start adjustment under the Tax Reform Act of 1986 for the same periods, respectively; the 6 months also include a charge of $491,000 from an income-tax accounting change. c-Includes a fresh-start benefit of $335,000, or 5 cents a share, and $2,264,000, or 34 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Rocky Image
description: Vice President Bush has frequently been photographed on the rocky coast near his plush Maine vacation home at Kennebunkport. But with Mr. Bush running for President and aiming for the votes of middle-class Americans, his advisers are getting sensitive about how he is pictured.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 22 about the politics and economy of Fiji and an article on July 28 about the Peace Corps role there misidentified the nation's Prime Minister. He is Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara, who first served as Prime Minister from 1970 until April 1987; his successor, Timoci Bavadra, was deposed by a coup in May 1987. The July 22 article also incorrectly characterized the land ownership situation in Fiji. Under certain circumstances, Indians and others who are not indigenous Fijians may purchase tracts of freehold land, which amounts to about 10 percent of Fiji's territory.

title: Upper Peninsula Power Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said its directors approved the formation of a holding company; it said the plan will be presented to shareholders at a meeting scheduled for December.

title: Dominion Textile Ltd reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $20 million mostly on the sale of the company's Burlington Industries stake. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: New Strategy Set by Apple
description: Apple Computer Inc.'s chairman, John Sculley, said today that the company's business strategy for 1989 and 1990 would be based on a new generation of input devices: the keyboards, mice and scanners that allow users to transmit data or to control the computer.

title: Southwest Orders 20 Boeing Jetliners
description: The Boeing Company said it had received a $560 million order from the Southwest Airlines Company for 20 of its 737-200 aircraft. Boeing said the order brings the total value of announced jetliner orders for 1988 to $20.3 billion, a record for any full year. It said the number of aircraft ordered this year reached 458, second only to the 1978 total of 461.

description: The United States today asked Americans to avoid travel to Burma because of violent protests and said its embassy in Rangoon remained closed to normal consular functions.

title: One Killed, One Hurt In Tompkins Sq. Area
description: One man was killed and another critically wounded early yesterday in a shooting near Tompkins Square Park in the East Village that was apparently drug related, the police said.

title: 7,500 Picket Universal Over Movie About Jesus
description: About 7,500 pickets chanting ''J-E-S-U-S'' in the manner of cheerleaders gathered in front of Universal Studios today to protest ''The Last Temptation of Christ,'' Martin Scorsese's film about a human Jesus struggling with his destiny as the Son of God.

title: Snap-On Tools In F.T.C. Inquiry
description: The Snap-On Tools Corporation said the Federal Trade Commission was conducting an inquiry into the company's relationship with its independent dealers, some of whom have filed lawsuits against the company alleging fraud. Snap-On, a maker of hand tools based in Kenosha, said it intended to cooperate fully with the F.T.C. Snap-On called the suits ''unfounded and malicious.''

title: Topics of The Times; Gentle Warrior
description: M. Carl Holman, who died this week at age 69, bridged many worlds. Born in Mississippi, he grew up in St. Louis and later became a college professor and community leader in Atlanta. In the 1960's, he went to Washington. While working at the Commission on Civil Rights, he became part of an unofficial ''black cabinet'' during the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations.

title: Bridge
description: The Lightner double, calling for an unusual lead, was designed for slam contracts but can apply at a lower level.

title: Is Soviet Tyranny Dead? Are the Struggles Over?
description: With utmost amiability, Ronald Reagan has created a devilishly difficult political puzzle for George Bush and invited him to go right ahead and solve it, sometime before Election Day.

title: JETS KEEP MAKING CHANGES
description: The The Jets will start Johnny Hector instead of their one-time Pro Bowl halfback, Freeman McNeil, against the Giants Saturday night.

description: b-Included a gain of about $165 million on the sale of the M.W. Kellogg Co. c-Net loss and included a charge of $65 million. The Henley Group said the decrease in revenue in the second quarter and 6 months is attributable to the sale of M.W. Kellogg in January 1988.

title: Washington Talk: Foreign Affairs; U.S. AND JAPAN PONDER A FREE TRADE PROPOSAL
description: It is an idea searching for its time to come. For some, that may be the next Presidential term, and for others it may be the 21st century.

title: Kinder-Care Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sports People; Youmans 'Clears Air'
description: Floyd Youmans, the Montreal pitcher who was suspended for drug use in June, admitted publicly for the first time yesterday that he used cocaine. The 23-year-old pitcher wept through most of a 30-minute news conference designed to ''clear the air.'' He first said only that he was suspended for failing to stay away from ''mood-altering chemicals.'' But when asked directly whether he had ever used cocaine, he replied: ''Yes I have. The last time was when I was suspended.''

title: Retail Sales Up in July, Led by Autos
description: Retail sales climbed five-tenths of 1 percent in July, the third consecutive monthly increase, but economists say rising interest rates threaten to dampen even this modest growth rate in the months ahead.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday GLUTTONS FOR STIMULANTS

title: RALLY IN TOMPKINS PARK TO PROTEST POLICE ACTION
description: The police expect to face large crowds in Tompkins Square Park again tomorrow as community organizers and residents plan to stage a march and rally to protest last weekend's violence. All parties say they hope there will be peace.

title: Toshiba Unit To Scale Back
description: The Toshiba Machine Company, whose illegal exports to the Soviet Union drew criticism from the West last year, said today that it would cut its American operations because of restrictions on its United States exports.

title: Major Study of 2 Clot-Dissolving Drugs Is Planned
description: Medical scientists are planning the largest study ever conducted on the life-saving effects of clot-dissolving drugs, comparing two that are the most widely used in treating heart attacks.

title: A Brazilian Blend
description: Joel Nascimento and the Brazilian Sextet are to give a free concert of Choro music, a Brazilian hybrid of 19th-century European salon music, African music and improvisatory jazz, at the Central Park Band Shell, at 72d Street, at 3 P.M. Sunday. Information: 860-1335.

title: Drought Cutting U.S. Grain Crop 31% This Year
description: In the gloomiest assessment yet of damage wrought by the drought, the Agriculture Department said today that the United States grain harvest this year would be 31 percent lower than last year. The harvest, estimated at 192 million metric tons, would be the smallest since 1970.

title: American Israeli Paper Mills Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in U.S. dollars. The company said the translation of the adjusted new Israeli shekel results into U.S. dollars in both fiscal periods is at the rate of exchange in effect at June 30 of nis 1.6228 to $1.00.

title: Bell Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $9,753,000 gain on the sale of disk operations. The company said pretax gains of $9,753,000 in the latest fourth and year amounted to $5,722,000, after taxes.

description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $752,000 from early redemption of mortgage bonds. c-After an extraordinary charge of $1,761,000 for reduction and restructuring of bank credit.

title: Red Lion Inns LP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Comparable year-ago figures are not available; the partnership acquired its 10 Red Lion Hotels on April 14, 1987.

title: Olympic Swimming; Breast-Stroker Sets American Mark
description: Mike Barrowman was a struggling high school swimmer until two summers ago, when Joszef Nagy, a Hungarian coach, entered his life. Nagy spoke no English. The first words he learned were ''strong in breast-stroke.''

Nora Hodges, 89, Dies; Teacher in Peace Corps
description: Nora Hodges, a teacher at the Dalton School for three decades and later a Peace Corps volunteer and staff member, died of heart failure Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 89 years old.

title: June Loss for Texas Savings Industry Put at $2.14 Billion
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank of Dallas said today that Texas savings institutions lost $2.14 billion in June - the largest monthly decline since the industry's troubles accelerated two years ago.

title: PGA Championship; Gilder Sets Mark to Take a 1-Shot Lead
description: The Oak Tree Golf Club's 7,015-yard, par-71 course, promoted as ''the toughest course in the country'' by its real-estate developers, proved a patsy for many of the golfers in today's opening round of the 70th PGA Championship.

title: Best Products
description: The New York-based Prospect Group Inc. has raised its stake in the Best Products Company to 9.9 percent, from 8.3 percent. Prospect, a consumer products and railroad concern, said Wednesday that it might approach Best's management with a takeover proposal. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Prospect said it had bought a block of 315,000 Best shares on the open market Wednesday for $15.50 a share. Best is a large catalogue-showroom chain based in Richmond.

title: COMPLAINTS ACCUSE POLICE OF WILD, RANDOM BRUTALITY
description: LEAD: The growing number of complaints of police brutality in last weekend's melee in Tompkins Square Park reached 81 yesterday, as protesters and passers-by who were drawn into the clash have been detailing their grievances in writing and in videotaped interviews conducted by the Civilian Complaint Review

title: DUKAKIS URGES MORE CARE IN SPENDING FOR THE MILITARY
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis returned to the scene of his own Army basic training here today after demanding in New York that money for the military be spent with more care.

title: Discounts at Buick
description: The General Motors Corporation is offering an additional discount of $100 to $300 on various optional equipment packages for its Buick Regal. The SD option package, for example, now represents a $1,350 saving over the list prices for the options it includes, compared with a $1,050 savings under the previous program. The discounts apply through Sept. 28. Sales of the Regal, one of G.M.'s new midsized front-wheel-drive cars, have been lagging behind production.

Fighting the Lure of Drugs in Brooklyn
description: As twilight falls in southern Brooklyn, in parts of Sheepshead Bay, Canarsie, Gravesend and Bensonhurst, scores of teen-agers begin a nightly ritual, congregating at pizza parlors, convenience stores, near subway stations and playgrounds.

title: Gould to Sell Chip Division
description: Gould Inc. said that it had agreed to sell its semiconductor division to the California Micro Devices Corporation for about $70 million. Gould also said it planned to reduce its headquarters staff by 30 percent.
