description: b-Includes a $32,100,000 investment writedown. c-Net income

title: Vermont Research Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: The company said the major reduction in work force announced in June occurred so late in the quarter as to have little favorable effect on operting expenses in this period.

title: Pay-Now, Learn-Later Plan Proves Popular in Michigan
description: Two years ago the Michigan Legislature enacted the nation's first state-run program to guarantee college tuition for students whose families invested in a special tax-free trust fund. State officials said they expected 3,000 to 5,000 applicants.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''BEATRIX POTTER: ARTIST AND STORY-TELLER,'' an exhibition of the author and the artist's drawings and letters and a recorded narration by Julie Andres of ''The Tale of Beatrix Potter,'' at lunchtime. The exhibition is open from 10:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesdays through Saturdays and 1 jto 5 P.M. Sundays, through Aug. 21, at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street. Suggested donations: children, students and the elderly, $1; others, $3. Information: 685-0610. SUMMER SUNDAY TWILIGHT LAWN CONCER, a program by the Banjo Rascals, 6 P.M. Sunday (picnicking starts at 5:30 P.M.) at the Greenburgh Nature Center, Dromore Road off Central Avenue, Scarsdale, N.Y. In case of rain, the concert will be given in the manor house. Free, but contributions are welcome. Information: (914) 723-3470. ''THE SECRET OF THE CARDBOARD ROCKET,'' a sky show about the adventures of two children, for ages 6 to 9, noon Saturday, at the American Museum-Hayden Planetarium, Central Park West at 81st Street. Admission: children, $2; adults, $3.75. Information: 769-5900.

title: TV Weekend; Hollywood's Gilded Age
description: ''Hollywood: The Golden Years,'' which makes its American debut on the Arts & Entertainment cable network Sunday at 10 P.M., is an excellent example of a documentary that is thoroughly entertaining without being frivolous, painstaking and penetrating without being boring or abrasive.

title: Two Indicted for Fraud In a Minority Aid Plan
description: One current and one former New York State official and a Long Island construction company have been indicted on fraud and perjury charges in a scheme to have the company approved as an enterprise run by women, State Attorney General Robert Abrams announced yesterday.

title: Gretzky Slid by Rangers
description: Wayne Gretzky might have been a Ranger instead of a King, but the Oilers' price was more than the Rangers were willing to pay.

title: Gap Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Control Board Clears Some Yonkers Spending
description: At 4:45 this afternoon, almost 52 hours after the State Emergency Financial Control Board declared Yonkers to be in a financial crisis and took over the city's fiscal life, the first formal approval on a city expenditure arrived by telex from the board's chairwoman, Gail S. Shaffer.

title: BRIEFS
description: Canadian Occidental Petroleum Ltd., Calgary, Alberta, an affiliate of Occidental Petroleum Corp., said it would sell a 6 percent interest in two large oil projects in northern Alberta to PanCanadian Petroleum Ltd., for $285 million.

title: Inspiration Resources Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Broker Is Charged In Trading
description: A former Merrill Lynch & Company stockbroker was charged yesterday with buying and selling securities based on advance knowledge of information in Business Week magazine.

title: Topics of The Times; Burma on the Brink
description: The defiant protests exploding across Burma testify to more than a quarter century of repression and misrule. Despite an overwhelming advantage in firepower, the military Government is on the ropes.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 447 money market mutual funds increased $840.3 million, to $265.55 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 125 institutional funds were down $86.7 million, to $68.64 billion. Assets of the 221 general-purpose funds were up $791.1 million, to $83.7 billion. The 101 broker-dealer funds rose $135.9 million, to $113.21 billion.

title: THIS IS HOW A TEXAN SAYS THANK YOU TO NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: As a courtesy, the Republican Party arranges for the home state delegation of the prospective Presidential nominee to stay at the same hotel as the candidate. It gives the hometown folks a perquisite and puts them at the center of the excitement.

title: Northern Air Freight reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KOCH CHEF QUITS OVER VIOLATION
description: After holding Gracie Mansion's inhabitant and guests in a week's suspense as light as one of his own souffles, Mayor Koch's live-in chef resigned yesterday in the aftermath of official reports that he had improperly used city workers and equipment to further his private catering business.

title: Review/Film; Nostalgia For Israelis Off to War
description: Any film about young men heading off to war is an easy trap for sentimentality, and a semi-autobiographical look at the naive idealism of high-school days is dangerously prone to myopia. ''Late Summer Blues'' stumbles into both these pitfalls, as it tells of four Israeli high school graduates about to be drafted in the summer of 1970, when soldiers were dying in the war of attrition over control of land bordering the Suez Canal. Directed by Renen Schorr, who is the exact contemporary of his characters, this painfully sincere film begs us to respond with flashes of nostalgic recognition, to weep at the thought of warriors dying young. But it lacks the artistic vision and historical perspective that might have allowed this loaded material to resonate with true emotion.

title: COURT RULES FOR POLAROID
description: A Federal judge upheld a crucial patent ruling in favor of the Polaroid Corporation today, saying that another judge who ruled against the rival Eastman Kodak Company was unbiased even though a relative of the judge owned Kodak stock.

title: Going Straight To the Source In the Drug War
description: Last April, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d toured the vast coca plant fields of Latin America pledging United States support for local efforts to attack cocaine production at its roots. It was just talk. The Reagan Administration has done virtually nothing to help Latin Americans curb the flow of cocaine to our shores.

title: Tours and Attractions Offered by Metro-North
description: In an effort to increase traffic and revenue in off-peak hours, the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, which operates commuter train service on the Hudson, Harlem and New Haven Lines, now offers 16 different tours -some combining rail and bus service - to various points of interest not far from New York City. Most are day trips, but two to Connecticut are overnight, with accommodations provided.

title: Leslie Antin, Student, Wed to Bruce A. Levy
description: Leslie Ellen Antin, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ira Antin of Succasunna, N.J., was married yesterday to Bruce Arnold Levy, a son of Justice and Mrs. David Levy of the Bronx. Rabbi Stephen Klein, assisted by Cantor Finley Bukaitz, performed the ceremony at the Crystal Plaza in Livingston, N.J.

title: Bally Sets A Spinoff To Holders
description: Under mounting pressure from investors to improve its financial performance, the Bally Manufacturing Corporation announced a plan today to spin off its hotel and casino businesses to its stockholders as a tax-free special dividend.

title: United Security Financial Corp of Illinois reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized capital losses of $10,127 and $12,400 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net income and includes realized capital losses of $41,400 and $66,200 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Homicides in Westchester Up
description: Homicides in Westchester County rose 50 percent last year, to 48, the medical examiner's office said today. Suicides and accidental deaths were down while traffic deaths were up 23.7 percent.

title: Sports People; Bowa's New Post
description: Larry Bowa, dropped as manager by San Diego two and a half months ago, will return to the city where he started his pro career to coach third base for the Philadelphia Phillies. Lee Thomas, the club's personnel director, said Bowa would be in uniform Tuesday in Los Angeles against the Dodgers. He replaces John Vukovich, who will assist Manager Lee Elia in the dugout. (AP)

title: House Gets a Sweeping Bill to Combat Drugs
description: The House of Representatives today received a sweeping and politically appealing anti-drug bill that includes an amendment allowing the death penalty to be imposed on those who commit murder in the course of a drug-related felony.

title: Weller's 'Spoils of War' To Open on Broadway
description: Michael Weller's ''Spoils of War,'' which had a successful run at the Second Stage in the spring, is to open on Broadway at the Music Box Theater on Nov. 10, with previews scheduled to begin on Oct. 28. Kate Nelligan, Christopher Collet, Alice Playten and Kevin O'Rourke will re-create their roles in Mr. Weller's autobiographical story of a 16-year-old boy and his divorced parents in New York in the late 1950's. Austin Pendleton will again be the director.

title: Atari Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $5,764,000 and $11,657,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Crown Andersen Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Review/Theater; Paul Robeson's Life Re-lived and Honored
description: The life, or a slice of the life, of one of America's great singers, a man of extraordinary intellect, conviction, physical prowess and artistic sensibility, unfolds with an urgent vibrancy on the stage of the South Street Theater, where ''Paul Robeson'' opened Wednesday night.

title: Telebyte Technology reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BUSH TO CAMPAIGN FOR BLACKS' VOTE
description: Vice President Bush indicated today that he would battle Michael S. Dukakis for the vote of black Americans, contending that he had a ''good shot'' at reversing historic voting trends.

title: Raid in Queens: 30 Drug Arrests
description: Seeking to demolish the major drug organization in southeastern Queens, law enforcement officials arrested 30 people, charging them with distributing heroin and cocain.

title: Kahane Renounces U.S. Ties To Seek Re-election in Israel
description: Rabbi Meir Kahane, who advocates expelling all Arabs from Israeli-held territory, has renounced his American citizenship so he can run again for an Israeli Parliament seat, his spokesman said today.

title: Top U.S. Cancer Official Going to Sloan-Kettering
description: Dr. Vincent T. DeVita Jr., the top Federal cancer official, is resigning to take a high position at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York City, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: They Poke Cows, Don't They?
description: A man was jailed Wednesday night after the police said he punched a police officer's horse in the face. Officer Claude S. Hall said he was patrolling near police headquarters Wednesday when he saw Alvaro Hernandez littering. The officer said Mr. Hernandez became angry and punched his horse, then grabbed the reins and shoved him and the horse into the street. Neither the officer nor the horse was seriously hurt.

title: Contra Aid: An Issue Democrats Can't Put to Rest
description: The angry words and bitter accusations of White House betrayal that filled the Senate chamber in Wednesday night's debate over aid to the Nicaraguan rebels clearly presage partisan confrontations on that issue through the November election.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I haven't seen anything like this in 19 years with the Weather Service. We haven't had a break for 40 days, and there's no letup in sight.'' - Edward Yandrich, of the National Weather Service. [ A1:2. ]

title: 18-MONTH STAY IN FOSTER HOME RULED FOR CHILD
description: The lone surviving child of a Brooklyn couple whose four other children died in infancy will remain in a foster home for the next 18 months, a judge ruled yesterday. After 18 months, a decision will be made on future custody.

title: New, Newer, Newest: A Film Retrospective
description: If growth is the criterion by which talent is judged, the ''New Directors/ Newer Films'' series starting today at Alice Tully Hall should provide considerable insight into the artistry of some 30 directors from around the world.

title: Macmillan Profit Falls 10%; Harcourt's Loss Narrows
description: Macmillan Inc. yesterday reported a 10 percent drop in second-quarter earnings, while another publisher, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., posted a loss.

title: Senior Kodak Officer To Head Sterling Drug
description: Dr. Leo J. (Jack) Thomas, a color film research chemist who rose to senior vice president at the Eastman Kodak Company, led the giant photography and chemical concern into the pharmaceutical business four years ago. Yesterday Kodak said that Dr. Thomas would take charge of its $2 billion drug division on Sept. 1.

title: Owner Reportedly Criticized Gretzky
description: Peter Pocklington, the owner of the Edmonton Oilers, said that Wayne Gretzky's ego had prompted his trade to the Los Angeles Kings and that the superstar's tearful departure from Edmonton on Tuesday was skillfully acted.

title: Review/Art; Synopsizing the Graphic Fabric of Modern Life
description: No doubt with conscious irony, Matt Mullican has left untitled his work on view at the Brooklyn Museum. This is perhaps the single aspect of the large-scale project that refuses to state its own name. With otherwise relentless persistency, Mr. Mullican's images speak in a disconcerting babble of tongues, each busily labeling experiences and objects from our everyday lives.

title: Expos Making Their Move
description: ''Beat the Mets?'' Buck Rodgers asked, sounding surprised at the question. ''I think so. We've got the pitching now. As good a defense as anybody, maybe the best in the big leagues. Our hitters are coming around. And we can run.'' He paused for effect, and added: ''We'll be there.'' After three months of skidding, three months of bragging about Andres Galarraga and little else, the Expos are recast and revived, and they are making a remarkable turnaround with runaway speed on the bases. And they are convincing baseball people that they will be there in strength, the successors to the Cardinals and the Pirates as the chief threat to the Mets.

title: Article 441888 -- No Title
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today proposed a $1.25 million fine, its largest ever, against the corporate operator of Pennsylvania's Peach Bottom nuclear power plant because 33 reactor workers slept or were negligent on the job.

title: Home Prices Post 3.4% Rise
description: A boom in the economy on the West Coast increased home prices between April and June, while prices lagged in the depressed oil areas, a real estate trade organization said today.

title: Western Federal Savings & Loan Assn reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $125,000 and $886,000 from the prepayment of debt for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes a charge of $464,000 and $5,145,000 from the prepayment of debt for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Vitronics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Fremont General Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations based upon the agreement for the sale of Fremont Insurance Group of $2,564,000 and $5,036,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, charges from discontinued operations of $1,632,000 for the quarter and $2,105,000 for the 6 months, and extraordinary credits of $371,000 and $620,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes income from discontinued operations from insurance operations prior to the Fremont Insurance Group sale of $4,063,000 and $8,524,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and charges from discontinued Group Health operations of $550,000 for the quarter and $505,000 for the 6 months.

title: Essef Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $690,000 net charge for a facilities restructuring for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Golden Nugget Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes pretax interest charges of $9,229,000 for the quarter and $12,937,000 for the 6 months, and a pretax charge of $8,511,000 for litigation expenses for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income and includes interest charges of $2,810,000 and $10,683,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and the 6-month also includes a $169,748,000 gain on the sale of a casino-hotel.

title: Niagara Exchange Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After capital gains of $83,000 for the quarter and $136,000 for the 6 months. c-After capital gains of $182,000 for the quarter and $260,000 for the 6 months. The company said its latest figures included the results of Old Charleston Insurance Co. for the latest 3 months ended June 30.

title: Smithfield Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
RESULTS PLUS
description: Track and Field

title: Pop/Jazz; Celebration Of Pop Fluff From the 50's
description: Watching ''The Taffetas - A Musical Journey Through the Fabulous Fifties'' at the Cherry Lane Theater, one wonders: Were we really so innocent all those years ago? The show, a celebration of pop fluff that has made its way from cabaret to Off Broadway, offers an amusing reminder of just how far pop culture has advanced - or declined, depending on one's taste - in the last 35 years.

title: N.C.A.A. Eyes Drug Testing
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association said today that it would press for drug testing even though a judge ruled the tests violates athletes's privacy.

title: Edgcomb Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Gives effect to a LIFO charges of $3,075,000 and $4,575,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said the year-ago 6-month includes 16 cents a share as a result of the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for pensions.

title: Mitsubishi Bank Offers 9.33% Notes
description: Mitsubishi Bank Ltd. is offering $100 million of notes due in 1991 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Biaggi to Stay On Fall Ballot, A Judge Rules
description: Mario Biaggi may remain on the Sept. 15 primary ballot, a state judge ruled yesterday, making it possible that despite two convictions in 18 months, his resignation from Congress and his stated desire to get off the ballot, he may win re-election.

title: Angola Refuses to Talk With Rebels
description: A senior Angolan official said today that his Government would not engage in political talks or negotiations with Angolan guerrillas, despite a new call for such talks by the United States.

title: Thornburgh Confirmed as Attorney General
description: The Senate today unanimously confirmed Dick Thornburgh, a former Republican Governor of Pennsylvania who is widely admired in law-enforcement and political circles, as the nation's 76th Attorney General.

title: Satanism in Hollywood?
description: At preview screenings this week, ''The Last Temptation of Christ'' proved a disappointment to audiences expecting shocking blasphemies, an undoubted masterpiece, or both.

title: James T. McDonald, Police Inspector, 85
description: James T. McDonald, a former assistant chief inspector of the New York City Police Department, died Wednesday following a stroke in Silver Spring, Md., where he lived with his daughter. He was 85 years old and had earlier been a resident of Ridge, L.I., and of Queens Village.

title: Macmillan Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago periods included a $3.8 million gain on the disposition of the company's software division. The share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: Bel Fuse Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Market Place; 'Securitization' Finds New Uses
description: WHEN automobile loans and computer lease receivables were first packaged and sold as securities in the spring of 1985, the breakthrough in finance made ''securitization'' a new buzzword in the financial markets.

title: Big Banks Lift Prime By a Half Point, to 10%
description: Several major banks, led by the Chase Manhattan Corporation, yesterday raised their prime lending rate by half a percentage point, to 10 percent, the highest level since June 1985. The increase was the third this year and economists said it was not likely to be the last.

title: Power Goes Out in Brooklyn
description: About 8,000 Consolidated Edison customers in the Bay Ridge, Dyker Heights and Bensonhurst sections of Brooklyn lost power for parts of last night and early today. The blackout occurred when three power cables shorted out for an undetermined reason, said a spokeswoman for the utility. The blackout began at 9:50 P.M., and power was restored at 1:50 A.M. The police sent extra patrols to the areas to help with traffic control and security.

title: A HOT ISSUE: THE CHURCH THAT WASN'T
description: At the end of a sun-washed Wall Street, as depicted in the newly issued New York statehood stamp, the spire of Trinity Church rises smartly over the city. The scene is labeled simply ''July 26, 1788.'' That's the problem. Anyone looking west on Wall Street on that date (when New York ratified the Constitution and joined the Union) would have seen - at most - the charred shell of the first Trinity Church, which burned in 1776 and remained in ruins during and after the Revolution. It would be another month before the cornerstone was laid for the second Trinity Church, the one shown on the stamp.

title: Auctions
description: Sports material has recently become something of a phenomenon on the auction circuit, with collectors going for the items the way bass used to go for May Bug Spoons. At the fourth annual Richard W. Oliver Antique Fishing Tackle Auction, held in Kennebunk, Me., June 30 to July 1, world-record prices were established for the three major fishing-tackle categories of lures, rods and reels.

title: Elizabethan Anthems
description: The Cathedral Singers, conducted by Stephen Sturk, are to present ''Glories of the Elizabethan Age,' a concert of anthems and motets by William Byrd, Orlando Gibbons, Robbert Parsons and Thomas Tallis at 7 P.M. on Sunday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street. Admission is free. Information: 316-7520.

title: Iraq Says the Iranians Broke Lull in the War With Shelling
description: Iraq accused Iran today of shelling Iraqi forces in violation of a promise Teheran made this week to cease all military activity before a formal cease-fire takes effect on Aug. 20.

title: Northwestern National Life Inurance reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses on investments of $6,585,000 for the quarter and $8,460,000 for the 6 months. c-After losses on investments of $995,000 for the quarter and $514,000 for the 6 months.

title: Review/Music; To Laud a Legacy, a Meeting of Sonic Worlds
description: The musicians who assembled at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening to celebrate the legacy of the jazz drummer Max Roach represented musical worlds that rarely meet on a concert stage.

title: Sports People; Starling Bout Voided
description: Larry Hazzard, the New Jersey State Athletic Control Board commissioner, yesterday voided the controversial welterweight fight in Atlantic City July 29 in which Marlon Starling, the defending champion, was knocked out by Tomas Molinares. Hazzard, who has studied tapes of the ending, ruled that Molinares's knockout punch, a right cross, was thrown after the bell ended the sixth round.

title: A Nursing Home Ward Is Approved for AIDS
description: State officials have approved plans for the first nursing home ward in New York specifically for AIDS patients and are considering several more proposals in hopes of providing up to 1,000 new beds at a cost of $100 million.

title: Jones Intercable Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said the sale of six cable systems during the latest year contributed $21,114,000, or $1.69 a share, to net income. In the prior year, the sale of two cable systems to a limited partnership contributed $5,469,800, or 43 cents a share. Jones Intercable, in addition, said that net income increased because of fees and distributions earned by the company upon the liquidation of certain managed limited partnerships totaling $15,807,000 in the latest year, compared with $2,142,000 in the prior year.

title: Cablevision Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said increases in net losses in 1988 compared to 1987 resulted primarily from additional interest, depreciation and amortization expenses related to the company's acquisitions and to losses generated by the company's development of programming operations.

title: Vast Amazon Fires, Man-Made, Linked To Global Warming
description: Like eerie ghosts of the trees and animals dying below, thick clouds of smoke are rising over the rain forest as the man-made fires of the annual dry season are once again upon the Amazon.

title: Baseball; Reds Rally Past Dodgers in 10
description: Eric Davis singled home Kal Daniels with two out in the 10th inning tonight, giving the Cincinnati Reds a 9-8 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: For Soviet Hope and Faith, Add Charity
description: The two women strolled through the garden and chatted, mostly about the sun and their youth, both of which seemed sadly elusive on this chilly summer day.

title: Restaurants
description: Three years ago, when Montrachet opened on one of those exasperating you-can't-get-there-from-here blocks in TriBeCa (just wait till your cabbie tries to find it), it was a gamble for a French restaurant with such lofty aspirations, something akin to Lutece relocating on Staten Island. Montrachet's unpretentious style, excellent Provencal food and modest prices soon lured legions of normally unadventurous uptown diners into this alien ZIP code.

title: UNR Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $7,493,000 for asbestos insurance recoveries for both period, and the 6 months include a gain of $1,100,000. c-Includes a tax benefit of $720,000 for the quarter and an $800,000 gain for the 6 months.

title: When Head Start Is Too Late
description: But what about the first three years?

title: Pillsbury's Pay To Ex-Official
description: The Pillsbury Company, which is in the midst of a reorganization after a loss of $69 million in 1987, has agreed to pay its former chairman $75,000 a month for two years, a person close to the company said today.

title: Cineplex to Sell Canada Theaters
description: The Cineplex Odeon Corporation said it had agreed to sell a group of theater properties in Canada to affiliates and clients of Carena Bancor Inc. of Toronto. Cineplex Odeon will sell 152 screens in 57 locations that it believes are not essential to its growth plans. The company owns 1,800 screens in more than 500 locations in the United States and Canada.

title: BMA Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes investment gains of $2,517,000 for the quarter and $1,710,000 for the 6 months. c-After investment gains of $2,318,000 and $3,707,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and tax credits of $792,000 for the quarter and $1,175,000 for the 6 months. The company said the year-ago quarter and 6-month revenue include consolidation of BMA-Australia results which were previously reported on the equity method.

title: Review/Art; Notebooks of an Artist Without Enough Time
description: As might be expected, ''The Sketchbooks of Ree Morton,'' currently on view at Franklin Furnace, is a modest, ephemeral exhibition. Morton did not have time to mature as an artist or to qualify for the major leagues of art history. A mother and homemaker who did not turn to art full- time until she was past 30, she died in an automobile accident in 1977 at the age of 41. Nonetheless, Morton's life and work reflects many esthetic currents of the 1970's, when emerging artists struggled with the authoritative legacy of Minimalism and its non-objective offshoot, Conceptualism. Morton's activites included installations and, toward the end of her life, some painting: they touched on the rising interest in feminism, decoration and subject matter, pulling them together in ways that, while unfulfilled, were quite unusual.

title: EARLY RALLY FALTERS BUT DOW ADVANCES 5.16
description: The stock market ended mixed yesterday after a rally attempt at the opening failed to take hold.

title: Louisville Journal; Helping Fix Flat Tires, Now That's the Ticket
description: Any police officer who has ever issued a traffic ticket has encountered the sad, contrite eyes of the guilty motorist.

title: Manuel Kulukundis, Shipowner, Dies at 89
description: Manuel E. Kulukundis, the Greek-born shipping magnate who went bankrupt in the early 1960's, died of heart failure Tuesday at his home in Southampton, L.I. He was 89 years old.

title: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $11,166,000 from the repurchase of debt for the quarter and 6 months; the 6 months also included a gain of $18,306,000 from an accounting change. The latest 6 months included a pre- tax gain of $3,158,000 on the sale of land. The year-ago 6 months included a pre-tax charge of $15,206,000 from the relocation of the company's insurance operations. The year-ago second quarter and 6 months also included a pre-tax charge of $98,947,000 related to a recapitalization plan.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Massachusetts Mutual Names Its Next Chief
description: LEAD: In 1962, his first year at the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, Thomas B. Wheeler sold policies with a face value of $1.5 million and got a place on the Million Dollar Roundtable, of which he is now a life member.

title: Review/Film; Hollywood's Youn Bloods in 'Youn Guns,' Tale of Outlawry
description: The western ''Young Guns,'' which opens today at the Manhattan Twin and other theaters, is less like a real movie than an extended photo opportunity for its trendy young stars. Dressing up in badges and holsters has often been an irresistible temptation for groups of photogenic young actors, and this film, in the tradition of ''The Long Riders,'' is happy to watch its cast play cowboy on an elaborate scale. However, ''Young Guns'' doesn't make the mistake of taking itself too seriously. It's a good-humored exercise, if also a transparent one, and it sustains its spirit of fun right up to the point of a final shootout, in which the young heroes are badly outnumbered. Even so, the film manages to end on a cheery note.

title: Why We Can't Afford Reaganomics Anymore; Shrinking Middle Class
description: To the Editor:

title: First Federal Savings & Loan Assn of Coumbia, Tenn reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Richard F. Sparks, Criminologist, 54
description: Richard F. Sparks, professor of criminology at Rutgers University in Newark, died of heart failure on July 30 at his home in Manhattan. He was 54 years old.

title: At the 9th Precinct, Pride Is Unshaken
description: Until Saturday night, the officers of the Ninth Precinct in the East Village thought they had managed what one of them called ''a juggling act'' - keeping the ethnically, culturally and economically diverse neighborhood relatively harmonious.

title: Uprising in Burma: The Old Regime Under Siege
description: A surge of military violence that has swept Burma and shaken its Government began at exactly 11:30 Monday night, when the brightly lit golden spire of the Sule Pagoda vibrated with the rumble of an approaching tank.

title: British Petroleum PLC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The net income represents replacement cost, which excludes inventory holding gains or losses. Share earnings represent American Depositary Receipts (ADR); each ADR equals 12 ordinary common shares. The company said as of June 30, 1988, one pound sterling equals $1.71, compared to $1.61 for 1987. The average January to June rate for 1988 was $1.82, compared with $1.59 in 1987. Results are in U.S. dollars.

title: Psicor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Careercom Corp., LeMoyne, Pa., which operates business schools, named Robert A. Smith president and chief operating officer. He is replacing Gary W. Rhodes, who, for personal and family reasons, has decided to take on the job of chief financial officer.

title: Tech-Sym Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Vestar-Led Group In M&H Buyout
description: M&H Drugs Inc., the retail drug operation of the Fleming Companies, will be acquired by Super D Drugs, a company formed by a group led by Vestar Capital Partners. M&H's managers will be the majority owners of Super D, and Don E. Lasseter, M&H's executive vice president, will be chief executive.

title: Burma's Ordeal: Months of Upheaval
description: March 20: Reports reaching Bangkok say as many as 28 people were killed the week before in Burma's most violent anti-Government protests since 1974. According to later reports, estimates of fatalities range from 2 to 200. May 11: An Amnesty International report says Burmese Army units have killed and tortured members of ethnic minorities in defiance of Burmese and international law. June 21: The Burmese authorities impose a dusk-to-dawn curfew in Rangoon and close several university campuses after 10 people, including 6 policemen, are killed and dozens injured in new rioting. The State Department describes the riots as much more serious than those in March because ordinary citizens have joined students. July 9: The authorities lift the Rangoon curfew and a ban on public gatherings, but Western diplomats say tension remains high. July 23: U Ne Win, who has ruled for 26 years, cites anti-Government riots as he resigns the post of chairman of the nation's only political party and announces a referendum on one-party rule. July 25: Some delegates to a ruling party congress voice opposition to the call for the referendum, July 26: U Sein Lwin, a hard-line retired army general who reportedly commanded the forces that suppressed riots in March, is chosen to succeed Mr. Ne Win as leader of the ruling party. The next day he is also named President. July 30: The authorities are reported to have seized more than 10 critics of the Government and the Burmese correspondent of The Associated Press. Aug. 3: Rangoon is placed under martial law after thousands of masked students march through downtown and denounce what they call repression by the new President. Aug. 7: Five people are killed and an undetermined number wounded in a weekend of anti-Government rioting. Aug. 8: Eight people are killed as tens of thousands of Burmese march in Rangoon and 14 other cities to protest against the Sein Lwin Government. Aug. 9: Thousands of Burmese demonstrate against the Government in more than two dozen cities and troops opened fire on some of the protesters, killing at least 36 in Rangoon and another city. Hundreds are arrested. Aug. 10: Clashes between demonstrators and Government forces grow. The Government radio says 30 people have been killed, but other reports put the figure as high as 100. Arrests over the last two days total about 1,500.

title: Patents; Electronic Shoes
description: Puma A.G., the West German manufacturer of athletic shoes, has patented electronic running shoes. Each shoe contains a miniature transmitter, receiver and time-counter. As a shoe hits the ground it emits a signal that bounces off the second shoe and returns. A computer, located nearby, monitors these signals and translates them into stride length. The second shoe transmits a signal as it leaves the ground, and sets off a counter that runs until the first shoe lands. That allows the processor to calculate the rate and time of each stride.

title: Contract Stalemate

Larry Bertuzzi, the N.H.L.'s chief negotiator, said that during meetings Thursday and yesterday the league offered increased salary and bonus packages under which senior referees could earn between $130,000 and $150,000 a year. But Dave Newell, a senior N.H.L. referee and president of the N.H.L. Officials Association, said: ''Our officials can not be bought at any price. Management wants to have the right to fire anybody at any time for any reason.''(AP)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5 Burma's new leader resigned as President and party chairman after anti-Government protests, the Burmese radio reported without offering a reason. U Sein Lwin was in power less than three weeks. Page 1 Somalis have fled to Ethiopia to escape fighting between a northern clan and the Government of Somalia. More than 300,000 refugees have crossed the Ethiopian border in the last two months. 1 China's new industrial strategy envisions using relatively cheap labor along the nation's coast to produce goods for world markets and relies increasingly on capitalist models of development. 1 A tunnel under Jerusalem's Old City, built 2,000 years ago, has become the focus of a dispute between Israelis and Palestinians. Both sides expect violence when archeologists resume excavations. 2 Five Nicaraguan opposition leaders have been jailed for the last month for political reasons, lawyers for the five charge. The Government contends that too much attention is focused on the case. 3 A truce to end guerrilla war in India was signed by leaders of a tribal insurgency in Tripura state and Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Government. The accord came after eight years of fighting. 3 Ferries across the Strait of Gibraltar have carried more than a million North Africans this year to Morocco, Algeria and Tunisia on vacations from jobs in northern Europe, more than in past years. 4 Lebanese militia on alert 2 U.S. denies test-site spying 3 U.N. offers peace team for Western Sahara 4 National 5-10, 17, 28 The Producer Price Index rose five-tenths of 1 percent in July for finished goods, the Government reported. Analysts said that the increase indicates that inflation is approaching worrisome levels. 1 Horsepower is increasing as American, European and Japanese auto makers compete to make faster cars. Some industry experts worry that the increased power is at the expense of safety. 1 Opponents of abortion in Atlanta, bolstered by the success of demonstrations at the Democratic National Convention, are continuing a campaign of demonstrations. Hundreds of protestors have been jailed. 6 Appeals court rejects curbs on minors' access to abortion 6 The Just Say No anti-drug campaign and Nancy Reagan, who has championed the campaign, have been exploited by Procter & Gamble in an effort to promote its products, former officials of the campaign contend. 6 Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, in his last day in office, signed an order that would require the appointment of independent prosecutors when allegations of wrongdoing are made against members of Congress. 6 Parts of a lawsuit against the F.B.I. by a black agent who has accused the bureau of racial harassment were dismissed by a Federal judge. But the judge gave the agent a chance to file a new complaint. 28 Army alters the way it teaches war 5 New trial ordered in case against Lyndon LaRouche Jr. 17 Financial adviser disappears; investors shocked 17 Record settlement in Louisisana dump case 17 Politics 8-9 Vice President Bush narrowed the list of potential running mates to six candidates. Mr. Bush will select a Republican Vice Presidential nominee after a final meeting with his senior advisers. 1 Michael Dukakis challenged the Republican Party to explain the ''borrow and spend'' philosophy that he said was driving up interest rates. He would not say how he would manage the budget deficit if he became President. 9 Jesse Jackson has influenced the way Americans think about blacks in politics, interviews with voters indicate. Blacks' expectations have risen; many whites think he made it easier to vote for a black for President. 9 The Republicans finish drafting a platform 8 The Vice President gets romantic 8 Jackson wins delay in video case 9 Regional 29-32 Police training in crowd control will be stepped up for new recruits, New York City police officials said. The decision to increase training results from the violence in Tompkins Square Park, the officials said. 1 Divisions in the East Village reflect the differences in the community, an area of roughly 90 blocks that embraces Tompkins Square Park. The community's attitude toward the police is sharply divided. 29 News analysis: Mayor Koch has repeatedly backed Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward when the department or Mr. Ward has come under criticism. The Mayor's opponents have not criticized that support. 30 News analysis: Free needles for drug addicts presents a dilemma for New York City. Proponents of the plan argue that stopping the spread of AIDS outweighs the risk of appearing to encourage drug use. 29 A fire in the Empire State Building forced the evacuation of 250 tourists from an observation deck and the observatory on the 102d floor. The electrical fire was extinguished after nearly two hours. 29 Eight radio stations were silent after the electrical fire in the Empire State Building, where the stations share an antenna, knocked them off the air. The stations resumed broadcasting four hours later. 32 Noses and throats have suffered in the New York area this summer from the heat, the humidity and unhealthy levels of ozone. Now come ragweed pollen and the start of the hay fever season on Monday. 29 Governor Cuomo went to Yonkers for the first time since the city was declared in contempt for defying a desegregation order and met with leaders of the N.A.A.C.P. who have criticized his handling of the case. 31 Attacks on home of witness in drug cases described at trial 31

title: COMPANY NEWS Genentech Stock Falls After Report
description: Shares of Genentech Inc., the nation's largest biotechnology company, dropped today to their lowest level this year amid speculation that the company's heart attack drug, Activase, may face tough competition from a much less expensive therapy. The drop followed a satellite news conference from London on Thursday announcing the results of a study that showed that the use of the drug streptokinase, which is considerably cheaper than Activase, in combination with aspirin could save thousands of lives each year.

''Cocktail'' earned $8.2 million and ''Rabbit'' $5.8 million.

Mr. Ortega, who is visiting Ecuador, also criticized the United States Senate for approving a package of aid for the rebels, calling it an act of ''aggression.'' He demanded that such aid be stopped.

description: Xian Tian hefted a cardboard box containing a ''Royal Flush'' ceiling fan, a gaudy four-bladed contraption with a globular lamp destined for an American discount department store.

title: Reviews/Music; More Than 2 Concertos, but Fewer Than 3
description: It was an evening of two, almost three, concertos at Mostly Mozart on Wednesday night. Bona fide specimens by Mozart - the one for clarinet in A and the Piano Concerto No. 25 - stood in the middle of this program at Avery Fisher Hall. But there was also Schubert's Third Symphony, from his 19th year. Its first two movements offer a clarinet part so elaborate as to be concertolike itself. Joseph Rabbai, from the festival's orchestra, was the soloist.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Feast of the Assumption, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City on Monday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Flight Delays Rise in Europe
description: The Association of European Airlines said today that the number of delays in scheduled European flights in June was at least three times higher than in June 1986.

title: Bonn Cuts Ghana's Debt
description: West Germany will write off 400 million marks, or about $210 million, in loans to Ghana, a West German official said Thursday. The amount represents slightly less than half the $495 million that the West German Government has loaned to the West African republic, the official, Dr. Volkmar Koehler, said while visiting Ghana. West Germany announced at the June summit of Western leaders in Toronto that it would write off about $1.7 billion in debt to third world countries.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Woodforde Upsets McEnroe: Mark Woodforde of Australia added to his string of upsets by beating eighth-seeded John McEnroe, 6-2, 2-6, 6-2, last night in the quarterfinals of the Player's International tournament.

title: Reporter's Notebook; A Little Romance and a Prediction
description: With their affectionate banter and cozy familiarity, Michael and Kitty Dukakis have played out a campaign romance that captivates many Americans who say they love nothing better than to see a husband who loves to show that he loves his wife.

title: COPING: With Volunteering
description: You walk down the street and there they are: the homeless. You can't pick up a newspaper or watch television without being reminded of AIDS sufferers. And you want to help, perhaps in return for your own good fortune. One way to do that is by volunteering. A 1987 survey conducted by the J. C. Penney Company found that 48 percent of Americans engage in some sort of volunteer work.

title: 5 Children Killed and 13 Hurt in Van Collision
description: A van carrying a children's softball team veered out of control into the path of a tractor-trailer in a highway construction zone today, killing five children and injuring 13, the authorities said.

Business Week Broadcaster Is Dismissed Over Holdings
description: Business Week magazine said yesterday that it had dismissed Rudy Ruderman, who broadcasts its daily stock-market radio reports, for violating the magazine's disclosure requirements by failing to disclose all of his stock holdings.

title: EMS Saved This Life
description: LEAD: Bill was bent over, fist to forehead like a Rodin bronze. I apologized for being late. The train was delayed and, uncharacteristically, I'd dawdled to get a cup of coffee. Bill didn't say anything. Surliness was unlike him, so I left to attend to the morning mail and messages.

title: COMPANY NEWS 450 Layoffs Set By Chip Maker
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation will lay off 450 employees and take a pretax charge of $18 million this quarter as a result of problems in its computer systems business, the company said today.

title: What Makes Transition Hard for Yonkers Can Make City Great; Economics, Not Race
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Manes Aide Helping Inquiry Into Corruption
description: Richard L. Rubin, a convicted former Queens Democratic Party official described as a ''power broker'' for the late Donald R. Manes, is cooperating with Federal prosecutors and other authorities investigating official corruption, court papers disclosed yesterday.

title: The Pros and Cons of Stun Guns
description: They may look out of place among the video gadgets and exercise gear, but stun guns are showing up in a number of mail-order catalogues. Marketed as personal protection devices, they are promoted to appeal especially to women, joining Mace and other chemical sprays as methods of repelling, but not killing, an attacker.

title: Review/Music; Aphoristic Kafka, for Soprano and Violin
description: The entire Monday evening installment of the Contemporary Music Festival at Tanglewood was devoted to ''Kafka Fragments'' (Op. 24), a spare but often wrenching 75-minute duo for soprano and violin by the Hungarian composer Gyorgy Kurtag. Completed in 1986, the work is a collection of mostly aphoristic settings of excerpts from Franz Kafka's letters and diaries.

title: Militia Fighting Feared in Beirut
description: The danger of violence in the Lebanese presidential election appeared to increase today as anti-Syrian Christian militiamen went on alert to forestall the election of an ally of Syria as president of Lebanon.

title: Reagan Gets Spending Bill
description: Republican lawmakers say they expect President Reagan to sign legislation that rushes $672 million to the Veterans Administration, the Federal prison system and other programs that are said to need the money ''for the continuation of many essential services.'' The bill was sent to Mr. Reagan today.

title: A Rise in Mortgage Rates
description: Interest rates on adjustable-rate home mortgages reached their highest level of the year and fixed-rate mortgages approached their yearly high in the week ended yesterday, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said.

title: What Have Musicians Done to Music?
description: ''The Survival of the Symphony: What Musicians Have Done to Music'' is the subject of six radio lectures from the BBC that can be heard on WNYC-FM (93.9) beginning Aug. 21 at 8:30 P.M. The series is part of the ''Reith Lectures,'' which have been broadcast on British radio for 40 years. Alexander Goehr, a professor of music at Cambridge University, is the host of the 30-minute shows.

title: Over 300,000 Somalis, Fleeing Civil War, Cross Into Ethiopia
description: More than 300,000 Somali refugees, fleeing civil war, have walked across the Ethiopian border in the last two months, relief officials say. The officials called the outpouring of refugees among the most sudden they have seen.

title: Harbingers Of Gloom
description: Lately I tense up and start to worry whenever I see young white men in business suits, especially if they are carrying briefcases. I have only a shred or two of evidence to back it up, but I now operate on the theory that young white men in business suits are a sure sign that bad news is not far off, especially if they are carrying briefcases.

title: Bush Prunes Running-Mate List; Doles, Quayle and 3 Others Stay
description: Vice President Bush pared his list of potential running mates in a long, spirited meeting today at which his senior advisers debated the pros and cons of having Senator Bob Dole on the national Republican ticket.

title: Attacks on Witness Detailed at Trial
description: A Queens prosecutor yesterday described a night of terror for a South Jamaica homeowner whose house was firebombed twice after his complaint to the police had led to a drug suspect's arrest.

title: Producer Prices Climbed by 0.5% In July, Adding to Inflation Fears
description: In a report widely regarded as evidence that inflation is approaching worrisome levels, the Labor Department said today that the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods climbed five-tenths of 1 percent in July.

description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today won an extension of a court order barring a businessman from selling videotapes of Mr. Jackson's speech to the Democratic National Convention.

title: Patents; Skiers' Speedometer Based on Doppler Effect

title: Big Payday Predicted
description: Mike Tyson will get a gross purse of ''well over $5 million'' from his heavyweight title defense Oct. 8 against Frank Bruno of England, the champion's manager predicted yesterday. ''And I'm being conservative,'' Bill Cayton said.

title: OPEC Leader to Travel
description: OPEC's secretary general, Subroto, will visit Iran, Iraq and Kuwait later this month, the oil group said today, The visit is apparently being made in hopes of finding a way to drive up oil prices. A spokesman for the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, Kemal Saiki, said Dr. Subroto was likely to make his tour in the last 10 days of August, the OPEC News Agency reported. OPEC has been struggling all year to push oil prices higher in a surplus-laden market, and industry analysts expect Dr. Subroto to focus on Iraq's refusal to join in observing output restrictions.

title: Left at Airport Gate? Hope for the Best
description: It happens to hundreds of thousands of Americans each year. They arrive at the airport for that long-scheduled vacation or business trip, look at the electronic board to check the departure gate and discover that their flight has been canceled.

He later blamed the ''failure of the political system'' for the continuing opposition to the plan.

Sharon Moe is to be the horn soloist. Also on the program are Mozart's Divertimento in D (K. 136) and Honegger's Symphony No. 2. The free concert will be repeated at 4 o'clock at Keating Hall on the Bronx Rose Hill Campus of Fordham University, at Southern Boulevard. Information: 549-1899 or 601-7399.

Plenty of hard data is also necessary, they say: the speed of a bat, the power of a punch, the shock of a blow, the length of a stride. So inventors are now planting sophisticated measuring devices in everything from football helmets to running shoes.

title: Ipanema Is Lovely No More
description: Rio's Ipanema beach, famous for its bikini-clad girls, has been closed until December because of a pollution threat caused by a smashed sewage pipe. The pipe broke in a storm that sent 13-foot waves crashing onto the shore. City authorities decided to move the pipe instead of repairing it.

title: Ex-Aides to Drug Drive Say Company Exploits It
description: Former top officials of the Just Say No anti-drug campaign that has been embraced by Nancy Reagan charged today that she had been exploited by Procter & Gamble in an effort to tie the campaign to its products.

title: Olympic Swimming; Backstroke Record Is Set by Collegian
description: A Harvard senior with a 3.0 grade-point average in anthropology seems an unlikely choice to take a year off from college to swim. David Berkoff is in the middle of such a year, and the move paid off today when, using his unusual underwater style, he twice shattered the world record for the men's 100-meter backstroke.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Choosing and Using Exterior Paints
description: Today's outdoor paints are long lasting and easy to apply with either a brush or a roller, and most can be used on different surfaces. But anyone who is tempted even in the full heat of summer to redo the shutters or the garage door should remember that no one paint can be used for everything or under all conditions, so read instruction labels carefully. Latex paints, which are thinned with water, are the easiest to apply. But oil-base paints, thinned with solvents, bond better to some surfaces, like old paint that is dusty or chalky. Latex paints dry quickly, and two coats can often be applied in one day. They are also less likely to peel if there are moisture problems. Avoid applying latex paint when the sun is at its hottest. Latex can be applied over oil paint, and vice versa, but if the old surface is glossy, sand it. Where bare wood is exposed, prime first. SURFACE WHAT TO USE Stucco, wood, aluminum, plywood or hardwood siding Flat latex house paint Doors, windows, wood trim Glossy trim paint or semigloss oil or latex house paint Wood shingles, shakes Semitransparent oil stain, if wood is raw or previously stained. If previously painted, allow to weather; then use opaque latex shingle stain.

Hours through traffic brought Vermont, also hot and humid, and a river squeezed by drought, too low for rafting and too foul with sewage for swimming.

And there have been fictional bridge mysteries, of which the most notable is Agatha Christie's ''Cards on the Table,'' with the vital clue provided by the discarded score-pad.

The ring, which had been in operation since the early 1970's, charged clients $200 to $275 an hour, investigators said Wednesday. Five people were charged with pimping and pandering. The records will not be made public, said Paul Siedel, Santa Clara County's Deputy District Attorney.

description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights today concurred in President Reagan's selection of William Barclay Allen, a California professor, as its chairman. He succeeds Clarence M. Pendelton Jr., who died June 5. The vote was 5 to 1, with Commissioner Mary Frances Berry in opposition. Mr. Allen, a professor of government at Harvey Mudd College who has served on the commission since April 1987, said he would not allow the commission ''to become an arm of advocacy groups in the civil rights movement.''

title: Secretary Bennett's Words
description: William Bennett, the third Secretary of Education, is already the most memorable. Mr. Bennett, who resigned this week, has never shied from controversy and gladly used his post as a pulpit. But often, he was better at raising provocative questions than providing thoughtful answers. His tenure will likely be remembered more for polemics than education policy or planning.

title: Meese Takes a Parting Slap at His Foes

description: A Washington Talk page article on Wednesday misidentified an agent of the Central Intelligence Agency who defected to the Soviet Union in 1985.

title: Olympic Boxing; U.S. Team Awaits Decision on Coach
description: There is still one spot on the Olympic boxing team to be determined and it will not be decided in the ring. On Sunday, in Denver, Ken Adams, the head coach who was suspended for six months because of an altercation with an official of the United States Amateur Boxing Federation, will have his appeal heard by an arbitrator, who will render a decision within five days. Then, the American boxers will know for certain who will lead them to Seoul, South Korea, for the Summer Games.

title: Insilco Holders Sue on Buyout
description: Stockholders of the Insilco Corporation have filed suit in Superior Court here to block a leveraged buyout of the company by management, contending that the value of the deal is ''grossly unfair and inadequate.''

title: A Skirmish Along the Wall Between Arab and Jew
description: A dark tunnel, barely wide enough for one person, lies more than 40 feet beneath the Old City of Jerusalem, ending in a mud-filled ancient cistern below the Via Dolorosa.

title: N-W Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and after extraordinary gains of $2,285,000 for the quarter and $6,329,000 for the 6 months.

title: 'The Last Temptation of Christ' Opens to Protests but Good Sales
description: After a month of protests and angry rallies by groups that consider the movie blasphemous, Martin Scorsese's ''Last Temptation of Christ'' opened today to long lines, sold-out theaters and scattered picketing.

title: KMW Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an after-tax charge of $595,000. c-Included a retroactive tax credit of $90,000, or 4 cents a share.

title: Blaze Forces Tourist Exit Of Skyscraper
description: A stubborn electrical fire broke out on the 86th floor of the Empire State Building yesterday afternoon, creating clouds of billowing smoke and some scary moments for hundreds of sightseers and office workers high up in the famed 102-story skyscraper.

title: Healthdyne Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax benefits of $5,000 for the quarter and $15,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income and after tax benefits of $290,000 for the quarter and $500,000 for the 6 months. The results for the latest second quarter included $1.5 million of start- up losses from the company's new perinatal services division. The year-ago periods' results included a gain of $1.3 million for the quarter and a $2.5 million gain for the 6 months on the sale of investment securities.

title: Midwest Financial Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $658,436 for the quarter and $1,794,403 for the 6 months. The latest 6 months is after a net gain of $616,501 from the sale of an office building.

title: Reviews/Music; 'Lucio Silla' in Concert At Mozart Festival
description: Throughout the performance of ''Lucio Silla'' on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, one thought kept returning: Mozart must have had incredible singers at his disposal to write such a bel canto marathon. Composed in the reigning opera-seria style when Mozart was 17 years old, the work is in effect an aria competition, an Olympic event for vocal gymnasts. There is plenty of drama in it, but mostly of the sort one experiences watching a high-wire tumbling act.

title: Napa Valley Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Paper in Minneapolis Curbs Use of Unidentified Sources
description: A Minneapolis newspaper has set strict rules for its staff on the use of unidentified sources after three of its articles raised questions about its handling of news.

title: LOTION TO SOAK UP OIL
description: To control oily skin, a special problem in hot, sticky weather, cosmetics companies have introduced products with a new technological twist.

title: Nixon Exercises His Civil Rights in Legal Dispute Over Papers
description: To the Editor:

title: Oneita Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The results given are pro forma becuase the company completed its initial public offering in July 1988.

description: The losses for the latest periods included $1,510,000 of expenses incurred in the company's solicitation of proxies of Centel Corp. shareholders. The year-ago revenue restated to conform to latest periods' presentation.

title: Atlanta Protests Prove Magnet for Abortion Foes
description: Opponents of abortion, bolstered by the success of protests that began at the Democratic National Convention here three weeks ago, are continuing demonstrations that are attracting followers from around the country.

title: I.R.A. Role Is Seen in Killing Of British Soldier in Belgium
description: Gunmen shot and killed a British soldier tonight as he sat in his car at a traffic light in this North Sea port city, Belgian and British officials said.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in Weekend yesterday with an article on clubs and restaurants gave an incorrect telephone number for Huberts at 575 Park Avenue, at 63d Street. It is 826-5911.

description: b-Includes pretax realized investment losses of $200,000 for the quarter and $177,516 for the 6 months. c-Includes pretax realized investment losses of $531,613 and $488,393 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Brookfield Federal Bank for Savings reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Dow Drops 1.78 as Wariness Persists
description: LEAD: Stock prices fell slightly yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average declined 1.78, to close at 2,037.52.

title: Merchants Bank of NY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
New Blood at Neiman-Marcus
description: A retailing dynasty ended today with Allen I. Questrom's appointment as president and chief executive of Neiman-Marcus Group Inc., whose department stores are known worldwide for their extravagant goods.

title: Anne Ramsey, 59, Best Known in Role Of Ogreish 'Momma'
description: Anne Ramsey, whose portrayal of the ogre-like mother in the comedy ''Throw Momma From the Train'' won her an Academy Award nomination, died of throat cancer Thursday night, her press agent, Stan Rosenfield, said today. Mrs. Ramsey was 59 years old.

title: PHLCorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $23,000 and $958,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,762,000 and $747,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Inventories Climb for 18th Month
description: Business inventories climbed for the 18th consecutive month in June, prompting some economists to warn that companies may be stockpiling goods in expectation of higher prices.

title: Review/Jazz; Ellington: The Big Band and Beyond
description: The ''Classical Jazz'' series came to a suavely spectacular finish Wednesday at Alice Tully Hall, with a tribute to Duke Ellington that was worthy of the great composer's intelligence and individuality. Instead of trotting out ''Satin Doll'' or ''Mood Indigo'' one more time, the concert brought together a 16-piece big band to play suites written between 1957 and 1960 - when, after more than three decades of leading a big band, Ellington had moved far beyond the conventions of themes punctuated by solos, of brassy flag-wavers and reedy ballads.

title: Property Trust of America reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The American Foot
description: The metrication of America moves slowly; this is one of only three countries (the others are Burma and Liberia) that do not conform to the metric system. Besides, for every step forward, the U.S. seems to take another back. Even the American ''foot'' is out of step.

title: Commercial Bancorp of Coloado reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: YANKS RALLY
description: The Yankees soared and fell and soared tonight. After losing a three-run lead and then almost losing the game, they were revived when Rickey Henderson hit a two-run single in the ninth inning that gave them a 6-4 victory over the Minnesota Twins at the Metrodome.

title: DOC Optics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Vanzetti Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $28,500 and $41,500 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: It's a Jungle Out There
description: New York City really is a tropical rain forest. The National Weather Service says so. For forty days and forty nights, the temperatures along the Hudson have been comparable to those along the Amazon. So has the humidity. Small wonder the natives talk more frequently than usual about thinking they are going mad.

title: Central Park Concert
description: Sussan Deihim, Richard Horowitz and Jon Gibson are to perform works of their own in a free concert at the Central Park Band Shell, at 72d Street, at 3 P.M today. The collaborative works by Miss Deihim and Mr. Horowitz combine Middle Eastern vocals and electronic sound. Mr. Gibson, a reed player who has worked with Terry Riley and Philip Glass, composes and performs music in the Minimalist style. Information: 860-1355.

title: WESTERN SAHARA MAY GET U.N. TEAM
description: The United Nations has proposed sending a peacekeeping force of about 2,000 soldiers and administrators to the Western Sahara as part of a plan for ending the war there between Morocco and the Polisario guerrillas, diplomats and United Nations officials say.

title: 22.9 Percent: A Youth Emergency
description: According to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, nearly half the working-age residents of New York City are neither employed nor looking for work. Only 22.9 percent of the city's 16-to-19-year-olds - less than half the national average - are in the labor force. Though worse in New York, the same problem also stirs concern in other cities. It constitutes an emergency, requiring an emergency response.

title: What Lawyers Owe to Justice
description: Judge Learned Hand once said that if we are to keep our democracy, there must be one commandment: ''Thou shalt not ration justice.'' Yet current national trends, raising the cost of private legal counseling while diminishing the availability of public law services, seem to break this rule. As a consequence, economic constraints, rather than the judge or jury, have become the arbiters of justice. It appears that only large corporations and the very wealthy can afford today's enormous attorneys' fees, which too often must be paid before justice can be achieved.

title: Chemical Fabrics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $154,000 for the quarter and $609,000 for the year.

title: Voters and Jackson: Confronting Racial Limitations and Lifting Them, a Bit
description: If the Rev. Jesse Jackson seems to be running almost as hard as ever in spite of losing the 1988 Democratic Presidential nominating race, it is because, he says, his real work is not yet done.

title: Review/Film; 'MAC and Me,' Family From a Distant Planet
description: If you made a film about a homesick extraterrestrial befriended by a little boy, would you dare to have the creature look like E. T.'s cousin? ''MAC and Me'' is such a shameless clone that its cute little alien has E. T.'s gangly, prune-skinned body, his elongated arms and fingers, his enormous, mournful eyes - that look of a cross between an infant and his own grandfather. Only a 2-year-old or an amnesiac might be surprised at any of this film's Spielbergian turns. Fortunately, there is some residual charm left in these borrowings, so ''MAC and Me'' may be mildly amusing to children too impatient to wait for the ''E. T.'' video to be released this fall.

title: Ultimate Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting of $2,000,000.

title: J. Higby's reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
New Conspiracy Trial Is Ordered For LaRouche and Six Followers
description: A Federal district judge has ordered a new trial in the Government's conspiracy case against Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., the political extremist.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a Federal appeals court ruling on minors' access to abortion misidentified the President who appointed Judge Theodore McMillian and incorrectly associated judges with dissents. Judge McMillian was appointed by President Carter, not President Johnson. He signed both the dissent by Chief Judge Donald P. Lay and the dissent by Judge Gerald W. Heaney. Judges Lay and Heaney did not sign each other's dissents.

title: Sequa Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $650,000 and $314,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Year-ago figures are restated for discontinued operations.

title: Posner Agrees To Return Art
description: The Miami Beach industrialist Victor Posner has agreed to return 13 Norman Rockwell paintings he took from the Sharon Steel Corporation after he bought the company in 1969.

title: Dome Petroleum Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income c-After a tax credit of $31 million for both the quarter and 6 months. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: COMPANY NEWS Gibbons, Green to Buy Lucky's Florida Unit
description: Two months after completing its $2.5 billion takeover of Lucky Stores Inc., the American Stores Company said today that it had agreed to sell Lucky's largest non-California operation for $305 million to Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen Ltd.

title: New Law Sets $100 Fines For Taking Shopping Carts
description: People who take shopping carts home from the store to carry groceries or who steal milk crates for storage will be subject to $100 fines under a bill signed into law today by Governor Cuomo.

title: Maxwell Adds a Twist To Offer for Macmillan
description: Robert Maxwell, the British entrepreneur, stepped up his efforts to gain control of Macmillan Inc. on two fronts yesterday.

title: George Woods, 62, An Ex-Book Editor At The Times, Dies
description: George Woods, for 21 years the children's book editor of The New York Times, died of lung cancer Thursday, at Englewood Hospital in Englewood, N.J. He was 62 years old and lived in Demarest, N.J.

title: Man Stabbed to Death While Delivering Pizza
description: An 18-year-old pizza deliverer was stabbed to death yesterday afternoon on a busy Manhattan sidewalk, apparently during a robbery attempt or a dispute, the police said.

title: EVERYTHING'S UP-TO-DATE IN SOUTH ROXY
description: LEAD: THE MAN THEY once called The Mayor of South Roxy was Jabbo O'Brien, who ran a news shop in a storefront on Eleanor Avenue, which the O'Briens had run since back when T.B. (Sweet Tommy) O'Brien stepped off the boat from Tooralooraloora in 1892. But then Coronet magazine died and Collier's and Look, and all the great columnists, like Hector Timmy, and Jabbo lost interest in journalism.

title: BASEBALL: National League; Bonds's Homers Power Pirates
description: Barry Bonds hit two homers and drove in a career-high five runs tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 10-4.

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: Between the Lines of History

title: North Africans Welcome Saharan Peace Move
description: Diplomats in North Africa have welcomed a United Nations proposal for resolving a 13-year war between Morocco and the Polisario Front in the former Spanish colony of Western Sahara, but the officials were also cautious regarding any quick settlement.

title: THE REPUBLICANS OF NEW ORLEANS: Political Memo; Reagan Role Will Include Look Ahead
description: It has been a year of last hurrahs for Ronald Reagan as his active political career edges ever closer to its end.

title: Reviews/Music; Clarinetist Plays Music Of Ellington
description: Jimmy Hamilton, the clarinetist who started a 26-year stint with the Duke Ellington Orchestra in 1942, has convened a small-scale Ellington revival at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas (near Ninth Street), where he is leading a sextet through next Sunday. With his fellow Ellington alumni Norris Turney on alto saxophone, Britt Woodman on trombone, Earl May on bass and Aaron Bell (who played bass with Ellington) on piano, along with Jackie Williams on drums, Mr. Hamilton's sets focus on lesser-known Ellingtonia, carefully arranged for the sextet as a miniature swing band. The members ride warhorses like ''Sophisticated Lady'' and ''I Got It Bad'' as solo features.

title: Sarah Strickler Weds Jonathan Cole, Lawyer
description: Sarah Allen Strickler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Strickler of Killingworth, Conn., and Jonathan Seth Cole, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray L. Cole of Wayne, N.J., were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents by John D. Henderson, the Justice of the Peace of Killingworth.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: GENERATION OF SWINE: Tales of Shame and Degradation in the '80s. By Hunter S. Thompson. (Summit, $18.95.) In the literary free-fire zone of American culture and political commentary, Hunter S. Thompson has always been on point. In his latest book, Mr. Thompson, author of ''Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas'' and ''Fear and Loathing: On the Campaign Trail '72,'' addresses new targets of opportunity - from Muammar el-Qaddafi and Ferdinand Marcos to a Soldier of Fortune trade show, from the George Bush campaign to handicapping the likelihood of a Democratic victory in November. His writing, ever feisty, proves again (as if it were necessary) that he is one of our most incisive, insightful and hilarious social critics. This collection, from his stint as a columnist for The San Francisco Examiner, is vintage Thompson. His celebrated gonzo style is here: facts blended with a savage embroidery of the truth. There are many swings of style and mood, but the heart of the book is disquieting. Mr. Thompson peers into the American future (so far as he is able) and is not happy. Assailing the present Administration, stockbrokers, television, newspapers and various foreign powers, he sees a sobering and profound discontent in American life. With ''Generation of Swine'' Mr. Thompson shows himself to be an outlandish, skeptical Jeremiah. But one harbors a suspicion that his is the kind of unvarnished, crazy wisdom that is valuable in these times. In moderation, of course.

title: Botanist's Quest: An Elusive Figwort
description: Richard S. Mitchell has what some people call the best job of all the 210,000 employees of the New York State government.

title: Headliners; Little Princess
description: The line of heirs to the British throne got a little longer last week. The Duke and Duchess of York had their first child, a 6-pound, 12-ounce girl. Andrew, the 28-year-old Duke of York and second son of Queen Elizabeth II, was with his wife, Sarah, when the as yet unnamed Princess of York, fifth in line to the throne, was born Monday at 8:18 P.M. A Buckingham Palace spokesman said all members of the royal family were ''very pleased with the news.'' Outside the hospital where his daughter was born, the Duke told reporters he was ''overjoyed.'' On Friday, mother and daughter were released - the Duchess sported a small bear-shaped badge which said, ''I'm a Mum'' - and the three were off to visit Grandma at her summer palace in Scotland.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Long Term AIDS Care Burdens Hospitals
description: LEAD: LONG ISLAND hospitals, operating at over 90 percent capacity and with a shortage of health care workers, are increasingly overburdened with AIDS patients no longer in need of acute medical attention.

title: WHAT HAYDN TAUGHT MOZART
description: The relationship of Haydn and Mozart has been the subject of much comment, most of it (as far as 19th-century and 20th-century scholarship is concerned) of a slightly surprised nature, because Mozartians have always considered Haydn a second-rate composer. But contemporary and near-contemporary documents and Mozart's own compositions make it clear that Mozart treated the elder composer and his music with loving attention. Their close relationship both musically and personally makes the Mostly Mozart Festival's Haydn week particularly apt.

title:
GARDENING;
The 80's Put More Stress on Drought
description: LEAD: THIS has been a summer of heat and drought throughout much of the country. For weeks, temperatures in the region have risen above 90 degrees each day, often approaching 100. Other regions have experienced even hotter temperatures, and while our drought was relatively short lived, theirs has persisted, with devastating results to gardens and farm crops.

title: THE DIFFERENCE THAT OUTWEIGHS ALL OTHERS
description: A HISTORY OF THEIR OWN Volume One. Women in Europe From Prehistory to the Present. By Bonnie S. Anderson and Judith P. Zinsser. Illustrated. 591 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $27.50.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: STARTING WITH THE PEOPLE. By Daniel Yankelovich and Sidney Harman. (Houghton Mifflin, $18.95.) Seldom has such faulty reasoning led to so valuable an argument. The pollster Daniel Yankelovich and Sidney Harman, who was Under Secretary of Commerce in the Carter Administration, think America's policies - specifically concerning the arms race and the economy - are way out of line with the values of its people.

title: Florence Carnet Branson Is Married to Kedar Bryan
description: At the Chevy Chase Presbyterian Church in Washington, Florence Carnet Branson, a daughter of James Taylor Branson Jr. of Chevy Chase, Md., and the late Florence Crowley Branson, was married yesterday to Robert Kedar Bryan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Cavenaugh Bryan of Dunn, N.C. The Rev. Leslie Campbell Tucker performed the ceremony.

title: PLAYING, NOT JOKING, WITH LANGUAGE
description: THE SIGNIFYING MONKEY A Theory of Afro-American Literary Criticism. By Henry Louis Gates Jr. Illustrated. 290 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $29.95.

title: Virginia Pope, a Designer, Marries John Boehling 3d
description: Virginia Pope, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leavitt J. Pope of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to John Gerard Boehling 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Boehling Jr. of Richmond. The Rev. John McCaffrey performed the ceremony at St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;
A Third Revival For the Bellevue
