description: LEAD: THE historic Bellevue, the 84-year-old grande dame of Philadelphia hotels, is undergoing a $100 million renovation intended to turn the national historic landmark into a mixed-use building with high-end shops, prestigious office space and an 173-room European-style hotel called Hotel Atop the Bellevue.

title:
ART;
Kolar Works at the Katonah Gallery
description: LEAD: THE Czech-born artist Jiri Kolar made his debut in the United States at the Guggenheim Museum in 1975 in a retrospective curated by Thomas Messer. Now Mr. Messer, who is just about to complete his tenure as director of the Guggenheim, has brought 54 works by Mr. Kolar from that museum's collection to the Katonah

title: Lies Men Tell Put Women in Danger of AIDS
description: The desire to make a good impression on a potential sexual partner leads so many men to lie about their sexual past and drug use that it is virtually pointless for women who are dating them to ask, a new study shows.

title: Corporate Training: From A B C's to Z
description: ''WE wanted to promote one of our good employees, a materials handler who had been with us for five years, to a better job, as supervisor,'' said Stephen J. Rodgers, personnel director at the Rawlplug Company in New Rochelle. ''But when it came to filling out the forms, he couldn't do them. And he couldn't complete what was essentially a third-grade math problem, either.''

title: Deborah Burks, Teacher, Marries M. J. Southwick
description: Deborah Parnelle Burks, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Parnelle Burks of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Michael John Southwick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Southwick Jr., also of Princeton. The Rev. Bruce M. Webber performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: Lisa Niemiera Married to James Collins in Jersey
description: The marriage of Lisa Anne Niemiera, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alexander K. Niemiera of Perth Amboy, N.J., and James Raymond Collins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Collins of Louisville, Ky., took place yesterday at St. Stephen's Roman Catholic Church in Perth Amboy. The Rev. Robert J. Zamorski officiated. Joanne Niemiera Martin was her sister's matron of honor. Dr. Alexander X. Niemiera, the bride's brother, was best man.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Mr. Gorbachev's Stark Critic
description: For more than three years of rule by Mikhail Gorbachev, Soviet leaders have argued publicly about virtually everything - except foreign policy. Yegor Ligachev, the Kremlin's No. 2, recently shook that apparent consensus with a frontal assault.

title: Arizona Congressman's Wife Is Found Dead in Her Garage
description: Ella Royston Udall, the wife of Representative Morris Udall, Democrat of Arizona, was found dead in her garage today, an apparent suicide. She was 59 years old.

title: Fares for Disabled Bring Suit
description: LEAD: A NUMBER of organizations representing the disabled are complaining about the county's recent doubling of ParaTransit system fares, and one group has filed a suit in United States District Court Federal in White Plains claiming that the increase is discriminatory.

title: THE NATION: A History of Republican Conventions; Despite a Well-Managed Game Plan, Republicans Play Intramural Hardball
description: THE Republicans are back in the South again, which is almost getting to be a habit. The national party that was founded in 1856 to fight slavery did not hold a Presidential nominating convention in a city of the Old Confederacy until 112 years later, when its delegates gathered in Miami Beach in 1968. But growing eagerness to foster Republican expansion in the South brought the party's convention back to Miami in 1972, to Dallas in 1984 and to New Orleans, in deep Dixie, this summer.

title: Teachers' Role Grows in Hiring Colleagues
description: LEAD: WHEN Oscar Scherer was being considered in the spring for principal of the Blue Mountain Middle School in the Hendrick Hudson School District in Montrose, he first was interviewed by a committee that included several teachers from the school.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Realizing a Special Goal
description: LEAD: Lynn Bobick, who is 27 years old and mentally retarded, will celebrate her bas mitzvah at the Jewish Community Center of Harrison later this month.

title: Prospects; Cray's Fast New Machine
description: Last Thursday, Cray Research Inc. announced the first sale of its new supercomputer, the Cray 3, to the Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center, which gets much of its financing from the National Science Foundation. The new machine, which will perform 16 billion calculations a second, will not be delivered until 1990. While Cray is still the leading supercomputer producer, competition has intensified from both American and Japanese makers. Will the early sale of the new machine keep Cray in front? Stephen P. Cohen Vice president, the Gartner Securities Corporation.

title: C. B. Train to Wed Marjory L. Hardy
description: Marjory Legare Hardy and Charles Bowdoin Train, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell E. Train of Washington, plan to marry Sept. 17, the parents of the bride-to-be, Anne F. Legare of Easton, Md., and William A. Hardy Jr. of Palm Beach, Fla., and Ketchum, Idaho, have announced.

title: A Drive in the Country And a Bonus Concert
description: IF the warm weather has brought out any wanderlust, consider a pleasant country drive that can yield the bonus of a concert. In Cambridge, N.Y., for instance, nestled in the Green Mountains not far from Bennington, Vt., L'Ensemble has been presenting chamber concerts every summer since 1979 in its own reconverted Barn Theater.

title: Tracy Ellin Wolff Marries Scott Powell, an Executive
description: The marriage of Tracy Ellin Wolff, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kurt J. Wolff of Chappaqua, N.Y., to Scott Lee Powell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth F. Powell, also of Chappaqua, took place last night at the Mansion at the Stouffer Westchester Hotel in White Plains. Village Justice William Crosbie of Tarrytown, N.Y., officiated.

title: A MAD, MAD, MAD, MAD MUNDO
description: LEAD: RAINING BACKWARDS By Roberto G. Fernandez. 223 pp. Houston: Arte Publico Press. Paper, $8.50.

title: Flooded Khartoum Is Seeking World Aid
description: Record floods in Khartoum have been so devastating that international help will be needed for at least three months to assist the 1.5 million people left homless, a Sudanese Government official said here today.

title: Ann Hackeling Marries
description: The marriage of Ann Katherine Hackeling, a daughter of Paula W. Hackeling and John C. Hackeling, both of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., to Geoffrey Scott Baker, a son of Ann M. Baker of Hilton Head Island, S.C., and Melvin C. Baker of Washington, took place yesterday at the home of the bride's mother. Justice Kenneth K. Rohl of the State Supreme Court in Hauppauge, L.I., officiated. The bride, who will keep her name, is a reading specialist and a special-education teacher. The bridegroom, a photojournalist, was until recently with the Times Journal Company in Springfield, Va.

title: THE REPUBLICANS OF NEW ORLEANS: The New York Times Delegate Survey; Convention Delegates: Who They Are And How They Compare

ART;
A Sculpture Festival That's Brimming With Invention
description: LEAD: EVER since the poet and art critic John Perreault became the director of the visual arts component of the Snug Harbor Cultural Center on Staten Island three years ago, the summer sculpture exhibitions have become the most feisty and vital outdoor shows mounted anywhere.

title: Cynthia Mayer Married to Daniel Perine Benfield
description: Cynthia Mayer, a daughter of Gerald M. Mayer Jr. of Newbury, N.H., and the late Gordonna Grower Mayer, and Daniel Perine Benfield, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford J. Benfield of Southold, L.I., were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Oyster Bay, L.I. The Rev. Bruce D. Griffith performed the ceremony.

title: Exit for Soviet Jews, Conflict for Americans
description: THE Israeli Cabinet's approval of a new emigration policy that would effectively require most Jews who leave the Soviet Union to go to Israel has created a dilemma for many American Jews, who want to help Israel but who also say that Soviet Jews should be able to choose where they want to live.

title: POSTINGS: Bronx Housing; Battery Park Dividend
description: Tomorrow morning in the High Bridge section of the Bronx, worlds away from bedroom views of the Statue of Liberty, work will begin on the first city-owned shells to be renovated using surplus Battery Park City revenues.

title: Backlash Looming On Auto Insurance
description: THE Senate passed a compromise automobile insurance bill last week that its designers say will curb rising insurance premiums and sent the measure, and the political problem it represents, to the Assembly.

title: Miss Myers Wed To Daniel M. Gill
description: The marriage of Debra L. Myers, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Myers of Haworth, N.J., to Daniel M. Gill, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel E. Gill of Rochester, took place yesterday at the Lutheran Church of Our Redeemer in Dumont, N.J. The Rev. Glenn Rudisill performed the ceremony.

title: Wanted: A Watchman Of the Waterways
description: WHEN the first European settlers arrived in lower Westchester in the 17th century, they had to have been impressed with the opportunities they found. Among the region's hills and valleys was a network of waterways that could provide bountiful hunting grounds for fur-bearing animals, and countless sources of water power to develop the agricultural and lumbering needs of the European colonial economies.

title: JAZZ AND EGGS OVER EASY
description: Anyone who has recently spent a Sunday prowling New Orleans will find it hard to believe, but once there were no jazz brunches.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Saint's Remains Stolen in Maine

title: When a Movie Serves a Mickey
description: In ''Cocktail,'' unquestionably the party-hearty movie of the year, the story's bartender hero, Brian Flanagan (Tom Cruise), recites this poem:

title: Question Of the Week; Should Sugar Ray Leonard Box Again?
description: Sugar Ray Leonard has proven himself to be a great boxer, and by all accounts a smart boxer. But the decision to box again is not smart. Whether Leonard wins or not, he is telling young athletes by his example to set aside health, conditioning, and age considerations for one more grab at the brass ring. Leonard has enough brass rings. He has proven himself a brave fighter in the ring. He should now exhibit a greater inner courage by saying enough. ROBERT J. SPITZER Homer, N.Y.

title: GENERATIONS OF TORMENT
description: My thanks to Peter Maas. His comparison of the indigenous Irish in the Six Counties to the American blacks in the Southern United States in the 1960's could jog the memory and conscience of Irish-Americans.

title: Therapy for Wife Batterers
description: ALL the men in the group are there because they have re- sorted to violence. In moments of rage, they have beaten their wives or girlfriends. Some say they ''only'' pulled a woman's hair or shoved her - never intending to break the woman's arm. Others blame the women for their actions and continue to deny that their behavior is abusive.

title: TED KOPPEL'S EDGE
description: TED KOPPEL HAS JUST surprised me - it's two hours to show time - by telling me he doesn't have a clue how he's going to start his program. It's 9:30 P.M. on Thursday, June 30, in the ABC ''Nightline'' conference room in Washington. Koppel and I, alone, are eating a typical ''Nightline'' dinner. Last night it was pizza, tonight it's Chinese delivery. The host asks perfunctorily if I'm enjoying the meal. ''It's not so good,'' I tell him, to elicit something beyond the niceties. ''Marshall, as we age our taste buds deteriorate,'' Koppel, 48, ripostes. Later I find out that he smokes heavily.

title: Why Market Technicians Are Confused
description: Investors who try to predict the stock market's direction by studying such fundamentals as corporate earnings and interest rates are not alone in their current confusion. Technicians, analysts who instead scrutinize the market's inner workings, also have wildly different forecasts.

title:
THEATER;
Play It Again, Fats: 'Ain't Misbehavin' ' Is Back
description: LEAD: TOMORROW NIGHT, 10 YEARS after it first arrived on Broadway, ''Ain't Misbehavin' '' will open again, with its original cast, at the Ambassador Theater. In 1978 this celebration of the music of Thomas ''Fats'' Waller won the Tony award as best musical and made a star out of Nell Carter. Not one of the five original cast members - Ms.

title:
GARDENING;
The 80's Put More Stress on Drought
description: LEAD: THIS has been a summer of heat and drought throughout much of the country. For weeks, temperatures in the region have risen above 90 degrees each day, often approaching 100. Other regions have experienced even hotter temperatures, and while our drought was relatively short lived, theirs has persisted, with devastating results to gardens and farm crops.

title: Reviews/Music; Incense and Love Songs In Bryan Ferry Concert
description: Love is all-consuming in Bryan Ferry's songs; it's a raw need like drug addiction, a spiritual sacrament, a paradise and an eerie limbo. His concert Tuesday at Radio City Music Hall, starting a three-night stand, opened with a swirl and chatter of percussion and the sight of a censer wafting the smoke of frankincense - invoking a ritual - as Mr. Ferry emerged to play his self-created role as idealized romantic crooner. Dressed in a formal suit and black necktie and performing with stylized, slow-motion gestures, he sang with a closed-in tone and a slight bleating quality, without the warmth of ordinary pop delivery, but sounding all the more vulnerable to the pains of love.

title: INSIDE
description: Uncertainty in Burma

title: Down to the Wire For a Play-Off Spot
description: ONE of the greatest battles in contract bridge history ended in Salt Lake City eight days ago near the end of the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals.

title: When Insurance Coverage Falls Short
description: In recent years, an increasing number of policyholders have taken aim at insurance companies in so-called bad faith lawsuits. The suits, which accuse the insurers of improperly rejecting claims brought under existing policies, have drawn a lot of attention. But another type of suit has been gaining ground with less fanfare. This second weapon may provide redress for a different group of policyholders: those who relied upon an agent or financial planner for advice and wound up underinsured.

title: Edward Bennett Williams, 68, Influential Trial Lawyer, Dies
description: Edward Bennett Williams, a celebrated trial lawyer and influential Washington insider whose clients included the teamsters leader James R. Hoffa to Senator Joseph McCarthy, died today after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

title: TRANSCENDING MOM AND DAD
description: THE BEGINNER'S BOOK OF DREAMS By Elizabeth Benedict. 325 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Elmo R. Zumwalt 3d, 42, Is Dead; Father Ordered Agent Orange Use
description: Elmo R. Zumwalt 3d, son of the admiral who ordered the spraying of Agent Orange in Vietnam, and who was exposed to the defoliant himself, died of cancer today at his home. He was 42 years old.

title: 3d world Travelers Look to Doctors
description: LEAD: AS more people journey to more nations for business and work, a visit to the local travel medical clinic is becoming part of the pre-departure itinerary.

title: Pagliarulo Deal Is Considered
description: The Yankees and the Chicago White Sox, perennial trade partners through the seasons, are apparently discussing another deal that could take place before the end of the month. If it does, Mike Pagliarulo will go to Chicago for Steve Lyons in a swap of third basemen.

title: ARMY FINDS WOMAN WAS VICTIM OF BIAS
description: The Army has decided that a black woman who was dismissed from her civilian job had been discriminated against by an Asian-American male supervisor and two white male officers.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Lendl Beats Connors: Ivan Lendl defeated Jimmy Connors, 6-4, 6-4, yesterday to advance to the final of the Player's International tournament in Toronto. Lendl, the defending champion, overcame Connors in a 2-hour-10-minute match played in 104-degree heat at the National Tennis Centre at York University. In the final, Lendl will play Kevin Curren, who defeated Mark Woodforde, 6-4, 6-2. Lendl's serve was the difference in a tight match that saw Connors, who will turn 36 next month, running down balls like a teen-ager. Lendl went ahead to stay in the first set by breaking Connors for a 4-3 lead. He finished off the set with two aces and a service winner, then broke Connors again for a 4-3 lead in the second set and served out the match.(AP) Frenchman vs. Swede in Final: Thierry Champion of France upset Marcello Filippini of Uruguay in straight sets yesterday to advance to the final against top-seeded Kent Carlsson in the Aosta Valley tournament in Saint Vincent, Italy. Carlsson, in the day's first semifinal, fought off Alberto Mancini, 6-3, 4-6, 6-4. Champion, who was unseeded, won by 6-2, 6-4.(AP) Perez-Roldan and Muster Gain: Guillermo Perez-Roldan of Argentina and Thomas Muster of Austria advanced to the final of the a clay-court tournament in Prague. In semifinal play yesterday, Muster, seeded third, defeated Fernando Luna of Spain, 6-3, 6-1, and Perez-Roldan, seeded second, defeated unseeded Martin Strelba of Czechoslovakia, 6-1, 6-1.(AP) A Strong Evert Advances to Final: Top-seeded Chris Evert beat No. 8 Stephanie Rehe, 6-3, 6-3, yesterday in a semifinal of the $300,000 Virginia Slims of Los Angeles tournament. Evert won the first three games of the first set, then Rehe won three to tie. Evert won the next three to clinch the set, and jumped to a 2-0 lead in the second set. After breaking Rehe for the third time to take a 5-2 lead, Evert was serving for the match but Rehe broke back at love, hitting a backhand winner down the line. Evert then broke Rehe at love and won the match when Rehe hit a forehand long. In the final, Evert will play either Gabriela Sabatini or Zina Garrison.(AP) Harness Racing Go Get Lost Equals Track Record: Go Get Lost, driven by Tom Sells, overtook Wip It Wood, the defender, at the half-mile pole and went on to register a four-length victory over Friendly Face in 1:57 2/5 in the $100,000 American Trotting Championship last night at Yonkers Raceway. The time equaled the track record set by Sir Taurus on July 13, 1987. Go Get Lost qualified as the second American horse for next Saturday night's International Trot, also at Yonkers. Go Get Lost returned $2.60 for $2 to win. Friendly Face, driven by Pekka Korpi, overtook Wip It Wood in the stretch for second.(AP) Road Racing Floridian Wins Again: Keith Brantly, 26, of Gainesville, Fla., won the Asbury Park (N.J.) 10-Kilometer Classic yesterday in 29:35.2, his fourth straight victory in the race. The eighth annual race was run in 90-degree temperatures and high humidity, slowing the runners. The University of Florida graduate broke away from the field of 5,000 runners at the 3 1/2-mile mark and went on to win by one and a half city blocks. The women's champion was Anne Hannam, 27, of New Zealand in 32:37.5.(AP) Auto Racing Unser Takes Final Round and Title: Al Unser Jr. led from the start yesterday and won the final round of the International Race of Champions at Watkins Glen, N.Y. It gave the Indy-car driver his second series championship in three years. Unser, from Albuquerque, N.M., earned $211,900 in winning the four-race championship for identically prepared Chevrolet Camaros. He also won the all-star series in 1986, finished second last year and is now the career leading money winner in the series with $524,900. Geoff Bodine started the 30-lap race on the 2.428-mile road course at Watkins Glen International leading Unser by 2 points. But he lost his bid for a second straight title because of two spins that took him off the course. Terry Labonte was second to Unser, 1.58 seconds behind. Labonte was second in the point standing, trailing Unser, 66-55.(AP) Golf Record Round for Hill: Dave Hill shot a tournament-record eight-under-par 64 yesterday to take a three-shot lead after the second round of the Syracuse Senior Golf Classic. Hill, who started the day in fourth place, was at 12-under-par 132, matching the best two-round total in tournament history. Doug Dalziel, who shot a 65 Friday for the first-round lead, had a 70 and was next at 135. Bruce Crampton, the defending champion, led by a stroke until he bogeyed the final four holes to finish at 137.(AP) Olympic Baseball U.S. Olympic Team Beats Cuba, 12-2: Ty Griffin led a 14-hit attack with four hits, including a home run and a double, and Ben McDonald pitched a six-hitter as the United States Olympic team defeated Cuba, 12-2, last night in the Carolinas Invitational in Charlotte, N.C. The one-sided victory was only the second for the Americans in six games against Cuba, considered to be the world's top amateur team. Cuba is not expected to take part in the Summer Games in South Korea next month.(AP)

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Long Beach, Calif.;
Catching Up With the Boom
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH Long Beach is California's fifth most populous city, it has largely been left out of the construction boom that has swept Southern California during the last decade.

title: A Top Arafat Aide Talks of a P.L.O. Exile State
description: A ranking aide to Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman, said today that the Palestine Liberation Organization is seriously considering proclaiming an independent Palestinian state and government, presumably in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Making Hard Sell for Amateur Sports
description: LEAD: RALPH A. DOUGAN, ex-soccer player and former high school athletic administrator, likes to chide himself for turning salesman. His product is a growing statewide amateur sports program, and his targets are corporations.

title: Experiencing Illness
description: To the Editor:

title: Aldis Stefansson Weds Richard Higgins
description: Aldis Stefansson and Richard Loren Higgins, the New York State Housing Commissioner, were married yesterday at South Cove in Battery Park City. Judge Bruce Gould of the Housing Part of New York City Civil Court officiated.

title: Brazil Accuses Scholar Of Aiding Indian Protest
description: The Brazilian federal police have brought charges against an American anthropologist who accompanied two Amazon Indian leaders on a visit to Washington earlier this year.

title: New Jersey Bell Seeks to Add New Services
description: LEAD: NEW JERSEY BELL has met with objections from the State Public Advocate on its proposed Caller ID service, which would let customers know the number of the call coming in before they pick up the phone.

title: O'Connor Criticizes Movie
description: John Cardinal O'Connor said today that he did not have to call for a boycott of the controversial movie ''The Last Temptation of Christ'' because sensible Christians would avoid it on their own. During a homily at a Mass at the Don Bosco Marian Shrine, the Cardinal said he had received many letters asking him to call for a boycott of the film, which portrays Christ as a man who questions his role on Earth. It opened in New York on Friday. ''I would suspect that Catholics and many others would be that intelligent on their own that the Archbishop of New York wouldn't have to lead a boycott,'' he said, adding that the film's most basic flaw was that it presented ''Christ as a lie.''

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: YOU'VE been in the shower or tub just long enough to get completely wet and soapy and - oh, no, it can't be. The telephone rings, and it's a caller who won't give up. On and on it rings and finally, despite vowing that you won't, you do.

title: New 'Scandal' Reopens Old British Wounds
description: They met in 1960 at a SoHo nightclub. She was an exquisite 16-year-old showgirl in feathers and sequins who sat laughing with customers between acts. He was a well-known osteopath to politicians and movie stars, the 46-year-old son of a clergyman, whose fondness for young women was rivaled only by his somewhat pathetic yearning to ingratiate himself with the British Establishment.

title: Playhouse's Future Up to Its Box Office
description: THE fate of the Sharon Playhouse, built in 1955, could be in the hands of ''Godspell.''

title: A New Accord On Duck Pond
description: LEAD: MUCH to their amazement, Mamaroneck officials are discovering that 6,000 cubic yards of ugly Duck Pond dirt may turn into a swan of sorts, courted by landfills that once might have rejected it.

title: Convention a Conservative Gathering
description: The delegates to the Republican National Convention are a very conservative group, separated by a vast ideological chasm from the Democrats who met in Atlanta, a poll conducted by The New York Times shows.

title: Mr. Bush's Problem
description: President Reagan has moved toward the political center. Michael Dukakis is sticking close to it. By all signs the voters like it. But George Bush is coming on making the noises of the far right.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: East Patchogue $155,000 113 Hagerman Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 12-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, basement, fireplace; taxes $2,235. Hauppauge $189,000 29 Sequoia Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 27-year-old ranch; den, basement, 0.5 acre, heated pool, cabana; taxes $2,900. Huntington $153,000 12 Valentine Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, wet bar, breezeway, 2-car garage; taxes $3,100. Lindenhurst $165,000 1024 North Niagara Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 36-year-old split level; dining room, eat-in kitchen, den; taxes $3,000. Mineola $120,000 101 Lincoln Avenue 1-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old co-op apartment; parquet floors, dining area, terrace; monthly maintenance $500. Williston Park $274,000 153 Park Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 55-year-old colonial; dining room, den, office, 1-car garage; taxes $2,900. OTHER AREAS Lebanon Township, N.J. $262,000 Anthony Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, 2 wood-burning stoves, 10 acres; taxes $2,600. Valhalla, N.Y. $240,000 5 Maple Hill Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 17-year-old ranch; living room, family room with fireplace, den, deck, attached garage; taxes $3,255. New Fairfield, Conn. $191,000 37 Hillview Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 12-year-old raised ranch; hardwood floors, wood-burning stove, 0.33 acre; taxes $1,075.

title: Headliners; Big Deal
description: Come next winter, Los Angeles may no longer be to hockey what Edmonton, Alberta, is to filmmaking. The owner of the Los Angeles Kings, which have had only five winning seasons in 21 years, last week made a deal for Wayne Gretzky, who helped make the Edmonton Oilers world champions four times in nine seasons and who is considered by many to be the best player ever to bounce a slap shot off a goalie's teeth. In Edmonton, where Gretzky was all but worshiped, angry fans called to cancel their season tickets and local legislators raved about outlawing the trade. But Gretzky wanted to go - his new wife, Janet Jones, is an actress and longtime Californian.

title: The Pyrenees
description: To the Editor: I read with keen interest ''Eating a Path Through the Pyrenees'' by G. Franco Romagnoli (Travel, June 26). However, there is a historical inaccuracy.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Cambridge, Mass.; Waterfront Condominiums
description: AN $85 million waterfront condominium, with 21 apartments priced at more than $1 million, will open on the Charles River here next summer, capping the transformation of a onetime research and development district on this city's east side.

title: Douglas W. Elliot Marries Suzette Fong in Los Angeles
description: The marriage of Suzette Lai Ung Fong, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Archie Fook Tse Fong of Honolulu, to Douglas Warren Elliott, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Harrison Elliott of Brooklyn, took place yesterday in Los Angeles. The Rev. Norman Ishizaki performed the ceremony at St. Alban's Episcopal Church.

title: Notebook; After Fading Away, Balk Calls Return With a Vengeance
description: Balks are back. Not that they have ever gone away since they burst on the season like a tidal wave of beach pollution, but they had seemed to fade from the forefront of everyone's attention.

title: Memories of World's Fairs Past
description: Herb Rolfes has vivid memories of the 1939 New York World's Fair, to which his aunt took him as a mere 9-year-old.

title: Car and Remembrance in Rural Maine
description: When Sue Davis fires up her favorite touring car, it's more than a figure of speech.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
A Watchdog Panel for Shore Projects
description: LEAD: WHERE once there was a string of nearly empty beaches and sand dunes, now much of the Jersey shore is crowded with single-family homes and town-house condominiums huddled close to the water. But the development surge that has changed the face of New Jersey's shoreline over the last two decades may soon be slowed.

title: Saving the Trellis: A Roslyn Landmark
description: The organization which has funded the restoration of the Milliken-Bevin Trellis at the Nassau County Fine Arts Museum in Roslyn (more accurately Roslyn Harbor) is the Roslyn Landmark Society, not the Roslyn Historical Society. There is not, and so far as we know, never has been, a Roslyn Historical Society, but this by no means indicates a lack of interest in local history in Roslyn. The Local History Collection at the Bryant Library, Roslyn's public library, is one of the best on Long Island, and is ably administered by Myrna Sloam, the archivist. Her predecessors, Anthony Cucciara and Marion Altman, were equally capable.

title: PERIOD PIECES
description: ALTHOUGH SHE ADMITS TO HAVING PERIODIC fantasies of living in rooms with gilt rococo mirrors and tufted bergeres, Barbara Jakobson, a New York art collector and design aficionado, says she is really ''firmly mired in the 20th century.'' At least a specific era from earlier in this century. The rooms pictured here, for example, ''were designed to look as though you have just been ushered into the stateroom on the A deck of an ocean liner.'' With the help of the Los Angeles architect Christian Hubert, she renovated two adjacent rooms and a bathroom in her Manhattan town house that for 21 years had been occupied by her son. Her inspiration came from a book published in 1938 by the designer Paul T. Frankl called ''Space for Living,'' which depicted walls lined with squares of grass cloth and raw plaster over a mantel. She also incorporated such architectural details as whitewashed ash veneer plywood surrounding the fireplace and radiator covers and lining the bathroom walls.

title: Both Parties Debase My Self-Respect
description: LEAD: Who's a better American -the one who votes or the one who doesn't? I was always told that you were some kind of irresponsible, ungrateful nincompoop if you didn't vote, but I found out that the opposite is true.

title: Katherine Hornady to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Randolph Hornady 3d of Garrison, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter Katherine Carr Hornady to William Edwards Magee, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Alexander Magee 4th of Baltimore. Miss Hornady is an assistant account executive at Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton, an advertising agency in New York. Her fiance is a trainee in the credit audit department at the Chase Manhattan Bank in New York. A Sept. 10 wedding is planned.

title: Home-Repair Services Assist Elderly
description: A retired costume-jewelry salesman, Michael M. Katz, 76 years old, is so inept with tools ''he can't knock a nail in the wall,'' his wife, Rose, says. Mrs. Katz, 74, is not much handier. So what is she to do when the bathroom faucet starts leaking and the fluorescent light in the kitchen will not go on?

title: The Great Flood of Heat: 42 Days And 42 Nights, and Life Is Altered
description: Six weeks now.

title: Miss Bourne Wed To F. B. Gibney Jr.
description: The marriage of Katherine Lattimore Bourne to Frank Bray Gibney Jr. took place yesterday at the home of the bride's father, Donald W. Bourne, in Waquoit, Mass. The Rev. Robert Thomas, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Dana Olan Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Olan of Great Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dana Michelle Olan to Darryl Erik Lieberman, a son of Ruth Lieberman of New York and Larchmont, N.Y., and the late Dr. Harvey Lieberman.

title: A Stalwart of Jersey City's Past
description: LEAD: WHEN 79-year-old Joseph R. Duffy sits on one of the benches painted red, white and blue in Paulus Hook Park near this city's waterfront, he ponders the importance of preserving the past in an area exploding with change.

title: Review/Opera; Debuts In 'Cav' And 'Pag'
description: It was business as usual with a vengeance at the New York City Opera on Tuesday night. Or at least one part of the company's business: Along with novelties new and old, and occasional up-to-date productions, the company seems to feel a mandate to present bread-and-butter repertory in stagings that are traditional to the point of defiant dowdiness.

title:
ART;
American Modernism: A Collector's Treasures
description: LEAD: ARTISTS like Georgia O'Keeffe, Arthur Dove, Marsden Hartley, John Marin, Stuart Davis and Charles Demuth almost always find a receptive audience that appreciates the vitality and conviction of their approach and admires their pioneering radicalism. As early Modernists, they wanted nothing less than the renunciation of tradition and the substitution of new modes suited to a new century.

title: Some Plans to Sightsee And Vote 'Right Way'
description: The New York, New Jersey and Connecticut delegations to the Republican National Convention this week in New Orleans will include a greater proportion of public and party officials and be considerably more white and more male than their Democratic counterparts in Atlanta last month.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''For people like us, in our early thirties, we've had to leverage ourselves to our eyeballs to get housing at all. After the down payment, who's got any extra cash to put into savings?'' -Diane Schmidt-Fellner, of Norwalk, Conn., on rising interest rates.

title: Some Cool Recipes for a Hot Summer
description: A SIMPLE summer lunch or supper is easily accomplished. Fresh ingredients such as tomatoes, peppers, herbs and peaches are abundant in the markets now. Combined with fresh fish, the menu is appropriately light yet satisfying, low in fat and attractive.

title: The Words Should Matter, Too
description: Why don't composers of contemporary operas want me to know what the singers are singing about? Perhaps I am merely suspicious by nature, but I have begun to think there must be a secret they are trying to keep from me. Are the words a code of some sort? If not, why am I so seldom allowed to know what they are saying up there on that stage? Excuse me, but I want to know. I don't think I am being unreasonable.

title: Bringing My Mother Into My House
description: Little by little, I'm bringing my mother into my house.

title: Volunteerism and Youth
description: The article on volunteers (''Help Wanted, P/T, Immediate: Volunteers Please Apply,'' July 3) stressed the need for community agencies to utilize their resources in recruiting volunteers and the need to tap new markets.

title: Classic French in New Milford
description: FROM a diner's perspective, the Northwest Corner is slowly becoming livelier, perhaps partially due to the influx of new weekend residents and summer visitors.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Sugar Ray Leonard Box Again?
description: Sugar Ray is still physically able to fight in the professional ranks - albeit a weight class higher than he's used to. He still has hand speed, though some may contend his legs are suspect. He still loves to box. So let him box. Pay him whatever the market will bear. BOB WATERS Whiting, N.J.

title: A. J. Becker, an Executive, Is Wed to Lynn Joy Israel
description: The wedding of Lynn Joy Israel, a daughter of Joan Israel of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Justin Israel of Greenwich, Conn., to Arthur Jonathan Becker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Steven Becker of Philadelphia, took place last evening at the Gold Lake Ranch in Ward, Colo. Cantor Meredith Stone officiated.

title: Make Work Pay More Than Welfare
description: Two bills, one in the House of Representatives and one in the Senate, call for raising the minimum wage, now at $3.35 an hour. The House version would raise it by 40 cents a year until it reaches $4.55. Sar Levitan, professor of economics at George Washington University and director of the Center for Social Policy, talked with the Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman, about America's declining wages and the need to increase the minimum wage. Question: In the last decade, 20 million new jobs were created. Would you characterize these jobs as good jobs? Mr. Levitan: It is overstating the case to say that most of the jobs created in the last 10 years have been good jobs. A large percentage are poor-quality jobs, meaning they are low paying with few benefits. Many of these jobs are also part-time jobs. Q. Since 1983 hasn't the growth of full-time employment outpaced the growth of part-time employment? Mr. Levitan: It is misleading to use 1983 as a benchmark to examine job creation. In 1982 we had just come out of a deep recession. There is a lag between the end of a recession and the creation of new jobs. Because of that recession, 1983 still had the highest rate of unemployment since World War II.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: One of the Guys The Wising Up of an American Man

title: Question Of the Week; Should Sugar Ray Leonard Box Again?
description: I say no - a thousand times no. He should not gamble and push his luck. I say this from my experience as a retired fighter. I have had three retina operations - back in 1933 - all unsuccessful and I have been blind in one eye all these years. We didn't have laser in those days, but percentages are the same. Sugar Ray has money and is doing well. What does he want? MAXIE PINK New York

title:
BODY AND MIND;
The Aggressors
description: LEAD: DR. DAN OLWEUS KNOWS THE BULLIES in Norway; at least those 8 to 16 years old in a population of 140,000 in 715 public schools.

title: Shuler Tries to Push Jets
description: After 10 years in the National Football League, a player shouldn't have his outlook changed by one game.

title: TUNNEL VISION
description: To the Editor: Readers who plan to do any driving in Italy and who speak little or no Italian can save themselves some grief by memorizing the phrases that appear at tunnel entrances along the Autostrade. Those with enough Italian will recognize immediately that the signs instruct drivers to turn on their headlights in the many tunnels through which the Autostrade run.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Is the Gretzky Trade the Biggest Ever?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Millions Flee Life's Toils To Risk Lives on Rafts
description: For relief from the heat, the pollution, the beeper, the office copier, some people are choosing to sit with a group of total strangers in the middle of a churning river that drops hundreds of feet in minutes.

title: Ronna Lynn Tulgan Weds Thomas W. Ostheimer
description: At the Seven Hills Country Inn in Lenox, Mass., Ronna Lynn Tulgan, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Tulgan of Pittsfield, Mass., was married last evening to Thomas Winslow Ostheimer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Ostheimer of York, Me. Rabbi Alan Berg officiated. Mrs. Ostheimer, who will retain her name professionally, graduated from Miss Hall's School and William Smith College. She received a master's degree in psychological education from the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, from which she expects to receive a doctorate in December. Her father, a cardiologist with Berkshire Physicians and Surgeons in Pittsfield, is an associate professor of medicine and the assistant dean for continuing medical education at the Berkshire Medical Center. Her mother, Norma P. Tulgan, is an educational consultant.

title: Bombs Kill 7 in Sri Lanka
description: Two bombs exploded in Sri Lanka today, killing seven Indian soldiers and destroying a bridge and part of a main railway line, the Indian Embassy said. A spokeswoman for the embassy said.

title: In a Jersey Suburb, a Fresh Air Party
description: It was shaping up to be the pool party of the summer until two uninvited guests - lightning and thunder -dropped in.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Sugar Ray Leonard Box Again?
description: Of course! He knows the risks he is taking and if the money is worth more to him than his sight, let him fight. STEVEN BERGMAN Brooklyn

title: LaPoint Traded To the Pirates
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates, who had been seeking a left-handed starting pitcher for several weeks, obtained Dave LaPoint from the Chicago White Sox today. The Pirates sent Barry Jones, a right-handed reliever, to Chicago.

title: Dr. Cunningham Weds Kristian Bagger
description: Dr. Carol Ann Cunningham, the daughter of Sylvia Cunningham Forster of Cooperstown, N.Y., and Russell Gadde of Columbus, Ga., was married yesterday to Kristian Bagger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Erik Bagger of Copenhagen. The Rev. Peter Ohrt, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony in the chapel at Dragsholm Castle in Horve, Denmark.

title: Turkmenistan President Out
description: The President of the Soviet Central Asian republic of Turkmenistan, Bally Y. Yazkuliyev, has been relieved of his post for ''defects in his work,'' the Government press agency said today. The 57-year-old Mr. Yazkuliyev, who had been in the post almost 10 years, will be replaced Roza Bazarova, a deputy prime minister.

title: U.N. Basks in Success but Still Needs Money
description: These are heady days at United Nations headquarters, with positive developments on Afghanistan and the Persian Gulf and the United Nations getting most of the credit.

title: Views From The No. 69 Bus Through Paris
description: Like most visitors to Paris, I'd always relied on the Metro to get around.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Rescuing a Fire Engine
description: LEAD: Once there was a little fire engine that could and, if some people in Bedford have their way, it will again.

title: Centers Offer Alternative to Nursing Homes
description: ADULT day-care centers are cheaper than a nursing center, offer more than a senior citizens' center and are growing in popularity in Connecticut, their advocates say. While the centers allow many frail, elderly people who cannot care for themselves to live at home, they can also give the person who cares for an elderly person a welcome respite.

title: THE WORLD: Submitting to the I.M.F.; Yugoslavia's Capitalist Tilt Becomes a Headlong Plunge
description: AFTER decades of hovering between Communism and capitalism, Yugoslavia's leaders are approaching economic policy as if they believe that, over the long term, almost nothing is more important than the marketplace. Still, the Communist leadership's continued reluctance to loosen the political reins raises doubts about their ability to follow their newfound economic faith.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: ON THE RUN

title: ALL OF AN AGE
description: INFANT, TODDLER OR TEEN, TODAY'S CHILD IS GARBED WITHOUT regard to the classic age categories. This year's back-to-school clothes make no big deal of when black may become part of a pre-teen wardrobe, or when color should be bright or muted. All ages may, and do, wear all varieties.

title: About Chess Moves
description: The New York Times has converted its method of chessboard notation to the algebraic system, in which each square is unambiguously identified by file letter and rank number. Explanations of the system are available from the Chess Column, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: MINES PUT AFGHANS IN PERIL ON RETURN
description: A new United States study says 10 million to 16 million land mines are hidden in Afghanistan, posing dangers that could delay the return of Afghan refugees.

title: Hint of New Peace Effort Amid Nicaragua Gloom
description: A year after the signing of a Central American peace plan, the confrontation that has torn Nicaragua for most of this decade seems little nearer to a permanent resolution.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Foundations; Learning to Cope With Myriad Subterranean Surprises
description: BEFORE an office tower goes up, it must go down - far enough for a rock-solid foundation. Far enough to expose a subterranean stew of manmade trouble - sewers, subway lines, highway tunnels, electrical substations, water mains, gas lines, diverted streams and assorted relics of the urban underground.

title: COMPUTERS IN COMMAND
description: LEAD: THE DREAMS OF REASON The Computer and the Rise of the Sciences of Complexity. By Heinz R. Pagels. 352 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: U.S. Aims to Deny Aid for Abortion Advice
description: The Reagan Administration will begin applying new regulations that deny Federal money to family planning clinics that give women information about abortion unless the clinics are covered by court injunctions against the regulations.

title: Taking Thrifty Cues From the Swiss
description: When a Saudi princess checked into a lakefront hotel in Geneva some time ago she asked the management to distribute $15,000 among the staff. The advance gratuities were to make sure her privacy would be rigorously protected; it may be assumed that she received attentive service. (Shrewd guests tip early.) In St. Moritz, an Italian industrialist is said to have nonchalantly written a check for nearly $10,000 after a weekend with his young girlfriend in a five-star hotel, to pay for his room, meals and a few extras like a special flower arrangement in the couple's suite, overseas telephone calls and Champagne sent up by room service. It does not take exceptional gourmandise or a preference for rare vintages to spend $200 on a dinner for two at Girardet's in Crissier near Lausanne, Stucki Bruderaolz in Basel, Chez Max in Zurich-Zollikon or Fischerzunft in Schaffhausen - all four among the Continent's finest restaurants east of Paris.

title: POSTINGS: Air Rights in Clinton; 7-Story Condo, Going for 10
description: In the Clinton section of Manhattan, where everything old is modest and everything new is massive, Pat Degliuomini is building something in the middle. His $2 million, seven-story (or 10-story) condominium under construction at 343-345 West 51st Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues is bordered by five- and three-story brownstones and is in the winter shadow of World Wide Plaza, the $585-million, avenue-to-avenue complex being raised a block south.

title: Return to Court For an Anchor
description: CHRISTINE CRAFT, the television anchorwoman who went to court when her employer said she was too old and too unattractive to go on the air, wants to go back to court, this time for good. But only after she goes to law school.

title: POSTINGS: Past and Present; East Side Touring
description: Beekman Place and Sutton Place have an infamous past and a seemingly exclusive present, but, said Howard Goldberg, who is leading two tours of the East Side enclaves today, they ''mirror the best of what New York is all about.''

title: Coping With Medical Waste
description: THE needles, syringes and other medical waste that have washed up on beaches this summer point to a larger problem confronting every medical institution: how to deal with infectious wastes that are increasingly barred from the hospitals' own incinerators.

title: Switzer on Top
description: For the eighth year in a row, Barry Switzer of Oklahoma has the top winning percentage among major-college football coaches, according to the 31st annual Top Twenty Coaches list. The list was originated in 1958 by Elmore Hudgins, former public relations director for the Southeastern Conference.

title: The Anglicans' Non-Universal Church
description: BEFORE the world's Anglican bishops filed solemnly into Britain's Canterbury Cathedral last Sunday for the closing ceremonies of their once-a-decade Lambeth Conference, they had dealt with topics from third world debt to interfaith dialogue, from armed insurrection to polygamy. The underlying question running through their three weeks of discussion, however, had been that of authority: Who, if anyone, can speak for the world's 70 million Anglicans?

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Columbus probably was not the first, but he was the first to come here and go home and hold a press conference.'' Malcolm Richardson of the National Endowment for the Humanities. [ 24:6. ]

title: Julia Muir to Wed J. D. Kenny Oct. 22
description: Julia Louise Muir, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Alexander Muir 2d of Larchmont, N.Y., and James Douglas Kenny, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis James Kenny, also of Larchmont, plan to marry Oct. 22.

title: Despite Slapstick And Wet-Sari Scenes, India's Film Industry Is Losing Some Steam
description: India's film industry pinned its hopes this year on a big-budget thriller in which the country's most popular matinee idol was trying for a comeback after an unsuccessful foray into politics.

title: THE REGION: Unity and Disunity; Brawley Case, Whatever Its Merits, Underscores Black Doubts on
description: FOR a brief time, it appeared that racially motivated violence in New York City would forge a common purpose among blacks who usually disagreed over personalities, politics and tactics. That budding unity - which had obvious implications for next year's municipal elections - has been torn apart by the case of Tawana Brawley. And, paradoxically, the deep-rooted suspicion with which blacks view the criminal justice system fostered both the coming together and the splitting apart of the coalition.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE ADVENTURES OF TELEMACHUS. By Louis Aragon. Translated by Renee Riese Hubert and Judd D. Hubert. (University of Nebraska, $18.95.) Published in 1922, Louis Aragon's novel ''The Adventures of Telemachus'' occupies a pivotal position in which Dadaism and Surrealism overlap. A subversive Dadaist impulse certainly figured in Aragon's choice of Francois Fenelon's 17th-century prose epic ''Aventures de Telemaque'' for a parodic model, since Fenelon's earnestly moralistic retelling of Homer and Virgil provided a target rich in literary reference and high-mindedness. The tale of the search by young Telemachus for his father, Ulysses, is traditionally read as a metaphor of self-discovery. In Aragon's interpretation, however, it is a comic case of self-dismantling, replete with surrealistic imagery. Advised by his cryptic guide Mentor and wooed by the sea nymphs Calypso and Eucharis, Telemachus tries to assemble a workable view of himself and the world. Instead, confusion reigns. Telemachus appears in one set piece after another. Deliberately stagy, each one celebrates and mocks the artifice with which it has been constructed. The actual story is scant and generally irrelevant to Aragon's declarations on language, fate and the void. Made against a jerry-built backdrop of ancient myth, these pronouncements sound laughable even when one detects the slyly placed kernel of seriousness hidden beneath the carnival trappings. In this inventive first translation into English, by Renee and Judd Hubert, Aragon's farce is a funhouse of double-think and mirror readings; the wise reader enters with disbelief well suspended and a taste for the game.

title: THE WORLD: Debate Today Has Echoes of the Past; U.S. in Central America: Years of Conflict and Suspicion
description: FOR a century and a half, United States Governments and citizens have argued about the country's role in Central America. How do they reconcile North American interests with Central American sovereignty? How deep and direct should United States involvement be? How much should Americans presume to direct these other lands in methods of governing themselves, even if the ostensible motive is to promote democracy?

title: WRITERS AND DICTATORS
description: JORGE BARROS TORREALBA, the publisher of Pehuen Editores, works in a pleasant ground-floor office with a small window that looks out over a front yard and a quiet street in an upper-middle-class neighborhood of Santiago. Among the capital's urban distinctions (terrible smog that mars the beautiful Andean setting, the general appearance of orderly well-being and the absence of a heavy uniformed police presence, which is striking for a tough military regime in power for 15 years) is the fact that hundreds of companies have set up headquarter offices in former mansions and more modest residences along the city's many tree-lined streets. Since the military coup of Sept. 11, 1973, 1 out of 10 Chileans has fled the country. so quite a few private homes have come on the market.

title: State Taking Action to Save its Lakes
description: LEAD: WITH so many Long Island Sound beaches closing, Connecticut residents may be wondering where to go when the weather gets hot. The state has a number of recreational lakes, large and small, that can serve as alternatives. And a $1 million state grant program that opens up this month is aimed at insuring the quality of

title: 7 Are Dead in Pakistan In Urban Ethnic Strife
description: Ethnic Pathan transportation workers set fire to buses of a rival group today, setting off widespread rioting throughout the city in which 7 people died and at least 12 were injured, hospital reports and witnesses said.

title: BY GYPSY WAGON, THROUGH THE JURA
description: The Jura, in the northwest corner of Switzerland, is all wide, rolling valleys, good-sized climbs and descents and primal surroundings of unending green in the summer and gaudy colors in the fall. The gypsy wagon, called the zigeunerwagen in German, is an old, accepted mode of transport in the Jura, which is horse country.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
description: Trouble between the county and its Probation Department mounted last week when lawyers for the former Probation Director, Marino J. Fanelli, filed a $2 million civil rights suit against the county in Federal District Court in White Plains.

title: THE NATION: 'Revolution' in Louisiana; Picaresque to Pragmatic
description: IT was late last spring, and Gov.

title: THE ANGEL FELL FOR WILLIE
description: LABRADOR By Kathryn Davis. 225 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: At Least 10 Reportedly Die In New Capsizing on Ganges
description: A boat capsized in the flooded Ganges River and at least 10 women died, it was reported Friday. The incident happened near where more than 400 people drowned in a ferry accident last week.

title: A Traveler's Finest Hour
description: EVERY tourist, it has been said, wants to be taken for a traveler, but the real achievement is to be mistaken for a native. To be looked on as a native, however fleetingly, is one of the most sublime pleasures travel can offer. It is a sign that often your worst fear - of standing out, appearing different -is unwarranted. It suggests that, having passed beyond the role of outside observer, you can, with your newly found cover, begin to participate in the life of the people.

title: YOUR CAN'T GET GOOD HELP AT HOME ANYMORE
description: Maybe baseball should blame the mothers of America. ''I don't know if mothers want to raise their sons to be catchers,'' said Joe McIlvaine, a Mets' vice president.

title: The Gates to Medical School Open Wider as Fewer Knock
description: Getting into medical school is much easier today than it was a decade ago, a result of a steep drop in applications. With a decline in the average grade of entering students, some schools are reducing class size to hold the line on admission standards.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Cambridge, Mass.; Waterfront Condominiums
description: AN $85 million waterfront condominium, with 21 apartments priced at more than $1 million, will open on the Charles River here next summer, capping the transformation of a onetime research and development district on this city's east side.

title: BREAKING OUT
description: AMONG THE STILL LIFES, NUDES AND wildly abstract paintings at a recent official art exhibit in Tallinn, capital of the Soviet Republic of Estonia, hung two portraits of Josef Stalin that, even a few years ago, might have earned their artists a one-way ticket to Siberia. But on a Saturday afternoon last May, they prompted little surprise from the viewers who flowed around me in the gallery. In one portrait, the dead dictator, wearing a grimy butcher's smock, slouched before a chart displaying selected cuts of meat.

title: A Vermonter's 'Tough' Help for the Sex Abuser
description: From her log home in this Champlain Valley town, Fay Honey Knopp, a 70-year-old Quaker minister, regularly corresponds with nearly four dozen prison inmates. Several are sex offenders.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Clayton, Mo.;
A Hotel Anchor For a 1958 Plan
description: LEAD: IN 1958, a master plan for Clayton, the seat of St. Louis County, suggested that a developer might want to buy up the homes in a 15-acre residential section just east of the city's downtown for a commercial development allowed under a special permit.

title: Audi's Drive
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: TO HELL WITH DYING By Alice Walker. Illustrated by Catherine Deeter. Unpaged. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $13.95. (All ages)

title: Question Of the Week; Should Sugar Ray Leonard Box Again?
description: At age 32, Sugar Ray Leonard still performs with all the spirit, vigor and gallantry of an Olympic athlete. In a sport full of human cash registers, whose sole incentive is money, Sugar Ray is a delightful aberration. When I watch him fight I feel privileged. ERIC H. MORRISON New York

title: Chile's Novel 'Venture Capitalist'
description: AUGUSTO GROB caught on to the idea at a public meeting near this commercial and agricultural center in Chile's southern lake region. At the meeting, a representative of Fundacion Chile - the Chile Foundation - offered to go into partnership with farmers and investors and provide the expertise to set up a berry farming and exporting business.

title: Readying 'Song of the Great Wall'
description: IN the intense heat of late July, a group of dancers rehearsed a work they had performed publicly many times. ''More tension! Everybody can do more. There has to be drama in it!'' exhorted the petite dancer-choreographer watching them.

title: Douglas Middleton Arthur Is Married To Janice L. Worth, Portfolio Manager
description: The marriage of Janice Lynn Worth, a portfolio manager at Oesterreichische Laenderbank in New York, to Douglas Middleton Arthur, a vice president in equity research at Kidder, Peabody & Company in New York, took place yesterday in West Park, N.Y. The Rev. Lloyd Duren, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the West Park Winery.

title: Pool Sales Booming in State
description: With beaches closing along the Shore because of medical and other waste, New Jerseyans have been turning to backyard pools for relief, creating a boom in sales of in-ground and above-ground models.

title:
DINING OUT;
Chinese Elegance in Woodbridge
description: LEAD: IT'S easy to miss Orchids in Woodbridge, tucked away as it is in a tiny shopping center that is neither highly visible nor easily accessible. It is worthwhile persevering because the attractive eight-month-old Chinese restaurant serves food that is above average.

title: The Superbabies: No Time for Childhood
description: A NEW movement in education, the push for ''superbabies,'' is growing stronger by the day. Advocates of starting children in school at the age of 4 are joined by two powerful allies, Senator Ted Kennedy and Governor Cuomo.

title: At Issue in Davis Trial: 2 Guns and Spent Slug
description: Two men, two guns and a piece of lead are at center stage as testimony in the trial of Larry Davis enters its fourth week tomorrow in the Bronx County Courthouse.

title: Antebellum Grandeur by the River
description: The River Road, which follows the Mississippi to New Orleans, evokes the elegance and prosperity of this part of Louisiana before the Civil War. The road was once lined with grand homes and working plantations, live oaks and magnolias. The plantations shipped their crops on the Mississippi, and the river traffic carried to the inhabitants news of European customs and fashions, which influenced the decoration of their homes.

title: Suddenly, Both Parties Are Speaking Spanish
description: FOR the first time in American history, both the Presidential and Vice Presidential candidates of a major party, the Democrats, are fluent in Spanish.

title: From Coast to Coast, Urban Rail Is Flourishing; Success in Portland
description: To the Editor:

title: Calm Is Reported in Burma, For Now
description: Rangoon was reportedly returning to normal today after the resignation Friday of the new Burmese leader, U Sein Lwin. Mr. Sein Lwin's resignation was forced by five days of protests in which hundreds of people were shot to death by soldiers.

title: The Rise and Fall of the Big Breakup Deals
description: JOHN K. CASTLE has grown up in the world of leveraged buyouts. He joined the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation in 1965 and a few years later made his mark at age 28 as head of the firm's Sprout Group, then one of the largest venture capital operations in the United States.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Sugar Ray Leonard Box Again?
description: The Sugar man is already a boxing legend. After an unbelievably successful career, the long layoff, and then coming back to take out another boxing great in Marvin Hagler, that should have been the climax of his career. I think Ray Leonard should not jeopardize his health to prove what we already know. LENNY APISCOPA Yonkers, N.Y.

title: One Dead and 19 Wounded in Cairo Protest
description: One person was killed and 19 wounded, including two policemen, when Egyptian security forces opened fire on Friday night to disperse Moslem fundamentalists calling for the imposition of Islamic laws, security officials said today.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE MASKS OF ROME. By Caroline Llewellyn. (Scribner, $16.95.) In Caroline Llewellyn's first novel, a feisty young art conservator working on a commission for a once great, now impoverished family realizes that their most prized painting is a forgery and finds herself involved in a web of intrigue, deceit and danger.

title:
FOCUS: ATLANTA;
An Apartment Glut in Atlanta Brings Lower Rents
description: LEAD: Spurred by strong growth in employment and favorable tax benefits, developers here went on a building binge over the last five years. They added more than 100,000 apartments, nearly one-third of the metropolitan area's total inventory.

title: At the Grocery, I Was the One Checked Out
description: ''PUT it back, lady.'' The gruff voice startled me so badly that I dropped the two tomatoes I had selected.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Auctions And Honors
description: LEAD: A stunning collection of United States gold coins will be sold at public auction Oct. 5 by Stack's of New York. It includes more than 250 coins, most in exceptional condition. The auction firm expects it to realize upwards of $5 million.

title: A Slight Edge Goes To Giants
description: While most of the Jets and Giants players agreed during the week that tonight's meeting between the teams was just another preseason game, the Giants' 24-21 victory produced a few key revelations for both teams.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We left a yellow rubber bath mat in the bottom of our tub for a couple of months. When we picked it up we found that it has left a yellow stain which we cannot seem to remove. We tried scouring powder, then tried rubbing with fine steel wool, but the latter left a gray stain, probably because of the tub's age (34 years). Is there any kind of rubber dissolving chemical I can try that might remove the stain without causing further wear of the thin enamel?

title: Learning to Master A Sheer Mountain Face
description: I was hanging from a spikelike piton midway up the Mirroire d'Argentine on the third day of the Alpine climbing course. The Mirroire, a 1,000-foot face of the Argentine Mountain near Solalex in the Swiss Alps, is as smooth as glass from a distance and crack-ridden up close.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: WORK AND PLAY. By Carlo Gebler. (St. Martin's, $12.95) This quirky and slight coming-of-age novel tells the story of Fergus Maguire, who is expelled from college after disappearing for a lost weekend of heroin snorting and carousing in London. He returns from this disgrace to the family home in Dublin, where his disappointed and disapproving father awaits. But after the elder Maguire dies in a swimming accident, the reading of his will reveals more anger than disappointment: Fergus's mother and sister are the only beneficiaries of the estate. The guilt-ridden young man returns to London, where he takes a job answering the mail at a television network. He gets involved with an old girlfriend, a new one and a crowd of unsympathetic friends who revive his former experiments with drugs. Of more interest, however, are Fergus's neighbors, an Indian family whose members are the victims of local terrorism that eventually leads to tragedy. In these few episodes Carlo Gebler shines, creating a portrait of London's class violence that stings with the evidence of a good writer at work. This fragment of storytelling suggests that Mr. Gebler, in his third novel, would have been better off concentrating on his own fictional vision rather than aping the recent crop of yuppie angst sagas.

title: About Cars; Honda Driver Rolling Along After 94,000 Miles
description: Dear Mr. Schuon, I read your column in 1984 on the Honda Prelude. I drove it, loved it and bought it. Everything you said was true. I have 94,000 miles of commuting on the odometer, get 34 miles to the gallon, and just got my first set of new tires at 92,000 miles. Jack Ader Levittown, L.I.

title: Stephanie Halliday Is Wed
description: At St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York, Stephanie Beth Halliday, a daughter of Gloria J. Mousa and David G. Halliday, both of New York, was married yesterday to Kevin Russell Kelly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Kelly of Sarasota, Fla. The Rev. Eugene J. Prior performed the ceremony. The bride, a graduate of Skidmore College, is a personnel manager at the Bank of New York. The bridegroom, the production manager at Continental Connector in Woodside, Queens, graduated from Villanova University.

title: The Pleasures of Just Watching a Son Grow
description: I AWAKEN to the sound of your voice issuing commands from the front yard. My dreams are interrupted and I refocus on you; I welcome the diversion. In my mind's eye I see your confident presence as you stand at a makeshift home plate, see your bat make contact as I hear the smack and see your slight but sturdy figure start to run. My mind and body are suffused with light as I let my feelings for you wash over me. You are an exquisite presence in my life, and I open myself to the experience of you.

title: When an Address Is Lost, Try a Map to Guide the Way
description: JUST how many ZIP codes can one remember? Or how many street addresses? Losing an address book can be disastrous.

title: Melee in Tompkins Sq. Park: Violence and Its Provocation
description: When the sun rose over Tompkins Square Park last Sunday after a long, hot, angry night, broken glass and bloodied brows bore witness to the most violent conflict between the police and a crowd in New York City in years.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: ANGEL FIRE. By Andrew M. Greeley. (Warner, $17.95.) When I was 13, I listened to a Christmas Eve sermon about the height of angels. It had nothing to do with faith or religion. It was just an unenlightened priest boring his congregation with the vital stats of angels. The memory of that sermon remained safely dormant until I read Andrew Greeley's 16th novel, ''Angel Fire.

title: Nancy R. Adelson To Wed Sept. 25
description: Dr. and Mrs. Edward Adelson of Potomac, Md., have announced that their daughter, Nancy Robin Adelson, and Lewis Richard Clayton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Clayton of New York, plan to marry Sept. 25.

title: Fighting Smoking, India to Ban Tobacco Ads
description: The Indian Government announced this week that it planned to ban advertising of cigarettes and other tobacco products as part of a campaign to reduce smoking after recent reports that 800,000 Indians are dying of tobacco-related diseases every year.

title: Repairing Mortar Joints
description: EVENTUALLY, almost all mortar joints in brick masonry deteriorate. Prompt repair is required, because even small cracks and crumbled areas admit moisture, which in time can cause major damage, especially in regions where freezing occurs.

title: Azinger Shoots Hole-in-One and Keeps Lead
description: Paul Azinger made a hole-in-one at the 202-yard fourth hole of Oak Tree Golf Club today with a 6-iron, then barely hung on to maintain his one-shot lead in the third round of the PGA Championship.

title: Verbatim; Both Sides
description: 'I don't think it would be permissible for the independent prosecutor to tell only half the story.' - James C. McKay, independent prosecutor, defending the conclusion in his report that Edwin Meese 3d was ''probably'' guilty of a crime, though no prosecution was warranted.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We left a yellow rubber bath mat in the bottom of our tub for a couple of months. When we picked it up we found that it has left a yellow stain which we cannot seem to remove. We tried scouring powder, then tried rubbing with fine steel wool, but the latter left a gray stain, probably because of the tub's age (34 years). Is there any kind of rubber dissolving chemical I can try that might remove the stain without causing further wear of the thin enamel?

title: U.S.-Greek Ties Look Unhappy but Unbreakable
description: WHEN Greeks and others debate the American military presence here, the talk turns generally on a blend of high drama and deep passion, political theater and diplomatic machismo. The negotiations currently under way on the future of the United States' four main bases and a string of lesser military installations have mixed in another ingredient: a cynical belief that, whatever public figures may say in public, in private the deal is as good as done.

title: Correction
description: The July 24 Personal Finance column misstated the yield for the Sierra Capital IV real estate investment trust. It was 5 percent, not 9.3 percent.

title: A LA CARTE
description: LEAD: A CHANGE of scene, one that transports the observer to another world, is reason enough to have lunch in the charming courtyard of the Hammond Museum in North Salem. Beyond a stately wrought-iron gate a fountain plays between formal rows of sycamore trees, their dappled trunks restating the sunlight glinting through the leaves.

title: Edward Bennett Williams, 68, Influential Trial Lawyer, Dies; A Brilliant 'Superlawyer'
description: Mr. Williams, considered a brilliant ''superlawyer'' who stood as a pillar of the Washington establishment, had no particular political power bloc of his own, but Republicans and Democrats sought his friendship and counsel, and he seemed always to be in good standing with the occupant of the White House Oval Office.

title: Some Wars Are Failing the Cost-Benefits Test
description: THE war between Iran and Iraq, one of the bloodiest conflicts of this murderous century, was sputtering last week to a stalemated conclusion.

title: at $6 an Hour, Bites are Free
description: LEAD: FIVE nights a week, as dusk settles over the Shore, Dana Dramis makes a 60-mile round-trip journey that takes her from Beesleys Point to Cape May. She frequently stops, but not to relish the serenity of a sunset over tranquil marshes or to revel in the whimsical charm of Victorian neighborhoods.

title: Thomas W. Philip, a Teacher, Is Wed To Lela Renee Schaus in Connecticut
description: Lela Renee Schaus, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Schaus of Farmington, Conn., and Delray Beach, Fla., and Thomas Winslow Philip, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Van Ness Philip of Bedford, N.Y., were married in Farmington yesterday. The Rev. James J. Conefrey performed the ceremony at St. Patrick Roman Catholic Church.

title: Reviews/Music; Capobianco's Staging Of Boito's 'Mefistofele'
description: Tito Capobianco's staging of Boito's ''Mefistofele'' counts as one of the New York City Opera's great triumphs and oldest active productions, dating back to 1969. Originally conceived as a vehicle for the late Norman Treigle, with his black, booming bass and spidery athleticism, it has survived handsomely with a notable succession of Mefistofeles, Fausts, Margheritas and Elenas. Friday night the opera returned to the repertory for the first time since 1986, but if truth be told, it has rarely been gone for more than a couple of seasons.

title: Reviews/Music; All-Schubert Program Is Played at Mostly Mozart
description: Making Schubert's chamber music understood in a space like Avery Fisher Hall is by necessity an inexact translation. Vienna 160 years ago had opened its houses to music. The age of the palace concert was over; that of the big concert hall was yet to begin. Mostly Mozart's program of Schubert on Friday night, in other words, was comprised of music meant for home and friends, not the nearly 3,000 well air-conditioned New Yorkers who showed up for this event.

title: Ancient Objects Get New Home
description: FOR years, the storage areas at Harvard's Peabody Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology were cluttered. ''Access to the collection was poor,'' recalls Una McDowell, the director of the museum's collections department. ''Things were cramped and difficult to get at.''

title: Long Branch Journal; City Wins Fight Against Bar Over Nude Dancing
description: THE last thing Vicki Stroby wanted in her city was a bar with nude dancing.

title: Primary Questions On Coverage Of the Conventions
description: The evolving nature of Presidential politics and the medium of television together have all but reduced party conventions to the level of the electoral college, which is to American politics what the vermiform appendix is to the human body. The trend has progressed to the point that the only question now is whether the national conventions will vanish entirely or be recognized for what they have largely become: unpaid advertising on as much prime-time television as can be grabbed off in the name of public service. But the long free ride is doomed.

title: Orientalisms Are Heard in Americans' MusicInfluence the Music of Americans Crystal.
description: ''East is East,and West is West/And never the twain shall meet'' was one of Kipling's less accurate predictions, at least where music is concerned. From Mozart's time to the present, superficial Orientalisms have lent local color to many a composition. In the 20th century, and especially since World War II, matters have advanced far beyond this harmless form of musical tourism. The very fabric of Western music has been affected by Oriental concepts, sometimes to the point of altering the accustomed nature of our musical experience beyond recognition.

title: New Rights Panel Member
description: President Reagan plans to appoint Sherwin T. Chan to fill the vacancy on the Civil Rights Commission left by the death in June of Clarence M. Pendleton, the White House said today. The President appointed William Barclay Allen, a professor of government at Harvey Mudd College in Claremont, Calif., to succeed Mr. Pendleton as chairman. Mr. Allen was already a member of the commission. Mr. Chan, 65 years old, is an engineering specialist with the Northrop Corporation.

title: P.L.O. Asks Jordan to Delay Passport Steps
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization has asked Jordan to freeze new passport measures that could leave Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied West Bank stateless, a P.L.O. official said today.

title: School Board to Vote on Condom Instruction
description: JUST how explicit should the new state-mandated AIDS curriculum be in teaching the use of condoms? The Three Village School District will address that issue Tuesday when the Board of Education meets to consider whether students at the Ward Melville High School in Setauket will be taught the ''Ten Recommendations for the Proper Use of Condoms.''

title: A. B. McCormick, Reporter, Marries Ardith C. Dentzer
description: The marriage of Ardith Campbell Dentzer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Dentzer Jr. of Larchmont, N.Y., to Andrew Borland McCormick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. McCormick Jr. of Lancaster, Pa., took place yesterday at the Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church in Larchmont. The Rev. Michael A. Drake performed the ceremony.

title: EXTENDING THE COMBAT ZONE
description: BEST LAID PLANS The Inside Story of America's War Against Terrorism. By David C. Martin and John Walcott. Illustrated. 392 pp. New York. Harper & Row. $22.50.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Empire of the Sun Starring Christian Bale, John Malkovich, Miranda Richardson, Joe Pantoliano, Rupert Frazer, Emily Richard, Leslie Phillips. Directed by Steven Spielberg. 1987. Warner Home Video.

title:
ART;
Beyond the Conventional
description: LEAD: THE current group exhibition at the Islip Art Museum, featuring seven artists, is a particularly satisfying show, not only because it introduces some work unfamiliar to regional audiences, but also because of its scope.

title: GENERATIONS OF TORMENT
description: I was pleasantly surprised by Peter Maas's article on Northern Ireland (''Generations of Torment,'' July 10). I applaud him for his honesty and dispassionate objectivity.

title: Mandela Reportedly Treated In Hospital for Lung Trouble
description: Nelson Mandela, the imprisoned leader of the outlawed African National Congress, has been hospitalized with a lung ailment, the South African Press Association said today.

title: New Studies Point to Fungus As Leading to AIDS Deaths
description: Clearing up a longstanding mystery, new genetic studies indicate that the microbe responsible for a kind of pneumonia that is a major killer of AIDS patients is a fungus.

title: BABY BOOMERS, SAD AND RESTLESS
description: LEAD: SAILING TO CORINTH By Irene Wanner. 235 pp. New York: Owl Creek Press/Kampmann & Company. $15.95.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
