title: Maine's Farm for Forgotten Animals
description: Marilyn Goodreau works from noon to midnight taking care of 9 horses, 6 ponies, 5 goats, 2 geese, a rabbit and a rooster on 200 acres of rolling farmland here in southern Maine.

title: GENERATIONS OF TORMENT
description: Peter Maas might have consulted the Provisional Irish Republican Army's own document ''Eire Nua'' to see that it is very much Marxist in nature, closer in political spirit to, say, Cuba or Nicaragua than to the present system of government that holds in the Irish Republic.

title: THE UNPREDICTABLE DAILINESS OF LIFE
description: BREAKING GENTLE By Beverly Lowry. 326 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title: Review/Dance; Ralph Lee's Mettawee River Troupe
description: The Central Park Summerstage festival got off to an uncharacteristically late start on Friday night at the Central Park Band Shell when a generator caught fire and delayed the show. But the show was worth the wait, for ''The Ringdove,'' a new piece by Ralph Lee and his Mettawee River Company, had all the charm and interest of a loose-structured bedtime story.

title: Otto Passman, 88, Louisiana Congressman Who Fought Spending
description: Otto E. Passman, an acid-tongued son of Louisiana sharecroppers who served in Congress for 30 years and pursued a relentless battle against spending for foreign aid, died yesterday at a hospital near his home in Monroe, La. He was 88 years old.

title: Qaddafi's Daughter
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Luminaries Let the Good Times Roll
description: What follows is a portrait of New Orleans from the collective palette - and palate - of those whose personal or professional histories give them more than a passing familiarity with the city. That the portrait has many features is not surprising, given the city's culture and history. While some of those who were asked for their favorite New Orleans attractions mentioned well-touristed places, a few gave more private spots. A quarterback for the New Orleans Saints cited a small sugar-box theater on Jackson Square, and a chef said he flees his hot kitchen by going to a jungle-like park at a bend in the Mississippi.

title: In Pakistan, Primacy of Islamic Law Means Reversal for Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Suns Sign No. 1 Pick
description: The Phoenix Suns have signed their first-round draft pick, Dan Majerle, to a five-year contract.

title: On Vcation, There Is No Escape From Home
description: SUMMER is proverbially vacation time, but running into someone you know can pop up at any time, wherever you go. And on a recent trip to St. Croix our adventure was marked by several such instances.

title:
TELEVISION;
All Aboard for a Magical Mystery Ride
description: LEAD: Dressed in a blue conductor's uniform and cap and standing before a brilliant green backdrop, Ringo Starr completes a scene, breaks into a chorus of ''There's No Business Like Show Business'' and dances a light soft-shoe across the set of ''Shining Time Station.'' The director, his own shoes covered in cloth booties to prevent dirtying the paper set, tries to match steps with the former Beatle.

title: Cynthia Reed Plans to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Ariane Wellin of Greenwich, Conn., and Adrian P. Reed of Centreville, Md., and Hobe Sound, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter Cynthia Elizabeth Reed to David Eliot Klein, the son of Mrs. David A. Klein of Stockbridge, Mass., and the late Mr. Klein. The couple plan to marry Nov. 19.

title: Cathryn Heine Wed
description: At Grace Episcopal Church in Madison, N.J., Cathryn Lou Heine, a daughter of Lowelle T. Heine of Newton, Ill., and David L. Heine of Longwood, Fla., was married yesterday to Mark Walker Kellstrom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arne Kellstrom of Singapore. The Rev. Robert W. Ihloff performed the ceremony. The bride is the Northeast region administrator at Equicor Inc., an employee benefits company in New York. The bridegroom is a research analyst at Paine Webber in New York.

description: TENNIS TOURNAMENT

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Evidence Aplenty That Walls Move
description: Not only have I read your article [ ''Stealing the Stone Walls of Westchester,'' June 12 ] with quite a bit of interest, but I believe that you might want to send a professional photographer to our village here in Hastings. On Broadway, just two or three blocks south of the intersection with the Farragut Parkway, the stone walls that border on the (Billie) Burke Estate has been showing bad evidence of the ravages taking place.

title: Fertile Ground for Roots of Success
description: Politicians here say it is no concidence that the mayors of the cities playing host to the national party conventions this year come from the same clubby neighborhood in New Orleans. This city's Seventh Ward seems to be something of a nurturing ground for prominent black politicians.

title: Yanks' Turnaround Is All for the Worse
description: The clubhouse scene was boisterous one night, quiet the next day. The sense of accomplishment the Yankees felt on Friday was suddenly gone in the late afternoon today, even though they are hanging in a division race that refuses to leave them behind.

title: More Records Fall as Swim Trials End
description: The United States Olympic swimming trials ended tonight with American records for Angel Myers and David Wharton and glory for Mary T. Meagher. They also ended with sadness for some fallen heroes of the past, notably Pablo Morales.

title: It's the Livelihoods of Shrimpers vs. the Lives of Turtles
description: FOR 23 seasons, Robin Sanders has endured heavy seas and hard times along the South Carolina coast, where he trawls the warm ocean shallows for shrimp.

title: Festivals To Interject Some Jazz
description: IT is hail-and-farewell time for both the Westchester Chamber and the Caramoor Festivals, and interestingly, the strictly classical fare at both is about to be tempered with a little jazz.

title: Review/Cabaret; British Music-Hall by Fascinating Aida
description: Adele Anderson, Dillie Keane and Denise Wharmby - the musical comedy trio who call themselves Fascinating Aida - represent a kind of wacky music-hall humor that seems very much a British home-grown style.

title: L.I. Sound Is Cleaner, but Bathers Remain Wary
description: All the beaches in this town on Long Island Sound have been open all summer, and the local health department says that the water is cleaner than it has been for years. But beachgoers are wary.

title: Sports of The Times; Why Backman's Better
description: If baseball were really this simple, half the athletes in North America would be waiting by the telephone for the mysterious Joe to call them, the way he called Gary Carter the other day.

title: Stravinsky Duo
description: OEDIPUS REX With Alan Howard, Neil Rosenshein, Felicity Palmer, Claudio Desderi; Amsterdam Concertgebouw Orchestra and NOS TV Men's Choir, Bernard Haitink, conductor. Produced by Harry Wich. Directed by Hans Hulscher. 1984. THE FLOOD With Pauline Daniels, Rudi van Vlaanderen, Kitty Courbois, with the voices of Sebastian Cabot, Elsa Lancaster, Paul Tripp and Laurence Harvey; Columbia Symphony, Robert Craft, conductor. Directed by Jaap Drupsteen. 1985. Stereo hi-fi Home Vision 90 minutes. $49.95.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Nyack
description: ''NYACK is a place that's growing up and coming out of adolescence,'' said Bunny Crumpacker, the author of The Guide to the Nyacks.

title: Holocaust Diary: A Child's Victory
description: THE comparison to Anne Frank is obvious.

title: 'The Predators' Ball'
description: To the Editor:

title: Fancy Feet
description: With the footwear industry reinstating the plain, classic pump, accessory designers are competing for a foothold in the shoe-ornament trade. Design Circle Ltd. of Dix Hills, N.Y., for example, carries 150 handmade styles in silk, lace and suede. The clips, which cost $15 to $30 a pair, are sold at shoe, jewelry and bridal boutiques, some pharmacies and even antique stores. Matching barrettes, lapel pins and earrings are also available.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: FAMILIAR STRANGERS: Gypsy Life in America. By Marlene Sway. (University of Illinois, $19.95.) Some 1,100 years ago, an Indian ruler sent a troupe of 12,000 minstrels as a gift to a Persian prince. When these people, the ancestors of today's gypsies, refused to farm, they were expelled to roam the earth, living on the edges of society as peddlers, blacksmiths, entertainers and magicians, offending Christian communities in Europe by their peculiar ways.

title: LAW ASSOCIATES FIND GOOD TIMES MUST END
description: A popular joke going around New York City law firms this summer tells of an old man who is accidentally sent to hell, only to be surprised by its splendor and tranquility.

title: Black Musicians in Art: Stereotypes and Beyond
description: ''The Portrayal of the Black Musician in American Art'' can make a difference. It is fresh. Its concern is the way the black musician has been represented in American art. What the show is really about is the response to black Americans during the last 200 years.

title: Depressive-Illness Stigma Insults Millions
description: To the Editor:

title: WITH GUNS SILENT, CAUTIOUS HOPE GROWS IN NAMIBIA
description: The longing for peace and liberation after seven decades of South African rule - 17 years of it illegal in terms of international law - is shared by the overwhelming majority of the 1.2 million people of this sparsely populated mineral-producing territory.

title: Jerome Kidder, Judge, 79
description: Jerome Kidder, a retired judge of the New York City Criminal Court, died Thursday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 79 years old and lived in Scarsdale.

title: Thomas F. Tully Wed To Susan E. Hentschel
description: Susan Elliott Hentschel, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Elliott Hentschel of Ogdensburg, N.Y., was married yesterday to Thomas Francis Tully, the son of Hannah Moynihan Tully of Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Thomas F. Tully. The Rev. John Yonkovig performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Cathedral in Ogdensburg.

title: Robinson Is Disappointing
description: For more than half the game Friday night, David Robinson was anchored at the Olympic bench as college forwards like Danny Manning and a high school all-America, Alonzo Mourning, filled in at center. A dominating big man would alleviate many of the concerns that John Thompson has about the United States basketball team he will take to Seoul, South Korea, for the Summer Games next month, but thus far, Robinson's disappointing play has raised questions, not provided answers.

title: Q and A; By SHAWN G. KENNEDY
description: Sizing Up a Neighbor

title: A Neurotic House Party
description: SEPTEMBER Starring Mia Farrow (in photo), Denholm Elliott, Dianne Wiest (in photo), Elaine Stritch, Sam Waterston, Jack Warden. Directed by Woody Allen. 1987. Orion Home Video. 82 minutes. $89.98. Rated PG. Some mildly vulgar language.

title: GENERATIONS OF TORMENT
description: Coverage by the press of events in Northern Ireland has produced an unintended, and unwelcome, consequence for British authorities - the awakening of conscience among Americans of Irish descent. Non-jury trials, detention without cause, mistreatment of prisoners, official cover-ups and sanctioning of police and military brutality are but some of the more recent examples of an atavistic Whitehall meanness toward the Irish people that are provoking anger among normally passive Irish-Americans. JAMES C. REILLY South Salem, N.Y.

title: No Headline
description: LEAD: IT is always reassuring, upon entering a Chinese restaurant, to see round tables filled with whole Chinese families, from grandfather to toddler, dipping their chopsticks with relish into steaming platters. This informal stamp of authenticity may not insure excellence, but it usually means that the restaurant offers several genuine dishes and that the price is right.

title: Labor Shortage Challenges Employers
description: A LABOR shortage is restricting New Jersey's otherwise vigorous economy, driving up wages and forcing employers to devise incentives to keep workers happy and lure new ones into the workplace.

title: M. G. Boyse Wed To Eleanore Kuhn
description: Eleanore Hopkins Kuhn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Kuhn of Salisbury, Conn., was a married there yesterday to Matthew Gordon Boyse, a son of Mrs. W. E. Boyse of Grosse Pointe, Mich. and the late Mr. Boyse. The Rev. Charles Bevan performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: Dukakis Defends Bush Over Record in War
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, questioned about a World War II gunner's challenge to Vice President Bush's account of being shot down over the Pacific, said, ''I don't think that kind of thing has any place in the campaign.''

title: A Narrow Escape From Poetry
description: WE all have our demons, our fears of the decline and fall of culture. Mine sometimes takes the form of regretting that we don't read much poetry anymore. Where will our flair come from, I sometimes wonder, our hyperbole, our mots justes? Unless we read poetry, we'll never have our hearts broken by language, which is an indispensable preliminary to a civilized life.

title: How Murdoch Makes It Work
description: RUPERT MURDOCH has not lost his ability to astound. Mr. Murdoch, who has gobbled up publishing and entertainment properties in remarkably large bites, announced his biggest deal yet last week: an agreement to buy Triangle Publications, publisher of TV Guide, from Walter H. Annenberg for $3 billion.

title: From Coast to Coast, Urban Rail Is Flourishing
description: To the Editor:

title: Needed: A New Pollution Industry
description: ''Beach Waste Raises New Fears'' [ July 17 ] makes me feel an even stronger urgency about this problem. Ocean dumping of all refuse must end. Land dumping of all refuse must end.

title: Federal Funds That Give a Helping Hand
description: Congress is considering an amendment to the Small Business Administration Act that would allow private organizations to receive financial assistance for projects to benefit small businesses owned and controlled by women. Enactment of this legislation would be a victory for groups that provide training programs for women entrepreneurs, among them the American Women's Economic Development Corporation. Beatrice A. Fitzpatrick, president and chief executive of the organization, has been lobbying for the legislation for eight years.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Home on Montauk Range If Gardner (Rusty) Leaver has his way, Western movies may soon be a misnomer. One look at the Montauk-based Mr. Leaver, resplendent in cowboy hat and ankle-length ''duster'' coat, sitting astride his cutting horse, Slingshot Cody, and ''Easterns'' may seem more appropriate for cowboy films.

title:
IDEAS AND TRENDS;
In Yellowstone, Determination to Leave the Flames Alone
description: LEAD: A PHILOSOPHY of allowing nature to make the rules with minimal interference from humans, is being tested here in Wyoming at Yellowstone, the largest national park in the country.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We left a yellow rubber bath mat in the bottom of our tub for a couple of months. When we picked it up we found that it has left a yellow stain which we cannot seem to remove. We tried scouring powder, then tried rubbing with fine steel wool, but the latter left a gray stain, probably because of the tub's age (34 years). Is there any kind of rubber dissolving chemical I can try that might remove the stain without causing further wear of the thin enamel?

title: Depressive-Illness Stigma Insults Millions; The Real Story
description: To the Editor:

title: We Must Find a Cure For Diseased Waters
description: THE scene is about the same wherever you go along the shoreline on Long Island - driftwood, healthy seaweed and roaming sea birds have become the exception. In their place in recent years is a sorrowfully changed environment.

title: Odds Not so Great
description: How important to a team's success is one man in hockey, a sport in which a player rarely spends two minutes on the ice per shift? In the case of Wayne Gretzky, mighty important.

title: Young vs. MTV: A Case of Modest Revenge
description: Neil Young has a simple reason for not joining some fellow rock stars in singing for commercials: ''I don't sing for nobody/ Makes me look like a joke,'' he declares in ''This Note's for You.'' He didn't suggest that making commercials ruins songs and betrays fans, or insist that advertising should leave rock alone, or snarl at the commercial tie-ins that infest most American cultural events. He didn't even hint that sponsorship equals control.

title: Mary Claiborne to Wed David Frediani
description: Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Augustine Claiborne Jr. of Richmond have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Taylor Claiborne, to David Raymond Frediani, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond R. Frediani of Roseville, Calif. The couple plan to marry Oct. 15.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MARKETS: Who Plays . . . Who Risks . . . Who Gains . . . Who Loses . . . By Martin Mayer. (Norton, $18.95.) The tremors that shook world financial markets last October have been closely scrutinized, yet thus far the reams of reports have done little to reassure anxious investors. Nor have they so altered the rules of the game that professionals on Wall Street would be willing to wager against the possibility of another blowout. Martin Mayer, the highly regarded financial writer, shares that concern and in the course of ''Markets'' tells us why. His new book, Mr. Mayer says, is ''about prices and where they come from.'' The reader is swept around the world, from the New Bedford, Mass., fish market to the New York Stock Exchange to Japan. Sprinkled throughout are sketches of a rich assortment of people, mostly men, who, in the author's words, ''thrive financially and psychologically on volatility, levels of unpredictability that disturb and frighten the average sensual man.'' Not surprisingly, the changes Mr. Mayer prescribes go far beyond those suggested to date. Computer-driven trading, for example, was played down as a cause of the crash by a Presidential task force. The author is not so sure; he believes a Federal ''transfer tax'' ought to be paid by all sellers of stock to curb its use. Even if the advice is not heeded, ''Markets'' tells an important story of how financial markets, protected by more than 40 years of relative peace, can evolve and subsequently construct their own global war games.

title: BAD DAYS AT 'BIG DRY'
description: I TURNED THE HORSES OUT again tonight.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: THE mouth of the river is wide. But the river narrows, and it's a wise captain who stays in the main channel. East Point Light's red tin roof rises above the marsh, just where its name implies. As you look west, tidal marsh runs thick and green clear to the distant trees.

title: Drug Reprieve
description: Between 6 and 10 track and field athletes who failed drug tests at the United States Olympic Trials in Indianapolis last month will not be barred from competing in the Summer Games because the drug use was either ''pre-declared'' or ''inadvertent,'' according to Mike Moran, a United States Olympic Committee spokesman. Moran's comments were reported yesterday in The Los Angeles Times.

title: The A,BC's of Assisting New Parents
description: IT'S a boy! Excitement, relief, pride, love, and the wonder of grandparenthood flooded me. Right behind them swelled a maternal wish to make everything perfect; erase discomfort, eliminate fatigue, brush away tears and guarantee the return of a trim figure. I didn't want to steal the joy, just banish the pain and inconveniences.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Yellowstone Visitors Face Road Closings

title: Kasparov's Style: Turning a Defense Into an Attack
description: THE world champion, Gary Kasparov, and his four-time opponent for the title, Anatoly Karpov, are poles apart on the question of defense: Whereas Karpov believes it is just something to get through without losing, Kasparov believes it presents another opportunity to win.

title: Carolyn Proga Is Wed In Ohio to Graham Vest
description: Carolyn Proga, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norbert J. Proga of Eastlake, Ohio, was married there yesterday to George Graham Vest Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vest of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Louis Pizmoht performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Justin Martyr. He was assisted by the Rev. Douglas Lovejoy-Carter, a United Church of Christ minister.

title: Ms. Swibold Wed To Jordan Becker
description: The marriage of Katharine Margaret Swibold, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Swibold of North Canton, Conn., to Jordan David Becker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Becker of New City, N.Y., took place last night in Simsbury, Conn. Rabbi Abraham Weisman performed the ceremony in the chapel at the Ethel Walker School, of which the bride is a graduate.

title: Fun and Games In 'Verona'
description: THOSE sounds you're hearing at the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival during performances of ''The Two Gentlemen of Verona'' are of laughter, a sign of life.

title: Fast Company
description: The woman who placed first two years ago in the final standing of the Mobil Grand Prix, Yordanka Donkova of Bulgaria, moved into a three-way tie for first place after winning the 100-meter hurdles in 12.45 seconds at the Budapest Grand Prix Friday evening. She is tied with Grace Jackson, a sprinter from Jamaica, and Petra Felke, an East German javelin thrower, both of whom did not compete in Budapest.

title: Finding Profits in Day Care and Kettle Drums
description: Fifteen years ago, the National Association for Female Executives was started to help women learn such business skills as writing resumes, asking for raises and surviving office politics. Its members are mostly white-collar workers who earn $32,000 on average. Now, the group has decided to bet its own money on its members and has set up a venture capital program for entrepreneurial women.

title: 40 Years Later, Long Lives the Babe
description: Tuesday marks the 40th anniversary of Babe Ruth's death. Larger than life, larger than death, larger with every passing year, he is the sports hero of our century.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: BIOLOGICAL FLUTES

title: Outdoors; To Sharpen Skill, Practice on Skeet
description: While fishing this spring with a young Maine guide, the conversation turned to fall grouse hunting and shotgun shooting in general. The guide said he did not shoot skeet, trap or any of the shotgun games because, ''I can't seem to hit clay targets, but I do very well on live birds.''

title: Sports of The Times; Denny McLain, a Fallen Star, Tries Again
description: The thought arose that Dennis Dale McLain was either the dumbest person in the world, the most naive person in the world, the craziest person in the world, the biggest jerk in the world, or the most hardheaded person in the world.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: PARTNERS. By John Martel. (Bantam, $18.95.) There's a joke going around that lawyers are now being used in place of rats in laboratory experiments. First, because there's an overabundance of them and, second, because there are some things rats just won't do. If we are to believe John Martel, the trial lawyer who is the author of this first novel, it's no joke. Stafford, Parrish & MacAllister is a snooty San Francisco law firm that has traditionally specialized in unexciting but lucrative fields. But the firm, led by Austin Barrington, is experiencing financial difficulties. Barrington has two choices: cut costs by lopping off several associates or risk everything by taking on a controversial case representing a town whose citizens have been poisoned by toxic waste. By choosing the latter, it would seem that Barrington is on the side of the angels. But, because of a laboratory error, he feels compelled to turn to nefarious deeds to save his case. Along for the ride are a brilliant young trial attorney, a stunning model turned lawyer and a homicide detective who's investigating several murders tied to the case. Unfortunately, Mr. Martel, who knows the ins and outs of preparing a court case and shows promise as a prose stylist, gives us stereotypical characters and then places them in overly familiar situations. This might not be fatal if ''Partners'' didn't get bogged down in the decidedly uninteresting private lives of its characters, thus deteriorating into little more than soap opera.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-23

title: DATABANK: August 14, 1988
Cordelia F. Biddle Wed to H. S. Zettler
description: Cordelia Frances Biddle, a freelance writer, and H. Stephen Zettler, an actor, were married yesterday in Fishers Island Sound off Connecticut aboard the M.V. Munnatawket, a ferryboat. William F. Henderson 3d, the purser and a Justice of the Peace in Waterford, Conn., performed the ceremony.

title: Zilch From ZIP
description: To the Editor:

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE END OF IDEOLOGY: On the Exhaustion of Political Ideas in the Fifties, by Daniel Bell. (Harvard University, $10.95.) In a new afterword, the sociologist Daniel Bell looks back on the decades since this collection of essays was published, finding still more signs of the dangers that come when ideas enslave minds. ''Daniel Bell brings particularly useful qualities to the study of sociology,'' Arthur Schlesinger Jr. said here in 1960. ''The fusion of journalistic skill and sociological knowledge . . . makes him one of the most rewarding commentators on American society.''

title: EX-REBEL CHIEF IN INDIA SEEKS IMMIGRANTS' OUSTER
description: The leader of an eight-year-old insurgency in the northeastern state of Tripura who signed a peace accord with the Indian Government on Friday said today that he would press for the deportation of tens of thousands of illegal immigrants from Bangladesh.

title: From Coast to Coast, Urban Rail Is Flourishing; Update Our Thinking
description: To the Editor:

title: Towns Seek to Curb Boat Wastes
description: LEAD: AS the East End continues to grow, so does the concern over the effects of boating on the environment.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Back to School, but What About a Bed?
description: LEAD: FOR many college students arriving at Long Island campuses later this month, the outlook for dormitory housing is mixed. In some cases, they will find that they will have to triple up in rooms.

title: Pamela Wilmot Weds Steven Clinkenbeard
description: Pamela Hall Wilmot and Steven Edward Clinkenbeard were married yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Ridgefield, Conn., by the Rev. Dr. William Grant Nigh.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; The Battle to Build Along the Shoreline
description: IN 1980, Jeffrey H. Shapiro, owner of the Cedar Island Marina in Clinton, paid $300,000 for 90 acres of intertidal flats adjacent to his eight-acre, 400-slip facility just in case he wanted to expand. Recently, he applied for permission to add 396 slips on 22 acres. After 16 days of hearings before the Coastal Management Division of the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection, and an outlay of $250,000 for legal fees and environmental studies, he said the panel recommended the application be denied.

title: STREETSCAPES: The Manhattan Apartment HouseAn 1880 Yorkville Survivor Destined for Demolition
description: BUILT in 1880 by the Rhinelander family, the six-story, 31-unit Manhattan, at the southwest corner of 86th Street and Second Avenue, is apparently the oldest large apartment house in New York City. But because it occupies a prime piece of what he calls ''one of the best plots in Yorkville,'' the owners' attorney, Martin Gold, expects it to be replaced by a modern structure in the next few years.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SHIPS AFIRE. By J. J. Armas Marcelo. Translated by Sarah Arvio. (Avon, Paper, $7.95.) To its conquerors, South America may have seemed a promised land, chockablock with cities of gold and fountains of youth, but to the bedraggled losers who first settled Salbago, the mythical island setting of this lush, lusty novel, paradise is more like a toxic-waste site. Nestled into metaphorical latitudes between the Old World and the New, the place soon becomes ''an enemy and a curse,'' a seedy way station teetering unsteadily between past and future. Worse yet, there is no escaping this fetid dump. In ''Ships Afire,'' the Spanish novelist J. J. Armas Marcelo has given us a wild world of baroque corruption and illusion, a place of devious sexuality and high irony where the history of imperial Spain has been deftly turned on its head. From a secret brothel of sea cows to a perpetually run-down cathedral that began crumbling even as it was being built, this surreal universe is filled with odd truths and odder inhabitants. Although the author is a native of the Canary Islands, his structure, style and skewed sensibility all recall Latin American fiction of the early ''boom'' period when novelists routinely performed magic tricks with time, history and language, enhancing reality by the fantasies they wove. But despite such reverberations, in this frisky translation by Sarah Arvio, Mr. Armas Marcelo shows himself to be an original, a unique voice that deserves to be heard from again.

title: Financing of Judo Is Defended by Y
description: I am writing about James Feron's article on the State Senate campaign between Senator Nicholas A.Spano and County Legislator Paul J. Feiner [ ''Feiner Begins His Challenge for Spano's State Senate Seat,'' July 17 ] .

title: IDEAS AND TRENDS: Powell's Plea; Courts Are Desperate, Too, as Death Rows Bring Forth Appeals
description: FOR the state and Federal judges who must deal with it, the death penalty has become a procedural nightmare, characterized by seemingly endless delay, confusion and a shortage of volunteer defense lawyers who have experience in the complexities of capital cases.

title: Noriega Says U.S. Uses 'Lies' Against Panama
description: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, observing his fifth anniversary as Panama's military leader, accused the Reagan Administration last night of creating a false crisis in Panama in an attempt to oust him.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: BROR BLIXEN: The Africa Letters. Edited and translated by G. F. V. Kleen. (St. Martin's, $18.95.) Here are the letters of a man whose greatest claim to fame may well be that he gave his wife, Isak Dinesen, syphilis and was reputed to be the lover of the aviator Beryl Markham. And yet his wife, whose married name was Karen Blixen, is absent from these pages.

title: Practice on Nutrition Falls Short of Preaching
description: Despite greater awareness of exercise and more healthy foods, many Americans remain ''significantly overweight,'' according to Federal researchers.

title: Stop Construction Until Power Available
description: In the article ''Managing Electric Use: A Strain After Shoreham'' [ July 31 ] , a Lilco spokesman is quoted as saying that the company is operating its plants at up to 99 percent of their total capacity during peak periods. It is clear that the power supply for current customers is in a precarious state. Yet the building of homes and big commercial structures continues.

title: The President's Night in the Sun
description: What started as morning in America reaches a climax tomorrow night in New Orleans. Ronald Reagan's address to the Republican National Convention will be more than a final appearance before the faithful. It will also be a trouper's dream, a chance to celebrate the accomplishments of eight years and confer what he can of that legacy on Vice President Bush.

title: Tense Talk
description: AFTER LOSING TO Jimmy Connors in the quarterfinals of last year's Wimbledon tournament, Slobodan Zivojinovic had this to say to a reporter: ''If I'm in the crowd, I'd be on Jimmy's side.''

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Concord, N.H.;
Fence Straddler Under Way
description: LEAD: A HOME-DEVELOPMENT project is under way in this state capital on 29 acres once owned by Hugh Gallen, the state's late Democratic Governor.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q & A: LOUISE BATES AMES;
'A Single Parent Has to Be Different'
description: LEAD: LOUISE BATES AMES, the associate director of the Gesell Institute of Human Development, says children today are no different than children in the past. It is the parents who have changed; they worry too much.

title: Where a Mini Look Is Always in Style
description: FOR the latest in munchkin summer fashion, it's all happening at the zoo. That's the newly renovated and resplendent Central Park Zoo, of course, where the sights include polar bears performing their famous synchronized aquatic routine, at left, and members of the cotton-candy set all spiffed up in their warm-weather dudlets.

title: Israeli Troops Kill Palestinian in Gaza Strip
description: Israeli soldiers shot dead a 52-year-old Palestinian in the occupied Gaza Strip today when a patrol opened fire on Arab demonstrators, the army said. The dead man, Mohammed Rezek, was the third Arab killed by troops this week.

title: Voters Reject Gambling
description: A referendum today showed continued strong opposition to return gambling to this island where casinos once flourished. Supporters had hoped that a favorable vote would persuade the Texas Legislature to pass legislation enabling legalized gambling. Unofficial returns from all 14 precincts showed 7,368 votes, or 59.3 percent, against legalized casino gambling to 5,962 votes in favor. The nonbinding referendum was called after a pro-gambling group gathered enough petition signatures. Proponents lost similar referendums in 1984 and 1987.

title: Blasphemy or Artistry?
description: Christians may disagree with some aspects of Martin Scorsese's challenging new film, ''The Last Temptation of Christ,'' but if they understand their own tradition they will not argue with his presentation of Jesus as attracted to marriage. They will argue rather that such an attraction is not a temptation at all.

title: Miss Penick Weds in R.I.
description: Joan Dabney Penick, a daughter of Mrs. J. Dabney Penick of Upper Montclair, N.J., and Watch Hill, R.I., and the late Mr. Penick, was married yesterday to Peter Somers Cooper, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Newbold Cooper of Warwick, Bermuda. The Rev. Seymour St. John performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Watch Hill Chapel.

title: Headliners; Big Debt
description: It appears that Robert E. Chambers Jr. will spend the rest of his life literally paying for his crime against Jennifer Levin. Mr. Chambers, who pleaded guilty to manslaughter in the strangling death of Miss Levin in Central Park two years ago, informed the court last week that he would not contest a $25 million civil damage suit filed against him by Miss Levin's parents. ''I do not wish the Levins to endure any more pain,'' he said in a note to the judge. His lawyer, Brian O'Dwyer, said he strongly warned Mr. Chambers that a refusal to mount a defense could result in the seizure of any assets he ever owns and the seizure of a portion of any income he might earn after he serves his 5- to 15-year prison sentence. ''I painted as bleak a picture as possible,'' said Mr. O'Dwyer.

title: Bayreuth Remains The Standard
description: A visitor to this summer's Bayreuth Festival, the Wagnerian shrine inaugurated in 1876 by the composer himself and located in this eminently pleasant northern Bavarian town, would have been hard pressed to detect signs of endemic ill health.

title: THE REPUBLICANS OF NEW ORLEANS: The New York Times Delegate Survey; Convention Delegates and the Public on the Issues
Beach Woes May Be Less Than Feared
description: THOUGH medical waste washing up on Connecticut beaches has prompted calls for stiff penalties for ocean dumping and raised fears of infection, some of the reaction has gone too far, environmental and health officials say.

title: A Kitty Wells Legacy - 95 Tunes, All Heartbreakers
description: When Kitty Wells, country music's first woman superstar, started her career in the mid-40's, American culture was changing. Because of the war, families who had stayed near home for generations experienced life beyond their farms. Blacks and women were allowed into workplaces they'd never been before. There was more money around. And after the war, people wanted to have a good time. The music industry, sensing this, was more than willing to supply what was needed, and new musical forms and off-shoots of older styles were everywhere.

title: Sending a Telex From Your Desk
description: The international advertising agency prides itself on being hip. Everything is stylish, modern and fast-paced; the executives spend 12 hours a day at their sleek desks, and everyone in the office has a powerful personal computer. Some have consoles on their desks that include a multiline telephone, a facsimile machine and a personal copier.

title: Extending FM's Reach
description: The pot of gold, as we know, is at the rainbow's end, and the trick is to reach it. That's the situation in which many FM listeners find themselves, trying to reach stations at the far end of the sky. Lately, they have been getting lots of help from FM tuners specifically designed for the growing segment of the population living far away from the urban centers where most FM stations are located.

title: The Hemlocks Are in Trouble
description: DEEPLY soak conifers, flowering and fruit trees, shrubs and other ornamentals; use a canvas soil soaker or attach a metal or plastic bubbler to the end of a garden hose; recycle water to fill watering cans and use it to soak annuals growing in containers on the patio or in window boxes. Finish garden plans and mail orders for fall-flowering bulbs. More on Adelgids

title: Miss Stager Wed To D. V. Maynard
description: At St. Peter's Lutheran Church in Chester Springs, Pa., Lauren Marla Stager, a daughter of Frederick G. Stager Jr. of West Chester Pa., and Sylvia T. Stafford of Upper Darby, Pa., was married yesterday to Daniel Varick Maynard, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin P. Maynard 3d of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and Prouts Neck, Me. The Rev. Fritz Ruccius performed the ceremony.

title: TOBACCO AND TRADE POLICY
description: The fundamental flaw in your article ''Pushing Cigarettes Overseas'' (July 10) is Peter Schmeisser's inability to distinguish between health policy and trade policy. Our trade policy is simple and straightforward. We want the same market access and treatment for United States tobacco products that is afforded to the tobacco companies of the country in question. If a country wishes to restrict for health reasons the sale or use of tobacco products, we will not object, so long as the restrictions apply equally to domestic and imported products.

title: TOBACCO AND TRADE POLICY
description: We appreciate Peter Schmeisser's article. The fact that so-called responsible leaders both in government and industry can ''push'' cigarettes when they know that smoking is ''as addictive as heroin'' and that it significantly increases the risk of illness and death suggests a serious flaw in the character of those leaders.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: THE TRADE BIND;
Now It's Harder to Fix a Recession
description: LEAD: Over the past two months, the dollar has reversed course, gaining about 5 percent against the Japanese yen and 9 percent against the German mark. It is not hard to identify the cause: the greater-than-anticipated improvement in the trade balance. But it is more difficult to see why the trade figures took currency traders by surprise.

title: Armenian Calls Dispute Political, Not Ethnic
description: A leading Armenian dissident who was recently expelled from the Soviet Union accused Soviet leaders on Friday of deliberately inflaming ethnic tensions to halt the growth of democracy in Armenia.

title: Aquino's Vice President Urges Her to Step Down
description: Vice President Salvador H. Laurel accused the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino of corruption and incompetence today and urged her to resign and call new elections.

title: Further Tribulations of the Chicken From Kiev
description: Chicken is to Kiev what baked beans are to Boston. Having survived a revolution, several purges and now perestroika, chicken Kiev is still the best-known dish in the capital city of the Ukraine. Ask any Intourist guide.

title: THE WORLD: Aid to the Contras; Same Debate, Another Vote
description: THE familiar arguments over United States policy on Central America echoed on Capitol Hill last week as the Senate took its 23d vote in the last five years on assistance for the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: C. B. Boocock Jr. Wed To Elizabeth Sanford
description: Elizabeth Beatty Sanford, a daughter of Mrs. Kenneth B. Beatty of Upper Montclair, N.J., and Machipongo, Va., and the late Mr. Beatty, was married yesterday to Cornelius Brett Boocock Jr., the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Boocock of Mantoloking, N.J. The Rev. Edward S. Prevost performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. Simon by-the-Sea in Mantoloking.

title: Revising Guatemalan History
description: To the Editor:

title: In Heart of Seoul, an Unwanted U.S. Presence
description: In the center of this crowded city lies a green expanse of rolling hills, complete with split-level homes, baseball diamond and 18-hole golf course. It is Yongsan, the United States military base that for many South Koreans has become a nagging symbol of the dominant American presence here.

title: Farmers' Markets Aid Needy Families
description: IN recent years Connecticut's farmers' markets have helped farmers stay in business and shoppers find the freshest produce. This year some of the markets, including a new one in Bridgeport, are also helping low-income families to eat a little better.

title: Paula McDonald Marries
description: Paula Wray McDonald and Bruce Clark Brubaker, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Clark Brubaker of Des Moines, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Donn H. McDonald of Des Moines, by Eric J. Palmer, the Magistrate of Mahaska County in Iowa. The bride, who will keep her name, is the manager of Frame Central, a Boston art framing concern. Mr. McDonald is a pianist and a doctoral candidate at the Juilliard School.

title: Auto Inurance: A Better Way
description: NEW JERSEY automobile owners, jolted last January by a $66 surcharge from the state's pool for uninsurable drivers, now face premium rate increases of over 13 percent, and a new surcharge of $73 for the pool, known as the Joint Underwriting Association (J.U.A.). Combined with the $70 you already pay to fund the J.U.A., those insured by a private insurance company will soon be paying, in effect, a $209 ''insurance tax'' to a state agency that doesn't even insure you - over and above your own insurance premium.

title: Gerald H. Peters Wed To Diane E. McFerrin
description: The wedding of Diane Elizabeth McFerrin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph McFerrin of Kansas City, Mo., to Gerald Harlan Peters, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Peters of Plandome, L.I., and Boynton Beach, Fla., took place yesterday at the George Hamilton Combs Chapel in Kansas City. The Rev. James Taranto, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Bruce Diamond performed the ceremony.

title:
GARDENING;
Herbs Suit a Formal Garden by the Sea
description: LEAD: MY formal herb garden grows in a seaside meadow, cloistered by Nantucket's scrubby vegetation. It is geometrically precise, yet utterly romantic; incongruous, but logical. It is an evocative 16th-century design that appeared by chance, a folly to satisfy my need for poetry and order in gardening.

title: Aging Tend: Drawbacks
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH Long Island usually scores high on listings of desirable places to live, most recently placing fourth in a Money magazine poll, Lloyd Bishop, a professor of education at New York University who has studied school enrollment on Long Island, sees a downside to the population trends.

title: That Was the Mexican Revolution That Was . . . or Was It?
description: When Cuauhtemoc Cardenas broke with Mexico's ruling party to run for President in last month's election, he quickly became a nonperson as far as the political establishment was concerned. Now his father, a revered former President, and a founder of that same party, appears to be getting the same treatment.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We left a yellow rubber bath mat in the bottom of our tub for a couple of months. When we picked it up we found that it has left a yellow stain which we cannot seem to remove. We tried scouring powder, then tried rubbing with fine steel wool, but the latter left a gray stain, probably because of the tub's age (34 years). Is there any kind of rubber dissolving chemical I can try that might remove the stain without causing further wear of the thin enamel?

title: 'SUPERREGIONAL' SUPERSTAR: Hugh L. McColl Jr.; A Carolina Banker Takes On Texas
description: HUGH L. McCOLL JR. learned a long time ago about the danger of confronting big challenges head-on. Some 30 years ago, on the lacrosse fields at the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill, he was bashed so hard by an opposing player that he was knocked unconscious.

title:
GARDENING;
The 80's Put More Stress on Drought
description: LEAD: THIS has been a summer of heat and drought throughout much of the country. For weeks, temperatures in the region have risen above 90 degrees each day, often approaching 100. Other regions have experienced even hotter temperatures, and while our drought was relatively short lived, theirs has persisted, with devastating results to gardens and farm crops.

title: In Amsterdam, 300 Years Of Jewish Life
description: The red brick building crowned with a crystal dome, its shell gable characteristic of Dutch classic style, carries a single clue to its past as a house of worship. Two lines from the Psalms, inscribed in Hebrew letters, flank the Ionic columns of the main doorway on the Jonas Daniel Meijerplein.

title:
INVESTING;
A Timer Who Is All in Cash
description: LEAD: As a discipline, market timing has always been controversial. Many experts believe that serious investors should buy stocks for their fundamental, long-term value - and not bail out of the market at the slightest hint of higher returns elsewhere.

title: Ellen Dickman Plans To Wed Steven Koch
description: The engagement of Ellen R. Dickman and Steven Koch has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Irwin L. Dickman of New York, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Koch of New York.

title: TAKING THE PRESS IN FOR REPAIRS
description: BEYOND MALICE The Media's Years of Reckoning. By Richard M. Clurman. 306 pp. New Brunswick, N.J.: Transaction Books. $24.95.

title: Disenchanted With the Beach, Swimmers Crowd the Pools
description: LEAD: WITH temperatures in the 80's early last Monday, and humidity levels not far behind, Lucy Carrion's mind was on Playland's beach. Her body, however, was a few hundred yards away, in Playland's 150-by-75-foot pool.

title: TOBACCO AND TRADE POLICY
description: Peter Schmeisser's article pointed out how willing our Government is to export death and disease for profit. Your cigarette ads appearing in the same issue show how shamelessly you want a cut of the action.

title: Italian Razzle-Dazzle at a Casual Cafe
description: IF your idea of dining out is serene surroundings, soft music, thick carpets and quiet conversation, forget Westbury's Caffe Baci. This casual cafe delivers crowds, excitement and razzle-dazzle. Caffe Baci is the latest in an unending stream of contemporary Italian cafes inundating Long Island. The Soho Grill had a short sojourn of six months at this location. The old Soho Grill, the new Caffe Baci and Caffe Spasso down the road are jointly owned. This new entry is an attempt to duplicate Caffe Spasso's successful formula.

title: The Spare, Sure Line Of Matisse
description: People think they know all about Henri Matisse, but most often they don't. None of the great painter/sculptor/printmakers of the 20th century has more surprises to spring when a major retrospective comes along. The most recent example of that is the unforgettable survey of his years in Nice that was put on at the National Gallery of Art in Washington by Jack Cowart and Dominique Fourcade in 1986. But it is true even of quite small dealers' exhibitions, like the survey of his prints that was mounted this summer by the Lumley-Cazalet Gallery in London. (Many was the longtime admirer of Matisse who had never before seen the prints in color that relate to his big decoration at the Barnes Collection in Merion, Pa.) The Lumley-Cazalet show is relevant in the context of the exhibition of Matisse prints owned by the Museum of Modern Art and on view there through Nov. 6. This show, first put on at the Fort Worth Museum of Art in Texas in October 1986, has been seen in five other cities on its leisurely way back to New York. For its present appearance, it has been augmented by six plates in vibrant color from ''Jazz'' (1947), which came to the museum in 1948 as a gift from the artist, and complete copies or specimen sheets from 12 other books illustrated by Matisse.

title: OLYMPIC PROFILE: Jeff Michels; Weight Lifter Carries a Heavy Burden
description: Jeff Michels, a weight lifter who has always set goals for himself, figured he was about two years away from setting a few world records when he went to Caracas for the 1983 Pan American Games. Winning three gold medals gave him that much more assurance he was on schedule.

title: Manhattan Town-House Demand Rises
description: WHETHER it is a desire for more space, or frustration with balky co-op boards, or simply a wish to own the roof above, the basement below and the garden behind, demand for one- and two-family Manhattan town houses in a city of apartment buildings is growing steadily, along with their prices.

title: Clinton Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Where to Get Repair Help
description: The following organizations offer minor repair services for the elderly. Unless otherwise noted, clients pay only for materials, although donations are encouraged.

title: The Gulf War: Some Lessons From 8 Years
description: Providing that it holds, the cease-fire between Iran and Iraq ends a war that cost up to a million lives, and it concludes a long laboratory session in modern warfare. ''What the Spanish Civil War was to

title: French Targets Are Bombed In Three Spanish Provinces
description: People thought to be Basque terrorists set off bombs at six French car dealerships and a dairy in northern Spain today, causing extensive damage but no injuries, Government officials said.

title: Patent Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: COLONIAL FURNISHINGS A look behind the scenes at the Yale University Art Gallery furniture collection is offered to those with reservations for a free lecture and tour at 2 P.M. Tuesday and 1 P.M. Thursday.

title: Weather, 'Tis Not Always Nobler at the Delacorte
description: William Shakespeare has never been at a loss for words about the weather, but there are some words the Bard never penned on the subject that are being bandied about these days at Central Park's Delacorte Theater, the outdoor summer forum for the free theater of the New York Shakespeare Festival. One gropes for the apt Shakespearean quote on the dripping whimsy of heaven but, without raiding Bartlett's, it is sufficient to say that the weather has been an indisputable wet blanket this season.

title: PRETORIA SAYS IT CAN BUILD A-ARMS
description: South Africa, which has long been thought to be developing atomic weapons, has the ability to produce a nuclear bomb, Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha said today.

title: Wisconsin Governor Relents On Air-Conditioning Capitol
description: This summer's heat has worn down Gov. Tommy G. Thompson's resistance to air-conditioning the Capitol. ''I've acquiesced,'' said Mr. Thompson, who had vetoed a budget item for installation of air-conditioning.

title: Lure of Banking Proves Irresistible to a Graduate
description: Raj Sinha graduated last year from the University of Chicago School of Medicine. He now works as an investment banker for Salomon Brothers Inc. in New York.

title: Corporations for Women to Seek - and To Avoid
description: Rosemarie B. Greco started as a secretary at the Fidelity Bank in Philadelphia. Nineteen years later, she's its president. At Pepsico Inc., Pam McGuire, a food law attorney, schedules her own hours so that she can spend time with her two young children.

title: Toledo Is Sued Over Random Stopping of Blacks
description: A Federal civil rights suit was filed Friday seeking an end to a new Police Department policy of randomly stopping and questioning black teen-agers in a racially mixed neighborhood.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Sugar Ray Leonard Box Again?
description: It isn't a question of Leonard boxing again that's at issue here. It's about money. Leonard is a box-office gold mine, the greatest entertainer the sport of boxing has seen. In the end, I will be surprised to see Donny Lalonde come away with a victory. Not because of Ray's efforts inside the ring, but because of his importance outside of the ring. JOSE RIVEROS Corona, N.Y.

title: New Math: Fewer Pupils, More Programs
description: LEAD: IT sounds like a trick question. How can a school built to hold 800 students be crammed to the rafters with only 400?

title:
THE VIEW FROM: HAMDEN;
A Town Experiences a Boredom Gap
description: LEAD: DOWN on Whitney Avenue, Bob's Surplus has a fresh coat of paint to cover the graffiti, but the letters ''E.C.L.'' - a symbol of the East Coast Locals - still stand high on the former co-op supermarket nearby. And across the street, the wall of the Spring Glen Luncheonette still sports the logo of the Spring Glen Thrashers, the letters ''S.G.T.

title: Cities, Stadiums and Responsibility
description: If George Steinbrenner feels unappreciated in New York, he can take comfort in the likelihood that he is still probably more popular than Walter O'Malley. For the younger set, O'Malley was the last owner of the Brooklyn Dodgers, a franchise beloved by its borough, more successful than any other in the National League after World War II, and richer than any other in baseball including the Yankees. At the peak of the affair, O'Malley moved the Dogers to Los Angeles where they played their inaugural season exactly 30 years ago.

title: Brain Injuries: Options Increase Programs and Support
description: LEAD: LESS than two years ago, while studying in the school library, Asher Labendz, a student at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, suddenly felt sick and collapsed on his way to the infirmary. He had suffered a brain aneurysm.

title: A 'Boy Mayor' Learns a Lesson
description: IT has been 10 years since Dennis Kucinich, dubbed Cleveland's ''boy mayor'' when he was elected at age 31, won a recall election by 236 votes. Within months, Cleveland became the first American city to plunge into default since the Depression.

title: Arch Support
description: LAST MONTH, WHEN RIDERS IN the Tour de France, the famed annual bicycle marathon, swept onto Paris's grandest boulevard, the Champs-Elysees, television viewers saw the final moments of the race against an oddly gorgeous backdrop: the Arc de Triomphe, that stately symbol of the French Republic, cloaked in tricolored drapery.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: A Wren Restoration Illuminates the Uses of Light
description: Acknowledged by architectural historians as the jewel of Sir Christopher Wren's smaller churches in the City of London, St. Stephen Walbrook (1672-79), Wren's own parish church on the street where he lived, was designed as a laboratory of the neo-classical forms that became the model for St. Paul's Cathedral. Recently the church has undergone a long and expensive structural restoration, supported in the main by the property developer and art patron Peter Palumbo, whose office adjoins the church. As part of the restoration team, George Sexton, an American architect and one of the younger generation of lighting consultants, devised a lighting plan appropriate to the building's integrity. The results provide the occasion for a consideration of light as a material component of architecture. Or, as Mr. Sexton would say, ''of that magic moment when you feel light becomes a material rather than something only to be in.''

title: Housing or Space Dispute Ensues
description: THE duck farmer sold his last duck some time ago and the truck farmer is losing enthusiasm for his lettuce and cabbages. Both of them now hunger for the profits to be made from that biggest cash crop of all: the housing development.

title: Caveat Emptor
description: AUTOMATIC focusing has become so much a part of the photography scene that it's easy to take for granted. Certainly no self-respecting camera buff would admit to ignorance of the subject. But for many people facing the prospect of buying a modern camera for the first time, the entire notion remains mysterious.

title: Bags and Boxes Full of Profits
description: ROGER STONE used to enjoy saying that no chief executive should stay longer than 10 years. Creativity would be replaced by rigidity, Mr. Stone would say, and that was just no good.

title: TALKING: Management; Buildings That Go It Alone
description: DISSATISFIED with the service they have received from managing agents over the years, a sizable number of condominiums and cooperatives are changing to self-management. Others report doing so because their management companies went out of business or no longer serviced buildings of a certain size.

title: On the Menu At London's South Bank
description: LEAD: The South Bank Arts Center along the River Thames and close to Waterloo and Westminster Bridges is not to be missed by anyone interested in some of the best music, theater, art and vintage and historical films that London can offer. It also has a variety of eating places, both within the complex and close by.

title: Others Died After Racing in Heat
description: Two men who died of heatstroke after running 3.5-mile races in Central Park this summer were not the first fatalities associated with the Manufacturers Hanover Corporate Challenge races, Fred Lebow said yesterday.

title: Gossamer Garments Replicate the Edwardian Garden Party
description: LEAD: PEOPLE today dress casually for sporting and outdoor events, but in the Edwardian era, people dressed elegantly for all events. In ''A Garden Party,'' the current exhibition at the Town House Museum of the New Canaan Historical Society, groupings of mannequins model summer dresses designed for such 1900's outdoor pursuits as a picnic, a garden club meeting or a croquet game.

title: Ways to Rise Above the 'Glass Ceiling'
description: While women have become commonplace in the work force - whether in coal mines or the executive suite - they continue to encounter obstacles. But as their numbers expand and their experience broadens, they are developing new ways of coping.

title: Another Flop For Mets
description: For the Mets, the sins had been bunched into one unforgivable inning, the first. There were three stolen bases, three walks, a wild pitch, a balk and an error. For the Expos, there were four unexpected, unearned, but totally appreciated runs.

title: Practical Traveler; Buying Duty-Free Products in Developing Nations
description: NOT many travelers are aware that a large number of items made in developing countries may be brought home duty-free, beyond the provisions of the usual $400 exemption: baskets made of willow or rattan from Senegal, toys from Israel, unset jade for jewelry from Taiwan, records and tapes from Trinidad and Tobago, coral jewelry from Barbados.

title: Phoenix Unearths 17th-Century Oddity
description: THE work of the 17th-century playwright Aphra Behn (1640-1689) remains obscure to contemporary theatergoers. An Englishwoman, she wrote 18 plays, 15 of which were produced. But her wicked ways included a series of most unsecretive love affairs and being jailed as a spy in the Netherlands, and so her works were more reviled than revived when the 1700's brought a return to Puritanism.

title: THE LIFE AND LOVES OF A TOUGH GUY
description: THE RAGMAN'S SON An Autobiography. By Kirk Douglas. 510 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $21.95.

title: Just Talking In English
description: In reference to Rhoda M. Gilinsky's article, ''Demand Grows for English Classes'' [ July 17 ] , your readers might like to know that the Ossining Public Library has free daytime and evening classes for foreign-born people who want to improve their conversation skills. This program is one of the services provided by the library's Education/Job Information Center. Volunteers donate their time and talent in an informal setting to help people from all over the world ''just talk'' in English.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
Life Sentences: Talking to Children
description: LEAD: MOTHERS of my generation (situated linguistically between ''children should be seen and not heard'' and ''don't lay that guilt trip on my head'') talk differently from other people. I know. I have been a mother for, collectively, 51 years - serving two concurrent terms.

title: No Headline
description: LEAD: THE Breck-Marshall tacked a sweeping path across the Mystic River, then expertly wove among the dozens of small boats dotting the waterway alongside the Mystic Seaport museum.

title: REPUBLICANS PRESS TO BUILD UP BUSH AS HEIR TO REAGAN
description: Republicans made final preparations today for a national convention that is intended to establish Vice President Bush as the credible heir to President Reagan and to heighten public anxiety about Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic nominee, who has been running ahead of Mr. Bush for most of this year.

title: HOLDING THE MAIL
description: To the Editor: Excellent piece on going-away arrangements (Practical Traveler, June 12) except for advice about having the Post Office hold mail.

title: Spanish Pottery Made in Ancient Styles
description: THERE are no pottery shops in Moveros. Yet this tiny village, about 150 miles northwest of Madrid, is renowned for its ceramics, sold in the homes of the women who make them.

title: Careers Overseas
description: To the Editor:

title: ETERNAL VERITIES TAKE A BEATING
description: BORN BROTHERS By Larry Woiwode. 611 pp. New York: Michael di Capua Books/ Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $19.95

title: Competition Intensifies at India's Top Schools
description: Scores of young men and women surged around the bulletin board not long ago at St. Stephen's College here, one of India's elite education institutions, craning to glimpse their names on lists announcing those selected for interviews.

title: WHY GOETZ GOT OFF
description: A CRIME OF SELF-DEFENSE Bernhard Goetz and the Law on Trial. By George P. Fletcher. 253 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95.

title: New Ethics Rules May Slow Conversions
description: TOUGH, new ethics rules that take effect Jan. 1 could hinder operations at the already overburdened Real Estate Finance Bureau of the New York State Attorney General's office. Attorneys critical of the new law believe this may lead to even further delays in approvals for condominiums and cooperatives.

title: New York's Job Market: Why So Many Are Sitting Out
description: THE founders of the Furniture Training Institute in Queens thought they had a formula for certain success: free instruction, hundreds of jobs to be filled and a pool of thousands of unemployed New Yorkers from which to draw trainees.

title: Americans Gain In Cup Qualifying
description: In an unusual display of offensive prowess, the World Cup soccer team of the United States defeated Jamaica, 5-1, today and advanced to the third qualifying round of the 1990 tournament.

title: Artists Joining Against Factory School of Painting
description: In this summer resort town, home of one of the nation's oldest art colonies, you can buy an original painting by Michael Stoffa for about $500. Or, for $29, a comparable-sized oil painting signed with the name Taylor.

title:
FOCUS: Atlanta;
An Apartment Glut Brings Lower Rents
description: LEAD: SPURRED by strong growth in employment and favorable tax benefits, developers here went on a building binge over the last five years. They added more than 100,000 apartments, nearly one-third of the metropolitan area's total inventory.

title: RED SOX WIN 24TH IN ROW AT HOME
description: The Boston Red Sox won their 24th straight game at Fenway Park today, tying the second-longest home winning streak in major league history. Dwight Evans drove in a career-high seven runs with two homers and a bases-loaded triple in a 16-4 rout of the Detroit Tigers.

title: Deal on Shoreham Not a Fait Accompli
description: Inadvertently missing from the written test [ ''Final Chapter in the Power Struggle,'' Long Island Opinion, July 31 ] but included in the oral address to the Energy and Environment Committee of the Suffolk County Legislature on July 14, 1988, after the statement ''Either way, win or lose, Shoreham's done,'' was the phrase ''which is what I thought prior to hearing testimony here this morning.''

title: FEDERAL STUDY TO DELAY PLAN FOR RIIS PARK
description: Consideration of a disputed proposal to build an entertainment and amusement complex on Federal park land in Queens has been put off for at least a year while the Government conducts an environmental impact study.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: New Orleans
description: New Orleans in August? Why not? The climate indoors is cool. And outdoors the pace is leisurely. For some New Orleanians, August has certain advantages, allowing plenty of excuses to relax in a leafy patio, schedule fewer appointments, lengthen the lunch hour and savor fine cooking.

title: Panel Will Seek Rescue For Historical Society
description: A committee of influential businessmen, arts administrators and educators has been formed to rescue the New-York Historical Society from a financial and management crisis that threatens the survival of the 184-year-old institution.

title: CRIME
description: Douglas Kiker, the NBC News correspondent, demonstrated a deft hand as a mystery writer in ''Murder on Clam Pond'' almost two years ago. He introduced a man named McFarland, an out-of-work, disillusioned journalist from Chicago who was holed up on Cape Cod. Mac, as he is called, was confronted with a murder and solved it. Being a skilled investigative reporter is not that different from being a private eye, after all.

title: A Little-Known Corner of Switzerland
description: The facade of every house in Guarda, in the Lower Engadine, is boldly painted, sometimes with whimsical creatures, sometimes with elegant geometric designs. The big white-washed houses are set close together on cobbled streets that occasionally widen into little squares centered on a fountain. Green slopes rise on every side of the compact village: the main street ends abruptly in fields and meadows, and across the narrow valley stands a wall of rugged mountains. This Swiss village is like an original illustration for a charming folk tale.

title: Maplejinsky Takes Alabama by a Neck
description: At the top of the stretch at Saratoga Race Track today, Maplejinsky was clinging to a slim lead and three of her four rivals in the Alabama Stakes were drawing closer. But when the finish line came up, Maplejinsky, who had led from the start, was still in front.

title:
ART;
Kinetic Sculpture's Abstract Techniques
description: LEAD: WHEN one hears about a kinetic sculpture exhibition, one usually thinks of flashing lights or components whirled by the wind. Such shows are a reminder that there is nothing new under the sun except that many of these sculptures are now computer-driven.

title: Soviet Folk Dancers Make Sparks Fly
description: Men dressed in fancy military uniforms spin and dance on the stage to a raging drum tempo, their legs flying in all directions. As they whirl, they clash their swords together so sharply that sparks actually fly.

title: Ms. Stanton Wed To John L. Nolen
description: The marriage of Patricia B. Stanton and John L. Nolen, who served as Peace Corps volunteers in Honduras, took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Stanton Jr. of Montclair, N.J. The Rev. Paul Wiese, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Switzerland
description: To the Editor: Marcia Lieberman's article about climbing the Breithorn in Zermatt, Switzerland (Travel, July 3), was exciting, but there are a myriad of other walking opportunities in Zermatt. There are over 280 miles of marked trails and many more unmarked ones. With cable cars and even an underground lift, one can reach the higher altitudes in a matter of minutes. The area is surrounded by 30 snow-covered peaks. There is even an occasional bench, painted red and strategically placed, where you can sit and admire the scenery. Best of all, as one walks along the trail, there are restaurants with sun terraces, to enjoy the scenery and sip coffee or a beer. EMANUEL LICHT Morris Plains, N.J.

title: Mollie Rimmer Weds Biologist
description: Mollie Davis Rimmer and Frederick Thomas Bedford Cunningham Hoopes, graduates of the Groton School and the University of Vermont, were married yesterday at St. Ann's Episcopal Church in Kennebunkport, Me. The Rev. Bertrand N. Honea Jr., assisted by the Rev. Laman Bruner, performed the ceremony.

title: ON THE ROAD WITH GOD
description: CAN SOMEBODY SHOUT AMEN! By Patsy Sims 234 pp. New York: A Thomas Dunne Book/St. Martin's Press. $15.95

title: From Coast to Coast, Urban Rail Is Flourishing; What National Debate?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Woman's Miniskirt, A Man's Attitude
description: I was offended by Edson Atwood's article, ''Ban the Miniskirt, Please'' (Opinion page, July 10) because of his blatant sexism and presumptuous attitude. Mr. Atwood is mistaken in thinking that this reader is interested in his uncontrollable voyeurism and his dictatorial tendencies.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: Written and photographed by Lou Stoumen, who has won two Academy Awards as a producer of documentaries, JOURNEY TO LAND'S END: A Paper Movie (Celestial Arts, Cloth, $19.95; Paper, $9.95) is a hip little fable for adults that takes a sad and humorous trip to the polluted End of the World, with time out for Love along the way. ''Now playing,'' the cover proclaims, ''at a future near you.'' The tale is carried along as much by pictures as by words. Mr. Stoumen has a rhythm of his own that leaves plenty of time for digression and jump cuts. His photographs range from clever to fey to abstract, from straightforward observation to obliquely viewed oddities and surprises. The images sometimes illustrate, sometimes suggest, sometimes crack wise, but always, as in more conventional movies, pictures and text dance with each other to move the story forward. Now and then the writing becomes too obvious or too precious, and the tale is perhaps a bit forced for the kind of profound lunacy it aspires to. Still, the journey has its strong and poignant moments, both visual and verbal: ''History has turned out to be / proud angry men wrapped in flags.'' The author can also be sharp and snappy, as in a vignette about a conceptual artist who masturbates in a shop window and has herself shot in the arm, thereby winning success with a line of designer jeans, ''a Major Foundation Grant and a Rock Star Lover.'' There's a dose of sardonic charm here, and a mournful smile at Land's End.

title: Eloquent Works: Learning the Language of a Father's Love
description: I'VE always anticipated the effortless, reassuring hug from my father, the kind that Gregory Peck as Atticus Finch delivers so easily to Scout in ''To Kill a Mockingbird.'' Twilight on the veranda, father to daughter, sitting shoulder to top of head.

title: DATA UPDATE: August 14, 1988
DANCE VIEW
description: Forget the costumes. The garish new costumes that Christian Lacroix designed this season for American Ballet Theater's revival of ''Gaite Parisienne'' may have caused gasps. Nevertheless, the more amazing thing about that revival was the enduring vitality of Leonide Massine's choreography.

title: A Week After Clash, Protestors Hold Quiet Thompkins Sq. Rally
description: A week after bloody riots despoiled the streets of the East Village, hundreds of people gathered in a cleaned-up and sun-dappled Tompkins Square Park yesterday for a peaceful rally of defiant speeches and a marathon of amplified rock music.

title: Only a Floor, but It's My Floor
description: HE always caught me in this position. I would be on my hands and knees on the floor, furiously scratching away with my fingernail. ''It's only a floor!'' he would say as I scraped the last raisin off the vinyl brick, seconds before his machine overtook me. ''Sure,'' I would think to myself. ''It's easy enough for him to say. I pay him to wax over whatever I've managed to clean (or not to clean). What difference does it make to him?''

title:
The View From: The Jobsite;
When the Building Inspector Speaks, the Builders Listen
description: LEAD: MICHELLE DePEW, the building inspector for the town of Southeast, of which this village is part, was headed out on a job one recent afternoon. She bumped along over muddy terrain in a neat beige Jeep-like vehicle, recently provided for her by the town so she could get to even the most difficult sites.

title: Housing Tax Credits? Not for This Investor
description: To the Editor:

title: National Politics Enlivens Shoreham Debate
description: LEAD: DEEP in August, when election-year contests would normally be steeped in torpor, a dragon of an issue is breathing fire on Long Island candidates for state and national offices.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: YESTERDAY: The Unauthorized Biography of Paul McCartney. By Chet Flippo. (Doubleday, $18.95.) At the height of Beatlemania in the late 1960's fence straddlers were not allowed. Hard-core Beatlemaniacs were divided into camps of John fans and Paul fans. Unfortunately, that attitude lives on in ''Yesterday,'' Chet Flippo's unauthorized biography of Paul McCartney - and it's obvious that Mr.

title:
GARDENING;
The 80's Put More Stress on Drought
description: LEAD: THIS has been a summer of heat and drought throughout much of the country. For weeks, temperatures in the region have risen above 90 degrees each day, often approaching 100. Other regions have experienced even hotter temperatures, and while our drought was relatively short lived, theirs has persisted, with devastating results to gardens and farm crops.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: GLENN MILLER SOUND The Glenn Miller Orchestra - authorized by the Miller estate to carry on the big band sound and tradition of the bandleader who was on an aircraft when it disappeared in 1944 - will perform at the Ocean Grove Auditorium Saturday evening.

title: The Cost of Money Is Definitely Up
description: The cost of money rose decisively, as the Federal Reserve voted unanimously to raise the discount rate to 6 1/2 percent from 6 percent, and the nation's leading banks raised their prime lending rate to 10 percent, from 9 1/2 percent. The discount rate, which is what the Fed charges on its loans to banks, is now at its highest level since July 1986. The prime rate, which is the basis for rates on corporate and consumer loans, is in double digits for the first time since June 1985. The discount rate, last raised in September of 1987, had been lagging market rates for some time. Those rates have been rising as investors looked at the signs of a vigorous economy and saw a potential for accelerating inflation. An eventual move by the Fed had been widely expected, but the markets still seemed taken aback by the Fed's timing. Many people had thought the Fed, entirely made up of Reagan appointees, would not act until after the elections.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ALMOST GOLDEN: Jessica Savitch and the Selling of Television News. By Gwenda Blair. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Cocaine. Suicides. Abusive sex. Abortions. Lesbianism. Amphetamines. Disposable marriages. Another biography of a self-destructive rock star? No, this is the picture we get of the television anchorwoman Jessica Savitch.

title: THE VIEW FROM OVER 30
description: POLITICAL PASSAGES Journeys of Change Through Two Decades 1968-1988. Edited by John H. Bunzel. With an Introductory Essay by Edward Shils. 354 pp. New York: The Free Press. $21.95. $ TTHIS book will probably remind a lot of people of ''The God That Failed'' or ''Witness'' by Whittaker Chambers or Norman Podhoretz's ''Breaking Ranks'' or some other entry in the growing library of up-from-leftism confessionals. Not without reason: in ''Political Passages'' there are essays by a dozen American intellectuals, many of whom believed 20 years ago that what they called Amerika was racist, fascist and genocidal, that Black Power was gonna get your Mama, that the Vietcong were the moral superiors of the Founding Fathers, but who have since changed their minds and are now, in the word of one of these converts, ''smarter.''

title: PROTESTS MARK BERLIN WALL'S 27TH ANNIVERSARY
description: West German protesters threw tomatoes and eggs at East German guards at the Berlin wall and Communist police hauled away protesting East German youths today as both sides marked the barrier's 27th anniversary.

title: 30 Killed in Iran Bus Crash
description: Two buses collided in northern Iran, killing 30 people and injuring 50, the Teheran radio reported today. The radio also said two strong earthquakes jolted the southern city of Bushehr, with no injuries or damage immediately reported. The two buses collided on the heavily traveled Teheran-Tabriz highway Friday, the report said.

title: Avid Gardener's Search for Blooms And Some Space
description: PURPLE and green thumbers alike, those of us who garden outdoors passionately must soon come to grips with our acqusitive tendencies.

title: In Lagos, Economic Dream Is Now Nightmare
description: At the crest of Nigeria's oil boom, in the early 1980's, radio transmitters of the Voice of Nigeria broadcast the voice of Africa's giant to the four corners of the world.

title: Living the Faith the Hutterian Way
description: LEAD: EACH day, the 350 Hutterians of the Deer Spring Bruderhof in Norfolk gather at their spacious dining hall for lunch. The older members ride to the hall in electric golf carts, while the youngest eat in their ''departments'' or day care centers.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: ALMOST all of the more than 400 inactive landfills in New Jersey still pose a threat of air and ground-water contamination, seven years after the passage of a state law aimed at closing them properly.

title: A Triumph for Poor Children
description: Stop for a moment and consider what a wonderful thing Governor Cuomo and the New York Legislature have now accomplished by enacting the Governor's Liberty Scholarship program. Forget all the passing urgencies of the moment; 10 and 20 years from now, this is one act that New Yorkers will remember, and with gratitude.
