title: Review/Pop; A Merger of Opposites By Ambitious Lovers
description: In funk's patterned rhythms and pop's smooth melodies, listeners hear the reassuring sound of ordered continuity. In what is loosely called downtown music, noise and improvisation jolt the listener with discontinuity. Arto Lindsay and Peter Scherer, who lead Ambitious Lovers, want nothing less than to merge those polar opposites. In their late set Tuesday at S.O.B.'s they came close enough.

title: In the Land Of Veiled Women
description: Rarely have I read such adolescent drivel as expressed in the article on the New Jersey Opinion page of July 10. It sounds like a response to the first surge of hormones in a 17-year-old.

title: Miss Pick Is Wed To Daniel Perera
description: Katherine Monique Pick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pedro J. Pick of Milton, Mass., and Caracas, Venezuela, was married yesterday to Daniel Gifford Perera, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Perera of North Caldwell, N.J. The Rev. Robert Houston, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Pick home in Milton.

title: Wrong Again
description: LEAD: Because the road to New Orleans was more clearly charted than the road to Atlanta, the Republicans have escaped most of the orgy of media speculation and confusion that bedeviled the Democrats' nomination process.

title: 5 DAYS IN NEW ORLEANS
description: sunday, Aug. 14 President and Mrs. Reagan arrive at Belle Chasse Naval Air Station. Welcoming ceremony at New Orleans Convention Center. Monday, Aug. 15 Convention opens. Address by President Reagan. Tuesday, Aug. 16 Platform presentation and vote. Address by Jeane K. Kirkpatrick. Keynote address by Gov. Thomas H. Kean of New Jersey. Wednesday, Aug. 17 Nomination of the Presidential candidate by Senator Phil Graham of Texas. Roll call of the states. Thursday, Aug. 18 Nomination of the Vice-Presidential candidate. Vice-Presidential nominee's acceptance speech. Acceptance speech by Presidential nominee.

title: From Coast to Coast, Urban Rail Is Flourishing; Good for Cities
description: To the Editor:

title: Q and A
description: Coast Shuttles

title: Red Sox Fan Questions Call
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Land in Vermont Confiscated
description: Federal law-enforcement agents have seized more than $1 million in property belonging to convicted drug dealers who allegedly bought it with the profits from illegal drug sales.

title: Old Acquaintances and Paths Not Taken
description: My husband, a gregarious Texan with a long stride and an easy smile, seems always to be chance-meeting aging reincarnations of people who still live and breathe within the landscape of his memory.

title: Call of 'Mush, You Winnebago!' Fills Yukon Air
description: More than 150 years after Americans in covered wagons began opening up the lands west of the Mississippi, a new brand of adventurers is out in force this summer on one of the continent's last frontiers.

title: 20's Epidemic Haunts Town
description: IN the 1920's, an outbreak of hoof-and-mouth disease wiped out nearly all the dairy cattle in Long Beach, Calif. Now that epidemic is coming back to haunt homeowners.

title: Limited Punishment Signaled in Jet Downing
description: The Pentagon report on the July 3 downing of an Iranian airliner by missiles fired from the Navy cruiser Vincennes recommends disciplinary action only against the ship's operations officer, according to a published report.

title: Cynthia Rolen, C.P.A., To Wed Douglas Furth
description: Comdr. and Mrs. L. F. Rolen of Richmond have announced the engagement of their daughter Cynthia Gwen Rolen to Douglas Layton Furth, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Furth of White Plains.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Chatham Township $612,500 19 Hall Road 4-bedroom, 4-bath, 15-year-old colonial; hardwood floors, sun room, patio, 2-car garage; taxes $5,715. Edison $180,000 27 Holly Place 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 27-year-old ranch; dining room, patio, full basement; taxes $1,866. Freehold $305,000 22 Woods Road 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 18-year-old colonial; pool, c/a, eat-in kitchen; taxes $3,544. Lebanon Township $262,000 Anthony Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, 2 wood-burning stoves, 10 acres; taxes $2,600. Millburn $225,000 15 Bodwell Terrace 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 25-year-old colonial; living room fireplace, porch, 1-car garage; taxes $2,969. Short Hills $1.3 million 79 Minisink Road 5-bedroom, 4-bath, 32-year-old colonial; 4 fireplaces, deck, family room, library, 2-car garage; taxes $12,060. OTHER AREAS Williston Park, L.I. $274,000 153 Park Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 55-year-old colonial; dining room, den, office, 1-car garage; taxes $2,900. Valhalla, N.Y. $240,000 5 Maple Hill Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 17-year-old ranch; living room, family room with fireplace, den, deck, attached garage; taxes $3,255. New Fairfield, Conn. $191,000 37 Hillview Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 12-year-old raised ranch; hardwood floors, wood-burning stove, 0.33 acre; taxes $1,075.

title:
MUSIC;
Quartet and Guitar Duo to Team Up
description: LEAD: TWO ensembles that do not quite fit the traditional mold will be the featured artists this afternoon at 4 at the Soclair Brooks Farm here. The Alexander String Quartet, along with the guitarists Michael Newman and Laura Oltman, will perform a joint program in the restored barn, which has become a popular summer concert setting.

title: History Proving Harder to Celebrate
description: Bring on the tall ships. And the commemorative coins. And the corporate sponsors and merchandise tie-ins. It's four years to the quincentenary of Christopher Columbus's voyage to the New World, and the American way of celebrating historical anniversaries is gearing up again.

title: Reviews/Music; A Finale at Tanglewood For New-Music Festival
description: The final concert of the Tanglewood Festival of Contemporary Music tonight was a satisfyingly varied program, played by the student orchestra of the Tanglewood Music Center and led, in all but one work, by Oliver Knussen, the British composer who has overseen this new-music festival the last few summers.

title: Day Care Not Baby Sittng
description: In the article ''Day Camp Is Not Day Care'' Connecticut Q&A, July 24) Allen Beavers is emphatic in his assertion that camp is not day care, which he equates with baby-sitting.

title: Tourist Industr's Eldness Summer: Pollution Raises Fears for Future
description: AS investigators continue to search for sources of this summer's beach pollution and strategies to combat it, Long Island officials and business leaders fear that this year's drop in tourism could persist next year.

title: INTO THE GARDEN
description: I HAVE JUST RETURNED FROM THE GARDEN WITH A basketful of blossom-tipped squash to cook for dinner. This squash will need no butter, not only because it is so fresh, but because it is an old-fashioned crookneck. It is funny looking, small and so frail that no commercial growers bother to ship them.

title: POSTINGS: On the Whippany River; 70 Mount Laurel Units in a Market-Rate Condo Project
description: In 1984, faced with a lawsuit stemming from the Mount Laurel court decisions, all five members of the Morris Township Committee voted to encourage the construction of 335 affordable housing units. Since then, all five have been voted from office. As in other communities throughout New Jersey, many residents of Morris Township have not been eager to accept the burden imposed by the State Supreme Court. In four years only 18 of the 335 units agreed upon have been built, while 21 more are under construction, said Harvey Moskowitz, a consultant to the township's planning board. And though another 250 units have been approved, many of the largest projects are trapped in court challenges.

title: Don't Risk America's Job Creation Boom

title: Results Plus
description: Golf Hill Wins in Syracuse: Dave Hill won the Syracuse Classic yesterday by five shots over Butch Baird and Bobby Nichols. ''It's a great feeling coming down the fairway knowing no one can beat you unless you drop dead or forget to sign your scorecard,'' Hill said after winning his second Senior PGA Tour title of the season with a 16-under-par 200. Hill, who had a one-stroke victory in June at the Senior Tournament of Champions in Carlsbad, Calif., won $37,500. Hill, who put himself in a commanding position Saturday with a tournament-record eight-under-par 64, shot a 68 in the final round at the par-72 Lafayette Country Club course. Nichols had a 68 yesterday; Baird a 69. Bob Charles and Doug Dalziel, the first-day leader, were third at 10-under-par 206.(AP) Auto Racing Rudd Edges Wallace: Ricky Rudd took the lead four laps from the end and held off charging Rusty Wallace to win a caution-filled Nascar race yesterday at Watkins Glen, N.Y. The victory was Rudd's first of the season and made him the 12th different winner in 18 races this season. The Chesapeake, Va., driver started fifth in the 40-car lineup and hung near the front throughout the 90-lap, 219-mile event on the 2.428-mile, seven-turn road course. There were eight full-course caution flags for 38 laps, keeping the field bunched. In fact, 22 cars finished on the lead lap, breaking the Winston Cup record of 19 set two weeks ago at Talladega, Ala. (AP) Track and Field Lewis Leads the Way: An American 400-meter relay team led by Carl Lewis won its event at a meet in Hengelo, the Netherlands, in a time of 38.64 seconds. The team - Michael Marsh, Mark Witterspoon, Joe DeLoach and Lewis - won the race in the final 100 meters when Lewis took a decisive lead over his West German and Dutch competition. In other events, Mary Decker Slaney won the 1,000 meters in 2 minutes 34.65 seconds, about 4 seconds off Tatyana Providokhina's 10-year-old world record. Johnny Grey won the 800 meters in 1:43.10, the best time in the world this year, while Willie Banks, world-record holder in the triple jump, reached 55 feet 2 inches, more than 3 feet under his record.(AP) Victory for Griffith Joyner: Florence Griffith Joyner and Edwin Moses easily won their last races in Europe before the Olympics, at a meet in Gateshead, England. Griffith Joyner, the world-record holder, won the 100 meters in 11.54 seconds, and Moses won the 400-meter hurdles in 48.67. Griffith Joyner was grabbed by a spectator before her race when she refused his request for an autograph. Officials quickly moved in to remove the man, who was allowed back into the stands. Griffith Joyner was unhurt but shaken.(AP) Dog Show Design on Success: A Gordon setter, Ch. Wildwood's Classic Design, who was 4 years old 12 days ago, celebrated her birthday by winning best in show at the 23d all-breed fixture of the Sand and Sea Kennel Club in Lakewood, N.J. For the black bitch with tan markings, who answers to the name of Traci, and is owned by Pamela, John and Virginia Radonis, it was her second top award; she also won at Wallkill a month ago. With yesterday's victory, where she led a field of 1,283, she became the first Gordon setter bitch ever to capture two bests, according to Pamela Radonis, who showed her.

title: Angry Inmates Set Jail Afire

At least eight people were injured in the three-hour uprising at the Essex County Jail and House of Correction, a pre-Civil War building, including five inmates and one firefighter who were treated for smoke inhalation and cuts. Prisoners pelted firefighters and police officers with cans and debris as flames poured through the roof.

title: Tax Watch; Need for Changes In Withholding
description: MOST people thought that filling out new W4 forms, which employers use to determine how much tax to withhold from workers' paychecks, was last year's headache. Legally, it was, because the Government required every employed person to fill out a new W4 as a result of the Tax Reform Act of 1986. But it's time to take out the calculators again. ''Now you really need to do another one of those because the rules have changed,'' said Thomas P. Ochsenschlager, partner in the Washington office of Grant Thornton, an accounting firm. And, while there is not a strict legal requirement this year as there was last, the form should be filed as soon as possible, he added.

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * China's Politburo will meet today in an effort to settle differences over the Government's decision to remove some controls on prices of goods and services. The decision has caused public discontent and the highest inflation since the Communist takeover in 1949. The Wen Wei Po newspaper in Hong Kong said that officials are divided on how much prices should be allowed to fluctuate as they seek their market levels.

description: The drought-related increase in soybean prices is raising concerns among newspaper publishers who have switched from conventional petroleum ink to ink made from soybean oil.

description: The underground leadership of the Palestinian uprising has decided that a declaration of independence should be issued for the West Bank and Gaza Strip, but the leadership will let the Palestine Liberation Organization carry out the initiative, Palestinians close to the leadership said today.

title: Clean Air, Still Beyond Reach

Air pollution has been reduced, but not by enough. The White House, Congress and polluters resist the hard choices necessary for further protection of public health and the environment.

title: The Needle Question
description: It's a tormenting choice. Does giving drug addicts free, clean needles promote drug abuse? Does failing to give them clean needles promote the spread of AIDS? No American city has yet implemented such a needle program. But New York officials now have finally approved an experiment involving 200 addicts that could begin this fall and help resolve the dilemma.

title: Edward Bennett Williams, Trial Lawyer, Dead at 68; A Brilliant 'Superlawyer'
description: Mr. Williams, considered a brilliant ''superlawyer'' who stood as a pillar of the Washington establishment, had no particular political power bloc of his own, but both Republicans and Democrats sought his friendship and counsel, and he seemed always to be in good standing with the occupant of the White House Oval Office.

Aerovironment, a privately held company with annual revenues of $11 million, designed the exterior and electronics and served as the project manager for G.M.'s Sunraycer. The car, equipped with a G.M. motor, suspension and solar cells, won the 1,950-mile race by solar-powered cars in Australia last November.

Pack Light, Keep Cool
description: Bryce Thatcher is a 25-year-old mountain runner who tends to go off in the wilderness for hours at a time. A water bottle is as critical to his fitness as a parachute is to the sky diver's landing. Thatcher designed a special backpack five years ago because he was tired of drinking water warm as soup. He also didn't like the way the water bottle slapped against his hip as he moved.

title: Bridge
description: Few octogenarians win major bridge titles, but one of them did at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, which ended Aug. 7 in Salt Lake City. Among the winners of the Senior Knockout, a three-day regional event that attracted an entry of 49 teams, was Chester Hirsch, a retired New York businessman, 82 years old, who now lives in Palm Springs, Calif.

The runners were responding to his decision to change a road race in Central Park yesterday into a ''fun run,'' with no official clock, because of the extreme temperature and humidity.

They are naturally pointing with pride to their successes of the last seven years, but the Republicans have not always been good at handling success when they had it.

description: This morning, my daughter had an attack of hysteria. She tossed in a trance in bed for more than an hour, gasping for breath in minor spasms, caught in a nightmare she couldn't escape. In horror and despair, my wife and I tried to hold and caress her.

title: Fast, Fast Deficit Relief
description: Thanks to Governor Dukakis's nomination for President, it has suddenly become especially reckless to speed in Massachusetts. Faced with an embarrassing unanticipated $400 million state budget deficit, the Governor and the Legislature reached for quick fixes. One is a new regime of fines for speeding, potentially the steepest in America.

title: Toyon-Wintu Center Journal; Rooted to Land in a Sea of Troubles
description: When outsiders visit this tiny Indian settlement 220 miles northeast of San Francisco, they see windowless houses with no running water or electricity. They see yards full of weeds and rubbish. They see dogs and chickens sharing the potholed streets with rusting, seemingly abandoned cars.

description: For three generations, Liz Patout's family has operated its sedate restaurant here without customers standing on chairs, throwing food or drowning out Dave the Cajun fiddler with his fortissimo renditions of the television theme songs from ''The Flintstones'' and ''The Beverly Hillbillies.''

title: Plunkett Released
description: The Los Angeles Raiders released the quarterback Jim Plunkett yesterday, ending a comeback attempt by the 40-year-old former Heisman Trophy winner, who was the oldest active player in the National Football League. Asked if he planned to try to catch on with another team, Plunkett laughed. ''I don't think there's too much demand for 40-year-old quarterbacks,'' he said. Plunkett's release indicated that Mike Shanahan, the first-year coach, intends to keep three quarterbacks, with Steve Beuerlein and Vince Evans being the top two. Plunkett joined the Raiders in September 1978 after spending the 1976 and 1977 seasons with the 49ers, who then released him. He was the first man picked in the 1971 N.F.L. draft by New England after winning the Heisman Trophy during his senior year at Stanford. Plunkett led the Raiders to two Super Bowl victories, after the 1980 and 1983 seasons, and was named the Super Bowl's most valuable player after the Raiders beat Philadelphia, 27-10, in January 1981. In his career, Plunkett had 1,943 completions in 3,701 attempts for 25,882 yards with 164 touchdowns and 198 interceptions. (AP)

title: Sather Pleads for Calm
description: Edmonton players should let their emotions on the trade of Wayne Gretzky die down before they decide what, if anything, they will do about it, Coach Glen Sather said yesterday. ''The important thing is that the players don't do anything drastic without discussing everything from a point of view which is not emotional,'' Sather, also the team's president and general manager, said in Edmonton, Alberta. Players have reportedly threatened to strike unless the owner, Peter Pocklington, sells the team. Sather called the threat ''ridiculous.'' The bottom line, he said, is that the trade to the Los Angeles Kings didn't have to happen. ''If Wayne totally wanted to stay and if Peter totally didn't want to trade him, they would have found a way,'' he said. ''I did personally go up to Wayne and tell him if he didn't want to be traded I would personally stop it.'' (AP)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: THE ECONOMY U.S. factories, mines and utilities raised output 0.8 percent in July. It was the biggest monthly increase this year and broader based than had been expected. As the latest evidence of a booming economy, it raised the possibility the Government will have to take steps to raise interest rates again to contain inflation. [ Page A1. ] The Government is investigating ''possible irregularities or improprieties'' involving two Navy contracts, valued at almost $900 million, with Electronic Data Systems. The company's parent, General Motors, disclosed the information to the S.E.C. [ A16. ] The Farm Credit System reported a $170 million profit for the second quarter, continuing an improvement trend based on a reduction in its provision for loan losses. The system has 37 borrower-owned banks and associations [ A2. ] Sales of cars and light trucks were strong in August but were down 6.6 percent from the comparable period a year earlier. Car sales fell 7.6 percent, while light-truck sales fell 4.9 percent. [ D5. ] COMPANIES Random House will acquire Crown Publishing, one of the last family-owned major publishing houses in the U.S. Crown has a stable of best-selling authors and is also one of the major players in the remainder market, buying overpublished books and reselling them at a discount. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. [ D1. ] A $70-a-share tender offer for Interco was begun. The $2.53 billion offer comes from Steven and Mitchell Rales and follows the rejection of their bid by Interco's board. Interco makes Ethan Allen and Lane furniture and Florsheim and Converse shoes. [ D1. ] Malrite Communications received a buyout offer of $10.25 a share in cash from a management group led by its chairman and chief executive. Analysts valued the offer at $170 million and said the company's assets might justify a higher price. [ D20. ] Eastern Airlines will offer a $69 one-way fare between Florida and 16 Northeast cities this fall to build traffic after the summer travel period ends. Competitors quickly matched the fare. [ D1. ] G.E. will sell its solid state division to Harris. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. [ D5. ] U.S. Shoe is exploring a sale of all or part of the company and has hired Merrill Lynch as an adviser. [ D5. ] Patrick Media will sell some billboards to reduce its debt. Patrick is the largest outdoor advertising company in the U.S. [ D20. ] MARKETS The stock market staged a broad retreat in subdued trading. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 33.25 points, or 1.6 percent, to 2,004.27, its biggest drop since it plummeted 44.99 points last Wednesday. The Dow is at its lowest level since May 27. [ D1. ] Prices of Treasury bonds and notes were little changed in very slow trading as credit market participants awaited today's report on the nation's June trade performance. [ D16. ] Grain and soybean futures made their strongest gains in a week in response to forecasts of triple-digit temperatures for most of this week in the drought-stricken Corn Belt. [ D15. ] The dollar finished mixed in mostly light trading ahead of today's report on the nation's trade deficit for June. On the Comex, gold rose $1.70 an ounce, to $433. [ D15. ] INTERNATIONAL The Mexican Government extended a freeze on prices, wages and the exchange rate until Nov. 30. It was the first major economic policy decision since the recent election. [ D11. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Pepsico's chairman expects growth on all three fronts - soft drinks, snacks and restaurants. Talking Business. CNN, C-SPAN: Live convention coverage, evening session, 3 hours. 8 P.M. ABC, CBS, NBC: Live convention coverage, evening session, 2 hours. 9 P.M. Week Ahead Tuesday: Platform presentation and vote. Address by Jeane J. Kirkpatrick. Keynote address by Governor Kean of New Jersey. Wednesday: Nomination of the Presidential candidate by Senator Phil Gramm of Texas and roll call of the states. title: Contradictory Tests
description: A second drug test on Miguel Lora, the World Boxing Council bantamweight champion from Baranquilla, Colombia, has revealed that no amphetamines were in his system. On Aug. 4, three days after Lora successfully defended his championship against Albert Davila of Pomona, Calif., at the Forum in nearby Inglewood, a test revealed amphetamines and methamphetamines in his system. Jose Sulaiman, W.B.C. president, has said he would take into consideration the result of the second test. (AP)

title: Maldive Chief Renominated
description: The Maldives Parliament nominated Maumoon Abdul Gayoom today for a third successive term as President, officials said. Mr. Gayoom, President since 1978, is credited with opening the Indian Ocean island chain to the outside world and developing a thriving tourist industry.

title: Artificial Brain Again Seen As a Guide To the Mind
description: FOR most of the last two decades, a quixotic science called neural network theory has been suffering through a dark age. All but a handful of enthusiasts had given up their dream of making intelligent computers by using networks of artificial neurons to electronically mimick the brain's circuitry.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING Glowing Honor Scores Upset: Glowing Honor, making her first stakes appearance and facing older fillies, led almost all the way to score a 2 1/2-length upset victory in the $122,800 Diana Handicap yesterday at Saratoga Race Track. The daughter of Seattle Slew and Glowing Tribute, owned by Paul Melln's Rokeby Stable and trained by Mack Miller, was keeping alive a family tradition. Her dam, Glowing Tribute, won the 1976 Diana as a 3-year-old and so did another daughter of Glowing Tribute, Wild Applause, in 1984. Glowing Honor, the lightweight in the field yesterday at 106 pounds, was one of only two 3-year-olds in the field of nine. The other, Sunny Roberta, finished second, with Graceful Darby third and Gaily Gaily fourth. Glowing Honor, who ran the mile and an eighth on the grass in 1:49 2/5 under Pat Day, paid $10 for $2 to win. Glowing Honor is now undefeated in three grass starts after losing her first three on the dirt. TENNIS Zivojinovic Advances: Second-seeded Slobodan Zivojinovic of Yugoslavia served 15 aces to beat Glenn Michibata of Canada, 7-6, 6-3, last night in the first round of the $125,000 Mennen Cup championships in Livingston, N.J. Zivojinovic, ranked 28th in the world, lost a 4-0 lead in the tie breaker as Michibata rallied for five straight points, but he held his two serves and broke Michibata with a volley winner to win the opening set. The second set was decided by a break in the fourth game. (AP)

title: Rig Count Falls by 5
description: The number of working domestic oil and gas rigs fell by five this week, to 940, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. Last week the rig count jumped by 51, to 945. A year ago this week, the count was 998, the company said. Baker Hughes's rig count, a widely watched index of drilling activity, reflects the number of rigs actively exploring for oil as of Friday, not the number of rigs producing oil. The rig count reached a peak of 4,500 in December 1981. But oil prices plunged to less than $10 per 42-gallon barrel in the summer of 1986 and the rig count went with it, dropping to 663 - the lowest since the count began.

title: Jersey Man Is Fatally Shot at a Queens Synagogue
description: A 49-year-old New Jersey man was shot to death at a Queens synagogue early yesterday, apparently during a robbery attempt after a ''Las Vegas Night'' at the synagogue, the police said.

title: A HARLEM LEGEND LIVES AGAIN ON BROADWAY
description: ''Ain't Misbehavin' '' is so torrid that it may be the only place in town where you feel happy to be hot. In their scrupulous re-creation of the Fats Waller show that first electrified Broadway a decade ago, the original cast and creators have conjured the same between-the-wars dream world as before. The stage of the Ambassador Theater turns into a mythic saloon where black jazz bounces against Tin Pan Alley pop, where 125th Street intersects 52d Street, where men coil around women in a plume of reefer smoke. It's always 3 o'clock in the morning. The joint is always jumping. And if there's a smell of summer sweat, it's of the sweetest old-time New York vintage: one part gin, two parts jitterbugging flesh.

An unprecedented event, to be sure, but just another example of how the Administration's strategy in pursuing arms control has been the correct one.

title: Deady Qualifies
description: When Mark Deady, a 20-year-old senior at Indiana University, finished third in the men's 1,500-meter race to qualify for the United States Olympic team last month, he had little time to celebrate. His time, 3 minutes 41.31 seconds, was still 2.41 seconds off the Olympic qualifying standard of 3:38.50. With seven weeks to match it or lose his place on the team, he set off for Europe. After several attempts, one in which he missed by just 8-hundredths of a second, he succeeded Sunday night, finishing fifth in Hengelo, the Netherlands, in 3:35.83. One American who may not share in Deady's joy is his landlord in Bloomington, Ind., Jim Spivey, the bronze medalist in the world championships last summer. Spivey had finished fourth in the trials, 21-hundredths of a second behind Deady, and would have been promoted to the team if Deady failed to make the standard.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL LOS ANGELES (NL) - Recalled Ken Howell, pitcher, from Albuquerque of Pacific Coast League. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Activated Bill Schroeder, catcher, from the 15-day disabled list. Placed Paul Mirabella, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list. BASKETBALL DETROIT (NBA) - Agreed to terms with James Edwards, center, on a multiyear contract. UTAH (NBA) - Released Bo Dukes, Todd Holloway and Aldwin Ware, guards, and Randal Smith and Andrew Kennedy, forwards. FOOTBALL BUFFALO (AFC) - Waived Vince Amoia, running back; Reggie Bynum, wide receiver; Zeke Gadson, linebacker, and Pete Curkendall, nose tackle. DENVER (AFC) - Waived Tony Lilly, safety; Bobby Micho, fullback; Loren Snyder, quarterback; Tony Colorito and Garry Frank, nose tackles; Richard Calvin, running back, and Raymond Phillips, linebacker. Placed Dan Remsberg, offensive tackle, and Charles Merritt, linebacker, on injured reserve. GIANTS (NFC) - Signed Joe Fields, center. Placed Harvey Clayton, cornerback, on injured reserve. Waived Mike Varajon and Charlie Sanders, running backs; Brian Sisley, linebacker; John Williams and Greg Harris, wide receivers; Dave Futrell, defensive end; Mike Black, center, and Willie Beecher, place-kicker. GREEN BAY (NFC) - Released Bud Keyes and Robbie Bosco, quarterbacks; George LaFrance and Teddy Wilson, wide receivers; Pat Taylor, linebacker, and Tony Mayes and Jim Bob Morris, defensive backs. INDIANAPOLIS (AFC) - Traded Tim Sherwin, tight end, to the Giants for an undisclosed draft choice. LOS ANGELES (AFC) - Released Jim Plunkett, quarterback; Phil Grimes, defensive lineman; Dwight Wheeler, offensive lineman; Walter Odom, tight end, and Jim Reynosa, linebacker. MIAMI (AFC) - Waived Gary Hulsey, defensive end; Aric Anderson, Kenneth Jordan, linebacker; Eric Andrade and Vincent Warren, wide receivers, and Derrick Thomas, fullback. NEW ORLEANS (NFC) - Released Paul Jurgensen, wide receiver; Florian Kempf, kicker; Tim McCabe, linebacker; Tony Stephens, nose tackle, and Ken Kaplan, offensive lineman. PHOENIX (NFC) - Signed Vai Sikahema, kick returner, to a two-year contract. WASHINGTON (NFC) - Waived Tim Jessie, running back; Kent Tramel, defensive tackle; Kurt Koch, defensive end; Doug Robison, punter; Jack Stanley, quarterback. Placed Dan Benish, defensive tackle, on injured reserve. COLLEGES METRO ATLANTIC ATHLETIC CONFERENCE - Named Richard Ensor as commissioner. MISSOURI - Named Darroll Gatson as men's assistant track coach. SOUTHERN METHODIST - Named Dave Wollman as head men's and women's track and field coach. WISCONSIN-OSHKOSH - Named Tom Lechnir as baseball coach.

title: IGX Is Acquired For $150 Million
description: The A. B. Dick Company said it had bought the privately held IGX Corporation for about $150 million. A B Dick, the Chicago-based subsidiary of the General Electric Company P.L.C. of Britain, makes office equipment, including offset duplicating machines and mimeograph and microfiche products. IGX, based in Waltham, Mass., was formed in the 1986 leveraged buyout of the Itek Graphix Corporation. IGX supplies graphic arts products under the Itek name.

title: K mart Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
GEORGE MICHAEL CONCERT
description: Behind his stubble, his black leather jacket, his dangling-crucifix earring and his pirate-style head scarf, George Michael - or the character he plays in his songs - is the kind of guy most teen-age girls could bring home to meet the folks. In a way, many of them have; his album ''Faith'' has sold nearly five million copies, and screams and shrieks greeted almost every move when he performed Sunday at Madison Square Garden, where he opened a sold-out three-night stand. As he has been since he led the British pop group Wham, Mr. Michael is still a teen idol, although he doesn't seem thrilled at the idea; early in the concert, he asked the audience to be quiet during ballads.

title: Estonians Are Told of the Secret Hitler-Stalin Pact

title: The Stubborn Facts of Trade
description: President Reagan sized up the nation's economy the other night with a recitation of rosy but incomplete facts. ''Facts are stubborn things,'' he said at the Republican Convention. Indeed: Barely 10 hours later, the Government reported that the trade deficit had worsened in June. This nagging negative is one stubborn fact that Mr. Reagan didn't even mention. Ignoring it won't make it go away.

title: Scarfs, Natty and Cool
description: ALL it takes is a little dexterity and some motivation - hot, sticky weather, for example, which makes for hot, sticky hair. People with even slightly longish hair are finding that scarfs 12 or 17 inches square pull it all together in style. The scarfs, in solids, tiny polka dots or paisley, are wrapped around ponytails, braids and chignons. At South Street Seaport, one young woman chose clean, cool lines, tightly wrapping her ponytail into a showhorse's tail. Others prefer to trip the light romantic, like a couple seen in SoHo with loosely bound hair and scarfs of fluffy black chiffon.

title: The Parties on the Issues
description: Excerpts from the party platforms. REPUBLICANS - ABORTION: ''The unborn child has a fundamental individual right to life which cannot be infringed.'' DEMOCRATS - ABORTION: ''The fundamental right of reproductive choice should be guaranteed regardless of ability to pay.'' REPUBLICANS - MINIMUM WAGE: ''As an alternative to inflationary -and job-destroying - increases in the minimum wage, we will work to boost the incomes of the working poor through the earned income tax credit . . .'' DEMOCRATS - MINIMUM WAGE: The party supports ''an indexed minimum wage that can help lift and keep families out of poverty . . .'' REPUBLICANS - CHILD CARE: ''In returning to our traditional commitment to children, the Republican Party proposes a radically different approach: establish a toddler tax credit for pre-school children as proposed by Vice President Bush, available to all families of modest means, to help them support and care for their children in a manner best suited to their families' values and traditions . . .'' DEMOCRATS - CHILD CARE: ''We believe that Government should set the standard in recognizing that worker productivity is enhanced . . . by major increases in assistance making child care more available and affordable to low and middle income families, helping states build a strong child care infrastructure, setting minimum standards for health, safety and quality . . . .'' REPUBLICANS - AIDS: ''Those who suffer from AIDS, their families and the men and women of medicine who care for the afflicted deserve our compassion and help . . . . We must not only marshal our scientific resources against AIDS, but must also protect those who do not have the disease. In this regard, eduation plays a critical role. AIDS education should emphasize that abstinence from drug abuse and sexual activity outside of marriage is the safest way to avoid infection with the AIDS virus. DEMOCRATS - AIDS: ''The HIV/AIDS epidemic is an unprecedented public health emergency requiring increased support for accelerated research on, and expedited F.D.A. approval of, treatments and vaccines, comprehensive education and prevention, compassionate patient care, adoption of the public health community consensus on voluntary and confidential testing and counseling, and protection of the civil rights of those suffering from AIDS or AIDS-related complex or testing positive for the HIV antibody.'' REPUBLICANS - BUDGET, TAXES: ''We oppose any attempts to increase taxes . . . . We will reduce to 15 percent the tax rates for long-term capital gains . . . . We call for a flexible freeze on current Government spending . . . . We call for a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution . . . .'' DEMOCRATS - BUDGET, TAXES: ''We believe that it is time for America to meet the challenge to change priorities after eight years of devastating Republican policies . . . to reinvest in its people within a strong commitment to fiscal responsibility . . . . Investing in America and reducing the deficit requires that the wealthy and corporations pay their fair share and that we restrain Pentagon spending.'' REPUBLICANS - SOUTH AFRICA: ''Republicans deplore the apartheid system of South Africa and consider it morally repugnant . . . . We believe firmly that one element in the evolution of black political progress must be black economic progress; actions designed to pressure the government of South Africa must not have the effect of adversely affecting the rising aspirations and achievements of black South African entrepreneurs and workers and their families.'' DEMOCRATS - SOUTH AFRICA: ''We believe that the time has come to end all vestiges of the failed policy of constructive engagement, to declare South Africa a terrorist state, to impose comprehensive sanctions upon its economy, to lead the international community in participation in these actions, and to determine a date certain by which United States corporationss must leave South Africa. REPUBLICANS - SOVIET UNION: ''Republicans are proud that it was a Republican President who extended freedom's hand and message to the Soviet Union. It will be a new Republican President who can best build on that progress, ever cautious of Communism's long history of expansionism and false promises. We are prepared to embrace real reform, but we will not leave America unprepared should reform prove illusory.'' DEMOCRATS - SOVIET UNION: ''We believe in . . . maintaining a stable nuclear deterrent sufficient to counter any Soviet threat . . . standing up to any American adversaries whenever necessary and sitting down with them whenever possible . . . testing the intentions of the new Soviet leaders about arms control, emigration, human rights and other issues . . .'' REPUBLICANS - MIDDLE EAST: ''The foundation of our policy in the Middle East has been and must remain the promotion of a stable and lasting peace, recognizing our moral and strategic relationship wtih Israel . . . We oppose the creation of an independent Palestinian state; its establishment is inimical to the security interests of Israel, Jordan and the U.S.'' DEMOCRATS - MIDDLE EAST: ''. . . This country, maintaining the special relationship with Israel founded upon mutually shared values and strategic interests, should provide new leadership to deliver the promise of peace and security through negotiations that has been held out to Israel and its neighbors by the Camp David accords . . .''

description: FOR more than four years, the merchandise trade deficit has shaken the nation's economy, even helping to cause the stock market crash last fall. Only now are the huge monthly deficits starting to shrink, running well below last year's pace despite a rise in June.

Article 592788 -- No Title
description: A maintenance man and his wife today claimed a record $26 million lottery jackpot with a ticket they said they kept on the family Bible. ''So I'd advise everybody to say your prayers,'' said Marvin Davidheiser of Brandon, Fla. ''You don't win it just on picking the numbers.'' The Florida Lotto jackpot will pay Mr. Davidheiser and his wife, Emily, about $940,000 a year, after taxes, for the next 20 years. The couple declined to give their ages.

title: EATING WELL
description: WITHIN the last decade, the shelves in health-food stores have come to look more like the shelves in supermarkets with their packaged mixes, frozen dinners and frosted cakes. At the same time, supermarkets have been filling their shelves with products labeled ''natural,'' ''no preservatives'' or ''low salt.'' For a while it seemed as if supermarkets were doing such a good job of pre-empting the health-food stores that many of the latter were being forced out of business.

title: Virginia Is for Lovers of the Local Fare
description: IN the food world, the adjective ''local'' has taken on the cachet once reserved for ''imported.''

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Chris Evert says she may retire this year if she wins another major event. In an interview published in the September issue of Esquire magazine, the 33-year-old Evert said, ''I'm going to play out the year. If I won a big one this year, I would probably retire at the end of it. And if I don't, I may still retire.'' . . . Jack Nicklaus, who has won a record 18 professional golf titles, says he is not sure whether he wants to continue playing. The 48-year-old Nicklaus has cut back his playing schedule in the last two years, but said he is not satisfied with the results. ''I'm not playing as well as I should, and I don't like it,'' said Nicklaus. ''I don't like it at all.'' Nicklaus has missed the cut in four of eight starts this year. . . . Gary Grant, a guard and the 15th player chosen in the N.B.A. draft in June, has signed a multiyear contract with the Los Angeles Clippers. The former Michigan standout was selected by the Seattle SuperSonics and then acquired by the Clippers in a draft-day trade. . . . Clarissa Davis, an all-America forward from the University of Texas, has left the United States women's Olympic basketball team because of an injured left knee. She suffered the injury last December in a game against Rutgers and missed the rest of the season. Fourteen players remain on the Olympic team roster. Two must be cut.(AP)

Jaafar Hussein, the governor of Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara, said that too many people had been issuing bad checks. Currently, anyone issuing bad checks is fined 100 ringgits, about $37, a check.

Over the next few months, Hechinger said, it will sell about half of the leases because of the stores' proximity to existing Hechinger outlets.

title: Review/Concert; Masur Leads Israel Philharmonic
description: The Israel Philharmonic led by Kurt Masur, the East German maestro, is making two guest appearances with the Mostly Mozart Festival at Avery Fisher Hall this summer, providing big-orchestra sumptuousness for a festival audience that usually gets by with chamber orchestra forces or less. The first concert, devoted to Mendelssohn and Beethoven, took place Monday night, and the second, an all-Haydn bill with Heinrich Schiff, the cellist, is scheduled for this coming Monday.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Day for Remembering
description: On Sept. 2, members of about 40 American families will gather at the Washington Cathedral for a memorial service to commemorate victims of the shooting down of Korean Airlines Flight 007 by a Soviet fighter plane five years ago. Shirley Yoo, a 16-year-old pianist from the Pittsburgh area whose father was on the downed plane, will play at the interfaith service.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis 3 Are Upset, but Connors Gains: Third-seeded Jimmy Connors advanced to the second round, but three other seeded players were beaten yesterday in the first round of the $602,500 Association of Tennis Professionals Championship at the Jack Nicklaus Sports Center in Mason, Ohio. Connors defeated Dan Cassidy, 6-4, 6-1. But fifth-seeded Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia was beaten, 6-4, 7-6, by Joey Rive of Fort Lauderdale, Fla.; seventh-seeded Guillermo Perez-Roldan of Argentina was eliminated, 3-6, 6-1, 7-6, by Carl Limberger of Australia, and eighth-seeded Jonas Svensson of Sweden was defeated by Michael Chang of Placentia, Calif., 6-2, 7-5.(AP) Annacone Is Upset: Simon Youl of Australia upset third-seeded Paul Annacone of Knoxville, Tenn., 6-3, 6-3, yesterday in a first-round match in the $125,000 Mennen Cup championship in Livingston, N.J.(AP) Cycling Harris and McCormack Triumph: Madonna Harris began the women's stages of the Coors International Classic with a road-race victory yesterday, and Alan McCormack won the men's stage in Grand Junction, Colo. McCormack, riding for the Wheaties-Schwinn team, outsprinted Roy Knickman, of 7-Eleven, at the finish for the victory, with both riders timed in 2 minutes 58.28 seconds. Harris, riding for Celestial Seasonings, finished in 1:46.07.

title: Review/Film; 'The Wash,' an Exploring of Ties That Break and of Ties That Bind
description: A Japanese-American woman in her 60's, so average and middle-class she might have stepped out of a detergent commercial, glares at her stubborn, self-absorbed husband. With a controlled intensity that carries the weight of 40 years, she asks, ''Why don't you want me anymore?'' That emotionally honest moment at the center of ''The Wash'' is one of many powerful scenes that shape this story of an older couple's painful separation and funny new romances. Though set in a Japanese section of San Jose, Calif., the small-scale film is less about any ethnic community than it is about the confused feelings that arise when a woman whose generation is more apt to endure unhappy marriages than to rupture them finally changes her life.

title: Pakistan: At A Glance
description: Government Mohammad Zia ul-Haq came to power in a military coup in 1977, deposing Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, who was executed two years later. For much of General Zia's tenure, human rights groups criticized Pakistan for imprisoning citizens without trial. The press was also under censorship. After ending eight years of martial law in 1985, General Zia hoped to unify the country using religion -more than 90 percent of the roughly 100 million Pakistanis are Moslem - under a plan that, among other things, banned liquor and gambling. But much of the plan, including drastic punishment under religious law, was never carried out. Last May, General Zia dismissed his Prime Minister, Mohammad Khan Junejo, and Mr. Junejo's Cabinet, accusing the civilians of incompetence, corruption and indifference to Islam. Elections were scheduled Nov. 16, putting the main opposition figure, Benazir Bhutto, daughter of the late Prime Minister, at a disadvantage: She is pregnant and expects to give birth then. History

description: The largest water company in Nassau County asked its customers yesterday to begin voluntarily conserving water, which has been depleted by increased use and a lack of rainfall.

Drugs Taint All Aspects Of Life in Sunset Park
description: Shouting from third-story windows, huddled on grimy stoops and gathered at busy street corners, residents of the 5900 block of Fourth Avenue in Brooklyn talked with resignation yesterday about how drugs have overtaken their struggling community and about the death of an undercover narcotics police officer there on Tuesday.

title: School Board Counts Workers for Trims
description: Dr. Richard R. Green, the New York City Schools Chancellor, yesterday presented the first phase of his plan to streamline the staff at Board of Education headquarters, the most significant element of which may have been finding out exactly how many are supposed to work there.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; Nerud Prescription: Hay, Oats, Water
description: The programs at most American race tracks outside New York's have become cluttered with little B's and L's over the last decade. Those letters, following a horse's name, are meant to indicate that he is being treated with either the anti-inflammatory Butazolidin (B) or the diuretic Lasix (L). Now it turns out that in Kentucky, even in the Kentucky Derby, those letters can stand for many things.

title: Rent Aid Is Enacted for Families With Children in Foster Care
description: Governor Cuomo has signed legislation authorizing up to $300 a month in rent subsidies for hundreds of families in which children have been forced to live in foster care because their parents cannot find adequate housing.

title: Baseball; Pirates Win by 2-1 In LaPoint's Debut
description: Dave LaPoint allowed three hits over seven innings in his Pittsburgh debut tonight, and Jose Lind and Tom Prince drove in runs following Atlanta errors as the Pirates beat the Braves, 2-1.

title: Parlux Fragrances reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and included a gain of $326,200 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Collegeville Journal; Will Success Spoil a Spiritual Haven?
description: For more than a century, St. John's Abbey has been known for its remote north woods peace. But this summer it is better known for a chronic shortage of parking.

title: U.S. Seeks Brain-Like Computers
description: The Defense Department's advanced research agency plans to increase significantly its financing for development of radically new kinds of computers that are based on how the brain works.

title: Bridge
description: When a bright, new international star clashes with one of the giants of yesteryear, the results are likely to be interesting. On the diagramed deal, from a tournament in Trouville, France, at the end of June, the West cards were held by Jaggy Shivdasani of Bombay, India, who made history last year by winning two major national team championships in his first appearance in the United States.

title: Puerto Rico Bonds
description: The Puerto Rico Highway Authority is issuing $287 million of highway revenue and refunding bonds in three tranches through Goldman, Sachs & Company. The notes have coupon rates from 6.50 percent for notes priced at par and due in 1990 to 8.125 percent for notes priced at 99.00 and due in 2013. The funds will be used to pay for the continuing long-range development of the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico's highway system. The notes are being backed by Highway Authority revenues from tolls, taxes and motor vehicle license fees.

title: Freedom to Conform?
description: The first real expression of George Bush's party leadership was the Republican platform. His people controlled the drafting; not a word could get in without his O.K. What does the result tell us about the Bush vision of America?

title: Harrowsmith Is Sold
description: Harrowsmith, a country-living magazine issued out of Vermont, is now part of Telemedia Inc. of Canada, which has acquired a majority interest in the bimonthly's parent, Camden House Publishing Inc. The cost of the transaction was not disclosed. Telemedia, the largest publisher of consumer publications in Canada, already owns the magazine's older Canadian counterpart, Harrowsmith Canada.

title: Ex-Broker Pleads Guilty
description: A former stockbroker charged in the insider trading scandal involving leaked copies of Business Week magazine pleaded guilty today, as expected, to one count of wire fraud.

description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend paid in January 1988. Latest periods earnings include the results of the resistor operations of Corning Glass Works, acquired in November 1987.

title: Market Place; Detroit's Papers: What Pact Means
description: THE Justice Department's decision last week to allow The Detroit Free Press and The Detroit News to merge their business operations promises to turn red ink into black if the arrangement is upheld by the courts. A Federal judge yesterday stayed the agreement until mid-September.

title: Birthday Parties
description: Photography's sesquicentennial - that is to say, its 150th anniversary - will be observed in 1989, and two Washington museums are using very different ways to begin marking it.

title: Life in the 30's
description: IN my paperback copy of the Bible, the Gospels occupy only 140 pages, a small percentage of the whole. Much of that is repetition: slightly different renderings of the Sermon on the Mount, the raising of Lazarus, the Last Supper, the Resurrection. So when you read them over, as I did yet again last week, you are struck by how little we really know about Jesus Christ, and how varied, in small ways, are the accounts of his life.

title: Introduction for L'eggs
description: In the introduction of L'eggs Sheer Elegance Silken Mist pantyhose, there are parts for Mistoffelees from the Broadway show ''Cats''; Sherrill Milnes as Don Giovanni, and Andre Soltner, the owner and chef at Lutece. All have been persuaded to play supporting roles to a woman decked out in a basic black dress and Silken Mist pantyhose for a night on the town. The multimillion-dollar campaign will begin with three print ads in September issues of fashion magazines, to be followed by national television spots in October. Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton is the agency.

title: Personal Health
description: With all the talk, concern and help available these days on sexual matters, it may be hard to believe that treatment is sought by only 5 percent of the more than 10 million men in this country who are chronically impotent.

title: Reynolds Smashes World Record for 400 Metters
description: Carl Lewis did tonight what he said he would do. He caught Ben Johnson in the last third of a 100-meter race to win their only confrontation this year before the Seoul Olympics. Their duel, however, was overshadowed by Butch Reynolds, who smashed one of the oldest records in track.

title: In Dual-Faith Families Children Sturggle For a Spiritual Home
description: MICHAEL LERNER'S father was Jewish and his mother was Episcopal. In the home of his youth, both faiths were practiced at various times, he says, and there was little conflict over religion. But as an adult, he found the two faiths at odds. Rather than embrace either, he turned to the spiritual tradition of yoga, studying with the Hindu teacher Swami Satchidananda.

title: Warrantech Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The deferred revenue to be recognized in the future periods is $691,521, compared to $61,986 a year ago. The share earnings for each first quarter are less than 1 cent a share. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Pakistan After Zia
description: The catch phrases about Pakistan's President, Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, were largely correct. He was a strong man, a devout Moslem certain it was his mission to impose unity on a fractious country. He brooked no rivals, groomed no heirs. His death at 64 in a still-unexplained air accident leaves a vacuum that could invite turmoil, even intervention by meddlesome neighbors.

title: 2 Groups Fight Over Montana Water
description: Extremely low river levels brought on by the West's prolonged drought have created a conflict between two groups over the region's lifeblood: ranchers who use water for irrigation and people in the tourism industry who want the water for streams to sustain trout populations.

description: A passenger train traveling from Leningrad to Moscow derailed and burst into flames on Tuesday, killing 22 people, including children, and leaving 107 injured, the official Soviet press agency Tass reported today.

Lox on Both Their Houses
description: They tell the story of the frontier town that had no lawyer, so they sent East for one. He set up shop, but there were no clients. He was about to head home when the town fathers got a bright idea. They brought in another lawyer. Suddenly, there was more than enough business for both. Lawyers generate conflict - despite new-fangled law school courses in dispute resolution.

title: Fixing Wobbly Chairs
description: LEAD: Chairs that stand on uneven floors eventually adapt to them and do not wobble. This is because chair joints give way under pressure from the weight of occupants, with the weakest joint the first to feel the strain; others follow, until the chair settles down comfortably on all four legs.

title: Promise of Deregulation Proved Tough to Keep
description: When President Reagan moved into the White House in 1981, he promised to cut through the ''vast web'' of Government regulations to make life easier for Americans, and, in a speech Monday, he claimed victory on this front.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Robbie Bosco, the former Brigham Young University and Green Bay Packer quarterback, has been named quarterback coach at Idaho State University, the head coach, Garth Hall, said yesterday. Bosco, who was cut from the Packers' roster this week after struggling with recurring shoulder injuries, will assume his coaching duties immediately. Hall, who is beginning his first season at Idaho State, coached Bosco as an assistant at B.Y.U. in 1984 when the Cougars went 13-0 and won the national collegiate football championship. . . . Steve Palermo, one of the American League's top-rated umpires, returned to work Tuesday night after a three-and-a-half-month absence because of an illness that left him chronically tired. . . . Ed Kelly stepped down as head coach of the New Jersey Eagles of the American Soccer League yesterday because of commuting problems, the team said. Kelly guided the Eagles (15-5) to a playoff berth in his first season as coach, but the team was eliminated in the opening round of the playoffs this past weekend by the Washington Diplomats. Kelly's commuting problems began this summer when he became the head soccer coach at Boston College and had to travel from Boston to New Jersey for games and practices.(AP)

title: Komatsu, Dresser In Joint Venture
description: Komatsu Ltd., the largest construction machinery manufacturer in Japan, and Dresser Industries, a leading oilfield service company in the United States, have signed a joint venture agreement. A Komatsu spokesman, Takashi Matsumura, said the joint company would make and sell construction machinery in the United States, Canada and Latin America, The Komatsu Dresser Company, equally owned by the two parents, will be based in the Chicago suburb of Libertyville, Ill. It will begin operations Sept. 1. Mr. Matsumura said the company plans to hire 5,000 workers there and at eight plants in the United States, Canada and Brazil.

title: Maxicare Cuts Off Coverage in Utah
description: Maxicare of Utah Inc. has announced its withdrawal from Utah, leaving 20,000 health-care subscribers uninsured. Harold C. Yancey, Utah's commissioner of insurance, said he hoped health-care providers would honor Maxicare contracts until the state could act to fill the vacuum left by the company's sudden departure. Maxicare of Utah, which operated under the national umbrella of Maxicare Health Plans Inc., had provided coverage in the state since 1984.

title: Nicaraguan Socialists Move Toward Center
description: The Nicaraguan Socialist Party, whose leaders have been articulate proponents of Marxism here for decades, has begun shifting its official ideology toward European-style social democracy.

title: Directors of Scherer Postpone Vote Count in Proxy Fight
description: A proxy fight for control of the R. P. Scherer Corporation was left undecided at the annual shareholders meeting today when directors delayed the counting of votes until next Wednesday.

title: Barkley Arrested
description: Charles Barkley, the All Star forward of the Philadelphia 76ers, was arrested yesterday after the New Jersey State Police said they discovered a loaded handgun in his car while stopping him for speeding.

The share earnings and shares outstanding are in units.

title: Olympic Diving; Louganis Looks Beyond Pool
description: The splash of gray hair at his right temple provides one clue that life as Greg Louganis knows it may be changing after many years of diving excellence. Acknowledging the possibility he might not qualify for the United States Olympic team provides another.

title: The Quayle Questions
description: Vice President Bush faced the press in New Orleans yesterday and gave his most impressive performance of the 1988 campaign. Relaxed in manner, crisp in response, he controlled the session with an authority that seemed to announce: President Reagan's gone. I'm in charge of this party now. But still he could not fully dispel the questions surrounding his choice as running mate of the young man who stood somewhat awkwardly by his side, Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana.

title: Brooklyn Legislator Pleads Guilty To Hiding Source of Contributions
description: State Senator Martin Markowitz pleaded guilty yesterday to misdemeanor charges of illegally hiding the sources of $25,000 in political contributions to his unsuccessful 1985 campaign for Brooklyn borough president. He was fined $7,500 and sentenced to perform 75 hours of community service.

title: Review/Rock; Steve Winwood Offers Optimism
description: From its beginnings, rock-and-roll has promised that pleasure can be a kind of redemption. Steve Winwood brings that promise to the surface. His recent songs, most of them with lyrics by Will Jennings, proffer hope and self-help advice, urging listeners to roll with the bad times and seize the good ones. The music is built on piano and organ tones from hymns and gospel; verses describe an uncaring world in minor keys, followed by warm major chords when choruses bring optimistic tidings. At his Radio City Music Hall show on Monday night, the audience rose to its feet for the Winwood-Jennings song that could be a secular yuppie creed: ''While you see a chance, take it.''

title: Mostly, Maybe Wholly, Mozart: Premiere of a Long-Lost Work

title: British Bank Has Profit

Pretax profits for the six months to June 30 were $:156 million, or $265 million. In the comparable period last year, the company had a loss of $:224 million, or $381 million, because of problems with its third-world debt.

title: Review/Theater; Amid Chaos, a Martyr in El Salvador
description: The brief public life and assassination of Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero of El Salvador was nothing if not dramatic. But in ''El Martirio del Pastor'' (''The Pastor's Martyrdom''), the Costa Rican playwright Samuel Rovinski has created a play that is strong in rhetoric, but weak in character development. In the performance at the Public Theater as part of the Festival Latino, the National Theater Company of Costa Rica under Alfredo Catania's direction brings admirably disciplined energy to the piece, but the impression it leaves is of a political lecture.

description: Swiss and French investigators are stepping up their inquiry into a stock swindle that they say cost investors at least $80 million.

title: Anxiety Linked to Some Chest Pain Cases
description: People who complain of chest pain but who have no evidence of heart disease score higher on tests for anxiety, depression and other neurotic traits than do people with pain from genuine angina, a new study indicates.

title: Farmers Stock Up On Talks
description: The stock of Farmers Group Inc. rose $4.25 to close at $67.50 today in heavy over-the-counter trading amid optimism by investors that an end to the eight-month-long takeover battle with B.A.T. Industries is in sight.

title: 'Playground' of a Building Joins the Local Color of Venice, Calif.
description: ''There goes the neighborhood,'' proclaimed the billboard that announced Chiat/ Day's new temporary headquarters in Venice, Calif. As one walks down a bleak graffiti-splattered street past a congregation of Brobdingnagian motorcycles toward a yellow, orange, aqua, brown and forest green striped warehouse, it is not clear where this neighborhood is going. Or why Chiat/Day, a much-honored advertising agency with half a billion dollars in billings, has left a plush office in the Biltmore Hotel in downtown Los Angeles to set up shop in the former home of the L.A. Louver Drape Company.

title: Dalkon Shield Trust Fund Faces Appeal
description: Payments to women injured by the Dalkon Shield birth control device will be delayed while the settlement that established a $2.47 billion trust fund is appealed, lawyers involved in the case said yesterday.

title: Court Questioning Harsh in Yonkers Appeal
description: A Federal appeals panel subjected both sides in the Yonkers desegregation case to hard questioning yesterday as the city and four councilmen appealed a judge's contempt order against them. The panel then extended the suspension of fines against them until it issues a ruling.

title: More Ambulances Are Out of Service
description: Nine percent more New York City ambulances were out of service last week than in the previous week, despite Mayor Koch's decision to use the automotive shops of the Police and Sanitation Departments to help repair ambulances and return them to service, according to a city report.

title: Israel Steps Up Use of Force to Undercut Uprising
description: The Israeli Army has adopted a newly aggressive and pre-emptive approach to crushing the Palestinian uprising, Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin said in an interview today. But in its first few days, at least, the new policy seems only to have brought more violence.

title: Review/Concert; Mostly Mozart Ensemble
description: Following the Israel Philharmonic, Kurt Masur and Beethoven's Fifth Symphony on Monday, audiences at the Mostly Mozart festival on Tuesday and last night were offered another orchestra with another East German conductor with another early-19th-century Viennese Fifth.

title: Barrett Resources reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain from a tax loss carryforward of $16,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $135,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: Swaggart Figure Jailed
description: The woman who says she was involved in the Jimmy Swaggart sex scandal was jailed and fined $500 today for prostitution. The six-month sentence had nothing to do with the episode involving the television evangelist but stemmed instead from an unrelated arrest at a motel last Sept. 21.

title: Lincoln North Carolina Realty Fund reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
2 Giants in Foot-to-Foot Fight
description: When the season begins, the Giants will have only one place-kicker, but neither Raul Allegre, the proven veteran, nor Brandy Brownlee, the free-agent rookie, see themselves as being involved in a competition.

title: General Magnaplate Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $87,190 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change for both the quarter and year.

title: A Stone Carver Finds His Niche in Grottoes Old and New
description: NINE years ago, Simon Verity, a stone carver, visited Austria and came across a 17th-century grotto built for the Prince-Archbishop of Salzburg at Schloss Hellbrun. The grotto ''caught my imagination,'' Mr. Verity said. ''It had all sorts of aspects that intrigued me.''

title: People
description: * Peter Zamiska has been named senior vice president, associate creative director and head of the art department at Lavey/Wolff/Swift, a subsidiary of the Omnicom Group.

title: Meese Leaves With Praise and Respect
description: To the Editor:

title: Galagraph Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: The Japanese Get a Taste Of Burgundy
description: The Takashimaya Company, one of Japan's largest department-store chains, has agreed to acquire a one-third interest in the Societe Leroy, a Burgundy wine wholesaler and shipper that has exclusive rights to the distribution of Romanee-Conti, the most famous of all red Burgundies and probably the most expensive red wine in the world.

title: Comcast Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Currents; Decorator's Fabrics And Book
description: IT'S never been considered unusual for John Stefanidis, the London-based decorator, to design custom fabrics for his clients. Now Mr. Stefanidis has begun manufacturing cotton prints from his designs. They are available in his showroom at Unit 7, Chelsea Wharf, Lots Road, Chelsea, London SW10 0QJ; he plans to open a shop on Fulham Road by October.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Our vacation house has electric baseboard heat. In the large living room the heating element makes clicking and banging noises constantly. This is much less of a problem in the bedrooms, which are smaller, and no problem at all in the smallest rooms. Do you know if anything can be done to stop this noise? A. Usually these noises are caused by the expansion and contraction of the heating elements or their housings. It is probably more noticeable in the living room because the heating elements are longer and thus expand more when heated.

title: Federal Resources Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the increase in earnings and revenue in the periods is due to the acquisition of Kenyon Home Furnishings Ltd. in May 1988 and New Generation Inc. in June 1987, as well as continued strong performance at Mid-West Spring Manufacturing Co., which was acquired in late 1986.

title: 3 Given Long Prison Terms In the Slaying of a Witness
description: Calling them ''merchants of death'' who had executed a ''good citizen,'' a Queens judge yesterday gave maximum sentences to three men convicted of killing a 61-year-old crime witness.

title: International Power Machines Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Tuktoyaktuk Journal; Happy Days in Arctic (Unless You Sell Ice Cream)
description: Jean-Baptiste MacLeod is an exhausted man. Out here on Canada's Arctic shoreline, 2,500 miles northwest of his native Montreal, he has been working 18-hour days in an attempt to bolster the fortunes of the business he bought five years ago, the Hotel Tuk Inn.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We don't mind from time to time if we have to enforce our will, even if it means a confrontation in concrete ways.'' - Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel. [ A8:1. ]

title: SAFETY CONCERNS SHUT U.S. REACTOR
description: A Department of Energy reactor that produces fuel for nuclear bombs was shut down last night because of concern that its operators may have used unsafe procedures when they started up the plant a few days earlier.

title: Autodesk Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BRIEFS
description: * AMP Inc., Harrisburg, Pa., said shareholders of Matrix Science Corp. had approved a merger bid that would result in an exchange of stock valued at about $110 million.

title: Playboy Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included gains of $290,000 and $1,924,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year, respectively, and also included a reversal of a tax credit of $1,686,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $518,000 for year. c-Net income d-Included a loss of $16,000 and a gain of $389,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from discontinued operations and also included tax credits of $2,597,000 and $4,180,000 for the same periods, respectively.

title: Arista Investors reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Franklin Roosevelt Jr., 74, Ex-Congressman, Dies
description: Franklin Delano Roosevelt Jr., a former United States Representative from New York and a son of the 32d President of the United States, died of lung cancer yesterday, his 74th birthday, at Vassar Brothers Hospital in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. He lived in Millbrook, N.Y., and Manhattan.

title: Treasury Prices Little Changed
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed in very sluggish trading yesterday, as market participants struggled to drum up business on a largely eventless day. Dealers said that activity was likely to remain in the doldrums for the next several sessions at least.

title: Tiffany & Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $644,000 for both periods from the writeoff of deferred financing costs resulting from the early repayment of the company's long-term debt. The company said it had a 25 percent comparable store sales increase for Tiffany's U.S. stores in the latest second quarter.

title: Currents; Frank Lloyd Wright, by Catalogue
description: Since Frank Lloyd Wright reproductions were first introduced in stores two years ago, the offerings of furniture and silver, fabrics and stained-glass windows have grown significantly.

title: Richard Glenn Gettell, College President, 76
description: Richard Glenn Gettell, former president of Mount Holyoke College, died of lung cancer Sunday at his home in Menlo Park, Calif. He was 76 years old.

title: Compumed Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income c-After gains on the settlement of disputed claims of $26,000 and $278,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: 1989 Trial in Apple Suit
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it had been notified that the trial date for its copyright-infringement suit against Microsoft Inc. and the Hewlett-Packard Company had been set nearly a year away.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-12

title: HDR Power Systems reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
It's No Masterpiece, But Yanks Take It
description: Beauty, as someone once said, is in the eye of the beholder. So to the Yankees, their 11-7 victory over the California Angels last night was a California sunset and a New York sunrise combined.

title: Continental Health Affiliates reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Rockwood Holding Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $556,000 and $1,591,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.
