description: b-After losses on disposal of discontinued operations of $359,000 and $735,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes a loss of $472,000 from discontinued operations. c-Includes extraordinary credits of $49,000 for the quarter and $510,000 for the year.

title: Rooney Hospitalized
description: Art Rooney Sr., founder of the Pittsburgh Steelers, was hospitalized for observation after suffering a slight dizzy spell last night, said Dan Edwards, a team spokesman.

title: Some in Seoul Finding Power Hard to Share
description: Four months into South Korea's relatively tranquil experiment with power-sharing, some members of the governing party are chafing at the unparalleled limits on their authority.

title: Professional Investors Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Rural Counties Are Still Gasping From California's Tax Revolt
description: The members of the Tehama County Board of Supervisors struggled in from the blistering 118-degree heat one recent morning, placed their straw cowboy hats over their hearts, recited the Pledge of Allegiance and sat down for another session of dismantling their county government.

title: Early Signs Of Success For Lear's
description: STARTING a magazine is a treacherous undertaking: only one in nine succeeds. And a new magazine for older readers certainly challenges the odds in a culture that idolizes youth.

title: Woman Accused of Hijacking Pleads Guilty to Lesser Crime
description: A woman accused of hijacking a jet to Cuba 19 years ago, using a gun and taking a 2-year-old child hostage, pleaded guilty yesterday to the least of the charges against her - that of interfering with the plane's crew.

title: Saxon Oil Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $276,261 and $351,843 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Fiat Plans to Add To Stake in Ferrari
description: Fiat S.p.A. said it plans to raise its 50 percent stake in Ferrari S.p.A. Fiat, which bought the stake in 1969, holds an option for the 40 percent owned by Enzo Ferrari, the company's founder, who died Sunday in Modena, Italy, at age 90.

title: Marking a March
description: With emphasis on eliminating poverty and unemployment and promoting world peace, more than 100,000 advocates of civil rights are expected to convene in Washington on Aug. 27 to mark the anniversary of the 1963 march on Washington.

title: College Basketball; Big East, A.C.C. Set Tournament for '89
description: Two of the nation's leading college basketball conferences, the Big East and the Atlantic Coast Conference, have agreed to join forces to solve one of the perennial problems of big-time college basketball - how to keep fans awake during the early portion of the season when major schools traditionally schedule pushover opponents.

title: Construction Of Homes Up; Permits Drop
description: Housing construction climbed 2.4 percent in July, but building permits for future construction fell at the sharpest rate since January.

title: At New Zoo, A Menagerie Of Plantings
description: IS it possible to miss the fauna for the flora? In the new Central Park Zoo, where bobbing sea lions send waves over the side of their glass pool, exuberant new plantings are giving these zoo favorites some serious competition. Brilliant pink-petaled coneflowers, bright purple asters and silvery gray Russian sage vie for the visitor's attention in one of the most luxuriant public gardens this side of Great Britain. No zoo-farer should resist savoring this masterly blend of perennials, annuals and shrubs ''Only one clump of Nicotiana was trampled by opening-day reporters,'' Lynden B. Miller said with relief last week as she scanned the 4,000 square feet of formal beds she had created. Mrs. Miller, a professional garden designer, was hired two years ago by the zoo architects, Kevin Roche John Dinkeloo & Associates, to redo the landscaping of the pool area, known offically as the Central Garden. ''There were formal plantings originally,'' said Kevin Roche, a partner in the firm, ''and I think the garden is important to help integrate the zoo with the park.'' The $100,000 needed for the plants and installation was provided by the Wallace Fund, established by DeWitt and Lila Wallace, founders of Reader's Digest. Planting began in

title: A Tale of Two Cities
description: On a visit earlier this month to Moscow, home of Russia's czars, Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci couldn't altogether escape the procurement scandal that has gripped the Pentagon this summer.

title: Consolidated Imaging Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a pretax gain of $172,668 for the settlement of a claim against a manufacturing of one of the company's mobile ct units. Share earnings figures reflect a 6-for-1 reverse stock split as of June 1988.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the Neiman-Marcus Group misstated the new position of Allen I. Questrom. He was appointed president and chief executive of Neiman-Marcus stores, the main division of the group.

title: Adirondack Film Maker Seeks Big-City Success
description: Fred G. Sullivan, his wife, Polly, and their four children hope that Friday is the hottest day of the year in New York City. They hope that the air-conditioning at every triplex and sixplex movie theater in Manhattan goes on the blink.

title: Inamed Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Editorial Notebook; Still Debating Robert Moses
description: Robert Moses was a great man and Robert Caro is a fine writer whose book about Moses, ''The Power Broker,'' would have been even better if the author had more sense of history.

title: Chemists Challenge a Theory on Life's Origin
description: A theory that life on earth may have originated at hot water vents in the ocean floor has been challenged by chemists who reported findings yesterday that organic compounds produced in such high-temperature environments would decompose almost as soon as they were made.

title: Eagles Owner And Wife Own John's 'Diver'
description: The owners of Jasper Johns's ''Diver,'' a work from a 1962 that was auctioned in May for a record $4.2 million, became known when the outsized painting, 7 1/2 feet high by 14 feet wide, went on view this week at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.

title: What if Nixon . . .
description: LEAD: When Edward Bennett Williams died last week, Washington lost its most controversial and admired trial lawyer. He had been consulted by Democratic and Republican Presidents. In 1985, I called him (I was working on my memoirs) to ask whether he thought Richard Nixon could have destroyed the White House tapes made after the Watergate break-in, gotten away with it and saved his

title: The Republicans in New Orleans: Convention Chronicle; A Nominee Is Chosen, And a New Verb Is Born
description: Everyone went Quayling today. To Quayle, the latest verb in the political lexicon, means to look for information about George Bush's little-known Vice-Presidential choice.

title: Workers Find Leak In an Electric Cable
description: Workers located a leak in an 11.6-mile electric cable between Connecticut and Long Island and planned to install temporary clamps to repair the problem, a spokesman for Northeast Utilities said yesterday.

title: American Exploration Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $1,694,000 from the cumulative effect of an acounting change.

title: Baseball Notebook; Yankees Pay Price For Failure to Trade
description: Make two columns. In one, place the names of Mike Boddicker, John Tudor and Dave LaPoint; in the other, place the names of the Baltimore Orioles, the Los Angeles Dodgers, the Pittsburgh Pirates, the Minnesota Twins and the Yankees. Now match the pitchers with their new teams.

title: Armtek Rejects Offer by Mark IV
description: The Armtek Corporation's board said it had unanimously rejected a hostile $40-a-share tender offer by Mark IV Industries. Armtek's directors told management to ''explore all available alternatives, including specific recapitalization proposals.''

title: Datamarine International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
Selling by 2 Central Banks Fails to Halt Dollar's Rise
description: The dollar moved higher yesterday despite two rounds of dollar sales by West Germany's Bundesbank and the Federal Reserve.

title: Atlantic Permanent Federal Savings & Loan Assn reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Suspect Charged in Death Of Officer Slain by Partner
description: A 23-year-old Brooklyn man on probation for a burglary conviction was in police custody yesterday, charged with second-degree manslaughter in the death of an undercover narcotics policeman who was accidentally shot by his partner.

title: American Real Estate Parters LP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $135,185 from early extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and 6 months, and gains on property transactions of $2,856,659 and $3,268,207 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes gains on property transactions of $460,478 for both the quarter and 6 months.

Panhandlers Inspired Luther to Greater Charity; Not Vietnam Vets
description: To the Editor:

title: Dionics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Year-ago quarter and 6-month results are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split payable Dec. 31, 1987.

title: Last Pontiac Cars Are Built in Pontiac
description: The last Pontiac produced in Pontiac by the General Motors Corporation has rolled off the assembly line, ending more than 60 years of automobile production in the city that lent its name to the car. The last two Fieros produced at the plant Tuesday were turned over to two workers who won raffles. They were among the 1,400 G.M. employees placed on indefinite layoff with the plant closing.

title: Firecom Inc reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: The company said the latest year includes a full year of the Auth Co. operations while the prior year included only nine months of this volume.

title: KEY RATES
China Issues Bonds
description: China's Communications Bank in Singapore issued $100 million of five-year bonds denominated in United States dollars, China's official press agency reported yesterday. The notes, which are the first the bank has issued abroad, have a yield of 9.375 percent. The bank said the issue would be used to back ''municipal construction and technological renovation.'' The agency said 23 banks and brokers from the United States, Europe and Asia had bought the bonds.

title: Man Who Killed an Intruder Is Fined on Weapons Charge
description: A Queens man who killed an intruder in his Flushing home and wounded another man with an unlicensed handgun last May was fined $500 during sentencing yesterday in State Supreme Court in Kew Gardens as a part of a plea arrangement.

title: Stocks Mixed in Slow Day; Dow Up 4.45
description: Stock prices were mixed yesterday in a lackluster session in which the Dow Jones industrial average rose 4.45 points to close at 2,025.96.

title: Writer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Town Hall Announces New Season Highlights
description: Appearances by Colleen Dewhurst, Barnard Hughes, Meredith Monk, Terence McNally and Ransom Wilson and a variety of recitals and debuts will be part of the 1988-89 season at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street.

title: Koch Hoping To Deodorize The Big Stink
description: For years it had been a big stink, the pungent odor of horse manure that dots southern sections of Central Park. Joggers step around it, bicyclists nose their wheels away from it, and the condominium dwellers looking out on it shut their windows to its smell.

title: Currents; Furniture Crafted Of Exotic Woods
description: IT is not surprising, given the proliferation of furniture makers in the last few years, that many talented women have emerged in the field. Two of them, Kristina Madsen and Rosanne Somerson, will show their latest work in an exhibition at the Pritam & Eames Gallery in East Hampton, L.I.

title: Parent & Child
description: THE ways children tease each other and the ways they respond to being teased can tell us much about their mental and emotional development. Beneath the taunting are clues to how well children can think in abstractions, and how well they understand the feelings and situations of others. Most important, child development experts say, teasing and being teased are ways for children to practice some of the social skills they will need as adults.

title: '88 TV Season: Mini-series and Films
description: For their fall television season, the networks will be relying more heavily on movies and mini-series than they have in recent years. Most series could not go into production until the writers' strike was settled, while a great many special movie presentations, based on scripts in the networks' possession before the strike began, have already been filmed.

title: Sara Lee Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
Data-Design Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said a change in its method of reporting depreciation on certain equipment as of July 1987 increased the latest year's net by $303,000, or 5 cents a share.

title: SFM Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE REPUBLICANS IN NEW ORLEANS: Man in the News; A Self-Effacing Nominee: George Herbert Walker Bush
description: Almost by definition, politicians are self-promoters. But George Bush's entire public career has been built on self-effacement, on loyalty, on his willingness to button his lip, on his readiness to play second or, if need be, even third banana.

title: Baron & Zaretsky Gets Ethan Allen Business
description: Baron & Zaretsky has announced that it has become the agency for Ethan Allen Inc., the furniture company owned by Interco. B.& Z. won the account a number of months ago but was prevented by the client from announcing it until the advertising was ready to run.

description: b-After extraordinary gains from debt retirement of $11,878 for the quarter and $202,170 for the 6 months. c-Net income and the 6 months includes a gain of $59,147 from debt retirement.

description: b-Net loss and includes a pretax charge of $12,000,000 for anticipated expenses, severance costs and writedowns.

description: b-Includes a $2,369,000 tax credit.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Collector of Companies Is Attracted to Formica
description: LEAD: Malcolm I. Glazer left school at the age of 15 to take over the family's watch-repair business after the death of his father. Since then, Mr. Glazer, a native of Rochester who is now 60, has quietly prospered, building a diverse empire run by his private company, the First Allied Corporation.

title: ABC Television Officer Named Chief of ESPN
description: Roger L. Werner, executive vice president of the ABC Television Network, was named president and chief executive today of ESPN Inc., the nation's largest cable network. He succeeds J. William Grimes, who resigned from ESPN to take the same posts at Univision Holdings Inc., the Spanish-language television and broadcast network.

title: Today's Schedule
description: All times are Eastern daylight. 8 P.M.: Session begins. 8:25 P.M.: Nomination of Senator Dan Quayle for the Vice Presidency, by Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois. 9:25 P.M.: Acceptance speech by Mr. Quayle. 9:50 P.M.: Acceptance speech by George Bush. 10:30 P.M.: Convention adjourns. Television Coverage ABC: ''Good Morning America'': James A. Baker 3d, Bush campaign manager, 7:09 A.M.; Henry A. Kissinger, 7:17 A.M. CNN: Live coverage, 1 hour. 11 A.M. C-SPAN: Live coverage, 3 1/2 hours. 1 P.M. CNN, C-SPAN: Live coverage, evening session, 3 1/2 hours, 8 P.M. ABC, NBC: Live coverage, evening session, 2 hours. 9 P.M. CBS: Live coverage, evening session, 3 hours. 8 P.M. PBS: ''Convention Night in Review.'' 11 P.M.

title: What America Lost In A-Bombing Japan
description: To the Editor:

title: Rayonier Timberlands reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are in units. The net income represents partnership income.

title: Soviet Ministry Calls Untrue Izvestia Report of Book Purge
description: The Soviet Culture Ministry today angrily denied a report in the Government newspaper Izvestia that libraries have been ordered to get rid of political books published before Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to power.

title: Parker & Parsley reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HMG-Courtland Properties reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: Arnold L. Raphel: An Envoy of Deep Commitment
description: Arnold Lewis Raphel, the United States Ambassador to Pakistan who died today in a plane crash there, was frequently at the center of diplomatic crises in his 22-year career.

title: McCormick Takes Lead
description: Kelly McCormick, the silver medalist in the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics in the 3-meter springboard, led a field of 12 divers tonight through the preliminary round of the event in Olympic trials.

title: Yields Rise Significantly
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds increased significantly for the week ended yesterday, with short-term rates posting the biggest gains since last Oct. 7. The movement led analysts to predict more increases over the next year.

title: Review/Theater; Strindberg Tormented
description: In his perceptive biography of August Strindberg, Michael Meyer credits the playwright with pioneering ''the depiction of men and women driven by love, hatred, jealousy or a mixture of all three to that nightmare border country where hysteria abuts on madness.'' More than many writers, Strindberg derived his art directly from his own tortured life; anyone trying to write a play about him has to contend with that fact. That the playwright in this case is Mr. Meyer himself appears to deepen the difficulty.

title: 5,000 in Burma Reportedly Hold a Peaceful Rally
description: As many as 5,000 people rallied peacefully today in Rangoon, the Burmese capital, diplomats who witnessed the rally said. It was the largest demonstration since last week, when soldiers shot and killed hundreds of protesters.

title: Analog Devices Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Integra Systems reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a tax benefit of $592,000.

title: Getting Lights on Track
description: JACK ROSS, who started his track lighting business, Track by Jack, 15 years ago, thinks track lighting can be a smart choice for the home. ''You can view a wall of artwork without having to overcome the glare of a lamp,'' he said. He has found that people with young children like to get lamps off the floor. And if you have a small apartment, track lighting ''adds to the visual length and depth of a room,'' he said.

title: Ex-Lawmaker Denies Scandal
description: Former Representative Thomas B. Evans Jr. said today that Dan Quayle had no relationship with a lobbyist who prompted headlines when her affair with Mr. Evans was disclosed several years ago.

title:
Review/Dance;
Soviet Troupe's Homespun Spirit Wrapped in Shimmering Opulence
description: LEAD: A tumultuous welcome was accorded the Georgian State Dance Company at the end of the first half of its opening night performance on Tuesday at the Mark Hellinger Theater, where the Soviet folk dance company performs through Sept. 4 on its national tour. There were not just cheers but also screams and a standing ovation from the audience.

title: A Farm Team Hits Million Mark
description: The Buffalo Bisons, drawing crowds at a record pace, today became only the second minor league team to sell one million tickets in a season.

title: Rexworks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results are restated for an accounting change to record quarterly income tax provisions and credits and reflect non-recurring adjustments.

title: Irish Distillers Bid Withdrawn
description: A British consortium has agreed to drop its bid for Irish Distillers P.L.C. after the European Commission intervened, a spokesman for the commission said today.

title: REPUBLICANS ACCLAIM BUSH AS THEIR NEW LEADER
description: George Herbert Walker Bush, who has steadfastly served the Republican Party over more than two decades as Congressman, national chairman and Vice President, was nominated by its convention tonight for President of the United States.

title: Where To Learn All About Design
description: THIS fall will see a wide variety of courses, lectures and workshops about interior design, its history and techniques. These are a sampling of what will be offered. Interior Design

title: Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The Defense Department will sharply increase financing for new kinds of computers that are based on how the brain works. The commitment from the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency represents a big endorsement of such computers and is likely to speed their development. [ Page D1. ] Housing construction climbed 2.4 percent in July, but building permits for future construction fell sharply. Analysts said the report indicated that housing activity was heading lower. [ D4. ] The F.C.C. is expected to rule this week on whether A.T.&T. can offer Holiday Inns a special discount on long-distance. [ D3. ] COMPANIES The F.D.A. approved the marketing of Rogaine, a prescription drug for treating hair loss. Rogaine, whose key ingredient is minoxidil, is made by Upjohn. [ A1. ] Bergdorf Goodman is negotiating to open a second store, across the street at the former home of F.A.O. Schwarz. But it faces competition from Au Printemps and others. [ D1. ] Takashimaya will buy a third of Societe Leroy, in the first Japanese investment in the Burgundy wine region. The French shipper holds exclusive rights to distribute Romanee-Conti, probably the most expensive red wine in the world. [ D1. ] The partial merger of Detroit's newspapers has been temporarily blocked by a Federal judge. The joint operating agreement was to have taken effect today. [ D1. ] Some Dalkon Shield claimants will appeal the Robins settlement that established a $2.47 billion trust fund, delaying payments to women injured by the device. [ D5. ] Carnival Cruise Lines will buy Gotaas-Larsen's cruise division, including the world's largest liner, for $260 million. [ D2. ] A consortium's attempt to take over Irish Distillers was blocked by the European Commission. [ D4. ] Farmers Group stock rose $4.25, to $67.50, amid optimism by investors that a takeover battle with B.A.T. is in sight. [ D7. ] A proxy fight at Scherer was left undecided at the annual shareholders meeting when directors put off counting the votes. [ D4. ] Varo received a revised offer of $22 a share, or about $90 million, from United Scientific, a London company. [ D4. ] Roger L. Werner was named chief executive of ESPN. The ABC executive replaces J. William Grimes, who resigned to head Univision Holdings, the Spanish-language network. [ D20. ] INTERNATIONAL Swiss and French investigators are stepping up their inquiry into a stock swindle that they say has cost investors at least $80 million and involved a half-dozen firms. [ D5. ] MARKETS Stock prices were mixed in a lackluster session. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 4.45 points, to close at 2,025.96, after a last-minute rally. [ D8. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed in very sluggish trading. Dealers said they expected the doldrums to continue until consumer price numbers are released Tuesday. [ D14. ] The dollar moved higher despite dollar sales by West Germany's Bundesbank and the Federal Reserve. [ D16. ] Sugar futures prices sank below 10 cents a pound for the first time in two months, amid signs of rising world supplies. [ D16. ] Yields increased significantly on C.D.'s, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds. [ D17. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Charter Medical is entering a complex buyout agreement, and many people are not sure why. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] Knight-Ridder and Gannett stock prices have fallen even though the Government approved a joint operating agreement between their Detroit newspapers. Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: Seahawk Oil International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ambassador's Death Is the First Since '79
description: Arnold L. Raphel, the United States Ambassador to Pakistan who died in a plane crash there yesterday, was the first American Ambassador in nearly a decade to be killed while performing his duties.

title: Immucell Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Home Improvement
description: FURNITURE finishes blemished by scratches or stains can often be repaired relatively easily, provided the damage does not penetrate to the wood beneath. Success lies in using the gentlest methods possible in making the necessary repairs.

title: Hughes Supply Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Sports of The Times; The Gastineau Watch
description: THE large man - 6 feet 5 inches, 275 pounds of earnest muscle -entered the Kennedy Airport Cafeteria. He wore a wavy mane that flowed over his shoulders and a black shirt open to a bristly chest and pleated gray slacks and black loafers unencumbered with hosiery and held a plastic bag that read ''I H NY'' and was without his 6-foot-2-inch fiancee, who has caused such a stir with him in recent times. He noticed through tinted glasses that the man ahead of him had ordered ham and egg on a croissant.

title: In Rumania, Razing All Ethnic Identity
description: To the Editor:

title: Enscor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: SECOND COAL MINE STRUCK IN POLAND
description: A strike in Poland's coalfields widened today, after several hundred miners occupied a second mine, refusing to work.

title: Talking Deals; Charter Medical's Buyout Strategy
description: UNLIKE many other companies that go deeply in debt in leveraged buyouts, the Charter Medical Corporation is in no danger of a hostile takeover. Nor is its chief executive thirsting for greater control. After all, William A. Fickling, Charter's chairman and chief executive, already commands 75 percent of the voting shares.

title: Teknowledge Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an income tax benefit of $48,000 and an extraordinary charge of $43,000. Latest year results include a $5.8 million restructuring charge.

title: Prime Motor Inns Inc reports earnings for
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $77,000. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $641,000 and $3,330,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Revenue for all periods excludes revenue from discontinued operations.

title: The Republicans in New Orleans; In Congress, Neither Loafer nor Leader
description: Vice President Bush's selection of Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana on Tuesday as his running mate initially drew high marks for political boldness, but a more measured debate has since begun over the 41-year-old Senator's qualifications and standing in Congress.

title: Staging Fights Is a Full-Time Job
description: A ragged soldier, his battered wooden prop sword extended, stalks his adversary.

title: U.S. General Among Dead
description: Brig. Gen. Herbert M. Wassom, who died today in the air crash that killed Pakistan's President, was named the senior American defense representative to Pakistan in July 1987.

title: Wavetech Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Quayle's Speech: Winning 'One for America's Future'
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of Senator Dan Quayle's speech accepting the Republican nomination for Vice President last night in New Orleans, as recorded by The New York Times: I accept your nomination for Vice President of the United States of America. Just -just think - 82 days from now George Bush and I are going to win one for you - win one for America's future, and yes, win one for the Gipper.

title: SCI Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TSR Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Anglo Energy Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $26,704,000 from the company's Chapter 11 reorganization for both the quarter and 9 months, includes pretax reorganization expenses of $231,000 and $896,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the quarter also includes a gain of $2,390,000 on the sale of assets and the 9-month also includes an $8,436,000 of pretax interest expense and amortization of discount on secured income notes. c-Net loss Year-ago quarter and 9-month results both include a provision of $58,255,000, recognizing the permanent impairment in the carrying value of certain of the company's equipment, and pretax interest expense and amortization of discount on secured income notes of $4,747,000 for the quarter and $13,946,000 for the 9 months.

title: Fewer Britons Lack Jobs
description: Unemployment in Britain in July was a seasonally adjusted 8.2 percent of the work force, down from 8.4 percent in June and 10.2 percent in July 1987, the Government said today. Last month's unemployment was estimated at 2.31 million people, down from 2.37 million in June and 2.87 million in July 1987.

title: NMR of America reports earnings for
Diner's Journal
description: Chinatown Cantonese

title: Elsinore Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Year-ago revenue includes interest income of $754,000 and $1,332,000 for the second quarter and 6 months, respectively, on a note receivable which was sold on June 29, 1987. The company said the latest and year-ago second quarters include additional provisions for estimated operating losses for New Jersey operations of $3.2 million and $3 million, respectively. The 1988 and 1987 figures do not include actual operating losses relating to Elsinore's New Jersey operations due to these provisions.

title: For P.L.O., a Government Doesn't Mean Negotiations
description: Although the Palestine Liberation Organization's leadership is reportedly close to a decision to accept Israel's existence and to declare a ''provisional Palestinian government,'' ' it is far from clear that such a move would produce any diplomatic breakthrough in the Middle East.

title: Of Arms and Words
description: The Defense Department's office of acronyms continues to work overtime, with new creations emerging from the continuing investigation into possible fraud and bribery in the letting of Pentagon contracts for weapons and equipment. In bidding for a contract, an arms maker is asked to make a ''best and final offer,'' a BAFO.

title: Modular Technology reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $285,000 for the quarter and $500,000 for the year. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $544,448 for the quarter and $655,689 for the year.

title: Air Wis Rejects Bid
description: Air Wis Services Inc., the big regional air carrier that has been repelling takeover attempts for the last year, rejected its third and latest offer. The company, whose Air Wisconsin subsidiary feeds United Airlines, said it was not for sale. On Tuesday, it announced that Cove Capital Associates Inc. had expressed interest in buying it at an unspecified price higher than its market value. Air Wis also said its board had voted to strengthen its defensive shareholder rights plan, but did not give details.

title: With Peace Near, Namibian Softens
description: Sam Nujoma, the rebel leader who may become leader of a free Namibia if American-brokered peace talks succeed, has begun to temper the fiery oratory that is his hallmark.

title: Hedging Plan For Aluminum
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has authorized a Federal power agency to buy option-like contracts to protect it against falling aluminum prices, officials of the agency, the Bonneville Power Administration, said today. The contracts would be bought from a broker - not acquired through trading.

title: Quintet at West End
description: Mickey Bass, a bassist, is leading a quintet, featuring Ralph Moore and Vincent Herring on saxophones, tonight and tomorrow at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway, at 114th Street (666-8750). Sets begin at 9, 10:30 P.M. and midnight and 1:15 A.M.; there is no fourth set on Saturday night. There is a $7 cover and a $7.50 miniumum.

title: KEY RATES
United Insurance Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a capital loss of $86,000 for the quarter and a capital gain of $37,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income d-Included capital gains of $229,000 and $424,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Honeybee Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest periods' losses included expenses of $727,000 for the quarter and $1,408,000 for the 6 months related to the purchase of a majority ownership of Honeybee by a wholly owned subsidiary of Spiegel Inc. as well as a proposed merger into the Spiegel subsidiary.

title: Spanish Group to Buy WEVD-FM
description: The Spanish Broadcasting System, which owns five Spanish-language radio stations in New York, Los Angeles and Miami, said yesterday that it planned to buy WEVD-FM in New York from the Forward Association.

title: Iraq Trying to Buy an Idled Steel Works in Texas
description: The USX Corporation wants to sell its idled Texas steel works to Iraq for more than $100 million. Iraq wants to take the plant apart and ship it home, where it would be reassembled and used to produce pipes for oil production and irrigation.

title: Maxco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $156,000 and an $838,000 loss on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net income and after net from discontinued operations of $38,000.

title: Lebanese Unable to Muster Quorum to Elect a President
description: The Lebanese Parliament failed to muster a quorum today to elect a new head of state, causing concern about a further decay of the political situation as President Amin Gemayel's six-year term nears an end.

title: Dukakis Woos Southern Blacks And Denounces U.S. Drug Policy
description: Michael S. Dukakis stumped through the South today, delivering his strongest appeal yet to black voters in a citadel of the civil rights movement. He also attacked his Republican opponents, accusing them of failure in the war on drugs and the space program.

title: Auctions
description: There's the aura of a Cecil B. DeMille spectacle in the news this week: furnishings, artworks, jewelry and memorabilia from the home of the fabled Hollywood producer will be auctioned by Christie's East in New York in October.

title: American Financial Enterrises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Collins Foods International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 24
description: The company said the decrease in revenue reflects the sale of the fast- food operations of Naugles Inc. in the fourth quarter of fiscal 1988.

title: Monarch Capital Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After capital gains of $30,000 for the quarter and capital losses of $98,000 for the 6 months. c-After capital gains of $768,000 for the quarter and $1,965,000 for the 6 months. The company said earnings were hurt by a $2.2 million loss from real estate operations during the latest quarter.

title: Richard Glenn Gettell, College President, 76
description: Richard Glenn Gettell, former president of Mount Holyoke College, died of lung cancer Sunday at his home in Menlo Park, Calif. He was 76 years old.

title: At Fulcrum of Conflict, Regulator of AIDS Drugs
description: Dr. Ellen C. Cooper has emerged as the most important gatekeeper for AIDS drugs in the nation, a role that has caught her in a spotlight of conflict that is rare for someone who is a mid-level manager at the Food and Drug Administration.

title: An Industry Overcome by the Heat
description: After two consecutive torrid summers, the air-conditioner industry finds itself confronted by an overwhelming clamor for its products that it cannot satisfy immediately.

title: Native Fijians Reclaim Their Island Nation; No Deaths in Coups
description: To the Editor:

title: SAVINGS UNITS SOLD IN A TEXAS RESCUE
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today that it had sold 12 insolvent savings and loan associations in Texas to an investment group headed by a Chicago banker and backed by a Texas steel company. The Government will provide an assistance package that could reach $1.3 billion over 10 years.

title: Victim Points To 2 Suspects In Arson Trial
description: Tearful at some times, combative at others, a former Queens homeowner described in court yesterday how his house had been firebombed twice after he complained to the police about neighborhood drug dealers. He pointed to two defendants on trial in the courtroom as among the three arsonists.

title: Bohemia Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a tax loss carryforward of $1,454,000.

title: Many Tried to Join Guard at War's Height
description: At the height of the Vietnam War, many Americans tried to enlist in the National Guard and the Reserves of the Army, Air Force and Marines as an alternative to being drafted into a combat unit.

title: Koch to Take Steps To Protect Horses
description: Reacting to an uproar over the treatment of carriage horses, Mayor Koch announced yesterday that the city would take steps to protect the animals during hot weather.

title: You Could Look It Up, but You'd Be Wrong
description: If the Encyclopaedia Britannica says there's a dam on the Rappahannock River that's 194 feet high and 8,850 feet long, it must be true, right? Wrong. The Salem Church Dam has existed since 1944 - but only on paper, as a proposal by the Army Corps of Engineers.

title: Complaint By Texas Air
description: The Texas Air Corporation said today that passengers had been illegally diverted from its flights by American Airlines and United Airlines, which it said had misused their computerized reservations systems.

title: Sports People; No Laughing Matter
description: John Michael Begley, the parking meter officer who accepted four baseball tickets from Pete Rose June 29 after ticketing the Cincinnati Reds' manager, has been given a two-day suspension without pay.

title: A Folk Singer Is Part of the Haydn Marathon
description: Jean Redpath will become the first folk singer to appear in the Mostly Mozart festival when she performs in its Haydn Marathon on Sunday at Avery Fisher Hall. Ms. Redpath, who is acknowledged internationally as the foremost interpreter of traditional Scottish music, will sing Haydn's Scottish Songs in afternoon and evening programs.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Brightening Outlook for Fox Network
description: EVEN after spending $3 billion for Triangle Publications, Rupert Murdoch is apparently not concerned about making ends meet. But if money worries should develop, he can take comfort in knowing that up-front sales for his Fox Television Network are up 30 percent this year. Industry experts say that means the network has already sold about $130 million in time.

title: Richard E. Paige, 83, Inventor and Musician
description: Richard E. Paige, an inventor, musician and author who held 170 patents, many of them in the packaging field, died of leukemia Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Mexico Plan on Oil Exports
description: Mexico is prepared to reduce its oil exports to help stabilize prices, but only if the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries develops a reasonable plan for similar action, Energy Minister Fernando Hiriart said today.

title: Seaport: Sprightly at 200, Mature at 5
description: The 200-year-old South Street Seaport has just turned 5 years old.

title: Horse Racing; Veitch Seeks a Million Double
description: Six 3-year-olds at Saratoga Race Track and 14 grass runners at Woodbine in Toronto will go to the post Saturday afternoon when $1 million races are run at different North American tracks on the same day for the first time in thoroughbred racing history.

title: Wilting Defense Can't Support John
description: The Yankees have lost six of their last nine games and 10 of their last 15. Their pitching has given up 43 earned runs in the last five games. Their hits come in the greatest numbers when they are superfluous, and often dry up altogether when they're most wanted.

title: Bantam Group Setting Up A Bargain-Book Division
description: The Bantam Doubleday Dell Publishing Group announced yesterday that it would establish a new division in the lucrative but increasingly competitive field of remainder and promotional books.

title: Elexis Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 447 money market mutual funds increased by $3 billion, to $268.56 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 125 institutional funds increased $575.3 million, to $69.22 billion. Assets of the 221 general purpose funds were up $1.66 billion, to $85.36 billion. The 101 broker-dealer funds rose $770.6 million, to $113.98 billion.

title: Academy Insurance Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,497,000 for the quarter and $2,491,000 for the 6 months, and tax credits of $1,648,000 and $2,290,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $142,000 and $59,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and tax credits of $493,000 for the quarter and $1,061,000 for the 6 months.

title: Workfare - It Isn't Work, It Isn't Fair
description: LEAD: The Senate's overwhelming passage of a welfare reform bill brought headlines trumpeting a new consensus born out of the magical concept of workfare. Yet, as the bill moves through Congressional conference committees, it still isn't clear whether requiring public assistance recipients to work off part of their grants does more harm than good.

title: Belden & Blake Energy reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Yankee Traders Triumph
description: Eyes were focused on the release of the Commerce Department's June balance-of-trade figures last Tuesday.

title: BUSH, IN ROUSING FINALE, VOWS MORE JOBS BUT NEVER A TAX RISE; BACKS QUAYLE DESPITE DISPUTE 1081>
description: Vice President Bush accepted the Republican Presidential nomination tonight with a pledge to ''keep America moving forward, always forward,'' but the beginning of his campaign was marred by an intense controversy swirling around his chosen running mate, Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana.

title: Native Fijians Reclaim Their Island Nation; Repression Increases
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about Women's Wear Daily incorrectly reported the status of a dispute between John B. Fairchild and the designers Hubert de Givenchy, Giorgio Armani and Bill Blass. Mr. Fairchild, chairman of the company that publishes the newspaper, currently permits coverage of those designers. In the past, he has banned them from its pages.

title: Gooden Throws Lightly
description: Dwight Gooden threw lightly on the sidelines for 10 minutes today and reported no problem with his right shoulder. But a more important test will come Friday in San Diego, when Gooden will pitch from the bullpen mound in the customary workout between regular starts.

title: Chavez Plans to End Fast Sunday at Mass
description: Cesar Chavez, the leader of the United Farm Workers, plans to end his fast Sunday at an outdoor mass at the union's compound here, a spokeswoman announced today.

title: Sturm, Ruger & Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Treasury Issues Climb Modestly
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes rose modestly in very light trading yesterday as traders marked time until the weekend.

title: Metal Resources reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Whirlpool To Control Philips Unit
description: The Whirlpool Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired a majority stake in the appliance business of the Dutch electronics company N. V. Philips. The jointly owned company will produce major household appliances for the international markets.

title: Public Service Enterprise Group reports earnings for Year to July 31
Materials Research Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-After tax credits of $421,000 for the quarter and $765,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: Trust Me, Folks
description: Two strange things took place at the Republican Convention, and they may tell us more than we care to know about American politics - and about ourselves too.

title: C-130 Hercules: A Workhorse in World Skies
description: Over the last 30 years, the Lockheed C-130 Hercules transport plane has been a workhorse in 60 nations, including the fleets of the United States Air Force, Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard.

title: Southern California Water Co reports earnings for 12mo June 30
description: b-Included a gain of $622,000, or 20 cents a share, from the sale of operating properties. c-After a $1,575,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: 2 Newspapers in Detroit Recall Laid-Off Workers
description: Scores of laid-off employees were recalled today by The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press after a Federal judge on Wednesday temporarily suspended a planned merger of all non-news operations at the newpapers.

title: William H. Phelps Jr. Dies at 85; Ornithologist and Conservationist
description: William H. Phelps Jr., an ornithologist, explorer and former trustee of the American Museum of Natural History, died of circulatory problems last Saturday at his home in Caracas, Venezuela. He was 85 years old.

title: Albany Impasse May Force 8 Health Agencies to Close
description: Eight independent agencies that monitor health-care needs and hospital services in New York State may close because of a dispute over state financing, state health officials and legislators said this week. The agency that covers New York City could be forced to close as early as next week.

title: GMI Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Reagan Signs Transition Bill
description: President Reagan signed a bill Wednesday that increases the amount of money for Presidential transitions, beginning with his, early next year. The amount for the incoming President and Vice President is increased from $2 million to $3.5 million and the amount for the outgoing President and Vice President goes from $1 million to $1.5 million. The money is for expenses ranging from finanacing transition teams to advising on policy and personnel for the incoming administration to costs of moving the outgoing administration out.

title: Native Fijians Reclaim Their Island Nation; Job for the Peace Corps
description: To the Editor:

title: Hostage Dies as German Drama Ends
description: A hostage was killed and two fleeing bank robbers were seriously hurt today when they were captured in a shoot-out with the police on a highway near here, ending a two-and-a-half-day ordeal for a busload of people held hostage.

title: Bush Makes a Choice
description: Even before questions began to surface about Senator Dan Quayle's National Guard service during the war in Vietnam, it could hardly be said that George Bush had made a conventional political choice that clearly bolstered his ticket, or that he had picked a running mate whose stature would enhance his own.

title: PAKISTAN SEEKING REASON FOR CRASH IN WHICH ZIA DIED
description: The body of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq was flown here this evening while investigators searched 330 miles away for the cause of the midair explosion and plane crash that killed him and the United States Ambassador on Wednesday.

title: George Bush's Gender Gap
description: At times this week, it has appeared that every third person at the Republican Convention is named Bush. Here is a daughter-in-law named Columba who was born in Mexico. There is a daughter nicknamed Doro who turned 29 yesterday. One son after another speaks out, at the microphone of one state delegation or another, on behalf of ''the finest father in America.'' Where have they come from all of a sudden?

title: Bear Stearns Deal In Dallas Realty
description: The Bear Stearns Companies said it would buy its second prominent part of the Dallas skyline, the 60-story First Interstate Bank Tower and adjacent property, for $167 million. Bear Stearns said it had organized an investment group to buy the angular, green-glass skyscraper and adjacent property from the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.

title: Sports People; Rooney Suffers Stroke
description: Art Rooney, the chairman and founder of the Pittsburgh Steelers, was in critical condition with a paralyzed upper right arm yesterday after suffering a stroke Wednesday. ''He's awake; he responded to questioning,'' said Dr. Theodore R. Gelet, a cardiologist who is Rooney's family physician. He said Rooney's prognosis was guarded.

title: Study Looks at Jets' Injuries
description: Professional football may be a hard-hitting contact sport, but at least as played by the Jets over the team's first 26 years, it may not have been quite as hazardous as has been assumed. And if one trend spotted by the team's physician, Dr. James A. Nicholas, continues, it may be safer still in the years ahead.

title: Helping Immigrants Obey the Law
description: The Southern California melting pot has cracks in it and immigrants who do not understand American laws are falling through.

title: China Plans to Revise Wage-Price System
description: Communist Party leaders have agreed on a five-year draft plan to revise China's system of prices and wages, the official New China News Agency said today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Hewlett-Packard Consolidates at Saatchi
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, which last week ended its four-year relationship with Leo Burnett USA, Chicago, on good terms, has decided to consolidate its advertising for computing products at its other main agency, Saatchi & Saatchi DFS/ Compton, San Francisco. The new business amounts to about $20 million; the amount of the entire account was not disclosed.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; March of Dimes Anniversary Project
description: People, Life and McCalls magazines are teaming up to offer advertisers a group-magazine buy for a joint special supplement called ''Our Children, Our Future.'' The 24-page section, commemorating the 50th anniversary of the March of Dimes Birth Defects Foundation, will appear in February and is expected to reach a circulation of 49 million.

title: Mediq Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,362,000 for the quarter and $4,563,000 for the 9 months; the 9 months also included an extraordinary tax benefit of $3,449,000. c-Net income d-After income from discontinued operations of $439,000 for the quarter and $641,000 for the 9 months. The year-ago periods' net from continuing operations included a $2,310,000 gain on the sale of stock.

title: T2 Medical Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings for the latest period reflect the company's initial public offering of 1,725,000 common shares completed in May and June.

title: Chemical Leaman Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a $1,572,347 charge for an accounting change. The company said the latest quarter and 6-month include a pre-tax non- recurring restructuring charge of $1,833,566.

title: Roy Rogers, Out to Lunch
description: The National School Lunch program has taken a few knocks from the Reagan Administration, but none as hard as handed out by the Marriott Corporation. Marriott, which owns the Roy Rogers fast food chain, thought to boost burger sales with a TV commercial that pokes fun at school lunchrooms. To the accompaniment of a tune, ''See You in September,'' actors dressed as cafeteria workers proffer trays of unattractive food to the camera.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Stephen Gardner, Stepher Felter and Marcus Kemp have been named senior vice presidents at Ammirati & Puris.

title: Sports People; Perry to Return
description: William (Refrigerator) Perry, who has missed the Chicago Bears' training camp to undergo treatment for an eating disorder, may rejoin the club for the season opener against Miami Sept. 4, Coach Mike Ditka said.

title: Pacific First Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a credit of $100,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Includes an extraordinary charge of $3,758,000. The company said first half net includes gains on sales of loans of $2.3 million this year and $23.1 million a year ago.

title: Jersey Self-Service Gasoline Ban Is Unconstitutional, Judge Rules
description: A Superior Court judge ruled today that New Jersey's 39-year-old law banning motorists from pumping their own gasoline is unconstitutional.

title: BTR Realty Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Foes of Zia: So Many, So Bitter
description: As speculation continued that the death of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan was caused by sabotage, Western scholars noted yesterday that the general had many opponents, both Pakistanis and foreigners, who might have felt they had reason to kill him.

title: Lawyer Ordered To Jail by Judge In Federal Trial
description: A Federal judge said yesterday that he had ordered the seven-day confinement of a defense lawyer for civil contempt of court and to ''make sure of her presence'' until the end of a narcotics and racketeering trial.

title: Purposely Flawed Shuttle Rocket Appears to Pass Crucial Test
description: The test firing of a purposely flawed booster rocket today appeared to be successful, removing a major obstacle to getting the space shuttle flying again, perhaps as early as next month, space agency officials said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addenda
description: * Carroll V. Dowden has set up Dowden Publishing Company, Saddle River, N.J., to publish single-sponsor and multi-advertiser magazines for health-care professionals.

title: Review/Theater; From Spain, a World of Fantasy Grounded in Folklore
description: ''Mariameneo, Mariameneo,'' the fantasy spectacle being staged through Sunday at the Public Theater by La Zaranda, a regional Spanish theater group, is an adventure in cultural crossings.

title: Review/Film; Freddy's Back, and His Disposition's No Better
description: The best job on Elm Street must be the undertaker's - business booms and is full of variety, thanks to endless deaths by special effects. The victims of Freddy Krueger are not simply slashed by the burned-to-death child murderer with the razor-clawed gloves who invades their dreams. In ''A Nightmare on Elm Street 4: The Dream Master,'' they are tortured by fire, water, earth and air. A woman burns, a man drowns in his waterbed, someone sinks into quicksand and several fly through the air. Where else would a young woman's arms fall off and be replaced by a bug's feelers, the better for her to be glued to death in a roach motel?

title: AMC Plans to Sell 605 Movie Theaters
description: AMC Entertainment Inc. said it plans to sell about 40 percent of its movie theater screens for about $200 million to New York-based TPI Enterprises Inc. The Kansas City-based movie theater chain, which owns almost 25 percent of TPI's stock, would manage the theaters, under the AMC name, and would continue to negotiate for their films.

title: A.T.&T. Price Cut
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it was reducing prices on three models in its line of I.B.M.-compatible computers by up to 28 percent in an effort to make the machines more competitive. A.T.&T. said it was reducing the prices of its 6286, 6312 and 6386 Workgroup Systems, with larger volume discounts. The price of an entry-level system based on the 32-bit 80386 microprocessor fell from $4,899 to $3,495.

title: Jewelry Salesman Held In Hit-and-Run Deaths
description: A Manhattan jewelry salesman was charged yesterday in the hit-and-run death of a young couple crossing West 23d Street on April 30.

title: An Ultimate Choice for the P.L.O.
description: Can the Palestine Liberation Organization step into the breach opened by King Hussein's official detachment from the West Bank and transform itself into an acceptable negotiating partner with Israel? Yes, if it renounces terrorism and explicitly recognizes Israel's right to exist as a Jewish state. No, if it offers less than that. And no as well, as far as some Israeli leaders are concerned, if it pushes too far and declares itself to be a provisional government.

title: Nicaragua Officials Allow Radio Station To Return to the Air
description: Nicaragua's Roman Catholic radio station, which was ordered shut last month, has been given permission to reopen, an Interior Ministry spokeswoman said today.

title: Sports of The Times; Still Living on the Line
description: SINCE losing both feet in a rocket explosion in Vietnam, Bill Demby has driven drag racers and learned to ski and taken up track and field. And as the television commercial graphically shows, with the help of a new device called a Seattle Foot, Demby can play basketball with the able-bodied. Same game. Same court. Same elbows. ''I'm still the last one to get picked for the game, but that's all right,'' Demby said. ''If they have nine, they can't play without me.''

title: Restaurants
description: The cast of dining spots along restaurant row in the Broadway theater district (West 46th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues) has changed dramatically in recent years. Once primarily a collection of family-run French bistros, it has become a medley that also features Italian, regional American and Oriental spots, some of which change identities as frequently as Broadway marquees.

title: Sports People; Round 4 for Leonard
description: In a news conference in Manhattan to confirm Nov. 7 as the date for his return to the ring, Sugar Ray Leonard said yesterday that he had something in common with Jason, the masked murderer in the ''Friday the 13th'' movies. ''We both keep coming back,'' he said.

title: Richfood Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to July 23
description: Year-ago figures are presented on a pro forma basis because the company converted to stock ownership in May 1988.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Health page on Aug. 4 about a new test to detect herpes viruses misstated the number of cases of blindness caused by the viruses. Herpes infections cause severe vision loss or blindness, usually just in one eye, in 10,000 to 20,000 people each year, according to Dr. Edmund C. Dunkel of the Eye Research Institute in Boston.

title: Curtice Burns Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 24
description: b-Includes a gain equal to 35 cents a share from the sale of franchises held by the company's national brands beverage division for both the quarter and year, gains of 8 cents a share and 27 cents a share for the quarter and year, respectively, from a more favorable tax rate, and a charge of 8 cents a share from the consolidation of the company's Michigan and New York pie filling and vegetable operations for both the quarter and year.

title: Achilles Head Called a Fake
description: A marble head of Achilles that was once regarded as one of the J. Paul Getty Museum's significant antiquities has been determined to be a fake, a museum spokeswoman said today.

title: PhoneMate Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: MAGAZINE EDITOR JAILED BY KENYA
description: The editor of a church magazine that has been critical of the Government's election practices has been sentenced to nine months in jail.

title: Seoul Journal; As Foes Meet, Old Longings Awake
description: Suddenly, Min Kyung Nam finds himself dreaming again about the home in the north he fled long ago.

title: Centocor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: Cuomo Signs a Bill Creating Parks Panel
description: Governor Cuomo signed legislation yesterday that forms a special commission to study whether the state should create a Hudson River Greenway, a chain of parks, open spaces and trails stretching from New York City to the Adirondacks.

title: Priest Seriously Injured In Robbery on 65th St.
description: The Rev. John Andrew of St. Thomas Church at 550 Park Avenue was seriously injured on Manhattan's East Side last when he was hit on the head and robbed by a man wielding a metal pipe, the police said.

title: Market Place; Upjohn Awaiting Rogaine Results
description: APPROVAL of Rogaine, the new drug for the treatment of hair loss in males, arrived at the right time for the Upjohn Company, which has seen sales of some of its best-selling drugs plummet as their patent protection expired.

title: Review/Art; Sculptors Make a Case For Expressionism
description: Among the few shows currently on view during these slow August days, two exhibitions devote space to works by sculptors who make persuasive cases for the vitality of expressionistic art.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Point-of-Purchase Magazine Sets Debut
description: P-O-P Times, a magazine devoted to the point-of-purchase industry, will bring out its first issue next month. The magazine, from Hoyt Publishing of Chicago, will be sent free to 15,000 people in marketing. Beginning in January, it will be issued bimonthly.

title: Transcipt of Bush Speech Accepting Nomination for President
description: Following is a transcript of Vice President Bush's speech accepting the Republican nomination for President last night in New Orleans, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Britain Holds Up Bid For Big Bread Maker
description: The British Government today stalled a $:1.7 billion ($2.87 billion) bid by Australia's biggest food company for the British bread company Ranks Hovis McDougall P.L.C.

title: Delta Is Planning Aircraft Purchase
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. hopes to place an order for new long-range aircraft by the end of the year, but it has not yet decided on the size and the type of plane, a Delta spokesman said. Jim Lundy, a spokesman for Atlanta-based Delta, made the comments after The Wall Street Journal had reported that the airline might order as much as $6 billion in new planes.

title: MMI Medical reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Britton Lee Inc., Los Gatos, Calif., a maker and distributor of computer hardware, appointed James B. Weil executive vice president for marketing and sales.

title: 2 in Westies Case Plead Not Guilty
description: After two years on the run, two suspected members of the Hell's Kitchen gang known as the Westies pleaded not guilty yesterday to murder and other charges.

Economic Scene; The Two Tickets: How They Differ
description: WITH the conventions out of the way and the Bush-Quayle and Dukakis-Bentsen tickets in place, the guessing game gets more serious as to what one slate or the other would mean for national economic policy.

title: Sports People; Holmes Under Scrutiny
description: Coach Darryl Rogers of the Detroit Lions said he is watching the veteran cornerback Jerry Holmes, who was signed after being released by the Jets, to determine what role, if any, he will play.

title: Lionel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a credit of $1,552,000 from an accounting change.

title: Review/Blues; Despair Dotted by Smiles
description: A performance by Bobby (Blue) Bland, the great rhythm-and-blues singer who's appearing through Sunday at the Blue Note (131 West Third Street), can be dizzying in its ironies. His songs hold the essence of desolation as he sketches misfortunes and betrayals in a voice that sounds as if it's been worn nearly threadbare through long suffering.

title: Japan in Appeal to Soviets
description: The Government asked the Soviet Union to scale down a planned military exercise in the Sea of Japan beginning Friday, Foreign Ministry officials said today. The Soviet Union earlier announced that it would conduct an artillery exercise in the Sea of Japan west of Hokkaido, Japan's northernmost island, starting Friday and lasting until Aug. 30. Japan expressed fears that the exercise could hurt fishermen operating near the exercise area.

description: Zimbabwean Pop

The company said results for the 1988 second quarter and 6-month include the operations of DFM Corp., which was acquired Sept. 1, 1987.

title: Botha Says He Is Seeking a Way To Permit the Release of Mandela
description: President P. W. Botha said today that he was trying to reach an agreement that would allow the release of Nelson R. Mandela, the imprisoned South African nationalist leader.

Legislator and Contractor: A Case of Mutual Benefit
description: Thirteen months ago, Representative Roy P. Dyson of Maryland visited the military electronics plant of the Unisys Corporation in Great Neck, L.I. The visit, he said later, was typical of those that members of the House Armed Services Committee make to the plants and offices of military contractors.

title: Berry Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Zenith Processor
description: Zenith Data Systems Corporation introduced a new multiprocessing computer that is based on as many as six Intel 80386 microprocessors operating simultaneously. The new multiprocessor was developed for the unit of the Zenith Electronics Corporation by Corollary Inc. of Irvine, Calif. Designed to run both the Unix and MS-DOS operating systems, the new computer is aimed at the market traditionally served by more expensive minicomputers. The computer is scheduled to be available during the first half of 1989. A spokesman said that the price of the system had not yet been determined, but that it would not be substantially less than current minicomputers.

title: Roy Rogers To Cancel Ad
description: Roy Rogers Restaurants, the roast-beef-and-burger chain, said yesterday that it would take off the air a television commercial that some school cafeteria workers had complained about.

title: Hard Rock Co-Founder Has Expansion Plans
description: Peter A. Morton, one of the co-founders of the original Hard Rock Cafe in London, has formed his own holding company and plans to export the noisy, perpetually crowded restaurant to Canada and Brazil.

title: For Children
description: Shown, Nature, Museums HERITAGE FESTIVAL, the 25th annual Huntington HIstorical Society Festival, with games, races, music, antique toys, quilts, furniture, international foods and exhibitions, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Sunday, rain or shine, at the Heckscher Ballfield, Madison Avenue at Sabbath Day Path, off Route 25 A, Huntington, L.I. Children, free; adults, $2. Information: (516) 427-7045. ''BEATRIX POTTER: ARTIST AND STORY-TELLER,'' an exhibition of the author and artist's drawings and letters and a recorded narration by Julie Andrews of ''The Tale of Beatrix Potter,'' at lunchtime. The exhibition is open from 10:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. today and tomorrow and 1 to 5 P.M. Sunday, the last day of the show, at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street. Suggested donations: children, students and the elderly, $1; others, $3. Information: 685-0610. ''SAMUEL'S GHOST,'' a story by Crossley-Holland told by Bob Barton and ''The Swineherd,'' a story by Hans Christian Andersen told by Kaye Lindauer, 11 A.M. tomorrow at the Andersen statue, near 72d Street and Fifth Avenue in Central Park. Free.

Kellogg in January 1988 and improved market demand in major product and service areas.

title: Legal Fees Set in One Texaco Case
description: Lawyers who had sought $9.5 million in fees for representing some Texaco Inc. shareholders during the company's bankruptcy proceedings were awarded $350,000 by a Federal judge yesterday.

title: B.A.T. Extends Lower Offer Only
description: B.A.T. Industries extended its $63-a-share hostile tender offer for Farmers Group Inc. until Wednesday, but failed to take any action on its $72-a-share, or $5 billion, offer, which expires Friday. B.A.T. made its higher bid conditional on the Los Angeles-based insurer's agreeing to a friendly merger. While Farmers has resisted overtures from the tobacco and financial services conglomerate since January, the companies held negotiations on a possible merger for the first time on Wednesday and resumed talks today. No information about the talks has been released.

title: First World Cheese reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax loss carryforwards of $33,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. The latest periods include results from the newly acquired Mountain Farm Inc.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Competence makes the trains run on time but doesn't know where they're going. The truth is, this election is about the beliefs we share, the values we honor, the principles we hold dear.'' - Vice President Bush. [ A15:1. ]

description: A 50-year-old woman was stabbed to death in her home here Wednesday morning, two days after a slaying in Dix Hills, 10 miles away.

title: Olympic Diving; Louganis Leads; Kimball In Sixth
description: Greg Louganis found himself in his accustomed place today, first, halfway through the 3-meter springboard competition at the United States Olympic diving trials. With his highest point total of the season, 722.88, he easily led the field of 12 into the final round Friday night.

description: Canadians waited 19 years to see a National Football League game in their country, but when the Jets and the Browns showed up tonight, they combined for only one touchdown.

description: Lawyers are no different from other homo sapiens in their aversion to being sued or, more peculiarly to their profession, to being charged with violations of professional ethics codes.

description: The Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said today that the Westinghouse Electric Corporation had agreed to pay $35 million to thousands of former employees in the settlement of an age discrimination case.

title: Bridge
description: An old saying has a bridge version that runs: ''A twitch in time saves nine contracts.'' A tiny twitch in the bidding can help the eventual declarer detect a bad break, even when the opponents have been silent.

description: Israel formally outlawed Palestinian ''popular committees'' today, saying the organizations had been helping run the eight-month uprising in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Tandy Net Up 28.8% in Period
description: The Tandy Corporation reported today that its earnings rose by 28.8 percent in the final quarter of its fiscal year from the period a year earlier.

title: After Zia, Maybe Bhutto - And Then What?
description: LEAD: The sudden death of President Zia ul-Haq, the graying soldier of Islam, has advanced Pakistan's political drama one more grim step. The President's legacy is a house divided. Now the military must decide, as civilian politicians must ponder, their role in politics. If the military agrees, finally, to abide by the Constitution and hold free and fair elections, Benazir Bhutto could be the likely winner.

title: For Albany Legislators, a Summer of Fits and Starts
description: The dog days of August have settled on the State Capitol, bringing brownouts that have darkened computer screens and prompted the cafeteria to serve such cold delicacies as cream of melon soup. The dim halls are empty, except for an occasional legislative staff member or bewildered tourist looking in vain for signs of democracy in action.

title: Free Park Concert
description: Christopher Keene is to lead the Long Island Philharmonic in a free concert at Heckscher State Park, Main Street at New York Avenue, Huntington, L.I., tomorrow evening at 8:30. The program is to include Rossini's Overture to ''La Gazza Ladra,'' Borodin's ''Polovtsian Dances,'' Handel's ''Water Music'' and Rimsky-Korsakov's ''Capriccio Espagnole.'' Information: (516) 293-2222.

description: The Speaker of the House, Jim Wright, will lead a Congressional delegation leaving today for Australia, a trip that will be governmental and reminiscent for the Speaker, all at the same time.
