Saturday Brass, Sunday
description: The Saturday Brass Quintet - Terry Szor and Scott McIntosh, trumpeters; Lawrence DiBello, horn player; Richard Kessler, trombonist, and Kyle Turner, tuba player - is to play works by Bach Gabrielli, Holborne, Gershwin and Lutoslawski at Wave Hill, West 249th Street in Independence Avenue, in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, on Sunday at 5 P.M. Tickets are $7. Information: 549-3200.

title: New Mexico Utility
description: The Public Service Company of New Mexico said it is abandoning a two-year-old reorganization plan that has encountered heavy opposition from state and local regulators and the utility's industrial customers and has led to a steep drop in the company's stock price. Under the proposal made last year, the utility planned to form a holding company for its generating and distribution operations. An initial reorganization plan was rejected in 1986. The company, based in Albuquerque, now plans to seek an unspecified rate increase.

title: Riesenberg Stays on the Move
description: It is doubtful that any Giant has seen his star rise and fall more this summer than Doug Riesenberg, a 6-foot-5-inch, 275-pound lineman from Moscow, Idaho.

title: Catholics Fight Crime That Has Shut Churches
description: There is a special collection box in the center aisle at St. Vincent de Paul Roman Catholic Church on West 23d Street with a sign that says, ''Keep Our Church Open.'' With the dollars and quarters and dimes that worshipers have dropped into the box, the church has hired a security guard this summer to sit at the door every afternoon, a time when until recently the church had been closed.

title: INSIDE
description: Mideast Dilemma If the P.L.O. recognized Israel as it declared a provisional government, a diplomatic breakthrough would not be assured. News analysis. Page A3. From a Rebel, Softer Words Sam Nujoma, the rebel leader who might lead a free Namibia, has begun to temper the fiery oratory that is his hallmark. Page A10. Whirlpool's Step Overseas The world's largest appliance maker will emerge from a deal between the Whirlpool Corporation and the Dutch company N. V. Philips. Page D1.

title: Morgan Keegan & Co Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Corrections
description: A Company Briefs listing in Business Day yesterday misstated the location of the Equion Corporation and the share price of a management buyout proposal for the company. The company, in Harrodsburg, Ky., received an offer of $9.25 a share from management.

title: Blount to Sell Steel Division
description: Blount Inc. announced an agreement today to sell its Washington Steel subsidiary to the Mercury Stainless Corporation for $290 million, taking Blount out of the specialty steel business.

title: Results PlusConnors Defaults: Third-seeded Jimmy Connors, suffering from tendinitis in his left elbow, had to default his third-round match yesterday in the Association of Tennis Professionals Championship in Mason, Ohio, to 14th-seeded Kevin Curren. Connors decided to rest the elbow in hopes he will be able to play in the United States Open, which starts Aug. 29. Bill Norris, the trainer for the association, said the elbow could recover in a week to 10 days.   Ninth-seeded Andres Gomez of Ecuador was charged with four code violations and forfeited his match to Carl Limberger. Gomez argued with the chair umpire, David Littlefield, over several calls in the first set, which he lost, 6-2. He trailed in the second set by 3-1 when he was called for his fourth infraction, resulting in a forfeit. Gomez was fined $2,350. '' (AP)  Giammalva Advances: Sammy Giammalva, seeded sixth, returned service well in the final two sets to defeat Tobias Svantesson of Sweden, 2-6, 6-4, 6-2, to advance to the quarterfinals of the $125,000 Mennen Cup yesterday in Livingston, N.J. Giammalva finally broke Svantesson's serve in the fifth game of the second set after failing to convert two service breaks in the first game of the second set and another in the third game.(AP)  Navaratilova Routs Hanika: Martina Navratilova routed Sylvia Hanika of West Germany, 6-1, 6-1, yesterday to advance to the quarterfinals of the Player's Challenge in Montreal. Navratilova, seeded first, has not lost to Hanika since 1982. Chris Evert, seeded second, also advanced by completing her rain-suspended match and beating Rene Simpson of Canada, 6-1, 6-2. Third-seeded Pam Shriver struggled past Nathalie Tauziat of France, 7-6, 6-4. (AP)  Golf  Watson Eliminated: Tom Watson came up a point short and was eliminated yesterday in the completion of first-round play at the $1 million International Golf Tournament in Castle Rock, Colo. Watson, needing a birdie-birdie finish to advance to the second round of the tournament, birdied the 17th hole but missed a birdie putt from four feet on the 18th.   Under the modified Stableford scoring system used for this tournament, eagles are worth 5 points, birdies 2 and pars nothing. Bogeys cost players 1 point and double bogey or worse cost 3. John Cook, the defending champion, also failed to advance. Ben Crenshaw and Mark O'Meara led 39 qualifiers from the 81-man field in the second half of the first round. Each had six birdies and two bogeys and tied with 10 points. Jeff Sluman, the new PGA champion, also advanced with 5 points.(AP)  Horse Racing  Lukas Wins Stakes Again: Pat Copelan led all the way to score a 10-length victory over Channel Three and Premier Playmate in the $96,000 Adirondack Stakes yesterday at Saratoga Race Track, giving the trainer D. Wayne Lukas his fourth straight victory in the race. Pat Copelan, who won her debut at Saratoga Aug. 4 by three lengths, is a 2-year-old daughter of Copelan and the Dr. Fager mare Ahrex, and is owned by William T. Young. She paid $3.20 for $2 to win as part of a Lukas-trained entry with Darby Shuffle, who finished fourth. The winner ran the six furlongs in 1:10 4/5 under Pat Day. Lukas won the previous three Adirondacks with Nervous Baba in 1985, Sacahuista in 1986 and Over All last year.  Cycling  Wilches Sprints to Victory: Pablo Wilches gave Colombia's Postobon team its first stage win in this year's Coors International Classic yesterday with a first-place finish in stage 11, the 107-mile Aspen to Copper Mountain Road Race. Davis Phinney of Team 7-Eleven regained the race leader's jersey from his teammate, Alex Stieda. Phinney finished third, edged out in a final sprint by Alex Grewal of Team Crest. The two led a chase pack that crossed the finish line about one minute 30 seconds behind Wilches, who finished in 4 hours 35 minutes 42 seconds.   In the third stage of the women's Coors, Leslie Schenk of Team Lowrey's broke from a lead group of racers on the second ascent up Fremont Pass to claim her second straight victory in the Copper Mountain road race. Schenk, of Cincinnati, finished the 54-mile course in 2 hours 27 minutes 1 second.
description: Tennis

title: Pop/Jazz; A New Generation Of Performers Is Revitalizing Cabarets
description: EXCEPT for Teresa Stratas, no singer in recent memory has brought to the music of Kurt Weill the combination of vocal bravura and fiery theatricality that the young soprano Angelina Reaux infuses into the composer's songs. In ''Stranger Here Myself,'' her one-woman cabaret show at the Public Theater, the singer and actress interprets some two dozen Weill songs from the point of view of a suicidal bohemian rebel thrashing through her memories alone in a hotel room.

title: Our Towns; Hikers' Census Counts Noses, Beaks and Bills
description: Jon Livingston, a camp maintenance director, sent word of a green-backed heron and a black-crowned night heron he saw near a remote earthen dam in Harriman State Park. ''I've never seen them here before,'' he said. Ed Harding, bulldozer operator at the park landfill, also had an odd sighting - an albino woodchuck.

title: Chili's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain from an accounting change of $600,000.

title: Native Fijians Reclaim Their Island Nation
description: To the Editor:

description: Fiscal 1987 results include an after- tax loss of $2,837,000 from spun-off operations.

title: Chancellor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

METRO DATELINES;
2 Officers Facing Charges in Clash
description: LEAD: The cases of the first two New York City police officers accused of brutality during clashes with protesters in Tompkins Square Park two weeks ago have been turned over to Police Department legal authorities ''for processing,'' a police spokesman said last night.

title: Com Systems reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $313,000 and $511,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $248,000 for the quarter and $472,000 for the 6 months.

title: Dow Up 1.07 In Sluggish Trading
description: Stocks yesterday struggled to their third consecutive gain, but worried traders were paying more attention to the market's continued sluggishness than to prices.

title: Vacaville Journal; They Lose Themselves In a New Maze Madness
description: Most people would not pay $7 to get lost, especially if it meant wandering about for hours in 90 degree-plus heat. Yet thousands of enthusiasts each day are paying to lose themselves in the Wooz, a Japanese-built outdoor maze that recently opened here.

title: Financial Services Corp. Acts as Investment Banker
description: The Financial Services Corporation of New York City, which is normally in the business of lending money to eligible businesses at below-market rates, is acting as an investment banker for West Mill Clothes Inc. of Woodside, Queens.

title: Family Paper First to Report Quayle's War Role
description: The first account of Wendell C. Phillippi's effort to help smooth Dan Quayle's way into the National Guard in the Vietnam War appeared yesterday in The Indianapolis News, where it was prominently displayed on the front page.

title: Yow Picks 12 for Seoul
description: Kay Yow, the coach of the United States Olympic women's basketball team, made her final cuts today. She reduced the team to the dozen players who will compete in Seoul, South Korea, next month.

title: 'Reform' for Incumbents
description: For nearly a decade, the House of Representatives has ignored serious campaign finance reforms, like curbs on contributions from special-interest political action committees. But last week the House finally got interested - in a ''reform'' that mostly serves to frustrate state and local officials who would challenge incumbent Congressmen.

title: One Killed and 8 Wounded in Brooklyn Shootings
description: One person was killed and eight others were wounded when shooting erupted twice at a Brooklyn housing project in a dispute that the police said might have been part of a turf war over drug sales.

title: On Stage
description: Jerome Robbins Retrospective

title: Metropolitan Baedeker; Living History at West Point
description: BECAUSE of its beauty, historic importance and training mission, the United States Military Academy at West Point - on the west bank of the Hudson River about 45 miles north of New York City - attracts hundreds of thousands of visitors a year, including an increasing number of foreign tourists. Military officers estimate the visitors at 2.5 million to 3 million a year, although some tourism officials put the number at perhaps half that.

title: Tekelec reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and includes a $381,000 after-tax charge from the discontinuance of two product lines.

title: Doctor Faces Charge on Waste
description: A Brooklyn physician was arrested yesterday and charged with illegally disposing of medical waste - 11 hypodermic syringes, 2 needles and 2 culture tubes - outside his Bedford-Stuyvesant office, the Brooklyn District Attorney announced.

title: Cellular Communications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Celina Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-11 The body of Pakistan's President, Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, was flown to Islamabad while investigators searched for the cause of the air crash that killed him and the United States Ambassador. Page A1

title: Cage Plays Cage
description: The composer John Cage is to participate in performances of his music at two free concerts at Lincoln Center tomorrow. The first, which is to take place on the North Plaza at 4 P.M., is a program of chance music called ''Cage Alfresco'' and is to feature the composer's ''Songbooks'' as one of five works performed simultaneously by Neely Bruce, Alvin Lucier and Mr. Cage. The evening concert, ''Cage Onstage,'' is to take place at Damrosch Park at 8:15. The program includes the American premiere of Mr. Cage's most recent piano work, ''Piano One,'' as well as works prepared piano, voice, percussion ensemble and electronic instruments. Isabelle Ganz is to be the vocal soloist. Both concerts are part of the Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors series, and are offered in celebration of Mr. Cage's 75th birthday. Information: 877-2011 or 877-1800.

title: For the Republicans, a Final Day of Boos and Hisses and Hugs and Kisses
description: The day had a Humpty-Dumpty feel to it.

title:
About Real Estate;
A Project Where Tennis Meets Long Island Sound
description: LEAD: The North Fork, a land of vineyards and quiet villages, is frequently touted as the Long Island resort area best suited for families. But new property developments are also trying to attract young professionals - buyers who have tended to head for the South Fork and the Hamptons.

title: European Allies Put Pressure on the U.S. To Pay Its U.N. Dues
description: Britain, West Germany and several other allies of the United States said today that they would not help the United Nations out of its financial difficulties because to do so would reduce pressure on Washington to pay its back dues.

description: BASEBALL

description: b-After tax credits of $367,000 for the quarter and $1,580,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: C.I.A. and Waldheim
description: Two months ago, it was reported that the Central Intelligence Agency had in its possession a profile of President Kurt Waldheim of Austria, written by a C.I.A. psychiatrist and dating from Mr. Waldheim's days as Secretary General of the United Nations. The news item caught the attention of the World Jewish Congress, which had been seeking the agency's files on Mr. Waldheim for a year in connection with alleged involvement in war crimes in World War II.

title: Old Ideological Battles Live On at New York's Riverside Church
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan, Growing Bolder, Tries to Nudge Burma
description: Japan, Burma's largest source of foreign aid, is subtly using its contributions to convince the Burmese Government that it must restore stability and carry out sweeping economic measures quickly, Western diplomats and some officials here say.

title: Varo Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes net of $600,000, or 14 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Brooklyn's Waterfront: Two Visions of a Compelling Vista
description: The panoramic promise of the Brooklyn Heights waterfront has spawned two very different visions of its future - a private residential enclave laced with public parks and a public park filled with private commercial enterprises.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
S.E.C. Picks Watchdog For Global Trading
description: LEAD: Faced with the need to police the growing number of stocks traded across national borders, the Securities and Exchange Commission's enforcement division announced yesterday that there would now be an associate director to handle all international affairs.

title: Nuclear Adviser Assails Methods At U.S. Plants
description: The head of a panel that advises the Department of Energy on safety at its nuclear reactors said yesterday that the procedure for dealing with the unexpected at the plants was ''very bad.'' He compared the system to testing an airplane for structural strength, seeing a wing flutter unexpectedly and then flying even faster.

title: N.H.L., Officials Plan New Talks
description: The National Hockey League and its officials held another negotiating session today in an effort to reach a new collective bargaining agreement. The officials' three-year pact will expire Aug. 31.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Ralph's Grocery Company is issuing through the First Boston Corporation $400 million of 14 percent senior subordinated debentures due in 2000 and priced at par. The notes are noncallable for five years.

title: Long Island Lighting Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a writedown of $1,345,110,000 from the effect of an accounting change for disallowed costs. c-Net income

title: Baseball; Tigers Win on Rally in Ninth
description: Dave Bergman capped a four-run rally in the ninth inning with a two-run homer, giving the Detroit Tigers a 6-4 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight.

title: Legal Publications: a New Growth Industry
description: As lawyers have proliferated and specialized, so have legal publications. The field, once the exclusive preserve of a handful of staid court reporting services, is now crowded by a growing flock of journals, newsletters and slick magazines covering everything from arcane ramifications of tax code changes to the relative virtues of expense account restaurants.

title: Pennwalt Plans to Sell Unit to Fisons
description: The Pennwalt Corporation said today that it would sell its pharmaceutical operations to Fisons P.L.C. of Britain for $460 million as part of a two-phase restructuring.

title: Shuttle Booster Is Fired in Test
description: The apparently successful test firing of a shuttle booster rocket yesterday could clear the way for the launching of the Discovery in the fall.

title: Polish Labor Unrest Spreads In Port City and to Five Mines
description: Labor unrest in Poland spread today as the number of coal mines being struck rose to five while transport workers joined port workers on strike in Szczecin, opposition leaders said.

title: Chicken by George
description: Geo. A. Hormel & Company announced it had bought Chicken by George Inc., the company founded by a former Miss America, Phyllis George. The price was not disclosed. Under the agreement, Hormel will buy all the assets of Chicken by George, based in Louisville, Ky., and operate the company as a division. In two years, Chicken by George has built a strong business in Kentucky. R.L. Knowlton, Hormel's chairman, said Miss George would be involved in new product development, marketing and promotion for chicken products as well as an expanded line of beef, pork, fish and turkey products.

title: A Look at the Splashiest Shows in Town
description: AFTER its dry spell of several months, the Bethesda Fountain - the bronze wings of its angel newly polished and the cracks in its basin fully repaired - will be turned on again today in Central Park. Built in 1863, it is the oldest working public fountain in New York City, and for more than a century it has attracted visitors in search of a cooling interlude.

title: Foreigners Are Detained in Prague After Marking '68 Soviet Invasion
description: About a dozen Western European demonstrators briefly unfurled banners on a crowded central square here today demanding ''freedom and human rights'' in Czechoslovakia.

title: General Parametrics reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said during the latest first quarter it adopted an accounting change which resulted in a one-time reduction of its tax accrual in the amount of $250,000, or 3 cents a share.

title: Halt the Perfumed Assault on Our Senses
description: To the Editor:

title: Study of Small Concerns
description: The Federal Reserve and the Small Business Administration plan to survey 4,000 small concerns on how financial deregulation has affected them. The concerns, selected at random, will be asked about the financial services they use. The study will be conducted for the Government by the Research Triangle Institute in North Carolina.

title: At the Movies
description: Pickle Perspective

title: Dining Out Guide: Midtown, on the West Side
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Aquavit **(Feb. 5, 1988), 13 West 54th Street (307-7311) - This is a dramatically designed restaurant in a former Rockefeller town house, incorporating birch trees and a sloping waterfall in the eight-story atrium dining room. There is also a ground-level cafe serving light meals and a variety of aquavits. Smoked salmon with horseradish cream (an appetizer) and an entree called one-side sauteed salmon, set over a chive butter sauce, are recommended salmon dishes. Crayfish is currently on the appetizer menu. Some entrees are poached turbot with brown butter and horseradish, medallions of veal, and snow grouse served with potato-zucchini cake and lingonberries. Brambleberry sorbet adds an appropriately Scandinavian touch to the meal. Downstairs is prix fixe, $32 for lunch and $55 for dinner. A la carte menu upstairs: $12 to $18.50 for main courses. Lunch from noon to 2:30 P.M. on Fridays. Dinner, 5:30 to 10:30 P.M. Fridays and Saturdays. Closed Sundays. Jezebel **(Aug. 28, 1987), 630 Ninth Avenue, at 45th Street (582-1045) - Jezebel's vast dining room is filled with foliage, antique lamps and white wicker. Lace covers the tables and vintage piano shawls are draped over ceiling pipes. A short walk from Broadway theaters, Jezebel features an authentic soul-food menu. The corn bread and baking-powder biscuits are recommended, as is smothered garlic shrimp. Rib bits and she-crab soup are other good starters. Main courses are huge, and include peppery fried chicken, chicken with waffles, and broiled salmon steak with black-eyed peas. Bread pudding, with raisins and Grand Marnier, is one of the high-calorie desserts. Prices range from $4.25 to $6.75 for appetizers, and $14.75 to $19.75 for entrees. Dinner is served at 6 and 9 P.M. seatings on Fridays and Saturdays. No reservations required after 10 P.M.; food served until 11:45 P.M. Marie-Michelle **(Dec. 25, 1987), 57 West 56th Street (315-2444) - In the density of restaurants in this part of town, Marie-Michelle stands out with distinction. The dining room is contemporary in design, with touches of Art Deco in the china and lighting fixtures. Marie-Michelle Rey is both the owner and lively hostess. The appetizer list offers a duck terrine in rich-flavored aspic, and sweetbread salad with endive and spinach. New to the menu is a carpaccio of the day's special fish, dressed with lime, lemon and mint. Recommended among the entrees are the lobster fricassee, with fresh ginger; grilled lamb chops; roast chicken with dauphinoise potatoes, and Norwegian salmon with mustard sauce. A new entree is the mignonette of beef with roasted shallots. The special house dessert is apple napoleon: a caramel-glazed pastry lid tops apple slices and pastry cream. Appetizers at dinner range from $7.75 to $11.75; entrees, $17.75 to $25.75. Lunch on Fridays from noon to 3:30 P.M.; Friday and Saturday dinner from 5:30 to 11:30 P.M. Closed Sundays until after Labor Day. Maurice ***(Dec. 19, 1986), Hotel Parker Meridien, 118 West 57th Street (245-7788) - This French restaurant is luxuriously decorated with mirrored panels, painted floral murals and Oriental-style rugs. The staff is highly professional. A winning appetizer is ravioli filled with scallops, zucchini and fresh thyme. Other selections include delicately cut smoked salmon with red and black caviar, and baked oysters with leeks. Duck Apicius is an acclaimed main course. The duck is roasted and glazed with honey, coriander, cumin, saffron and white pepper, and served with the glaze and a tart sauce. Calf's liver, smoked Maine lobster, roast quail with apples, and striped bass fillet scaled with crisp potato slices are other entree choices. The raspberry napoleon is a recommended dessert. Prix-fixe lunch is $32; prix-fixe pre-theater dinner is $36 (served from 5:30 to 6:30 P.M.). Dinner is also a la carte, at $9.50 to $17.50 for appetizers, and $23 to $35 for entrees. Friday lunch from noon to 2:15 P.M. and dinner on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays from 6 to 10:30 P.M. Manhattan Ocean Club *(June 10, 1988), 57 West 58th Street (371-7777) - Neither a club, nor particularly maritime in decor, this is a handsome and sophisticated midtown seafood house. The main dining room is painted in cream color and pastels, and ceramic pieces by Picasso are installed behind glass on the walls. A twisting stairway leads to an upstairs dining room. Tuna with veal mousseline, five oysters baked five ways (with Pernod, curry, peppers, pesto and oregano), and crab cakes are recommended to start. Tuna steak is charred outside, and is enhanced by a tomato-mint vinaigrette. Other good entrees are halibut with beurre blanc, farm-raised striped bass with soy and ginger sauce, and mahi-mahi with citrus butter. Desserts are copious and complex; the house special is a little chocolate shopping bag filled with white chocolate mousse and surrounded with strawberry sauce. Appetizers at dinner range from $8.50 to $11.50, and entrees from $19.50 to $26.50. Open noon to midnight on Fridays, 5 P.M. to midnight Saturdays and Sundays. What the stars mean, page C21.

title: Toying With Child Safety
description: For years, the American Academy of Pediatrics has urged that toy package labels explicitly warn about small parts on which a child might choke. A bill sponsored by Representative Sam Gejdenson of Connecticut and just approved by the House Energy and Commerce Committee would require reluctant toy makers to do just that.

title: Precision Standard reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of $500,000 for the writeoff of a large receivable acquired with the assets of Monarch Aviation in fiscal 1987.

Apple Suit Faces 1989 Trial
description: Apple Computer Inc. said Wednesday that it had been notified that a trial date for its copyright-infringement suit against Microsoft Inc. and the Hewlett-Packard Company had been set nearly a year away.

title: National Security Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $415,000 for the quarter and $660,000 for the 6 months.

title: Federation Plans For '94 World Cup
description: The United States became an automatic qualifier for the 1994 World Cup when it was designated as the host nation for the event last month. Since then, the United States Soccer Federation, the national governing body for the sport, has been working to establish what Werner Fricker, the federation's president, called a competitive environment for the players.

title: NUI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $2,499,000 for the quarter and $4,681,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss d-After net from discontinued operations of $119,000 for the quarter and $1,539,000 for the 9 months.

title: U.S. Experts Helping Zia Crash Inquiry
description: The United States sent two teams of experts to Pakistan today to help the Government investigate the airplane explosion that killed the nation's President and the American Ambassador there. State Department officials said they had growing suspicions, but no proof, that sabotage was a factor in the crash.

title: Convention Message Is Garbled by Quayle Static
description: The carefully drawn plans of the Bush campaign to use the Republican National Convention as a four-day television commercial have been overwhelmed by the attention the campaign itself has stirred up in the selection of a running mate.

title: In Yonkers, 4,000 Units Are Delayed
description: When four members of the Yonkers City Council decided to defy a court-ordered housing desegregation plan, they did so by voting down an amendment to the city's zoning ordinance that would dramatically change future development in Yonkers.

title: Orion Pictures Sets 12.75% Notes
description: The Orion Pictures Corporation is issuing $200 million of senior subordinated reset notes yielding 12.75 percent and due in 1998 through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers have signed Greg Harris, a rookie wide receiver from Troy State recently waived by the Giants. Harris, the Giants' 11th-round draft choice, caught 93 passes for 1,445 yards and 11 touchdowns in college. He averaged 5.8 yards on punt returns, with a touchdown, and 18.1 yards on kickoff returns. . . . Julio Cesar Chavez of Mexico, the undefeated World Boxing Association lightweight champion, will meet his World Boxing Council counterpart, Jose Luis Ramirez of Mexico, in a 12-round fight in Las Vegas, Nev., Oct. 29 to unify those titles for the first time in 10 years. Chavez is 61-0 with 49 knockouts and Ramirez is 101-6 with 82 knockouts. . . . The Cleveland Cavaliers have picked up the one-year option on the contract of the forward Larry Nance and have added two years to the deal, putting him under contract through the 1991-92 season. Nance averaged 19.1 points and 9.1 rebounds last season for the Cavaliers and the Phoenix Suns, from whom he was acquired in a trade Feb. 25.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Ameritrust Corp., Cleveland, said its board had approved a stockholder rights plan that provides the right to purchase one share for each share currently held.

title: The Candidates' Military Records b
description: George Bush: Bush served in the Navy from 1942 to 1945 and was a carrier pilot in the Pacific. He was shot down and rescued by a submarine. Bush was discharged as a lieutenant and was decorated with the Distinguished Flying Cross and three Air Medals. Dan Quayle: Quayle served in the Indiana National Guard from 1969 to 1975. Michael Dukakis: Dukakis served in the Army from 1955 to 1957 and was stationed for 16 months in South Korea as part of the United Nations delegation to the Military Armistice Commission. He was discharged as a specialist third class. Lloyd Bentsen: Bentsen was a major in the Army Air Corps and served as a bomber squadron commander during World War II. He later served in the Air Force Reserve. Bentsen received the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Air Medal with three oak leaf clusters. Source: Associated Press

title: Hills Department Stores reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Arrow Bank Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Freedom Democrats
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film; Trials of a Movie Maker
description: The four little children of Fred G. Sullivan, a k a ''Adirondack Fred,'' do not want to starve. And they don't want to be sold to the gypsies, either. They say as much, several times, during the course of Mr. Sullivan's ''Beer Drinker's Guide to Fitness and Film Making,'' in hopes that this film will let their father strike it rich and stop having to worry about where the next diaper is coming from. But audiences may hope otherwise, despite the fact that Mr. Sullivan's jokey, charmingly ingenuous (and actually very elaborate) home movie happens to be a real delight.

title: Iranian Airliner Said to Emit Civilian, Not Military, Signal
description: A Pentagon investigation into the American downing of an Iranian airliner last month has found that the airliner was emitting only a civilian signal, ABC News reported tonight.

title: Mets Quietly Fall to Krukow
description: The Mets got three more hits today than they did the day before: five, to be exact. And they got one more run than the day before: one, to be axact.

title: TV Weekend; Falling For a Client's Dead Wife
description: ''I was in trouble, see, trouble of a very special kind.'' Charley, a well-to-do New Yorker, is telling his story to a bartender, just the way cigarette-puffing Scotch drinkers used to do in the moody little mysteries of the 1940's, to which the Showtime movie ''Gotham'' is a tribute or an insult, depending on how you feel about those taut and steamy film noir thrillers.

title: Surgical Care Affiliates reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $214,989 and $371,179 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Share amounts reflect a 5-for-1 stock split distributed July 11.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Senator Dan Quayle's work in newspapers and his interests in the Pulliam publishing empire, Central Newspapers, misstated the circulation of The Arizona Republic. It was 320,409 daily for the 12 months ended Dec. 27, 1987.

title: American Capital Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said the latest 6-month includes preferred stock dividends totaling $3,019,000, compared to no preferred stock dividends in the year-ago period.

title: Loan for Brazil 95% Committed
description: Just six weeks after major international banks began trying to raise $5.2 billion of new money for Brazil, 95 percent of that amount has been committed, according to Maiilson da Nobrega, Finance Minister of Brazil, and William R. Rhodes, chairman of the bank advisory committee. As a result of this support, Michel Camdessus, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said he would recommend to his board that funds from a previously arranged $1.4 billion I.M.F. loan to Brazil be released.

title: PAKISTAN RECEIVES SOVIET SYMPATHIES
description: The Soviet Union sent condolences to Pakistan today for the death of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, and hinted that the event might lead to an improvement in Moscow's bitter relationship with its southern neighbor.

title: Telos Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $89,000 gain from discontinued operations.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Young & Rubicam Buys Finnish Agency Stake
description: Young & Rubicam has decided to further its more than 20-year relationship with Taucher Advertising of Helsinki, Finland, by purchasing a minority interest in the agency. Y.& R. says that the move is expected to lead to a majority purchase agreement within the next few years. Meanwhile, the new partnership is being called Taucher-Young & Rubicam.

title: Review/Film; The Mob, to Have and to Hold
description: Jonathan Demme is the American cinema's king of amusing artifacts: blinding bric-a-brac, the junkiest of jewelry, costumes so frightening they take your breath away. Mr. Demme may joke, but he's also capable of suggesting that the very fabric of American life may be woven of such things, and that it takes a merry and adventurous spirit to make the most of them. In addition, Mr. Demme has an unusually fine ear for musical novelty, and the sounds that waft through his films heighten the visual impression of pure, freewheeling vitality. If making these films is half as much fun as watching them, Mr. Demme must be a happy man.

title: Turner Eager to Tee Off
description: Sherri Turner was a nonwinner on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour entering this year. She had been close a couple of times, but victory always eluded her. That changed in May when she won the Mazda L.P.G.A. Championship for her first victory, then came back a week later to capture the L.P.G.A. Corning Classic.

title: Allied Research Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Afghan Chief's Brother Granted Haven in U.S.
description: The younger brother of Afghanistan's Soviet-backed leader has defected to the United States with his family and is being accepted as a refugee, a Reagan Administration official disclosed today.

title: I.B.M. Suffering in PC's Despite Its New Line
description: The International Business Machines Corporation's PS/2 computers, introduced 16 months ago, are in trouble.

title: Title Defense
description: Miguel Lora will defend his World Boxing Council bantamweight title against Raul Perez of Mexico in Las Vegas, Nev., on Oct. 29, Don King said yesterday.

title: Those New Disposable Contact Lenses
description: Extended-wear soft contact lenses, introduced seven years ago, have been redesigned so that they can be worn for a week or two and then thrown away. The earlier version has been blamed for a variety of eye problems, but the new lenses promise added safety and convenience.

title: Why Fundamentalists Reject 'Last Temptation'; Religious Affiliations
description: To the Editor:

title: Quixote Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,670,000. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $640,000 for the quarter and $1,843,000 for the year.

title: George Bush's Mission
description: ''I am a man who sees life in terms of missions,'' Vice President Bush said as he accepted the Republican nomination for President in a speech that had two missions: to set himself apart from Ronald Reagan and to set himself apart from Michael Dukakis. He accomplished the first mission forthrightly. His approach to the second involved some jarring distortion.

title: SCE Revises Bid for Utility
description: SCEcorp, maintaining pressure on its intended takeover target, said today that it had sweetened its stock-swap offer for the San Diego Gas and Electric Company to $2.25 billion from $2.15 billion.

title: An Artful Garden for Battery Park, Created by a Painter and an Architect
description: From the beginning, it was a most unusual project: a work of art and a work of landscape architecture; a kind of miniature wooded city with crisscrossing gravel paths instead of streets and avenues; a living sculpture made of earth and sky, grass and gravel, wind and water, buildings and flowers.

title: The Cost of Ducking School Reform
description: How serious is New York's Legislature about improving New York City schools? For months, Albany has procrastinated over a sensible reform agenda. At least three measures ought to remain high on the list of essential business as the Legislature reconvenes to finish its drawn-out session.

title: Acquisition of LCI
description: LCI Communications Inc., a medium-size telecommunications company, has agreed to be acquired by two investment firms, E. M. Warburg, Pincus & Company and Primus Venture Partners, for about $200 million. The cash transaction includes the Litel Communications Corporation, an LCI subisidary based in Worthington, Ohio. Litel, which began operating in 1985, provides long-distance and other transmission services to about 30,000 customers in Ohio, Michigan, Indiana, Illinois and Pennsylvania. Litel expects to have revenues of more than $140 million in 1988.

title: China-Soviet Talks Set
description: China and the Soviet Union will hold talks here on Aug. 27 to seek solutions to the Cambodian conflict and improvements in Chinese-Soviet relations, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said Thursday. The talks will be led by a Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, Igor A. Rogachev, and his Chinese counterpart, Tian Zengpei.

title: High-Tech Whistle-Stops for Dukakis
description: Cloaking himself in the mantle of Harry S. Truman, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis rode a whistle-stop train into small-town America today, past the heaps of rusted automobiles, the factories, towns, water towers and working-class backyards of the country's midsection.

title: No Green Card, No Day Care
description: There are three women in Arlington, Va. - a teacher, an artist, a secretary - all married, each with a young child. They are able to work because they share a baby sitter. Maria, the sitter, comes from Latin America, has two children of her own, a year of paid experience, great warmth and no visa. The three mothers, eager to do right by Maria and relieved to have found a fine person in whose hands to leave their children, have begun Maria's labor certification process, the prerequisite to a permanent resident visa, or green card.

title: Rates Barely Move in Slow Trading
description: Interest rates were little changed in light trading yesterday.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Decline 1.6% on Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest on the Big Board fell 1.6 percent in the four-week period that ended on Monday.

title: Timberland Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-ago figures are pro forma results that assume a $30.5 million stock redemption, which occurred on June 20, 1986, and $7.8 milion of bank debt were financed as of Jan. 1, 1987 with proceeds from the issuance of 3,335,600 shares of common stock.

title: QUAYLE DECLARES HE BROKE NO RULES TO GET INTO GUARD
description: Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana, the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, confronted questions about his military service today, saying that he had done nothing improper in finding a coveted position in the National Guard and that he had not enlisted in the Guard to avoid combat in Vietnam.

title: Despite Beating, He Wants to Teach Again
description: Gary Smith's memory of the precise moment the school year ended for him last spring was of a pitch thrown during the third inning of a softball game. Mr. Smith, a teacher for 16 years at Intermediate School 166, the Roberto Clemente School near Yankee Stadium in the Bronx, was umpiring the game.

title: Saturday Brass, Sunday
description: The Saturday Brass Quintet -Terry Szor and Scott McIntosh, trumpeters; Lawrence DiBello, horn player; Richard Kessler, trombonist, and Kyle Turner, tuba player - is to play works by Bach, Gabrieli, Holborne, Gershwin and Lutoslawski at Wave Hill, West 249th Street and Independence Avenue, in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, tomorrow at 5 P.M. Tickets are $7. Information: 549-3200.

title: U.S. Can Only Gain If Soviets Scrap Radar
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESERVING FOOD AT HOME
description: The tomatoes are beginning to ripen all at once now, and there are more of them than you can use. Home canning, the traditional answer to the overabundance of summer's harvest, must be done with care to avoid the risk of botulism and other toxins. Always use only the freshest, firmest unblemished fruits and vegetables. To be sure that your canned tomatoes, corn relish or blackberry jam will be both delicious and safe to eat, you can consult inexpensive publications offered by the Government. Write to the Superintendent of Documents, United States Government Printing Office, Washington, D.C. 20402-9325, to order these pamphlets: Home and Garden Bulletin No. 8 - ''Home Canning of Fruits and Vegetables,'' $1.50; and No. 56 - ''How to Make Jellies, Jams and Preserves at Home,'' $2.50. Here are some basic tips. Equipment Use only sterilized jars designed for home canning, fitted with new two-part lids. Do not re-use old lids. Lids and jars, with directions are at most houseware stores. Processing Use a boiling-water bath for jars containing high-acid foods (most fruits and pickles), and a pressure-canner for low-acid foods (vegetables) Sealing Check seals 24 hours after canning to see that they are tight. Do not store any jars with faulty seals; refigerate them and eat the contents in a few days.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Having gone through this week, I think I know how I'm to introduce myself: 'Stand at attention. Name, Dan Quayle; rank, sergeant; serial number, 303504096. Indiana, National Guard, six years and proud of it.' '' - Senator Dan Quayle. [ 8:4. ]

title: The Early Shopper Gets the Right Size
description: Yes, it's still warm enough to shrink from the thought of wool sweaters and tweeds. But now is the time for all good shoppers to buy fall clothes with a minimum of anguish.

title: Yonkers Solution Won't Draw on Failed Policies of the Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Peugeot Introduces New Models in U.S.
description: With its minuscule presence in the United States automobile market continuing to decline, the French automobile maker Peugeot S.A., is pinning its hopes for recovery on a new model that Europe has named its car of the year. The front-wheel-drive Peugeot 405 is being offered in three models, and its base price is $14,500.

title: Reagan to Meet With Indians
description: President Reagan is planning a White House meeting with American Indian leaders who protested his remark in Moscow in May that the United States perhaps ''should not have humored'' the Indians, the White House said today. Mr. Reagan had told the Soviets that the United States had perhaps ''made a mistake in trying to maintain Indian cultures.''

title: Benvenuto, Pollution! (Ciao, Love in the Air)
description: Although toplessness reigns at trendier spots, women do not bare their chests at this beach. It is a place where big families disgorge from little cars. The old folks here speak slurred small-town dialects while their teen-age grandchildren wear the latest in department store imitations of designer swimwear.

title: U.S. Makes Clear That Actions in Defense Of Its Gulf Force Won't Be Second-Guessed
description: In approving the recommendations made by the Vincennes board of investigation, Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci sent a clear signal to the Navy today that - at least in the Persian Gulf - he will bend the rules of accountability when a ship captain does what the captain thinks is necessary to defend his ship.

title: North European Oil Royalty Tr reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The share earnings are in units.

title: Lower Ratings for G.O.P.
description: Slightly fewer people watched the Republican National Convention this week than the Democratic convention in July, ratings show.

title: Defect Is Found In New Pistols Used by Police
description: The New York City Police Department has ordered 2,000 officers to turn in their new, so-called hammerless off-duty revolvers because of a manufacturing defect that could cause the weapons to jam.

title: Golf; Daniel Shoots a 66 to Lead by a Stroke
description: Beth Daniel has suffered from a professional golfer's occupational disease: severe lower back pain and dislocated spinal disk. She played so badly, by her standards, in 1986 and 1987 that she said she would rather not play than compete that way.

title: Confinement Order Suspended by Judge
description: A Federal judge yesterday suspended an order committing a defense lawyer to a week's confinement in the Metropolitan Correction Center for civil contempt of court in a narcotics and racketeering trial.

title: Why Fundamentalists Reject 'Last Temptation'
description: To the Editor:

title: Coradian Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Queen Still Reigns in Sport of Kings
description: You may have heard that the sky is falling at Saratoga this year, that the queen of American race tracks is ailing and her subjects are abandoning her.

title: Gas Leak in Space Shuttle Is Repaired on Launching Pad
description: Technicians today apparently sealed a gas leak in a steering engine compartment of the space shuttle Discovery, another step toward clearing the space shuttle Discovery for launching in late September or early October.

title: Giants Stadium Games Won on Penalty Kicks
description: Soccer returned to Giants Stadium tonight for the first time in three years as a crowd of 23,821 watched a doubleheader involving four foreign teams.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: National Ballet of Canada Names Director
description: The National Ballet of Canada today named Reid Anderson, a Canadian dancer and choreographer who helped found Ballet British Columbia, as its new artistic director.

Ellington Alumni
description: Jimmy Hamilton, a clarinetist, and Aaron Bell, a pianist, are leading a sextet of Duke Ellington Orchestra alumni tonight and tomorrow at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., plus a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover with a $7.50 minimum at tables and $10 admission at the bar.

title: KEY RATES
Did Shakespeare Err on Bohemia After All?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bird by Any Other Name
description: Several correspondents have pointed out that this column was all wet once again the other day for saying there was a shortage of colorful nicknames for women in public life.

title: U.S. Savings Rescue Set in Texas at Cost Of Up to $5.5 Billion
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board today announced its most expensive rescue package yet for insolvent savings and loan associations. The transaction could cost the Government as much as $5.5 billion over 10 years.

title: Nils Gosta Sahlin, College President, 88
description: Nils Gosta Sahlin, former president of Quinnipiac College in Hamden, Conn., died of heart disease Thursday at the Sound View Specialized Care Center in West Haven, Conn. He was 88 years old and lived in New Haven.

title: Afghan President's Brother Says Kabul Rulers Will Fall
description: The brother of the Afghan President said here today that the Soviet-backed Government in Kabul had little support from the Afghan people and would collapse soon after the last Soviet troops pulled out of the country.

title: Thrift Aid Under the Southwest Plan
description: Assistance packages worked out by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board and the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation in their bid to save Texas's ailing savings institutions. Total value of cash or equity capital provided by acquiring institutions is about $87 million; the cost to the F.S.L.I.C. ranges from $6 billion to $9 billion. May 13, 1988: Coastal Banc Savings Association of Houston acquires four insolvent savings institutions. Coastal contributes new capital of $3.5 million; F.S.L.I.C. cost is $138.3 million. May 18, 1988: Southwest Savings Association, Dallas, acquires four insolvent savings institutions. Southwest provides $25 million in equity capital; F.S.L.I.C. cost is $2 billion. May 25, 1988: First Savings of Brenham, Tex., acquires Bluebonnet Savings Association of Texas, in Hempstead. First Savings provides $1.8 million; F.S.L.I.C. cost is $9.9 million. June 22, 1988: Merabank, a Federal savings bank in Phoenix, acquires two savings institutions. Merabank contributes $8.8 million in new capital; F.S.L.I.C. cost is $83.9 milion. Aug. 18, 1988: An investment group, Gibson Group/LSST Financial Services, headed by a Chicago banker and backed by a Texas steel company, acquires 12 insolvent savings and loan associations. Gibson contributes $48 million in cash; F.S.L.I.C. cost is $1.3 billion. Aug. 19, 1988: Eight insolvent Texas savings institutions are consolidated under the F.S.L.I.C. Initial F.S.L.I.C. cost is $2.5 billion; long-term cost could total $5.5 billion. (Source: Federal Home Loan Bank Board)

title: Lafleur Gets a Shot With the Rangers
description: On Sept. 7, Guy Lafleur will be inducted into the National Hockey League Hall of Fame in Toronto. Three days later, his place in the sport's history secure, Lafleur will attempt to gain a spot on the Rangers' roster. The team announced yesterday that it would grant Lafleur a tryout next month when its training camp opens.

title: Settlement in Trading Case
description: Mohd A. Aslimi, a former executive vice president of the Spectran Corporation, has settled Federal civil charges that he illegally sold his stake shortly before the company announced that it would post substantial losses for the first quarter of 1986.

title: Self-Defense as Defense: Unwritten Law for Gun Users
description: A Manhattan physician shoots and wounds a cane-wielding man trying to break into his office. A token clerk shoots one of four assailants trying to rob him in a Brooklyn subway station. A Queens man, in his home, kills one robber and wounds another.

title: Pace Membership Warehouse Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 17
description: b-After tax credits of $714,000 for the quarter and $950,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss and after a loss of $286,000 from the repurchase of subordinated notes.

title: Tax for School Desegregation Upheld
description: A Federal appellate court panel today upheld a district judge's order that imposed a sharp increase in property taxes here to help pay the cost of a school desegregation plan.

title: Why Fundamentalists Reject 'Last Temptation'; Faith and Fury?
description: To the Editor:

title: Rufus C. Harris, 91, Educator in the South
description: Rufus C. Harris, former president of Mercer and Tulane universities, died Thursday. He was 91 years old.

title: Denver Bank Infusion
description: Marvin Davis, the billionaire financier, has transferred $8.3 million into Metro National Bank of Denver to meet minimum Federal standards and to prevent the bank's failure. Mr. Davis, the primary owner of the $77 million bank in Denver's 17th Street financial district, made the contribution to Metro's capital just after the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation held an auction for the bank in which the F.D.I.C. tried to find a buyer for it. The infusion of capital brings the bank's capital-to-assets ratio to 7 percent, the minimum required by regulations, and increased Mr. Davis's contributions to Metro to $32 million, a spokesman said.

title: Aaron May Leave
description: The highest-ranking black executive on a major league team, Henry Aaron, is considering leaving baseball because, he said, blacks are not being allowed to move into the game's top positions.

title: Keeping the Air Cool: An Expert's Advice
description: Air-conditioners have been working overtime this summer, one of the hottest of the century. While some cooler air has arrived in the Northeast, air-conditioners will still be a part of life for a while.

title: A PLAYGROUND 'DERELICTS' CAN'T ENTER
description: Mayor Koch, calling Tompkins Square Park a ''cesspool'' where ''sandboxes are soiled with feces and urine,'' said yesterday that the New York City Parks Department would set aside a playground inside the East Village park that would be off-limits to anyone not accompanied by a child.

title: Unpaid Eyes and Ears of the Police
description: Several nights a week, Jeff Cates puts on a blue uniform, pins a shiny silver star to his shirt and circles a wide swath of the West Village, keeping an eye out for crime.

title: Thousands Are Reported Dead in Burundi Clashes
description: Thousands of people were killed in ethnic clashes in Burundi this week before the army restored order, diplomats and opposition leaders said today.

title: Judge Rescinds Term Promised In Swindle Case
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan withdrew a promise of a light prison sentence to an admitted swindler yesterday after ruling the defendant had tried to trick him into imposing an even lighter sentence.

title: Suspect Is Charged In Slaying at Project
description: A 26-year-old man has been charged in a slaying that the police said was part of a turf war over drug sales that erupted into gunfire in a Brooklyn housing project Thursday.

title: The Editorial Notebook; 'The Hippies Really Bug Us'
description: At noon on an August day, the sweet smell of marijuana drifts through Tompkins Square Park. A pudgy woman tosses crumbs to pigeons; a young man soaps himself in the wading pool; another sleeps in the tattered bandshell. ''There's no more stories. Everything's been written. Give us a break!'' a third yells to a woman with a notebook. The stories are of Aug. 7, when an attempt to clear the area left 44 people injured and New York City's Police Department with egg on its face.

title: Bank Building & Equipment reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a loss of $371,000 from the sale of the company's discontinued Anderson Professional Dental Inc. unit. The company said in the year-ago third quarter a pretax gain of $3,812,000. In the latest second quarter there was a pretax gain of $230,000.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 17.

title: Infant Transplant Program Is Halted to Reassess Issues
description: Citing medical, ethical and emotional difficulties, the Loma Linda University Medical Center has decided to suspend a program in which newborn babies with lethal brain defects were put on life-support systems to preserve their organs for transplant.

title: Varco International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Burma Names a Civilian as New Leader
description: Burma named Attorney General Maung Maung, one of the Cabinet's two civilians, as the nation's new leader today, a week after widespread protests and violence forced his predecessor from office.

title: Your Money; Municipals Need Careful Handling
description: Driven by the perils of the stock market and the vagaries of the Tax Reform Act of 1986, record numbers of individual investors have taken refuge in municipal bonds this year. But they are not socking them away as they once did. Nowadays, the more astute municipal-bond investors constantly re-examine their holdings to see whether bond swapping might be in order.

title: C. Ray Smith, 59, An Author, Teacher And Critic of Design
description: C. Ray Smith, a writer and critic in the field of architecture, died of a heart attack Thursday in the emergency room of Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 59 years old and lived in Manhattan and Krumsville, Pa.

title: PPG Purchase Of Grow Group
description: PPG Industries said today that it had reached an agreement to acquire the Grow Group Inc. for $16.625 a share, or about $233 million. The price reflects Grow

title: 11 Minutes to Downing of an Airliner
description: Eleven hectic minutes elapsed from the time the cruiser Vincennes first opened fire on a handful of small Iranian gunboats until the vessel mistakenly shot down an Iranian civilian airliner, according to the Pentagon's report of the episode.

title: Bridge; Which is the better strategy: a six-person or four-person team?
description: An old debate, never likely to be settled, concerns the best size for a squad in a major knockout event. A six-person team permits some players to rest but may cause arguments over the lineup. A four-person team may have a stamina problem, and this appeared to be the case in the Spingold Knockout semifinals, played in Salt Lake City on Aug. 4.

title: Did Shakespeare Err on Bohemia After All?; Verona to Milan
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets Fall In 10th
description: The Mets, who scored a total of one run in their last two games, raised the ante to two runs tonight. But that still wasn't enough, as the San Diego Padres broke through Randy Myers with two down in the 10th inning and sent the Mets to their third straight defeat, 3-2.

title: International at Yonkers
description: Lou Guida is not very diplomatic when it comes to the $200,000 International Trot on Saturday night at Yonkers Raceway. Guida doesn't regard any of the six foreign horses as a threat to his Mack Lobell. All that concerns him is Go Get Lost, the other United States entry in the mile-and-a-quarter race. The race has been shifted to Yonkers after 29 years at Roosevelt Raceway, which has closed.

title: Patents; 'Smart Card' Keeps Track Of Betting
description: The Gtech Corporation, the nation's largest supplier of computer systems for state-run lotteries, has developed a computerized ''smart card'' for gamblers to use to keep track of their bets.

title: A Sale at Koppers
description: The Koppers Company said that it had agreed to sell its environmental resources subsidiary in its first divestiture since it was acquired in June by Beazer P.L.C. of Britain for $1.8 billion. Terms were not disclosed on the sale of Keystone Environmental Resources Inc., based in Monroeville, Pa., to the Pittsburgh-based Chester Engineers Inc. But as part of the deal, Koppers said that Chester Engineers had agreed to honor a commitment by Beazer's chairman, Brian C. Beazer, to guarantee all nonunion workers a job or an equivalent salary through June 1989. Keystone's 250 employees are nonunion.

title: Yanks Stumble After a Big Lift
description: The afternoon began with a smattering of fans scattered through a largely empty stadium. And it was, if anything, slighty emptier when the evening ended.

title: Filing by Armtek On 'White Knights'
description: The Armtek Corporation said it had begun talks with unidentified ''white knights,'' in an apparent attempt to ward off a sweetened $44-a-share hostile bid from Mark IV Industries. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the New Haven-based Armtek said its board had met and authorized management to investigate whether the parties would participate in a possible recapitalization or would acquire the chemical maker.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Lexicon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $229,855 and $220,655 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and tax credits of $247,500 for the quarter and $191,500 for the 9 months. c-Net income d-Includes a loss of $280,085 for the quarter and income of $3,226,056 for the 9 months both from discontinued operations, and the 9 months also includes a tax benefit of $1,768,000. The company said the year-ago 9-month loss from continuing operations includes provisions for unrealized losses on marketable securities and income taxes on the sale of property of $418,430 and $593,500, respectively.

title: Group for Aged Assails Quayle
description: The National Council of Senior Citizens said today that Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana, the Republican Vice-Presidential nominee, had a voting record on issues affecting the elderly that was a ''disgrace.''

title: Groton Strike Painless, So Far
description: Like many people here in the self-proclaimed ''Submarine Capital of the World,'' Steve Meronek thought economic calamity would befall southeastern Connecticut when he and 10,000 other workers went on strike seven weeks ago at the Electric Boat shipyard.

title: Missouri County Finds Cost of Justice Is Too High
description: This is cattle, corn and soybean country, but the hardiest product here in Schuyler County is its civility, though even that is under some stress this year.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tim Perry, the 6-foot-9-inch forward from Temple who was the top draft pick of the Phoenix Suns and the league's seventh pick over all, has agreed to a multiyear contract. Perry said he had agreed to a five-year guaranteed contract, but would not disclose salary figures. Sources told The Phoenix Gazette that the contract was worth more than $3.5 million. . . . The Pittsburgh Pirates have obtained Gary Redus, an outfielder, from the Chicago White Sox for Mike Diaz, an outfielder-first baseman. Redus, 32, was batting .263 with 6 home runs and 34 runs batted in with 26 stolen bases. Diaz, 28, was batting .230 with no home runs and 5 r.b.i.

title: Gastineau Ends Sack Slump
description: Tony Jones, who isn't even an agent, might have helped Mark Gastineau earn $825,000 this season with the Jets.

title: Bolshevik Coup Lacked Popular Support
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Hurt as a Highway Chase Ends in Shootouts in Conn.
description: A Connecticut state trooper, a West Haven police officer and the man they were pursuing were wounded yesterday in two shootouts that ended a brief chase on Interstate 95 and through nearby woods in West Haven, the state police said.

title: Pioneer Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $25,000 for the quarter and $112,000 for the 6 months.

title: Excerpts From Crowe's Remarks on Downing of Iranian Jet
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, at a news conference today on the Navy investigation of the downing of an Iranian airliner:

title: Hometown Crowd Turns Tables On Press for Questioning Quayle
description: It was clear that the hometown crowd was going to be receptive, even before the motorcade passed a Walgreen's drugstore bearing the sign: ''Dan, tell your Dad his film is in.'' But the people here turned out to be more than receptive for Dan Quayle's debut on the national campaign trail, after several days of intense questions about his military record.

title: NAVY WON'T PUNISH ANYONE IN DOWNING OF IRANIAN PLANE
description: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci said today that no one from the United States Navy would be disciplined for the downing of an Iranian civilian jetliner by an American warship in the Persian Gulf last month.

title: Gold Cards, Parties and Late Rent
description: The Story of My Life By Jay McInerney 189 pages. The Atlantic Monthly Press. $16.95.

title: Home Federal Savings & Loan Assn (San Diego) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes pretax gains on the sale of securities of $7,592,000 and $10,869,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes an accounting change gain of $2,757,000. d-Includes pretax gains on the sale of securities of $5,566,000 for the quarter and $14,572,000 for the 6 months. The company said the year-earlier quarter and 6 months also included pretax loan loss provisions of $4,000,000 and $5,015,000, respectively. Year-earlier periods are restated for an accounting change.

title: Article 664188 -- No Title
description: The bright yellow newsletter called International Dateline Report arrived in the mailbox every two weeks, proffering what appeared to be expert investment advice.

title: NBC and CBS Reduce Role of Self-Censors
description: Two of the nation's television networks took important steps last week to reduce further the internal censorship of the programs they broadcast. NBC has disbanded its office of broadcast standards and practices, and CBS, which has been steadily diminishing the size of its censorship operation for several years, said it would eliminate the position of vice president of program practices.

title: Senator Kerry Divorces
description: Senator John Kerry and his wife, Julia, have been granted a divorce under the no-fault divorce law of Massachusetts. Final papers ending the 18-year marriage were filed late Thursday, said Adam Chase, a spokesman for the 44-year-old Senator's Boston office.

title: Swiss Joblessness Low
description: Unemployment in Switzerland, already the lowest in the industralized West, dropped to a six-year low last month, while the number of vacant positions reached a seven-year-high, the authorities said today. The Federal Office for Industry and Labor said that a total of 20,963 jobless were registered in July, an 8.7 percent drop from the previous month. The office said this was the lowest figure since October 1982.

title: Olympic Diving; Louganis on Team a 4th Time
description: Two days ago, Greg Louganis offered the startling opinion that it wouldn't shock him if he failed to make the United States Olympic diving team this year. Who was he kidding? With a typically splendid performance on the 3-meter springboard tonight, he breezed his way onto the team with 1,440.52 points, the most among the 11 finalists, to make the Olympic team for the fourth time. He also qualified in 1976, 1980 and 1984, when he won gold medals in both the springboard and the 10-meter platform. Bradshaw Gets Other Place

title: Ramones at the Ritz
description: The Ramones, a rock band, is to perform tonight at 12:30 A.M. at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800). Tickets are $13.50 in advance, $14.50 the day of the show.

title: Greenwell Drives Red Sox Past A's, 7-6
description: Mike Greenwell took over the major league lead in runs batted in, driving in three tonight, including the game-winner in the seventh inning, to rally the Boston Red Sox past the Oakland Athletics, 7-6.

title: Scotty's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-After a gain of $3,569,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for inventory and a gain of $2,784,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Carlyle Group Unit Lifts Bid for Oakite
description: A unit of a Washington investment firm, the Carlyle Group Inc., has sweetened its offer for Oakite Products Inc. to $45.50 a share in cash. The previous $44-a-share offer from Carlyle Investors V Ltd. was rejected by the chemical company, based in Berkeley Heights, N.J.

title: Late Selling Causes Dow To Drop 11.03
description: LEAD: The stock market underwent an abrupt turnabout in the last 15 minutes of trading yesterday, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average down to an 11.03-point loss.

title: Jeans Company Head Is Ordered Arrested
description: A Federal judge issued an arrest warrant for the creator of Sasson jeans, Paul Guez, who disappeared this week while free on bond for reportedly threatening the life of a bankruptcy judge, his lawyer said.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Fibreboard Corp., Concord, Calif., said it had begun presentations describing its new program for settling injury claims to attorneys for claimants in asbestos-related matters.

title: Budget Outlook Called Brighter
description: Reflecting unexpectedly robust economic growth, the Congressional Budget Office announced today that it had revised sharply downward its projection for the budget deficit in the 1989 fiscal year.

title: Farah Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Sir Frederick Ashton, 83, Dies, Ending a Choreographic Era
description: Sir Frederick Ashton, one of the greatest Classical choreographers of the 20th century and a former director of the Royal Ballet, died in his sleep Thursday night at his home in Sussex, England. He was 83 years old. Sir Frederick's death brings to a close an era in ballet shaped and presided over by three great innovators: George Balanchine, Antony Tudor and Sir Frederick.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Key Testimony Is Faulted In Queens Firebombing Case
description: Lawyers for two defendants charged with firebombing the Queens house of a drug-case witness sought to show yesterday that the homeowner's identification of their clients - the key evidence - was not to be believed.

title: Bradley Quest for 5th Term Puts End to Epitaphs of '87
description: As recently as last fall, the prevailing view here was that Tom Bradley was politically finished after four terms as Mayor, rejected statewide in the election for Governor and blamed at home for growing pollution and congestion.

title: CONTINENTAL AIRLINES PLANS LAYOFFS OF 900
description: Continental Airlines Inc., a unit of the Texas Air Corporation, said today that it would lay off 900 managers, pilots, flight attendants and ground employees in a schedule realignment and management restructuring.

title: Equitex Inc reports earnings for As of June 30
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: Fed Policy Makers Voted to Tighten Credit
description: By an 8-to-3 vote, the Federal Reserve Board's policy makers decided in late June to push up interest rates further in an effort to fight inflation, according to minutes of the discussions released today.

title: Xtra Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,396,000 for the quarter and $1,099,000 for the 9 months. c-After net from discontinued operations of $728,000 for the quarter and $1,592,000 for the 9 months.

title: Hard Bop at Birdland
description: Bill Hardman on trumpet and Junior Cook on saxophone are leading a hard-bop quintet tonight at Birdland, 2745 Broadway, at 105th Street (749-2228). Music begins at 9 P.M.; there is a $5 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: I Hear America Mowing
description: LEAD: So Mike Dukakis cuts his grass with a hand-powered mower. This fact is often cited as evidence of the Duke's frugality and ''old-fashionedness.'' But I think it also suggests another trait of the Democratic Presidential nominee. Sanity.

title: Aircoa Hospitality reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Recognition Equipment Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $730,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: Blasts Rock Gloucester, Mass.
description: A series of about 10 underground explosions ripped through this seacoast city today. Two houses were damaged and 200 people were forced to evacuate their homes and businesses, but no one was injured. Fire Chief Barry McKay said the explosions had apparently been caused by gasoline in the sewer system, a result of a petroleum distribution yard's effort to remove a gasoline tank.

title: Canada Inflation Rate
description: Canada's annual inflation rate dipped slightly in July despite a surge in the cost of housing, food and transportation, the Government's statistical agency reported today. Inflation eased to 3.8 percent, from 3.9 percent in June. ''This is the lowest year-to-year increase since June of 1986,'' Statistics Canada said in its monthly commentary. But the monthly index showed prices rising a strong six-tenths of 1 percent over June, with five of seven major components posting price rises. In June, prices rose one-tenth of 1 percent. Analysts said the strong rise in the monthly inflation rate could cause a tightening by Canadian monetary authorities, leading to higher interest rates.

title: Lawyer, 19, Must Wait for the Bar
description: A former child prodigy who challenged the constitutionality of a ruling prohibiting him from taking the New York State bar examination because he started law school too young has won partial satisfaction.

title: Charges Stand in Arms Case
description: A Federal judge refused today to dismiss criminal charges against a former C.I.A. agent accused of conspiring to illegally ship arms to the rebels in Nicaragua and of concealing the covert operation.

title: Del-Val Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lawmakers: How Some Served
description: At least a dozen of those now in Congress enlisted in local National Guard or Reserve units as young men during the Vietnam War. Page 9.

title: Boston Digital Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: 20 Years Ago, Naive Czechs Did Themselves In
description: LEAD: Twenty years ago tomorrow, the Soviet Union coined one of our century's more memorable euphemisms. By means of half a million soldiers and 5,000 assault vehicles, Moscow ''rendered brotherly help'' to Czechoslovakia because its boss, Alexander Dubcek, had just stated his intention to put a ''human face'' on socialism.

title: Gretzky: Deal With Dividends
description: When the Los Angeles Kings agreed last week to pay $15 million in cash for Wayne Gretzky, perhaps the most dominant hockey player of all time, they had already taken steps to subsidize their investment.

title: Koreas End 3-Year Drought in Talks
description: North and South Korean legislators met today for the first time in nearly three years, but failed to agree on the scale or agenda of joint parliamentary talks they hope to hold later this month.

title: Patents; Tapping the Energy Of Geothermal Steam
description: Engineers at the Unocal Corporation have designed a system that makes it easier to tap the energy of geothermal steam.

title: Kremlin Clears More Stalin Victims
description: More than 600 victims of Stalin's terror have been cleared of the charges for which they were executed or sent to labor camps, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda reported today.

title: Review/Jazz; Frank Morgan And Revelations Of Be-Bop
description: Though the piano was out of tune, the sound system was nonexistent, someone in the audience was whistling along with the band and a bartender insisted on talking more loudly than the music, the alto saxophonist Frank Morgan played a set of astounding music Thursday night, introducing one astounding solo after another.

title: Gaetti Injured
description: He has 26 home runs, 76 runs batted in and is hitting .299, but for Gary Gaetti, the Minnesota Twins' Gold Glove third baseman, the season could either be over or drastically curtailed.

title: Review/Pop; Emmylou Harris Journeys Down Memory Lane
description: For well over a decade, Emmylou Harris has stood as a proudly independent figure in the world of country music. A close friend and collaborator of Gram Parsons, who helped invent the sound of modern country-rock, Ms. Harris has consistently eschewed country music formulas to explore some of the more obscure corners of the country and folk tradition. On most of her albums, her instrumental cohorts have been the Hot Band, a shifting agglomeration of musicians whose original members were Elvis Presley's sidemen.

title: Jersey Gas Leak Forces Evacuation in 2 Towns
description: About 100 residents in Perth Amboy and Woodbridge Township were evacuated from their homes today after utility crews accidentally pierced a gas line, city officials said.

title: Optical Coating Laboratory Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a credit of $553,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Net income The latest quarter included a $1.1 million charge resulting from a special contribution to the company's ESOP.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Elliott Graham on Wednesday gave his age incorrectly.

title: Excerpts From Questioning of Quayle About Guard Role in Vietnam War
description: Following are excerpts from reporters' questions and Senator Dan Quayle's answers yesterday in Huntington, Ind., as recorded by The New York Times. At some points crowd noise made the questioning unintelligible. Issue of Service in Guard

title: Review/Film; Rival Divers Brave the Depths of the Sea
description: At one point in ''The Big Blue,'' Jacques Mayol (Jean-Marc Barr), the not-of-this-world deep sea diver who is the elusive hero of Luc Besson's new film, shows his wallet to a friend. There's a nicely framed picture of a dolphin inside. ''That's my family,'' Jacques says shyly, then he asks, ''What kind of man has such a family?'' Good question.

title: Warwick Insurance Managers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included after-tax capital gains of $64,261, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $346,897, or 9 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Included after-tax capital gains of $100,858, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $251,311, or 7 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: Applied Data Communications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Bentsen Derides His Foes
description: The Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, Senator Lloyd Bentsen, said today that the Republican National Convention had been a ''Mardi Gras for the Moral Majority'' that ignored the concerns of working people.

title: Patents; University Patents Unit Is Acquired by Maxwell
description: University Patents Inc., one of the first for-profit companies established to market university inventions, announced this week that it had sold its licensing business to a new company controlled by the British publisher Robert Maxwell.

title: Our Hostages Aren't Persian Rugs
description: LEAD: Hojatolisalam Hashemi Rafsanjani, Speaker of the Parliament in Iran, has given us a classic example of Persian rug merchant bargaining - whatever the clerical wrappings.

title: Hormel, Geo A & Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Why Fundamentalists Reject 'Last Temptation'; Blasphemous Fable
description: To the Editor:
