title: Ruder Urges Insider Drive
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, David S. Ruder, urged other stock market regulators today to introduce effective and compatible laws to deter insider trading.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies of Sports Pages yesterday about the Yankee-California game misstated the outcome of the Thursday night game in Detroit between the Tigers and the White Sox. The Tigers won, 6-4.

title: National Computer Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $225,000 for the quarter and $682,000 for the 6 months.

title: 'Starlight Express' Out of the Tunnel?
description: In the 17 months since its opening in March 1987 to what were at best mixed reviews, ''Starlight Express'' has taken in $36 million at the Gershwin Theater and has been seen by more than 925,000 people - and it has yet to recoup its investment.

title: Tech Data Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Instrument Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $1,825,000 for the quarter and $3,750,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,140,000 and $1,236,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and tax benefits of $940,000 for the quarter and $3,470,000 for the 9 months, and the 9 months also includes a loss of $1,502,000 from early extinguishment of debt. The company said the latest quarter and 9-month include a pretax gain of $1.8 million on termination of a pension plan.

title: G.M. Cleared In Shutdown
description: An Ohio judge dismissed all but one claim today in a $319 million lawsuit filed by the city officials of Norwood, Ohio, against the General Motors Corporation in an effort to block the closing of G.M.'s assembly plant in Norwood.

title: As Shoreham Deal Falters, Critics Bandy Alternatives
description: The stalemate in Albany over the state's pact with the Long Island Lighting Company to close the Shoreham nuclear power plant has raised serious questions about the viability of the deal and given its opponents time to lobby for alternatives.

title: Patents; An Antiperspirant Based on Antihistamines
description: The Bristol-Myers Company has developed an antiperspirant based on antihistamines. Traditionally, antiperspirants have used aluminum chlorohydrate as the active ingredient, but researchers have long thought that antihistamines - the agents that stifle allergic reactions to pollen - might be more effective.

title: Review/Opera; Old 'Lucia' Features New Leads
description: The New York City Opera brought back Tito Capobianco's by now venerable, or at least old, 1969 production of Donizetti's ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' Thursday night, with newcomers singing Lucia and her lover Edgardo (as well as the nurse Alisa, Lucia's hapless husband, Arturo, and the conniving villain Normanno). Scenically, the opera, now directed by Mr. Capobianco's wife, Gigi Elena, needs an overhaul. But vocally, the audience had plenty to cheer about.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Navratilova Upset: Natalya Zvereva of the Soviet Union stunned top-seeded Martina Navratilova, 6-1, 6-4, last night in a quarterfinal match at the Player's Challenge tournament in Montreal. Earlier yesterday, Chris Evert, Gabriela Sabatini and Pam Shriver advanced to the semifinals. Evert, seeded second, beat fifth-seeded Helena Sukova, 6-2, 6-1. Sabatini, seeded fourth, defeated seventh-seeded Lori McNeil, 6-3, 6-3. Shriver, the defending champion, beat Terry Phelps, 7-6, 6-4.(AP) Krickstein Gains: Aaron Krickstein, seeded 12th, beat Kevin Curren, seeded 14th, 3-6, 6-2, 7-6, in a quarterfinal match at the Association of Tennis Professionals championship in Mason, Ohio. Anders Jarryd of Sweden, seeded 11th, defeated 13th-seeded Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland, 6-7, 6-3, in another quarterfinal match.(AP) Zivojinovic Falls: Jeff Tarango, a Stanford junior, upset second-seeded Slobodan Zivojinovic of Yugoslavia, 4-6, 7-6, 6-1, yesterday to advance to the semifinals of the Mennen Cup in Livingston, N.J. In other matches, top-seeded Andre Agassi defeated Matt Anger, 6-4, 6-1; Simon Youl of Australia beat sixth-seeded Sammy Giammalva, 6-4, 6-4, and fifth-seeded Yahiya Doumbia of Senegal defeated Marc Flur, 6-4, 6-2.(AP) Horse Racing Rio Claro Triumphs: Rio Claro turned back a late rush by Steve Canyon yesterday at Saratoga to score a half-length victory in the New York Turf Writers' Cup, the summer's major steeplechase race. The winner, a 5-year-old son of Damascus Silver owned by Paul Portier and trained by Andrew Elder, won a three-way duel to the wire with Steve Canyon and Jive With Five, who was a length back in third. Rio Claro, who paid $9.80 for $2 to win, ran the two and three-eighths miles over 12 fences in 4:15 2/5 under Gregg Morris. Auto Racing Mears Wins Pole Position: Rick Mears took the top qualifying spot for the Quaker State 500 yesterday and became the first driver ever to sweep the pole positions for the three 500-mile Indy-car races.(AP) Golf Nicklaus Nears Mark: Jack Nicklaus gained the third round of the International Tournament yesterday in Castle Rock, Colo., all but assuring that he will become the first golfer to reach the $5 million mark in earnings. Nicklaus, who has won $4,997,550, must beat only 3 of 54 other players to reach the milestone. (AP)

title: Lewis May Not Have Chance to Repeat
description: Carl Lewis said tonight that because of a dispute with a United States Olympic track coach here, he might not run on the Olympic 400-meter relay team.

title: Parcells Must Cut Receivers
description: Shortly after the Giants completed their final preparations today for the exhibition game with the Pittsburgh Steelers at Giants Stadium Saturday night, Coach Bill Parcells made some observations on survival in the National Football League.

title: Hal Freeman, 52, AIDS Protester
description: Hal M. Freeman, who resigned as manager of the Department of Health and Human Services' regional Office of Civil Rights here two years ago in protest of the department's policy toward AIDS victims, died of the disease July 30. He was 52 years old and lived in San Francisco.

title: Italian Bid For Irving Is Set Back
description: The Irving Bank Corporation's atttempt to resist a hostile takeover offer from the Bank of New York suffered a serious setback yesterday.

title: Pakistanis Quietly Showing Rare Unity After Zia's Death
description: As officials prepare for the funeral of Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, Pakistanis of all regions, creeds and ethnic groups, shocked and subdued by their President's violent death, have been drawn into a rare and perhaps tentative spirit of unity.

title: Patents; A Process to Store Aircraft in Shrink-Wrap
description: Shrink-wrap is a taut, tough plastic covering used to package everything from soft drinks to stereo equipment. This week, James Talbot, co-founder of Fana Inc. of Springfield, Pa., patented a process to store large military aircraft in shrink-wrap. The Army, Air Force and Marines have begun using the covering for storage of aircraft components, and aircraft manufacturers are considering it for use in shipping.

title: Next Office Revolution: 'Voice Mail'
description: At many companies, the interoffice memo has learned to talk. A new generation of telephone answering machines is replacing the memo and the message slip, uprooting office folkways in the process.

title: Thomas B. Dorsey, News Executive, 60
description: Thomas B. Dorsey, former director of the Los Angeles Times-Washington Post News Service, died of a heart atttack Wednesday at the Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 60 years old.

title: Research Group Says AIDS Cases May Be Twice the U.S. Estimate
description: Analysts from the Hudson Institute, a private research organization, estimated today that the number of Americans infected with the AIDS virus is more than twice the Government's estimate and that infection among heterosexuals may be three times as high.

title: Blast Said to Rock Soviet Site in Afghanistan
description: As many as 500 people were killed and 250 were wounded in an explosion at a Soviet munitions dump in Afghanistan, a Western diplomat and Afghan guerrillas said today.

title: Koch and Jackson Set to Meet on Aug. 31
description: Mayor Koch and the Rev. Jesse Jackson are to meet in Manhattan on Aug. 31 for a discussion aimed at mending their differences.

title: Some Now in Congress Joined Reserve or Guard
description: Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana is among at least a dozen members of Congress who, as young men in the Vietnam War era, joined local Reserve or National Guard units and served out military tours near their homes.

title: About New York Extra! Extra! Get Yer L'Equipe On 42d Street
description: A young West African businessman, recently arrived from Paris, hurriedly leafed through the pages of L'Equipe, the daily bible of French sports fanatics. After a minute's search, furtively executed to avoid the inevitable cry, ''Please don't open the papers,'' he located the craved soccer scores.

title: Clendenon Surrenders
description: Donn Clendenon, a hero of the Mets' World Series victory in 1969 and now an attorney and businessman in Sioux Falls, S.D., turned himself in to the police in Sioux Falls Thursday to face a complaint that he possessed cocaine on Aug. 9.

title: Karl Schriftgiesser, 84, a Former Journalist
description: Karl Schriftgiesser, an author and retired journalist, died yesterday at the Gill Oddfellows nursing home in Ludlow, Vt. He was 84 years old and had lived in retirement for many years in Londonderry, Vt.

title: Polaroid Says Cuts in Jobs Will Be More Than Planned
description: Looking for ways to cut costs and improve profitability as it prepares for a possible takeover battle, the Polaroid Corporation said today that it wanted to trim its work force by more than it had planned.

title: COPING: With Travel Photography
description: In the repertory of travelers' nightmares, the one about pictures that do not come out seems to happen with terrifying frequency. The scenario goes like this: You go on a once-in-a-lifetime trip to, say, Katmandu, and shoot roll after roll of film to immortalize your memories and impress your friends. But after returning home, you discover that all the pictures you took are blank.

title: Von Karajan Suffering Circulatory Problems
description: Because of blood circulation problems, Herbert von Karajan could not conduct a performance of Mozart's ''Don Giovanni'' tonight at the annual Salzburg cultural festival, organizers of the event said.

title: Goodyear to Sell Its Oil Pipeline
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said that its 1,750-mile All-American Pipeline, which it started building three years ago, would be sold to pay debts. Goodyear's chairman, Robert E. Mercer, said that while the company was developing a plan for selling the oil pipeline to a group of purchasers, ''no consortium has been formed, no negotiations have been held and no specific terms have been discussed, including price.''

title: The Rowan Case Belongs in Court
description: On June 14, Carl Rowan, the syndicated columnist, shot and slightly wounded an intruder at his Washington home. As a result, Mr. Rowan now faces gun possession charges that could bring him two years in jail. He has pleaded not guilty and calls the decision to prosecute him one that turns ''fairness and the law upside down.''

title: International Cogeneration reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: New Data Show Continued Risk of Lead Poisoning
description: ATLANTA, July 19 (AP) -

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: U Maung Maung; Widely Traveled Leader for Rangoon
description: ''Learning from the past,'' Burma's new leader, U Maung Maung, once wrote, ''may give us humility and help us grow big.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: AUGUST 20, 1988
description: The Economy

title: Unisys Leaving South Africa
description: The Unisys Corporation, the second-largest American computer company, said today that it had agreed to sell its South African subsidiary to a South African company that has interests in electronics.

title: INSIDE
description: The Unlicensed Gun

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5, 28 No Navy officers will be disciplined for the downing of an Iranian civilian airliner by an American warship over the Persian Gulf, Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci said. A report on the incident was released. Page 1 Military analysis: The Navy's rules of accountability for ship captains appear to have been bent by the Defense Secretary, who approved the recommendations of the Vincennes board of investigation. 1 The downing of the Iranian jetliner occurred 11 minutes from the time the Vincennes first opened fire on Iranian gunboats, according to the Pentagon's report of the incident, in which 290 people died. 5 Burma named a new leader, U Maung Maung, the Attorney General and one of two civilians in the Cabinet. People who had demonstrated against the Government appeared to remain unsatisfied. 3 Pakistanis are shocked and subdued over the death of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq. In Karachi, where President Zia had few admirers, there are few displays of mourning, but no visible rejoicing. 3 The brother of the Afghan President said that the Soviet-backed Government in Kabul had little support from the Afghan people and would collapse. Sediqullah Rahi denounced his brother, President Najibullah. 2 Moscow has cleared 636 victims of Stalin's terror of the charges for which they were executed or sent to labor camps and plans to investigate the assassination of Sergei M. Kirov, the newspaper Pravda reported. 4 North and South Korean legislators met for the first time in nearly three years, but failed to agree on the agenda or number of participants in joint parliamentary talks they hope to hold later this month. 3 Middle-class Italy takes to the beach in August at places like Marina Velca, 50 miles from Rome. Italians are enjoying economic prosperity and governmental stability, while a sensational murder occupies headlines. 4 Seven British soldiers killed in Ulster 1 Walesa threatens Gdansk strike 4 National 6-9 New telephone answering machines are changing the way people in offices communicate. Voice mail systems, based on specialized computers, can answer phones, route callers and dispense information. 1 Eight Texas savings and loans were consolidated into a new savings institution by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. The transaction could cost the Government as much as $5.5 billion over the next 10 years. 1 Tom Bradley's political career, thought by many to be over after four terms as Mayor of Los Angeles, has come back to life. Mr. Bradley, who will be 71 years old in December, will run for a fifth term in April. 6 A murder in Schuyler County, Mo., in April 1987, may set too high a cost for justice in the community. The trials for the two men charged with the killing could bankrupt the economically depressed county. 6 Copter crashes in Wyoming forest fire; one killed 6 Judge imposed tax for desegregation is upheld 7 Research group puts AIDS infections at up to 3 million 7 Children remain at risk of lead poisoning 7 Fuel leak in space shuttle is repaired 7 Politics 7-9 Senator Dan Quayle faced questions about his military record. He defended his decision to join the National Guard and insisted that he had not used improper influence to avoid combat in Vietnam. 1 A partisan crowd in Huntington, Ind., turned out to cheer Dan Quayle as he returned to his hometown in his debut on the campaign trail. Many residents were angry at the press. 1 National Guard or Reserve service was completed by at least a dozen people now in Congress. As young men in the 1960's and '70's they served out military tours at home rather than in Vietnam. 9 Michael Dukakis made whistle stops in Illinois, Missouri and Arkansas. He repeated promises of economic opportunity and indirectly questioned the qualifications of Vice President Bush's running mate. 7 TV Review: Politicians and reverence for the family 9 Regional 29-32 Striking workers in Groton, Conn., have not suffered economically because of the seven-week-old walkout at the Electric Boat shipyard. Many have found full- or part-time work in the region's booming economy. 29 Checks written by Yonkers may not be cashed unless they are signed by Secretary of State Gail S. Shaffer, Ms. Shaffer told local banks. The city had distributed payroll checks without a state board's review. 29 A teacher who was attacked last spring by a youth with a baseball bat says he wants to return to teaching even though he lost his right eye. Gary Smith was one of four teachers attacked in one week. 29 People who used unlicensed guns to defend themselves have generally not received prison sentences in New York City, even though they are liable to up to a year in jail, law-enforcement authorities say. 29 New York City's auxiliary police are the unpaid civilian shadow of the Police Department. They wear a similar uniform, patrol the streets and try to help bridge the gap between the police and the public. 30 A stalemate over the deal with Lilco to close the Shoreham nuclear plant has raised questions about the viability of the pact with New York State and given its opponents time to lobby for alternatives. 30 Lawyers tried to discredit a witness in the trial of two men charged with firebombing the home of a Queens drug witness. The lawyers said the homeowner's identification of their clients should not be believed. 31 Police recall 2,000 defective ''hammerless'' revolvers 31 Koch would bar ''derelicts'' from Tompkins Square playground 31 Koch-Jackson meeting set 31 Tricky defendant loses promised sentence 31

title: New Buyout Offer For Irish Distillers
description: GC & C Brands Ltd. has begun a new bid for the Irish Distillers Group P.L.C. that values Ireland's leading whisky distiller at 253 million Irish pounds, or about $354 million. The $5.60-a-share offer was made hours after GC & C received regulatory clearance from Britain's Panel on Takeovers and Mergers to proceed with a new bid for the distiller, which makes Jameson and Bushmills whiskies.

title: State to Sign ALl Checks From Yonkers
description: Tensions between Yonkers and the state board that has taken control of its finances mounted yesterday as the chairman of the board, Secretary of State Gail S. Shaffer, told local banks not to cash any city checks not bearing her signature.

title: WALESA THREATENS A STRIKE IN GDANSK
description: Lech Walesa today threatened to stage a strike at the Lenin Shipyard in Gdansk if the Government refused demands by striking coal miners and dockworkers to legalize the Solidarity union.

title: AFTER THE CONVENTION: Review/Television; Politicians and Reverence for Family
description: The family sitcom made the transition from prime time to prime time in the Republican National Convention. Television viewers, who had the luck or burden of being able to hear what delegates in the sound-soaking Superdome could not, found that both the main candidates and everybody else in sight were running for or with or on the family. Just which family - the great American family or the great Bush family or the great Quayle family - was not always clear.

title: Joseph Barnett, Psychoanalyst, 62
description: Dr. Joseph Barnett, a psychoanalyst who specialized in the field of personality development, died of heart failure Sunday at the Sarasota (Fla.) Memorial Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I., and Sarasota.

title: WHAT COLOR IS YOUR LEOTARD?
description: BODIES Why We Look the Way We Do (And How We Feel About It) By Barry Glassner. 288 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $19.95.

title: A Musical About Brel and Blues
description: WHEREAS the 20-year-old Jacques Brel musical with the unwieldy title hammered away at its themes through songs, dispensing with a standard ''book,'' the new Brel musical at the John Drew Theater in East Hampton through Saturday - ''Jacques Brel Blues,'' it is called - talks itself into oblivion.

title: F. Paul Lumia Is Married To Melanie Anne Maslow
description: At the First Presbyterian Church in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., Melanie Anne Maslow, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Maslow of Dallas, Pa., was married yesterday to F. Paul Lumia, a son of Col. and Mrs. S. Albert Lumia of Bear Creek, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Wallace F. Stettler performed the ceremony.

title: The Gift of a Great Dealer - And Collector
description: Walking along the stately broad streets - shut-faced, but serving here and there as a lofty municipal belvedere - that lead to the Musee d'Art et d'Histoire in Geneva, Switzerland, visitors will find on every hand a poster that says ''Berggruen Collection.'' If they know something of the international art world as it has existed since World War II, they will head straight for the museum. As dealer, publisher and small-scale impresario, Heinz Berggruen from 1948 till 1980 was omnipresent on the Left Bank of Paris.

title: THE NEW FURS
description: This season women are being offered a wide range of choice in all aspects of fashion - and fur coats are no exception. They come in many different shapes, lengths, patterns and even colors. As ''name'' clothes designers become more and more active in fur collections, they too are adding to the already notable diversity.

title: Two Directors Put Their Stamp On Their Dreams
description: Back in 1974, Francis Ford Coppola was already mentioning the auto-industry maverick Preston Tucker as a future film subject. And Martin Scorsese had been given a copy of Nikos Kazantzakis's ''Last Temptation of Christ'' while making ''Boxcar Bertha,'' which was released in 1972. When a project hangs over a film maker's career for a decade and a half, how can it fail to become a monumental albatross? The film maker's decision to keep such an idea in sight must surely indicate that the project has become (to invoke one of Mr. Coppola's much less vital undertakings) one from the heart.

title: Republican Ticket Hopes to Bridge More Than One Gap
description: SHORTLY after George Herbert Walker Bush selected J. Danforth Quayle 3d as his running mate on the Republican ticket, Mr. Bush was asked why he had not picked someone more different from himself. ''He's different from me,'' Mr. Bush said of Mr. Quayle, ''I'm 64 and he's 41 and that's good.''

title: Indian Group Seeks Political Input
description: AMONG the American political leaders who will march along Fifth Avenue in Manhattan today, in a parade celebrating the 41st anniversary of India's independence, few can claim Indian descent. But a Scarsdale resident, Dr. Priscilla Parameswaran, and the national organization she represents are striving to change that.

title: Argentina Attacks Tradition of Anti-Semitism
description: The Argentine Congress has adopted a law against discrimination on the basis of race, religion or national origin that Jewish leaders have hailed as a historic accomplishment.

title: A Frenzy Of Feeding At G.O.P. Convention
description: REPUBLICANS considering a run for the governorship of New Jersey went on a crusade at the party's national convention: a crusade to make sure that none of the county Republican chairmen went hungry.

title: Correction
description: An article on Aug. 7 about Lyons characterized the city incorrectly; it is not walled. A map with the article misidentified the hill district; it is La Croix Rousse.

title: Designs From Nature Translated Into Silver
description: STEPHEN DWECK is a sculptor who went into the jewelry business seven years ago and achieved success with dramatic necklaces and bold earrings combining silver with semiprecious stones, cameos or pearls. He is now entering a field where his sculptural abilities are more evident: silver accessories for the home.

title: Era of Droughts Can Mean Change in Our Meat-Eating Habits
description: To the Editor:

title: Medical Decisions and Personal Choices
description: IF you wanted to, you would be hard pressed to find a forum where you could discuss the many difficult questions raised by medical care today, much less shape public policy on these questions.

title: Kimball Tragedy In Another Light
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: TANIA: Memories of a Lost World. By Tania Alexander. (Adler & Adler, $16.95.) It can't be much fun to be the daughter of a celebrated femme fatale. Tania Alexander's mother was the Russian fascinator Baroness Budberg, known to her admirers as Moura - and Moura's admirers were many. They began with her father, the wealthy landowner and diplomat Ignatiy Platonovich Zakrevsky, who used to stand her, when she was 6 or 7 years old, on the dinner table and make her recite poetry to his guests; continued with her first husband, Ioann von Benckendorff, a

title:
TV VIEW;
Openness on Soviet TV Is Not Without Static
description: LEAD: The power of television in the Gorbachev era is almost palpable. Last winter, when I was in Moscow, there was a large dinner at a restaurant well known for its easygoing interpretation of tipping. The padded bill we were handed was astonishingly high. However, a couple of judiciously dropped words to the effect that these practices could end up on the nightly investigative reporting program, ''Perestroika Spotlight,'' froze smiles and reduced the bill.

title: Community College Strives to Respond Quickly on Jobs
description: DR. JOSEPH N. HANKIN of Westchester Community College may be the only college president whose own description of his job includes the role of leader of a S.W.A.T. team. But in his case, the Special Weapons and Tactics unit was after an educational objective.

title: DOWNWARDLY MOBILE MINA
description: LEAD: THE PINK AND THE GREEN And ''Mina de Vanghel.'' By Stendhal. Translated by Richard Howard. 148 pp. New York: New Directions. $17.95.

title: Republican Revenge
description: True, the Democrats started this year's sniping. ''Where ... was ... George?'' they chanted, to Senator Edward Kennedy's lead, during their Atlanta convention. ''Poor George,'' said Ann Richards, the keynote speaker, ''he can't help it. He was born with a silver foot in his mouth.'' Stung, the Republicans retaliated last week - and ran the name-calling into the ground.

title: Dying Tract in West Is Named a Birds' Refuge
description: The Stillwater National Wildlife Refuge became the second Western Hemisphere Shorebird Reserve in the country today, but the honor may be a hollow one for a once lush sanctuary that is now a dying swamp.

title: Jane M. Sikorski Is Wed
description: At St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bedford, N.Y., Jane Marie Sikorski, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Sikorski of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married yesterday to Angelo Santinelli, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Santinelli of Belleville, N.J. The Rev. Charles Kavanagh, assisted by the Rev. Gerard C. Reedy, performed the ceremony. The bride is a marketing representative for the International Business Machines Corporation in Manhattan. Mr. Santinelli is studying for an M.B.A. degree at Harvard University.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: A Fee-Free Day In National Parks And Monuments

title: NONFICTION
description: A BRIDGE TO PEACE. By Kevin M. Cahill. (Haymarket Doyma, $17.) This is a collection of previously published articles by a physician who has been, as he puts it, ''privileged to share numerous crises with the peoples of the Third World.'' He was in Managua in 1972-73, running the relief program after the earthquake, and then back in Nicaragua many times - in 1987, he made clinical rounds in a tiny hospital at Puerto Cabezas that had been crippled by the United States economic embargo. He toured war-torn Lebanon in 1982: ''Armenian scholars no longer search for God in the Near East School of Theology in West Beirut. . . . The conference hall where ecclesiastical nuances were once the topic of discussion now contains two operating tables for assembly-line amputations and a bin for severed limbs.'' He has been involved with the health care system in Somalia for more than 25 years. In these essays, Kevin M. Cahill addresses United States policy in Nicaragua, Israeli policy in Lebanon and America's potential role in Northern Ireland. But the themes that recur most forcefully are the saddening reminders of how wars, embargoes and famines affect the lives of those who will never shape policy. There is regret, but there is anger as well: ''The antibiotics we take for granted do not exist in the real world of Puerto Cabezas. There mothers and babies die of treatable infections because a U.S. President wants Nicaragua to 'cry uncle.' '' Whatever his subject, Dr. Cahill, director of the Tropical Disease Center at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York, commands our attention with the unmistakable authority of a journeyer returned from scenes of great suffering. As a physician, he has ministered to the afflicted, whether refugees in Somalia or AIDS victims in New York, and in his essays he is an advocate for all his patients.

title: Officer Recounts Role in Larry Davis Shootout
description: In some of the most dramatic testimony yet heard in the trial of Larry Davis, a police officer described last week how he pulled his badly wounded partner to safety during a barrage of gunfire in a Bronx apartment almost two years ago.

title: In Canada, a Long Shot
description: Mill Native, a 40-1 long shot, roared past Equalize through the stretch today to win the Arlington Million in track-record time at Woodbine.

title: Remembering Pinero
description: To the Editor:

title: Laura J. Wade, Nurse, Marries
description: Laura Joan Wade, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter H. Wade of Pawling, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Thomas John Farley Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Farley of Madison, Wis. The Rev. Richard M. Brackett performed the ceremony at St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church.

title: Anna P. Pastore Is Wed To John A. Sommers Jr.
description: Anna Price Pastore, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Pastore of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to John Anthony Sommers Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sommers of Weston, Mass. The Rev. Thomas L. Stiers and Msgr. James E. Collins, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church.

title: SNOW WHITE AND THE DIRTY KIDS
description: LEAD: WHOEVER FINDS THIS: I LOVE YOU By Faye Moskowitz. 178 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $15.95.

title: A Holiday With Pickax And Shovel
description: A FULL coffee pot, crusted with pitch-black soot, was brewing over red-hot coals. Nearby the Taylor River gushed past boulders midstream in its steep path down the mountain. A group of campers, meeting for the first time and trying to remember each others' first names, huddled near the fire as the temperature started its dizzy descent from a daytime high in the 70's to near freezing at night.

title: 80's Pop Stars Pay Tribute to 30's Populists
description: ''Folkways: A Vision Shared'' (Columbia 44034, LP, cassette and CD) was recorded to accomplish a good deed - buying the catalogue of Folkways Records for the Smithsonian Institution. The album also gives a few good reasons why Folkways deserves the attention. With Bruce Springsteen, U2, Bob Dylan, John Cougar Mellencamp, Willie Nelson, Little Richard, Brian Wilson and five others performing 14 songs by Woody Guthrie and Huddie (Leadbelly) Ledbetter, it should remind a few million fans just how much rock owes a pair of itinerant, ornery, left-leaning songwriters who were discovered in the 1930's and have stayed current ever since. Instead of the feel-good sentimentality of typical pop benefit records, ''A Vision Shared'' has at least a few moments of populist anger; its songs won't be bullied.

title: THE SUBJECT WAS FASHION
description: Being in fashion is one great feeling money can buy. But most of us sense a real gulf, if not an existential chasm, between the price of beautiful clothes and the cost of their materials and labor. Consider, for instance, a $300 evening dress by Victor Costa, which may be nearly a line-for-line copy of another designer dress costing $3,000. In the Costa, will you feel only 10 percent as beautiful?

title: The Students Behind Burma's Revolt
description: ''WE have no leader, we have no arms,'' said a Burmese student, lifting the bandanna that masked his face as he marched through Rangoon on a recent day of anti-Government protests. ''But one day we will remove this Government,'' he went on. ''They are shooting at us and we will die. But we will not die in vain.''

title: Benita Harris Is Wed To Curtis W. Perkins
description: Benita L. Harris and Curtis W. Perkins were married yesterday at the Crystal Plaza in Livingston, N.J., by the Rev. Dennis Fletcher, a United Methodist minister.

title: Defending Quayle, Bush Says His National Guard Service Will Cease to Be an Issue
description: Vice President Bush said today that his running mate, Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana, was a victim of a ''feeding flurry'' of rumors that will turn out to be a ''tempest in a teapot.''

title: Mack Lobell Takes International Trot
description: Mack Lobell again justified his claim as the top horse in harness racing by winning the 30th edition of the International Trot tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. We left a yellow rubber bath mat in the bottom of our tub for a couple of months. When we picked it up we found that it has left a yellow stain we cannot seem to remove. We tried scouring powder, then fine steel wool, but the latter left a gray stain, probably because of the tub's age (34 years). Is there a rubber dissolving chemical I can try that might remove the stain without causing further wear of the thin enamel?

title: Safety Remains Elusive at Morrell
description: JUST after she took the job last summer, Carri Lee Miller knew it was a mistake. Her hands would ache after every day at Morrell's meatpacking house here, where she sometimes had to make 1,900 cuts an hour on the hogs' heads that passed by her station. At night, she would wake up in pain with her fingers clenched in a fist that she could not open alone.

title: Nuclear Phobia Over Shoreham
description: NUCLEAR power plants have generally performed safely during the last 34 years, with only one major accident, at Chernobyl in the Soviet Union, and one minor accident, at Three Mile Island in the United States. Since 1954, 408 nuclear power plants worldwide have had more than 4,500 reactor-years of safe operation.

title: AUSTRALIAN DEALMAKER: John Cornell; The Man Who Sold Hollywood on 'Crocodile Dundee'
description: AT Paramount Pictures here one day last spring, the atmosphere was celebratory. The reason: Just four days after its release, ''Crocodile Dundee II'' - which has become one of this summer's top-grossing movies - had recouped its $15 million budget and was pulling in more than $1 million daily.

title: Coe Loses Again
description: When Juan Samaranch, the president of the International Olympic Committee, learned that Sebastian Coe, the 31-year-old British middle-distance champion, had failed to qualify for the 1988 Games, he was dismayed. After all, as Samaranch told The Guardian of London, ''Sebastian Coe is a great Olympic champion, having won the 1,500-meters title twice and made many other contributions to the sport.''

title: POSTINGS: Conversion on East 66th Multiple Choices
description: At the conversion of 301 East 66th Street, the sponsor is offering outside buyers 22,000 possibilities. Only 22 apartments in the 202-unit building are for sale right now, but each is being offered with enough options to allow 1,000 combinations for the mathematically inclined and the choosy. While an option package is as common in new construction as in new cars, it is unusual in the conversion of older buildings. Why? ''It's a nightmare,'' said Bill Kunkel, director of sales.

title: Parental Grief
description: To the Editor:

title:
MUSIC;
BERNSTEIN ON BERNSTEIN AT 70
description: LEAD: On the occasion of his 70th birthday, the composer and conductor Leonard Bernstein was asked by The New York Times to write an article. He replied with the following poem. The accompanying photographs were taken in June when Mr. Bernstein conducted the Chicago Symphony Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Carol Meyer Married To Lloyd Westerman
description: The marriage of Carol Elizabeth Meyer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley F. Meyer of Great Falls, Mont., to Lloyd Goodwin Westerman, a son of Frances Westerman Collins of New York and White Meadow Lake, N.J., and the late Joel Westerman, took place last evening at the Meadow Lark Country Club in Great Falls. Rabbi Leonard Greenberg officiated.

title:
INVESTING;
Fallout From Leveraged Buyouts
description: LEAD: AS the stock market approaches the first anniversary of its record peak - the Dow hit 2,722.42 on Aug. 25, 1987 - the most important question on Wall Street is: Where have all the investors gone?

title:
GARDENING;
Giving Iris a Headstart in the Fall
description: LEAD: HERE we are nearly through the summer, and it's already time to plant iris, the poor man's orchid. Certainly their flowers are just as interesting and As with orchids, the petals are not always the same color, and some bicolors are most striking in appearance. Iris that stand out in a planting, however, seem to be those with light-colored standards, the upright petals, and darker falls, the petals that turn downward.

title: Kimball Should Stay at Home
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Gaetti Faces Surgery
description: It appears that Gary Gaetti, the Minnesota Twins' All-Star third baseman who tore knee cartilage while stealing a base last Tuesday, will be out three to five more weeks. That's the prognosis if Gaetti undergoes arthroscopic surgery, as the team physician, Dr. Harvey O'Phelan, has recommended. Gaetti, who had hoped to return to the lineup without surgery, will get a second opinion tomorrow.(AP)

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. We left a yellow rubber bath mat in the bottom of our tub for a couple of months. When we picked it up we found that it has left a yellow stain we cannot seem to remove. We tried scouring powder, then fine steel wool, but the latter left a gray stain, probably because of the tub's age (34 years). Is there a rubber dissolving chemical I can try that might remove the stain without causing further wear of the thin enamel?

title: Boxer, 22, Is Dead From Ring Injury
description: A 22-year-old Los Angeles boxer died in a hospital today, a day after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage while being knocked out as he defended his state lightweight title.

title: Power and the Justice of the Peace
description: JULY 20 was a historic day in the political careers of two Americans. Michael S. Dukakis was selected by the Democratic National Convention to run for President, and in one of those monumental coincidences, I was chosen by the Hampton Democratic Caucus to be Justice of the Peace. (That's Hampton Connecticut with its 1,400 souls, not Hamden, not East Hampton, not even the Hamptons on Long Island.) What's that you say? They are not comparably significant jobs. In some respects, that is true. While the Hampton Justice of the Peace has practically unlimited power, the President is saddled with annoying checks and balances.

title: President Lyndon Johnson: The War Within
description: IN ONLY TWO BRIEF YEARS -1964 and 1965 - Lyndon B. Johnson did more to advance the cause of black Americans than any American President since Abraham Lincoln, and initiated a program for the enrichment of American life as revolutionary and far-reaching as the New Deal. ''We are entering a new era of good feeling,'' pontificated The Washington Post in 1964, ''and Lyndon Johnson is the gargantuan figure making it all possible.'' Yet little more than a year later, Johnson's own immense powers became an accomplice of his own destruction - propelling him into a war that would dissolve his vision and end his hopes. The story of that transformation, the beginnings of which I witnessed as one of the President's assistants, makes it clear that the war in Vietnam was not only a national tragedy but a personal tragedy for one of the most formidable men ever to occupy the White House.

title: Not Quitting
description: Don't count out Eddie Robinson. Ever since the Grambling football coach passed Paul (Bear) Bryant's career record of 323 victories in 1985, there has been speculation that he would be stepping down.

title: Telling Stores With Light
description: ''CHRIS IS ALWAYS DRAGGING ME OUTSIDE IN THE moonlight and saying, 'What color is that?' '' Judy Freeman looks over at her husband and laughs, as if conjuring up all the moments they have spent in pursuit of intangibles.

title: Headliners; Tourist Trap
description: Traveling alone through Peru, Cynthia S. McNamara stumbled into a nightmare. The 40-year-old American teacher, who has been touring South America for two years, was arrested last December on charges that she was one of the Maoist Shining Path guerrillas who killed two Government officials. Witnesses said one of the terrorists was a ''gringa.'' A local prefect, recalling that Ms. McNamara had been in the remote region, ordered her arrest. Four months later, after her innocence was established, she was released. But earlier this month she was rearrested on the same charges in an apparent mix-up.

title: THE REGION: Tompkins Square Park; When Police and Protesters Break An Unwritten Code
description: IN the 1960's, political marches and demonstrations often resulted in violent confrontation between protesters and the police. But since then, mass protests have become increasingly commonplace, coordinated and even cooperative affairs, as police departments around the country adapted their tactics to include negotiation and restraint.

title:
Ridgewood Journal;
Village Grapples With Decades-Old Parking Need
description: LEAD: ''I TRIED for three days straight to get here during my lunch hour, but couldn't find a parking place,'' said Diane Van Heeft at the paint and wallpaper store.

title: Hunting Curbs Proposed to Bolster Duck Populations
description: Shorter seasons and shooting hours, lower bag limits and other restrictions for the 1988-89 duck season have been proposed by the Fish and Wildlife Service.

title: More Than Just Going Through the Motions
description: IT takes a special something to face the world upside down while hurtling unsupported through the air. David Iversen, a gymnastics teacher, calls it ''guts.''

title: Buy Out Steinbrenner
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: How the Lung Reacts To Ozone Pollution
description: SMOG has one component, ozone, that comes out mostly in the summer, and this summer, both ozone pollution and public concern about it have been at a high point. This year, hot weather appears to be the main culprit. Readings compiled last week by the Environmental Protection Agency confirmed that ozone in urban areas has been at its highest levels of the decade. Preliminary data showed that at four-fifths of the monitoring stations around the country, ozone levels exceeded the Federal standard on more days through mid-August this year than in all of 1987, said John H. Thillmann, director of Washington operations for the agency's Office of Air Quality Planning Standards.

title: Carrie Fishman to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Monte Fishman of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Carrie G. Fishman to Daniel S. Polsky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Polsky of Floral Park, Queens. Miss Fishman is an associate at the New York law firm of Otterbourg, Steindler, Houston & Rosen. Her fiance is a senior consultant in the national reorganization and bankruptcy group at Price Waterhouse in New York. The wedding is planned for Oct. 8.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-19

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Tampa, Fla.;
Young Renters Spur Market
description: LEAD: THE St. Croix, one of the newest of Tampa's upscale rental apartment communities, plans to lure young professionals with amenities that include a weight room, a whirlpool spa and a complimentary continental breakfast on weekdays.

title: SCIENCE FOR MADMEN
description: LEAD: RACIAL HYGIENE Medicine Under the Nazis. By Robert Proctor. Illustrated. 414 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $34.95.

title: THE NATION: Pro & Con: Do the Poor Benefit?; What a Minimum Wage Does to the Economy
description: SINCE 1938, when the Government required employers to pay their workers at least 25 cents an hour, periodic challenges to the New Deal idea of a statutory minimum wage - which now stands at $3.35 an hour - have rarely amounted to more than academic exercises. This year, things could be different. Committees in the House and Senate have cleared legislation that would raise the minimum for the first time since 1981. The House bill calls for a rise of $1.70 an hour over four years; the Senate's would add $1.20 over three years.

title: INDIA'S SOUL FOOD
description: TO AN INDIAN FAMILY, THE tandoori meal is not just food. Like Sunday supper for some Americans, this meal is the high point of the week. I remember gathering with my family and friends in cool breezes at an outdoor concert in New Delhi under tamarind and mango trees. There, we would dig a pit to smoke, grill and roast chicken and meat. As the juicy morsels of meat were taken from the pit, we'd devour them instantly.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Private Sellers Are Sweetening the Bait
description: LEAD: LIKE some builders who have begun offering incentives to buyers in order to sell houses, many private sellers are trying to give themselves a competitive edge through creative marketing.

title: I.R.A. Claims Killing of 8 Soldiers As It Steps Up Attacks on British
description: The bomb blast that killed eight British soldiers today in Northern Ireland is part of a stepped-up campaign by the Irish Republican Army in recent months to target British troops there and elsewhere in Europe.

title: Thomas Curcio Is Married To Virginia Ellen Freese
description: Virginia Ellen Freese, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Freese Jr. of Shelter Island, L.I., and Thomas Curcio, a son of Rita Curcio of Baldwin, L.I., and the late Henry Curcio, were married yesterday at the Freese home. Howard Cronin, a town justice of Shelter Island, performed the ceremony.

title: Paul J. Cupp, Retailing Executive, 86
description: Paul J. Cupp, former chairman of Acme Markets Inc., died of heart failure Monday at Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in Bryn Mawr.

title: Robbery Suspect Is Arrested Minutes After Leaving Bank
description: An armed robber walked out of the Broadway Bank and Trust in Wayne Township today with a bag of money and was arrested 10 minutes later, officials said.

title:
GARDENING;
Giving Iris a Headstart in the Fall
description: LEAD: HERE we are nearly through the summer, and it's already time to plant iris, the poor man's orchid. Certainly their flowers are just as interesting and As with orchids, the petals are not always the same color, and some bicolors are most striking in appearance. Iris that stand out in a planting, however, seem to be those with light-colored standards, the upright petals, and darker falls, the petals that turn downward.

title: New Hampshire
description: To the Editor: The answer to a question about a purported American Stonehenge in New Hampshire (Q & A, June 26) asserted the following:

title: Michel Plitt, Teacher, Wed To Dr. Thomas P. Rothwell
description: The marriage of Michel Plitt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Godfrey Plitt of East Hampton, L.I., to Dr. Thomas Peter Rothwell, the son of Ann Hall of North Fort Myers, Fla., and the late Thomas Rothwell, took place yesterday at the Windy Dune estate in Amagansett, L.I. Edward W. Horne, the town judge of East Hampton, performed the ceremony.

title: Special Today; Fashions of the Times
description: Magazine, Part 2 * Special reports in this issue include: * The new choices for fall, more varied than ever before. * Evening drama - strong lines and striking details. * Great examples of the season's looks, for less. * Accessories, an important part of today's dressing.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''A November certificate of deposit that yields 8.5 percent looks pretty yummy.'' - Maury N. Harris, chief economist, Paine Webber, on why activity in other investments is so slow.

title: Simms Passes Test as Giants Win
description: With Phil Simms starting for the first time in the preseason and Zeke Mowatt starting for the first time at tight end, the Giants made short work of the Pittsburgh Steelers this evening. Simms threw a pair of touchdown passes to Mowatt as the Giants defeated the Steelers, 28-17, and boosted their preseason record to 3-0.

title: 87 Art Objects Are Pilfered From a Baltimore Gallery
description: Officials at the Walters Art Gallery said today that a ''sophisticated'' thief concealed the removal of $500,000 in small Asian works during the curator's vacation so carefully that staff members didn't realize they were gone.

title: Catastrophic Health Act Turns Into a Monster
description: To the Editor:

title: For Recreational Anglers, Slim Pickings, Too
description: LEAD: It was another hot, oppressive August day when thoughts drifted toward the sea. But for men like Fred Byrd and Artie Latch, such longings are unnecessary; the sea is their way of life. As recreational boat owners, they have played on the sea most of their lives, and had expected to be with it all their lives.

title: Researchers Testing Water At a Busy Vineyard Harbor
description: Researchers from the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution have begun a three-year study of water quality in Edgartown Harbor, one of the most picturesque and busy anchorages on the East Coast.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: AMY'S CHILDREN. By Olga Masters. (Norton, $16.95.) This last novel by the Australian writer Olga Masters, who died in 1986, takes place during the Great Depression and World War II, when women and children were abandoned by men who went off to find work, then were taken away by war. Amy Fowler bears three girls in the three years before her husband leaves her.

title: Some Alleys can Now Do Everything but Bowl
description: THE score sheet and pencil are going the way of the human pin setter for many Connecticut bowlers as the newest trend in the industry - computerized, automatic scoring - takes hold.

title:
BODY AND MIND;
Who Is to Decide?
description: LEAD: THE RESEARCH MANAGER OF A MASSACHUSETTS computer company was cutting logs in his woodshed when his knee slipped beneath the blade of the chainsaw. In seconds, his leg was nearly severed. He managed somehow to bind the leg with a tourniquet and drive himself to a nearby hospital. There, doctors packed his limb in ice and had him immediately flown by helicopter to the emergency room of a major medical center in

title: Bronx Courthouse
description: To the Editor:

title: A $200,000 Slip-Up
description: A design error will force workers to take down and rebuild the center section of a partly completed $16 million bridge near downtown Minneapolis. The mistake will cost up to $200,000, take three to four weeks to correct and force an overnight shutting of Interstate highway ramps. Al Pint of the Minnesota Department of Transportation said the state's design consultant inadvertently included a rise in camber in a 30-foot section of the bridge, which is more than a half-mile long.

title: THE SCOURGE OF CHOICE
description: THE COCAINE WARS By Paul Eddy, Hugo Sabogal and Sara Walden. Illustrated. 399 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Company. $18.95.

title: ROUGH PASSAGE
description: Ocean passages like Tom Wicker's are, and should be, all about revelation. I look back on a trans-Atlantic voyage I made last year, alone with my father, and I see how it has changed our relationship. The ocean has a way of telling us who we are. For a long time, I had thought my father and I had let superficial differences get in the way of our ''connecting.'' But as we crossed the ocean, sharing both close quarters and the responsibility for a safe passage, I saw how solid some of the differences were. I discovered that, although we share a lot, we're as often at poles. And that was O.K.

title: Shoreham Impasse Likely to Continue
description: LEAD: AS the New York State Assembly prepares to meet in Albany on Tuesday, an impasse between Governor Cuomo and Long Island state assemblymen who object to his proposed Shoreham settlement shows little signs of easing.

title: Standing Ovations for Shoes and Socks
description: IT may seem like the dull television, but at the J. C. Penney Company, merchandise buyers have been known to watch lengthy television shows starring nothing but shoes, followed by more shoes - and then stick around for the sock show.

title: Living Life By the Rules of the Book
description: My parents live life by the good book. Not the Bible, mind you, but the Entertainment Book. This is the book to end all books, they say. It's a short stubby volume, about four inches thick, and it's filled with coupons for tickets, free dinners and other special discounts for hundreds of places.

title: Inspiration on the Hudson
description: FREDERIC EDWIN CHURCH had many virtues, but modesty was not one of them. The Hudson River painter once wrote to a friend, ''About an hour this side of Albany is the Center of the World - I own it.'' He was referring to Olana, the grand, sybaritic palace he built in the 1870's on a hilltop overlooking the Hudson River.

title: Ms. Powell Wed To Evan Zuckert
description: The marriage of Alison E. Powell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Duke Powell of Wyckoff, N.J., to Evan Alexander Zuckert, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Owen M. Zuckert of Stamford, Conn., took place yesterday at St. Thomas's Episcopal Church in New Haven. The Rev. Michael F. Ray performed the ceremony.

title: Rooney's Condition
description: He was still unconscious and listed in critical condition, but three days after he suffered a stroke, Art Rooney, the 87-year-old founder of the Pittsburgh Steelers, seemed to be doing more than holding his own yesterday.

title: Bridgeport Man Held in Shootings of Two Officers
description: A Connecticut state trooper remained in critical condition yesterday as authorities sought to confirm the identity of a suspect in a shootout in which a New Haven police detective was also wounded.

title: Holly Harder to Wed Bruce Catlin on Oct. 8
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry U. Harder of Greenwich, Conn., and Saranac Inn, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Holly Harder to Bruce Catlin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Catlin of Woodstock, Vt., and Sabael, N.Y. The couple plan to marry Oct. 8.

title: Q and A
description: No Disclosure for Illness

title: THE NATION: Iron Fist, Velvet Glove; There Are Two Lines of Thought On Policing Pentagon Contractors
description: AS lawmakers and Pentagon leaders grapple with ways to reduce fraud in military contracting, a clear division is emerging between two styles of enforcing honesty among arms suppliers.

title: THE STUBBORN STRENGTH OF YITZHAK SHAMIR
description: AFULA, IN NORTHERN ISRAEL, IS a drab industrial town that some Israelis compare to Toledo, Ohio.

title: THE WORLD: A Voice From Pakistan; Now Is the Best Time For the Americans To Push Democracy
description: NOW that virtually everyone in Pakistan seems to think that President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq was killed by someone through an elaborately planned operation, many are trying to guess who would have most benefited from his death.

title: Strongest Quake in 54 Years Said to Rock Himalayan Area
description: The strongest earthquake in the area in 54 years shook the Himalayas along the India-Nepal border early Sunday, the United States Geological Survey reported today.

title: Jazz Veteran to Be Saluted at Festival
description: LEAD: BACK in the late 1930's, when Charles McLean, a jazz pianist, was just starting out, he would spend all his free time in Harlem, traveling from his home in Rockville Centre to the Savoy Ballroom or the Apollo Theater to ''hang around my idols, men like Chick Webb and John Kirby.''

title: Dull Disks
description: To the Editor:

title: On an Island of Ice, in an Arctic Odyssey
description: While much of North America has been sweltering through a summer of record heat, a group of Canadian scientists have been rafting across the Arctic Ocean on a leviathan of floating ice.

title: The Shadow of a Stranger
description: IN OUR AREA, Michael Ross is a household name. It rides past you on people's bumpers (''Electric Fry Michael Ross''). It calls to you from headlines and editorials about capital punishment. Recently I heard it used as a grim verb by one of my high school students. He was describing to a friend the plot of a movie he had rented: ''Then this guy took this girl out to a pond and he Michael Rossed her.'' Connecticut has convicted Michael Ross for the murders - and in some cases the rapes - of six young female victims and has sentenced him to die in the electric chair.

title: Constance E. Kheel, Artist, Weds Timothy Smith on L.I.
description: Constance Elizabeth Kheel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore W. Kheel of New York and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday at her parents' home in East Hampton to Timothy Don Smith, a son of Eugenia R. Smith of Lakeland, Fla., and Don C. Smith of Largo, Fla. Town Justice James R. Ketcham officiated.

title: Joffrey Memorial Season Set by Ballet Company
description: A new ballet by James Kudelka and the revival of George Balanchine's ''Cotillon'' will be presented by the Joffrey Ballet in its Robert Joffrey Memorial Season at City Center, from Oct. 26 to Nov. 13.

title: A Rarely Seen Polish Play is Staged
description: TO summer theatergoers looking for a real - indeed, a surreal and radical - change of pace, ''Princess Ivona,'' a 1935 play about a girl who has been variously described as charmless, awkward, apathetic and ugly, may be just the thing.

title: Why 1992 Makes Portugal Jumpy
description: LEAD: IN an atmosphere of apprehension and anticipation, Portugal is trying to redo its economy, changing centuries-old social traditions - even its whole psyche - to become more competitive with the other members of the Common Market as all move closer to the consolidation widely called ''1992.''

title: Stately Home With a Trove From Egypt
description: THE smoking room at Highclere Castle, about 60 miles west of London, looks pretty much as it has for years, with its large brown leather sofa and chairs. The carved wooden fireplace, terra-cotta-colored walls and inlaid marble table under Canaletto paintings make a male retreat that must have seen many a bridge or gin rummy game.

title: Help From the Defense
description: JAPANESE players, like the Chinese, are rising in the bridge firmament. One of these days a Far Eastern team is going to capture a world title.

title:
MUSIC;
The Very Model Of Modern G & S
description: LEAD: WITH the season drawing to a close, the Essex County Department of Parks, through its Division of Cultural and Historic Affairs, has but a few outdoor events remaining in its extensive summer series.

title: Question Of the Week; Is the Gretzky Trade the Biggest Ever?
description: There are two contexts in which the magnitude of a trade should be judged. The first is the extent of news media coverage and public interest in a deal. In this respect, l'affaire Gretzky ranks with the Tom Seaver, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and O. J. Simpson trades as a mega-event. The second and more important criterion relates to the impact of the trade on the teams involved. There can be little doubt that no other deal in the history of sports has even come close to affecting the fortunes of the parties to the transaction as radically as did the transfer of Babe Ruth from the Boston Red Sox to the New York Yankees, in 1920. ROBERT N. GOLDMAN New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: WHATS DOING IN: Los Angeles
description: Americans are foreigners in their own land in the new Los Angeles. New sights, sounds and smells assault the senses: Korean billiard parlors and acupuncture clinics, Japanese Buddhist temples and eel restaurants, Chinese supermarkets and Confucian schools, Mexican yerbarias and clinicas, Armenian mamoul pastry, Guatemalan love potions.

title: Cease-Fire Takes Effect in 8-Year Iran-Iraq War
description: CAIRO--After almost eight years of a war that has claimed an estimated one million lives, a cease-fire between Iran and Iraq was reported holding tonight.

title: Explorations in a Land of Glaciers
description: LEAD: GREENLAND had always seemed to me to lie at the edge of the earth, a place well outside the traveler's reach. For the Norsemen who settled it a thousand years ago, it was indeed at the edge. Beyond it, they believed, lay Ginnunqapqap, the great abyss.

title: Gift of New Life For an Aerial Prototype
description: IN the early 1940's, Harry Hleva drove his 1937 Studebaker to an aircraft plant in Stratford, where his job was to help build an aircraft called a ''flying boat.'' Today, in his 1988 Dodge, Mr. Hleva heads for almost the same spot, to work on the very same craft.

title: Celebrating The Complexity Of Paper
description: Rags make paper, Paper makes money, Money makes banks, Banks make loans, Loans make beggars, Beggars make rags. (Anonymous 18th-century ditty)

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE BOATS OF CHERBOURG. By Abraham Rabinovich. (Seaver/Holt, $19.95.) The Channel port of Cherbourg, France, one of the priority targets for seizure by the Allies during World War II, has figured prominently in the history books. But a far less publicized adventure story carries us into the same harbor two decades later.

title: THE NEW CHOICES
description: Comforting as it was to be told that this color or that silhouette was the right one - those days are gone. Today, fashion is about making choices. Most women have already settled on the hem lengths they like best. Now they can concentrate on experimenting with the other elements that add up to individual style and flair.

title: EXERCISING OPTIONS
description: Choice. The word itself rings with promise, with giddy freedom.

title: Cease-Fire Takes Effect in 8-Year Iran-Iraq War
description: After almost eight years of a war that has claimed an estimated one million lives, a cease-fire between Iran and Iraq was reported holding tonight.

title: Rebels in Ethiopia Work to Modernize Eritrea
description: By day, this narrow valley carved into the steep mountains seems nearly deserted, the only movement herds of goats scrambling among the rocks. But as dusk falls and the danger of Ethiopian MIG bombers fades with the light, the valley springs to life.

title: Catastrophic Health Act Turns Into a Monster; Fairness Has Fled
description: To the Editor:

title: FOCUS: Chicago; The Merchandise Mart Gets a Facelift
description: DRIVEN by strong demand for showroom space, Chicago's 24-story, 4.2-million-square-foot Merchandise Mart - the world's largest wholesale buying center under one roof - is undergoing a $100 million, 10-year renovation. It is the first major renovation of the building, which was put up in 1929.

title: BUSH STRUGGLING TO SHED QUESTIONS ON QUAYLE SERVICE
description: Vice President Bush and his Republican backers around the country struggled this weekend to break free from questions about his running mate, Senator Dan Quayle, and to focus public attention instead on what they saw as Mr. Bush's substantial accomplishments at this week's Republican National Convention.

title: Charlotte Meyer Married to Charles Glen Arnold
description: Charlotte Russell Meyer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Meyer of Glen Cove, L.I., and Charles Glen Arnold, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Glen E. Arnold of Brownstown, Ill., were married in Los Angeles yesterday. The Rev. Malcolm Boyd, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the gardens of the Westwood Marquis.

title: Horace Greeley's Home Is Under Renovation in Chappaqua
description: LEAD: FOR 20 years, Horace Greeley, the newspaper publisher, was perhaps the county's most famous weekend resident, hanging his trademark white hat in two Chappaqua homes.

title: In Prague, Wistfulness for a Long-Wilted Spring
description: At 1 P.M. on Sunday, quiet groups will gather and attempt to lay flowers at several sites here to mark the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia 20 years ago, an event that crushed the brief blossoming of what was called Communism with a human face.

title: The Banks Are in Big Trouble, Too
description: THE sad plight of the savings industry has recently become front-page news. Outside observers have pegged the cost of liquidating or forcing the merger of insolvent savings institutions at $50 billion, or more - well above the roughly $20 billion available to the industry's deposit insurer, the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, through 1990. Slowly but surely the American people and Congress are beginning to realize that taxpayers will be tapped to pay F.S.L.I.C. insured depositors at insolvent savings institutions.

title: Trade Deficit Takes Turn for the Worse
description: The trade deficit worsened in June, coming in at $12.5 billion, the largest since February. Imports in June rose 5.7 percent, to $39.3 billion, and exports fell 2.4 percent, to $26.8 billion. That was taken as a sign that the American economy, and its appetite for foreign goods, remains strong, perhaps strong enough to persuade the Fed that it must further tighten up on the money supply. One encouraging note came out of the trade report - the May deficit, originally put at $10.9 billion, was revised downward to $9.8 billion.

title: The Two Americas
description: Listening to George Bush on Thursday night, I heard echoes of two clashing themes in American life, two strains that have been in conflict through almost all this country's history.

title: A Consumer Activist Candidy Studies His Hometown
description: When Ralph Nader was growing up in Winsted, he would go to City Hall to watch his neighbors debate local issues. These town meetings gave the young Mr. Nader a look at democracy in action, and he was fascinated.

title: The Life of a Fisherman's Mate
description: I AM up at daybreak, filling the old metal thermos with fresh coffee, the red and yellow jugs with juice. Efficiently I pack the cooler: ham and cheese for the men, tuna salad for the girls, chips and Oreos for the kids. I remember the light beer for my Dad, the Coors for my Coloradan husband and the diet soda for myself. After stuffing a few last toys and a wooly Sesame Street blanket into the duffel, I decide to rest a minute.

title: Tuning In the Universe Sites
description: THE RADIO TELESCOPE, WHICH makes pictures from the radio waves emitted by distant objects (as opposed to the optical telescope, which focuses on light waves) has been with us since World War II. It has revealed previously undetected entities in the universe and, because radio waves are not distorted by the earth's atmosphere to the degree that light waves are, it has the potential to unveil the clearest possible images of astronomical phenomena. The problem is that resolving the pictures yielded by radio waves requires a telescope of oversized dimensions. Early radio telescopes were large enough to let us know that amazing things were out there, but too small to let us see them very well. The challenge of building bigger telescopes has been addressed by a system that combines signals received by an array of strategically placed antennae, all focused on a single object.

title: College Denied Liquor License
description: The Boston Licensing Board Thursday rejected Boston College's petition for a license to serve alcohol at its Alumni Stadium football field and in the Silvio O. Conte Arena. At a hearing on the petition Wednesday, residents of Newton and the Brighton section of Boston near the college asked that the license be denied. ''People should be going to games to enjoy the games, not to drink,'' said Mary Talty, a member of the Brighton-Allston Improvement Association.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: HERITAGE FESTIVAL The folks at the Huntington Historical Society must be doing something right; they've been doing it for 25 years now, the ''it'' being the annual Heritage Festival. And today's the day for the special 25th anniversary edition of the festival. From 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. the Heckscher Ballfield, off 25A, will be alive with activities that take in the entire family: ice cream making and weaving for small fry; more than 100 antique and knickknack dealers for browsers and collectors; a new project, ''Count Me In!'' which, through questionnaires filled out at the fair, hopes to make ''a living record of 1988 Huntington''; and, for everyone, entertainment by such groups as El Teatro Rodante Hispanico, the Doug ''Harmonica'' McClean Blues Band, and the Huntington Ballet Theater. Admission is $2 or 50 cents for children 5 through 12, with those under 5 admitted free. For those who like their days really complete, the Huntington Arts Council caps the day with a production of the musical ''Shenandoah'' at 8:30 P.M. at nearby Heckscher Park. This performance, by Plaza Productions, is free, so bring along a picnic dinner and stay for it all. NEW/OLD MUSIC

title: Diana R. Laing, Chaplain, Weds
description: At St. Paul's Episcopal Church in North Andover, Mass., Diana Randolph Laing, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Christopher Laing of Ely, Cambridgeshire, England, was married yesterday to Charles Adams Thierry, the son of John Adams Thierry of Hill, N.H., and Mary Mills Hatch of Portsmouth, N.H.

title: DATA UPDATE: August 21, 1988
Writer of Bogus Tickets to Stay on the Force
description: A traffic patrolman who wrote more than 1,000 bogus tickets and gave some motorists a break will remain with the Police Department, his superiors have decided.

title: WILL THE STEALTH BOMBER WORK?
description: Malcolm W. Browne's revealing report ''Will the Stealth Bomber Work?'' (July 17), about the Pentagon's latest boondoggle, is another example of how the pockets of tired United States taxpayers are bring picked clean by fast-talking military contractors.

title: INSIDE
description: Buying Time in Burma

title: Are Museums Hospitable to Art and People?
description: Ah, museums! Repositories of culture, arenas of experimentation, chapels for worshiping the most sterling human creations.

title: Correction
description: A review of ''Jefferson and Monticello: The Biography of a Builder'' on July 31 misstated the elevation of Monticello's site in Virginia. It is 857 feet above sea level.

title: LIVING ON A COAST PAYS OFF, U.S. SAYS
description: Regional disparities in personal incomes widened in 1987, as residents of coastal states continued to earn more than residents in most other areas, the Government reports.

title: After a Long March to Nomination, Bush Sprints to Establish Identity
description: VICE PRESIDENT BUSH walked onto the stage of the Republican National Convention last week and, after eight often trying years, became what he had always claimed he was: his own man.

title: Winky Stearns Is Wed To P. K. Hussey on L.I.
description: Winifred Clarke Stearns, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Stearns of Hanover, N.H., and Point O' Woods, Fire Island, L.I., and Peter Kilpatrick Hussey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gorham W. Hussey of Calgary, Alberta, were married yesterday at the Church at Point O' Woods by the Rev. Dr. Daniel M. Young, a Baptist minister.

title: The Past Yields to Present 'Village' Needs
description: THE cratered parking lots, abandoned gas stations and derelict garages that were the secret playgrounds of several generations of Greenwich Village children are gradually being replaced by new, expensive condominium and cooperative apartment houses.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Advertising for Volunteers
description: LEAD: Where should Westchester's volunteer fire departments and ambulance services, on which so many residents rely during emergencies, turn when they have a crisis? To an advertising agency, suggests John E. Hand of Yorktown, the Republican who is majority leader of the County Board of Legislators.

title: LYNDON JOHNSON: THE WAR WITHIN
description: At times during his Administration, President Johnson's always eccentric behavior took a ''huge leap into unreason,'' according to Richard N. Goodwin, a special assistant to the President in 1964 and 1965.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: York, Me.; New Victorian Replaces Old
description: A NEW HAMPSHIRE builder is re-creating the century-old Union Bluff Hotel, which burned down last year, by building a wooden Victorian-style hotel on the original foundation.

title: Clinton Housing
description: Because of a production error, the following letter from the Borough President of Manhattan appeared in only some of last week's editions.

title: Reagan Praises Quayle, Citing 'Enthusiasm'
description: After staying out of the political spotlight at his California ranch this week, President Reagan today praised the ''energy and enthusiasm'' of Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana, the Republican nominee for Vice President.

title: Lisa J. Amoroso is Married on L.I. to David Walker
description: Lisa Jean Amoroso, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene V. Amoroso of Houston, and David Elisha Walker, a son of Mrs. Bayard Walker of New York and East Hampton, L.I., and the late Mr. Walker, were married yesterday. The Rev. Donald J. Desmond performed the ceremony at the Most Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in East Hampton.

title: Premature Praise?
description: To the Editor:

title: TALKING: Inheritances; Selling A Distant Property
description: WHEN an elderly person dies, it is not uncommmon for a family member living far away to inherit the home in which that senior relative had been living.

title: In the Capital, the Party of the Century
description: In her spare time, Etta Virginia Luck Jones said, she does nothing.

title: THE LIVING DEAD AND THE PUFFER FISH
description: PASSAGE OF DARKNESS The Ethnobiology of the Haitian Zombie. By Wade Davis. Illustrated. 344 pp. Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press. Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $9.95.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Boston;
Theater Joins Midtown Plan
description: LEAD: THE Lyric Stage Company recently announced that it will leave quaint Beacon Hill to move into the half-deserted Theater District adjacent to the Combat Zone, a notorious adult entertainment area in the 1960's that is also deteriorating. The company has signed a 20-year lease with two five-year options for a 9,000-square-foot floor in a five-story building at 49 Boylston

title: Suits: Pairing Off
description: IT'S NO SECRET TO THE SARTORIALLY hip that a suit can be more than the sum of its parts - the jacket serving as a sport coat now and then, the pants doubling as odd trousers. Mixing it up, some peole believe, can lend a wardrobe variety and punch.

title: Greenspan's Grapple With Inflation
description: EVER since Alan Greenspan became chairman of the Federal Reserve Board a year ago this month, the big question has been whether he would be as effective an inflation fighter as his predecessor, Paul A. Volcker. Now that the Federal Reserve has decided that inflation is indeed a threat, Mr. Greenspan's strategy is becoming evident for the first time.

title: Miss Cheston To Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. George M. Cheston of Philadelphia and Somerville, Me., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Sydney Cheston, to Jonathan Winthrop, a son of Angela Forbes Winthrop of Hamilton, Mass., and the late Frederic Winthrop. The couple plan to marry Oct. 1.

title: St. Paul's
description: To the Editor: Dean Alan Webster's article ''St. Paul's Is for Yanks, Too'' (Travel, July 10) brought back many pleasant memories. When I am in London, I always enter St. Paul's Cathedral as its architecture, grandeur and beauty appeal greatly to me. A visit to the American Memorial Chapel, behind the main altar, is always included.

title: Some Tips for Midyear Tax Planning
description: IT is time for some midyear tax planning, financial experts say, and the exercise promises to be particularly perplexing this time around.

title: On the Road Again, In Search of Home
description: LONG ISLAND, you had your second chance and you blew it.

title: YANKEE FEMINISTS
description: THE LIMITS OF SISTERHOOD The Beecher Sisters on Women's Rights and Woman's Sphere. By Jeanne Boydston, Mary Kelley, and Anne Margolis. Illustrated. 369 pp. Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press. Cloth, $32. Paper, $12.95.

title: The Riddle of Kid Chocolate
description: A brief obituary in this newspaper recently noted that Kid Chocolate, the former boxing champion, died in Havana under, if not mysterious circumstances, then certainly unrevealed circumstances.

title: Dina Eve Caplan, Lawyer, to Marry
description: Announcement has been made by Florence Caplan of White Plains of the engagement of her daughter Dina Eve Caplan to John Peter Spyros Sarbanes, a son of Senator and Mrs. Paul Sarbanes of Baltimore.

title: George Hartland Vollmuth Marries Janet K. Langlois
description: The marriage of Janet Kathleen Langlois, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Learned Langlois of Massena, N.Y., to George Hartland Vollmuth, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Vollmuth of Massapequa Park, L.I., took place yesterday at the Van Alen House in Kinderhook, N.Y. Judge Warren E. Zittell, the County Judge of Columbia (N.Y.) County, officiated.

title: 2-Hour Commutes and Ladies Nights
description: There was a time here in this mountainous region 90 miles north of New York City when the Catskills were an easy place to define.

title: When Big-Name Talents Tackle Trifles
description: At lunch the other day at China Grill, an exclusive French-Chinese restaurant in Manhattan, a disturbing incident occurred. Coffee was served. The cream came in a geometric, sharply angular polka-dotted designer creamer; I watched in fascination as the cream dribbled, not into my coffee cup but langorously down the jutting lip of the chic pyramidal spout.

title: Charges Stand in Arms Case
description: A Federal district judge refused Friday to dismiss criminal charges against a former C.I.A. agent accused of conspiring to ship arms illegally to the rebels in Nicaragua and of concealing the covert operation.

title: Author Seeks to Inspire Black Youth
description: WHEN Walter Dean Myers was a poor teen-ager living in Harlem, he often dreamed of what it would be like to become a lawyer.

title: China Steps Into Modern Dance, Warily
description: At first glance, the ballet barre appears to be made of wood, but upon closer examination, it turns out to be of cast iron. This is a no-frills dance studio. Functional to be sure; yet, by American standards, drab, cramped, cold and dimly lighted. Like almost everything else in China, it exudes an aura of hardship, stoically endured. The studio's one amenity - a luxury virtually unheard of in capitalist countries - is the abundance of live musicians available as accompanists on a variety of instruments.

title: Full-Frontal Comedy
