description: GOOD MORNING, VIETNAM Starring Robin Williams (in photo), Forest Whitaker, Tung Thanh Tran, Chintara Sukapatana, Bruno Kirby, Robert Wuhl, J. T. Walsh, Noble Willingham, Richard Edson, Juney Smith. Directed by Barry Levinson. 1987. Touchstone Home Video. 120 minutes. $29.95. Rated R.

title: Prosecutors Shot in Florida After Robbery and Abduction
description: One of two prosecutors shot in a robbery died Friday after he was taken off a life-support system. A man found sleeping on a beach in Naples was charged in the shooting, which the police said was a random crime.

title: A Man for the Ages on Staten Island
description: Surrounded by yellowing volumes of history in the library of his Staten Island home, 82-year-old Loring McMillen sits at his oversized desk, remembering with precision obscure facts about the borough. He has been Staten Island's official historian since 1934, and his research has helped to preserve its heritage.

title: Rarely Seen Polish Play is Staged in Westport
description: TO summer theatergoers looking for a real - indeed, a surreal and radical - change of pace, ''Princess Ivona,'' a 1935 play about a girl who has been variously described as charmless, awkward, apathetic and ugly, may be just the thing.

title: Iceland's Rugged Landscape
description: IT was snowing heavily when we crossed the pass. The white sky merged with the white slope and I lost sight of the skiers in front of us. ''Which way should we go?'' I asked my friend, Thora Thorhalsdottir. ''I can't see anything.''

title: BARD OF THE BAR
description: A LETTER TO PEACHTREE And Nine Other Stories. By Benedict Kiely. 209 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $17.95.

title: Bed Covers
description: To the Editor: I am still chuckling over the article on ''How to Sleep in an Austrian Bed'' (Travel, July 24).

title: Player Benched
description: While facing aggravated manslaughter and drunken driving charges, Robert Speidel, Rutgers University's top linebacker, will not be allowed to play in games, according to Kevin MacConnell, director of sports media relations. He said the school had decided that Speidel would be allowed to practice but not play with the Scarlet Knights.

title: Marathon Walker, 81, Keeps Stride
description: LEAD: HARRY ABRAMS has a special affection for the old movie cowboy Tom Mix, but if they make a film of his life story Mr. Abrams wants to be portrayed by someone a bit more like Paul Newman.

title: Revival Of Ferries Planned
description: FOR 250 years, Delaware River ferries linked Camden and Philadelphia. By 1991 the service, which ended in 1952, may be resumed.

title: Carter Is Reported to Meet With Arafat Adviser in Cairo
description: Jimmy Carter met here with a senior official of the Palestine Liberation Organization, an Egyptian Foreign Ministry official and a P.L.O. official said today.

title: George Sand, New and Old
description: To the Editor:

title:
NUMISMATICS;
A New Scholarly Reference Book for the Home Library
description: LEAD: MANY important coin books have appeared in recent years. None, perhaps, is more comprehensive or more significant than ''Walter Breen's Complete Encyclopedia of United States and Colonial Coins,'' published by Doubleday.

title: Cultural Program Inspires Teachers
description: LEAD: SIX teachers sat in a semicircle recently, passing around pieces of Mark Twain's life: a letter he wrote on black-bordered stationery while he mourned the death of his wife and daughter and his handwritten remarks in a book that ''apparently the proofreader was drunk all the way through.''

title: THE WORLD: Q & A: U.S. Refugee Coordinator; What the World Owes 12 Million Refugees
description: THE world has about 12 million refugees, people who fear persecution in their homeland, including many who have been uprooted by war. The war in Afghanistan created the world's largest refugee population, some five million people who have lived in Pakistan and Iran. Though civil war may continue in Afghanistan, the Soviet withdrawal is raising hopes for repatriation.

title: North Hills Project Is Challenged
description: THE fate of a proposed 98-unit condominium complex in North Hills is enmeshed in a protracted legal battle that has pitted three residents against the village's planning board in a dispute over the development of environmentally sensitive land.

title: Mariners Win a Laugher From Yankees
description: The Mariners looked at the lineup the Yankees sent to their clubhouse last night and laughed. Claudell Washington was listed at first base, Don Mattingly as the right fielder and Ken Phelps as the left fielder. It all turned out to be a mistake, though, and eventually a corrected lineup was relayed to the clubhouse.

title: Re: 'Rabbit'
description: To the Editor:

title: Eleanor B. Bingham Married
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Dark Harbor, Me., Eleanor Berry Bingham, a daughter of Alice C. Bingham of New York and Memphis and Charles T. Bingham Jr. of Washington, was married yesterday to Thomas Downs Mallory Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mallory of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Lucia P. Ballantine Walden performed the ceremony.

title: Familiar Scene for Fresh Air Children
description: Eight-year-old Paul Bryant entered the bus terminal, scanned the crowd and ran to the awaiting embrace of his uncle. It was a scene that has been played out countless times over the Fresh Air Fund's 112 years: an inner-city child returning from a country vacation.

title: Some Doors Are Closing
description: A NUMBER of treaties and international agreements say that refugees should not be sent back to countries where their lives or freedom would be threatened. But they do not require countries to admit people who fear such dangers. More and more, countries are adopting new rules, laws and policies to restrict admissions of refugees.

title: Transferring Paper Into Memory
description: THE new Apple Scanner and a software package called Omnipage, taken together, have achieved a radical breakthrough in the world of scanning, the process of converting drawings and photographs into electronic computer files. The products, introduced earlier this month at the Macworld exposition in Boston, have the potential to do for scanner sales what the Lotus 1-2-3 spreadsheet did for personal computers.

title: Folk Themes and Memories in Show by 9 Black Women
description: THEY are called naive, primitives, folk artists or outsiders, but ''para-artists'' might be a more accurate term. After all, these untutored painters and sculptors work without conscious reference to conventional art yet somehow parallel to it and, anonymously, they have exerted an enormous influence on it.

title: Teaching Youths How to Prevent Aids
description: LEAD: FROM classrooms and community centers to beaches and boardwalks, using everything from rhyming raps to printed shoelaces, public and private agencies are intensifying their efforts to teach teen-agers about AIDS and how to avoid it.

title: Diet Is a Growing Concern at the Zoo
description: Aware that captive populations of the black rhinoceros were suffering anemia and were failing to reproduce, Dr. Ellen Dierenfeld, nutritionist at the Bronx Zoo, suspected that they were suffering deficiencies of vitamin E.

title: Forty Niner Holds On in Tight Travers
description: He won like the champion he has always been.

title:
The View From: Heritage Hills;
Camp-Like Quality Prevails Among the Condominiums
description: LEAD: ''IF you liked summer camp, you'll love Heritage Hills.'' Irma Diamond, age in the won't-tell category, offered this opinion while lazying around one of the three pools at the vast Heritage Hills condominium development here.

title: Headliners; Party Animus
description: William F. Buckley Jr. can sometimes be a most arch conservative. Mr. Buckley said last week that he was so fed up with Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut, a liberal Republican, that he had formed a political action committee to support Mr. Weicker's Democratic opponent. Mr. Buckley's announcement came after Mr. Weicker criticized Republican conservatives and said he would not run on this year's party platform. Denouncing

title: Article 768888 -- No Title
description: After five years of legal wrangling, Federal and state officials say preparations are finally under way to remove 108 grams of dangerous radium from a nondescript one-story building in Queens.

title: Re: 'Rabbit'
description: To the Editor:

title: Sluggish Agassi Advances in Modest Surrounding
description: So what is the No. 4-ranked tennis player doing in a place like this? Many of the big names on the men's tour were in Cincinnati this week or practicing for the United States Open, which begins in nine days.

title: When Ordinary Movement Becomes Extraordinary
description: Two remarkable programs offered this past season at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater forced audiences to think about the kinds of movement that may serve as dance movement and the kinds of people who may legitimately call themselves dancers.

title: DATABANK: August 21, 1988

ART;
A Show Full Of Eye-Catchers
description: LEAD: THE slide registry maintained by the Jersey City Museum is another piece of a resume that artists can toss out when hoping to land a gallery or a curator for an exhibition. Artists from all over the state have slides on file there, but for its own summer show the museum has dipped into submissions from Hudson County - meaning primarily work from Jersey City and

title: POSTINGS: Garment District Remake Design Showplace
description: The four corner buildings at Broadway and 39th Street once were centers for textile merchants who served the Garment District. But while three of the buildings were being transformed into malls of designer showrooms, 1412 Broadway was held to the old ways by Arnold Steinberg, its owner for 20 years. Now that one, too, will change.

title: Glassmaking Finds a Home in Vermont
description: THE oversized banner announcing ''Simon Pearce Glass'' comes into view as you drive over the covered bridge that leads into Quechee, Vt.

title: On Language; Let the Credits Roll
description: PROBABLY NO industry imposes its strange argot on the public quite as carelessly as Hollywood does. Those who want to understand the industry must learn about gaffers and juicers, key grips and wranglers, greensmen and gobos, inky dinks and skypans, not to mention focus pullers, Foley men and line producers.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q & A: DORIS ARMSTRONG;
'There Is Still a Shortage of Nurses''
description: LEAD: THE Governor's Task Force on the Nursing Shortage recently recommended, after a 10-month study, that nurses be coaxed to enter and stay in the profession by offering them higher salaries, improved working conditions and more opportunities to get ahead.

title: BEHIND THE FATAL MASK
description: LEAD: ETHEL ROSENBERG Beyond the Myths. By Ilene Philipson. 390 pp. New York: Franklin Watts $18.95.

title: Greek for Every Day
description: To the Editor:

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: DREAMS OF LEAVING. By Rupert Thomson. (Atheneum, $19.95.) Imagine the quintessential English village filmed by Luis Bunuel and written by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. Elms shade the cottages, but no one is ever able to leave - until baby Moses Highness escapes downriver in a basket launched by his father.

title: CLASSIC COVER
description: Women who follow their own personal style are the genuine leaders of fashion. The women pictured here, for instance, have all created an individual look that is a variation on an established and elegant theme. The timeless simplicity of their long camel-colored coats signals a revival of classic American clothes for this fall and winter. In a season of choices, each woman selected this tasteful, traditional style, giving a vote of confidence to the effortless American way of dressing that emphasizes comfort, function and practicality. The dash of fashion is in the cut of the coat rather than in its color or the details of its design. It's this attention to form and function that is characterizing fashion's move into the next decade. The result is a no-nonsense look of quiet elegance that triumphs over the exaggerated silhouettes and excessive frills shown in past seasons by many top designers. Instead of choosing a garment with a limited life, women are opting for a classic that can be worn for years, whether it is a superbly fitted coat or a casual flaring one.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: BEING INVISIBLE, by Thomas Berger. (Penguin, $6.95.) An advertising copywriter with the power to disappear exacts retribution for the assorted indignities of modern life. ''Here, as in previous books, [ Thomas ] Berger evinces an almost Jacobean feeling for revenge, an ear turned to that howl of vengeance that drowns out the small voice urging us to turn the other cheek,'' Francine Prose said here last year. TIME'S ARROW, TIME'S CYCLE: Myth and Metaphor in the Discovery of Geological Time, by Stephen Jay Gould. (Harvard University, $8.95.) To appreciate the immensity of our geological past, we have had to learn to reconcile two kinds of time, writes Stephen Jay Gould. Linear time points like an arrow toward an ever- receding future, while cyclical time rolls along like the seasons. ''In retelling the story [ of geology ] in the light of an ancient dichotomy, Mr. Gould brings us closer to comprehending the vast fourth dimension that lies beyond space,'' David Rains Wallace said here last year. ''The Gould style and wit remain, and the complex argument expands the play of ideas that is the chief pleasure of reading him.''

title: Night Stops Second Round
description: As cars left the Sands Country Club with headlights on and golfers could hardly see the flags from 150 yards, the second round of the $225,000 Atlantic City Classic was finally suspended for obvious reasons at 7:35 P.M. this evening.

title: Harlan Griffin Stabler Wed to David Sexton
description: Harlan Griffin Stabler, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles N. Stabler of Rocky Hill, N.J., was married yesterday to David Sexton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carroll M. Sexton Jr. of Ormond Beach, Fla. The Friends Stony Brook Meeting House in Princeton, N.J., was the setting for the Quaker ceremony.

title: FICTION
description: TOY SOLDIERS. By William P. Kennedy. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) When it comes to selecting innocent victims, the fertile imaginations of terrorists seem to be exceeded only by those of thriller writers. Airplanes full of tourists held for political ransom are, of course, now overly familiar. The same is true for cruise ships, hotels and conventions of business leaders. What fresh targets are left to grab the attention and awaken the sympathies of a toughened public? What will force even the most defiant government to capitulate to impossible demands? How about the capture of an exclusive boys' school, located in the hills of Rome, where members of the American elite - senators, presidents of gigantic corporations and even Mafia dons - send their sons for a veneer of Old World education? The idea certainly attracts one drug-dealing revolutionary, known as Sharif and code-named the Flaming Sword. He has his followers seize the students of St. Anselm's School, then begins issuing outrageous demands, the most extreme of which is that the Sixth Fleet never return to the eastern Mediterranean. If Sharif wins, as the American President points out, ''he'd be the biggest thing to hit the Middle East since Mohammed.'' For a plot like this to work, either in a thriller or as a terrorist action, it must be well planned, move swiftly and carry enough of a realistic edge to make the threats believable. Luckily for the student body of St. Anselm's, Sharif lacks what it takes. Unfortunately for the reader, William P. Kennedy, an advertising executive who is the author of two previous novels, is only somewhat more successful. The intricate planning of ''Toy Soldiers'' is adequate, its scenes of sudden violence well written, but page after page of boring explication slows the novel's pace to a crawl. In addition, the lack of rounded characters makes it difficult to care about what fate befalls any of them, from the most angelic child to the master of evil himself.

title: 5 MORE COAL MINES JOIN POLISH STRIKE
description: Poland's leaders struggled today to contain labor unrest, as the number of coal mines struck by workers rose to 10 and labor organizers at the country's biggest steel mill threatened a strike.

title: A Recital That Altered A Life
description: ''OH, darling, just a little music for Grandma and Grandpa. Please? You'll just love it, Mother; she plays like a little angel!'' How many times have we shown off the accomplishments of our children to captive audiences in our home, deriving tremendous personal satisfaction from the child prodigy among us? How much of our own ego is tied up in these successes of our children - from baseball to soccer to school plays to piano recitals. On and on and on, we push our children to perform. Of course, all these activities are good for them. Or are they? I wonder if we stop at all to think of the pressure to excel that we impose on our children. What of the effect on them if they feel they don't succeed? I overheard a conversation recently as I was playing tennis next to a soccer field. A game was in progress, and the 5-year-old boys were playing their hearts out. But all I heard was the coach, furious at one boy who let the ball get by him.

title: U.N. Plans $35 Million for Conference Centers
description: The United Nations plans to spend up to $35 million in 1990 and 1991 to build conference centers in Addis Ababa and Bangkok, according to unpublished budget projections prepared by the Secretariat and made available to member governments.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Pittsburgh;
3 Tax-Exempts Pay City Fee
description: LEAD: A $280 MILLION construction project in the heart of this city's medical community has taken on great significance for property-tax-exempt institutions locally and nationwide.

title: Czechoslovakia
description: To the Editor: Readers of the Travel section may be interested in my recent experience in Czechoslovakia.

title: Denial of Hinckley Outing Linked to Foster Sketch
description: A letter that John W. Hinckley Jr. wrote to obtain a sketch of the actress Jodie Foster nude prompted a mental hospital to cancel its plan to take the Presidential assailant on a field trip, according to people familiar with the case.

title: Man Held in Light Bulb and Sunglasses Fraud
description: The target was ''Tex-Moishe,'' a swindler of sunglasses, a master predator of packaging tape, a brigand who fleeced his way up and down the East Coast, stealing millions from merchants of light bulbs.

title: Margarita Gatchalian Weds
description: Margarita Gatchalian, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jose A. Gatchalian of Manila and Benicia, Calif., was married yesterday to Denny J. Jarecki, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Jarecki of Waukesha, Wis. The Rev. Christopher Maloney performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Notre Dame in New York. The bride is the business manager for Ellen Jacobs Associates, a public relations firm in New York. Mr. Jarecki is an arts administrator at the City Center Theater in New York.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Leasing by Foreign Companies; Banks Create a Bright Spot in a Sluggish Market
description: LIKE the restaurateurs cashing in on a surge of tourists from across the globe this year, Manhattan landlords are renting space to foreign companies with prodigious appetites for office expansion.

title: PAINTERS FROM THE MIDNIGHT SUN
description: NORTHERN LIGHT Nordic Art at the Turn of the Century. By Kirk Varnedoe. Illustrated. 286 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $50.

title: Remember the Base-Closings Bill
description: In a burst of good sense, the House voted overwhelmingly last month to let the Pentagon close redundant military bases. It looked as if the bill might then quickly be reconciled with a slightly different Senate version. Instead, it got caught up in politicking over President Reagan's veto of the defense authorization bill.

title: Alyson Craig Flournoy To Wed J. C. Schaible
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Flournoy of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Alyson Craig Flournoy to John Clifford Schaible, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford R. Schaible of Dayton, Ohio. The couple plan to marry in December.

title: For Hamptons, House Numbers
description: LEAD: A CERTAIN charm associated with country living is characterized by the familiarity that exists between homeowners and the members of the community that service them, such as shopkeepers, the police and postal service employees. East Hampton residents enjoyed this special type of homespun intimacy until about l5 years ago.

title: Verbatim; Dead Letters
description: 'I didn't want to have greedy little eyes and greedy little fingers going over them. My aunt may have been many things, but to my knowledge she was not a writer.' - Stephen Joyce, James Joyce's grandson, defending his decision to destroy letters from his Aunt Lucia, the writer's schizophrenic daughter.

title: Leslie Roberts Married To Robert M. Guillot Jr.
description: Leslie Jane Roberts, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Leslie Roberts Jr. of Philadelphia, and Robert Miller Guillot Jr., the son of Dr. and Mrs. Guillot of Florence, Ala., were married yesterday. The Rev. Russell Claussen performed the Protestant ceremony at the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims in Brooklyn.

title: Tech Troubles
description: To the Editor:

title: ENGLISH HURT HER LIPS
description: PALM LATITUDES By Kate Braverman. 384 pp. New York: The Linden Press/ Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: 2 Koreas, Teeth Clenched, Continue Border Talks
description: North and South Korea once again failed today to make headway in their second day of talks at this border village, but both sides said they would meet again Monday to discuss terms for a joint parliamentary meeting.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: August 21, 1988
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 3 FALLEN HEARTS, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $4.95.) The scandals and horrors of her past return to haunt a bride in a backwoods town. 2 6 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles terrorists in England, Ireland and America. 3 4 SPHERE, by Michael Crichton. (Ballantine, $4.95.) Four scientists explore an alien spaceship found on the floor of the South Pacific. 4 4 HOT FLASHES, by Barbara Raskin. (St. Martin's, $4.95.) title: Ms. O'Brien Wed In Massachusetts To Robert Rohn
description: At the First Congregational Church in Nantucket, Mass., Katharine Louise O'Brien, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donal Clare O'Brien Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and Nantucket, was married yesterday to Robert Lawrence Rohn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Wesley Rohn of Naples, Fla., and Litchfield, Conn. The Rev. Thomas Richard, minister of the First Congregational Church, and the Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr., minister of the First Presbyterian Church in New Canaan, performed the ceremony.

title: HOW FAR TO PUSH THE AMERICANS
description: LEAD: ENTER THE DRAGON China's Undeclared War Against the U.S. in Korea, 1950-51. By Russell Spurr. Illustrated. 335 pp. New York: Newmarket Press. $22.95.

title: Naval Maneuvers
description: LEAD: SOUTHAMPTON commercial fishermen who fear that naval exercises conducted 26 miles offshore will scare off fish have asked Representative George J. Hochbrueckner to help persuade the Navy to practice somewhere else. The fishermen's fears came from a July 6 announcement in the Coast Guard's local notice to mariners, which warned of exercises using live ammunition in a 70-square-mile area south of the Shinnecock Canal.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Beyond the Droughts; The Green Revolution: How Much Farther Can It Go?
description: BY the end of the fall harvest, world grain supplies could be the tightest since World War II. While the Department of Agriculture says there is little danger that the world will run out of food, some experts outside the Government insist that the extent of the damage is being seriously understated. They warn that rising prices and tight supplies could cause setbacks in the war on hunger.

title: France Announces Accord on New Caledonia
description: The French Government announced an agreement today on the future of New Caledonia that offers amnesty for many jailed Melanesian separatists and sets rules for a referendum in 1998 on independence for the South Pacific territory.

title: Airliner's Tires Blow Out
description: An Eastern Airlines Boeing 727 jet blew two tires today as it landed and skidded to a stop at National Airport, but none of the 156 people aboard was injured, officials said. The plane, Flight 158 from Miami, came to a halt at the intersection of the airport's two longest runways, forcing their closure for more than three hours. Hundreds of passengers were reported stranded.

title: SHAME IN SIMLA
description: THE WORLD ELSEWHERE And Other Stories. By Nirmal Verma. 238 pp. St. Paul: Readers International/ Consortium Book Sales. $16.95.

title: POSTINGS: White Plains Town Houses 30 Homes Where Two Once Stood
description: In southern Westchester County, where homes offered for $200,000 are considered moderate-cost housing, four new town houses will be priced at just under $150,000. The condominiums are part of a 30-unit development in White Plains whose prices peak, in fact, at $185,000. Ranging from 710 to 1,030 square feet, the one-bedroom town houses have one or two levels or one level and a loft, and all have one-car garages. And with no health club or other common facilities, even the monthly charges are low - from about $100 to $150.

title: Nostalgia Embraces 70's Punk
description: Nostalgia, sentimentality and other forms of weepy nonmacho behavior are much derided in the harder, tougher precincts of rock-and-roll. And no rockers thought themselves tougher than the early, mid-1970's-vintage New York punks. It is thus an almost delicious irony that we seem to be seeing a budding nostalgia boomlet for just that mid-70's New York punk-rock scene.

title: On Maine's Grand Tour, Mexico Is North of Paris
description: George Skoglund works in Denmark, Sweden and Norway, but he doesn't run an international business. He is a brick mason and Denmark, Sweden and Norway are towns in Maine.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Help for farmers; Africa's Push To Become Self-Sufficient
description: AFRICA, the only continent unable to feed itself, may soon experience a green reform, but not a green revolution, agricultural experts say.

title: Correction
description: An article about Leonard Bernstein on page 1 of the Arts and Leisure section today gives an incorrect time for part of the Tanglewood gala honoring him. The final program, which he will conduct, is scheduled for next Sunday at 2:30 P.M., not in the evening.

title: Judge a Suicide As Reports Cite Sexual Conduct
description: A judge killed himself in a deserted hallway of the county courthouse Thursday after he learned that allegations of sexual misconduct were being published. A friend said the judge felt hounded by the press and unable to bear it anymore.

title: Can Bush as Bush Steal the Show?
description: The biggest question about the four-day television show sponsored by the Republican Party in New Orleans - ''All in the Family Ties'' - was whether it was going to be a continuing series or a one-shot pilot constituting an unsuccessful screen test for George Bush.

title: Linda Ishkanian Weds
description: Linda Ishkanian, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vahe Ishkanian of Teaneck, N.J., and Edward Joseph Munshower 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Munshower of Ormond Beach, Fla., were married yesterday at St. Illuminator's Armenian Apostolic Cathedral in New York. The Rev. William Yurko, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony. The bride is a vice president and a lawyer at Siegel & Gale, a corporate communications company in New York. The bridegroom is a fixed-income trader and mutual fund portfolio manager at the McKay-Shields Financial Corporation in New York.

title:
THEATER;
Just Whose Role Is It Anyway?
description: LEAD: When broadway names leave Broadway shows, seat belts are fastened for a bumpy night. The inevitable departure of a Robert Lindsay, a Carol Channing or a Bernadette Peters creates the potential for seismic action, felt mostly in the box office.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: NATALIE & R.J.: Hollywood's Star-Crossed Lovers. By Warren G. Harris. (Dolphin/Doubleday, $16.95.) Here is proof that you can judge a book by its cover - or at least by its title. ''Natalie & R.J.: Hollywood's Star-Crossed Lovers'' is a straightforward telling of the tale of Natalie Wood and Robert Wagner.

title: JOHNSON WANTS TO 'PUMP UP' METS
description: Dave Johnson, fighting new depths of anxiety over his backsliding Mets, said today that he would address a team meeting before Sunday's game ''to try to pump the guys up.''

title: Pollution Ills Stir Support for Environment Groups
description: The state of many beaches this summer and scientific reports that pollution may be altering the climate are the two key factors contributing to a surge of support for the environmental movement.

title: Q and A
description: Foreign Currency

title: Symbol of Wilds' Return Flies in Massachusetts
description: Fifty years after hundreds of families were displaced to make way for the Quabbin Reservoir in central Massachusetts, a new inhabitant is trying to make a life there.

title: Neighborhood Groups Wield Influential Role in Yonkers
description: FOUNDED at the turn of the century, the Park Hill Residents' Association has focused its energies over the decades on the usual concerns of civic groups across suburban America: trimming trees, installing a new street sign, opposing a zoning variance.

title: Reviews/Music; Chicago Group in Premiere of Mozart Scoring
description: If the string quartet and the orchestra had largely aristocratic ties in Mozart's day, the wind band was a more populist and adaptable ensemble, as much at home in a parade or a concert in the town square as in a more intimate salon performance. The Chicago Symphony Winds have been specializing in this literature for a decade, and at a Mostly Mozart concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening the group and a half-dozen guest singers and players presented an ample selection of Mozart's music for variously configured wind ensembles.

title: Veterans Administration Criticized for Errors
description: A Congressional committee has charged that the Veterans Administration, which provides $14 billion a year in disability and pension benefits to about 4 million Americans, has been unfair to thousands of veterans and has concealed its own findings of ''error and bias.''

title: MAKING A CASE FOR DISTORTION
description: FLANNERY O'CONNOR Collected Works: ''Wise Blood,'' ''A Good Man Is Hard to Find,'' ''The Violent Bear It Away,'' ''Everything That Rises Must Converge,'' Stories and Occasional Prose, Letters. Edited by Sally Fitzgerald. 1,281 pp. New York: The Library of America. $30.

title: Montauk Catch Proving Elusive
description: LEAD: CAUGHT between the tides of politics and pollution, people who make their living from the sea have not had a very good summer.

title: A Just Declaration - Palestinian Statehood
description: LEAD: It is inevitable that there will be a unilateral Palestinian declaration of independence and statehood covering the disputed territories. What remains to be seen is whether the proclamation of the Palestinian state leads to peace in the Middle East or to catastrophe for both Israelis and Palestinians.

title: 5 Children Die in Fire in Jersey Project
description: Five children died in their beds early this morning as smoke from a kitchen fire filled and blackened their bedrooms in a housing project here.

title: American Sound: Blues to Country
description: THE Charles Ives Center for the Arts in Danbury is promising an ''afternoon of fun'' today from 1 to 6 P.M. ''with the sights and sounds of America,'' namely blues, jazz, folk and country.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Emergency Pet Care
description: It is a typical case. The cat lives in a six-story apartment building in Mamaroneck. It's a hot summer night, and the family feline leaps daintily out the open window to enjoy the fresh air.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: DANBURY BICYCLE RACES Last year 500 bicyclers participated in the Downtown Danbury Criterium. This year, with nine races scheduled from 8 A.M. and 3 P.M. today, up to 900 participants are expected. No more than 100 cyclers are permitted to race at any one time.

title: THE MAN WHO BOUGHT BLOOMINGDALE'S
description: In Phil Patton's article ''The Man Who Bought Bloomingdale's'' (July 17), Robert Campeau attributes an episode of severe depression to an allergic reaction to anesthesia.

title: Blasts Rock Gloucester, Mass.
description: A series of about 10 underground explosions, apparently caused by gasoline in the sewer system, ripped through this seacoast city today. The explosions blew off 20 to 40 manhole covers, damaged two houses and caused the evacuation of about 200 people from homes and businesses, but no one was injured. Fire Chief Barry McKay said the gasoline in the sewer system was apparently been a result of a petroleum distribution yard's effort to remove a gasoline tank.

title: A Briefing for the Next President
description: MR. PRESIDENT, almost instantly you need to make the most important economic decision of your Administration.

title: Guard Those Flanks
description: WHENEVER your correct strategy calls for an attack on the queenside, it is wise to an equal part of your attention to what might happen on the other wing.

title: Korean War Memorial Is 'Way Overdue'
description: In reference to the recent article about Eli S. Belil and his effort to build a Korean War memorial:

title: 80 Homemade Knives Seized At Rikers Detention Center
description: A large cache of homemade weapons has been uncovered on Rikers Island by New York City correction officers conducting a search, a spokeswoman for the correction department said.

title: Inflation Reduced
description: To the Editor: ''Inflation Redux'' (Prospects, July 31) evidently could not quote an economist of the disinflationary bent. I offer my forecast.

title: For Cardinal, Frustration and Regrets on Yonkers
description: Seven months after the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York was thrust into the middle of the Yonkers housing desegregation dispute, the main consequences have been a convoluted court case, confusion over the church's stand and a palpably frustrated John Cardinal O'Connor.

title: Posters at The Modern: From 'Daubed Effigies' To Cherished Art
description: In one of his stories of the 1890's, ''In the Year of Jubilee,'' the English novelist George Gissing describes an underground station in late Victorian London: ''High and low, on every available yard of wall, advertisements clamoured to the eye; theatrs, journals, soaps, medicines, concerts, furniture, wines, prayer-meetings - all the produce and refuse of civilization announced in staring letters, in daubed effigies, base, paltry, grotesque.''

title: 'DESTROY EVERYTHING THAT IS BORING'
description: LEAD: THE ILLUSTRATOR By James Robison. 202 pp. New York: Summit Books. $17.95.

title: 2 Canadian Tories Call Kickbacks Routine
description: Two Conservative Party legislators have charged that kickbacks are routine in Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's Conservative Government.

title: Democrats Concede Seat to Goodhue
description: LEAD: FOR the first time in her political career, State Senator Mary B. Goodhue is running virtually unopposed as she seeks a sixth term in the 37th Senatorial District, a sprawling area that takes in part of White Plains, most of northern Westchester and all of Putnam County.

title: FICTION
description: FARAWAY PLACES. By Tom Spanbauer. (Putnam, $16.95.) In ''Faraway Places,'' Tom Spanbauer's promising fiction debut, images of innocence are woven into a taut, brutal narrative of three murders as witnessed by a 13-year-old named Jake Weber. The setting is Wind River, Idaho, a rural landscape where power lines hinge the alfalfa fields to the sky. The drama begins when Jake takes a forbidden swim in the river, during which he sees on shore three people he's been told to avoid - and whose murders he watches in shocked succession. As Jake gropes to comprehend these and other gruesome events, Mr. Spanbauer fills his story with analogies and associations drawn from Jake's everyday life, using everything from the boy's catechism to fairy tales, comics and movies, even the state fair. Thus seemingly mundane observations are connected, perverted by the sinister. A whirring fan, the chords of a church organ, the rustling of pigeon wings and cottonwood leaves lead the precocious Jake to recall the screams of a dying woman, a murderer's savage cursing, the hideous sound of five Doberman pinschers devouring their owner's corpse. Throughout the novel, Jake's mother's litany with her rosary beads and her assurances that ''one thing always leads to another'' feed the child's superstitious conviction that his disobedient swim has caused the violence that now haunts him. And as this conviction grows, the repetitious, incantatory quality of Jake's injured monologue, which initially seems vexing, ultimately comes to hypnotize, shimmering like the brilliant sun on the alfalfa fields.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
After the Bluefish
description: LEAD: The New Rochelle Municipal Arena will be one of the three starting points for a major sport-fishing tournament on Friday and Saturday, when the Arthur Smith Bluefish Tournament of New York will be open for the first time to anglers setting out into Long Island Sound, as well as into the open ocean.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Boston;
Theater Joins Midtown Plan
description: LEAD: THE Lyric Stage Company recently announced that it will leave quaint Beacon Hill to move into the half-deserted Theater District adjacent to the Combat Zone, a notorious adult entertainment area in the 1960's that is also deteriorating.

title: Crash's Survivor Heals and Grows
description: THE lone survivor of a Northwest Airlines crash in Detroit a year ago is doing ''amazingly well'' and may need no further surgery.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: A GODFORSAKEN HOLE. By Evgeny Zamyatin. Translated by Walker Foard. (Ardis, $17.95.) Evgeny Zamyatin (1884-1937) stands squarely in the great tradition of Russian writers who loathe closed society and lovingly pillage it for material. He is principally known in the West for his razor-sharp dystopian novel ''We'' (published in 1924 and said to be the inspiration for Orwell's ''Nineteen Eighty-Four''), which portrays a mathematically programmed society governed in the name of happiness and ''nonfreedom'' by an autocratic ruler called the Well Doer.

title: A Bright Newcomer
description: FOR the past month I've been shooting with the Chinon Genesis, a camera described by its maker as ''the first major new development in 35-millimeter design in decades.'' More accurately, it's one of a trio of new and shapely cameras designed to bridge the gap between simple ''point-and-shoot'' models and single lens reflexes. The other two bridge cameras are the Olympus Infinity Super Zoom 300 and the Yashica Samurai.

title: NOT JUST ANYONE'S LIFE
description: FAMILY POLITICS By John Buckley. 332 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: A NEW report by the New Jersey Conservation Foundation recommends rezoning and other measures to protect the Manumuskin River watershed in Atlantic and Cumberland Counties.

title: Marcy Innes, a Teacher, Marries Perry D. Nelson
description: Marcy Holbrook Innes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George L. Innes of Bronxville, N.Y., and Perry Duncan Nelson, the son of Duncan Morse Nelson of Sudbury, Mass., and the late Mrs. Robert T. Parsons, were married yesterday. The Rev. Cynthia Briggs Kittredge performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Moseley Chapel at Governor Dummer Academy in Byfield, Mass.

title: Turmoil at the Elliman Co-op Brokerage
description: THE last few weeks have brought the chaos of civil war to Douglas Elliman, a 77-year-old industry leader known for quiet integrity in the business of selling Manhattan co-ops and managing posh apartment buildings.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf Nicklaus Hits $5 Million Mark: Jack Nicklaus passed $5 million in career earnings yesterday, but a three-putt bogey on the 17th hole cost him a place in the final round of the International Golf Tournament at Castle Rock, Colo. Nicklaus appeared to have a berth in the final sewed up until he hit the par-5 17th, probably the easiest hole he designed on the Castle Pines Golf Club course. Under the modified Stableford scoring system used for this tournament, a double-bogey, and anything higher, costs a player 3 points. In Nicklaus's case, he dropped from 7 points and a berth in the 18-man final round to 4 points and out. Nicklaus finished in a four-way tie for 34th, worth $5,275 from the total purse of $1 million. That was enough to make him the first man to reach $5 million in career earnings. He is now at $5,002,825. Bruce Lietzke led the 18 qualifiers with 14 points. Jodie Mudd and Ben Crenshaw each had 13 points.(AP) Moody Grabs Second-Round Lead: Orville Moody made seven birdie putts and missed only one green in regulation yesterday, shooting a six-under par 65 to go nine under and grab the second-round lead at the $250,000 Greater Grand Rapids (Mich.) Open. Moody had a two-day total of 133 and a one-shot lead over first-day leader Chi Chi Rodriguez and Harold Henning. The defending champion, Billy Casper, and Jim Ferree, who won the tournament in 1986, were two shots off the lead.(AP) Basketball Olympians Win Again: Jeff Grayer, a 6-foot-5-inch guard from Iowa State, led all scorers with 18 points Friday night as the United States Olympic team overwhelmed a team of National Basketball Association players, 100-67, at Richfield, Ohio. Grayer was the fifth player to lead the United States team in scoring in the four games against N.B.A. opposition. Danny Manning of Kansas shared the lead with Dan Majerle of Central Michigan on Aug. 7 in Providence, R.I. The Olympic team won all four games. On Friday, Mitch Richmond of Kansas State scored 14 points, Manning 12, Willie Anderson of Georgia 11 and Hersey Hawkins of Bradley 10. David Robinson, center on the Olympic team, got into early foul trouble, picking up his fourth foul just 29 seconds into the second half. He finished with 6 points and 5 rebounds in 12 minutes.(AP) Cycling Gold Medalist Fails to Qualify: Mark Gorski, winner of the 1984 Olympic gold medal in the 1,000-meter event, lost a national championship and a berth on this year's United States Olympic team after Ken Carpenter beat him Friday night in the final of the men's match sprint at the United States track cycling Olympic trials and national championships in Houston. Carpenter, of La Mesa, Calif., pulled away from Gorski on the last lap and held on to win his first national sprint championship and a trip to Seoul. Carpenter, the 1987 Pan Am Games gold medalist, was timed in 11.49 and 11.95 seconds, beating Gorski in straight heats. Connie Young, who competed as a speed skater in the Winter Olympics in 1980 and 1984, will ride in the first women's Olympic match sprint competition. (AP) Mike Engleman Wins 14th Stage: Mike Engleman of the Wheaties-Schwinn Team held on through 106 miles of heat and gusting winds yesterday to win the Morgul-Bismarck Circuit Road Race, the 14th stage of the men's Coors International Bicycle Classic, at Superior, Colo. The 7-Eleven Team, however, held on to the top three spots in the overall standing heading into today's final stage, the University of Colorado-Boulder Circuit Race.(AP) Road Racing Qualifiers for Fifth Avenue Mile: John Pfisterer of Witold's Runners was the third and final qualifier for the Mercedes Fifth Avenue Mile Run, winning yesterday in 4 minutes 19 seconds in Central Park. Barbara Brew of Brooklyn led the women in 4:51. Auto Racing Elliot Wins Pole Position: Bill Elliott won the pole position for today's Champion 400 stock-car race at Brooklyn, Mich. He qualified in his Ford Thunderbird at 174.940 miles per hour yesterday and took more than two m.p.h. off the track record he set in June. Nine other drivers also broke Elliott's old record of 172.687 and all 40 cars for the race exceeded 170 m.p.h., making it one of the fastest fields ever assembled at Michigan International Speedway. Beside Elliott in the front row will be Geoff Bodine, whose Chevrolet Monte Carlo was clocked at 174.381 m.p.h.(AP)

title: Small Inner-City Hospitals in U.S. Face Threat of Financial Failure
description: Across the country, small community hospitals in poor inner cities appear on the brink of failure, squeezed by fluctuations in state and Federal Medicaid reimbursements and a rise in indigent patients depending on them, health policy experts say.

title: The Hunts of Texas: Swaggering Their Way to Big Deals - and Big Losses
description: LEAD: Even by Texas standards, the Hunt brothers stand astride their state as larger-than-life figures - leaders of a powerful, sprawling dynasty, brash business gamblers and flamboyant social mavericks whose lives have been a prime-time saga for more than a quarter century.

title: Catastrophic Health Act Turns Into a Monster; Good for Millionaires
description: To the Editor:

title:
Long Island Interview: Andrew J. Maloney;
Federal Prosecutor With Battles on Land and Sea
description: LEAD: THE pipe he puffs in his office where the telephone never stops ringing lends Andrew J. Maloney an amiable look.

title: FICTION
description: THE RETURN. By Richard Maynard. (Donald I. Fine, $17.95.) In this science-fiction thriller, the second novel by the Australian writer Richard Maynard, seven astronauts leave Earth in search of life on other planets. They have no reason to believe that their society's social and technological development will not continue to flourish. After spending 15 years in space, they know that much more time - perhaps as much as several centuries - has passed on Earth, yet still they expect a warm welcome home. Instead they discover that in their absence man has devolved to a level of prehistoric savagery. Presented as a memoir by the spaceship's captain, ''The Return'' chronicles the men's adventures as they struggle to retain a trace of civilization in a ruthless land where only the strong survive. In the process, scenes of ritual human sacrifice and cannibalism are juxtaposed with glimpses of great pastoral beauty; as the men move through the countryside, abandoned, overgrown cities loom as symbols of their lost greatness. At the same time, the astronauts' attempts to discover the cause of mankind's decline is central to the story's momentum. The solution they finally piece together is an ironic one, with a terrifying implied threat to the future of today's world. ''The Return'' is gripping in its portrayal of seven men trapped in a place that is both familiar and horrifyingly unfamiliar. More than that, it is a chilling vignette of an all too plausible fate that may await us.

title: Still No Beef
description: The last balloon has been swept from the Superdome, the last hangover attended to, the last rhetorical cannon spiked. With a gavel's bang Thursday night, the long and largely unedifying process by which America selects its Presidential candidates came to a merciful end. Two candidates survive, one to be chosen. But first the candidates themselves must provide a reasonable basis for choice.

title: SUNY Arts Dean Advocates Realism
description: LEAD: IN preparing students for careers in the theater, Israel Hicks believes in a pragmatic approach. ''We have to offer a realistic picture of what the industry is,'' said the new dean of the division of theater arts, design technology and film at the State University of New York at Purchase.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
THE BUILDINGS WE NEVER SAW
description: LEAD: In a market saturated with books on design, ARCHITECTS IN COMPETITION: International Architectural Competitions of the Last 200 Years (Thames and Hudson, $65) stands out both for its original subject matter and for intelligent execution. The Dutch writers Hilde de Haan and Ids Haagsma, co-authors of eight books on architecture, have produced a volume that combines lavish illustration with fascinating history.

title: Leon McAuliffe, Musician, 71
description: Leon McAuliffe, one of the early members of Bob Wills's popular swing band the Texas Playboys, died today at a local hospital after a long illness. He was 71 years old.

title:
GARDENING;
Giving Iris a Headstart in the Fall
description: LEAD: HERE we are nearly through the summer, and it's already time to plant iris, the poor man's orchid. Certainly their flowers are just as interesting and As with orchids, the petals are not always the same color, and some bicolors are most striking in appearance. Iris that stand out in a planting, however, seem to be those with light-colored standards, the upright petals, and darker falls, the petals that turn downward.

title: Unmasking the Frailties of Stone and Steel
description: The Gothic Cathedral of Chartres, 40 miles southwest of Paris, stretches nearly an eighth of a mile from western doors to eastern apse. Built to offer medieval visitors a glittering foretaste of Paradise, in its 762d year it still looks every inch the part.

title: George Sand, New and Old
description: To the Editor:

title: John Pennetto Is Wed To Cassandra Van Cott
description: Cassandra Illeana Van Cott, the daughter of Cassandra Pappas Van Cott of Mount Vernon, N.Y., and the late Assemblyman George Elbert Van Cott, was married yesterday to John Michael Pennetto, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Augustine A. Pennetto of Mount Vernon. The Rev. Peter Kyriakos performed the ceremony at the Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Concordia Celebrates 50th Year Afloat
description: Her supporters wear T-shirts and monogrammed sweaters, wave flags, and buy prints of their idol. They pour thousands of dollars into making her look good, and they ignore the fact that she is old.

title: The Computer As Carry-On Bag
description: COMPUTERS you can take with you - variously called notebooks, laptops and portables, depending on size, features and marketing strategies - are enjoying a boom in sales. Although they can serve just as space savers on a cramped office or home desk, since they usually take up less room than conventional desktop machines and can easily be packed away when they're not needed, presumably most portables are bought to be taken along on business or vacation trips. If you travel by plane, that raises several problems.

title: Noted With Pleasure
description: Democracies of Desire

description: Butler $225,000 44 Gormley Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 24-year-old ranch; patio, c/a, two-car garage; taxes $3,500. Marlboro $335,000 25 Steeplechase Drive 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 4-year-old colonial; brick fireplace, deck, central vacuum; taxes $3,500. West Orange $250,000 14 Devonshire Terrace 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 36-year-old split level; c/a, recreation room, formal dining room; taxes $4,351. OTHER AREAS Mamaroneck, N.Y. $430,000 411 Rushmore 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 35-year-old split level; fireplace, dining room, family room, playroom, deck, 1-car garage, walk to transportation, schools and shopping; taxes $7,505.
