Albertson, L.I. $265,000 26 Terrace Court 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old brick Cape Cod; dining room, den, fireplace; taxes $3,000.

title: George Sand, New and Old
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
Chinese Elegance in Woodbridge
description: LEAD: IT'S easy to miss Orchids in Woodbridge, tucked away as it is in a tiny shopping center that is neither highly visible nor easily accessible. It is worthwhile persevering because the attractive eight-month-old Chinese restaurant serves food that is above average.

title: POSTINGS: Western Jersey Homes Postcard Pretty
description: ''I've been trying to sell a home for 60 days, and I think I'm 10 minutes away from one,'' Frank Morano said last week. The New Jersey builder's eagerness to sell the first house in his development, planned for 32 units, suggests the difficulty a soft market poses in Clinton Township, an area of western New Jersey many might not have considered before, even for a project with much going for it.

title: Question Of the Week; Is the Gretzky Trade the Biggest Ever?
description: It will prove to be the biggest ever if the talent-filled Oilers do not win the Stanley Cup in 1989 or if the talent-lacking Kings do. DAVID BERNKLAU Brooklyn

title: SODDENLY, ONE WINTER
description: ROUND IRELAND IN LOW GEAR By Eric Newby. Illustrated. 308 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: A.N.C. ACTS TO HALT CIVILIAN ATTACKS
description: Leaders of the African National Congress have for the first time accepted responsibility for some recent bombing attacks on civilians and said they have taken the first steps to prevent a recurrence.

title: Belgian City Of Romanesque Treasures
description: ONE can easily imagine the awe experienced by pilgrims and travelers over the past thousand years as they approached Tournai in Belgium, an ancient center of religion, trade, politics and art. For today, as you near the city by rail or road, passing through the gentle Brueghelian landscape of the Wallonian, French-speaking part of the country, the eerie, monolithic five towers of the Romanesque cathedral have an aura of Stonehenge about them.

title: Tech Troubles
description: To the Editor:

title: Collectors Can Find Challenges From Ordinary Issues
description: SIR Arnold Machin may not have realized quite what he was starting when he designed the classic profile of Queen Elizabeth II that has appeared on British stamps since 1967.

title: Mount Vernon Concert Series Evokes History at St. Paul's
description: YOU needn't go all the way to Colonial Williamsburg to get a taste of living musical history: a noontime trip on Tuesday or on Aug. 30 to the Saint Paul's National Historic Site in Mount Vernon will do. ''For these final two concerts in our August 'Listen 'n' Lunch' series,'' said Connie Cullen, the administrator of St. Paul's, ''we've tried to build programs that allow the church to evoke something of its own history through music.

title: A RESTORATION THAT ISN'T ONE
description: IT WAS THE ABANDONED GARDEN THAT most intrigued interior designer David Anthony Easton and artist James Steinmeyer. There was, in fact, no main house, simply a tiny cottage divided into two rooms, which were used as studies by their owners. The property, part of a 220-acre farm along the Hudson Valley, once belonged to Walter R. Wilder, an architect and former associate of Stanford White, and his wife, Louise Beebe Wilder, a well-known landscape architect. ''Neither the cottage nor the grounds had been touched for about 50 years,'' says Easton.

title: Silent McReynolds Lets Actions Speak for Mets
description: Bill Clinton, the Governor of Arkansas, was flying East for his 20th class reunion at Yale this year when he ran into Tom Selakovich, the sports agent, on board the airliner. The Governor got right to the point on one of the issues of the day regarding a citizen of Arkansas.

title: FUN AND GAMES FOR SADOMASOCHISTS
description: BAD BEHAVIOR By Mary Gaitskill. 203 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $15.95.

title: Dawn Upshaw Is Guest At Informal Reception
description: Dawn Upshaw will be the guest at a reception tomorrow from 5:45 to 6:45 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall as part of the Mostly Mozart Festival's Meet-the-Artist program. Tickets, which include food and wine, are $16.50, and are available at the box office or by telephone: 877-1800, extension 547.

title: Blacks in the Student Movement
description: To the Editor:

title: Is U.S. Open Closed to Fans?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Pepping Up Programs With Hollywood Pros
description: THOSE who think that corporate videos are as dry, dull affairs, have not seen some of the latest ones. ''Video programs can no longer afford to be dull or amateurish,'' said James Kaminsky, editor of Corporate Video Decisions, a monthly trade magazine. ''Productions now tend toward glamour and sophistication.''

title: Anne Brophy Has a Bridal
description: Anne Redmond Brophy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Frederick Brophy of Greenwich, Conn., was married at Christ Episcopal Church there yesterday to Standish Heminway O'Grady, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. O'Grady of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Richardson Schell, headmaster of the Kent School, and the Rev. Alastair Votaw performed the ceremony.

title: New Law Takes Aim at Young Boaters
description: A NEW law requiring youths 16 years old or younger to pass a state-approved boating safety course before they operate motorboats in New Jersey is drawing praise from many parents and groans from junior yachtsmen.

title: Question Of the Week; Is the Gretzky Trade the Biggest Ever?
description: The most professional athletic talent to switch teams as a result of a single trade has to be the trade of Frankie Frisch and Jimmy Ring from the New York (baseball) Giants for Rogers Hornsby of the St. Louis Cardinals on Dec. 20, 1926. Both Frisch and Hornsby are Hall of Famers. DAVID ALVAREZ Montclair, N.J.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE ARIZONA KID By Ron Koertge. 228 pp. Boston: Joy Street Books/Little, Brown & Company.

title: John A. Livingston, Architect, 85
description: John A. Livingston, a naval architect and marine engineer, died of heart failure Tuesday at the Maine Medical Center in Portland. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: John Andretti Is Struggling
description: John Andretti's sophomore year in Indy-car racing hasn't been easy. When Andretti gets into the cockpit of the green and white Skoal Bandit March 88C in the 13th position for the Quaker State 500 at Pocono International Raceway this afternoon, the 25-year-old driver will be trying to break a severe run of bad luck. He has failed to finish any of the nine races on this year's PPG Indy-car circuit. A rash of engine failures has put the promising young driver on the sidelines at each event, except last month at the Meadowlands, where he crashed.

title: Some Preliminary Results in the Rush From Welfare to Work
description: IN the last few years, it has become conventional wisdom that the best way to overhaul the American welfare system is to move able-bodied people off the dole by requiring and helping them to get jobs. Legislation now approaching a decision point in Congress embodies that very principle.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Maine's Envoy Is Remembered

title: Cadets learn to Put Best Feet Forward
description: THE United States Coast Guard Academy, in order to turn its recruits into officers, makes them undergo rigorous physical training -running, jumping, calesthenics. In order to turn them into gentlemen and ladies, it makes them dance.

title: The Winner in the Straw Vote
description: Think of straw hats as romantic reminders of earlier, easier times. Or think of them as portable shade, which these days can qualify as a priceless commodity. Better still, don't think of them at all; just sit back and enjoy their grace and beauty, the sweep of those wide brims decorated with flowers or ribbons like something from a Degas or a Renoir. Or admire the clipped brims turned down in the manner of a sassy flapper by John Sloan.

title: No Headline
description: The commander of the National Guard headquarters unit to which young Dan Quayle was assigned in 1969 said today that he ''definitely did not receive a call from anybody'' ordering or urging Mr. Quayle's enlistment.

title: Meet Flywheel & Ravelli, Hucksters
description: MISS DIMPLE: Law offices of Flywheel, Shyster and Flywheel. You want to speak to Mr. Ravelli? He's not in now, Madam. Mr. Flywheel's here. Oh, you don't want to speak to Mr. Flywheel? Groucho: Who doesn't want to speak to Mr. Flywheel? Give me that phone, Miss Dimple. I'll show her a thing or two. So, Madam, you don't want to speak to me? No, this isn't Ravelli. This is Flywheel. 'F' like in Flywheel, 'l' like in fly, 'y' like in Flywheel, 'wheel' like in wheel cutlet, and 'fly' like in milk. Listen, Madam, I'll have none of your lip, but I'll take an ear of corn. Goodbye! (Door opens) Mrs. Brittenhouse: Oh, Mr. Flywheel, I simply love the things you say.

title: Boating Deaths Up Despite Speed Laws
description: DESPITE new speed limits on some waterways in the state, 13 people have died this summer in boating accidents in Connecticut, only three short of the record set in 1980, as boat traffic continues to increase.

title: Agent Orange Suit: A Veteran's Legacy
description: LEAD: TEN years ago, a Vietnam veteran from Yorktown laid the basis for one of the nation's largest class-action lawsuits by suing several makers of Agent Orange. The veteran, Paul M. Reutershan, a helicopter crew chief in the United States Army, said he suffered from cancer as a result of his exposure to the herbicide in Vietnam.

title:
INVESTING;
Heat Wave Dividend for Con Ed
description: LEAD: IN addition to the steady hum of air-conditioners, another sound is wafting through New York's sultry air: coins clanging into Con Edison's cash register.

title: Second President of Palau Is Found Shot to Death
description: The President of this American trust territory in the Pacific, Lazarus Salii, was found shot to death in his home today, the authorities said. The police a gunman entered the home and killed him; a Presidential spokesman said suicide had not been ruled out.

title: Spanish, With the Accent on Seafood
description: PORT JEFFERSON is a town in love with summer and the sea. Ferry crowds jam the streets and restaurants dot the harbor. At least half of those restaurants fly nautical colors. Costa de Espana, a Spanish entry tucked into a parking lot behind Main Street, is no exception. Its name and menu say seafood. Views from the restaurant are of that parking lot, not of the nearby harbor. The restaurant is an attractive sight, though, with its umbrella-topped tables outside and large, glassed dining room in front. The bar is a cozy gem featuring low-beamed ceilings and a wood-burning fireplace. Hordes of diners have taken their toll, however: Carpeting on the stairs is tattered, and restrooms look as if the fleet is in. Predictable stucco walls are punctuated with paintings of flamenco dancers, matadors and bullfights (yes, some are painted on black velvet).

title: G. W. Arnett 3d, Miss Walker Wed In Connecticut
description: Marylou Dillon Walker, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Smith Walker of West Hartford and Westbrook, Conn., and George Washington Arnett 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Arnett 3d of Tiburon, Calif., were married yesterday at St Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Clinton, Conn. The Rev. David M. Walker, the bride's uncle, officiated. He was assisted by the Rev. Beverly Berman, a Congregational minister.

title:
GARDENING;
Giving Iris a Headstart in the Fall
description: LEAD: HERE we are nearly through the summer, and it's already time to plant iris, the poor man's orchid. Certainly their flowers are just as interesting and As with orchids, the petals are not always the same color, and some bicolors are most striking in appearance. Iris that stand out in a planting, however, seem to be those with light-colored standards, the upright petals, and darker falls, the petals that turn downward.

title: Norway Arsonist Set 62 Fires
description: The police say they have arrested a man who admitted setting 62 fires in three years, an arson record in Norway. No one was injured in the fires, which caused an estimated $15 million damage. The 36-year-old man told investigators he had used paper and a lighter to start the fires, always on weekends.

title: Melissa Wheeler Weds R. B. Waud
description: At the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich, Conn., Melissa Ann Wheeler, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Phillip Wheeler of Greenwich and Verbier, Switzerland, was married yesterday to Reeve Byron Waud, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius B. Waud of Lake Forest, Ill. Dr. Olin C. Robison, the president of Middlebury College and a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Dr. Avery C. Manchester, a United Methodist minister.

title: Don't Shoot Your Kids Indiscriminately
description: ''When you were little. . . ,'' parents would say to their children; and then they would relate what the children had been too young to remember. Most of us learned about our early lives that way, and our self-images derive at least partly from these parallel accounts.

title: Jubilee: Real or Just Free Theater?
description: IT's being promoted as a statewide theater festival - a jubilee, in fact. For the second summer, New Jersey's professional theaters are getting a chance to take a show on the road - within the state. Last year, six theater companies gave five or six performances each in the Railroad Terminal Building at Liberty State Park in Jersey City.

title: Mattingly May Not Even Be the Best Hitter in the Division
description: Don Mattingly has generally been considered the best hitter in baseball the past few years, but he suddenly faces a challenge from a player whose production in his brief major league career makes him look remarkably like Don Mattingly.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: San Diego;
Rapid Growth Being Slowed
description: LEAD: EXPENSIVE condominiums and town homes are changing the housing scene and character of Pacific Beach, a formerly quiet San Diego coastal community of 40,000 once dominated by single-family homes. The residential market here has been affected by San Diego's exploding population growth and city officials are imposing building slowdowns.

title: Long Island Journal
description: Olympics on My Mind On a sunbaked, breezeless field in East Hampton, on a 95-degree day so muggy even the thermometer seems to sweat, Bianca Jagger is crouched in a three-point stance, ready to run the 100-yard dash.

title: Premature Praise?
description: To the Editor:

title: F.B.I. KEPT A FILE ON SUPREME COURT
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation kept a confidential file on the United States Supreme Court from 1932 until at least 1985, according to recently obtained F.B.I. documents.

title: Realism On TV: Bright Outlook Re: 'Rabbit'
description: To the Editor:

title: Social Security Number for Children Disputed
description: A group of Christian fundamentalists are challenging a Government requirement that children 5 years old and up must have Social Security numbers for their parents to claim them as exemptions on tax returns.

title: Catastrophic Health Act Turns Into a Monster; Nursing-Care Fund
description: To the Editor:

title: Indians Hike to Reagan Ranch
description: Twenty-two members and supporters of American Indian tribes walked up a seven-mile mountain road to President Reagan's ranch today, seeking a dialogue on Indian rights.

title: 'The King of Children'
description: To the Editor:

title: JERSEYANA
description: THE Adamses, the Kennedys, the Rockefellers, the Fords: these are among the family dynasties that have provided America with generations of leaders in politics, industry and philanthropy. There is one family dynasty, however, that comes from the bottom of the pile.

title: Question Of the Week; Is the Gretzky Trade the Biggest Ever?
description: Yes, Wayne Gretzky has dominated hockey more than anyone has dominated a major sport in history. That alone makes the Gretzky trade the biggest ever. The trade has also made at least 10 more teams Stanley Cup contenders. The Oilers traded away their favorite son and their competitive edge. ANTHONY C. PROVIDENTI Jr. Port Washington, L.I.

title: Israelis Report Killing 3 Guerrillas in Lebanon
description: The Israeli Army said today that its soldiers shot and killed three Palestinian guerrillas in southern Lebanon early this morning as they were trying to cross the border into Israel, apparently to carry out a terrorist attack.

title: Melissa Huggins Marries John E. Opel
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York, Melissa Read Huggins, a daughter of Barbara Merrill Huggins of New York and the late Rev. Kenneth Read Huggins, was married yesterday to John Edward Opel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Roberts Opel of Sanibel Island, Fla., and Shelburne Point, Vt. The Rev. Jane Henderson performed the ceremony.

title: The Annual Test: Braving the Ocean
description: EVERY SUMMER, it's the same question. Will I get up the courage and ambition to swim in the Atlantic Ocean or won't I?

title: The Silent Springs of Prague
description: Those who seek meaning and justice in history have to reckon with Czechoslovakia. Twenty years ago today, its 14 million people awoke to discover their country swarming with a half-million Warsaw Pact troops under orders to suppress a phantom counterrevolution.

title: Luce's Point of View
description: To the Editor:

title: Jerseyans Are Fighting Back on Rising Auto Insurance Costs
description: Joseph A. Tomeo is at 3,400 and counting. His goal is to obtain 500,000 signatures on petitions calling for the recall of the New Jersey Senate for what he says is its failure to deal with the state's rising automobile insurance costs.

title: Taping Between Drywall Panels
description: ALTHOUGH gypsum wallboard, more often called drywall, is much easier to apply than plaster, one part of the process is a common stumbling block: sealing the seams between panels with drywall tape. This is a crucial step in finishing a surface, because if done poorly the taped seams are difficult to disguise by sanding and painting. In addition, the tape may loosen or develop wrinkles, requiring that the job be done over.

title: William Francis McCalpin Married To Sara Morgan Judge in Vermont
description: Sara Morgan Judge, the director of South and East Asian programs for AFS Intercultural Programs in New York, and William Francis McCalpin, a program associate at the Rockefeller Brothers Fund in New York, were married yesterday.

title: Dukakis Leaves Controversy to Foes
description: By the time Gov. Michael S. Dukakis got to the Texas hill country for a courtly stroll with Lady Bird Johnson by her husband's grave, the Democratic Presidential candidate had settled into a carefully designed pattern. The order of the day was simple: Avoid controversy.

title: Wendy Beth Stevens Plans to Wed Sept. 24
description: Wendy Beth Stevens and Donald Hal Schneidman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Schneidman of Rye Brook, N.Y., plan to marry Sept. 24, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Jay Stevens of Great Neck, L.I., and Jupiter, Fla., have announced.

title: Which Weapons of War Qualify as Humane?
description: To the Editor:

title: Managing Crises by Taking to the Airwaves
description: WHEN the Samurai crisis hit the American Suzuki Motor Corporation in June, the company turned to video. Right after Consumer Reports magazine declared that the Samurai had flunked its road tests, Suzuki's general manager, N. Douglas Mazza, mailed videotapes to the company's dealers. On screen, Mr. Mazza told dealers the Samurai was safe.

title: BASEBALL: American League; Red Sox Send A's To 3d Loss in Row
description: The Boston Red Sox handed Todd Burns his first major league loss with seven runs in the first two innings and beat the Oakland Athletics, 7-5, today to send the Athletics to their third straight loss.

title: America's Musician at 70
description: It is an unlikely scenario: Peter Pan grows up and becomes a Grand Old Man. But no more improbable than our waking up one day this week to discover that Leonard Bernstein, the perennial wonder boy of American music, is a white-maned eminence in the tradition of such hardy elders of the baton as Leopold Stokowski, Arturo Toscanini, Pierre Monteux and Bruno Walter.

title: As Politburo Squabbles, a Less Timid Public Takes Sides
description: IT is becoming harder to shock the public in Mikhail S. Gorbachev's land of falling taboos, but the Moscow State University drama players succeeded last month with their performance of ''The Black Man'' at a theater near the Kremlin.

title: Ideas for Tomatoes, Even Green Ones
description: AT last, real tomatoes are back. Though fancy shops have taken to stocking them all winter long, tomatoes from hydroponic farms in Israel and the Netherlands never taste like the sun-ripened ones from your garden or the farm down the road. As for those pale pink numbers from Florida, we won't even discuss them.

title: Several Kinds of Eaters That I Have Known
description: DOCTORS and psychiatrists have recently identified a new field in medicine. ''Eating Disorders'' is the generic term and anorexics, looking into mirrors and seeing fatty pads where there is in reality only skin and bone, have become a familiar subject to any reader of the popular press.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Cross My Heart Starring Martin Short, Annette O'Toole, Paul Reiser, Joanna Kerns. Directed by Armyan Bernstein. 1987. MCA Home Video. 91 minutes. $79.95. Rated R.

title: Full Life, Empty Values
description: I HAVE never met Barbara Klaus, but I admire her ability to maintain a sense of humor about life on Long Island. I'm sure I've joined countless readers who laugh as they recognize themselves in familiar scenes.

title: Frances A. Alling Marries Christopher Travis Tully
description: Frances Ann Alling and Christopher Travis Tully, both graduates of Lynchburg College, were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Atonement in Tenafly, N.J., by the Rev. Jeffrey B. MacKnight.

title: Super 7 To Draw Close To a Wilton Battle LIne
description: LEAD: RESIDENTS south of the Norwalk-Wilton town line are applauding, residents to the north are lamenting, but for both, another piece of Super 7 moved one step closer to reality this month when the Army Corps of Engineers allowed construction of the highway to The Corps' decision pertained to the 2.1-mile, $30 million segment of road in Norwalk that will run from the existing portion of Super 7 -extending from Interstate 95 to New Canaan Avenue - north to Grist Mill Road.

title: Headliners; Diver's Trials
description: Some people drove from Florida to Indiana last week to watch Bruce Kimball try out for the Olympic diving team. They were not rooting for him. Earlier this month, Mr. Kimball's car plowed into a crowd of Florida teen- agers, killing two of them and injuring six others. The police said Mr. Kimball, who won a silver medal in the 1984 Olympics, was drunk. He is to be arraigned Aug. 29 on five felony charges, including two counts of manslaughter. After he remorsefully announced last week that he would go on to the Olympic trials, some friends of the accident victims traveled to the trials in Indianapolis to urge that he be disqualified. One of them, Craig Deiter, said, ''We just don't understand how a guy can kill two people and then go represent our nation.''

LEAD: Portugal's leading athlete, Rosa Mota, who won the marathon at the world championships last year and the Boston Marathon earlier this year, is in peak form to win a gold medal at the Olympic Games next month.

title: Re: 'Rabbit'
description: To the Editor:

title: GOOD MEN, BEAUTIFUL WOMEN AND CRUEL BANKERS
description: THE CORNER OF RIFE AND PACIFIC By Thomas Savage. 226 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $16.95.

title: SWEET ARE THE USES OF ORGINAL SIN
description: LEAD: ADAM, EVE, AND THE SERPENT By Elaine Pagels. 189 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: Zia Is Buried Before a Muted and Prayerful Throng
description: Beneath the four white marble minarets of a mosque that looms over this capital, President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq was buried today in a military funeral attended by at least 100,000 Pakistanis.

title: Woody Plants for Summer Blossoms
description: THE recent hot spell delayed lawn work especially seeding or sodding of new lawns; since cooler growing weather is coming next month, major lawn work can now be organized; for established lawns continue setting mowers to cut high - at least two inches - to encourage deep root growth. If they have finished blooming, dig carefully, divide roots and replant day lilies, phlox, astilbes and other spring-blooming perennials. Transplant broccoli, cabbage and cauliflower to the vegetable garden; keep up with ripening harvests, especially squashes, tomatoes, cucumbers and sweet corn. Native Plants

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: 4 Sailors Face Court-Martial In Hiding Girl on a Destroyer
description: Four sailors will be court-martialed for their parts in helping a 16-year-old Irish girl stow away aboard the destroyer Conyngham last month, the Navy said Thursday. Four other sailors will face lesser charges.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
3 Reports, 1 Trend: Office Vacancies Decline
description: LEAD: THEIR numbers differ, but reports released recently by three major commercial brokerage concerns point to one key conclusion: vacancy rates for office space in Westchester have dropped to their lowest levels in three years.

title: LOVE WITH ITS TROUSERS ROLLED
description: ''Love reciprocated is always rejuvenating,'' T. S. Eliot said in 1958. ''Before my marriage I was getting older. Now I feel younger at seventy than I did at sixty. . . . An experience like mine makes all the more difference because of its contrast with the past.''

title: Question Of the Week; Is the Gretzky Trade the Biggest Ever?
description: In Canada, definitely yes. But in the United States, where sports fans in a large section of the country get their thrills from truck and tractor pulls and professional wrestling, definitely not. HOWARD DIAMOND Union, N.J.

title: Excess of Vitamin A Prompts Recall of Cereal in 25 States
description: The Kellogg Company has announced a 25-state recall of about 29,000 boxes of Frosted Mini-Wheats Biscuits cereal that may contain too much vitamin A and cause a burning sensation in the mouth.

title: BASEBALL: National League; Pirates Overcome Ryan and Astros to Win, 2-1
description: Jose Lind's two-run single in the sixth chased Nolan Ryan, who had pitched five and two-thirds perfect innings, and John Smiley allowed five hits in seven innings for his first victory in six weeks as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Houston Astros, 2-1, today.

title: FOCUS: Chicago; Chicago's Huge Merchandise Mart Gets a Facelift
description: Driven by strong demand for showroom space, Chicago's 24-story, 4.2-million-square-foot Merchandise Mart - the world's largest wholesale buying center under one roof - is undergoing a $100 million, 10-year renovation. It is the first major renovation of the building, which was put up in 1929.

title: Sports of The Times; Greenwell Knows the Score
description: The standard line is, ''I don't look at the scoreboard.'' It goes along with, ''I never pay attention to the crowd'' and ''I don't read the papers.''

title: HUNTS ARE RULED PART OF A SCHEME TO CONTROL SILVER
description: A Federal jury in Manhattan ruled yesterday that the Hunt brothers of Dallas conspired with a group of other investors in a racketeering scheme to corner the world silver market in 1979 and 1980.

title: NONFICTION
description: YOUR MONEY OR YOUR LIFE: Economy and Religion in the Middle Ages. By Jacques Le Goff. Translated by Patricia Ranum. (Zone/MIT, $18.95.) Much less ambitious than the subtitle suggests, ''Your Money or Your Life: Economy and Religion in the Middle Ages'' focuses on a shift in the church's attitude toward usury over the course of the 13th century ''to show how an ideological obstacle can fetter or delay the development of a new economic system.'' Jacques Le Goff, a medievalist who is director of the Ecole des Hautes Etudes en Sciences Sociales in Paris, argues that ''the great controversy surrounding usury constitutes what might be called the 'labor pains of capitalism.' '' During the 13th century, the church's power was beginning to decline and the monetary economy was growing in strength. The problem was that usury, a necessary component of capitalism, was an unmitigated evil to the church. In an earlier book, ''The Birth of Purgatory,'' Mr. Le Goff said that the doctrine of purgatory reached its full development in the late 12th century. In ''Your Money or Your Life,'' purgatory is cast as the church's solution to the theological problem of usury. Before the development of purgatory, a usurer could reach heaven only by making restitution of his sinful gains, something rarely done. The advent of purgatory provided another route: ''The hope of escaping Hell, thanks to Purgatory, permitted the usurer to propel the economy and society of the thirteenth century ahead toward capitalism.'' Mr. Le Goff moves his argument forward in tiny increments, and while the translation is very readable, it is not always clear what point he is trying to make. Over all, however, the book is lucid and surprisingly engaging.

title:
GARDENING;
Miniature Roses Thrive in the City or Country
description: LEAD: MINIATURE roses have finally come into their own. For the first time in its 50-year history All-America Rose Selection Inc., a group of the nation's largest producers of roses, has chosen two miniatures among its four prize winners for 1989. The miniature roses are New Beginning, yellow and orange-red, and Debut, a red blend.

title: Dr. Berger Wed To J. W. Mandell
description: In the Anabel Taylor Chapel at Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y., Dr. Elizabeth Hope Berger, a resident in obstetrics and gynecology at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York, was married last night to James William Mandell, a candidate for an M.D. degree and a Ph.D. degree in neurobiology at the Cornell Medical College. Rabbi Scott Glass performed the ceremony.

title: Offering Hope to Battered Women
description: LEAD: ''I WAS with him since I was 14 years old,'' she said, smiling. ''We had four beautiful years together; he never touched me before we were married. It wasn't until then that I found out his mother had been abused by his father, who was an alcoholic. My husband never took drugs or drank, but we were affected by what he saw at home.

title: Entrepreneur, 9, Runs Afoul of Law
description: ENTREPRENEURS all have to start somewhere, and for Max Schilling, his place of business was an eye-catching lemon-yellow structure on Sunlit Drive until borough officials closed him down this month for breaking a local zoning law.

title: Looking Hard at Science's Self-Scrutiny
description: AN extraordinary exchange erupted last month in the stately pages of Nature, a leading scientific journal. An investigating team appointed by the journal reported that an article it had published a few weeks earlier was based on ''a delusion.'' In rebuttal, the principal author of the article, Dr. Jacques Benveniste of the Inserm Laboratory of the University of Paris, complained that he had been subjected to a ''Salem witchhunt.''

title: Alex Katz Featured In Show of Works At Galasso Gallery
description: ELIZABETH GALASSO Fine Art Leasing is such a small space that its shows can scarcely be more than introductions to or footnotes about artists. Consequently, viewers who aren't already in the know must depend on the statements-cum-news releases issued by the gallery.

title: Ban Is Working On the Railroads
description: WHEN the Long Island and Metro-North railroads banned smoking on trains six months ago, railroad officials worried that they might lose ridership.

title: Poorer Air Quality Adds to Environmental Woes
description: LEAD: IN a summer marked by concerns of a global warming trend, medical debris washing up on beaches and brown algae and low oxygen levels in the Sound and bays, Long Island faces another manifestation of an overburdened ecology: diminishing air quality.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''How many people think, 'Gee, I wish I were on a deserted island?' Well, we're the people who are doing it.'' - Richard Brink, on a five-mile long ice island in the Arctic. [ 1:6. ]

title: Redeemer of Cans Gets a Reprieve
description: IN April, the end seemed near for We Can, a nonprofit can and bottle redemption center for homeless and poor people. It was about to be forced out of a vacant lot on West 43d Street to make room for high-rise condominiums, and it had nowhere to go.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: GREEK ICONS

title: The Olympic Mind Games Begin
description: The Olympic Games begin in less than a month. Athletes have finished their physical conditioning. Now the hardest part begins: the mental preparation. The position and posturing that athletes do to gain a psychological edge on their opponents is as interesting as the events themselves.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Albertson $265,000 26 Terrace Court 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old brick Cape Cod; dining room, den, fireplace; taxes $3,000. Bay Shore $95,000 43 Center Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 65-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,200. Bethpage $288,000 8 Patricia Court 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 16-year-old colonial; finished basement, inground pool, 1-car garage; taxes $6,700. Plainview $244,500 65 Sylvia Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 32-year-old split level; dining room, den, eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage; taxes $4,000. Wading River $121,000 180 Cliff Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 25-year-old ranch; basement, 0.50 acre, walk to private beach; taxes $1,400. OTHER AREAS Mamaroneck, N.Y. $430,000 411 Rushmore 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 35-year-old split level; fireplace, dining room, family room, playroom, deck, 1-car garage; taxes $7,505. Collinsville, Conn. $195,000 9 Birch Knoll Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; walk to town and schools, 109-foot by 199-foot lot; taxes $1,711. West Orange, N.J. $250,000 14 Devonshire Terrace 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 36-year-old split level; c/a, recreation room, formal dining room; taxes $4,351.

title: Prospects; Book Houses Consolidate
description: The publishing industry witnessed further consolidation last week when Random House Inc. agreed to buy the Crown Publishing Group. Once an industry made up of dozens of independent, family-run companies, book publishing is now dominated by six major companies: Advance Publications, Hearst, MCA, the Pearson Group, Bertlesmann A.G. and Gulf and Western. With so much consolidation, how will book publishing change? Michael Korda Editor in chief, Simon & Schuster, a unit of Gulf and Western.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: JEAN BAER has a wonderful vault.

title: Books: More Than Just a Good Read
description: I HAVE a passion for books. Being one of those people who can't go to sleep at night without reading ''just a few pages,'' my sorely needed eight hours of sleep is frequently reduced to six. I have a stack of books on the floor next to my bed which are ''next to be read.''

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. We left a yellow rubber bath mat in the bottom of our tub for a couple of months. When we picked it up we found that it has left a yellow stain we cannot seem to remove. We tried scouring powder, then fine steel wool, but the latter left a gray stain, probably because of the tub's age (34 years). Is there a rubber dissolving chemical I can try that might remove the stain without causing further wear of the thin enamel?

title: Florida-Bound in a Behemoth
description: I HAVE used various modes of travel: a 747 jet, a drafty troop train in Korea, an ocean liner, a Harley-Davidson cross-country and even, I must confess, a horse and buggy in Tennessee. But I had never ridden in a recreational vehicle. I had seen a number on highways, been intrigued with their swaying bulk and stolid-looking drivers, but I had trouble picturing myself behind the wheel. I have trouble no longer. I recently borrowed a 30-foot Chieftain Winnebago and drove from Manhattan to Disney World in Florida and back, accompanied by my wife and two prepubescent sons.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Subject: Outdoors
description: LEAD: Last year Robert Erler of Hawthorne signed up for the training program to become a Volunteer in the Parks given by the County Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation. The course, for which registration is now open, qualifies participants to teach environmental awareness in local schools and to lead field trips in three county nature preserves.

title: LOVE AMONG THE ISMS
description: MEMOIR OF A MODERNIST'S DAUGHTER By Eleanor Munro. 271 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: MONOLOGUES OF MOTHER AND SON
description: ADELE AT THE END OF THE DAY By Tom Marshall. 248 pp. Boston: Faber & Faber. Paper, $8.95.

title: At 74, a (Movie) Star Is Born
description: Talk of success in America and what do you mean? Take Reizl Bozyk, who never performed a word in English - well, maybe a few here and there - during 60 years in Yiddish theater, suddenly catapulted to a top role in the new movie ''Crossing Delancey,'' opening Wednesday at the Plaza. Don't 60 years of top billing in Yiddish, which some heartless ones believe is headed the way of silent films, also represent success, particularly when they were spent in entertaining Yiddish audiences on three continents?

title: TV for the Boardroom and the Factory Floor
description: AT companies around the country, television screens are lighting up the workplace. More than ever, employees are receiving their job training from videotape along with information about company services, benefits and programs. At a many companies, live broadcasts about late-breaking company news are being transmitted by satellite to television screens in employee gathering areas and coffee rooms. Corporate broadcasts and videotapes vary in content and quality, but most have the same basic purpose - to improve the flow of important information from management to employees.

title: Where Bush Throws Weight Around
description: The Kennedys played touch football, the Bushes pitch horseshoes. And the Bushes do it with as much passion, vigor, and spirited competitiveness as that relatively mild sport allows. Not that it's easy. Any novice who has tried to hang an iron shoe around the stake from the required distance - 30 feet for women, 40 feet for men - knows that.

title: Question Of the Week; Is the Gretzky Trade the Biggest Ever?
description: Wayne Gretzky's domination of his sport is unparalleled in any other professional league. No other athlete singularly gains as much respect as the Great One does in hockey. Whether his dealing to the Kings will stimulate hockey in Los Angeles remains to be seen, but this was definitely a blockbuster deal for Canadians and Americans alike. LANCE WACHENHEIM Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Burma Asks for Time to Set Things Right
description: The Burmese Government sought to buy time from its restive population today with the publication of extensive self-criticism and a plea for time to explore economic and political restructuring.

title: MANDELA RELEASE IN 4 WEEKS SEEN
description: A South African official said today that he believes that Nelson R. Mandela, the imprisoned leader of the African National Congress, would be freed within three to four weeks.

title: Debate On Over Risks In Quarries
description: For generations, the lure of the cool deep water and craggy terrain of this city's granite quarries has proved too strong. Drawn as if by the Lorelei, youthful trespassers have come to the quarries to deepen their tans, drink stronger waters and tempt fate by diving into the dark, dangerous deeps.

title: Ms. Jewett Weds Dr. Stephen Teach
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Bromley Jewett, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. and Freeborn G. Jewett Jr. of McLean, Va., to Dr. Stephen John Teach, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard I. Teach of Buffalo, took place yesterday at the Warwick Reformed Church in Warwick, N.Y. The Rev. James E. Vincent performed the ceremony.

title: CHILD'S PLAY, WOMEN'S SWAY
description: What memories Phyllis Rose sparked in ''Child's Play, Women's Sway'' (Hers column, July 17)! I remember spending long nights furtively sitting on the kitchen floor of my friend Nancy's mother's house playing jacks - furtively, because we were college graduates at the time, 23 years old, she busy in a career on Seventh Avenue, I studying journalism. We told no one because we were embarrassed; but we were obsessed with the game. We played fiercely, competitively, often giggling, sometimes yelling. It wasn't until I read Phyllis Rose's article that I finally understood why two grown women had such fun playing a child's game. DEBRA MORGENSTERN KATZ Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: About Chess Moves
description: The New York Times has converted its method of chessboard notation to the algebraic system, in which each square is unambiguously identified by file letter and rank number. Explanations of the system are available from the Chess Column, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: Clubs Confronting Issues Over Gender
description: FIFTEEN years ago, when Dorothy Swegel's business was beginning to grow, she was invited to lunch at the White Plains Exchange Club, an all-male preserve. ''I instantly saw what I was missing,'' she recalled. ''Everyone was talking about business and exchanging information; while businesswomen like myself, who could have benefited from the goings on, were excluded from membership.''

title: Bottle Returns: Society's Demise
description: I WORRY that civilization is a circle and that today's world may not be a better time and place.

title: Eleo Kaemmerer Marries a Writer
description: Eleanor A. Kaemmerer, the daughter of Weston Linn Thomas of New York and Ninatic, Conn., and the late B. A. Kaemmerer, was married in Niantic yesterday to Jonathan Blair Hensleigh, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard E. Hensleigh of Carlisle, Mass. Judge Michael D. Hurley of the Superior Court of Connecticut performed the ceremony at Mrs. Thomas's home.

title: In Nebraska, Hardships Ease on Each Fall Saturday
description: Right about 2 o'clock in the morning on those special Saturdays, when the automobile turns southeast onto State Highway 92, Harold and Polly Gentry and Darrel and De Willet, two retired couples who live in nearby Gering, begin another autumn adventure.

title: Massachuetts Is Under Criticism For Poor Care of the Mentally Ill
description: The Massachuetts system for the mentally ill, now in the midst of a five-year overhaul, is being faulted for poor care and unsafe conditions by legislators, patient advocates and mental health professionals and administrators.

title: Don't Blame Bee for Yellow Jacket's Sting
description: To the Editor:

title: TAKE ME OUT TO THE METAGAME
description: A WHOLE NEW BALL GAME An Interpretation of American Sports. By Allen Guttmann. 233 pp. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press. Cloth, $24.95. Paper, $10.95.

title: Realism On Tv: Bright Outlook
description: To the Editor:

title: Raising Funds: Year-Round Effort
description: ''IT'S amazing what a difference a year makes,'' said Suffolk County Executive Patrick G. Halpin, a Democrat.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: SUSSEX AIR SHOW Champion aerobatic pilots, wing-walkers, World War II fighters and bombers, flying comedy acts and a parachute demonstration will all be part of the annual air show at the Sussex Airport Friday through next Sunday.

title: Least-Employable Aided in Chicago
description: The slogan ''welfare-to-work'' sounds beguilingly simple. But the reality of finding a job and getting off public assistance is neither smooth nor speedy, according to Project Match, an organization here dedicated to helping unemployed mothers, school dropouts and others hold jobs, even if they start out by losing a succession of them.

title: Dukakis Shouldn't Take Black Votes for Granted
description: To the Editor:

title: A Day at the (Oink, Oink) Races
description: LEAD: ''WE'RE from Bayonne,'' Bob Kraynik said. ''We're really just city people. This is definitely our first pig race.''

title: ANTI-U.S. ATTACKS SPREAD IN PANAMA
description: The regime of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama has widened its harassment of American officials in recent weeks as a way of forcing the United States to lift punitive financial measures against the country, senior Administration officials said.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Why Can't The Mets Hit Anymore?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Underground Ballet
description: GAITE PARISIENNE Starring Alexandra Danilova (in photo), Frederic Franklin (in photo) and Leon Danielian, with the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo. Video Artists International, Inc. 38 minutes.

title: SOUND
description: When compact disks made their first appearance, everyone marveled at their dynamic range. For the first time in the history of recorded sound, it was possible to hear the entire span from pianissimo to triple forte. The merest whispers could be captured in all their delicacy, and at the other end of the scale, orchestral thunder would burst forth undiminished.

title: Voters Now Give Bush Edge Over Dukakis, a Poll Shows
description: Voters polled after the Republican National Convention favored Vice President Bush over Michael S. Dukakis by 51 percent to 42 percent, Newsweek magazine said today.

title: P.D.A.'s In Politics
description: Once upon a time, the picture on the nation's front pages the morning after a convention ended was always the armpit shot, the picture of the two candidates raising their arms, hands linked and looking jubilantly juvenile.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: CONSTANCE RING. By Amalie Skram. Translated by Judith Messick with Katherine Hanson. (Seal Press, Cloth, $18.95; Paper, $10.95.) Need an antidote to the summer trash you were so excited about just a month ago? Meet Constance Ring, a turn-of-the-century Norwegian heroine who has been brought to modern America in superb form by the translators Judith Messick and Katherine Hanson.

title: Parks System is Celebrated
description: IT began 75 years ago with a modest state appropriation, and a year later five acres of Westport salt marsh was bought as the first piece of a statewide mosaic of greenery and open space. The state's parks system is now three-quarters of a century old, and some of the parks' best friends are celebrating.

title: Depiction of Bush as a Carpetbagger Is as Lasting as His Links to Texas
description: In his autobiography, ''Looking Forward,'' George Bush recalls one of the frustrations of his first statewide political race in Texas.

title: Nights Past: When the Best In Us Came Out
description: IT is summer and the nights are hot and sultry, but with the air-conditioner to cool the house, the heat on these hot nights is hardly noticed, and the nights hold little in them to be remembered. It was not this way during the summer nights of my childhood. The heat was noticed, and I well remember those nights.

title:
RECORDINGS;
An Enduring Bel Canto Hit, and a Miss
description: LEAD: In the early 1830's, with Rossini in premature retirement and Verdi still a struggling student, Italian opera was dominated by Donizetti and Bellini. They were rivals and not particularly fond of each other, but they agreed on one thing: the poetic gifts of Felice Romani (1788-1865), the foremost librettist of the period.

title:
ART;
Manipulating the View
description: LEAD: THE 25 photographers selected by fellow photographers Ann Chwatsky and Jim Lennon from 129 entries to the East End Arts and Humanities Council's 10th annual juried photography exhibition make a stronger showing than one normally finds in a juried format. With one or two exceptions, the traditional interpretation of nature as a picturesque subject is missing.

title: THE WORLD: A Sense of Paranoia; What Zia's Death Means For Pakistan and the U.S.
description: WHEN he seized power in 1977, Mohammad Zia ul-Haq was a relatively unknown general who was not given much chance of surviving long in the turmoil of Pakistan. He not only succeeded but proved himself a master at manipulating the country's divisive political forces and advancing American interests in one of the world's most unsettled regions.

title: Ellen G. Green Is Wed To Perry Corrin Reith
description: Ellen George Green, a daughter of Mrs. Leonard H. Moche of New York and Mount Kisco, N.Y., and the late Dr. Arthur L. Green, was married yesterday to Perry Corrin Reith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Reith of Baltimore. Msgr. Herman L. Heide, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Neil R. Jordahl, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the chapel of Manhattanville College.

title: After 30 Years, a Jammed 2-Lane Country Road Awaits Relief
description: LEAD: THROUGH a pair of quaint Morris County towns, past picturesque downtowns, up and over sloping grades, winds a two-lane country road. Much of the day, however, the thoroughfare is choked with bumper-to-bumper traffic, honking horns and exhaust fumes more reminiscent of the big city than tranquil suburbia.

title: PERU OFFERS LAWS TO COMBAT TERROR
description: Arguing that Peru's democracy should do more to defend itself against terrorism, President Alan Garcia has proposed a series of laws to limit the freedom of action of the Shining Path guerrilla movement.

title: Mitchell, Williams Make Team
description: A year of mental and physical problems came to a joyful end tonight for Michelle Mitchell. In Wendy Lian Williams's case, the joy came after a four-year wait.

title: Miss Casimir-Lambert Becomes Bride
description: The marriage of Veronique Casimir-Lambert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pierre Casimir-Lambert of Geneva, to Frederick Harlan Batrus, a partner in Lazard Freres & Company in New York, took place yesterday at St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Brookville, L.I. The Rev. Edward Maloney, the president of the Fordham Preparatory School, performed the ceremony.

title: Computers in the Corner Office
description: LEAD: WHEN he gets to the office early each morning, Charles M. Harper turns on his computer. He will check grain prices and look at updated economic forecasts from Washington. In the afternoon, he is likely to log onto a Dow Jones service to scan analysts' views and earnings prospects for a company he wants to buy.

title: THE PEN AND THE SCALPEL
description: LEAD: I HAD BEEN A GENERAL surgeon for 15 years when, at the age of 40, the psychic energy for writing inexplicably appeared. It was an appearance that was to knock over my life. For 15 years I had studied, practiced and taught surgery at the Yale School of Medicine, all the while enjoying the usefulness and the handsomeness of the craft.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $252,000 3 Macy Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 24-year-old raised ranch; dining room, family room, in-law apartment, 2-car garage; taxes $4,906. Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. $413,000 5 Brace Terrace 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 40-year-old colonial; fireplace, unfinished basement, porch, 2-car garage; taxes $6,354. Mamaroneck, N.Y. $430,000 411 Rushmore 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 35-year-old split level; fireplace, dining room, family room, playroom, deck, 1-car garage; taxes $7,505. Collinsville, Conn. $195,000 9 Birch Knoll Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; walk to town, schools, 109- by 199-foot lot; taxes $1,711. Darien, Conn. $485,000 28 Fairmead Road 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; master suite with whirlpool bath, new eat-in kitchen, 1-acre; taxes $3,027. Norwalk, Conn. $341,000 3 Watering Lane 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 23-year-old split level; solar hot water panels, on cul-de-sac, half an acre; taxes $2,855. OTHER AREAS West Orange, N.J. $250,000 14 Devonshire Terrace 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 36-year-old split level; c/a, recreation room, formal dining room; taxes $4,351. Albertson, L.I. $265,000 26 Terrace Court 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old brick Cape Cod; den, fireplace; taxes $3,000. Bay Shore, L.I. $95,000 43 Center Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 65-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,200.

title: The Town That Breathes Cognac
description: ONE spring morning I found myself in a subterranean cave in southwestern France sipping cognac.

title: Small but Special in Westport
description: THE storefront space long occupied by Pearl's in Westport is now a charming Italian restaurant called Da Pietro, after its owner and chef, Pietro Scotti.

title: Miss von Schaumburg Wed
description: Mary Anne von Schaumburg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth von Schaumburg of Bloomfield, N.J., was married there yesterday to Stephen Martin Burns, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel M. Burns of Garden City, L.I. The Rev. Michael Kreder performed the ceremony at St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Burns is a research associate with Russell Reynolds Associates in New York. Her husband is to join W. R. Grace & Company Sept. 1 as an associate in mergers and acquisitions.

title: Theater's New Crop Takes Root
description: Six years ago, while the young director Des McAnuff's audacious musical play, ''The Death of von Richthofen as Witnessed From Earth,'' was running at the Public Theater, its creator was contacted by David Singer, a young producer with another bold project. How would Mr. McAnuff like to adapt and direct a musical based on Jules Verne's novel ''Around the World in 80 Days'' to be a Radio City Music Hall extravaganza?

title: Even Newark Is Afraid Of Go-Go Development
description: NEWARK passed a turning point last year when it tore down four public housing high-rises. What it was turning toward, however, is still a matter of debate.

title: Dr. Christina B. Casals-Ariet Is Married
description: Dr. Christina Brock Casals-Ariet, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jordi Casals-Ariet of New York and Port Jefferson, L.I., and David Mason Little 3d, a son of Mrs. Little Jr. of West Hartford, Conn., and Chocorua, N.H., and the late Dr. Little, were married yesterday.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Somerset County Office Space Expanding
description: LEAD: THE market for first-class office space is slowly evolving in north-central Somerset County, as evidenced by a series of sleek low-rise structures that are springing up in clusters amid the Somerset Hills.

title: Correction
description: A caption on page 19 in some copies of the Arts and Leisure section today misidentifies one of the two Marx Brothers. The one on the right is Groucho, not Harpo.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Sunnyside
description: LEAD: VIRGINIA PASSARIELLO pushed a switch and the fountain she and her husband, Nicholas, recently built in the backyard of their house in the Sunnyside Gardens section of Queens came to life, helping to cool a steamy afternoon. Beside it bloomed a colorful patch of zinnias.

title: A MAN AND THE IDEA OF A WOMAN
description: PALM-OF-THE-HAND STORIES By Yasunari Kawabata. Translated by Lane Dunlop and J. Martin Holman. 238 pp. Berkeley, Calif.: North Point Press. $19.95.

title: Frances Ruml Weds Frederic Beckley
description: Frances Towne Ruml, the daughter of Mrs. Anton T. Lahnston of Cambridge, Mass., and South Bristol, Me., and Beardsley Ruml 2d of Cambridge, was married yesterday to Frederic Atcheson Beckley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Beckley of Camp Hill, Pa. The Rev. Robert W. Tobin performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Cambridge.

title: Fiscal Blueprint Burdens Not New
description: WHEN the 33 members of a special state commission started work on developing a fiscal blueprint for the state and local governments to follow, they received some sound advice from two former New Jersey Governors.

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. We left a yellow rubber bath mat in the bottom of our tub for a couple of months. When we picked it up we found that it has left a yellow stain we cannot seem to remove. We tried scouring powder, then fine steel wool, but the latter left a gray stain, probably because of the tub's age (34 years). Is there a rubber dissolving chemical I can try that might remove the stain without causing further wear of the thin enamel?

title: Gauging the Election by Nominees' Outlooks
description: If psychological research completed yesterday is an accurate measure in the current Presidential race, the winner will most likely be Michael S. Dukakis. And the reason will be that he is more optimistic than George Bush.

title: Reviews/Music; Herbig Conducts Haydn In Mostly Mozart Series
description: The Mostly Mozart festival is having a Haydn Week, and right off the bat I think the organizers should be thanked for not calling it ''Heaps of Haydn'' or any other alliterative derivative that, marketing history tells us, might all too easily have sprung to their minds. The week of concerts, which continues today with a ''Haydn Marathon'' of several hours duration, was kicked off Friday night by the festival orchestra with Gunther Herbig on the podium and Ken Noda and Elmar Oliveira as piano and violin soloist, respectively.

title: An Old Hand Starts a New Label
description: Nobody could ever accuse Seymour Solomon of having a one-track mind. While the record company he started in 1950, the Vanguard Recording Society, was heavily weighted toward the Baroque (which, with his help, was then just beginning the boom that has yet to stop), Vanguard was a lot more, including Joan Baez and P.D.Q. Bach (who of course is a lot less Baroque than the name implies), as well as Beethoven and Mozart and a lot more.

title: Bill on Altered Films Passes Joint Committee
description: A modified version of a bill that would establish the first Government film commission has been approved by a House-Senate conference committee. The 13-member commission would have the power to require labeling of some classic films that have been altered by coloring or other technology.

title: Where Personal Finances Are in the Public Eye
description: Even by the standards of the Federal Government, where most workers have a pretty good notion of how much their colleagues are paid, those who labor for senators, representatives, Congressional committees or support staffs find themselves in a remarkably revealing financial fishbowl.

title: Roar in the Wilderness Raises Ire Over Vehicles
description: The trail just outside the Glacier Peak National Wilderness area here has seen so much motorized traffic lately that some hikers have started calling it the Interstate.

title: 19 Arrests in Protest at Washington Sq. Park
description: A protest challenging the midnight curfew at Washington Square Park ended Saturday night in 19 arrests. Later, demonstrators asserted that the police had singled out leaders of the protest for arrest.

title: The Reagan Right: No Bark, No Bite
description: LEAD: As the new academic year begins, the mood on American campuses is distinctly upbeat. A 7 percent increase in the consumer cost of higher education gives institutions of marginal quality the nerve to charge $20,000 a year for tuition, room and board, and the license to get away with it. More important, the leftist faculty elite has not only emerged from the Reagan years unscathed but is looking forward to the liberal Democratic barbecue of the Dukakis administration, which, they hope, will start next year.

title: Listless Mets Lose, 1-0
description: Before the game, Dave Johnson gathered the Mets and told them to quit worrying about their three-month slump. Go out and have some fun again, he said, and remember you're still in first place.

title: Bush and Bentsen Each Have Son Who Served in the National Guard
description: Vice President Bush and Senator Lloyd Bentsen each had a son who enlisted in the Texas Air National Guard in 1968. But their commanding officer at the time said in an interview today that neither son was admitted because of his affluent background or high-level connections.

title: Results Plus
description: Basketball

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There's a big residue of good will about New York City schools. You might even call it a consensus. It's not simply the people who know that the future of the city is tied to the schools, but there is still a love for the New York City public schools by those who have been part of it. A lot of people went to these schools. The education system gave them their start, and they want the schools to work for other people's children.'' - Richard R. Green, New York City Schools Chancellor. [ B2:6. ]

title: Bush: A Hit, An Error
description: In picking Senator Dan Quayle as his Vice Presidential partner, George Bush didn't remove the doubts about his leadership; he multiplied them. His judgment is now an issue more than ever - not whether this bird from Indiana can fly or whether he dodged the Vietnam draft but whether Bush would pick the best available people to help govern the country.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: When Don Sutton was released by the Dodgers earlier this month, reports about his career pointed out that he was one of 10 pitchers in major league history with 3,000 or more strikeouts. Did he ever lead the league in strikeouts for a season?

title: Police in Israel Arrest 3 Arabs in Haifa Bombing
description: The police said today that they had arrested three Arabs believed to be responsible for a bombing that wounded 25 people in downtown Haifa on Saturday night.

title: Inaugural Spoilsport
description: Whether George Bush or Michael Dukakis gets elected in November, getting inaugurated in January will cost him more than it cost Ronald Reagan. Thanks to William Proxmire, the Wisconsin watchdog, John Q. Taxpayer will no longer pay to help stage private functions on the new President's big first day.

title: TV Notes
description: Lessing on Her Career

title: Olympic Boxer Shakes Off Past and Hopes for Happy Ending
description: THE lines are memorized, as if he were reciting a favorite bedtime story, one that begins with ''Once upon a time,'' and has the usual happy ending. Andrew Maynard hasn't finished writing his story yet, but that does not lessen his enthusiasm for giving listeners a detailed account of what has transpired thus far. Even if he were to be denied the ultimate success in Seoul, South Korea, in September, Maynard's smile says that the worst is over.

title: No Time for Diplomacy
description: In recent years the most critical stage in the appointment of United States ambassadors has been the confirmation proceedings before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, where partisan politics can swamp a nomination.

title: JOHN GABRIEL, PERSONALLY
description: Soap opera stars who go into cabaret often bring with them values -prefabricated glamour and slick packaging - associated more with television image-making than cabaret intimacy. To his credit, John Gabriel, a singing actor who for 10 years portrayed a doctor on ''Ryan's Hope,'' falls back only sparingly on his television celebrity. Mr. Gabriel, who is appearing at Jan Wallman's (49 West 44th Street) Wednesday evenings this month, is a gruff-voiced baritone who projects a calm unpretentious manliness. While capable of fairly strong theatrical projection, he scales no lyrical heights. Everything is offered from a more conversational point of view.

title: MacNamara, Clapp To Handle Beefeater
description: Buckingham Wile, an importer of wines and spirits, has shifted its recently acquired Beefeater gin to MacNamara Clapp & Klein. The agency already handles the importer's Cutty Sark Scots Whisky, B&B DOM Liqueur and Metaxa Greek Liqueur. The budget is $7 million to $8 million. The Kobrand Corporation sold Beefeater to Buckingham Wile's parent, Whitbred North America, in March. AC&R/DHB & Bess, a division of Saatchi & Saatchi, is the former agency.

title: Women Take Lead in Ending Long Marriages; Can't Legislate Tastes
description: To the Editor:

title: Ads for Michelob Dry To Begin in 5 Markets
description: Anheuser-Busch Inc. will begin the first phase of its national campaign for Michelob Dry on Sept. 1 in selected markets. They are Fresno and Santa Barbara, Calif.,; Tallahassee, Fla.; Dayton, Ohio, and Houston.

title: G.E. Investment Aide Joining Olympus Fund
description: Wall Street knows Jack Nash and Leon Levy for the decades they spent running Oppenheimer & Company. Leveraged buyout specialists know them from Odyssey Partners, the investment boutique they opened when they left the brokerage business in 1982.

title: DOUBTS CAST ON PEARY'S CLAIM TO POLE
description: A new analysis of the expedition diary and other archives, focusing on navigational errors, suspect distance records and inexplicably blank pages in Robert E. Peary's diary, has raised the strongest doubts yet about the credibility of the explorer's claim that on April 6, 1909, he became the first person to reach the North Pole.

title: Big Apple: New York Nickname With a Southern Accent?
description: LEAD: New York City got the Statue of Liberty from France, the Cloisters from Spain, and Babe Ruth from Boston. And it got the nickname Big Apple from - Columbia, S.C.?

title: Burmese Refugees Denounce What Long Kept Them Silent
description: Samson Dah, 7 years old, held a placard that read, ''Let the People Speak,'' and his father, Dr. Saw Shwe Dah, spoke of the plight of his countrymen in Burma.

title: Sports World Specials; Olympic Airlift
description: Outside the fertile realm of a public relation man's imagination, there was no particular reason to suppose that a certain couple of shipments that went from the United States to Asia a while back had anything to do with the Olympics.

title: New Statistics Could Jolt Traders
description: The dog days of summer have enveloped the credit markets, but analysts said that developments this week could shake participants out of their pre-Labor Day torpor.

title: Eric A. Messer Is Wed To Hillary B. Chassin
description: Hillary Beth Chassin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray J. Chassin of Roslyn and Westhampton Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to Eric A. Messer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Messer of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. Rabbi Edward Schecter performed the ceremony at the Water's Edge at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Jersey Fire Deaths Rise to 6
description: A 9-month-old boy has become the sixth person to die from injuries suffered in a fire early Saturday at the Currie's Woods housing project here, officials said. The boy, Ravon Cousins, died at 6:58 P.M. yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital in Newark. Fire officials said the cause of the blaze was still not known. The Hudson County Prosecutor's Office said it was examining the smoke alarm system at the 715-unit project.

title: VICTIMS OF CRASH PRAISED IN CAPITAL
description: Ambassador Arnold L. Raphel and Brig. Gen. Herbert M. Wassom, who were killed in a plane crash last week in Pakistan, were praised today as exemplary public officials in a moving ceremony here marking their final Washington homecoming.

title: Iraq's Secret Oil Pipeline
description: Iraq is ready to export oil through the Persian Gulf, using a secret oil pipeline that was not damaged in the war with Iran, oil and shipping officials said today.

title: Bozell, Jacobs Chosen By a Japanese Client
description: The Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt/Pacific division has been tapped to handle the Asics Tiger Corporation's athletic shoes and active wear account in the United States. The budget is $7 million. No agency search was conducted. The client, whose parent company is based in Tokyo, said it had chosen the shop because of its familiarity with the Pacific Rim and Tokyo affiliates. BJK&E/Pacific won the Clarion auto stereo business last year and continues as the agency for Kawasaki motorcycles. Asics Tiger of Japan, however, is using another agency.

title: Cultures Clash on Island of Clambakes
description: The scene might have been one drawn from ''The Great Gatsby'': men in dinner jackets and women in evening dresses sipped champagne, nibbled petits fours and danced to jazz under a billowing white tent on the harbor here Saturday night.

title: Metro Matters; She Is Outspoken And Out Running To Win Support
description: Ruth W. Messinger, City Councilwoman and permanent thorn in the city administration's side, is speaking in a measured, deliberate, no-nonsense monotone.

title: Mission of an AIDS Unit Is Not to Cure, but to Care
description: In a fifth-floor hospital room, a woman worries about who will raise her son if she dies of AIDS. Nearby, another woman lingers, well enough to leave if she had a home but too sick to return to the streets.

title: Infant Killed When Hit by Van
description: A 4-month-old boy was killed when struck by a van while picnicking in Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx last night, the police said. They said the infant, Justo Martinez, was in his stroller next to his mother, Luisa Martinez, 21, near West 246th Street and Manson Road, when hit by the van, driven by Lorgio Cano, 59, of 566 East 191st Street. The mother suffered a leg injury.

title: MORRIS SHUTS OUT WHITE SOX
description: Jack Morris pitched a two-hitter for his 21st career shutout and the Detroit Tigers completed a four-game sweep today with a 5-0 victory over the error-plagued Chicago White Sox. The Tigers lead the Red Sox by four games and the Yankees by six games in the American League East.

title: Teachers, Where Were You in the Great Computer Revolution?
description: To the Editor:

title: GDANSK SHIPYARD TO JOIN STRIKERS
description: Leaders of the outlawed Solidarity trade union called a strike tonight at the big Lenin shipyard in Gdansk for Monday after the Government refused an earlier offer of talks with the union's national leaders to defuse a wave of labor unrest.

title: 'Gold Rush' Of Cosmetics Into Nigeria
description: United States manufacturers of beauty products for blacks are penetrating a new market with increasing success: Nigeria.

title: Auto Racing; Rahal Terminates Chevrolet's Streak
description: Bobby Rahal won the crashed-filled Quaker State 500 Indy-car race today, ending Chevrolet's seasonlong dominance and taking the series point lead.

title: Amy Einsidler Is Bride Of Keith Martin Lewis
description: Amy Einsidler, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Roy Einsidler of Lawrence, L.I., and New York, and Keith Martin Lewis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan L. Lewis of Rochester, were married yesterday. Rabbi Robert J. Eisen officiated at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York.

title: New Chairman At Chevron
description: The Chevron Corporation said Friday that its vice chairman, Kenneth T. Derr, had been elected chairman and chief executive, effective Jan. 1. Mr. Derr, who is 52 years old, succeeds George M. Keller, who will retire at the end of the year at the age of 65.

title: INSIDE
description: Off Course? A new analysis suggests that Robert E. Peary, credited with being the first to reach the North Pole, may have been miles from his goal. Page B7. Buyout Offer for Wickes Frustrated with Wall Street, the chairman of the Wickes Companies offered $2.6 billion to buy the maker of auto and home products. Page D1. An Unexpurgated 'Jungle' Material deleted from ''The Jungle,''

title: Sports of the Times; U.S. Tennis Hope Becomes a Reality
description: IT is reminiscent of when the Beatles were all the rage and Joe Namath was the proprietor of Bachelors III, although on a much smaller scale. Andre Agassi, his streaked, blond shoulder-length hair blowing in the wind, trotted into the men's locker room at Newark Academy an hour before yesterday's match, cradling still another bouquet of flowers given to him by a female admirer.

title: Has Public TV Lost Its Way? Bills in Congress Fuel Debate
description: A battle is being fought for the heart and mind of public television. On one side are the 186 stations in the Public Broadcasting System, struggling to keep pace with cable channels that duplicate their fare and siphon viewers. On the other side is a well-organized group of independent producers who say that public television has pandered to an affluent audience while neglecting its mandate to create innovative programming.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES Wickes's chairman wants to take the company private in a leveraged buyout valued at $2.6 billion in cash and debt, with backing from Drexel Burnham Lambert. Sanford C. Sigoloff, the turnaround specialist who led Wickes out of bankruptcy in 1985, has grown frustrated with Wall Street as the company's stock failed to recover from the October plunge. Wickes also announced that it had lost $12.4 million in the second quarter, compared with a profit of $18.9 million a year earlier. [ D1. ] A new retailing concept is experiencing problems. Some of the medium-sized specialty stores that provide clothing for affluent professional women have closed and others are showing mediocre results. One chain, Alcott & Andrews, is seeking a buyer to help it finance its aggressive expansion plans. [ D1. ] THE ECONOMY Companies are seeking to limit obligations for retired workers' health care costs and some may soon take steps to cap their liability. Employers could realize tens of millions of dollars a year in savings, but retirees would face much higher expenses. [ D1. ] A wave of savings-bank consolidations may be coming in the Northeast, led by the New York real-estate developers Paul and Seymour Milstein. The Milsteins, who already own Emigrant Savings and have acquired almost 10 percent of Greater New York Savings, have offered $20 a share for Home Savings. [ D1. ] A complex plan to revitalize the uranium-mining industry awaits action in the House after quietly passing in the Senate. [ D1. ] The Hunt brothers face numerous problems in addition to the $130 million judgment against them for conspiring to corner the world silver market. The Saturday ruling came as the Hunts are trying to settle a $1.5 billion dispute with 23 lenders. [ D2. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT Nigeria is becoming an important market for American makers of beauty products for blacks, to the dismay of African manufacturers of products licensed by U.S. companies. [ D10. ] Argentina's new economic plan has met strong resistance, with farmers protesting key provisions and the main opposition party threatening to block the sale of part of the national airline. [ D10. ] Union Carbide is close to selling a polyethylene plastics plant in Bombay. Sealed bids for the 27-year-old plant, operated by the company's Indian subsidiary, will be opened on Thursday. [ D2. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS New York's ethnic press is booming. At least 12 foreign-language dailies and dozens of weeklies and other papers are serving the fast-growing immigrant communities. [ D1. ] A new satellite network is aiming at farmers. RFD-TV will concentrate on news, weather and market reports of primary interest to people involved in agriculture. [ D8. ] Two financing bills offer different views of public broadcasting. A group of independent producers is telling Congress that PBS spends too much money on shows that cater to the affluent and not enough for innovative programming. Television. [ D8. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS A potentially important week begins for the credit markets. Several economic statistics will be released, and bond prices could move substantially if any numbers are out of line with expectations. Credit Markets. [ D7. ] Lawsuits over Chubb's rain insurance raise fascinating issues on a variety of legal subjects, including insurance law, the law of contracts and the law governing the relationship between a principal and its agent. Business and the Law. [ D2. ] A takeover bid has sent Interco's stock surging. A $70-a-share offer by Steven and Mitchell Rales has lifted the stock to $72.75, compared with $49 in mid-July. Market Place. [ D6. ]

title: Rangoon Hauls Out Barbed Wire In Anticipation of More Protests
description: Soldiers have taken up positions in downtown Rangoon and barbed wire has been stretched across some streets in anticipation of more anti-Government demonstrations in the Burmese capital on Monday, diplomats said today.

title: A LOOK AT THE LIFE OF THE 'QUEEN OF SOUL'
description: It's not easy to turn Aretha Frankin's life into a standard pop star biography, but ''Aretha Franklin: The Queen of Soul'' - to be shown tonight at 9 on Channel 13 - strives to do just that.

title: Big Treasury Offerings Are Set This Week
description: Big offerings of new short- to intermediate-term securities highlight this week's Treasury calendar.

title: Adoptive Parents Ask States For Help With Abused Young
description: Before he turned 13 and was placed in a psychiatric hospital, Mark Richards tried to burn down his home. He sexually abused his younger brother and terrorized him with a butcher knife.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank of New York named Frank L. Peterson Jr. and Frank Scarangella senior vice presidents.

title: A Tough Decision For Rutgers Player
description: This past Friday could have been a memorable evening for Eric Young of Rutgers University, one he would recall long after he put his spikes on for the last time.

title: You Can Build A Boat in a Week
description: LEAD: THE WoodenBoat School in Brooklin, Me., is an outgrowth of WoodenBoat magazine. So many readers asked where they could learn the basic (and not so basic) boating skills that the school was established in 1981. The faculty is drawn from professional boat builders, teachers and others who not only possess expertise, but teaching ability that generates enthusiasm in their students.

title: Dr. Annabel Barber Marries Dr. Robert C. Wang
description: Dr. Annabel Elizabeth McMullan Barber, a resident in general surgery at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, was married in New York last evening to Dr. Robert C. Wang, the director of residency training at the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital. The Rev. Henry Strobel, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the chapel at the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: Philharmonic Benefit
description: Schubert's ''Rosamunde'' Overture, the Beethoven Violin Concerto and excerpts from Wagner's ''Gotterdammerung'' form the program for the benefit concert that opens the New York Philharmonic season, on Sept. 14 at 7:30 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall. Zubin Mehta is to conduct, with Isaac Stern as the soloist in the Beethoven.
