Tickets for the black-tie event are $125 (preconcert cocktails are included), $300 and $500 (dinner is included in both prices) and - for a box of eight seats -$6,000 (preconcert reception, intermission cocktails and dinner for eight included). Information: 874-2424.

title: AT LEAST 700 DEAD IN A MAJOR QUAKE IN THE HIMALAYAS
description: A devastating earthquake rumbled across eastern India and Nepal before dawn Sunday, killing more than 700 people.

title: National Guard Is Used in a Test To Curb Drug Flow From Mexico; Action in Congress
description: The expansion of the military's role in drug enforcement has been a popular idea in Congress recently despite strong opposition from the armed forces and its supporters.

title: Ellen Kramer and Neil Blond, Publisher, Are Wed
description: Ellen Deborah Kramer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton E. Kramer of Far Rockaway, Queens, and Neil Cary Blond, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold N. Blond, also of Far Rockaway, were married yesterday at Congregation Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I. Rabbi Israel Chait officiated, assisted by Rabbis Walter S. Wurzburger and Ralph Pelcovitz.

title: TELEVISION AND EVANGELISM
description: Ministry of Greed The Inside Story of the Televangelists and Their Holy War By Larry Martz with Ginny Carroll Illustrated. 260 pages. A Newsweek Book/ Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $18.95.

title: Jean-Paul Aron, Philosopher, 61
description: Jean-Paul Aron, a philosopher and writer who announced last year that he was suffering from AIDS, died Saturday, hospital officials said. He was 61 years old.

title: Brendan Malone Joins Piston Staff
description: Brendan Malone, an assistant with the Knicks and former head coach at Rhode Island, was named an assistant coach with the Detroit Pistons today.

title: Mattingly Hot After Yank Loss
description: The defeat was like all the others this summer. It began and then it was over, quickly, quietly, almost sadly for the Yankees. They played, they lost, they dressed and left. The lone exception was Don Mattingly, who sat in front of his locker yesterday and let his anger spill out.

title: A Hot Retailing Concept Runs Into Trouble
description: A new retailing concept, medium-sized specialty stores that provide clothing for affluent professional women in a setting where shopping can be quick and efficient, has run into problems.

title: Sports World Specials; Bump and Run
description: For auto racing fans who attended this past weekend's activities at the raceway in Pocono, Pa., the 500-mile Indy-car race yesterday may not have been the most entertaining event. One of the curtain raisers was the Coors RaceTruck Challenge for showroom stock mini-pickup trucks, and it is an event that is fast gaining popularity.

title: Agency Merger In Richmond
description: Even young ad agencies are jumping into the acquisition game. Hawley Martin Partners, which opened its doors in Richmond two weeks ago, has acquired that city's Ford & Westbrook in an exchange of stock. The deal brings Hawley Martin's total billings to $50 million - Richmond's No. 2 in size behind the Martin Agency. David N. Martin and Stephen

title: Branch of Japan Bank Gets a New Manager
description: A changing of the guard has occurred at the New York branch of the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd. Toshiichi Hashimoto, who is 56 years old, has become the new general manager.

title: Foreign Studies Will Sharpen Our Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Tennis; Sabatini Defeats Zvereva With Ease
description: Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina won a battle of teen-agers today by beating Natalya Zvereva, a 17-year-old player from the Soviet Union, 6-1, 6-2, in the final of the Player's Challenge women's tournament.

title: AWAITING RULING, YONKERS LOOKS BEYOND TURMOIL TO THE FUTURE
description: As Yonkers enters a potentially pivotal week, it faces several possibilities - the jailing of four City Councilmen who have resisted a court-ordered housing desegregation plan, the resumption of bankrupting fines, or perhaps a resolution of the conflict between the city and the court. Still, many residents, developers and public officials are looking beyond the immediate turmoil to what the future holds for the embattled city of 194,000.

title: British Inflation Rate Up
description: Britain's inflation rate edged up to 4.8 percent in July from 4.6 percent in June, the Employment Department said Friday. The retail price index rose one-tenth of 1 percent in the month, mostly from higher prices of cars, driving insurance, non-seasonal food, electricity and gas, the department said. Prices of fresh food and clothes fell, however. Analysts said that higher costs of home loans should push August's retail price index up seven-tenths of 1 percent, sending annual inflation well above 5 percent, analysts said. They said the annual figure could reach 6 percent by early 1989, compared with 3.3 percent in January 1988.

title: DOLE SAYS QUAYLE IS DAMAGING BUSH
description: Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, today added to complaints about his party's nomination of Senator Dan Quayle, saying his presence on the Presidential ticket would make it harder to retain the White House.

title: Outdoors: Anglers Find Designer Lures Alluring
description: AN angler's skills should increase with experience, but the graybeard often makes little attempt to be innovative, relying on techniques, lures or flies that never fully embrace all of the challenges he encounters.

title: MINIMALIST ZARZUELA FROM REPERTORIO ESPANOL
description: The Repertorio Espanol company, which offers a variety of plays, zarzuelas and other attractions at the tiny Gramercy Arts Theater (138 East 27th Street) has a modest delight on tap in its production of ''La Generala Alegre,'' a 1910 operetta by Amadeo Vives, heard Saturday evening.

title: Dr. Madeleine Stam Weds a Physician
description: Dr. Madeleine Stam, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jacob Stam of New York and Sheffield, Mass., and Dr. Lewis Karl Schrager, a son of Drs. Alvin and Gloria Schrager of Westfield, N.J., were married yesterday at the Jewish Community Center in Harrison, N.Y. Rabbi Shawn Zell officiated.

title: 10,000 in Prague Protest 1968 Invasion
description: About 10,000 people marched through the capital today, shouting ''Freedom!'' and ''Russians go home!'' on the 20th anniversary of the Soviet-led invasion that crushed the ''Prague Spring'' of 1968.

title: Indians Hike to Reagan Ranch
description: Twenty-two members and supporters of American Indian tribes walked up a seven-mile mountain road to President Reagan's ranch Saturday, seeking a dialogue on Indian rights.

title: New York's Chancellor Seeks To Broaden Teachers' Role
description: Richard R. Green will move into his first full academic year as New York City's Schools Chancellor next month resolved to further decentralize the 942,000-student school system and to broaden the role that schools and teachers play in the non-academic lives of their students.

title: John A. Livingston, Architect, 85
description: John A. Livingston, a naval architect and marine engineer, died of heart failure Tuesday at the Maine Medical Center in Portland. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: World Bank Road Study
description: Third-world countries need $43 billion worth of repairs to their roads because they failed to spend $12 billion to maintain them in the last decade, the World Bank said in a recent report.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly LAW OF THE SEA - PREPARATORY COMMISSION - SPECIAL COMMISSIONS - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: The Bush Dilemma
description: The first rule of choosing a running mate is taken from the Hippocratic oath: first, do no harm.

title: CHAVEZ ENDS FAST OVER PESTICIDE USE
description: Cesar Chavez ended his 36-day fast today by breaking bread with the children of Robert F. Kennedy at a Mass as thousands showed their support for the farm labor leader's boycott of California table grapes.

title: Traveler, a Year Old, Influences but Trails
description: Next month's issue of Conde Nast Traveler warns of encephalitis in Japan, tear gas in the South Korean city welcoming the Olympics and a ripoff cab ride in Rome.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of August 21, 1988: MONDAY BRE Properties Standard Products Continental Illinois Tyco Labs Quanex Corp United Illuminating San Diego G&E TUESDAY Angelica Corp Gap Inc Century Tel Entr Home Depot Inc Duquesne Light Kellwood Co EDO Corp Rose's Stores Gannett Co Westvaco Corp WEDNESDAY Bowater Inc Penn Pwr & Lt First Virginia Banks SCANA Corp NL Industries Wolverine World Wide Northern States Pwr MN Wrigley (Wm) Jr Pacific Scientific THURSDAY Amer Medical Intl Interlake Corp Bank of Boston FRIDAY Bairnco Corp Ryder System Dexter Corp Scotty's Inc Harris Corp Varian Associates MDC Holdings Inc Whittaker Corp

title: Fire Blocks Amtrak Corridor
description: A fire broke out tonight in the locomotive of an Amtrak passenger train heading from New York to Washington, forcing the evacuation of the 172 passengers on board, an Amtrak official said. The passengers of Train 123 were moved to a rear car, then taken by bus to Washington, said an Amtrak spokeswoman, Marci Larson. No one was injured, she said. Power, cut during the fire, was restored briefly about 11 P.M., allowing about 10 trains backed up by the fire to move through officials said.

title: Officers Seize Tons of Cocaine In Queens Raid
description: More than two tons of cocaine and $2 million in cash - stashed in grocery bags that said ''Just Say No to Drugs'' - were seized late Saturday at a Queens apartment in what the authorities called the largest drug raid in New York City, officials said yesterday.

title: Santa Fe Journal; The Woodstock of Indian Art Draws Faithful by the Droves
description: Patricia Marie, a Phoenix pottery collector, was trembling with emotion as she signed two checks totaling $9,500 and received two polished vases in return.

title: I.R.A. Blast Prompts Security Review
description: The British Government began a wide-ranging review of its security arrangements in Northern Ireland today after eight British soldiers were killed in an Irish Republican Army attack.

title: Marjorie Seidel Married
description: Marjorie D. Seidel, a daughter of Herbert B. Seidel of St. Louis and the late Gayle Sosin Seidel, was married yesterday to Jay A. Yelon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Yelon of Brooklyn. Rabbis Alan Lavin and Ezra Finklestein officiated at Temple Shalom in Brooklyn. Mrs. Yelon, a classified advertising saleswoman at The New York Times, graduated from the University of Hartford. Her husband, who graduated from the New York Institute of Technology, is a third-year student at the New York College of Osteopathic Medicine.

title: Union Carbide to Sell Plastics Plant in India
description: The Indian subsidiary of the Union Carbide Corporation is close to selling its polyethylene plastics plant in Bombay, which has been closed for more than two years.

title: Death Toll in Ethnic Clashes In Burundi Is Put at 3,000
description: Ethnic clashes in northern Burundi last week left about 3,000 people dead and sent at least 16,000 fleeing across the border to escape the bloodbath, a diplomat said today.

title: On Foreign Affairs
description: There are more and more working couples in the United States Foreign Service, and one of them consists of Robert B. Oakley, the National Security Council specialist on the Middle East at the White House, and his wife, Phyllis B. Oakley, the deputy spokeswoman of the State Department.

title: Styron Given MacDowell Medal
description: William Styron joined the ranks of Robert Frost, Elliot Carter, Willem de Kooning and 25 equally illustrious Americans yesterday when he received the Edward MacDowell Medal for excellence in the arts, for his achievements as a writer.

title: Track and Field; Johnson Beaten Again in 100-Meter Race
description: Calvin Smith and Dennis Mitchell of the United States both took the measure of Ben Johnson this afternoon, defeating the Canadian world champion in a 100-meter race here.

title: National Guard Is Used in a Test To Curb Drug Flow From Mexico
description: In what United States Government agencies describe as a limited test program, about 100 American National Guardsmen have for the first time been deployed along the United States-Mexico border seeking to decrease the flow of drugs from Mexico.

title: Lucie Livingston, A Teacher, Weds
description: At Temple Emanu-El in Manhattan, Lucie Livingston, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frederick R. Livingston of New York and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Seth George Aidinoff, the son of M. Bernard Aidinoff of New York and Amagansett, L.I., and the late Mrs. Aidinoff. Rabbi David M. Posner performed the ceremony.

title: With Gulf War Quiet, Foes Grapple Verbally
description: Iran and Iraq traded accusations of cease-fire violations today, but United Nations officials supervising the day-old truce said it was still in place.

title: National League; Astros' Agosto Stops Pirates
description: Gerald Young's two-out single in the 14th inning drove in Billy Hatcher with the winning run as the Houston Astros beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 2-1, today.

title: Reaching Out to as Many Americans as Possible
description: To the Editor:

title: Highbloom Leaving DDB for New Career
description: Lloyd Highbloom has resigned as executive vice president, director of business development and a board member of DDB Needham Worldwide to pursue a new career. In a weekend announcement, he said he would disclose his plans later.

title: Massachusetts Borrows to Cover Expenses
description: The Dukakis administration, facing sluggish tax revenues, has been forced for the third time in two months to borrow $200 million to cover state expenses. And Massachusetts officials said more short-term borrowing may be necessary.

title: Waldheim Unwelcome
description: In 1987 the Justice Department placed Kurt Waldheim, the President of Austria, on its ''watch list'' of people suspected of involvement in war crimes. The department based its decision mainly on World War II German Army documents.

title: Unblock Copyright Bill And Bring It to a Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 959988 -- No Title
description: At the turn of the century, most pregnant women saw the doctor only when the pregnancy was confirmed and when the baby was delivered. That pattern still prevails for thousands - among industrialized nations, the United States ranks an ignominious 19 in preventing infant deaths.

title: Managers Set Buyout Of Wickes
description: Sanford C. Sigoloff, the turnaround specialist who guided the Wickes Companies out of bankruptcy in 1985, said tonight that he and other members of management had agreed to take the company private in a leveraged buyout. Including debt that would be assumed, the deal is valued at $2.6 billion.

title: Barbara Haber, Physician, Wed
description: At the Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale, N.Y., Dr. Barbara Ann Haber, a postdoctoral fellow in pediatrics, and Dr. Jonathan Andrew Flick, an assistant professor of pediatrics, both at the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, were married yesterday by Rabbi Jack Stern.

title: From a Master, Batons That Aren't Just Sticks
description: Richard Horowitz has been a principal timpanist with the Metropolitan Opera orchestra since 1946. But numerous international conductors who call him their right-hand man are as likely to refer to his sideline -baton making - as to his drumbeat. To them, his name is as linked to their instrument as Stradivari is to the violin, or Steinway to the piano.

title: Raid on Police Station Rekindles A Fear of Terrorism for Greeks
description: Just as Greece seemed to be recovering from an unusual bout of terrorist attacks, a squad of urban guerrillas seized a police station here without firing a shot, tied up the officers inside and stole a small arsenal of weapons.

title: Lincoln Sought Save Civil War Haven for His Oldest Son
description: Reasons abound for the powerful and the not so powerful to seek haven for themselves or their sons in time of war.

title: Jem Records President Confident Despite Woes
description: For two decades, Martin L. Scott, the 38-year-old president and co-founder of Jem Records Inc., has tied his fortunes to those of the pioneering independent record company.

title: Women Take Lead in Ending Long Marriages
description: To the Editor:

title: SINCLAIR'S JUNGLE WITH ALL MUCK RESTORED
description: More than 80 years after publication of ''The Jungle,'' Upton Sinclair's harrowing account of unsanitary practices and sweatshop conditions in the meatpacking industry, the novel is about to be published exactly as its author wrote it. The edition published by Doubleday, Page exploded on the American consciousness when it was published in 1906, but Sinclair's original version is more damning of those he believed responsible for allowing such conditions to exist.

title: Market Place; A Takeover Bid Revives Interco
description: A HOSTILE takeover bid has worked magic on the stock of Interco, a St. Louis company not highly rated by Wall Street, but one whose subsidiaries in shoes, furniture and apparel are among the best known in the country.

title: U.S. Aid to Uranium Mining Meets Political Resistance
description: Largely hidden from press and public attention by its complexity, a plan to revitalize the depressed United States uranium-mining industry with huge injections of public money has quietly won approval in the Senate and awaits action in the House.

title: The Fed Stops Inflation, for Now
description: With unemployment at a 10-year low and factory output near capacity, is inflation just around the corner? Probably not, but only because the Federal Reserve seems determined to do whatever is necessary to maintain price stability. The Fed's tough stance deserves support.

title: Correction
description: A front page article from Huntington, Ind., about the Bush-Quayle campaign and the Quotation of the Day in some copies Saturday gave an incorrect serial number for Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana. His serial number is 303504096.

title: Live, From Omaha, a Network for Farmers
description: Cross the Financial News Network with home shopping programs, instructional shows, country music videos and old Westerns. Now beam the result at farmers, ranchers and their families - at least those with a satellite dish in the back yard.

title: SOBER MESSAGES, WITH SPIRIT
description: In the late 1970's, the English Beat mixed reggae and rock with political messages and complicated lyrics about romance, wrapping intelligent words in music so catchy that it reached a large pop audience. Two singers from the English Beat, Ranking Roger and Dave Wakeling, formed General Public in the early 1980's and now, a year after the breakup of General Public, Ranking Roger has emerged with his own band. Although his album is called ''Radical Departure,'' he has kept the same peppy musical hybrids while raising the proportion of songs on political and social topics.

title: Land of Opportunity
description: On the other side of the diplomatic coin, being ambassador to the United States is often a stepping stone to greater things. Five years ago Yugoslavia's Ambassador, Budimir Loncar, returned home from Washington and was soon appointed Deputy Foreign Minister. Now he is Foreign Minister in Belgrade.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Consumer Prices July Durable Goods July Wednesday Merchandise Trade Balance 2d Qtr. Thursday Gross National Product 2d Qtr. Corporate Profits 2d Qtr. Friday Personal Income July

title: Savings Banks Attract Aggressive Acquirers
description: It was an unlikely scene for a hostile takeover battle. The streets in this sleepy corner of Brooklyn were ghostly silent, save for an occasional subway train that passed overhead. Several locals were lazily leaning against parking meters. A few more slouched on stoops.

title: Splintering Of Markets: A Fine Art
description: IN Atlanta 91 percent more consumers have video cassette recorders than in Buffalo. Hispanic families in Houston show higher loyalty to retail grocers than Hispanic families in Chicago do. Women are 31 percent more likely than men to cite price as a reason for choosing one store over another. And so the differences, sometimes unaccountable, go.

title: 10,000 in Prague Protest 1968 Invasion; Kremlin Is Silent
description: The Soviet Union today observed the 20th anniversary of its invasion of Czechoslovakia with an enforced silence in the streets and in the press.

title: Just One More Setback For the Battered Hunts
description: A $130 million judgment against the Hunt brothers is the latest in a series of problems faced by the sons of the late Texas oilman H. L. Hunt.

title: Fifties From Heaven: It's the White Tuxedo!
description: It's beginning to look like a daily habit -a man in a white tuxedo hops out of a limousine and spends a couple of minutes handing out $50 bills to passers-by before being chauffeured away.

title: A Unit of G.M. To Lay Off 550
description: A unit of the General Motors Corporation plans to lay off 550 workers at its bearing manufacturing plant here and move its spindle bearing operations to Sandusky, Ohio, officials of New Departure-Hyatt Bearings said.

title: Blast in Beirut Wounds 18, Including 3 Syrian Soldiers
description: A car bomb exploded in mainly Moslem West Beirut today, wounding 18 people, including three Syrian soldiers. The police found and dismantled another bomb in another part of town.

title: Deanna M. Schindel Wed to H. A. Stecker
description: Deanna Marjorie Schindel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen F. Schindel of Brooklyn Heights and Becket, Mass., was married yesterday to Howard Adam Stecker, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Stecker of Fair Lawn, N.J. Rabbi Simon Glustrom performed the ceremony at the Water's Edge at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens.

title: FOREST FIRES RAGE IN WESTERN PARKS
description: Gale-force winds whipped more than 300,000 acres of wildfire across Yellowstone National Park on Saturday, the worst day of fires in the park's history. Roads have been closed once again and a resort village evacuated Saturday remained closed today.

title: Cuts Sought In Retirees' Health Costs
description: A growing number of companies, anticipating that rapid growth in medical costs will continue, are seriously considering ways to limit their obligations for retired workers' health costs, benefits consultants say.

title: Nancy Stone, Teacher, Wed to Joel Poznansky
description: Nancy Rachel Stone, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Stone of Washington, and Joel Benjamin Poznanksy, the son of Drs. Jack and Dulcie Poznansky of London, were married yesterday at the Westin Hotel in Washington by Rabbi Stanley Rabinowitz.

title: On Your Own; An Appetizer For Tennis Fans At the Open
description: For tennis fans who have been shut out of tickets to the United States Open, beginning Aug. 29 at Flushing Meadow Park in Queens, you are not alone: all 13 day sessions and 2 of 8 night sessions are already sold out, according to the United States Tennis Association. But there is a ''replacement activity'' on 18 field courts at the U.S.T.A. National Tennis Center the week before the Open.

title: Where's the City's Traffic Plan?
description: It's been nearly two years since New York City Transportation Commissioner Ross Sandler presented a ''menu of options'' to reduce traffic congestion in central Manhattan. He wanted the city to decide by February 1987 which meal to order. Yet no plan has yet emerged from his department, nor has there been action on any front.

title: James Hubball, Ex-Headmaster, Dies at 85
description: James Miles Hubball, who was headmaster of the Buckley School in Manhattan for 25 years until his retirement in 1972, died after a brief illness yesterday at his home in Southport, Conn. A former resident of Manhattan, he also had a home on Sanibel Island on the Gulf coast of Florida. He was 85 years old.

title: Serbs and Montenegrins Protest Yugoslav Strife
description: More than 20,000 Serbs and Montenegrins have threatened to take up arms to settle ethnic strife in Yugoslavia's Kosovo Province.

title: 7 Killed and 33 Hurt As a Suspicious Fire Guts an Illegal Club
description: Seven people were killed and 33 others, including a dozen firefighters, were injured yesterday when a fire raced through a basement social club that had been operating illegally in the Bronx, the authorities said.

title: On Your Own: Fitness; Exercising at High Altitude
description: THE altitude here is 6,600 feet above sea level. The new arrival from a lower altitude who begins working out immediately feels the difference. Within a minute or two, the breath comes in ragged gasps and it seems impossible to draw enough air into the lungs. The pace of the workout is slower, and the heart beats faster.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-10 An earthquake hit India and Nepal, killing more than 700 people. The authorities in India's Bihar state and in Nepal said many victims were buried in their homes and that the final toll may be much higher. Page A1

title: Reaching Out to as Many Americans as Possible
description: To the Editor:

title: News from Nee-kha-rahg-wah
description: It's becoming fashionable among TV and radio correspondents on the scene and politicians in Washington to pronounce Nicaragua the way the Nicaraguans do. Other countries south of the border get standard American treatment - mex-ih-co not meh-hee-co, bruh-zill not brah-seel, chilly not chee-lay. But the standard nicka-rahg-wuh often comes out nee-kha-rahg-wah, rolling the r and curling the g.

title: Sports World Specials; It Had to Happen
description: Given the growing popularity of baseball cards on the major and minor league levels, perhaps it was inevitable that the craze would spread to the amateur level. And when it did, one logical source was the Cape Cod League.

title: 50-Year Cinematic Tradition Fades on the West Side
description: A half-century-old cinematic tradition on upper Broadway - as eccentric, small-scale and neighborly as the Upper West Side used to be - will end next Sunday as the Embassy 72d Street Twin Theater turns out its lights for the last time.

title: Action on Detroit Merger Delayed
description: The Gannett Company and Knight-Ridder Inc. said Friday that they would wait until Sept. 8 to argue for a partial merger of their Detroit newspapers rather than immediately appeal a Federal court's 30-day restraining order against it.

title: Knee Surgery for Jets' Crable
description: The Jets, who had avoided the avalanche of injuries that marked their last few seasons, got bad news today: Bob Crable, the virtual captain of the defense, will undergo exploratory knee surgery Monday that will keep him out of the season's opener, at least.

title: A Torrid Summer's Dream: Gentle Breezes and Purple Turtlenecks
description: If summer means fun and frolic in the park, or a walk in a gentle breeze on the waterfront, then perhaps summer is finally beginning.

title: Eagles' 2 Black Quarterbacks Give Credit to Coach
description: BUDDY RYAN, twirling a whistle on a cord back and forth in his right hand, stalks the Philadelphia Eagles' practice as if he were a cop patroling a bustling beat. It is the last blistering day of the Eagles' two-a-day practices, and for players new and old, Ryan has left no doubt that this season his Eagles will fly all for one and one for all.

title: Jaguar Will Cut 1,200 Jobs
description: Jaguar P.L.C. plans to eliminate 1,200 jobs in the next three years to increase productivity and compete better with West German rivals, The Financial Times newspaper reported Saturday.

title: Olympic Diving; Louganis Qualifies; Kimball Does Not
description: The name at the top of the list was the ever-familiar one.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Denver Bank Infusion
description: Marvin Davis, the billionaire financier, has transferred $8.3 million into Metro National Bank of Denver to meet minimum Federal standards and to prevent the bank's failure. Mr. Davis, the primary owner of the $77 million bank in Denver's 17th Street financial district, made the contribution to Metro's capital just after the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation held an auction for the bank in which the F.D.I.C. tried to find a buyer for it. The infusion of capital brings the bank's capital-to-assets ratio to 7 percent, the minimum required by regulations, and increased Mr. Davis's contributions to Metro to $32 million, a spokesman said.

title: Argentines Resisting Plan to Aid Economy
description: When President Raul Alfonsin showed up for the rain-drenched opening earlier this month of the Argentine Rural Society's annual farm and livestock show, he was greeted by booing, hissing and banners that called him a liar.

title: Golf; Inkster Triumphs After Trailing by 10
description: Juli Inkster, who was 10 shots behind Beth Daniel with 14 holes to go today, charged back with a string of four consecutive birdies and a six-under-par 65 to force a playoff at the Sands Country Club. Then Inkster tapped in a 2-foot par putt after a tricky downhill chip to beat a tired and fading Daniel on the first hole to win the third Atlantic City Classic.

title: Susannah Rabb and David Bailin Wed
description: Susannah Lynette Rabb, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Rabb of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to David Bailin, a son of Jerome Bailin of Paramus, N.J., and the late Elaine Bailin. Rabbi Arthur Hertzberg performed the ceremony at the Princeton Jewish Center.

title: A Renaissance For Ethnic Papers
description: For the first time since the 1920's, the tide of immigration is at flood stage in New York City, with millions of Asian, Caribbean and European newcomers in search of a better life.

title: Stacy Ballen, Lawyer, Wed to Mitchell Stier
description: The marriage of Stacy Lynne Ballen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard L. Ballen of Clifton, N.J., and Hilton Head Island, S.C., to Mitchell Jay Stier, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Stier of Alexandria, Va., took place yesterday on the yacht Princess of New York in the Hudson River off Manhattan. Rabbi Harvey Goldman, assisted by Cantor Marc Biddelman, performed the ceremony.

title: Mexico to Raise Oil Prices
description: The Government oil monopoly, Petroleos Mexicanos, or Pemex, will raise its prices for crude oil exports to customers in the Western Hemisphere on Sept. 1, but the prices will not change for exports to Europe.

title: NON-WESTERN WORKS DOMINATE FILM ARRAY AT NEW YORK FESTIVAL
description: Asian and Eastern European films will occupy a prominent place at the 26th New York Film Festival, opening Sept. 23 at Lincoln Center, and movies from China, South Korea, Portugal and Rumania will be shown at the annual event for the first time.

title: Basketball; Ex-Redmen Unite In Winning Cause
description: Some of the great St. John's teams from the recent past held a reunion of sorts at the Felt Forum yesterday, and the collection of players won a ball game and had a grand old time.

title: Horse Racing; Rivalry Is on Hold After Travers Duel
description: Forty Niner and Seeking the Gold are developing as close and consistent a rivalry as racing has ever seen, but the 3-year-old sons of Mr. Prospector now seem likely to head separate ways for a while.

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * Spain may have to raise its inflation target of 3 percent for the year, after an unexpectedly sharp rise in the consumer price index. The index rose 1.3 percent in July, which puts inflation so far this year at 2.9 percent. That compared with monthly rises of four-tenths of 1 percent in June and 1 percent in July last year. ''This will make it difficult to meet the target,'' said Pedro Perez, the Economy Secretary, adding that the Government may revise its target upward in September. Inflation was 4.6 percent last year.

title: Business and the Law; Questions Raised In Insurance Fight
description: WHEN the Chubb Corporation began offering rain insurance two years ago to help farmers hedge against drought, it never imagined that the insurance would produce a costly legal battle. But now that Chubb, saying its agent badly oversold the rain insurance, has refused to issue the policies to 6,200 farmers, lawsuits are piling up.

title: Robert S. Potter, Ex-Lawyer, Is Dead at 68
description: Robert S. Potter, a lawyer, died of cancer Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 68 years old.

title: On Your Own; A TRIATHLON FOR NOVICES AND EXPERTS
description: TO the average recreational athlete, the mere mention of a triathlon might conjure up images of men and women on a near fanatical mission, trying to push their bodies through endless miles of pain and anguish in the waters and roadways of Hawaii.

title: Olympic Notebook; VERSATILE ATHLETE WON'T BACK DOWN
description: The United States Olympic Committee has set Sept. 2 as its target date for resolving all issues of Olympic team eligibility, but at least one case is likely to continue beyond that date.

title: Ellen Dolgins Is the Bride Of Jeffery A. Bosch on L.I.
description: Ellen Dolgins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Dolgins of Neponsit, Queens, and Jeffery A. Bosch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Bosch of Wading River, L.I., were married yesterday at the Harrison Conference Center in Glen Cove, L.I. Cantor David Benedict officiated.

title: Army Hot Line Gives Soldiers a Chance to Be Spy Catchers
description: A flier put out by the Army warns military personnel to keep an eye out for suspicious actions, to listen for foreign accents and to beware of ''James Bond'' characters. Report them, the flier instructs. CALL SPY. The flier, a promotion for a counterespionage toll-free telephone number, is distributed to Army personnel nationwide by the Army Intelligence and Security Command. In the year since it was created, the hot line has received more than 20,000 calls.

title: Bridge
description: The Australian Inter-State Championships, an event with no American equivalent, came to a surprising end here Friday night. New South Wales, which has long been dominant, seemed likely to sweep the board but wound up in second place in all three events.

title: Girl, 3, Dies as a Fire Sweeps Her Home in Rochdale Village
description: A 3-year-old girl was killed last night when a fire swept through the bedroom of her home in Rochdale Village, Queens, the police said.

title: NEW CAST IN CITY OPERA'S 'BOHEME'
description: All the principal roles except Schaunard changed hands at the New York City Opera's ''Boheme'' on Saturday afternoon, and the new team gave an honest, unpretentious, basically effective performance of the opera: a performance in which one could feel afresh the admiration and affection that is due this perfectly constructed work.

title: U.S. and Pakistan Begin Investigating Crash Wreckage
description: Pakistani and American teams began detailed examinations this weekend of the wreckage of the aircraft in which President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq was killed on Wednesday along with the United States Ambassador to Pakistan and 28 others.

title: MOST SOCIAL CLUBS RUN THE GAMUT OF ILLEGALITY
description: LEAD: The Bronx social club where seven people were killed in a fire yesterday was one of hundreds of illegal clubs throughout New York City where building, fire and liquor laws are nearly always ignored and where danger is nearly always present, authorities say.

title: Soviet Rocket Falls in Canada
description: The body of a non-nuclear Soviet rocket crashed early today in northeastern Canada after lighting up the sky from New Mexico to Michigan as it fell from orbit, the Defense Department said.

title: A 'Fortress Europe' in 1992?
description: The date now set for the economic unification of the 12 countries in the European Community is 1992. Not since Napoleon's quest to unite Europe has anything so ambitious been attempted. Today, of course, it is not artillery but the force of logic -that Europe cannot compete with Japan and the United States without a radical restructuring - which dictates the dismantling of cumbersome barriers to the internal movement of goods, capital, people and services.

title: Birnin Kudu Journal; For Women in Politics, the Microphone Is Dead
description: The topic was women, but, as is often the case in Nigeria's traditional, Islamic north, the speakers here were men.

title: Pakistan After Zia; Washington Regrets Death of a Solid Ally But Holds Out Hope for Democratic Change
description: Beneath the official expressions of praise for President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan after his death last week, American policy makers are quietly expressing the hope that the deaths of General Zia and many of his top military aides will bring a new opportunity to move Pakistan toward democracy.

title: PHINNEY SCORES A MAJOR HOME VICTORY
description: A boyhood dream came true for Davis Phinney today when he won the 14th edition of the Coors International Bicycle Classic here in his hometown. A crowd estimated at 30,000 roared with delight as he claimed third place on the last of the race's 15 stages, crossing the finish line with his arms held high in triumph.

title: Elyse Applebaum Married in Jersey
description: Elyse Sue Applebaum, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald I. Applebaum of Iselin, N.J., and Michael Andrew Newhouse, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Newhouse of New York, were married yesterday in Harbourton, N.J.

title: Soccer; Team From Peru Wins Tournament
description: A crowd of 27,433 turned out to see Sporting Cristal of Peru capture the Marlboro Cup soccer tournament at Giants Stadium this afternoon with a 4-0 victory over Barcelona of Guayaquil, Ecuador. In the consolation game, Benfica of Portugal defeated Nacional of Medellin, Colombia, 3-2.

title: Parcells to Cut Down Giants
description: Some coaches describe roster cuts as one of their more unpleasant duties. After a dreadful performance by the Giants' special teams unit Saturday night against the Pittsburgh Steelers, Coach Bill Parcells may find one or two decisions are easy.

title: On Your Own; Put a Light In Your Putter
description: Finding time to squeeze a game of golf into a busy schedule can be difficult. To stretch the hours available to you, a lighted putter will be on the market in a few months, for players who want to keep up to par in the dark. The Pick Point Sports Company, based in Mirror Lake, N.H., plans to introduce the Nitelite putter in January to complement its line of illuminated golf balls.

title: Review/Theater; 'King John,' a Cautionary Tale Of Undercutting and Overreaching
description: ''King John'' is so seldom seen and so little beloved that one may wonder why the New York Shakespeare Festival is bothering to stage it now at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park. There's one obvious reason, of course: Joseph Papp has vowed to produce every work in the canon in his Shakespeare Marathon. Why not dispose of ''King John'' when the moon is full, the tickets are free and there's at least a sporting chance that an audience might show up? It would be folly to squander ''Othello'' or ''As You Like It'' or any other hot Shakespeare ticket on the dog nights of August.

title: Baseball; Red Sox' Hurst Stops Angels
description: Bruce Hurst won his sixth consecutive decision since coming off the disabled list and improved to 11-1 at home this season as the Boston Red Sox defeat the California Angels, 6-2, tonight.

title: Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: Research Industries Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EDBERG SLIPS, BUT LENDL STILL RANKS NO. 1
description: It could only happen on the tennis computer. After moving up to second in the rankings after winning Wimbledon and almost overtaking Ivan Lendl for the No. 1 spot, Stefan Edberg of Sweden has dropped back to third, behind Mats Wilander and Lendl, who is still holding on to the top spot after almost four years. Now, it is Wilander who can become the new No. 1 player at the United States Open if he outplays Lendl.

title: Waxman Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $666,000 from the early repayment of debt. c-Includes an extraordinary loss of $1,590,000. d-Net loss Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in July, and a 2-for-1 stock split paid in January 1987.

title: Training Gifted Young Dancers In Ballet Theater's Special Look
description: ''I want a long, soft arm line,'' Jurgen Schneider called to his seven ballet students. ''Feel that nice, long, elegantly placed hand and the grouping of your fingers.''

title: Six in Florida Indicted on Charges Of Training Anti-Nicaragua Force
description: In a second such case in six weeks, a Federal prosecutor announced today that six men had been indicted on charges of recruiting, training and arming mercenaries to fight the Government of Nicaragua.

title: Indepth Data Inc reports earnings for
description: The company is a developement stage firm.

title: Horizon Healthcare reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $30,000 and $393,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes a loss from discontinued operations of $133,000. The company said the comparable year-ago figures not applicable; the company went public on May 7, 1987.

title: Police Raided Club Where 6 Died in Blaze
description: Over the last four years and as recently as last month, New York City police officers repeatedly raided a Bronx social club, where six people died in a fire on Sunday, but lacked the legal clout to force its permanent shutdown, a police official said yesterday.

title: Sports People; Reason to Play
description: Mike Schmidt, who is on the 15-day disabled list with bursitis in his right shoulder, has a clause in his contract that states he must be available to the Philadelphia Phillies for 130 games. The third baseman, who has played in 108 games, is scheduled to be activated Aug. 28 if he is no longer troubled by pain while batting.

title: Bridge
description: Guidelines are useful, but they are no substitute for careful thought. West learned this the hard way on the diagramed deal from the Imp Pairs Championship at the recent Summer Nationals in Salt Lake City.

title: Employers Act to Stop Family Violence
description: Moving cautiously into a new area of corporate responsibility, a growing number of companies have begun to treat family violence as a sickness undermining the health and performance of their employees.

title: Linear Instruments Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $37,937 for the quarter and $57,387 for the 9 months.

title: Thomas C. Simons, 59; A Financial Executive
description: Thomas C. Simons, an insurance and financial executive who was chairman of the Capital Holding Corporation, died of cancer of the esophagus on Wednesday in Louisville, Ky., where he lived. He was 59 years old.

title: Cool Again: The Double-Breasted Suit
description: The V-shaped man in the double-breasted suit is back, adding stylish swagger to hot city streets and tailored cool to corporate offices. The newer silhouettes, with their swooping lapels, broadened shoulders and extra chest, project masculinity, athleticism and aggressiveness. They also bespeak a cavalier attitude toward the heat.

title: Godfather's Team Forms Own Agency
description: After winning the Pillsbury's Godfather's Pizza account, Tom DeCerchio, a 28-year-old copywriter, and Bryan Buckley, an art director/copywriter who is 24, have opened their own agency, Buckley/DeCerchio. The charter account adds up to $6 million.

title: DUKAKIS, ANGERED, DEFENDS WAR ROLE
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis today rebuked a Republican Congressman who suggested that the Governor had avoided service in the Korean War.

title: Soviet Award System Altered To End Brezhnev-Era Abuses
description: The Soviet system of conferring awards and decorations has been changed to end the devaluation of state honors under Leonid I. Brezhnev, the official press agency Tass reported today.

title: Our Towns; Finding a Sense Of McMission In McNuggets
description: At first, Irv Klein hired a few retarded adults to work at his 13 McDonald's as a do-gooder thing. But soon he realized that the retarded handled Lot and Lobby, Happy Meals and Salad Bar beautifully and that they didn't go quitting on him in a few months, as teen-agers did.

title: Furor Over Bay Burial of Dredged Material
description: The Army Corps of Engineers is exploring a plan to use underwater pits near the shores of Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island and Monmouth County, N.J., to bury dredged material that does not meet Federal ocean dumping standards, and the plan has created a furor.

title: Profitt's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said some earnings disruption was caused by its May 31 acquisition of the department store assets of Lovemans of Chattanooga.

title: Secret of Finding Volunteer Work May Just Be to Think Small
description: To the Editor:

title: School Redistricting Is at Issue
description: Two prominent state lawmakers warned the New York City Board of Education yesterday that it would have to redraw the district lines of the 32 community school boards.

title: Burma's Protest Spreads To Professional Classes
description: Protesters in Burma mounted the largest demonstrations today since a widespread uprising two weeks ago, as opposition to the Government appeared to grow bolder and more broadly based.

title: College Corner Journal; Singular Loyalty for Divided School
description: In 1893, the residents of this and the neighboring town built a school and saw to it that everything, even the building itself, was divided. The eastern half of the College Corner Union School was in Ohio; the western half was in Indiana.

title: Autopsy Is Scheduled For Slain Palau Leader
description: Guam's chief medical examiner was flying today to Palau to assist in an autopsy to determine whether President Lazarus Salii of Palau killed himself, as investigators are said to suspect, or if he was the island republic's second president to be assassinated.

title: Gen. Lewis A. Mologne, 56, Hospital Chief
description: Maj. Gen. Lewis A. Mologne, commander of the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, died yesterday of cancer at the center. He was 56 years old and lived in Washington.

title: YANKEES BATTERED BY ATHLETICS, 9-2
description: From the first batter on, Charles Hudson said, he had no idea where his pitches were headed. And they wound up just about everywhere - in the left field corner, in Carney Lansford's midsection, rarely anywhere near the strike zone.

title: Irish Distillers Rejects British Bid
description: Irish Distillers Group P.L.C., makers of Ireland's leading whiskies, said it had rejected a takeover bid from Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the big British hotel group. Distillers's chairman, Joe McCabe, said the offer by GC & C Brands Ltd., a group acting for Grand Met, valuing Distillers at 250 million Irish pounds, or $350 million, did not reflect the true worth of the company.

title: GOVERNOR IS ASKED TO STOP EXECUTION
description: The Louisiana Pardon Board tonight recommended that the death sentence of a New Orleans man convicted of a 1977 killing be commuted to life in prison.

title: New Pakistani Hopes and Old Fears
description: The political air of Pakistan is suddenly full of hope and challenge.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Boeing Co., Seattle, said it had received $31.9 million in Air Force contracts for survivable power systems, the Minuteman missile system, and the B-52H bomber.

title: KEY RATES
How Pigeons Navigate
description: The view that homing piegons can use the magnetic field of the Earth to find their way has been challenged by experiments involving 659 birds set free in 35 releases. Some had magnets attached, to counteract the Earth's magnetism, and they did just as well as those without magnets.

title: By Design; Head Wraps
description: During the dog days of August the only reason for donning a head scarf is to keep a clear brow and a cool nape. Come the crisp days of autumn, though, this accessory will take on a much more elegant function.

title: Ray Eames, 72, a Founder of Firm That Designed the Eames Chair
description: Ray Eames, who as a partner in the design firm The Office of Charles and Ray Eames exerted a powerful influence on furniture and industrial design over the last 40 years, died of cancer on Sunday at Cedars-Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles. She was 72 years old.

title: Jacobson Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: The company said results for the latest 6-month reflect a difficult retail environment, with continued softness in consumer spending and increased pressure on expenses and operating margins.

title: Loan Auction at Continental
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation will try a new approach - a public auction - to sell more than $75 million in problem loans it acquired in its 1984 bailout of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, officials said today.

title: His Bold Statement Transforms the Debate On Greenhouse Effect
description: SITTING in his office near the Columbia University campus, seven floors above the internal combustion of fossil fuel along Broadway, James E. Hansen held a large pair of what he called loaded dice. He was making a point last week about the probabilities of drastic climate change as a result of the greenhouse effect.

title: Deliberations Begin In Firebombing Case
description: A Queens jury began deliberating yesterday in the case of a teen-ager and an older man charged with firebombing the house of a South Jamaica man who complained to the police about drug-dealing in front of his house.

title: Sports People; Rutgers Star Out
description: Robert Speidel, the Rutgers linebacker who is facing criminal and university charges stemming from his role in an alcohol-related car accident in May, withdrew from training camp yesterday. If he is convicted, Speidel could face a sentence of up to 30 years in prison and a $100,000 fine and expulsion from Rutgers. He said he would be out until after he meets with the dean of Cook College, a part of the university. No date has yet been set for the meeting.

title: Chriss Gittens, Actor, 86
description: Chriss Gittens, who performed for 35 years in the British Broadcasting Corporation's long-running radio serial ''The Archers,'' died Sunday. He was 86 years old.

title: P.&G. Brazil Deal
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said it had agreed to buy a controlling interest in Perfumeria Phebo S.A., a Brazilian cleaning and personal-care products company, for about $70 million. While P.&G. has extensive dealings in Latin America, the purchase would mark its first asset ownership in Brazil, the company said. P.& G has plants or offices in Mexico, Peru, Venezuela, Chile and Colombia. Phebo, which is expected to keep its name, will become a subsidiary of P.&G.'s Latin American division.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Prices Dip as Anticipation Builds
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes sagged in extremely dull trading yesterday as participants reacted defensively in anticipation of a new report on inflation, as well as the sale this week of $25 billion of short- and intermediate-term securities.

title: Pepper Johnson Might Shift
description: With Carl Banks, one of the Giants' key linebackers, still unsigned, all sorts of thoughts have been going through the mind of Coach Bill Parcells.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: National Convenience Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $6,531,000 from an accounting change. c-Net loss

title: Review/Television; The Advertising World
description: Hardly has the last of this year's major political conventions, with their packaging of candidates, cleared the screen than ''CBS Summer Playhouse'' fills the prime-time vacuum with a drama about packagers of another variation, the advertising agencies that bring us all those commercials.

title: Books of The Times; A Romantic Tale of the New World
description: The Bride of the Wilderness By Charles McCarry. 438 pages. New American Library. $18.95.

title: Castle Energy reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,039,406 from the settlement of debt.

title: Review/Music; Celebrating Cage in All His Variety
description: John Cage's 76th birthday is only two weeks away, on Sept. 5, but his disciples are intent on prolonging the celebration of his 75th up to the last moment. Through July and August, the Museum of Modern Art has been offering works by Mr. Cage at its free Friday and Saturday evening Summergarden concerts, and Lincoln Center joined the party on Saturday with two free concerts in its Out-of-Doors series.

title: Bacardi Imports Picks Black-Oriented Firms
description: Bacardi Imports, a marketer and distributer of wines and spirits, including Bacardi rum, has decided to expand its minority market advertising by tapping Jamison & Leary and FraserSmith to handle its black-oriented consumer advertising and promotion campaigns. In April, Bacardi had awarded its Hispanic marketing to Castor Spanish International Advertising.

title: Review/Music; Melvin Gibbs's Urban Sound
description: ''Farrakhan's Dream - Kahane's Nightmare,'' which opened the Melvin Gibbs and Friends second set at the Knitting Factory on Thursday night, explained what Mr. Gibbs, the bassist and composer, is all about.

title: Young Inmates Form Airborne Firefighter Force
description: It was the dawning of Day 3 for the thousand-acre wildfire burning in the rocky northern ridges of the San Jacinto Mountains.

title: Computer Simulations
description: AS you have probably noticed, people have been getting increasingly stupid since 1947.

title: BRE Properties Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes net gains on sales of investments of $3,637,000 for the quarter and $4,989,000 for the year.

title: Italians Will Push Irving Bid
description: After a ruling by the Federal Reserve Board that was believed to have set back Banca Commerciale Italiana's bid for the Irving Bank Corporation, the Italian Government agency that controls the bank said yesterday that it would ''provide all the information requested'' by the Fed.

title: Laurel Savings Associations reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $38,000 and $44,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Officials in Jersey City Are Criticized by Kean
description: Governor Kean strongly criticized Jersey City school officials today for retaining a top-flight New York law firm to fight the state's bid to take over the troubled district.

title: Off-Season Crop for Seed Corn
description: Fearing a shortage of the seeds farmers will need to plant next year's corn crop, the nation's seed producers are scrambling to plant new fields of seed corn in the Southern United States and in South America.

title: Apple Computer Alters Its Corporate Structure
description: Apple Computer Inc. announced a sweeping corporate reorganization today that splits the company into four autonomous divisions and eliminates the position of chief operating officer.

title: Jerome Zerbe, 85, Photographer Of Cafe Society and a Columnist
description: Jerome B. Zerbe, a chronicler and photographer of international society, died Friday at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan after a long illness. He was 85 years old.

title: Japanese Are Seeking A Dialogue
description: COMMUNICATIONS - with an added emphasis on human quality - is keeping three Japanese companies busy this summer.

title: West Bank Arab Dies After Clash With Army
description: A 22-year-old Palestinian died today of gunshot wounds sustained in clashes with Israeli soldiers in the occupied West Bank on Sunday night. Four others were wounded in the incident, Palestinians said.

title: POLAND DECLARES EMERGENCY RULES TO QUELL STRIKES
description: The Polish Government moved tonight to curb a wave of labor turmoil that has shaken the country for seven days, imposing special security measures on three regions where strikes are under way.

title: Max & Erma's Restaurants Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a pretax gain of $181,000 on the sale of assets.

title: Topics of The Times; Where's the Juice?
description: How much real juice do diluted fruit ''blends,'' ''punches,'' ''ades'' and ''cocktails'' contain? The Food and Drug Administration would allow manufacturers to keep that information secret - and mislead the public.

title: Assembly Expected to Pass an AIDS Bill
description: About 200,000 New York State residents would become eligible for Medicaid, and rules would be established governing physicians' disclosure of AIDS test results, under legislation expected to be passed this week by the State Assembly.

title: Secret of Finding Volunteer Work May Just Be to Think Small
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports People; Surgery for Gaetti
description: Gary Gaetti, the Minnesota Twins' All-Star third baseman, underwent arthroscopic surgery on his left knee yesterday and may miss the rest of the season. Gaetti, who suffered cartilage damage a week ago, was batting .298 with a team-high 26 homers and 76 r.b.i. (AP)

title: How to Choose a Vice President
description: If Senator Bob Dole is right that the incautious choice of Dan Quayle as his running mate is hurting George Bush, at least two vital questions are raised:

title: In the Sierras, the News on Acid Rain Is Mixed
description: LEAD: A TEAM of scientists reported last week that there is both good and bad news for the cold, crystal-clear alpine lakes at high altitudes in California's Sierra Nevada range. Their studies of one typical lake found that despite some ''acid pulses'' that plunged the lake into temporarily acid states, the lake has not suffered permanent damage from acid rain.

title: 'Holy Grail' of Blood Research Is in Sight
description: SCIENTISTS are coming close to isolating one of the most important and elusive groups of cells in the human body, the ultimate source of all blood cells and the immune defense system.

title: Software Group Picks Site
description: A computer software consortium said today that it had chosen Cambridge, Mass., as its home.

title: Blues With a Jazz Touch
description: Silent Partner, the harmonica player Charlie Musselwhite's backup band, wandered out onstage to do the requisite two or three warm-up tunes at Tramps on Friday night. From the first few bars of the opening funk-blues instrumental tune, it was clear that the trio - Andrew (Junior Boy) Jones on guitar, Russell Jackson on bass and Tony Coleman on drums - wasn't about to go through the motions. One of those road-hardened, tough bands that occasionally come through New York, the group showed no mercy with a dance beat.

title: QUAYLE RECEIVES STANDING OVATION
description: Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana took his defense of his Vietnam service record before the national convention of the Veterans of Foreign Wars tonight and received a standing ovation after reiterating his assertion that he received no special treatment in joining the National Guard.

title: Needed in Yonkers: Old-Fashioned Politics
description: LEAD: We were on our first gin and tonic when the Yonkers councilman came on public television. By the time he was finished, we were well into our second. ''A petty ward heeler playing politics with the United States Constitution,'' someone muttered. We all nodded.

title: Blaming the Vincennes' Victims
description: ''I believe the actions of Iran were the proximate cause of this accident and would argue that Iran must bear the principal responsibility for the tragedy.'' So says Admiral Crowe, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, endorsing the Pentagon's report on the shooting down of the Iranian airliner by the U.S.S. Vincennes.

title: Barden Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring charge of about $840,000 from the termination of a foreign distributor for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Secret of Finding Volunteer Work May Just Be to Think Small; To the Editor:
description: My husband had to retire from teaching and has been reading at the Lighthouse for the Blind, which always needs volunteers. I did clerical work for them and some reading, too. He also went through the training program of the Literacy Volunteers.

title: Business and Health; Hospital Ventures: Some Successes
description: MOST hospitals have historically been operated as not-for-profit institutions, but in recent years some have formed subsidiaries and begun new businesses to make money and supply badly needed revenue to the parent. However, braving the marketplace through such diversification, while rewarding for some hospitals, can be disappointing for others venturing onto unfamiliar ground.

title: Results Plus
description: Horse Racing

title: Joseph P. Alduino, 81, Ex-Times Executive
description: Joseph P. Alduino, a former controller of The New York Times, died of pneumonia early Sunday at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston. He was 81 years old and lived in Boston.

title: Two Arrested In Plot to Sell Radios to Iran
description: Two Long Island businessmen were arrested yesterday on charges they conspired to illegally export 500 military radios from the United States to Iran.

title: USA Today's TV Offshoot Is Preparing for Its Debut
description: The Gannett Company is betting $40 million that millions of America's television viewers will tune in to a news program that takes as its inspiration the newspaper USA Today.

title: Beita Journal; Where the Hot Rage of April Is Now Cold Fury
description: Strident anti-Israel graffiti is scrawled across almost every wall in orange paint so bright it looks as if it might glow in the dark.

title: Yellow Pages Project For Southwestern Bell
description: The Southwestern Bell Corporation's Southwestern Bell publishing unit and Donnelley Directory, a unit of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, have formed a partnership to publish Yellow Pages directories in the Baltimore and Washington markets.

title: Wickes Companies reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $22,817,000 and $38,348,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net income and income from discontinued operations of $11,205,000 and $14,179,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; a gain of $19,223,000 and $126,020,000 on disposal of discontinued operations for the same periods, respectively; and extraordinary losses of $21,463,000 and $22,532,000 for the same periods, respectively. The extraordinary losses result primarily from a $20 million charge to cover all costs and liabilities related to certain PVC-backed carpeting. The company this year adopted FASB No. 96, which required reduction of income tax expense for utilization of tax credits rather than classification of such utilizations as an extraordinary item. Prior year amounts have been restated for this new accounting and for operations discontinued in 1987. Applications of FASB No. 96 increased income from continuing operations by $1,986,000, or 4 cents a share, and $4,233,000, or 9 cents a share, for the year-ago quarter and 6 months, respectivley. Income before extraordinary items for the fiscal 1987 second quarter and first half rose by $12,943,000, or 27 cents a share, and $51,374,000, or $1.08, respectively. There was no effect on net income.

title: Integon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After realized investment losses of $413,000 for the quarter and $6,391,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes realized investment gains of $4,891,000 and $8,624,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: MOTHER TO APPEAL 'GLASS CAGE' RULING
description: A mother who won a two-year fight to enroll her AIDS-afflicted daughter in school finds her victory bittersweet and is appealing the ruling.

title: India's Military Joint the Earthquake Rescue Effort
description: A day after a major earthquake struck eastern India and Nepal, Indian Army engineers and Air Force helicopters joined rescue workers today in Bihar state, one of the worst-hit areas.

title: Merger in Apparel
description: The Russell Corporation, a maker of athletic and sports apparel, and Quality Mills Inc., a North Carolina apparel maker, said today that they had reached an agreement under which Russell will acquire Quality. Under the deal Russell will exchange either 1.2 of its shares or $18.30 for each Quality share.

title: I.B.M. and a University Plan Swift File Network
description: The International Business Machines Corporation and Carnegie Mellon University announced plans yesterday to create an experimental nationwide computer network that will permit high-speed transmission of computer files.

title: Suspect Is Arrested In West Islip Slaying
description: A 22-year-old West Islip man was arrested Sunday night and charged with second-degree murder in the stabbing death last week of a 50-year-old West Islip woman during a robbery, the Suffolk County Police said.

title: GANGS IN COLOMBIA FEUD OVER COCAINE
description: Colombia's two largest drug-trafficking rings are turning their guns on each other as part of a battle for control of the cocaine market in New York, Colombian Government officials say.

title: Whodunit (and a Howdidtheydoit?) on Broadway
description: The obvious question - How can a 33-foot-high, eight-ton bronze sculpture disappear from the top of a building near City Hall? - would be easier to answer if it had not happened four decades ago.

title: New Proposals Bolster Search For Life in Space
description: LEAD: DESPITE a recent budgetary disappointment and the skepticism of some public officials, the nation's search for signs of extraterrestrial intelligence is forging ahead.

title: USMX Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Cherokee Group reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
description: The company said as a result of the collection of fire insurance proceeds, the apparel division recognized a gain of $5,075,000 and priority a gain of $262,000. These gains are reflected as other income in the consolidated statement of earnings for the 6-month ended May 28, 1988.

title: New Software Shows Off Mac's Best Features
description: TWO features of the Mac may be responsible for its increasing popularity for both home and business. One is the Mac's graphical user interface, which allows the user to give commands to the computer by pointing at pictures or menu choices and clicking a button, rather than typing in strings of non-English commands; the other, which is related, is the easy-to-use software. Macintosh users, according to surveys, use twice as many programs as their DOS PC counterparts because software is easier to learn and use on the Mac.

title: Ross Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said its estimated tax rate for the latest periods was 24 percent lower than the statutory rate. Fiscal 1987 periods reflect a 39 percent rate, which was offset by an extraordinary $216,000 credit.

title: Steinbrenner Offers a Blast of His Own
description: One day after Don Mattingly's scathing public attack, George Steinbrenner said he was confused. He was not, however, at a loss for words.

title: Sports People; Rooney in Coma
description: Art Rooney Sr., the 87-year-old chairman and founder of the Pittsburgh Steelers, who was hospitalized last week with a stroke, slipped into a coma yesterday. Rooney's condition was downgraded to critical and unstable at Mercy Hospital in Pittsburgh. ''Right now I'm the most pessimistic I've been about the outcome,'' Dr. Theodore Gelet said. ''He's exhibiting evidence of increased pressure on the left side of his brain . . . and he has decreased respiration.''(AP)

title: PHH Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain from discontinued operations of $2,433,000. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $189,000 and a gain from a change in income-tax accounting of $24,973,000.

title: Workers to Assume Control Of a Bankrupt Shipbuilder
description: One of the largest shipbuilding and tugboat companies on the West Coast is scheduled to emerge from two years of bankruptcy proceedings Tuesday under the ownership of its 400 union workers.

title: Anchorage Holds Vote
description: Voters in Anchorage will decide today whether they want the city and an organizing committee to continue its campaign to win the staging rights of the 1994 Winter Olympics.

title: Coal Miners Sue Union Over Wages Lost in Strike
description: A group of miners filed a $1 billion lawsuit Monday against the United Mine Workers and its leadership, contending that they were prevented from recovering wages lost during a 3 1/2-year strike.

title: Seagate Trips, Industry Cringes
description: Traditionally an industry whose profits seem always on a roller-coaster ride, the business of making hard disk drives for computers appears poised for another downturn.

title: Sports People; Johnson Pulls Out
description: Ben Johnson, the world record-holder in the 100-meter dash, has decided on doctor's orders to pull out of the Grand Prix track and field finals in West Berlin on Friday. He will return to Canada to continue his preparations for the Olympic Games. On Sunday, he finished third in an international meet at Cologne, West Germany, to Calvin Smith and Dennis Mitchell of the United States. Last Wednesday, he lost to Carl Lewis.

title: Trans World Music Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: There were 382 stores in operation at July 30, comapred with 231 a year ago.

title: A Correction
description: An editorial, ''The News From Peary,'' on Sept. 7, 1909, acclaimed the discovery of the North Pole after this cable was received from Robert E. Peary: ''I have the Pole.'' The Times asserted that further proof was unnecessary, given Peary's reputation. The editorial also took note of the contested claim of Dr. Frederick A. Cook, who said he reached the Pole in 1908. ''The one thing certain,'' The Times commented, ''is that the North Pole has been discovered by an American explorer.''

title: Shelton Leigh Palmer and Debbie Gold Wed
description: Debbie Sommers Gold, a daughter of Mrs. Ben Sommers of New York and the late Mr. Sommers, was married at the Central Synagogue in New York last evening to Shelton Leigh Palmer, a son of Mr. and Mr. Lon T. Palmer of Huntington, L.I. Rabbis Stanley Davids and Iser Freund, a great-uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: The Talk of Lake George; For Once-Crystalline Tourist Mecca, a Murky Future
description: On his first visit to upstate New York in 1791, Thomas Jefferson wrote, ''Lake George is, without comparison, the most beautiful water I ever saw . . . its waters limpid as crystal.''

title: Researchers Hint at Role For Nerves In Arthritis
description: IN a new approach to treating arthritis, researchers find that they can counter joint damage and inflammation in animals with an experimental drug that blocks nerve hormones. The studies suggest that the nervous system may be just as important as the immune system in causing arthritis damage.

title: America, Too, Has Its Prisoners of Conscience
description: To the Editor:

title: ETZ Lavud Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the figures are adjusted to the rate of exchange of the Israeli Shekel to the U.S. dollar as of June 30, 1988.
