Bishop Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $51,000 and $115,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-After tax credits of $100,000 for the quarter and $220,000 for the 9 months. Latest third quarter includes $2,040,000 in non-recurring costs principally from writedowns of various assets. The company said the non-recurring costs in the latest third quarter were connected with programs designed to put a halt to operating losses and return the company to a more cost-effective posture.

title: Rise Technology reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Careers; Counselors Cite Intricacy Of Problems
description: THE job counseling business in the New York metropolitan area is busy, but not necessarily busier than a year or two ago. Yet counselors say the problems of their clients have become more complex.

title: Driver Beaten After Killing Infant in Park
description: Angry bystanders beat a man who drove across Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx Sunday night and struck and killed a 4-month-old boy, the police and witnesses said yesterday.

title: Ross Stores Inc
description: b-Includes a non-recurring asset valuation charge of $620,744.

title: Collins Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $351,500 and $506,500 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9-month also includes a loss of $2,078,431 from discontinued operations. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $250,847 and $418,436 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and extraordinary gains of $154,000 for the quarter and $340,000 for the 9 months.

title: INSIDE
description: Blood Cell Assembly Line Scientists may be close to isolating stem cells, which are found in bone marrow. These cells, at left above, go through a series of steps that give rise to all other kinds of blood cells.

title: Banker's Note Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Net loss The company attributed the improved results to consistent inventory planning and control combined with operating expense reductions implemented early this year.

title: Particle Accelerator Hindered by Defects
description: THE Stanford Linear Collider, a shoestring particle accelerator built to steal a scientific march on a costly European counterpart, has bogged down in a plethora of minor defects exacerbated by a protracted heat wave.

title: Sailing Craft Technology Will Win Cup Match
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Gordon Pollock, Oral Pathologist, 91
description: Dr. Gordon Pollock, an early advocate of prophylactic dentistry and a founder of the New York Institute of Clinical Oral Pathology, died of a heart attack Saturday at the Norwalk Hospital in Connecticut. He was 91 years old and lived in New Canaan.

title: Washington Talk: Government Officials; Psychiatric Treatment And a Need for Secrecy
description: In Washington the nexus between power and stress creates a portion of the clientele for many psychiatrists, psychologists and mental health professionals. Their caseloads include members of Congress and senior officials in the Reagan Administration.

title: South Africa Cracks Down on Anti-Draft Group
description: The Government restricted an anti-draft organization today, under nationwide emergency laws.

title: Lobbyists Spent Over $63 Million in '87
description: Led by a group advocating a strong Social Security system, lobbyists spent more than $63.62 million trying to influence Congress in 1987.

title: American Business Computrs Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Topics of The Times; Bad Timing for Police Pensions
description: Billions in paper values disappeared from the New York Stock Exchange last Oct. 19, causing severe hardship for some investors - and small disappointment for future pensioners of New York City's transit and housing police forces. Now the transit and housing cops are trying to ease that disappointment, unfairly.

title: New Orleans Facing Deficit Kept Secret for Convention
description: Mayor Sidney Barthelemy disclosed today that the city faced a $19 million budget deficit this year and said officials kept the deficit secret to avoid negative publicity during last week's Republican National Convention.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Leaders in Texas Deal Bring New Credibility
description: LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board's decision last week to sell 12 insolvent savings institutions in Texas to an investor group brings new leadership to a segment of the state's troubled industry.

title: Sports of the Times; Walter Weiss in the Stadium
description: WHEN he was growing up in Suffern, N.Y., Walter Weiss dreamed of playing for the Yankees. To indulge him, Walter's parents sent him to a baseball camp in Florida - a nice way to spend the February break, play outdoors, get some exercise.

title: IMO Delaval To Buy Varo
description: IMO Delaval Inc. said today that it had agreed to buy Varo Inc., a maker of police and military night vision systems, for $113 million in cash, topping an offer from Britain's United Scientific Holdings P.L.C.

title: Article 196788 -- No Title
description: Maxicare Health Plans Inc., the nation's largest for-profit health maintenance organization, today reported a second-quarter loss of $59.5 million, nearly $10 million more than it had predicted two weeks ago.

title: I.R.A. Shifts Tactics, and the Results Are Deadly
description: In a message to its members last year, the Irish Republican Army identified the crucial ingredients needed to sustain its long-running guerrilla war against the British in Northern Ireland. ''Morale is the vital key to our success,'' the statement declared, ''and the key to high morale is successful operations.''

title: Patterns
description: Fashion Shows on Video

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MARKETS The dollar surged higher against the mark and other European currencies, but the rise was curtailed by coordinated dollar selling by the Federal Reserve, the Bundesbank and eight other central banks. Though the intervention was broader than last week's, traders said the effects of the move might wear off quickly. The prevailing view among traders is that the dollar will climb, helped by attractive U.S. interest rates. [ Page A1. ] Program trading may not be so pervasive as some investors had feared, a detailed report from the New York Stock Exchange indicated. Traders said the amount of such computerized trading -only 10 percent of the overall volume on the Big Board last month -appeared to be off sharply from last spring. But they said it could still jolt the market. [ A1. ] Stock prices continued their pattern of listlessness, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 25.78 points. That brought the Dow to 1,990.22, its lowest closing level since May 27. [ D1. ] Prices of Treasury bonds and notes sagged in dull trading as participants reacted defensively in anticipation of a new report on inflation, as well as the sale this week of $25 billion of short- and intermediate-term securities. [ D12. ] Prices of soybean, corn and oat futures plummeted their permitted daily limits on the Chicago Board of Trade in reaction to rainfall in Iowa and slack foreign demand for American grain and soybean products. Wheat futures also closed sharply lower. [ D13. ] COMPANIES An Italian Government agency said it would comply with a Federal Reserve request for information in connection with Banca Commerciale Italiana's takeover bid for Irving Bank. The Fed said on Friday that the Istituto per la Ricostruzione Industriale was considered a bank holding company and would be required to file a formal application. Some banking experts questioned whether Istituto would be willing to meet the Fed's requirements. It was not clear from the Istituto statement whether it was prepared to comply with all the Fed's stipulations. [ D1. ] A Seattle shipbuilding company will emerge from bankruptcy under a new name, Unimar, and the ownership of its 400 union workers. It is believed to be the largest union-led and employee-owned company on the Pacific Coast. [ D1. ] Shares of Wickes jumped sharply on the first day of trading since a management group announced plans to buy the company. Wickes stock rose $3.875, to $13.125, surpassing the $12-a-share offer announced on Sunday. [ D2. ] Apple Computer announced a sweeping reorganization that splits the company into four autonomous divisions and eliminates the position of chief operating officer. [ D4. ] I.B.M. and Carnegie Mellon will create an experimental network that will permit high-speed transmission of computer files. Its designers believe the system has the potential to alter the way office work is done because it will let people use interconnected computers at widely separated sites. [ D4. ] A management group will buy Lear Siegler's auto-interior unit for $500 million, with financing from Kidder, Peabody. [ D3. ] Alltel will buy CP National in an exchange of stock valued at about $300 million. Alltel is the nation's 13th-largest telephone system; CP National has interests in communications, energy and air traffic control equipment. [ D3. ] Pfizer will buy the 80 percent of Oral Research, the maker of Plax, that it does not already own. [ D3. ] IMO Delaval agreed to buy Varo, a maker of police and military night-vision systems, for $113 million in cash, topping an offer from Britain's United Scientific Holdings. [ D3. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS For-profit ventures by nonprofit hospitals have had mixed results. Business and Health. [ D2. ] Some retail optical companies remain attractive takeover candidates, analysts say. Market Place. [ D6. ]

title: Officials Predict September Shuttle Launching
description: The space shuttle Discovery should be ready for launching the last week of September, space agency officials and the astronauts said today, citing successful propulsion tests and the repair of a steering-rocket leak.

title: Geneva Talks on Cyprus Due
description: The Turkish Cypriot leader, Rauf Denktash, and the Greek Cypriot President, George Vassiliou, arrived in Geneva today for United Nations-mediated talks. They said they hoped their divided island could be united in a federal republic.

title: Jeans Creator Is Held Over Threat to Judge
description: The creator of the bankrupt Sasson jeans empire surrendered yesterday and was ordered held without bail for violating an agreement that had freed him while he awaited trial on a charge he threatened a judge's life.

title: P.L.O. HARD-LINERS STEP UP THREATS
description: As the Palestine Liberation Organization leadership charts a new strategy, Syrian-backed dissidents say they will resort to political and military means to block any concessions to Israel.

title: New Steps Take Aim At Rare, Fatal Reaction To General Anesthesia
description: IT was a key moment in the history of modern anesthesia.

title: Goldsmith/Jeffrey Wins El Al Account
description: Goldsmith/Jeffrey, an agency begun a little more than a year ago, has been awarded the El Al Israel Airlines account. The budget is $1 million, bringing the agency's billings to more than $15 million.

title: American Woodmark Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a credit of $560,000 from an accounting change.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Savings Bank F.S.B., White Plains, named Diane F. Sherry senior vice president.

title: METS AND GOODEN DO AN ABOUT-FACE
description: Can the Mets snap out of their two-month swoon and turn it on? Well, they turned it on tonight, and Dwight Gooden's right shoulder even passed the big test with flourishes.

title: Reopening an Old Wound; Quayle's Guard Duty in Vietnam War Era Puts the Focus Again on
description: This was supposed to be the election in which the postwar baby boom came into its own in American politics. It's been a rough coming-out party. Last year, Democratic candidates struggled with personal issues that arose out of the counterculture of the 1960's - sexual behavior and drugs.

title: Review/Jazz; Williams And Hinton As a Duo
description: The pianist James Williams and the bassist Milt Hinton started their first set at Zinno on Thursday night with the standard ''Autumn Leaves.'' Mr. Hinton, one of jazz's great bassists, slid into his notes, alternating between a bouncing two-four strut and a burly, flowing walk. Mr. Williams, who at 38 is almost 30 years younger than Mr. Hinton, placed logical, skipping lines over Mr. Hinton's beat. He'd open a chorus with a new motif, and Mr. Hinton would catch the motif's rhythms and fit them into his bass lines.

title: Winn-Dixie Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: There were 53 weeks in the latest year, compared to 52 weeks in the prior year.

title: Fall in Computerized Trading Indicated on Stock Exchange
description: The first detailed report on program trading on the New York Stock Exchange, released yesterday, showed that the computerized trades might not be so pervasive as some investors had feared.

title: Johnson Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Tiny Snail Is Credited as a Force Shaping the Coast
description: TO a surprising extent, the rock-bound New England coast may be the work of a relatively recent interloper from Europe. The interloper, a dime-sized brown snail called the periwinkle, was introduced in Nova Scotia almost 150 years ago, and, according to researchers, it has been working its way south ever since, slowly turning muddy marsh areas into cobbled beaches.

title: Cherokee Rejects $13-a-Share Offer
description: The Cherokee Group said it had rejected a $13-a-share, $161 million buyout offer from an investor group, calling it inadequate. However, the women's clothing and shoe company said it expects the group, which includes Cherokee's No. 2 executive, Robert Margolis, to revise its bid again this week.

title: Chess
description: The Schweizersche Kreditanstalt International Tournament in Biel, Switzerland, ended on July 29 in a tie for first place between the Yugoslav champion, Ivan Sokolov, and Boris Gulko, grandmaster-in-residence at Harvard University. Each scored 7-4 in the 12-player round-robin competition.

title: To Complete the Look
description: The horizontally striped shirt is a strange animal. It's a shirt maker's shirt, unusual to the eye and unforgiving to the wearer. Unlike the ubiquitous vertical-stripe variety, which makes a man look thinner, the horizontally striped shirt makes him look broader.

title: Harvey of St. John's Ineligible
description: The Redmen of St. John's, whose 17-12 record last basketball season was largely fashioned through the speedy and agile backcourt performances of Michael Porter and Greg (Boo) Harvey, announced yesterday that Harvey had been declared academically ineligible for the fall semester. He will miss at least seven games at the beginning of the season.

title: Profit Tripled By Bond Corp.
description: The Bond Corporation reported today that its profit in the fiscal year ended June 30 more than tripled, mainly because of sharply higher beer sales.

title: OWNER'S CHOICE OF WORDS
description: Following is the text of a statement by George Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the Yankees:

title: U.S.-Australia Airline Pact
description: After two and a half years of negotiations, the Governments of Australia and the United States have agreed to expand airline service between the two countries.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Tuning Out
description: Widespread ownership of television sets changed the way Americans followed national political conventions. Now, burgeoning ownership of video recording machines may encourage them to avoid the political process altogether.

title: Reviews/Music; A Haydn Marathon at Mostly Mozart
description: The Haydn Marathon at Mostly Mozart Sunday afternoon and evening was a curious affair, not without its distinct rewards, but not convincing as a way of getting to the point of Haydn's music. From 2 P.M. to sometime after 10, pianists, singers and chamber ensembles offered up this and that from the great man's inexhaustible catalogue. This listener, like most of the audience, came and went for shorter stretches; Haydn's music is economical, and excess of any kind is foreign to it, so it seemed better to make a selection than to immerse oneself.

title: Plant Genetics reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sports People; Coe May Get Chance
description: Sebastian Coe, who has set 12 world records during his international running career, may participate in the Olympic Games at Seoul, South Korea, next month even though he didn't qualify for Britain's Olympic track and field team earlier this month. Coe, who has won the 1,500-meter run in each of the last two Olympics, ran fourth in a British trials heat for that event two weeks ago and failed to make the final.

title: Some Say Politics Tints How Quayle Is Recalled
description: Interviews about the college career of Senator Dan Quayle have become this town's biggest export, but people on both sides of the town-gown line say that local politics may have colored the memories about a DePauw University student who was by most accounts entirely unmemorable.

title: For Each School Year, 60 Days of Nagging
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance; Stepping Loudly In a Mix of Movements
description: Alfred Desio brought his unusual Zapped Taps style to the Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors Festival on Sunday night at Damrosch Park, but his guests nearly stole the show from the Los Angeles-based dancer.

title: 17 Prison Guards Suspended
description: Seventeen Trenton State Prison guards were suspended with pay after refusing to submit to urine tests for drug use, Corrections Department officials said today. And another officer was suspended after he was accused of selling cocaine on the street. The actions are part of a wider investigation into drug activity among the prison's guards, said a department spokesman, James Stabile.

title: In the Marion Prison
description: MARION, Ill.

title: Fujitsu D-RAM's
description: Fujitsu Ltd. said it would become the first Japanese company to produce one-megabit dynamic random access memory microchips, known as D-RAM's, in the United States. The company said that its Fujitsu Microelectronics subsidiary would upgrade a plant now under construction in Gresham, Ore. Fujitsu said its strategy stems from an unexpected shortage of D-RAM's, a key electronics component. Last year, Fujitsu tried to buy Schlumberger Ltd.'s Fairchild Semiconductor unit, a major chip supplier to the United States military. But the Federal Government opposed that move.

title: Market Place; More Takeovers Of Optical Chains
description: ALTHOUGH the retail optical business has expanded a bit too fast in a few cases, several analysts expect some publicly held companies to remain attractive takeover candidates because of the aging of the nation's population and favorable regulatory developments.

title: Batus Extends Bid for Farmers
description: Batus Inc. said it had extended until Wednesday its sweetened $72-a-share, $5 billion offer for Farmers Group Inc. as merger talks continued, although no details about the talks have been disclosed. The conditional offer from Batus, the American arm of B.A.T. Industries, was to expire last Friday and revert to the previous $63-a-share level unless Farmers agreed to a friendly deal.

title: He Helped Christians To Understand Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: For Poland, Hard Lessons
description: From the coalfields of Silesia to the shipyards of Gdansk, Polish workers are once again on strike, demanding not only pay increases but renewed recognition of the banned Solidarity union.

title: Judge Issues 2 Bench Warrants To Jail Kenmore Hotel Operators
description: Two operators of the Kenmore Hotel, one of the largest remaining single-room-occupancy residences in New York City, were sentenced yesterday in Manhattan Civil Court to from 15 to 20 days in jail for refusing to correct violations and make repairs.

title: First Federal of Alabama reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company went public in December 1986.

title: Alltel in Stock Deal To Buy CP National
description: The Alltel Corporation, the nation's 13th-largest telephone system, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the CP National Corporation in an exchange of stock valued at about $300 million.

title: Secret of Finding Volunteer Work May Just Be to Think Small
description: To the Editor:

title: PARLAYS AND PICK-SEVEN ARE BAD BETS
description: The computers that run the betting machines at New York's racetracks and offtrack betting parlors can be programmed to accept wagers on virtually any proposition: the first four finishers, the next eight winners, the third-place finishers in the odd-numbered races.

title: Buyout Set For Lear's Seating Unit
description: A management group financed by Kidder, Peabody & Company agreed today to acquire the Lear Siegler Holdings Corporation's auto-interior unit for $500 million in cash, the largest leveraged buyout in the auto parts industry.

title: Dollar Climbs, but Rise Is Curbed By Intervention of Central Banks
description: The dollar surged higher against the West German mark and other European currencies yesterday, but the rise was curtailed by a coordinated dollar-selling effort by the Federal Reserve, the Bundesbank and eight other central banks.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It was a rumbling sound that seemed evil, demonic.'' - Ishrar Jha of Patna, India, describing Sunday's earthquake. [ A3:3. ]

title: BUSH OVERTAKES DUKAKIS IN A POLL
description: Vice President Bush overtook Michael S. Dukakis in popularity after the Republican National Convention even though many voters are skeptical of his running mate, Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana, according a CBS News Poll.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Abbey to Cathedral
description: The Washington Cathedral, the great Gothic edifice towering above the northwest quadrant of the District of Columbia, was constructed to fulfill the intention of the city's original planners to have ''a great church for national purposes.'' Insofar as the institution, also known as the National Cathedral, functions unofficially - and ecumenically - as the nation's church in the capital of a secular republic, it is appropriate perhaps that it will play host next month to the choir of Westminster Abbey, the site of every English coronation since 1066.

title: Amateurs Build Small Satellites
description: AMATEUR radio enthusiasts in the United States and Brazil are building four small communications satellites, which they expect to launch next year from a European Space Agency Ariane rocket.

title: Jets' Crable to Miss '88 Season at Least
description: The Jets have learned that Bob Crable, their veteran inside linebacker, is lost for the season. Exploratory surgery today determined that he will require extensive reconstructive surgery on cartilage and ligaments in his right knee, and his career could be in jeopardy.

title: Lowe's Companies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a $5,226,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why do men have nipples? A. The presence of nipples and other breast tissue in men ''exemplifies the fact that the basic body plan of men and women is similar,'' according to Dr. Bruce McEwen, an expert on sex hormones. ''There are exaggerations in each sex based on early development and later hormonal influence,'' he said.

title: Wickes Shares Jump On News of Buyout Plan
description: Shares of the Wickes Companies jumped sharply yesterday, the first day of trading after investors led by a management group and Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. announced plans to buy the company.

title: Lund Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Washington Talk: Briefing; Happy Birthday
description: Popular lore has made the ''hot line'' famous as a red phone in the Oval Office, used in dire emergencies when the President of the United States wants to bend the ear of the General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union. In fact, the system uses written, not voice messages. In any case, next Tuesday marks the 25th year for the system, which was put into operation with a test message on Aug. 30, 1963.

title: Ending Years of Stalemate, Eritrean Rebels Drive Ethiopians Into Retreat
description: For a decade, this was the headquarters for Ethiopian Army forces battling Eritrean rebels in the world's longest guerrilla war. Now, after a string of rebel victories in these bleak, stony mountains, it is a rear area for the Eritrean People's Liberation Front, and the officers' barracks and perimeter foxholes are deserted.

title: International Terrorism Is Up 7%, Report Says
description: The number of international terrorist incidents increased 7 percent last year, to 832, mainly because of bombings in Pakistan by agents of the Afghan intelligence service, the State Department reported today.

title: Worlco Deal Hits Snag
description: Worlco Data Systems said today that the Maxwell Communication Corporation refused to complete its acquisition of Worlco. Maxwell had agreed to pay $3 a share for Worlco.

title: Sex Roles Reign Powerful as Ever In the Emotions
description: DESPITE two decades of assaults on sexual stereotypes, new research shows that when it comes to emotional life, men and women seem as bound as ever by traditional sex roles.

title: Burundi Reports 5,000 Are Dead In Resurgence of Ethnic Warfare
description: The Burundi Government said today that at least 5,000 people had been killed last week in ethnic clashes between the majority tribe and the minority group that rules the small Central African nation.

title: Newest of the Yorks Gets Name: Beatrice
description: The two-week-old daughter of the Duke and Duchess of York has been named Beatrice Elizabeth Mary, Buckingham Palace said today.

title: At 'The Hole,' Patrons First Had to Be Frisked
description: It was a dimly lighted place to go when the licensed bars had closed for the night, a place to have a few beers or a few ''blows'' of cocaine, a place like dozens of others dotting the working-class neighborhood in the Morris Heights section of the Bronx.

title: Commericial Intertech Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Proud to Run With Quayle, Bush Says
description: Vice President Bush today gave an impassioned defense of Dan Quayle before fellow war veterans, telling them he was proud to have the Indiana Senator as his running mate.

title: Swiss Merger Bid For Essex Blocked
description: A Federal appeals court upheld a lower court ruling that blocked Swiss-based Gurit-Heberlein A.G.'s takeover offer for the Essex Chemical Corporation. The decision was a setback to Gurit's bid to acquire Essex - its partner for 20 years in a joint venture to sell adhesives to the auto industry - through a stock tender offer.

title: Soviet Newspaper Rejects Notion Of Moscow Role in Death of Zia
description: The Communist Party newspaper Pravda today heatedly denied Western speculation that Afghanistan and the Soviet Union may have had a hand in the plane explosion that killed President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan and 29 others.

title: New York Area Hears Rumbling of Drug War
description: In recent weeks the upper reaches of New York's multibillion-dollar cocaine industry appear to have gone through some tumultuous changes, including the arrival of the first massive shipments of cocaine from Colombia's Medellin traffickers, the authorities say.

title: Albertson's Inc reports earnings for 13wks to July 28
Triad America Accord Seen
description: The Saudi billionaire Adnan Khashoggi has agreed to pay up to $35 million to the Triad America Corporation, his troubled United States holding company, under a tentative settlement reached by attorneys and trustees, a newspaper reported.

title: Fire in Amtrak Engine
description: Amtrak service was back to normal today after service between New York and Washington was blocked for four hours by a fire Sunday night in the locomotive of a passenger train heading for Washington from New York, officials said.

title: Panel of Bishops Will Study Reports of Miracles in Texas
description: A panel of bishops will be appointed to study the reports of miracles at a charismatic church, the Roman Catholic bishop of Lubbock has announced.

title: Hopper Soliday Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company converted from a closed-end fund to an operating corporation last Dec. 31.

title: With Roots in State and in Past, Guard Has Many Missions
description: The National Guard, a militia with roots deep in American history, often found itself in the middle of the turmoil that shook the nation in the 1960's.

title: Bush's Baby-Boom Crap Shoot
description: LEAD: ''Laissez le bon temps rouler.''

title: Imperial Holly reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Fiscal 1988 results do not include the results of Holly Sugar Corp., which was merged into Imperial Holly Corp. in April 1988.

title: Imre Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Smith Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $8,000 and $123,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $8,000 and $205,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: One Small Step Toward Ending U.S. Debt
description: After more than four years of legal wrangling, the state and Federal governments have reached an agreement for disposing of the money that Minnie Vogel left to reduce the national debt when she died in 1984.

title: Chemical Banking
description: The Chemical Banking Corporation, formerly the Chemical New York Corporation, is offering $100 million of 9 1/2 percent notes due in 1991 at a price of 99.87 to yield 9.55 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. For purposes of investment, the four-year notes are noncallable and yield about 67-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. Underwriters said the issue was rated Baa-1 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's.

title: For the Pub Crawler, More Time to Crawl
description: The bitter and the stout flowed unabated today, even after Big Ben chimed 3 o'clock, as drinkers toasted the new laws that went into effect permitting pubs to stay open through the day.

title: Koreas Break Off Talks With Both Sides in a Huff
description: Talks between North and South Korea broke off today with no agreement and no word when they might resume.

title: Crews Fighting The West's Fires Are Reinforced
description: Temperatures fell, the wind died down and the Army arrived yesterday, improving conditions for the weary crews battling forest fires that have charred thousands of acres of Montana and Wyoming, especially in Yellowstone National Park.

title: Bass in Talks On Macmillan
description: The Robert M. Bass Group disclosed yesterday that it had met with Macmillan Inc. to explore alternatives to Macmillan's restructuring plan.

title: Buehler International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

New Chief at Chevron Sees Greater Expansion
description: In electing Kenneth T. Derr chairman and chief executive, the Chevron Corporation promoted a vice chairman known for moving rapidly: in his swift management of Chevron's merger with the Gulf Oil Corporation, and in his own climb up the corporate ladder.

title: 6 Men Attack 2 After Making Anti-Homosexual Comments
description: Six men attacked two others with knives and a baseball bat last night on Manhattan's Upper West Side after harassing the two men with anti-homosexual comments, the police said.

title: Oil Rig Count Declines
description: The number of rigs exploring for oil and natural gas in the United States slipped to 937 this week from 940, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. A year ago the rig count was 1,012.

title: Dow Reaches Lowest Level Since May
description: The prices of stocks continued a pattern of Monday listlessness yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average fell 25.78 points in exceptionally slow trading. The drop brought the blue-chip index to 1,990.22, its lowest closing level since May 27.

description: Isabelle (Izzy) Grossman's grandmother lives a life steeped in old-world Jewish culture on the Lower East Side of New York. Her parents live, as the grandmother describes it, ''in Florida with Red Buttons'' (in a retirement community there).

title: Taylor Files Report
description: Lawrence Taylor, the Giants linebacker, has filed a traffic report with the police in Morristown, N.J., recounting the events that prompted him to dent the door of a truck after a traffic incident last week.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Time-Life Assignment For Fallon McElligott
description: Time-Life Books, Alexandria, Va., has assigned Fallon McElligott, Minneapolis, to handle seven titles in its Time-Life library. The seven-figure budget will cover the Epic of Flight; Time Frame, a history of the world; the Kodak Library of Photography; Gardener's Guide; Vietnam Video; World War II Video, and Victory at Sea Video. Along with developing campaigns, the agency will buy and place media.

title: Park Employee Dies in Roller-Coaster Fall
description: A 26-year-old maintenance worker at the Astroland Amusement Park in Coney Island plunged to his death yesterday during a lunchtime ride on the Cyclone roller coaster.

title: Interco Files Suit On Takeover Bid
description: Interco Inc. has filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court here accusing groups led by Steven and Mitchell Rales of Washington of violating securities laws in their $2.7 billion bid for the retail company. The lawsuit, filed against the Cardinal Acquisition Corporation and City Capital Associates L.P., contends that the $70-a-share offer involves so much debt and so little equity that it would, if consummated, violate Federal margin regulations.

title: Real Estate; West Jersey Commercial Site Planned
description: FOR much of the last decade, commercial space developers in New Jersey have been pushing westward and building mainly to accommodate the growth of New Jersey-based companies and the desire of New York companies for cheaper alternatives to high Manhattan rent.

title: P.L.O. Says It Will Pay Salaries in West Bank
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization said today that it was assuming responsibility for paying civil servants in the West Bank whose salaries were cut off when Jordan broke ties with the Israeli-occupied territory last month.

title: Cuba Data Curbs Ended
description: Restrictions on importing and exporting books, films, phonograph records and other informational material to and from Cuba are eliminated by the trade bill signed into law yesterday by President Reagan. The ban also applied to newspapers, posters, photographs, microfilms, microfiche and tapes.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Travel-Guide Competition To Increase
description: THE competition in the field of travel-guide magazines, the periodicals that contain precise listings of all flights, will soon heat up with a new monthly for frequent fliers, called the ABC International Executive Flight Planner. ABC International, its publisher, plans for it to compete head-to-head with Dun & Bradstreet's Official Airline Guide and its supplementary publication, Frequent Flyer.

description: Thomas B. Doyle, the head of traffic control at the New York City Department of Transportation, was named yesterday to run the Emergency Medical Service, which has been the subject of widespread criticism.

description: The Supreme Court has begun exploring the possibility of using computers to make its opinions instantly available to a wide audience.

title: Ex-Aides Assail Depiction of Johnson as Paranoid
description: Charges by a former White House aide that Lyndon B. Johnson displayed paranoid and irrational behavior as President have provoked criticism and hostility from several other officials who served in the Johnson Administration.

title: U.S. to Provide $565 Million In California Savings Bailout
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that it would provide $565 million in financial assistance to an investor group that intends to merge two California savings institutions.

description: American universities have established a beachhead across the Canadian border, opening branches in Canadian towns and cities and enrolling Canadian students.

title: Nursing-Home Payments Faulted as Too Selective
description: A New York State system that pays nursing homes more to accept the most seriously ill patients has excluded thousands of others with major health-care needs, industry officials and advocates for the aged say.

title: Back to the N.B.A.
description: Bill Musselman, whose extensive resume includes a Big Ten Conference championship and more than 100 N.C.A.A. rules violations at the University of Minnesota in the 1970's, was named yesterday as the first head coach of the Minnesota Timberwolves, a National Basketball Association expansion franchise that will begin play in the 1989-90 season. In an earlier N.B.A. coaching job, Musselman led the Cleveland Cavaliers to a 27-67 record during parts of two seasons from 1980-82. Musselman spent the last four seasons in the Continental Basketball Association, where he won a championship each year, with three different teams. During his time at Minnesota, Musselman won 69 games and lost 32 in four seasons. But his championship season, 1971-72, was marred by a brawl during a game against Ohio State after which two Gophers, Corky Taylor and Ron Behagen, were suspended for the rest of the season. After Musselman left, the Gophers were put on probation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association for three years when the rules violations were discovered.

title: Overeater's Penalty: That Sleepy Feeling
description: THE link between fatigue and overindulgence in food and alcohol has been confirmed many times throughout the ages.

title: Rallying for a Woman
description: After a year of imprisonment for contempt of court, Dr. Elizabeth Morgan, a plastic surgeon who defied judicial authorities by hiding her daughter from her former husband, alleging he had sexually abused their child, is becoming a rallying point for advocates of women's rights.

title: Koch Orders Agencies to Prepare Budget Cuts
description: Spurned by both Albany and the City Council in his requests for tax increases to hire more police officers to fight drugs, Mayor Koch yesterday ordered nearly all city agencies to prepare to trim 1.5 percent from their current budgets as a way to finance his $110 million anti-drug plan.

title: Dibrell Brothers Inc reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said the year-ago figures included substantial restructuring costs and a writedown of assets, as well as delays in tobacco shipments from Brazilian operations. The company also said its fiscal 1988 performance was credited to increased profitability of its tobacco operations and the inclusion of Florimex, the flower trading unit acquired in 1987.

title: Anchor Savings Offering Notes
description: The Anchor Savings Bank is offering $100 million of 9 3/4 percent collateralized notes, due in 1993, at a price of 99.98 to yield 9.755 percent, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley.

title: First Sea Water Battery
description: The Norwegian state oil company, Statoil, said today that it had discovered a way to provide power on the ocean floor without using miles of expensive cable. The company said it would install the world's first commercial sea water battery in a project connected with an oilfield development off central Norway. The battery uses sea water as the electrolyte and absorbs oxygen in the same way that fish do. The 24-volt battery will be used to power a ''reference station,'' a fixed point on the seabed for navigation and oil exploration.

title: Bank of Montreal Yield at 10.166%
description: The Bank of Montreal is offering $150 million of 10 percent subordinated notes, due in 1998, at a price of 99.28 to yield 10.166 percent, through underwriters led by the Union Bank of Switzerland.

Krasney, had resigned to prevent any conflict that could arise because of the seat he holds on the board of Revco D.S., which is a major American Greetings retail account. Revco filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on July 28.

title: Robots to Make Fast Food Chains Still Faster
description: Restaurant industry experts are predicting that the fast food business will undergo a technological revolution in the next few years that will place increasing numbers of robots and other labor-saving devices in the kitchens. The machines will flip hamburgers, bag french fries, spread pizza dough, fry chicken, bake biscuits, stuff burritos and deliver drive-in orders to cars in about half the time and at about half the cost that human workers require.

The package approved by Judge Harold White puts trade creditors and bank creditors ahead of all other parties - including unsecured creditors, bondholders and shareholders - to be paid should the company be liquidated.

But something is happening in the world, a movement away from the fist and the gun. It remains true in many places, as Mao Zedong proclaimed, that ''power comes from the barrel of the gun.'' But the notion is also spreading that such power has limited use and sooner or later brings only unsatisfactory results.

title: Review/Television; Gregory Peck: Snippets of 40 Years
description: In the obligatory opening montage of ''Gregory Peck - His Own Man,'' two glimpses of the actor in the 1940's leap out of the jumble of scenes from films as different as ''Roman Holiday,'' ''Moby Dick'' and ''The Omen.'' Here, in ''Gentleman's Agreement'' and ''Spellbound,'' is the young Gregory Peck staring into the camera: dark wavy hair, nearly gaunt cheeks, eyes that threaten to burn through the screen. He was, Lauren Bacall says in an interview here, ''this beautiful creature.''

title: Review/Music; A Haydn Program, All in D Major
description: To Kurt Masur and the Israel Philharmonic fell the privilege of representing Haydn's most popular symphonic work in the Mostly Mozart festival's Haydn Week at Avery Fisher Hall. They played the ''father of the symphony's'' 104th child, by traditional count, and in any case his last, the ''London'' in D Major. The Philharmonic is not the most polished of orchestras and Mr. Masur is no wizard of technical precision, so one had to accept from the outset that this would be a slightly tousled account, but on its own terms it was rousing and quite enjoyable.

description: The Bush campaign backed away yesterday from Vice President Bush's declaration that one of his ''missions'' as President would be to create 30 million new jobs in eight years.

title: British Economy Gains
description: Britain's economy grew at a faster-than-expected 1.3 percent rate in the second quarter from the first quarter, the Government said today. The country's inflation-adjusted gross domestic product, measured by the total output of goods and services, rose 5.1 percent from the second quarter of 1987, the Central Statistics Office said. Output in the manufacturing sector grew 1.6 percent in the latest period, while service sector output grew 1.7 percent, the office said.

title: Quake Leaves Heavy Scars In North India
description: A few hours after an earthquake struck Bihar state on Sunday, Mohammad Abid strung a large, flimsy sheet of green plastic across the courtyard of his ruined home and herded his family under the fragile shelter with their clothes, beds, mattresses, food and cooking pots.

title: In the Market for a Little Greatness

Everybody said so, at least everybody who could get access to a television camera, and after you heard those TV-savvy guys and women announce that George Bush would have to make the greatest speech he had ever made in his life, how could you have the cheek to disagree with them?

description: The controversy grows over Senator Dan Quayle's decision to enlist in the National Guard in 1969, thereby reducing the threat of his exposure to combat in Vietnam.
