title: Tootsie Roll Pact
description: Tootsie Roll Industries said it had agreed to buy the Charms Company, a private candy maker, for $65 million in cash. The proposed transaction is expected to be completed by October, the company said. Charms, based in Colts Neck, N.J., had sales of about $38 million in 1987 and a pretax income of about $3 million.

title: Sutcliffe Explains
description: Rick Sutcliffe said yesterday that reports the Chicago Cubs were thinking about trading him were a misunderstanding. ''It was my agent, Barry Axelrod, who had asked the Cubs about the clause in my contract concerning what eight teams I would not play for, and not the Cubs who made the request,'' Sutcliffe said. He had said earlier he was annoyed that the Cubs had requested a list of the teams he would refuse to play for, and could not understand why General Manager Jim Frey had asked for the list. ''After talking to Barry, we cleared it up,'' Sutcliffe said. ''Sutcliffe is going to pitch for me next year, probably opening day,'' the Cubs' manager, Don Zimmer, said. Sutcliffe gave Frey the list of eight teams, which he refused to name. (AP)

title: Meese Order on Prosecutors Is Reviewed by Thornburgh
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh expressed strong reservations today about an order signed by his predecessor, Edwin Meese 3d, to appoint special prosecutors whenever members of Congress face serious allegations of wrongdoing.

title: ROBERTSON DRAWS A REBUKE ON FILM
description: A leader of a major Jewish organization has reproached Pat Robertson for his reluctance to condemn anti-Semitic statements made by critics of the movie ''The Last Temptation of Christ.''

title: Kirk Douglas And Anger
description: Here he is, Kirk Douglas, 71 years old now, his dimpled chin still very much intact, sitting in a friend's East Side apartment. The star of ''Champion,'' ''Lust for Life,'' ''Spartacus,'' ''Lonely Are the Brave,'' ''Paths of Glory'' and many other films. The actor the French nicknamed la Brute Cherie (the Darling Brute). The man who played a key role in breaking the Hollywood blacklist by putting Dalton Trumbo's name on the ''Spartacus'' script. The father of four successful sons, all financially secure, one a two-time Oscar winner.

title: Big Board Chief Sees Shift in Tokyo
description: The chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, John J. Phelan Jr., came to the only stock market bigger than his own today and pronounced the Tokyo market open to foreign firms, after years of struggle.

title: Hans G. Adler, 78; Survived Nazis
description: Hans Gunther Adler, a scholar and German-language author who wrote about his experiences in Nazi concentration camps, died of heart failure Sunday at the Mead Bank Nursing Home in Battersea, England, his son, Jeremy, said. He was 78 years old. Mr. Adler won the Leo Baeck Prize, a major Jewish award, in 1958 for his first major work, ''Theresienstadt 1941-45.''

title: Emons Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $62,413 and $366,025 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss d-Includes a gain from extinguishment of debt of $1,485,839 for the quarter and a loss of $2,050,176 on the reorganization for the year, and tax credits of $33,616 and $35,714 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: With Army Restrained, Burma Unrest Grows
description: Anti-Government demonstrations in Burma reportedly grew larger today as the military, which killed hundreds of protesters earlier this month, maintained a newly passive presence in the streets.

title: Beyond Yonkers: Cracking Gilded Ghettos
description: LEAD: There is a joke they tell in the crowded luncheonettes around the Yonkers City Hall:

title: Deere & Company reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Lynchburg, Tenn.
description: LEAD: THIS time of year the zinnias that grace the tables at Miss Mary Bobo's Boarding House come straight from the backyard. So do the tomatoes, okra, squash, corn, eggplant, peppers and greens.

title: New Dome Atop Cityspire Seen as Violating an Accord
description: The new dome atop Cityspire, the mid-Manhattan skyscraper that is 11 feet taller than permitted, was assembled in apparent violation of an agreement between New York City and the developer, who has been ordered to cease further construction at the summit of the 72-story tower.

title: Crescott Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $380,000 and $212,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss and after gains from discontinued operations of $381,000 for the quarter and $1,019,000 for the 6 months. The company said the latest quarter and first half include gains of $1,643,000 and $1,746,000 respectively, on the sale of marketable securities resulting substantially from the sale of Crescott's common stock holdings in William Carter Co. The latest quarter and first half also include results for three Ohio vending businesses acquired in the fourth quarter of 1987.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Exotic Staples on Sale

title: An Italian Keeps Designers Stepping
description: QUESTION: What do the designers Azzedine Alaia, Geoffrey Beene, Romeo Gigli and Gianfranco Ferre have in common?

title: Sangatte Journal
description: ''When the engineers from the two sides meet in the middle of the Channel, under these waters bloodied by so much combat, the cordial handshake they will exchange will do more than all the diplomatic instruments to seal a sincere alliance between the two peoples,'' exulted Sebastien Krantz, a member of the French Parliament.

title: Just One Under Par In the Metropolitan
description: Although the rough is short and the greens are huge, only one player, Tom Joyce of Glen Oaks, was able to break par in the first round of the Metropolitan Open at historic Baltusrol Golf club today.

title: Radiation Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Fiscal 1988 net reflects a favorable $1,247,000 adjustment for income taxes due to the decrease in the federal income tax rate. Backlog was $54,239,000 as of June 30, 1988, compared to $30,540,000 a year earlier.

title: Little Prince Productions Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Littlefield, Adams & Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $27,000 for the quarter and $106,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $223,000 and $442,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Marchers in the Baltic republics of the Soviet Union demonstrated in the three capitals to mark the anniversary of the 1939 Nazi-Soviet pact that led to the Soviet takeover of the region. Page A1

title: TRW Receives Contracts
description: TRW Inc. said it had been tentatively awarded $508 million in contracts by NASA to develop an orbiting X-ray astrophysics observatory.

title: Twins Master Tigers Again
description: Kent Hrbek's second homer of the game, a two-run shot in the 10th inning tonight, lifted the Minnesota Twins over Detroit, 7-5, for their 10th straight victory against the Tigers.

title: Mets Getting Back On Winning Track
description: The Mets, who still deny that they can ''turn it on,'' turned it on again tonight and beat the Los Angeles Dodgers for the second straight game, 5-1.

title: KEY RATES
Crable Philosophic About His Surgery
description: Bob Crable showed up in the Jets' locker room today, and for a man who was facing career-threatening knee surgery, the linebacker was fairly upbeat.

title: U.S. Shifts Troops' Homes in Panama
description: The United States is moving families of servicemen to safer locations in Panama or back to the United States, Administration officials said today.

title: Tennis; Top-Seeded Schapers Loses
description: Seventeen-year-old Pete Samprass of La Quinta, Calif., who turned pro last February, upset top-seeded Michiel Schapers of the Netherlands, 7-5, 7-6, today in the first round of the Nynex Tennis Classic.

title: Quayle Calls Allegation On Sex 'a Lot of Trash'
description: Senator Dan Quayle, trying to fight off the latest problem encountered in his week-old campaign for the Vice Presidency, today angrily denied allegations that he made a sexual advance to a Washington lobbyist in a 1980 golfing vacation in Florida with two other Congressmen.

title: SPI-Suspension & Parts Industries Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income backlog at June 30, $35.9 million versus $43 million a year earlier. The company said production costs in the latest periods have been significantly higher than planned for some products because of technical production problems.

title: The Era of the Edible Blossom: Innovation and Rediscovery
description: FLOWERS and herbs have contributed culinary color to meals, both regal and lowly, for centuries. But today lilacs, mimosa, roses, spearmint and violets - candied, swirled into syrup, infused in cordials or otherwise preserved - are reappearing in innovative cuisine. Flowers like squash blossoms and nasturtiums are part of the decorative-edible larder, too, and fresh herbs are playing an ever larger role.

title: Market Place; Basic Industries: A Closer Look
description: FOR some investment professionals, it is back to basics - basic industries, that is. Stocks of companies in such areas as chemicals, steel, paper and forest products are undervalued and offer buying opportunities, thanks to stronger earnings, leaner operations and an improved outlook for exports, these professionals insist.

title: Forfeiture of Profit in Pentagon Fraud Cases Urged
description: Leaders of the House Armed Services Committee called on the Pentagon today to require its suppliers to agree to forfeit profits on any contract that is found to have been won through fraud.

title: Networking Products Introduced by Digital
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation introduced several computer networking products today that the company said would make it easier to transfer data throughout a business.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Ali Haji-Sheikh was cut by the Washington Redskins yesterday, even though he did not miss an extra point or field-goal attempt during the preseason. His job was in jeopardy from the start of training camp because the Redskins' top draft choice was Chip Lohmiller. . . . The New England Patriots said they intend to place the quarterback Tony Eason on the injured reserve list next week, because he has not recovered sufficiently from off-season surgery on his throwing arm. The Patriots waived the veteran place-kicker Tony Franklin. . . . Gary Dunn, a nose tackle for 12 years, was among 10 players cut by the Pittsburgh Steelers, and the move left the team with only three active players who have Super Bowl rings: Mike Webster, Robin Cole and Dwayne Woodruff. The Steelers also cut Gordie Lockbaum, who was their ninth pick in the draft.(AP)

title: Sports of The Times; Kareem: One More Time
description: THE Legos were piled on a table in the suite overlooking Central Park. No, building with plastic blocks is not how Kareem Abdul-Jabbar is spending his summer, but it is how his son, Amir, going on 8, passes his spare time on the road.

title: 2 Men Beaten By 6 Youths Yelling 'Fags'
description: Two men were attacked Monday evening on the Upper West Side of Manhattan by a group of knife- and bat-wielding teen-agers shouting anti-homosexual epithets. Gay rights advocates said it was the latest incident in a trend of increasing violence against people perceived to be homosexual.

title: Trustcompany Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bhutto Says Her Party Could Win Fair Elections in Pakistan
description: Benazir Bhutto, the opposition leader, said today that she and her party could win a fair election if one was held in Pakistan in November.

title: Book Notes
description: PEN's Larger Purpose

title: Oh, Ma, Let Me Join the National Guard
description: LEAD: Senator [Quayle], was there a waiting list when you got in the National Guard?

title: Partnership Seeks Wyatt Cafeterias
description: Furr's/Bishop's Cafeterias L.P. said it had offered to acquire the Dallas-based Wyatt Cafeterias Inc. for $87 a share, or $179 million. The bid follows an $84-a-share tender offer proposed three weeks ago by Wyatt Cafeterias' employee stock ownership plan. The earlier offer will be considered at a stockholders meeting on Sept. 6.

title: Sanctions Won't Speed Apartheid's Demise
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Leader of Black Panthers Refuses to Quit San Quentin
description: Huey Newton, the former Black Panther leader, refused to leave prison on his scheduled release date today, demanding that officials also free Elmer Pratt, a former Panther.

title: Fluorocarbon Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a $1,049,000 gain on the sale of a 50 percent interest in a Japanese joint venture.

title: S&K Famous Brands reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $401,400 gain from an accounting change.

title: Whiting Petroleum Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Cigna to Sell Horace Mann for $500 Million
description: The Cigna Corporation agreed today to sell the Horace Mann Companies, a personal insurance company that sells mainly to teachers, for about $500 million in cash to a group led by the leveraged buyout firm Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen Ltd.

title: Intelligent Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''Some people will certainly die much sooner if they can't afford AZT. Are we really going to have people dying because they can't afford access?'' - Mervyn F. Silverman, president of the American Foundation for AIDS Research. [ B10:5. ]

title: U.S. SAID TO WANT NO FURTHER CLIMB IN DOLLAR'S VALUE
description: The Reagan Administration believes that a further rise of the dollar could be troublesome and it prefers a stretch of stability, a senior official indicated today.

title: Olympics; Controversy Over Coe's Status Grows
description: The president of the national governing body for track and field in the United States, Dr. Leroy Walker, yesterday questioned the possibility that Sebastian Coe of Britain would be allowed to participate in the Seoul Olympics as a ''wild-card'' entry.

title: Hard-Hitting Campaign Is Opened by President
description: President Reagan started his post-convention campaigning for the Republican ticket today, accusing Democrats of taking a ''far left'' line on issues ranging from crime to defense, and defending Senator Dan Quayle of Indiana, the Republican candidate for Vice President.

title: Stuarts Department Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a gain of $902,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. Year-ago figures are restated for an accounting change.

title: Fed's View Of Foreigners Now Tougher
description: In deciding to change how it treats foreign governmental entities that seek to acquire banks in the United States, the Federal Reserve Board has turned its back on a strongly worded 1983 memorandum that Paul A. Volcker, then the chairman, sent to Congress.

title: United Education & Software reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Guilford Mills Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $300,000.

title: Restaurant to Produce Its Own Label
description: Turback's, a restaurant in Ithaca, N.Y., that serves only New York wines, expects to become the state's first restaurant to have its own winery and retail shop on the premises.

title: Cocaine Glut Pulls New York Market Into Drug Rings' Tug-of-War
description: Experts believe that the war between the world's two largest cocaine-trafficking organizations over the New York market is a result of a worldwide glut of cocaine and a decision by one of the cartels that it can no longer afford to stay out of the nation's most lucrative drug market.

title: U.S. Trying to Deport A War Crimes Suspect
description: Federal authorities have begun deportation proceedings against a Minneapolis man accused of crimes in World War II.

title: Morsemere Financial Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings for 1987 are not available because the company converted to a stock form of ownership in August 1987.

title: Tyson Hurts Right Hand In Scuffle With a Boxer
description: Mike Tyson's Oct. 8 title defense against Frank Bruno was in jeopardy yesterday after the heavyweight champion sustained a hairline fracture of the right hand when he and another heavyweight, Mitch Green, scuffled in an early morning street brawl in Harlem.

title: 5 More Guards Suspended at Jersey Prison
description: Five more guards at Trenton State Prison have refused drug tests, joining 17 other guards suspended for the same reason in a continuing drug investigation at the prison, officials said today.

title: Syncor International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $484,000 and $1,461,000 in the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes a gain from discontinued operations of $179,000 for the quarter and a loss of $730,000 for the year; a gain from disposal from discontinued operations of $26,000 for both periods; and tax credits of $788,000 and $979,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: When Families Go Home Again
description: LEAD: LAST month Marly Thomas arrived for her family's annual reunion in Bibb County, Ala., carrying the freight of history: five scrapbooks of family photographs, including pictures of her husband's grandfather, Papa Thomas, who built a two-story frame house in Bibb in 1897.

title: How Bilzerian Scored at Singer
description: Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida financier, moved into the roomy offices on the 11th floor of the Singer Company's Stamford, Conn., headquarters in February, shortly after winning his first takeover fight.

title: A Leap and Derailing Delay Subway Service
description: Subway service along the IND Eighth Avenue line in Manhattan was suspended for an hour yesterday afternoon, the Transit Authority said, when a man tried to commit suicide on one track and, in an unrelated incident, an empty train derailed on the opposite track 15 minutes later.

title: Los Angeles Journal; At Long Last, Dogs Have Their Day
description: Heaven knows, it's hard to govern Los Angeles. Pressure groups pull every which way: developers, environmentalists, Jews, blacks, homosexuals, Armenians, Koreans, each with a different agenda. And now come the dogs. Why not a park where urban canines can revert to the wild and romp uncurbed, unleashed, unfettered by human rules and regulations? Finally, after years of bitter wrangling and politicking, a park for leashless dogs opened officially in Laurel Canyon on Saturday.

title: Dissidents See Scherer Victory
description: The dissident shareholders of the R. P. Scherer Corporation said today that their candidates would win two contested seats on the board when the offical results are announced on Wednesday. A group organized by Karla

title: Tin Mill Prices Raised
description: Two steel companies announced price increases on tin mill products today. The USX Corporation said it would raise its prices by 9.5 percent. The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said it would raise its prices by 8 percent. Both price increases are scheduled to go into effect on Oct. 1.

title: Paul F. Switz, Consultant, 82
description: Paul F. Switz, an economic development consultant to Puerto Rico, died after suffering a stroke Sunday at Duke University Medical Center in Durham, N.C. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Black Churches: New Mission on Family
description: Dismayed by the disintegration of so many inner-city families, black churches have started many new community programs to reduce teen-age pregnancy, keep children in school, provide adolescent boys with role models and find adoptive homes for black infants.

title: Ethics Office Terms Trip By Mrs. Meese Improper
description: The Office of Government Ethics has determined that it was improper for the wife of former Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to accept a free trip to China last summer as part of her husband's delegation to an international legal conference.

title: Insilco Talks To Another Suitor
description: The Insilco Corporation said it had talked with another potential purchaser of the diversified industrial company. Insilco, which did not name the potential suitor, has received a $29-a-share offer from a management-led group, ISC Holdings Inc. The company said that it continued to provide information to other parties and that it could not assure that a transaction would result from the new talks.

title: Burndy Sale Move
description: The Burndy Corporation said it had asked Goldman, Sachs & Company to explore the possible sale of the company, as well as other alternatives for maximizing shareholder value. The company, which makes electronic products and electrical connectors, said a decision would be made only after the alternatives had been explored. After the announcement, Burndy's stock price jumped $3.125, to $16.50 a share. The 23.3 percent gain was the largest today on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Brown-Forman Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
New York Milk War, Round Two
description: Last year a Federal court finally smashed a milk dealers' cartel, handing consumers an immediate benefit in the form of lower milk prices. But now that victory appears threatened: the dealers' cartel could be replaced by a dairy farmers' cartel.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: BASEBALL Taiwan Team Rallies: Tai Chung, Taiwan, was on the verge yesterday of being the first Far East team to be knocked out of the Little League World Series in the first round since 1970. But Taiwan came back from a 4-0 deficit to defeat Curundu, Panama, 5-4, in Williamsport, Pa. Jui-Cheng Chen, the winning pitcher, reached base on an infield hit with two out in the bottom of the sixth to cap a two-run rally and to drive in the winning run. (AP) GOLF Mondry Leads U.S. Amateur: Josh Mondry of Franklin, Mich., birdied five of the last six holes yesterday on the way to a four-under-par 66 that gave him the lead after the first round at the 88th United States Amateur in Hot Springs, Va. Half of the 291 golfers in the field, including Mondry, were playing on the par-70 Cascades Course at the Homestead. The other half played the mountain resort's par-72 Lower Cascades layout. The low 64 scorers then advance to match play to determine the champion. (AP)

title: Wild-Card Entries
description: The United States Tennis Association announced yesterday that 16 players from this country, eight men and eight women, have been awarded wild-card entries into the singles draws of the United States Open, which will start Monday at the National Tennis Center at Flushing Meadows, Queens. The women are Carrie Cunningham, Elise Burgin, Debbie Graham, Beth Herr, Stacy Martin, Laxmi Poruri, Jennifer Santrock and Shaun Stafford. The men are Scott Davis, Tommy Ho, Ricky Leach, Scott Melville, John Ross, Pete Sampras, Jeff Tarango and Robbie Weiss.

title: Passenger Shoots Cabby in Dispute Over Fare
description: A taxicab driver from Queens was shot early yesterday by a Manhattan bartender in a predawn dispute over a fare, the police said. The bartender tried to flee in another cab but she was arrested two blocks away after the driver of a third cab followed her and called the police.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aritech Corp., Framingham, Mass., said it would reorganize its North American operations into two divisions and consolidate its manufacturing operations at a plant in Hickory, N.C.

title: What's Good for Persian Gulf Is Good for Brazil
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Pop; Wonder's World Of Peace
description: Stevie Wonder is a pop creator whose concerts are more than just musical events. The concentrated power of his musical personality and his integration of a sweeping variety of idioms into an indelible style, along with his charisma and enthusiasm, combine to make his concerts communal celebrations at which divisions of race, class and nationality melt away.

title: Wade C. Stephens, 55, New Jersey Educator
description: Wade Carroll Stephens, the director of studies at the Lawrenceville School, a coeducational New Jersey boarding school, died of a heart attack Sunday while vacationing in Ogunquit, Me. He was 55 years old and lived on the Lawrenceville campus.

title: 2 Convicted in Bombing In Jamaica
description: A Queens man and a teen-ager were convicted yesterday of firebombing the home of a South Jamaica man who had complained to the police about drug-dealing outside his house.

title: Republic Gypsum Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Congressman, Called Too Liberal, Overwhelms a Conservative Rival
description: Representative Mike Synar today defeated a primary challenger who labeled the five-term Democrat too liberal for his largely rural district in northeast Oklahoma.

title: Emergency Rooms Stay Open in Los Angeles
description: State and county health officials announced today what they called a ''financial Band-Aid'' to help 11 inner-city hospitals keep their emergency rooms open for the next two months.

title: Talks on Smoking Bill Break Down in Albany
description: The first face-to-face meeting between the state's health commissioner and key legislators on a bill to establish statewide smoking restrictions ended in an impasse Monday night after participants were unable to resolve questions of how the restrictions would be enforced in many upstate counties.

title: Consumer Prices Up 0.4% in July
description: Fueled by higher food prices caused by the drought, consumer prices edged upward by four-tenths of 1 percent in July, the Labor Department reported today.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Portland, Ore., branch of the Bank of Tokyo Ltd. yesterday began offering $50 million of 9 3/8 percent deposit notes, due in 1991, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley.

title: Mostly Kind Given for Cross
description: To the Editor:

title: Education; Baltimore Mobilizes To Cut Dropout Rate
description: Businesses here have joined City Hall, school officials and neighborhood groups in an effort to improve the quality of potential employees by reducing the high school dropout rate, which is now about 45 percent.

title: Maverick Restaurant Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said latest second quarter earnings were negatively impacted by higher cost of sales, particularly the cost of poultry.

title: As Tension Rises, Solidarity Again Seeks Talks
description: Leaders of the outlawed Solidarity labor union appealed for talks with the Government again today, a day after a range of emergency measures were instituted to halt a wave of labor disruptions.

title: Tasters' Choices: Using Blooms and Where to Buy Them
description: FOR the most part, flowers and herbs taste the way they smell, so rely on your nose.

title: International Aluminum Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes refunds of $1,220,000, or 27 cents a share, of workers compensation premiums paid in prior years.

title: Jack Sher, 75, Writer And Director of Films
description: Jack Sher, who wrote, directed or produced 32 feature films, died in his sleep yesterday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 75 years old.

title: Memtek Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss Latest quarter share net is less than 1 cent.

title: A Long, Dry Summer Promises Fine Wines
description: THROUGHOUT the Middle West, long hot days devoid of rain have stunted the fields of corn that cover so much of the landscape. But the drought has not been a disaster for all growers in the region. For some wine makers, the unusual weather may result in a better-than-usual product.

title: Will Basic Justice Be Denied Ronald Monroe Unto His Execution?
description: To the Editor:

title: Delta Woodside Industries reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,154,000, or 7 cents a share, on the sale of marketable securities. The company said year-ago fourth quarter and year net is restated.

title: U.S. Notes and Bonds Advance
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved higher in moderate trading yesterday, as participants were relieved by a Government report showing that one important measure of inflation was not moving rapidly upward.

title: Fraud Trial Begins on ZZZZ Best
description: The fraud trial of Barry J. Minkow, the one-time carpet-cleaning ''whiz kid,'' opened in Federal court here today.

title: Handleman Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: Year-ago first quarter includes gains totalling $480,000, or 3 cents a share, including a gain from settlement of a lawsuit.

title: Security Federal Savings reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and share earnings do not include earnings from the year's first quarter since the company made its initial public offering on Nov. 26, 1986.

title: Ames Department Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Economic Scene; The Reagan Era: Gains and Losses
description: HAS Reaganomics left Americans better off than than were eight years ago? George Bush offered a litany of superlatives to the Republican convention last week that was only slightly marred by hyperbole. Inflation is indeed down to 4 percent from 13 percent, and the banks' prime interest rate is now less than half the 21 percent briefly experienced during the credit crunch of 1981.

title: Jail's Robots Tough, but Not Bulletproof
description: Officials of Alameda County, across the bay from San Francisco, are borrowing technology from the computerized factory to help automate a new jail. Robot carts will be used to feed the 3,000 prisoners. The carts, which will be 2 feet wide, 7 feet long and 17 inches high, will be guided by computers and will follow magnetized wires embedded in the roadway. The county has ordered 18 of the 1,200-pound, $80,000 carts to ferry food trays from a kitchen to units that will house several hundred prisoners. After a cart arrives, guards will distribute the food.

title: Education; Colleges' Pet Projects Face a Money Squeeze
description: Tucked into the comprehensive spending bill passed by Congress last December was a provision for a $1.6 million grant for the development of buses powered by fuel cells. The recipient was to be ''the university in the nation's capital which was involved in the feasibility study.''

title: Marinades Prolong the Tastes of Summer
description: LEAD: NOW is the time when kitchens are brimming with baskets filled with the best and most beautiful produce of the year.

title: Why Angelenos' Weekends Are Easier
description: ONE of the distinct differences between the West Coast and the East - specifically between the rival metropolises of Los Angeles and New York City - is the observance of weekends. We vacate differently, especially during these hot months. This was made apparent to me in my first and only year of college in New York, when the locals fled on Friday night leaving behind a city of hot, deserted September streets.

title: Democratic Strategy; Dukakis Plays Down the Quayle Issue As Peripheral to Doubts About Bush
description: To listen to Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic Presidential nominee, you wouldn't think there was much of a controversy about Senator Dan Quayle, the Republican Vice-Presidential choice, and his decision to join the National Guard at the height of the Vietnam War.

title: Automated Systems reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $195,000 from an accounting change.

title: Vega Biotechnologies reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Peru Frees American Woman Imprisoned in Terrorist Raid
description: An American arrested three weeks ago on terrorism charges has been released from jail, the police said today.

title: Dropout Program Is Sought At Elementary School Level
description: New York City will begin shifting some of its dropout-prevention resources from high schools to the elementary grades, the Schools Chancellor, Richard R. Green, said yesterday.

title: Claire's Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Net income and the 6-month includes a $530,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: Koch Plans Task Force To Combat Illegal Clubs
description: Mayor Koch, branding as ''murderers'' the operators of a Bronx social club where six people were killed in a fire last weekend, said yesterday that the New York City Police, Fire and Building Departments would form a task force to crack down on similar illegal clubs around the city.

title: Education; Lessons
description: If computer programming colleges, truck driving academies and other profit-making trade schools did not exist, politicians and journalists would have to invent them.

title: Education; Judge Orders Bankrupt School to Close
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge has ordered Bishop College, a 108-year-old predominantly black school, to close because it failed to come up with the $1.85 million needed to cover its 1988-89 deficit.

title: Review/Theater; Three Plays on Desire
description: The movie-within-the-play in Aaron Sorkin's one-act comedy ''Hidden in This Picture'' deals with a platoon of ''disillusioned marines'' on the island of Guam. But the film is being made on a farm outside of Schenectady. Weeks behind schedule, millions over budget, the director (Nathan Lane) watches calmly as an army of extras moves into action for the last sunset.

title: THOUSANDS MARCH IN BALTIC CAPITALS, AIRING RESENTMENT
description: Tens of thousands of demonstrators, some demanding independence from Moscow, marched through the capitals of the three Baltic republics tonight to mark the anniversary of the 1939 Nazi-Soviet pact that led to the Soviet takeover of their region.

title: Aquanautics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $75,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $3,000 for the quarter and the year includes a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $33,000. The company is in the development stage.

title: The Summer of Our Discontent
description: ''The summer of '88,'' our children will tell their children, ''started like any other summer. A little rain, a little shine, a little warm, a little chill. Then, in early July, something happened.

title: New Consolidated Chief Will Keep Store's Style
description: In a 30-year career with seven different retailers, James M. Guinan has discovered the secret to a successful store is no different for Bloomingdale's than for Pic 'n Save.

title: New Doskocil Bid Urged by Wilson
description: The Wilson Foods Corporation, facing a takeover threat by the Doskocil Companies, said it was willing to discuss the possibility of an improved offer that could lead to a friendly merger.

title: Ending the Rape of Tongass
description: Why does Washington shell out some $50 million annually to chop down towering Sitka spruce trees in an ecologically fragile Alaskan wilderness?

title: Courtnall's a Capital
description: Because an arbitrator ruled that the bylaws and contracts of the National Hockey League are subject only to the interpretation of its president, a 26-year-old forward has become the property of the Washington Capitals. Geoff Courtnall, a left wing who played out his option with the Edmonton Oilers in May and as a free agent signed an offer sheet with the Rangers, went to the Capitals after a ruling by John Ziegler, the league president, who said that a team could trade its right to match an offer for a free agent who was formerly its property. The Oilers had traded their right on Courtnall to Washington in return for Greg Adams, and the Capitals indicated they would retain Courtnall by matching the offer put forward by the Rangers. The Rangers, Courtnall and the N.H.L. Players Association protested to Ziegler that the Oilers should not be able to trade the right. But Ziegler ruled the Oilers had the right and the arbitrator, Joseph Kane, found that the league's bylaws and contracts are subject only to the president's interpretation, and Ziegler's decision stood.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Times Magazine Group To Sell Southern Travel
description: The Southern Progress Corporation in Birmingham, Ala., has agreed to buy Southern Travel magazine from The New York Times Company's Magazine Group for undisclosed terms.

title: Durables Orders Declined 7% in July
description: Orders for ''big ticket'' durable goods, hurt by an expected drop in demand in the volatile transportation sector, fell a sharp 7 percent in July, the biggest setback in four years.

title: Files Show New York Official Cut Tax Sharply for Landlord
description: A New York City official, acting without the full knowledge of his superiors, repeatedly reduced the tax assessments of buildings owned by the city's largest commercial landlord, according to municipal tax records and interviews with city officials.

title: Varlen Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Marketing Systems of Amerca reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addenda
description: * Sassy magazine's circulation has increased 60 percent, to 400,000 from 250,000.

title: Omnicorp Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said its business is seasonal, with the greater portion of activity occuring in the second half of the year.

title: South Africans Lose a Reputation for Invincibility
description: The reputation of the South African Army as an invincible force has been challenged by the war along the Angolan-Namibian border.

title: Jewish Father for Palestinian State?
description: It seems unlikely: A Jewish philosopher, at the University of Maryland, has emerged as the father of a proposal for Palestinians to declare their independence and establish a state in the territories now occupied by Israel.

title: Alien Farm Workers Win Fight Against I.N.S.
description: A Federal judge here has ruled that the Immigration and Naturalization Service has been too restrictive in handling applications for legal status by alien farm workers. Government lawyers said the decision might make it more difficult to keep those who are ineligible from being permanently admitted to the United States.

title: Central Illinois Public Service Co reports earnings for 12mo July 31
Paul Harris Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Net income and in the 6 months includes a gain of $844,000 from an accounting change.

title: Bell Atlantic Names Successor to Its Chief
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation said yesterday that Raymond W. Smith, president and chief operating officer, would succeed Thomas E. Bolger as chief executive when he retires on Dec. 31. Mr. Bolger, 61 years old, will remain chairman for a transition period into 1989, Bell Atlantic said.

title: 23 Hurt in South African Blast
description: At least 23 people were wounded today when a bomb exploded in a fast-food restaurant in the eastern port city of East London.

title: Consumer Prices a Bit Higher
description: Led by higher food prices, consumer prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent in July. Economists said the moderate increase should reduce fears of renewed inflation. Page D1.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Altshiller Reitzfeld Job
description: Altshiller Reitzfeld announced it had been selected as the agency for Sun Resorts' Mullet Bay Resort and Casino and its Caravanserai Hotel properties on the Carribean island of St. Martin. The budget is more than $1 million. The agency will focus on radio ads, which began at the end of July, as well as the sponsorship of cultural radio programs in the fall. It is expecting to run print ads as well.

title: Review/Film; Love, In the Style Of Lelouch
description: The enduring appeal of Claude Lelouch's film ''A Man and a Woman'' is largely due to its aura of head-over-heels love. However problematic the romance and sentimental the story, falling in love seemed spontantous and irresistible, beyond anyone's control. Mr. Lelouch has tried and tried in the 22 years since to recapture that film's easy allure (most blatantly in ''A Man and a Woman: 20 Years Later'') but the job seems to get tougher and tougher. In ''Bandits'' he contrives a story of jewel thieves and fairy-tale love, and only proves that trying too hard is a sure way to kill romance.

title: Mattingly Rescues Yankees in the 9th
description: Tommy John was a loser last night, but the Yankees weren't.

title: Tom Brown Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and share net was less than 1 cent because of preferred dividend requirements.

title: Solidarity Calls For Talks Again
description: Leaders of the outlawed Solidarity labor union appealed again yesterday for talks with the Polish Government, a day after a range of emergency measures were instituted to halt a wave of labor disruptions.

title: Federal Control Urged to Keep Costs Down on AIDS-Related Drugs
description: Two health organizations asked the Government today to require that AIDS-related drugs and vaccines developed with Federal assistance be made readily available to patients at the lowest possible prices.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Many in Public Relations Would Love to Do This
description: Every seasoned public relations man or woman would dearly love to tell all, but few do. Robert J. Wood, former chairman and chief executive of Carl Byoir & Associates (now part of Hill & Knowlton), has unburdened himself in a new book, ''Confessions of a P.R. Man,'' published at $18.95 in hard cover by New American Library. Mr. Wood, who wrote his book with the journalist Max Gunther, is in the nice position of spilling the beans while being out of the line of fire, corporately speaking, since he retired several years ago.

title: Side Dishes Suitable for Center Stage
description: Marinated Green Beans and Yellow Peppers Preparation time: 15 minutes Cooking time: 10 minutes 1 pound green beans 1 large yellow sweet bell pepper 6 tablespoons olive oil 2 tablespoons tarragon vinegar or other white-wine vinegar Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste 1 heaping tablespoon finely minced shallot 1 heaping teaspoon finely chopped chervil or parsley.

title: Rises in Local Costs Trail U.S. Rate
description: Consumer prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area rose four-tenths of 1 percent in July, but price increases so far this year have stayed below the national average for the first time in six years.

title: Bavaro Signs Four-Year Pact
description: Mark Bavaro and the Giants agreed to terms yesterday and the all-Pro tight end joined the team for the afternoon practice at Giants Stadium.

title: More Officers May Be Facing Charges
description: The charges against two police officers accused of using excessive force during the melee in Tompkins Square Park are likely to be followed by others as the Civilian Complaint Review Board investigates the more than 100 complaints it has received, Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday.

title: Personal Health
description: The recent development of a test to determine whether people are destined to develop a devastating, inherited neurological disorder known as Huntington's disease is causing considerable anguish among potential beneficiaries. Many, it seems, simply would prefer not to know whether they will develop the incurable disorder, even though the information may help them plan better for their future.

title: Foreign Policy: No Holy Rite
description: Republicans are arguing these days that Gov.

title: Grand Met Buys Stake in Distiller
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. said it had purchased a 4.5 percent stake in Irish Distillers Group P.L.C. as part of its hostile attempt to acquire Ireland's largest distiller. Grand Met had offered 253 million Irish pounds, or about $354 million, for Irish Distillers late last week, through a subsidiary, GC&C Brands. Irish Distillers' board rejected the offer on Monday.

title: Trade Gap Narrowed By 14.9% in 2d Quarter
description: The nation's trade deficit shrank 14.9 percent in this year's second quarter on a balance-of-payments basis, helped by a record high level of exports and the first quarterly decline in imports in three years.

title: The Hopis Turn Back Indiana Jones
description: The Hopi Indian tribe's religious beliefs have accomplished what giant spiders, ancient booby traps, murder-minded ruffians and supernatural events failed to do - they have halted the movie adventurer Indiana Jones.

title: Enserch Exploration Partners Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago periods are restated to reflect increased revenue and income from the appropriate accounting for a portion of the company's drilling program.

title: MOMENTUM BUILDS TO MAP ALL GENES
description: Scientists from a growing number of countries are joining in the huge effort to decipher the chemical language of all the human genes, scientists said here today.

title: New Bid for Varo By United Scientific
description: Varo Inc., which has agreed to be acquired by IMO Delaval Inc. for $25 a share, or $113 million, said it had received a $26 offer, worth $117.5 million, from United Scientific Holdings P.L.C. of Britain. United Scientific had previously offered $22 a share for Varo, a maker of police and military night-vision systems. Varo, based in Garland, Tex., had rejected an earlier $17.50-a-share offer from United Scientific, and it made no further comment on the new offer.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Columbia Savings and Loan Association, Beverly Hills, Calif., elected as a director John H. Kissick, executive vice president and director of West Coast corporate finance for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: ECC International reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,100,00 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Bank of Montreal (California) reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss and after a $753,000,000 provision for losses on third-world debt for both the quarter and 9 months. Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Montreal Stock Exchange.

title: Ford Sees Strong Sales for 1988-89
description: Executives of the Ford Motor Company said today that the outlook for car and truck sales remained strong despite forecasts by some industry analysts of an imminent slowdown.

title: Erly Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
First Federal Rules Proposed Governing Garbage Landfills
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today proposed the first Federal regulations to help prevent contamination of the environment by municipal garbage landfills.

title: International Trade
description: The Utah Jazz and a professional basketball team in Zaragoza, Spain, would like to make a trade, but an overweight backup center, Mel Turpin, may ruin the delicate details of the swap. The Jazz hopes to send Turpin, a center from the University of Kentucky whose listed weight is 268, to Zaragoza for Jose Ortiz, a 6-foot-10-inch center who was the Jazz's No. 1 draft pick in 1987 and who has three years remaining on his contract with Zaragoza. For that reason, Utah must compensate the Spanish team. Before deciding to send Ortiz to Utah, Zaragoza watched Turpin play on Saturday against a team of junior college players in Salt Lake City. He scored 23 points and grabbed 19 rebounds, but looked considerably heavier than 268 pounds. After the game, Turpin admitted he had not played basketball all summer and was out of shape. David Checketts, the Jazz president and general manager, admitted on Tuesday that the Spanish team has a big concern about Turpin's weight and said he expected to discuss the situation soon with Jose Luis Rubio, the president and part-owner of the Zaragoza team.(AP)

title: Quayle: The Real Issue
description: Try to imagine Dan Quayle as President of the United States.

title: U.S. Criticism Sets Off a Furor in Israel
description: A storm broke out in Israel today over unusually harsh criticism the United States directed at Israel earlier in the week for its policy of expelling Palestinians accused of fomenting the uprising in the occupied territories. Israel formally rejected the criticism today.

title: Democratic Donkeys Up for Sale in Georgia
description: Some special Democrats who showed up at last month's Democratic National Convention are looking for a place to stretch their legs - all four of their legs.

title: Why Single Out China as Mideast Arms Seller?
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Improvement
description: WINDOW and door screens, in addition to permitting ventilation, keep insects from entering the house. Late summer and early fall, when insects seek winter quarters, is a good time to inspect screens for holes and tears.

title: Slow to Arrive, Computers Are Moving Into Patient Care
description: While records of everything from credit card purchases to airline reservations are now stored and organized on computers, doctors in most offices and hospitals are still using pen and paper for a patient's medical information.

title: Big Investors Meet Texaco
description: Representatives of two groups with large positions in Texaco Inc. stock met yesterday with James W. Kinnear, Texaco's chief executive, about ways they could have more say on the company's board.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Some nails are popping out of our walls, especially near the ceiling. A man we consulted told us the paint must be scraped off, and then the nails driven in deeper and the holes covered with perforated tape and cement. Then the walls must be repainted. Is all this necessary? A. Driving the nails deeper won't help them hold any better. You have to drive in an additional nail a few inches above or below the original one, recessing the head slightly. Q. In the basement of our 110-year-old Victorian house are brick columns or piers that support the main floor joists. On several of these columns, the bricks and the mortar near the bottom seem to be deteriorating; the bricks are powdering and turning to dust. What could be causing this? Can it be fixed by fitting a sleeve around the columns and pouring concrete into the sleeve? A. The bricks could be deteriorating from moisture or because they were not formulated to carry the kind of weight and stress to which they have been subjected all these years.

title: Nervous Iraqis Cheer the Cease-Fire
description: A cease-fire with Iran has stilled eight years of war and given rise to forgotten and conflicting passions here: release and joy and a dread that the fledgling peace is yet too frail to hold.

title: Report Faults Justice Dept. on Ethics Policy
description: The Justice Department, unlike other Federal agencies, does not require employees to file confidential financial disclosure reports and has failed to periodically evaluate its ethics program, Congressional investigators said today.

title: Eritrean Rebels Emphasize Women's Rights
description: ''The difficulties started just when I was born,'' Besrate Mengeste said, describing the life of women in traditional society in the Eritrean region of north Ethiopia.

title: Wheeling to Settle
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation said it would settle claims arising from two iron ore ventures that it had undertaken before filing for reorganization under Federal bankruptcy laws. Wheeling will pay the Iron Ore Company of Canada $46 million and will surrender all of its rights and interests in the venture. It will also pay $25.5 million and surrender its rights to the Butler-Itasca mine, which has been shut down. Both agreements are subject to the approval of the bankruptcy court.

title: Spreading Fire Forces Evacuation Of Big Yellowstone Development
description: A fire that has charred a 35-mile swath across the heart of Yellowstone National Park forced hundreds of visitors out and was threatening one of the park's most picturesque areas, officials said today.

title: Race Barred in Placing a Child
description: A Federal judge has ordered the city of Philadelphia to return a black child to his white foster parents. He said deciding the child's placement on nonracial grounds would encourage treatment of people as individuals.

title: A Year Later, a Saner Market
description: Last summer was a golden age for Wall Street. The Dow Jones industrial average was at 2,700, and there was widespread belief it was headed for 3,000. Some even predicted 3,300.

title: Minnesota Dean Hired By Conference Board
description: The Conference Board yesterday named Preston Townley, who has been dean of the Carlson School of Management at the University of Minnesota since 1984, as its new president.

title: Accounts
description: * Gillette Co., Boston, to Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson, Boston, for Myoko, a new line of 10 products currently being test-marketed in Boston.

title: Reviews/Music; Songs and Chants of Latino Pride
description: Joseph Papp walked out on stage at the Delacorte Theater on Monday night and addressed the mostly Latin crowd in Spanish, then introduced diplomatic delegates from various countries. The words Cuba and Nicaragua sparked standing ovations, the audience chanted ''No pasaran,'' and the musical program of Mr. Papp's 12th annual Festival Latino was on.

title: Calendar: Crafts and Hand Paper Making
description: From Heart and Hand: Fordham University Plaza at Lincoln Center, Columbus Avenue at 62d Street, 212-677-4627.

description: b-Includes an unusual LIFO reserve charge of $501,000.

title: Humphery Keeping Rookie on Bench
description: After all the energy, cash and expertise that went into making Terry Williams their second draft pick, the Jets will start a converted ninth-round wide receiver at the critical left cornerback position.

title: Ciccarelli Cited for Assault
description: Saying that professional athletes are not above the law, a judge sentenced Dino Ciccarelli of the Minnesota North Stars to one day in jail and fined him $1,000 today for hitting another National Hockey League player with his stick.

title: AM Communications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Leonard Frey, Actor, Dies at 49; Was in 'Fiddler' and Other Films
description: Leonard Frey, an actor admired for his vivid and often flamboyant performances, died of AIDS yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. He was 49 years old.

title: Review/Concert; Drama of Haydn's 'Nelson' Mass
description: As part of its all-Haydn week, the Mostly Mozart festival presented a particularly grand, expansive Haydn program Tuesday night at Avery Fisher Hall, repeated last night. The music consisted of the Symphony No. 91 in E flat, the Cello Concerto in C (Hob.VIIb:1) and the ''Missa in Augustiis'' in D minor, better known as the ''Lord Nelson'' Mass.

description: New Perspective on Bulimia

description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $683,000.
