Hartford Man Dies In Police Shootout
description: A Hartford man was killed in a shootout with Hartford police Tuesday night after he was involved in a shooting in the city's North End, the police said.

title: New Broadway Top: $55
description: When ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway Dances'' opens on Broadway in February, it will be dancing to the tune of a $55 top ticket price - a new Broadway record.

title: Books of The Times; When the Pizza Business Was Only a Sideline
description: Last Days of the Sicilians At War With the Mafia: The F.B.I. Assault on the Pizza Connection By Ralph Blumenthal Illustrated. 354 pages. Times Books. $18.95

title: Home Warranties Bill Is Approved in Albany
description: All new homes sold in New York State will carry one-year warranties on workmanship and six-year warranties on structural defects under a bill passed tonight by the Assembly.

title: Roots of Tompkins Sq. Clash Seen in Young and Inexperienced Officer Corps
description: The New York City Police Department's final report on the violence in Tompkins Square Park is essentially a profile of a breakdown in command and a prescription for measures to insure that it does not happen again.

title: A Friend Finds Dukakis a Cut Above
description: In a continent of Jesse Jackson supporters, Layiwola Shoyinka is one African whose enthusiasm has been with Michael S. Dukakis all along.

title: Article 742388 -- No Title
description: A foam producer has agreed to pay a record $700,000 in civil penalties to settle what is believed to be the first lawsuit in the nation filed by a state to stop emissions suspected of depleting the ozone layer.

title: Addendum
description: * Sudler & Hennessey will open a health communications agency in Australia called S&H/Melbourne.

title: Why Closing Down Ailing Thrifts Is a Bad Idea
description: To the Editor:

title: Oxford Energy reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
'House I Live In' Serves No One Belief or Party
description: To the Editor:

title: Tyson's Turbulent Rounds: Conflict, Crisis, Street Fight
description: Back in November 1986, before he fought for the heavyweight title against Trevor Berbick, Mike Tyson was talking about his managers, Bill Cayton and Jim Jacobs, and sounding a bit like the ''What, me worry?'' character from Mad magazine, Alfred E. Neuman.

title: Mexicans See Tumult Come To Congress
description: The Mexican Congress is being introduced to the complexities of competitive multi-party politics, and while the change has been hailed as a boon for democracy, it has not done much to advance parliamentary decorum.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: THE ECONOMY Washington and Moscow will soon complete a huge grain deal involving millions of tons of wheat, corn, soybeans and soybean meal. The deal will make American farmers happy. Whether it will raise domestic food prices - as overseas grain sales did in the 1970's - is not clear. Despite the drought, the Agriculture Department said, U.S. grain stocks are adequate to provide the Soviet Union with additional grain. [ Page A1. ] A military contractor is trying to force the Navy to conduct a second competition for a contract worth an estimated $100 million. Comptek Research argues that the fraud inquiry has found illegal acts during the selection process for the contract. [ A21. ] The U.S. trade deficit shrank 14.9 percent in the second quarter, helped by a record level of exports. [ D2. ] Sales of American-made cars and light trucks fell 13.4 percent in mid-August. That was considered a strong showing. [ D5. ] MARKETS The dollar fell against all major currencies. Traders attributed the decline to continued intervention by some central banks and to a report that the Administration found the dollar's recent rise troublesome. Gold rose $2.70 an ounce on the Comex, to $434.90. [ D1. ] Stock prices rebounded strongly, lifting the Dow Jones industrial average above the 2,000 mark. The Dow climbed 37.34 points, to 2,026.67. Today marks the one-year anniversary since the Dow reached its peak of 2,722.42. [ D1. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped modestly in sluggish trading. The highlight of the session was a $7.25 billion auction of five-year Treasury notes. [ D16. ] Corn and soybean futures prices moved sharply higher on the Chicago Board of Trade, amid fears of a frost. Wheat and oats also advanced. [ D15. ] Yields rose again on C.D.'s, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds. [ D6. ] COMPANIES Farmers Group agreed to a merger with B.A.T. after the British company raised its offer to $75 a share in cash, or about $5.2 billion. B.A.T. wants to make financial services its fourth business line after tobacco, retailing and paper. [ D1. ] The three largest steelmakers announced price increases on sheet steel used for cans. Steel used for beverage cans will be exempted because the industry is seeking to reclaim market share from aluminum companies. [ D1. ] Ford Motor executives believe the outlook for sales is strong, despite analysts' forecasts of a slowdown. [ D5. ] Ashland Oil will pay $25 million to two former executives who claimed they were dismissed for refusing to offer or cover up bribes to foreign officials. Ashland said it would take an after-tax charge of about $25 million in its fiscal fourth quarter. [ D4. ] A proxy challenge against two Scherer directors succeeded, election auditors said. That means 5 of the 11 directors support an effort by the largest shareholder to sell the company. [ D4. ] Harcourt Brace Jovanovich is dismissing 750 workers at its six theme parks, about 10 percent of the work force. [ D4. ] GTE California was ordered to cut telephone rates by $218 million by California's State Public Utilities Commission. [ D4. ] Citicorp does not expect to make any sizable acquisitions in the banking industry in the next year, its chairman said. [ D16. ] INTERNATIONAL France will soon ease its embargo against Iranian oil by allowing French companies to trade goods for Iranian oil. [ D6. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS State lotteries are good business for 27 states but offer long odds for players. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] Continental Illinois stock has climbed sharply. The F.D.I.C. will soon sell its 69 percent stake. Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: Karajan and the Vienna To Play at Carnegie Hall
description: Herbert von Karajan will conduct the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra in three concerts at Carnegie Hall in February, it was announced yesterday. The concerts will mark Mr. Karajan's first appearance in New York since 1982 and his first concerts in Manhattan with the Vienna orchestra.

title: Sinking-Fund Debentures For May Department Stores
description: The May Department Stores Company is offering $175 million of 10 7/8 percent sinking-fund debentures due in 2018, at a price of par, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Epidemic of Dangerous Eating Disorder May Be False Alarm
description: Widespread reports of a dangerous epidemic of the eating disorder bulimia are vastly overstated, new studies conclude.

title: Illinois Legislator Pushes Reforms
description: A state agency is considering a proposal to dissolve the University of Illinois Athletic Association, in the wake of an inquiry that led to the resignation of Athletic Director Neale Stoner and two others.

title: Text of '39 Pact: Baltic Nations Enter Soviet Orbit
description: Demonstrations on Tuesday in the Baltic republics of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia marked the anniversary of a 1939 nonaggression treaty between the Soviet Union and Nazi Germany. A secret protocol to the treaty, found and made public by the West at the end of World War II, is considered the basis for the Soviet takeover of the Baltic region in 1940. The Soviets, however, say the protocol may be fraudulent. Here is the text of the treaty and protocol, as published by the State Department.

title: Citicorp Head Says He Sees No Major Acquisitions Soon
description: In a regularly scheduled meeting with stock analysts yesterday, Citicorp's chairman, John S. Reed, said he did not think the bank was likely to undertake any sizable acquisitions in the banking industry this year or next.

title: Czech Invasion Wrong, Soviet Journalists Say
description: A group of Soviet journalists strongly suggested in an article published here today that the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia in August 1968 was a mistake.

title: The Boss Is Confused
description: THE Boss admits he is confused.

title: Graf Breezes Past Sanchez
description: Sixteen-year-old Arantxa Sanchez got a good look at the best in women's tennis today, and it's a good thing she didn't blink. Steffi Graf, the No .1 female player in the world, needed only 39 minutes and some booming forehands to beat the young Spaniard, 6-2, 6-0, today in the second-round of the United Jersey Bank Classic.

title: Japan Defense Minister Quits In Wake of Submarine Crash
description: Japan's Defense Minister resigned tonight after taking responsibility for a submarine accident last month in which 30 civilians died and which brought the military here under harsh criticism.

title: Strawbridge & Clothier reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: In the latest 6 months, costs of $1,207,000 for pre-opening expenses of new stores reduced net earnings by 9 cents a share. The company said its lower earnings in the latest second quarter were largely due to heavier-than-planned markdowns.

title: Go Ahead, Pile It On. Peoria Can Take It
description: To the Editor:

title: Dukakis Says He Will Push 'New Economic Patriotism'
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis delivered a message of ''new economic patriotism'' to American workers today and took the Reagan Administration and Vice President Bush personally to task for rising interest rates and falling family incomes.

title: Methode Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Himont Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Talking Deals; Lotteries: States The Big Winners
description: THE California lottery this week offered its second-biggest jackpot: $35 million. Broadcasts and newspapers statewide were filled with reports about it and it seemed as though everyone was asking, ''What would you do with the money if you won the $35 million?'' and at the same time trying to devise a system for picking the six numbers that the state would draw from a hopper.

title: Chile to Lift Emergency Rule
description: The Government today decreed an end to all states of emergency for the first time since Chile's President, Gen. Augusto Pinochet, took power after a 1973 coup, the Interior Minister announced.

title: 3 Agents and Player Charged in Fraud of Colleges
description: A Federal grand jury indicted three agents today, finding that improper payments and threats of violence were used to induce dozens of athletes to sign professional management contracts while they were in college.

title: A Theater Company Faces the Problems Of Its Own Success
description: This fall at Lincoln Center, when Robin Williams and Steve Martin begin waiting for a Godot who never arrives, many theatergoers will face a similar problem: they will be waiting for tickets that never arrive because there aren't enough to go around.

title: Sysco Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: Latest fourth quarter includes 14 weeks, while the year-ago quarter was a 13-week period; fiscal 1988 consisted of 53 weeks, while 1987 was a 52-week period.

title: Dan Quayle's Slender Senate Career
description: Senator Dan Quayle's opponents charge that quite apart from his decision to join the National Guard at the height of the Vietnam War, he is merely an amiable and ambitious lightweight, not to be taken seriously as a contender for Vice President, let alone the President he could conceivably become. These critics point especially to his legislative record. They have a point, since that record can charitably be described as undistinguished -though it is not without some interesting wrinkles.

title: Corrections
description: An article Monday on the Washington Talk page about Congressional salaries and expenditures misstated the annual staff payrolls of four Senators. The Senators and their payrolls are: Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, $1,543,352; Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, $1,544,546; Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, $1,236,084, and Frank R. Lautenberg, also a New Jersey Democrat, $1,217,762.

title: Mob Trial Going to Jury Today in Jersey
description: One of the longest Federal criminal proceedings in the country will enter its final stage Thursday when a jury begins deliberating extortion, gambling and narcotics charges against 20 men accused of making up virtually the entire membership of the New Jersey faction of the Lucchese crime family.

title: Guatemalan Plans Peace Effort
description: President Vinicio Cerezo says he will travel to other Central American capitals next month in an effort to revive the flagging regional peace process.

title: Farm Credit Bonds Set for $3.24 Billion
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation is offering $3.24 billion of bonds, priced at par, in three tranches through various securities dealers.

title: George Payson Shettle, Investment Adviser, 78
description: George Payson Shettle, an investment adviser, died of Parkinson's disease on Tuesday at Tibbitts Nursing Home in White Plains. He ws 78 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: Burundi Blames Exiles for Outbreak of Violence
description: The massacres that left at least 5,000 people dead during tribal warfare here were portrayed by the Government today as an effort by dissidents to discredit the new regime.

title: Chipwich to Merge With Peltz Food
description: Chipwich Inc. has agreed to merge with the Peltz Food Corporation, a frozen-food distributor based in New York. Robert B. Peltz, president and sole shareholder of Peltz Food, will receive 2.5 million shares of Chipwich stock, making him the largest individual shareholder. Mr. Peltz will also receive cash and a promissory note totaling $1.5 million. Chipwich shares closed at $1.625 yesterday in over-the-counter trading.

title: Polish Unrest, in 10th Day, Shows Signs of Waning
description: The latest round of labor unrest in Poland appeared on the wane today, as strikes ended at five coal mines and work resumed at a rail repair yard and large turbine factory.

title: Husband Mails $1 Million as Ransom for Wife
description: Officials here were hopeful of a break in the month-old kidnapping of the wife of a millionaire businessman after he sent nearly $1 million to 12 people listed in a ransom note as having been wronged by him.

title: Joyce Still Leads Metropolitan
description: The Metropolitan Golf Association was more than kind and courteous to the players today in the second round of the Met Open at the Baltusrol Golf Club.

title: Vehicle Sales Strong But Off 13.4% in Period
description: Sales of new American-made cars and light trucks totaled 298,576 units in mid-August, a strong showing that was nonetheless 13.4 percent below sales in the comparable period a year ago, when buyer incentives were more generous.

title: Caesars New Jersey Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss c-After a loss of $4,439,000 from the early extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and year.

title: Kingston Systems reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company noted the latest first- quarter loss was significantly smaller than the $1,142,249 loss reported in the preceding fourth quarter ended March 31.

title: Order for Boeing
description: The Boeing Company said it would announce an aircraft sale today and that the deal would mark a record annual order rate. Boeing declined to elaborate, but a Prudential-Bache analyst, Paul Nisbet, speculated that Delta Air Lines Inc. might have ordered aircraft worth $4 billion to $6 billion. A Delta spokesman said the airline was considering a big purchase but would have no announcement until later in the year. Mr. Nisbet also said that a joint venture between GPA Ltd. and Rolls-Royce P.L.C. might have placed a large order with Boeing. Boeing's shares were up $2.125 yesterday, closing at $58.75 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Fort Worth Journal; Bid Day: Sororities Round Up The Future
description: ''Oh, my God, we've got Valerie!'' shouted a sorority sister from Alpha Phi.

title: Ahead of Schedule
description: John Vanbiesbrouck, the Rangers' goalie who severely cut his left wrist on June 13 when the glass top of a coffee table at his home in Rye, N.Y., broke under his weight, said yesterday he would report to Three Rivers, Quebec, on Sept. 10 when the Rangers begin preseason training. After the 24-year-old goalie underwent five hours of microsurgery to repair three severed tendons and a sliced nerve, the team announced he was not expected back for four to six months. Vanbiesbrouck, who has been undergoing rehabilitative therapy on his wrist, fingers and arm since a cast was removed on July 11, said he received the news he would be permitted to rejoin his team when he visited the New York office of Dr. Susan Craig, who performed the surgery, on Tuesday. ''I was ecstatic,'' he said from Petoskey, Mich., where he was on a fishing holiday. ''I've tried to stay optimistic through the rehab, during which I relied heavily on Dr. Craig and Wendy Levine, my therapist. It was a long, slow process, starting with simple finger movement and then working to form a fist which took me until early August to achieve. I haven't recovered 100 percent, I must continue the therapy treatment to complete the nerve regeneration, but Dr. Craig said I've made so much progress that it's unlikely I could badly hurt my wrist or fingers again. So when camp opens, I'll be there.''(AP)

title: Adobe Resources Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $2,995,000 for the quarter and $4,564,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $8,550,000 and $8,838,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said year-ago quarter includes a $19,516,000 gain on sale of an investment.

title: General Binding Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Yankees, Stay Home
description: LEAD: I'm a baseball fan, not a lawyer, but my hunch is that somewhere between trademarking, landmarking and just plain tough negotiating there must be a way to prevent sports team owners from holding cities hostage to demands for luxury sky boxes and parking concessions.

title: U.S. Clears A.T.&T. Plan
description: A joint venture between the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and Telerate Inc. does not violate a 1982 consent decree that bans electronic publishing by A.T.&T., a Justice Department official said today. The venture was formed to let currency traders execute trades at the keyboard of a computer terminal.

title: Market Place; Some Good Signs At Continental
description: EVER since the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's $4.5 billion bailout of the Continental Illinois Corporation in 1984, investors have been skeptical of the stock of this Chicago-based bank holding company. But there are signs that Continental may be turning around.

title: LaRussa Plays It Cautiously
description: Even with the largest lead in the major leagues, one that has shrunk not at all in nearly three weeks, Tony LaRussa will not permit himself a peek past today. Not to the series with Boston next week, not to the 10 games in 14 days against Kansas City and Minnesota next month, certainly not to the playoffs in October.

title: Metro Matters; Little Is Said And Less Is Done About Yonkers
description: A new slogan seems to have captured the imagination of New York's leading citizens: ''Just say nothing.''

title: Medical Lab Indicted On Dumping Waste
description: A Perth Amboy medical laboratory and two employees were indicted yesterday on charges of recklessly disposing of hazardous waste - 2,000 contaminated blood vials and other medical waste, the State Attorney General, W. Cary Edwards, announced.

title: Inquiry Into Seat Belts Opened
description: Federal engineers have opened an investigation of claims that the rear seat belts on 1.7 million Ford Escort and Mercury Lynx cars can cripple passengers in a crash, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said today.

title: Corporate Software Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Findings on Tompkins Sq. Prompt 2 Police Supervisors to Lose Posts
description: The New York City Police Commissioner, in a sharp and sweeping criticism of his department's handling of the Tompkins Square Park clash, said yesterday that the ranking chief on the scene that night would retire and that the precinct captain would be temporarily relieved of his command.

title: Entrepreneur Pleads Not Guilty
description: A computer software entrepreneur pleaded not guilty today to 11 counts of felony larceny stemming from what prosecutors said was a plan to bilk six investors out of a total of more than $500,000 to keep his business operating.

title: Tip for a Visit to the Doctor: Have 3 Questions Ready
description: Simply by preparing three questions to ask before walking into the doctor's office, patients can improve the chances they will feel satisfied with the visit, a new study has found.

title: American Science & Engineerng Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $24,000. c-Net loss

title: Mortgage-Backed Transcapital Issue
description: The Transohio Savings Bank, a unit of the Transcapital Financial Corporation, is offering $100 million of 9.60 percent mortgage-backed bonds due 1992, at a price of par, through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: B.A.T. Bid Is Accepted By Farmers
description: B.A.T. Industries finally obtained a definitive merger agreement today from Farmers Group Inc., after raising its offer to $75 a share, or a total of $5.2 billion.

title: 3 NATIONS DISCUSS ANGOLA PULLOUTS
description: Angola, Cuba and South Africa started talks today to set a timetable for the withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola.

title: Trailers Flip Onto Car And Kill 2 on Thruway
description: A truck hauling two trailers of chemicals flipped onto a car today, killing a couple from Wisconsin and forcing authorities to close part of the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway for two and a half hours, the state police said.

title: Sallie Mae Notes For $500 Million
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $500 million of floating-rate notes due in 1990, with underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Quayle Tries to Go Beyond 'Distractions'
description: Senator Dan Quayle tried tonight to move beyond what he called ''the distractions'' of the controversy over his military record by denouncing Michael S. Dukakis as ''anti-defense.''

title: Necessity, the Mother of New Careers
description: IN 1981, Michael Pangia, a stockbroker, needed a new cornice built for his Brooklyn town house. ''Without a cornice, the building looked empty, like a person without a head,'' he said. A year later, his house had a cornice and at the age of 38, Mr. Pangia had a new job: designer and builder of cornices.

title: Sudan, Drowning in Troubles
description: As if civil war, a $12 billion debt, locusts and drought were not enough, the Sudan now finds its capital inundated by an overflowing Nile. In just two days this month, six times as much rain fell on Khartoum as in all of 1987. One and a half million Sudanese are now without shelter, food or clean water. A shaky Government, overwhelmed even by normal administrative tasks, has little hope of coping with this calamity.

title: New Rules Are Planned for Challenges to Tax Assessments
description: The New York City Finance Department will devise new rules and procedures for taxpayers contesting tax assessments and it will work to inform property owners that such challenges can be made, the Finance Commissioner, Stanley E. Grayson, said yesterday.

title: Report Finds Schools Lacking Crucial Counseling
description: The 180,000 children in New York City's middle schools do not receive adequate guidance counseling at a crucial time in their educational careers, a research group said in a report yesterday.

title: Edward W. Duffy, Executive, 68
description: Edward W. Duffy, retired chief executive of the USG Corporation, died of heart failure Monday at Evanston (Ill.) Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in Glenview, Ill.

title: Bridge
description: A famous English player-writer, S. J. Simon, observed that defense is the hardest part of the game. It is certainly true that good players, quite capable of executing end plays and squeezes when they are in the declaring seat, overlook many opportunities for clever defense.

title: For Maple, Use a Stain That Has Little Red
description: LEAD: NOT so fine as mahogany, walnut or cherry, or so common as pine, maple has always been a sturdy favorite for making both simple everyday pieces and better country furniture. It has endured from early Colonial days and for good reason: the wood of the sugar, or hard, maple was strong, reliable and, above all, abundant.

title: Tandycrafts Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Rodman & Renshaw Capital reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Review/Film; Moving Beyond Boyhood In an Australian Town
description: Unless a genius comes along to shake up the material, another coming-of-age film does not offer much hope for originality; the best anyone can expect is that it will not seem too stale and that it might even break out with an innovative quirk or two. ''The Year My Voice Broke'' is certainly not fresh, but it is so pleasant and unpretentious that we can almost forget the total lack of surprise in this deftly acted Australian film.

title: Gennady Smakov, 48, Translator and Author
description: Gennady Smakov, a scholar, translator and author of two books on dance, died Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 48 years old. Mr. Smakov died of a brain tumor, according to a friend, Joseph Brodsky.

title: Review/Opera; The Lighter Side of Love
description: Hector Berlioz toyed with the idea of setting Shakespeare's ''Much Ado About Nothing'' to music as early as 1833, but didn't get around to it until 1860. When Berlioz finally did transform the play into an opera - ''Beatrice and Benedict,'' his last major work - he concentrated on its lighter side, jettisoning the character Don John (and with him a subplot that tells us a great deal more about Beatrice), and adding a comic figure, the musician Somarone.

title: Reorganization Plan for the PTL Is Rejected
description: A Federal Bankruptcy Court judge rejected the proposed reorganization plan for the PTL television ministry today, saying it did not take into account the ministry's poor financial condition.

title: Action Industries reports earnings for Year to June 25
description: b-Includes a gain of $642,100 from an accounting change. c-Net loss and after a loss of $9,905,100 from discontinued operations.

title: British Unemployment
description: Long-term unemployment in Britain has fallen below one million for the first time in more than five years, the Government reported today. The number of people out of work for longer than 12 months dropped by 81,000 in the second quarter, to 948,000. The report said the rate among the young declined by 36 percent from a year ago.

title: Hong Kong Tower Of Glass
description: TO the Chinese, No. 8 augurs prosperity.

title: Price Rise Set for Steel Used in Cans
description: The nation's three largest steelmakers have announced price increases on sheet steel used for cans, a move that will affect prices on everything from food cans and aerosol containers to oil and air filters.

title: Birtcher Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Mother Fights Prison Term For Alleged Misuse of Fund
description: Maria DeSillers went to court today to fight a possible jail sentence for failing to turn over financial records and luxury items allegedly bought with donations for her late son's liver transplants.

title: Washington Nearing Accord on a Big Sale Of Grain to Russians
description: The United States and the Soviet Union will soon complete a huge grain agreement under which the Soviets will buy millions of tons of wheat, corn, soybeans and soybean meal, Administration officials said today.

title: Charter Federal Savings & Loan Associaion reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $79,000. c-Net income d-Includes tax benefits of $107,000 and $3,689,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the loss in the latest quarter was mainly due to the reversal of $995,000 of accrued interest on commercial real estate loans placed in nonaccrual status.

title: Stockholm Journal; Socialists Against the Wall, Fearing the Ballot Box
description: The leaders of the Social Democratic Party, which has ruled Sweden for 50 of the last 56 years, were worried a few months ago that overconfidence would be the party's main problem in the general election next month. But with the campaign officially beginning, the Social Democrats are no longer concerned that the rank-and-file will take the election for granted.

title: Conseco and I.C.H.
description: Conseco Inc. and the I.C.H. Corporation announced a merger agreement in principle under which each I.C.H. share would be exchanged for either one Conseco share or $5.25 plus half of a Conseco share. The agreement, under which I.C.H. would operate as a separate entity owned by Conseco, provides for the exchange of .095 of a Conseco share for each share of I.C.H. stock owned by I.C.H.'s largest shareholder, the Consolidated National Successor Corporation. I.C.H. is based in Louisville, Ky., and Conseco in Carmel, Ind. Both are insurance holding companies. Robert Shaw, principal owner of Consolidated National, will become chairman of the merged companies. Conseco's chairman, Steve C. Hilbert, will become chief executive.

title: Losing Bidder Contests Contract Involved in Pentagon Case
description: In the first such case stemming from the Federal investigation of fraud in Pentagon procurement, a producer of military electronic equipment is trying to force the Navy to conduct a second competition for a contract worth an estimated $100 million.

title: Foster, L B Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a $2,299,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $3,341,000 and $6,255,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and a loss from the disposal of discontinued operations of $8,054,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: 12 Arrested Outside Event Featuring North
description: A face-off between demonstrators supporting and opposing Oliver L. North resulted in a dozen arrests tonight outside a Republican fund-raising event where the Iran-contra defendant appeared.

title: Navy Reservist Guilty in Flag-Burning Case
description: A Federal jury today convicted a member of the Naval Reserves of burning an American flag outside an armed forces recruiting station in a demonstration.

title: Reviews/Music; Texas Romantic On Heartbreak And Foolishness
description: The search for honky-tonk heaven continues in Texas. Since the outlaw country movement of the late 1970's, songwriters in Austin have minutely examined the myth of the honky-tonk, where romance and fistfights and music and drink, exaltation and self-destruction all swirl together. Austin's younger songwriters can't take the myth in full seriousness, but they can't shake it off, either. Jimmie Dale Gilmore, who brought his band to the Lone Star Cafe on Tuesday night, leans toward the romantic side of the myth; about a decade after his songs were carried to the outside world by Joe Ely, Mr. Gilmore is on a national tour.

title: Solidarity Lacks Wide Support for Strikes, But the Regime Can't Prevent a Recurrence
description: As the tide of labor unrest sweeping Poland appeared to ebb today, the Government and the outlawed Solidarity trade union remained locked in paralyzing standoff.

title: Garcia Marquez's First Play Gets Mixed Reviews
description: Gabriel Garcia Marquez's first play opened this week in the city where his stardom as a novelist began two decades ago. This time, however, the reviewers were less generous with the Nobel Prize winner.

title: Sony Profits Soar Fivefold
description: The Sony Corporation said yesterday that its profit soared fivefold in its first quarter on the strength of a ''gratifying sales performance'' and successful cost reductions.

title: Ashland, Ex-Officials In Settlement
description: Ashland Oil Inc. said today that it would pay $25 million to two former executives who contended they had been dismissed for refusing to offer or cover up bribes to foreign officials. As a result, Ashland said it would take an after-tax charge of about $25 million in its fiscal fourth quarter.

title: Diodes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $55,501 for the quarter and $239,239 for the year. c-Net loss

title: Second Chance
description: Kerwin Bell, who last year at the University of Florida set Southeastern Conference career records with 56 touchdowns passes and 7,585 yards gained passing, signed with the Atlanta Falcons, one day after being waived by the Miami Dolphins. The Falcons, who finished with the worst record in the National Football League last year, have the first opportunity to claim players who are waived. Bell was beaten out for the third quarterback job in Miami by David Archer, who was Atlanta's starter at the beginning of last season. Before signing Bell, the Falcons had only two other quarterbacks: Chris Miller, the starter, and Erik Kramer. Scott Campbell, a reserve, will be lost for the season after suffering a knee injury on Saturday night in a victory over Tampa Bay. . . . The Chicago Bears said Otis Wilson, one of their starting linebackers, would undergo surgery to repair damage to his left knee suffered in an exhibition game Monday night against the Dallas Cowboys. Wilson will miss at least half the regular season.(AP)

title: Bush Intensifies Debate on Pledge, Asking Why It So Upsets Dukakis
description: With President Reagan at his side in a raucous campaign rally here, Vice President Bush intensified his argument with Michael S. Dukakis today over the Pledge of Allegiance. He said he would have signed a bill that Mr. Dukakis vetoed in 1977 requiring teachers to lead their classes in the pledge.

title: Cycare Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: In December 1987, the company adopted FAS 96 on accounting for income taxes. The change increased this year's first quarter net by $1.5 million, or 27 cents a share.

title: Chittenden Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: New Proof Offered On Effects of Lead In Early Childhood
description: A study provides new evidence that exposure to relatively low levels of lead during early childhood can slow and perhaps permanently stifle mental development.

title: Parents Agree to Detente in the Clothes Wars
description: THE clothes war between parents and children appears to be over. Interviews with psychologists, parents and children around the nation show that while there are still some minor skirmishes on the fashion front, for the most part parents and youngsters have called a truce. And the truce seems to be holding even as the new school year opens. As long as children dress appropriately for special occasions, parents these days are pretty much letting them wear what they choose the rest of the time. ''Parents are feeling more relaxed,'' said Dr. Judie Alpert, a professor of psychology at New York University. ''Parents teach children to choose their battles, and parents have to learn to choose their battles, too.''

title: Omni Exploration Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Figures for 1987 have been restated to account for a tax refund.

title: Quilted Eye Wear For a Sporty Look
description: FIRST there were quilted handbags, often with the unmistakable look of Chanel. Then came quilted clothes, quilted furs and even quilted jewelry. Now quilting has come to eye wear. Judging from the glasses seen about town recently, the popular material is a rich black leather. Quilted much like the classic Chanel handbag, the material covers the sidepieces, giving a sporty look to the wearer and stiff competition to the newest plastic entries to the eye-wear scene.

title: Brazil Gets I.M.F. Loan
description: The International Monetary Fund approved a $1.4 billion loan to Brazil on Tuesday, to go along with proposed new loans of $5.2 billion from commercial banks, an I.M.F. spokesman said.

title: Why Closing Down Ailing Thrifts Is a Bad Idea; Attach Some Strings
description: To the Editor:

title: Lincoln Center Hopes Its New Logo Has Power of Suggestion
description: Holding his arm high so that it framed his head in a 90-degree crook, the designer Ivan Chermayeff explained, ''It all came down to a gesture of performance.''

title: France to Ease Embargo on Iran Oil
description: French officials have indicated in recent days that France will soon ease its embargo against Iranian oil by allowing French companies to trade goods, especially food, for Iranian oil.

title: Where the Accessories Are for Deaccessioning
description: IN Massachusetts, some people get their Mass Mocas mixed up. There is the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Arts in North Adams, which isn't to open until 1992. Then there is the Massachusetts Museum of Culture and Accessories, a shop devoted to avant-garde housewares and fashion accessories made by 20 artists. It opened in Lenox in May.

title: Scientists Search for Signs Of Marine Life at Sludge Site
description: Several mornings each month, an old Army boat leaves the dock here and chugs 12 miles out to sea to the dumping ground for more than a billion tons of sewage sludge.

title: Another Bias
description: Jay Bias, a younger brother of the late University of Maryland basketball star Len Bias, has enrolled at Allegany Community College in Cumberland, Md. Bias, a 6-foot-5-inch forward who was a high school basketball all-America selection at Northwestern High School in Prince George's County, Md., averaged 25 points and 12 rebounds as a senior and became one of the nation's most highly recruited schoolboys. But Bias failed to pass a National Collegiate Athletic Association standard that requires freshmen at Division I schools to maintain at least a 2.0 grade-point average as a high school senior and score at least 700 on the Scholastic Aptitude Test.(AP)

title: A Split House Depicts Life In 1790's and 1950's
description: LEAD: WHEN it comes to new exhibits, curators can experience the same opening-night jitters that actors do on stage. ''Will the public understand what we are saying?'' is the question curators ask themselves as the curtain goes up on their displays.

title: Jens Peter Larsen, 86, an Editor, Musicologist and Haydan Scholar
description: Jens Peter Larsen, a Danish musicologist whose investigations into the music of Haydn contributed enormously to understanding of the composer's style, died Monday of complications from gallbladder surgery. He was 86 years old and lived in Copenhagen.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Old Sailors Never Die
description: The last of the Navy's World War II salts, Rear Adm. John D. Bulkeley, will retire next Wednesday. But at his insistence, the 77-year-old admiral will go in an unobtrusiveness that contrasts totally to his rip-roaring career at sea.

title: LABOR FEDERATION ENDORSES DUKAKIS, CITING UNION ISSUES
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. today endorsed Gov. Michael S. Dukakis for President, hoping that labor's support will do more good for Mr. Dukakis in 1988 than it did for Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic Presidential nominee in 1984.

title: NCNB Texas Deposits Cut
description: Depositors at the NCNB Texas National Bank have withdrawn about $300 million in recent weeks, and bank officials say the total could double.

title: Comair Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Della Femina Names President of Boston Unit
description: Michael H. Reingold, 52 years old, has been named president of the Boston office of Della Femina, McNamee WCRS, which alone brings in billings of $150 million and has a staff of 200. The overall agency's billings exceed $600 million.

title: Miners Strike to Protest Austerity in Hungary
description: More than 300 miners were on strike at an important southern mining area today. the state radio said. It was the first reported worker protest of strict economic policies imposed under Prime Minister Karoly Grosz.

title: Sanderson Farms reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,250,000, or 13 cents a share, from an accounting change.

title: Quake Jars Salt Lake City
description: A small earthquake rattled a section of northeastern Salt Lake City, but was not related to a series of tremors that shook central Utah earlier this month, seismologists said. The quake, measuring 2.1 on the Richter scale of ground motion, occurred at 11:13 P.M. M.D.T. on Tuesday.

title: Museum Loot Found In Guard's Basement
description: Asian artworks worth as much as $1 million that were stolen from the Walters Art Gallery here have been discovered in a museum guard's basement, the police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation have announced.

title: Court Reinstates a Woman's Suit Charging That Police Failed
description: In a ruling that could expand the duty of the police, a Federal appeals court Tuesday reinstated a suit by a woman who said officers derided her complaints about her husband's violence and failed to help her.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING Claramount Wins Easily: Claramount splashed to a front-running 20-length victory over Whodam and Cavanagh Special in the $124,600 West Point Handicap for New York-breds yesterday at Saratoga. The race was switched from grass to dirt because of heavy rain and the winner's margin of victory was the largest in New York this year. Claramount, a 4-year-old son of Policeman, had raced in California until last month, then was flown in to beat fellow New York-breds in the Evan Shipman at Belmont. Claramount, owned by Edward Wachtel and trained by Howie Tesher, paid $6.80 for $2 to win yesterday after running the mile and an eighth in 1:49 1/5 under Chris Antley. LITTLE LEAGUE Texas Team in Semifinals: Todd Abbott had three runs batted in and Jason Powell threw a four-hitter as Spring, Tex., rolled to an 8-2 victory over Andover, Mass., to move into the semifinals of the Little League World Series in Williamsport, Pa. Spring, the South Region champion, will play the West champion, Pearl City, Hawaii, today. Craig Hickman scattered seven hits and Mark Livingstone had two hits and two runs batted in as Glace Bay, Nova Scotia, defeated Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, 5-1, to earn a spot in the semifinals against Taiwan at 2 P.M. today. (AP)

title: Benefiting From Barter Services
description: SEVERAL years ago when the Chrysler Corporation had to put on its best financial face to obtain a $4.5 billion Federal loan, it had to grapple with the problem of a huge unmoving inventory of automobiles. It finally cleared them out by trading the autos for advertising space and time. More recently, Cunard Lines Ltd. swapped cabins and meals for advertising as well as airline seats, tableware for its dining rooms and air-conditioning units.

title: Athens Rules 'Christ' Film May Be Seen
description: The Government today rejected a demand by the Greek Orthodox Church that Martin Scorsese's film ''The Last Temptation of Christ'' be banned in Greece. To do so, the Government said, would be contrary to the principles of Socialism and freedom of the arts.

title: Itel Raises Stake In Shipping Line
description: The Itel Corporation, controlled by Samuel Zell, a Chicago real estate executive, has increased its stake in the American President Companies, a shipping concern based in Oakland, Calif., to 12.5 percent, from 11.4 percent. In a filing Friday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Itel said it had bought 162,700 Series B preferred shares on the open market from Aug. 10 to Aug. 12 at prices of $56.25 to $56.75 a share.

title: Further Rise For Yields
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds, which have been up strongly in the last few weeks, rose again in the week ended yesterday.

title: Buying Lollipops for $65 Million
description: LEAD: By dominating the lollipop business, Melvin and Ellen Gordon hope to gain ground - and retail shelf space - in their battle against other candy makers.

title: 43 Are Accused of Poaching Black Bears For Body Parts
description: A three-year undercover operation has resulted in charges against 43 people accused of poaching black bears for their gall bladders, which are prized in Asia as aphrodisiacs and medicine, it was announced Tuesday.

title: Artists Who Enfold Many Possibilities
description: IN the deft hands of Masahiro Chatani and Kunio Ekiguchi, two Japanese origami artists, paper can be transformed into virtually anything the mind can imagine or the eye can see. More than 40 examples of their work are on exhibit at Gallery 91 in Manhattan, through Oct. 14.

title: Smucker, J M Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Midwest Communications reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Restless Captives
description: Cracks are appearing in the Eastern European foundations of the Soviet empire.

title: Shoney's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes recapitalization expenses of $1,113,000 and interest expense of $1,710,000 which effectively reduced net by $2,185,000. The company said it borrowed $585 million to finance the recapitalization and pre-paid $41,100,000 of the bank debt during August.

title: U.S. Appeals Court Upsets Federal Rules on Sentencing
description: The first Federal appellate court to rule on new sentencing guidelines for Federal crimes has declared them unconstitutional, ruling that the commission that drafted them violated the constitutional doctrine of separation of powers because some of its members were judges.

title: U.S. to Slightly Ease Its Ban On Fee Payments to Panama
description: The United States announced today that it was easing a ban on payments to the Government of Panama that has made it difficult for American companies to do business there.

title: Duplex Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Genovese Drug Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 12
description: b-Includes a gain of $487,000 from an accounting change. Year-ago quarter and 6-month are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split declared Sept. 8, 1987.

title: Bush Has Slight Lead Over Dukakis in Poll
description: A third major national poll has put Vice President Bush narrowly ahead of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, suggesting that the troubles faced by Mr. Bush's running mate had not prevented the Vice President from winning a clear boost from his party's National Convention.

title: It's Easy as 1-2-3 As Mets Sweep
description: The Mets, who arrived in town with a four-game losing streak and a dwindling lead, left tonight with a three-game winning streak, a 5 1/2-game lead and eight victories in nine games this season against the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Dollar Has Broad Decline As Official Pressure Mounts
description: The dollar fell against all major currencies yesterday in active trading. Traders attributed the decline to continued intervention by some central banks and to a report that the Reagan Administration found the recent rise in the dollar troublesome and preferred a period of stability.

title: TV Notes
description: Michaels-Style Emmys

title: Comdial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: For 'Teenspeak,' Like Another Meaning for the Multipurposeful 'Like'
description: So these two teen-age girls are sitting in the park and one is like totally gaga about this cute movie actor but she's afraid to ask for his autograph. So the other girl goes like: ''Getting an autograph is like, be brave and ask for it. I got it. I just went up to him and he like, 'O.K. honey, anything you want.' '' Is that, like, English? Already the bugbear of many parents, teachers, and other adults who perceive a decline of language and thought, the word ''like'' seems to have assumed a new function. No longer a mere beatnik affectation or semiliterate tic, the word is now used by some young people as a substitute for the straightforward verb ''to say.''

title: People
description: * Robert Natiello has been named president of Newton & Wakeby, a new in-house agency at Schlott Realtors.

title: Gabelli Settles S.E.C. Case
description: The New York investor Mario J. Gabelli and companies he controls today settled disciplinary charges contending that they violated Federal securities laws in their abortive attempt to take the Di Giorgio Corporation private in 1987.

title: Judge Delays School Admission of Girl With AIDS
description: A Federal judge ruled today that a girl with AIDS should be tutored at home while her mother appeals a decision that the child can attend school if she is quarantined in a specially built glass booth.

title: Insider Definition Urged
description: The chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, John J. Phelan Jr., called today for the establishment of common worldwide definitions of insider trading in an attempt to combat unscrupulous traders and reassure investors.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Astro-Med Inc., West Warwick, R.I., a graphics recording and printing company, said it had received a $700,000 order from McDonnell Douglas Astronautics Co., St. Louis, for thermal printers to be used during the firing of the Delta rocket.

title: Dresher Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Coe Won't Be In; Bile May Be Out
description: The men's 1,500-meter final in the Seoul Olympics was assured yesterday of not having one great runner, Sebastian Coe of Great Britain, the world record-holder. And it could be missing another, Abdi Bile of Somalia, the current world champion.

title: Proper Paperhanging
description: ''PEOPLE spend a lot of money on wall coverings, and they don't want to have a bad installation,'' said Robert Gaul, a New York interior designer. That's why it is important to find a paperhanger who has experience with the papers on the market and the methods and adhesives used to hang them.

title: Review of a Plan For a Jail Barge Is Drawing Fire
description: Leading opponents of the Koch administration's plan to moor a prison barge on the Greenwich Village waterfront said yesterday that the procedure under which the project is being reviewed might be illegal and ought to be stopped.

title: DUKAKIS SAYS BUSH LAGS ON A DEBATE
description: Michael S. Dukakis's campaign today accused Vice President Bush of ducking an early debate, with the Democratic nominee vowing to show up anyway.

title: U.S. AND EUROPEANS REPORTEDLY BREAK A MAJOR SPY RING
description: American and West German officials have uncovered a spy ring that has been supplying Hungarian intelligence agents with secret Western military documents, including United States Army plans to defend Europe, according to Reagan Administration officials familiar with the case.

title: Marimekko Unit Hires Chief to Help It Recover
description: As in the United States, business mergers overseas often require a period of adjustment, during which the acquired company surrenders its momentum. Such was the case with Marimekko Inc., the Finnish designer and producer of home textiles and clothes, which was acquired in 1985 by the Amer Group, an international diversified marketer of consumer goods.

title: In Greenwich, Housing Problem Is Huge
description: Most towns these days worry about affordable housing. Some are worrying about segregated housing patterns. A few, concerned about property values, even worry about whether some new houses are too small.

title: Twins Rout Tigers Behind 6-Run Inning
description: Dan Gladden and Kirby Puckett each hit home runs to highlight a six-run second inning as the Minnesota Twins defeated Detroit, 8-2, tonight and finished the season series with 11 consecutive victories over the Tigers.

title: Man Killed and Officer Wounded In Gun Battle at Brooklyn Project
description: A 22-year-old man was shot to death by the police and an officer was wounded yesterday during a gun battle in Brooklyn, the authorities said.

title: KEY RATES
Medtronic Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income from a $39.2 million settlement of patent litigation with Intermedics Inc. after legal expenses and deferral of $13 million which was accounted for as future royalties amortized over the remaining five-year patent life, $24 million was recorded as earnings before income taxes.

title: Phone Rate Cut In California
description: The State Public Utilities Commission today ordered GTE California to cut its telephone rates by $218 million. It was the second rollback ordered this year, and the two together will reduce the company's annual revenue by 13.5 percent, or $330 million. The company's president, David E. Anderson, said the reduction was excessive. GTE California, the state's second-largest telephone company, is a unit of the GTE Corporation of Stamford, Conn. Company officials said no decision had been made on whether to appeal the cuts ordered by state regulators, either one of which constitutes the largest phone rate reduction ordered in recent years. The latest cut, effective Sept. 6, will lower the average monthly bills of GTE's 2.7 million customers by $4, to $25.95. GTE California, based in

title: Rupp's Grandson Hurt
description: Chip Rupp, a grandson of the former Kentucky coach Adolph Rupp, will not play basketball for West Virginia this season after undergoing knee surgery. The 6-foot-7-inch, 210-pound junior forward had transferred from Vanderbilt.

title: Crisis Declaration Expected For 2 Psychiatric Hospitals
description: The New York State Office of Mental Health is expected to declare an emergency today to deal with overcrowding at the state-run psychiatric hospital in Brooklyn and the city hospital that acts as its admitting center, city and state mental health officials said yesterday.

title: LEADER OF BURMA ENDS MARTIAL LAW
description: In the face of continuing protests, the Burmese Government lifted martial law today, withdrew its soldiers from the streets and proposed a referendum on an end to 26 years of one-party rule.

title: Suspect Is Wounded In Robbery at Hotel
description: A police sergeant critically wounded one of two robbery suspects who shot him in the arm early yesterday at the Hawthorne Circle Motor Inn, on Route 9-A, the Mount Pleasant Police Chief said.

title: Kimmins Environmental Service reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
National City Unit Sets Deposit Issue
description: National City Bank, a unit of the National City Corporation, is offering $100 million of 9 5/8 percent deposit notes due in 1993, at a price of par, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Jaguar to Drop 1,200 Jobs
description: Jaguar P.L.C., the British maker of luxury cars, plans to eliminate about 1,200 jobs over the next three years in an effort to increase efficiency. The move, announced on

title: Yugoslav Bread Riot Reported
description: Workers struggling to make ends meet under Yugoslavia's rising inflation stampeded while waiting on line to buy bread, and a newspaper here said today that 20 people had been injured. The incident reportedly took place in the town of Titov Veles in Macedonia, Yugoslavia's southernmost province, the Belgrade daily Vecernje Novosti said. It did not indicate when it occurred. Quoting a local paper, Nova Macedonia, the Belgrade daily said that bakeries often disregard instructions to produce at least 60 percent of their loaves in cheaper bread varieties.

title: Car Insuring: Jersey Law Missing Goal
description: For the first time in New Jersey's long-running debate over high automobile-insurance rates, there are grudging admissions by Governor Kean and some lawmakers that legislation enacted five years ago to curb rising premiums has only worsened the problem.

title: Baltic Demonstrations: A Gamble for Gorbachev
description: The slogans and speeches in the three Baltic republics Tuesday night must have burned the ears of the more conservative colleagues of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader. The speakers, Estonians, Latvians and Lithuanians who had received official permission to assemble, called for independence from Moscow, equated Communism with the Nazi swastika and accused the Soviet authorities of falsifying history.

title: Papers' Plea In Detroit
description: Detroit's two large daily newspapers have asked their six unions to support an attempt to overturn a 30-day stay that is blocking their joint operating agreement.

title: New Campaign From Pioneer
description: The home electronics division of Pioneer Electronic (USA) Inc., which has not come out with any new advertising in two years, could not have found a phenomenon more natural than ''cocooning'' to use for its new campaign beginning in September. ''Cocooning'' refers to the stay-at-home trend of the baby boom generation.

title: Review/Television; Passages Of Youth
description: Here's a real summer refreshment: a provocative television memoir of growing up by Michael Blakemore, the theater director, which can be seen tonight at 9 on Channel 13.

title: Fuzzy Dice Decor: The Car Interior As Living Room
description: ERIN MURPHY SCHNEEWEISS keeps two tiny teddy bears on the dashboard of her sporty white car: one wears a white dress with a veil; the other, a dinner jacket and top hat. ''Everyone sees them,'' said Mrs. Schneeweiss, who lives in Midland Park, N.J., and drives a 1986 Pontiac Fiero. ''Everyone asks if I'm married, everyone says congratulations, and they bring back memories every time I look at them. They're a very personal thing.''

title: Xerox Acquisition
description: The Xerox Corporation said it had agreed to acquire a unit of Crowntek that specializes in the research and development of data base software systems. Xerox said it expected to complete the acquisition of the unit, the Advanced Information Technology division of a Crowntek subsidiary, the Computer Corporation of America, in the third quarter. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Life in the 30's
description: SOMETIMES the holes say as much about you as the fabric. Over the years I've written half a dozen essays about my husband, too many to count about my children, a handful about my mother and one about my grandmother on the occasion of her death. I've never written one entirely about my father. There are lots of reasons for that, and the most important one may be, oddly enough, that my father is very much alive. It's impossible to imagine him any other way. He is not cut out to be a wraith, a memory, a dream of life. He has a personality, which, couched in culinary terms, would be something like clam chowder - the kind with the tomatoes, not the cream, the kind that seems to have odd little bits of everything thrown together, with a good deal of pepper. His most powerful character traits are a curious mind, an indefatigable sense of humor and a deep and abiding sentimentality beneath a veneer of brusqueness, rather like a mussel in its shell.

title: Article 851088 -- No Title
description: The White House Office of Management and Budget will release a report Thursday estimating the fiscal 1989 Federal budget deficit at $144 billion, Administration officials said today.

title: Re-creating A Classic House Shingle by Shingle
description: LEAD: PAINT a picture of a summer afternoon at seaside in New England, circa 1880. Show a big, rambling, shingled house, with porches stretching out to greet the sea and couples in linen whites strolling across the lawn.

title: Broadview Savings reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and the company said in the 6-month net exceeded preferred dividend requirements. The company said in the latest quarter it realized a $4,500,000 gain on the sale of the Sea Ranch property in Florida.

title: Bentsen Asserts Quayle Lacks Needed Maturity
description: Lloyd Bentsen, the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, suggested today that his Republican counterpart, Dan Quayle, lacks the maturity required of someone who might have to lead the country.

title: Greek and Turkish Cypriots to Resume Talks
description: The leaders of the Greeks and Turks on Cyprus agreed today to start new talks about reunifying their divided Mediterranean island and set June 1, 1989, as the deadline for a settlement.

title: Met-Pro Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shares are fully diluted.

title: A Hot Pot Won't Scorch This Counter Top
description: STEVEN DITCH, who took the heat-resistant epoxy resin material used for laboratory counters and turned it into kitchen counter tops and tables, now has an improved Tuff Top.

title: V Band Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said international sales were down sharply in the period due to the ''big bang'' deregulation period and the October stock market crash.

title: Licensed Carters Have Too Much to Lose by Illegal Dumping
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk: The Media; TV Coaches: Success Is Appearing to Be in Charge
description: Since the actor-director Robert Montgomery gave free tips to President Eisenhower on how to conduct himself before television cameras, coaching politicians and Federal officials for television appearances has become a thriving industry here.

title: Parent & Child
description: CASEY GORKA has come to expect the responses children have to her 7-year-old daughter, Julia, who is retarded and has problems with her vision and sense of touch.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Grand Old Poster
description: For a time last winter the Republicans were a party in search of a poster, the kind that holds the attention of a viewer long enough to induce a purchase. Ultimately, the Republicans settled on a poster for its national convention that depicts the skyline of the New Orleans French Quarter.

title: Sale of Brunswick By Scott and Mead
description: The Scott Paper Company said it and the Mead Corporation had completed the sale of the Brunswick Pulp and Paper Company and related timberlands. The Georgia-Pacific Corporation purchased the holdings for about $665 million.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''No one tells union members how to vote. Our members and their families make up their own minds.'' - Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. [ A1:3. ]

title: Treasury Prices Fall Slightly
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped modestly in sluggish trading yesterday, a session whose major highlight was a $7.25 billion auction of new five-year Treasury notes.

title: Sergeant Who Killed Partner Says Suspect Pushed Gun Hand
description: A police sergeant, testifying at an unusual court hearing, said yesterday that he accidentally fired his service revolver last Tuesday - fatally shooting his partner - after a suspect pushed his gun hand.

title: Outdoors; L.I. Added to Bluefish Contest
description: ONE of the East Coast's richest bluefish tournaments begins tomorrow.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Checkmate, Waldheim
description: A few days ago it was reported that Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic Presidential candidate, had informed the World Jewish Congress that he was opposed to lifting a Justice Department ban on entry into this country by Kurt Waldheim, the President of Austria.

title: Rising Numbers of Women Force Prison Transfers
description: Lynette (Squeaky) Fromme, who is serving a life term for a 1975 attempt to assassinate President Gerald R. Ford, is among dozens of Federal prisoners who are being transferred in a major shuffling of female inmates, prison officials said today.

title: Soviets Agree to Open Files on the Nazi Genocide to U.S. Scholars
description: The Soviet Union has agreed for the first time to open its archives on the Nazi genocide to United States scholars, a step that is expected to give a clearer picture of how Eastern European collaborators helped put to death millions of Jews and others.

title: 180 Years Of Changing Floor Styles
description: FOR those dedicated to restoring an old house in all its authentic particulars, ''Floor Coverings for Historic Buildings'' is a useful tool. The book surveys the changing fashions of its subject from 1750 to 1930.

title: BF Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Latest quarter was only the fourth quarter of operations for the company so comparative figures for the prior year are not available.

title: Convicted Cyanide-Pill Killer Will Not Face State Charges
description: Stella Nickell, convicted in Federal court of using cyanide-laced pills to kill her husband and a stranger, will not face state murder charges, prosecutors said.

title: The Editorial Notebook; So Where's the Daddy Track?
description: It's called the ''mommy track,'' The Times reported recently, and some law firms may even make it official. It's a new two-level system in legal work. Women are on the lower tier, as usual, but this time by hard choice: They're stepping off the fast track to have more time with their children.

title: Dissidents Gain Seats At Scherer
description: A proxy challenge against two directors of the R.P. Scherer Corporation was successful, election auditors said yesterday. That means five of the company's 11 directors support an effort by the largest shareholder to sell the company.

title: Boole & Babbage Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $3,458,000, or $1.03 a share, from the sale of a product family.

title: Robertson Rebuts Criticism in Dispute About Film
description: Pat Robertson defended himself yesterday against criticism that he had not spoken out against anti-Semitic statements in the protests against the movie ''The Last Temptation of Christ.''

title: Dow, in Strong Rebound, Rises 37.34
description: Stock prices rebounded strongly yesterday, lifting the Dow Jones industrial average back above the 2,000 mark.

title: Harcourt Sets Layoffs Of 750 at Theme Parks
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. is dismissing 750 workers at six of its theme parks around the nation in a cost-cutting move, company executives said today.

title: Foothill Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $363,000. c-Includes extraordinary gains of $45,000 and $90,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said all share net figures are fully diluted.

description: These are the main conclusions and recommendations of the report on the violence at Tompkins Square Park. Many of the proposals are now being put into effect, police officials say. The Breakdown in Command

description: Woman in the Dark A Novel of Dangerous Romance By Dashiell Hammett 76 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: Pan Am Faces Pension Outlay
description: Pan American World Airways Inc. has said that it might have to pay $119.1 million to cover its annual pension contributions for the fiscal years 1987 and 1988.

title: New York Extending Medicaid Eligibility and Shifting Services
description: In the first major expansion of New York State's Medicaid program in more than 20 years, the State Assembly today gave final passage to a bill that would extend eligibility to about 200,000 people who are living at the edge of poverty.

title: California Microwave Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss Year-ago results include a non- recurring writedown of $5.7 million, primarily as a result of restructuring the company telecommunications operations.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 15 about the new president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters misstated who was honored at a party sponsored by the union at the Democratic National Convention. It was Representative William L. Clay, Democrat of Missouri, not Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts.

title: Engineering Measurements Company reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest year's loss is primarily the result of a writeoff related to the bankruptcy and default by the buyer of Engineering Measurement's former traffic products division; the writeoff in legal expenses produced a loss of $839,000.

title: A Lily Sniffer's Heaven Is a Place Called B & D's
description: VISITORS to B & D Lilies on P Street in this cool coastal town on the Olympic Peninsula often make their way to the two-acre test field a few miles away. Here, they are free to wander up and down the tidy rows of lilies, B & D's catalogue in hand, checking off those they find especially appealing. They may even pick a few blossoms, since the owners, Bob and Dianna Gibson, don't mind. Certainly, they'll take a close look and a deep breath, savoring the rich and heady fragrance of white or pink or crimson or gold beauties.

title: Open Positions on Short Sales Decline by 0.5% on Nasdaq
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported a five-tenths of 1 percent monthly drop in the ''short interest'' for the most-active over-the-counter securities in its national market system.

title: Review/Dance; From Field Trips, a Mix Of Styles and Standpoints
description: It was ''tune up'' time at Performance Space 122 on Monday night when dancers and performance artists participating in the organization's annual Field Trips did an engaging preview performance of the show that will be seen, from Sept. 5 to Oct. 8, by audiences in San Diego, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Seattle, Milwaukee and Syracuse. The aim of the program is to present a variety of styles and perspectives, and it certainly has this year.

title: Yankees Win on 5 In Ninth
description: In a game in which Dennis Eckersley was shell-shocked and Gary Ward was shaking, the Yankees registered their most remarkable victory of the season yesterday, a 7-6 decision over the Oakland Athletics.

title: Mother and 2 Children Die in Syracuse Fire
description: A mother in a wheelchair and her two young children were killed this morning when fire tore through their tiny wood-frame house on the south side of Syracuse, the authorities said.

title: Employers Casualty Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $18,103 for the quarter and $426,017 for the 6 months. c-Includes capital gains of $3,829 and $4,379 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Hako Minuteman Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Central Reserve Life Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $57,738 and $82,128 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes capital gains of $134,413 for the quarter and $144,391 for the 6 months.

title: Computrac Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Horse Racing; Cordero to Appeal 10-Day Suspension
description: Angel Cordero Jr. today accused the Saratoga Race Track stewards of inconsistency and prejudice against him after he was handed a 10-day suspension for careless riding.

title: Hungarian Test-Tube Baby
description: Hungary's first test-tube baby was born today, the official press agency reported. The 6-pound-11-ounce girl was born at the Pecs Medical University maternity clinic in the south of the country.

title: Karajan Resigns From Salzburg Board
description: The conductor Herbert von Karajan, who last week canceled a performance at the Salzburg Music Festival because of illness, resigned on Thursday from the festival's board of directors.

title: Mediation Bid Seen in Polish Strikes
description: A prominent Roman Catholic scholar met today with Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader, in what appeared to be the first attempt at mediation between the Government and striking Polish workers.

title: Progress Reported in Talks on Angola Withdrawal
description: Diplomats reported progress today in talks to set a timetable for the withdrawal of 47,000 Cuban troops from Angola.

title: Albany Passes Numerous Bills Prior to Recess
description: New York's 211th legislative session took another lurching step toward conclusion this morning when the State Assembly, having resolved some long-outstanding issues and left others unresolved, recessed at 4:08 A.M.

title: Early Naming of a Strong Science Adviser Urged
description: Leaders of 23 science and engineering societies today urged the two Presidential candidates, Vice President Bush and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, to appoint a White House science adviser early in a new administration.

title: Dunkin' Donuts Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Contempt Charge Is Dropped In Donations Case in Florida
description: A judge today spared Maria DeSillers a jail sentence for contempt of court, ruling that she could not be ordered to surrender records and items bought with donations for a liver transplant for her son Ronnie, who has died.

title: Bush Hears Brzezinski
description: Once a national security adviser, always a national security adviser.

title: Evergood Products Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Results for the latest periods include the acquisitions of Great Earth International Inc. and the assets of Josu Inc.

title: Budapest Gets the Last Laugh on Moscow
description: LEAD: The Soviet Government under Mikhail S. Gorbachev is looking to Hungary as a model for reinvigorating its economy and pouring new life into a circulatory system threatened by ideological atherosclerosis. Does the Kremlin really know what it is in for?

title: Phonetel Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
O'Brien Learning To Avoid the Sack
description: For 27 straight games dating to 1986, including regular season, playoffs and exhibition, Ken O'Brien has been sacked at least once. Over the last three regular seasons he was dumped 152 times.

title: 1871 Rights Law Now Used for Many Causes
description: A 117-year-old Federal civil rights law, passed by a Reconstruction era Congress to protect former slaves from maltreatment by local officials, is becoming an ever more powerful tool for challenging a widening array of official actions that have nothing to do with race, from zoning decisions to bar admission requirements to state insurance laws.

title: Condominiums Divide Angry Tompkins Square Residents
description: As demonstrators confronted the police recently over the use of Tompkins Square Park in Manhattan's East Village, residents across the street in the Christadora House watched with the wariness of vulnerable strangers in their own neighborhood.

title: Eldon Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 9
description: Share earnings figures reflect a 25 percent stock dividend accounted for as a 5-for-4 stock split effected in July 1988.

title: Bonn Leads European Rate Rise
description: West Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank, led a series of Europe-wide interest rate increases today aimed at stopping the dollar's recent advance.

title: Diplomats Serve On the Front Lines
description: Arnold L. Raphel, the Ambassador to Pakistan, who was killed in a plane crash with President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq last week, was the 152d American diplomat since 1780 to lose his life while performing duties overseas, according to the State Department.

title: The News Corporation Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $4,624,000 from an extraordinary item for the quarter; the year includes a gain of $5,227,000 from an extraordinary item. c-Includes a gain of $300,095,000 and $303,064,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from an extraordinary item. Figures are in US dollars with revenues and income of Australian and United Kingdom operations converted at the average exchange rates for each period. Each ADR represents two of the company's ordinary shares. The company said that in the quarter and full-year periods, improved results were due to gains in United Kingdom, Australia and Pacific Basin, publishing operations, acquisitions in Australia and the Pacific Basin and foreign exchange trading gains. Profitability gains were moderated by higher interest expense, lower dividend income and lower profits for television stations, and filmed entertainment operations in the United States. Throughout the year a decline in minority interests helped offset a use in interest expense. Net income and extraordinary items declined from previous year levels due principally to the absence of significant asset sales and the new business start-up costs for the Fox Broadcasting Co. US operations in 1988 accounted for 42 percent and 40 percent of consolidated revenues and operating profit, respectively; revenues and operating profit of the United Kingdom represent 28 percent and 37 percent, respectively; and the Australian and Pacific Basin operations represent 30 percent and 23 percent, respectively.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''So the idea that you have to be long on the tooth to be qualified for the national ticket is one that I reject, speaking as one who is relatively long in the tooth these days.'' - Vice President Bush. [ D17:3. ]

title: Centercore Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company noted that sales for the latest periods included those from the Canadian and U.K. operations acquired in Mid-1987.

title: Some Tandy Work Will Leave Korea
description: The Tandy Corporation is moving some production out of its South Korean plant because of the ''general level of cultural change and political uncertainty'' in that country, the company's chairman, John Roach, said. The production will be shifted to company plants in Taiwan, he said. ''This does not mean we are getting out altogether,'' Mr. Roach said. Any future moves will depend on South Korea's level of stability.

title: Women in Law Can Be Mommies and Partners
description: To the Editor:

title: Sandra D. Flanagan Wed
description: At the Metropolitan Synagogue in New York, Sandra Daitch Flanagan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert B. Daitch of Harrison, N.Y., and Rancho Mirage, Calif., was married yesterday to George A. Degan, president of Degan Fabrics. Rabbi Joel S. Goor performed the ceremony. The bride's previous marriage ended in divorce, as did that of the bridegroom, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Morris Degan of New York. The bride's father, chairman of Daitch-Shopwell from 1962 to 1980, is a consultant to A.&P., which acquired Shopwell in 1986.

title: Running Out on Irangate
description: So short is the memory of public and press that George Bush rolled through the week of his Presidential nomination and out on the campaign trail without having to say a word about his part in the disastrous Irangate affair or display again his inability to remember much about it.

title: Lewis Will Run in Relay
