description: Carl Lewis, seeking to win four gold medals for the second consecutive Olympics, will definitely run on the 400-meter relay team, Stan Huntsman, the United States Olympic track coach, said today.

title: Nets Sign Morris
description: The Nets announced yesterday that they signed Chris Morris, their first-round pick in the National Basketball Association draft. Morris, a 6-foot-8-inch forward from Auburn, was the fourth pick over all in the draft. Although the terms of the contract were not announced, the length is expected to be four years. The Nets hope Morris will eventually replace Orlando Woolridge, the high-scoring forward who recently signed with the Los Angeles Lakers as a free agent. ''Having this contract put to bed early will let us all concentrate on basketball from now until the start of training camp,'' said Harry Weltman, the Nets' general manager. New Jersey opens camp on Oct. 7.

title: Fans Finding Out 'This Isn't Texas'
description: LEAD: Between 6,000 and 10,000 well-heeled devotees of the Nebraska and Texas A&M; football teams will begin painting New York red or maroon tonight in advance celebration of a victory in the Kickoff Classic tomorrow at Giants Stadium.

title: About Real Estate; Co-op Buyers Seek Deals In Flatbush Conversions
description: In the 1930's Flatbush was considered one of Brooklyn's most desirable residential neighborhoods. Its tree-bowered streets of roomy Dutch colonial homes and grand Georgian mansions also had six-story brick elevator buildings with apartments that reflected the same gracious style of living.

title: Review/Music; Gay Men's Chorus in a Mix of Sounds
description: The New York City Gay Men's Chorus left New York yesterday for a European tour - its first - that will take it to London, Amsterdam, Paris and Cologne, West Germany. As a combination final dress rehearsal and farewell concert, the ensemble tried out its program Wednesday evening at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, where it was rapturously received by an audience that substantially exceeded the church's capacity.

title: The Birthplace of the Hot Dog? Now Thereby Hangs a Tale
description: To the Editor:

title: Zydeco on the Water
description: A music cruise featuring Queen Ida and her Bon Temps Zydeco Band will close a summer jazz series aboard the Hudson River Dayliner tomorrow at 9 P.M. Queen Ida, whose real name is Ida Guillory, is an accordionist who specializes in zydeco, a combination of Cajun, Creole, jazz and rock music. In addition to the concert, there will be a Mardi Gras celebration, with costumes, masks and Cajun food. Tickets are $20 in advance or $22.50 tomorrow. Boarding begins at 8 P.M. Information: 399-4444 or 496-7070.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 The key figure in a spy ring that transferred secret NATO military documents to Soviet bloc agents was identified by West Germanany as a former United States Army sergeant living in West Germany. Page A1

title: Review/Film; Growing Up, and Into Baseball
description: You know what kind of girl she was. You probably know what kind of summer it was, too. The light was golden. The beach was clean. He was young and impressionable, she worldly and wise. Whenever he had trouble, she helped get him through, and because of that he can never forget her. Oh yes, he also had a friend, and the friend's every thought was of losing his virginity. There was an older woman on hand who (inevitably, in stories like this) was happy to oblige.

title: Foreign Abducters Held To Be Liable in the U.S.
description: In a decision applauded by human rights activists, a Federal district judge here has ruled that officials of foreign governments can be sued in American courts for the abduction and presumed killing of political opponents.

title: Inflation Eases in Mexico
description: Consumer price rises have continued to ease under a tough anti-inflation program, with an inflation rate of seven-tenths of 1 percent in the first half of August, the Bank of Mexico announced Wednesday. It predicted smaller increases in consumer prices for the remainder of the month once sales taxes are reduced and other measures taken under the Government's economic solidarity pact.

title: At the Movies
description: Investigative Director

title: Hotel Maxim's
description: Hongkong and Shanghai Hotels Ltd., the parent company of the Peninsula Group of hotels in Asia, said it had agreed to buy the Hotel Maxim's de Paris in New York, formerly the Gotham Hotel, for $127 million. The company said the hotel would be renamed the Peninsula, after a hotel of the same name in Hong Kong. The acquisition is the company's first acquisition in the United States. The 23-story hotel, at Fifth Avenue and 55th Street in Manhattan, contains 250 luxury rooms, including 31 suites. It is owned by a subsidiary of the Southmark Corporation.

title: Yonkers Panel Will Reconsider Housing Stance
description: The City Council will meet Friday under a Federal judge's order to reconsider its opposition to a court-ordered housing desegregation plan, but Councilmen fighting the order said they saw no hope of change.

title: Pauley Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said depreciation, depletion and amortization expenses increased in 1988 primarily as the result of the inclusion of Hondo Oil & Gas properties which became part of Pauley when it acquired all the outstanding shares of Hondo Oil & Gas in an exchange of Stock in January. The company said interest expense also increased as a result of the exchange and its subsequent acquisition of Fletcher Refinery in March. The company has not restated results for periods prior to the exchange, and therefore, figures for the current and prior fiscal years are not comparable.

title: On Stage
description: Singing for Others' Suppers

title: At The Bar
description: Black prosecutors, outsiders at the office and suspects at home, are struggling with painful times. White colleagues wonder if they are too sympathetic to black defendants; other blacks accuse them of complicity with a racist system.

title: The Long Heat Also Polluted the Air
description: The hot, stagnant air that engulfed the New York region for most of the summer created unusual amounts of smog and the highest levels of ozone, its main component, in a decade.

title: VCR Exports By Japan Fall
description: Exports of video cassette recorders from Japan fell to 1.84 million in July, from 1.88 million a year earlier, the fifth straight monthly decline compared with 1987, Finance Ministry statistics showed. Exports rose from 1.8 million in June.

title: A New Air Control Tower For Kennedy Is Approved
description: Construction of a new, 30-story control tower that officials say will greatly enhance air safety and slightly reduce flight delays at Kennedy International Airport was unanimously approved yesterday by the commissioners of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly LAW OF THE SEA - PREPARATORY COMMISSION - SPECIAL COMMISSIONS - 10 A.M. COUNCIL FOR NAMIBIA - 10 A.M.

title: Review/Pop; Armatrading at Pier 84
description: In some of Joan Armatrading's songs, love is a comfort and a refuge, a state of grace - just as in the vast majority of pop. For Miss Armatrading, though, love can also usher in a whole new set of tensions and uncertainties, from jealousy and loss to murderous rage.

title: Bentsen, Addressing V.F.W., Draws Cheers and Boos
description: Serving as military point man for the Democratic ticket, Senator Lloyd Bentsen went before the Veterans of Foreign Wars here today with a defense of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis on national security policy and an attack on the Republican candidates for making ''scurrilous charges.''

title: Arizona Instrument reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Zapata to Sell Unit For $153 Million
description: The Zapata Corporation has agreed to sell the assets of its Zapata Financial Services unit to Citicorp North America Inc. for $153 million. Zapata, a Houston-based company with interests in offshore drilling, marine services and fisheries development, said it also expects to sell the assets of its Zapata Automotive Leasing unit for about $37 million before Sept. 30. The company said it expected the sales would result in a $65 million gain.

title: Economic Scene; Looking Ahead In World Trade
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN, in signing the 1,000-page trade bill into law, declared that it would ''help us continue our efforts to open markets.'' He thus reversed his earlier veto of an almost identical trade bill. This time he went with those advisers who said the second bill, despite some flaws, was essential to expanding ''free and fair'' trade - and to protecting Republican Party interests in the coming Presidential and Congressional elections.

title: Specialty Equipment Cos reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The share earnings from the year- ago periods are not adjusted to include the 2.5 million shares sold in the company's initial public offering on July 2, 1987. Adjusted to reflect those shares, net per share would have been 37 cents in the year-ago second quarter and 70 cents in the year-ago 6 months.

title: BUSH IS CAUTIOUS ABOUT DEPLOYING A MISSILE DEFENSE
description: Vice President Bush has spelled out a cautious approach to the Strategic Defense Initiative, adopting a position that made him a less ardent advocate of the missile defense program than either President Reagan or some Republican conservatives, including his own running mate, Senator Dan Quayle.

title: Quayle's Wealth Shouldn't Be an Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Confrontation in Nicaragua

title: Ameriana Savings Bank of NY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $487,000 for the quarter and $589,000 for the 6 months, and losses on disposal of discontinued operations of $1,100,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income and includes income from discontinued operations of $340,000 and $373,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Ameriana Savings went public in February 1987.

title: Church Still a Thorn for Sandinistas
description: When Nicaragua's Roman Catholic bishops left last week to meet with Pope John Paul II in Rome, they were leaving behind a church that remained at the center of political conflict.

title: For the Next Drought, Crop Insurance
description: Federal relief for drought-devastated farmers was about as close to a sure thing as there is in American politics. Congress knew that with rising commodity prices promising substantial savings in regular farm support programs, even a generous bailout would not breach the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings anti-deficit law. And with the election just months away, both political parties were eager to curry favor with farm-state voters.

title: Detained Foe of Apartheid Is Hospitalized
description: A black member of a labor group that opposes apartheid has been admitted to a hospital in Johannesburg in serious condition after more than two years in detention under South Africa's emergency laws, the police said today.

title: Jersey's Funds For Schools Found Flawed
description: New Jersey's system of financing public education was declared constitutionally flawed today by a state administrative law judge who said it failed to eliminate financing disparities between affluent suburban and poor urban school districts.

title: Women in Law Can Be Mommies and Partners; Other Kinds of Practice
description: To the Editor:

title: Fabri-Centers of America Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
From Cool to Exultant, With a Touch of Blue; Lincoln Center Mixes Blues, Gospel and Folk
description: AT Lincoln Center this weekend, applied musicology should yield jubilant results -not inside the concert halls, but at a pair of free American music festivals outdoors in Damrosch Park. Tomorrow at noon, Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors will present its second annual Blues and Gospel Festival, with a set starting every hour from noon to 9 P.M. by performers including John Lee Hooker, Johnny Copeland, the Persuasions, John Cephas and Phil Wiggins and Sister Sadie and the Famous Biblettes. On Sunday, the fifth Folk Heritage Festival will do the same with traditional and new songs by cowboys, sailors, prisoners and city folk, performed by Christine Lavin, Oscar Brown Jr., Leon Bibb, Sylvia Tyson (formerly of Ian and Sylvia) and John Herald, and others. Listeners can trace for themselves the connections and innovations from style to style. Or they can just tap their toes and sing along as the spirit moves them.

title: Gulf Foes Open Direct Talks in Geneva
description: The Foreign Ministers of Iraq and Iran opened direct, face-to-face negotiations today aimed at consolidating their five-day-old cease-fire into a permanent peace settlement.

title: Louis Shere, Tax Researcher, 88
description: Louis Shere, a former director of tax research for the Federal Treasury Department and a retired Indiana University professor, died here Wednesday. He was 88 years old. Mr. Shere joined the university faculty in 1948 and taught courses in federal, state and local finance. He also taught special courses on the economies of underdeveloped nations.

title: Birthday Party for a 70-Year-Old Prodigy
description: Leonard Bernstein, far and away America's most famous classical musician, turned 70 years old today. And just as his entire career has been larger than life, so was his birthday party.

title: Owner of Social Club Charged in Six Fire Deaths
description: The owner and operator of an unlicensed Bronx social club where six people died in a fire Sunday was charged last night with six counts of manslaughter, the police said.

title: Barry Wright Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The latest quarter results include a charge of $2.2 million as a result of company restructuring. The latest 6-month figures include an after-tax provision of $3.1 million also the result of restructuring costs.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Market Place; Investors Look to Europe in '92
description: INVESTMENT fund managers with global portfolios are already looking to 1992, the year the European Community has chosen to remove its internal trade barriers. While there are strong doubts that the European nations will be able to adhere to their economic integration schedule, no one questions the direction in which Europe is headed or the assumption that the changes will have dramatic market consequences.

title: Yes, a Police Riot
description: New York City's Police Department deserves no praise for its handling of a demonstration in Tompkins Square Park in the early morning of Aug. 7. But Commissioner Ward and Police Department officials who prepared a report on the incident deserve credit for candor.

title: A Deficit That Will Avoid Spending Cuts Is Projected
description: The Reagan Administration predicted today that the budget deficit in the fiscal year 1989 would be $144 billion - low enough to avoid the automatic spending cuts that are specified by the Gramm-Rudman budget-balancing law.

title: TRW Pleads Guilty in 1984 Fraud Case
description: TRW Inc. ended a four-year grand jury investigation today by pleading guilty to Federal charges of conspiring to overcharge the Government on contracts involving military aircraft engines and parts for the M-1 tank.

title: Corrections
description: A dispatch from Moscow July 7 on a conference on exploration of Mars referred incorrectly to Titan Systems, Inc., of La Jolla, Calif. It is a subsidiary of the Titan Corporation of San Diego.

title: Our Towns; Read This Paper And Discard It? Heaven Forbid!
description: Thanks to an impressive international tour by the Islip garbage barge, followed by a summer of syringes in the sand, Long Island is now in a strong position to declare itself America's most interesting solid waste mess.

title: Nepalese City Digs Out After Quake
description: Shelters were being put up and battered buildings were being torn down today as residents, troops, the police and relief workers set about repairing this city, which was devastated by an earthquake on Sunday.

title: Forest Oil Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said in the year-ago 6-month preferred stock dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Campaign on Dropouts A First for Ad Council
description: The Council of State Governments, Lexington, Ky., has decided to try to lower the high school dropout rate by sponsoring a yearlong national ad campaign, with the help of the Advertising Council and Ashland Oil. The effort, which uses ads originally produced by Ashland Oil, is the first in which the Ad Council has used a corporate campaign as the basis for a nationwide public service campaign.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Amoco Chemicals Co., Chicago, said it had begun to increase capacity at its four polypropylene plants by 300 million pounds.

title: Order for Six Aircraft Gives Boeing a Record
description: An order for six 737-500's from Sweden's domestic airline has raised the number of aircraft ordered from the Boeing Company this year to a record 466.

title: Greece, the U.S. Bases and the Dukakis Factor
description: A frequent topic of conversation among officials here these days is the question of how Greek-American relations would be affected if Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts were elected President, a debate that is particularly pointed because of the prolonged talks over the future of American military bases here.

title: Merger Mania Strikes Europe As Barrier-Free Market Nears
description: Europe's staid industrialists long looked down on Wall Street's boisterous takeover scene as a financial Wild West. In recent months, however, Europe has been doing its best to imitate American merger mania.

title: Bogosian and Rivers Hone Acts At In-Town Tryouts
description: JOAN RIVERS prowls the stage of Michael's Pub and gleefully dishes the dirt. Narrowing her eyes and cackling with conspiratorial merriment, she pounces on flab, body hair and any possible blemishes on the perfect images of the rich and famous.

title: Graf Beats Hanika Very, Very Slowly
description: After one point, Steffi Graf sat in the corner in a chair reserved for the ball girls and fumed. Later, she blasted a ball so hard off the clay court that it bounced into the fifth row of the stands.

title: Pop/Jazz: From Cool to Exultant, With a Touch of Blue; 11 Days of Prime Jazz In Greenwich Village
description: THE 11-day Hennessy Village Jazz Festival, which opens today with a free concert at the Village Gate from 4:30 to 7 P.M., is less a festival than a celebration of the extraordinary state of workaday jazz life in Greenwich Village. Though there are free special events, the festival, which takes place mostly in clubs, points up the abundance of jazz that is to be found any week in the Village. There is no other neighborhood in the world that has the sort of concentration and quality of jazz featured there.

title: EX-U.S. SERGEANT CALLED KEY FIGURE IN ESPIONAGE RING
description: West German officials today identified a former United States Army sergeant living in West Germany as the key figure in an espionage network that transferred secret NATO military documents to Soviet-bloc agents.

title: Times Sees Profit Decline
description: The New York Times Company expects its third-quarter earnings to be lower than a year ago, it said yesterday. The company also disclosed that it had repurchased 2.5 million shares of its class A common stock so far this year and that it planned to buy back as much as 2 million more shares.

title: 8 Hurt in Revenge Shooting
description: A gunman in a car fired about 18 shots at a crowd outside a pool hall Wednesday, wounding eight people in an attack the police said was carried out in revenge for a gang shooting earlier this week. No arrests were made, and none of the witnesses could provide a description of the vehicle, Police Officer Ralph Askew said today. None of the victims was seriously injured.

title: Baseball; Reds' Rookie Stars In Debut
description: Keith Brown held St. Louis to four hits over seven innings tonight, winning his major league debut as the Cincinnati Reds beat the Cardinals, 4-1.

title: TV Weekend; Of MIG's, Bugs and a Spy With Feelings
description: Granted, ''Steal the Sky'' is nine parts hokum to one part history. But let's not quibble. The two-hour spy story on cable television's Home Box Office Sunday night at 9 has abundant Middle Eastern atmosphere, an appealing performance by Ben Cross as an Iraqi pilot who becomes the target of Israeli intelligence in the person of Mariel Hemingway, and a tense half-hour climax, deftly directed by John Hancock.

title: Sale Won't End Career Of Peltz Food's Owner
description: In the 1940's Robert B. Peltz used to spend Saturdays unloading crates of apples at his father's produce warehouse. He would earn $3 for moving 850 crates. ''I thought I was overpaid,'' Mr. Peltz remembered.

title: Oppenheimer Capital LP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Share earnings are in units. The partnership commenced operations July 9, 1987, so comparative figures are not available.

title: Dow Falls 15.82 as Trading Remains Light
description: LEAD: The stock market observed the anniversary of its historic peak with a broad decline. The Dow Jones industrial average, which reached 2,722.42 on Aug. 25, 1987, closed yesterday at 2,010.85, down 15.82 points.

title: Dining Out Guide: Cold Seafood Specials
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. Alcala **(March 18, 1988), 349 Amsterdam Avenue, at 77th Street (769-9600) - This is a warm and inviting place, with a long marble-topped tapas bar and an elevated brick-walled dining room. It's fun to start off at the tapas bar with its assortment of appetizers. Among the more intriguing tapas (the selection varies daily) are fresh anchovies in a vinegar-laced marinade; morsels of chewy octopus in a similar dressing with pimentos; tender golden rings of fried calamari, and rosy smoked trout over sliced cucumbers with dill. Entrees $14 to $20. Dinner, 5:30 P.M. to midnight Friday and Saturday. Closed Sunday. Cafe Luxembourg **(Aug. 5, 1988), 200 West 70th Street (873-7411) - This stylish and lively Art Deco dining room in the Lincoln Center area offers a seasonal menu that is cleverly orchestrated. An enticing summer starter is the lemony salad of cured red snapper brightened with a cilantro vinaigrette. Another possibility is marinated shrimp in a basil vinaigrette, served with an avocado mousse. Entrees $16 to $25. Dinner, 5:30 P.M. to 1:30 A.M. Friday and Saturday; 6 P.M. to 12:30 A.M. Sunday. Coastal **(June 12, 1987), 300 Amsterdam Avenue, at 74th Street (769-3988) -Somebody in the kitchen of this serious Upper West Side fish house knows how to cook fish and season it deftly. Among the appetizers worth trying is the trio of vibrant little ceviches: salmon nuggets in tomato concasse, citrus-marinated tuna with red pepper, and red snapper paired with matchsticks of fresh coconut, scallions and Tabasco. Entrees $12.50 to $21. Dinner, 6 P.M. to midnight Friday and Saturday; 5:30 to 10 P.M. Sunday. Gotham Bar and Grill **(Oct. 4, 1985), 12 East 12th Street (620-4020) - This restaurant features a spacious and comfortable multi-tier dining room, and a cooking approach that is contemporary, but not freewheeling. The seafood salad is one of the best in town. Arranged around a pretty fanned avocado is a sparkling abundance of mixed greens replete with squid rings, lobster, scallops, octopus slices and mussels. Tiny red beads of flying-fish roe add a lovely saline edge to the assembly. The entire combination is tossed in a lively olive oil-and-lemon vinaigrette. There are also a shellfish terrine consisting of prawns, scallops and lobster topped with creme fraiche, and marinated mackerel served with yellowfin potatoes. Entrees $24 to $28. Lunch, noon to 2:30 P.M. Friday; dinner, 6 to 11:30 P.M. Friday and Saturday; 5:30 to 10 P.M. Sunday. John Clancy's **(March 11, 1988), 181 West 10th Street (242-7350) - This is a graceful Greenwich Village restaurant, with a step-down main dining room and bar, whitewashed brick walls and pastel garden prints. As a refreshment in these warm summer days, the chef prepares a cold whole lobster, cracked and served in its shell alongside a salad that varies from day to day: orzo, wild rice or cherry tomatoes with a scallion vinaigrette. Entrees $17.50 to $28.50. Dinner, 6 to 11:30 P.M. Friday and Saturday; 5 to 10 P.M. Sunday. The Sea Grill **(May 20, 1988), 19 West 49th Street (Rockefeller Center) (246-9201) - This restaurant offers a sophisticated subterranean setting facing a graceful outdoor cafe (the skating rink in winter). The chef's style is reflected in a sparkling appetizer called medallions of lobster tartar. The barely steamed lobster meat is coarsely chopped and arranged over spokes of endive and garnished with strips of sun-dried tomatoes and fresh tarragon, then drizzled with extra-virgin olive oil and lemon. Entrees $26 to $27.50. Lunch, noon to 3 P.M. Friday; brunch, noon to 3 P.M. Saturday; dinner, 5 to 11 P.M. Friday and Saturday. Closed Sunday.

title: Lori Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $4,414,000 for the quarter and $4,724,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $976,000 and $1,074,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and the quarter also includes a tax charge of $802,000.

title: Homefree Village Resorts reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Support for Barkley
description: One week after Charles Barkley of the Philadelphia 76ers was arrested on a gun charge on the Atlantic City Expressway, the owner of the 76ers said yesterday that Barkley had his full support.

title: Charge Against Tyson Dropped
description: Mitch Green, the fighter who said he was punched by Mike Tyson in a street fight early Tuesday in Harlem, withdrew assault charges yesterday against the heavyweight champion.

title: Two Agents Plead Not Guilty
description: Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom, the two agents accused of racketeering, mail fraud and extortion in connection with their contracts with college athletes, pleaded not guilty yesterday at their arraignment in Federal District Court in Chicago. Their attorneys said they would mount a vigorous defense challenging the Government's theory of fraud in the case.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of money market funds rose $369 million, to $269.1 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Institutional funds rose in value by $456 million, to $69.68 billion; general purpose funds increased by $17.6 million, to $85.37 billion, and broker-dealer funds fell by $104 million, to $114 billion.

title: AIDS Vaccine to Be Tested on Volunteers in U.S.
description: An experimental AIDS vaccine made with a genetically altered version of the virus used in smallpox vaccinations will soon be tested on volunteers at six university medical centers, the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases has announced.

title: Linda L. Holland Marries Dr. Eric Spellman, Dentist
description: Linda Levine Holland, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joshua Levine of Rye, N.Y., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married last evening to Dr. Eric H. Spellman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney Spellman of Mount Vernon, N.Y., and Pompano Beach, Fla. Rabbi Leonard H. Poller officiated at the Hampshire Country Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Moscow Journal; Having Western Cake Isn't the Same as Eating It
description: The Astro Pizza truck was parked by the Moscow River this week, selling its genuine American pizza, when Anatoly Bogdanov, smartly dressed and feeling a bit hungry, walked up to the window and dropped his rubles on the counter. ''Two slices, please,'' he said. ''Sorry,'' the clerk said. ''Only hard currency today.''

title: Article 077388 -- No Title
description: In winning its bitter, protracted battle to acquire Farmers Group Inc., B.A.T. Industries has fulfilled its goal to lessen its reliance on tobacco holdings, while the $5.2 billion deal may spur more takeover activity in the insurance industry, analysts said today.

title: Money for North
description: By dialing an 800 number, a person can make a non-deductible contribution by check, charge or money order to the North Defense Trust, a fund established by former United States Naval Academy classmates of Oliver L. North, the star of last summer's Iran-contra hearings.

title: Astro-Med Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: The company said year-ago results are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split on Aug. 15.

title: Women in Law Can Be Mommies and Partners; Pity the Poor Daddies
description: To the Editor:

title: CBI Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Barnwell Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Percy Foreman, Texas Lawyer, 86; Defended the Assassin of Dr. King
description: Percy Foreman, the flamboyant lawyer who defended James Earl Ray in the assassination of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., died yesterday at Methodist Hospital in Houston. He was 86 years old.

title: Adage Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-After a tax credit of $65,000.

title: New Dorm at Columbia Means Diversity
description: Columbia University opens a handsome 417-bed dormitory today that officials say symbolizes the completion of a dream, a national student body. But it also means Columbia's undergraduate college will take in far fewer students from the New York metropolitan region.

title: Dukakis Makes Sharpest Attack On Administration's Drug Policies
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis denounced the Reagan Administration's drug policies today as ''criminal'' and ''absurd,'' making his strongest statements yet on an emotional issue that has been central to the 1988 Presidential campaign.

title: KEY RATES
Story on Mrs. Dukakis Is Denied by Campaign
description: Michael Dukakis's Presidential campaign, responding to comments by Senator Steve Symms, an Idaho Republican, issued a statement Wednesday saying any suggestion that Kitty Dukakis had ever burned an American flag was ''totally false and beneath contempt.''

title: Books of The Times; China and Africa: Trade, a Void and a Crusade
description: The Star Raft China's Encounter With Africa. By Philip Snow 250 pages. Illustrated. Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $19.95.

title: Kabul Residents See Salvation in Zia's Death
description: In Kabul's dusty bazaars and in Government offices, the death of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan has been welcomed as a turning point in the Afghan war.

title: Review/Art; After Old China's Values Crumbled
description: Modern Chinese painting has not had much of an audience in the West. It does not have the mastery or breadth of the Song and Ming Dynasty paintings with which Chinese art is largely identified. However confident, it is groping. It cannot reassure the ever more atomized West, as older Chinese painting and sculpture can, of the holistic potential of art. Nor can it respond to a current need to believe that a civilization can indeed exist in which art does not have to fight for its place and in which the lessons of the past matter.

title: U.S. Agents Seize Files In California Statehouse
description: Armed with search warrants, Federal agents spread through the state Capitol in Sacramento late Wednesday night and seized numerous documents from the offices of six California legislators.

title: West Bank Villager Is Killed by Other Arabs
description: A Palestinian man was dragged from his West Bank home and hacked to death by a gang of Arabs today.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with The Doctor's World column in Science Times Tuesday misidentified a rare, fatal reaction to general anesthesia. It is malignant hyperthermia.

title: Medical Tests for Greek Chief
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou went to London today for medical tests after being diagnosed as having a hardening of the aorta, the Government announced. The Government spokesman, Sotiris Kostopoulos, said Mr. Papandreou, 69 years old, was advised to go abroad for further treatment after being admitted to a hospital in Athens for tests two days ago. He denied reports that Mr. Papandreou was to undergo bypass surgery.

title: Review/Film; Costa-Gavras's 'Betrayed,' the World of Bigotry
description: When a widowed Midwestern farmer named Gary Simmons (Tom Berenger) falls in love with a demure young newcomer named Katie Phillips (Debra Winger), he wants her to know everything about his world. So he takes her camping and hunting, but these prove not to be ordinary recreational outings. The campsite is at a white-supremacist outpost in Montana, where vacationers dress in Ku Klux Klan robes and burn crosses as they gather to sing ''Amazing Grace.'' And at the hunt, which takes place at night and employs vicious dogs and live ammunition, the prey is a terrified black man.

title: Grand Central Versus Trump On Trash Site
description: The operators of Grand Central Terminal revealed plans yesterday to improve sanitation around the dowdy old station by expanding a loading dock and garbage-collection site - next to the Grand Hyatt Hotel.

title: Storm Batters Cameroon
description: Torrential rains battered the northern town of Kousseri on Wednesday, killing one person and leaving more than 1,000 homeless, the Cameroon radio said today. The four-hour downpour destroyed 315 houses of mud and thatch, the radio said.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Miles and McLaughlin

title: Home Resales Fell 5% in July
description: Sales of existing single-family homes fell 5 percent in July as mortgage rates moved higher, a real estate trade group reported today. It was the first decline in six months. The National Association of

title: Colorado Prime Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
Quayle's Wealth Shouldn't Be an Issue; Doing the Best
description: To the Editor:

title: Perkin-Elmer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes income of $2.8 million and $11.7 million for the quarter and year, respectively, from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and includes income of $2.6 million and $6.5 million for the quarter and year, respectively, from discontinued operations; and also includes a pretax restructuring charge of $65.2 million and $73.3 million for the quarter and year, respectively. Backlog at July 31 was $373.8 million versus $402.6 million at July 31, 1987. The company said net income includes the earnings of Concurrent Computer Corp. as a discontinued operation. The company, which holds 82 percent of Concurrent's stock, previously reported that it would tender its shares in Concurrent to Massachusetts Computer Corp. under a tender offer.

title: National Bank of Canada reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a charge of a $276,000,000 provision for losses on LDC loans. Figures are in Canadian funds. Assets at July 31 were $30.67 billion versus $30.33 billion.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Rudder at the Ritz

title: Corrections
description: A headline in some copies on Aug. 14 on an obituary of Elmo R. Zumwalt 3d, whose father ordered the spraying of Agent Orange in Vietnam, mischaracterized the younger Mr. Zumwalt's experience with the defoliant when he served there. He was exposed to it but said he could not prove that exposure was responsible for his illnesses.

title: Angels Cut Presence On 46th St.
description: Nearly three months ago, the Guardian Angels swept into Restaurant Row on 46th Street in Manhattan amid headlines and controversy.

title: Skipper Rejected Help With Refugees, Navy Says
description: A Navy ship bound for a nearby port was in the area and offered to help when another American warship assisted but did not rescue a boatload of Vietnamese refugees in the South China Sea in June, Navy officials said today.

title: Japan's Rules On Chocolate
description: Japan should eliminate barriers that restrict American chocolate manufacturers from promoting their products in that country, the chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee said in letters to trade officials of the two countries. In the letters, Representative

title: Senator Quayle: Just a Creature of His Times
description: LEAD: Senator Dan Quayle is being portrayed as virtually unique in having both supported the Vietnam War and found a way to avoid combat. Actually, he was the rule in the Vietnam era, not the exception.

title: Yanks' Nemesis Does It Again
description: The rainout here three weeks ago precipitated an entire array of discomforting changes for the Yankees. Schedules were shuffled. Travel arrangements were reworked, and an expected day off evaporated in an instant. It left both plans and people upset.

title: Continental Graphics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company attributed the decline in earnings primarily to lower operating income from the film services segment and an increase in corporate expenses incurred by becoming a publicly held company as of July 30, 1987.

title: Review/Art; A Forgotten Pioneer in Completely Abstract Painting
description: Manierre Dawson's brief painting career is one of the forgotten cul-de-sacs of 20th-century art history, one that the small exhibition of his paintings on view at the Whitney Museum of American Art shines light into, without completely illuminating.

title: Steven Kletz Married To Diane Spiro on L.I.
description: Diane Ruth Spiro, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Spiro of Kings Point, L.I., was married last evening to Steven Kletz, the son of Blanche Kletz of New York and the late Sidney Kletz. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson, assisted by Cantor David Benedict, performed the ceremony at the Spiro home.

title: Rail Bailout Is Set
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge has approved a $14 million state bailout of the Chicago, Missouri & Western Railway. Two of the railroad's creditors, Citicorp and Heller Financial Inc., which are owed more than $100 million, had opposed the rescue plan, which involves a package of grants and loans, and had sought to have the railroad shut down and its assets sold.

title: Merger Mania Strikes Europe as Barrier-Free Market Nears
description: Europe's staid industrialists long looked down on Wall Street's boisterous takeover scene as a financial Wild West. In recent months, however, Europe has been doing its best to imitate American merger mania.

title: Crowds Throng Streets in Burma, Pressing Rulers to Step Down Now
description: With the Burmese Government in retreat, hundreds of thousands of jubilant demonstrators filled the streets of Rangoon again today, demanding that the nation's leaders step aside without the slow formalities proposed on Wednesday, diplomats and other witnesses said.

title: A Doctor Aiding Illegal Adoption Is Given a Delay
description: The sentencing of a Manhattan physician who pleaded guilty to unlawfully aiding Joel B. Steinberg and Hedda Nussbaum in an adoption was postponed yesterday after a Criminal Court judge said he needed more time to consider the case.

title: Detective Says Suspect in Officer's Death Denied Bumping Shooter
description: A 23-year-old Brooklyn man accused of manslaughter in the shooting of a police officer last week told a detective later that he did not push or touch a sergeant who fired the fatal shot, according to court testimony yesterday.

title: Chile's Curbs Go but the Candidate Stays
description: By lifting the restrictions on civil liberties under which Chileans have lived for nearly 15 years, Chile's military Government has taken a step toward creating the open electoral environment it has promised for the coming presidential plebiscite.

title: Auctions
description: Last October, right after Black Monday, experts predicted that contemporary art would be the first domino on the auction market to fall. Their reasoning: the significant number of ''new money'' buyers that had come to dominate the field. ''I thought we'd all be going on a very long vacation,'' recalled Allan Stone, a New York dealer.

title: Bolar Pharmaceutical Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Once Again, the Poles Rise in Protest
description: They rise and are beaten down.

title: Sydney Symphony to Make U.S. Debut
description: The Sydney Symphony Orchestra will give 13 concerts in the United States in October and November, with Dame Joan Sutherland as the guest soloist for three concerts. The orchestra, under the direction of Stuart Challender, its chief conductor, will begin the tour in Los Angeles on Oct. 16, and will end it on Nov. 6 in Manhattan, Kan. It will be the Australian ensemble's first visit to this country.

title: Where the Clubs Are and All That Jazz
description: The Hennessy Village Jazz Festival begins today and runs through Sept. 5 at various clubs in the area. For ticket information, call individual clubs. A pass, available for $15 at Sweet Basil and the Village Gate, will allow 50 percent off the music charge for the first and second sets during the festival; table minimums, if any, will apply. Some of the clubs are offering third sets free to pass holders. Here is a schedule of events and locations. Today 4:30 TO 7 P.M. Village Gate, 160 Bleecker Street (475-5120). Free opening concert with the Ron Carter Quintet, the Kenny Barron Quintet, the Bob Berg and Mike Stern Quartet, Take 6, Junior Mance and Marty Rivera, and the Dirty Dozen Brass Band. At 9:30 P.M. Downstairs: Dirty Dozen Brass Band (through Sunday). At 10 P.M. On the terrace: Junior Mance and Marty Rivera (every night). 8 P.M. Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (533-7902). Chico Hamilton Quartet. Through Sunday. 9:30 P.M. Arthur's Tavern, 57 Grove Street (675-6879). Mabel Goodwin, Freddie Francis and Mellisa Slocum. (Also tomorrow and next Thursday through Sept. 3.) 9:30 P.M. Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at 10th Street (982-3260). Ahmad Jamal Trio. Through Sunday. Also: exhibition of Milt Hinton's jazz photography. 9:30 P.M. Village Corner, Bleecker Street and La Guardia Place (473-9762). Lance Hayward and Jim Roberts. (Also tomorrow.) 9:30 P.M. Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at Perry Street (255-4037). Don Cherry Quartet (through Sunday). 9:30 P.M. Visiones, 125 Macdougal Street (673-5576). Michael Formanek Quartet with John Abercrombie. 9:45 P.M. Bradley's, 70 University Place (228-6440). Barry Harris. Also tomorrow. 10 P.M. Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, at Bleecker Street (242-1785). Abdullah Ibrahim (Dollar Brand) with Ekaya (through Sunday). 10 P.M. 55 Bar, 55 Christopher Street (929-9883). Hico Band. Tomorrow 2 P.M. Sweet Basil. Eddie Chamblee Quartet. (Also Sept. 3.) 2 TO 6 P.M. Village Gate. N.Y.U. Jazz Jam. (Also Sept. 3.) 7:30 TO 11 P.M. Steamboat Jazz Cruise, on the DeWitt Clinton, Pier 16, Fulton Street and the East River (406-3434). Take 6, with the Rodney Jones Quartet. 8 AND 10 P.M. Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street (242-1785). Artist-sponsored concert series, with the Errol Parker Septet. 9:30 P.M. Visiones. Mike Freeman Quartet. 10 P.M. 55 Bar. Mark Barish Trio. Sunday 1:30 TO 6 P.M. Carlos 1. Vinnie Knight and Friends. (Also Sept. 4.) 2 TO 6 P.M. Village Gate. New School Jazz Jam. (Also Sept. 4.) 3 P.M. Sweet Basil. Doc Cheatham. (Also Sept. 4.) 8 P.M. Cat Club, 76 East 13th Street (713-5148). George Gee and his Make Believe Ballroom Orchestra. 9:30 P.M. Arthur's Tavern. Freddie Francis Trio. (Also Sept. 4.) 9:30 P.M. Village Corner. Lance Hayward and Frank Kimbrough. 9:30 P.M. Visiones. Jim Pepper Quartet. 9:45 P.M. Bradley's. Red Mitchell and Bill Mays. (Through Sept. 3.) 10 P.M. #55 Bar. Lene Stern Band with Wayne Krantz. Monday 8 P.M. Fat Tuesday's. Les Paul Trio. (Also Sept. 5.) 9:30 P.M. Arthur's Tavern. Grove Street Stompers. (Also Sept. 5.) 9:30 P.M. Carlos 1. Hamiet Bluiett Telepathic Orchestra. (Also Sept. 5.) 9:30 P.M. Village Gate. Salsa Meets Jazz. (Also Sept. 5.) 9:30 P.M. Village Vanguard. Mel Lewis Big Band. (Also Sept. 5.) 9:30 P.M. Visiones. Bill Warfield Big Band. 10 P.M. Sweet Basil. Dakota Staton. 10 P.M. 55 Bar. Mike Stern Trio. Tuesday 4 TO 7 P.M. Sweet Basil. Jon Ballantyne Trio. 8 P.M. Fat Tuesday's. George Coleman Quartet (through Sept. 4). 9:30 P.M. Arthur's Tavern. Al Bundy. Also Wednesday. 9:30 P.M. Carlos 1. Henry Butler and Alvin Batiste Quartet (through Sept. 4). 9:30 P.M. Village Corner. Lance Hayward and Jim Roberts. 9:30 P.M. Village Gate. Dr. John and the Louisiana Luminoids (through Sept. 4). 9:30 P.M. Village Vanguard. Illinois Jacquet Big Band (through Sept. 4). 9:30 P.M. Visiones. Geovanni Arencibia and Sunrise. 10 P.M. Sweet Basil. John Scofield Trio, with Terri Lyne Carrington and Anthony Cox (through Sept. 4). 10 P.M. 55 Bar. Paul Sullivan and Stomu Takashi. Wednesday 4 TO 7 P.M. Sweet Basil. Jed Levy Quintet, with Peter Leitch, Peter Madsen, Ray Drummond and Billy Hart; and the Rob Schneiderman Group, with Slide Hampton. 8 P.M. Greenwich House. Nana Simopoulos Group, with Mark Joseflberg, Chip Jackson and Cristos Gopsinas. 9:30 P.M. Village Corner. Jim Roberts and Frank Kimbrough. 9:30 P.M. Visiones. Ray Anderson Quartet. (Also Thursday.) 10 P.M. 55 Bar. Mike Stern Trio. Thursday 4 TO 7 P.M. Sweet Basil. Uli Lenz, with Cecil McBee and Joe Chambers. 8 P.M. Greenwich House. Walter Thompson Ensemble, with Frank London, Tomas Ulrich, Joe Fonda and Hollis Headrick. 10 P.M. 55 Bar. Esther Blue. Sept. 2 9:30 P.M. Visiones. Bobby Previte Quartet. 10 P.M. 55 Bar. Burr Johnson Sept.3 8 TO 11 P.M. Steamboat Jazz Cruise, with Harlem Blues and Jazz Band. 9:30 P.M. Visiones. Gust William Tsilis Quartet, with Peter Madsen, Mike Formanek, Bill Stewart and Joe Lovano. 10 P.M. 55 Bar. Jim Mason Quartet, with John Mosca. Sept. 4 9:30 P.M. Visiones. Mitch Forman Quartet. 9:45 P.M. Bradley's. Red Mitchell and Kenny Barron. (Also Sept. 5.) 10 P.M. 55 Bar. David Tronzo, Haze Greenfield, Phil Arnold, Richard Weller, Joe Gallant, Lene Stern. Sept. 5 2 TO 6 P.M. Sweet Basil. Swing, Brother, Swing, with Harold Osley, Benny Powell, John Gordon, Ernest Hayes, Jimmy Lewis, Kalil Madi and Eddie Chamblee. At 10 P.M., Art Blakey and the Jazz Messengers. 9:30 P.M. Village Corner. Jim Roberts. 10 P.M. 55 Bar. Mike Rabinowitz Quartet.

title: Jack Henry & Associates reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said Finser Capital Corp. and its subsidiaries are included since their acquisition in November 1986.

title: No Surprises in Draw
description: Steffi Graf, trying to win her first United States Open title and complete a Grand Slam of the four major tournaments in a calendar year for the first time since Margaret Court did it in 1970, yesterday was seeded first for the tournament, which will begin Monday at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Queens.

title: Nystrom Shifted; Sutter Re-signs
description: Bob Nystrom, who played 14 seasons with the Islanders and was the team's assistant coach last season, is moving from behind the bench into the front office.

title: Daniel Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss Results for the latest 9-month include a pretax charge of $5,375,000 from discontinued operations.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; At Last, a Second Issue Of Memories Magazine
description: After a nine-month hiatus since its premiere, Memories magazine, a Diamandis Communications publication that re-examines popular events of the last half-century, is coming out with its second issue, dated Oct. 11. In addition, it has called on Gregory G. Coleman, formerly vice president, national ad manager at Diamandis's Woman's Day, to take on the job of vice president, publisher.

title: Economic Growth Even Stronger, But So Is Inflation, Revision Shows
description: The nation's economic growth during the spring was stronger than previously reported, despite the depressing effect of the drought. With the growth, however, came the specter of inflation.

title: Who Will Be There, and When
description: The second annual Blues and Gospel Festival is scheduled for tomorrow and the fifth annual Folk Heritage Festival is set for Sunday at Lincoln Center, as part of the 18th Out-of-Doors festival. All events are free and will take place at Damrosch Park. Information: 877-2011. Tomorrow NOON. Sister Sadie and the Famous Biblettes. 1 P.M. Little Buster and the Soul Brothers. 2 P.M. Daryle Ryce. 3 P.M. Richard (Big Boy) Henry. 4 P.M. Chris Cain Band. 5 P.M. John Cephas and Phil Wiggins. 6 P.M. Gospel Christian Singers. 7 P.M. The Persuasions. 8 P.M. Johnny Copeland. 9 P.M. John Lee Hooker. Sunday NOON. Sally Rogers and Howard Bursen. 1 P.M. Sotavento. 2 P.M. Cindy Kallet. 3 P.M. Horse Sense. 4 P.M. Laurie Lewis and the Grant Street Band. 5 P.M. Schooner Fare. 6 P.M. Leon Bibb. 7 P.M. Christine Lavin. 8 P.M. Sylvia Tyson and John Herald. 9 P.M. Oscar Brown Jr.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Joseph P. Maggio, Interior Designer, 61
description: Joseph P. Maggio, who owned a design firm bearing his name in Manhattan, died of a heart attack last Saturday at his home in South Egremont, Mass. He was 61 years old.

title: The Shadow of the Beast
description: Like Yeats's rough beast in ''The Second Coming,'' apostles of political murder are slouching back into view. The State Department reports that terrorist incidents worldwide climbed to 832 last year, a 7 percent jump. The precision is misleading, since there's no rule for distinguishing one person's ''terrorist'' from another's ''freedom fighter.''

title: CDI Corporation reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a $7,639,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Agassi Advances: Andre Agassi, ranked fourth in the world, rallied to beat unseeded David Pate, 6-7, 6-4, 6-4, in a first-round match of the $190,000 Norstar Hamlet Challenge Cup tournament yesterday in Jericho, L.I. Yannick Noah of France, seeded fourth, also advanced by beating unseeded Slobodan Zivojinovic of Yugoslavia, 6-3, 6-7, 6-3, in the completion of a first-round match suspended by rain Wednesday night. (AP) Krishan Gains: Second-seed Ramesh Krishan of India advanced to the quarterfinals of the $123,400 Nynex Open in Rye Brook, N.Y., with a 6-2, 6-1 victory over 15-year-old Tommy Ho. LITTLE LEAGUE Taiwanese Team in Final: Fong-An Tsai scattered six hits and hit a three-run home run as Tai Chung, Taiwan, rolled to a 16-1 victory over Glace Bay, Nova Scotia, and advanced to the final against Pearl City, Hawaii, in the Little League World Series in Williamsport, Pa. Tsai struck out 12 and walked 2.(AP)

title: Dillon Acquisition
description: The Dillon Companies, a supermarket chain based in Hutchinson, Kan., said its Kwik Shop Inc. subsidiary had agreed to buy forty-six 7-Eleven convenience stores from the Southland Corporation, based in Dallas. Terms were not disclosed. Dillon, a unit of the Kroger Company, said it would operate the stores as part of its Kwik Shop chain.

title: Gillette Secures Big Credit Line
description: The Gillette Company said it had secured $1.2 billion in credit for the stock repurchase program it created as part of a settlement with a dissident shareholder group that had tried to take control of the company.

title: Blasius Renews Fight for Atlas
description: Blasius Industries said today that it intends to solicit consents from shareholders of the Atlas Corporation in a renewed attempt to gain control of the natural resources concern based in Princeton, N.J.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Middle Eastern

title: Harriet Blacker Is Married To M. E. Harlib, Executive
description: The marriage of Harriet Blacker, a daughter of Rebecca Blacker of Plainview, L.I., and the late Louis Blacker, to Matthew E. Harlib, the son of Yetta Harlib of Westport, Conn., and the late Abraham Harlib, took place last evening at the Tavern on the Green in New York. Rabbi Joel S. Goor performed the ceremony.

title: Glenex Industries Inc reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $4,717,097 from the sale of Hal Roach Entertainment Inc. common stock and tax credits. c-Includes a gain of $4,918,883 from the sale of Hal Roach and tax credits. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Elway Injured As Broncos Win
description: John Elway passed for two touchdowns to Ricky Nattiel before leaving the game with a strained right shoulder, leading the Denver Broncos past the Indianapolis Colts, 21-20, tonight.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Tough Year For Harper's Bazaar
description: FASHION is fickle, and so is fashion advertising. One recent result has been hard times at Harper's Bazaar. Once the solid No. 2 magazine behind Vogue, it now trails Elle as well.

title: Interphase Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Nevada's High Court Allows Suit on Rock Band's Lyrics
description: The Nevada Supreme Court refused today to dismiss a lawsuit charging that a fan of the British rock band Judas Priest committed suicide and another injured himself because of the group's lyrics.

title: Bush Transcript on 'Star Wars'
description: Following is the transcript of Vice President Bush's statements on the Strategic Defense Initiative in an interview on his campaign plane Wednesday evening:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the Polaroid Corporation misstated the plans of Milton S. Dietz, a senior vice president. He is not among a group of executives who have agreed to leave the company as part of an early retirement plan. The number of executives planning to leave under the plan was also misstated. It is 7 of the company's 27 officers.

title: Britain's Interest Rates Raised to 2 1/2-Year High
description: The British Government, trying to curb inflation, pushed up interest rates today to a two-and-a-half-year high after announcing a record trade deficit for July that was almost double the previous record.

title: Gambling Up In Nevada
description: Gamblers lost a record $4.07 billion in casinos in Nevada in the 1988 fiscal year, a 9.8 percent gain in revenue from the previous year, the Gaming Control Board reported today.

title: Review/Film; A Detective Who Just Won't Wait
description: Chuck Norris's big problem in ''Hero and the Terror'' is that he is a police detective who never waits for his backup. As Danny O'Brien, his life is full of other unlikely complications: he feels guilty about undeserved heroism; his pregnant girlfriend, who used to be his psychiatrist, won't marry him; his best friend is killed by a serial murderer just waiting to get Danny next. And the script he lives in seems so perfect for Charles Bronson that the audience wouldn't blink if Mr. Bronson jumped out shooting from behind a parked car. But Danny's big problem is that he's too stupid and impatient to wait for help.

title: YELLOWSTONE FIRE NEARS SCENIC AREA
description: Brisk winds carried a 108,300-acre forest fire over defensive lines today, fanning flames to within less than half a mile of one of Yellowstone National Park's most scenic areas and forcing officials to close the park's west entrance.

title: Sharper Image reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income The company said comparable store sales decreased 5.9 percent for the second quarter. The company attributed the latest second quarter loss to continued lower merchandise margins and higher selling and occupancy expense.

title: Selma, Landmark of Rights Drive, In Racial Split Over Mayoral Vote
description: The Selma City Council is deadlocked along racial lines on whether to certify the election of Mayor Joe Smitherman to a seventh term, with his black challenger asserting that the Mayor is a ''dictator'' who stole the election.

title: Bay Financial Corp reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The company said latest year revenue includes gains on disposition of investment of $4,279,935. The company changed its fiscal year-end to June 30 from May 31, so comparable year-ago figures are not available. The company noted that in its fiscal year ended May 31, 1987, it recorded a loss of $8,161,000 on revenue of $43,079,000, which included gains on disposition of investment of $10,829,750.

title: Red Cross Seeks Unity
description: The American Red Cross, according to its president, Richard F. Schubert, is beginning a campaign to persuade the International Red Cross organization to accept Israel's Magen David Adom - Red Shield of David -as a full member.

title: Texas Instruments Endorsement Seen
description: Texas Instruments Inc. will announce next week that it is endorsing a computer design based on a standard promoted by Sun Microsystems Inc., several industry executives said.

title: Two Groups in Rightist Bloc Form a Single Party in Israel
description: The two main political parties that make up Israel's right-wing Likud bloc formally merged into a single party today in advance of elections on Nov. 1.

title: Clairson International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
description: b-Net income The company went public in November 1986, which ended its S Coporation status. Year-ago net is presented pro- forma as if the company accrued an income tax liability prior to the public offering.

title: Poll Shows Bush in Lead
description: A Washington Post/ABC News Poll published today showed Vice President Bush leading Michael S. Dukakis by 48 percent to 46 percent, with Mr. Bush gaining ground especially among political independents and young people.

title: Coe Withdraws
description: Sebastian Coe, the British runner, said yesterday that he would no longer consider the needs of the national team in his training. ''I have to accept the fact that the door has been closed by the British board on my international career,'' Coe said in West Berlin, where he was to run in the International Amateur Athletic Federation-Mobil Grand Prix final. ''I am not bitter, but it is a disappointment.''

title: For Blacks at Least, Atlanta Is Still Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Benafuels Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: World of Advantage Made a Sturdy Ladder for Quayle to Climb to Success
description: When George Bush selected his running mate last week, his aides said he aimed for an attractive young conservative with no political baggage built up from long exposure to national politics - a sort of Jack Kemp without Jack Kemp.

title: Restaurants
description: My reacquaintance with the Post House could not have come at a more propitious moment: just after a trip to northern California, where I was confronted with such ghastly combinations as sweetbreads with orange sections and red snapper with blueberries. From Kennedy Airport, I went straight to this eight-year-old East Side steakhouse craving meat and potatoes.

title: Harvard Catches 'Fenway Fever'
description: As the Boston Red Sox struggle in a tight pennant race, some of their biggest fans are toiling equally hard inside ivy-covered walls, calculating the likelihood of victory in October.

title: Ex-Senator Price Daniel, 77, Dies; Was Texas Governor for 3 Terms
description: Price Daniel, a former Governor of Texas and former United States Senator from Texas, who served along with Lyndon B. Johnson in the 1950's, died of a stroke yesterday at his ranch in Liberty, Tex. He was 77 years old.

title: Forschner Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest quarter and 6 months reflect additional $100,000 tax charge for prior year taxes.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday THE SOUNDS OF WANING

title: Takeshita Seeking China Trade
description: Japan's Prime Minister, Noboru Takeshita, arrived in China today for his first state visit, amid wary hopes in the Japanese business community that an elusive prize - access to China's huge market and cheap labor - may be within its grasp.

title: Fansteel Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The year-ago periods included non- recurring pretax losses of $629,963 and $1,254,963.

title: Louise Oelbaum Wed To Robert Rubenfeld
description: Louise Ann Oelbaum, a vice president of the Wells, Rich, Greene advertising agency in New York, and Robert A. Rubenfeld, who is of counsel to the law office of Leon H. Charney in New York, were married last evening at the Plaza in New York. Rabbi Stanley M. Davids, assisted by Cantor Richard Botton, performed the ceremony.

title: Treatment for Ali
description: Muhammad Ali, seeking to relieve the slurred speech and tremors that have plagued him in recent years, is undergoing blood-cleansing treatments by a doctor who blames the former heavyweight boxing champion's condition on household pesticide poisoning and not blows to the head, as had been suggested by other diagnoses. Dr. Rajko Medenica of Hilton Head, S.C., an immunologist, treated Ali this week. ''I feel like I can fight Tyson,'' Ali said yesterday at Hilton Head Hospital after an eight-hour treatment.(AP)

title: As the Parley Begins, Doubts Remain On What Iran and Iraq Really Want
description: The wisdom advanced by outsiders here once ran like this: Iraq could never win its war with Iran; Iran could never lose it. With bewildering speed over the last few months, those precepts have been remolded.

title: Acquisition Set For Horchow
description: The Neiman-Marcus Group has signed a letter of intent to acquire Horchow Mail Order, a Dallas-based company that sells novelty merchandise through catalogues, the companies announced yesterday.

title: Diagonal Data Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
L.I. Philharmonic
description: Christopher Keene is to lead the Long Island Philharmonic in a free concert of works by Rossini, Bizet, Borodin, Handel and Rimsky-Korsakov at Eisenhower Park on Stewart Avenue in East Meadow, L.I., Sunday at 8 P.M. Information: (516) 293-2222.

title: Mair-Davis Duo
description: The Mair-Davis Duo (Marilynn Mair, mandolinist, and Mark Davis, guitarist) are to give a free concert a the North Plaza of Lincoln Center, tonight at 6:15 as part of Lincoln Center's Out-of-Doors series. The program includes works by Vivaldi, Beethoven and Bartok, and a new work by Fred Liliencamp. Information: 877-1800.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Apparel Brands Inc., a division of Hartmarx Corp., Chicago, named Gerard M. Transue executive vice president and brand manager of its Briar men's wear division.

title: A Cappella Jazz
description: A free performance of music, from inspirational songs to original jazz pieces, is to be given by an a cappella sextet, Take 6, tonight at 8 in the WQXR Auditorium at The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street.

title: Review/Film; Anatomy of a Murder: A Real-Life Whodunit
description: If Randall Adams and David Harris can agree on anything, it's that fate dealt them a terrible hand when, on Saturday, Nov. 27, 1976, it threw them together. Mr. Adams knows that his whole life would have been different if he hadn't run out of gas that morning, if he hadn't been hitchhiking and if Mr. Harris hadn't picked him up. Mr. Harris, who gave Mr. Adams a ride in a car he had stolen a day earlier, wonders what would have happened if Mr. Adams, who was living in a seedy Dallas motel with his brother, hadn't refused to give him a place to sleep.

title: Abusing the Pledge of Allegiance
description: Many issues can be honorably and profitably addressed this fall - how to maintain peace and prosperity, help the underclass, shrink the deficit. Yet the 1988 Presidential campaign has begun with a coarse exchange over the Pledge of Allegiance, initiated by Vice President Bush. As a political ploy, it demeans Mr. Bush, insults his opponent and threatens to turn the Pledge - an honorable and decent ritual - into a political football.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chairman Is Resigning From Arkansas Best
description: LEAD: H. L. Hembree has resigned as the chairman and chief executive of the Arkansas Best Corporation, the trucking, furniture and tire retreading conglomerate that was acquired two months ago by the investment bank Kelso & Company.

title: Reggie Jackson Approaches Yanks
description: Reggie Jackson a Yankee again?

title: Budd Is Engaged
description: Zola Budd, the record-setting distance runner whose visits to her native South Africa resulted in repeated demonstrations by anti-apartheid groups, said Monday she has become engaged to be married. But Budd, now a student at the University of the Orange Free State after retiring from running, and her fiance, Mike Pieterse, the co-owner of a liquor store in Bloemfortein, South Africa, Budd's hometown, said they had not yet selected a date. (AP)

title: Andrew W. L. Brown, Auto Union Official, 73
description: Andrew W. L. Brown, a retired official of the United Automobile Workers, died of heart failure Aug. 16 at St. John Hospital in Detroit. He was 73 years old and lived in Grosse Pointe Park.

title: Quayle Makes Case in 'Show Me' State
description: Standing in the middle of Main Street in this small Missouri town, Dan Quayle said he did not want to talk about the Vietnam War anymore.

title: Insilco Agrees to a Higher Offer
description: Less than a month after the Insilco Corporation agreed to be acquired in a deal worth $950 million, the company said today that it had signed a definitive agreement to be acquired in a transaction worth a total of $1.1 billion.

title: Dollar Declines Widely After Central Banks Act
description: The dollar fell against all major currencies in busy trading yesterday after the central banks of West Germany and several European nations raised key interest rates.

title: Bronx Arts Ensemble
description: The Bronx Arts Ensemble, directed by Stephen Somary, is to present a free concert at Rockwood Drive Circle in Van Cortlandt Park, near Broadway and Mosholu Avenue in the Riverdale section of the Bronx on Sunday at 2 P.M. The program, which is called ''Serenades and Dances,'' includes a Beethoven Rondino for wind octet, the Brahms Serenade No. 2 in A, and the ''Van Cortlandt Polka'' by John Freeman. The concertr is to be repeated on Sunday at 4 P.M. at Keating Hall on the Bronx Rose Hill campus of Fordham University, Southern Boulevard and East Fordham Road. Information: 549-1899 or 601-7399.

title: Lisbon Shopping Area Burns
description: A fire destroyed much of Lisbon's historic shopping district, killed one person and injured 43 today before firemen brought it under control.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums SCOTTISH GAMES, a variety of activities, from 8 A.M. to 5 P.M. tomorrow, with Highland dancing, piping, caber toss, putting the stone and other games, and an assortment of Scottish pies, cakes, fish and chips and Scottish gifts, sponsored by the Long Island Clans Association, at the Old Westbury Gardens, Old Westbury Road, between Jericho Turnpike and the Long Island Expressway, on Long Island. Admission to the grounds: children, $1; the elderly, $3.50; others, $5; admission to Westbury House: children, $1.50; the elderly, no additional charge; others, $3. Information: (516) 333-0175 or (516) 333-0048. ''THE OLD MAN KNOWS BEST,'' a story by Hans Christian Andersen told by Lorraine Ackerman, 11 A.M. tomorrow at the Andersen statue, near 72d Street and Fifth Avenue in Central Park. Free. ''CINDERELLA WORE COMBAT BOOTS,'' a play with a new slant on the legendary character, 5 P.M. Fridays, 1 P.M. Saturdays and Sundays, at the Westside Arts Theater, 407 West 43d Street. Tickets: $7. Reservations: 541-8394. ''THE WIZARD OF OZ,'' a show by the Puppetworks Theater, 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays at 287 Third Avenue, in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. Tickets: $3.75. Information: (718) 834-1828. ''THE ROSE THAT REFUSED TO BLOOM,'' a musical with audience participation, 1 and 3 P.M. Saturdays, and ''The Snow White Show,'' a musical, 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays, at the 13th Street Repertory Company, 50 West 13th Street. Tickets: $4. Information: 675-6677. MYSTIC (CONN.) SEAPORT, a 17-acre outdoor maritime museum with historic ships, boats, exhibition buildings and two restaurants. Open 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily. Admission: children, $5.50, under 4, free; adults, $11. Information: (203) 572-0711. CLINTON HISTORIC MUSEUM VILLAGE, a 10-acre farm with a 1763 mill, blacksmith shop, log cabin and general store, open 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Tuesdays through Sundays, a quarter of a mile off Interstate 78, Clinton, N.J. Admission: children, $1.50; the elderly, $2; others, $4. Brochure available. Information: (201) 735-4101. VALLEY RAILROAD, with 1910 cars carrying passengers fromn the old Essex Station in Connecticut to Chester, a 10-mile round trip. Then a one-hour cruise up the Connecticut River may be taken from the Deep River Station, 10:30 and 11:45 A.M., 1:15, 2:45, 4:15 and 5:30 P.M., Saturday and Sunday; no boat trip connecting with the 5:30 train. Train-boat combination: children, $4.95; adults, $9.95; train only: children, $2.95; adults, $6.95; children under 2, free. Brochure and map available. Information: (203) 767-0103. JAPANESE HILL AND POND GARDEN, with exotic fish in the pond, a water lilies display and other flowers in bloom on the conservatory plaza at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. The garden is open Tuesdays through Fridays from 8 A.M. to 6 P.M., and on weekends and holidays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., 1000 Washington Avenue, at Crown Street. Information: (718) 622-4433. BARTLETT ARBORETUM, a 63-acre garden owned by the University of Connecticut, with flowers, trails, a tree walk with labeled trees and a dwarf conifer collection, at 151 Brookdale Road, Stamford, Conn. Information: (203)322-6971. THEODORE ROOSEVELT SANCTUARY, a preserve of 12 wooded acres, with trees and vines planted to attract birds, and a visitors' center, in Oyster Bay, L.I. Admission: $1.50. Information: (516) 922-3200.

title: Bridge
description: For a century or so, the term ''test match'' has referred to cricket contests between different segments of what used to be the British Empire. And the Australians and the New Zealanders borrowed the term for their regular bridge battles. Until a decade ago, Australia was dominant, but the pendulum then swung the other way.

title: Genrad Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $4,255,000 and $6,889,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and a provision for disposition of discontinued operations of $34,500,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Chalone Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Quayle's Wealth Shouldn't Be an Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Lyle Trails by 2, at 69, Despite 3 Bogeys
description: Sandy Lyle, the Scot who won the Masters last April, had a rare 18 holes of golf today that started with three bogeys, included four straight birdies at the turn and produced one bruised spectator who was struck by his ninth tee shot, which bounced off the man and back onto the fairway.

title: Art Rooney, 87, Founder of N.F.L.'s Steelers, Dies
description: Art Rooney Sr., the founder of the Pittsburgh Steelers and a figure on the American sports scene for more than half a century, died yesterday at Mercy Hospital in Pittsburgh, eight days after suffering a stroke in his office at Three Rivers Stadium. He was 87 years old.

title: Capital Rally to Recall Dr. King and His Dream
description: Politically literate Americans remember or know of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s thunderclap eloquence and essential optimism 25 years ago, when he stood before the Lincoln Memorial and told of his dream for an end to state-enforced racial segregation.

title: Manuel Is Man With Mission
description: Someone suggested to Coach Bill Parcells earlier this week that the Giants' game with Cleveland Friday night in Cleveland might give an indication of where the team stands on the eve of a new season.

title: Small Plane Crashes Through Shop Roof, Killing Three People
description: A small plane crashed through the roof of a print shop today, killing three people in the plane and severely burning one person on the ground.

title: Meditative Methods
description: Instruction on meditative methods for training the mind will be given at 2 P.M. Sunday at the Jacques Marchais Center of Tibetan Art on Staten Island, Glenn Mullin, a translator of Tibetan texts, will talk about the Lojung practice, which deals with the integration of kindness, compassion and wisdom into daily life. The lecture is free with the museum admission of $2.50 for adults, $2 for the elderly and $1 for children. The museum is at 338 Lighthouse Avenue in Richmondtown; hours today, tomorrow and Sunday are 1 to 5 P.M. Information: (718) 987-3478.

title: Review/Film; 'Coverup,' Iran-Contra Affair
description: ''Coverup: Behind the Iran-Contra Affair'' loses force as the movie makers run out of evidence that a shadowy right-wing group has been conducting American foreign policy and threatening constitutional rights, and settle for surmise, speculation and the tricks of film making to bolster their case. (Sad but unilluminating pictures of injured Laotians are used to accompany reminders of the C.I.A.'s ''secret war'' in Laos.) This overreaching expose, which opens at the Public Theater today, leaves less doubt about the political predilections of its producers, Barbara Trent, Gary Meyer and David Kaspar, than about their allegations.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Hawley Martin Wins National Tobacco Work
description: Hawley Martin Partners, a newly formed Richmond shop, has won the National Tobacco account over seven other agencies after a two-month search. The budget, $4 million for 1988, is expected to grow to accommodate new products.

title: Swiss and Germans Use National 'Poison Pills'
description: When two well-known Swiss food companies, Nestle and Jacob Suchard, made hostile bids for Rowntree P.L.C., the British confectioner, last spring, their competing offers sparked a debate that is still raging throughout Europe: Why can Swiss corporations succeed in hostile takeovers in other countries, while it is well-nigh impossible to succeed in a hostile bid against a Swiss company?

title: Crash on L.I.R.R. Cuts Service
description: Service was canceled on the Port Jefferson branch of the Long Island Railroad east of Huntington last night when a westbound commuter train struck a flatbed tractor-trailer truck and injured 18 people, none seriously, officials said.

title: Hungary Labor Dispute Ends With Miners Back on the Job
description: More than 300 employees of a coal mine in southern Hungary returned to work today after a 20-hour strike that posed the first worker challenge to the strict economic policies of Prime Minister Karoly Grosz.

title: Booton Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest 9-month includes expenses of $270,000 related to a defeated hostile tender offer from Sensor Control Corp.

title: Treasury Prices Off in Slow Day
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped in slow trading yesterday, pushed down by a drop in the dollar and an economic report that suggested that the pace of the expansion and inflation continued to accelerate in the second quarter.

title: Huge Chunks of Rotting Pier Clog the Ambrose Channel
description: A large section of a rotting pier broke off in Staten Island yesterday, sending huge chunks of debris through the Ambrose Channel in a half-mile slick, the authorities said.

title: Pastor Admits Sexual Assaults
description: A Southern Baptist minister was sentenced Wednesday to 10 life terms after he pleaded guilty to charges in a series of burglaries and rapes, prosecutors said.

title: Art Rooney Never Changed
description: SEVERAL months ago, concerned about what would be diagnosed as a blood clot in his right arm, Art Rooney, in a bathrobe, walked slowly out of his old Victorian home at 940 North Lincoln Street in Pittsburgh toward the hospital ambulance at the curb.

title: Irving Mansfield, 80, a Publicist, Author and Television Producer
description: Irving Mansfield, a producer, publicity agent and writer, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80 years old.

title: Changes in Roster Unlikely for Mets
description: The Mets were told yesterday not to expect any outside help in the homestretch of the pennant race or in the playoff or World Series. But for the first time in perhaps three months, they didn't seem to need any.

title: Staking Out Positions on Missile Defense
description: ''I don't think 'Star Wars' can be effective. I think it's a fantasy and a fraud and we ought to stop spending billions on it.'' - Michael S. Dukakis May 26, 1988, Los Angeles Times interview

title: Heins Wins on 25-Foot Putt
description: The only player who played the historic Baltusrol Golf Club at even par for three rounds won the Met Open today.

title: News Corp. Profit Off 67.5%
description: The News Corporation, Rupert Murdoch's Australian holding company, reported yesterday that its earnings for the fourth quarter ended June 30 had plunged 67.5 percent even though its revenues had increased 23.3 percent.

title: Ciccarelli Reacts
description: Dino Ciccarelli, believed to be the first National Hockey League player ever sentenced for an on-ice incident, said yesterday that the National Hockey League had let the situation escape its jurisdiction.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; Java Gold Retired As Comeback Fails
description: ''It would take a miracle for Java Gold to make it back to the races,'' Paul Mellon said last week, and today owner of Rokeby Stable announced he had stopped waiting for one. The broken foot that cost Java Gold the Horse of the Year title last season has ended his racing career, and he is being retired to stud.

title: Artra Group reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,387,000 and $1,642,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and tax credits of $1,322,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $2,636,000 for the quarter and $3,698,000 for the 6 months.

title: Perle Systems reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Mesa Medical Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Hartford Archbishop Assails Democrats on Abortion
description: Archbishop John F. Whealon of Hartford announced yesterday that he was ''unable in conscience to remain a registered Democrat'' because of the Democratic Party's support of legalized and government-financed abortions.

title: Energen Corp reports earnings for 12mo June 30
description: The company said year-ago results are restated due to a change in recognition of nonconvential fuel tax credits on an interim basis.

title: Control Data China Sale
description: The Control Data Corporation, based in Minneapolis, said yesterday that it had sold computers valued at $4.1 million to five industry institutes in China.

title: General Microelectronics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Charles T. Rice, Lawyer, 94
