description: Charles T. Rice, a lawyer who was active in New York's Irish-American community, died of heart failure Saturday at Flushing Hospital in Queens. He was 94 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Jews and Christians Owe Debt to Pharisees
description: To the Editor:

title: Standing Fast on Yonkers
description: A Federal Court of Appeals has rightly upheld contempt citations against the city of Yonkers and four of its councilmen for refusing to remedy decades of official racial discrimination. It's possible the city will now take the case to the U.S. Supreme Court - thus solidifying its dubious reputation as a national symbol of resistance to racial progress. The case still cries out for political leadership. When will Governor Cuomo use his powers of persuasion to help resolve this crisis?

title: A Choice for Candelaria
description: The Yankees will allow John Candelaria to decide whether he can pitch despite a sore right knee, but they have apparently told the left-hander that the option portion of his two-year contract will be renewed only if he agrees to continue working.

title: Police and Protesters Have Clashed Before in Tompkins Square; Strangers and Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: Police and Protesters Have Clashed Before in Tompkins Square
description: To the Editor:

title: Toyota Leads Japan in Profit
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation reported today that its earnings surged 31.1 percent in the fiscal year that ended June 30, making it Japan's most profitable company this year.

title: Gulf Peace Negotiations Hit A Potentially Serious Snag
description: The peace talks between Iran and Iraq ran into potentially serious trouble today when an old dispute resurfaced between the two countries over the ownership of a waterway, diplomats and United Nations officials said.

title: Kappa Networks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest periods include a writeoff of about $125,000 of obsolete finished goods inventory.

title: Atlantic Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Museum Closes Sept. 6
description: The Brooklyn Children's Museum will be closed from Sept. 6 through Sept. 30 while improvements are made to accommodate more visitors and school tours. A computerized visitor-orientation system and an exhibition area for preschool children is to be completed, and repairs and painting will be done during the closing. The museum is at 145 Brooklyn Avenue, at St. Marks Avenue, in the Crown Heights section. Information: (718) 735-4400.

title: Anchor Bank Alters Lending
description: Anchor Savings Bank said yesterday that it would cut back on some of its non-mortgage lending activities. Donald Thomas, Anchor's chairman, said the savings bank would no longer arrange auto loans through car dealers and was de-emphasizing commercial lending. Anchor, based in Hewlett, L.I., said it would make new commercial loans only to its current customers.

title: Buyout at Steel Heddle
description: The Steel Heddle Manufacturing Company, a producer of textile mill supplies based in Greenville, S.C., said today that it had agreed to be acquired for $105 a share by an investor group led by its senior management. The $75 million leveraged buyout is subject to the execution of a definitive agreement and requires shareholder approval. Steel Heddle employs 1,050 people in five plants in South Carolina, North Carolina and Georgia.

title: Baldwin Technology Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said year-ago figures have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Aug. 15.

title: Schmidt Injury Is Pinpointed
description: Mike Schmidt, the Philadelphia Phillies' third baseman, has a tear in the rotator cuff of his right shoulder and will undergo tests next week to determine the extent of the injury, the club said today. If the tear is partial, said Dr. Phillip Marone, the team physician, it could heal with rest. A full tear might require surgery. The Phillies' president, Bill

title: Pentagon Curbs Its Use Of Private Consultants
description: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci has signed a directive curtailing the Pentagon's use of private consultants in response to the investigation of such outside experts in the procurement fraud inquiry.

title: Racism Figured in Hastings Impeachment; Is This Justice?
description: To the Editor:

title: Wellco Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $83,000 and $583,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Japan Consumer Prices
description: Consumer prices in Japan fell two-tenths of 1 percent in July from the previous month, but rose five-tenths from the year before, the Government's Management and Coordination Agency said today. The year-to-year increase marked the 14th monthly rise in a row. Prices had also fallen in June by two-tenths, but were up by the same amount from the previous year. The July month-to-month decline reflected a drop of 3.6 percent in the cost of shirts and sweaters, a 2.2 percent decline in vegetable prices and a 1.6 percent decline in fish prices.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary Aug. 18 of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. omitted two survivors. They are his brothers, James, of Santa Ana, Calif., and Elliott, of Indian Wells, Calif.

title: Black Journalists Report Progress in Hiring but a Lag in Promotion
description: The National Association of Black Journalists, meeting here this week, had mixed reviews of gains by minority groups in the profession over the last 20 years: cheers for some progress in hiring and dismay over the lack of promotions to management positions.

title: Late Games
description: The Yankees' game against the Angels began too late to be included in this edition.

title: Excerpts of Court's Ruling On Compulsory Oath to Flag
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's 1943 decision in West Virginia State Board of Education v. Barnette, declaring unconstitutional a state law that required students to salute the American flag and recite the Pledge of Allegiance. Justice Robert H. Jackson wrote the opinion.

title: Continental May Receive Pacific Route
description: Throwing a new curve into an already convoluted proceeding, a Federal appeals court today ordered the Government to allow Continental Airlines to begin flying passengers between Seattle and Tokyo.

title: Art Work 'Fingerprint'
description: To help prevent art forgeries, Ioan G. Crihan, an engineer in New York City, has developed a radioactive ''fingerprint'' that is to be placed on valuable works. Mr. Crihan's procedure calls for mixing a radioactive isotope with a resin and planting a speck of the material on the painting or sculpture. The owner would then record the speck's location and measure its radioactivity.

title: Jean Michel Basquiat: Hazards Of Sudden Success and Fame
description: In a city that exalts successful artists in the fashion of rock stars, Jean Michel Basquiat seemed blessed. When he burst onto the art scene in 1981, his paintings of anguished figures were hailed by some critics as works of genius. Admirers besieged him at Manhattan's hottest night clubs. Sales of his art grossed millions of dollars.

title: Home State Ruling Upheld
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge ruled today that the financier Marvin L. Warner cannot avoid paying $22 million in restitution stemming from the failure of Home State Savings Bank, as he was ordered to do by an Ohio court.

title: Canada Plans Test Program For a Deadly Brain Condition
description: Canadian scientists announced a program today for testing people at risk of developing Huntington's disease, the devastating and fatal brain condition that usually goes undiagnosed until symptoms show up in adulthood.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Arafat Aide Says P.L.O. Will Form Exile Regime
description: A senior official of the Palestine Liberation Organization said tonight that the group had decided to declare the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip independent and to form a government in exile for the territories.

title: Mayes Practices
description: Rueben Mayes softened a bit yesterday on his statement that he has no future with the New Orleans Saints, but the running back still believes he will be playing somewhere else in 1989. Mayes, a Pro Bowl pick in each of his two seasons in the National Football League, walked out of the Saints training camp Aug. 15 to press demands that the final year of his contract be renegotiated. He was back practicing with the Saints under the threat of being made ineligible to play anywhere in the N.F.L. this season. Coach Jim Mora said he doubted that Mayes would play today against Pittsburgh in the Saints' last preseason game. Mayes is upset that his base salary of $175,000 is fourth-highest among Saints running backs. He is coming off knee surgery, which has complicated negotiations for both sides. Mayes and his agent, Bob Evans, said they were told by the Saints' general manager, Jim Finks, that if Mayes reported to preseason camp and his knee appeared sound, his 1988 contract would be negotiated. (AP)

title: Cuban Goods Logjam
description: The Cuban Government has announced emergency plans to deal with huge stockpiles of merchandise in Cuban ports. The backlog - 311,000 tons of merchandise on Aug. 15 - is disrupting the country's economy and costing Cuba millions of dollars in penalties to foreign shipowners. The emergency plan calls for dock workers to work on shifts around the clock. It also compels the nation's warehouses to prepare for merchandise 16 hours a day, rather than the usual eight.

title: New York Merc Chief Resigns After Inquiry
description: William M. Bradt, the embattled chairman of the New York Mercantile Exchange, resigned late Thursday after the Commodity Futures Trading Commission found he had acted in an inappropriate fashion in some exchange matters.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY AUGUST 27, 1988
description: Companies

title: Stacey J. Moritz Wed To David M. Brodsky
description: Stacey J. Moritz and David M. Brodsky, partners in the New York law firm of Schulte Roth & Zabel, were married last night at the Water Club in New York. Judge Jose Cabranes of Federal District Court in New Haven officiated.

title: In Spirit, Tibet's Lamas Resemble Iran's Mullahs; New Peace Initiative
description: To the Editor:

title: Miller Returns
description: Ten days after he announced that he was leaving Loyola of Chicago because of academic problems and that he was investigating the possibility of attending Oklahoma or Nevada-Las Vegas, Kenny Miller changed his mind. On Thursday, the 20-year-old sophomore, a 6-foot-9-inch center who last season became the first freshmen to win a National Collegiate Athletic Association rebounding title, told Chuck Schwarz, the Loyola athletic director, he had decided to return to Loyola even though he will be academically ineligible to play basketball during the fall semester. The earliest that Miller, who averaged 13.6 rebounds and 14.7 points last season, could return to action would be in the sixth game of the season, on Dec. 18 against California-Irvine.(AP)

title: New York City's Hall of Science Discovers a Success Formula
description: Two years after it reopened after extensive renovations, the New York Hall of Sciznce in Queens has been so successful that the city wants to expand and improve it further, officials say.

title: YONKERS: THE COST OF DEFIANCE
description: On Aug. 2 the City of Yonkers and four Councilmen were held in contempt of court for refusing to approve part of a court-ordered housing desegregation plan. Following are the requirements of the housing order and the actions taken against the city for its refusal to approve them. The Consent Decree

title: BURMA ARMY URGED TO AID PROTESTERS
description: Large crowds gathered Friday at the Shwe Dagon Pagoda in Rangoon, where speakers called on the army to support the peaceful but leaderless insurrection that has turned much of the Burmese population against the Government.

title: Charming Shoppes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Golf; 2 Surprises Emerge to Lead
description: Mike Reid, a slim golfer who surprises people when he does well on strong courses against big, powerful golfers like Sandy Lyle and Greg Norman, surprised himself a bit today with a three-under-par 67 at the long Firestone Country Club South course.

title: COPING: With Finances for Students
description: Though Personal Finance 101 may not be in the curriculum, the first year of college can be a test for students and their families on such matters as bank accounts, credit cards and insurance policies.

title: 4th Jet Hobbled in Fit of Campaign Delays
description: The jet carrying Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate, and his entourage was grounded for repairs today after a passenger door was forced closed in an incorrect position.

title: Television; Urbanites After Dark
description: Even the adroit direction of Tony Richardson cannot conceal the patched-together quality of ''After Midnight,'' a one-hour drama to be shown tonight at 9 o'clock on ABC.

title: Mail Boxes Etc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 6-for-5 stock split paid in July.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Washington Talk Briefing column yesterday on a speech by Richard F. Schubert, president of the American Red Cross, misidentified the organization he addressed in some copies. It is the World Jewish Congress.

title: Interco Is Seeking Alternatives to Bid
description: Interco Inc. said it had begun discussions with third parties, including commercial banks, about alternatives to a hostile takeover offer of $70 a share from the Rales brothers of Washington. Interco has rejected the $2.53 billion bid by City Capital Associates, a company controled by Steven and Mitchell Rales.

title: On the Road to Ending Rural Isolation by Forging Bus Links
description: Transportation specialists grappling with rural America's problems of growing isolation in an increasingly urban nation have found some innovative solutions scattered from upstate New York to northwest Nebraska and central Virginia to the Ohio shores of Lake Erie.

title: ALL 20 ACQUITTED IN JERSEY MOB CASE
description: One of the longest criminal trials in the United States ended abruptly today with the acquittal of 20 defendants accused of making up the entire membership of the Lucchese crime family in New Jersey.

title: In Spirit, Tibet's Lamas Resemble Iran's Mullahs
description: To the Editor:

title: Entwistle Raises Frequency Stake
description: The Entwistle Company said it had raised its stake in Frequency Electronics Inc., a maker of precision timing equipment, to 8.2 percent from 5.6 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Entwistle, a maker of insulated wire, said it had bought 132,800 Frequency shares on the open market for $10.31 a share.

title: Ski Coach Quits
description: Greg Windsperger, who was the jumping coach of the United States ski team during the Olympic Winter Games of 1984 and 1988, has resigned, team officials announced yesterday. According to John Bower, the Nordic program director for the ski team, Windsperger expected to begin work soon for Airtex Industries in Minneapolis, where he has been hired as general manager of the consumer-products division. Windsperger, 34 years old, joined the team's coaching staff in 1980 after a successful competitive career from 1969 to 1977, during which he took part in the Olympic Games of 1976 and the world championships of 1974. Tom Daggett, the jumping coordinator, will become the jumping director Sept. 1. (AP)

title: Review/Pop; Don Cherry, on or Off Trumpet
description: The first third of the trumpeter Don Cherry's set at the Village Vanguard on Wednesday night was filled with musical hemming and hawing: the group's tenor saxophonist, James Clay, who had Mr. Cherry's trumpet, hadn't appeared. Jazz is about improvisation, so the group, made up of members of Ornette Coleman's early, radical, ground-breaking group -Charlie Haden on bass and Billy Higgins on drums - performed short solo pieces.

title: Angola Talks Are Suspended
description: Talks on a timetable for withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola were suspended today to allow negotiators to consult their governments. The negotiators, from Angola, Cuba and South Africa, agreed to reconvene here in the week of Sept. 5. Earlier, the parties had agreed to set the timetable by Sept. 1.

title: Imtec Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Suspicious Cuts In Rocket Seals Prompt Inquiry
description: Suspicious cuts in some O ring seals that were intended for use on space shuttle booster rockets have led to a Federal investigation, officials said today.

title: Eye Drops Called 'Liquid Sunglasses'
description: An eye surgeon has developed what he calls ''liquid sunglasses'' - eye drops that absorb 98 percent of the sun's ultraviolet rays without affecting vision.

title: Eckersley Cited In Trial Delay
description: A kidnapping and attempted-murder trial has been postponed after the defendant's lawyer said it would hurt the Oakland Athletics' pennant chances and harm the career of his client's brother, the relief pitcher Dennis Eckersley.

title: 'A Certain Portion of the Doings of Gotham'
description: LEAD: It will give me much pleasure, gentlemen, to comply with your suggestion and, by dint of a weekly epistle, keep you au fait to a certain portion of the doings of Gotham. And here if, in the beginning, for ''certain'' you read uncertain, you will the more readily arrive at my design. For, in fact, I must deal chiefly in gossip, whose empire is unlimited, whose influence is universal, whose devotees are legion; - in gossip which is the true safety-valve of society - engrossing at least seven-eights of the whole waking existence of mankind.

title: Union Leader Backs Police in Tompkins Sq. Clash
description: The leader of New York City's largest police union yesterday defended the actions of police officers during the clash with demonstrators at Tompkins Square Park earlier this month, and predicted that most of the 111 brutality charges filed against the police would be found invalid.

title: 2 Officers Charged in Ft. Wadsworth Assault
description: Two Federal police officers were arrested yesterday and charged with assaulting three 14-year-old boys who trespassed on Fort Wadsworth on Staten Island because they wanted to play soldier. One of the boys suffered a broken nose.

title: Jackson Rules Out Comeback Attempt
description: Reggie Jackson's rumored return to the Yankees appeared to fall through today after the 42-year-old retired player and his agent denied that Jackson was interested in a comeback. But Bill Goodstein, a New York lawyer Jackson has used on occasion for business matters, stood by his account that Jackson has been contemplating a return.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Little League Hawaiian Team in Final: A team from a small Hawaiian city has won a pair of one-run games to earn a game against a Taiwanese powerhouse in the Little League World Series championship game today in Williamsport, Pa.

title: A Tool for Removing Plaque in Arteries
description: A father-and-son team won a patent this week for a tool to clear human arteries of plaque, a primary cause of heart disease.

title: G.M.-Penske Deal
description: Penske Transportation Inc. has agreed to buy a majority stake in the General Motors Corporation's diesel fuel-injection business, G.M. said. Penske Transportation, a subsidiary of the Penske Corporation of Red Bank, N.J., is to own 80 percent of the new venture, which will be formed from G.M.'s Rochester Products plant in Wyoming, Mich. G.M. would own the remaining 20 percent. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Penske bought a majority stake in G.M.'s diesel-engine business in November.

title: Why 2 Savings Units Struggle
description: Texas may be the capital of sick savings and loan institutions, but the Northeast is by no means exempt from the problem. The number of troubled institutions in the region is growing, and with interest rates rising that trend will continue.

title: Letter: On New York's Port; Maritime Industry Eulogy Is Premature
description: To the Editor:

title: EASTERN AIRLINES BLOCKED BY JUDGE ON LAYOFFS PLAN
description: A Federal judge today barred Eastern Airlines from dismissing 4,000 workers and then threw Eastern and the airline industry into confusion by leaving open the question of whether he will allow the airline to slash its flight schedules next week.

title: Wallace in Crash
description: Rusty Wallace, the Winston Cup season point-leader, survived a crash and escaped serious injury yesterday afternoon at the Bristol (Tenn.) International Raceway during practice for the Busch 500 Nascar race, which will be run tonight. The 31-year-old driver's Pontiac slid into the fourth-turn wall on the half-mile track, climbed to the top of the wall, turned over and rolled five times along the straightaway before coming to rest on its wheels just past the finish line. Rescue workers needed 15 minutes to remove Wallace from the battered car. The driver was conscious and alert as he was placed in an ambulance, his head bandaged, for the ride to Bristol Memorial Hospital, where he underwent X-rays and was held for observation. A hospital spokesman said the driver suffered no apparent injuries and was expected to be released today in time to qualify in his backup car for the race tonight. (AP)

title: Bernard J. Meislin; Lawyer, 60
description: Bernard J. Meislin, a corporate lawyer, died of pancreatic cancer Aug. 17 at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston, N.J. He was 60 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J.

title: National Business Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a special charge of $2,163,000 for the quarter and special charges of $31,105,000 from writedowns, impairment of goodweill and restructuring costs in the 9 months. Figures are in Canadian funds. As reported, management of National Business Systems was assumed by Hees International Bancorp Inc. after irregularities were discovered in National Business' financial statements. As a result of a subsequent restructuring program, year-ago comparative figures are not available. Regarding that restructuring, National Business said it has arranged a new $40 million (US) credit facility to replace its previous facility. In addition, the company said it has completed the restructuring of its operations along divisional product lines. National Business said CIBC Wood Gundy was retained to handle the sale of its 76.9 percent interest in NBS Transaction Services Inc. through a controlled auction, and final offers are expected before the end of the month. National Business said management expects to complete the restructuring and recapitalization over the next few months.

title: Captain Loses His Command Over Episode With Refugees
description: The captain of an American warship is being permanently relieved of his command and has been ordered to prepare for a court-martial because of his failure to rescue a boatload of Vietnamese refugees, Pentagon officials said today.

title: African Music Discussed
description: The evolution of traditional African music will be discussed by a panel of musicians at the Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street, from 2 to 4 P.M. today. At 3 P.M. on Sunday, Cheryl Byron and Something Positive will present a program of songs, chants, dances and stories reflecting African-Caribbean culture. Admission to the music seminar is $6. The Sunday show is free with museum admission, which is $1.50 for adults and 50 cents for children, students and the elderly. Information: 864-4500.

title: Becker, Lendl Gain
description: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl and third-seeded Boris Becker of West Germany reached the semifinal round of the $190,000 Norstar Hamlet Challenge Cup today.

title: WESTERN BLAZES THREATEN TOWNS
description: Residents of two towns on the edge of this park were warned today that they might have to evacuate because of a 30,000-acre forest fire. Inside the park, rangers shepherded convoys of tourists down roads otherwise closed by fires burning nearly 20 percent of the park.

title: Review/Theater; New Telling, to Music, Of an Old Garden Story
description: Carlos Morton's musical comedy ''The Garden'' (''El Jardin''), which the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater has been performing at locations around New York this month, is just the sort of production we have come to expect from the exuberant street theater company. Loosely based on the story of Adam and Eve, the show is a freewheeling mixture of domestic farce and political allegory. Its characters include a Chicano Adam and Eve and a terrorist-inciting Satan.

title: Rooney Mourned By Thousands
description: Thousands of people today paid their last respects to the Pittsburgh Steelers' founder, Art Rooney Sr., who died Thursday. Rooney, who was 87 years old, died of complications of a stroke he suffered last week.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; From Patio to Garage
description: For people closing summer homes, one chore is deciding what to do with outdoor furniture. Some of it, expecially the new ornamental teak and cast-aluminum models, is sturdy, durable and made to be left outdoors. Other popular styles, though, are prone to rust or are too flimsy to withstand harsh weather. Furniture that is to be left outdoors will benefit from an end-of-season cleaning. Treat metal furniture with wax - automobile wax is fine - to protect the finish. Teak furniture will age to silvery gray if left untreated, and many people like this look. If you want to retain the original finish, though, paint these pieces with teak oil. Furniture that is to be stored indoors should also be thoroughly cleaned, to inhibit rust and mildew. Use a soft brush and mild soap and allow for thorough drying outdoors. Store in a cool, dry place, protected by a cover of old sheets or other cloth. TYPE TREATMENT Canvas or upholstered; glass- Clean, cover and store. topped; painted wood, wicker, rattan. Extruded aluminum with May be left outdoors. baked-on finish and no visible seams; cast aluminum; teak, cedar or birch.

title: Mary Murphy, Archivist, Wed to Robert L. Gaumer
description: At St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bay Shore, L.I., Mary Eleanor Murphy, a daughter of Mrs. John J. Murphy of Bay Shore and the late Dr. Murphy, was married yesterday to Robert L. Gaumer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul D. Gaumer of Chambersburg, Pa. The Rev. Charles A. Lennon performed the ceremony.

title: Sale Deal Reached For Texas Rangers
description: Eddie Chiles, the majority owner of the Texas Rangers, announced last night that he had agreed to sell his controlling interest in the American League baseball team to a group of investors who have been associated with efforts to secure a major league franchise for Tampa, Fla.

title: American Contact With Spy Ring Was in '74, Investigators Are Told
description: Two Hungarian-born Swedish brothers who were arrested this week when Western officials broke up a major espionage ring have admitted working for the Hungarian intelligence service, the Swedish authorities said today.

title: Carbide in Pledge to India
description: The Union Carbide Corporation has assured a court that it will keep $3 billion in assets, the amount the Indian Government claims as compensation for the 1984 gas disaster that killed more than 2,800 people.

title: F.B.I. Is Accused of Intimidation By Attorneys for Hispanic Agents
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is using surveillance and an unfounded investigation in an effort to intimidate the attorneys for 311 Hispanic agents who have charged the bureau with discrimination in a lawsuit, the lawyers have asserted.

title: Bridge; Players should ask themselves: 'What is my opponent up to?'
description: Two questions that chess players ask themselves instinctively, but that bridge players often forget, are ''Why did my opponent do what he just did?'' and ''What is he up to?''

title: 'Bitterest Flavor' Created in Compound
description: The Atomergic Chemetals Corporation of Plainview, L.I., has patented what it contends is the bitterest flavor in the world. ''It's vile,'' boasted Mel Blum, the compound's co-inventor and president of Atomergic. ''It has a lingering, terrible taste.''

title: 2 Sweeteners Are Patented
description: The General Foods Corporation announced yesterday that it had received a patent on two new sweeteners that are 2,000 to 2,500 times sweeter than sugar.

title: Ensource Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and after a $1,775,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: London House Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Pledge Is Used Voluntarily
description: Teachers throughout Massachusetts continue to lead children in the Pledge of Allegiance each day, on the voluntary basis supported by Gov. Michael S. Dukakis.

title: Your Money; Where to Find Funds for College
description: For those students who thought their lack of money made college an impossible dream, there is good news: funds are available, even at this late date.

title: U.S. Suggests Easing Fuel-Economy Rules for New Cars
description: The Transportation Department today proposed relaxing the fuel economy requirements for 1989 and 1990 model automobiles, saying the move would save American jobs. But the reduction would be less than was granted auto makers in the last three years.

title: Making a Safer Blow-Dryer: Progress, but at a Snail's Pace
description: At a time when people are grumbling about the quality of small electric appliances, many manufacturers are not listening. Or so it seems, judging by the flimsy toasters, corn poppers, hair dryers and other disposable appliances that have given plastic and tin a bad name.

title: Review/Theater; A Fading Prizefighter Confronts His Facade
description: Joey Dillon, the title character in ''The Fighter'' by Daniel Keene, comes home to his seedy apartment and goes through his nightly ritual. Changing to his sweat pants and putting a towel around his neck, he steps on a scale, winces at his weight and then removes the towel and tries again. The silent scene goes on so long (at Theater for the New City) that it seems less like a prelude to a play than a play itself, somewhat on the order of Franz Kroetz's ''Request Concert.'' The fighter shares an abject loneliness with Mr. Kroetz's heroine.

title: Jazz Marathon on Radio
description: A marathon jazz-radio broadcast devoted to the saxophonists Charlie Parker and Lester Young continues through Tuesday at 1 A.M. on WKCR-FM, (89.9).

title: Two Postponed Votes Delay Griffin Takeover of Resorts
description: Resorts International Inc. adjourned a special stockholders meeting today because not enough votes had been cast to approve Merv Griffin's offer to acquire the gaming and real estate company.

title: Good Banking News: Checks Will Clear Faster
description: As if bank statements were not onerous enough, there will be some new reading material stuck in with your canceled checks in the next few weeks.

title: Hats Are for Horses, Not Him, Koch Says
description: Mayor Koch, who last week proposed a new-fangled manure catcher to solve a problem at the tail of the carriage horses in Central Park, revealed yesterday that he has an old-fashioned idea for a problem at their heads: straw hats to keep them cool.

title: Interest Rates Little Changed in Slow Day
description: Interest rates were little changed in credit markets yesterday. Securities dealers said a combination of too much apathy and too many vacations kept the prices of debt securities steady.

title: In Gdansk, a Growing Sense of Futility
description: Clattering in toward central Gdansk from Nowy Port to the northwest, the No. 10 tram lurches along right under the sooty brick walls and idle, rusty cranes of the Lenin Shipyard.

title: Symbolism, More Than Legal Precedent, Is the Issue in the Bush and Dukakis Clash
description: For more than a week, George Bush has been taunting Michael S. Dukakis for vetoing a Massachusetts law that would have required teachers to lead their classes in the Pledge of Allegiance. Governor Dukakis has retorted that such a law would be unconstitutional, and that Vice President Bush would not be qualified to be President if he had signed it.

title: Farmsted Telephone Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Cauthen Injured
description: The jockey Steve Cauthen fell and was knocked unconscious by two horses while racing yesterday in the Country Club Hotels Handicap at the Goodwood race course in Chichester, England, but he was not believed to be seriously injured. A spokesman at St. Richard's Hospital said that an examination revealed no broken bones, but that Cauthen would be kept overnight for observation. Cauthen, who rode Affirmed to the American Triple Crown in 1978, was unconscious after being knocked to the ground when his mount, the filly Preziosa, fell coming down a hill in the path of 13 runners. Preziosa rolled over Cauthen, then brought down a pursuing horse, Cuva. Cuva also tumbled over Cauthen, who was face down on the turf when medical help arrived. He was carried off the course on a stretcher but regained consciousness shortly after arriving at the hospital. It was the fourth time the 28-year-old Kentucky native had fallen at Greenwood, more than all his other falls in Britain put together. Race stewards interviewed four other jockeys involved in the race and watched a videotape of the race, and found no one was to blame.(AP)

title: Top Executives Leave Scotty's
description: Scotty's Inc., a manufacturer of building materials and retailer of hand tools, said yesterday that its chairman, James W. Sweet, had retired. The company also said its president, Dennis Stults, had resigned to pursue other interests.

title: Age of Golden Clarity Bows to Hegemonicists
description: Sociologists, the people who gave us such memorable locutions as ''charisma'' and ''life style,'' ''the power elite'' and ''the lonely crowd,'' are now speaking a language so dense that other sociologists can hardly understand them.

title: Chrysler and Maserati Plan To Reduce Their Joint Effort
description: The Chrysler Corporation and the Italian auto maker Maserati said today that they had reduced the scope of their joint efforts, setting the stage for a complete severing of relations.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Once the Yonkers City Council approved the terms of the Consent Judgment, the Council became obligated to carrying out its commitments. If a member of the Council is unwilling to abide by such commitments, his option is to decline to serve on the body that is bound, not to act in defiant disregard of the commitments and the federal court judgment that memorializes them.'' - A panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. [ 28:3. ]

title: U.S. Aides in Panama Deny New Harassment by Noriega
description: American officials here have challenged assertions from Washington that the Government of Panama has stepped up harassment of United States military personnel and their families.

title: Post on Futures Panel
description: Neil Sherman, first vice president and associate general counsel at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., said Thursday that he had withdrawn his name from consideration to be a member of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. People involved in the futures industry had said that the White House had offered Mr. Sherman the job, but Mr. Sherman said that, for personal reasons, he had decided he did not want to be considered. Commissioner William Seale will leave the five-member panel on Thursday.

title: Shorewood Packaging reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Davis Water & Waste Indusries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Dow Up 6.58; Volume Lowest of Year
description: LEAD: Stock prices were nudged moderately higher yesterday, as trading slowed to its lowest point of the year.

title: INSIDE
description: Iraq Takes Tough Line

title: An All-Dvorak Concert Is Planned for St. John's
description: The 147th anniversary of Antonin Dvorak's birth will be observed with an all-Dvorak concert on Sept. 10 at 7:30 P.M. at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street. The composer's actual birthdate is Sept. 8.

title: Blessings Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 16
description: The latest periods' earnings were adversely affected by an after-tax writedown of $1,036,300 of part of the company's long-term investment portfolio.

title: Warsaw Is Proposing Talks To End Remaining Strikes
description: Poland's leaders today proposed direct negotiations with representatives of ''different social groups'' and with ''workers' representatives'' to defuse the labor confontations shaking the country.

title: Copper Prices, Now Up, Are Seen Settling Down
description: After slipping for several weeks, copper prices have begun to rebound again because of a renewed tightening of supplies brought on in part by copper workers' strikes in Peru and Canada.

title: Detained Apartheid Foe Dies In a Hospital in South Africa
description: A black union organizer and opponent of apartheid who was detained without charge for 26 months died in a hospital today, three days after collapsing in his prison cell, the police said.

title: About New York; Doctor's Journey: Miles Still to Go, Promises to Keep
description: One of the busiest medical practices on Queens Boulevard in Forest Hills belongs to Dr. Carlisle L. St. Martin, a neurologist.

title: One Challenge Left To Manville Plan
description: The Manville Corporation said it faced only one remaining legal challenge to its bankruptcy reorganization plan. It said the deadline had passed for a group of 700 people who said that they had been injured by asbestos to appeal to the United States Supreme Court to review the plan. The group's objections to the plan had previously been dismissed by lower courts. Manville was the nation's leading asbestos producer when it filed for protection from its creditors six years ago under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: Lionel Deckle McLean, Dental Surgeon, 88
description: Dr. Lionel Deckle McLean, a dental surgeon and the first black to serve as president of the New Jersey Dental Association, died of respiratory failure last Saturday at University Hospital in Newark. He was 88 years old and lived in Jersey City.

title: Rheometrics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Tucker Holding reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Net per share is not applicable because the company went public in July 1987.

title: WEST BANK UNIONS CLOSED BY ISRAEL
description: Israel closed the offices of Palestinian unions representing doctors, lawyers and other West Bank professionals today, saying the groups had begun associating with ''terrorist organizations.''

title: Here's a Solution for New York's Sludge
description: LEAD: Like many politicians who are in office, Mayor Koch likes things the way they are. More than a decade ago, he was offered an alternative to ocean dumping for New York City's sewage sludge. But then, as now, he dodged his responsibility for safe, nontoxic sewage disposal.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 48.

title: Waste Found In Ambulances That Were Sold
description: Investigators for the New York City Council found medical equipment or possibly infectious wastes in 10 of 17 city ambulances sold at an auction last week, Peter F. Vallone, the council's Democratic majority leader, said yesterday.

title: Quayle Struggles to Put Confident Face on Drive
description: It was a tableau meant to show just how well the new campaign was doing.

title: Police, Drugs and the Social Contract
description: While Congress mulls yet another omnibus drug bill, street gangs spreading violence and addiction roam free in much of urban America. Angry voters are asking local officials to take effective action now.

title: Enzo Fano, Water Specialist, 57
description: Enzo Fano, an internationally known water-resources specialist at the United Nations, died of a heart attack Thursday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 57 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Urban Earth
description: Harvie Swartz, a bassist, is to lead his group Urban Earth in a free concert tomorrow at 4 P.M. at the Rotunda in Riverside Park, at West 79th Street near the Hudson River Boat Basin. Information: 408-0263.

title: Harnischfeger Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a loss of $18,111,000 from the early retirement of debt for both the quarter and 9 months, and the quarter also includes a loss from the reversal of a tax loss carryforward. c-Net income d-Includes tax credits of $2,500,000 and $8,000,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said previous year's figures are restated to conform to current year's presentation.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Air France will introduce direct service on Fridays between San Juan, P.R., and Paris, starting Nov. 4.

title: Corrections
description: In the Dining Out column in Weekend yesterday, an incorrect star rating was given for the Gotham Bar and Grill, 12 East 12th Street. The restaurant received a three-star rating when it was reviewed on Oct. 4, 1985.

title: On the Trail of Illegal Trash: Grisly Finds, Futile Pursuits
description: It was a sultry August afternoon, a scorcher, when the heat smokes you like a Lucky and stubs you out in the overflowing ashtray of Manhattan.

title: Dollars Flow for Bogus Hard-Luck Tales
description: A couple whose hard-luck stories netted them up to $200 an hour from good Samaritans were apartment managers who moonlighted as confidence artists, the authorities said Thursday.

title: Jobs Even More Out of Aliens' Reach
description: Immigrants having trouble getting work because employment of illegal aliens is prohibited are now finding it even harder because of a Federal crackdown on their makeshift hiring halls: street corners.

title: Baseball; Dodger Rookie Takes Seventh Straight
description: Tim Belcher, a rookie, won his seventh straight decision and a two-run double by John Shelby highlighted a five-run fourth inning tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 7-2.

title: Trade Mission To Go to Japan
description: Commerce Secretary C. William Verity Jr. will head a trade mission to Japan next month to promote sales of American consumer goods, the department said today.

title: Flooding in Nepal Quake Area
description: Tons of food, clothing, blankets and other aid continued to flow into the region today despite heavy rains that slowed relief operations after a strong earthquake that struck last Sunday. Doctors from Britain, Japan and France joined the effort to treat the injured and prevent epidemics from breaking out as the rains flooded many neighborhoods in Biratnagar, Nepal's second-largest city. The Home Affairs Ministry in Katmandu announced that the number of deaths attributed to the earthquake had been put at 704.

title: Panel Upholds Contempt Finding But Curbs Fines Against Yonkers
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday affirmed a lower court's finding of contempt and the imposition of fines against the City of Yonkers and four members of the City Council who have blocked compliance with a court-ordered housing desegregation plan.

title: Tough Pitching and Luck Give Mets Fourth in Row
description: The revived Mets rolled in from California last night and opened a nine-game homestand with fierce pitching, outrageous good fortune and a 3-0 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

title: Man Is Charged in Slaying Of Midtown Pizza Deliverer
description: A Queens man was charged yesterday in the stabbing to death of a pizza deliverer in a midtown building two weeks ago.

title: Latshaw Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: The company said in July it signed an agreement with Biotech Electronics Ltd. of Montreal in which Latshaw Enterprises lent $2.5 million to Biotech and received a promissory note.

title: British Censors Refuse To Cut 'Temptation'
description: British film censors, rejecting demands of some church leaders, decided Thursday to allow Martin Scorcese's film ''The Last Temptation of Christ'' to be shown without cuts.

title: Youths Charged In Death of Man Stabbed in Park
description: Two youths have been charged in the slaying of a man who was stabbed to death in Central Park Monday night during a fight with a group of about 20 teen-agers, the police said.

title: Police and Protesters Have Clashed Before in Tompkins Square; Gentrification's Price
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush 'Star Wars' View Welcomed by Dukakis
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, a sharp critic of the Strategic Defense Initiative, said today that he was pleased to hear Vice President Bush saying that deployment of the proposed missile defense system should be contingent on the outcome of further research.

title: Choral Society Auditions
description: Five days of auditions for the New York Choral Society will begin at 5:30 P.M. Tuesday at CAMI Hall, 165 West 57th Street. The society, which celebrates its 30th anniversary this year, makes annual appearances at Carnegie Hall and other performance halls around the country. Auditions, which are by appointment only, will also be held Wednesday, Thursday and on Sept. 7 and 8. Information: 724-6633.

title: Special Prosecutor Drops E.P.A. Case Without Indictment
description: An independent prosecutor said today that she would not seek criminal charges against a former senior Justice Department official who had been accused of misleading Congress in 1983 about the handling of Environmental Protection Agency documents.

title: Xplor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Comparable year-ago figures are not applicable; last year the company changed the close of its fiscal year to Dec. 31 from Aug. 31.

title: Head of Lab Charged in Illegal Disposal
description: The head of a diagnostic laboratory in Brooklyn was arrested yesterday and charged with illegally disposing of medical waste, including two blood vials containing the Hepatitis B virus. He was also charged with creating a risk of serious injury to others.

title: Investigators Still Examining Seized California Documents
description: Federal officials said today that they were still evaluating documents and other materials seized late Wednesday and early Thursday in searches of some legislative offices at the state Capitol.

title: July Incomes Up by 0.6% as Wages Rose
description: Bolstered by the biggest increase in wages in seven months, Americans' personal incomes rose six-tenths of 1 percent in July. The pace of consumer spending slowed in part because fewer people bought automobiles.

title: An Improved Form Of Anti-Cancer Drug
description: The Cetus Corporation of Emeryville, Calif., received a patent this week for a new form of the anti-cancer drug, interleukin-2, or IL-2. Company officials believe the new compound, which entered human medical trials in April, can be administered in lower doses and with fewer side effects than the existing version of IL-2.

title: Geodynamics reports earnings for Qtr to June 3
BUSH TURNS HEAT ON 'LIBERAL' RIVAL
description: Vice President Bush offered politically conservative East Texas a scathing attack on Michael S. Dukakis today, alleging that his Democratic rival was hiding a litany of ''liberal'' faults.

title: Korean Talks Adjourn in a Deadlock
description: Talks between North and South Korea ended in a deadlock today, with the two sides saying they had no plans to resume meetings until after the Olympic Games in Seoul are over in October.

title: Review/Concert; Beaux Arts Trio In a Marriage Of Age and Spirit
description: Last summer, the Beaux Arts Trio underwent a personnel change that was, to all appearances, odd. Its founding cellist, Bernard Greenhouse, had retired, and rather than disband the ensemble, the remaining members - Isidore Cohen, the violinist, and Menahem Pressler, the pianist - decided to find a replacement. Their first choice was Peter Wiley, who was born in 1955, the year the trio was founded.

title: U.S. Promises $1 Billion for Deals To Save Nine Savings Institutions
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today that it had arranged to merge nine more insolvent saving institutions with healthy ones. It said it had committed almost $1 billion in assistance to the transactions.

title: N.A.A.C.P. and Boston Settle Challenge to a Housing Plan
description: The city and the N.A.A.C.P. today settled a challenge to an agreement over a non-discriminatory public housing plan worked out in June between the Boston Housing Authority and the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Excerpts From Federal Court of Appeals Ruling on Yonkers
description: Following are excerpts from the ruling by a panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit on appeals by the City of Yonkers and four City Council members held in contempt for refusing to adopt legislation needed for a court-ordered housing desegregation plan. The unanimous opinion was written by Judge Jon O. Newman.

title: Macmillan Rejects Bid Of Maxwell
description: Macmillan Inc. said today that it had rejected the $2.1 billion takeover offer from Robert Maxwell, the British publisher, calling it inadequate.

title: Kickoff Game: 'Bowl in Reverse'
description: Miles from the intense emotions of their campuses, nearly a week before another college football game will take place, the Aggies of Texas A&M and the Huskers of Nebraska attempted to define the significance of the sixth Kickoff Classic.

title: Filipino Opposition Leaders Form Anti-Aquino Coalition
description: Vice President Salvador H. Laurel and opposition leaders today announced the formation of a new coalition to challenge President Corazon C. Aquino.

title: Maybe Bush Has Already Won
description: LEAD: The Presidential campaign, only now formally set to begin, is in fact virtually finished.

title: As Soviets Leave, Kabul Calmly Awaits Storm
description: Soviet soldiers sat shirtless in the morning sun at the airport here today, watching Hind helicopters loaded with rockets lift in a swirl of dust toward the ridges of the Hindu Kush, the broad mountain range to the northeast. A soldier carrying a guitar walked past a Russian man in his 20's, wearing wraparound sunglasses, jeans and running shoes, gripping a submachine gun.

title: Last Refuge For Bush
description: Late in August George Bush refused to debate Michael Dukakis before late September. Political analysts figured Bush wanted to wait and look at the polls. If they showed he was sure to be elected, he would say he couldn't debate until October, when, if his polls were still terrific, he'd say, ''I'll be ready in February.''

title: Wickes Units Might Be Sold
description: One or more of the Wickes Companies' operating units would be sold if a management-led investor group succeeded in buying the company, the group disclosed yesterday.

title: When Tying the Knot Goes Gordian
description: Weddings are becoming precarious occasions here.

title: PCA International reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $235,000 and $282,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $100,000 and $189,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; the 6 months also include a pretax gain of $212,618 from the sale of undeveloped land.

title: First Executive Stake Acquired
description: A group led by Rosewood Financial Inc., a Dallas investment firm controlled by Caroline Rose Hunt, has acquired a 6.2 percent stake in the First Executive Corporation for more than $54 million.

title: Racism Figured in Hastings Impeachment
description: To the Editor:

title: Clubs Settle Suits on Bias In Membership Women May Join Friars And the Union League
description: Two formerly all-male enclaves - the Friars Club and the Union League Club -have settled sex discrimination complaints with New York City, officials said yesterday.

title: Donald DeLue, 90, Sculptor of Monuments
description: Donald DeLue, a sculptor known for monuments and memorials, died yesterday in his sleep. He was 90 years old and lived in Leonardo, N.J.

title: Burma's Road to Self-Liberation
description: Burma is now witness to an elemental display of pure people power. Changes are occurring without covert or overt help, sanctions or the carefully confected phrases of diplomats, and without even visible leadership for the protest movement. The Burmese people seem near to sweeping away the one-party Socialist dictatorship that misruled and intimidated them for 26 years.

title: KEY RATES
an Irish Family to the Gothic Manor Born
description: The Silence in the Garden By William Trevor 204 pages. Viking. $17.95.

title: Tramps Leaves 15th St. For a SoHo Reopening
description: Tramps, the longtime blues and rock club at 125 East 15th Street, will close at its present location tonight after the last set, by Otis Rush.

title: Track and Field; Aouita Captures Grand Prix Title
description: Said Aouita of Morocco easily captured the mile today, wrapping up the men's overall season title in the Grand Prix final, the last major international tuneup before the Seoul Olympics.

title: Soviet Interior Ministry Troops Get More Power to Quell Protesters
description: The Soviet Union has expanded the powers of its Interior Ministry troops, granting them broader authority to bear arms, suppress public demonstrations and enter private homes in pursuit of criminals.

title: Reagan's Allergy Unchanged
description: President Reagan's allergist has determined that there has been no essential change in his sensitivity to pollen, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said today. The President, who receives weekly shots to control the allergy, has been undergoing a series of annual checkups during his August vacation.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 10.

title: Judge Orders Seizure of Items Purchased in Donations Case
description: A judge ordered the seizing of jewelry and other luxury items today that Maria DeSillers is reported to have purchased with some of the $690,000 donated by strangers for her dying son's liver transplants.

title: Jerome Robbins Show Gets a Change of Title
description: ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway Dances'' has a new name: ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway.''

title: Homework For Parents
description: Joshua Robert Lipkin Sautter, age 5, will begin kindergarten this fall at a public school in Washington. His parents have bought him a shiny backpack, and his uncle has given him a ''Ghostbusters'' lunch box.

title: Joanne Brackeen
description: Joanne Brackeen, a pianist, is to perform tomorrow at 3 P.M. at the Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway (718-638-5000). The concert is free with museum admission, which is $3 for adults and $1.50 for students and the elderly; free for children under 12 years old.

title: The Cordero Phenomenon
description: Horse racing is a game in which human will is not supposed to matter. The race may not always go to the swift but, as Damon Runyon said, that's the way to bet it. The best horse usually wins, racing luck evens out in the long run, and the best jockeys are simply the ones who ride the best horses.

title: Richard E. Merriam Is Dead at 69; Fought Chicago Machine Politics
description: Richard E. Merriam, a former Chicago alderman who lost to Richard J. Daley in a 1955 mayoral race and then became an adviser to three Presidents, died Thursday of a heart attack at his Chicago home. He was 69 years old.

title: Giants Are Bruised in Exhibition Finale
description: The Giants, who seemed so dominating in three previous games, closed their exhibition schedule this evening by taking a battering from the Cleveland Browns in a 17-13 defeat at Cleveland Stadium.

title: Corrections
description: A Company Briefs listing in Business Day on Thursday, about the export of microwave ovens to 11 European countries, incorrectly described the plan. The exporter is the Sharp Electronics Corporation, the United States operation of the Sharp Corporation of Japan, and the ovens will be American-made.

title: Corrections
description: A question in the News Quiz last Saturday incorrectly described the succession to President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan. After General Zia's death on Aug. 17, Gulam Ishaq Khan, the leader of the Senate, became Acting President under the Pakistani Constitution.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-4, 26 Two brothers arrested in Sweden have admitted working for the Hungarian intelligence service, Swedish officials said. The Hungarian-born brothers were arrested when Western officials broke up a spy ring. Page 1 A growing sense of futility in Gdansk has set in as a strike continues at the Lenin Shipyard. A tram ride past the yard is the only way to check on striking workers inside, since police have sealed other approaches. 1 Poland's leaders proposed talks with representatives of ''different social groups'' and with ''workers' representatives'' to deal with the labor unrest. The proposal raised the possibility of contact with Solidarity. 2 Soviet Interior Ministry troops have been given broader authority to bear arms, suppress public demonstrations and enter private homes in pursuit of criminals. The decree has not been widely publicized. 3 Iran and Iraq disputed the ownership of a waterway during peace talks in Geneva. Iraq said it would not let the talks advance unless Iran cedes to Iraq full sovereignty over the waterway, the Shatt al Arab. 3 Protesters called on Burma's army to support the insurrection against the Government, which diplomats in Rangoon think will fall soon. Crowds filled the streets of the capital. Fears of lawlessness are growing. 3 Tribal and state marriages in Kenya have come into conflict as women who have married men according to tribal law have stopped their husbands from taking a second wife in the city under statutory law. 4 American officials in Panama have challenged assertions from Washington that the Government of Panama has stepped up harassment of American military personnel and their families. 4 The P.L.O. will declare a government in exile and seek to assume administrative oversight for the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, an aide to Yasir Arafat says. 4 West Bank union offices closed 4 An eerie calm has gripped Kabul as Soviet soldiers continue to withdraw. People are nervous about the future; mosques in the Afghan capital are packed on Fridays, the Moslem day of rest and prayer. 26 Korean talks adjourn in deadlock 3 National 5-8 Eastern Airlines was blocked from dismissing 4,000 workers by a Federal judge's order. The judge left open the question of whether he will allow the airline to cut its flight schedules as planned next week. 1 Nine insolvent savings institutions will be merged with healthy ones, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced. The board said it had committed almost $1 billion in assistance to the transactions. 1 An independent prosecutor will not seek criminal charges against a former Justice Department official who had been accused of misleading Congress in 1983 on the handling of environmental agency documents. 1 The Pentagon's use of consultants is being curtailed. An order by Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci, issued in response to the investigation of procurement fraud, requires his approval for new contracts. 8 Growing isolation in rural areas was the subject of a conference of transportation specialists, who suggested ways of linking abandoned bus stations to Greyhound Lines, the only surviving national bus service. 5 Street-corner hiring of immigrants has become the object of a Federal crackdown, making it more difficult for them to find work. Several cities in California are exploring ways to help immigrants find jobs. 5 The language of sociology has become so dense that some sociologist think that it has become jargon. They worry that the language has lost its precision in describing the condition of the individual in society. 7 Part-time con artists find way to Los Angeles pocketbook 7 Seizure is ordered of items purchased in donations case 7 Lawyers suing F.B.I., accuse bureau of intimidation 8 Politics 6 News analysis: The clash of symbols between George Bush and Michael Dukakis has come to center on Mr. Dukakis's veto of a bill requring teachers to lead their classes in the Pledge of Allegiance. 1 Dan Quayle voiced confidence as he told Vice President Bush that the campaign was going well. But Mr. Quayle has given confusing answers about his stand on the right to own guns and his resume. 6 Bush offers Texans scathing attack of rival 6 Fourth campaign jet is hobbled 6 Regional 27-30 A ruling against Yonkers was upheld by a Federal appeals court, which affirmed a finding of contempt and the imposition of fines against the city and four City Council members who voted against a housing plan. 1 An organized-crime trial in Newark ended after 21 months with the acquittal of 20 defendents accused of making up the Lucchese family in New Jersey. It was one of the country's longest criminal trials. 1 The Environmental Police Unit of New York City's Sanitation Department has helped bring cases this summer against labs, clinics, hospitals and doctors for improperly disposing of medical waste. 27 Ambulances sold at an auction last week by New York City were found to be carrying medical equipment and possible infectious waste, the Democratic majority leader of the City Council said. 27 The New York Hall of Science in Queens has been so successful in the two years since it reopened that the city wants to expand and improve it, officials said. It was built as part of the 1964-65 World's Fair. 27 Two formerly all-male clubs - the Friars Club and the Union League Club - settled sex-discrimination suits with New York City, officials said. The city plans to investigate all private clubs for discriminatory policies. 27 Two youths are charged in Central Park murder 29 Laboratory head charged in illegal disposal of waste 29 Police union leader defends officers at Tompkins Square 29 Koch says hats are for horses, not him 29

title: Review/Film; Enter a Talking Horse And Other Party Animals
description: ''Hot to Trot,'' which opened yesterday at the Criterion Center and other theaters, bills itself as ''the funniest talking horse movie ever.'' That's not so very much to live up to. But even so, ''Hot to Trot'' doesn't qualify, since its biggest innovation is the idea of a horse named Don who's as wisecracking, irreverent and messy as the human characters. The film never gets any funnier than a sequence that has Don wrecking the apartment of his human friend, a stockbroker named Fred, with the help of a goat, a pig, a duck and other self-proclaimed party animals.

title: FICTION
description: EYESTONE. By D. R. MacDonald. (Pushcart, $15.95.) When you pick up D. R. MacDonald's skillfully written first collection of short stories, you'll be transported to Nova Scotia, and to Cape Breton Island in particular. The time will be spring or summer. The modest houses you visit will be surrounded by wildflowers and mown hay; there will be rocky fields with small streams nearby. The people you meet will either be very old or very young, but it will be the old people who will dominate your thoughts. Laconic, proud, Gaelic-speaking and fiercely independent, they are men and women who simply have to be reckoned with. How, for example, can you forget a woman like Mrs. Corbett from the collection's title story? By nothing but sheer, cool presence she persuades her younger landlord to let her stay in his house, only to turn around and nonchalantly give it back to him. In the highly charged story, ''Of One Kind,'' you'll encounter another older woman, Mrs. MacKay, who is blind and widowed but far from fearful. When Red Donald, a handyman even older than she, comes to help with the chores, he gets caught up in the reminiscences of her youth, with results that are as sad as they are exciting. You won't find these singular old people watching television in rest homes or playing bingo at church socials. Instead, they're living out the traditions of their Scottish ancestors, sometimes railing magnificently at life and sometimes accepting even its most indelicate truths. It is an affecting experience to visit the island that is home to these difficult but exceptional people. And D. R. MacDonald, with his taut, clean and honest prose, couldn't be a better guide.

title: TALKING: Cooling; Central Systems Gaining
description: UNTIL this summer's seemingly endless series of torrid days, installing central air-conditioning in a single-family house was not considered a necessity. Only 56 percent of newly built houses outside the South are constructed with central air-conditioning, according to the National Association of Home Builders.

title: A Swingtime Revue: Tunes of the Big Bands
description: THE Music Theater of Connecticut is getting on the bookless bandwagon. With its current revue, ''Jukebox Saturday Night,'' the fledgling but nomadic theater, which has moved from Fairfield to Wilton in less than a year, is manifesting the latest trend in New York City's musical theater: compilation musicals, or shows that consist of hit tunes from past decades.

title: POSTINGS: All in the Family; Steel Plant Making Way for Twin Residential Towers
description: For more than 40 years, Peter Ventricelli's family has made steel girders for the construction industry. Now, he plans to raise a few of his own and right over the site of his Grand View Steel Company in Lodi, N.J. Grand View Towers, with 192 condominiums, will replace the 8,000-square-foot plant on Route 46 and Contant Avenue. The decision was sparked by the company's need for larger quarters. Next March, it will move to a new building four times larger. Then, the 1.7-acre lot in Lodi will be cleared and construction will begin.

title: A Thriller Of Twists And Turns
description: IN ''Murder by the Book,'' now being presented by the Arena Players Repertory Company in East Farmingdale, a vitriolic book critic and successful author of mystery thrillers has an argument with his estranged wife, who then brandishes a gun and shoots him.

title: Clancy's Star Wars
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTCESTER GUIDE
description: TUAREG CALLIGRAPHY Some 50 pieces of calligraphy in the obscure language of the Tuareg, a Berber people of the Sahara, will go on exhibition Thursday through Oct. 2 at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers. Tuareg comprises 21 letters and can be written in any direction, indicated by the orientation of the characters. Generally it reads from bottom to top.

title: DATA UPDATE: August 28, 1988
India Murder Scandal Mixes Sex and Politics
description: It's ''Dallas,'' Delhi-style. In the last few days, a single story has tantalized newspaper readers, radio listeners and television viewers across northern India with a scenario that mixes not only scandal, murder, sex and class, but high-level politics as well.

title: 39 Illegal Social Clubs Closed In Crackdown After a Blaze
description: Less than a week after six people were killed in a fire in an illegal basement social club in the Bronx last Sunday, a city task force has begun a crackdown on similar clubs, which are scattered across New York City.

title: Brand-New Degree And No Place to Go
description: MY DAUGHTER recently graduated from one of those Boston-area colleges that half the high- school valedictorians, editors in chief and Merit Scholarship finalists would kill themselves to get into. Now that she is home, we have all had some time to reflect on the following facts: (1) - While the world applauds a liberal arts education, few prospective employers are actively seeking an international relations major.

title: Cleaning the Ocean: Use Existing Facilities
description: Letta Tayler's article [ ''Congress Considers Ocean Cleanup Plan,'' Aug. 7 ] outlines well both the problems of ocean pollution and certain legislation proposed to address those problems. Clearly, more funds are needed for marine research and, as Representative Hochbrueckner pointed out, for additional cleanup efforts.

title: Things Got Tough When the Steel Mill Shut
description: Half the steelworkers who lost their jobs when the Bethlehem Steel Company closed its plant here in 1983 remained unemployed for at least three years, according to a new state report on the effects of plant closings.

title: Spy Case Leaves Ohio Town In Shock
description: In this little Midwestern town of 5,000 people with its wide, tree-lined streets and classic old white-frame houses, the dominant verities include the Cleveland Browns, the flag, and the honor of the United States.

title: METS LIGHT IT UP (EARLY, LATE)
description: And the rocket's red glare, the bomb bursting in air, Gave proof through the night that Roger McDowell was still there. Talk about attention-getters. Bill Veeck had his exploding scoreboard. Charles O. Finley had Bugs Bunny pop out of the ground behind home plate. George Steinbrenner unleashes Billy Martin.

title:
ART;
Tracing the Changes and Constants of an Innovative Sculptor
description: LEAD: ''WILLIAM TUCKER: The American Decade, 1978-88,'' at the Storm King Arts Center here, is composed of only 17 sculptures plus large drawings, yet it has the effect of being a sweeping, high-minded exhibition. Mr. Tucker is a scholar as well as a constantly innovative sculptor, and both his constants and his changes keep one fully absorbed.

title: Notebook; McKeon Faces Problem: To Manage or Be General Manager
description: Jim Frey and Bobby Cox have tried managing and being general managers, and they prefer being general managers. Whitey Herzog held both jobs at the same time, and then he readily relinquished the general manager's duties and continued managing. Lou Piniella fled the front office after seven months and later returned to the dugout. Now it's Jack McKeon's turn to decide. The decision could have been much easier, but McKeon, the San Diego general manager, created a tough choice for himself by managing the Padres to the best record in the National League since he replaced Larry Bowa as manager three months ago today.

title: Law Teacher Wed To Ms. Woodman
description: Catherine Lynne Woodman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thaddeus A. Woodman Jr. of Youngstown, Ohio, and Walter Patrick Loughlin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. L. Leo Loughlin of San Jose, Calif., were married yesterday. Acting Justice Anne G. Feldman of New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the couple's summer home in Amagansett, L.I.

title: 2 Festivals To Cap Weekend
description: LEAD: IF MORE is better, then Labor Day weekend should be memorable when it comes to the performing arts on Long Island.

title: Review/Rock; Voice, Guitar and Soul By Robert Cray at Pier 84
description: Restraint may be fine for diplomats and pitchers, but for musicians playing a long show to an audience in an uncomfortable place, it gets to be wearing. Robert Cray, the genial singer and guitarist who performed Thursday night at Pier 84, may be the perfect symbol for the 1980's: not only is he restrained and utterly controlled - though not cold - but he's a revivalist as well, drawing on early soul to give his material passion.

title: The Passing of Quarterbacks Into Dominance
description: Troy Aikman had completed 6 of 7 passes for 131 yards against a defense that would be in two national championship games. He was trying to overcome Miami's 14-7 lead with 9 minutes 18 seconds left in the first half. Then the classic dropback passer was sacked by Jerome Brown, a defensive tackle, and Aikman left Oklahoma's fourth game of the 1985 season with a broken left leg.

title: Sorting Out Who Was Who in Rome
description: The face suggests a man encumbered by imperial burdens, and no doubt he was. Among the 22 ancient Roman busts now on display at the Emory University Museum of Art and Archeology, this smoothly carved rendering of an older man with close-cropped hair, slightly turned-down lips and heavy brow might well strike a viewer as the sculptural embodiment of authority. So might another portrait, its artfully molded features including the faint worry lines and conspicuously studious expression that characterized depictions of powerful men during the Julio-Claudian period of the first century A.D., when this sculpture was made.

title: Stamford to Bring Back Trolleys for Downtown
description: STAMFORD will replace the buses it now uses to shuttle shoppers and commuters to stores and offices in the downtown area with gas-powered reproductions of 1900's-era enclosed streetcars, city officials said.

title: Oyster Bay May Ban Big Project
description: PROMPTED by a proposal to convert a shipyard into a complex of condominiums with a full-service marina and boat repair center, and by concern about the proposal from local residents, baymen and environmentalists, the Town of Oyster Bay is considering a one-year building moratorium for the waterfront area in the Oyster Bay hamlet.

title: On Taming Those Defensive Moves
description: IF you want to be lazy and cut short the kind of extensive openings analysis that is rife these days, there are some ways of accomplishing this.

title: THE NATION: 13 Campaigners; Reagan Cabinet's New Task: Help Bush Win Presidency
description: AT a recent Cabinet meeting, Samuel R. Pierce Jr. handed out ''Bush for President'' neckties. Then, a White House aide said, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development told the group: ''Guys, it's now time to get on board and push for Bush.''

title: Some Light Fare in Hartford
description: IN the vanguard of the grilled meats-and-fish trend, Congress Rotisserie has been a moderately priced mainstay of Hartford since it first opened its doors three years ago.

title: Drama vs. Noise at the Open
description: In recent years, attention has focused on the negatives as many tennis players have come to view the United States Open as a necessary evil, such as visiting the dentist at least once a year. There are the jets thundering overhead, trains rumbling nearby, boisterous crowds, scheduling quirks and sticky, late-summer New York City weather, all of which make the Open unique, but also the most disconcerting of the Grand Slam tournaments.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Montpelier, Vt.;
Land-Sale Curb Called Effective
description: LEAD: THE Vermont Legislature, in a move to regulate companies that subdivide and rapidly resell rural land to city dwellers, last year passed laws that both increased oversight of such deals and raised taxes on land-sale profits. According to state officials and representatives of the land companies, the results have proven to be dramatic.

title: Getting Rough
description: The rule for boxers seems simple enough: Inside the ring, it pays to punch; outside the ring, it costs. Mike Tyson apparently forgot it last week. The heavyweight champion was in an all-night Harlem clothing store in the wee hours when in walked Mitch (Blood) Green, a rather contentious fighter whom Tyson had defeated in 1986. The two men disagree over how their street bout started, but both agree that Tyson threw a punch -Green's nose and eye bear witness. ''I had no other choice,'' said Tyson. Said Green: ''He sucker-punched me.'' But Tyson may have jeopardized a multimillion-dollar payday when he did so. He injured his hand, which may prompt the postponement of a bout set for Oct. 8.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Newark, Del.; Drought Dries Construction
description: MARVIN S. GILMAN was one of the lucky builders. He started his 105-home development in this university town on the Maryland state line before the city turned off the tap.

title: At Compounce, Sellout Crowds
description: FOR Joseph Balestrieri, the new co-owner of the Lake Compounce Festival Park in Bristol, it was a bittersweet experience. Thousands of cars were trying to get into the amusement park, but for the most part, they were unable to move because of a huge traffic tieup.

title: 'With Pen in Hand': Long-Range Effects
description: Re: Wilma Davidson's recent Opinion page article ''With Pen in Hand, We Hesitate'':

title: Dissension Among Jurors Emerges After Lucchese Verdict
description: Most of the jurors in the 21-month Federal racketeering trial of 20 defendants accused of making up the membership of the Lucchese crime family had their minds made up to vote for acquittal before deliberations even began, a woman who served on the panel said yesterday.

title: A Change In Rule on Conversion Attempts
description: It will be possible this college football season for a defensive team to score during a conversion attempt. The defense can block a kick behind the line of scrimmage, recover the loose ball and return it the length of the field. Or it can return a kick that is deflected in midair. Or it can return an intercepted 2-point conversion pass, or a fumble caught in midair. Fumbles on the ground still cannot be advanced by the defense.

title: The Justice Department Takes On Diplomatic Tasks Pursuing Foreign Targets
description: AS he waits in tropical splendor at his home in Honolulu, Ferdinand E. Marcos, the former President of the Philippines, has reason to worry about the work of Justice Department prosecutors in Manhattan.

title: Seeking an Advantage With New Surfaces
description: WHEN it comes to tennis courts ''everybody is constantly trying to reinvent the wheel,'' said Jerry Gray, president of the tennis division of the United States Tennis Court and Track Builders Association.

title: Many Shades of Jazz in a Relevatory Trove
description: Plowing through ''The Commodore Recordings, Volume One'' (Mosaic Records, 197 Strawberry Hill Avenue, Stamford, Conn.,06902; albums only) is a bit like exploring ''Moby Dick'': it's stuffed with all sorts of odds and ends, it takes a long time to get through it, and by the time the experience is over, it's changed you. The volume's 23 albums, with 345 tracks (67 of them previously unreleased) feature everything from classic sessions - including Billie Holiday's ''Strange Fruit'' session and Lester Young's Kansas City Six recording date -to 18 tracks of rare Teddy Wilson solo piano performances. When the listening gets hard, a 64-page booklet - including an inteview with Commodore's founder, Milt Gabler, and excellent annotations by the jazz critic Dan Morgenstern - can help pass the time.

title: No More Veeps
description: LEAD: Perhaps the most significant and constructive change in national politics would be the abolition of the Vice Presidency. The history of this office, and of its bearing on the Presidency and on good government, is one of distraction and of near-disaster. The nomination of Senator Dan Quayle is only the most recent example.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: The Glass Menagerie Starring Joanne Woodward, Karen Allen, John Malkovich, James Naughton. Directed by Paul Newman. 1987. MCA Home Video. 134 minutes. $79.95. Rated PG. Contains some strong language.
