title: An Ample Reward
description: HOW do you thank a man who led your team to Super Bowl glory and was too proud to ask for a reward? The Washington Redskins thought money might be the answer, and Doug Williams said they thought right. At the team's welcome home lunch on Friday, Williams was given a new contract that will make the quarterback a million-dollar man for the next three years.

title: USAir Pact Reached On Flight Attendants
description: After months of dispute including a job action that forced 170 flight cancellations, USAir and its flight attendants' union have reached a tentative agreement on wage parity for former Pacific Southwest Airlines attendants.

title: Ann Timmons, Actress, Marries David N. Biette
description: At the First Presbyterian Church in Manhattan, Ann Elizabeth Timmons, a daughter of Dr. G. Dean Timmons of Stow, Ohio, and Janet W. Timmons of Akron, Ohio, was married yesterday to David Normand Biette, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Biette of Reading, Mass. The Rev. Peter L. Amerman performed the ceremony.

title: Arafat Said to Be 'Playing With' Idea of Exile Rule
description: The United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, said today that Yasir Arafat, the Chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, is ''playing with'' the idea of setting up a government in exile to represent Arabs in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title:
MUSIC;
Operetta With an 80's Flounce? Yes, Say Two Directors
description: LEAD: What, these days, are we to make of operetta? There may be as many answers as there are directors willing to tackle the hoary genre, and New York audiences will have the opportunity over the coming months to sample two fresh but contrasting approaches through the work of two very different directors.

title: FICTION
description: THE HOUSE THAT JACK BUILT. By Ed McBain. (Henry Holt, $16.95.) Ed McBain, the prolific, pseudonymous master of the terse, fast-paced - and formulaic - mystery novel, has once again reconstructed a classic children's story and added a sardonic twist. Jonathan Parrish, who was a homosexual and had AIDS, has been murdered at his beach-front home in the Florida Keys, and his brother Ralph, a homophobic farmer from Indiana, has been charged with the crime. Enter Matthew Hope, a middle-aged, middle-class, middle-of-the-road defense attorney who is convinced of Ralph's innocence. Naturally, the apparently simple case quickly turns Byzantine, replete with wealthy heiresses, illicit romances, sordid sex, a mysterious figure in black and a sassy private investigator called Toots Kiley. (''Who nicknamed you Toots?'' asks her new partner. ''It's not a nickname,'' she replies.) To a regular reader of Mr. McBain's books - already familiar with his one-sentence paragraphs and taut, punchy dialogue - ''The House That Jack Built'' will probably be a welcome addition to the Matthew Hope series, of which there are now eight books. A first-time reader, however, may be distracted by the author's occasional lapses in logic. (It is unlikely, for example, that a local newspaper's morgue, capable of preserving a birth announcement from 1906, would not maintain a file on one of the town's leading businesses.) Even more distracting, however, is the author's obvious manipulation of the plot.

title: Accord Is Reached on Housing Plan in Boston
description: The city and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People have settled a challenge to an agreement over a non-discriminatory public housing plan worked out in June between the Boston Housing Authority and the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Long Fight Over, She's Prepared to Become Scoutmaster
description: LEAD: THE Boy Scouts of America told her no, and so did the courts, but time was on Catherine N. Pollard's side. In a week and a half, after a fight of nearly a decade and a half, she will become the leader of a Boy Scout troop.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: The Stables Are Full

title: Little Growth in Home Prices Expected in New York Region
description: With an unusually large number of homes for sale and buyers insisting on bargains, a consensus has emerged among economists and real estate professionals that prices in the New York metropolitan region will increase little, if at all, for the rest of the decade.

title: Donald Verrilli Jr. And Miss Laster, Lawyer, Marry
description: At the Riverside Church in New York, Gail Winnifer Laster, the daughter of Mabelle W. Brown of Spring Valley, N.Y., and James S. Laster of Oakland, Calif., was married yesterday to Donald Beaton Verrilli Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Verrilli of Wilton, Conn.

title: A Debut for New Films New Slide Films Make Their Debut An Assessment of the Newest Slide Films
description: PHOTOGRAPHERS who like to try new films, the way some people like to try on new clothes, have been busy lately. Within the last 12 months the parade of chic and stylish emulsions has gone on practically nonstop, joined by such model revamping as the relabeling of Kodak's VR-G color-print films as Kodacolor Gold.

title: John Kiernan Jr. Weds Mary Howarth, Lawyer
description: Mary Lee Anne Howarth, a lawyer, and John Burke Kiernan Jr., a vice president of investment banking at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York, were married yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Closter, N.J. The Rev. Daniel P. O'Neill performed the ceremony.

title: AIDS Case Open: AIDS Unit Not
description: LEAD: THE Westchester County Medical Center, criticized by the State Department of Health for allegedly failing to provide confidentiality to a patient carrying the AIDS virus, has been unable to resolve its differences with the department and has not received permission to open a special unit to treat AI

title: Leaders of the Pack
description: JUST FLASHY PACKAGING, smoke and mirrors, glitz without substance - at least that's the skeptic's view of the cosmetics business. But in reality, many more women are drawn to decorative makeup, skincare and fragrance packaging than are put off by it. And it seems that packaging is becoming increasingly more elaborate.

title: POSTINGS: 680 for Torrington; Condos Around A Lake
description: The first condominium community in Connecticut to surround and own a lake is being built in Torrington on the shores of a brass company's conceit. Stillwater Pond was created in 1911 by the Coe Brass Company to insure a supply of fresh water for its growing business. The Naugatuck River was dammed, and Stillwater grew to lake-size dimensions - a mile-and-a-half long and 700 feet wide. But then the brass industry declined, Coe went out of business, and its fresh water was used only in winter, when it was cut and stacked in an icehouse.

title: B. J. Scanlan Wed To Cynthia Chang
description: The marriage of Cynthia Chia-yu Chang, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chao-ying Chang of Jamaica Estates, Queens, and Monterey, Mass., to Brian James Scanlan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Scanlan of Bristol, R.I., took place yesterday. The Rev. Salvatore Riccardi performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church in Jamaica Estates. He was assisted by the Rev. Wu-tong Hwang, a Presbyterian minister.

title: Nancy Lewin, Banker, Weds Steven John Sun
description: Nancy Lee Lewin, a vice president in domestic banking at Chase Manhattan Bank, and Steven John Sun, an associate in investment banking at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, were married yesterday in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Avery C. Manchester officiated at the First Church of Round Hill.

title: Guadalcanal
description: To the Editor: Like many other veterans of the war in the Pacific who read Moana Tregaskis's article on Guadalcanal, I found ''Glancing Back to '42 . . .'' (Travel, July 10) both intriguing and evocative.

title:
MUSIC;
Boys Getting Earlier Start for Chorus
description: LEAD: RANDALL SVANE, music director of the Newark Boys Chorus, says that boys' voices are changing earlier than they used to.

title: Shedding Weight
description: THAT was undoubtedly William (Refrigerator) Perry who appeared on defense for the Chicago Bears in the team's preseason loss to the Los Angeles Rams Friday night, but for those who have followed the ups and downs of his career, it was clear this Refrigerator was minus a crisper or so. Indeed, he was an eighth of a Perry lighter than he was last spring, when he tipped the scales at 377 pounds. After treatment for an eating disorder, Perry seems to be down to the 330-pound range, and while that's not exactly svelt, Perry and his coach, Mike Ditka, both seemed delighted.(AP)

title: Q and A
description: Spouse Can Pay Rent

title: Schools Trying to Desegregate On Their Own
description: HAVING city and suburban youngsters train for health-care careers together, study marine sciences and take field trips everywhere from farms to city skyscrapers are among the first proposals for ways to help break down the racial dividers between school districts across Connecticut. They will not be the last. As the new school year begins, programs to desegregate the state's schools are expected to be a major topic of discussion. What put the issue in the forefront was a report last December by the State Education Department that called attention to the lack of desegregation in the state's 166 public school districts.

title: Races Won't Settle Disputes
description: The squabbles between Michael Fay, chairman of New Zealand's challenge for the America's Cup, and the San Diego Yacht Club are unlikely to subside with the start of the cup series Sept. 7 in San Diego.

title: NONFICTION
description: YANGTZE: Nature, History, and the River. By Lyman P. Van Slyke. (Addison-Wesley, $14.95.) The Yangtze River flows 3,900 miles through China from its glacial source at 20,000 feet on the Tibetan-Qinghai plateau to the East China Sea, watering regions where nearly 350 million Chinese live. Yet sections are so rugged that the world's third-longest river (after the Nile and the Amazon) was not navigated from source to mouth until 1986. These are but a few of the intriguing facts about the Changjiang, or ''Long River,'' as the Chinese call it, served up by Lyman P. Van Slyke, a professor of history at Stanford University. His book is most readable when it cites eyewitness accounts of early Chinese and Western travelers or describes the commerce in tea, rice and salt that created wealth in ancient China. He also brings alive the perilous navigating technique known as tracking, in which onshore gangs of coolies straining against heavy bamboo hawsers slowly hauled the river junks upstream against the surging white water of the gorges. When Mr. Van Slyke turns to geography, his narrative style dries up, and there are no voices from the river people caught up in the momentous economic changes today. This could have been a good book to pack along on one of the popular Yangtze cruises but for Mr. Van Slyke's insistence on rendering virtually every Chinese name in the old Wade-Giles ''romanization'' devised in the 19th century rather than in the Pinyin system used throughout China today. The author contends that ''Wade-Giles and pinyin exist side by side''; perhaps at Stanford they do, but not along the Yangtze, where the Western tourist may not understand that Mr. Van Slyke's ''Chungking in Szechwan province'' is now the city of Chongqing in Sichuan or that the spectacular Hsi-ling Gorge coming up is spelled Xiling in the guidebooks.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST

title:
TELEVISION TYCOON: George Gillett Jr.;
Assembling an Entertainment Empire, Deal by Deal

By day, he skied with his creditors at the Vail and Beaver Creek resorts, which he bought in 1985 while on vacation. In the evening, he had them hauled up ''one of our mountains'' on a sled as they drank schnapps and admired the starlit sky.

title: A Secret Way to Fly Cheaper

I could fly to Detroit and take a commuter plane to Lansing, or fly to Detroit, rent a car and drive the rest of the way. Since I'm a public-interest lawyer, my first concern was cost. Could I afford the extra expense of flying through to Lansing?

title: Single Goal in Chicago: Black Mayor
description: More than 500 representatives of community and church groups gathered today at a South Side church and determined that they would settle on one black candidate to support in next year's special election for mayor.

description: For a 19-year-old tennis player who is supposed to be feeling the pressure of being ranked No. 1 in the world, Steffi Graf has looked awfully comfortable this week.

title: In the Wake of a Crash, Questions
description: LEAD: SHORTLY after one o'clock on the rainy morning of July 27, a single-engine plane slammed into the dense woods of the Rockefeller estate here. Aboard were Peter V. Church, 31 years old, and John A. Griffiths, 30, of Greenwich, Conn. Their last known words were: ''Mayday - Mayday - Mayday,'' a distress signal heard by the Coast Guard near Bridgeport,

description: Throughout his long life, the Mexican muralist Diego Rivera had an uncanny sense of timing.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: In Middle America, a Movie Finds Its Milieu
description: ''She was 8 or 9. On the evening news, a report from Vietnam - it was during the fall of Saigon, in 1975, she thought - showed some people walking along a road with bundles on their backs. Some were carrying babies in their arms. Army jeeps chugged along the road. The landscape was believable - a hill in the distance, a paved road with narrow dirt shoulders, a field with something green planted in rows. The road resembled the old Hopewell road that twisted through the bottomland toward Paducah. For the first time, Vietnam was an actual place. As Sam watched, a child in a T-shirt and no pants ran down the road, and its mother called after it, scolding it.'' - Bobbie Ann Mason, ''In Country''

title: Schools Can Survive With the PTA
description: I, too, sympathize with the plight of the organizations mentioned in the article ''Help Wanted, P/T, Immediate: Volunters Please Apply'' (July 3). PTA's at the local, state and national levels have depended on volunteers to provide support for schools, school districts and students since 1897.

title: Violence in Northern Ireland Marks Extradition of Convict
description: Six bombs exploded in Northern Ireland's two main cities and demonstrators fought with the police to protest the extradition of a convicted Irish Republican Army guerrilla, the police said today.

title: Bankruptcy Closes Sites For Waste in Vermont
description: The financial collapse of a New Jersey company that builds plants to convert waste into energy has sent 60 Vermont communities scrambling to dispose of their garbage as officials try to work out a solution.

title: Ms. Elsen Weds C. A. Rooney 3d
description: Susan Rachel Elsen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon H. Elsen of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Charles Augustine Rooney 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rooney Jr. of Montclair, N.J., were married last evening at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park. Judge Judith S. Kaye of the New York Court of Appeals performed the ceremony.

title: New York Weighs Shift In Setting Bond Rates
description: Local governments in New York would be allowed to negotiate the interest rate on new bond issues rather than selling the bonds at interest rates set through competitive bidding, under terms of a bill the New York Assembly is expected to consider next month.

title: Miss Stowell Has Wedding
description: Susan Scott Stowell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Curtis Stowell of Riverside, Conn., was married there yesterday to Peter Romer Chapman, a son of Mrs. William Lansing Chapman Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Chapman. The Rev. Dr. Philip E. Perkins performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: NONFICTION
description: A WOMAN ON PAPER: Georgia O'Keeffe. By Anita Pollitzer. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, Paper, $12.95.) By showing Alfred Stieglitz some drawings by Georgia O'Keeffe, Anita Pollitzer brought about what is perhaps the most storied conjunction in American art. Pollitzer's account of that incident in January 1916 anchors this epistolary memoir-cum-biography, written more than 30 years ago but unpublished until now because O'Keeffe, who died in 1986, refused to approve the manuscript. Pollitzer and O'Keeffe became friends while studying at Columbia University in 1914-15, and they apparently remained so until Pollitzer's death in 1975. Yet the book, which contains 40 black-and-white photographs, suggests they were closest during their student days and for the next few years. Pollitzer quotes only a few letters to her from O'Keeffe after 1917; thereafter, she relies on O'Keeffe's letters to others and references to occasional meetings. The early chapters, written as memoir, are thus the more vivid, personal and insightful. When she's required to fall back on secondary sources, her narrative tails off into warmed-over, sketchy biography. And, of course, she doesn't write critically; her portrait, as one might expect, is thoroughly affectionate and deferential. O'Keeffe was a reclusive person, and 30 years ago her correspondence might have created a stir. But with 125 of her letters (including a number to Pollitzer) published last year in the catalogue for the exhibition celebrating the centennial of her birth, this book reads like an afterthought or a footnote.

title: Why Can't The Mets Hit Anymore?
description: The Mets don't have a hitting problem, they have a rhythm problem. Players gain rhythm in practice, and playing regularly. Any platoon system disrupts a player's rhythm, as he plays one day and sits the bench another.

title: The Low Road
description: Ronald Reagan showed in 1980 that a conservative could run an affirmative campaign of ideas. His themes were lower taxes, higher military spending and other ideas shaped by the modern conservative movement, all presented in a framework of optimism. Like them or not, they were powerfully effective.

title: In Schools, the Test is for Asbestos
description: SPECIALLY trained consultants have been inspecting many of Westchester's schools this summer, but their mission has had little to do with education. Instead, they have been testing all the building materials in schools for traces of cancer-causing asbestos.

title: Districts Pressed for Class Space
description: AROUND Connecticut this fall, elementary school students will attend classes in makeshift classrooms, in rooms without blackboards and other features expected in the classroom, and even in rented commercial space, as enrollments for kindergarten to third grade increase.

title: BASEBALL: National League; Dodgers Top Phils for Lasorda's 1,000th Victory
description: Tim Leary and two relievers combined on a six-hitter tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 4-2.

title: PLUSES OF MALPRACTICE SUITS
description: I am a 1979 graduate of the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine; I consider myself to be intelligent, compassionate and morally upright (Body and Mind: ''Pluses of Malpractice Suits, by William Ira Bennett, July 24). Yet, I and thousands of other physicians like me, have been influenced negatively by the current system of protecting against medical malpractice in this country. We order more tests than necessary; we worry that each bad outcome (and these are almost always when we have done the correct thing but the result was unsuccessful) will lead to a subpoena; we give up certain areas of our professional lives (e.g. delivering babies) because the risk of a suit is too high. Dr. Bennett may believe that defensive medicine is ''hard to prove.'' I invite him to my next medical-school reunion; he will quickly discover what can happen to an idealistic med student in 10 years.

title: 'With Pen in Han': Long-Range Effects
description: Wilma Davidson's article was wonderful to read and confirmed so many things for me. My son was plagued with ''rigid teaching'' methods. He suffered from some sort of nonspecific dyslexia, which prevented him from being able to spell.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: SAY YOU WANT ME. By Richard Cohen. (Soho, $17.95.) Brendan Beame, the hero of Richard Cohen's third novel, is a man who feels he has been left behind. A struggling commercial artist, he looks after Jeff, his 18-month-old son, while Lila, his business executive wife, heads off to work each day as the family breadwinner.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE POISON CONTROL CENTER IN FARMINGTON;
Hot Line Helps Poison Victims Before It's Too Late
description: LEAD: IT was is mid-afternoon, a quiet time at the Connecticut Poison Control Center in Farmington, a hotline in Farmington that receives about 100 distress calls in a 24-hour period. and two nurses were waiting for the telephone to ring.

title:
GARDENING;
Ideal Tropicals for the Summer Garden
description: LEAD: MANY tropical and subtropical plants are used in our gardens and adapt well to summer since they are so tolerant of heat.

title: There Are No 'Best,' Except. . .
description: All sensible people with more than a casual interest in music hold these truths to be self-evident: There is no such thing as a best performance, and there is no such thing as a best performer. Sometimes it is hard to hold on to the verities, especially when reading record reviews in which performers and their performances are treated as consumer commodities (''Miss Hooter's 'Dove sono' is carefully made and should give acceptable service over the short run, but in our tests the performance carried a potential for shock when heard in an excessively dry room. The 'best buy' still is Zabaglione's version, recorded in her shower in 1936 and now available on the Permamoist label.'').

title: Ms. Snelling, Artist, Weds
description: The marriage of Diane Bryant Snelling, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Snelling of Shelburne, Vt., to James Krauss, a son of Frances Krauss of Highland Park, Ill., and the late Hyman J. Krauss, took place yesterday at the Snelling home. Judge Alden Bryan of the Vermont District Court in Burlington officiated.

title: Africa
description: To the Editor: This is an addition to the reply given in the Q & A column of July 17, to the person interested in travel in Zaire and around the Congo River.

title: Managing Mail
description: To the Editor:

title: Karren Bain Is Married
description: Karren J. Bain and Christopher Garrity, both graduates of Sarah Lawrence College, were married yesterday at the Kent (Conn.) Congregational Church by the Rev. Glen Rainsley. The bride, a daughter of David Bain of Kent and Susan Wise of New Orleans, is the general manager of the New York office of Corporate Executive Offices. The bridegroom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Garrity of Milton, Mass., is an account executive at Pace Advertising in New York.

title: Taormina
description: To the Editor: Some years ago while vacationing in Taormina, Sicily, I suffered a heart attack and was hospitalized for 20 days there. The doctors, nurses and a Roman Catholic nun were wonderful. The building was very old, the plumbing primitive and the bathroom unisex. I was in an eight-man ward where there was no privacy (no screens). When my wardmates discovered that my parents hailed from a nearby village called Salice and that I spoke Sicilian, they adopted me. The total cost for 20 days was $400; it was a fantastic experience! JOSEPH FEMINO Salem, Mass.

title: Getting Attention
description: Cesar Chavez is eating again. The 61-year-old president of the United Farm Workers of America broke his 36-day fast last week surrounded by thousands of supporters of his boycott of California table grapes. Twenty years ago, Mr. Chavez ended a 25-day fast by sharing a Roman Catholic Communion with Senator Robert F. Kennedy; last week, he shared Communion with the late Senator's children. Mr. Chavez engaged in the fast, during which he lost 33 pounds, to call attention to his union's demand for a ban on five pesticides used on table grapes.

title: Uplifting Tragedy
description: BLACK ORPHEUS Starring Marpessa Dawn and Breno Melo (in photo), Lourdes de Oliveira. Directed by Marcel Camus. 1958. Connoisseur Video Collection. 103 minutes. $79.95. In Portuguese, with English subtitles.

title: Group Assails School Lunches
description: School lunches are too often made up of fried foods and other dishes with a high fat content, a consumer nutrition group said, urging the Federal Government to change its farm commodities program to encourage cafeterias to serve healthier meals.

title: Paying Workers Extra to Be Their Own Efficiency Experts
description: AS the notion of profit sharing once unsettled labor-management relations, so now is something called gain sharing. This performance incentive device, linked to increases in productivity or reductions in costs, is increasingly popular among employers, but sometimes is greeted with suspicion by organized labor.

title: David W. Geen Wed To Jessica R. Wilson
description: Jessica Ruth Wilson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sloan Wilson of Winter Park, Fla., was married yesterday to David William Geen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Geen of Pelham Manor, N.Y. The Rev. Norman C. Siefferman performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in King George, Va.

title: The Promise That Failed
description: DEATH IS GRAY, AN ASHEN dusky gray. It comes as a fog, sometimes creeping in stealthily, other times dropping like a curtain. The eyes often register it first, drifting off to a distant horizon beyond mortal knowledge. Curiously, those who know death intimately will look not only in the eyes, but also at the fingernails. As darkness descends, the crescent moon rising from the base of the nail will seemingly bathe its entire surface in a ghostly light. Eventually, the body also takes on this pallor. Pale blue veins stand out like spidery tracings. As muscles lose tone and organs malfunction, a chalky turgidity sets in.

title: Baseball's Subordination to Authority Exemplifies Capitalism; The Marxian Family
description: To the Editor:

title: THIS SYMBOLISM CLEARED FOR TAKEOFF
description: IMAGES OF FLIGHT By Clive Hart. Illustrated. 300 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $32.50.

title: Coastal Pollution: No Quick Remedy Seen
description: ALTHOUGH some initiatives now under way could slightly improve conditions along New Jersey's coastline by next year, marine scientists and others say the worst of the state's coastal pollution problems will persist for years, or even decades.

title: End to County Pay for Keeler Urged
description: ''IF she were perceived as easy to beat,'' said Anthony J. Colavita, chairman of the New York State and the Westchester County Republican Party, ''I'd have 50 candidates.''

title: 'The Lottery'
description: In The Book Review of July 3, Judy Oppenheimer, the author of ''Private Demons: The Life of Shirley Jackson,'' described some of the public reaction to the printing of Jackson's short story ''The Lottery'' in The New Yorker in 1948: ''Nothing in the magazine before or since would provoke such a huge outpouring of fury, horror, rage, disgust and intense fascination. . . . Readers felt called upon to invent their own . . . explanations. . . . 'You are tools of Stalin.' . . . 'In this story you show the perversion of democracy.' . . . 'I suppose . . . a magazine may decide to print something that hasn't any point just to get people talking.' '' The excerpts that follow are derived from the mail received by The Book Review since the publication of Judy Oppenheimer's essay last month. Evidently the passage of 40 years has not deprived ''The Lottery'' of its power to compel interpretation. To the Editor:

title: The Dark Side of Globalization
description: MONEY talks. Koreans own The Washington Times. From the G. Heileman Company Inc. - the brewer - to Bonwit Teller - the department store - Australians have come up from down-under to buy companies throughout the United States. And you can drive all over this nation on General Tires - made by a company now owned by the Germans - or on tires made by Firestone - which was recently bought by the Japanese.

title: CHILDREN'S SCIENCE FOR GROWN-UPS
description: RAINBOWS, CURVE BALLS And Other Wonders of the Natural World Explained. By Ira Flatow. Illustrated. 240 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $15.95

description: DURING the last part of August, no one worries more about the weather than Walter L. Bichay, the food and beverage director of the Rye Town Hilton here.

title:
GARDENING;
It's Easy to Multiply Plants at This Time of Year
description: LEAD: PROPAGATING plants makes more than just good economic sense: it is the essence of creative gardening. After all, continuing new life from the old is what helps keep a gardener young at heart.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Newtown
description: NEWTOWN sprawls over 60.38 square miles of wooded, rolling hills along the Housatonic River in Connecticut's northern Fairfield County, but its heart, in the view of many residents, is a few blocks of quintessential New England known as Main Street.

title: JARUZELSKI CALLS FOR 'TURNAROUND' ON POLISH POLICIES
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, today mounted an attack on Government policy and called for a ''courageous turnaround'' to pull Poland out of its economic and labor crisis.

title: Jets End Exhibition Season by Showing They Need Practice
description: The Jets' preseason ended about a month too soon, judging by how the team closed it today.

title: Pop Passports - At a Price
description: Not too long ago, I was sure that the best thing a band could carry was a foreign passport. All the better if it came from a place that didn't have nonstop air service to New York or didn't conduct business in English; distance from our mainstream was a kind of pedigree. But in popular music, everything conspires to shrink that distance, and fast. As the worldwide audience beckons, farflung musicians have to decide whether and how much to modernize and internationalize. If they go too far, innovation can turn into homogenization.

title: Lobbies
description: To the Editor:

title: Elisa M. Gribin Wed To Michael Litchman
description: The marriage of Elisa Margaret Gribin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathanial D. Gribin of Kings Point, L.I., to Michael Jay Litchman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry M. Litchman of Providence, R.I., took place last evening at the Plaza in New York. Rabbi Robert S. Widom officiated. Mrs. Litchman, who graduated magna cum laude from Wheaton College, is a saleswoman with the Corcoran Group Downtown, a New York real-estate brokerage. Her father is the publisher of Comin' Back, a periodical directed to trauma survivors and their families.

title: Touring High Weald Landmarks
description: LEAD: LIKE squat, red-faced bishops wearing miters slightly askew, oast houses are visible for miles on the rolling hills of the High Weald in Kent.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: THROUGH their windshields, through the heat-warped air rising from overheated engines and overheated tarmac, they can see the drawbridge thumbing its nose at the sky. In the back seat, the kids, whose patience is at Min. and fluid capacity at Max., fidget and fuss. Up front sit the parents, anxieties focused on overheating engines, unchecked burners on the stove back home, lunch and the weight they didn't lose in time for the annual trip to the

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
Throwing One's Weight Around
description: LEAD: SOMETIME next week, I'll be sitting in my den, reading the paper, when a deafening roar emanating from the upstairs closet will puncture the late-summer tranquillity.

title: The Presumed Uniqueness of Japan
description: FIVE YEARS IN JAPAN HAVE LEFT me thinking a good deal about Bernstein, the scratchy-voiced business manager in the movie ''Citizen Kane.'' When a visitor speaks admiringly of a wealthy man, Bernstein waves him off. ''It's no trick to make a lot of money,'' he says, ''if all you want is to make a lot of money.'' Japan in the late 1980's understands Bernstein. It is fabulously rich, and sure to get richer. It is so rich that even its own people have come to believe it. That wasn't the case when I arrived in 1983.

title: Why Can't The Mets Hit Anymore?
description: The first-place Mets are first in home runs, second in runs batted in, and fourth in batting average in the National League.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Flagstaff, Ariz.;
Wanted: More Rental Housing
description: LEAD: BUILDERS in this popular ski area, with a population that is growing 3 to 4 percent a year and now stands at 41,000, are responding to a demand for rental housing that has reached the point of waiting lists for unfinished apartments.

title: Marchers Exhorted to Go After 'Deferred Dreams'
description: A crowd marched to the Lincoln Memorial today, 25 years after the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. spoke there of his dream of racial brotherhood, and were exhorted to work for ''deferred dreams'': easing poverty and expanding opportunity.

title: Verbatim; Self-Blame
description: 'The handling of the demonstration at Tompkins Square Park was not the New York City Police Department's finest hour. . . . The pictures of officers striking demonstrators with their nightsticks erase the good will and praise the department earns every day for its good deeds and heroic actions. ' -New York City Police Department, in its report on the Aug. 6 melee.

title: Correction
description: A graphic accompanying the Week in Business column last week misstated the monthly increase in the rate of factory utilization. The July rate was four-tenths of a percentage point higher than June's.

title: New Rules Are Issued On Rights of Victims
description: LEAD: FOR some crime victims, coping with the criminal justice system can be almost as traumatic as the crime itself. They may have to deal with insensitive, perfunctory questioning; fear resulting from real or imagined threats and intimidating acts by defendants; lack of clear explanations of proceedings and decisions during and after the case.

title:
THEATER;
Should Equal Opportunity Apply on the Stage?
description: LEAD: James Earl Jones as Big Daddy, the patriarch of a powerful white Southern family?

title: Lynda Gould Married to Steven DeLott
description: Lynda J. Gould, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce I. Gould of Great Neck, L.I., was married there last evening to Steven Rand DeLott, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart C. DeLott of Great Neck. Rabbi Mordecai Waxma, assisted by Cantor Benjamin Siegel, performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel.

title: Brooke White Marries Neal Sandford
description: The marriage of Nancy Brooker Cunningham White, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. White of Bedford, N.Y., to Halsey Neal Sandford, the son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Halsey Sandford of Louisville, Ky., took place yesterday at the Bedford Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Thomas Hughart performed the ceremony.

title:
DINING OUT;
Solid Italian Cuisine in Clifton
description: LEAD: SICHUAN, Japanese or Tex-Mex are all fine when the mood strikes, but the restaurants that New Jerseyans always seem to come back to are the solid, predictable Italian ones. Bel'Vedere, a popular Passaic County standby, is in a converted house in Clifton. The restaurant has been packing them in - literally, because tables are shoe-horned into every available space - since 1984.

title: Business Falls Off At Shore
description: ''IF things don't get better in the next couple of years when my lease is up, I'll be through for good,'' said Artie Martell, a boardwalk luncheonette owner who said his business here has dropped 60 percent from last year because of ocean pollution.

title: Death Cases: The Law Is Reluctant to Start Over
description: OFFICIALS in Louisiana last week were grappling with one of the most painful legal issues imaginable: whether the state should execute a convicted murderer whose supporters claim significant new evidence that he may be innocent.

title: 'The Lottery' 'The Lottery'
description: In The Book Review of July 3, Judy Oppenheimer, the author of ''Private Demons: The Life of Shirley Jackson,'' described some of the public reaction to the printing of Jackson's short story ''The Lottery'' in The New Yorker in 1948: ''Nothing in the magazine before or since would provoke such a huge outpouring of fury, horror, rage, disgust and intense fascination. . . . Readers felt called upon to invent their own . . . explanations. . . . 'You are tools of Stalin.' . . . 'In this story you show the perversion of democracy.' . . . 'I suppose . . . a magazine may decide to print something that hasn't any point just to get people talking.' '' The excerpts that follow are derived from the mail received by The Book Review since the publication of Judy Oppenheimer's essay last month. Evidently the passage of 40 years has not deprived ''The Lottery'' of its power to compel interpretation. To the Editor:

title: GIANTS NOT DISTRAUGHT OVER FINAL LOSS
description: One interesting aspect of the Giants' 17-13 loss to Cleveland on Friday was the team's reaction.

title: Housing Lottery Hitting a Snag
description: LEAD: ALREADY, a few rocks have been thrown and a few windows have been broken.

title: Drug Search Angers Workers
description: More than 200 workers at a city construction project last week were forced to kneel before drug-sniffing dogs or lose their jobs after a former employee reported that drugs were being used at the construction site. An angry union official likened the experience to slavery. City officials said Thursday that the Aug. 18 search at the Morton H. Meyerson Symphony Center turned up nothing. ''When they make you get down in front of an animal on your knees, that's getting back into slavery,'' said Bill Hawkins, business manager of Local 481 of the the ironworkers union.

title: Terrorist Blast Sets Off International Mystery
description: Important new information is emerging about the life of one of the world's most wanted terrorists, who was apparently killed here last month in an incident that still baffles investigators, according to Greek, Italian and American antiterrorism officials.

title: A Subtler Solidarity Raises Its Head
description: Shortly after 8 o'clock this morning, Lech Walesa, the Solidarity founder, drove quietly out of the Lenin Shipyard, where he had been with striking workers since Monday. After a shower at home, he drove to St. Brygida's Church here to huddle with his advisers and the Bishop of Gdansk.

title: THE GUIDE
description: QUILTS GALORE Not only is the Suffolk County Folk Arts Center, based at Hallockville in Northville, opening a new exhibition today, but it also has tied its musical series, ''Suffolk Rural Heritage: A Celebration in Song,'' to the show. And since the exhibition is ''Sound Avenue Quilters,'' the concert is ''A Patchwork Symphony.'' That is, the fiddler Eric Martin and the banjo player-vocalist Stephen Sanfilippo will perform traditional tunes with the same titles as traditional American quilting patterns. The concert is at 1 P.M. and is part of opening day festivities that run from 1 to 3. The exhibition itself features 25 quilts, 60 photographs and various artifacts that trace quilting as a pastime in the area - it was, with quilters meeting regularly once a week for more than a century - from the early 1800's right up to the 1950's. After today, the exhibition can be seen from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., Wednesdays through Sundays, through Oct. 9 at the barn of the multi-building farm museum on Sound Avenue. The suggested donation of $2 includes a guided tour of the complex. MUSICAL VARIETY

title: THE REGION: Enforcing Rules; Breaking Ties Binding The Inspector And Inspected
description: THE fire that swept an illegal social club last weekend, killing six people and injuring 33, raised a number of troubling questions. The apparent lack of coordination among city enforcement agencies, for instance, prompted Mayor Koch to demand stepped-up reviews of other such clubs by teams of police officers, firefighters and building inspectors. But a more shadowy issue remains: the difficulty of inspecting public places, and fully enforcing the laws intended to keep people safe, while keeping the inspectors honest.

title: Hyla M. Pottharst Married in West
description: The marriage of Hyla Marian Pottharst, an associate in the New York office of the Los Angeles law firm of Paul, Hastings, Janofsky & Walker, to Benjamin Belknap Wagner, an associate in the New York law firm of Cahill Gordon & Reindel, took place yesterday at the Neighborhood Church in Palos Verdes, Calif. The Rev. Edward A. Koonz, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: For a Grand Foreign Policy Debate
description: Vice President Bush and Governor Dukakis have all the makings for a profound debate on foreign affairs, if they would only join the issues.

title: Refugees Find Compassion in Language Program
description: East meets West and old meets young in an innovative program here that has become a model for other cities in helping elderly refugees break out of isolation and restore self-esteem.

title: Two Six-Man Teams Enter the Battle Successful Transition
description: CAN two six-man teams go to battle without anyone on the bench? Apparently not. But a group of stars recently found a tricky solution to this problem: One team sat North-South at three tables, and became East-West at the same table for the next round. Their opponents moved one table in the opposite direction to the boards, before the imp scores were calculated.

title: SHE TYPED WHILE OTHERS DANCED
description: CONFIDENTIAL SECRETARY Ann Whitman's 20 Years With Eisenhower and Rockefeller. By Robert J. Donovan. Illustrated. 208 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $19.95.

title: DOCTOR DOLITTLE, INNOCENT AGAIN
description: Hugh John Lofting's ''Story of Doctor Dolittle,'' the first of 12 adventures starring the bluff and rotund physician from Puddleby-on-the-Marsh who loved animals and learned to speak their language, was published in 1920. Like many of Beatrix Potter's little tales, it had its genesis in letters written to specific children - in this case, Lofting's own. Serving as a captain with the Irish Guards during World War I, the author wrote the story-letters from the trenches in France about the remarkable doctor. In part, they enabled him to remain close to his two young sons; in part, too, they transported him to a better time (about 1830) and place (an imaginary English country town), in which a caring healer, disdainful of personal gain, attends his fellow creatures selflessly and embarks periodically on far-flung errands of mercy or scientific inquiry.

title:
FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS;
Florida Vacation For Asian Roach
description: LEAD: WHEN the Asian cockroach started showing up last year in Tampa, Fla., some New Yorkers worried. The Asian cockroach can fly, and given New York's longstanding battle with the German cockroach, some snake-bit local residents fretted that their homes would be in the Asian roach's flight path.

title: Reunion of Strings at Silvermine
description: Thirty years ago, the violinist and conductor Paul Wolfe founded a string quartet and began a series of concerts at the Silvermine Guild Arts Center in New Canaan. The pull of other musical activities eventually led to the disbanding of the ensemble, although the chamber series would become a community fixture.

title: LILITH WAS THE OTHER WOMAN
description: I, EVE By Edward Le Comte. 134 pp. New York: Atheneum. $14.95

title: PROMISES TO KEEP
description: Francis Ford Coppola has ''gone Hollywood'' more than he may realize (''Francis Ford Coppola: Promises to Keep,'' by Robert Lindsey, July 24). In your profile, Mr. Coppola complains about the cruelty-to-animals charges that greeted the famous decapitated-horse scene in ''The Godfather.'' According to Mr. Coppola, ''Thirty people were shot in the movie but people only talked about 'cruelty to animals.' ''

title: Sailors in Sunken Peru Sub Rescued
description: Rescuers have freed 23 sailors trapped in a sunken Peruvian Navy submarine for almost 24 hours after it collided with a Japanese fishing trawler, Peruvian President Alan Garcia said tonight.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Little League Taiwanese Cruise to Title: The Tai Chung team from Taiwan defeated Pearl City, Hawaii, 10-0, yesterday in the 42d Little League World Series championship game in Williamsport, Pa. It was the fifth consecutive time a squad from the Far East had won the tournament. Chen-Lung Yu pitched a one-hitter and Wei-Chih Chen was 4 for 4 with a three-run homer.

title: Buddy, Can You Spare A Coupon for a Meal?
description: To the Editor:

title: Pamela Anne Kurtz to Wed Christopher Welch, Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert John Kurtz of North Hampton, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Anne Kurtz, to Christopher Donnelly Welch, the son of Mrs. Peter Charles Welch of Boston and Osterville, Mass., and the late John Donnelly of Dedham, Mass. The couple plan to marry Sept. 24.

title: For Accuracy, Artist Stages Civil War
description: THE young soldier falls to the ground, his facial features frozen in an agonized grimace. His comrade, poised by his side, falters and also falls. They are the dead; two young men fallen in the service of their country during the Civil War. But appearances can be deceiving.

title: A PORTRAIT OF THE ARTIST AS A DIRTY OLD MAN
description: SCANDAL By Shusaku Endo. Translated by Van C. Gessel. 261 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Company. $18.95.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Garden Ornaments Come of Age
description: Unlike their polished and pristine cousins - restored antiques for well-appointed interiors - period garden ornaments increase in value the more they show their age. There is a premium on the mottled silvery patina of old lead or lichen-encrusted stone, the results of natural weathering.

title: INSIDE
description: Vision and Reality in Africa

title: At College, Truth And Passion Await
description: DEAR Son, Soon you will be off to college. What fatherly advice can I give you?

title:
FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS;
Taking Revenge Becomes Popular
description: LEAD: LAST November, a small company that designs novelty items introduced one of the holiday season's hottest gifts. Called the Revenger, it was a small black box with flashing lights that attached to dashboards and -when buttons on top of the device were pushed - simulated the sound of machine-gun fire.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My patio consists of a concrete base over which is a layer of pebbles. The pebbles are cemented in place with epoxy and form a layer a little over 1 1/2 inches thick. Some of the pebbles are starting to loosen, leaving pockets or holes that are uncomfortable to walk on. What clear solution can I use to anchor the pebbles and fill the cavities?

title: Central Islip Gets New Plans For Revitalization
description: LEAD: THE decade-old plans for revitalization of the once-thriving community of Central Islip took a step forward recently when the New York Institute for Technology announced a proposal for a high-technology industrial park. The plans include 600 units of housing and a hotel-retail office complex on the grounds of the former Central Islip Psychiatric

title: Golfer's Son Dies In Pool Accident
description: The 2-year-old son of the pro golfer Al Geiberger died today, one day after falling into a swimming pool near his home here, a Loma Linda University Medical Center spokeswoman said.

title: IDEAS AND TRENDS: 'Star Wars' and Mars Missions; Ambitions for the Space Program Are Revived, in a Partisan Way
description: AS the space shuttle is readied to reclaim the heavens, Democrats and Republicans are vying to articulate bold visions of where the spaceship and the space program should go. Although space as a topic got light treatment in the Presidential primary campaigns, the candidates now seem eager to talk about it.

title: Dr. Elizabeth Hillyer Marries
description: Dr. Elizabeth Venini Hillyer, a daughter of Mrs. Stanley H. Hillyer of New York and Beverly, Mass., and the late Mr. Hillyer, was married yesterday to Stephen Ward Parker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Cortlandt Parker of Bedminster, N.J., and Portsmouth, R.I. The Rev. Barbara Platt-Hendren and the Rev. Frederick Baldwin performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Beverly Farms, Mass.

title: As Rangoon's Power Erodes, Experts Say It Has Itself to Blame
description: As Burma appeared poised today at the brink of a new era, diplomats here said its leaders could blame only themselves for a series of events that has turned most of the population against them.

title: The Hamlet That 'Hamlet' Needs
description: IT'S not that, all at once, the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival has come up with a ''Hamlet'' of consequence; it's just that the new Hamlet, Sheridan Crist, is transmitting a vital central force to a production that's been around, in alternating repertory, all summer.

title: Patricia Greene Weds
description: Patricia Anne Greene, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Irwin A. Greene of Southampton, L.I., was married at her parents' home last evening to Jeffrey James Feriola, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Feriola of Hempstead, L.I. Rabbi David Greenberg officiated. Mrs. Feriola, who graduated from Stephens College, is a medical administrator for the Cigna Corporation in Irvine, Calif. Her father is a prosthodontist. Mr. Feriola, who graduated from the University of California at Irvine, is a skin-care consultant in Irvine. His father is an artist.

title: Can Unions Build the Ships?
description: Last week in Seattle, 400 union and non-union workers bought WFI Industries, a privately held tugboat manufacturer that had been in financial difficulty for more than two years. The purchase was made using an employee stock option plan financed by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Donald Liddel, the leader of the Inlandboatmen's Union of the Pacific, will assume the post of chairman and chief executive of the company, renamed Unimar Industries Inc. Can employee ownership and union management help save American companies? Michael Milken Senior vice president, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: Quayle Kept the Faith Despite a Tough Week
description: The toughest week of his life was coming to a close, and Senator Dan Quayle was feeling, as he says he always does, very good about himself.

title: STREETSCAPES: 134, 136 and 138 East 93d Street; A Pioneer Row Anticipating Lexington Avenue
description: THE three brick rowhouses at the southwest corner of 93d Street and Lexington Avenue, built in 1862, date from the time when Yorkville was still an independent village.

title: A Schoolboy Bully Looks Back, With Regret
description: THE bully is a fact of school life which neither time nor circumstances has changed. While the subjects, books, equipment and the students and teachers, themselves, change with the generations, bullies remain the same. They are as old as Cain and Abel and they will continue to exist as long as some kids are big and mean and others are not prone to fight.

title: Reagan Address Assails Dukakis
description: President Reagan capped a week of campaigning and fund-raising in California today by accusing Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, Vice President Bush's Democratic rival, of putting national defense in jeopardy and plotting to send ''the ship of state into dry dock.''

title: On This Tour, Those Who Serve Also Play Host
description: TENNIS - especially tournaments featuring the grand old players - is increasingly being used as a promotional tool and a form of business entertainment. One of the best known is the Prudential-Bache Securities Grand Champions tour, in which the players do double duty as competitors and hosts.

title: TRYING TIMES FOR LACROIX
description: WHAT A DIFFERENCE A YEAR MAKES.

title: In Such a Summer, Even a Princple Wilts
description: HOW hot has it been? It's been so hot that the dog has preferred to sleep on the slate entry floor rather than in one of our bedrooms. It's been so hot that the guinea pig no longer suffers an emotional breakdown when it's taken out of its cage and put on the cool kitchen floor.

title: Summer '88: Hello, Holly
description: THE little black dress in which Audrey Hepburn won so many hearts as Holly Golightly a generation ago is back.

title: Prices of New York Hotel Deals Expected to Jump
description: The sale of the Maxim's de Paris Hotel to a Hong Kong company for $127 million, a price that many experts call outrageously high, reflects a boomlet that is expected to add 3,000 hotel rooms in New York City this year.

title: TRIUMPH FOR SAINT LAURENT
description: After 30 years, Yves Saint Laurent can still create a collection that brings an audience to its feet and sums up, in the most perfect and superb way, the current international mood of fashion. At the recent fall couture showings, one or two other creators were at their best. But Saint Laurent eclipsed them all. Meanwhile, last year's shooting star, Christian Lacroix, was grappling with turning points in his new career, which are explored on the following two pages.

title: THE WORLD: Q & A Red Cross; Anatomy Of the Aid That Follows A Disaster
description: GOVERNMENTS and relief agencies around the world offered help last week after an earthquake devastated parts of Nepal and northern India on Sunday. Among them was the American Red Cross. Jose A. Aponte, the director of international services, described the difficulties of disaster relief in an interview with Robert Pear, a reporter in the Washington bureau of The Times.

title: Brazil Now a Vital Crossroad For Latin Cocaine Traffickers
description: For years, watching helplessly as the rising power of the cocaine barons spread violence and corruption along the Andean backbone of Latin America, United States drug experts shuddered at the thought that Brazil would someday be drawn into the narcotics trade.

title: Dry Spell Is Not Likely To Ruin Foliage Colors
description: Hot, dry weather this year should not keep Vermont's trees from displaying their usual array of fall colors, experts said this week.

title: John Sayles Steps Up to Bat
description: Trumpets and banjos playing Dixieland, athletes in baggy flannel uniforms, fleecy clouds and bright sunshine, and cigar smoke and grass and dirt so real you can smell them.

title: Sports of The Times; Iron Mike Tyson on the Streets
description: He was nearly 6 feet tall, weighed about 200 pounds, had a punch like a wrecking ball, was the heavyweight champion of the world in his early 20's, grew up tough, frequented saloons and savored the grape, was a brawler in and out of the ring and claimed that ''I can lick any son-of-a-bitch alive.'' He loved expensive jewelry and elegant clothes, dumped managers regularly, put down opponents - he called one ''the best foot racer in the country'' - beat his wife and kept mistresses, and, naturally, was one of the great sports heroes of his time.

title: Farewell To the Chief
description: In the same St. Peter's parish church where Art Rooney attended daily Mass and communion for decades, the funeral yesterday for the owner of the Pittsburgh Steelers was attended by nearly 1,000 mourners: his five sons and their families, National Football League executives, former Steeler players, more than 60 members of the clergy, and hundreds of his friends.

title: A Vacation From Vacations
description: ALONG with mosquito bites, peeling noses and crab grass, summer means vacations. I know what you're thinking, vacations are wonderful. You can relax, see new places, get to do all sorts of things and reduce the normal levels of stress. Don't believe it.

title: For Russians, the Americanisms Are Coming
description: A Moscow lawyer recently overheard a conversation that went something like this:

title:
BODY AND MIND;
Telltale Hands
description: LEAD: SHE'S HERE BECAUSE OF HER YELLOW hands. As she holds them out for me to examine, I'm reminded for a moment of the way in which women, under old Moslem custom, were examined by the physician: only the hands, thrust demurely through a curtain, were allowed to be scrutinized. My patient's hands are beautiful, like an advertisement for hand lotion.

title: Indoor Antennas Challenge Rooftops
description: Antennas are eyesores. Some people refuse to have them on the roof. Others, living in apartment houses, couldn't put them on the roof even if they wanted to. As for indoor antennas, most are equally ugly and less effective.

title: Sir Frederick Ashton, Poetic Innovator
description: Sir Frederick Ashton was the Shakespeare of ballet - not the Shakespeare who wrote revenge tragedies but the poet who composed love sonnets. The great English choreographer's genius - his refined sensibility and unbounded imagination - soared to heights of poetic metaphor that constantly looked new to dance. His special and unsurpassed contribution was to reveal the lyrical aspect of classicism in 20th-century ballet.

title: THE LEGACY OF WIDOWHOOD
description: I was touched by Rhoda Tagliacozzo's article ''The Legacy of Widowhood'' (Hers, July 31).

title: CONGRESS SAYS B-1 LACKS SPARE PARTS
description: In a finding disputed by the Defense Department, a Congressional report released today says that most of the Air Force's 99 new B-1 bombers are being grounded every day because of a continuing shortage of spare parts.

title: Jennifer A. Jordan Marries Mark P. Conley, a Student
description: At Our Lady of Sorrows Roman Catholic Church in White Plains, Jennifer Anne Jordan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Jordan of White Plains, was married yesterday to Mark Peter Conley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Conley of Barrington, R.I. The Rev. Paul Stefan, assisted by Msgr. John Healy, performed the ceremony.

title: Shaker Village Buoyed by New Blood
description: Frances Carr used to wonder whether the Shaker village in this bucolic town on the shores of Sabbathday Lake in southern Maine would endure.

title:
GARDENING;
Ideal Tropicals for the Summer Garden
description: LEAD: MANY tropical and subtropical plants are used in our gardens and adapt well to summer since they are so tolerant of heat.

title: Airport Transit
description: To the Editor: ''The Train From the Plane, European Style'' (Travel Advisory, June 19) listed 10 cities in Europe that have direct train service from the main airport to downtown. Included was information on London/ Gatwick and Paris/Orly.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; How Will The Giants And Jets Do in '88?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Computer Talk
description: To the Editor:

title: HALF IS BETTER THAN NONE
description: Wine in half-bottles (375 ml.) will mature faster than in full-bottles (750 ml.). This is caused primarily by oxygen permeating the cork in relatively greater proportion because of the smaller quantity of wine in the half-bottle. Thus, a young half-bottle may be more drinkable than its full-bottle counterpart.

title: Shop Thrives With Swedish Imports
description: WHEN Dick and Estelle deJounge left their native Sweden for the United States to market a nontoxic flypaper he had invented, they had no idea they would become better known as the owners of a store called Country Swedish in Westport.

title: Why Can't The Mets Hit Anymore?
description: I view the question as academic, simply because this Met team is in first place and for most of the season it has had the best winning percentage, although the pace has slowed up a bit lately. They are hitting enough to hold first place.

title: Laura Todd Wed To Eric Widing, Gallery Director
description: At St. Michael's of the Valley Episcopal Church in Rector, Pa., Laura Kerr Todd, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burt K. Todd of Ligonier, Pa., and Eric P. Widing, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. William Widing Jr. of Duxbury, Mass., were married yesterday. The Rev. James Simons and the Rev. C. Jon Widing, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: Lisa R. Gutenstein Weds Jeffrey Lewis Silvershein
description: The marriage of Lisa Robin Gutenstein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gutenstein of Ridgewood, N.J., to Jeffrey Lewis Silvershein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Silvershein of Franklin Lakes, N.J., took place last evening at the Pierre in New York. Rabbi Martin Freedman officiated.

title: Review/Music; Bernstein Festivities Continue at Tanglewood
description: Tanglewood's celebration of Leonard Bernstein's 70th birthday is lasting four days, starting with the actual birthday gala Thursday night. Tonight's installment might have seemed oddly removed both from Mr. Bernstein and from Tanglewood's public image. But it was actually close to him, close to Tanglewood and of considerble musical interest.

title: Gregory Slonaker Marries Ms. D'Alonzo in Delaware
description: At St. Joseph-on-the-Brandywine Roman Catholic Church in Greenville, Del., Anne D'Alonzo, a daughter of Mrs. Benjamin Bracken of Wilmington, Del., and the late Dr. C. Anthony D'Alonzo, was married yesterday to Gregory Risser Slonaker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Slonaker of New Kensington, Pa. The Rev. J. Thomas Cini performed the ceremony.

title: U.S. Official Nears Elusive Triumph: An Intricate Peace in Southern Africa
description: After devoting the last eight years of his professional life to the intractable conflict in southern Africa, Chester A. Crocker seems tantalizingly close to witnessing a settlement of the complicated situation there.

title: In Poland's Walkouts, The Church Is Broker
description: TO spot a striking worker at any of the coal mines or shipyards and docks shut down by Polish workers last week, it was enough to look for two small signs.

title: Brookfield is Toasting its Heritage
description: TO celebrate their town's heritage, residents of Brookfield can drink a toast with Heritage, a new wine created by a local winery especially for the festivities.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: JAZZ FESTIVAL Noel Pointer, master of the electronic violin, will be at Branch Brook Park in Newark on Saturday for the International Jazz Festival, which gets under way at noon. (The festival is new this year, but the Essex County Parks Department hopes to make it an annual event.) While Mr. Pointer's work today may be viewed as a break with tradition, he has his roots in classical music.

title: Adventures in Abandonment
description: Though this has been an era of magisterial biographies by such writers as Leon Edel, Richard Ellmann, Joseph Frank, Judith Thurman and Justin Kaplan, among others, it has also evolved a new subspecies of the genre to which the name ''pathography'' might usefully be given: hagiography's diminished and often prurient twin. In the traditional biography the subject is usually substantial enough to support high claims for his or her cultural significance; the spirit of the times may also be examined, as a way of presenting and comprehending the subject. Thus, for instance, in Ellmann's posthumously published life of Oscar Wilde the story of Wilde and the history of his epoch dovetail; Mr. Frank's immensely ambitious biography-in-progress of Dostoyevsky is a fact-filled, analytical study of the novelist in the social and political context of 19th-century Russia.

title: Filipino Opposition Leaders Form Anti-Aquino Coalition
description: Vice President Salvador H. Laurel and opposition leaders announced today that a new Philippines coalition to challenge President Corazon C. Aquino had been formed.

title: ADVENTURES IN ABANDONMENT
description: JEAN STAFFORD A Biography. By David Roberts. Illustrated. 494 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $24.95.

title: Carnival Cruise's Spending Spree
description: IT'S a steamy August day and hundreds of tourists swarm into the embarkation terminal at the port here. At least six gleaming white cruise ships are lined up, bow to stern, ready to leave. But the activity is most intense around one ship - Carnival Cruise Line's Jubilee, a sleek vessel draped with a banner proclaiming ''Carnival's Got the Fun!''

title: Pamela Hastings Wed To Andrew Bohjalian
description: Pamela Dillenback Hastings was married yesterday at the home of her parents, Prof. and Mrs. Philip K. Hastings of Williamstown, Mass., to Andrew Peter Bohjalian, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Aram Bohjalian of Mount Vernon, N.Y. and Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The Rev. Robert Buckwalter, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Per Diem Costs Drop in Europe

title: Nebraska Wins Classic
description: The Texas Aggies were not going to take this game sitting down. They never do. The Twelfth Man, by the thousands, stood throughout the evening in the north end of Giants Stadium. The ''Aggie War Hymn'' carried through the humid air in the Meadowlands.

title: Why Can't The Mets Hit Anymore?
description: The Mets' incompetence at the plate can be attributed to the blatant impatience of their hitters. Most of them simply refuse to accept a walk and consequently they swing at first pitches and balls out of the strike zone when they're ahead of the count. The Mets are also guilty of overswinging, which could be because of their tremendous egos. They all want to hit the big home run but they fail to realize that a few singles and doubles can get the job done. JOHN A. D'AMATO Jr. Bellmore, L.I.

title: Mourning Is Cut
description: HE gave it the old college try, but since he's never been to college, there was hardly any shame when Alonzo Mourning was cut yesterday from the United States Olympic basketball team.

title: Johnson Hit Wins 5th in Row
description: The seventh-inning stretch, a longstanding ritual of dubious aerobic value, was completely superfluous last night at Shea Stadium.

title: A Kentish Countryside Possessed
description: ''THE world, according to the best geographers, is divided into Europe, Asia, Africa, America and Romney Marsh.'' So wrote the Rev. Richard Barham, who served as a rector in the fifth of those continents some 170 years ago and drew heavily on the experience when he composed his ''Ingoldsby Legends,'' a collection of tall tales immensely popular in 19th-century England. He knew all about the local ghosts and witches; he had learned to turn a blind eye when the smugglers used his church to hide their French brandy; and, above all, he'd come to love the odd, elusive atmosphere of a part of Kent that genteel people tended to shun, thinking it unhealthy and vaguely barbarous.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: A WOMAN. By Peter Hartling. Translated by Joachim Neugroschel. (Holmes & Meier, $29.50.) This graceful novel by Peter Hartling, a West German writer and editor, is told through letters, diary entries, snatches of memory and elegant passages of narrative. It opens in turn-of-the-century Dresden, where Katharina, the daughter of well-to-do parents, lives out a magical childhood.

title: Kate Benton and James Doughan, Actors, Marry
description: Kate Benton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Benton of New York, Wareham, Mass., and Dublin, N.H., was married yesterday to James Francis Doughan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo F. Doughan of Apple Valley, Minn. The Rev. Stephen Ankudowich, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Benton home in Wareham.

title: Silver After the Hunt Debacle
description: IT is safe to say that the Hunt brothers of Dallas have never recovered from the collapse of the silver market in 1979 and 1980. Neither has the metal. Silver soared from $9 an ounce in September 1979 to $50 an ounce in January 1980, only to collapse to $10 within two months; the debacle was relived last week. A Federal civil jury in Manhattan ruled that the brothers - Nelson Bunker, William Herbert and Lamar - conspired with a group of Middle Eastern investors in a racketeering scheme to corner the world silver market. The Hunts, who lost an estimated $2 billion in the collapse and face many other lawsuits, were ordered to pay more than $130 million in damages to Minpeco S.A., a Peruvian commodities concern.

title: U.S. Officials Split Over Whether to Appeal Ruling on P.L.O.
description: Reagan Administration officials are engaged in a bitter internal debate over whether to appeal a Federal court decision that upholds the right of the Palestine Liberation Organization to keep an observer mission at the headquarters of the United Nations in New York.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island Recent Sales
description: Bluepoint $159,000 323 Second Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 20-year-old ranch; den, eat-in kitchen, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,600. East Patchogue $125,000 101 Roslyn Lane 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage, walk to beach; taxes $1,900. Holbrook $175,000 79 Joanne Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 12-year-old colonial; dining room, den, laundry room, 2-car garage; taxes $3,200. Mineola $155,000 12 Holly Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, screened porch; taxes $1,500. St. James $328,000 5 Twixt Hills Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 22-year-old colonial; basement, 0.5 acre, pool, deck, cabana; taxes $5,600. Williston Park $259,000 63 Campbell Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; new eat-in kitchen, den, aluminum siding, 2-car garage; taxes $2,400. OTHER AREAS Chappaqua, N.Y. $275,000 31 Brook Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 26-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, heated sun room, 1-car garage, brook; taxes $5,243.
