title: Quayle Learns What Hart, Ferraro and Biden Know; Suntan Kids
description: To the Editor:

title: Dean Rusk
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting in Touch With Favorite Buildings
description: Whether Chinese dignitaries, Michiganders passing through, or suburbanites in for the day from Chevy Chase, visitors walking along the Mall in Washington seem drawn to the National Gallery's East Building - not always only because of its exemplary modernism or or changing exhibitions, but because of an intriguing feature of the building.

title: HOLDING 'BONFIRE' UP TO A MIRROR
description: LEAD: Can anyone say anything new about Tom Wolfe's ''Bonfire of the Vanities''? After a book has spent more than 40 weeks on the best-seller list, perhaps not. Or, if anything new is to be said, perhaps it will be by holding ''Bonfire'' up to an unusual mirror. The mirror I propose is a novella entitled ''Master and Man,'' a story about a middle-aged businessman that Leo

title: Power Plays From the Court to the Courtroom
description: AS fans across the country look forward to the beginning of the U.S. Open tennis championships tomorrow, members of the industry are pondering the future of a sport rife with factional disputes. Since 1968, when professional players were allowed to compete in all tournaments, dozens of not-for-profit and for-profit institutions have staked out claims on the game. And unlike professional baseball and football, which are administered by commissioners with substantial authority, or golf, where the players are united under the Professional Golfers Association, tennis has no central regulating power.

title: Contract Dispute Will Test County's New Ethics Code
description: LEAD: THE county's ethics code, signed into law last Monday by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, is about to get its first test, which could further strain the uneasy relationship between Mr. O'Rourke and some members of the Board of Legislators.

title: Russia's Troubled Superstar
description: ONE RESISTS IT, BUT THE physical resemblance to James Dean is inescapable. The Soviet gymnast Dmitri

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Montpelier, Vt.;
Land-Sale Curb Called Effective
description: LEAD: THE Vermont Legislature, in a move to regulate companies that subdivide and rapidly resell rural land to city dwellers, last year passed laws that both increased oversight of such deals and raised taxes on land-sale profits. According to state officials and representatives of the land companies, the results have been dramatic.

title: Memories Are Made of This
description: ''WHAT will you miss most about Westchester?'' a friend asked, when I said I was returning to England after 25 years away.

title: Computers Are Steadily Revolutionizing School
description: To the Editor:

title: Battling for Borrowers in a Slow Market
description: THE sluggish pace of residential sales has not only frustrated sellers and brokers, but it also has slowed traffic at mortgage desks in many regions of the country.

title: Bush's Aim: Loyal Republicans, Fickle Democrats
description: IF Senator Dan Quayle was such an awful choice for Vice President, why was George Bush doing so well in the polls last week? Or could it be that the electorate did not consider the Senator so awful, or considered other issues to be more important?

title: Happy Birdsday, Roger
description: For most of this century, birds and Roger Tory Peterson have enjoyed a kind of symbiotic relationship, each profiting by the other's company. He has introduced more birds to more people than anyone else - and the birds, in turn, have made him the best known of living naturalists. Today he celebrates his 80th birthday, or ''birdsday,'' in the bird watcher's play on words.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island In a Slow Market, Some Houses Sell Fast
description: LEAD: IN a housing market where many developers have begun offering buyers a variety of incentives, it has been business as usual - in some cases, better than usual.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Chain Retailers; Merchants of the Malls Test Manhattan's
description: THE nation's largest retailer, Sears, Roebuck & Company, has never captivated Manhattan with its merchandising magic. But this fall, as part of a growing invasion of chain stores onto the nation's most populous island, Sears will try to build its base from Third Avenue.

title: Getting Close
description: Closeness counts in horseshoes, of course, but what about in polar exploration? A new study of the expedition diary and other records kept by Robert E. Peary has raised doubts about the explorer's claim that he reached the North Pole, although he was doubtless somewhere in the vicinity that April day in 1909. The analysis, written by Wally Herbert, a British polar explorer, is published in the September issue of National Geographic. Mr. Herbert said that navigational errors and suspicious distance records suggested that Peary could have been 30 to 60 miles off course. Some experts said, so what? William O. Field, a retired official of the American Geographical Society, said, ''I would say he got close enough to it.''

title: CRIME
description: DEATH TAKES THE STAGE by Donald Ward (St. Martin's, $15.95) is an unusual first novel. Hard to pin down, it is a combination of tragedy and a kind of comedy that often verges on farce. It also has moments of terror, including a Grand Guignol scene that will be hard to forget. It pokes good-natured fun at the little-theater movement of Los Angeles and the egocentric types who slave there hoping for the big break. It takes a sensitive look at homosexuals. And, yes, there are murders and a nebbish theater agent who sets out to solve them.

title: Karin Bain Bride Of John Z. Kukral
description: Karin M. Bain, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John N. Bain of Bernardsville, N.J., was married there yesterday to John Zavertnik Kukral, the son of the late Dr. and Mrs. John Charles Kukral of Riverside, Ill. Msgr. Richard A. Behl performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church.

title: A Beach Parade Of Small Distractions
description: I LOVE to sit on the beach and people watch. Correction: baby watch. As I make my foray onto the sand, my intentions are honorable. Armed with hat, sunglasses, No. 24 sunscreen and the season's hottest new novel, I situate myself on an uncrowded, clean stretch of coastline close enough to the water to catch the ocean breeze. I usually get no farther than page 10 when the show begins.

title: The Royal Court Turns 100 (Send Money)
description: Reflecting on 100 years of royal Court history, one could be forgiven for misquoting Oscar Wilde. To be responsible for one theatrical renaissance might be luck. To be responsible for two suggests that something is seriously right. A certain rough magic found its way into the brickwork of that dowdy little building in Sloane Square, and has stayed there through triumph and disaster, controversy and crisis - often crisis. It's altogether predictable that the Royal Court Theater should this year be celebrating its centenary not just by staging some decidedly odd new work, but with a public appeal for the $1.4 million without which, it would almost seem, production of plays will perish and the theater's very fabric crumble.

title: Harold Salemson, 78, Film and Book Critic
description: Harold J. Salemson, a former film and book critic who translated biographies of Pablo Picasso, Salvador Dali and Georges Simenon, died Thursday at Community Hospital in Glen Cove, L.I., after suffering a heart attack. He was 78 and had lived in Glen Cove for 30 years.

title: HALF IS BETTER THAN NONE
description: Frank J. Prial might have suggested, in his article ''Half Is Better Than None'' (Wine, July 24), that readers save some of those empty half-bottles for use later on.

title: For a Small Town, Down Means Up
description: This city, known best as a center of fine leather work, is also now officially recognized as one of New York's most depressed communities. City officials could not be more thrilled.

title: Laura L. Nieboer Wed To C. Clarkson Hine Jr.
description: Laura Lynn Nieboer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Nieboer of Rochester, was married yesterday to C. Clarkson Hine Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hine of Chicago and Shelter Island, L.I. Clifford D. Clark, a lay minister at the East End Church of Christ in East Hampton, L.I., performed the ceremony at Union Chapel in the Grove on Shelter Island.

title: Around the Big Bend In Far West Texas
description: ON our last trip to Big Bend we had a full moon, which can make a night in the desert incandescent.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Hooksett, N.H.;
SCI to Build In New Park
description: LEAD: SCI Systems, a Fortune 500 company, announced last month that it would build its New England sales and manufacturing plant here, largely because of the town's central location. It is adjacent to Manchester, the state's largest city, and 15 miles south of Concord, the state capital.

title: BISTRO BASICS
description: THE MOST EXCLUSIVE restaurant in Paris is not Taillevent, Jamin or any other multi-starred gastronomic grail, but a threadbare bistro with 10 tables, a kitchen hardly the width of two baguettes end-to-end and a staff of three. It is called Chez la Vieille. ''A very special place that I've always wanted to visit'' is how Michel Rostang, the chef-owner of a Michelin two-star restaurant in Paris that bears his name, described it recently.

title: Hartford Plans An Experiment In the Sciences
description: A $1 million project to improve the math and science skills of teachers, particularly those in elementary and junior high schools, was announced today by Hartford business and education leaders.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-19

title: These Feds on Film Don't Go by the Book
description: Near the end of Jonathan Demme's acclaimed new farce, ''Married to the Mob,'' the undercover F.B.I. agent Mike Downey has a bad moment. Vinnie the Slug and Nick the Snake (or is it Al the Worm?) blow Downey's Hawaiian-shirt cover and march him at gunpoint to mob boss Tony the Tiger Russo's garish honeymoon suite in Miami Beach's Eden Roc hotel. Downey is wired, but somehow the mopes never think of patting him down to discover the secret F.B.I transmitter. Nor does the hapless Downey make use of it to transmit a prearranged alarm to his heavily armed backup team, which has infiltrated the hotel.

title: Why Can't The Mets Hit Anymore?
description: On paper, the Mets don't hit when Strawberry doesn't hit. But in reality, the Mets are lackng a spark, the kind that Kevin Mitchell or Ray Knight once provided. A team can win in many ways, but never without passion. DIANE COFFIELD Great Neck, L.I.

title: AFRICA TIMETABLE REMAINS A HURDLE
description: The latest round of negotiations toward peace in Angola and Namibia has ended with a narrowing of differences but no breakthrough on the crucial issue of a timetable for the withdrawal of South African troops from Namibia and of Cuban forces from Angola.

title: Sparse Coverage For Top Events
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Quayle Learns What Hart, Ferraro and Biden Know; Gender Gap Is Real
description: To the Editor:

title: Killings in German Hostage Incident Stir Dispute
description: West German politicians have acknowledged a catalogue of errors that contributed to the deaths of two teen-age hostages in a 54-hour episode last week.

title: Q. and A.: Airline Ratings A Year Later
description: FLIGHT delays can sour a getaway, and summertime and holiday weekends provide the most frustration as vacationers converge on the nation's airports. This was the first summer that travelers could get some indication of trouble ahead.

title: Appearance Anxiety
description: THE MAN IN MY LIFE placed his hands lightly on my temples, stepped back a half-pace and said, ''Your face is dear to me.'' Such a world of tender scrutiny was implied in those words that I knew I would remember them long after assorted ''you're beautifuls'' had been consigned to the dustbin of personal history.

title: TEA AND COMPLACENCY
description: THE RETURN OF A NATIVE REPORTER By Robert Chesshyre. 320 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: 'Of Settings Designed For Respite Care
description: Jeanne Clare Feron's article [ ''Offering Temporary Care for the Elderly,'' July 31 ] will go a long way toward informing care givers about where they can get relief from their exhausting responsibilities. Your long list of day-care programs provides invaluable information for thousands of people who feel they have nowhere to turn to for help.

title: Miss Rehkamp, A Lawyer, Wed To D. T. O'Brien
description: Marlene Valerie Rehkamp, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Rehkamp of Mill Neck, L.I., was married yesterday to Duncan Thomas O'Brien, a son of Anne O'Brien of Boston and the late Duncan T. O'Brien. The Rev. John E. MacInnes performed the ceremony at the St. Dominic Roman Catholic Chapel in Oyster Bay, L.I.

title: U.S. LISTS EFFECTS OF ATOM SMASHER
description: The Department of Energy, in a preliminary report on environmental changes that would be caused by construction of the proposed superconducting super collider, says 100 miles of new roads will be required if the atom smasher is built in Arizona or Colorado.

title: Harry Raybin, 87, Expert in Poison Control
description: Harry W. Raybin, a pioneer in the development of poison control centers throughout the country, died of pneumonia Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87 years old.

title: Three New and Different Galleries
description: GALLERIES come and go, but it seems that in the last few years in Connecticut, more have come than have gone. And of these, the majority are private, which is remarkable, considering how unpredictable the business can be even in an ideal setting - that is to say, a city with a large audience for art.

title: Flavor is Put in Ice Cream Cones
description: HAVING a hundred flavors of ice cream to choose from may not be enough for some ice cream devotees once they get their hands on a new product that hit the market recently - flavored ice cream cones.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article in the Aug. 7 issue of Education Life incorrectly listed Morehouse College in Atlanta as offering a master's degree in real estate. The Morehouse program is restricted to undergraduates.

title: Russian History And the Yanks
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Library for Blind to Move, and Grow
description: After four years of intense lobbying, advocates for the visually impaired have won $17.5 million in state money for the relocation and expansion of New York City's Library for the Blind and Physically Handicapped.

title: My Mouth, the Dental Museum
description: AS a retired person I have discovered that the very parts of the body most commonly needing attention at about age 65 are feet, eyes and teeth. I have also discovered that these three areas are least likely to be covered by one's medical program.

title: Partnership Study
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL: American League; ROYALS BEAT TWNS S GUBICZA FANS 14 FOR CLUB RECORD
description: Mark Gubicza set a club record with 14 strikeouts tonight as he pitched the Kansas City Royals to a 4-1 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

title: Swingtime Revue: Tunes of Big Bands Resound in Wilton
description: THE Music Theater of Connecticut is getting on the bookless bandwagon. With its current revue, ''Jukebox Saturday Night,'' the fledgling but nomadic theater, which has moved from Fairfield to Wilton in less than a year, is manifesting the latest trend in New York City's musical theater: compilation musicals, or shows that consist of hit tunes from past decades.

title: A Gulf Truce Leaves Rebels In a Quandary
description: Across mountains and marshes and plains, the eight-year-old war between Iran and Iraq has spawned another battle of smaller, more shadowy forces whose future now seems clouded by the sudden talk of peace.

title: Working on Wicker
description: SUMMER weather can take a severe toll on wicker porch furniture. While valuable antique wicker should be handled by professionals, ordinary wickerwork can be refreshed and often repaired by amateurs.

title: Correction
description: A front-page article July 24 on the Presidential race and an accompanying map incorrectly summarized 1984 election results. Walter F. Mondale received 40 percent or more of the 1984 major-party Presidential vote in 18 states; he received 37.93 percent in Indiana, 39.64 percent in Kentucky, 39.80 percent in Georgia and 39.98 percent in Missouri.

title: Israelis Are Said to Suspect Guerrillas in Killing of a Boy
description: The police today found the body of an 8-year-old Jewish boy whose head was crushed with a rock, and they said Palestinian guerrillas may have killed him, the Israeli radio reported.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Mow Lawn, Eat Plants

title:
FOCUS: Laughlin, Nev.;
A Tiny Town Grows as Casinos Multiply
description: LEAD: WITH the opening of its second major casino/hotel this year and the completion last year of a four-lane bridge making it easier to reach, Laughlin is suffering the kind of growing pains that can be expected of a speck of a town turned suddenly into a thriving city.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Bridgeport, Conn. $195,000 77 Montgomery Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; deck overlooking water, fireplace; taxes $2,354. Monroe, Conn. $252,500 24 Boot Shop Lane 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 26-year-old raised ranch; family room with wood stove, pool, 1-acre; taxes $2,184. Weston, Conn. $575,000 3 Pink Cloud Lane 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 18-year-old contemporary; glass walls overlooking pond, pool, 2 acres; taxes $4,735. Chappaqua, N.Y. $275,000 31 Brook Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 26-year-old Cape Cod; heated sun room, 1-car garage, brook; taxes $5,243. Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. $391,000 10 Warren Road 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 32-year-old contemporary; family room, deck, 2-car garage, river view, 2.9 acres; taxes $6,333. North Salem, N.Y. $300,000 Route 124 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, family room, 2-car garage, 1 acre; not yet assessed. OTHER AREAS Livingston, N.J. $220,000 104 Vere Terrace 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 25-year-old contemporary; c/a, 1-car garage, dining room; taxes $3,172. Maplewood, N.J. $220,000 11 Beach Street 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 26-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, 2 fireplaces, full basement; taxes $3,450. Mineola, L.I. $155,000 12 Holly Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, screened porch; taxes $1,500.

title: Washington Jail Crowding: Few Cells and Much Discord
description: Some city officials refer to it as ''musical cells.'' But it is no game. Rather, it is a desperate effort by the District of Columbia's Department of Corrections to respond to court orders that have set limits on the number of prisoners that can be housed in the city's overcrowded jails and prisons.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: SOMEWHERE in the minds of a lot of busy, high-powered people there lurks a vision. The vision is of themselves, in pajamas or robe, in bed or sprawled in a capacious chair, reading and occasionally running to the refrigerator. Not in the evening, but all day long. And the all-day-long, for goodness sake, is not a day off or a weekend, but a weekday, a business day.

title: New Yonkers Group Opposes Council
description: As the City of Yonkers lost another round Friday in its court battle over a zousing desegregation order, some residents' call for compliance was sounded more loudly than ever with the formation of an umbrella organization made up of 20 groups, including labor unions, homeowners' associations, political action groups and the Yonkers Federation of Teachers.

title: TO LEAD IS TO LIE
description: HUMBUGGERY AND MANIPULATION The Art of Leadership. By F. G. Bailey. 187 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press. Cloth, $27.50. Paper, $8.95.

title: Story on Quayle Is Local News for His Family's Papers, and They Cover It
description: If the press ''went into a feeding flurry'' on the Dan Quayle story, as Vice President Bush has said, then Mr. Quayle's family newspapers here, The Indianapolis Star and The Indianapolis News, were among those leading the sharks to the bait.

title: The Amazon
description: To the Editor: Anyone considering a cruise on the Amazon River ought to read Jules Verne's ''Eight Hundred Leagues on the Amazon.'' Published in English many years ago, it's about a four- month voyage in 1852 in which a whole village travels from Iquitos to the sea on a giant raft, complete even with a church. The famous science fiction writer created a detective story tense with powerful suspense from first page to last, and his skill in interweaving lively and detailed descriptions of the aborigines, the towns along the river, the fauna and flora is masterful. LEO MILLER New York, N.Y.

title: Yankees Drop to Season Low
description: The frustration in the clubhouse has become commonplace. Players mope; the manager wrings his hands in distress. Nothing helps.

title: Keeping Track Of True Fans
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Carolyn Springer Weds S. C. Ferruolo
description: Carolyn Elisabeth Springer, a daughter of Mrs. Lawrence A. Springer of Brunswick, Me., and the late Mr. Springer, and Stephen Carl Ferruolo, the son of Mrs. Anthony Ferruolo of Warwick, R.I., and the late Mr. Ferruolo, were married yesterday. The Rev. Jonathan B. Appleyard performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Brunswick.

title: Brain Surgery Offers Ray of Hope for Epileptics
description: LONG ago, 26-year-old Nancy Giles of Ozone Park, Queens, spent her days helping her mother do the housekeeping or walking the blocks nearest her home.

title: Steven N. Knight Wed To Kimberly D. Brown
description: Kimberly Dixon Brown, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Harman Brown Jr. of Mountain Lakes, N.J., was married there yesterday to Steven Newell Knight, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Newell S. Knight Jr. of St. Louis. The Rev. Ross Doyel, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Freddie Fourie, performed the ceremony at the Community Church (United Church of Christ).

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''The message Pohl was trying to get across was that the Bundesbank was ready to play tough and for a long time. I think he succeeded.'' - John Baker, chief dealer, Bank Julius Baer in New York.

title: Blast Kills 2 in Punjab
description: A powerful bomb strapped to a motor scooter exploded in a crowded market in Punjab state today, killing 2 people and wounding 30, 10 of them seriously, the police said. There was no immediate claim of responsibility, but the police said they suspected Sikh militants who are fighting for a separate homeland in the northern border state. The explosion occurred at 10:30 A.M. in Ajanala, about 20 miles south of Amritsar.

title: Q and A
description: Trains in Fall

title: Ashe Looks Back at a Year of Troubles and Triumph
description: ARTHUR ASHE really did not have much of a choice in the matter. Quiet, unassuming, almost bookish-looking in the horn-rimmed glasses he wore then, he was nonetheless cast as a symbol in the late 1960's, that often turbulent period of political and social change in this country. Ashe was black and he was a tennis player, a combination that made many people uneasy in a sport in which everyone wore white. And because he was a celebrity, he had a forum for his views.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The situation is critical, really critical, I have only 18 agents here and we only have 300 in all of Brazil. Everything favors the traffickers.'' - Claudio Barrouin Mello, narcotics division chief of the federal police in Rio de Janeiro. [ 1:2. ]

title: Quayle Learns What Hart, Ferraro and Biden Know; Dreams That Died
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting Down
description: When Leonard Bernstein turned 70 years old last week, the world of music turned out to celebrate. The party took place at Tanglewood, the Berkshires estate that is home to the Tanglewood Music Center, at which Mr. Bernstein first studied nearly 50 years ago. With Beverly Sills as host, a weekend of music began with a four-hour gala concert that was quite literally an all-star show.

title:
GARDENING;
Ideal Tropicals for the Summer Garden
description: LEAD: MANY tropical and subtropical plants are used in our gardens and adapt well to summer since they are so tolerant of heat.

title: The Martial Arts as Moneymakers
description: AS is traditional, next month's Olympics in South Korea will include a demonstration sport popular in the host country. Korea's choice is tae kwon do, a swift, high-kicking form of karate. That could be good news for America's 5,000 to 10,000 instructors in the martial arts.

title: United Nations Peacekeeping Assignments
description: 1948-present: Middle East - force set up to watch borders between Israel and neighboring Arab countries. 1949-present: India and Pakistan - troops in Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir to monitor cease-fire between India and Pakistan 1956-1967: Egypt - force sent to secure cease-fire between Egyptian forces and Israeli, French and British troops in Sinai. 1958: Lebanon - observation group sent to halt arms smuggling. 1960-1964: the Congo - operation to insure withdrawal of Belgian and other foreign troops and to prevent civil war. 1962-1963: West New Guinea - security force sent to keep peace after accord between Indonesia and the Netherlands. 1963-1964: Yemen - mission to certify disengagement of Arab forces in Yemen's civil war. 1964-present: Cyprus - force set up to prevent fighting between Turkish and Greek Cypriots; since 1974 partition, has maintained buffer zone. 1965-1966: India and Pakistan - mission to supervise cease-fire along border. 1973-1979: Sinai - force sent to oversee cease-fire between Egypt and Israel. 1974-present: Golan Heights - contingent supervises cease-fire between Israel and Syria. 1978-present: southern Lebanon - troops sent to confirm withdrawal of Israelis from area and to restore security. April 1988-present: Afghanistan and Pakistan - small contingent set up to monitor Soviet pullout from Afghanistan and Pakistani and Soviet compliance with accords. August 1988: Iran and Iraq - group formed to monitor provisions of cease-fire.

title: 'The Lottery'
description: In The Book Review of July 3, Judy Oppenheimer, the author of ''Private Demons: The Life of Shirley Jackson,'' described some of the public reaction to the printing of Jackson's short story ''The Lottery'' in The New Yorker in 1948: ''Nothing in the magazine before or since would provoke such a huge outpouring of fury, horror, rage, disgust and intense fascination. . . . Readers felt called upon to invent their own . . . explanations. . . . 'You are tools of Stalin.' . . . 'In this story you show the perversion of democracy.' . . . 'I suppose . . . a magazine may decide to print something that hasn't any point just to get people talking.' '' The excerpts that follow are derived from the mail received by The Book Review since the publication of Judy Oppenheimer's essay last month. Evidently the passage of 40 years has not deprived ''The Lottery'' of its power to compel interpretation. To the Editor:

title: Daniel Meyer Weds Audrey Heffernan
description: Audrey Rayelyn Heffernan, the daughter of Edward David Heffernan of Maplewood, N.J., and the late Doris Mae Heffernan of Yardley, Pa., was married yesterday to Daniel Harris Meyer, a son of Morton L. Meyer and Roxanne Harris Frank, both of St. Louis. Rabbi Joseph Rosenbloom and the Rev. James Gardner, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at All Souls Unitarian Church in Manhattan.

title: THE WORLD: A Latin Lesson; Peru Sees Another Hope Running Low
description: DURING his first two years in office, a Government-sponsored boom in consumer spending gave President Alan Garcia Perez the highest popularity ratings of any recent Peruvian leader. Yet when he marked the third anniversary of his inauguration on July 28, with the economy once again in crisis and his own reputation in tatters, he lamented: ''Now nobody wants to remember those first two years.''

title: Solomon A. Klein, Lawyer, 82
description: Solomon A. Klein, the former chief counsel to the Judicial Inquiry on Professional Conduct of the New York State Supreme Court, died of cancer of the prostate Friday at his summer home in Shelter Island, L.I. He was 82 years old and lived in Long Boat Key, Fla.

title: Endles Horizons at Summer's End
description: A MARVELOUS sunny day: dry, hot and with a cloudless sky of deep blue.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My patio consists of a concrete base over which is a layer of pebbles. The pebbles are cemented in place with epoxy and form a layer a little over 1 1/2 inches thick. Some of the pebbles are starting to loosen, leaving pockets or holes that are uncomfortable to walk on. What clear solution can I use to anchor the pebbles and fill the cavities?

title: Magazine Using Nude Photos Is Dressed Down by Managua
description: After a public debate about the role of sexual humor in revolutionary society, the Sandinista Government has lifted its ban on a weekly magazine that printed photos of semi-nude women.

title: TV VIEW
description: LEAD: Genoa City, Pine Valley and Bay City, the fictional sites of three popular daytime soap operas, have finally witnessed the arrival of AIDS, accompanied by accolades for addressing a significant social issue. CBS's ''Young and the Restless,'' ABC's ''All My Children'' and NBC's ''Another World'' have each woven the topic of AIDS into their storylines.

title: Susan Livingston Weds
description: Susan Marie Livingston, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Livingston of Haworth, N.J., was married there yesterday to Thomas Elliott Van Buskirk, the son of William J. Van Buskirk of Jackson Heights, Queens, and the late Sara S. Van Buskirk. The Rev. Martin O'Brien performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Heart. The bride is the assistant director of recruiting in New York for Touche Ross, the accounting concern. Mr. Van Buskirk is an analyst at Value Line Inc. in New York.

title: 'The Lottery'
description: In The Book Review of July 3, Judy Oppenheimer, the author of ''Private Demons: The Life of Shirley Jackson,'' described some of the public reaction to the printing of Jackson's short story ''The Lottery'' in The New Yorker in 1948: ''Nothing in the magazine before or since would provoke such a huge outpouring of fury, horror, rage, disgust and intense fascination. . . . Readers felt called upon to invent their own . . . explanations. . . . 'You are tools of Stalin.' . . . 'In this story you show the perversion of democracy.' . . . 'I suppose . . . a magazine may decide to print something that hasn't any point just to get people talking.' '' The excerpts that follow are derived from the mail received by The Book Review since the publication of Judy Oppenheimer's essay last month. Evidently the passage of 40 years has not deprived ''The Lottery'' of its power to compel interpretation. To the Editor:

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: San Francisco; A South Beach 'Urban Village'
description: TWO national developers are building an 863-unit, mixed-income, rental apartment complex here in a rundown waterfront district of decaying warehouses. The site is in one of the last developable areas in a city with a vacancy rate of 2 percent or under.

title: Fighting the Greenhouse Effect
description: THE worst of this summer's searing heat may be over, but the concerns that it raised about a global warming trend - known as the greenhouse effect - seem certain to linger.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: WILBUR AND ORVILLE: A Biography of the Wright Brothers, by Fred Howard. (Ballantine, $12.95.) In a day when inventors of flying machines often belonged among those who claimed to transmute lead into gold or to communicate with the dead, the Wright brothers had to convince the world that their Wright Flyer was indeed worth paying for. This ''account of the efforts to exploit the Flyer is a suspense story, bearable only because we know how it came out in the end,'' Tom Ferrell said in The Book Review last year. ''The series of negotiations and frustrations, approaches and withdrawals might have maddened lesser men.''

title: NONFICTION
description: UP CLOSE AND PERSONAL: The Inside Story of Network Television Sports. By Jim Spence with Dave Diles. (Atheneum, $19.95.) For more than 25 years Jim Spence toiled the fields for ABC Sports, starting as a gofer and winding up as a senior vice president. So if anyone is qualified to give us the ''inside story of network television sports,'' it is Mr. Spence. Touching all bases - from ''Monday Night Football'' to behind-the-scenes financial maneuvering for various sporting events - Mr. Spence, with the able help of Dave Diles, a former broadcaster for ABC Sports, has given us a lively, entertaining and informative look at the television sports business. And make no mistake, it is a business, one that is now something of a runaway train. For instance, ABC acquired the rights to the 1976 Winter Olympic Games in Innsbruck, Austria, for $10 million. Contrast that figure with the $309 million paid for the 1988 Winter Games in Calgary, Alberta, and you can see why the argument that money and sports have become synonymous makes sense. ''Up Close and Personal'' is conversational in tone, filled with anecdotes about touchy negotiations, backstabbing and enormous egos (Howard Cosell comes immediately to mind). Mr. Spence is wise enough to give his own voice an occasional rest while eliciting interesting commentary from some of those with whom he worked. And, to his credit, he's not afraid to take on the tough issues - such as the influence television has on sports - though the reader might not always agree with his conclusions. All in all, sports fans and people interested in the business side of television will find much to admire in this book.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE ROBIN'S NEST;
The First Customers Toddle In at Phelps
description: LEAD: NEAR the parking lot of the Robin's Nest, leaning against a fence, is a large leftover wood sign that reads, ''Future home of a child-care center at Phelps.'' The sign and a pile of concrete were once the only tangible promises of what was to come; now there is a yellow, blue and red one-story building and, inside it, a whole staff and a gaggle of youngsters.

title: How Frightfully WellDecorated
description: What kind of film works a word like ''mangel-wurzel'' into the conversation? The kind of film that a lot of us secretly enjoy more than we should. A mangel-wurzel, for the uninitiated, is a variety of large beet used by Europeans as cattle feed, and reference to it is made casually during the pastoral section of ''A Summer Story.'' But what on earth would make such a thing, in this context, so delicious? The fact that it's part of the larger framework of a film filled with natural fibers and rampant Anglophilia, with linen and tweed, with straw hats and walking sticks and - inevitably - white flannel.

title: Toward a Cleaner And Healthier Sound
description: The continued contamination of Long Island Sound represents the single greatest environmental threat to the Sound Shore of Westchester County.

title: Winning More Points On Cable Television
description: WHILE tennis has been declining in popularity on broadcast television, it is becoming a star attraction on cable. The amount of tennis programming on cable television has grown steadily over the past four years, mainly on USA Network and ESPN.

title: Plane Makes Belly Landing; 7 Passengers Slightly Hurt
description: Seven people suffered minor injuries today when a TWA jetliner made an emergency belly landing at O'Hare Airport after its nose gear failed to deploy, airport officials said.

title: West Virginia Takes Independent Route for a Bowl
description: As long as there is no championship tournament in Division I-A, and the 18 postseason bowl games continue, the 9 independent teams in the East will do fine.

title: Provisions Of Program
description: Among the benefits of the Urban Enterprise Zone Program are:

title: New Zealand Cut Down to Size
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Marina Brings Life to Norwich Waterfront
description: HOLLYHOCK ISLAND in Norwich once was the city's landfill and it lies 13 miles upriver from Long Island Sound. Its views include a junkyard and a sewage treatment plant and it seems to be an unlikely spot for a $50 million marina and office project.

title: Naivete for Its Own Sake
description: TIME was when ''folk art'' meant work made in innocence of industrial reality and intended to serve a purpose - furniture, trade signs, portraits and the like. Now, the term covers just about anything made by the untutored and largely for self-expression. Purists grind their teeth in vain, but naivete for its own sake is a business that is here to stay, and no one person has done more to make it so than Herbert Wade Hemphill Jr., part of whose collection is on view at the Noyes Museum.

title: Practical Traveler; What to Consider When Choosing a Bike Rack
description: TRANSPORTING bicycles with your car using a roof- or trunk-mounted bike rack seems straightforward.

title: The Crucial Choice: Can't or Won't
description: I KNEW that I was a child of the 60's, and that the world has changed a whole lot since I was 20. So if sometimes my own kids have looked askance at my views, suggesting politely (and not so politely) that they were somewhat dated, it never bothered me. For I have been rather proud of the sensibility of my formative years.

title: Janet V. Slove Is Married to Michael D. Schwamm
description: Janet Vivian Slove, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Lawrence Slove of Westfield, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla., was married last evening to Michael David Schwamm, a son of Jay Marc Schwamm of New York and Ellen Schwamm Brodkey of New York. Rabbi Charles Kroloff performed the ceremony at the Puck Building in New York.

title: Millville Journal; Turmoil Eases on Barge Plan for Quiet River
description: JANICE BURCHAM delivered nine lambs while her sister Jeanette was in China for three weeks in April. It was nothing unusual for the twins, who farm 35 acres on the banks of the Maurice River here, where they were born 62 years ago in the big red brick house their grandfather Amaziah Burcham built in 1865.

title: Cynthia Gelinas, Lawyer, Marries
description: Cynthia Abiodun Gelinas, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Gelinas of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Roy A. Rothman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Rothman, also of Scarsdale. The Rev. Robert F. Grippo performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church. He was assisted by Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel.

title: Man Killed During Argument
description: One man was killed and two others, including an off-duty New York State corrections officer, were wounded yesterday in an early-morning gun battle in Brooklyn that broke out among a group of people who had been at a party, the police said.

title: The Melange Of Cultures In Belleville
description: ON the Metro a chic young woman, in black leather pants and reading the latest Sagan, sits near a Tunisian woman in sky-blue yashmak with her husband, clad in djellaba, and five children. I express surprise to her husband that she wears the veil in Paris. ''Why not?'' he laughs, flashing gold teeth. ''She is my wife!'' The young woman gives a look of disapproval. And we all get out at Belleville.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THE Army Corps of Engineers has proposed spending almost $200 million on a project to restore 12 miles of beaches in northern Monmouth County that have suffered decades of erosion.

description: Running After Certain Words

title: IMMIGRANT WRITING: GIVE US YOUR MAXIMALISTS!
description: LEAD: I'm one of you now.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: GROUND ZERO. By Andrew Holleran. (Morrow, $16.95.) In his first novel, ''Dancer From the Dance,'' published 10 years ago, Andrew Holleran depicted gay male life in New York, with oddly prophetic nostalgia, as a flamboyant but doomed quest for perpetual romance. In ''Ground Zero,'' a collection of essays (some of them previously published) that were written since the advent of AIDS, Mr.

title: About Chess Moves
description: The New York Times has converted its method of chessboard notation to the algebraic system, in which each square is unambiguously identified by file letter and rank number. Explanations of the system are available from the Chess Column, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: Actors Say They Duped Hosts of TV Talk Shows
description: There are said to be those who don't believe everything they hear on syndicated television talk shows, like guests telling all about sex. A story out of Chicago says the skeptics may be right.

title: Quayle Missed 2 Guard Drills in 6 Years
description: The Indiana National Guard has released records that indicate that Dan Quayle was absent without leave for his last drill meeting, but a Guard officer played down the seriousness of the offense.

title: Suns' Garrett Lost Up to 12 Weeks
description: Dean Garrett, a second-round draft choice of the Phoenix Suns this year, will be sidelined 10 to 12 weeks with a fractured foot, the team announced today.

title: INDIGNANT READERS AND UNSPEAKABLE MUSIC
description: SELECTED LETTERS OF VIRGIL THOMSON Edited by Tim Page and Vanessa Weeks Page. 413 pp. New York: Summit Books. $24.95.

title: Rosemary Pugh Wed To Walter H. Piper
description: Rosemary Pugh and Walter Hammond Piper were married yesterday in an outdoor ceremony at Lake Waramaug in New Preston, Conn. Christopher Combs, a justice of the peace, officiated.

title: Pinstripe Pride Wearing Thin
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Love Affair With Scottish River Is Uncovered
description: WHEN John Inglis Hall's ''Fishing a Highland Stream'' (Viking, $16.95) surfaced in a carton of books sent to me for possible review, I began to scan it idly and discovered that I had been neglecting a gem.

title: Interest Grows in Continuing-Care Communities for Elderly
description: LEAD: RESIDENTIAL complexes that are tailored to meet the changing needs of the elderly are gaining in popularity as an alternative to more conventional housing and nursing homes, housing specialists and advocates for the elderly say.

title: Waste Disposal Center Opens
description: The first permanent disposal center for household hazardous waste on the East Coast opened today in this Martha's Vineyard community. The center, financed by a $28,000 state grant, will hold household wastes like paints, solvents and pesticides from the six towns on the island. James Gutensohn, commissioner of the state Department of Environmental Management, said, ''We are reducing the threat to the water supply that stems from disposing of these wastes in a landfill.''

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My patio consists of a concrete base over which is a layer of pebbles. The pebbles are cemented in place with epoxy and form a layer a little over 1 1/2 inches thick. Some of the pebbles are starting to loosen, leaving pockets or holes that are uncomfortable to walk on. What clear solution can I use to anchor the pebbles and fill the cavities?

title:
PERSONAL FINANCE;
Smart Ways to Cut the Estate Tax Bill
description: LEAD: IN the pantheon of financial mythology, this fallacy is firmly enshrined: ''I don't need estate planning. That's just for the very wealthy.'' In fact, many people are wealthier than they think. Owners of real estate may be sitting on hundreds of thousands of dollars in equity. Add jewelry, antiques or heirlooms, perhaps a vacation home or an inheritance .

title: Train Service Resumes After L.I.R.R. Crash
description: Train service resumed today on the eastern part of the Port Jefferson branch of the Long Island Rail Road, less than 48 hours after a train hit a stalled tractor-trailer.

title: 5 Cubans Stage Protest in Statue of Liberty
description: Five Cubans, calling for the ouster of Fidel Castro, handcuffed themselves to a railing inside the crown of the Statue of Liberty yesterday.

title: Hosiery to Match Every Mood
description: THE socks made by the Sock Hop in Los Angeles are, by turns, tough or tender.

title: The Rise in Rates Spreads to Europe
description: Interest rates headed higher in Europe, led by West Germany's central bank. The Bundesbank lifted its discount rate to 3.5 percent, from 3 percent, and similar increases were imposed in Britain, France, Switzerland, Austria, the Netherlands and Canada. The German move was accompanied by strong words from Karl Otto Pohl, the Bundesbank president, who said it was intended as an ''important signal'' to the world markets that Germany would act aggressively to curb further gains in the dollar's value. The West German mark has fallen 16 percent against the dollar in the past seven months, and the situation poses an inflationary threat in Germany. Higher interest rates in Germany should attract some money away from dollar investments and toward the mark. That was the immediate effect, with the dollar dropping to 1.86 marks. The previous week it had been over 1.90 marks.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Art From Russia
description: LEAD: Last year, Anton Kumankov, 30, a portrait artist from Moscow, and his half-brother, Nikita Pokrovsky, 37, an associate professor of philosophy at Moscow State University, visited the United States as part of a cultural exchange program. One of their stops was Pepsico World Headquarters in Purchase:

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Victoria
description: Autumn in Victoria, British Columbia, means that it's time for the Pacific salmon to return to spawn and die in the rivers where they were hatched. And there's little that the Victorians don't know about salmon. They catch it, eat it, smoke it, watch it, photograph it and local artists even paint it.

title: Pacific Dunlop Diversifies Its Way Into America
description: COWARD shoes, Champion batteries, Ansell medical gloves, Lifestyle condoms, Telectronics pacemakers.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
I Won the Grand Slam, and So Can Graf
description: LEAD: MY heart goes out to young Steffi Graf as she strives to join the elite band of tennis players to achieve the coveted Grand Slam by winning the United States Open, which begins tomorrow.

title: OLYMPIC PROFILE: Sylvia Poll  A 17-year-old swimmer from Costa Rica goes after her nation's first Olympic gold medal.; Who Is Sylvia? Costa Ricans Know
description: Far from the elite swim clubs of Florida and southern California, farther yet from the East German athletic centers that have turned out dominant female swimmers for more than a decade, a 17-year-old Costa Rican athlete is training methodically at a local health club and dreaming of Olympic glory.

title: Utilities Pay Builders to Cut Power Use
description: ONCE upon a time, when power was cheap and everyone thought progress meant using more of it, utility companies used to advise architects and developers on ways to raise electricity consumption in new buildings. The theory was that workers could be more productive in buildings with more artificial lighting and with cooling systems built without regard for the sun and other natural factors.

title: IF BILLY BUDD HAD BEEN A RAT
description: A CHOCOLATE SOLDIER By Cyrus Colter. 278 pp. New York: Thunder's Mouth Press. Cloth, $19.95. Paper, $9.95.

title: Driver Test Wreck Kills Woman
description: A 77-year-old woman taking a driving test crashed through the wall of the examination station Friday, killing a woman and injuring four other people. The dead woman was identified as 43-year-old Sandra Warnes of Longview. Bob Fletcher, a state police spokesman, said the woman taking the driving test, Pearl A. Kamm, ''put her vehicle in reverse and backed into a tree at the facility,'' adding, ''She then put it in forward and maintained that her foot slipped off the brake and onto the gas pedal.'' Ms. Kamm was not hurt.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
A Childhood Scrapbook
description: LEAD: Among the many photographs in ''The Children of New Rochelle at the Turn of the Century,'' an exhibition at the Castle Gallery of the College of New Rochelle, are several lent by Helen Lynn of New Rochelle.

title: Among the Elderly, Togetherness Is Selling
description: AS a growing number of elderly Americans become more affluent and live longer, healthier lives, many are finding themselves more in need of companionship than long-term custodial care. An increasing number of real estate developers are responding to this demand by building group residences that, for those who can afford them, combine the convenience of a hotel with the community spirit of summer camp.

title: Heat Wave Threatens Pumping Limits
description: MANY of the 41 water suppliers in Nassau County fear that the surge in customer demand, primarily to irrigate lawns and plants parched by the summer's prolonged heat wave, may cause them to exceed pumping limits the state imposed two years ago to protect dwindling underground aquifers.

title: Churchill's Sanctuary In Kent
description: A MAN'S house is his best refuge, a legal maxim dictates, and so it was with Chartwell, Winston Churchill's country seat for more than four decades. From late 1922 to his death in 1965 Churchill sought safe harbor at Chartwell through election defeats, stock market losses, the political drought of the 30's (now known as the wilderness years), and the long, sad twilight after World War II.

title: Florida State Adjusts To Perilous Spot at the Top
description: Of all the events that have taken place in the last two weeks on the campus of Florida State University, one of the most highly anticipated moments appeared on television screens here early last Wednesday evening. Four days after having been proclaimed the leading football team in the nation by the news-agency polls for the first time in the 41-year history of the program, the Seminoles responded to the distinction in the art form of their time: a rap-music video.

title: High-Ranking Navy Admiral Punished for 'Improprieties'
description: One of the Navy's highest-ranking admirals has asked to retire after being disciplined for unspecified ''improprieties,'' a spokesman for the Navy said today.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
A French Series Recalls the Revolution
description: LEAD: FRANCE has issued the third in a series of coins to mark the bicentennial of the French Revolution. The theme of this year's coin is ''fraternite,'' one of the principles upon which the revolution was based.

title: Professional Engineer, 'A True Consultant'
description: The July 24 article ''Checking Out Houses on the Market,'' was undoubtedly an ego trip for the three firms written about, but did little to inform the public about the all-important issue of credentials. New York State Education Laws dictate that only licensed professional engineers or registered architects, may serve the public in the evaluation of mechanical and structural systems. These laws exist for the protection of the public, and anyone performing building inspections without the proper credentials is doing so illegally.

title:
WINE;
A Tasting of State Offerings
description: LEAD: COMPLAINTS about New York State wines run the gamut from ''too sweet'' to ''too foxy'' (a term used to describe the distinctive taste of wines made from native American grapes, like the Concord). However, a recent tasting at the New Gallery Restaurant and Wine Bar in Tarrytown led to the discovery of a New York State white - 1986 Millbrook Chardonnay - that was neither sweet nor foxy and a bargain when compared to many bottles from France and California.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: For all the effects of television on the country's political conscience at the time and for all the wide-screen, technicolor power of ''Platoon'' and ''Full Metal Jacket'' now, it is still the black and whites that best call up the visual memories everyone over a certain age has of America's longest war. THE AMERICAN EXPERIENCE IN VIETNAM (Boston Publishing/Norton, $39.95), a competent illustrated history, contains many of those photographs, along with shots, in color as well as in black and white, not published before. We see again the self-immolation of a Buddhist monk on a Saigon street in 1963, the execution by a bullet to the head of a suspected Vietcong officer in 1968, the anguish of a young woman kneeling over a body at Kent State University in 1970. ''The American Experience in Vietnam'' - successor to a 25-volume set called ''The Vietnam Experience,'' which was also put together by the writers Clark Dougan and Stephen Weiss and the picture editor Kathleen A. Reidy - takes the reader from Lyndon Johnson's inheritance of the Kennedy legacy and a time when ''neutralization was unworkable, withdrawal unthinkable,'' to the commission and construction of Maya Ying Lin's Vietnam Veterans Memorial on the Washington Mall and the debate over whether it stands as a ''black gash of shame.'' What the book doesn't do is match language with image. The text has a film-documentary organization that intersperses segments of conventional narrative with bites of oral history from servicemen, politicians, reporters, officers and prisoners of war. The bites have some power, sometimes; the narrative on occasion reads like the script for a voice-over. But then there are the pictures.

Three dozen men and women from all parts of the country recall their most exciting experiences. 12 9 30 THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GREAT POWERS, by Paul Kennedy. (Random House, $24.95.) How economic and military forces affected the fortunes of great nations in the past 500 years. 13 * 8 10 CAPOTE, by Gerald Clarke. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) The life of Truman Capote. 14 7 3 SENATORIAL PRIVILEGE, by Leo Damore. (Regnery Gateway, $19.95.) A reporter's reassessment of the 1969 accident on Chappaquiddick Island. 15 13 11 A TRAIL OF MEMORIES, edited by Angelique L'Amour. (Bantam, $12.95.) Quotations from the works of Louis L'Amour, compiled by his daughter. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 60 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 2 2 21 SWIM WITH THE SHARKS WITHOUT BEING EATEN ALIVE, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $15.95.) Strategies for succeeding in business. 3 3 152 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $16.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 4 5 16 CONTROLLING CHOLESTEROL, by Kenneth H. Cooper. (Bantam, $17.95.) A physician's program to prevent heart disease through exercise and diet. 5 40 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) The Second College Edition of a standard work, updated in 1982. And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) FLANNERY O'CONNOR: Collected Works. (Library of America, $30.) The novels, stories, essays and selected letters of the great Southern writer who died at 39, master of a circumscribed, violent, primitive universe through which she led her readers inexorably to some larger and very unpleasant truths. BAD BEHAVIOR, by Mary Gaitskill. (Poseidon, $15.95.) In the nine stories of her first published collection, Ms. Gaitskill renders a grungy and mostly New York world, full of sex and chemical substances, at once objective and sympathetic in their lean prose. THE ILLUSTRATOR, by James Robison. (Summit, $17.95.) Ash, the protagonist of Mr. Robison's skillful first novel, is an illustrator who becomes an artist through immersion in destructive elements - love, obsession, defeat, messy modern life. ADAM, EVE, AND THE SERPENT, by Elaine Pagels. (Random House, $17.95.) Learned and politically sensitive, Ms. Pagels focuses on two polar ideas in early Christianity - moral freedom and original sin - and argues that original sin won out because of its convenience in justifying the rule of Christian emperors. FAMILY POLITICS, by John Buckley. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Another funny book by another funny Buckley, a lively farce about a political quarrel in a big, rich, celebrated family. BREAKING GENTLE, by Beverly Lowry. (Viking, $17.95.) In her fifth novel, Ms. Lowry confidently and ironically explores the minds of a family of four who live on a horse ranch in Texas and whose thoughts are more poetically organized than most folks'. CAN SOMEBODY SHOUT AMEN! by Patsy Sims. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) The lives and beliefs of some itinerant American tent-revival evangelists, their wives, helpers and constituencies, written with respect and without condescension. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Robert H. Schmid, Advertising Executive, 76
description: Robert H. Schmid, a retired advertising executive, died of lung cancer Friday at his Manhattan apartment. He was 76 years old and also lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: The Goddess in Tennessee
description: IN CASE YOU DIDN'T know, the world's only full-sized replica of the Parthenon is in Nashville. It has been thus since 1897, when a plaster model of the great, columned temple was constructed, for some reason, as part of the city's centennial celebration. In the 1920's, the model was used to cast a permanent structure in concrete.

title: Officer Recalls Injury in Larry Davis Shootout
description: The only woman among the seven police officers who confronted Larry Davis in a Bronx apartment almost two years ago calmly told the jury at his trial last week what it felt like to be shot in the face in a gun battle with the defendant.

title: BUSH CONTRASTS HIMSELF AND RIVAL
description: Vice President Bush told cheering supporters in his adopted home state today that he will continue efforts to contrast key policy differences with Michael S. Dukakis, a strategy that aides assert is succeeding.

title: Awesome or Terrible?
description: To the Editor:

title: FICTION
description: THE TUNNEL. By Ernesto Sabato. Translated by Margaret Sayers Peden. (Available Press/Ballantine, Paper, $4.95.) Ernesto Sabato is best known for the second of his three novels, ''On Heroes and Tombs,'' a massive, intricate chronicle of murder and passion set in the Argentina of the 1950's. In his 1948 debut novel, ''The Tunnel,'' these themes are already on display, but in a simplified, almost fabulistic form. Mr. Sabato's narrator introduces himself, his crime and the object of his passion in the very first sentence: ''It should be sufficient to say that I am Juan Pablo Castel, the painter who killed Maria Iribarne.'' He then launches into an account of his affair with Maria, a married woman who first draws his attention at an art exhibit. Once their affair begins, however, her elusiveness provokes his jealousy, plunging him into a ''personal hell of analyzing and imagining.'' Does she see other men? Does she actually love her frail, blind husband? Does she love Castel himself? His attempts to answer these questions grow increasingly contorted and obsessive; finally, his crazed solipsism displaces romantic passion as the real subject of the novel. While Castel crouches, knife in hand, in the shrubbery outside Maria's weekend retreat, he makes his condition explicit: ''After all there was only one tunnel, dark and solitary: mine, the tunnel in which I had spent my childhood, my youth, my entire life.'' When it was first published in Spanish, ''The Tunnel'' won the applause of Thomas Mann and Albert Camus and was described as an existentialist classic. Some of today's readers may find Castel's descent into insanity a trifle romanticized. Still, in this fine new translation by Margaret Sayers Peden, Mr. Sabato's novel retains a chilling, memorable power.

title: Rosalie W. Ripley, Designer, Is Wed
description: At St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Bantam, Conn., Rosalie Wagstaff Ripley, a daughter of Mrs. Louis R. Ripley of Litchfield, Conn., and the late Mr. Ripley, was married to Richard A. Furniss Jr., a son of Mrs. Furniss of Narberth, Pa., and the late Mr. Furniss. The Rev. Robert Back performed the ceremony.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL '88
description: The college football season began last night with Nebraska beating Texas A&M, 23-14, in the Kickoff Classic. Today's sports section looks at these aspects of the coming season: * Florida State is living with the billing, and burden, of the No. 1 ranking. * Star quarterbacks abound. * Syracuse tries to stay on top in the competitive Eastern region. * Statistical trends and schedules.

title: ASTROS' SCOTT INJURED
description: Mike Scott left the Houston Astros' game with the Pittsburg Pirates tonight becuase of a strained left hamstring. Scott suffered an injury to the same hamstring on June 21 and was placed on the 21-day disabled list. Scott (13-4) reinjured the hamstring while pitching in the top of the first inning tonight.

title: Taxi Driver Shot Dead; Robbery Is Suspected
description: A taxi driver was found shot to death in Upper Manhattan early yesterday after what detectives think was a robbery, the police said.

title: Why Digital Has Lost Half Its Value
description: MANY stocks have come down to earth since the market peaked on Aug. 25 of last year, but few have made a thud as loud as the Digital Equipment Corporation.

title: An Artist Who Thrives on Contradictions
description: Ever since the tumultuous 1960's, when artists as unlike as Andy Warhol and Robert Smithson helped broaden the boundaries of art by challenging its accepted hierarchies, the medium in which an artist chooses to work has seemed less important than what that artist makes of it. Today it is possible - as by and large it was not in the 40's and 50's - to work with a variety of materials concurrently, and to draw directly from the supermarket of everyday life.

title: Amtrak
description: To the Editor: The article ''Across America by Rail'' (Travel, July 28) struck a strong chord with my wife and me, for we traveled from New York to California and back in April on Amtrak. We took the train to Los Angeles, and then drove a rent-a-car up the Pacific Coast Highway to San Francisco and back to Los Angeles. This was, without a doubt, the most enjoyable vacation we have ever had. On the train, there was no radio, no newspaper, a continuous panorama and interesting people at mealtime and in the lounge car. The only real shock we had was that there are no rent-a-car agencies near the Los Angeles train station, and the taxi ride to the nearest one cost $25. ROBIN E. SPOCK JANICE A. SPOCK Spring Valley, N.Y.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My patio consists of a concrete base over which is a layer of pebbles. The pebbles are cemented in place with epoxy and form a layer a little over 1 1/2 inches thick. Some of the pebbles are starting to loosen, leaving pockets or holes that are uncomfortable to walk on. What clear solution can I use to anchor the pebbles and fill the cavities?

title: Press Unfair in Coverage of Quayle's Past, 55% of Voters Say
description: Most voters say news organizations' coverage of Senator Dan Quayle's past has been excessive and unfair, according to a study made public today.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: RARE MANUSCRIPTS ''The Medieval Book,'' an exhibition of rare Middle Ages and Renaissance manuscripts from the Yale University collection, may be seen through Nov. 1 at the Beinecke Library on the Yale campus.

title: Spear Carrying: A Job With Potential
description: The belief that there are no small parts, only small actors, is the backbone of a spear carrier's life. Their names are the ones you skim in the program. Their job, for the most part, is to be silent and only technically visible. Their big moment is exeunt omnes.

description: To the Editor:

description: IF David McHeffey were asked how he survived the daily commuting to and from his Wall Street office, he'd say it really wasn't a bother, that he rather enjoyed it.

title: A Buyout Bust
description: To the Editor:

title: DATABANK: August 28, 1988
Review/Music; Schwarz Conducts Final Program in Mostly Mozart Series
description: Gerard Schwarz devoted the two final concerts in this summer's Mostly Mozart series to four works by the festival's namesake, and he arranged them in a sequence that made an interesting point about the emotional terrain Mozart's music covers. The first half was given over to dark, brooding works - the singlemindedly somber Masonic Funeral Music (K. 479a), and the stormy Piano Concerto in D minor (K. 466). After the intermission came the bright, almost frothy Violin Concerto in D (K. 218). And the program ended on a more complex note, with the Symphony No. 36 in C (K.425), the ''Linz'' - a work that includes patches of tragic darkness amid stretches of vivacity.

title: The U.S. Needs Foreign Investors
description: ECONOMIC nationalism is on the rise and foreign investment in America is increasingly a target. A recent survey showed that 78 percent of the public would favor limiting foreign investment in this country and 40 percent would like to halt it altogether. Politicians are pandering to the public's fears and advocating restrictions on foreign investments. Instead, they should be explaining the dangers of limiting this kind of investment.

title: Where Roadhouse Looks Can Deceive
description: RESTAURANT explorers on the prowl for the unexpected will be in their glory at Riverhead's Peconic House. It is an almost total surprise. The name surprises. It says seafood but is Italian. The menu surprises. It reads like standard cliche Italian-American, but the cooking here is anything but routine. Even the location in Riverhead is a surprise. This is not a community known as a gourmet crossroads. Nor does the Peconic House's setting around the corner from a Caldor shopping center (Riverhead Plaza) give a clue that this is anything but an ordinary roadhouse.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: MAKING HISTORY: The Radical Tradition in American Life. By Richard Flacks. (Columbia University, $35.) In this book Richard Flacks offers a sweeping reinterpretation of ''the left tradition in American history,'' from the 19th century to the present, together with proposals for the revitalization of that tradition.

title: 2 Housewives Sitting Around Writing
description: HOW does a Long Island housewife with a husband and two children turn her fantasies into fiction? If you ask Susan Isaacs, the novelist and screenwriter, whose newest novel, ''Shining Through'' (Harper & Row) is on the best-seller list, she will tell you to start writing the day you put your children on the school bus.

title: U.S. Says Soviets Are Expanding Base for Warships on Syrian Coast
description: The Soviet Union is building a new home for its warships in the Mediterranean by expanding a military installation that it operates on the coast of Syria, Reagan Administration officials said this week.

title: Bangladesh Floods Kill 80
description: Floods set off by heavy rains have killed more than 80 people in Bangladesh and authorities have declared a disaster alert, officials said today. They said 33 people were killed on Friday when houses collapsed and a boat ferrying flood victims capsized in the Jamuna River. Thirty-two inches of rain have fallen in northern Bangladesh in the last three days, flooding 21 of the country's 64 districts.

title: POSTINGS: Manny Hanny's Move; 5th to Madison
description: Behind the green plywood at the northwest corner of Madison Avenue and 57th Street, workers for Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company are preparing for Veteran's Day weekend and the parade of armored cars that will arrive at the door. At 3 P.M. on Thursday, Nov. 10, the Manufacturers Hanover branch down the block at Fifth Avenue and 57th Street will close, and movers will use the long weekend to bring teller computers and 2,500 safe deposit boxes - in sections that weigh a ton -to the new location, which will open the following Monday.

title: Different Views Of a Swamp
description: How do you twist a wetlands story?

title: Zucchini Blossoms in Provence
description: IN the shade of the yellow-and-white striped awnings of Nice's bustling market in the Cours Saleya, mounds of deep purple eggplants and stalks of garlic piled high make way for an unlikely looking neighbor - a bunch of orange flowers. A handwritten sign stuck in their midst alerts shoppers and the curious alike to what they are: fleurs de courgettes, zucchini blossoms. They're pretty enough, but why would anyone want to eat them?

title: A Look at Work by Polish Artists
description: THE first multi-media exhibition in the metropolitan area devoted exclusively to the works of contemporary Polish artists is under way at the White Plains Public Library.

description: When a University of Colorado student asked, ''Is New England a separate country?'' action was taken to make sure the astonishing question would not burn the ears of faculty members again.

description: GOVERNOR KEAN returned to work last week from the Republican National Convention in New Orleans to find some new items added to the list of issues he momentarily left behind to deliver the convention's keynote speech.
