Its six occupants stared intently at the data displayed on large video screens and carefully operated the flight controls. Their three counterparts on the ground crew, meanwhile, relayed instructions over headphones.

title: AFGHAN GUERRILLAS STEP UP ATTACKS ON CAPITAL AREA
description: Afghan guerrilla forces today sharply accelerated attacks on Kabul and on troops of the Soviet-backed Government within 10 miles of the capital.

title: Guadalcanal
description: To the Editor: I was one of the marines who was there in World War II and have been there subsequently and feel keenly the nostalgic realism that Mrs. Tregaskis wove into the story. It is good writing, with a strong ring of conviction. VICTOR H. KRULAK San Diego, Calif.

title: Why Can't The Mets Hit Anymore?
description: The lack of clutch hitting by the Mets over the 1987 and 1988 season can be attributed to the power of the pen and the written word. On paper, the Mets have been proclaimed the team to dominate their division and league. Apparently, the Mets players are quite literate and therefore, play as if destiny is on their side. Somehow, some way, they know that they will prevail at game's end. But although paper and baseball bats are both made from the same basic material, paper will not score the runner from second or third with two outs. MARTIN BASKIN New York

title: Guadalcanal
description: To the Editor: Anyone who was involved in World War II, as so many of us were, naturally knows Guadalcanal, but Mrs. Tregaskis captured the history and brought us up to the present very thoroughly and expertly. It would be more than interesting to people involved in this era to look back on some of the other outposts that played an important part in the war. DONALD G. GIFFIN Tucson, Ariz.

title: 'You Never Recover Your Original Self'
description: PROBABLY the oldest mystery to vex mankind is what, if anything, occurs after death. For a decade, Kenneth Ring, a psychology professor and researcher at the University of Connecticut, has looked into the question through the near-death experiences of others.

title: In Africa, Tribal Hatreds Defy the Borders of State
description: THE slaughter in Burundi this month of thousands of members of two warring tribes is a reminder that, for many Africans, the most threatening kind of ethnic hatred is black against black.

title: INTO THE MOUTHS OF BABES
description: James Traub quotes the judge in the Beech-Nut trial as saying that it was ''unusual for a corporate executive to do time for consumer fraud'' (''Into the Mouths of Babes,'' July 24).

title: It's Time to Plan a Third-World Revival
description: THE debt burden of the less developed countries can no longer be treated just as a banking problem. More fundamentally, it is a trade problem, a jobs problem and a geopolitical problem. Indeed, developing country debt and economic growth issues are so critical to both United States foreign policy and the domestic economy that it must be a priority item for the next President.

title: Videotape Shows Battle Scene on Vincennes
description: A videotape made by the Navy has provided the public with its first close-up glimpse of the dramatic scene aboard the cruiser Vincennes during the incident in which it mistakenly shot down an Iranian passenger plane, killing all 290 people aboard.

title: War on Drugs, War on Guns
description: The first shots erupted at 12:23 A.M. when a group of six men surrounded two others, killing one and wounding the second. An hour later, a few blocks away, gunfire from a passing car raked a group of 25 listening to rap music on a streetcorner, wounding seven. Police recovered cartridges from military assault rifles. ''Every day this is a war zone,'' a neighbor said. ''The [ drug ] dealers have bigger guns than the police . . . .''

title: Anne W. Hulecki, a Lawyer, Is Wed To Charles King 3d in Massachusetts
description: At the Smith College Chapel in Northampton, Mass., Anne Winnifred Hulecki, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward John Hulecki of Worcester, Mass., was married yesterday to Charles King 3d, the son of the late Dorothy Warden King of Southport, Conn., and the late Mr. King Jr. of Wilton, Conn. The Rev. William Guindon, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: The Case of Paul De Man
description: THE BAR IN THE AUDITORIUM lobby at the University of Antwerp was crowded with scholars in baggy suits, itinerant students, assorted hangers-on. There were also a few prosperous-looking older men, who turned out to be childhood friends of Paul de Man - the focus of an international conference held last June at the university. You wouldn't have known from the sessions listed in the program - ''Paul de Man and the Contingency of Intention,'' ''Anthropomorphism and Tropes in de Man'' - that they had come for any purpose other than to celebrate the memory of a local boy made good.

title: Americans and Vietnamese, Apart Again
description: THE sequence of events was all too familiar to those Americans who had hoped the time had come to build a bridge to Vietnam after more than a decade of false starts.

title: With State's Help, Plainfield Rebounds
description: LEAD: MAYOR Richard L. Taylor remembers summer evenings spent downtown when he was growing up in the 1950's. Back then, Plainfield was the economic hub of central New Jersey, and downtown was the hub of Plainfield, with more than 30 stores and a movie theater clustered in a single city block.

title:
GARDENING;
Ideal Tropicals for the Summer Garden
description: LEAD: MANY tropical and subtropical plants are used in our gardens and adapt well to summer since they are so tolerant of heat.

title: Miss Maher Wed To E. M. Hawley
description: The marriage of Mary Frances Maher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Maher of Greenwich, Conn., to Edward Mullins Hawley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Phillip M. Hawley of Los Angeles, took place yesterday at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn. The Rev. Gilbert D'Souza performed the ceremony Kathleen Hunt Maher was her sister's maid of honor, and Dr. Phillip M. Hawley Jr. was his brother's best man.

title:
FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS;
Car Entry Fee On Hold for Now
description: LEAD: ONE year ago Mayor Koch said he supported $10-a-day fees on vehicles entering Manhattan south of 59th Street. Business leaders harshly criticized the proposal, claiming it would cost the city hundreds of thousands of jobs. The city's Transportation Department said it would study the issue.

title: FICTION
description: FOREIGN MATTER. By Robert MacLean. (Atheneum, $17.95.) Not all the mentoring goes on in the business world. Here we have an aspiring humorist receiving instructions from the dead - in this case, P. G. Wodehouse. Bounteous internal evidence in this first novel proclaims that Robert MacLean has closeted himself with a stock of Wodehouse's most representative works, from which he has abstracted archetypal Wodehousian characters and plot devices. In ''Foreign Matter,'' Mr. MacLean employs Wodehouse's basic situation, a gang of zanies assembled at a country house - but on a Greek island instead of in Shropshire. Predictably, he updates the Master with some fairly overt sex, more talked about than accomplished, and topical references like ''Set your phasers on stun.'' There are significant objects to be stolen, concealed or recovered (a horrible painting, a dead dog, a diary), an allowance to be extracted from an unwilling elder, and young lovers (better described as young lusters) to be united. The cast also includes Bertie Wooster and Jeeves figures. The former, called Toby Tucker, is devoted to sleeping, drinking and dancing. But, unlike his literary model, he is also devoted to his girlfriend, Marcie, whose vocation is shopping. The Jeeves figure, in one of Mr. MacLean's better twists, is Marcie's precocious young daughter, who thinks ''in megabytes.'' Following Wodehouse's model, Mr. MacLean puts his Bertie figure through the ritual of seeing his plans go humiliatingly awry, whereupon the Jeeves figure, with awesome intelligence and guile, saves the day at the cost of further humiliation to the Bertie figure. The Wodehouse parallels are brazenly abundant, even including that staple, the vicious dog that traps people on top of wardrobes. However, one tends to be indulgent with this upstart Canadian because his imitation makes not unpleasant light reading. And Mr. MacLean's good taste in mentors could bode well for his future.

title: Renewed Drive for Foster Parents
description: LEAD: FACED with a pressing need to find more foster parents, the county's Department of Social Services last week announced a new advertising campaign and an increase in the fees paid for foster care.

title: After 30 Years, Penny Parking Comes to an End In a Quiet Town
description: LEAD: SYLVIA C. DAVIS, the town meter maid, had just flipped to a fresh page in her ticket book when a woman rushed from the bank, waving a nickel at her.

title:
DINING OUT;
Inventive Performance in Dobbs Ferry
description: LEAD: LIKE its namesake, Off Broadway presents new, fresh and inventive fare from a young and enthusiastic crew in neat but uncomfortable surroundings and for reasonable prices. The culinary product at this restaurant is so superior, however, that were it offered in a more luxurious ''theater,'' the performances would be sold out and at twice the price.

title: Troubled Museums Try to Master the Fine Art of Survival
description: ONE by one, sometimes painfully, museums have come to realize that their task is much harder than simply hiring a staff and hanging exhibits, with the backing of a few generous patrons. Over the last 20 years, even as museums have competed harder for attention and dollars, their expenses have risen, often outstripping the resources of even the wealthiest benefactors. ''Art museums used to be run privately,'' said Samuel Sachs, the director of the Detroit Institute of Arts. ''At the end of the year, you would do your books, there was a deficit, you would sit down with your trustees, they would pass the hat, and that was that. But that isn't possible any more.''

title: Hard Talk is Needed
description: Interest rates are up and the dollar has bumped down because of renewed fears of inflation. Still, the world economy is muddling along despite repeated prophecies of doom over the last decade. Both U.S. Presidential candidates skip warily aside from hard questions of what they would do about the huge U.S. deficits and strains in the international trade and finance system.

title: Miss Hunsinger Wed in Delaware
description: Wendalyn Sue Hunsinger, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Willard L. Hunsinger of Newark, Del., was married yesterday to George Colby Lunt 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lunt 2d of Deerfield, Mass. The Rev. David Wasgatt performed the ceremony at St. Stephen's Lutheran Church in Wilmington, Del.

title:
FOCUS: Laughlin, Nev.;
A Tiny Town Grows as Casinos Multiply
description: LEAD: WITH the opening of its second major casino/hotel this year and the completion last year of a four-lane bridge making it easier to reach, Laughlin is suffering the kind of growing pains that can be expected of a speck of a town turned suddenly into a thriving city.

title: Mussels: Clean, Adaptable and Relatively Safe
description: MUSSELS are inexpensive to buy and adaptable to a variety of seasonings. And since they are always eaten cooked, some of the safety concerns relating to bivalves raw on the half-shell do not apply.

title: U.N. Strains to Meet The Demand for Peace
description: THE sending of United Nations peacekeeping forces to Afghanistan and the Persian Gulf and the possibility that other contingents will soon go to other unstable areas shows that the dispatch of soldiers is becoming an important function for the world organization.

title: HIS ART WAS ALL HE MASTERED
description: TOLSTOY The Ultimate Reconciliation. By Martine de Courcel. Translated by Peter Levi. 458 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $27.50. TOLSTOY By A. N. Wilson. Illustrated. 572 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $25.

title: Quayle Learns What Hart, Ferraro and Biden Know
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
Survey of Sculptor's 6 Decades
description: LEAD: THE East Hampton sculptor Ibram Lassaw has been celebrated for pioneering a three-dimensional equivalent to Abstract Expressionism: pieces in metal that incorporate swift movement and shifting perceptions.

title: Sound's Plight Ignored By Pool Owners
description: I am writing in response to the article ''As Beaches Empty, Crowds at Pools Grow'' (Aug. 7). I am saddened and disgusted by the attitudes of the people interviewed in the piece.

title: Point O'Woods: 90 Years of Gentility and Privacy
description: POINT O'WOODS, Fire Island, is where you'll find sand in the church pews and Margaret Truman Daniel singing in the choir. It's where Carol Channing and the heads of the nation's top corporations go barefoot and where Sunday sermons are given by a bishop, John S. Spong, the Episcopal Bishop of Newark, but ''just another minister in residence here,'' according to one homeowner.

title: Strategies for the Chip Shortage
description: IT is getting hard to remember when memory was cheap. Prices for computer memory chips have climbed in recent months as 256K D-RAM's have been in short supply. That chip, more formally known as the 256-kilobit dynamic random access memory chip, is the most common memory chip used in personal computers.

title: Faulty Locks Prevent Opening of a Badly Needed Court Jail
description: New holding cells needed for dozens of defendants awaiting court appearances in lower Manhattan have been completed for more than a year, but they stand empty because their special locking and alarm systems do not work properly.

title: The Fall Concerts Await Suscribers
description: WITH the concert season in its annual end-of-summer doldrums, the moment seems right to look ahead to the fall, especially remembering that the early concert subscriber gets better seats and lower prices and can ignore the sold-out signs sure to appear when such superstars as Itzhak Perlman, Jorge Bolet and Rudolf Nureyev arrive. The following roundup is by no means a complete listing - just a sampler for what looks like a terrific season ahead.

title: Dukakis, at Rally, Invokes Themes of Dr. King
description: Governor Michael S. Dukakis reached for the redemptive imagery of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. today, urging a crowd commemorating Dr. King's dream to ''march on'' for racial and economic justice.

title: Claryss Hartman Weds in Denver
description: Claryss Nan Hartman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Hartman of Cherry Hills Village, Colo., and Thomas Crawford Jamieson 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jamieson Jr. of Princeton, N.J., and Londonderry, Vt., were married yesterday. The Rev. George I. Welch performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Cathedral in Denver. He was assisted by the Rev. Fred H. McCallin, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: STICK THIS IN YOUR MID-SIZED VUITTON
description: TILL WE MEET AGAIN By Judith Krantz. 534 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $19.95.

title: 1 Dog, 2 Dogs, 3 Dogs. . .
description: LEAD: THESE are dog days, in more ways than one. And no knows that better than Officer William Feola of the Hawthorne Police Department, who has been out there counting warm noses for New Jersey's annual dog census.

title: Of Tudor Thai and Swiss Siam
description: THE large billboard first appeared about six months ago on Sukhumvit Road, one of Bangkok's major arteries, and advertised in glowing colors a new housing project. This in itself was hardly unusual. Such signs -enormous, handpainted and displaying a good deal of pop-art imagination (lakes and tranquil tree-lined streets supposedly available in the city center) - are just as common as the outsize movie billboards that once inspired a French connoisseur to write a learned monograph about them.

title: CONNECTICUT OPINION
description: I HAVE a theory that I call Having a Great Time. Wish You Were Here Instead of Me. I strongly believe that nobody actually has a good time on his vacation. Actual vacation memories are blocked out and replaced with wishful remembering.

title: Merry Oldsmobile Still at Top of Heap
description: FOR years, I wouldn't have admitted this, but as a youth I suffered from Oldsmobile envy.

title: 'The Lottery'
description: In The Book Review of July 3, Judy Oppenheimer, the author of ''Private Demons: The Life of Shirley Jackson,'' described some of the public reaction to the printing of Jackson's short story ''The Lottery'' in The New Yorker in 1948: ''Nothing in the magazine before or since would provoke such a huge outpouring of fury, horror, rage, disgust and intense fascination. . . . Readers felt called upon to invent their own . . . explanations. . . . 'You are tools of Stalin.' . . . 'In this story you show the perversion of democracy.' . . . 'I suppose . . . a magazine may decide to print something that hasn't any point just to get people talking.' '' The excerpts that follow are derived from the mail received by The Book Review since the publication of Judy Oppenheimer's essay last month. Evidently the passage of 40 years has not deprived ''The Lottery'' of its power to compel interpretation. To the Editor:

title: FEW GET OUT OF THE BOX
description: BROTHERS Black and Poor - A True Story of Courage and Survival By Sylvester Monroe and Peter Goldman. With Vern E. Smith, Terry E. Johnson, Monroe Anderson and Jacques Chenet. Illustrated. 284 pp. New York: Newsweek/William Morrow & Company. $18.95.

title: Shea Needs QuietVision
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: MARY SHELLEY: Her Life, Her Fiction, Her Monsters. By Anne K. Mellor. (Methuen/Routledge, $25.) Raised by her father (William Godwin) after her mother (Mary Wollstonecraft) died giving birth to her in 1797, Mary Shelley was deprived of a loving nuclear family and thus desperately sought to create one both in her fiction and in her life.

title: Misheard, Misread, Misspoken
description: OH, SHE MAY GET woolly, women do get woolly, because of all the stress!'' The singer is a thick-headed rookie pitcher aboard the team bus in a scene from ''Bull Durham,'' the splendidly detailed baseball movie. Exasperated, his catcher snatches the guitar away. ''It ain't woolly,'' he barks. ''It's weary! And it's not nobody's got stress. They're wearing a dress!'' There's a word for misspoken words. Why, in this era of mass communications, is there no word for words that are misheard?

title: Eugene Daniell, 83, Political Advocate Of Underdog, Dies
description: Eugene S. Daniell Jr., a champion of the underdog who was known for his oratory in the state Legislature, died Friday at a local hospital. He was 83 years old.

title: An Ex-Cliff Dweller Fears for Nassau
description: My husband and I are homeowners who, as so many others have done in the last 35 years, gave up cliff dwelling in New York City, with its accompanying congestion, pollution and noise, for the green pastures and clean air of Nassau County. In recent years, we have become increasingly disturbed by the progressive urbanization of this area.

title: Guadalcanal
description: To the Editor: Mrs. Tregaskis' article was one of the most interesting I have read on such an unusual place. Years ago I read ''Guadalcanal Diary,'' and I am always interested as an amateur World War II buff in what has happened to those islands.

title: Prisoners Moving Upstate to Ease Overcrowding
description: Corrections officials will begin transporting inmates by chartered airplanes to two new 700-bed prisons in northern New York on Monday to ease overcrowding in New York City jails.

title: Mercedes Won Takes Hopeful
description: There was a mild upset at Saratoga, the renewal of an old rivalry in New Jersey and a surprising runaway in Illinois as Mercedes Won, Alysheba and Cryptoclearance scored important Grade I victories at different tracks today.

title: James Whitney Wed To Laura L. Scheerer
description: The marriage of Laura Lochrane Scheerer to James Apel Whitney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James D. Whitney of Tucson, Ariz., took place yesterday in East Hampton, L.I., at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Scheerer 2d of New York and East Hampton. Edward W. Horne, the town judge of East Hampton, performed the ceremony.

title: Former Mayor of Union City Is Held Liable for Damages
description: The former mayor of Union City, William V. Musto, and six others, convicted in 1982 of bilking the city of funds for school projects, have been held liable for $728,640 in damages stemming from the scheme, the United States Attorney's Office here said.

title: 39 Composers Receive Commissions From New Fund
description: Max Roach, John Adams, Ornette Coleman, David Del Tredici, Peter Schickele, Anthony Davis, Dominick Argento, Lois V. Vierk, Charles Dodge and John Cage are among the 39 composers who have received commissions in the first year of the new Meet the Composer/Reader's Digest Commissioning Program. The announcement was made Wednesday by John Duffy, president of Meet the Composer.

title: Amy Fabrikant Marries
description: Amy Beth Fabrikant, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Fabrikant of New York, was married last evening to Gregory William Eagan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Eagan of Amherst, N.Y. Rabbi David Posner officiated at Temple Emanu-El in Manhattan. The bride is a jeweler for Robert Fabrikant Inc., of which her father is the owner and president. Mr. Eagan is an investment banker with Prudential-Bache Securities. His father is the director of purchasing for Arvin-Calspan Industries, an aeronautical engineering concern in Buffalo.

title: The Anxiety Index Is Campaign's Wild Card
description: MICHAEL S. DUKAKIS has yet to lay out specific proposals for the economy, but he has begun to contest the notion that the state of the nation's fiscal health automatically redounds to the favor of George Bush.

title: POSTINGS: Saratoga's Rip Van Dam; Failed Bids
description: Saratoga Springs had an auction this month and not enough people came, or they didn't bring enough money. Whatever the reason, bids on the Rip Van Dam Hotel started at $500,000, peaked at $1.7 million and were rejected by the owner.

title: Jersey Insurer Blames False Claims for Deficit
description: The state-run association that provides automobile insurance for more than two million New Jersey drivers has attributed some of its financial problems to ''profiteering by fraudulent doctors, overlitigious lawyers, dishonest body shops and fortune-seeking policyholders.''

title: Historic Collections from the Trucial States
description: IN hobby magazines, ''dunes'' are the stamps of the former Trucial States, seven emirates along the northeastern edge of the Arabian peninsula.

title: Gretzky Is Gauge
description: IN the National Hockey League, where million-dollar-men are not a dime a dozen, the only one known to have reached that plateau is Wayne Gretzky. The Great One's well-publicized move to the Los Angeles Kings - and reports that he is getting a $5 million signing bonus and a $2 million annual salary - are having some interesting effects on player salary negotiations. The players and their agents, it seems, no longer measure contracts in money, but in Gretzky increments.

title: Beautiful Music From a Twisted Time
description: In Amsterdam in September of 1943, Anne Frank recorded news of Italy's surrender in her diary but thought the broadcasts ''too optimistic''; the German occupation instituted ''Operation Silver Fir,'' calling for the assassination of three Dutch civilians for every Nazi shot by resistance fighters, and Herbert von Karajan came to lead the city's famed Concertgebouw Orchestra in an ambitious series of recording sessions.

title: Red or Blue Blossoms for Summer
description: Weed; pull them out or they will set seed that survives over winter to grow in the garden next year. Work on the lawn: weeding, seeding and sodding; keep mowers set to cut high, at least two inches. Prune hedges. Plant evergreens. Dry herbs. Take cuttings of geraniums, impatiens and begonias to root and grow indoors as house plants. Lobelias

title: A New Play Dissects Mexico's Press, And It's Not A Pretty Sight
description: At the entrance to the Teatro El Galeon in Mexico City, where ''Nadie Sabe Nada'' is performed nightly to rapt and often indignant audiences, a large sign of the sort seen alongside highway construction sites is prominently displayed. ''Please pardon whatever discomfort this work may cause you,'' it reads.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Costly Homes Proliferating in Hunterdon
description: LEAD: IN the last five years the westward movement of the office market into Hunterdon County has transformed it from rural countryside to corporate destination. And that, in turn, has brought a spurt in expensive housing in the 427-square-mile county, situated in the northwestern part of the state and a 75-minute drive from both Manhattan and

title: Guadalcanal
description: To the Editor: As an old South Pacific buff, I was pleased to see a remote and distant shadowline of nigh-forgotten islands reappear in print. Thanks in no small part to the illustrious Richard Tregaskis and his epic ''Guadalcanal Diary,'' the very name of Guadalcanal must long remind the world of the legendary feat of arms performed there by our forces. RICHARD H. MAURY Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: Watson Closing In on Record Earnings
description: Suddenly Tom Watson is there again.

title: Brooks Rennert, Executive, Weds
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y., Brooks Gloria Rennert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Rennert of Manhasset, L.I., was married yesterday to Stephen Xavier Wright, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Wright of Rye. Msgr. William F. Burke performed the ceremony.

title: Patricia Sue Sachs Marries Bradley N. Schreiber
description: Patricia Sue Sachs and Bradley N. Schreiber were married yesterday in Chatham, N.Y., at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Martin Sachs, also of New York. The bridegroom is the son of Bernard Schreiber of New York and Stroudsburg, Pa., and the late Irene Schreiber. Rabbi Michael Szenes officiated.

title: Nigeria, Diversifying, Builds an Oil Refinery
description: A glittering new oil refinery here, the largest and most efficient in black Africa, represents Nigeria's latest step away from crude oil exports.

title: Jackson Calls Koch Meeting One of Many
description: Facing political fire for his plan to meet with Mayor Koch, the Rev. Jesse Jackson said yesterday that the Mayor was just one of many New Yorkers he would see during a visit this week, including the representatives of Tawana Brawley.

title: Send Humanitarian Aid to All Nicaraguans; Washington's Promises
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary Saturday of a Chicago politician and Presidential adviser and the accompanying headline misstated his name. He is Robert E. Merriam, not Richard. The obituary, also incorrectly named Mr. Merriam's father. He is Charles E. Merriam, not William.

title: Julia Beardwood Wed to J. A. Willens
description: Julia Mary Beardwood and Jonathan Allen Willens were married in Washington yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's mother, Dr. Susan P. Willens. Rabbi Harold S. White performed the ceremony. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Beardwood of Saffron Walden, England, and Doha, Qatar. The bridegroom is also a son of Howard P. Willens of Washington.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Retirement Planning
description: Taking advantage of a new service, more than 1.5 million people have called the Social Security Administration in the last three weeks to learn how much they can expect in Social Security retirement checks.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Activated Dennis Lamp, pitcher, from the 15-day disabled list. Placed Jeff Sellers, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Extended the contract of John Wathan, manager, through the end of the 1989 season. MINNESOTA (AL) - Activated Mark Portugal, pitcher. Placed Charlie Lea, pitcher, on the 21-day disabled list. Acquired Jim Dwyer, outfielder, from Baltimore for a player to be named later. YANKEES (AL) - Activated Willie Randolph, second baseman, from the 21-day disabled list. Optioned Randy Velarde, infielder, to Columbus of the International League. ATLANTA (NL) - Traded Ken Oberkfell, infielder, and an undisclosed amount of cash to Pittsburgh for a player to be named later. CINCINNATI (NL) - Placed Jose Rijo, pitcher, and Jeff Treadway, infielder, on the 21-day disabled list. Recalled Tim Birtsas, pitcher, and Luis Quinones, infielder, from Nashville of the American Association. HOUSTON (NL) - Sent Alan Ashby, catcher, to Tucson of the Pacific Coast League for a rehabilitation assignment. PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Activated Shane Rawley, pitcher. Purchased the contract of Al Pardo, catcher, from Maine of the International League. Optioned Danny Clay, pitcher, to Maine. >FOOTBALL ATLANTA (NFC) - Agreed to terms with Scott Case, cornerback; John Rade, linebacker, and Rick Bryan, defensive end. MIAMI (AFC) - Waived David Archer, quarterback; Shawn Beals and Michel James, wide receivers; Tom Kelleher, fullback; Bob Gruber, offensive tackle; Travis Simpson, center; Mike Smith, cornerback; Selwyn Brown, safety; Jerry Beasley, linebacker, and Charles Bennett, defensive end. Placed Glenn Blackwood, safety, on the reserve-physically-unable-to-perform list. MINNESOTA (NFC) - Released Barry Bennett, defensive tackle; Jeff Jenkins and Greg Richardson, wide receivers; Charles Wilson, running back, and Derek Burton, offensive tackle. SAN FRANCISCO (NFC) - Waived George Cooper and George Mira Jr., linebackers; Jeff Glasser, defensive tackle; and Darryl Pollard, cornerback. TAMPA BAY (NFC) - Waived Gerald Carter, wide receiver; Bill Ransdell and Bob Gagliano, quarterbacks; Anthony Simpson and James Evans, running backs; J.D. Maarleveld, offensive lineman; Dan Sileo and Randy Edwards, nose tackles; Kevin Kellin, defensive end; Don Graham, linebacker, Ray Isom and Randy Bellinger, defensive backs.

title: California Lawmakers Linked to Bribery Inquiry
description: Federal agents' searches of state lawmakers' offices last week were part of a two-year-old undercover operation in which dummy companies lured lawmakers with bribes, a lawyer close to the investigation says.

title: Ah, the Good Old Days In the Fifth St. Pool
description: To the Editor:

title: Isuzu Selling in Germany
description: Isuzu Motors Ltd. has started selling its Gemini cars equipped with 1,500-cc diesel engines in West Germany, the Japanese company's first car sales there, an Isuzu spokesman said Friday. Isuzu's sales target is 3,000 cars in the first year. Isuzu's 40 percent-owned IBC Vehicle Ltd., located near London, has started exporting its commercial Midi vans to continental Europe, the spokesman added. The vans, equipped with 2,000-cc engines, should sell around 1,000 a month.

title: Vicorp Restaurants Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a $1,796,000 charge from the early extinguishment of debt and a $17,473,000 pretax gain from the sale of a subsidiary. In the year-ago third quarter, preferred stock dividend requirements exceeded net.

title: Davis Water & Waste Indusries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
WATCH AND LISTEN
description: A sensor that clips onto an earlobe, fingertip or your chest can provide a digital readout of your heart rate while you exercise, and a new version can talk.

title: Review/Music; A Tasting Menu of Jazz
description: Anybody doubting the appeal of free jazz on a late-summer afternoon had only to go to the Village Gate on Friday afternoon for the opening of the Hennessy Village Jazz Festival. The two cavernous rooms of the Village Gate were filled to capacity, and the line of people waiting to get in wound around the block.

title: Correcitons
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article from Washington Saturday about a special prosecutor's decision not to seek charges in a case involving the Environmental Protection Agency incorrectly described the circumstances of Anne M. Burford's resignation from that agency. She resigned before the independent prosecutor began her inquiry. An article in the Washington Talk

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Aug. 29, 1988: MONDAY Albertson's Inc Watkins-Johnson TUESDAY Coachmen Industries Longs Drug Stores MD Ipalco Enterprises WEDNESDAY Ametek Inc Lee Enterprises Deere & Co Stanley Works THURSDAY Atlantic Energy Times-Mirror Chrysler Corp Washington National Corp

title: Balchem Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Criminal Fines, by the Day
description: ''Day fines,'' long used in Sweden and West Germany to punish criminals, have now been introduced to this country in an experiment in Staten Island. The concept offers promise for overworked American courts and city jails.

title: Tracy-Locke Regains A Taco Bell Account
description: Tracy-Locke, Los Angeles, has made a comeback, winning the Taco Bell San Francisco and Salinas/Monterey franchises again after losing the account 18 months ago. The budget is $3.5 million.

title: Housing Bias Bill May Bring End to 'No Children Allowed'
description: Barbara Grumley still gets mad when she thinks about it.

title: Farmsted Telephone Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Atlantic City: Failure Behind the Facade
description: Seen from afar, the Atlantic City skyline has the bulk and reach of a metropolis. But these impressive structures are casinos. Ten years after legalized gambling came to this faded resort, the skyline is a facade: the city behind the Boardwalk remains a slum.

title: Yankees Squelch Rumors, But Mattingly Is Unfazed
description: The Yankees insisted today that they have neither pursued nor considered trade offers for Don Mattingly, despite reports published Saturday in Toronto that they had.

title: Jets Unimpressive In Preseason Finale
description: Based on the Jets' final preseason performance, a 27-24 loss to the Green Bay Packers, their fans will need to have lots of patience and keep their fingers crossed.

title: Shop Now, Shuss Later
description: SAVVY skiers know the season starts sometime in August or September, when ski shops hold sales on equipment and clothing.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday New-Home Sales July Tuesday Leading Indicators July Factory Orders July Wednesday None Thursday Construction Spending July Friday Unemployment August

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Horchow and Neiman United for Third Time
description: LEAD: ''To possess the ingredients of style is to know how to live pleasantly and give pleasure to others,'' wrote Roger Horchow, founder of Horchow Mail Order Inc., in a book defining an approach to style that has earned him millions in the last 15 years.

title: Derby Sweep For a Filly
description: Dash for Speed won the $550,000 All American Derby today and become the first filly to win all three quarter-horse derbies at Ruidoso Downs.

title: Debra Yedwab, a Lawyer, Married to Ross Pearlson
description: Debra Yedwab, an associate at Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler, and Ross Pearlson, an associate at Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson, both New York law firms, were married yesterday at the Livingston Country Club in Irvington, N.J., by Rabbi Simon Glustrom.

title: Question of Selection; Bush Took Secrecy Over Consensus In Choosing Quayle as Running Mate
description: The Bush campaign contends, after what it admits has been a rough 10 days, that all the questions about Dan Quayle are behind it.

title: Bentsen Discovers That Selling Dukakis in South Is No Small Task
description: When Senator Lloyd Bentsen signed on as the Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate, a big part of his assignment was to be Michael S. Dukakis's ambassador to the South, the man who would reassure the formerly faithful there.

title: Sharpton Arrested With 15 Others in Protest
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton and 15 other people were arrested yesterday afternoon when they blocked traffic on the F. D .R. Drive for a few minutes during a march to protest racism by the police.

title: Avrett Wins Chex Cereals
description: Ralston Chex Cereals has tapped Avrett, Free & Ginsberg as its advertising agency after a five-way race. The account billed about $13.5 million last year, according to Leading National Advertisers.

title: Washington Talk: Working Profile/Kenneth M. Duberstein; Reagan's Chief of Staff, but Bush's Point Man By STEVEN V. ROBERTS
description: Under the original plan for the Republican National Convention, President Reagan and Vice President Bush were not supposed to cross paths. But there was ''a lot of pulling and tugging on the question,'' one White House aide said, because political commentators were citing the plan as fresh evidence that Mr. Bush was concerned about being overshadowed by Mr. Reagan in his week of triumph at New Orleans.

title: 14 ARE ARRESTED IN CHICAGO RALLIES
description: With hundreds of club-carrying police officers keeping the groups apart, hooded Ku Klux Klansmen preaching white supremacy staged a rally today in the same park where a multiracial group was arriving for a commemoration of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Fourteen people were arrested, most for disorderly conduct, in a tense afternoon at Marquette Park, where similar rallies sparked violence and resulted in 17 arrests two years ago.

title: Computer Power Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Exchange Rate Alters Iranian Economic Picture
description: To the Editor:

title: Agnico-Eagle Mines Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The company said revenue figures are restated to reflect accounting changes.

title: Spartech Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Fortune Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company began operations on July 17, 1987.

title: Come Home, Allie Reynolds
description: THE mere idea that Reggie Jackson would return for the last month of the season to play for the Yankees again in the team's supposed pennant drive made many shake their heads. After all, the main problem with the Yankees, as everyone knows, is not hitting, it's pitching.

title: Concurrent Computer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said the latest fourth quarter operating income increased by $800,000 because of a change in an actuarial assumption related to pension expense.

title: Coming Ads Show Surge Of Creativity
description: DESPITE the humidity and the summer doldrums, Madison Avenue's creative types have been busy. Ad campaign plans, gimmicky or otherwise, are being unfurled, and the prognosis is: they will either succeed or fail.

title: Inquiry on Food Ads Continues
description: The attorneys general of eight states are cooperating in a summer-long investigation of whether the advertising of some of the nation's largest food companies has misled consumers about the healthfulness of certain products.

title: Trade Pact Is Expected To Advance in Canada
description: After months of acrimonious debate, Canada's House of Commons is expected to approve this week the free-trade agreement reached last October between Canada and the United States.

title: Hach Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Peru Says Trawler Rammed Sub
description: President Alan Garcia was quoted today as saying the crew of a Japanese fishing boat caused the sinking of a Peruvian Navy submarine, killing 7 sailors and leaving 23 trapped in the submarine for nearly 24 hours.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Auto Racing Fourth in a Row for Senna: Ayrton Senna of Brazil won his fourth straight Formula One race, capturing the Belgian Grand Prix in Spa-Francorchamps yesterday and taking a big step toward winning the 1988 drivers championship. Senna has 75 points with seven victories this season, while his McLaren-Honda teammate, Alain Prost of France, has 72 points with five races left. Prost finished second yesterday. The next race is Sept. 11 at Monza, Italy, but only the top 11 of 16 finishes count in the final total. Senna led for all but a few seconds on the first lap yesterday. Prost overtook him on the first turn, but Senna regained the lead on the next long straightaway. The Brazilian beat Prost by 30.47 seconds on the 43-lap race over a 4.312-mile circuit through thickly wooded countryside. Thierry Boutsen of Belgium was third in a Benetton-Ford, more than a minute behind Senna.(AP) SHOW JUMPING Prudent Rides On: Katie Monahan Prudent of Middleburg, Va., moved closer to becoming the first show jumper to sweep the sport's triple crown when she rode Special Envoy to a jumpoff victory in the $50,000 International Jumping Derby yesterday at Newport, R.I. Six of 33 entries qualified for the timed jumpoff by riding without penalty over a 28-obstacle, 1,246-yard course. Prudent needs only a victory in the American Gold Cup in Devon, Pa., on Sept. 18 to complete the triple crown. She won the first leg, the American Invitational in Tampa, Fla., on April 2. ROAD RACING Victory for Diaz: David Diaz of Boulder, Colo., who took the lead with two miles to go, won the New York Road Runners Club's third annual Back to Work four-mile run in 20 minutes 11 seconds yesterday at Central Park. Gordon Bakoulis of the Atlanta Track Club set a meet record of 22:38 in winning the women's title. A field of 1,150 competed.

title: Golf; Reid Stops Watson on First Playoff Hole
description: After Tom Watson missed a 3-foot putt for par on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff today, Mike Reid tapped in a two-footer for par-4 to win the NEC World Series of Golf and prevent Watson from passing Jack Nicklaus as the leading money-winner in PGA Tour history.

title: Automedix Sciences reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is a development stage company and has not yet realized an revenue.

title: Centennial Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-earlier results are not directly comparable because the company became publicly traded in June 1987. On a pro-forma basis, the company posted a loss of $393,000 on revenue of $5,074,000 for the year-ago fourth quarter; for the fiscal 1987, pro-forma earnings were $1,498,000, or 6 cents a share on revenue of $29,574,000.

title: In Accord on Grooves
description: When the PGA Tour's Policy Board put off indefinitely a ban against use of irons with square grooves, it made a move acceptable to most of its leading players. Although the majority of tour pros want the square or U-shaped grooves outlawed on tour, they do not want their tour getting into the rules-making part of the game; that has traditionally been the job of the United States Golf Association.

title: Just a Teen-Ager With Grand Ideas
description: THE guests had eaten dinner, and without any prodding from her father, Steffi Graf helped clear the table as she would if she were home in Bruehl, West Germany, returning with placesettings for coffee and dessert. It was a reminder that the best tennis player in the world is still just a teen-ager, one who plays pinball, becomes animated when talking about books she has read and enjoys the privacy of her room, where she likes to dim the lights, turn up the stereo and dance the night away.

title: Metro Tel Corp reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Integrated Circuits Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $53,864 from refinancing of bonds.

title: Heart Federal Savings & Loan Associaion reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $541,000 from an extraordinary item for both the quarter and 6 months. The company said 1988 earnings reflect the effects of changes in accounting for loan fees. The company also said because it chose not to restate loan fees and resulting earnings from prior periods, the 1987 figures are not entirely comparable.

title: Of Profanity And Profits: A Network's New Focus
description: ALMOST from the moment that NBC was acquired by the General Electric Company, the network's management has been charged with eliminating or cutting back operations that cost money, while finding new ways to make money. Perhaps the most vivid example of this new philosophy at work was NBC's recent transformation of its broadcast standards department, which had scrutinized every program and commercial for objectionable material before it aired, into a new and smaller unit with the mission of making NBC's shows more commercially exploitable, through such means as product tie-ins.

title: Milton Sperling, Screenwriter, Is Dead at 76
description: Milton Sperling, whose 50-year career as a screenwriter and producer included an Academy Award nomination for ''The Court-Martial of Billy Mitchell,'' died after a long illness at his home here. He was 76 years old.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Hair, Washington Style
description: ''No doubt about it, I will miss the Reagans,'' said Robin Weir, who has been Nancy Reagan's Washington hairdresser for the last seven and a half years. ''I'll miss seeing President Reagan bop by in his shorts on the way to the exercise room, and I'll miss Mrs. Reagan's advice on what gifts I should buy for people. Having them go to California is like having good friends get transferred overseas.''

title: Bridge
description: Running winners can create problems for the defense even when there is no prospect of a squeeze or an end play. An illustration is the diagramed deal from a social game in Sydney, Australia. Sitting South was Tim Seres, who after three decades as the brightest star Down Under seems to have opted for retirement from tournament play.

title: Piedmont Natural Gas Inc reports earnings for Year to July 31
U.S. Is Using Random Blood Tests to Gauge Spread of AIDS
description: The Federal Government has begun blood-testing surveys that officials say should help clear up within the next several months uncertainty about how fast the AIDS virus is spreading.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Relief pitchers are generally measured by saves, but what about victories by a relief pitcher? Who are the leaders for a season and for a career?

title: Blessings Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 16
description: The latest periods' earnings were adversely affected by an after-tax writedown of $1,036,300 of part of the company's long-term investment portfolio.

title: Western Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said second-quarter net income was lower than the year- ago quarter due to continuing expenses from assimilating the December 1987 acquisition of the Kansas deposits and branches of American Savings.

title: Emmy to 'Thirtysomething'
description: The Emmy awards celebrated their 40th anniversary Sunday night with a starry extravaganza that bestowed awards on a number of top television shows from the three major networks.

title: Engineering's Top Programmer
description: Employees at the MacNeal-Schwendler Corporation like to make a simple boast: in the non-Communist world, one cannot fly in an airplane or ride in a car that has not been analyzed by their computer software program known as MSC/Nastran.

title: Distinctions Blur as Deaf Actors Share a Stage
description: As soon as the powerful-looking Akahira Yonaiyama moves across the stage, speaking in Japanese sign language as he goes, the blur of simultaneous translations begins.

title: College Football; Quiet Satisfaction for Huskers
description: As the University of Nebraska Cornhuskers approached the point of last season that would either satisfy an annual demand or create another disappointment, some uncharacteristic sounds were coming out of Lincoln.

title: Nancy B. Golinko Wed To Dr. Paul L. Krawitz
description: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., Nancy Beth Golinko, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard J. Golinko of Lawrence, was married yesterday to Dr. Paul Lavey Krawitz, the son of Harry Krawitz and Dr. Gertrude Krawitz of Buffalo. Rabbi Joel Zion performed the ceremony.

title: Tele-Marketing Dukakis
description: Does it bother you when a stranger calls up to make a telephone pitch for a product, charity or political campaign?

title: Kappa Networks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest periods include a writeoff of about $125,000 of obsolete finished goods inventory.

title: Cerprobe Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a $169,500 gain from an accounting change.

title: Problems in New York's Welfare System: Judging an Agency's Mistakes and Decisions
description: Rejected by the city's welfare system, facing imminent eviction and homelessness, the woman - along with more than 70,000 New Yorkers last year - had been granted her day in welfare court.

title: HEI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and includes net of $1,779,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Electro-Sensors Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Attitude Helps Your Putting
description: IF your putting has been bad this year, join the club. Tom Watson four-putted in both the Masters and the United States Open. Nick Faldo might have won the Grand Slam if he made any putts. Kristi Albers four-putted the last hole of the United States Women's Open on national television - from three feet. Or how about Bernhard Langer? In the final round of the British Open, from three feet he took five putts.

title: In Katmandu, Mustaches For a Melancholy Queen
description: Young boys dressed as shimmering cows led a celebration of thousands of Nepalese through the narrow streets of Katmandu's old quarter today, a celebration to mark death in the family.

title: Swimmer Is Banned For Drugs
description: Angel Myers, who won three events at the United States Olympic swimming trials and had a chance to win five Olympic medals, was disqualified yesterday from the Games in Seoul, South Korea, for using a banned drug. The name of the drug was not disclosed.

title: Giants Getting Ready
description: Before their opening game against the Washington Redskins on Labor Day night, the Giants have a week to tidy up loose ends and Coach Bill Parcells foresees no enormous problems.

title: The Talk of Basra; In Iraq's Troubled Waters, It's Time Now to Go Fishing
description: Five men and a boy, all clad in white robes, went fishing today on the banks of the Shatt al Arab. With bread and a paste of sesame to bait stout hooks, they reported to a stranger, they would catch fish big and small, but thus far had not caught any. The confession was made with a laugh.

title: Britain's Trade Jitters
description: A record monthly trade deficit has raised fears that Britain's extraordinary economic resurgence of the 1980's is suddenly in danger.

title: Muppet Chef Whips Up Commercials for Post
description: The Swedish chef, one of the Jim Henson Muppet lot, will be featured in an $8 million General Foods Post cereal campaign for Croonchy Stars. The TV commercials, produced by Grey Advertising in association with Jim Henson Productions, will begin airing Sept. 5.

title: INSIDE
description: What Happened in Burundi? The wounded are streaming into hospitals in Burundi, and officials are trying to determine how tribal conflict led to 5,000 deaths. Page A8. Ancient, Modern Katmandu Though the Himalayas have proved no barrier to modern and Western influences, the Nepalese capital retains its traditional culture. Page A3. Max Shulman Is Dead Max Shulman, creator of the Dobie Gillis character and a humorist whose work chronicled postwar America, died yesterday. He was 69. Steffi Graf Aims for Slam Steffi Graf hopes to achieve the Grand Slam with a victory at the United States Open tennis championships. SportsMonday, page C1.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Tool Orders Fell in July As Expected
description: Orders for American-made machine tools fell 33.1 percent in July from the previous month, partly as a result of seasonal demand changes, a report to be released today by the industry's trade association says.

title: Municipal Development reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Fee income is $2,547,594 for the latest quarter and $1,347,748 for the year- ago quarter; fee income for the latest 9 months is $7,077,858 and $3,514,531 for the year-ago 9 months. The company attributed the latest third-quarter loss to the expansion of its unibase data entry service bureau combined with a decline in financial advisory fee income from its James J. Lowrey & Co. unit. The company said it completed two key privatization projects in the latest quarter: the Fargo-Moorhead Toll Bridge and the Jacksonville Mental Health Clinic.

title: Hungarian Meets Rumanian For Talks on Ethnic Dispute
description: Karoly Grosz, the Hungarian leader, began talks with President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania today in Arad, Rumania. The talks, the first between leaders of the two Warsaw Pact allies in 11 years, are aimed at resolving a long-simmering ethnic dispute.

title: 3 More Youths Held In Park Killing
description: Three more teen-agers have been charged with beating and stabbing a man to death in Central Park last week, the police said.

title: TV Notes
description: Americans in Moscow

title: Army May Have Added To Revenge in Burundi
description: Survivors of brutal tribal warfare streamed into the village hospital here today, bearing multiple wounds they said had been inflicted by soldiers who were sent to restore order, but who appeared to have taken revenge as well.

title: Seahawks Deal Reported
description: The Seattle Seahawks have been sold to a California real-estate developer for about $80 million, pending approval by the league and the team owners, The Seattle Times reported today.

title: Plan Weighed to Seal Reactor for 30 Years
description: The G.P.U. Nuclear Corporation has filed a report with the Nuclear Regulatory Commission that proposes sealing the crippled Three Mile Island Unit 2 reactor for 30 years after a $1 billion cleanup is completed.

title: In Burma, a Rising Chorus Warns of Coming Anarchy
description: With the Burmese Government silent and apparently inactive four days after withdrawing its troops from the streets, residents are voicing growing fears of crime, disorder and a breakdown in services.

title: Ms. Golomb Weds David Frankfurter
description: Anath Golomb and David T. M. Frankfurter were married yesterday in Truro, Mass., at the home of the bridegroom's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. E. J. Kahn Jr., also of New York. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dan Golomb of Newton, Mass. Rabbi Caryn Broitman performed the ceremony.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about Citicorp's acquisition plans misidentified the buyer of Union Bank of California. It was California First Bank.

title: Allure Cosmetics reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Market Place; Westwood One Awaits Recovery
description: INVESTORS in Westwood One Inc., the nation's largest radio programming producer and distributor, might rightly have thought they had seen Black Monday revisited. Without any apparent warning, the company's stock plummeted $5.25, or 26.9 percent, to $14.25 on May 31.

title: Sherwood Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a loss from sale of retail offices and costs of terminating clearing operations of approximately $19,691,000 and a $1,580,000 extraordinary gain on extinguishment of debt. c-Net income Results for 1987 include the retail operation from February 1987.

title: Boardwalk Damaged In Fire That Hurts 13
description: An early morning fire at a boarding house destroyed a block of this resort city's boardwalk yesterday and slightly injured 13 people, the authorities said.

description: The crowd would have been the envy of one of the smaller tournaments on the circuit. The players were only practicing, but people did not appear to mind, following the pied pipers of tennis with paper and pens in hand, getting closer to the stars than they will be able to when the United States Open begins today.

title: Lima Journal; New Chapter for Vargas Llosa: The Art of Politics
description: In the heat of a major political crisis here last year, the Peruvian novelist Mario Vargas Llosa took up the banner of opposition to the Government's nationalization of private banks and, to his considerable surprise, found himself transformed overnight into a new political leader.

title: Baldwin Technology reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said year-ago figures have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Aug. 15.

title: A New Hall Rises; So Do Opinions
description: Word spread as quickly as the fire on the night in August 1985 when an arsonist burned the 234-year-old Town Hall here to the ground. By 2 A.M., when the flaming pillars at the front of the hall came crashing down on Main Street, hundreds of people were on hand to watch.

description: b-Net income

title: West Bank Man Is 2d in 3 Days to Be Killed by Other Palestinians
description: A West Bank Palestinian believed to have collaborated with the Israeli authorities was found beaten to death and tied to an electric pole in the West Bank city of Hebron today.

description: b-Net loss

description: b-Net income

description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $1,255,000 and $3,177,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and an extraordinary credit of $91,000 and $696,000 for the same same periods, respectively. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $4,549,000 and $7,660,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and an extraordinary credit of $2,999,000 and $5,443,000 for the same periods, respectively. The company said its results treat Continental Graphics Corp. and Simplicity Pattern Co. as discontinued operations. The pending sale of Continental is expected to be completed during the third quarter of fiscal 1989; Simplicity Pattern was sold in the fourth quarter of fiscal 1988. The company also said the improved results from continuing operations for the latest quarter and 6 months were due primarily to income earned on the Simplicity sale proceeds.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; You Are Where You Eat
description: The nation's political scientists, who will descend on Washington for their annual meeting this week, have received some politically scientific advice on where to eat from three specialists on dining in the capital.

title: For Christians, Too, Eight Has a Message
description: To the Editor:

title: The Burning of Rondonia
description: A calamitous cycle of destruction is unfolding in Rondonia, the heavily forested Amazon province in western Brazil. The tragedy is a lesson to Brazil and to the international agencies that finance its projects that heedless development can wreak havoc with the global environment, not just Brazil's. Cattle ranchers and thousands of landless settlers recently brought in by the Government are torching the tropical forest to clear the land. The fires are so extensive that they add appreciably to the global pollution that now may be warming the earth's climate. The richly diverse forest, ancient home to a fifth of the world's plant and animal species, is being destroyed irreversibly, and its Amerindian inhabitants are dying from imported diseases. Stripped of the trees that recycle forest nutrients, the soil yields only a few years' crops before the settlers move on, to destroy more forest.

title: Charming Shoppes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Eve Caren Hinlein Weds Arthur Shaw in California
description: Eve Caren Hinlein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce M. Hinlein of Haverford, Pa., was married in San Francisco yesterday to Arthur V. Shaw, a son of Leonard Shaw of Chicago and Sheila Brand of Evanston, Ill. Rabbi Martin Wiener performed the ceremony at Temple Sherith Israel.

title: Barbara Radley Weds Gordon F. Kingsley Jr.
description: The marriage of Barbara Dahlia Radley, a daughter of Dr. Herbert S. Radley of Woodland Hills, Calif., and the late Charlene Wilder Radley, to Gordon Francis Kingsley Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kingsley of Wellesley, Mass., took place yesterday in the gardens of the Hotel Bel-Air in Los Angeles. Rabbi Richard I. Schachet and the Rev. John Simmons, a Lutheran minister, officiated.

description: Melitta U.S.A. has called on three agencies to look after its advertising following a six-way review that lasted three months.

description: Results reflect adoption of FASB No. 96.

Pact Is Reached To Cut Jet Noise Over New Jersey
description: After months of pressure from citizens and legislators in New Jersey about airplane noise created by new flight paths at Newark Airport, the Federal Aviation Administration has agreed to new procedures to remedy the problem.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Advanced Products & Techologies reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Review/Television; A Muralist Encounters Capitalism
description: Diego Rivera, the Mexican artist whose 1933 mural at Rockefeller Center was blasted off the wall because it included a portrait of Lenin, is the subject of a documentary to be shown on Channel 13 at 9 tonight. ''Rivera in America'' follows the artist throughout the 1930's when, already something of a national treasure in his native Mexico, he received commissions for murals in San Francisco, Detroit and New York.

title: Nightmare in Anaheim
description: In the closing weeks of a mostly miserable summer, the Yankees have suddenly discovered one more opponent in the American League East: themselves.

title: Jail Escape by Helicopter Foiled in Florida
description: A West German imprisoned for selling classified technology to the Soviet Union and Eastern European countries tried to escape the Federal prison here in a helicopter Saturday, officials said today.

title: Boston Community Mourns A Drug Feud's Victim, 11
description: Two years ago, worried about rising crime in her neighborhood of Roxbury here, Alice Moore sent her daughter Darlene Tiffany to South Carolina to live with relatives.

title: Max Shulman, Humorist, Is Dead; Chronicler of Postwar Life Was 69
description: Max Shulman, a novelist, playwright and humorist who created the Dobie Gillis character and steered him through four seasons on prime-time television, died of bone cancer yesterday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 69 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Everyone wants to regionalize all our revenue-producing assets, like the convention center, the rail and bus terminals and the airport, but no one ever says, 'Let's take a share of your drunks, drug addicts and poor and spread them around.' '' - Seth Grossman, a lawyer and City Councilman in Atlantic City. [ B2:4. ]

title: Fraud Entangles Finance in Bogota
description: Juan Ricardo Escobar's former friends among the rich and respectable of Bogota now know they were wrong to trust the suave young stockbroker with their savings, but it still pains them to admit they were taken in by his charm.

title: Quayle's Record in Senate Reflects Fervently Held Conservative Views
description: Dan Quayle's legislative record reflects a solid conservative bent, but it could pose problems for him with farmers, senior citizens, women and others in the nation's heartland, where he is counted on to help the Republican ticket.

title: Outdoors: Subtle Signs of Summer's End
description: WHEN the postmidnight temperature dropped to 42 degrees a short while ago, I stood in the meadow's mist the following morning moved by the same urge that sent clamoring flights of Canada geese overhead on their annual late August flights from the salt ponds to inland fields of grasses and grains.

title: Review/Music; Johnny Cash and Family
description: Johnny Cash came to New York on Friday as a family man, with his wife, June Carter Cash, and their 18-year-old son, John Carter Cash, joining him on stage at the Ritz. The bass-baritone rockabilly singer, who made his first record in 1955, has become a country patriarch; Mr. Cash married into one country-music dynasty, the Carter Family, and he collaborated with his son on his forthcoming album.

title: Target for Guerrillas: Kabul's Morale
description: Intensified attacks by guerrilla forces in and near Kabul are intended to bring about the collapse of the Soviet-backed Government by sapping the morale of the Afghan Army and undermining confidence in the regime, Western and Asian diplomats and knowledgeable Afghans said today.

title: GLOBAL BRIEFS
description: * Japan's vehicle production rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in July from a year earlier, the sixth straight month of year-to-year gains, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said. July's production of 1.1 million vehicles included 711,435 cars, down 2.3 percent from the previous year. Truck production rose 6.8 percent, to 385,865, while buses increased 11.8 percent, to 4,697. Production from January to July totaled 7.43 million vehicles, up three-tenths of 1 percent from the period a year earlier.

title: Eugene S. Daniell Jr., Dead at 83; Ex-Lawmaker in New Hampshire.
description: Eugene S. Daniell Jr., a champion of the underdog who was known for his oratory in the State Legislature, died Friday at a local hospital. He was 83 years old.

title: Rap Music, Brash And Swaggering, Enters Mainstream
description: Rap is so stupid def, it's bum-rushin' the mainstream. It's housin' 'em all - word, homes. Translation: Rap is so incredibly fine, it's breaking down the doors of mainstream society. It's bringing down the house - and that's the truth, friend.

title: Dollar General Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Gangs Kill Nine in California
description: Violence among street gangs caused at least nine deaths in Los Angeles and Riverside counties over the weekend, and the Los Angeles police hastily formed a task force to patrol the worst areas.

title: Millicom Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said the latest quarter and 6 months reflect the consolidation of Millicom Cellular (UK) Ltd., which was acquired in March 1987. The company also said the latest periods reflect costs and expenses associated with the consolidation, as of March 31, 1988, of joint ventures now directly owned through subsidiaries. The company also said the increased losses, which were expected, were a result of costs associated with the planned expansion of the paging operation of Metagram America Inc. and increases in the costs and expenses incurred in the planned expansion of the profitable operations of Millicom Cellular (UK).

title: Belgian Investors Start Revamping at Scotty's
description: Belgian investors have begun a revamping of Scotty's Inc., a diversified building supply company in Winter Park, Fla., after completing an estimated $28 million stock purchase from the company's chairman, James W. Sweet, who has announced his retirement.

title: Bangladesh Floods Kill 100
description: Floods in Bangladesh have killed more than 100 people, and many more are still missing in ravaged northern districts, officials said today. At least 20 people drowned or were killed by snakes in the last 24 hours, they said.

title: Jay Schroeder Might Be Traded
description: The Washington Redskins are reportedly considering trading Jay Schroeder, their former starting quarterback.

title: Doctor Prescribes Aerobic Exercise
description: Doctors can be opinionated and rigid, and they sometimes stubbornly cling to ideas long after medical research in some area has taken a new turn. They are, after all, mere humans. But many doctors also change their minds when new ideas emerge, admitting it is time to embrace new thinking.

title: More Pressure for Rate Rise Seen
description: Credit market analysts contend that there will be more upward pressure on short-term interest rates this week, even though upcoming economic reports may suggest that the vigorous expansion is slowing.

title: Barris Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income The company said the fourth quarter loss is primarily attributable to a provision for unrealized losses on equity securities of $6,571,000 and a $782,000 writedown relating to the company's corporate bond portfolio. The company also cited extraordinary costs of $2,907,000 incurred in connection with the Media General Inc. proxy contest.

title: PDA Engineering reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss The company said it settled all matters and secured a release from its lease obligation for former corporate offices. This settlement was within the $1.5 million reserve for losses which was established in the fourth quarter of 1987.

title: Catcher Hits Wall And Breaks Hand
description: Darren Daulton, the Philadelphia Phillies' reserve catcher, punched a wall in the team's clubhouse and broke his right hand Saturday. Daulton was angered by being called out on strikes in the ninth inning of a 4-2 loss to the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Indian Tribe Agrees to Drop Claim To Tacoma Land for $162 Million
description: In one of the biggest settlements of an American Indian land claim in this century, the Puyallup Indians have voted to drop claims to some of the most valuable property in Tacoma in return for $162 million in cash, land and jobs.

title: A Horror Surpassing Hitchcock?
description: In a scenario reminiscent of a summer horror movie, thousands of bats have driven a family from their home in this normally placid village along the old Erie Canal in Oneida County.

title: Calmly, Dukakis Stokes Home Fires
description: Over the next two days, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis will travel to nine towns. He will meet with a Chamber of Commerce, talk to home buyers, chat with newspaper editors and visit a produce market.

title: Comedians as Ad Stars: Absurd Yet Credible
description: To Jeff Altman, Nestle Toll House Ready-to-Bake Cookie Dough is very much a laughing matter. Valvoline motor oil, Arby's Roast Beef and Tostitos corn chips are hysterical.

title: Books of The Times; Perceptive Cyclist in Eastern Europe
description: Stealing From a Deep Place By Brian Hall 271 pages. Hill & Wang. $18.95.

title: Julia L. Hechtman Is Wed to Eric Sall
description: Julia Leah Hechtman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert B. Hechtman of Chestnut Hill, Mass., was married at the Hotel Meridien in Boston yesterday to Eric Stuart Sall, a son of Frances Sall of Fayetteville, N.Y., and the late Dr. H. David Sall. Rabbis Roland B. Gittelsohn and Gunter Hirschberg officiated.

title: Washington Tempts A Canadian Publisher
description: The Toronto Sun Publishing Corporation is seriously considering beginning a morning tabloid in the nation's capital that would appeal to a distinctly different type of reader than do the two existing dailies.

title: Miss Zimet Weds Ian J. Elfenbaum
description: Michelle Zimet, an associate at Siemon, Larsen & Purdy, and Ian J. Elfenbaum, an associate at Radzilowsky & Dobish, both Chicago law firms, were married last evening at the Tavern on the Green in New York. Rabbi David Lincoln performed the ceremony, assisted by Cantor Morris Luffman, a great-uncle of the bridegroom.

title: Cooler Weather Calms Forest Fires in the West
description: A second day of calm weather aided firefighters in their battle against forest fires today, and near-freezing temperatures slowed flames in Montana.

title: Detective Is Accused of Assaulting Sergeant
description: An off-duty detective, sleeping in his car in the Bronx with a gun on his lap, was found by a police sergeant yesterday and arrested and suspended when he punched the sergeant in the face, the police said.

title: Storm Strikes South Carolina, Killing One
description: A tropical storm rolled ashore today, bringing heavy rain and strong winds that destroyed more than a dozen mobile homes, killing one person, and knocked out power to thousands of people.

title: Bertrand Russell, on the Candidates' Claims
description: If you'll excuse the pun, Vice President Bush is acting like a bush leaguer. He's running around the country telling selected audiences how marvelous he'd be in the majors, but he's always striking out or getting caught off base.

title: One of Baseball's Good Hops
description: Joe Garagiola's eloquent squawk rose a few decibels when he read a coded list of indigent baseball players. He said, ''Look at that - 1951. And look at that - 1943.''

title: Golf; Jones Loses Lead, Then Wins
description: Rosie Jones lost an early five-shot lead today, then recovered to break out of a five-way tie with a birdie on the 16th hole to capture the $265,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association world championship.

title: Computer Assignment For Saatchi & Saatchi
description: National TechTeam has named Saatchi & Saatchi DFS/Torrance, Calif., its ad agency. The budget is $1 million.

title: Nurses in San Francisco Vote To End Strike After 4 Weeks
description: Striking nurses at six hospitals voted today to end a four-week walkout, approving a contract that will raise their pay three times over 34 months.

title: Giants Rock Mets in Ninth
description: Through eight innings, there had been collisions and calamity, injuries and intrigue and enough lineup changes to leave almost everyone on both the Mets and the Giants seriously disoriented.

title: Denver Museum Chooses Director
description: The Denver Art Museum has appointed a new director with 17 years' experiebnce at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in new York.

title: Fans Left With Pick-5 as Storm Disrupts Saratoga
description: A violent rainstorm that crashed through Saratoga Race Track late this afternoon forced the cancellation of the last two races, including the featured John A. Morris Handicap.

title: Entertainment Publications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $900,000 for the latest year and $3,263,000 for the year- earlier period.

title: Reviews/Music
description: Tanglewood's celebration of Leonard Bernstein's 70th birthday has been full of Mr. Bernstein's music. But the largest single Bernstein score heard here over this four-day span has been one of his most controversial. Saturday night in the Shed, the Opera Theater of the Indiana University School of Music presented a staged performance of ''Mass,'' Mr. Bernstein's ''Theater Piece for Singers, Players and Dancers.''

title: National League; Pirates Gain Some Ground
description: Andy Van Slyke and Jose Lind hit run-scoring singles during a three-run rally in the eighth inning as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Houston Astros today, 4-3.

title: Optek Technology reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $114,895 and $209,540 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax benefit of $132,000 and $311,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Tax Watch; I.R.S. Rulings On College Funds
description: A PLAN for tuition prepayment adopted by the state of Michigan looked like an answer to prayer to many parents, anxious about how to save for their children's educations in the face of mushrooming costs. They could deposit a few thousand dollars with the state, which would invest it for tax-free growth. The child would be guaranteed the tuition for a four-year education at a state school. The money, less an administrative fee, would be refunded if the child did not attend college.

title: London House Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Nomad Children, Lost in New York's Maze
description: They are nomad children, hundreds of New York City children who are moved each night from one foster care home to another. These children, ranging from infancy to adolescence, spend most of their days in field offices of the city's Special Services for Children. At night they are shuttled from borough to borough, carrying what few possessions they have in plastic bags. These children have been lost in the maze of the city's foster care system.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transcription error, an article from Gdansk, Poland, on Friday about an attempt to settle strikes in Poland misidentified a mediator.

title: Latshaw Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: The company said in July it signed an agreement with Biotech Electronics Ltd. of Montreal in which Latshaw Enterprises lent $2.5 million to Biotech and received a promissory note.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9

title: Iraq Appears to Toughen Stance on Control of Disputed Waterway
description: Iraq appeared to toughen its position in the United Nations-sponsored talks on the gulf war today, publicly claiming full sovereignty over the disputed Shatt al Arab waterway.

title: Inquiry Seen For Southern
description: The United States Attorney in Atlanta is expected to confirm that the Justice Department is investigating the Southern Company for possible tax fraud. Robert L. Barr Jr., the United States Attorney, said he would comment Monday on reports of the investigation.

title: Biden Is Back
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, released from the hospital after two aneurysm operations, made his first public appearance Saturday since February. Choking up and in tears at times, the former Democratic Presidential candidate told a party gathering, ''Ladies and gentlemen, it's good to be home.'' Mr. Biden said that doctors had pronounced him fit to return to an active life.

title: Political Memo; Accentuating the Positive Can Lead to Nasty Campaign
description: If your taste in political campaigning does not run to the harsh attack and counterattack, you would be well advised to do all of the following for the next 10 weeks: Turn off your television and radio, throw away all your newspapers, don't answer your telephone and don't open a single piece of mail that does not come from a known and dear relative.

title: Rift Over Abortion Is Mended for Two
description: Nearly two months after a judge refused to stop a 27-year-old mother of three children from having an abortion that her husband vehemently opposed, Christine Anderson is back together with her husband.

title: Tigers Are Stunned By Brewers, 12-10
description: Paul Molitor hit a two-run homer in the seventh inning today as the Milwaukee Brewers twice overcame five-run deficits and beat the Detroit Tigers, 12-10.

title: A Small Plane Lands Safely On the Garden State Parkway
description: A small plane with two people aboard developed engine trouble over New Jersey last night, but landed safely on the Garden State Parkway in Galloway Township near Atlantic City, the police said.

title: BURUNDI PRESENTS ITS SIDE OF STORY
description: Burundi's Foreign Minister, Cyprien Mbonimpa, today ascribed the tribal killings in the north of his country to invading ''rebels'' from neighboring Rwanda but said the fighting was now over.

title: Words to Rap By
