description: The hip-hop slang that is finding its way into American speech is traceable to black language and inner-city speech patterns that have long been evolving, said Robert Farris Thompson, a professor of African and Afro-American art history at Yale.

title: Over 50, Overqualified and Unemployable
description: To the Editor:

title: For Rectors and Churches, Ecclesiastic Summer Stock
description: The preacher climbed the steps to the high marble pulpit of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church yesterday and, looking politely to the right and left, began his sermon. Somewhere - he didn't know where -in the congregation, sat a three-member search committee from a church in New Jersey that was considering hiring him as its rector.

title: Lorimar Agrees To Sell Station
description: The Lorimar Telepictures Corporation said Friday that it had agreed to sell WPGH-TV in Pittsburgh to the owner of stations in Hartford, and Miami.

title: To Raise the Saving Rate, Try Spending
description: Are Americans saving too little? Does a low ''national saving rate'' lie at the heart of our economic troubles? Most politicians and many economists think so, but they're on the wrong track.

title: Recalling a Booming Role
description: Irving Mansfield, the well-known producer, public relations specialist and book promoter who died last week at the age of 80, was not widely remembered for his connection to athletics.

title: Afghan Joins Soviets in Space
description: The first Afghan in space and two Soviet astronauts were sent into space this morning to join two others aboard the Mir space station. The 8:23 A.M. launching of the Soyuz TM-6 spacecraft, with the Afghan, Captain Abdol Ahad Mohmand, 29 years old, and Vladimir Lyakhov, 47, and Dr. Valery Polyakov, 46, aboard was televised live from Soviet Central Asia. Dr. Polyakov is to remain aboard Mir to observe the health of Vladimir Titov and Musa Manarov, astronauts who have been in space since last December, officials said. Captain Mohmand and Mr. Lyakhov are to join the others in a week of research aboard the space station.

title: Warsaw Party Approves Plan For Broad Talks
description: The Communist Party's Central Committee approved a draft resolution today for broad-based talks to resolve the country's social and economic ills.

title: Willamette Valley Journal; Watching Grass Grow Is More Than a Pastime
description: A variety of grass called Manhattan forms the turf in Central Park, Regal surrounds the White House, and Munich's Olympic Stadium is carpeted with Derby. The seeds for all originated near here in the Willamette Valley, which produces 70 percent of the world's ryegrass.

title: Review/Music; Dancing to the Beat of a Cultural Mix
description: Coladera, the bubbly dance music from the Cape Verde islands, came to S.O.B.'s on Friday night, played by Luis Da Silva and his backup band, Les Anges. Dance music has to be judged on how well it works: during the second set, the dance floor was packed and churning.

title: 4 Die in Plane Crash In Rural Connecticut
description: A small airplane crashed into a thickly wooded area in this small town yesterday, killing four people, the state police said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amoco Chemical Co., Chicago, named Joe C. Strickland president of Welchem Inc., its Houston-based subsidiary that makes chemicals used in the production of oil and natural gas.

title: Send Humanitarian Aid to All Nicaraguans; Democracy First
description: To the Editor:

title: Promising Signs for Fall Retail Sales
description: Merchants across the nation are hoping that retail sales for the fall season will return to the solid beat they had before the October stock market crash, after which many Americans cut back on their buying. But while the signs so far are vaguely promising, they are not uniformly encouraging.

title: Associated Communications Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income Year-ago 6-month includes a pretax gain of $763,335 from non-recurring sales of properties. Year-ago second quarter and 6-month include a pretax gain of $5,357,536 from the sale of an investment, and per-share figures for those periods are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in April.

title: Send Humanitarian Aid to All Nicaraguans
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Matters; Public Financing: Will It Be No? Yes? Or a Yawn?
description: Andrew J. Stein is going about these days making quite a pronouncement, the kind that might be called cocky for want of a more polite word. ''I will go into the new year with my debts retired,'' he says. ''And with $1 million in the bank, approximately.'' Now this is a very courageous prediction, because Mr. Stein, the City Council President (and possible mayoral candidate) owes a lot of money. He has a debt of $334,875 from his 1985 race for Council president and another debt of $79,000 from his unsuccessful Congressional race in 1984.

title: Ensource Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and after a $1,775,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Only Bills Offered by Treasury This Week
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to the bill market, beginning with today's regular auction of new three-month and six-month bills, and ending tomorrow with an auction of 20-day cash management bills.

title: First Boston May Go Private
description: First Boston Inc. is discussing a possible merger with Financiere Credit Suisse-First Boston that would create a private company, First Boston announced yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES First Boston is discussing a possible merger with its European investment bank to form a private company. The talks are being held with Credit Suisse, the Swiss bank that is First Boston's partner in the jointly held European venture, Financiere Credit Suisse-First Boston. The announcement followed months of rumors and speculation, and a $15 rise in First Boston's stock since May. [ D1. ] A Federal judge is expected to decide tomorrow whether Eastern Airlines will be allowed to begin its curtailed flight schedule. The judge barred Eastern from dismissing 4,000 workers on Friday in an order that said other issues would be considered in a final ruling. Eastern had planned to close its hub at Kansas City, Mo. [ D3. ] THE ECONOMY Orders for machine tools fell 33.1% in July, partly because of seasonal shifts in demand. The monthly report by an industry group said orders were up 57.2 percent from July 1987. [ D1. ] Some retailers see signs of improved sales in merchandise areas that have been depressed, including women's apparel. [ D1. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT Canada's House of Commons is expected to approve this week the free trade agreement with the United States. The opposition Liberal Party has vowed, however, to block passage of the accord in the Senate until the next general election. [ D2. ] Nigeria will begin exports of refined oil products next year. A new Japanese-designed oil refinery is one of several projects aimed at diversifying the economy of the oil-rich country. [ D8. ] The reputation of Bogota's stock exchange has been tarnished by a stockbroker's embezzlement of at least $13 million from his clients. The swindle has focused Colombia's attention on illegal financial activities stemming from widespread tax evasion and the laundering of drug money. [ D8. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS Some stand-up comedians have found second careers as commercial spokesmen. With the rise of an American ''comedy culture,'' advertisers have decided it can be more effective to sell a product with silliness than with seriousness. [ D1. ] Washington may get a new tabloid newspaper. Toronto Sun Publishing, which recently bought a printing business in Maryland, is interested in the market because of its nearly recession-proof economy. Riders on Washington's subway system might also be drawn to a paper with a smaller format, the company says. [ D6. ] A magazine for high school students is telling advertisers about the merits of its readers. High School Sports magazine, which distributes 500,000 copies, says there has been a surge of interest in the teen-age market, which spends more than $80 billion a year on items from sneakers to stereos to groceries. [ D6. ] NBC made a dramatic change in its broadcast standards office is an example of the new cost-consciousness at the networks. The department will now focus on marketing and product tie-ins, shifting censorship responsibility to producers. Television. [ D6. ] A selective mixture of new advertising ideas shows variety and innovation. Advertising. [ D7. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Some analysts see more upward pressure on short-term rates, even though new reports may suggest that the economy's expansion is slowing. Credit Markets. [ D5. ] The I.R.S. plans to tax income from tuition prepayment plans, so parents may want to consider such tax-exempt investments as municipal bonds in planning how to pay for their children's education. Tax Watch. [ D2. ] Westwood One is waiting for radio advertising to improve so that it can regain its once-strong earnings growth - as well as a higher stock price. Market Place. [ D4. ]

title: Germans Act On Rates
description: The Bundesbank is planning to change the method by which it operates variable-rate tenders for securities repurchase pacts, dealers said today.

title: A Major Builder Picks Williams Whittle Shop
description: Long Signature Homes, one of the top 10 builders in the Washington-Maryland-Virginia area, has retained Williams Whittle Associates to handle its seven-figure advertising budget. Out of 15 agencies that competed for the business, the two other finalists were DDB Needham, New York, and the Earle Palmer Brown Companies.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Russia's Worst-Kept Secret
description: It's nearly a half-century since Stalin and Hitler stunned the world by signing the nonaggression pact that cleared the way, weeks later, for the invasion of Poland and the outbreak of World War II. But the pact's secret protocols have never been published in the Soviet Union, though official permission was granted for rallies in Baltic states protesting what isn't acknowledged. Ending this absurdity would honor Mikhail Gorbachev's promise to fill in the blank pages of Soviet history.

title: A Helping Hand From Steve Garvey
description: IT'S not as big a spectacle as the United States Open, which starts today at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Queens, but the 18th annual United States Tennis Association Teachers Conference has its own brand of surprises.

title: Imtec Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: B B Real Estate Investment reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The year-ago share net figures aren't comparable because of a recapitalization plan.

title: Ah, the Good Old Days In the Fifth St. Pool
description: To the Editor:

title: Geodynamics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 3
Orthodox Israeli Women Win Some Ground
description: Rabbi Yisrael Lau today became Israel's first municipal chief rabbi to be elected in a procedure in which women took part.

title: Staar Surgical reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: FiscaL 1987 periods have been restated to reflect the effect of certain adjustments.

title: Graf Remains On a Roll
description: Displaying a dominance like that of a champion prizefighter in the ring against an overmatched contender, Steffi Graf won another title today. The 19-year-old West German routed Nathalie Tauziat of France, 6-0, 6-1, in 41 minutes to win the United Jersey Bank Classic and enter the United States Open on a roll.

title: Magazine Pursues Advertisers for the High School Market
description: High School Sports magazine, which has quietly addressed almost three million students for more than three years, has begun a campaign to sell the advertising world on an economically powerful age group that spends more than $80 billion a year on everything from sneakers to stereos to groceries.

title: 2 Lawyers, Maris Fink And Kevin J. Liss, Wed
description: At Congregation Agudath Sholom in Stamford, Conn., Maris Joy Fink and Kevin Jay Liss, 1988 graduates of the Columbia University School of Law, were married yesterday by Rabbi Joseph Ehrenkranz, asssisted by Cantor Ivor Lichterman.

title: Monica Nozyce Is Wed To Mitchell G. Mandell
description: Monica Lisa Nozyce, a daughter of Drs. Maximo and Molly Nozyce of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Mitchell Gregory Mandell, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gary V. Mandell of Monmouth Junction, N.J. Rabbi Melvin Sirner and Cantor Lawrence Avery performed the ceremony at Beth-El Synagogue.

title: Harnischfeger Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a loss of $18,111,000 from the early retirement of debt for both the quarter and 9 months, and the quarter also includes a loss from the reversal of a tax loss carryforward. c-Net income d-Includes tax credits of $2,500,000 and $8,000,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said previous year's figures are restated to conform to current year's presentation.

title: Ruling Awaited on Eastern Flights
description: A Federal judge is expected to decide tomorrow whether Eastern Airlines will be allowed to begin its curtailed September flight schedule.

title: SCORES ARE KILLED IN AIR SHOW CRASH IN WEST GERMANY
description: Three jets from a precision flying team of the Italian Air Force collided and crashed today during a low swoop past a crowd of 300,000 at a United States air base in West Germany, killing at least 46 people and injuring as many as 500 others. Many of the injured suffered serious burns.

title: Alliance Well Service Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $976,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a music article on Friday about Leonard Bernstein's 70th birthday celebration misstated the dates and place of screenings of television programs featuring Mr. Bernstein. The screenings were presented last Wednesday to Friday at Tanglewood in Lenox, Mass., under the auspices of the Museum of Broadcasting in New York.

title: Noted Trader Plans to Quit
description: Richard J. Dennis, the multimillionare renowned for his prowess as a commodities trader, said today that he was quitting to concentrate on politics.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alberto-Culver Co., Melrose Park, Ill., a manufacturer of toiletries, said it would buy Save-Way Beauty Supply from Windmere Corp., Hialeah, Fla., a producer of personal care products.

title: Mestek Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
2 Leading Financiers Will Merge Companies in $1.65 Billion Deal
description: Sanford I. Weill, who created the brokerage firm now known as Shearson Lehman Hutton, re-emerged yesterday as a Wall Street powerhouse with the announcement that he and Gerald Tsai Jr., another leading financier, would merge their current companies in a $1.65 billion deal.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Does a compass work on the Moon? A Theoretically, yes, but ''you wouldn't want to depend on getting back home using it,'' said John W. Dietrich, curator of lunar samples at the Johnson Space Center, Houston.

title: Community Planning Urged To Prevent Teen-Age Suicide
description: Federal health officials have issued guidelines to help communities prevent clusters of suicides, especially among teen-agers. Rule No. 1: Don't wait for the problem to begin.

title: Cem Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NHD Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: The company said it plans to open three stores during the second half of 1988.

title: Foodmaker Chain Gets Buyout Offer
description: Foodmaker Inc., which owns Jack in the Box fast-food outlets and Chi-Chi's Mexican restaurants, said today it had agreed to a $19.125-a-share buyout proposal from a group led by Gibbons, Green van Amerongen. If the $239 million deal is completed, it would be Foodmaker's second buyout in three years.

title: Cellular Products reports earnings for Year to March 30
Market Place; Reporting Rule's Effect on Detroit
description: INVESTORS who like to pore over financial statements to do their own analysis will have a tougher time when it comes to sizing up automobile companies and other industrial enterprises with large financing subsidiaries. Because of a ruling by the Financial Accounting Standards Board, these subsidiaries' results, which have been reported separately, are going to be consolidated into the corporate parent's profit-or-loss statement and its balance sheet. The new method begins with statements for 1988.

title: Yonkers and the South
description: The city of Yonkers, N.Y., is in much the same situation as that in which the Southern states found themselves in the 1960's. The lesson in that, if Yonkers chooses to learn it, is that the city would be better off to comply with Federal court orders rather than to continue its hopelessly outdated version of ''massive resistance.''

title: U.N. CHIEF PRESSES A GULF COMPROMISE
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar asked the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council today to help him break the deadlocked Iran-Iraq peace talks, diplomats said.

title: Command Airways Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Copperweld Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
In Burma's Fragmented Opposition, Hint of Unity
description: A group of older politicians and retired military men formed an opposition alliance in Burma today under the titular leadership of U Nu, the former Prime Minister who was overthrown in a coup 26 years ago.

title: Madison Gas & Electric Co reports earnings for 12mo June 30
Canine Virus Tied to Seal Deaths
description: A team of Dutch scientists announced today that they had identified an animal virus that more commonly infects dogs as the cause of the puzzling epidemic that has killed more than 7,000 seals this year in the North Sea and the Baltic.

title: Man in Court on Heroin Charges Is Arrested in Slaying of Girl, 11
description: A man appearing in court today on a drug charge was arrested in connection with the recent fatal shooting of an 11-year-old girl in a poor, crime-ravaged neighborhood, the police said.

title: Decom Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: b-Net income and includes tax credits of $57,000 and $227,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Nathan's Returns To Coney Island Roots
description: Nathan's, known best for its hot dogs and crinkle-cut french fries, has decided to bring its Coney Island roots alive by having the actor Lou Jacobi portray Nathan Handwerker, the man who founded Nathan's 72 years ago.

title: Cardinal Distribution Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $336,000 and $396,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively, and the latest quarter also includes a gain of $4,409,000 on the sale of discontinued operations.

title: Nutmeg Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Piniella Talks to Jackson
description: Lou Piniella said today that he spoke with Reggie Jackson last Friday about a possible comeback by the 42-year-old former player. But Piniella, the Yankee manager, said he never received the impression in their telephone conversation that Jackson seriously intended to try playing again.

title: On Horse Racing; Sloppy and Dreary Ending at Saratoga
description: The last time it rained this hard, the only horses left were two passengers on an ark. Only a few more than that stuck around for the season's final day of racing at Saratoga this afternoon.

title: Why Not Adult Day Care?
description: LEAD: I was called to the emergency room the other day to see an 82-year-old widow, a victim of a mild stroke. For the last 12 years, I have seen her transformed from an active and independent woman, enjoying retirement with her husband, to a person who depends on others. She developed complications from diabetes, heart disease and anemia.

title: Latest Surgery For Parkinson's Is Disappointing
description: THE transplant of fetal tissue into the brain, a daring procedure that many experts have considered the best hope for treatment of Parkinson's disease, is yielding disappointing results, say Swedish scientists who have tried the operation on two patients.

title: G.M. Merges Units
description: The General Motors Corporation said that its AC Spark Plug division would combine with the Rochester Products division to form the AC Rochester division, putting all units that make electronic engine-management systems into one operation. The consolidation, which will take effect Sept. 1, will affect 28,000 employees in 10 countries. The reorganization follows the sale on Friday of Rochester Products' diesel fuel-injection business to a joint venture of G.M. and the Penske Corporation.

title: New-Home Sales Decline by 4.7%
description: New-home sales suffered their steepest drop in seven months in July, and economists predicted further softening as rising mortgage interest rates push up the cost of buying a home.

title: Sabonis Is Named To Soviet Team
description: The Soviet Union's star basketball center, Arvidas Sabonis, who had been sidelined with a torn Achilles' tendon for the last 18 months, will be playing for the Soviet team in the Olympics, Soviet officials announced.

title: La-Z-Boy Chair Co reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
People-Wise Programs
description: BACK in the 1960's, Joseph Weizenbaum wrote a program to demonstrate the possibilities and limitations of communicating with computers in natural language - English, for example - rather than in programmer's jargon. He named the program Eliza, after the Eliza Doolittle of ''Pygmalion.''

title: N.Y.U. Clerical Staff Strikes for Pay Parity
description: Clerical workers at New York University walked off the job yesterday morning in an attempt to disrupt the start of the school year and force the nation's largest private university to raise its offer of a 5.5 percent annual pay increase.

title: Engine Maker Cuts 1,042 Jobs
description: Pratt & Whitney today announced the elimination of 1,042 salaried jobs in the last of three rounds of job reductions intended to make the company more competitive in the commercial and military jet-engine business. Pratt & Whitney, a division of

title: About Chess Moves
description: The New York Times has converted its method of chessboard notation to the algebraic system, in which each square is unambiguously identified by file letter and rank number. Explanations of the system are available from the Chess Column, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: Sports People; Cauthen Improves
description: Steve Cauthen, the American jockey who was injured in a fall at Goodwood race track in England last Friday, was discharged from St. Richard's Hospital in Chichester yesterday after tests revealed no serious injuries. A statement from the hospital said that ''nothing of significance'' was shown on X-rays taken of the 28-year-old Cauthen. Cauthen is not expected to return to riding for about three weeks. (AP)

title: Challenging the Billboard Industry
description: Concerned about what they consider visual blight and rampant commercialism, a growing number of local governments are clamping down on billboards.

title: Cosmo Communications Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Higher Cocaine Prices Discourage Few Users
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Drossman Wins Ellesse
description: Ellesse, acquired by Reebok International Ltd. in January, has moved its in-house account to Drossman Lehmann Marino without a competition. The budget is expected to exceed $3 million. The $25 million agency plans to develop print and television campaign for the sports shoe and sportswear maker.

title: After Rebels' Gains, Ethiopia Vents Its Wrath on Civilians
description: ''The tanks ran over the people and ground them up,'' Amena Mohammed remembered later. ''Bodies fell over us. I covered the two children with bloody clothes and pretended to be dead. We hid among the dead bodies for three days.''

title: CUOMO THREATENS YONKERS OFFICIALS FOR DEFYING COURT
description: Governor Cuomo said today that he would act to remove from office four Yonkers City Councilmen who have blocked a court-ordered housing desegregation plan unless the United States Supreme Court indicates that it will hear their appeal of a contempt order..

title: Sports People; Appeal Planned
description: Kirt Myers, the father of Angel Myers, who was banned from the United States Olympic swimming team after failing a drug test, said yesterday that his daughter hoped to undergo an independent test at Indiana University and would pursue an appeal of the ban.

title: You Promised Me You'd End Terrorism, Recognize Israel
description: LEAD: You invited me to Tunis and for several hours there we had a thorough and brisk conversation on Aug. 20. You told me you were surprised by the number and brutality of my questions. Yet those are the questions raised not only by Israelis but by every Jew in the world, and by many people who are not involved in the Arab-Israeli conflict.

title: Intellectual Duel: Brash Challenge, Swift Response
description: QUESTION: Of what possible use is the following series of numbers: 1, 1, 2, 2, 3, 4, 4, 4, 5, 6, 7, 7...?

title: Frequency Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: Synercom Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Mutual Fund Sales Drop
description: Mutual fund sales fell to $7 billion in July from $8.2 billion in June and $13.2 billion in July 1987, the Investment Company Institute said today.

title: Yankees Let Rumor Linger
description: George Steinbrenner, given a chance to silence the Don Mattingly trade rumors once and for all, stopped short today. Instead, the Yankees' principal owner repeated his stated policy of accommodating any unhappy player with a trade.

title: International Rectifier Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax charge of $378,000. c-Includes a tax charge of $215,000 for the quarter and income from discontinued operations of $295,000 for the year.

title: Japanese Buying Up the Good Life in France
description: What do Chateau Lagrange, the Bordeaux vineyard; Lucas Carton, the three-star restaurant, and Carita, the hairdresser, have in common?

title: Chess
description: After a period in which Viktor Korchnoi experienced an eclipse, the erstwhile challenger for the world championship won the Royan International Tournament in France last month. Korchnoi, who has lived in Switzerland since his departure from the Soviet Union, scored 7-2 to capture first place.

title: From Tut to Taylor, Moving-Image Museum Captures Film History
description: A ''Zorro'' lunchbox, an Elizabeth Taylor Sew Easy Fashion Kit and a coming-attractions jigsaw puzzle portraying Buster Crabbe in ''King of the Jungle'' are among the thousands of artifacts that will be unveiled to the public on Sept. 10 when the American Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, opens its doors.

title: Merrill Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Corrections
description: A report in Sports Pages Friday on the death of Graustark, a thoroughbred stallion, gave an incorrect age.

title: Essex Chemical Rejects Gurit Bid
description: The Essex Chemical Corporation said that its board had unanimously rejected a proposal from Switzerland's Gurit-Heberlein A.G. to buy Essex for $32 a share, or a total of about $241 million.

title: Liberalism, as in Liberty, Is a Cause for Pride; An American Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Walesa Fires a Broadside for Solidarity
description: Lech Walesa warned today that strikes in Poland will not end until ''talks open possibilities for resolving our problems, and particularly the issue of Solidarity.''

title: The 'Student-Athlete' Myth
description: The indictments involving college sports handed down by a Federal grand jury in Chicago last week focused on the dubious activities of three player agents. But of greater significance were the plea bargains that nearly four dozen athletes accepted to avoid indictment: they admitted defrauding their colleges by taking payments from agents and signing professional management contracts while still playing college games.

title: Nostalgia Network Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Banks Settles With Giants
description: Carl Banks, the Giants' All-Pro linebacker, ended his 45-day holdout yesterday by agreeing to a contract that could make him the team's second-highest paid player.

title: Cortronic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Says Drug Lord Is Indicted
description: Investigators and prosecutors were first struck by the extravagant purchases and showy life style of Thomas Mickens. Only later, they said, did they realize how deeply his power extended in the drug world of South Jamaica, Queens.

title: The Step Still Untaken in Poland
description: The big news was what didn't happen at last weekend's emergency session of Poland's Communist Party Central Committee. Despite oncoming economic chaos and hints by party leaders of a national dialogue without preconditions, Warsaw still flinches from recognizing Solidarity.

title: Entree Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 23
description: The company said the latest quarter includes pretax earnings of $1,318,000 resulting from a reversal of a provision for disposing assets.

title: Whittaker Corp reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Korea-U.S. Trade Gap
description: South Korea's trade surplus with the United States shrank by 15.7 percent in the first seven months of the year, to $4.66 billion, from $5.53 billion a year earlier, the Government reported today. Officials attributed the reduction to Korea's revaluation of the won. Korean merchandise exports to the United States rose 10.8 percent, to $11.39 billion, in the period, while imports from the United States surged by 41.5 percent, to $6.73 billion, the report said.

title: Matsushita Is Expanding In Computers
description: After an absence of 24 years, one of the world's largest electronics companies, the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, said today that it would re-enter the market for sophisticated computers.

title: Plastics Industry, Under Pressure, Begins to Invest in Recycling
description: UNDER pressure from anti-pollution legislation and shrinking landfill space, the plastics industry is moving rapidly to develop technology for recycling its products, like beverage bottles and plastic bags, after they have been used by consumers.

title: Plea for a Prisoner
description: This morning a group of Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish clergymen and women is to call at the Federal Bureau of Prisons on First Street Northwest to urge that better medical treatment be accorded Anne Henderson Pollard, the wife of Jonathan Jay Pollard, the former United States Navy intelligence analyst who was convicted of spying for Israel and sentenced to life imprisonment last year.

title: Richard P. Chapman, Boston Banker, 83
description: Richard P. Chapman, former chairman and president of the New England Merchants National Bank, died Friday. He was 83 years old. Mr. Chapman, who lived in Brookline, joined the old Merchants National Bank of Boston when he was 22 and became president in 1952. Under his leadership New England Merchants became Boston's fourth-largest bank. Mr. Chapman became chairman in 1964 and retired in 1970.

title: John W. Rindlaub, Bond Executive, 80
description: John W. Rindlaub, a retired executive vice president of Municipal Issuers, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Saddle River, N.J. He was 80 years old.

title: Global Fire Is Linked to Dinosaur's Demise
description: A STUDY of ancient clay deposits has provided new evidence supporting the theory that global fires ignited by a meteorite impact contributed to the demise of the dinosaurs and many other creatures 65 million years ago, scientists at the University of Chicago reported last week.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Julius Rudel as Pianist In Brooklyn Arts Series
description: The conductor Julius Rudel will give a piano performance with the St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble at the opening of the ninth season of the Arts at St. Ann's on Oct. 23 at 4 P.M. at the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity, 157 Montague Street, in Brooklyn Heights. The concert, the first of three by the chamber ensemble, will feature Mendelssohn's String Quartet No. 1 in E flat major (Op. 12), Copland's Nonet for Strings and Mahler's ''Songs of a Warfarer.'' Other concerts by the ensemble will be on Feb. 12 and May 7.

title: Nets Get Walter Berry
description: Walter Berry, the college player of the year for the 1985-86 season while he was at St. John's, was obtained by the Nets yesterday from the San Antonio Spurs for Dallas Comegys.

title: Brawleys Pay Surprise Visit To Lawmaker
description: The tangled Tawana Brawley case took unexpected new turns yesterday with a surprise visit by the upstate New York teen-ager and her fugitive mother to a Congressman's office in Washington, and a decision by the Rev. Jesse Jackson to get involved in the case for the first time.

title: Douglas Computer reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Prime Vantage Point for the Palestinians
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization's observer mission here is one of the group's most vital diplomatic outposts, a place from which the P.L.O. influences the United Nations agenda and maintains ties with dozens of nations.

title: Talking Business; with Brendsel of Freddie Mac; Behind the Move To Sell Stock
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, decided last month to allow savings and loan associations that owned its preferred stock to sell those shares to the public. Freddie Mac was chartered by Congress in 1970 to help develop a secondary market for mortgages.

title: Continental Materials Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and includes a gain of $902,000 from an accounting change.

title: Careers; Physicists Find Many Fields Open
description: IN this highly technical age, physicists are in good demand, said Charles Montrose, professor of physics at the Catholic University of America in Washington.

title: Pro Football Notebook; No Scrimmaging Over Strike This Time
description: The 1988 National Football League season is five days away, yet there is still no collective bargaining agreement between players and management. Both sides agree that free agency remains the crucial snag.

title: Satellite Placed in Discovery Cargo Bay
description: Workers at the Kennedy Space Center tonight finished loading the space shuttle Discovery's cargo bay with a $100 million satellite nearly identical to one destroyed in the Challenger explosion in 1986.

title: Tenters to Alaska Are the Real Pioneers
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Richards Wins John Silver's
description: Long John Silver's, a seafood restaurant chain based in Lexington, Ky., has named the Richards Group in Dallas as its agency. The budget is $15 million, and a regional television campaign is scheduled to begin in October.

title: Fries Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss

title: 'Smokeless' Cigarette Ready For Sales Tests Amid Fight
description: The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company started taking orders for its new ''smokeless'' cigarette yesterday from distributors, supermarkets and discount chains in test markets, amid attacks by medical groups that want the product banned as a health nostrum.

title: Toronto Bank To Offer Notes
description: The New York branch of the Toronto Dominion Bank of Toronto offered $200 million of 10.20 percent subordinated notes due 1998 at a price of 99.85 to yield 10.22 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Where Mum's the Word
description: The editors of the Corporate Crime Reporter, a weekly newsletter here, decided in the midst of the debate over the independent prosecutor's report on Mr. Meese that it would be interesting to see how other Federal prosecutors would have handled the case.

title: Dukakis, Stung by G.O.P. Attack, Urges Debate on Campaign Issues
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, displaying a growing frustration with a campaign debate dominated by the Republicans, acknowledged today that he was having difficulty getting his message across in the last few weeks, but said the fault was not with the message.

title: KEY RATES
Sterling Chemicals To Offer Common
description: Sterling Chemicals Inc. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering of up to 11 million shares of common stock through Goldman, Sachs & Company and Lazard Freres & Company.

title: Giants' Taylor Gets 30-Day Suspension For the Use of Drugs
description: Lawrence Taylor, the premier linebacker of the Giants, was suspended yesterday by the National Football League for 30 days for violating its substance-abuse policy.

title: Pill for Impotence
description: Early tests of the pill form of a drug used to help impotent men achieve an erection indicate that the pill is safer, more convenient and just as effective as the injectable version, according to a recent report in the Annals of Internal Medicine.

title: Sports People; Wilson Is Cut
description: Marc Wilson, who spent five years trying to provide the solution to the Los Angeles Raiders' quarterback problem, was told yesterday that he wasn't the answer in Green Bay. The eight-year veteran, cut by the Packers, was among several well-known players to be released.

title: ECI Telecom Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Umbrellas, not Racquets, at Open
description: If it is a Grand Slam event, then it must be raining. Weather problems plagued the Australian Open, the French Open and Wimbledon this year, and yesterday, steady rain all but washed out play on the first day of the United States Open.

title: Baseball; Dodgers Sparked by Griffin
description: Alfredo Griffin hit his first home run of the season and 20-year-old Ramon Martinez won his first major league game as the Los Angeles Dodgers edged the Montreal Expos, 2-1, tonight for their fourth straight victory.

title: Sports of The Times; Taylor's Dangerous Game
description: LIVE fast, die young and leave a good-looking corpse. That was the motto of the main character in ''Knock on Any Door,'' a novel written many years ago by Willard Motley.

title: Merry-Go-Round Enterprises Inc () reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
A Veto for the Milk Scam
description: Will New Yorkers again be forced to pay monopoly prices for milk? A year after a Federal court dismantled a dairy processors' cartel that had been run with the blessing of the state, the Legislature is busy nurturing a nascent dairy farmers' cartel. The question now is whether Governor Cuomo is willing to buck the farm lobby and veto legislation that would almost certainly mean higher milk prices for consumers.

title: Airline Unions Making Use of Railway Labor Act
description: Until recent times, the Railway Labor Act at the center of the dispute between Eastern Airlines and its unions was considered so powerful a tool against labor strikes that in the 1970's some airline unions lobbied to have it repealed. But times have changed. Three unions representing Eastern workers have used the act in Federal court to block Eastern's management from laying off 4,000 workers.

title: Forcing Poverty on AIDS Patients
description: A year's supply of AZT, the only drug with some efficacy against the AIDS virus, costs a patient $8,000. A Federal grant to the states is available for those who can't afford it. But the grant runs out in September, leaving uninsured patients with a choice. They can stop taking AZT, or spend themselves into poverty, until their assets are worth less than $3,100, so as to qualify for Medicaid.

title: Cotton States Life & Health Insurance Co reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $350,814 and $449,335 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes realized investment gains of $270,387 for the quarter and $519,852 for the 6 months.

title: William Woolfson, 84, Ex-College Director
description: William C. Woolfson, retired administrator of the Poe Center of Bronx Community College and a founder of the United Federation of Teachers, died of a heart attack Sunday. He was pronounced dead on arrival at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville. He was 84 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: Fashion; By Design; Plaid Makes a Comeback
description: Schoolgirls in their little pleated skirts are not the only ones who will be clad in plaid in the coming months. Plaid is back. A fashion that comes and goes, surfacing for a few seasons and then fading away, it's turned up in new guises this time, not just as classic tartan kilts or flannel work shirts, but in everything from evening dresses to bracelets, shoes, scarfs, gloves, hats, handbags and suspenders.

title: America's Cup; Conner Chooses Rigid Sail
description: Dennis Conner said today that he would probably defend the America's Cup with a hard sail on his 60-foot catamaran, rather than the more common soft rig.

title: Diplomacy Is Attracting More as a Second Career
description: Here in a class of the United States Foreign Service were the American diplomats of tomorrow: an urban planner, a film maker, a USA Today reporter, an art teacher, an aide to Mayor Koch of New York, a photographer, a businesswoman with an M.B.A., a smattering of lawyers and a few people close to completing Ph.D.'s.

title: Leland Journal; Summer Plague: Heat and Tourists
description: Everything, it seems, has gone to extremes this summer in this normally cool, normally quiet Great Lakes village, the heart of Midwestern moderation.

title: Acquisition by Unit Of Texas Eastern
description: A subsidiary of the Texas Eastern Corporation, Petrolane Inc., and its affiliated master limited partnership., Petrolane Partners L.P., agreed to a two-part purchase of International Controls Corporation's liquified petroleum business for $175 million.

title: Health Chief and AIDS: A Chant of Critics Amid Praise
description: For two years now, Stephen C. Joseph, as Health Commissioner of New York City, has commanded the fight against AIDS from the epidemic's toughest front.

title: Brazil Will Restrict Mining
description: Brazil's constituent assembly voted today to restrict development of the country's vast mineral wealth to Brazilian-controlled companies. This decision, confirming a preliminary vote in April, is to become part of the new constitution when it is finished next month.

title: FOES OF PINOCHET ISSUE PLEA ON VOTE
description: With Chile's military leaders virtually certain to nominate Gen. Augusto Pinochet for eight more years as President, opposition leaders issued last-minute pleas today for a compromise candidacy. The opposition also said it had the electoral support to defeat the general.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Publisher Named At New York Woman
description: Amy Rappeport, who was involved in the founding of New York Woman magazine three years ago, has been named its publisher. She has stepped in for Julie Lewit-Nirenberg, who resigned.

title: Metropolitan Consolidated Inustries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a tax credit of $476,000. c-Included tax credits of $326,000 for the quarter and $520,000 for the 6 months. The company said the latest periods included gains of $1,014,000 for the quarter and $2,803,000 for the 6 months from the sale of securities and the sale of certain real property.

title: Financial Printing Unit To Be Sold
description: The Service Resources Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to sell its financial printing unit, the Chas. P. Young Company, which it called a victim of last October's market crash.

title: Charged With Incompetence, Mayor Faces Impeachment
description: The Mayor of Florala, who is accused of incompetence and damaging his town's reputation, went on trial today on impeachment charges that included the pardoning of drunken drivers.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly LAW OF THE SEA - PREPARATORY COMMISSION - SPECIAL COMMISSIONS - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Our Towns; A Crusader Sees Only One Issue In Yonkers: Race
description: It is 13 years since Winston Ross filed the complaint that led to the Yonkers civil rights suit, and still he is waiting. It is 10 years since a Justice Department attorney, Josh Bogin, began his research on discrimination in Yonkers with a phone call to Winston Ross.

title: Books of The Times; A Contemplative Adapts to the World
description: Wheat That Springeth Green By J. F. Powers 335 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Trade Pacts Called Threat
description: An international group of industrialists and politicians said today that existing world trade agreements could be threatened by new regional accords.

title: Italian Bank Ends Irving Bid
description: Banca Commerciale Italiana yesterday withdrew its offer to acquire 51 percent of the Irving Bank Corporation, a friendly deal that Irving's management had supported.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Leif J. Ostberg, maker of Huffy shoes, for the introduction of its new Huffy Children's footwear, and Roxanne Swimwear and its subsidiaries, Harbour Casuals and Quantum Sportswear, to Creston & Associates.

title: Toll Brothers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Backlog as of July 31 $102,800,000 versus $125,763,000 a year earlier.

title: Coherent Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: The latest quarter include4s $1,887,000 in charges related to the company's decision to close its surgical operations in San Juan Capistrano, Calif., and consolidate these functions at its facilities Northern California. The company said it restated the 1987 results for the adoption of FASB No. 96. The effect of the restatement on the year-ago quarter and 9-month was an increase in the net loss for those periods of $668,000 and $1,105,000, respectively.

title: Gottschalks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $689,000 from cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alpha Microsystems, Santa Ana, Calif., a maker of multi-user multitasking computer hardware and software systems, named John S. Cain president. Mr. Cain, who will also continue as chief operating officer and chief financial officer, is replacing Robert B. Hitchcock, who will remain chairman and chief executive.

title: Fashion; For Galanos, Elegance Is Eternal
description: James Galanos is constantly refining his craft. Although his position is secure as one of the world's foremost designers, he continues to experiment with new shapes and cuts.

title: Liberalism, as in Liberty, Is a Cause for Pride
description: To the Editor:

title: Ousted Panama Chief Visits U.S. for Talks
description: Eric Arturo Delvalle, the ousted President of Panama, has arrived in the United States and is expected to meet with State Department officials.

title: The Prisons Of Poland
description: Wladyslaw Frasyniuk is a former member of a regional coordinating commission of the outlawed Polish labor union Solidarity. He comes from Wroclaw in Lower Silesia in Eastern Poland.

title: Major Video reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After net of $41,168 for the quarter and a loss of $86,565 for the year, both from discontinued operations.

title: Dow Climbs 24 Points in Sluggish Trading
description: Stocks rose strongly yesterday, but trading remained very slow in advance of the Labor Day weekend.

title: INSIDE
description: Fighting Los Angeles Smog The Environmental Protection Agency announced a ban on new construction of big pollution sources in Los Angeles. But little immediate effect is expected. Page A14. Afghan Coalition Is Urged The Afghan Prime Minister urged the United States and Pakistan to support a government representing ''moderates'' and the guerrillas as well as the ruling party. Page A10. Soviet Star Center to Play The Soviet Union's 7-foot-3-inch star basketball center, Arvidas Sabonis, who has been injured for the past 18 months, will play in the Olympics, Soviet officials said. Page B7. Tooth Size and Cooking Researchers believe they have found a link between an evolutionary decline in human tooth sizes and the introduction of cooking, which made food softer. Science Times, page C1.

title: Japan's Retail Sales Rise
description: Sales at Japan's leading department stores and supermarkets in July rose 8.5 percent, to 1,736.9 billion yen ($13 billion), from the period a year earlier, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today. In June, sales climbed 7.2 percent, the ministry said. The data cover 371 department stores and 1,961 supermarkets.

title: Rehnquist Chides Senate on Judicial Nominations
description: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist today criticized the way the Senate decides on judicial nominees, saying that lawmakers expect the nominees to give instant answers to complex constitutional questions.

title: Bilzerian Acquires Shares in Hadson
description: The Florida investor Paul A. Bilzerian has acquired two million shares of the Hadson Corporation as part of Hadson's agreement to buy HRB Holdings Inc., a division of the Singer Company, company officials said.

title: Cape Town Journal; Afrikaners Feud Over Past, and Path to the Future
description: Sitting on the newly painted green bench of a canvas-and-wood ox-wagon, Flip Du Plooy cracked his whip, and the seven pairs of oxen took their first steps on a 2,000-mile journey into the past.

title: Review/Music; Finale for Bernstein's Birthday Gala
description: Leonard Bernstein conducting the Serge and Olga Koussevitzky Memorial Concert at Tanglewood has become an annual event. But the 1988 version this afternoon was special. It came as the closing concert of the festival, it capped the four-day Tanglewood celebration of Mr. Bernstein's 70th birthday, and it included a bonus segment of Bernstein birthday tributes conducted by Seiji Ozawa, the music director of the Boston Symphony.

title: U.S. Approves Texaco Penalty
description: The Energy Department today gave final approval to an agreement with Texaco Inc. calling for $1.25 billion in payments to the Government over five and a half years to settle accusations of overcharging for price-controlled crude oil. Details of the accord were announced in February.

title: Samuel Arch Latt, 49; Physician and Teacher
description: Samuel Arch Latt, a physician and geneticist, died of an apparent heart attack Sunday at his home in Newton, Mass. He was 49 years old.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the rescue of several ailing savings and loan institutions by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, misstated the number of institutions involved in the lead paragraph. It was 10. The article also misstated the number of deals arranged so far under the agency's Southwest Plan to merge more than 100 sick institutions into healthy ones.

title: Bank of Nova Scotia Joins Flurry of Bank Offerings
description: Last week's flurry of bank debt offerings in the corporate market, the result of recent movements in interest rates, raised the total amount of new bank issues over the last two weeks to more than $2 billion, or nearly a third of all straight debt offerings during the same period.

title: Lyles Is Released As Jets 'Refurbish'
description: The Jets crossed another veteran off their list today to pare the roster to 47 players.

title: U.S. WILL ALLOW P.L.O TO MAINTAIN ITS OFFICE AT U.N.
description: Acting on foreign policy grounds, President Reagan decided today not to contest a ruling allowing the Palestine Liberation Organization to maintain its observer mission to the United Nations.

title: Bowmar Instrument Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $394,000. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $153,000 and $402,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Fraud Claims Result In $630,000 in Fines
description: The New Jersey Department of Insurance collected about $630,000 in fines as a result of fraud investigations so far this year, compared with $19,000 all of last year, the state's Insurance Commissioner, Kenneth D. Merin, said.

title: ABC Wins Top Series Emmys
description: ABC's baby-boomer shows - ''Thirtysomething,'' the ensemble drama on people in their 30's living in the 1980's, and ''The Wonder Years,'' a 1960's nostalgia comedy - were honored as the best television series at the 40th annual Emmy Awards Sunday night.

title: Hodgson Houses Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Armor All Products reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Transact International reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Sooner Federal Savings & Loan Assn reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $5.4 million and $3.4 million from real estate operations for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively; provisions for loan losses of $11.4 million and $15.4 million for the same periods, respectively; latest year also includes a $3,639,000 gain on the early repayment of borrowings from the Federal Home Loan Bank; and the prior year also includes a $1,426,000 extraordinary loss.

title: Bush Goes After Dukakis on Defense
description: Vice President Bush, heartened by polls showing him even with Michael S. Dukakis, today ripped into his opponent's stand on military issues, charging that the Democratic nominee would endanger arms negotiations by making ''unilateral'' concessions to the Soviet Union.

title: Robertson Ward, 90, A Designer of Resorts
description: Robertson Ward, an architect who designed many Caribbean resorts, died Wednesday of heart failure at the Nuffield Hospital in London. He was 90 years old.

title: Fashion; Patterns
description: The photographs of Lauren Hutton wearing man-tailored looks in the Barneys New York fall catalogue are both alluring and mysterious. Shot by the top fashion photographers Steven Meisel and Constance Hanson, Ms. Hutton wears everything from Barneys private-label jackets and trench coats to silk pajamas to nothing at all.

title: Drug Tests for Students At Falwell's University
description: The 6,000 students at the Rev. Jerry Falwell's Liberty University face mandatory drug screening this year.

title: Brendle's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Communications Systems reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The latest 6-month results include a $200,000 after-tax charge for the estimated cost of closing a sales office.

title: Human Teeth, Small Already, Keep On Shrinking
description: PEOPLE with especially small teeth may represent the advance guard of human evolution, at least in dentition. They seem to be at the forefront of a 100,000-year trend.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addenda
description: * Franznick & Cusatis and Great Events Promotions have merged to form Franznick, Deutsch & Molligo.

title: Dr. Harold Aaron, Consultant, 82
description: Dr. Harold Aaron, formerly a medical consultant to Consumers Union Inc., which publishes the monthly Consumer Reports magazine, died of Parkinson's disease yesterday at his summer home on Fire Island. He was 82 years old and lived in Tenafly, N.J.

title: Secret Service Agent Sued for $27 Million
description: A Manhattan lawyer who says he was beaten by a Secret Service agent last spring sued the agent yesterday for $27 million.

title: Bush Backed Sale of Arms to Iran, 2 Senators Conclude in New Book
description: Two Senators conclude in a new book that Vice President Bush endorsed the sale of weapons to Iran. They say he did so either out of loyalty to President Reagan or because he, too, ''was consumed'' with the idea of freeing American hostages.

title: Sports People; A Not-Guilty Plea
description: Saying ''the whole country in a sense is watching him,'' a judge in Tampa suspended Bruce Kimball's driving privileges yesterday but refused to impose travel restrictions on the former Olympic diver while he awaits trial on alcohol-related manslaughter charges.

title: Tennis; Pros May Design Tour Similar to Golf's
description: Citing what it claimed was the inability of the Men's Tennis Council to govern and market the men's game effectively, the Association of Tennis Professionals has decided the explore the option of organizing its own international tour in 1990.

title: Cullum Companies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,495,000 from an accounting change.

title: Yankees Lose, 9-6, as the Slide Continues
description: The Yankees escaped the misery of California, but they did not escape their mounting troubles. Tonight at the Kingdome, they lost a 3-0 lead, then lost again -this time 9-6 to the Seattle Mariners - and saw their losing streak stretch to a season-high five games.

title: Liberalism, as in Liberty, Is a Cause for Pride; Conservative Handful
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Leading Financiers Will Merge Companies in $1.65 Billion Deal
description: Sanford I. Weill, who created the brokerage firm now known as Shearson Lehman Hutton, re-emerged yesterday as a Wall Street powerhouse with the announcement that he and Gerald Tsai Jr., another leading financier, would merge their current companies in a $1.65 billion deal.

title: Dr. Max Black, 79, Author and Philosopher
description: Dr. Max Black, an author, educator and an authority on the philosophy of language, died of heart complications Saturday at Tompkins Community Hospital in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 79 years old and lived in Ithaca.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some copies Saturday in the Sports People column misidentified a jockey who was injured. It was Steve Cauthen, not Rusty Wallace.

title: Cut at V.A. Hospitals Charged
description: The Veterans Administration has taken more than 13,000 beds at its hospitals out of service while telling Congress that budget cuts have not hurt service, the House Veterans Affairs Committee said today.

title: Ehrlich Bober Financial reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $45,000 and $289,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a loss of $120,000 for the quarter and a gain of $1,272,000 for the year both on the sale of a subsidiary. c-Net income d-After income from discontinued operations of $53,000 for the quarter and $358,000 for the year.

title: Blyth Holdings Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sociology Branches Out But Is Left in Splinters
description: Sociologists of the past referred to their discipline as ''the queen of the sciences,'' but a look at what sociologists do today reveals that the queen rules over a highly fragmented realm.

title: Phillips-Van Heusen Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $152,000 for both periods and also includes a preferred dividend requirement of $2,047,000 and $4,094,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $2,931,000 and $4,202,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Foster-Care Homes Violating Leases
description: New York City has sometimes housed more children in group foster-care shelters than permitted by state regulations and by the leases for the shelters, a Koch administration official said yesterday.

title: Powell Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a $92,000 tax credit.

title: Queenie A. McFarland, 91, a Restaurateur
description: Queenie A. McFarland, who was ac tive until two years ago in the manage-ment of Sweets seafood restaurant, a family business at Fulton and South Streets, died of cardiac arrest Sunday at Mountainside Hospital in Glen Ridge, N.J. She was 91 years old and lived in Caldwell, N.J.

title: Years of Dueling Agendas Slow Atlantic City's Growth
description: People here all protest that they want the best for Atlantic City, and no one is insincere. Everyone uses the same words, like ''redevelopment'' and ''housing'' and ''schools'' and ''amenities.'' But what they mean by those words often differs, obscuring a conflict in agendas that is the source of much of the political paralysis here, over 10 years since the first casino opened and the money began to flow.

title: Air Express International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $849,000 and $1,226,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Review/Television; Bad News on Foster Care Gets Worse
description: In a 1979 documentary on foster care, ABC News concluded that too many children were being placed in foster care and that they stayed there too long, were poorly supervised and got lost in the system. Returning to the painful subject tonight at 10 o'clock in ''Crimes Against Children: Failure of Foster Care,'' an ABC News ''Closeup'' documentary finds that in many ways things have gotten worse.

title: Jitters at Justice
description: Justice Department officials are watching nervously as the new Attorney General, Dick Thornburgh, considers personnel changes in the department's senior staff.

title: Revere Ware President Takes a Farberware Job
description: Peter B. Cameron used to think that Revere Ware made the best pots and pans, but that was when he was president of the cookware company. His switch to head Farberware, a major competitor, was announced yesterday, prompting him to say, with newfound loyalty, ''I would describe Farberware as far superior.''

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Wade Boggs of the Boston Red Sox, who went 12 for 23 last week, raising his league-leading average to .363, was named the American League player of the week. . . . Pedro Guerrero, who was 12 for 28 in his first full week with the St. Louis Cardinals after being traded for John Tudor, was named National League player of the week. . . . Tim Perry, the forward from Temple who was the top draft pick of the Phoenix Suns last June, signed a five-year contract with the club yesterday.(AP)

title: Chip Market Competition Heating Up
description: The market for microprocessor chips based on technology known as reduced instruction set computing is growing increasingly competitive with numerous new companies entering the field.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 A ruling on the P.L.O. mission to the United Nations will not be appealed, President Reagan decided. A Federal District judge held that a law passed by Congress to combat terrorism did not apply to the mission. Page A1

title: 29 Trying to Feed Homeless Are Arrested in San Francisco
description: Twenty-nine people were arrested today as they tried to give food to the homeless in Golden Gate Park.

title: Jackson and Israeli Spoke of Black Hebrews
description: To the Editor:

title: New Strife in Lebanon Amid Political Impasse
description: A new round of fighting in the mountains east of Beirut and a wave of bomb explosions in the Moslem part of the capital have underlined growing sectarian tension in Lebanon.

title: Los Angeles Penalized for Pollution
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it would bar all new construction of major sources of air pollution in the Los Angeles area when a stopgap Congressional moratorium on such sanctions expires Wednesday.

title: WEST GERMAN BANS AIR FORCE SHOWS
description: The West German Defense Minister announced today that he was banning further displays of military aerobatic flying over West Germany.

title: Wall St. Firms Mentioned In Inquiry on Swiss Trading
description: As many as 30 Wall Street brokerage houses failed to detect a broad insider trading scheme, information obtained by a Congressional subcommittee indicated.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption Saturday gave an incorrect time element for a picture of striking shipyard workers in Gdansk, Poland. The picture was made Thursday.

title: Police Set to Strike At Metro-North Rail
description: The union representing the police for the Metro-North Commuter Railroad said yesterday that it would strike at midnight Tuesday.

title: Soviets Send Doctor to Space Station
description: Three astronauts, including an Afghan pilot and a doctor studying the effects of weightlessness, were launched into space today aboard a Soyuz spacecraft in a mission that will take them to the orbiting Mir space station.

title: American Telemedia Network reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Unico American Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income and restated for an accounting change.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Acustar Official Hired By Harvard Industries
description: LEAD: Lee H. Runk resigned yesterday as president of Acustar, the Chrysler Corporation's auto parts subsidiary, to become president and chief operating officer of Harvard Industries Inc., which earlier this year had tried to buy Acustar for $1.2 billion.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's not important with whom I sit down at the table. I'll hold talks with the cleaning lady, if she's properly authorized.'' - Lech Walesa, warning that strikes will continue in Poland unless the Government deals with Solidarity. [ A3:4. ]

title: ICM Property Investors Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Introductory Step Toward Powerful Chip
description: NEC Informations Systems Inc., a subsidiary of the giant Japanese electronics company, last week unveiled two new personal computers based on the Intel 80386 SX microprocessor. The SX chip, which was referred to as the P9 in its development phase, is a simplified version of the powerful 80386 processor that allows customers to step up to 386-class performance at a lower cost.

title: Pravda Revives Cry of 'U.S. Started the Cold War'
description: A full-page article in Pravda today blamed the United States for instigating the cold war and said forces in the West continued to support such antagonistic positions.

title: Primerica Builder Sees Deals, Not Retirement
description: In 36 years on Wall Street, Gerald Tsai Jr. started obscurely as a stock analyst, became a money manager of legendary proportions in the 1960's, faded to near obscurity in the 1970's, and returned to the limelight in the 1980's when he transformed the American Can Company into the Primerica Corporation, a financial services company.

title: Hemingway on Spain: Unedited Reportage
description: Thirty dispatches written by Ernest Hemingway while reporting from the Loyalist side during the Spanish Civil War have been published for the first time exactly as he wrote them. They include two that have never appeared before in any form.

title: CH Heist Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
What Makes New York's Board of Ed a Byword for Bureaucracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Youth Serves Mets: Cone, Jefferies Star
description: The next generation of Mets stole the show with arms, bats and outrageous performances last night in Shea Stadium.

title: Braniff Expanding Amid Eastern's Woes
description: Braniff Airlines is planning to add even more flights at Kansas City, Mo., while the future of Eastern Airlines' operations at that airport remains unsettled, an industry official said yesterday.

title: Doctor in Mexico Defends His Innovative Transplant Procedures
description: In his sixth-floor office at La Raza Medical Center here, Dr. Ignacio Madrazo Navarro sits alongside stacks of correspondence from around the world. Each letter is a plea from a patient suffering from Parkinson's disease, asking Dr. Madrazo for an operation.

title: Jean Marchand, Canadian Politician, Dies at 69
description: TORONTO, Aug. 29 -

title: Private Commerce Stands Poised For a Modest Debut in Space
description: A LITTLE rocket set to be lofted in a few weeks from an old Government launching pad on the Florida coast marks the start of a new era in private space ventures and, experts hope, the beginning of a commercial space industry that will reap billions of dollars in profits by the turn of the century.

title: Major Realty Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $624,000 for the quarter and $985,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income The year-ago revenue included a $6.1 million sale of prime land.

title: An Elvis Stamp? Return to Sender
description: LEAD: The news that the Postal Service is considering a new stamp recalling Elvis Presley sent shivers down my spine.

title: Post-Zia Pakistan: The Sorting-Out Process Starts
description: Every morning here a silent procession of ordinary people, some of them poor and disabled, forms around the pile of withering flowers that marks the grave of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Keye/Donna 'Musical' for New Suzuki
description: ''IT was our first musical,'' said Leonard Pearlstein, describing Keye/Donna/Pearlstein's commercial for Suzuki's new four-wheel-drive vehicle, the Sidekick.

title: Prices Rise Amid Thin Trading
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved higher in very thin trading yesterday, pushed upward by technical factors, a rise in the dollar and a dip in commodity prices.

title: Top Officer Is Ousted At American Medical
description: Four major shareholders in American Medical International Inc., the large hospital concern, have succeeded in ousting its chairman and chief executive, Walter L. Weisman.

title: Kabuki Star Applies His Art of Dance to Ravel
description: Tamasaburo, the graceful, seductive star of Kabuki, cupped an imaginary butterfly in his thin white hands. Then the butterfly took flight, and with it the music - not the reedy, percussive strains of Kabuki but the bold notes of Maurice Ravel.

title: Man Sentenced to Life Term In 1982 Murder of a Trooper
description: A Dayton, N.Y., man, who was convicted of murdering a state trooper in 1982, was sentenced today to 42 years to life in prison.

title: Bernstein Tribute Tonight
description: A musical tribute to Leonard Bernstein and Morton Gould in Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center was rained out last night and has been rescheduled for tonight at 8:15. . The program of music by the two composers and conductors will be played by the Harmonie Ensemble, under the direction of Steven Richman.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Michael Daly has been elected senior vice president at Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver.

title: G.O.P. Leads Tighter Race for Funds
description: Republican committees are far ahead of their Democratic rivals in fund-raising for the 1988 elections, but the gap is narrowing and Americans are giving less money to party organizations than they used to, according to a Federal report made public today.

title: A Queens Panel Indicts 3 Whites In a Bias Case
description: Three white men have been indicted on charges of beating two black women in what the Queens District Attorney, John J. Santucci, termed a racially- -motivated argument near Aqueduct Raceway in July, his office announced yesterday.

title: Man Linked to John Gotti Is Slain on Brooklyn Street
description: A 52-year-old man described as an associate of John Gotti was killed early yesterday in a fusillade as he walked to his car in the Flatlands section of Brooklyn.

title: Cotton Supply Outlook
description: Prospects for another good cotton crop this year could push the total supply for the coming year to the highest level in more than two decades, the Agriculture Department reported today. Based on Aug. 1 indications, the cotton harvest could be 14.9 million bales, up from 14.8 million bales last year, the department's Economic Research Service said in a report. The increase would result from a larger acreage this year, despite a reduction in per-acre yields. In all, the total 1988-89 supply will be about 20.5 million bales, the most since the 1966-67 season.

title: Bridge
description: A player who hits on a pretty ending and thereby lands a doubled game contract often rushes off to tell the story, expecting to bask in warm appreciation. Occasionally he is disappointed, as was Bill Cole of Bethesda, Md., on the diagramed deal. He told the story against himself in the May/ June issue of the Washington Bridge League Bulletin.

title: U.S. Electronics Exports Up 32%
description: Exports of United States-made electronics products rose 32 percent in the first half of 1988, shrinking the nation's deficit in that sector, an industry trade group said today.

title: Afghan Urges U.S. and Pakistan To Press Guerrillas to Negotiate
description: The Afghan Prime Minister urged the United States and Pakistan today to support his Government's repeated calls for a coalition that would involve ''moderates'' and guerrilla representatives as well as leaders of the pro-Soviet ruling party.

title: Widespread Abuse of Drugs By Pregnant Women Is Found
description: A frighteningly high number of babies are being exposed to cocaine or other illegal drugs in the womb, according to data from 36 hospitals around the country. The findings, described yesterday at a news conference, were gathered from hospitals in both urban and suburban areas, serving patients from all socioeconomic groups.

title: CNW Chooses New Chairman
description: Robert Schmiege was elected today as chairman and chief executive of the CNW Corporation and its railroad subsidiary, the Chicago & North Western Transportation Company, the company announced.

title: Well Yields Oil In Paris Suburb
description: Elf Aquitaine, the French oil giant, announced today that it had found oil in Ivry-sur-Seine, a suburb on Paris's southeast border. ''It's not a gusher,'' said

title: U.S. Reports Significant Rise In Education of Work Force
description: One of every four workers in the United States is now a college graduate as against just one in every five 10 years ago, the Labor Department said today in a report showing significant increases in education levels in the American work force.

title: Six Americans Listed Among Air-Show Dead
description: The Pentagon said today that six Americans were among those killed on Sunday when three Italian jets collided at an air show at the United States air base here and one plunged into the crowd in flames.

title: Cab Offers Heavenly Discount
description: Taxicab passengers headed for church can put an extra dollar in the collection plate or their pockets on Sundays as a result of a fare discount approved by the City Council on Monday. The discount was offered last week by the Red Bird Cab Company when it received approval for a rate increase, City Attorney Bryant Aldridge said. The deal applies only on Sunday mornings and may be denied if the cab driver suspects the rider is not going to church, Mayor Roy Culler said.

title: INSIDE
description: Accord on Western Sahara

title: Northeast Utilities
description: Northeast Utilities said it had arranged with a group of New England utilities to provide three months of additional short-term financing for the portion of the Seabrook nuclear project subject to default. The Seabrook project is a 1,150-megawatt nuclear plant on the New Hampshire shoreline, awaiting licensing from the Federal Government. Northeast said its Connecticut Light and Power Company unit would finance nearly $5 million for the 11.6 percent share in Seabrook owned by the Massachusetts Municipal Wholesale Electric Company, which decided against continuing its financing in June.

title: Japanese Aid on Tunnel
description: A Japanese maker of construction machinery, Komatsu Ltd., has agreed to provide the Robbins Company of Seattle with technology on soft-ground tunnel-boring machinery, Komatsu said in a statement today. Robbins, involved in boring the tunnel under the English Channel between Britain and France, has been licensing its technology for hard-rock tunneling to Komatsu since 1963. The accord also covers joint development of new machinery and other products.

title: Tyson Plans Soviet Trip
description: Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, is reportedly heading for the Soviet Union.

title: Quake Jeopardizes Development Plans in Nepal
description: The earthquake last week in eastern Nepal is likely to deal a serious setback to the country's economic development, according to officials here.

title: Biotechnology Dispute Is Rekindled
description: A provocative footnote in a Federal court decision earlier this month has reignited a dispute over who really pioneered the method for producing new substances through genetic engineering.

title: Saatchi Seeks to List Its Shares in Tokyo
description: Saatchi & Saatchi announced that it had filed an application to list its shares on the Tokyo stock exchange, and that it expected to begin trading in mid-October. It has already filed a securities registration statement with the Japanese Finance Ministry for a public offering of 1.56 million shares, at a price to be fixed at the time of issue.

title: Garam Chasma Journal; Mud, Faith and Flash Of Mountain Warriors
description: Now a ramshackle town of one-story houses on the banks of a torrent, Garam Chasma was once a popular resort for Pakistanis who came for the natural hot springs. But there is little tourism now.

title: Judge Offers Sympathy To 5 Queens Arsonists
description: The judge in the case of five Queens homeowners convicted of setting fire to a planned shelter for foster-care babies contended yesterday that the city's actions might have driven them to commit the crime.

title: A Speedy Appraisal Of Stars & Stripes
description: There is usually not much of a breeze off the coast of San Diego at this time of the year. But try to tell that to Duncan MacLane, who was awash in a wall of water Monday aboard Stars & Stripes, the America's Cup defender.

title: Quayle Vows to Fill Gaps In His Grasp of Drug Issue
description: Senator Dan Quayle says he has not spent much time studying the drug issue but plans to learn more about it in his campaign for the Vice Presidency.

title: French Dieting
description: To The Living Section:

title: Defiant 4: The Councilmen Who Are Blocking the Yonkers Housing Plan; Edward J. Fagan Jr.
description: The seven City Councilmen of Yonkers, Edward J. Fagan Jr. notes with some satisfaction, have been called -both affectionately and pejoratively -Big Bird and the six Smurfs. At 6 foot 3, he is Big Bird.

title: Watch It, Doggy, Here Comes the Pit Bull Patrol
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Reinstates Principal Dismissed After Speech
description: A principal who was dismissed after accusing school committee members of interfering too much in his high school's operations was ordered reinstated Monday by a Middlesex Superior Court judge.

title: Satellite Sales Split Agencies
