description: Amid a fierce interagency battle, the State Department has recommended that the United States allow the export of communications satellites for launching on Chinese rockets, officials at the department said today.

title: Dow Off by 3.20 Points in Slow Trading
description: Stock prices ended mixed yesterday as volume remained at the extra-slow pace of recent days.

title: Prices Received by Farmers Increased by 2.1% in Month
description: The prices that farmers received for grain and other raw products rose 2.1 percent from July to August, an increase that was partly a result of this year's drought, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Tuna Dressed as Pastrami
description: PASTRAMI is as much a part of the New York delicatessen scene as corned beef, kosher dill pickles and cheesecake.

title: Woman Is Pregnant Despite Court Order For Birth Control
description: An 18-year-old mother of three who was ordered to practice birth control throughout her child-bearing years is pregnant again, but the judge who sentenced herfor child abuse says she will not revoke the probation.

title: Review/Television; Hands That Could Launch the Missiles
description: Frederick Wiseman, public television's determinedly mute yet consistently eloquent guide to surprising corners of American life, takes us tonight to Vandenberg Air Force Base in California to look in on young officers who are being trained to man the launching-control centers of the Minuteman intercontinental ballistic missiles. These are the people who will send off nuclear weapons, should the order be given.

title: McEnroe Surveys Home Turf
description: By his own admission, John McEnroe is not among the favorites to win the United States Open. That status belongs to any of the top five seeded players, he said. McEnroe, though, will never be a bit player as long as he remains in the game. Even when his matches are uneventful, the quotations from Chairman John are usually among the more colorful of the day.

title: People Who Put Color Ahead of Art
description: LEAD: A new language formation, ''people of color,'' is making its appearance these days on the near horizon and with it a gathering storm is taking shape. ''People of color'' are every hue but white and are non-European in origin. And only ''people of color'' are authentically American, so we now are being told.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; The Value of Life
description: What's the dollar value of a human life? Different Federal agencies have come up with different figures, while some agencies have avoided the issue entirely, according to a study by Clayton P. Gillette of Boston University School of Law and Thomas D. Hopkins of Rochester Institute of Technology. The estimates are relevant in the formulation of cost-benefit analyses, and the promulgation of Federal regulations.

title: Elementary Curriculum According to Bennett
description: Secretary of Education William J. Bennett today presented his version of the ideal elementary school curriculum, a course of study that emphasizes classic children's literature, rigorous mathematics lessons and foreign language instruction beginning no later than the fourth grade.

title: Y.&R. Has Big Plans For Fraser
description: FOR Young & Rubicam, winning the $30 million House of Fraser account last week was a major coup. House of Fraser Ltd., owned by the Fayed family, is Britain's largest retail chain, with 65 department stores throughout the country. And it will be Y.&R.'s biggest account in Britain, surpassing British Gas.

title: Rally for Biaggi Planned 4 Days Before Primary
description: Representative Mario Biaggi, who has been convicted on Federal charges twice in the last year, will be honored at a rally sponsored by Bronx social and community organizations and several unions four days before the Sept. 15 Democratic primary.

title: About New York; Abbie Hoffman Does Stand-Up For His Beliefs
description: The comic was hitting his groove. ''Let me tell you about the night Jerry Falwell and I slept together,'' Abbie Hoffman announced, leering lewdly at an adoring audience. ''Jimmy Swaggart took movies.'' The clown prince of 60's radicals, who 20 years ago helped nominate a pig for President, was appearing at Stand-Up New York, an Upper West Side comedy club. Telling jokes professionally is a new (and tentative) twist for a man whose life - through 51 years, 53 arrests and seven years on the lam - has been a crusade for causes. From the Vietnam War to fighting drug testing, Abbie Hoffman has manned the barricades.

title: Rescuing the Refrigerated Tomato
description: As most anyone who grows tomatoes will tell you, the tomato tastes and smells best if it is picked, sliced and served - all within a few minutes. Such empirical knowledge has passed down through generations of gardeners, cooks, and tomato eaters. Now, chemists at the Department of Agriculture have confirmed this, and hope their work will point the way to enhancing the flavor of the scourge of the winter salad - the refrigerated tomato.

title: Anchovy Alert
description: To The Living Section:

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Acme United Corp., Fairfield, Conn., a maker of medical equipment, shears and scissors, promoted Stephen T. Bajda to senior vice president, finance.

title: Defiant 4: The Councilmen Who Are Blocking the Yonkers Housing Plan; Henry Spallone
description: ''Meet me at the Raceway Diner,'' Henry (Hank) Spallone said when he telephoned. ''I'll show you around.''

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; More Nixon Tapes
description: Sometime next year, the National Archives will make available to the public about 60 hours of President Nixon's White House tapes - the first such since 12 1/2 hours were entered into evidence in court trials, including cases concerning Watergate. More tapes will be made public in subsequent years.

title: Rutgers End Suspended
description: James Jenkins, a junior tight end on the Rutgers football team, has been suspended for two games, reportedly for testing positive for a banned substance. Kevin MacConnell, a spokesman for the university, would not confirm that the suspension was drug-related, but Jenkins told The Courier-News of Bridgewater, N.J., that it was, although he did not identify the drug for which he tested positive. Jenkins, a 6-foot-2-inch, 238-pound junior from Staten Island, has three years of eligibility remaining.(AP)

title: The Pop Life
description: Statements of Wonder

title: Review/Film; Camera Eye Sees Through an Eye That's Askew
description: In less than a decade, ''The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat'' has gone through several startling and successful incarnations - an essay became an opera, which is now a film. Each version reinforces the haunting atmosphere of loss in a story that began with the neurologist Oliver Sacks's 1979 observation of a patient he called Dr. P., a music teacher with an impairment that caused him to see objects without recognizing them. A glove or a rose might be utterly mysterious shapes to him, though he never lost his feeling for music.

title: Freer Collection at the Smithsonian To Be Inaccessible for Three Years
description: When the Smithsonian Institution accepted the industrialist Charles Lang Freer's gift of his collection of Oriental art and a magnificent gallery in which to display the pieces, it also accepted his condition that the works never be shown elsewhere.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Mark IV Industries, New Haven, has filed suit against the Armtek Corp., accusing Armtek's board of misusing anti-takeover measures to prevent shareholders from determining whether they want to accept Mark IV's $44-a-share, or $500 million cash tender offer.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly LAW OF THE SEA, PREPARATORY COMMISSION, SPECIAL COMMISSIONS - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Ojeda's 6-Hitter Stops Padres
description: On the night after David Cone shut out the San Diego Padres on one hit, the Mets came up with a creative encore in Shea Stadium last night: Bob Ojeda shut out the Padres on six hits.

title: The Party Winds Down on Socializing by Phone
description: After a much-heralded entry into the telecommunications marketplace, hookups that allow callers to socialize by telephone from home are fast fading in popularity.

title: The Pledge vs. the Good Old U.S.A.
description: For the last two weeks, George Bush has been defining himself and Michael Dukakis. He presents himself as patriotic, tough and caring. He portrays the Massachusetts Governor as a closet liberal who favors unilateral disarmament and furloughs for felons and hates the Pledge of Allegiance.

title: National Health Must Start With Quality Care; In Britain, It's All Free
description: To the Editor:

title: Critical Shuttle Rocket Test Is Lauded by Manufacturer
description: The redesigned space shuttle booster performed virtually perfectly in a critical firing earlier this month despite being peppered with intentional flaws, the manufactuer, Morton Thiokol Inc., announced today.

title: Bonds Edge Higher on Slow Day
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved modestly higher in dull trading yesterday.

title: Pretoria Finishes Its Angola Pullout
description: The Cuban colonel walked slowly across a floating steel bridge near here today minutes after the last South African troops crossed from Angola into northern Namibia, two days ahead of schedule.

title:
Eating Well;
How Much Juice in Those Fruit Drinks?
description: LEAD: IN need of a cheap vacation? Stroll your neighborhood supermarket and imagine yourself living in the labels on the fruit drinks.

title: Burlington Motor
description: Burlington Motor Carriers Inc., the trucking subsidiary of Burlington Northern Inc., has been spun off to an investor group in a leveraged buyout for $90 million. The buyout group includes the company's senior management, and investment bankers from Lepercq, de Neuflize & Company; Chase Manhattan Bank, and Alex. Brown & Sons. Burlington Northern will keep a non-voting interest in its former subsidiary, the company said. Burlington Northern, which owns the nation's largest private railroad as well as substantial energy and forest products companies, said the sale was part of a plan to focus on its core railroad business. Burlington Motor, which is based in Fort Worth and employs 2,700 people, had revenues of $195 million in 1987.

title: Zvereva Upset By Steinmetz
description: The financial rewards have been few, crumbs compared with what Steffi Graf, Chris Evert and Martina Navratilova have earned. Kim Steinmetz is one of the starving artists of tennis, a dwindling few who play for the sheer enjoyment of a game. She has long since reconciled the fact that she will not find her name associated with a line of tennis apparel or listed among the winners of the United States Open.

title: TV Industry to Fight Against Drinking and Driving
description: The three major television networks and the Hollywood studios that create most of their programming are joining in a coordinated attack against drinking and driving that will include dialogue in popular entertainment shows as well as public-service advertising.

title: Fannie Mae Sets 9.15% Rate On Its 4-Year Debentures
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, set the interest rate for a $750 million issue of four-year debentures to be offered through various securities dealers.

title: Israel Didn't Premeditate Its 1967 Attack on the U.S.S. Liberty
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan Sontag, in Seoul, Speaks on Jailed Writers
description: The American writer Susan Sontag and writers from seven countries held a reception tonight at the International PEN Congress to dramatize the imprisonment of five South Korean literary figures.

title: A Choice of Varieties As Wide as the Sea
description: SEAWEED is classified by color. Of the eight major groups, three are used for food. Red seaweed, or Rhodphyta, includes dulse, purple nori, ogo, agar and Irish moss. Brown seaweed, or Phaeophyta, includes kelp, kombu, wakame, arame, hijiki and rock weed. Sea lettuce belongs to the Chlorophyta, or green seaweed group.

title: Walter F. Prude, 78; Aided Careers of Ax, Rubinstein and Stern
description: Walter Foy Prude, who helped to direct the careers of Arthur Rubinstein, Marian Anderson, Isaac Stern and many other artists during his more than four decades in concert management, died of heart failure Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital after a long bout with emphysema. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Topics of The Times; The PAC Bonanza
description: According to the Federal Election Commission, special interest political action committees are contributing at a record rate to this year's Congressional races.

title: Missing in Action: From a Lost War, a Haunting Echo That Won't Be Stilled
description: On the wall of Ann Mills Griffiths's office in Washington is a framed rubbing of her brother's name from the Vietnam War Memorial. Lieut. Cmdr. James B. Mills has been missing since Sept. 21, 1966, when his Navy F-4 was lost on a night mission over North Vietnam.

title: Soviets Working to Leave a Legacy in Afghanistan
description: Western diplomats said today that the Soviet Union had taken steps to integrate northern Afghanistan's economy with that of Soviet Central Asia.

title: New Bid Is Set On Irving Bank
description: The Bank of New York yesterday reiterated its position that it was prepared to raise its bid for the Irving Bank Corporation slightly if Irving dropped the defenses it has adopted to protect itself from a hostile takeover.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about limits on new construction in Los Angeles because of air pollution misquoted Lee M. Thomas, the Environmental Protection Administrator, on the need to renew the Clean Air Act. Mr. Thomas said: ''Failure to reauthorize the Act could lead to many more sanctions on areas as well as mandatory Federal pollution plans and litigation, which will only further delay the goal we all want: clean air.''

title: Reporter's Notebook; Black Journalists Gather For 20 Years' Reflection
description: For blacks in journalism, passages from the Kerner Commission's report of 1968 have become as familiar as the words of Frederick Douglass or W. E. B. DuBois.

title: Domtar Notes
description: Domtar Inc., a Montreal-based manufacturer of pulp and paper products, is offering $100 million of 9 5/8 percent notes due in 1993 at a price of 99.79 to yield 9.68 percent though underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The notes are noncallable and yield about 68 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. Underwriters said the new notes are rated A-3 by Moody's and A- by S.&P.

title: Steve Jones Says No
description: Steve Jones, a former world record-holder in the men's marathon, declined yesterday to accept a spot on the British Olympic team, saying he would not be able to prepare properly for the marathon, which will be run on Oct. 2, the closing day of competition at Seoul. The 33-year-old Welsh runner, who set a world record of 2 hours 7 minutes 3 seconds at Chicago in 1985, had been picked on Sunday to replace Hugh Jones, who was forced to withdraw because of an injury. Now the spot will go to Dave Long, whose career best is 2:11:22, in the London Marathon last April.(AP)

title: Homeless Ex-Marine Yields After Protest at Historic Fort
description: A homeless former marine barricaded himself in historic Fort Vancouver Monday to protest what he said was a lack of help for troubled Vietnam veterans, then surrendered in exchange for a chance to talk to reporters.

title: Computer Analyst Marries Batya Spirn, Editorial Aide
description: At the Manhattan Beach Jewish Center in Brooklyn, Batya Spirn, the daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Charles A. Spirn of New York, was married last evening to Ari Jerenberg, the son of Natalie Jerenberg of Hillcrest, Queens, and the late Dr. Norman Jerenberg. The bride's father, the head chaplain at the Mount Sinai Medical Center, and Rabbi Simcha Krauss officiated.

title: U.S. Praises 30-Nation Anti-Drug Effort
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh today announced the completion of a campaign to seize drugs that involved agencies from 30 nations, including Panama, whose de facto leader is under indictment in the United States on charges of narcotics smuggling.

title: National Health Must Start With Quality Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Aug. 24 incorrectly described the problems surrounding a new building, Cityspire, east of Seventh Avenue between 55th and 56th Streets in Manhattan. The assembly of a dome on top of the building, which is taller than permitted, apparently violated an agreement with New York City in which the developer had agreed to stop working on the upper floors.

title: Taylor Awaiting N.F.L. Directive
description: The agent for Lawrence Taylor, the Giants' All-Pro linebacker who has been suspended for 30 days for violating the National Football League's substance-abuse program, said yesterday that Taylor was at home in New Jersey awaiting a directive from the league on a rehabilitation program and had ''a sincere desire to overcome this problem and get it behind him.''

title: MOSCOW CRITICIZED ON AFGHAN ACCORD
description: The United States said today that the Soviet Union had violated the Geneva accords on Afghanistan by sending aircraft from Soviet territory to bomb guerrilla positions inside Afghanistan.

title: Report on Fetisov
description: Vyacheslav Fetisov, the captain of the Soviet national hockey team, has been given permission from the highest authorities to play this season in the National Hockey League, according to an article in The Toronto Star. The article quotes Lou Lamoriello, the general manager of the Devils, who hold the draft rights to Fetisov. After attempting to negotiate with Soviet hockey officials for the last year, Lamoriello recently visited the Soviet Union to consolidate plans for Fetisov's move to the Devils.

title: Index of Economic Trends Shows Its Steepest Drop in Eight Months
description: The Government's chief economic forecasting gauge fell eight-tenths of 1 percent in July, slipping below its level of early spring.

title: 1,000 Protest Attacks Aimed At Homosexuals
description: At least 1,000 demonstrators held a candlelight vigil at Broadway and 100th Street on the Upper West Side of Manhattan last night to protest recent violence against homosexuals and the police arrested more than 100 of them for blocking traffic.

title: Wallenberg Seen in '86, Swede's Report Says
description: A well-known Swedish businessman and novelist has given the Stockholm Government new evidence he says shows that Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat presumed to have disappeared in Soviet prisons after saving thousands of Jews from the Nazis, was alive as recently as 1986 and may be alive today.

title: Billabong Beaujolais
description: To The Living Section:

title: John F. Riordan, 85, Ex-Bell Labs Engineer
description: John F. Riordan, a mathematician and engineer who was on the technical staff of Bell Laboratories for 42 years and later taught at Rockefeller University, died of Alzheimer's disease Saturday at the Ocean Manor nursing home in Scituate, Mass., where he lived. He was 85 years old.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: ONCE upon a time, there was an exquisitely quiet wooded area in a community called Travis in western Staten Island. Travis is still there, but what had been secluded and sylvan is now a bustling multi-screen movie theater alongside a giant bowling alley, with their attendant parking lots and traffic jams.

title: Pre-Freshman Remedial Programs Raise Chances for Academic Success
description: ''Solipsistic! I'll be. . . .'' said the professor, beaming with pleasure, as he looked over his students' work sheets.

title: A.T.P. Plans Tour in '90
description: With Mats Wilander, Brad Gilbert, Tim Mayotte and Yannick Noah by his side, Hamilton Jordan, the chief executive officer of the Association of Tennis Professionals, reiterated yesterday that the players will organize their own international tour in 1990 because of the inability of the Men's Tennis Council to effectively govern the men's game. Jordan, the former White

title: 6 Reported Dead in Hong Kong Plane Crash
description: A Chinese Trident jetliner carrying 89 people crashed into the water while landing at the international airport in Hong Kong today and 6 people were killed, the Government said.

title: Judge Lets Eastern Cut Air Service
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that Eastern Airlines could sharply reduce its service today, as planned, but could not lay off 4,000 workers without negotiating with their unions.

title: About Education
description: ''I see schools as places that feed children, educate their parents and provide early childhood education.'' This is how Richard R. Green, New York City's Schools Chancellor, described the schools' modern mission in a New York Times article last week. In cities, he explained, the teachers may be the most important adults in children's lives.

title: Critic's Notebook; Behind the Blessings of a Prodigy, Risks for Child, Music andListener
description: The promoting, encouraging and marketing of child prodigies may not constitute child abuse, but it is a form of robbery. When children are deprived of childhood the loss to all of us is great. Children show us things about ourselves we would not otherwise see. They offer us an education at least as valuable as the one we extend to them.

title: The Shoes of Shoeless Joe
description: FOR the young actor named D. B. Sweeney, Shoeless Joe Jackson started out as a role, but turned into something of a cause. D. B. Sweeney got turned around by Shoeless Joe, both at home plate and in his heart.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''These events cost me half my Armenian friends. Some of them were frightened away.

title: Let Eliot Be Remembered for His Poetry; 'After Strange Gods'
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Wall St.'s View Of Bid for Wickes
description: WHAT is the real worth of the Wickes Companies? From Wall Street's perspective, Sanford C. Sigoloff is trying to buy the huge maker of auto parts and home furnishings for a song.

title: Northrop MX Papers Seized
description: Federal investigators have seized documents related to the Northrop Corporation's work on the MX missile program, a company spokesman said today.

title: Getting Vital Drugs Into the Brain
description: The brain is equipped with a sophisticated barrier that keeps foreign substances in the blood like bacteria and toxins from reaching brain tissue. But this blood-brain barrier, as scientists call it, also keeps out potentially useful substances like drugs to treat cancer and AIDS.

title: Enemy of Abortions Is Also Taking Issue With Protest Tactics
description: A former president of the Southern Baptist Convention said that while abortion was ''an abomination before God,'' he opposed tactics being used by opponents of abortion that have led to hundreds of arrests this summer.

title: Metro-North Police Ordered Not to Strike
description: A Federal judge has barred the railroad police union from shutting down the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, a railroad spokeswoman said yesterday.

title: Chrysler Rebate
description: The Chrysler Corporation increased cash incentives for its Eagle Premier automobiles to $750 from $600, retroactive to Sunday. The nation's third-largest car maker said the incentives would be available on 1988 and 1989 models and the offer would be available indefinitely. The company said it sold 2,058 of the cars in the first 20 days of August, down 10.8 percent from the 2,281 sold in the July period. Chrysler introduced the Eagle Premier at the end of last year.

title: South Africa Blast Hurts 7
description: A powerful explosion badly damaged the headquarters of the South African Council of Churches, an influential antiapartheid organization, early today, officials here said. A police spokesman said seven people were injured, none seriously. The council represents almost 11 million South African Christians and vigorously opposes apartheid. The police cordoned off the area near the building, known as Khotso House.

title: Hazel Dawn, Stage Actress, Is Dead at 98
description: Hazel Dawn, a celebrated singer and actress in the early decades of the century who was known as ''The Pink Lady,'' died Sunday at the home of her daughter in Manhattan. She was 98 years old.

title: Resorts Clears Griffin Offer
description: Stockholders of Resorts International Inc. today approved Merv Griffin's offer to buy the gaming and real estate company.

title: Applauding New York, Softly
description: AN opulent dessert wine made by the Great Western Winery in the Finger Lakes region of New York State won the Governor's Cup for the second consecutive time in this year's statewide wine competition.

title: Police Shoot Off-Duty Officer
description: An off-duty New York City police officer was seriously wounded last night in a shootout with two other police officers who were responding to a report of a disorderly man, officials said.

title: Topics of The Times; Breast Cancer, Caught Early
description: The National Cancer Institute recommends yearly breast X-rays for women over 50, but health insurance doesn't normally cover the procedure, which may cost up to $200. Only eight states now mandate insurance coverage of mammography screening. A sensible bill approved by New York's Legislature and awaiting Governor Cuomo's signature would make New York the ninth.

title: 2 Bankers Get Prison In Energy Loan Case
description: A Federal district judge today sentenced two former bank officers to prison for contributing to the near-collapse of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company in 1984.

title: Councilmen In Yonkers Seek Relief
description: The City of Yonkers and the four Councilmen who are blocking a court-ordered housing desegregation plan applied to the United States Supreme Court today for continued relief from contempt fines against them.

title: USX-Soviet Pact
description: The USX Corporation said its steel division had concluded an agreement to provide the Soviet Union with 88,000 tons of seamless steel tube for oil well casing. ''As best we can tell, it is the largest order we've been involved with in the Soviet Union,'' a company spokesman, Thomas Ferrall, said. The price of the deal was withheld. The agreement requires the delivery of 44,000 tons in the fourth quarter and the other half in the first quarter of 1989. USX last sold steel to the Soviet Union about 20 years ago.

title: Los Angeles Journal; Patrol Is Welcome Sight Amid Smog
description: People laugh when Charles J. Gibson, a California Highway Patrol officer, pulls over their automobiles and trucks.

title: Jackson Nears Accord In Suit Over Videotape
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson has reached a tentative settlement in his suit to stop the distribution of a videotape of his speech to the Democratic National Convention, his lawyer said today.

title: Ex-Gov. Robb, Seeking Senate Seat, Objects to Drug Investigation
description: The Senate campaign of Charles S. Robb, the former Virginia Governor, has filed a complaint with Federal election officials objecting to a private detective's investigation of reports linking Mr. Robb to people who used drugs.

title: Report Finds a 10% Decline in U.S. Use of Water
description: While the drought this summer is imposing new water restrictions on many Americans, water use is already down nationally, partly because of a declining supply of water.

title: British Troops Shoot 3 Ulster Gunmen in Car
description: British troops shot dead three gunmen in Northern Ireland today near the spot where an Irish Republican Army bomb killed eight soldiers 10 days ago, the police said.

title: Islanders Sign 2
description: The Islanders announced yesterday that they have signed two defensemen who helped take St. Lawrence University to the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament last spring. Those who signed were Hank Lammens, whom the Islanders had selected in the eighth round of the 1985 draft, and Pete McGeough, the Islanders' 12th-round selection in 1983.

title: Black Magazine Is Called Off
description: It's back to the drawing board for 35-year-old Wilmer C. Ames, who had a dream to start a black-oriented magazine, but failed to come up with enough financial backing.

title: Jets Get Linebacker
description: The Jets, with little depth on an inexperienced linebacker corps, picked up a Super Bowl veteran yesterday by acquiring Robin Cole after he had been cut by the Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: Agency Rejects I.B.M. Plea
description: The General Services Administration's Board of Contract Appeals denied a request yesterday by the International Business Machines Corporation to dismiss parts of a protest filed by the Hughes Aircraft Company over a $3.6 billion contract to build a new air traffic control system for the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Univision Names Head Of Spanish Network
description: Univision Holdings Inc., which is owned by Hallmark Cards Inc., yesterday announced the appointment of Joaquin F. Blaya as president of its Spanish-language television network.

title: The Noble Sea Vegetables: Algae With Image Problems
description: LEAD: SLIMY green stuff that clings to swimmers and litters storm-washed beaches: that's seaweed. A mild, nutty, sweet, crunchy taste sensation: that's a sea vegetable.

title: Continental To Cut Fares
description: Continental Airlines said yesterday that it planned to cut its lowest urestricted fares by an average of 55 percent on 38 routes from Denver. The service has been plagued by overcapacity and decreased travel because of the depressed oil economy.

title: Reds Defeat Pirates For Jackson's 19th
description: Danny Jackson became the National League's first 19-game winner tonight, and Luis Quinones's two-run double capped a six-run first inning as the Cincinnati Reds defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6-4.

title: Conspiracy Ruling Today
description: Baseball's club owners will learn today if they are guilty a second time of conspiring against free agents. Lawyers on both the players' and the owners' sides expect George Nicolau, the arbitrator, to rule against the owners in the case involving 1986 free agents.

title: A Left Turn for Schmidt?
description: Mike Schmidt has a small but complete tear of the rotator cuff in his right shoulder, but the Philadelphia Phillies third baseman said today he will get a second and third medical opinion before deciding on his future.

title: Hanoi to Aid on Searches
description: The State Department said today that Vietnam had agreed to resume cooperation on finding the remains of Americans listed as missing in action during the Vietnam War.

title: The Gulf War Isn't Over
description: An ancient quarrel over the vital waterway separating Iran and Iraq threatens to scuttle the gulf war truce even before talks begin in Geneva. Iraq now balks at compliance with the terms of the United Nations cease-fire resolution, insisting on full naval access to the disputed Shatt al-Arab in advance of peace talks. In that case, counters Ayatollah Khomeini, Iran should consider itself at war. Secretary General Perez de Cuellar urgently needs the major powers to help lean on Iraq to put the peace process back on track.

title: The Dinner Table, Equality's Last Hurdle
description: LEAD: I CONFESS to lusty eating habits. Cooks have always loved my zeal. Most of the men I've dated, however, haven't. Growing up around a table of 10, with five older brothers encouraging me to dig in with them, I never anticipated that men would disdain a woman's hearty appetite. Only at a table for two, under the scrutiny of my first boyfriend, did

title: Harry Roman
description: Hambros P.L.C., the international banking and financial services group, said it had bought Harry Roman & Company, a privately owned mergers and acquisitions group based in Los Angeles, for an undisclosed sum. Harry Roman should increase Hambros's offerings to its United States clients, the London-based banking group said in a statement.

title: Jane Watson, a Nurse, Weds Walter R. Bailey
description: The marriage of Jane Carpenter Watson, a registered nurse, and Walter Ronald Bailey, a partner in the New York law firm of Rogers & Wells, took place yesterday in Christ Chapel at the Riverside Church in New York. The Rev. Fanny Erickson, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Cross at Marine Base Must Go, Judge Rules
description: A 65-foot tall Latin cross erected 22 years ago at a Marine base in Hawaii must be removed or replaced by a nonreligious symbol, a Federal judge ruled today.

title: Food Notes
description: A Bit of the Old and New The Jewish New Year, Rosh ha-Shanah, begins at sundown on Sept. 11, and of timely interest is ''Kashruth'' by Rabbi Yacov Lipschutz (Mesorah Publications), which explains the ancient principles behind kosher food rules, and also discusses some concerns of the modern cook.

title: Diners Club Is Awarded U.S. Contract
description: The General Services Administration yesterday awarded Diners Club Inc., a subsidiary of Citibank, a one-year contract to provide credit card service to more than 400,000 Federal employees who travel frequently on Government business.

title: Shaw Is Cut
description: Brian Shaw, a guard who was the first-round draft choice of the Boston Celtics, was the final player cut yesterday as the United States Olympic men's basketball team reached its 12-player limit.

title: Accused Spy's Home: Porcelain and Privacy
description: If Clyde Lee Conrad, the retired Army sergeant accused of heading a major spying ring, had needed anonymity but did not like a long commute, he could hardly have picked a better spot than Bosenheim.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: Burmese State Workers Unite Against Regime
description: State employees formed a united front today for protests against the Government, striking another blow at the embattled regime of the President, U Maung Maung.

title: Rates Up Slightly On Citicorp Paper
description: Interest rates rose slightly at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper. The bank holding company sold $50 million of the 91-day paper at an average rate of 8.369 percent, up from 8.36 percent last week.

title: Dukakis and Bush Trade Fire in Heavy Barrages; Republican Continues to Stress Ideology Theme
description: Vice President Bush came to the political homeland of Senator Jesse Helms today, and to the delight of many of the audience he outdid the conservative North Carolinian in the fervor of his attacks on liberalism.

title: Banks Signs Pact; Starts Workouts
description: Carl Banks officially ended his 44-day holdout this morning.

title: Well, Almost a 'Homeless Prosecutor'
description: For a while, a general in New York City's war on drugs feared that he would become the nation's ''only homeless prosecutor.''

title: KEY RATES
Riot's Legacy of Distrust Quietly Stalks a Soviet City
description: It is six months since the weekend of horror when Albert M. Mamedov called his Armenian neighbors to gather the children and come quickly because a mob was going door to door, hunting for Armenians.

title: Always an Ethnic
description: To the Editor:

title: July Orders To Factories Dropped 3.5%
description: Orders received by the nation's factories for manufactured goods fell sharply in July, pulled down by the biggest drop in military orders in more than four years.

title: Jackson Arouses Passions During a Non-Campaign Swing
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, the former Democratic Party presidential candidate, swept through New York City yesterday in a campaign-like swirl of cars, police and press. Mr. Jackson was running, he said, ''to keep hope alive,'' making little mention of the party's nominee, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, and pressing his own themes of racial fairness, consensus, aspiration and voter registration.

title: Penney in $700 Million Plan To Buy Stock for Employees
description: In the largest such deal ever, the J. C. Penney Company said yesterday that it would borrow $700 million from big insurance companies and give the money to an employee trust so it can buy Penney's stock.

title: Bridge
description: In bridge, as in life, there is a big difference between being very poor and being destitute. The player who appreciates this can sometimes make a positive move in the bidding because his hand is not as bad as it might have been.

title: Books of The Times; A Revisionist View of the Odd Life of Beatle John
description: The Lives of John Lennon By Albert Goldman 719 pages. William Morrow & Company. $22.95.

title: Boxing Notebook; Bout by Bout, McGirt Defeats His Faults
description: When he was growing up in Brentwood, L.I., James (Buddy) McGirt used to sit behind the wheel of his father's white Cadillac, an unlighted cigar in his mouth, and pretend to be driving the vehicle the way the father, also named James, did.

title: A Washed and Smoked Brain, Perhaps
description: Every time I mention Adm. Arleigh A. Burke in this column, I get two or three things terribly wrong. For this reason I have been hesitant to report that Admiral Burke, a hero of World War II, is alive.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The index of leading indicators fell 0.8 percent in July, to a level below that of early spring. The drop in the Government's chief economic forecasting gauge was the steepest in eight months. Economists said the fall in the index, along with other recent data, seemed to suggest that the brisk economic conditions of recent months may be waning. [ Page A1. ] Orders for manufactured goods fell sharply in July, pulled down by the biggest drop in military orders in four years. [ D5. ] Prices paid to farmers for grain and other products rose 2.1 percent in August, in part because of the drought. [ D4. ] The State Department called for the U.S. to allow the export of communications satellites for launching on Chinese rockets, saying national security interests would not be hurt. The Transportation Department contends the deal will hurt U.S. companies. [ D1. ] A campaign against drinking and driving will be initiated by the three major television networks and the Hollywood studios that create most of their programming. [ A1. ] Two former bank officers were sentenced to prison for contributing to the near-collapse of Continental Illinois. [ D2. ] The American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, reversing a longstanding position, will allow its 270,000 members to sell securities, insurance and other financial services. [ D2. ] COMPANIES Eastern Airlines can reduce its service today, as planned, but cannot lay off 4,000 workers without negotiating with their unions, a Federal judge ruled. Eastern said it would appeal. [ D1. ] Gould will be acquired by Nippon Mining for approximately $1.1 billion. The deal will be the fourth largest acquisition by a Japanese company of an American one. [ D1. ] J. C. Penney will borrow $700 million from big insurance companies and give the money to an employee trust so it can buy Penney stock. The move is the latest example of a trend: companies pay for employees to own their stock as a defense against takeovers. [ D1. ] Bergdorf Goodman will open an additional store, featuring men's wear, across the street from its Fifth Avenue base. [ D1. ] The Government chose Diners Club to provide credit-card services to more than 400,000 Federal employees. [ D7. ] An I.R.S. agent said executives of Georgia Power and its parent, the Southern Company, engaged in a complex six-year scheme to evade millions of dollars in taxes. [ D11. ] Public Service of New Mexico eliminated 19 percent of its work force as part of a $250 million cost-cutting program. [ D4. ] Stockholders of Resorts International approved Merv Griffin's offer to buy the gaming and real estate company. [ D4. ] MARKETS Stock prices ended mixed as volume remained at the slow pace of recent days. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 3.20 points, to 2,038.23, but the broader market advanced. [ D8. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved modestly higher in dull trading, as economic data were in line with market expectations and had little effect on prices. [ D15. ] The dollar held within a narrow range, while gold fell 60 cents an ounce on the Comex, to $428.80. [ D16. ] Prices of pork futures plunged for the second straight day amid signs of an expected seasonal upturn in hog slaughters. [ D16. ] TECHNOLOGY Scientists are trying to breach the barrier that allows the brain to keep substances in the blood from reaching brain tissue. [ D6. ] Chemists are hoping to improve the refrigerated tomato. [ D6. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Modern forecasters would not have done any better at predicting the Depression than their untooled predecessors, a recent study has concluded. Peter Passell. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] What is Wickes worth? Some analysts say Sanford C. Sigoloff is trying to buy Wickes for a song. Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: Accounts
description: * Bell Atlantic to Devon Direct Marketing and Advertising, Malvern, Pa.

title: New Jersey's Faulty No-Fault
description: In California, high automobile insurance rates have inspired a consumer revolt and a set of ballot initiatives aimed at controlling costs. In New Jersey, where rates are even higher, residents may be forgiven a certain cynicism about efforts to control costs. Every time Trenton has put its collective hand to this problem in recent years, the result has been higher rates, not lower. Yet the remedies remain clear.

title: With Macrobiotic Cooking, A Balance of Yin and Yang
description: FOR most of his life, a Japanese man named George Ohsawa devoted his time to developing and promulgating the concepts of macrobiotic eating, which he believed would lead to a healthier, more balanced life. While Mr. Ohsawa lectured all over the world, his wife, Lima, was always with him. It was her job to develop the application of the theory: to create the recipes and cook food that would exemplify the macrobiotic way.

title: Congressman Weighs Offer by Tawana Brawley to Testify at Hearing
description: The chairman of the House Subcommittee on Criminal Justice is considering an offer by Tawana Brawley to testify before a Congressional hearing.

title: Time For Decision
description: Events in the Middle East are moving to a crossroads. For many years, hard choices have been put off because, on the Israeli side, so many people wanted to believe they need never be made and that the impasse would melt away with time; and because, on the Palestinian side, leaders felt more secure by temporizing than by taking political risk.

title: Mollusk Lovers Are Rejected
description: Gov. George Deukmejian today vetoed a bill to make the Banana Slug the official state mollusk. ''It is not representative of the international reputation California enjoys,'' the Governor said. The bill to recognize the slug, which is bright yellow and about the size of a banana, was introduced in the House of Assembly on behalf of the Redwood Campfire Kids, a children's group. The state has an official insect, the Dog-Faced Butterfly.

title: Real Estate; 2 Deals Aid Office Tower In Manhattan
description: AFTER years of planning, negotiations and delays, the steel framework is rising for a 50-story office tower that will cover the full western blockfront of the Avenue of the Americas between 45th and 46th Streets.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: B.C. Willis, 86; Led Chicago Schools for 13 Years
description: Benjamin C. Willis, who as Superintendent of Schools in Chicago in the 1960's was accused of perpetuating segregation by refusing to move black children into white schools, died at his home in Plantation, Fla., on Saturday, his family said yesterday. He was 86 years old.

title: C.P.A. Group Votes to Allow Members to Sell Securities
description: The American Institute of Certified Public Accountants reversed a longstanding position today by voting to allow the group's 270,000 members to sell securities, insurance and other financial services.

title: New York City Fails to Meet Air Standard
description: The waning days of August have brought a fresh, even autumnal tingle to New York City's weather. But the last day of the month has also brought a more serious reminder of what is in the air: As of midnight tonight, New York City will be in violation of a Federal law for failing to meet air-quality standards established under the Clean Air Act of 1970.

title: Bush's Son Quits Thrift Unit
description: Neil Bush, citing a possible conflict of interest with the Presidential campaign of his father, has resigned from the board of Silverado Banking Savings and Loan, an insolvent Denver thrift institution facing a Federal bail-out.

title: Houston Industries Sees Profit Decline
description: Houston Industries Inc. said its after-tax earnings would decrease $15 million to $20 million a month, unless it can defer charges for costs associated with one unit of its South Texas nuclear plant.

title: Georgia Power Faces Tax Inquiry
description: In an affidavit unsealed today in Federal District Court here, a special agent of the Internal Revenue Service maintained that high-ranking executives of the Georgia Power Company and its parent, the Southern Company, had engaged in a complex six-year plan to evade millions of dollars in corporate taxes.

title: Tampering Charge Goes by Wayside
description: Commissioner Peter Ueberroth said yesterday that the remarks by a Toronto Blue Jays' executive about the possibility of the Yankees' trading Don Mattingly is a matter that could attract his attention. The Yankees, however, said they did not plan to bring it to the commissioner's attention.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (AL) - Signed Jerry Hairston, outfielder-designated hitter. Purchased the contract of Carlos Martinez, third baseman-outfielder, from Birmingham of the Southern League. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Optioned Tom Filer, pitcher, to Denver of the American Association. Activated Paul Mirabella, pitcher, from the 15-day disabled list. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Recalled Felix Fermin, shortstop, from Buffalo of the American Association. Sent Dave Rucker, pitcher, to Buffalo. BASKETBALL U.S. OLYMPIC TEAM - Cut Brian Shaw, guard. FOOTBALL ATLANTA (NFC) - Released Kerwin Bell, quarterback, and Mark Marz, defensive end. Claimed Steve Dils and Hugh Millen, quarterbacks, and Gene Lang, running back, from waivers. BUFFALO (AFC) - Placed Bruce Mesner, nose tackle; Flip Johnson, wide receiver; and Carlton Bailey, linebacker, on injured reserve. DENVER (AFC) - Re-signed Tim Lucas, linebacker. Placed Dave Studdard, offensive tackle, on injured reserve. GREEN BAY (NFC) - Signed Phil Epps, wide receiver. KANSAS CITY (AFC) - Waived Sherman Cocroft, defensive back. Placed Herman Heard and Christian Okoye, running backs, on injured reserve. INDIANAPOLIS (AFC) - Waived Orlando Lowry, linebacker. Obtained Anthony Griggs, linebacker, from the Cleveland Browns for an undisclosed draft choice. JETS (AFC) - Claimed Robin Cole, linebacker, and Ralph Jarvis, defensive end, off waivers. Waived Darryl Pearson, wide receiver. Placed Ken Rose, linebacker, on injured reserve. MINNESOTA (NFC) - Waived Sam Anno and Joe Cain, linebackers; Stafford Mays, defensive end; Riley Walton and Brad Beckman, tight ends; Reggie Ward, wide receiver; Randy Rasmussen, guard, and Jamie Fitzgerald, safety. NEW ENGLAND (AFC) - Re-signed Marvin Allen, running back, and Eric Naposki, linebacker. Waived Rich Camarillo, punter; Mike Ruth, nose tackle; Jerry McCabe, linebacker; Rodney Lossow, center; Derrick Beasley, safety; Steve Wilburn, defensive end; Greg Ours, center, and Howard Feggins, cornerback. Placed Tony Eason, quarterback; Lin Dawson, tight end; Thomas Benson, linebacker; Dennis Gadbois, wide receiver, and Tom Gibson, defensive end, on injured reserve. PHILADELPHIA (NFC) - Re-signed Mark Konecny, running back, and Jonathan Dumauld, defensive end. Claimed Shawn Beals, wide receiver-kick returner, from waivers. Waived Ron Johnson, wide receiver. Placed Gerry Feehery, center, and Matt Patchan, offensive tackle, on injured reserve. WASHINGTON (AFC) - Placed Russ Grimm, guard, and Joe Caravello, tight end, on injured reserve. Re-signed Anthony Allen, wide receiver, and Terry Orr, halfback. HOCKEY BUFFALO (NHL) - Signed Francois Guay and Grant Tkachuk, forwards, and Brad Miller, defenseman. ISLANDERS (NHL) - Signed Hank Lammens and Peter McGeough, defensemen. SOCCER LOS ANGELES (MISL) - Signed Waad Hirmez, Fernando Clavijo, and Doug Neelly, defenders; Jim Gorsek and A.J. Lachowecki, goalkeepers; Michael Collins, Mark Frederickson, Cha Cha Namdar, Daryl Doran and Ben Collins, midfielders, and Gary Heale, forward. COLLEGES ADELPHI - Named S. Andrew Baumbach as sports information director. C.W. POST - Named Steve Guthoff as offensive line coach. PITT - Suspended Hosea Heard, flanker, indefinitely from the football team. MANHATTAN - Named Boris Bandov as assistant men's soccer coach. MOUNT ST. VINCENT - Named Chuck Mancuso athletic director. SLIPPERY ROCK - Named Robertha Abney associate director of athletics. TEMPLE - Suspended John Armstrong, safety, and Gary Mobley, cornerback, for disciplinary reasons. WEST VIRGINIA STATE - Named Percy (Chico) Caldwell athletic director.

title: Defiant 4: The Councilmen Who Are Blocking the Yonkers Housing Plan; Nicholas V. Longo
description: For Nicholas V. Longo, these are heady times. He has been on the ''Today'' show, ''CBS This Morning'' and radio talk shows around the country. Cameras follow him down the steps of City Hall. In a local restaurant, a woman rushed up to him with a $1,000 check for his ''cause.'' He is thinking of running for Congress.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday on recycling plastics misstated the affiliation of Jeanne Wirka. She is with the Environmental Action Foundation in Washington.

title: Addendum
description: * Chief Executive Magazine says its rate base climbed 7 percent, to 30,000, and will increase its ad rates 11 percent, effective with its January/February issue.

title: Tucker Owners, By a Car Possessed
description: IN 1948, Preston Tucker marketed ''The Car of Tomorrow Today'': a fastback four-door sedan with a rear engine, a windshield designed to pop out in a collision and a Cyclops headlight linked to the steering mechanism so that it turned in same direction as the front wheels.

title: Washington Talk: The Pentagon; After the Scandal, Quick Fixes v. Decisive Actions
description: At times, the bureaucrats in charge of revising Pentagon buying practices in the wake of the latest scandal have seemed like physicians in a frenzy of exploratory surgery.

title: It's Near Canada, but It's New York's Jail
description: A jail opened here today on the banks of the St. Lawrence River, hard by the Thousand Islands wilderness, a few hundred yards from the Canadian border. A New York City jail. Faced with overcrowded jails, neighborhood opposition to new jails and a three-year wait before the opening of a 1,000-inmate jail on Staten Island, city correction officials are flying prisoners to this remote and sparsely populated land of big skies and permafrost winters, some 280 miles northwest of Rikers Island, the city's major jail center in the East River.

title: Drug-Linked Fugitive Arraigned
description: A former fugitive, identified by the authorities as the leader of a drug organization linked to the Colombo crime family, pleaded not guilty yesterday to Federal charges of racketeering and extortion.

title: First Fidelity Sets $100 Million Issue
description: The First Fidelity Bancorp is offering $100 million of 9 3/4 percent mortgage-backed bonds due in 1993 at a price of 99.92 to yield 9.77 percent through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: At This Wedding, Only the Ziti Is Tasteful
description: VINNIE BLACK'S COLISEUM (''The Cadillac of Caterers'') in Greenwich Village is a shade less glittery than Leonard's of Great Neck, L.I., the service a touch clumsier than the Rainbow Room's and the food not quite as haute as the Manor's in West Orange, N.J. Nevertheless, it's been booked solid for months.

title: Bergdorf Will Open A 2d Store
description: Bergdorf Goodman said yesterday that it would open an additional store across the street from its base at Fifth Avenue and 58th Street. The building, at 745 Fifth Avenue, is the former home of F.A.O. Schwarz.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chrysler Picks Chief For Auto Parts Unit
description: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation yesterday named Thomas T. Stallkamp as chairman of its automobile parts subsidiary and Forest J. Farmer as president.

title: Corrections
description: A caption with an article in Science Times yesterday about a private space venture by the EPrime Aerospace Corporation gave an incorrect date for the planned launching of the company's first rocket. It is Oct. 6.

title: As Talks Stall, Iranian Warns War Isn't Over
description: With peace talks between Iran and Iraq apparently making no headway, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini was quoted today as having said that the eight-year-old conflict was not over and that Iranians should feel they are still at war.

title: Barbizon Hotel Sold To Developers
description: Two real-estate owners and developers whom Donald J. Trump outbid for the Plaza Hotel in March have settled instead for another historic Manhattan hostelry, the Barbizon on East 63d Street, the seller reported Monday.

title: 5 Palestinians Are Wounded As a Two-Day Strike Begins
description: Israeli troops shot and wounded five Palestinian protesters today as Arabs throughout the Israeli-occupied territories began a 48-hour strike in sympathy with deported Palestinians.

title: Freddie Mac's Stock Offering
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, yesterday announced details of the public offering for its preferred stock.

title: Let Eliot Be Remembered for His Poetry
description: To the Editor:

title: Tandem-Nynex
description: Tandem Computers Inc. said it had entered an agreement with Nynex Information Solutions Group Inc. under which the New York company will integrate and market Tandem products in large-scale systems aimed at the finance, manufacturing and telecommunications industries. Nynex Informations Solutions is a subsidiary of the Nynex Corporation, the telephone operating company in the New York area. Tandem markets products primarily for on-line transaction processing, such as airline reservation systems and matic teller machines.

title: Defiant 4: The Councilmen Who Are Blocking the Yonkers Housing Plan; Peter Chema
description: Of the four City Councilmen who have defied a Federal desegregation order, Peter Chema is the only one representing a district where none of the low-income housing is to be built.

title: Book NotesHerbert Mitgang
description: F.B.I. and Libraries

title: Marjorie Draper, 60, Civic Leader in Jersey
description: Marjorie Draper, a leader in New Jersey civic and community affairs, died Sunday at her home in Montclair, N.J., after a brief illness. She was 60 years old.

title: An Unedited 'Raisin in Sun' for TV
description: Filming has just been completed on the first production for next season's ''American Playhouse'' series on PBS, a new three-hour version of Lorraine Hansberry's play ''A Raisin in the Sun,'' to be broadcast in January. The television production, starring Danny Glover and Esther Rolle, will include scenes written by Ms. Hansberry 30 years ago but never seen in any production of the play.

title: Lessons
description: The Board of Education in New York City was understandably reluctant to say how many people work at its Brooklyn headquarters. Recently, though, in response to pressure from Mayor Koch, it counted them and announced the total: 6,447, or one for every 147 students.

title: Dukakis and Bush Trade Fire in Heavy Barrages; Democrat Denounces Rival's Stand in the Iran-Contra Affair
description: After weeks of being pummeled by his Republican Presidential rival, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis counterpunched today with a broad new assault on Vice President Bush's conduct in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Sonoma Dynasty: The Sequel
description: THE reserved smile is the same; so are the restless energy and the rugged frame. Adversity comes and goes, but you have to keep in shape. Only the reading glasses - very proper; no aviator chic here - hint that Sam Sebastiani has put on a few years.

title: China's Heady and Heralded Yellow Wine From Shaoxing
description: IN 240 B.C., Lu Buwei, the Prime Minister of China under the first Emperor of the Qin dynasty, directed the compilation of an encyclopedia of all that was known. Called the ''Spring and Autumn Annals,'' the encyclopedia included myriad tales, this among them:

title: A Partial Victory for Eastern
description: A Federal judge ruled that Eastern Airlines could sharply reduce its service today, as planned.

title: Cablevision Stake Raised
description: A group led by Sandler Associates of New York said today that it had raised its stake in the Cablevision Systems Corporation to 10.4 percent, from a previous holding of 7.3 percent.

title: U. of Vermont Promoting Diversity
description: The University of Vermont, prodded by a tiny but restless number of students who are members of minority groups, is moving on several fronts to promote racial and cultural diversity on its 10,000-student campus here.

title: HOPEFULS DISAGREE ON DEBATE DETAILS
description: Negotiators for the Presidential candidates predicted today that there would be debates between the contenders this fall, but they disagreed about almost everything else, such as how often, when and under what ground rules the debates would be held.

title: Dukakis Learned Lesson as Teacher
description: In Michael S. Dukakis's first semester in 1979 as an unemployed politician and Harvard faculty member, he got bad grades from his students.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: THE technique of breading meat and fish, properly performed, is a quick and easy way to impart extra texture and flavor. Unfortunately, it is often done incorrectly, leaving foods soggy and greasy. I recently made a batch of chicken nuggets in herbed breading for a quick, casual summer dinner.

title: Infant, 5 Others, Shot in Dispute
description: Six people, including an 11-month-old child, were wounded yesterday evening when a dispute between two teen-agers during a basketball game in the Bronx erupted in shooting, the police said.

title: Economic Scene; Forecasters' Art In 1929 and Now
description: WHEN the Great Depression slammed into the economy in 1929, professional forecasters never knew what hit them. That is understandable, given the primitive state of their science a half century ago. But now that economists are armed with sophisticated mathematical models and big computers to crunch the numbers, forecasters could not possibly be caught asleep at the switch. Right?

title: Delay at Scherer For Board Seat
description: Neither contender for a contested board seat at the R. P. Scherer Corporation will take part in meetings or board votes until a court rules on the dispute, the company said. The gelatin capsule maker also said a shareholders meeting scheduled to resume Thursday would be put off until Sept. 26 pending action on court challenges involving the board election.

title: Irving Honigsberg, Lawyer, 80
description: Irving Honigsberg, a real-estate lawyer, died of complications after surgery Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SAHARA FOES MOVE TO END THEIR WAR
description: Morocco and the Polisario Front guerrillas agreed today to a United Nations peace plan to end the 13-year-old war in the former Spanish colony of Western Sahara.

title: Gould to Be Acquired By Nippon Mining
description: In the fourth-largest Japanese acquisition of an American company, Gould Inc. said yesterday that it would be acquired by the Nippon Mining Company for $23.25 a share, or about $1.1 billion in cash.

title: New Mexico Utility Cuts 799 Jobs
description: The Public Service Company of New Mexico today announced a $250 million cost-cutting program and immediately eliminated 799 jobs, or more than 19 percent of its 4,126 staff.

title: Black & Decker Saws Faulty
description: Black & Decker Inc. has agreed to send owners of 500,000 electric miter saws kits to fix a faulty blade guard. A company spokeswoman, Barbara Lucas, said the guard sometimes jammed, leaving the blade exposed. The company said owners should call (800) 541-7136 for kits for these models: 1703 (type 1), 1703-1, 3090 (types 2 and 11), 3091 (type 1), 3417 (type 11), 3417-04 (type 3), 7715, 7715-1 (types 1, 2 and 3), 7715-04 (type 2), 7716 (types 1A1, 2, 11), 7716-04 (type 1), 7717 (types 3, 11 and 21), 7718 (type 2), and Sears Model 901.23470.

title: Hospital in Chicago to Close
description: One of the area's largest inner-city medical centers announced today that it would close because it cannot pay its bills.

title: Yankees Battered Again, 7-1 Yankees Battered By Mariners, 7-1
description: The Yankees lost again tonight, but they also made a last-ditch attempt to save their season by acquiring a relief pitcher for their weary and overworked bullpen.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Late Payments On Mortgages
description: The number of Americans behind on their mortgage payments rose in the April-June quarter for the second time in two-and-a-half years, The Mortgage Bankers Association of America said today.

title: SOLIDARITY SAYS WALESA WILL TALK WITH GOVERNMENT
description: A spokesman for Solidarity said tonight that the Government would begin talks here Wednesday with Lech Walesa, the founder of the union movement, on ending labor unrest and introducing political and economic changes in Poland.

title: Determination, at the Risk of Jail
description: One is a retired New York City detective who carries a .38-caliber revolver in the trunk of his car and worries about Yonkers becoming another Bronx.

title: A $5 Deposit on Auto Batteries To Curb Waste Is Voted in Suffolk
description: The Suffolk County Legislature passed a bill today that puts a $5 refundable deposit on automobile batteries sold in the county, a move to encourage recycling and remove the batteries from everyday waste.

title: China Begins Price Freeze
description: China announced a price freeze today for the rest of the year and warned that the grain harvest could be smaller than in 1987.

title: U.S. Jeep/Eagle Dealers Plan a Joint Campaign
description: Chrysler's 1,500 Jeep/Eagle dealers, which sell the Eagle Premier and Jeep Cherokee, have decided to pool their resources in celebrating their first anniversary with a jointly purchased media campaign scheduled to make its debut Sept. 6.

title: New Soviet Threats in Asia: Culture and Charm
description: Senior Soviet and Chinese officials have been meeting this week in Beijing for discussions that may well lay the groundwork for peace in Cambodia. While an end to the Cambodian conflict is obviously important, the meetings have taken on an even greater significance. That both powers would agree to participate underscores the remarkable political changes unleashed in the Far East by the enlightened diplomacy of Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: National Health Must Start With Quality Care; Utopia for Whom?
description: To the Editor:

title: Chile Junta Picks Pinochet as Candidate
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet, who has ruled Chile for 15 years, was formally nominated by the armed forces and the police today to seek a new eight-year term as President in a one-man plebiscite on Oct. 5.

title: U.S. HOUSE SALES BLOCKED BY JUDGE
description: A coalition of advocates for the homeless won a Federal court order today temporarily blocking the Department of Housing and Urban Development from selling foreclosed single-family homes to the highest bidder.
